title: F.T.C. Approves Pennwalt Takeover
description: An agreement to sell a New Jersey chemical plant has cleared the way for the $1.05 billion takeover of the Pennwalt Corporation by the French oil giant Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine. The Federal Trade Commission unanimously accepted an agreement that allows completion of the $132-a-share deal, the companies said.

title: Maxus Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $70 million from an accounting change. The latest second quarter net equals less than 1 cent a share due to preferred dividend requirements. uf90 McKesson Corp(N) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Revenue 1,817,700,000 1,650,300,000 Net inc 24,000,000 b23,100,000 Share earns .57 .54 Shares outst 44,400,000 46,300,000 b-After a loss of $900,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have seen the reports and have not reached any conclusion myself. One thing I have learned over the past 17 months is that the truth is hard to find and it remains so. But I am determined to know the truth.'' -Maj. Robin L. Higgins, wife of Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins. [ A7:2. ]

title: Clarcor Fends Off Bid from Banner
description: Shares of Clarcor Inc. fell sharply after the company disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had repurchased a 6.3 percent stake in the company from Banner Industries. The transaction put an end to a perceived threat to take over Clarcor, a diversified manufacturer based in Rockford, Ill. Banner, a mechanical components manufacturer based in Cleveland, had received clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to acquire more than 50 percent of Clarcor's shares outstanding.

title: Computer Horizons reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $961,000 from an accounting change.

title: President Stresses Schools and Drugs in His Courting of Governors
description: Seeking to strengthen his already strong ties with the nation's governors, President Bush today invited them to a meeting this fall to discuss ways to improve the American educational system.

title: Chess
description: It's a well-known fact of chess psychology that the attacker gets the lion's share of the credit, and why not? There is nothing more stirring than a cascade of surprising sacrifices culminating in checkmate.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Novacek Beats Sanchez: Karel Nova-cek of Czechoslovakia defeated Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday to capture the Hilversum tournament in the Netherlands. The eighth-seeded Novacek needed 1 hour 10 minutes to overcome Sanchez, seeded second. The match had been scheduled for Sunday but was postponed because of rain. Novacek, ranked 88th in the world, won $14,000. (AP) Soviet Player Wins Easily: Andrei Chersakov of the Soviet Union easily beat Vincente Solves of Spain, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the Head Cup grand prix tournament in Kitzbuehel, Austria. Chersakov, seeded 11th, and Eduardo Bengoechoa of Argentina, seeded 15th, who beat Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-2, were the only seeded players to complete first-round matches in the tournament. (AP) Victory for Chang: Michael Chang, in his first match since Wimbledon, defeated Pete Sampras, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in first-round play at the Volvo International tournament at Stratton Mountain, Vt. Nicholas Pereira of Venezuela, last year's junior Grand Slam winner, lost to Paul Annacone, 7-5, 6-2.(AP) Mayotte Rallies Successfully: Tim Mayotte rallied from behind yesterday to defeat Brad Gilbert, 3-6, 6-4, 7-5, in the championship match of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington. Gilbert held a lead of 6-3, 1-1 Sunday night when the match was suspended because of rain. Mayotte, ranked No. 11 in the world, received $50,575 for the victory. Gilbert, seeded second, ranked No. 12, got half that amount.(AP) YACHTING Britain's Lead Grows: Denmark placed first and third in the third race of the Admirals Cup international competition off Cowes, England, yesterday, but Britain increased its overall lead with three events to go. The 28-mile in-shore race favored bigger boats, and Stockbroker's Container of Denmark held off its challengers after a strong start to win on corrected time. Andelsbanken, a Danish yacht that was second in the Channel Race over the weekend, finished third.

description: Results are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: The Rest of the Toolbox
description: LAST week we discussed sections of PC Tools Deluxe version 5.5, a very complete $129 package from Central Point Software. Two other parts are the hard-disk backup and the desktop manager.

The company said results from the latest second quarter included a non- recurring charge of $7 million.

description: The company said that 1988 results were restated for the effects of an accounting change for unbilled revenues.

description: b-Net loss

title: A Worthy Immigration Update
description: In 1986, a Federal law addressed illegal immigration by legalizing the status of long-term undocumented aliens and imposing sanctions on employers who hire new ones. Though bureaucratic problems remain that could jeopardize some of those aliens, Congress is now turning its attention to legal immigrants with a bill that confirms two worthy principles: the importance of reuniting families and America's need for skilled workers.

title: Armstrong World Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Xerox Profit Increases 7.2%
description: The Xerox Corporation reported a 7.2 percent gain in second-quarter earnings today and attributed the improvement to its revamping.

title: Our Towns; Two Stamfords: Chirping Birds Or Gunfire?
description: It sounds at first like an industry-recruiting commercial for the city of Stamford. The voice is dulcet, against a background of a tinkling piano and the lyric chirp of birds. Stamford. Beautiful. Peaceful. On the shore of picturesque Long Island Sound. . . . Home to more corporate chief executives than any city. . . . The highest per-capita income in the nation. . . . Stamford . . . a wonderful place to raise a family.

title: KEY RATES
Courier Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: The latest 9-month included non- recurring gains of $3.8 million from the sale of the company's 50 percent interest in North American Directory Corp. and termination of company pension plans.

title: Ozone-Thin Air Disperses, Scientists Say
description: Air partly depleted of ozone appears to be transported from Antarctica to New Zealand and southern Australia by air currents in the atmosphere, scientists reported last week.

title: Bush Vetoes Measure On U.S.-Japan Fighter
description: As expected, President Bush today vetoed legislation that sought to impose several conditions on the United States-negotiated deal to produce an advanced jet fighter with the Japanese.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Affiliated Banc Corp., Holyoke, Mass., named Jeffrey Lalonde chairman and chief executive of Affiliated and its Vanguard Savings Bank unit.

title: Texas Utilities Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Koch Endorsed By Police Union For Re-election
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch received the endorsement of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday in his campaign for re-election.

title: Convex Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $353,000 for the 6 months.

title: National Gypsum Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods' earnings included a gain of $782,000 resulting from the repurchase of outstanding debt. The year-ago periods included gains of $38.8 million resulting from the sale of Lafarge Coppee common stock, $2.2 million resulting from debt repurchases, and income of $1.9 million from discontinued operations, all for the quarter; the 6 months included extraordinary gains of $43.9 million and income of $2.6 million from discontinued operations. The 1988 periods have been restated to reclassify American Olean Tile Co. results to discontinued operations and the reclassification of cash flow information in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 95.

title: 'An Inferno of Bombs': The Ordeal of Beirut
description: Hardly a building remains unscathed in West Beirut as Lebanese Christian forces and their Syrian foes clash. Most residents have fled. Those who have not rush to basements at the first crash of a shell. Article, page A7.

title: Just After Deadline, Israel Offered to Trade Prisoners
description: Minutes after the announced deadline for the killing of Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins this afternoon, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin offered to trade Israel's Lebanese Shiite Muslim prisoners for all the hostages, Israeli and Western, being held by Shiite organizations in Lebanon.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; An Iconoclast Takes a Look At the Future
description: To some in the advertising industry, John Philip Jones is a troublesome iconoclast. The 59-year-old chairman of the advertising department at the Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University is a leading proponent of the theory that advertising's impact on consumer behavior is weaker than many marketing professionals believe.

title: Texas Air Reports Heavy Losses
description: The Texas Air Corporation, the nation's largest airline company, yesterday announced heavy second-quarter losses, as Eastern Airlines, its strike-crippled bankrupt subsidiary, reported that its losses for the quarter exceeded total sales.

title: 2D THREAT ISSUED; BUSH CONVENES SECURITY PANEL; Videotape Released
description: A terrorist group in Lebanon said today that it had hanged a hostage Marine colonel, and distributed a grisly videotape that showed a figure identified as the American twisting at the end of a rope.

title: Red Sox, Stanley Move In On Orioles
description: Dwight Evans sparked a six-run second inning with a leadoff homer and the Boston Red Sox inched closer to first-place Baltimore in the American League East tonight with a 9-6 victory over the Orioles.

title: As Hepatitis B Spreads, Physicians Reconsider Vaccination Strategy
description: FOR reasons ranging from cost to poorly implemented policies, too few people benefit from some of the newest and most effective life-saving measures.

title: Fodor Is Freed Without Bail in Drug Case
description: Eugene Fodor, the violinist, who was arrested last week and charged with possession of cocaine and heroin, was released from a Martha's Vineyard jail today on personal recognizance.

title: Mozambican Party Backs Rebel Talks
description: President Joaquim A. Chissano has emerged from the party congress of his ruling Mozambique Liberation Front, which concluded its work Sunday, with a mandate to negotiate a peaceful settlement to the brutal insurgency that has devastated Mozambique.

title: United Brands CoN) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bennett Asks Tougher Drug Fight, Declaring Crack 'Biggest Problem'
description: William J. Bennett, the Bush Administration's drug policy director, proposed a national strategy yesterday that includes a much tougher approach in using law enforcement to fight drugs. He also declared that crack was ''our biggest and most immediate problem.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, with a $12 million budget.

title: Liz Claiborne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Coors Seeks Some Stroh Operations
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the fourth-largest brewing company in the United States, said yesterday that it was ''exploring options to acquire certain assets'' of the Stroh Brewery Company, the third-largest beer maker.

title: Researchers Say Methanol May Not Fulfill Clean Air Hopes
description: AS Congress considers clean- air legislation that would require millions of new cars to run on fuel other than gasoline, many Government analysts and environmentalists are questioning whether methanol, the most likely alternative, will significantly reduce air pollution.

title: Wang Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Fiscal 1989 results included a one- time provision of $30 million for the quarter, and the year also included a $234 million restructuring charge, which included the cost of employee severance; costs associated with the realignment of U.S. sales, service, and administrative support units; plant closing costs; and adjustments of the asset values of business activities outside the company's newly defined core businesses.

title: New Breed of Robots Have the Human Touch
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 1 about new robots called teleoperators referred incorrectly to the views of John Molino, president of the Tech-U-Fit Corporation in Alexandria, Va. He said he believed the robots would assist, but not replace, shuttle crews working in space.

title: Dynamics Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $825,000 in income from CTS Corp. while the year-ago second quarter included income of $587,000 from CTS. c-Included $3,964,000, or 98 cents a share, from a settlement of patent litigation. The company has an equity investment in CTS.

title: As Beach Erosion Accelerates, Remedies Are Costly and Few
description: USING computerized measuring techniques, scientists are tracking with new precision the erosion that is eating away 90 percent of the nation's coasts.

title: Texas Air Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included a charge of $131 million.

title: Cross & Trecker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $910,000. The company said that third quarter results included non-recurring charges of $25 million, of which $21.3 million related to a major restructuring program. The program involves offering three operating units for sale, the sale of a joint venture, a consolidation of two operating units and a writedown of other assets.

title: 'El Big Bang' for Market in Spain
description: Spain's stock markets rose today, the first day of trading under a new system that introduced the most sweeping changes in the exchange's 158-year-old history.

title: Judge Rules That Rose Case Should Go to a Federal Court
description: In another unexpected judicial development in the Pete Rose case, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that Rose's lawsuit against A. Bartlett Giamatti belongs in United States District Court in Columbus, Ohio, where the baseball commissioner wants it, and not in state court in Cincinnati, where Rose wanted it.

title: Nipsco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Crawford & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings results are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected in June.

title: INSIDE
description: Guilty Verdict on Wall St. Five principals of a defunct New Jersey investment partnership, Princeton/Newport, and a former Drexel Burnham Lambert trader were found guilty in the first case that charged racketeering on Wall Street. Page D1. Mets Trade for Viola The Mets obtained Frank Viola, last year's Cy Young Award winner in the American League, by sending Rick Aguilera, David West, Kevin Tapani and two players who will be named later to Minnesota. Page B7. Beach Erosion Accelerates Scientists estimate that 90 percent of the beaches on the East and Gulf coasts are eroding, driving many communities to adopt costly, ineffective remedies that only make matters worse. Science Times, page C1.

title: New Face and Name For the Ritz Theater
description: The Ritz Theater on Broadway is getting a new look and a new name. It will be called the Walter Kerr Theater as a salute to the longtime drama critic.

title: We Have a Flag Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Tighten Neckties to Kick Up Their Heels
description: Four Manhattan lawyers will rise from their desks tomorrow afternoon, straighten their ties and hail cabs to Lincoln Center for what may prove to be the apex of their careers as performance artists. The event is ''Megadance,'' a modern-dance marathon to be presented tomorrow and Thursday evenings at Alice Tully Hall as part of the Serious Fun festival. The piece they will perform is ''Sloss, Kerr, Rosenberg & Moore'' by Ann Carlson, a performance artist and choreographer.

title: Worldcorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $3,200,000.

title: Review/Television; The Villain Is Old Age, Harming Even the Young
description: ''The Golden Years?'' begins with the grisly account of a 79-year-old Ohio woman, afflicted with Alzheimer's disease, who was severely beaten and sexually abused, presumably by members of her family. This example of what the introduction calls ''a subject we can no longer afford to ignore'' prepares one for a tabloid-style ain't-it-just-terrible hour adorned by discolored flesh, broken limbs and torn organs.

title: Article 166189 -- No Title
description: The Energy Department has proposed spending $21.5 billion over the next six years to correct hazardous and unlawful conditions at its nuclear sites around the country. The money would be used to clean up pollution, to repair equipment and for research to develop new methods to dispose of radioactive and chemical waste.

title: The Death Squad
description: Finally and tragically there is no escape from the truth that the nations of the world have known but run away from for years:

title: Savings Unit Has Big Loss
description: Lincoln Savings and Loan, which was seized by Federal regulators in April, lost $847 million in the first six months of the year, sending its net worth plunging to a negative $906 million, California officials said.

title: North's Right to a Military Pension Is Questioned
description: Congressional investigators issued a legal opinion today saying that Oliver L. North's conviction for destroying Government documents in the Iran-contra affair casts ''serious doubt'' on whether he is entitled to his military pension.

title: A Prominent Indian Abandons Gandhi With Harsh Rebuke
description: A prominent member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's governing Congress Party resigned his party membership and seat in Parliament today and leveled a stinging attack on Mr. Gandhi's leadership.

title: 10-Day Shutdown For Ford Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would shut its plant in Atlanta for 10 days, beginning next Monday. The shutdown, the second for the Atlanta plant this summer and the fifth involving a Ford plant, followed weak orders for its products, the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable.

title: Correction
description: A brief article in some copies on Sunday about an agreement under which the actor Rob Lowe could avoid prosecution on charges that he videotaped a girl performing a sex act in an Atlanta hotel room described the agreement incorrectly. District Attorney Lewis R. Slaton said Mr. Lowe agreed to perform 20 hours of community service over two years, not two years of community service.

title: Six Guilty Of Stock Conspiracy
description: The five principals of a defunct New Jersey investment partnership and a former trader with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. were found guilty yesterday by a Federal jury in Manhattan of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock deals.

title: 'Outsider' Ravitch Runs as Exactly That
description: Richard Ravitch enjoys his role as the only outsider among the four Democratic mayoral candidates. The troubles of New York City, he says, can be resolved only by someone not tied to all the old ways of governing it.

title: Canada Packers reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Tighter Control Urged on Disabled Veterans' Pay
description: The Veterans Administration paid $1.7 billion in 1986 to veterans with ''ordinary diseases of life'' that were not caused or aggravated by military service, Congressional investigators said today.

title: With 2 Premiers Tarnished, Japanese Party Gets Down to Squabbling
description: One week after Prime Minister Sousuke Uno announced that he would resign, Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party has dissolved into fierce factional and cross-generational battling for the choice of a new leader and perhaps even a new style of leadership.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Careers; Construction Opportunities For Women
description: ''I BUY my work clothes at the Gap; my friends go to Bloomingdale's,'' Beth M. Leahy, 34 years old, said last week.

title: Let's Not Count on the Earth to Heal Itself; Wolf in the Greenhouse
description: To the Editor:

description: Preferred Stock

title: Van Dorn Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest-quarter results included a one-time charge of $1.7 million for equipment writedowns and a charge of $310,000 from the closing of a facility. The company said about $1.6 million was spent in the latest quarter to develop new containers, representing a significant increase in those expenses over the year-ago second quarter.

title: A Tale of Survival at Sea: A 2-Week Ordeal in a Raft
description: They had been dating. He was talking marriage. She wasn't sure. He wanted to see how she liked long-distance sailing. She wanted to teach him fly fishing. So off they went on a romantic-sounding adventure to Bermuda.

title: Review/Music; Tanglewood Offers a Contemporary Bazaar
description: Perhaps this year's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood reflects the chaos around us. Its first two days have been an international bazaar (at times, a flea market) of musical style; hardly a university of ordered disciplines and calm discourse.

title: Most Networks Show Tape
description: ABC News declined to use video footage purporting to show the hanging of Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins yesterday, relying on freeze-frame photos instead, while CBS, NBC and CNN all played a short section of the videotape.

title: Duquesne Light Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Golden Valley Microwave Foods reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Myers (L.E.) Group (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $85,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $483,000 for the quarter and $846,000 for the 6 months.

title: Trooper and 9 Others Held in Drugs in Jersey
description: A New Jersey state trooper, an Atlantic City police officer and eight others have been indicted on charges of operating an alleged cocaine ring, state officials said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Limited Inc., Columbus, Ohio, the largest women's apparel store chain in the nation, is offering $100 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Surgery for Reds' Ace
description: Danny Jackson, the Cincinnati Reds' left-hander who made a spectacular debut in the National League last year with a 23-8 record, underwent shoulder surgery yesterday and is through for the season.

title: A Bidding War for Professors Who Know Wall Street Ways
description: A bidding war has broken out among the nation's business schools for finance professors.

title: Hooked on Scanning
description: SCANNERS often transform the thinking of their users as quickly as they transform paper documents. Some people move from ''I can't imagine why I would ever want one of these things,'' to ''I can't imagine how I'll ever again get by without one'' in a matter of minutes.

title: Four Couturiers Who Conquered Paris
description: Four blockbuster collections! In the glory days of the 1950's, when Christian Dior and Cristobal Balenciaga shared the top honors, that would have been a record for the French couture. But in last week's Paris openings of fashions for next fall and winter, Yves Saint Laurent, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel and Valentino Garavani, whose headquarters are in Rome, each presented distinguished collections.

title: General Chosen as Polish Prime Minister
description: The newly elected Polish Communist Party leader, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, nominated the Interior Minister today to be his successor as Prime Minister, the nation's official press agency said.

title: Peoples Energy Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * J. Len van Zyl has been named president and chief executive of Lewis, Gilman & Kynett.

title: A Struggling Wang Revamps Operations
description: An Wang, the 69-year-old founder of Wang Laboratories Inc., at home recovering from cancer surgery two weeks ago, is already taking an active role in directing his company's business. It looks like the Lowell, Mass., computer maker will need all of its founder's many talents.

title: Immigrants Face Threat To Amnesty
description: Immigrants who were granted amnesty under the 1986 immigration law could lose their legal status and be deported because of bureaucratic confusion or because they are unaware that a second deadline must be met in the coming months, immigrants' rights groups have warned.

title: Blame Hezbollah
description: Who is responsible for the killing of Lieut. Col. William Higgins of the Marines, if indeed he has been killed? Was Israel right or wrong in kidnapping Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, whom it believed to be a terrorist perhaps involved in the colonel's kidnapping? What should the United States do now?

title: Cross & Trecker Restructuring
description: The Cross & Trecker Corporation, the second-largest independent machine tool manufacturer, announced a restructuring that will involve the sale of three units and an interest in a joint venture.

title: Bridge
description: Competition for two major knockout team championships continued today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships. Predictably there were no surprises in preliminary play Sunday, since most teams were involved in three-way matches with two to survive.

title: Vietnam to Allow Prisoners Who Aided the U.S. to Leave
description: Vietnam has agreed to resettle in the United States at least 19,000 former prisoners who had been closely associated with the United States-backed Government in Saigon, State Department officials said today.

title: Xerox Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: The Big Gains Rip-Off
description: Cutting taxes on capital gains was a bad idea when it was just one of the few substantive proposals George Bush made in his shabby Presidential campaign; and it's still a bad idea now that some Democrats have foolishly taken it for themselves.

title: Mistake in Identity Pays Compliment to a Rookie
description: While watching the videotape today of Saturday's scrimmage against the Washington Redskins, Bobby Hammond, the Jets' running-backs coach, asked, ''Who is that running? Freeman McNeil?''

title: Cutting Flood Insurance
description: MANY people endorse the exclusion of undeveloped barrier islands from the National Flood Insurance Program which, in effect, subsidizes coastal development. Critics of the program say that the low-cost insurance encourages shoreline development, and that taxpayers pick up the tab when the inevitable storm strikes.

title: Wellman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflected a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 15, 1989.

title: In '88, 6 States Executed 11, Half the Executions of '87
description: Eleven prisoners were executed in six states last year, less than half the number of inmates who were put to death the previous year, the Justice Department said Saturday.

title: 10 Are Missing as Barge Is Sunk Off Louisiana in Hurricane
description: A self-propelled barge serving as an oil rig was sunk early today in the season's first hurricane about 25 miles south of Morgan City in the Gulf of Mexico. Ten men were believed trapped inside the capsized wreck.

title: Ogden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNR Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,681,665 and $2,675,235 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss from reorganization matters of $109,619,174 for both periods. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $8,915 and $16,091 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included a tax credit of $1,100,000.

title: Merchants Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment gains of $42,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $3,000 for the quarter and a gain of $138,000, both from investments.

title: Buffett to Add To Coke Stake
description: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire Omaha investor, said today that he planned to seek permission from Federal antitrust officials to raise his stake in the Coca-Cola Company to 15 percent, from 6.75 percent.

title: Bracelet Monitor a Bail Rule For Freed Ex-Murder Convict
description: V. James Landano, freed after a Federal judge vacated his murder conviction and life sentence because of prosecutor misconduct, was fitted today with an electronic monitoring bracelet as a condition of bail.

title: Beijing Insists Khmer Rouge Share in Rule
description: China defied the United States, the Soviet Union and other countries meeting here to negotiate a peace agreement for Cambodia by insisting today that its Cambodian Communist ally, the Khmer Rouge, be allowed to play a role in governing the country.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Voluntary Hospitals Picks Chief Executive
description: LEAD: After almost a year of restructuring, Voluntary Hospitals of America Inc. has selected Robert W. O'Leary as its president and chief executive.

title: Tucuman Journal; In Argentina Today, Not Steak, but Stark Hunger
description: As eagerly as if they were expecting toys, about a thousand children line up in shifts for the spartan lunch served daily in two dining rooms operated by the Church of San Pedro Nolasco.

title: Stocks Up Strongly as Dow Rises 25.42
description: Stock prices finished strongly yesterday, buoyed by a surge in bond prices and gains in several blue-chip issues and in certain takeover-related stocks.

title: Manischewitz Calls Off Deal
description: The B. Manischewitz Company has scuttled its deal to be acquired, according to the Beverly Hills investment firm that wanted to buy it.

title: American Express Apology Is $8 Million, Not $4 Million
description: The American Express Company agreed to pay twice as much as it originally announced to settle accusations that it had conducted a campaign of disinformation against Edmund J. Safra, a banking competitor, people involved in the agreement said last night.

title: Salomon Units to Pay Fine Of $4 Million in Cocoa Case
description: Phillip Brothers Inc., the commodity marketing and trading subsidiary of Salomon Inc., and three affiliates agreed today to pay $4 million, a record fine, as part of a settlement of Federal disciplinary charges.

title: Co-Steel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $3.2 million and $5.9 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sales of Kidneys Prompt New Laws and Debate
description: Last summer Colin Benton died after receiving a kidney transplant at a private London hospital.

title: Mayor Usry Returns to Work
description: Mayor James L. Usry returned to work today for the first time since his arrest last week in connection with a corruption scandal. Mr. Usry left early after spending part of the day in meetings at his City Hall office, a secretary said. He did not return telephone calls today to The Associated Press. Mr. Usry and 13 other political leaders and executives were arrested Thursday after an eight-month undercover investigation into municipal bribery and corruption. Mr. Usry, 67 years old, the city's first black mayor, was charged with bribery, conspiracy, official misconduct and accepting unlawful gifts.

title: Why Mr. Cheney Needs a Game Plan
description: The House has played havoc with Secretary Cheney's defense budget. Some of its acts were pure pork, not principle. And while some of those based on principle seem sound, others are questionable. Mr. Cheney and President Bush will continue to face just such legislative chaos until they offer Congress a coherent strategy and budget reflecting the new realities of global power.

title: Edgar Kaufmann Jr., 79, Architecture Historian
description: Edgar Kaufmann Jr., an architecture historian, curator and philanthropist who preserved his family's celebrated Frank Lloyd Wright-designed house, Fallingwater, as a public museum, died of leukemia yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Xerox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bloch Goes Home to Washington And Has a Chat With an Austrian
description: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department diplomat under investigation for espionage, returned to his Washington home from New York today trailed by Federal agents and reporters, and chatted for 45 minutes with a correspondent for Austria's state-financed television service.

title: Budget Roundup; House Sets Its Own Spending After Debate on the Cost of Lawmakers' Mail
description: The House of Representatives turned its attention tonight to its own budget, approving a $1.6 billion appropriation for Congress and its related agencies after a sharp debate over how much lawmakers are spending on mail.

title: Military Recruiting Hurt By Tight Labor Market
description: Although no one is yet predicting a crisis, experts say that after six years of enlisting large numbers of well-qualified young men and women, the United States armed forces may well be heading into a time of troubles in recruiting.

title: Bush Statement About Hostages
description: Following is the text of the statement by President Bush tonight calling for the release of hostages in the Middle East:

title: Bird Returns to Court After a Back Injury
description: Larry Bird, who was expected to miss from four to six weeks after fracturing a bone in his lower back over the weekend, made a stiff, gingerly return to the basketball court yesterday.

title: Chrysler Net Climbed 6.6% In Quarter
description: By shipping a higher proportion of more expensive models than it did a year ago, the Chrysler Corporation managed to increase its profits by 6.6 percent in the second quarter, the company said today.

title: U.S. Note Offering Is Set by Thailand
description: The Kingdom of Thailand yesterday became the first Southeast Asian nation to tap the American capital markets, as it priced a $200 million offering of 10-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Review/Theater; On London Stage, the 'A's' Are Rather Flat
description: This summer the West End is giving its regards to Off Broadway as well as to Broadway, with ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune'' and ''Steel Magnolias'' joining ''Anything Goes'' and other musicals. Opening in August is a new American play, Donald Freed's ''Veteran's Day,'' starring Jack Lemmon and Michael Gambon.

title: U.N. Today
description: Trusteeship Council Meets at 11 A.M.

title: Comdial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Allergan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings were not given because Allergan was spun off to SmithKline Beckman shareholders on July 26 before SKB's merger with Beecham Plc.

title: Koch Reference Is 'Chintziness'
description: He was not commenting on the criminal charges, but Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday pronounced Leona M. Helmsley guilty of ''chintziness.''

title:
FOUR POINTS OF LIGHT;
For the Homeless, A Room and a Job
description: LEAD: DAYS INNS of America has changed the lives of 25 homeless Atlantans over the past 18 months through a program that provides jobs and housing until they can afford their own.

title: The Changing Landscape
description: BARRIER islands are at once the most vulnerable and the most resilient parts of the coastline. Formed and nourished by sand carried on currents that run along the shore, they are constantly in motion, rising, falling and migrating. A storm can divide them in an afternoon, forming inlets in low-lying areas.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group IncN) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings not available; the company went public in July 1988.

title: Arnold Bank, Physician, 58
description: Arnold Bank, chairman of the department of neurological and sensory sciences at Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia, died of leukemia Sunday at the center. He was 58 years old and lived in Elkins Park, Pa.

title: Greenwell Is Disabled
description: Mike Greenwell, the Boston Red Sox outfielder who was runner-up to Jose Canseco for the American League's most valuable player award last season, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday because of a severely sprained left ankle.

title: Agents Are Wooed
description: The top five agents in baseball, a group representing almost half the major league players, have been invited to a meeting in New York tomorrow to hear about plans for a proposed new league.

title: Mets Trade for Viola After 7th Loss in a Row; Cardinals Beat Darling, 3-2
description: The great swoon worsened tonight when the Mets fell to the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2, lost for the seventh straight time and dropped seven games out of first place with 59 to go.

title: Talking Business; With Deutch of Century Pacific Investment; Building Housing And Tax Credits
description: Many companies sponsoring real estate limited partnerships - programs intended to reduce tax liability and provide capital appreciation from both profits and the eventual sale of the properties - have found it difficult to adapt to restrictions on tax shelters in the tax code. Some companies have done well, however, by specializing in a relatively unknown tax credit designed by Congress to support rental housing for low-income people.

title: Questar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York Can Do Better on Jobs for Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Nonbombers Succumb to Toronto
description: The race is moving ahead, even if the Yankees are not. July is done, and now the season has moved into its final two months. But a chance to leap forward froze last night; another night passed, another opportunity slipped away.

title: Chrysler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
1991 Election For Council Is Proposed
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission yesterday proposed 1991 elections for a 51-member City Council that would assume the many new powers over the city budget and land use the commission has recommended giving it.

title: Economic Boom in the South Ebbs as Advantages Diminish
description: After outpacing the rest of the nation for most of the past three decades, the South's economic boom has cooled as some of its competitive advantages have diminished or disappeared.

title: BMC Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Eastern Airlines
description: Eastern Airlines, in a promotion aimed at funeral homes, is offering a 50 percent discount for corpses shipped aboard its passenger jets until Aug. 31, a spokesman said. Funeral directors can also earn bonus frequent-flier miles based on the volume of business they bring to Eastern if they sign up for another program for cargo shippers, she said. The airline, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, has been crippled by a strike since March.

title: NUI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for the quarter and $4,682,000 for the 9 months. The company said that the latest third quarter reflected the inclusion of the income of City Gas Co. of Florida, which NUI acquired as of Aug. 1, 1988, partly offset by lower earnings for the New Jersey division and the impact of higher levels of debt, principally associated with the City Gas acquisition.

title: CGC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Integrated Genetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,300,406 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss The latest periods' results included $10 million from the sale of the company's Human Fertility Hormone Technology to the Ares-Serono Group.

title: Market Place; Excess Tendering In Bid for NWA
description: THERE are 29.5 million outstanding shares of NWA Inc. Yet investors somehow tendered or promised for delivery a total of 31 million shares in a $3.6 billion offer from Wings Holdings Inc. that expired last Wednesday.

title: NBI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,397,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-After tax benefits of $4,290,000 for the quarter and $11,408,000 for the year, and losses from discontinued operations of $5,432,000 and $33,470,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Gump's Specialty Stores Said to Fill Top Position
description: Ken Watson, who recently resigned at the president and chief executive of Cartier Inc., has reportedly been appointed the chief executive of the Gump's specialty store chain based in San Francisco, whose four stores are noted for their fine art and antiques.

title: Release All Hostages, U.N. Says
description: A resolution demanding the release of all hostages and condemning hostage-taking was approved unanimously by the 15 members of the Security Council today.

title: U.S. WEAPON SALES TO THIRD WORLD INCREASE BY 66%
description: American arms sales to the third world increased sharply last year and nearly matched Soviet sales, which declined from the previous year, the Congressional Research Service reported today.

title: New York Report on AIDS Assails Inadequate Financing
description: A New York City AIDS planning agency said yesterday that government officials have failed to commit the billions of dollars needed to address the AIDS epidemic.

title: For U.S., Few Options of Retaliation
description: If Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins's death is confirmed, the Bush Administration will find itself confronting the same quandaries that have prevented its predecessors from retaliating for most previous terrorist attacks, former and present Government officials said today.

title: Church's Fried Chicken Inc reports earnings for 12wks to June 11
description: b-Net income

title: Amre Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $5,278,000 and $7,274,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $605,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the year. Revenue represent contract revenue. The company said aggregate dollar and share earnings for the year-ago periods have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Mysterious Particle
description: The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., has analyzed the largest sample ever of the mysterious Z#0 (pronounced zee-zero) particle and succeeded in obtaining a measure of its mass that is six times more precise than any other. The finding sheds light on a fundamental building block of nature and helps scientists better understand the forces that hold the universe together.

title: Pacific Telecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Itel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-Included a gain of $3 million from curtailment and settlement of a foreign pension plan. c-Included a gain on sale of Conergics Corp. of $5.5 million for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: What's Spanish About Hispanic Descent?
description: To the Editor:

title: An $81 Million Bond Issue For Shelby County, Tenn.
description: Shelby County, Tenn., priced a total of $81 million in general-obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding. The bonds will be used for public improvement, schools and special purposes.

title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN
description: A new survey of drug users shows that the number of casual users has sharply dropped but that addiction to cocaine and crack is growing, Federal officials said today.

title: Prices Received by Farmers Fell 0.7% From June to July
description: Prices farmers received for raw products dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, compared with June but were up 2.8 percent from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Leon Leonidoff, 95, the Producer Of Radio City Shows for 42 Years
description: Leon Leonidoff, the producer of several hundred extravaganzas at the Radio City Music Hall from the day it opened until his retirement 42 years later, died Saturday in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 95 years old.

title: Environmentalists Fighting Airfield Development
description: In 1971, New York State used its right of eminent domain to take 8,657 acres just west of the former Stewart Air Force Base, displacing about 1,500 residents in the process. The land was needed, officials said, to create a buffer against noise and to permit the gradual expansion of Stewart as a civilian airport.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Transportation
description: If catchy phrases are the spice of politics, then pity Samuel K. Skinner. To stir up interest in a national transportation policy he must turn ''infrastructure'' into an appetizing mouthful.

title: McDonnell To Sell Unit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had agreed to sell its network systems business to British Telecommunications P.L.C. for $355 million.

title: Inmates Put to Work Against Graffiti
description: Prison work gangs began painting over graffiti on the Long Island Expressway yesterday morning and, a few hours later, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced that measure and others for removing - or at least obscuring - the spray-painted blanket that covers much of New York City.

title:
FOUR POINTS OF LIGHT;
Affordable Insurance Revitalizes Neighborhoods
description: LEAD: ALLSTATE Insurance Company wanted to find a way to make homeowner's insurance affordable and available to people in Chicago's deteriorating neighborhoods.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., agreed to acquire Pancretec Inc., San Diego, a maker of ambulatory infusion pumps for about $54 million.

title: Cholesterol Reduction May Avert Cancers
description: CHOLESTEROL reduction has long been tried as a preventive measure to ward off heart disease. But now there are tantalizing hints that, in a certain category of cancer cases, cholesterol reduction might head off tumor formation as well.

title: Mets Trade for Viola After 7th Loss in a Row; Aguilera, West Sent to Twins
description: With one minute or so left before the midnight deadline for trades, the Mets landed the big one tonight when they acquired the ace pitcher Frank Viola from the Minnesota Twins for Rick Aguilera, David West, Kevin Tapani and two other young players.

title: Beijing Regime to Fall, Student Leader Asserts
description: Wuer Kaixi, the Chinese student leader who fled China after the Government crackdown on the democracy movement in June, said yesterday that he believed the Chinese Government would fall within two to three years but that student leaders still welcomed dialogue and contact with Beijing.

title: Anthony Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Amoskeag Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Browns and Eagles Stretch in Hyde Park
description: The Cleveland Browns and the Philadelphia Eagles arrived today for their pre-season National Football League exhibition game Sunday and headed straight to a famous London landmark to work out.

title: European Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices in the European Community rose three-tenths of a percentage point in June over the previous month, the community's statistical agency, Eurostat, reported today. The office said prices were 5.4 percent higher than a year earlier. The European Community warned that, despite the moderate price increase in June, inflation rates were ''clearly higher than in 1988'' for the 12 member states, except for Denmark, Greece and the Netherlands.

title: 'Cold Fusion' Research Enjoys a Boom in Utah
description: Professor B. Stanley Pons has given up trying to convince critics that he and his colleague Martin Fleischmann may have unlocked fusion, the power of the sun, in a laboratory beaker.

title: New York Court Upholds Howard Beach Convictions
description: A New York State appeals court yesterday upheld the manslaughter and assault convictions of three young men in the Howard Beach attack and refused a defense request to reduce the prison sentences imposed on them.

title: Frances Wright, 92, Harvard Astronomer
description: Frances Woodworth Wright, a Harvard University astronomer who taught celestial navigation to Navy officers, died of cancer Sunday. She was 92 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Rally in Treasury Issues Continues
description: The credit market rally continued yesterday as dealers further bid up the prices of Treasury notes and bonds. But the gains, which amounted to as much as 7/8 point on some securities, were recorded on light volume.

title: Ancient Site Reveals Skill Of Indians With Crops
description: IN an aerial photographic survey of ancient Indian croplands, anthropologists at the University of Colorado have found evidence that 550 years ago the Anasazi had already developed advanced agricultural practices, including widespread use of small pebbles as a mulch to retain soil moisture.

title:
FOUR POINTS OF LIGHT;
Students Are Trained To Tackle Wall Street
description: LEAD: IN 1982, working with the New York City Board of Education, American Express created a two-year program to prepare high school juniors and seniors for jobs in the financial services industry that did not require a college education. The program, called the Academy of Finance, started with 35 students at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Timely Forecast For Saratoga
description: rrThe concept of time travel has intrigued man for centuries. Imagine stepping back into glorious periods of world history, or exploring the future to see if civilization has advanced and solved the eternal riddles of existence.

description: THE House of Representatives last week called on the Bush Administration to investigate and report on problems caused by nuclear reactors orbiting the Earth.

title: Q&A
description: Standing on One Leg Q.Why do some birds - flamingos, for example - stand around on one foot? A.There is no one proven answer, but there are several plausible theories, bird authorities agree.

title: Gymnastic Girls, Not Women
description: Phoebe Mills, a talented 16-year-old gymnast, retired last week after a 10-year career during which she won an Olympic medal and succeeded Mary Lou Retton as America's top female in the sport. Ms. Retton, the darling of the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, retired at age 17 -which is apparently becoming the upper age limit for females who aspire to world-class competition in gymnastics.

description: Year-ago second quarter included a gain of $2.7 million from the sale of trademarks, which if not realized, would have resulted in a net loss for that period of about $4 million.

The company said that net loss for the latest fiscal year included $3,525,000, which represents its pro- rata share of the losses of Memory- Tech, a 40 percent owned compact disc joint venture. On July 17, the company transferred this interest in Memory-Tech to Mitsubishi. In this transaction, Mitsubishi arranged the company's release from guarantees of Memory-Tech obligations of about $12,000,000.

title: Before His Abduction, Higgins Talked of Risks
description: Two weeks before Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins was kidnapped, he told a Norwegian television correspondent traveling with him of the dangers that members of the United Nations observer force faced in Lebanon.

description: The director of academic tutoring at North Carolina State University today supported the accusations of abuses set forth in a newly released book about the school's basketball program.

title: By Design; Return of the Snood
description: One of the most captivating fashion ideas to be seen at last week's Paris couture shows was, in fact, almost invisible.

title: Judge Approves Accord Settling Yonkers Budget
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a 1989-90 budget for Yonkers that specifically marks $24 million to build two schools required by his desegregation plan for the city.

title: Cuba Charges Ex-Official With Corruption
description: A former Interior Minister of Cuba and three former ministry heads have been arrested in a continuing crackdown on corruption, the official newspaper Granma reported today.

title: Atlantic City Retread
description: Atlantic City residents understand better than most people that the more things change, the more they remain the same. Every few months Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, squares off in the resort city with a new challenger, but the result - a knockout of the challenger, usually within a round or two - is always the same.

title: Ex-H.U.D. Official Recants Testimony
description: A former general counsel for the Department of Housing and Urban Development told a House subcommittee today that he never rendered the legal opinion that has been cited as the basis for discretionary awards of millions of dollars in Federal housing subsidies.

title: Chile General Tells Opposition Not to Tamper With Amnesty
description: The man who has long been the leading military advocate of democratic transition in Chile says efforts by opposition leaders to reverse a 1978 amnesty for political crimes could endanger that transition.

title: Kenneth R. May, 65, Ex-Lutheran Bishop
description: The Rev. Kenneth R. May, retired bishop of the Western Pennsylvania-West Virginia Synod of the former Lutheran Church in America, died of complications from an aortic aneurysm Friday. He was 65 years old and lived in McCandless, Pa.

title: Chrysler Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Autoclave Engineers reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: Top Banks Join Drop In Prime
description: Acting a few days after the Federal Reserve signaled a further reduction in interest rates, several leading banks, including Citibank, the nation's largest, announced yesterday that they had lowered their prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 10 1/2 percent.

title: Tracy Austin's Summer Place
description: One of the best-kept sports secrets of the summer is that team tennis, nurtured zealously by Billie Jean King for the last 15 years, is still functioning. An even bigger surprise to many tennis followers in the metropolitan New York area may be that the league, Domino's Pizza TeamTennis, has a team about 35 miles from Manhattan, and it includes Tracy Austin, a two-time United States Open singles champion.

title: Sister Thomas Cushing, Hospital Director, 85
description: Sister Thomas Francis Cushing, executive director of St. John's Hospital in Queens for 22 years before retiring in 1982, died yesterday at Maria Regina Convent in Brentwood, L.I., where she lived. She was 85 years old.

title: LeMond to Compete
description: Greg LeMond, the Tour de France champion, has decided to compete in a World Cup cycling event in Montreal, race organizers announced yesterday.

title:
FOUR POINTS OF LIGHT;
Rescuing Young Lives From Rough Streets
description: LEAD: THE EAST Oakland Youth Development Center, sponsored by The Clorox Company in the neighborhood where the business got started, helps disadvantaged children and young adults navigate the thin line between making it and failure.

title: Delchamps Inc reports earnings for 13wks to July 1
description: The company said the results for the year-earlier periods covered a 14- week period and a 53-week period, respectively.

title: Police Removing Roadblocks at Reservation
description: Mohawk leaders and the state police agreed today to ease a 10-day-old standoff at the St. Regis Indian Reservation and remove some roadblocks on the Mohawk territory, officials said.

title: Enron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $40.3 million, or 85 cents a share, from the sale of the company's half interest in its cogeneration business, and $14.9 million, or 31 cents a share, from the sale of shares of Mobil Corp. stock. Also included were extraordinary charges of $9.3 million from early extinguishment of debt.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 An American hostage was killed by a Shiite Muslim group in Lebanon, members of the terrorist group said. A second terrorist group threatened to kill a second American hostage by nightfall today unless Israel freed a Muslim cleric. Page A1

title: Amid an 'Inferno of Bombs,' With Nowhere Safe, 250,000 Flee Beirut in a Week
description: Lebanese no longer brag about being brave.

title: 3 Men Hurt in Harlem In Collapse of Building
description: Three construction workers were injured yesterday afternoon when the building they were rehabilitating in Harlem partially collapsed, burying them under plaster and debris.

title: Zhou Yang, Ex-Culture Official In the Chinese Party, Is Dead at 81
description: Zhou Yang, a leading literary arbiter in the Communist Party for nearly 60 years and, in his later years, a champion of artistic freedom, died today. He was 81 years old.

title: Diamond Shamrock Offshore Partners reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest quarter reflects a loss of $13 million on anticipated property sales. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Books of The Times; Characters Who Lead Quiet Lives of Desolation
description: Kiss in the Hotel Joseph Conrad And Other Stories By Howard Norman 158 pages. Summit Books. $18.95.

title: Giants' Major Move Is Pleasing (To Most)
description: After one week of training camp, Coach Bill Parcells made major changes today in the Giants' offensive line. The moves were very good for William Roberts, good for Bob Kratch and Damian Johnson, and not so good for Eric Moore.

title: Reuss Is Traded
description: Jerry Reuss was traded from the Chicago White Sox to the Milwaukee Brewers last night for Brian Drahman, a minor league pitcher.

title: Westin Leaves ABC to Join King World
description: Av Westin, a news producer for ABC and CBS for more than 35 years, was named senior vice president for reality programs for King World Productions yesterday. King World is one of the largest distributers of syndicated shows for television, including ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy.''

title: Once Again, Cranston Takes Center Stage On Bailout Issue
description: The word going around the House Banking Committee room Thursday afternoon was that, sooner or later, Senator Alan Cranston would switch.

title: Samuel Beckett's Wife Is Dead at 89 in Paris
description: Suzanne Deschevaux-Dumesnil, the wife of the playwright and novelist Samuel Beckett, died on July 17 in Paris. She was 89 years old.

title: Helmsley's Business Neglect Related
description: Leona M. Helmsley was so uninterested in reports about the financial performance of her hotels that she threw them out as soon as she received them, her former personal assistant testified yesterday.

title: 3 Arrested in Tent Removals
description: Three people were arrested in Tompkins Square Park early this morning in a protest against city park rangers who tore down eight to 10 tents shortly before midnight. A police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said that there was no violence. Sergeant O'Donnell said the three people arrested were Paul Augusta, 25 years old, of 114 East 53d St., and Francisco Acuary, 38, a homeless man, who were both charged with disorderly conduct and harassment, and Stacy Brown, 20, of 356 West 34th St., who was charged with disorderly conduct.

title: Growth Seen In Germany
description: West Germany's economy will grow strongly this year and is likely to continue to expand for two more years, although less forcefully and with higher inflation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report released today.

title: Home Office Reference Lab reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Job Shuffle At Industry Publications
description: AMID a general slowdown in media trade advertising, three of the ad industry's most important publishing companies exchanged top executives yesterday.

title: Oxford Names Stephen Sondheim Visiting Professor of Drama
description: Oxford University announced yesterday that the theatrical producer Cameron Mackintosh had set up a $2.9 million endowment to support student drama at the university and that as a result the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim has been named Oxford's first Visiting Professor of Drama and Musical Theater.

title: Resettling of Defectors: A Job Between Agencies
description: When it comes to weighing proposals that might strip a Government agency of a fiefdom, time slows down. As weeks slide into months and months into quarters, discussions drag on and on. It is G.S.T., some here say, or Government Standard Time.

title: American Water Works Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the net income in its latest second quarter was increased by $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share, because of a re-estimate of uncollectible accounts.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing captives held in Lebanon, based on a listing from The Associated Press, gave an incorrect age in some copies for one hostage, Robert Polhill. He is 55 years old, the A.P. says, not 35.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The House took a major step to press the television industry to reduce the amount of violence in programs, waiving antitrust laws so that the industry can meet to adopt voluntary guidelines on reducing such programming. But the networks said they doubted the action would have much effect, noting that the measure did not require the industry to reach agreement on guidelines. [ Page A1. ] The purchasing managers' survey fell to a level that indicates declining activity in the manufacturing sector of the economy for the third consecutive month. [ D1. ] Construction spending in June fell to its lowest level in eight months. [ D2. ] Dan Rostenkowski outlined to colleagues a proposal that would index for inflation assets acquired after Dec. 31. But a ranking Republican said the plan did not go far enough on reducing capital gains taxes. [ D1. ] The Federal Home Loan Bank Board will let Home Federal Savings of San Diego, one of the nation's largest savings associations, convert into a commercial bank. [ D2. ] The Administration warned that it might wage a fight over several provisions of the savings bailout bill if an agreement is not worked out with Congress on how to account for the cost of the rescue. [ D2. ] MARKETS The indictment of as many as 50 commodity traders and brokers on charges that they cheated investors is expected to be announced today by the Justice Department. [ D1. ] Treasury bond prices rose by more than a point in heavy trading, although the rally was pared by profit-taking. [ D14. ] Signaling that interest rates are likely to fall further, Alan Greenspan said the Fed is continuing to ease credit. [ D2. ] Yields continued to fall on C.D.'s and money market accounts. [ D20. ] The stock market staged one of its wildest performances in weeks, gyrating up and down and reflecting a continuing lack of conviction about the course of interest rates. [ D8. ] The dollar tumbled in choppy trading, weighed down by additional evidence of sluggish economic activity and expectations of further interest-rate declines. [ D15. ] COMPANIES Ford Motor has tentatively raised its 1990 model prices by an average of 4.8 percent, its largest increase in recent years. The company said the increase reflected the cost of installing safety air bags or motorized seat belts mandated by law. [ D1. ] Continental Airlines announced lower fares for weekend travelers, prompting a flurry of discounting by rival air carriers. [ D4. ] Pennzoil said its continuing operations posted solid gains in the second quarter although net income fell sharply. Unocal's profit rose 88 percent. [ D5. ] Polygram will acquire Island Records in a deal believed to be worth $300 million. [ D18. ] Cameron Iron Works agreed to merge with Cooper Industries in a deal the companies valued at $700 million. [ D4. ] TECHNOLOGY Digital typography is about to become part of the basic software controlling personal computers and work stations. [ D1. ] A rechargeable battery that stores 75 percent more power for the same volume of chemicals has been developed. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS If President Bush has his way, one-third of the vehicles in cities will be powered with cleaner-burning alternatives to gasoline and diesel fuel. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The expectation that capital gains tax rates may come down seems to have helped push stock prices up in recent weeks. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] Three important advertising publications exchanged top executives. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D18. ]

description: Debt

title: Brush Wellman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month both included a gain of about 17 cents a share from the settlement of a tax assessment, and the 6-month also included a 13 cents a share gain from the sale of a product line and a two cent a share charge from the prepayment of notes.

title: Harvard and Radcliffe Split Fund Drives
description: Harvard University is changing the way it solicits donations to present the financial needs of Radcliffe College more prominently.

title: Aguilera Feels Relief; He Will Start as a Twin
description: By the time the trade was finally made, Rick Aguilera was well prepared for it. Yesterday morning, he caught an early flight from St. Louis to New York, arrived at Yankee Stadium about the fifth inning and was throwing in the Minnesota Twins' bullpen as the game stretched into the late afternoon.

title: Golden Poultry Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: The share earnings reflected 25 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: Bridge
description: The top-ranked squads all advanced safely in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here Monday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, but there was a major upset in the Women's Knockout Teams.

title: Bureau Having Trouble Filling Jobs for Census
description: The Northeast's labor shortage, long the bane of fast-food restaurants, department stores and other sectors of the region's service economy, is hobbling a new employer: the 1990 census.

title: Macao Journal; Tiny Piece of Empire, Cringing in Giant Shadow
description: Once this was an international haven for spies and smugglers and political refugees, as colorful and corrupt as wartime Casablanca. But today most of Macao's waterfront sin and swagger have disappeared, leaving a small backwater port whose faith in the future and ambitious plans to become a commercial center have been rocked by the turmoil in China.

title: INSIDE
description: H.U.D. Consultants Named An investigator identified 20 Republicans and others who were paid as consultants on a housing program linked to favoritism. Page A16. Japanese Buying Colleges Japanese universities and companies are spending millions of dollars to establish a foothold in American higher education. Education, page B8. Mayoral Candidates Debate Mayor Koch defended his record in a Democratic debate and implied that his opponents are amateurs. Page B1. Mets Trade Wilson Toronto obtained Mookie Wilson, the senior Met, and signed his former teammate, Lee Mazzilli. Page A17. >U.S. Socialist Leader Dies Michael Harrington, whose writings helped inspire the War on Poverty, died of cancer. Page D23.

title: Avondale Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $762,000 and $1,921,000 for the quqrter and 6 months, respectively. In the year-ago 6-month period preferred stock requirements exceeded net income.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government is trying to reform Britain's education system by copying much of what it believes to be the American practice. But conversations with British politicians and education experts during a recent trip to London suggest that there is much misunderstanding of how American education really works.

title: Buffton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $719,000, or 19 cents a share.

title: MAI Amends Prime Offer
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. today amended its bid to acquire the minicomputer business of Prime Computer Inc. and is now offering $525 million in cash. The previous offer was for $450 million in cash and $150 million in debentures. Prime, based in Natick, Mass., has already reached an agreement for the whole company to be acquired by J. H. Whitney & Company for about $1.25 billion in cash.

title: Canadian Drug Expert Denies A Conflict of Interest in Testing
description: After a break of one month, the Canadian Government inquiry into the use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes resumed today with a prominent Canadian drug expert denying that his reponsibilities with the International Olympic Committee created a conflict of interest.

title: Market Place; Tax-Cut Outlook And the July Rally
description: THE expectation that capital gains tax rates may come down seems to have helped push stock prices up in recent weeks as investors delayed selling their shares.

title: Economic Scene; Murky Choices On Methanol
description: IS methanol the fuel in your future?

title: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings represent units.

title: Job-Protection Bid Likely for Rose
description: While they appeal the decision that took the case out of the Cincinnati court where it began, Pete Rose's lawyers apparently also will have to go to court to try to extend protection for Rose's job as manager of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Dynatech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Terrell Is Ineffective Once More For Yanks
description: They are like a summer rerun now. They win, then lose, win again, then lose again. All season - from April's early days until now - the Yankees have staggered and stumbled through a race that has not yet cast them aside.

title: Nothing in the Least Bit Shifty About Albany's Budget Shifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Images Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting change. The company said that during the latest quarter it recorded a non-recurring gain on the sale of a 25 percent interest in a Texas imaging center, partially offset by expenses related to the settlement of certain litigation and the writeoff of the company's Canton and Columbus, Ohio imaging center projects, of $84,510.

title: Wine Talk
description: Until recently, one of the more attractive ways to kill a Saturday in Paris was to have lunch at Jacques Melac's wine bar at 42 rue Leon-Frot, just off the rue de Charonne in the working-class 11th Arrondissement. With a plate of Auvergne sausages and salamis and a hunk of Cantal cheese, all of it washed down with the wines Mr. Melac bottles right there in the basement, a leisurely lunch could begin at 1 P.M. and easily last until 5.

title: LESSONS
description: In 1987, scholarly journals in this country published 215 articles on John Milton, 132 on Henry James and 554 on William Shakespeare.

title: Otto Heller, Lace Manufacturer, 76
description: Otto Heller, founder and chairman of Lace of France, a Manhattan-based lace manufacturing and importing company, died last Thursday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Pitt-Des Moines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Food Aid to Poland Linked to Free Markets
description: The European Community and the United States made it clear today that they would try to use their emergency food aid as a lever to pry Poland away from state trading and toward free markets.

title: Israel Adamant On Terms to Free Abducted Sheik
description: The Israeli Government insisted today that it would not release on its own the Shiite Muslim cleric abducted from Lebanon by Israeli commandos last week, even if it meant that more hostages might be killed.

title: Ex-Editor Is Chosen To Be New Curator Of Nieman Program
description: Bill Kovach, the former editor of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, has been named curator of the Nieman Foundation, a program for journalists at Harvard University.

title: John Ogdon, 52, a British Pianist Who Championed the New, Dies
description: John Ogdon, a British pianist best known for his championship of complex late-Romantic and 20th-century scores, died yesterday at Charing Cross Hospital in London, where he was admitted Monday with bronchial pneumonia. He was 52 years old.

title: Canada Malting reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed the revenue and earnings gains in the latest second quarter to benefits from the acquisition of Great Western Malting Co. in March and to higher malt prices as a result of last year's drought. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Linett & Harrison Job
description: Linett & Harrison, a three-month-old agency in Springfield, N.J., has won the $1 million Prestige Toy account this week and will begin television advertising this fall in the New York area for the company's line of stuffed toys. The agency was formed in late April after Caryl Linett, its president and creative director, left the same jobs at Keyes Martin Gaby Linett in Springfield. She was joined by Sam Harrison, a Keyes Martin senior vice president, who is the new shop's executive vice president and director of account services.

title: Imperial Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $1,779,000 for the quarter and $2,799,000 for the 6 months, and provisions of $56.6 million and $82,175,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, for credit losses in the wholesale consumer loan and corporate bond portfolios. c-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $964,000 for the quarter and $1,655,000 for the 6 months. Imperial said $25.9 million of the provisions for credit losses in the latest second quarter were related to consumer loans and $27 million were related to corporate bonds.

title: Kemper Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $67,235,000 for the quarter and $77,820,000 for the 6 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $5,803,000 for the quarter and $10,618,000 for the 6 months.

title: Waste Illegally Stored at Weapons Plant
description: The Federal Government's Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant is illegally storing thousands of gallons of poisonous chemicals laced with radioactive contaminants, the Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday.

title: Liberty Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $2.4 million for the quarter and $2.9 million for the 6 months. c-After realized investment gains of $300,000 and $7.2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Smith Toils Nonstop In Pursuit of a Coach
description: Three suits, their tags still on them, hang in the closet of Neil Smith's Manhattan hotel suite, hardly unwanted, but nonetheless unworn.

title: Pennzoil Cites Solid Gains, but Net Is Off Sharply
description: The Pennzoil Company said its continuing operations posted solid gains in the second quarter although net income fell sharply. Revenues in the quarter increased by 44.5 percent, to $791.2 million, from $547.6 million a year ago.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic in the Park
description: Weather reports had threatened rain, but nonetheless an audience estimated at 30,000 came to Central Park on Monday night to hear the New York Philharmonic. As it turned out, the listeners beat the odds -dark clouds loomed but not a drop of rain fell - and they had the benefit of a cool, breezy evening as well as music by Berlioz, Prokofiev and Dvorak.

title: M-A-R-C Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chemicals on Rails: A Growing Peril
description: For a week the burning wreckage of a derailed chemical train filled the air at Freeland, Mich., with acrid fumes, keeping hundreds of people from their homes.

title: Viola Gets the Ball For a Start Tonight
description: Frank Viola, the newest and highest paid member of the Mets, flew into town this afternoon, joined his new teammates in the locker room at Busch Stadium, found his uniform No. 16 pre-empted by Dwight Gooden, accepted No. 26 instead, tossed his gear into Gooden's locker by mistake and heard from Manager Davey Johnson that he would pitch Wednesday night against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Alba-Waldensian Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $106,587 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Virtuous Stand-Ins For Dietary Villains
description: ''YOU people,'' began a recent letter. This is the kind of salutation that sets most people's teeth on edge, and in this case referred to health professionals as well as those who write about health and nutrition.
