title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Ford Motor Credit Corporation, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $200 million worth of notes through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Cuomo Delays Rules for Gay Renters
description: Despite pressure from gay groups, the Cuomo administration has delayed drafting housing regulations to expand the rights of unmarried couples and has indicated that it will leave the issue to the Legislature and the courts.

title: NBC News Chief Trying to Smooth 'Rough Spots'
description: The president of NBC News, Michael Gartner, said yesterday that he had made a special effort to resolve some persistent problems and what he called rough spots that have plagued his leadership of the news division during the past year and that have led to continuing speculation about his future at the network.

title: Shared Medical Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest 6-month results reflected an accounting adjustment that added $5 million, or 22 cents a share, to earnings. The company also said it incurred certain unspecified nonrecurring expenses during the latest first quarter, primarily for the creation of certain employee benefit plans.

title: The Pop Life
description: March of the Pixies ''I'm a Dadaist but in a very naive way,'' Charles (Black) Francis, the chief songwriter and lead singer of the popular cult band the Pixies, explained in a telephone interview the other day from Los Angeles. ''I spend more time on poetic structures and rhyme schemes than I do on topics.''

title: SPX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $35,200,000 and $40,000,000 from discontinued for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included income of $5,500,000 and $9,500,000 from discontinued operations operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: McDonnell Pact
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had been awarded a contract worth $691 million by the Air Force to produce four more C-17 aircraft. The planes are to be delivered in 1991. The new order brings to six the number of C-17's ordered by the Air Force of a planned total of 210 to modernize its current military airlift command fleet by the year 2000, McDonnell Douglas said.

title: Garvey vs. Garvey: The Latest Chapter
description: Is there life after Steve Garvey? Can the former ballplayer's ex-wife, Cynthia Garvey, finally wash him out of her hair? She has been trying to do just that, she says, for the eight years they have been apart. And now comes what she bills as the final exorcism, an angry autobiography titled ''The Secret Life of Cyndy Garvey.''

title: Washington Energy reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included income of $5,942,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said latest-year loss largely resulted from its second-quarter loss from reduced gas sales through the company's utility subsidiary, Washington Natural Gas.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LETTER from a flower-loving friend:

description: Results for the latest second quarter and 6 months included an after-tax gain of $86.8 million, or $2.39 a share, associated with the sale of the company's holdings in Burlington Resources Inc. Results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months included an after-tax gain of $1.7 billion, or $41.46 a share, from the $3 billion cash settlement of the litigation between Pennzoil and Texaco Inc. and after-tax non-cash charges of $303 million from the disposition and writedown of certain assets and other charges.

title: Oriana Atkinson, an Author, 94
description: Oriana Atkinson, a writer and the widow of Brooks Atkinson, a former drama critic of The New York Times, died of pneumonia on Monday at the Huntsville (Ala.) Hospital. She was 94 years old and had lived in Huntsville for 10 years.

description: Fungi for Aficionados

title: In Italy, a New Leader Faces Old Problems
description: For the sixth time in his durable political career, Giulio Andreotti took charge as Italy's Prime Minister last week, and he wasted no time in calling for budget austerity, a crackdown on tax evaders and stepped-up preparations for Western Europe's economic integration at the end of 1992.

title: Homestead Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After a charge of $819,000. The latest second quarter loss included a charge of $14.2 million from the disposal of securities and a provision for a subsidiary's losses. The company said it intends to sell a controlling interest in this subsidiary, Homestead Mortgage Acceptance Corp.

description: The latest periods included a gain of $310,000 on the sale of loans and investments. The year-ago quarter included interest of $885,000 from a federal tax refund which was included in other income. Year-ago 6 months included a gain of $137,000 on the sale of loans and investments.

description: b-Net income

title: Review/Television; Human-Interest Journalism, in NBC Program
description: Although ''Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow'' comes to us under the auspices of NBC News, its heart is less with hard journalism than with softer human-interest features. And although it boasts tomorrow's special effects, its content is akin to yesterday's popular magazines and its techniques resemble today's real-crime shows. The premiere of what may become a regular feature on Channel 4 can be seen tonight at 10, with further episodes threatened for Aug. 2 and Sept. 13.

title: New Jersey Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: George Vaughn, 92, World War I Air Ace And School Founder
description: George A. Vaughn Jr., a World War I air ace who went on to become a founder of the New York Air National Guard and the College of Aeronautics, died of cancer Monday at New York Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: Genzyme Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Plans for Making Profit as Well as Money
description: Small change can mean big bucks for the United States Treasury.

title: Judging a Meal by Its Bread
description: SOME people crave ice cream. Others cheesecake. Still others find solace in fudge. I love bread. There is just something about its chewy, starchy consistency that instantly makes me feel happy, something about its aroma that makes me feel secure, something about actually preparing a loaf of bread at home that makes me feel accomplished.

title: Administration Threatens Fight on Savings Rescue
description: The Administration warned today that it might wage a fight over several provisions of the savings and loan bailout bill if agreement is not worked out with Congress on how to account for the cost of the rescue.

title: Shadowy Terror Group Has Strong Ties to Iran
description: ''We are headed for dealing with evil at the roots,'' the founding manifesto of the Party of God says, ''and the roots are America.''

title: Review/Music; Patinkin: From Singing Actor to Acting Singer
description: With his taut, Irish-sounding tenor and air of intense volatility, Mandy Patinkin is an anomalous musical theater personality in a Broadway tradition of rugged baritones and happy-go-lucky tenors. Instead of a bland, all-American confidence, he radiates a fierce, neurotic intelligence. And in ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' he distilled a new musical-theater archetype: the sensitive man.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Thiokol Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss of $10.3 million from an accounting change. Latest year results included a pretax charge of $18,905,000 related to the company's reorganization. Share earnings have been retroactively restated to reflect the 2-for-5 reverse stock split of Thiokol Corp. common shares.

title: Jumping-Jacks Shoes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Lilly Unit Lawsuits Settled by Abbott
description: Abbott Laboratories said it had settled all litigation involving an Eli Lilly & Company subsidiary that had accused the pharmaceutical company of patent infringement. The settlement ends four separate legal actions pending in United States District Court in Los Angeles. Terms of the settlement with the unit, Hybritech Inc., based in San Diego, were not disclosed.

title: Bettis A. Garside, 94, Relief Agencies' Head
description: Bettis Alston Garside, a relief executive and educator, died yesterday in the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: John W. Guilfoyle, 67, a Retired Executive
description: John W. Guilfoyle, a retired executive of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died of cancer Sunday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 67 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Manchester, Vt.

title: Sweet Season Arrives For Month at Saratoga
description: The endurance and appeal of New York's oldest and favorite race track will be celebrated anew at 1:30 P.M. Wednesday when racing at Saratoga begins for the 122d season.

title: Bridgestone Move
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, which last year completed a $2.6 billion acquisition of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, said it was consolidating its tire business, giving it a new name and a single corporate headquarters. The merged company will be known as Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. and it will be based in Akron, where Firestone was founded in 1900. Firestone's corporate headquarters are in Chicago and Bridgestone's American unit has been based in Nashville. John J. Nevin, Firestone's chairman and chief executive, will serve as the chairman of Bridgestone-Firestone until he retires next year, the company said.

title: Kansas Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grim Vigil, Then Reprieve for Hostage Family
description: The American relatives of Joseph James Cicippio waited two hours after the deadline for his execution had passed today before learning that his Lebanese captors had given him a 48-hour reprieve.

title: Ideal Metal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Gillette Is Guilty In Patent Case
description: The Gillette Company has been found guilty of infringing on the shaving cream gel patent held by S. C. Johnson & Company of Racine, Wis. In a decision on Monday, United States Magistrate Robert B. Colling said Gillette's Foamy Gel infringed on Johnson's patent on Edge Gel. He ordered Gillette to pay Johnson's legal fees and damages, which will be assessed in a second phase of the trial.

title: John C. Franklin, 84, a Retired Executive
description: John C. Franklin, a retired executive with the General Dynamics Corporation and a number of other corporations, died Monday at his home in Winter Park, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Philips's Polygram Buying Island Records
description: Polygram Records, one of the world's three largest record companies, said yesterday that it would acquire Island Records.

title: Medicare Paid for More Than Just a Pedicure; System Is Skewed

description: b-After a gain from an accounting change of $274,000.

description: * American General Finance Inc., Evansville, Ind., a subsidiary of American General Corp. of Houston, named Roy Haley president, chief executive and a director, replacing John Bolger, who will become vice chairman.

title: Communications Transmision reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest year figures included the results of the company's majority owned subsidiary, ALC Communications Corp., on a consolidated basis. The company also said the previous year loss included a one-time analog equipment writedown and a gain from a contract termination settlement which combined contributed a net loss of $5.7 million.

title: K-Tron International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Pricing Plan For I.B.M. System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced a new pricing structure for its System 370 software that could bring price cuts or increases, depending upon how a customer's system is organized. The increases will be most prevalent at the higher end of the processor group structure and decreases at the lower end, the company said.

title: BP Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $1,267,000 and $1,839,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Council Land-Review Role Increased
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission, in a major shift, decided yesterday that the City Council should be able to review nearly all zoning and land-use matters and that the mayor should appoint a majority of the members of the Planning Commission in its proposed new government.

title: Good Guys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Red Sox Win Pair, Trail Orioles by One
description: Baltimore's lead dwindled to one game in the American League East tonight as it lost a day-night doubleheader to Boston, 5-3 and 6-2, giving the Orioles 13 losses in 14 games.

title: Birmingham Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a LIFO inventory reserve charge of $1.1 million. c-Included a pre-tax gain of $1.3 million from the sale of investments.

title: ECO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income c-Included $904,000 in one-time licensing fee income for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Political Memo; States Afraid of Being Outshone by Bush
description: If one thing was clear at the close of the 81st annual meeting of the National Governors' Association today, it was that the Federal budget deficit will place a growing burden on the states and make innovation far more difficult.

title: Ford Raises Prices for 1990 Models
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had tentatively raised its 1990 model prices by an average of 4.8 percent, its largest increase in recent years, mostly because of the added cost of installing safety air bags or motorized seat belts mandated for the first time by Federal law.

title: Review/Television; Game Is Beat the Clock, And the Showman Wins
description: If the two Republican candidates for mayor had accepted the invitation to last night's debate, sponsored by Channel 2 and New York Newsday, that would have put six men on the stage, delivering answers of one minute or 30 seconds to questions about crime, homelessness, education, race, AIDS and the other issues that afflict New York City. So the regrets of Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ronald Lauder ought to earn them a few points in the popularity polls.

title: Acclaimed Instructor Uses Magic to Motivate Other Teachers
description: The four elementary school teachers recently gathered around Jaime Escalante were being shown what he has demonstrated to hundreds of high school students. By sleight of hand, he showed them that if you cut a piece of rope with scissors, tie a special knot and whisper some magic words, the result is a set of one-third portions.

title: Sumter Journal; Last Widow Keeping The Confederacy Alive
description: In a region where commemorating the War Between the States was once akin to a civil religion and where the mythology of the ''lost cause'' still occasionally fuels a wistful peroration or two, Daisy Cave is a living icon.

title: All Yields Fall Further
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to fall for the week ended yesterday.

title: Shots in Night Hint at Beijing Guerrilla War
description: It is at night, when the capital's broad streets are eerily quiet and army troops are manning roadblocks to stop vehicles, there is a hint that some citizens have effectively declared war on the Government.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 13 about the transformation of Kellogg, Idaho, from an old mining town to a trendy resort misidentified the sculptor whose work was being installed. He was David R. Dose.

title: Odds Against Rookie From Navy
description: In the summer of 1984, Travis Wallington had just finished a Navy supply school in Athens, Ga. In the summers of 1985 and 1986, he was a supply officer aboard the USS Gary, a guided-missile fast frigate out of Long Beach, Calif. In the summers of 1987 and 1988, he was helping to coach football at his alma mater, the United States Naval Academy.

title: Cameron Iron Works In Deal With Cooper
description: Cameron Iron Works Inc., a maker of tools used for oil drilling, has signed an agreement to merge with Cooper Industries, the companies said today.

title: American Gets U.N. Post
description: Ronald I. Spiers, a veteran American diplomat, will be the new Undersecretary General for General Assembly Affairs, the top-ranking American at the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced today. Mr. Spiers, 64 years old, was Ambassador to Pakistan from 1981 to 1983 and has also served as Ambassador to the Bahamas and Turkey. He has been Under Secretary of State for Management since 1983. He replaces Joseph Verner Reed, named chief of protocol for the United States.

title: Civil Rights Pioneer Is Columbia's New Dean
description: Columbia University yesterday named Jack Greenberg, a lawyer who successfully argued many of the nation's landmark civil rights cases, as dean of its undergraduate college. The appointment takes effect Sept. 1.

title: Ply Gem Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included special gains totalling $3.6 million and $4.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company attributed revenue and earnings gains in the latest second quarter to a first-time contribution from SNE Enterprises, acquired last March, and to continued demand for the company's home improvement products.

title: Aquino Signs Autonomy Law For Restive Muslim Regions
description: Trying to end years of separatist unrest, President Corazon C. Aquino signed into law today a measure that could lead to some autonomy for 13 southern provinces. Most of the Muslim minority lives in those provinces.

title: After a Fast Start, Courter's Bid Is Faltering
description: Less than two months after Representative Jim Courter won the Republican nomination for governor, his campaign is stumbling from one setback to another.

title: Account
description: * Getty Petroleum Corp. to Pancom International, Stamford, Conn., with an undisclosed budget.

title: Broad-Based Rally Is Pared Back
description: Treasury bond prices rose by more than a point in heavy trading yesterday, but what had been a broad-based rally throughout the credit markets was pared on waves of profit taking.

title: Crecuts, Carhops and the Cold War
description: I ate lunch the other day at one of those ersatz 1950's diners where nostalgia rather than taste dictates menu selections.

title: Real Estate; Manhattan's Lag in Office Construction
description: IT might be a hard point to make to anyone who lately has had to maneuver around construction sheds and huge cranes outside the office towers under construction on the West Side of Manhattan, but commercial development activity on the island is on the wane.

title: Lauder Vows Tax and Worker Trims
description: In the first detailed economic statement of his campaign, Ronald Lauder yesterday distanced himself from other New York City mayoral candidates by calling for cuts in taxes and in the size of the municipal work force.

title: Information Science reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,522,100.

title: Patent Is Awarded To Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. said the United States Patent Office had awarded it a patent for the recombinant DNA technology used to prepare tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., its blood-clot-dissolving drug. Upon receiving the patent, Genentech immediately filed a lawsuit for patent infringement against the Burroughs Wellcome Company and other defendants in an ongoing litigation involving two previous patents.

title: 3-Part Fannie Mae Offering Is Priced at $1.7 Billion
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday priced a total of $1.7 billion in debentures at par through various securities dealers. The agency, known as Fannie Mae, issues debentures each month.

title: Bear Stearns Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect the 5 percent stock dividends declared on May 4, 1989 and Aug. 1, 1989.

title: Healthdyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $115,000 for the quarter and $240,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $5,000 and $15,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Hurricane Hits Texas Coast But Does No Major Damage

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Agassi and Noah Advance: Andre Agassi, the defending champion, easily defeated Glenn Michibata of Canada, and Yannick Noah survived a match point before downing Jeremy Bates of Britain yesterday in the first round of the Volvo International tournament at Stratton Mountain, Vt. Agassi beat Michibata, 6-2, 6-2, and Noah came back to beat Bates, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2. After his match, Noah, who has been troubled by injuries since 1986, said he may retire after the United States Open. (AP) Bunge Upsets McNeil: Bettina Bunge returned to singles play yesterday for the first time since 1987 and toppled fifth-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-2, 6-0, in the $200,000 Great American Bank Classic in San Diego. (AP) YACHTING 4th Cup Race to French Boat: Britain clung to its overall lead in the Admiral's Cup international championship yesterday as Corum won for France in the fourth race of the six-race series off Cowes, England. (AP) GOLF Sugg, 19, Advances: LaRee Sugg, 19 years old, is a rising junior at U.C.L.A. and the only black who played in the national collegiate championships. She was among the 147 contestants who were vying for 64 match-play spots in the United States Women's Amateur championship at Pinehurst, N.C., yesterday. Suggs finished with a two-day total of 154. Pat Hurst finished with a two-day total of 2-under-par 143 to take medalist honors. Hurst, Donna Andrews, Jean Zedlitz and Michiko Hattori, were the only four players to finish under par. Andrews, of Lynchburg, Va., and Zedlitz, of Pleasanton, Calif., shot 144. Hattori, of Japan, had a 145.(AP) SWIMMING Evans Stars: Janet Evans swam the fastest 400-meter individual medley this year in winning the event last night at the United States Swimming Long-Course National Championships. Evans, who won the three golds in the Seoul Olympics, was timed in 4 minutes 39.36 seconds, finishing nearly 8 seconds ahead of Michelle Griglione of Alexandria, Va. Richard Schroeder of Lindsay, Calif. won the men's 100 breast-stroke in 1:02.46, his third consecutive 100 in the championship. Julie Kole of Baltimore won the 200 freestyle in 2:00.95. Mary Ellen Blanchard of Norcross, Ga., upset Tracey McFarlane of Palm Springs, Calif., in the 200 breast-stroke. The 16-year-old turned in a lifetime best of 2:31.59.(AP)

title: Yonkers Budget Is Certified
description: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan certified a budget for Yonkers today, ending concern that the state's fourth-largest city would end up in default. The $372.3 million budget was adopted Monday by Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan. The city had reached a stalemate over $24 million for two new schools, which had been ordered by Judge Sand to remedy what he found to be 40 years of discrimination. The budget that the judge adopted was almost identical to one approved last week by the Yonkers City Council.

title: Economic Watch; Sleep? Why? There's No Money in It
description: Most people think they sleep because they are tired. Now come two economists from Michigan State University who say people sleep because they have nothing better - or remunerative - to do. The findings, in a study for the National Bureau of Economic Research by Jeff Biddle and Daniel Hamermesh, offer a striking example of economists' relentless search for economic motivations in everything from having babies to mugging tourists to going to church - and how, in the process, they sometimes generate real insight. description: b-Included a $350 million restructuring charge for both the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago quarter and 6-month are restated to reflect results from Eastman Kodak Credit Corp. The company said that in addition to the restructuring costs, earnings were further depressed as the benefits of increased volumes were offset by higher costs, including greater interest expense, and the unfavorable impact of exchange rate changes.

title: Rivals Clash With Koch In TV Debate
description: In the first televised debate among the four Democratic candidates for mayor of New York City, the incumbent, Edward I. Koch, defended his record in office against an onslaught last night by three opponents who recited a familiar litany of his shortcomings and the city's problems.

title: Man Sentenced in '85 Killing
description: A man who left his son's body along a Nebraska road four years ago has been sentenced to 40 years in prison for the 1985 murder of his roommate. Eli Stutzman, 38 years old, was convicted of killing Glen Albert Pritchett, 24, who lived with him and his 9-year-old son, Danny. After Mr. Pritchett's body was found, Mr. Stutzman left Austin. His son's body, called ''Little Boy Blue'' because of blue pajamas, was later found in a Nebraska ditch and not identified for two years. Mr. Stutzman was arrested in 1987.

title: Cable Channel To Alter Signal
description: The Discovery Channel will become the latest cable television programmer to scramble its satellite-delivered signal in an attempt to thwart video pirates, a company official says.

title: J.T. Moran Fincl reports earnings for Year to March 31
Madison Ave. Begins Its Own Assault on 'The Queen'
description: Day after day, Leona Helmsley sits in a courtroom in lower Manhattan, a woman even her own lawyer in her tax-fraud trial describes as abrasive, explosive and suspicious.

title: Time Warner Payout
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would begin paying cash for the 100 million shares it accepted from Warner shareholders under the Time offer that expired on July 24. Time, which is paying $70 a share for Warner, said that about 175 million shares out of 198 million were tendered. Time itself owns an additional 17 million shares of Warner. Time said it had accepted 57.1 percent of the total shares tendered. With the purchase of the 100 million shares, Time Warner will own 59.3 percent of Warner's common stock.

title: Howe Richardson reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Don Heffner, Former Baseball Player, 78
description: Don Heffner, a major league second baseman for 11 years and the manager of the Cincinnati Reds for half of the 1966 season, died today at Huntington Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Pushing the Limits Of Rechargeables
description: Batteries are the weak link in the consumer electronics revolution, with dead ones stalling the operation of everything from cordless telephones to laptop computers. That has created demand for rechargeable batteries, but the most common rechargeables, which contain nickel and cadmium, are expensive and run out of power faster than disposables.

title: Action Auto Rental Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cuomo on Rose
description: Regardless of whether he bet on baseball games or not, Pete Rose should be enshrined in the Baseball Hall of Fame, according to Gov. Mario Cuomo, who discussed the thorny problem with reporters during a flight back to Albany from Chicago Monday night. If it is determined that Rose bet on games involving his own team, he would be banned from baseball, but could still be elected to the Hall of Fame.

title: Air Express International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Commodity Indictments Expected
description: The Justice Department is expected to announce on Wednesday the indictments of as many as 50 commodity traders and brokers on charges that they cheated investors.

title: Cilcorp Inc reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Japanese Are Buying Into Ailing U.S. Campuses
description: Eager to give their students direct exposure to an American point of view, the Japanese are spending millions of dollars to buy campuses, start new programs with American colleges and give themselves a foothold in higher education here.

title: N.B.A. Raises Salary Cap
description: The salary cap that will apply to National Basketball Association teams for the 1989-90 season will be $9.802 million, an increase of approximately $2.6 million over last season's $7.232 million.

title: Soviet Emigre Shares Skills
description: MIKHAIL BRUNSHTEYN, formerly of the Soviet Union and now of Cedarburg, Wis., was surprised to find himself lecturing famous wine experts on the fine points of Soviet sparkling wine.

title: Review/Film; Problems (In Toto) Of Being Parents
description: Ron Howard's bittersweet adult comedy, ''Parenthood,'' lays out an entire catalogue of psychological stresses afflicting family life in white middle-class America, then asks if the rewards of being a parent are worth all the agony. Yes, yes, yes! this sophisticated sitcom of a movie proclaims in a gushing final sequence in which the screen rains a new generation of healthy newborn babies.

title: From Heroes To Ancient History
description: rrPompeii is history, embedded in lava. Joan of Arc is history, a woman with a sword. Lyndon Johnson is history to a new generation. And in baseball, Mookie Wilson and Frank Viola are history in their former towns.

title: Reliance Group Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest-quarter results included an after-tax charge of $8,600,000, or 12 cents a share, on the settlement of lawsuits and a pretax loss of $1,700,000 on portfolio investments. Year-ago quarter results included $9,900,000 pretax gain on portfolio investments.

title: IBM Credit Offers Notes at 7 3/4%
description: The IBM Credit Corporation, a unit of the International Business Machines Corporation, is offering $400 million worth of 7.75 percent notes due 1992 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the nomination of Czeslaw Kiszczak as Polish Prime Minister misidentified a candidate opposed by six Peasant Party legislators. It was Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the presidential nominee, not Mr. Kiszczak.

title: Comshare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $337,700 from discontinued operations.

title: SENATE GIVES BUSH A MISSILES VICTORY
description: The Senate gave President Bush a long-sought victory today in the dispute over the military budget by supporting a compromise under which the Pentagon would deploy two kinds of mobile land-based nuclear missiles.

title: Driver-Harris Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $36,000 for the quarter and $94,000 for the 6 months. c-Included tax credits of $156,000 and $199,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: All the Right Moves For Jet's Stallworth
description: Ron Stallworth, the Jets' rookie defensive end, was drafted from Auburn this spring on the fourth round. In camp, he was assigned to the right side, behind Marty Lyons. Last Saturday, the 6-foot-5, 262-pound Stallworth had the most sacks, three, in a scrimmage against the Washington Redskins.

description: To the Editor:

title: Revamped Mets Win To Stop the Streak at 7
description: On the day of the great recasting, Frank Viola, Jeff Musselman and Keith Miller came and Mookie Wilson went. Bob Ojeda announced ''the season starts today.'' Darryl Strawberry took extra batting practice and said it felt like ''opening day.'' Dwight Gooden tossed a baseball from a mound for the first time in a month. And Davey Johnson gave his lineup ''a little shakeup'' to see if he could energize the swooning Mets.

Was Austere Envoy a Spy? In Austria, It's 'Unthinkable'
description: Austrians and Americans who knew Felix S. Bloch during his seven years at the American Embassy here remember him for his self-control and inner discipline.

title: Ferry Will Play for Rome Team Instead of Signing With Clippers
description: Danny Ferry, the star Duke forward who was the second player picked in the National Basketball Association's June draft, has reportedly passed up a chance to play for the Los Angeles Clippers next season in favor of a $1 million contract to play for the Messaggero Rome team in the Italian professional league.

title: Molson Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Steel Downturn Seen
description: A projected slowing in business activity will result in a decline of 3 percent in shipments from steel service centers this year, the Steel Service Center Institute said Monday. The institute is a trade association of the steel service center industry. The centers purchase and distribute one of every three tons of carbon industrial steel products and nearly half of all stainless steel produced in the United States.

title: An F.B.I. Bloch Party
description: Here are the undisputed facts in the case of Felix Bloch, the American diplomat. The F.B.I. suspects him of passing secrets to the Soviet Union. On June 22 he was placed on leave and stripped of his State Department building pass. On July 21 ABC News disclosed that he was under investigation. On July 27 he appeared at his daughter's house on Hamilton Road in Chappaqua, N.Y. His arrival turned a placid suburban block into a carnival of reporters, cameramen and F.B.I. agents grimly keeping Mr. Bloch in their sights.

title: Citadel Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: This year's second quarter and first half net included a net insurance recovery of $1.4 million. Year-ago second quarter and first half net included net gains of $1.5 million on sales of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock.

title: Businessland Sets Training Division
description: Businessland Inc., the nation's largest non-franchised personal computer chain, said it was forming a training division to provide a comprehensive standardized computer education program across the country. Businessland, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would increase its management, support staff and classrooms and would develop a national reservation system to accommodate the projected demand for training.

title: Cintas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's time for the television industry to forge a partnership with America's families to scale back the atmosphere of violence.'' - Senator Paul Simon. [ D18:3. ]

title: Cosmetics Companies Quietly Ending Animal Tests
description: Several leading cosmetics companies have quietly stopped testing products on animals. The moves are in response to years of pressure by animal-rights groups and reflect growing confidence in the reliability of alternative testing methods.

title: Top Helmsley Aide 'Knew Too Much'
description: Shortly before Leona M. Helmsley dismissed her top aide, Frank J. Turco, in 1986, Helmsley executives who knew their companies had paid millions of dollars of the couple's private expenses discussed their fear that Mr. Turco ''knew too much,'' a Helmsley executive testified yesterday.

title: The Lessons of Mr. Lucas
description: Without question, the Senate Judiciary Committee's rejection of William Lucas as assistant attorney general for civil rights was a bitter defeat for the Bush Administration. But it is also an opportunity to redo the job of filling this most important post and do it right.

description: Though it may once have owed its existence to America's fondness for bootleg liquor and illicit sex, Tijuana is now a booming and confident metropolis that is increasingly the envy of Mexico.

title: A.T.&T. Barring Chemicals Depleting the Earth's Ozone
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that by 1994 it would end all use of chemicals that deplete the earth's ozone layer.

description: The diplomatic crisis between India and Sri Lanka, largely defused for now, has been a sideshow to the continuing deterioration of stability in Sri Lanka.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: VEAL chops, one of the most expensive cuts of meat, can be wonderfully tender and subtle when cooked properly, but the margin for error is narrow. For my taste, veal chops must be cooked to medium. A rare veal chop is unappetizingly pink and lacking in flavor, while one well done, of course, is dry.

description: Rose Schulman, an acting teacher at the nation's oldest repertory company, the Hedgerow Theater of Rose Valley, Pa., died after a heart attack on Sunday at the Crozer Chester (Pa.) Medical Center. She was 79 years old.

Nissan Sedan Priced at $38,000
description: The Nissan Motor Company says it is pricing its Infiniti Q45 luxury sedan at $38,000, putting it in the same price range as Toyota's Lexus and just below the most expensive European-made luxury sedans. The Q45 is a four-door sedan, equipped with a 4.5-liter, 32-valve, 278-horsepower V8 engine. Its two-door coupe, with a 3-liter, 162-horsepower V6, will be priced at $23,500.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omni Magazine Trying To Achieve New Image
description: For a scientific publication, Omni magazine's newest advertisements are rather earthy, not to mention earthbound. Instead of ethereal images of planets and stars - or even semiconductor chips - the television ads feature an actor imitating the sounds of a spaceship, robot and other futuristic items.

title: Article 696589 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan yesterday decided that five principals of a New Jersey investment partnership and a former trader for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. would have to forfeit more than $3.8 million for engaging in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock deals.

title: Genevieve R. Hanfield, Broker, 57
description: Genevieve R. Hanfield, a real-estate broker who specialized in sales of houses and cooperative apartments in Greenwich Village, died of bone cancer Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Soviet Agent Linked to Bloch Is Reported to Be an Employee of the U.N. in Paris
description: The investigation that led to suspicions of espionage by Felix S. Bloch, a State Department official, began this year when American intelligence agents, acting on a tip, started to follow a man in Austria who was posing as a Finnish businessman, Government officials say.

title: Bush and Senate Leaders Support Sweeping Protection for Disabled
description: President Bush and leading members of the Senate agreed today to support legislation that would extend Federal civil rights protection to 37 million handicapped Americans and people ill with AIDS or infected with its virus.

title: Soviet Team Expels 2
description: Dmitri Bilozerchev, a triple gold medalist in the Olympics, and a teammate, Vladimir Gogoladze, were removed from the Soviet Union's team for the world gymnastics championships because of a two-day drinking binge, a report in Sovetsky Sport announced. Bilozerchev broke a leg badly in a car accident while driving while intoxicated in 1985, but made a spectacular comeback in the Olympics at Seoul, South Korea, getting six perfect marks and winning gold medals in the pommel horse and rings.(AP)

title: Labor Unions, Not Custom, Curbed Corporate Greed
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Allows Bid For Plessey
description: Britain today cleared the way for an English-German consortium to resume a hostile takeover offer for the Plessey Company, a large military contractor.

Eisner, told The Orlando Sentinel in an article today. Mr. Eisner said specific plans for the three-year expansion would be announced in six weeks.

title: 2 Parts Whimsy, 1 Part Cholesterol: Edible Architecture
description: THOSE who doubt the richness of contemporary architecture and design need only look as far as a new project sponsored by the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS, in which high-calorie designs by Gaetano Pesce, Michael Graves, Wendell Castle and others will blend with cookie sheets and eggbeaters.

title: House Defeats a Move to Bar District Money for Abortions
description: Supporters of abortion rights won a major victory in the House of Representatives today, beating back an effort to continue barring the District of Columbia from paying for abortions.

title: Morgan Guaranty
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York is offering $150 million in notes through Prudential-Bache Capital Funding. The 7 7/8 percent notes are due in 1991 and are priced at 99.95, to yield 7.902 percent, or about 42 basis points higher than the Treasury two-year note. The issue, which is noncallable, is rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.&P.

description: Varian Associates Inc. said it would undertake a substantial realignment of its operations and management structure to reflect changes in strategy. The company's new strategy would focus on growth opportunities in semiconductor equipment, analytical instrumentation and medical products.

title: Polish Party Leads General to Victory
description: In a deft display of machine politics, Poland's Communist leadership snuffed out a parliamentary uprising today and pushed through the party's nominee for Prime Minister.

'Killing Fields' to Be Shown In Cambodia for First Time
description: ''The Killing Fields,'' the movie that showed the brutality of the Khmer Rouge in the 1970's in Cambodia, is to have its first showing in a Cambodian theater on Friday, the director of the film said today.

title: Stern Plans Furniture Production
description: ROBERT A. M. Stern, who has been making custom furniture for years, has just joined the growing ranks of architects designing pieces for mass production.

title: Reviews/Music; Some Fancy Flute Work
description: On too many of his albums, the flutist Hubert Laws smothers his solos in goopy pop-jazz arrangements. But in a rare New York engagement through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Mr. Laws is allowing himself to play some of the daredevil, harmonically intricate material that established him as the leading jazz flutist of his generation.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I HAVE made my home among small houses and ragged streets and the distinctive low-tide scent of the Hudson for more years now than I care to count. But I have never truly lived there. I have breakfasted there, I have slept there, I have joined the tourists on their weekend strolls through what was once New York's Bohemian shore. But live there? Sadly, no.

description: The Central Intelligence Agency has told the White House that Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins was probably killed before Monday, the day a pro-Iranian terrorist group said it hanged the Marine officer, Administration officials said today.

title: Commerce
description: Compared with subsidies, tariffs are a piece of cake. Everyone in international trade agrees that tariffs exist to protect industries, and because the protection is all aboveboard, postwar trade negotiators have rather easily succeeded in cutting tariff rates to a fraction of their levels in the 1930's.

title: John Tiedemann, 55, ABC Vice President
description: John H. Tiedemann, senior vice president and general sales manager at ABC-TV, died of a heart attack Tuesday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I., after major surgery. He was 55 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: Tyson Sued in '88 Brawl
description: Mitch Green filed a lawsuit against Mike Tyson yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, charging that the heavyweight champion seriously injured him in a Harlem street brawl a year ago and that Tyson reneged on a promised rematch in the ring. Green appeared at a police station after the fight with his left eye swollen shut.(AP)

About three months ago, he joined the board of W. R. Grace & Company, a specialty chemical maker with far-flung interests ranging from energy and health care to book and video distribution. He also recently joined the board of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation, an engineering and construction company.

The all-animation campaign created by Soghigian & Macuga of Washington is being coordinated by public radio stations across the country. It will include spot television as well as movie trailers, with newspaper, magazine and direct-mail support. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting provided seed money for the project.

title: A Log Cabin Need Not Be Humble

Convinced that the cabin, made from a kit of precut parts, would reduce their property values, they petitioned the building inspector to ''do something,'' but the house went up anyway. Now, like a lone mobile home, it is the subject of vitriolic cocktail-party talk.

title: Karl Malden Is Elected
description: The actor Karl Malden was elected today to be the 27th president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the entertainment-industry organization responsible for the Oscar ceremonies. Mr. Malden, who won an Academy Award in 1951 for his role in ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' replaces Richard Kahn, a public-relations executive, whose one-year term expired.

title: Jacobs Offers to Buy Avon for $2.2 Billion
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he had sent a letter to Avon Products Inc. offering to buy the cosmetics company for $41 a share in cash, or about $2.2 billion.

title: Eastern Asset Sale
description: Eastern Airlines said it had signed a final agreement to sell a package of assets including aircraft, flight slots, two Canadian routes and spare parts and engines to Midway Airlines Inc. for about $210 million. The company, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, had announced the transaction in June. Eastern said it expects to file for Bankruptcy Court approval within 10 days and, if the court approves, complete the transaction in the fall. It said Midway, based in Chicago, had arranged financing.

title: Zenith National Insurance Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: No Way to Make Tax Policy
description: The House Democratic leadership is in a desperate scramble to raise revenue without violating the fairness of the 1986 tax reforms. That may still be possible, but President Bush has made it mighty hard. The result, meanwhile, is an unseemly test of political strength where winning has become more important than good law.

title: Hyman Hirsch, Institute Founder, 84, Dies
description: Hyman Hirsch, a New York City teacher who founded the Institute for Retired Professionals at the New School, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Opera; New 'Traviata' in Santa Fe
description: The Santa Fe Opera enjoys an unfair advantage over most other music festivals. The open-air performances, set against the backdrop of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, often radiate a youthful freshness that can induce a benign out-of-body state of mind in the visitor from the flatlands. It was sometimes difficult to keep in mind on Monday evening, for instance, that the company's handsome new staging of ''La Traviata,'' one of this season's five new productions, failed in important ways to measure up to internationally accepted vocal standards, such as they are. It was easy to overlook such details in a performance that, whatever its flaws, forcibly reminded one of Verdi's deep humanity as well as of his musical genius.

He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rookie Tight End Fits Giant Mold as Blocker
description: Though Mark Bavaro has caught 211 regular-season passes in his four years as a pro tight end, the Giants drafted him because he blocked so well. Two years before Bavaro arrived, the Giants signed Zeke Mowatt as a rookie free-agent tight end because he was a devastating blocker.

description: High-definition television, called by some the next wave in electronics, might not be a big enough breakthrough to restore competitiveness to the American industry, the Congressional Budget Office said in a report released Tuesday.

6th Suspect in Park Attack
description: A sixth suspect was arrested last night in connection with an assault July 23 on two men who had been sitting in Carl Schurz Park, near Gracie Mansion, the police said. The police have labelled the assault bias-related because the dozen attackers shouted anti-homosexual slurs at the victims. The suspect arrested last night was Anthony Flores, 16, of 250 East 105th Street.

title: Review/Theater; A Garcia Marquez Tale Opens Festival Latino
description: In the fiction of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the weight of history hangs like a stone in the sweltering atmosphere, and the spirits of the dead haunt the living in feverish dreams. Time stands still in the sense that the dead continue to stir as long as the tiniest memory of them persists. For the living, dreams of the distant past are often more vivid than the grinding physical realities of the present. Nothing essentially changes. In an atmosphere simmering with political unrest, the revolutions that sweep the land leave conditions only worse than before.

title: '88 Farm Costs Up 7.5%
description: The cost of running the nation's farms rose 7.5 percent, to $118.4 billion, in 1988, the Agriculture Department reported today. Despite the increase, the figure falls short of the record $131.8 billion that farmers spent in 1981, before the general financial crunch that stalled expansion in the agricultural sector. In 1987, farmers spent $110.1 billion for buildings, feed, livestock, rent, labor, seeds and plants, fuels, equipment and other components of raising livestock and crops. The increase outstripped the nation's overall inflation rate, which was 4.4 percent last year.

title: A Message to Motorists: Car Phones Can Call 911

Israel's painful but gutsy decision to capture the Hezbollah's field commander and his aides, after the failure of all other means of handling hostage-taking over a decade, is being criticized as provocative.

description: Latest second-quarter per share net is less than 1 cent due to preferred stock dividends. Year-ago quarter results included a tax credit of $3,000,000. Results for 1988 have ben restated. The company said the decline in net income was primarily due to an increase in realized capital losses on investments, heavy second quarter catastrophe losses and a decline in income from foreign exchange translation adjustments. Net investment income in the latest second quarter was up 20.8 percent to $224.4 million. For the six months, net investment income rose 17.7 percent to $439.3 million. Realized losses on investments amounted to $48.7 million for the latest second quarter compared with $17.3 million in the year-ago period. Realized losses on investments totaled $88 million in the first six months of 1989 compared with $67.6 million in the year-ago six months. Earnings per common share amounts were based on income after deduction of preferred stock dividends.

title: Review/Pop; Nigeria's Fela Makes Political Opinion Sing
description: Rough-hewn music, swivel-hipped dancing and implacable oratory swirled together in the concert by Fela Anikulapo Kuti and Egypt '80 on Friday night at the Apollo Theater. Fela, as he calls himself, has been Nigeria's most outspoken dissident musician since he began leading a band, then called Afrika '70, nearly two decades ago. He has spent time in jail and some of his supporters, including his mother, were killed by Nigerian police officers and soldiers. But his songs have stayed angry and pointed as he continues to denounce corruption and injustice, and his music is as propulsive as it is stubborn.

title: Lomas to End Its Dividends
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation, a struggling diversified financial services company, said that it would suspend dividends on its common and common equivalent preferred stock until the company's financial reorganization is completed, the commercial leasing division is sold and the company has been profitable for a while.

title: Review/Dance; Musician in a Maple for a Troupe on a Hill
description: Wave Hill's imaginative summer Dancescape series got off to a promising start on Saturday night with a performance by Kei Takei's Moving Earth company. Each choreographer in the series has chosen an environment in this sprawling 28-acre estate in Riverdale. Ms. Takei selected a hill fringed by a thick forest for her ''Wild Grass River.'' Unbeknown to her, the area was a river some 8,000 years ago. And that sense of magic pervaded this new piece.

title: Miners Strike in Yugoslavia
description: Hundreds of ethnic Albanian miners staged a strike today for a second day in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo to protest a delay in receiving June's wages, but others returned to work after being promised wage payments.

title: Q&A
description: Cleaning Concrete Q.We have a new home and would like to keep the concrete driveway clean, but so far we are having a problem with rust and oil stains from automobiles that are parked there even for a short while. Can you offer a solution? A.Removing the stains is always difficult unless they are tackled immediately. Some of the commercial preparations sold for this purpose do a pretty good job of removing - or at least lightening - grease and oil stains. But for rust stains try a commercial rust remover, sold in hardware stores.

title: More H.U.D. Fees Disclosed
description: Government investigators told Congress today that they have uncovered an additional $1.2 million in payments to well-connected Department of Housing and Urban Development consultants.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN made of carefully selected seasoned wood and installed properly, clapboard siding can be maintained in excellent condition for as long as a house stands. Still, cracks, warping and decay can occur. When they do, prompt action is needed. If the edges of a crack meet precisely, it usually can be repaired with waterproof wood glue, available at home centers. First, gently pry the loose piece away from the rest of the clapboard, using a putty knife or flat pry bar. Then spread glue along both edges and press the piece back into place. Clamp the seam by driving a row of 6-penny (2-inch-long) finishing nails into the undamaged clapboard underneath, just below the lower edge of the glued piece.

title: Did We Have to Drop the Bomb?
description: LEAD: Americans have been taught that the atomic bomb saved hundreds of thousands of lives by making it unnecessary to invade Japan at the end of World War II. However, a secret U.S. intelligence study discovered last spring in the National Archives directly contradicts this traditional notion.

Its two parts, chair and footstool, have leather upholstery contained in molded plywood shells, which have a veneer of rosewood and are supported by polished aluminum pedestals. The leather arms, cushions and backrests snap off for easy attention and interchange, essential for even wear.

title: Reviews/Music; Love Songs by Mica Paris
description: Mica Paris, a 20-year-old British singer who performed Monday night at the Bottom Line, has nearly all the skill she needs to reach the audience for romantic pop-soul crooners like Anita Baker and Al Jarreau. Her voice rises from a lustrous alto to a warm mezzo-soprano by way of the billowy swoops and curves that have made Ms. Baker's records sell by the millions. And her songs burble the kind of unabashed lovers' tidings, from distrust to temptation to longing to satisfaction, that ease seductions as they purr from a home stereo.

title: Reviews/Music; Magmouat Hakmoun, From Morocco
description: Hassan Hakmoun, who brought his Gnawan Moroccan band, Magmouat Hakmoun, to the Village Gate on Tuesday night, is one of those musicians who can prod and inspire his musicians into a frenzy. A virtuoso of rhythm, he slammed out riffs on his sintir (a cello-like lute), changing the accent on the notes, making new riffs from the last note of an old one, leaving notes out to vary the rhythms, picking up and slowing down tempos. And his group - three percussionists who danced and sang - would respond; Gnawan music, a mixture of African and Arabic elements used in healing ceremonies that often take all night, is nothing if not a group music.

title: Pilots Angered by Airing of Tape of Banter Before Fatal Crash
description: Responding to the public airing of casual conversations among crew members in a passenger jet just before a fatal crash in Texas last year, the airline pilots' union today called for legislation restricting the release of such recordings. But it backed away from a threat to protest the public airing by turning off cockpit voice recorders.

Radja, 6-foot-10-inch center, had his first workout with his new team on Tuesday at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass.

title: PHOTO GIVES HOPE TO FAMILIES OF 2

title: Beverly to Sell 45 Nursing Homes
description: Beverly Enterprises Inc. reached agreement to sell the 45 nursing homes it operates in Michigan to a combination of buyers for about $62.4 million. The sales are part of the Pasadena, Calif., health-care company's plan to sell 370 nursing homes to reduce its debt, which totals $900 million. Tendercare Nursing Homes of Ontario and Evansville, Ind., is buying 42 of the 45 homes.

title: Nigeria's Fela Makes Political Opinion Sing
description: Rough-hewn music, swivel-hipped dancing and implacable oratory swirled together in the concert by Fela Anikulapo Kuti and Egypt '80 on Friday night at the Apollo Theater. Fela, as he calls himself, has been Nigeria's most outspoken dissident musician since he began leading a band, then called Afrika '70, nearly two decades ago. He has spent time in jail and some of his supporters, including his mother, were killed by Nigerian police officers and soldiers. But his songs have stayed angry and pointed as he continues to denounce corruption and injustice, and his music is as propulsive as it is stubborn.

The company said that under the Fed's present guidelines, it could have up to 5 percent of its First Union Securities' revenues generated by the new activitites, with the remaining 95 percent generated by bank-eligible activities like bond sales and trading now managed by the securities dealer division of First Union's Funds Management Group.

title: Lauder Tries to Fill Style Gaps With Debate on Competence
description: The main campaign event one day recently was in a Suffolk County park to which thousands of elderly people from Queens and Brooklyn had been bused. Edward I. Koch, New York Mayor and mayoral candidate, dropped in by helicopter, conducted a blitzkrieg tour of the picnic area, spoke briefly over a fuzzy public-address system and helicoptered out. Two contenders for Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes and Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, stopped by, as well.

title: Review/Film; Stallone Behind Bars In 'Lock Up'
description: Frank Leone, a prisoner who is put through the wringer in Sylvester Stallone's new movie, ''Lock Up,'' is a warmer character than the churning one-man war machine of the same actor's ''Rambo'' series. A lug with a trusting hangdog loyalty to his girlfriend and buddies, he is closer in spirit to the original Rocky Balboa.

title: Review/Pop; Johnny Ray, Still 'Cry'-ing
description: When Johnnie Ray became a singing sensation 38 years ago with the hit single ''Cry,'' his husky voice, broken phrasing and eccentric way of bearing down heavily on syllables earned him the nickname ''Mr. Emotion.'' At a time when mainstream pop was at its blandest, he injected it with a badly needed hint of rhythm-and-blues rawness. Even then, however, his singing was very limited. If he sounded bravely iconoclastic in small doses, his harsh, grating voice didn't wear well on the ears.

title: Paterno Cites Problems
description: In a book to be published next month, Coach Joe Paterno says he had problems with underclassmen on last season's 5-6 team, the first losing one at Penn State in 50 years.

title: ABC News Delays Airing Plea by Hostage
description: ABC News, alone among the national television news organizations, refused yesterday to broadcast the videotaped plea for help by Joseph James Cicippio, an American hostage in Lebanon, in its special news bulletins.

title: International Minerals & Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $1.3 million for the quarter and income of $6.7 million for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $3 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year, and a loss of $3.3 million reflecting an adjustment of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $14.6 million for the year. The latest fourth quarter included a gain of $20.6 million, or 90 cents a share, primarily from the conclusion of income-tax audits. Year-ago quarter included total charges of $12.1 million mostly from the sale of certain operations and restructuring.

title: California Attorney General Calls For a Statewide Vote on Pollution
description: The State Attorney General today proposed a sweeping ballot measure to reduce pollution of the air Californians breathe, the water they drink and the food they grow and eat.

title: Conseco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said all share earnings are fully diluted. The company also said its latest quarter's results were not affected by the acquisition of National Fidelity Life Insurance Co., which was completed June 30, 1989.

title: Mountain Medical Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Latest Bid Is Rejected By Plessey
description: A day after receiving official clearance to resume their joint bid for the Plessey Company, the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain and Siemens A.G. of West Germany today made a new offer of $3.3 billion for the British military and telecommunications giant.

title: Echoes of struggle for rule of law in China reverberate on Columbia campus.
description: On a balmy summer day, the Columbia University campus seems as remote from Tiananmen Square psychically as it is geographically. But in the office of Professor R. Randle Edwards of Columbia Law School, the recent tremors in China have registered clearly and profoundly.

title: Loews Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $18,067,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Applied Biosystems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FPI Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains of $400,000 for the quarter and $1 million for the 6 months. c-Net income and after gains of $1.8 million for the quarter and $6.9 million for the 6 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Michael O'R. Nash, Photo Editor, 69
description: Michael O'R. Nash, who was photo and communications chief in Paris during a long career in The Associated Press foreign service, died in Paris today after a long battle with cancer, his family said. He was 69.

title: Hecla Mining reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: American Heritage Life InFvestment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $707,189 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Cigna Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $9,200,000 and $21,900,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $13,800,000 for the quarter and $24,800,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago period results have been restated to reflect implementation of SFAS No. 97.

title: Vons Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included a $2 million tax credit. Results for 1989 included the Southern California Safeway operations acquired in August 1988. In addition to increased interest expense, the company said its second quarter results primarily reflected costs associated with the integration of acquired operations including identifiable one-time charges of $3.4 million and operating inefficiencies and other costs not readily identifiable.

title: Walter W. Belson, 87, A Trucking Publicist
description: Walter W. Belson, retired assistant to the president and director of public relations for the American Trucking Associations in Washington, died of a stroke Tuesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 87 years old.

title: Reece Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Champion Parts reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Cuisinarts Bankruptcy
description: Cuisinarts Inc., famous for its food processors, which surged in popularity in the 1970's, filed for protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws on Wednesday.

title:
The Editorial Notebook;
Let Viewers Judge 'Days of Rage'
description: LEAD: Should public television broadcast ''Days of Rage: The Young Palestinians''? It should indeed. Most viewers will readily sense the pro-Palestinian sympathies of its producer, Jo Franklin-Trout. Yet even in the current turmoil over terrorism, Americans need to listen to the documentary's aggrieved voices.

title: Green Forest Lumber reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds. The company said the latest quarter loss was due to the closing of its sawmill operations at Chapleau, Ont., for the completion of new facilities.

title: Playboy Sets Pay-Per-View TV Service
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it would cancel its Playboy Channel cable service on Dec. 1 to concentrate on the growing pay-per-view market.

title: Rose's Lawyers Plan To Appeal Decision
description: Pete Rose's lawyers, as expected, said yesterday that they would appeal the decision by a Federal judge to keep Rose's lawsuit against the baseball commissioner in United States District Court in Columbus, Ohio, instead of moving it back to a state court in Cincinnati.

title: Rights Group Deplores Level of Abuse in Ethiopia
description: On the eve of the first high-level official contact in a decade between Washington and the Government here, Amnesty International issued a report today on what it called ''the high level of serious human rights abuses'' in Ethiopia.

title: Biomira Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Wendy's International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Included a gain of $5,191,000 from an accounting change and a $594,000 gain from early extinguishment of debt. Latest-quarter results included a $255,000 gain from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Comptek Research Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Franco-Nevada Mining Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Donohue Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-earlier share earnings results have been restated to account for a 2-for-1 stock split July 29, 1988. The company said results were affected by the decrease in the price and demand for newsprint as well as the increase in the value of the Canadian dollar versus the U.S. dollar. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Moore-Handley Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included for the 6 months an $83,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Big Retailers Gained in July; Durables Remain in Slump
description: The nation's largest retailers yesterday mostly reported improved year-to-year sales in July, spurred by continued strength in apparel sales. Big-ticket durables sales, however, remained in a slump, indicating consumers were postponing major purchases.

title: Leading Indicators Dip Again
description: The Government said today that its chief economic forecasting gauge declined in June for the fourth time in five months, renewing concerns that the longest economic expansion in peacetime history may be nearing an end.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Southwest Water Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Green Defends His Coaches And Says He Won't Quit
description: Dallas Green, responding to George Steinbrenner's most recent public criticisms, yesterday offered both a spirited defense of his coaching staff and a pledge that he would never be provoked into quitting his job as manager of the Yankees.

title: Review/Opera; Massenet's Infrequently Performed 'Cherubin'
description: It would be senseless to try to define or analyze charm, but as a Supreme Court Justice said in a different context, you know it when you see it. And you see it in all its magnetic mystery whenever Frederica von Stade steps onto a stage. If there could be such a thing as a collective smile, it broke out in the Santa Fe Opera's audience the moment the irrepressible mezzo-soprano came bounding out in the title role of ''Cherubin.'' For the space of a couple of hours on Tuesday evening, Miss von Stade charmed one into believing that Massenet's amiable sequel to ''The Marriage of Figaro'' was an unfairly neglected minor masterpiece.

title: The Suburbs Go Urban
description: To the Editor:

title: The Candidates and the Kids
description: A central measure of a society is how well it treats its children. By that standard, New York City is in trouble. Nearly 40 percent of the city's 1.7 million children live in families that are poor. The infant mortality rate is rising. There are 7,325 children in homeless families. And the number in foster care is 35,000 and climbing.

title: El Chico Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-After a gain of $667,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: Hanover Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included fresh-start benefits of $2,572,000 for the latest quarter and $4,374,000 for year-ago period. Year-ago figures restated for FAS 97.

title: 'Liaisons' at the Quad
description: Roger Vadim's 1960 film ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' will begin an open-ended run today at the Quad 2 Cinema, 34 West 13th Street. The film is an updated version - by Mr. Vadim, Roger Vailland and Claude Brule - of the 18th-century novel of sexual adventure and deceit by Choderlos de Laclos. Gerard Philipe and Jeanne Moreau co-star; the film is in French with English subtitles. Admission is $7. Information: 255-8800.

title: Julius J. Adams, 88, Ex-Newspaper Editor
description: Julius J. Adams, managing editor of The Amsterdam News from 1938 to 1950 and a former member of New York's Republican State Committee, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2d Black Priest Joins Capital Congregation
description: A black priest was dismissed from his teaching job Wednesday after he announced that he had joined the Rev. George A. Stallings in setting up a separate African-American Catholic congregation.

title: Make the Terrorists Pay
description: LEAD: After the apparent murder of Lieut. Col. William Higgins and the threats to execute hostage Joseph Cicippio, America again has to decide whether to appease, ignore or fight terrorism. The current approach of changing the nation's policy with each headline not only fails to deter terrorism but actively encourages it.

title: Delmed reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $2,250,000 charge for the settlement of the company's patent infringement disputes with Baxter International Inc. for the quarter, and a charge of $350,000 for related attorney fees, which were offset by other income of $355,000 (for the quarter and $350,000 for the 6 months) related to an insurance claim associated with litigation settled by the company in 1988 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $112,000 for the quarter and $81,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month also included an $842,000 loss on provision for disposal of discontinued operations.
