title: Schwitzer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results are pro-forma. The company was spun off from Household International Inc. in May.

title: PEN Branch Reopens In Czechoslovakia
description: Czechoslovakia has allowed the domestic branch of the PEN writers' organization to reopen, and its board includes authors who are both banned and officially sanctioned, PEN participants said.

title: Gibson Greetings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ms. Billings Wed To Michael Sacca
description: Elizabeth Preudhomme Billings, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Franklin S. Billings Jr. of Woodstock, Vt., was married there yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church to Michael Francis Sacca, a son of Mrs. Gregory F. Sacca of Gloucester, Mass., and the late Mr. Sacca. Canon Donald E. Boyer, performed the ceremony, assisted by his wife, the Rev. Marcia M. Boyer, also an Episcopal priest. The bride, who will keep her name, is a professional weaver. A graduate of Milton Academy and Earlham College, she received a master's degree in fiber work from the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Her father, a former Chief Justice of the Vermont Supreme Court, is the Chief Judge of the United States District Court for Vermont. Her mother, Pauline Gillingham Billings, is the chairman of F. H. Gillingham & Sons, owners of a general store in Woodstock. Ms. Billngs is a granddaughter of the late Franklin S. Billings, who was Governor of Vermont in the 1920's.

title: Justice Agency Tightening Policy On Telling Press of Investigations
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced today that he would not prosecute journalists who obtain disclosures about criminal investigations but would charge Federal officials who are their sources.

title: Rangers Consider Possible Roles for Patrick and Pleau
description: Neil Smith, the newly installed general manager of the Rangers, has spoken in recent days with both Larry Pleau and Craig Patrick, and sources say, those discussions have involved possible roles in the organization.

title: Chattem Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $405,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Union Valley Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $635,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Panel Action On Futures
description: A House committee, voting hours after prosecutors announced a number of indictments against commodities traders, approved legislation Wednesday evening reauthorizing the Federal agency that regulates commodity futures exchanges.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: French Film Festival

title: Connecticut Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Centocor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results from the year-ago second quarter and 6-month included a gain of $3,371,000 related to the provision of services of Repligen Corp.

title: Concord Journal; Smoke Rising From Historic Battle
description: What do you do when the Federal Government wants to make your neighborhood look exactly the way it did on April 19, 1775?

title: Reviews/Art; In Connecticut, Contemporary Classics at Aldrich
description: The 25th anniversary of the opening of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn., has been pointed up this summer by two exhibitions, both of which in succession have filled the entire museum. The first was a group show of works by artists now active in Connecticut, with Cleve Gray, Tim Prentice and others conspicuous among them. The second, now on view, is of contemporary paintings, sculptures and photographs from the collection of Dr. Marc and Livia Straus.

title: NVR L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday.

title: Newmont Cancels Plans for Peabody
description: Citing the effects of a continuing strike in the coal industry and the uncertain impact of legislation to cut acid rain emissions, the Newmont Mining Corporation canceled plans to recapitalize the Peabody Holding Company, in which it holds a stake.

title: Halliburton Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest 6 months included a gain of $1.3 million from an accounting change. Results for the year-ago 6 months included a $9 million gain from uniform cost capitalization for certain inventories and manufactured equipment, net of taxes.

title: OHM Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Pricor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Cuomo Weighs Plan to Pay Lawyers Suing State
description: In a move expected to be closely watched in other states, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is to decide soon whether to approve a bill that would force the state to pay the legal costs of some people who sue it.

title: Austin Is Hospitalized
description: Tracy Austin, the two-time United States Open women's singles champion who now plays team tennis with the New Jersey Stars, was injured yesterday in an automobile accident in Millburn, N.J. Austin, 26 years old, was taken to the emergency room of Overlook Hospital in Summit for X-rays. Michael Sniffen, the hospital president, said that at the request of Austin's family he was limited to revealing only that she would be kept overnight for observation and that her condition was satisfactory.

title: U.S. Official Promotes Utilities' Bond Cause
description: James Jura, administrator of the Bonneville Power Administration, has been meeting recently with underwriters to persuade them that refinancing $2.8 billion in bonds for the Washington Public Power Supply System's three remaining nuclear plants is a solid and safe investment.

title: Empire District Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Farm & Home Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months' net reduced by preferred dividend requirements.

title: ERC International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Automotive Industries Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., named Orland Wolford, president and chief operating officer, to the additional position of chief executive. He replaces Ronald G. Farrell, who resigned as chairman and chief executive but will continue on the board.

title: Bovar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company formerly called Bow Valley Resource Services Ltd. said the latest results reflect a downturn in the land drilling and oilfield supply industries and losses realized with respect to its equity investment in Western Star Trucks Inc. The company also said the latest period was positively affected by $1.9 million relating to a foreign exchange gain on the translation of U.S. debt net losses associated with the discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mets Try But Just Don't Get Job Done
description: No ninth-inning rescue this time for the Mets. No splashy debut by Frank Viola, pitching four-hit ball and breaking the gloom. No little winning streak to carry home to New York for the weekend intrusion of the first-place Montreal Expos. And no edge over the St. Louis Cardinals, who hung on to shade the Mets today, 6-5, and hold them to a split of the four-game series.

title: Grumman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OPEC Output Still High
description: OPEC nations continued to pump oil at a robust rate in July despite promises to curtail their crude output, the International Energy Agency said today in its Monthly Oil Market Report. The agency estimated that the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries produced about 21.3 million barrels a day last month.

title: Sleazy but Legal
description: You don't have to read the polls to know that a lot of Americans have little use for the Washington political establishment, or that minorities and the poor believe the criminal justice system prosecutes them but protects the rich and the powerful.

title: Lincoln Center Jazzes It Up Classically
description: Summer is traditionally jazz-festival time, and this summer more than most, New York has been awash in festivals. Be it a repertory series put on by Carnegie Hall or the 92d Street Y, or the annual JVC Jazz Festival, American pop is becoming more familiar to halls usually devoted to European classical music.

title: Groupe T.C.G. (Quebec) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter and first- half figures included results from Auto Point Inc., acquired in June 1988. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months' losses included a pre-tax charge of $19 million related to investments. Year-ago periods' share earnings are on a pro forma basis based on the number of shares after completion of a public offering of 6,740,000 common in August 1988. Prior to the offering the company was a unit of Kinder- Care Inc.

title: Giants Sign Reasons To One-Year Contract
description: In 1987, Gary Reasons, the Giant inside linebacker, lost his starting job after missing 39 days of training camp because of a contract dispute. Today, he agreed to a one-year contract after missing 10 days of camp.

title: Chicago Rivet & Machine reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Vehicle Sales Up 0.7% in July
description: Heavy discounting helped push domestic auto sales to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.6 million in July, the best showing so far this year.

title: 3 Superintendents Lead In Search for Chancellor
description: Three school superintendents in other major cities have emerged as the front-runners for schools chancellor in New York City, Board of Education officials and others said yesterday.

title: Mennen and McCann
description: McCann-Erickson New York increased its billings from the Mennen Company yesterday by between $7 million and $10 million a year. The company gave the agency its Home Expression Group's account, consisting of three units that make paper party goods and household fragrance products. McCann, a unit of the Interpublic Group, already handles Mennen's Speed Stick and Lady Speed Stick deodorants, which spent $26 million on advertising in 1988.

title: Index Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Given Deadline to Protect Sea Turtles
description: A Federal district judge said today that Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher had no right to suspend enforcement of regulations on shrimpers to protect sea turtles from drowning and gave the agency until Monday to draft temporary measures.

title: Interhome Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $14.4 million. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Auctions
description: Shaker Samplings A slender, seven-foot-tall Shaker chest of drawers is to be auctioned at noon on Sunday at Hancock Shaker Village in Pittsfield, Mass. The 1830's pine chest of nine graduated drawers, in the original red stain finish, is one of several unusual offerings in the annual sale of Shaker furnishings organized by Willis Henry Auctions Inc. of Marshfield, Mass. The chest, made at the Shaker community in New Lebanon, N.Y., is expected to sell for $30,000 to $35,000.

title: Books of The Times; Cuban Immigrants in the 50's of Desi and Lucy
description: The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love By Oscar Hijuelos 407 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY Congressional conferees hammered out a compromise agreement on financing the savings and loan bailout that is acceptable to the Administration. Under the agreement, $20 billion of the bailout will be put on the budget and the remaining $30 billion will go on other Government accounts. Passage by the Senate of the plan is expected today, but passage in the House is less certain. [ Page A1. ] The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell one-tenth of 1 percent in June, the fourth decline in five months. The drop renewed concerns that the longest economic expansion in peacetime history may be nearing an end. [ D1. ] The productivity of American workers rose two-tenths of 1 percent in the April-June period as output climbed 1.7 percent. [ D2. ] The nation's retailers reported mostly improved year-to-year sales in July, spurred by continued strength in apparel sales. [ D2. ] Sales of domestic cars and light trucks rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from July 1988, helped by heavy discounting. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Congressional investigators say they have evidence that Bolar Pharmaceutical may have fraudulently submitted a brand-name drug in place of its own in trying to win F.D.A. approval. [ D1. ] The S.E.C. charged two investors of Fermat Associates with attempting to defraud more than 100 brokerages. [ D1. ] An executive vice president of American Express is leaving the company, saying he accepted ''executive responsibility'' for an investigation that led to a campaign to discredit a banking competitor. [ D1. ] A work stoppage resolution was passed by the master executive council of Eastern Air Line Pilots Association. [ D3. ] Plessey received a new $3.3 billion offer from General Electric Company of Britain and Siemens A.G. of West Germany. [ D3. ] A New Jersey investor began a $32-a-share tender offer for Di Giorgio. The offer values the company at $154.2 million. [ D3. ] An auditor's report concluded that Lincoln Savings and Loan improperly recorded millions of dollars in profits on real estate transactions. [ D4. ] Time Warner is likely to sell Scott, Foresman, officials familiar with the company said. [ D5. ] Dale W. Lang agreed to acquire a half-interest in Ms. and Sassy magazines. Terms were not disclosed. [ D5. ] Playboy Enterprises is canceling its Playboy Channel cable service to concentrate on the growing pay-per-view market. [ D5. ] MARKETS Nearly one-third of the commodities traders and brokers indicted by a Federal grand jury may agree to cooperate and as a result, a new wave of indictments could soon be revealed, people working on the case said. [ D1. ] Stock prices were modestly higher and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 4.17 points, to 2,661.61. Over-the-counter stocks rose to an all-time high. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased as traders sold securities ahead of today's release of July unemployment data. [ D12. ] The dollar rose against most major currencies, bolstered by concern about the hostage situation. [ D13. ] Soybean futures plunged to a 20-month low. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The nation's low unemployment rate was expected to lead to a rise in wages. But the big wage increases never materialized, and now the window of opportunity has passed. Economic Scene. [ D1. ] Gas turbine manufacturing and coal and lime production companies are positioned to benefit from new regulations on pollution control. Market Place. [ D6. ] The chairman of Campbell-Mithun-Esty resigned, citing negative coverage in the advertising trade press. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: Famous Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to July 16
Seeing a Dependent and Declining U.S., More Japanese Adopt a Nationalistic Spirit
description: In a volume called ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' selling briskly in Tokyo bookstores these days, a dark-horse candidate to be the next Prime Minister argues forcefully that Japan no longer needs to act like the deferential stepchild of the United States.

title: Penn Central Offers $200 Million Issue
description: The Penn Central Corporation yesterday priced $200 million in subordinated debentures due in 1999 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Stake Is Raised In Software Maker
description: Walter H. Haefner, a Swiss industrialist, raised his stake in Computer Associates International Inc. to 21.5 percent, from 20.5 percent, and said he would buy 2.56 million more shares of the computer software concern, based in Garden City, L.I. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Haefner said he would buy the additional shares so his stake would not be diluted by Computer Associates' acquisition of Cullinet Software Inc.

title: Knicks Re-sign Tucker
description: The Knicks announced yesterday that they had signed the free-agent guard Trent Tucker to a multiyear contract. Tucker in recent years has been the team's most effective 3-point field goal shooter. Terms and conditions were not revealed, but the agreement is believed to be worth $2.5 million over three years.

About Real Estate;
Condos Offer View From Bay Ridge
description: LEAD: Should you get lost in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, look for a 14-story building topped by a 6-foot-high, 42-foot-round crown that glows in the dark. It stands on 64th Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, next to the Gowanus Expressway.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Dorothy Donegan

title: Congress
description: Representative Mary Rose Oakar, a Roman Catholic who grew up poor in the ethnic enclaves of Cleveland's West Side, has always considered herself an opponent of abortion.

description: Stock prices were modestly higher yesterday as investors stayed on the sidelines awaiting today's report on employment in July.

title: Review/Television; ABC News Offers Potpourri In 'Primetime Live' Debut
description: Star power drives television journalism. The networks' investment in the personalities who front the nightly news programs affirms their resplendent place in the corporations' books and in the public esteem. They are more icons than anchors.

title: GWC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Washington Talk; Q.&A.: Mollie Orshansky; The Hand That Shaped America's Poverty Line As the Realistic Index
description: The poverty line has become one of those fundamentals of government on which Federal, state and local officials rely in calculating aid to the poor. Politicians use it to argue about how humane or inhumane their opposition is. The index was developed in the early 1960's by Mollie Orshansky, who was then an economist for the Social Security Administration. It was chosen by the Johnson Administration as a demonstration of the need for the War on Poverty. In a recent interview the economist talked about the measure, including how she thinks it should be used.

title: Police Diary: Stakeout in Times Sq.
description: Tedium and frustration mix with sudden action in a Times Square surveillance post that the Midtown South Precinct uses to try to stop street crime. Following is a diary of parts of two days in July that a reporter and photographer spent with the police: Day 1

description: In terms of art, Long Island is not exactly going quietly into the lazy days of late summer. On the contrary, from Roslyn to Riverhead and eastward to the various Hamptons, the current exhibitions in the area's museums and alternative spaces offer pleasures and challenges to many tastes and levels of sophistication.

Giuliani Changes His Stance To Accept Right to Abortion
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, clarifying once again his stance on abortion, completely accepted yesterday women's ''right of choice'' on abortion, except for a personal disclaimer.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SALTY STORIES,'' tales of humor and suspense by Thomas McKean, with audience participation, 2 and 4 P.M. tomorrow, at the South Street Seaport Museum, 12 Fulton Street. Admission free with museum admission: children, $2; adults, $5. Information: 669-9430. ''CASTLE DESIGNS ON THE ROCKS,'' a workshop for children ages 5 to 11 and their families, to learn how to design and build model castles, 1 to 4 P.M. tomorrow, at Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, south of the Great Lawn at 79th Street, in Central Park. Reservations and information: 772-0210. ''DAD'S ALWAYS RIGHT,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen, told by Lorraine Ackerman, 11 A.M. tomorrow, at the Andersen Statue, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue, in Central Park. Free. ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES,'' a musical by Mark Erson and William Toscano, 10:30 A.M. today and Aug. 11, by the Penny Bridge Players, 520 Clinton Avenue, between Fulton Street and Atlantic Avenue, Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Information: (718) 855-6346. ''PLAY TO WIN,'' free performances by Theaterworks/U.S.A., about the baseball player Jackie Robinson, for children 8 and older, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays and 11 A.M. Saturdays and Sundays, through Aug. 13, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets, distributed on a first-come first-served basis, at 9 A.M. on the day of each performance. Information: 677-5959. ''SKATES,'' ''MAGGIE AND THE PIRATE'' AND ''APT. 3,'' three short pieces, 1 and 3:30 P.M. today through Monday, presented by Tada, a children's acting group, at 120 West 28th Street. Tickets: children, $5; adults, $7. Information: 627-1732. ''TOY BOOKS EXHIBITION,'' a show of century-old toy books - small-format publications for children - printed by stationers in the South Street Seaport, on view through Labor Day, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily, at Bowne & Company Stationers, 211 Water Street. Free. Information: 669-9400.

The Documentaries
description: Documentaries and short films in the Film '89 part of Festival Latino will be shown in the Little Theater at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The screenings begin today and continue through Aug. 13. There are no English subtitles unless otherwise noted. Admission to each hourly screening is $5. Information: 598-7155. Here is a schedule of films for this weekend. Today ''QUE QUEDA DE NUESTRO AMOR'' (''What's Left From Our Love,'' Argentina), and ''Made in Argentina'' (Argentina), subtitled. At 6 P.M. ''WHAT A GUY!'' (United States), and ''Krik? Krak!: Tales of a Nightmare'' (Haiti/United States), subtitled. At 8 P.M. Also Sunday at 10 P.M. ''LAS TEJEDORAS DE NANDUTY'' (''The Nanduty Weavers,'' Argentina) and ''Tango, Bayle Nuestro'' (''Tango, Our Dance,'' Argentina). At 10 P.M. Tomorrow ''CRONICA DEL CARIBE'' (''Caribbean Chronicles,'' Mexico) and ''Como Una Pintura Nos Iremos Borrando'' (''As a Painting, We Will Eventually Fade,'' Mexico). At 2 P.M. ''IMAGENES'' (''Images,'' Mexico) and ''El Camino Largo'' (''The Long Road,'' Mexico). At 4 P.M. Also Sunday at 2 P.M. ''MEMORIA VIVA'' (''Live Memory,'' Brazil), subtitled. At 6 P.M. ''TREN GAUCHO'' (''Gaucho Train,'' Argentina) and ''Evita: Una Mujer . . . un Pueblo'' (''Evita: A Woman. . . the People,'' Argentina). At 8 P.M. ''30 DE AGOSTO'' (''Aug. 30,'' Puerto Rico) and ''The People Rise'' (United States). At 10 P.M. Sunday ''MIRNA BAEZ: LOS ESPEJOS DEL SILENCIO'' (''Mirna Baez: Mirrors of Silence,'' Puerto Rico) and ''Chabuca Granda . . . Confidencias'' (''Chabuca Granda . . . Confidences''). At 4 P.M. ''LIGIA ELENA'' (Puerto Rico); ''LA MIRADA DE MYRIAM'' (''Miriam's Glance,'' Colombia); ''Escuchemos a las Mujeres'' (''Listen to the Women,'' Nicaragua) and ''Solas o Mal Acompanadas'' (''Alone or in Bad Company,'' Argentina). At 6 P.M. ''A NIGHT IN HAVANA, DIZZY GILLESPIE IN CUBA'' (United States). At 8 P.M.

title: Review/Dance; A Melange of Offerings for Serious Fun
description: Any suspicion that Serious Fun was beginning to take itself seriously was dispelled by the low level of most of the offerings on the series' annual Megadance program on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

The company said 1988 results were restated to reflect the recording of certain expenses.

title: Chinese Opposition Group Plans Secret Parley in West Next Month
description: A new opposition group that seeks to provide a democratic alternative to China's Communist Party will hold its inaugural congress of 120 delegates from around the world next month, two Chinese exiles have announced.

title: Cassidy's Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $365,000 special gain. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Universal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There was a significant decrease in earnings from title insurance due to the continued soft real estate market and an increase in claims arising from policies written in prior years.

title: HOSTAGE IS SPARED
description: President Bush was prepared to order an air strike against suspected terrorist strongholds in Lebanon if kidnappers had carried out a threat to kill an American hostage, Administration officials said today.

title: Medical Panel Is Developing Tougher Drug Test for Athletes
description: The International Olympic Committee medical commission is developing a drug test that could be used to disqualify athletes from the Olympics even if they do not test positive for drug use immediately after their competition.

title: Weirton Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest 6-month results were adversely affected by $5,100,000 special vacation bonus to employees and a $5,300,000 in expenses related to the public secondary issue of common stock.

title: Linear Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,006,000.

title: Unilever Expands
description: Unilever N.V., the British-Dutch food company, said it had acquired the remaining 50 percent of the West German food company Homann-Gruppe G.m.b.H. after receiving approval from West German authorities. No terms were disclosed. Unilever already owned half of the West German company, whose annual sales total 529 million marks, or about $285 million. The remaining stake was bought from the Homann family as part of the heritage of Fritz Homann, who died in January. His will specified that the stake be sold to Unilever.

title: Judge Tells Defense Lawyers To Talk About Fee Payments
description: A state judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered three defense lawyers to testify before a grand jury that is investigating whether the leaders of a drug ring on the Lower East Side of Manhattan paid the lawyers' fees.

title: Reviews/Art; Poiriers and Vuillard, in Upstate New York and Westchester
description: For more than a decade, Anne and Patrick Poirier have been remaking, with mixed results, the archeology of ancient civilizations. Like Piranesi, they have seen a peculiar beauty in the ruins of Greece and Rome and have spent years traveling from one excavation site to the next. For the French couple, antiquity is a wellspring of memory.

title: Harvard and Japanese In Skin Research Deal
description: In an unusual commercial and academic joint venture, Harvard and Massachusetts General Hospital today accepted $85 million from Japan's leading cosmetics company for a new skin research center. The company would have exclusive rights to sell health and beauty products growing out of the research.

title: Immucor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: Interstate General L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: U.S. Official Meets With Palestinians
description: A group of Palestinians met with a visiting senior American official today and laid down hard-line conditions for peace negotiations with the Israelis.

title: Hurricane Veers Off From Caribbean Isles
description: Hurricane Dean veered out into the Atlantic today with winds up to 85 miles an hour, and the National Weather Service lifted hurricane warnings for all the islands of the eastern Caribbean including Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: Review/Film; Silliness And Science That Equal One Einstein
description: It says a lot about ''Young Einstein'' that the cast includes actors named Yahoo, Lulu, Peewee and Su, goofy play names that set the tone for this Monty Pythonesque ramble through the early life of Albert Einstein.

title: Amvestors Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net realized investment losses of $2 million, including $2.5 million in gains from the sale of bonds and a $4.5 million writedown of bonds held for the quarter, and net realized investment losses of $2.3 million for the 6 months.

title: White House Reaffirms Anti-Terrorist Policy While Taking Steps to Work Around It
description: Faced with a crisis in the Middle East, the Bush Administration today reaffirmed the American policy of not negotiating with terrorists, even as it took steps to get around that prohibition in practice.

title: Strong Evidence Discovered That AZT Holds Off AIDS
description: For the first time, researchers have strong evidence that the drug AZT can significantly delay the onset of AIDS in people showing mild symptoms of immune system damage.

title: PSE Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Theater; Stories of a Puerto Rican Circus at Festival Latino
description: When midsummer torpor imbues the theatergoer with a sense of overwork at the mere mention of the word experimental, the arrival of a Puerto Rican company with just such a production at the start of the Festival Latino in New York should banish all such forebodings.

title: Our Towns; Peace and Quiet And Gravel Pits In Scenic Valley
description: When Dr. Cavin Leeman and his wife, Diane Zimmerman, decided to buy a 200-year-old farmhouse in the silky green hills of Dutchess County a year ago, they were smitten by the peace and quiet and the gentle grandeur of the valley around them. When they moved in, no one had planned a gravel pit on farmland just across the road. That came early this year.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday priced $200 million of notes due 1994 through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes were given an 8 1/2 percent coupon and were priced at par to yield about 87 basis points more than the five-year Treasury note. Noncallable by the company, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,228,000 for the quarter and year; the year also included income from discontinued operations of $2,581,000 and a gain of $39,602,000 on the disposal of the company's business products. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Education Systems Corp., which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

Results included net charges for the company's supplemental performance plan of $14.6 million and $19 million for the latest quarter and year, respectively, and $1.4 million and $5.4 million for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. The company said the supplemental performance plan, which terminates with the public offering of common shares which was commenced on July 27, provided an incentive bonus payment to certain key employees based on an increase in the value of the company. The supplemental performance plan will be funded by Hanson Plc, which owned the company prior to the public offering.

title: Arafat to Continue Diplomatic Effort in Mideast
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, said at a Palestinian congress in Tunis today that the P.L.O. would continue its recent diplomatic efforts to reach a Middle East settlement.

Review/Film; A Dance of Sex and Love, Through a Lens Darkly
description: A guileless beauty in a long flowered dress, Ann Millaney sits cross-legged on the couch in her psychiatrist's sunny office and describes her fear of the week: what will we do with all the garbage piling up in the world? Her soft Southern voice floats over the image of Graham, her husband's straggly old friend, who stops for a shave in the men's room of Ray's Bait Shop and splashes a little water under his armpits before he drives on to Baton Rouge, La., and Ann's spacious white house.

Tyco and Bozell
description: Tyco Industries awarded the account for its View-Master Ideal division, the maker of hand-held, three-dimensional viewers for children, to Bozell, Tyco's agency since 1985. The creative-only account will add $11 million in billings to Bozell's work for the toy maker.

title: Senate Committee Says Animosity Led To Investigation by U.S. Nuclear Agency
description: A Senate committee said yesterday that an internal investigation at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of charges of misconduct by a high-ranking official appeared motivated as much by ''personal and professional animosity'' as by any legitimate need.

title: American Eagle
description: American Airlines said its commuter carrier, American Eagle, would open a hub at Miami International Airport, the home base of the strike-crippled Eastern Airlines. American Eagle's president, Robert E. Martens, said the carrier planned to open on Oct. 1 with 20 flights a day from Miami to Key West and West Palm Beach, also in Florida. It also plans to expand to other Florida cities, like Fort Myers, Marathon and Naples. The commuter service will also seek approval from the Federal Government and the Government of the Commonwealth of the Bahamas to schedule flights from Miami to the Bahamas.

title: Renegotiations On Prime Offer
description: J. H. Whitney & Company, under pressure from its banks, said today that it had entered negotiations to reduce its $1.2 billion offer for Prime Computer Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Avantek Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., was the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by a group including the Bass brothers. The group has raised its stake in Avantek and is seeking Federal permission to more than $15 million if the company's shares.

title: Judge Orders Art Dealer to Return Rare Mosaics to Church of Cyprus
description: In a decision that museum officials say will be used to set guidelines in the acquisition of antiquities, a Federal judge in Indianapolis ruled yesterday that an art dealer who acquired four sixth-century Byzantine mosaics was not a good-faith purchaser and must return the rare fragments to the Autocephalous Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus.

title: National Western Life InsurFance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The decline of earnings was mainly attributable to a loss in the latest second quarter of $549,000 at the company's brokerage subsidiary, Westcap Corp. Westcap had earnings of $881,000 in the 1988 second quarter.

title: Benita S. Feurey, Reporter, 49
description: Benita S. Feurey, a television reporter and editor who specialized in consumer affairs, died of cancer Wednesday at Miriam Hospital in Providence, R.I. She was 49 years old and had residences in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: Cosmopolitan Artworks Along Suburbann Byways
description: ''August for the people and their favorite islands,'' W. H. Auden said, and it may or may not be relevant that where art is concerned Long Island comes on very strong this month. At the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn, we can find Gustav Klimt and his colleagues Egon Schiele and Oskar Kokoschka in turn-of-the-century Vienna.

description: A picture caption with the Points West column in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified a daughter of Cynthia and Steve Garvey. She is Krisha Lee.

title: Ferrer to Fight Charter Plan At the Justice Department
description: The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said yesterday that he intends to challenge the proposed revision of the New York City charter with the Justice Department on the ground that it violates the Federal Voting Rights Act.

description: b-After a gain of $142,000. c-Net loss The company said 1989 figures included net refundable taxes of $1,870,000 as a result of an acquisition earlier this year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Market Place; Who Could Gain In Clean Air Act
description: WITH President Bush's clean-air initiative pushing the country firmly in the direction of stricter pollution control, some analysts are looking at companies that stand to gain from tighter regulation. The Administration estimates that the cost of compliance with its proposals would be $14 billion to $19 billion a year. Industry estimates, which vary broadly, run as high as $50 billion.

title: Voyager, Heading Toward Neptune, Sights 3 Undiscovered Moons
description: Three previously unknown moons of Neptune have been photographed by Voyager 2, and mission scientists said yesterday that their gravitational forces could account for the peculiar broken rings of orbiting material believed to surround the huge planet.

title: Apple Computer Gets Postal Pact
description: In its first significant Federal contract, Apple Computer Inc. will supply the United States Postal Service with Macintosh IIx personal computers for its nationwide system. Depending upon demand, the five-year agreement may total as much as $30.2 million for systems and other services. The Apple bid includes more than 25 subcontractors supplying peripheral products for the Macintosh.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Results Plus
description: SWIMMING Barrowman Sets Record: Mike Barrowman of Rockville, Md., set the world record in the qualifying round of the men's 200-meter breaststroke yesterday, and then came back to win the final at the United States long course national championships in Los Angeles. Barrowman, 20 years old, was clocked in 2 minutes 12.90 seconds in his heat at Southern Cal's Olympic Pool, breaking the record of 2:13.34 set by Victor Davis of Canada during his gold-medal performance in the same lane at the 1984 Games.

title: FRP Properties Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $690,000 from an accounting change.

title: For an Ill Widow, 83, Suicide Is Welcome
description: LEAD: A close friend, an 83-year-old widow in rapidly declining health, plans to commit suicide within a couple of months.

title: Robert Phelps, Writer Who Edited Colette and Cocteau, Dies at 66
description: Robert Phelps, an editor, an author and a translator, died of cancer of the colon on Wednesday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 66 years old and also had Parkinson's disease.

title: Files Show Pierce Was Busy With Social Details
description: The files of Samuel R. Pierce Jr. offer a glimpse of a figure who was known as ''Silent Sam'' during his tenure and who has become reclusive in the months since Congress began investigating the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Cooperation Expected From Indicted Traders
description: One day after 46 commodity traders were indicted here, people working on the case said nearly one-third of the defendants had agreed to cooperate and that, as a result, a new wave of indictments would soon be disclosed.

'Ketchup Hit the Back of My Head'
description: To the Editor:

title: Unum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change.

title: For Police Surveillance Team, Action Punctuates the Tedium
description: Unseen by his quarry, Sgt. Mike Keaveney stood at the window of reflective glass, a pair of binoculars trained across Broadway. No one could see in, he knew that. But still it seemed eerie to be looming there, a bulletproof vest strapped bulkily under his T-shirt, staring down at the three figures huddling around a parked Cadillac Seville.

title: DSC Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $518,000 for the quarter and $477,000 for the 6 months.

title: Group Suspends Decision to Kill A U.S. Captive
description: Pro-Iranian militants said tonight that they had suspended a decision to kill an American hostage to allow more time for the release of a Shiite Muslim cleric abducted by Israeli commandos in southern Lebanon last week. But the group issued new demands and said they must be met within days.

title: Milgray Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gunmen Open Fire On Brooklyn Street; 2 Killed; 3 Wounded
description: Three brothers were shot, one of them to death, another man was also killed and an innocent bystander was wounded after two men walked up to the group on a Brooklyn street last night, opened fire and then chased some of the victims onto adjoining streets before gunning them down, the police said.

title: Those Who Would Be Mayor Must Recognize Needs of Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Takeover Law
description: Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois signed legislation Wednesday intended to prevent hostile takeovers of corporations. The law authorizes the issuance of ''poison pill'' shareholder rights or options plans by Illinois corporations without shareholder approval. Such plans can make hostile takeovers prohibitively expensive. The law also includes ''asset freeze'' clauses that provide for a three-year delay of mergers, sales or stock transfers to a shareholder who acquires 15 percent or more of a corporation's stock without the board's approval.

title: Suddenly, No Room at the Top
description: Last spring, before the Baltimore Orioles began their improbable flight to the top of the baseball world, Frank Robinson, the manager, was not thinking of high flight so much as survival. After the previous season's ride through the lower depths, when the team lost its first 21 games on the way to a 107-loss, last-place finish, Robinson, along with nearly everyone else, was not looking for miracles in Baltimore this year.

title: Keye/Donna Decision
description: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein Los Angeles has dropped out of the American Suzuki Motor Corporation's review of its account, reportedly worth $30 million in annual billings, that was announced in May. The account may be worth half the agency's billings. Suzuki has seen sales plummet since Consumer Reports magazine said last year that its Samurai four-wheel-drive vehicle has a propensity to tip over during sharp turns. The company said it would announce next week which agencies were participat-ing in the review.

title: Nicaragua's Economic Woes Made in U.S.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Salesman Tells Of Kickbacks For Helmsley
description: A former liquor distributor testified yesterday at Leona M. Helmsley's tax-fraud and extortion trial that Mrs. Helmsley's top aide forced him to pay kickbacks to keep the Helmsley Hotels account.

title: Central Vermont Public Servce reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mrs. Fernandez Weds a Lawyer
description: Genevieve Fisch Fernandez, a public relations consultant, and Richard Gilbert Hewitt, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Lowell Hotel in New York by Judge J. Daniel Mahoney of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The bride was a widow and the bridegroom was a widower. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a senior consultant at Ruder-Finn, a public relations firm in New York. A graduate of Barnard College, she is a former home building and decorating editor at Good Housekeeping magazine in New York and the author of ''The A B C's of Decorating'' and ''American Traditional.'' She is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Abraham M. Fisch of New York.

title: Del Taco Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included an after- tax gain of $6,520,000, or 76 cents a share, on the sale of the company's Applebee's restaurant business.

title: A Drug Policy, at Last
description: Like a straitlaced parent who prefers to deny an adolescent child's drug problem, the Reagan Administration responded fitfully when confronted with crack, the potent cocaine derivative that is devastating whole areas of American life.

title: Pantasote Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
49% Sosa Stake For D.M.B.&B.
description: Sosa & Associates, a leading Hispanic advertising agency, announced yesterday that it had sold a 49 percent interest to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/U.S.A. and, not coincidentally, had been awarded the Spanish-language advertising and promotions account of Burger King, a major D.M.B.&B. client.

title: Pratt & Lambert Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago 6-month results included after-tax gain of $285,000 on the sale of property.

title: Takeover of NWA Said Completed
description: Wings Holdings Inc., a private investment partnership, announced the completion of its $3.6 billion offer for NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines. Wings Holdings said that 28.6 million NWA shares had been tendered by 5 P.M. on Wednesday, the deadline for physical delivery of stock promised for tender before the offer expired on July 26.

description: b-Included tax credits of $87,000 and $227,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: RESEARCHERS FIND NEW DRUG SLOWS PARKINSON'S PACE
description: A new drug slows the progress of Parkinson's disease, the crippling neurological disorder, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Those 'Women in Love' Sisters, in 'The Rainbow'
description: The new BBC adaptation of ''The Rainbow'' is faithful, in its picturesque fashion, to the spirit of D. H. Lawrence's novel about the Brangwen family in turn-of-the-century Nottinghamshire. The first hour of the three-hour movie can be seen tomorrow at 9 P.M. on the Arts & Entertainment cable network.

title: St. John's in the Garden
description: Madison Square Garden Enterprises and St. John's University announced yesterday that the Redmen would play six regular-season games, including four against Big East Conference opponents, at the Garden each season for the next five years.

title: 'Tales of Exile'
description: ''Tales of Exile,'' a dance-theater collaboration by the choreographer Ruby Shang, the composer Carman Moore and the director Gilberte Tsai, is to be performed at the Lincoln Center Fountain Plaza tomorrow evening at 6:30. Admission is free. Information: 877-1800.

title: Optimism at G.M. On Market Share
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, says the slide in the company's share of the American car market is not yet under control, but he believes the auto maker will show gains next year because of the new Saturn compact and other models. At the start of the decade, the nation's No. 1 auto maker sold nearly half of all the cars bought in the country, but its share has since slipped steadily. In the first six months of 1989, G.M. held 35.7 percent of the United States auto market.

title: W. P. Farnsworth, 87, Air Force's Auditor
description: William P. Farnsworth, auditor general of the United States Air Force from 1955 to 1963, died Tuesday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Informix Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Summary
description: International A2-7 If another hostage had been killed, President Bush was prepared to order an air strike against suspected terrorist strongholds in Lebanon, Administration officials said. Page A1 A decision to kill a U.S. hostage has been suspended, pro-Iranian militants said, to allow more time for the release of a Shiite Muslim cleric abducted by Israeli commandos in Southern Lebanon last week. A1 Faced with a Middle East crisis, the Bush Administration reaffirmed the American policy of not negotiating with terrorists, even as it took steps to get around that prohibition. A6 Palestinians met a top U.S. official and laid down conditions for peace negotiations with the Israelis. The first thing they made clear was that they considered themselves only agents for the P.L.O. A7 Arafat to continue diplomatic effort in Mideast A7 Nicaragua's military conscription will be suspended until national elections are held in February, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced. The moratorium is scheduled to begin on Sept. 1. A3 A new Chinese opposition group that seeks to provide a democratic alternative to the Communist Party will hold its inaugural congress next month somewhere in the West, two Chinese exiles have announced. A2 In Japan, impatience with the U.S. is pervading political discussion. Often, it seems rooted in a belief that America has been slow to recognize its dependency on Japanese resources. A7 A black South African homeland has effectively sealed off two communities that have resisted being incorporated into the homeland, civil rights lawyers and field workers say. A7 Human rights abuses in Ethiopia were described in a report issued by Amnesty International on the eve of the first high-level official contact in a decade between Washington and the Government in Ethiopia. A3 National A8-11, B5-6 At H.U.D., Samuel R. Pierce Jr. was instrumental in providing Federal assistance to prominent Republicans, friends and former aides who sought his help, correspondence from his eight-year tenure shows. A1 The files of Samuel R. Pierce Jr. offer a glimpse of a figure who was known as 'Silent Sam' and who has become reclusive since Congress began investigating the Department of Housing and Urban Development. A9 A drug slows Parkinson's disease, researchers reported. This is the first time that any drug has been shown to delay the symptoms of a neurological disease. A1 Drug trafficking organizations, enticed by the huge profits reaped by selling cocaine and crack, have expanded beyond the nation's cities into rural states. A1 The drug AZT appears to delay AIDS in people showing mild symptoms of immune system damage, researchers reported. Until now, AZT had only been shown to be effective in patients with full-fledged AIDS. A1 A savings and loan bailout bill will be vetoed by President Bush, he promised, because of a provision he claims breaks down the budget-cutting discipline of Congress. A1 An investigation at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, into charges of misconduct by a staff official ap-peared to have been personally motivated, a Senate committee said. A8 A budget for the District of Columbia was approved by the House of Representatives that would ease restrictions on the city's ability to pay for abortions. Abortion opponents had called for the rejection of the bill. A10 Harvard and Japanese in skin research deal A8 Historic Concord battle spills into the present A8 Justice Dept. tightens policy on disclosures to press A10 Washington Talk A11 The poverty line is a fundamental of government. The economist who developed the index two decades ago talked about how it was invented and how it should, in her view, be used. Regional B1-4 Midtown South anticrime squads have been staking out the Times Square area from a network of hidden surveillance posts in an attack on common street crimes. B1 For the job of schools chancellor in New York City, three superintendents in other major cities have emerged as likely front-runners, the city's Board of Education said. B1 SUNY approves 5% pay raises for its 29 campus presidents B2 While campaigning, Ronald Lauder shows little of the ordinary politician's aptitude for establishing an ersatz intimacy with strangers. He appears serious, rather than gregarious, and introspective. B1 Ravitch campaign begins broadcasting commercials B3 Giuliani changes his stance to accept right to an abortion B3 The N.A.A.C.P. has sued five towns in New Jersey, accusing them of using residency requirements to block blacks from holding municipal jobs, and is investigating the hiring practices in other towns in New Jersey and Connecticut. B2 Three defense lawyers must testify before a grand jury that is investigating whether the leaders of a drug ring on the Lower East Side of Manhattan paid the lawyers' fees. B3 The Bronx Borough President plans to challenge the proposed revision of the New York City charter with the Justice Department on the ground that it violates the Federal Voting Rights Act. B4 A young police officer was killed in Essex County by a blast from a shotgun carried by a fellow officer as they burst into a house in Irvington on a drug raid. B2 Audit critici es New Jersey pool in car insurance B2 Liquor distributor testfies about kickbacks to Helmsley Hotels B4

title: Productivity Rose 0.2% In Quarter
description: The productivity of American workers increased modestly in the second quarter after declining in the first quarter, the Labor Department said today.

Investor Starts Tender For Di Giorgio Shares
description: The New Jersey investor Arthur M. Goldberg began a $32-a-share tender offer today for the Di Giorgio Corporation, a diversified San Francisco-based company. The offer values the company at $154.2 million.

Executive At American Express Quits
description: An executive vice president of the American Express Company announced yesterday that he would leave the company, saying that he accepted ''executive responsibility'' for an investigation that had led to a campaign to discredit Edmond J. Safra, a banking competitor.

description: Word had reached the special anti-drug force here in the capital of Soviet Turkmenia that poppy was being grown and harvested for opium on the Kalinin collective farm.

title: Nicaraguans Reach Pact on Contras
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and leaders of Nicaragua's internal opposition signed an accord today urging that the contras be disbanded. Mr. Ortega said he would press for the breakup at a meeting of Central American leaders that begins Saturday.

title: Hospital Receives Mortgage
description: A Harlem hospital has received a $150 million mortgage that will allow it to construct a new building, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today. Joint Diseases North General Hospital, at 1919 Madison Avenue, will build a new hospital two blocks away with 240 beds, including 40 for people with AIDS.

title: Cyprus Asks Judge to Order Prompt Return of Mosaics
description: Lawyers for the Republic of Cyprus returned to court today in an effort to obtain immediate release of four sixth-century church mosaics that an Indiana art dealer had been ordered to surrender.

description: James T. Kearney, director of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, N.Y. He was 38 years old and lived in Newburgh.

title: Toyota Says Lexus Is Selling Rapidly
description: The Toyota Motor Company is ''overrun with orders'' for its new Lexus luxury model, and the car will probably be sold out for 1989 before it is formally introduced Sept 1., Lexus's general manager, J. David Illingworth, said. He said Toyota had begun shipping the car to 70 dealers who have set up separate showrooms for it.

description: In a state where cars cost $1,000 a year to insure and insurance companies are only slightly more popular than termites, Republicans say they fear their candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter, has set himself up for a pounding with his call to deregulate the industry.

description: Racial segregation in 10 of the nation's largest cities is more deeply entrenched and takes more forms than social scientists previously thought, a study by the University of Chicago has found.

title: Hollace Wilson Weds a Student
description: The Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Hollace Stander Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Wilson Jr. of New York and West Chop, Mass., to Eric D. Swanson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Swanson of Green Bay, Wis. The Rev. James C. Martin performed the ceremony.

title: Noranda Weighs Bidding for Amax
description: Noranda Inc., the giant Canadian mining and forestry company, may try to buy Amax Inc. to block its proposed friendly takeover of Falconbridge Ltd., Noranda's chairman and chief executive, Alfred Powis, told The Financial Post of Toronto. Noranda has long been known to have an interest in taking over Falconbridge, a nickel mining concern that is one of Canada's best-known companies, and has been buying up shares over the past year.

title: Raphael Scobey, Entertainment Lawyer, 72
description: Raphael G. Scobey, a Manhattan lawyer who specialized in the entertainment business, died of lymphoma yesterday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: 25 Killed in Cuba Train Wreck
description: Two speeding passenger trains collided head-on about 100 miles east of Havana early today, killing at least 25 people and injuring 100, the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported. It said many passengers were trapped inside the wreckage. The Havana radio said that the accident occurred in the city of Colon and that an army helicopter was helping to transport the injured.

title: Report on Talent Bank Holds Koch Responsible
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch must bear ''ultimate responsibility'' for the Talent Bank, a New York City job referral office that systematically funneled jobs to political leaders, a report by the New York State Commission on Integrity in Government says.

title: W. L. Mellon, Humanitarian, Is Dead at 79
description: William Larimer Mellon Jr., an heir to his family's banking and oil fortune who in midlife became a disciple of Albert Schweitzer and spent his remaining years as a medical missionary in Haiti, died of cancer and Parkinson's disease on Thursday at his home in Deschapelles, Haiti. He was 79 years old.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I wish to say - I address the White House - that Lebanon has a solution; the freedom of the hostages is solvable.'' - President Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran.

description: Arthur Rutzen, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who later became a Commerce Department official, died of an aneurism Thursday at the Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 79 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: HOUSE CUTS FUNDS FOR THE MILITARY
description: In another slap at the Pentagon, the House today approved a $286.4 billion military spending bill that provides no money for the Advanced Tactical Fighter and slashes funds for the advanced cruise missile.

title: Harassing Calls Show Decline When Phones Identify Callers
description: The number of obscene or harassing telephone calls has fallen sharply in the first test of a system that allows people to see the number of the phone the call was dialed on before they answer.

title: Correction
description: An article on Tuesday about the resignation of an Indian legislator misidentified the nationality of an arms manufacturer in some copies.

title: Akihito's Tone: A Bit Less Imperial
description: For more than seven months, the Japanese have been watching carefully but patiently for clues to the kind of reign to be established by the unassuming 55-year-old marine-life specialist who became their Emperor after the death of his father, Hirohito.

title: India-Sri Lanka Talks End in Deadlock
description: India and Sri Lanka ended negotiations today on arranging the withdrawal of Indian troops from Sri Lanka, and both sides were deadlocked on the timing of the pullout and on a package of security and political measures for the Tamil minority there, diplomats said.

title: Bank Seeks Charter Switch
description: The American Savings Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had filed an application with the State to convert from a Federal charter to one issued by New York State.

title: Drew Joins Lakers
description: Larry Drew, a free-agent guard, has signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, the team said yesterday. No terms were announced.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Chang Upset: Michael Chang became the second highly seeded player in two days to be beaten as he lost to unseeded Jim Grabb, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Volvo Internationa tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt. The second-seeded Chang fought off two match points, one with a powerful passing shot, but slammed an easy overhead into the net to lose the match. Top-seeded Andre Agassi, the defending champion, was ousted Thursday by David Wheaton. Grabb will play 14th-seeded Jim Pugh in the semifinals, and third-seeded Brad Gilbert will play Wheaton, a 20-year-old, who defeated No. 9 Jim Courier, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in a match delayed more than 2 1/2 hours by rain. Gilbert advanced with a 6-4, 7-5 victory over Glenn Layendecker. Pugh beat Robert Seguso, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) Gustafsson Eliminated: Johan Anderson of Australia, a qualifier, beat eighth-seeded Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, 6-4, 6-3, to advance to the semifinals of the Swedish Open in Bastad. The Swedish-born Anderson upset top-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia in the opening round. Anderson, 17 years old, will play Bruno Oresar of Yugoslavia. Oresar advanced with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Karel Novacek.(AP) GOLF Fiori in Front: Ed Fiori shot a four-under-par 67 yesterday to take a two-stroke lead after the second round of the St. Jude Classic in Memphis. Fiori, who shot an opening-round 65, was at 10-under-par 132, two strokes in front of Jim Gallagher, Bob Gilder and Billy Ray Brown.(AP) Littler Leads: Gene Littler survived an 18th-hole bogey to shoot a five-under-par 67 yesterday for the first-round lead at the U.S. West Showdown Classic in Jeremy Ranch, Utah. Dale Douglass and Lou Graham were tied for second at 68 in the seniors tournament.(AP) Zahringer Gains Met Semfinals: George Zahringer of Deepdale, who won the title two years ago, defeated Larry Tedesco of Birchwood, 1-up, yesterday to advance to the semifinals in the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. The 36-year-old Zahringer will oppose Pat Fogarty of Links at Lido, who eliminated Mike Meehan of Wheatley Hills, also 1-up. Dick Siderowf of Century, winner of the championship four times, also advanced when he defeated Kyle Ross of Monmouth by 1-up on the 20th hole. Siderowf, a two-time British amateur champion, will play Jerry Springer of Brae Burn, who beat Jeff Thomas of Plainfield West, 1-up. Amateur Final Set: Brandie Burton and Vicki Goetze won semifinal matches yesterday to advance to today's final of the 89th United States Women's Amateur championship in Pinehurst, N.C.(AP) Daniel Takes Lead: Beth Daniel sank long birdie putts on the final two holes yesterday to finish with a 66 and a one-stroke lead over Rosie Jones after the first round of the Greater Washington Open in Bethesda, Md.(AP)

title: Senate, 99-0, Passes Bill on Oil Spills
description: The Senate approved comprehensive legislation on oil spills today, making the enactment of such a law likely after years of unsuccessful attempts in both houses of Congress.

title: Silence On N. Y.'s Economy
description: The economic indicators for New York City are disquieting. When it comes to economics, however, New York's politicians are just plain quiet.

title: International Banknote Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Iranian and Bush
description: Following are excerpts from remarks today by President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and President Bush on the issue of hostages in Lebanon. The Iranian leader's statement, in a sermon in Teheran, was translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a Federal agency. Mr. Bush's remarks, in answer to questions from reporters at a White House photo session, were transcribed by the Federal News Service. RAFSANJANI STATEMENT

title: Summer People's Worries: Deer Ticks and Box Turtles
description: It is high summertime in the Hamptons, and people are worried about the things they worry about every summer. How is the water? How is the parking? Can the area survive the tourists who race to the boutiques, drive up the price of ice cream and clog the sidewalks and beaches?

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;
With Buying Tableware
description: LEAD: The tourists are buying, buying, buying all over the globe. Whether it is blown glass in Venice or bone china in England, everyone is looking for a bargain. But determining what constitutes a smart purchase in tableware requires some education.

title: Pop vs. Patrimony in Italy
description: Even before the first electric guitar chords had been struck, the vibes from a Pink Floyd concert in Venice last month were bad. They have resounded all summer long here, giving fresh life to time-honored questions about the use of Italy's historic city centers for mass entertainment.

title: Emco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $925,000 for the quarter and $1,692,000 for the 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mesa L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results for the latest second quarter included an $11.3 million net gain associated with sales of oil and gas properties. Share earnings are in units. The company said the loss in the latest second quarter was primarily due to low gas prices coupled with higher interest and depreciation expenses associated with the acquisition of properties in December from Tenneco Inc.

title: Intrex Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after income of $406,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $1,262,000 and $1,449,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: 5 in Bomb Shelter Are Killed By Syrian Shelling in Beirut
description: A highly explosive Syrian shell pierced a bomb shelter in Beirut today, killing 5 people and wounding 30 others taking cover from artillery bombardment.

title: A Perfect Night for Stieb Is Ruined by Kelly
description: A small crowd waited quietly at his locker, but Dave Stieb didn't seem to notice. He sat down, untied his shoes, then lowered his head and asked for a few moments alone. He had done all this before.

title: Appeals Court Turns Down Suit Against Author
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday refused to reinstate a suit against Janet Malcolm, a staff writer at The New Yorker, by a psychologist who said Ms. Malcolm libeled him by fabricating quotations she said were his in an article published in 1983.

title: George Mason Jr., 65, Real-Estate Executive
description: George F. Mason Jr., a lawyer and president of Gunston Hall Inc., a California home building corporation, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St Joseph's Hospital in Orange, Calif. He was 65 years old and lived in Laguna Hills, Calif.

title: Pension Experts Aren't Worried
description: Experts on pension fund management, reacting to Congressional testimony on Wednesday that raised questions about the supervision and soundness of the nation's private funds, said yesterday that the concerns were overstated and that most of the funds are healthy.

title: Antonia Brico, 87, a Conductor; Fought Barriers to Women in 30's
description: Antonia Brico, a conductor who led her own orchestras in New York in the 1930's and who devoted her life to fighting prejudice against women in the orchestral world, died on Thursday after a long illness. She was 87 years old and had lived at the Bella Vita Towers, a nursing home in Denver, since 1988.

title: Aides to Pierce Hid Much Data, Papers Indicate
description: Documents from the files of Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, show that housing officials hid from Congress the extent of political favoritism in subsidy programs.

title: Allan H. Reuben, Lawyer, 58
description: Allan H. Reuben, a Philadelphia lawyer and civil rights advocate, died Thursday at Jefferson University Hospital, Philadelphia, after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Elkins Park, Pa.

title: Models for Eastern Europe?
description: Poland, Hungary and the Baltic Republics are alive with change. Many of the taboos that have cramped their politics, economics and diplomacy for decades are now being lifted. Americans rightly want to foster the trend toward greater freedom, but aren't clear on what to do.

title: Hit Parade by Mets Drowns Out the Expos
description: The Shea Stadium fans made happy noises on their way to the exits. The people in the home team clubhouse talked of optimism. The flaws in the early innings had been obscured by an 11-5 Met victory over Montreal.

title: Half a Goal for Bahr
description: When the Cleveland Browns play the Philadelphia Eagles tomorrow at Wembley Stadium in London, Matt Bahr of the Browns will have mixed feelings. ''I always dreamed I would play football in the famous Wembley Stadium,'' he said. ''But the dream was that I would be kicking a round ball against someone like Arsenal rather than our kind of ball in an N.F.L. preseason game against the Philadelphia Eagles.''

title: 15 Months Under Fire at City Hall Agency
description: May 19, 1988: It is reported that former city employees have told investigators for the Commission on Government Integrity that records of job applicants at the Mayor's Talent Bank were altered or destroyed to delete references to patronage affiliations. The coordinator, Joseph DeVincenzo, in an interview, dismisses the allegations, but adds that it is the city's policy to discard stale or obsolete resumes every six months or so. July 13 and 21: Mr. DeVincenzo testifies in closed session before the commission. Jan. 9, 1989: Nydia Padilla-Barnham, the director of the Talent Bank who resigned in 1987, testifies to the commission that instead of recruiting minority employees, the agency was used to dispense patronage and that the vast majority of jobs went to white men. She also describes in detail the destruction of documents and the altering of computer files to cover up the political side of the agency. Jan. 11: Mr. DeVincenzo, speaking before the commission, denies that his agency was used for patronage, disclaims knowledge of applicants with political ties and says the destruction of records was routine. His assistant, James G. Hein, also denies allegations of patronage, but testifies that Mr. DeVincenzo ordered him in February 1986 to cleanse the computer and paper files of out-of-date resumes and of ''any references to political figures.'' Jan. 23: Mr. DeVincenzo files papers saying he would retire by the end of April, thereby insuring full rights to an annual $52,000 pension. Feb. 24: In his resignation letter to the Mayor, Mr. DeVincenzo says he ''never lost sight of our affirmative-action goals.'' The Mayor later testifies that he was ''distressed'' to learn on Feb. 17 that his assistant had retired before being forced to resign. Aug. 4: Mr. DeVincenzo's indictment on 11 counts of perjury is announced. It cites his testimony on July 13 and 21, 1988, and on Jan. 11, 1989.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 Iran's new President offered his help in trying to end the hostage crisis in Lebanon. President Bush said the offer would be explored ''to the fullest.'' Page 1

title: Iowa Southern Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jets' Offense Awaits Chance To Throw Weight Around
description: From left to right, the numbers read like respectable batting averages: 290, 280, 270, 275, 300. But these are no singles hitters. Rather, they are the individual weights of the offensive line of the Jets.

title: Suitor in 3 Offers For Dataproducts
description: The Dataproducts Corporation, a manufacturer of computer printers in Woodland Hills, Calif., said it had received three proposals from DPC Acquisition Partners to buy Dataproducts or acquire a number of its subsidiaries. The bid from DPC for all of Dataproducts is worth $15 a share, of which at least $10 would be in cash. The deal could be worth $283.7 million.

title: Expeditors International of Wash.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Atlanta Gas Light Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a credit of $2,908,000 from an accounting change.

title: Portland Draftee Signs
description: Cliff Robinson, a second-round draft pick from the University of Connecticut, has signed a multiyear contract with the Portland Trail Blazers. ''I wanted to come here and show that I could play hard all the time and play with some consistency,'' he said in Portland after his first workout. Robinson, a 6-foot-10-inch forward, averaged 20 points and 7.4 rebounds last season and shot 47 percent from the field.(AP)

title: In Beijing, Humdrum Masks the Scars of June
description: The peculiar thing about Beijing, two months after troops and tanks crushed the democracy movement, is how normal life at first seems to be.

title: Frank Gulden Jr., Mustard Executive, 82
description: Frank Gulden Jr., retired chairman and president of Gulden Mustard Company, Inc., a division of American Home Products Corporation, died Wednesday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Bay Shore.

title: Allied Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a credit of $78,135 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: ARCO's Hopes High on Well
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that a new well it is testing on the Alaskan North Slope could prove to be one of the largest discoveries in the United States in the past 10 years.

title: Trainer Sues Barkley
description: Al Boulden, who was let go as trainer of Iran Barkley on June 21, says in a lawsuit that he is owed $47,000 for past fights and $50,000 for Barkley's coming bout against Michael Nunn. Yesterday in Houston, where Boulden lives, State District Judge Jack O'Neill, responding to the lawsuit, granted a temporary restraining order to halt plans for the Barkley-Nunn middleweight fight scheduled for Aug. 14 in Reno. In the suit, Boulden says he was preparing Barkley for the Nunn fight when he was let go. Barkley's manager, John Henry Reetz, says Boulden never had a contract with Barkley.(AP)

title: Unions, After Smyrna
description: Last week the United Auto Workers union suffered a humiliating defeat in its bid to represent employees at a Nissan plant in Smyrna, Tenn. The Smyrna workers rejected the U.A.W. because Nissan already provided high wages and job security. With these benefits in hand, a U.A.W. presence posed more threat than promise.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 9.

title: Leisure Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's results included a $1.6 million gain from a land sale.

title: Review/Dance; Native Traditions at Jacob's Pillow
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival this season has presented a mix of dance forms - ranging from classical ballet to performance art - that is typical of the festival's history of eclecticism. But one of its most unusual programs, which is intended to call attention to indigenous traditional dance in the United States, opened Tuesday night at the Ted Shawn Theater to a packed and wildly exuberant audience.

title: Nevada Power Co. reports earnings for Year to June 30
Whitney Cuts Prime Computer Bid
description: Under pressure from its bankers, J. H. Whitney & Company cut its bid today for Prime Computer Inc. by $74 million, to $1.18 billion, and Prime accepted the new offer.

title: Healthco International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Victory for Reason on Howard Beach
description: This week the New York Supreme Court's appellate division rightly affirmed the convictions of three young men in the Howard Beach murder case. In the process it condemned the racially motivated attack that resulted in the death of a black man, and clarified the principle that racial discrimination, whether by the defense or the prosecution, has no place in jury selection.

title: New York Jobless Rate Dips, But Jersey Figure Is Constant
description: The unemployment rate in New York State dipped slightly last month, while in New Jersey it held fast, according to data released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Woman Dies in Fire at Hartford Y.W.C.A.
description: A woman was killed and three other residents were injured when a two-alarm fire broke out in a lounge at the Y.W.C.A. early today, the third fire in the same area of the building this summer according to residents.

title: Leona and the Little People
description: Leona Helmsley, wife to Harry, is very handsome, very rich and very much in trouble. Mrs. Helmsley is accused of having evaded more than $4 million in income taxes by charging the little luxuries she bought to dress up their country home -among them a marble dance floor, a huge stereo system and several acres of pachysandra - to the Helmsley real estate empire.

title: Green Answers His Critic Again
description: In the late afternoon, as a drizzle fell softly outside, Dallas Green found shelter in the Yankee clubhouse with his coaches. Four of them sat together, as if there were some kind of safety in numbers, and they may have been wondering what would happen next in a season already full of typical Yankee turmoil.

title: SSMC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss of $24.7 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss of $26.7 million for the 6 months. c-Net income and included income of $300,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and net income of $2.2 million for the 6 months. Latest second-quarter and 6-month results included pretax expenses of $16.8 million and $19 million, respectively, from the merger of SSMC with STM Holdings Inc., a unit of International Semi-Tech (Far East) Ltd.

description: THE BISHOP'S BOYS A Life of Wilbur and Orville Wright By Tom D. Crouch Illustrated. 606 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: Changes at Salant
description: Acting to eliminate what it called a profit drain, the Salant Corporation, a diversified apparel producer, said it would dispose of two Perry Ellis women's apparel lines but retain two other Perry Ellis lines. The name was acquired by Salant after the death several years ago of Perry Ellis, the designer. Salant said it would transfer the Perry Ellis Collection for Women division to Perry Ellis International, owner of the trademark, and close the Perry Ellis Portfolio for Women. Salant is continuing the Perry Ellis America for Women and Perry Ellis for Men divisions. But because of the dispositions, Salant will take a one-time charge of $6.5 million in the second quarter ended July 1.

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $542,000 and $619,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,580,000 and $5,742,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.
