description: Summer Squall ran true to his record by remaining undefeated with a 1 1/2-length victory over Dr. Bobby A. today on a rainy afternoon at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Filly's Distant Admirer Getting a First Glimpse
description: The reputation of Peace Corps as one of trotting's greatest fillies had reached such proportions that last February she was purchased for a hefty $1.8 million, virtually sight unseen.

title: Debt Swapped In Nature Deal
description: Madagascar has arranged to cut its foreign debt burden by agreeing to hire 400 forest rangers, the World Wide Fund for Nature said today. Under the deal, the Indian

title: Inter-Tel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Army Corps Grants One-Year Approval For Prison on Barge
description: Plans by New York City to moor a prison barge on the Greenwich Village waterfront for up to five years, which had provoked local outrage, were quashed yesterday when the Army Corps of Engineers denied a permanent mooring application and issued a one-year permit instead.

title: What Shocked Me Most About the Flag Decision
description: LEAD: When I argued on behalf of Gregory Lee Johnson in the Texas flag-burning case before the Supreme Court last March, I had no idea that the eventual 5-4 opinion sustaining such activity as protected symbolic speech would cause such paroxysms of reaction. Nor did I ever suspect that some formerly unremitting defenders of the First

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15.

title: Review/Music; At Tanglewood, a Gruber Premiere
description: In recent years, the two concerts of Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music on Wednesday and Thursday have marked the festival's closing and climax.

title: New York H.U.D. Chief Reassigned
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has temporarily transferred the director of its New York office to an administrative position in Washington, pending the outcome of several investigations.

title: Law Helps Cubs Edge Pirates In the 9th
description: Vance Law broke a ninth-inning tie with a run-scoring single, and Ryne Sandberg and Mark Grace each hit a home run tonight to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The victory moved Chicago within one game of the first-place Montreal Expos in the National League East.

title: The Videotape Becomes A Sales Representative
description: For three years the Zenith Electronics Corporation packed a videotape with each of its videocassette recorders. The tape explained how to operate a videocassette recorder.

title: Battle Mountain Gold Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAEL IS PLEASED HOSTAGE IS SPARED
description: The Israeli Government was of two minds today about the latest turn in the hostage crisis, delighted that the American hostage Joseph James Cicippio had been spared for now but dubious that the group holding him is genuinely serious about negotiating an end to his captivity.

title: Morgan and Smurfit Study New Venture
description: The Morgan Stanley Group and the Jefferson Smurfit Group of Ireland said yesterday that they are considering forming a new venture that would acquire and merge their interests in two major paper and packaging concerns, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation and the Container Corporation of America. Sources familiar with the proposed transactions valued the deal at over $2 billion.

title: Bow Valley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said after preferred share dividens, net income in the year-ago 6 months equaled less than one cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Police Blamed in Deaths of British Soccer Fans
description: A judge leading the investigation into the disaster at an English soccer stadium last April blamed senior police officers today for the events, in which 95 people died.

title: Iranian Leader's Limits Are a Problem for Bush
description: As President Bush tries to resolve the hostage crisis, he is dealing with a new Iranian Government headed by a leader regarded here as more moderate and pragmatic than Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. But the new leader is being challenged by militant hard-liners in Teheran.

title: In War on Smog, Latest Target Is Paint
description: In the war against smog, the battle has moved from the smokestack and the tailpipe to the paint store.

title: Officers Implicated In Report on Death Of a Retarded Man
description: A mentally retarded man who died last month in a struggle with the police suffocated when the officers lay on him and cut off his breathing, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Money Isn't the Lure For Antarctic Trekker
description: To the Editor:

title: Railroad Insider Case Settled
description: Richard Schreiber, a former senior labor lawyer for the railroad unit of Burlington Northern Inc., this week settled Federal insider trading charges that he purchased Burlington stock and options while possessing nonpublic information about the company's planned restructuring last summer.

title: 6 Guards Dismissed Over Expense Padding
description: Six New York State prison guards have lost their jobs for filing padded expense vouchers, officials of the state's Department of Correctional Services said today.

title: Could Truman Pay His Bills?
description: LEAD: United States Presidents, upon retirement from office, hardly need worry about employment. A liberal pension is now provided, together with a variety of perquisites, and Ronald Reagan surely does not lack for appealing offers. It was not always so. Harry S. Truman, while in the Oval Office in April 1952, was deeply concerned about his future income.

title: 2 Mechanics Are Suspended After Blocks Are Found in Jet
description: Investigators have found that rubber wheel blocks were left in a Piedmont Airlines jet that had to land with one wheel up in North Carolina, and the airline said today that it had suspended two mechanics.

title: Khmer Rouge: Not the Murderers They Were
description: LEAD: Making sense of the Cambodian peace process is like counting the spokes of a spinning wheel. Nevertheless, after the first week of the ministerial conference in Paris, at least three major changes are evident.

title: Egon Orowan, 87, Engineering Professor
description: Egon Orowan, a professor emeritus of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Wednesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Review/Ballet; London Festival Takes On a Royal Danish Work
description: The Royal Danish Ballet it is not. That was the least to be said about the London Festival Ballet on Thursday night when it introduced its own full-evening version of ''Napoli,'' the Copenhagen company's signature piece.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; If Frozen Food Thaws
description: Power failures during summer thunderstorms are always a hazard. Here is some advice from the United States Department of Agriculture on what to do with frozen foods when the electricity goes out. First, open the freezer as little as possible. A full, freestanding freezer will hold its temperature for about two days; a half-full freezer about one day. Most frozen food that has been kept above 40 degrees Fahrenheit for more than two hours should be discarded. Hard cheese, butter and margarine can be refrozen or refrigerated. If you are uncertain about frozen food, follow these guidelines: $ Ice crystals Thawed but held still intact, above 40 degrees F food still cold under 2 hours (40F or under) Beef, veal, lamb, Refreeze Cook and serve, or pork, poultry cook and refreeze. Variety meats Use within 48 hours Cook and serve (kidney, liver, etc.) Do not refreeze. immediately. Casseroles, stews, Cook and refreeze Cook (or reheat pies immediately or thoroughly) and serve. Do not re- serve immediately. freeze previously cooked dishes. Foods containing Cook and serve Discard. dairy items immediately.

title: Paul Tortelier, a Cellist Of Political Commitment
description: When the French cellist Paul Tortelier appeared in April with the New York Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y, he ended a 35-year absence from New York City concert stages. While such a long time away may seem peculiar, Mr. Tortelier offers a simple explanation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bombardier Inc., Montreal, a maker of railroad engines and equipment and high-speed trains, said its Canadair unit signed a $200 million (Canadian) contract to sell 10 new Canadair CL-215 firefighting amphibians and 15 CL-215T turboprop retrofit kits to the Spanish Government. Deliveries will begin in 1990.

title: On-Time Flights Slip In June, U.S. Reports
description: Severe weather on the East Coast in June caused major airlines to slip in the number of flights that arrived on time, the Transportation Department said Thursday.

title: Dollar Jumps; Selling by Fed Is Reported
description: The dollar rose sharply against major currencies yesterday after the employment report for July convinced many traders that the economy was not slowing down sharply and that there was therefore less reason to expect the Federal Reserve to move interest rates lower soon.

title: Dorsett's Knee Surgery Puts Career on the Line
description: The Denver Broncos' running back, Tony Dorsett, suffered a torn ligament in his left knee and possible other damage, placing his career in jeopardy, the team's trainer, Steve Antonopulos, said today.

title: Arrow Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,332,000 for the quarter and $4,378,000 for the 6 months. Latest second quarter and 6 months' share earnings for both periods were less than one cent a share. The company recorded $6.3 million of operating income in the second despite general softness in the semiconductor market.

description: An Air Force captain assigned to the electronics-security unit of an airfield in West Berlin, an important military intelligence-gathering and communications post, is suspected of spying, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Glasnost Throws Light on Soviet Union's Birth Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; A New and Disputed Push To Ease Design Protection
description: When people think about patents, they usually envision a new machine or new drug. But the Patent and Trademark Office also issues design patents that protect the distinctive styling and appearance of everything from tennis shoes to toaster ovens.

Bridge

description: The Senate ethics committee is investigating whether Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican, violated the law or evaded Senate limits on speaking fees by taking payments for a book promotion deal and by letting trade groups pay for personal travel, the panel said today.

description: Ivory Coast, the world's biggest cocoa grower, said today it had signed an agreement to sell a record 500,000 metric tons of next year's crop, a deal that is almost certain to help the country's flagging economy.

title: Motel 6 L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings are in units.

title: Goldin Proposes Plan to Combat Juvenile Crime
description: Charging that New York City's government has failed to respond forcefully to an ''epidemic of juvenile crime,'' Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin called yesterday for harsher punishments for young offenders.

description: Year-ago third-quarter results included a non-recurring charge of $2.2 million on the disposition of a hotel, and both year-ago periods included $2.2 million after-tax gains from the disposition of assets.

title: IRAN'S PRESIDENT OFFERS U.S. HELP IN HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: Iran's new President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, offered today to help end the hostage crisis in Lebanon, a move that President Bush said would be explored ''to the fullest.''

title: Quaker Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
14 Companies Are Fined
description: The European Commission said today that it had fined 14 European Community producers of welded steel mesh more than $10 million for operating an illegal cartel. The commission, the European Community's executive body, said in a statement that the companies had operated a cartel between 1981 and November 1985 that involved agreements to set market shares, fix prices and restrict exports. The Treaty of Rome, which established the European Community, outlaws agreements between companies that restrict competition. The highest fine, equivalent to $5 million, was imposed on Baustahlgewebe of West Germany.

title: House and Senate Pass Plan To Rescue Savings and Loans
description: Wrapping up an intensive six-month effort, the House gave final approval early this morning to a monumental plan to rescue the savings and loan industry, two hours after approval by the Senate.

title: Diane M. Murray Marries a Teacher
description: Diane Margaret Murray, the daughter of Mrs. Morgan T. Murray of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Mr. Murray, was married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Hewlett, L.I., to Kenneth John Monk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Monk of Chorley, Lancashire, England. The Rev. William Galvin performed the ceremony.

title: The Yankees And That Hollow Look
description: This is the time of year the manager of the Yankees traditionally wears a look like a raccoon, with big dark circles around his eyes. These somber shadows are brought on by fatigue, anguish, grief and dyspepsia, all of which are synonyms for George Steinbrenner.

title: Soviet Pilots Star at Oshkosh Show
description: Each summer this city of 50,000, best-known for the brand of overalls that bears its name, becomes home to what has been called the aeronautical equivalent of Woodstock: the world's largest annual air show and fly-in.

description: The company said year-ago figures have been restated.

title: Injured Austin Replaced
description: The New Jersey Stars of the Domino's Pizza TeamTennis league announced yesterday that Tracy Austin, who was in an automobile accident Thursday in Short Hills, N.J., suffered a broken bone in her right leg in the crash and was being cared for at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. The Stars' coach, Asim Sengun, named Leigh Thompson, a 25-year-old former touring pro who is now the women's tennis coach at Maryland, to replace Austin.

description: Herman J. Cohen, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, arrived today for talks with the Ethiopian Government, the first by a high American official since 1978.

Islanders Sign Henning As Assistant to Arbour
description: Lorne Henning, who played all nine of his seasons in the National Hockey League with the Islanders and played a role in their four Stanley Cup championships, is returning to the team as an assistant to Coach Al Arbour. Henning, whose playing career ended in the 1980-81 season, signed a contract ''lasting more than one year,'' the Islanders announced yesterday.

title: Author Misidentified
description: To the Editor:

title: Number of Jobs Rises as Jobless Rate Holds Steady
description: In a report suggesting surprising economic buoyance, the Labor Department announced today that the number of jobs increased by 169,000 in July and that after three straight monthly decreases the ranks of factory workers edged up.

title: Rise and Fall of Key Player at H.U.D.
description: As Thomas T. Demery, former Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, tells it, he came away from an early meeting with his chief, Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., with a very distinct impression.

title: Lumex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Richard Macgill, 78, Former Bank Executive
description: Richard G. Macgill, former chairman of the New Jersey National Bank, died Tuesday at the Medical Center at Princeton (N.J.), after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: WASHING CHLORINE AWAY
description: Swimming in a chlorinated pool can leave hair dry and brittle. Hair absorbs chlorine, which bleaches it and breaks down protein bonds. Those who color their hair or have permanents are particularly vulnerable to damage because chemically treated hair is more porous.

title: About New York; Process Server Makes a Living With Duplicity
description: James Haigney - who just might be the only process server who uses a wheelchair - has been known to, well, lie. Just ask the man in Queens who eagerly came to the door to hear about the big money he had won from Publishers Clearing House, only to be slapped with a subpoena.

title: General Datacomm Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago third quarter loss included $6 million of charges for restructuring and consolidation activities. Year-ago 9 months included $7.9 million in restructuring charges.

title: Review/Opera; Old China's Simple Intricacies
description: The idea behind ''A Night at the Chinese Opera'' is both simple and as intricate as a set of Chinese boxes. Judith Weir, a Scottish composer, has inserted into her three-act work an actual 13th-century Chinese play that appears to parallel the life of the opera's protagonist, a civil engineer named Chao Lin, who misinterprets it and tries to use it to predict his own destiny. But Chao has an appointment with Death, who is not so easily outwitted.

title: Bond Prices Tumble on Jobs Data
description: Treasury bond prices tumbled yesterday in response to a surprisingly strong employment report from the Labor Department.

title: Congress Agrees: Time to Go
description: Harried members churned through last-minute business, poised for the dash to the airport and the long August recess. Page 9.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATRUDAY, AUGUST 5, 1989
description: Economy

title: In Enclave, Mayor's Race Hinges on Crime
description: Every afternoon at 3 o'clock, a private patrol car begins rolling through one of the prettiest neighborhoods in Brooklyn. It cruises under canopies of ailanthus and maple trees, past unbroken rows of 19th-century brownstones, chocolate-rich and crisply preserved, with their jaunty window bays and welcoming stoops.

title: Your Money; Rules Clarified On 'Safe Harbors'
description: Thanks to a recently proposed addition to Federal tax regulations, thousands of executives who received ''golden parachute'' payments in the last three years, after their employers merged or were taken over, may be able to file amended income tax returns and claim refunds. Others who were especially aggressive in classifying the payments - as stock options perhaps -may be notified by the Internal Revenue Service that additional taxes, plus interest, are owed.

title: RISE FOR WEEK IS 18.21
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, depressed by losses in the bond market after a surprisingly strong July employment report allayed fears of recession and dampened hopes of further declines in interest rates.

title: Sun-Philips Pact
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said it would announce a significant agreement with Philips N.V. of the Netherlands on Tuesday. Philips Components, the largest semiconductor supplier in Europe, will announce plans to produce a number of derivatives of Sun's Sparc microprocessor, which is based on reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. Philips will be Sun's first European licensee. Sun said the agreement had strategic importance in light of expected European-content requirements coming in 1992. The link with Philips also continues Sun's drive to establish Sparc as an industry standard. Sun has already licensed Sparc to the Toshiba Corporation, Fujitsu Ltd. and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan and to several Taiwan-based personal computer manufacturers.

title: Air Midwest Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $145,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Arabs Feel Anger Flare In New York
description: The Rashid family has had their Arabic record and book store on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn Heights since 1947. They are Arabs, yes, but proud Americans, too.

title: Traveling Along In French Circles
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Colgate's Next Trick: Controlling the Chaos
description: In a funny sort of way, Reuben Mark is suffering from too much success.

title: 'Soft' Concerns About the Truth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EXISTENTIAL MURDER
description: THE EXECUTION OF JUSTICE By Friedrich Durrenmatt. Translated by John E. Woods. 216 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: It's Perfectly Clear (At Least Some of the Time)
description: THERE was a time, not too long ago, that I could see everything. I could thread any needle, dial the telephone without squinting, read the Playbill in a darkened theater and study the minuscule list of ingredients in all the things I shouldn't have been eating in the first place.

title: Review/Theater; Sondheim's Romanesque Burlesque
description: The funny thing that is happening near Interstate 95, a road otherwise outstanding for tragically bottlenecked traffic on the New England trade route, is the musical that is opening the season for the American Festival Theater here.

title: And Then There Was One
description: In 1920, the third largest expenditure of South Carolina was payments to Confederate Army veterans and their widows. This year it was $2,600, the annual payment that went last month to Daisy Cave of Sumter, who is believed to be 97 years old. Mrs. Cave is the last living widow of a Confederate veteran, a status she has held since Kate Nelms died in Corinth, Miss., in 1987. Mrs. Cave was in her 20's when she married Henry Benjamin Cave, then 75, in 1919. Times were hard and many young women in the South married older men who had veterans' benefits. She said she never pressed her husband to talk about the War Between the States. The tales of the war, she said, ''have been told so many times, they done rusted.''

title: Smart Parent Quiz
description: THIS is a parents' alert. In a few weeks, your children will be back in school. Which means homework. And questions - lots of questions. Many will be the kind of questions to which you know you once knew the answers, but for which your only response now will be a panicky expression (which you hope your child doesn't see) and either a mumbled response or a ''Sweetheart, why don't we ask (fill in the blank with name of spouse or grandparents - they told you, didn't they?). If the child is old enough, you might suggest looking it up. (Many an encyclopedia has been bought for this very purpose.) The quiz that follows should get you primed for the autumn onslaught. The questions were culled from among teachers and parents nationwide, who cited them as some of the most frequently asked. Now, memorize the answers, on page 16. You'll be retested next month.

title: Women's Caucus Is Focusing on Abortion Rights
description: The National Women's Political Caucus, a group that has often been overshadowed by feminist organizations with sharper demands, pledged this weekend to work within the two-party system and to make abortion rights the focus of its work in the next year.

title: Correction
description: A chart last week accompanying an article about the Harvard Business Review provided an incorrect scale for measuring the publication's advertising pages. The figures showed the number of advertising pages, not a multiple of that number.

title: 18 KILLED IN BEIRUT AS BATTLES RESUME
description: Eighteen people were killed and 55 wounded in Christian East Beirut today in renewed artillery exchanges between Christian and Syrian forces, the police said.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE number of public one-room schools, schools with one teacher for the first eight grades, has decreased because of population growth and the increased busing of students to central sites. There were nearly 150,000 public one-room schools in 1930; in 1971 there were less than 2,000, and in 1987 about 700. However, the decline has been offset by an increase in private one-room schools. In 1971 there were fewer than 200 such schools; as of 1987 there were more than 600, of which Amish and other Mennonite groups account for more than 80 percent. In 1972 the United States Supreme Court upheld the prerogative of the Amish to maintain their own schools. - - Dr. Mark W. Dewalt, Susquehanna University, ''One-room Schools in the United States''

title: Death, Too, Zips Along Montana's Highways
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ IN ESSEX

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SOMEONE WONDERFUL. By Barbara Neil. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $17.95.) With her second novel, Barbara Neil has given us a new love story in fine old British tradition. At its center is private, gentle Lily Teape. Orphaned at the age of 6 and left to grandparents who refuse to believe that she's a relation, Lily faces a dreary childhood.

title:
GARDENING;
Safeguarding Irises and Peonies
description: LEAD: PLANTINGS of irises and peonies have been known to last for more than 50 years, especially those at family plots in old cemeteries. While not entirely free of problems, these durable perennials are extremely long lived and require relatively little care. Caretakers at cemeteries have had to do little more than the remove spent flowers or an occasional weed.

title: Police in South Africa Clash With Mourners
description: Thousands of mourners defied armed South African police today to bury two student supporters of the African National Congress. Later, the mourners clashed with the police after the officers tried to disperse them with tear gas.

title: The Grandparent Business: Not So Simple Any More
description: THERE I was, breezing along in my early 50's, feeling pretty sure of myself professionally and personally when nincompoopery suddenly set in. My daughter and son-in-law, parents for just under 10 weeks, had asked if we would baby-sit while they went to eat at a fancy place with a view of the Manhattan skyline. We were delighted. Of course we would watch our first grandchild.

title: A CORRECTION: THE UNINSURED
description: This is a corrected version of a chart that appeared July 30 with an article about people in the United States who lack health insurance. This chart shows people under age 65 without health insurance, by family income. Population figures are in millions Source: Employee Benefit Research Institute.

title: For Singles, With Children
description: A RENTAL complex in this incorporated ''city within a city'' in Denver is trying to attract single parents and small families by offering child-care and self-help money-saving services.

title: Parklike Cemeteries Used For Leisure-Time Pursuits
description: LEAD: LONG ISLANDERS searching for peace, quiet and open space increasingly are finding those features in a place little thought of as a recreational center: their local cemeteries.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's possible, of course, that the people with really big money and really big-bucks possessions would feel differently about what they'd most hate to lose or have stolen from them. It's asking too much to believe that they would rather lose an important diamond ring than an unimportant ring with a four-generation background of nostalgia.

title: Design: Western Flair; Rough and Ready
description: The look is easily identifiable: Navajo blankets and beautifully handcrafted clay pots, rough-hewn furniture and cactus plants. Indeed, Western artifacts are as much a part of the American design culture as Shaker or Colonial objects. But rather than creating a total down-home environment, those who embrace this Western esthetic today tend to happily transplant elements of it in relatively small doses, placing just a few objects in modern settings.

title: Boo Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Theodore Austin Weds Martha Fetter
description: Martha Sue Fetter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Fetter of Wintergreen, Va., and Ludlow, Vt., was married yesterday to Theodore Mark Austin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Austin of Haverford, Pa., in a nondenominational service at the Calvin Coolidge Memorial Foundation Church in Plymouth, Vt. The Rev. Carroll Goodridge, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: FLASHCARD
description: HARVARD and Radcliffe Colleges enrolled the largest number of freshman National Merit Scholars named in 1988, 5 percent of the total. Over all, there were 6,210 freshman Merit winners; almost three-fifths of them enrolled at 234 private schools and the rest at 156 public institutions. - National Merit Scholarship Corporation

title: A Boom, As Nature Fails to Satisfy Demand
description: Although fish have been farmed in this country for more than 30 years, aquaculture has never been what you would call a booming business. Most of the entrepreneurs who dominate the business lack the resources and sophistication to bring their fish to the mass market.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: When you hear the words ''Leica camera,'' what adjectives spring to mind? My list runs as follows: indestructible, mechanical, professional, expensive. Photojournalists who have to take pictures on the run might add ''indispensable.'' Of course, we would all be thinking of M series Leicas, rangefinder cameras with interchangeable lenses and the durability of wrought iron.

title: Plan for Hydroelectric Project At Old Mine Upsets Residents
description: MAYOR Charles E. Lombardo, a former local Planning Board chairman, has grown accustomed to this northern Morris County community's struggles during the last decade over the use of an old mine tract.

title: RAYMOND CARVER: A STILL, SMALL VOICE
description: A year after his death, the recurring image I associate with Raymond Carver is one of people leaning toward him, working very hard at the act of listening. He mumbled. T. S. Eliot once described Ezra Pound, qua mentor, as ''a man trying to convey to a very deaf person the fact that the house is on fire.'' Raymond Carver had precisely the opposite manner. The smoke could be filling the room, flames streaking across the carpet, before Carver would ask, ''Is it, uh, getting a little hot in here, maybe?'' And you would be sitting in your chair, bent achingly forward at the waist, saying, ''Beg pardon, Ray?'' Never insisting, rarely asserting, he was an unlikely teacher. I once sat in and listened while Carver was interviewed for two and a half hours. The writer conducting the interview moved the tape recorder closer and closer and finally asked if Carver would put it in his lap. A few days later the interviewer called up, near despair: Ray's voice on the tapes was nearly inaudible. The word ''soft-spoken'' hardly begins to do justice to his speech; this condition was aggravated whenever he was pressed into the regions of generality or prescription.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: The equation, art plus government equals controversy is just as true today as it was in 1907 when Augustus Saint-Gaudens sought to redesign the $20 gold piece.

title: Duffel Coats Are Losing Their Old Utilitarian Image
description: The duffel coat is moving up the fashion ladder. This upwardly mobile style started as a rugged coat for country wear and bad weather, made in sturdy fabrics like loden cloth. Leather toggles anchored it securely, a hood that buttoned under the chin kept out the wind, and the fabric was frequently water resistant so it would keep out the rain.

title: All in the Game
description: Unlike most women, Ami Radunskya is partial to mathematics. But then hers was not a typical woman's upbringing.

title: The Moment to Free All Hostages
description: In the current brief respite from hostage-killing, President Bush may have an opportunity to arrange a swap of all hostages, and perhaps even to reach an understanding of sorts with states sponsoring terrorism.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; For the Flavor of Jazz and the Spirit of Ziegfeld
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Reviews from the A La Carte column have no ratings. A Taste of Paris

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SUNDAY IN THE PARKS

Jackson $189,900 79 Bethel Church Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1-year-old contemporary; 2-car garage, den, patio; taxes $3,000. Livingston $155,000 262 North Livingston Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,591. Millburn $260,000 165 Myrtle Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; den, deck, eat-in-kitchen, h/w floors; taxes $2,956. North Brunswick $119,900 1905 Crocus Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 23-year-old colonial; family room, full basement, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,152. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $450,000 Beech Hill Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 16-year-old New England barn; fireplace and cathedral ceiling in living room, library, den, family room, loft, deck w/hot tub, brook, 3-car garage, 3.45 acres; taxes $6,622.
