title: Labor Forms Potent Alliance for Dinkins
description: Labor unions, including many representing New York City workers, have mounted their most intense campaign in recent years for a mayoral candidate, Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

title: The Hostages: Fear and Hope
description: There was new danger but also new hope for hostages in Lebanon last week. The captors' complex motives make the outcome highly unpredictable. The Week in Review, section 4.

title: Lunatics and Lovers in Airy Comedy
description: RICHARD DRESSER doesn't dawdle when he sets up a play. In the Phoenix Theater Company's production of ''Alone at the Beach,'' five singles in their 30's have answered an ad for a summer share in the Hamptons - and each has been instantly accepted by George, the owner of the beach house.

title: Miss Combemale, Designer, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Pamela Pauline Combemale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Combemale of New York and Winthrop, Me., to Paul Robert Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter K. Murphy of Bonn, took place yesterday in Wilton, Conn. Edward Rimer, a Wilton justice of the peace, officiated at the Old Town Hall. Mrs. Murphy owns Pamela Combemale Inc., an interior design concern in New York. Her father is the president of INCA Management, a financial advisory company in New York.

title: Senator's Criticism of Israel Leads to Party Dispute
description: In an unusual dispute in the Republican Party, Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has denounced Senator Bob Dole for criticizing a commando raid in which Israeli soldiers seized a Muslim cleric in Lebanon.

title: 'Workshop Sharecroppers'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Unspoken Reunion
description: When Frank Viola joined the Mets in their locker room in Busch Stadium, St. Louis, last Tuesday afternoon, he and Ron Darling shook hands and smiled and exchanged pleasantries. But they didn't talk about ''the game.'' They didn't have to; it's been there, in the records and in their memories ever since they pitched in it against each other and made college baseball history.

title: Pierce Helped His Old Law Firm On H.U.D. Requests, Files Show
description: Despite a pledge during his Senate confirmation hearings to ''sever'' his ties to his former New York law firm, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. regularly did personal favors for his former colleagues and interceded with subordinates in the Department of Housing and Urban Development on their behalf, documents from his office files show.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
After 12 Years, Glen Cove's Regaining Movies
description: LEAD: A 30,000-SQUARE-FOOT building containing a sixplex cinema and 4,000 square feet of retail space under construction in downtown Glen Cove marks the most recent phase of the city's urban renewal program.

title: Diana de Brito and Jonathan Gottlieb, Lawyers, Are Married in Tarrytown
description: Diana Rosalina de Brito, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Dantas de Brito of New York and Port Chester, N.Y., was married last evening at Biddle House in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Jonathan Edward Gottlieb, a son of Bobbie E. Gottlieb of New York and Rye, N.Y., and the late Robert P. Gottlieb. Rabbi Mark L. Weiner performed the ceremony.

title: Air Force Suspect Reportedly Had Access to Codes
description: A United States Air Force captain who is under investigation on espionage allegations had access to codes used for Air Force communications at a vital intelligence post in West Berlin, military officials said today.

title: 2 Years to Go For Shoemaker
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rietveld's Little House Looms Large
description: A SEVERE yet friendly rectangular box, the Schroder house is semidetached, at the end of a row of brick houses on Prins Hendriklaan in Utrecht. It looks startling today; when it was built in 1924, it must have shocked everyone.

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: I can inform Joseph Epstein that there is nothing wrong with the conscience-and-guilt appeal in battling racism. The civil-rights movement grasped in its early years - in the budding days of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People - that conscience and guilt are two sides of the same moral coin, and that any society claiming to be civilized must wrestle with both conscience and guilt when rectifying the wounds it creates. In the lengthy process of mending our wrongs, guilt functions as a spur to conscience. MARTIN KILSON Professor of Government Harvard University Cambridge, Mass.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: QUIDDITIES: An Intermittently Philosophical Dictionary, by W. V. Quine. (Belknap/Harvard University, $9.95.) Beginning with ''Alphabet'' and ending with ''Zero,'' one of the century's great logicians writes miniature essays on ''Atoms,'' ''Etymology,'' ''Fermat's Last Theorem,'' ''Redundancy,'' ''Rhetoric'' and other favorite themes. The book ''is infused with a deadpan humor that can light up even the most austere subjects,'' John Gross said in The Times in 1987. ''At almost every turn there are cheerful ripples of wordplay,'' as in the title, which at various times has meant essence, a subtle distinction and a quibble. PARIS TROUT, by Pete Dexter. (Penguin, $7.95.) After a Georgia shopkeeper named Paris Trout kills a 14-year-old black girl, the people in the town of Cotton Point try to convince themselves that they are somehow different from their racist, paranoid neighbor. ''Mr. Dexter's strongest suit is his exquisite understanding of the finely meshed engines of greed, appetite and self-interest that drive a small town,'' Deborah Mason said in The Book Review last year. '' [ His ] great accomplishment is to remind us, with lucidity and stinging frankness, the lengths to which we will go to deny our own racism and to reassure ourselves that we are innocent.'' The novel won the National Book Award. Penguin has also republished DEADWOOD ($7.95), Mr. Dexter's story about Wild Bill Hickok and his deranged friends. In 1986 our reviewer, Ron Hansen, said the novel is ''unpredictable, hyperbolic and, page after page, uproarious.'' VIDEO NIGHT IN KATHMANDU: And Other Reports From the Not-So-Far-East, by Pico Iyer. (Vintage, $9.95.) A British journalist finds that some of the weirdest things in Asia come from the ''Coca-Colonizing forces'' of America's ''pop-cultural imperialism'': fern bars in Bali, apartments in Tibet decked out like Greenwich Village pads. ''His travels have yielded a meticulously observed and reported book,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year, ''a magical mystery tour through the brave new world of Asia.'' FRYE STREET & ENVIRONS: The Collected Works of Marita Bonner, edited by Joyce Flynn and Joyce Occomy Stricklin. (Beacon, $9.95.) This collection of fiction, plays and essays by one of America's pre-eminent black writers includes short stories about ghetto life that are ''hard, unrelenting [ and ] rendered with exquisite craftsmanship, with a brevity like a master's ink sketch of brash strokes that reveal everything,'' Doris Jean Austin said here in 1988. FAMILY OF SPIES: Inside the John Walker Spy Ring, by Pete Earley. (Bantam, $4.95.) When John Walker, an officer in the Navy, started peddling secrets to the Soviet Union, he was motivated not by ideology but by greed. Pete Earley, who had to pay Mr. Walker for his story, exposes ''his superficially slick but profoundly distorted mind,'' Lucinda Franks said here in January. ''The result is an unusually penetrating portrait of the banality of evil, of a psychology that usually defies intimate understanding - the narcissist whose rationalizations make his wrongdoing seem almost normal.'' THE RAT, by Gunter Grass. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Harvest/Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $9.95.) In a concatenation of stories within stories, Gunter Grass tells of the dawning of the posthuman age when the world is overrun by rats. ''This exhilarating, exhausting, maddening, brilliant, funny and profoundly disturbing novel is about the end of mankind, the end of plot, the end of syntax, the end of language,'' Janette Turner Hospital said here in 1987. The same publisher has also reissued Mr. Grass's 1978 novel, THE FLOUNDER ($11.95). Our reviewer, Morris Dickstein, described it as ''a gargantuan fable that spans a period from the Stone Age to the 1970's . . . [ an ] exuberantly inventive work.'' A GODLESS JEW: Freud, Atheism, and the Making of Psychoanalysis, by Peter Gay. (Yale University, $9.95.) The author of the recent biography ''Freud: A Life for Our Time'' contended in this earlier work that atheism was more of an influence than Judaism on the founding of psychoanalysis. Mr. Gay uses ''great sensitivity and insight'' to argue against those who characterize psychoanalysis as a Jewish science or a form of religion, one reviewer said in 1987. THE NIGHT OF THE WEEPING WOMEN, by Lawrence Naumoff. (Ivy, $3.95.) After a young couple move to a farmhouse in North Carolina, they each take a cue from their parents and start having marital difficulties. Last year our reviewer, Valerie Gladstone, said ''this tight, intense first novel . . . makes suffocation look like a lot more fun than marriage.'' MUSINGS: The Musical Worlds of Gunther Schuller, by Gunther Schuller. (Oxford University, $11.95.) The composer Gunther Schuller tries to break down the walls between artistic domains, combining the rigors of classical composition with the inspiration of jazz. In 1986 our reviewer, Carol J. Oja, said these essays are ''a joy to read. . . . 'Musings' reveals the exuberance and depth of his work.'' THE TRIARCHIC MIND: A New Theory of Human Intelligence, by Robert J. Sternberg. (Penguin, $8.95.) A Yale University psychologist argues that intelligence is not a single abstract quality that can be measured like temperature, pressure or the brightness of light. The best I.Q. test is life itself and how successfully we negotiate its corridors. This book is ''a lively popular account of his work on intelligence,'' Philip N. Johnson-Laird said here last year. ''The book is laced with tests for the reader to take and tips on how to improve intelligence - the faculty rather than the test score.''

title: Officials Issue Warning on Tainted Clams
description: State health officials were warning seafood lovers to be on the lookout for poisonous clams shipped from Maine to four cities in upstate New York.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
A Picking Manual For Guest Harvesters
description: LEAD: Devoted gardeners do not travel in summer. If they do, they limit their journeys to a few days in late May between the spinach, early lettuce and June pea or risk a few days in early July between the last of the peas and the first green beans and summer squash.

title: At Last, a Plan That Reduces the Pain
description: The Mexican debt agreement is good for both Mexico and the banks. Mexican negotiators asked for 55 percent reduction in either principal or interest, or an 80 percent refinancing of 6 years of interest payments. The banks met Mexico more than two-thirds of the way with a 35 percent reduction of debt or interest payments or a 60 percent refinancing of interest payments over four years. This outcome should meet Mexico's financing needs, especially with oil prices and world interest rates currently more favorable than assumed in Mexico's original calculations.

title: Labonte to Start a New Winston Team
description: Immediately after Terry Labonte won the 500-mile NASCAR Winston Cup race at Talladega Superspeedway last Sunday, he confirmed a rumor that had been circulating for months. At the end of this season, he announced, he would leave the Junior Johnson team and start his own Winston Cup team.

title: Using Capers as More Than Decorations
description: CAPERS are much underused in our cooking; their function is mostly decorative. We put them on top of hors d'oeuvres or mix them into the occasional steak tartare, but we rarely do anything particularly creative with them. Recently, while on holiday in Italy, on the border of Umbria and Tuscany, I came across the best capers I have ever tasted (they were good enough to eat on their own, like olives) and discovered some interesting ways of using them as more than a mere garnish.

title: Freedom Summer Legacies
description: THERE are certain things I remember about our family's long summer trips from the land of Lincoln into the heart of Dixie. I remember the blinding sun reflecting off the windshields of approaching cars; the heat blowing through the windows upon my parents, my brother, my sister and me, and the black .38 pistol my father packed in the glove compartment.

title: NONFICTION
description: CLEARING THE BASES: Baseball Then and Now. By Bill Starr. (Michael Kesend, $18.95.) Ty Cobb was not as good as his .367 career batting average, say the baseball computer analysts; if he were playing today he would hit only .289. That only proves Cobb's greatness, say the critics of such analysis - .289 is impressive hitting for a 102-year-old. Bill Starr, a minor-league player in the 1930's and owner of the San Diego Padres of the Pacific Coast League until 1955, says that the players of the 1920's and 30's get a bum rap. It is wrong to assume that because athletes are generally faster, bigger and stronger than in the old days, baseball players necessarily are better, Mr. Starr says in ''Clearing the Bases.'' Those traits make for better football and basketball players, but baseball depends on hand skills more akin to those used in golf, and quickness rather than foot speed. The theory that a lively ball created higher batting averages in the 20's and 30's is bunk, says Mr. Starr. Rather, Babe Ruth established that hitting drew fans and a higher salary, and players altered their bats and styles in Ruth's image. Mr. Starr cranks out his own statistics to show that players of the old days managed to hit the long ball while keeping strikeouts - much more an embarrassment then than now - to a minimum. Mr. Starr emphasizes that his book is no nostalgia trip. Too bad, for as he makes these and various other cases with quotes from old-timers, the reader gets too-brief glimpses of a time when all manner of spitballs were common, owners figured one ball should last a whole game and crowds milled around the outfield during games.

title: Tokyo Settles on a New Prime Minister
description: Toshiki Kaifu, a former minister of education with little background in foreign or economic affairs, was virtually assured today of election as the next Prime Minister of Japan when four of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's five faction leaders endorsed him.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Japanese Taxes Take Prices Up, and Down

title: HER PSYCHIC HAD A HEADACHE
description: REMEMBERING THE BONE HOUSE An Erotics of Place and Space. By Nancy Mairs. 273 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Twice-Told Tales Can Cast a Spell
description: Scarlett O'Hara, weeping at the bottom of her grand, gauche staircase, vows, ''I'll find a way to get him back. After all, tomorrow is another day!'' Margaret Mitchell's brilliant open ending has kept audiences arguing about Scarlett's resourcefulness for more than 50 years. But if ''Gone With the Wind'' had first appeared in the sequel-mad summer of 1989, Scarlett's famous final line would hold the sure promise of ''Gone With the Wind II.''

title: Suede, Often in Anything but Black, Is Riding High
description: Forget the black leather motorcycle jacket and the tight black leather pants. Think about a fringed suede jacket and suede jodhpurs or jeans. That's the style that promises to lead the fashion pack this fall.

title: What's Government Doing in the Arts Anyway?; For Common Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: STREETSCAPES: The Loth Silk Factory; A Ghost Coming to Life In Washington Heights
description: IT should be the centerpiece of a 19th-century New England mill town, a long, low, brick mill building surrounded by tenements. But Joseph Loth's silk factory, completed in 1886, is not in Massachusetts or New Hampshire. It is on the west side of Amsterdam Avenue between 150th and 151st Streets.

title: A Steady Observer for Trembling Moodus
description: IN Moodus, they call her the Earthquake Lady. Each time the ground moves, the windows of Cathy Wilson's house rattle and the stereo speakers that hang on the wall shake. At times, loud thumps send ripples through her water bed, waking her at all hours of the night. And sometimes, rumbling jackhammer-like noises from below send her 20 cats scattering in every direction.

title: THE SUMMER REPORT: Endpaper; New Kid On Campus
description: EVERY NOW AND THEN I come across articles in magazines or letters to the editor describing the problems that older people have with their spare time at retirement. As a rule they go to Florida that first winter, then on to other parts of the nation, until they get the wanderlust out of their systems. Major repair and replacement projects around the home take up more of their time. But not for long. They sign up at a local high school for classes in painting and music, calligraphy and all the other things they thought they would like as hobbies. But the short-term nature of these classes soon finds them in need of something deeper to which they can apply themselves.

title: STEVE JOBS: OUT FOR REVENGE
description: STEVE JOBS, SHIRT SLEEVES rolled up to his elbows, long hair over his collar, sits like a virtuoso at the keyboard of his new computer. Behind him, projected onto a huge screen, computer images -silvery letters and symbols - expand and shrink, leap and pop about as Jobs puts the machine through its paces. An audience of 200 business people watches as he demonstrates how, in seconds, the computer can find a reference buried in the complete works of Shakespeare or create a model of a bouncing molecule. Speakers boom out a message by way of the voice-mail system, and then broadcast a snatch of Bach - ''synthesized,'' Jobs boasts, ''from pure mathematics.''

title: High Health Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, Mozambique Sees a Way to Halt Its Own Devastation
description: THE statistics recited by Mozambique's President Joaquim Chissano have testified to the grim effects of more than a decade of vicious guerrilla war - 600,000 to 700,000 Mozambicans dead in a land of 15 million, an additional 1.6 million displaced as refugees, 2,599 primary schools and 822 rural health clinics destroyed or forced to close, 44 factories and more than 1,000 stores ruined.

title: INSIDE
description: Savings Banks Saved, Congress Heads Home

title: Disaster Leads to Safety on the High Seas
description: Until 10 years ago, the fatalities in post-World War II sailboat races could be counted on four or five hands. Occasionally, a sailor might fall overboard and drown, and a boat would disappear with all hands. Never was it said that sailing was as predictably risky as mountain climbing or powerboat racing. But on Aug. 13, 1979, in a day of storm and terror, 15 yachtsmen were killed in waters between England and Ireland when hurricane-strength winds and 50-foot breaking waves overwhelmed the 303 ocean-racing keel boats in the Fastnet Race.

title: David Carleton And Karin Malin Exchange Vows
description: Karin Elizabeth Malin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Malin Jr. of New York and Canaan, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York to David Ernest Carleton, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. William L. Carleton of Kent, Wash. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William A. Amstein and the bridegroom's father, the minister of the First Presbyterian Church in Kent.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Bernie S. Siegel; 'If You Enjoy Living, You Live Longer'
description: THE greatest disease of mankind is a lack of love, according to the surgeon and author Bernie S. Siegel, who advocates that the body can be healed through the mind. Dr. Siegel talks about caring, not curing; living, not merely postponing death through medical intervention, and above all loving oneself and others.

title: Paolo Baffi Dies at 77; Headed Italian Bank
description: Paolo Baffi, the former governor of Italy's central bank, died on Friday night after a long illness, the bank announced today. He was 77 years old. The bank did not disclose the illness. Mr. Baffi, one of the major economic figures in postwar Italy, worked for 40 years with the Bank of Italy, the country's central bank. As its governor from 1975 to 1979, he shaped Italian monetary policy. He introduced the statistical system still used to analyze monetary and credit issues.

title: Wendy Bermant Is Married in Rye
description: The marriage of Wendy Lynn Bermant, a daughter of Ruth C. Bermant of Purchase, N.Y., and David W. Bermant of Rye, N.Y., to Gregory Richard Lynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Lynn of New Canaan, Conn., took place last evening at the Westchester Country Club in Rye. Cantor Raymond Smolover and the Rev. Giles R. Spoonhauer, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. STEVEN S. SHAINMARK;
Fewer Hours on Duty for Young Doctors
description: LEAD: NEW YORK recently became the first state to limit the number of hours hospital interns and residents may work. The State Legislature adopted the rules after a commission concluded that long hours had led to some instances of poor patient care.

title: Detroit's Dog Days
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUR ENTER HALL; SKINS BEAT BILLS
description: Under a blistering sun in near-90-degree heat, Mel Blount, Terry Bradshaw, Art Shell and Willie Wood stood outside the the Pro Football Hall of Fame here, drenched in their suits. But inside the hall, there was now a dry, sparkling, bronze bust of each. In enshrinement ceremonies this morning, the four became part of the National Football League's glistening litany of special stars.

title: Katharine Hardy to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rodney D. Hardy of Edina, Minn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Katharine Munson Hardy and Lieut. James Stuart Erskine, U.S.N., the son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Erskine of North Arlington, N.J.

title: Works in Progress; The Clock Strikes Back
description: IN ITS HEYDAY, THE ENGLE clock traveled the Eastern Seaboard, drawing the curious like a sideshow. Built over 20 years by a Pennsylvanian named Stephen Engle, the clock - 11 feet tall, with 48 moving figures, two organ movements that play at regular intervals and a tellurian, which maps the moon and stars -was completed in 1877. It was purchased by a Capt. and Mrs. Jacob Reid, who, recognizing a profit-making artifact, billed it as the eighth wonder of the world. (A period advertisement is at right. The people are not drawn to scale.) ''To show you how popular it was,'' says Thomas J. Bartels, ''in York, Pa., during a two-week period in January 1878, it drew 8,000 people paying a quarter apiece.''

title: Polish Rail Workers Protest Food-Price Rises
description: Protesting recent food price rises and dismal working conditions, thousands of Polish rail workers in the heavily industrialized southern region of Silesia staged a one-hour walkout today, warning that failure to quickly redress grievances would lead to further labor action, the state television reported.

title: Blaming the Medium for Its Message
description: It is not entirely happen-stance that photographs are at the center of the stormy political dispute brought on by indirect Federal support of works by Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano. Much more than paintings, sculptures, plays, novels and poems, camera images seem to bring the world directly to our doorstep. When the world they bring is distasteful or repugnant, it is easy to blame the medium for the message.

title: Boy, 2, Shot in Head on Walk
description: A 2-year-old boy was shot once in the head late yesterday morning as he was walking down the street with his mother in Douglaston, Queens, the police said. He was in critical condition at Long Island Jewish Hospital last night. The mother and son were walking down Horace Harding Boulevard and Marathon Parkway around 11 A.M. when the mother heard a popping sound and then saw that her son had been shot, Sgt. Peter Berry said. A passing car stopped and took the boy to Deepdale Hospital, from where he was transferred to Long Island Jewish Hospital. No arrests have been made.

title: China Lists 20 Deaths In Nuclear Accidents
description: The Government reported today that about 20 people were killed and more than 1,200 injured in accidents involving radioactive materials in China between 1980 and 1985. The disclosure, in the official China Daily, gave no details and did not indicate whether there had been further injuries or fatalities in the last few years.

title: 'The Abyss': A Foray Into Deep Waters
description: The nightmares began underwater.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Short In Sleeve But Long In Style
description: The current revival of the short- sleeved jacket makes so much sense one wonders what took it so long to come back. Sticky summer days take most of the fun out of dressing up; in fact, they make it a chore. Of course, there is always the option of dispensing with a jacket or blazer altogether, but that's not practical for women whose jobs, or personalities, require a touch of formality. Besides, leaving your jacket at home might provide some relief from sweltering temperatures outside, but that extra layer comes in handy inside, when you are shivering in full-volume air-conditioning.

title: A Rush to Buy Duty-Free Goods
description: One company that is profiting from the growth in international travel is Duty Free International Inc. The company - which operates 49 stores at airports and on national borders - sells duty-free items from cigarettes to perfumes at discounts of up to 60 percent.

title: Unequal Contest
description: Lisa Burke, 15 years old, and Molly Tolkoff, 14, of Brookline, Mass., play a rough and tough, competitive brand of ice hockey for the Brookline High School freshman team. Rough play is not unusual for this sport. What is unusual is that their teammates are boys. In two years, however, the girls won't be on the varsity team. ''The boys will be bigger and better than us,'' Miss Burke said. Before puberty, elementary and secondary schools capitalize on this gender nongap and put boys and girls together in required physical-education classes.

title: Notes From All Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Angels' Move to Top Blends Homers, E.R.A. and Shutouts
description: The California Angels are one of the surprise teams of the season, but perhaps the most surprising aspect of their unexpected success has been the rare combination they have put together. They lead the American League in home runs, earned run average and shutouts, and no team has done that in nearly 30 years.

title: IRAN AND CAPTORS DELIVER REBUFFS ON THE HOSTAGES
description: Iran and a pro-Iranian group in Lebanon today rebuffed overtures from the United States and Israel aimed at arranging the release of hostages, but Administration officials said the setback did not foreclose further diplomatic efforts.

title: Odd Alignments of Race and Politics
description: THE clash over the nomination of William C. Lucas as the Justice Department's top civil rights enforcer was an intriguing display of racial politics in which the battle lines were anything but straight.

title: High Health Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Indictment of a Former Aide to Koch Could Impede Mayor's 4th-Term Bid
description: Just when disaffected voters were beginning to take a second look at Mayor Edward I. Koch, the indictment of a former top City Hall aide on perjury charges, announced Friday, is forcing them to look yet again, politicians in New York City say.

title: CD's Available for a Song
description: FOR VETERANS OF THE compact-disk revolution - those who were buying anything, anything at all, that was issued when CD's first came on the market and were extremely scarce - the present state of affairs seems like a second CD revolution. In those early days, music lovers and audio buffs) who had to be the first on the block with new technology were happily (well, almosst happily) paying up to $22 for a single disk. Selection was limited and re-stocking of sold-out items a fantasy.

title:
DINING OUT;
Elegant Setting in a Purdys Farmhouse
description: LEAD: HoW the mighty have fallen. Not long ago The Box Tree in Purdys ranked among the best restaurants on the East Coast; but in recent years changes in kitchen personnel have taken this once heavenly place out of the firmament and placed it solidly on Main Street between the drugstore and the barber shop.

title: Afghan Rebel Disavows Role in Ambush of Rivals
description: Nearly a month after an incident in which an Afghan guerrilla group is said to have killed 30 members of a rival faction in an Afghan mountain gorge, the Muslim fundamentalist leader accused of ultimate responsibility for the killings denied today that he played any role.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Three recent books, handsomely produced and well illustrated, are each a good browse. The first is ''The Guinness Book of Stamps,'' part of the Guinness Superlatives series. Herein are found the biggest stamp and the smallest, the fastest delivery and the slowest, and a wealth of information on how and why stamps are produced.

title: The Pharisees' Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheila J. Dailey Wed in Scarsdale
description: Sheila Jeanette Dailey and Henry Davis Rohrer 3d were married yesterday at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Noonan performed the ceremony.

title: Christine D'Auria Becomes a Bride
description: Christine Hasbrouck D'Auria, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. D'Auria of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to William John Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Donovan of Rockville Centre, L.I. Msgr. William Gallagher and the Revs. Thomas O'Donnell and John Castaldo officiated at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington.

title: Asbestos Abatement: Committees Can Help
description: The recent article ''Schools and Asbestos: Law Posing Problems'' correctly delineates several challenges facing those confronting asbestos problems in schools, or other buildings in which they live, work, shop or learn. In fact, the requirements under the Asbestos Hazard Emergency Response Act may soon be expanded in New Jersey to include all public buildings, vastly increasing the demand for qualified inspectors, management planners, abatement contractors and monitoring firms.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: After reading the articles on Spain (Travel, May 28), I would like to add several comments. Yes, Seville has a lot of hotels, but there is a tremendous difference between Alfonso XIII and the next level (first class). The Dona Maria Hotel, while desirably situated, has dingy, dark, rather seedy rooms. The rooftop pool was empty during our stay in late spring of 1988.

title: D. J. Reed 3d Wed To Susan Bowen
description: Susan Elizabeth Bowen and David John Reed 3d were married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., by the Rev. Richard Greenwood, a Congregational minister. He was assisted by his wife, Deborah Anne Rundlett, a candidate for ordination in the Presbyterian Church.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a wood end table that has a mark caused by a glass of water and a spot where paper is stuck to the finish. Can you advise me how to remove these blemishes?

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Mamaroneck
description: LEAD: THE scenery along Boston Post Road in Mamaroneck is like that along most other commercial avenues in Westchester - until the road passes Harbor Island Park. There, with pleasure boats plying the waters beside ballfields and food stands, the vista is more like a New England seaside village.

title: New Jersey Revelers Arrested As Blackout Hits Boardwalk
description: A power failure early yesterday in Seaside Heights, a New Jersey island resort town, left tens of thousands of people in the dark on the boardwalk and in bars and dozens of others stranded on amusement park rides, including a Ferris wheel, the police said.

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: Joseph Epstein says what some of us have been thinking. As a bourgeois white male, I have become such a repository of condemnation and guilt from dozens of causes demanding liberation from my oppression that I surely qualify as a universal victimizer. This condition makes me a victim as well, or, to use terminology fashionable in therapy chat, co-dependently addicted to guilt, and a survivor, eligible for a blame-support group. THOMAS FITZGERALD Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Nancy Northup To Wed Writer
description: Nancy Jean Northup and Daniel Martin Bergner are planning a September wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Samuel Northup of Rowayton, Conn., have announced. Mr. Bergner is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Bergner of Silver Spring, Md.

title: In Sri Lanka, Grim Mystery of a Missing American
description: On July 17, 1988, a 30-year-old New York businesswoman in robust health and near the peak of a successful career set out on an odyssey of discovery.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Development Moves Past Water's Edge
description: LEAD: OVER the last decade, much progress has been made in converting the Hudson River waterfront's abandoned rail yards and warehouses into a string of office towers and residential complexes. Now redevelopment is moving out onto existing piers.

title: INSIGHT ISN'T EVERYTHING
description: LEAD: HOW DOES TREATMENT HELP? On the Modes of Therapeutic Action of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy. Edited by Arnold Rothstein. 232 pp. Madison, Conn: International Universities Press. $32.50.

title: Lilco Conservation Plan a Hit
description: LEAD: CUSTOMERS of the Long Island Lighting Company are flocking to join a residential energy cooperative that allows the utility to turn off central air-conditioners, pool pumps and electric water heaters for limited periods during summer hot spells in exchange for cash rebates.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Edinburgh
description: Edinburgh's castle high on the rock has looked down on many a triumph and tragedy in the proud Scots capital, but every year since 1947, Britain's ''Second City'' steals the spotlight from London during the three weeks of the international festival.

title: The Baltic Republics Are on the Road to Capitalist Socialism
description: VISITORS to the three small Soviet republics bordering the Baltic Sea often remark that the only thing obviously Soviet about them is their poverty. By culture, tradition and temperament they incline more west than east.

title: 4 Say Atom Industry Ordered Counseling And Harrassed Them
description: At least four workers who complained about safety and environmental problems at four military nuclear plants run for the Government by private contractors say they were ordered by their superiors to see psychiatrists or psychologists.

title: Japanese Artists Forgo Lotus Blossoms for Urban Blight
description: It may have been unkind, but it was apparently not considered ridiculous when the writer V. S. Pritchett described Tokyo in 1962 as an ''anthill'' of a city. Today, of course, Tokyo is exactly the capital one would expect in a country that dominates the international financial world, a sprawling, crazy-quilt metropolis resembling in parts New York and London and Hong Kong.

title: Highlights Interrupt the Erratics-on-Avon
description: Casual dress is the mode on stage at Stratford this summer. Hamlet lounges around the castle at Elsinore in his pajamas, as if he had brought the wrong clothes home from Wittenberg. Still wearing pajamas, he sleepwalks through ''To be or not to be,'' redirects the Players and enters Gertrude's bedchamber looking as if it were time for him to retire. In his mother's room, he suddenly extracts a dagger from his pajama bottoms in order to slay Polonius. Inexplicably, Polonius is hiding under the covers in Gertrude's bed, despite the fact that there is an appropriate arras in the background. Not until he is shipped away to England does Hamlet change his costume, and then he simply puts on an overcoat over his pajamas.

title: How Teaching by Computer Played Out
description: THE computer is becoming almost as common as the blackboard in the nation's classrooms, but most schools have yet to use it more inventively than they use the blackboard.

title: Elusive Parking Spaces Frustrate Garth Road Residents
description: LEAD: WHEN Daniel Heyman lived in Manhattan, he didn't have a parking problem. But that was because he didn't have, or need, a car.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Earthy Pottery From Portugal
description: SOMEHOW cabbage soup tastes more savory from a bowl in the shape of a giant cabbage leaf, and honey sweeter from a honeybee pot. And the table will look more festive if the braised duck and rice is served in a duck tureen.

title: Once Again, Ryan Fails Against Orioles
description: The rookie Bob Milacki won for the first time in a month tonight, scattering seven hits in eight and one-third innings as the Baltimore Orioles won for only the third time in 17 games, beating Texas, 5-2, and continuing their domination of the Rangers' ace, Nolan Ryan.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
For children Of Alcoholics, A Program That Helps
description: LEAD: THE SEVEN STUDENTS seated in a circle at St. Michael's College, in Winooski, Vt., were all children of alcoholic parents. A visitor observed that they seemed to be acting secretive, especially on the subject of their families. It is one of the signs of having grown up in an alcohol-abusing household, according to Linda Hollingdale, assistant director of the college's Resource

title: Three Gems in an Azure Setting
description: FAVIGNANA, Levanzo and Marettimo, as the three small islands that make up the Egadi archipelago are called, lie just off the western coast of Sicily, opposite the port of Trapani. Each island has steep and stony coastlines, a few scattered farms and one small town whose inhabitants have lived - for thousands of years - by quarrying the rock beneath them and harvesting the waters around them.

title: Review/Dance; A Merger and a View Of Future Pleasures
description: The Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival has gotten off to a breezy, pretty start with a program by Nikolais and Louis Dance that was seen on Thursday night at the renovated Damrosch Park Band Shell. The program was of particular interest for several reasons, among them the fact that Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis were honored by New York City on Tuesday, the official opening night, with a citation from Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STOCKHAUSEN ON MUSIC: Lectures and Interviews. By Karlheinz Stockhausen. Compiled by Robin Maconie. (Marion Boyars, $27.50.) Since the early 1950's, Karlheinz Stockhausen has been Germany's leading composer. He has sought to develop compositional systems that, coupled with extensive work in the electronic production and manipulation of sound, have resulted in a rigorous, fascinating music that to even the most casual listener reveals the extreme sophistication of its organization and design.

title: Tara McKelvey Weds Michael H. Kott
description: Tara Shannon McKelvey, the daughter of Susan Purcell of Santa Fe, N.M., and John McKelvey of Kansas City, Mo., was married yesterday to Michael H. Kott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jan Kott of Stony Brook, L.I., and Santa Monica, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Beatrice Blair, an Episcopal priest, at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery in New York. Mrs. Kott, who was until recently a news clerk at The New York Times, graduated from Georgetown University and studied political science at the Free University in Berlin. Her father is the president of the Modwest Research Institute in Kansas City.

title: Mr. Clean Fraternity
description: ''IT MAY COME as a surprise,'' reads the advertisement in bold, black letters, ''but one of the most active organizations in the fight against alcohol abuse, date rape and hazing is a fraternity.''

title: Kaiser Kudos
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavs Astir Over Serbian's Rise
description: The hottest political topic in Yugoslavia is Slobodan Milosevic - what he has done and, even more, what he might do next.

title: Rubber Duck Races Stir Fears of River Pollution
description: RUBBER-DUCK racing seems to be on the verge of becoming a rage in Connecticut, but environmentalists are worried that some of the thousands of ducks that will be released will add to the plastic pollution of the state's rivers.

title: Why Can't We Help the Veterans?
description: Your article on the veteran's hospital (''Veterans Hospital Faces Change,'' July 16) left a lot of unanswered questions.

title: Mets Foil Expos Again
description: Darryl Strawberry had not been in the starting lineup, and when the game was over last night, he was nowhere to be found in the clubhouse. But Strawberry, on a night he apparently wanted to be inconspicuous, had been forced to make one appearance on the night.

title: THE REAL SUPERPOWER IN RUSSIA
description: LEAD: CLAWS OF THE BEAR The History of the Red Army From the Revolution to the Present. By Brian Moynahan. Illustrated. 468 pp. Boston: A Marc Jaffe Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: David Blair Wed To Bernice C. May
description: Bernice Clark May, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Clark May of Lancaster, Pa., and David Belmont Blair, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David William Blair of Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Lancaster. The Rev. James Walsh officiated.

title: THIS LAND WAS THEIR LAND
description: GOD GAVE US THIS COUNTRY Tekamthi and the First American Civil War. By Bil Gilbert. 369 pp. New York: Atheneum. $22.50.

title: Star Quotient
description: To the Editor:

title: Waking Up From the California Dream
description: In ''The End of the Innocence,'' the plaintive title song of Don Henley's latest album, the Eagles' former lead singer yearns for a faraway time ''when days were long and rolled beneath a deep blue sky.''

title: Why the Small Investor Stays Out
description: Last Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average soared past 2,661, its highest level since the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, 1987.

title: Two Arkansas Families Trade Shots in Pie Fight
description: A pie fight here has the elements of a slapstick comedy except for one thing: Nobody is throwing pies.

title: Pollution: The Risks for Travelers
description: SOME travelers think a change of scenery means a breath of fresh air, but if they're headed for Rio de Janeiro, Milan or Seoul - to name just a few cities - they are wrong. Air pollution has spread to most cities around the globe, turning skies gray, choking many residents and raining soot.

title: Fixing Customers' Cars and Attitudes
description: THIS summer, with the ever-increasing trend of families' shying away from long-distance travel in favor of vacations close to home, car repairs and simple tuneups are keeping many service stations in New Jersey busy.

title: Natalie duPont Edmonds Is Married To Peter Andrew Fair on Cape Cod
description: Natalie duPont Edmonds and Peter Andrew Fair were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Raymond Webster officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Edmonds Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Osterville. Mr. Fair is a son of Mrs. Frederick Maul Fair of New York and Mountain Top, Pa., and the late Mr. Fair.

title: Reduced to Despair
description: To the Editor:

title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help
description: NEVER will I forget the pathetic sight of a tiny, stiff-legged cocaine-addicted baby, trembling nervously and crying for help.

title: While Stieb Misses, Righetti Reminisces
description: In the ninth inning Friday night, as the crowd inside the Skydome rose slowly to acknowledge Dave Stieb's big moment, one Yankee pitcher turned toward a teammate and asked if he had ever witnessed a no-hitter.

title: A Canadian Builder Strides to Broadway With 'Shenandoah'
description: Howard Hurst, who heads a Canadian real estate development corporation, is not by nature an impulsive or emotional man. Indeed, sitting in an office backstage at Broadway's Virginia Theater, the impeccably tailored and soft-spoken chartered accountant appears to be the picture of cautious deliberation. Yet, last June, by his own description, he was a man ''obsessed,'' and the reason for that, he says, was the musical ''Shenandoah.''

title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT
description: MONKEY BAY By Elaine Ford. 244 pp. New York: Viking.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SINEWS OF POWER: War, Money and the English State, 1688-1783. By John Brewer. (Knopf, $19.95.) For 200 years before 1688, Britain was not a major military power, either by aspiration or achievement. In the following century, argues John Brewer in ''The Sinews of Power,'' the military sustenance required for an emerging empire was made possible by the development of a complex and competent financial and administrative bureaucracy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't want that. What's that? It's a complete game.

title: Man Dies in Fall From Roof
description: A Queens man who was locked out of his apartment by his wife was fatally injured early yesterday when he fell five stories while trying to enter a window by lowering himself by rope from the roof, the police said. The man, Gregory Allen, 39 years old, of 31-07 49th Street in Woodside , fell when the rope broke about 1:50 A.M., said Sgt. Pete Berry, a police spokesman. Mr. Allen died of his injuries at 2:47 A.M. at Elmhurst Hospital Center, he said.

title: Harlem Curator Helps Redefine Photography
description: The object is a fan, round with a long stem handle, of the type supplied by undertakers for promotional purposes and handed out free in churches. On its surface, however, are pictures of children, birds and flowered hats, amid bits of fabric, keys and buttons, all remnants of childhood memories.

title: Energy: Planning To Plan
description: THE Energy Department last week held the first in a series of public hearings aimed at creating a national energy ''strategy'' by December 1990. In many respects, the quest for a strategy was seen a tacit acknowledgement by the Administration that the Energy Department is to have a much bigger role in setting priorities and policies for energy development in the 1990's than it did in the 1980's.

title: Freed Inmate Settles Suit With Producer Over Rights to Story
description: Errol Morris, the film maker whose movie ''The Thin Blue Line'' helped to free a death row inmate, has settled a lawsuit brought by the man he helped to free, lawyers for both sides say.

title: Japan's Small-Business Owners Give Ruling Party a Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lessons in Sand Castles
description: DO most women with children look forward to summer vacation as I do, with a mixture of longing and dread? Who can withstand the charms of summer? The lengthening tender evenings, sharp scents of new-mown grass, the crisp bite of summer peaches, melons and corn? Then the inevitable whine, ''What do I do now?'' of someone underfoot.

description: MEDIAN RESALE HOUSE PRICES June89 May 89 June 88 Nation $93,200 $92,600 $90,200 Northeast 149,800 143,800 147,300 Midwest 72,100 70,300 70,000 South 84,900 84,100 83,900 West 134,100 142,300 127,000 *4*(Source: National Association of Realtors) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.11 10.20 10.74 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.88 8.90 7.90 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 9.90 9.97 10.57 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.60 8.67 7.94 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.08 10.14 10.70 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.89 8.80 8.11 Co-ops (N.Y.)
