title: V.A. Problem Is Not Lack of Money
description: It is implied in your article that the only problem that the V.A. at Northport has is one of lack of funds. This is not so!

title: Easy Goer Rallies to Win Whitney
description: Easy Goer's enormous talent took on an added dimension today when the 3-year-old colt overcame real trouble for the first time in his career and went on to score a stirring 4 1/2-length victory over older horses in the $287,500 Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Worst Hay Fever Season In Years Seen for '89
description: LEAD: ALLERGY sufferers should brace for the worst hay fever season in years, according to Dr. Richard J. Mangi, director of the Pollen Count Center at the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven.

title: Telephone Calls Reassure Elderly
description: LEAD: EVERY morning, Sue Ward, a computer broker for the Neptune Computer Group of Stamford, takes a few minutes to call a friend, Lillian DeMaio, who is more than twice her age. The calls leave Ms. Ward pleased to hear that her friend is just fine, and Mrs. DeMaio, who lives alone and suffered a stroke last year, happy to know that someone checks regularly to be sure all is well.

title: What's Government Doing in the Arts Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Oil Flows In, But the U.S. Can't Save Enough of It
description: EVERY day, the United States adds 60,000 barrels to the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a sea of stored crude intended to cushion the effects of a disruption in the flow of imported oil. But even as the reserve grows larger - 22.3 million barrels were added in the last year - the protection it offers shrinks.

title: Outdoors; Treasures, but No Takers
description: Experts are angling for an explanation of the results of the R. W. Oliver auction of antique and classic fishing tackle in Kennebunk, Me., last month. Although the 755 lots in the auction sold for $436,000, exceeding the presale low estimate of their value by $45,785, buyers showed little interest in some choice items, among them two extremely valuable fly fishing reels.

title: When Child's Play Isn't Fun
description: ONE OF THE MOST worrisome reports a pediatrician can hear from a parent is that a child has lost all interest in favorite toys. A child who can no longer take pleasure in playing may be signaling a psychiatric emergency. Though the pediatrician may not be formally trained in child psychology, such emergencies must always be as much a concern as medical problems. But how does anyone employ psychiatry, a discipline built on conversation, on a child too young to talk? When doctors or parents face a screaming baby, how can they sort out what is a developing emotional or psychiatric problem from simple hunger, say, or diaper rash?

title: What's Government Doing in the Arts Anyway?; They'll Have to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Answers To Quiz
description: Fold back to page 7 and you can read these next to the questions.

title: Another August Under the 'Whine Sign'
description: The anguished-looking little girl in a pink dress knew exactly which one it had to be. ''David has this one,'' she declared. ''I want it.''

title: NOW, FOOD GIANTS FARM FISH, THREATENING SMALL GROWERS
description: Food companies like Geo. A. Hormel & Company and ConAgra Inc. have been processing farm-raised fish for years. But few have been eager to farm fish because it is riskier and more capital intensive than processing. Over the years, Coca-Cola, Dow Chemical, Kraft, United Fruit and Weyerhaeuser have all jumped in and out of fish farming. And last year, Domsea Inc., a subsidiary of the Campbell Soup Company, sold its 11-year-old Coho salmon farm in Washington. ''To be successful would have required more capital than we wanted to put in,'' said Edward Brauer of Domsea, which still processes salmon and trout.

title: Judith Steinhardt Is Wed
description: Judith Lynn Steinhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Steinhardt of White Plains, was married there last evening at the Stouffer's Mansion to Daniel Albert Carasso, a son of Dr. Roberta Carasso of Newport Beach, Calif., and Pierre Carasso of Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Elihu Schagrin officiated. The bride, 25 years old, a graduate of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., and the Brooklyn Law School, is a lawyer for Bronx Legal Services. Mr. Steinhardt, 27, graduated from the University of Southern California and received an M.B.A. from Georgetown University. He is a securities analyst with Goldman Sachs & Company in New York.

title: Learning to Be a Maine Boy, Fresh Air Style
description: Quincy Collins lives at 125th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem, where he is used to hearing police sirens wail throughout the night and seeing homeless people.

title: Beware Of Hama Rules
description: There is a pause in the hostage crisis, but there is no end to its danger. To understand why - to understand the danger - read Thomas L. Friedman's brilliant new book ''From Beirut to Jerusalem.'' Especially the chapter called ''Hama Rules.''

title: Solutions to the Fat Problem
description: WHAT do Americans worry about most? According to a recent Gallup Poll, many of us replied fat was the most troubling issue in our lives. Fat, we said, caused us more anxiety than Muammar el Qaddafi, racism, pesticides, nuclear warheads, sexually transmitted diseases, drugs and even the prime rate.

title: A Tax By Any Other Name
description: TRYING to make sense of the new taxes that went into effect on July 1 can be added to anyone's list of impossible jobs. In their frenzy to avoid an income tax and the Governor's veto, our legislators constructed a mare's-nest that should give everybody something to complain about.

title: Lusty Verses and Cultural Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Bring Back That Old Awfulness

title: An Owner Welcomes Court Decision
description: Richard Welch, in decrying a recent Court of Appeals ruling that permits unrelated people to occupy single family homes (''Court V. Family: Homeowners Lose,'' Opinion, June 25), implies that we homeowners who would do so are not working, middle-class people, and that the ruling will devalue neighborhoods. I think he is limiting his thinking to absentee landlord situations where a homeowner rents for profit.

title: SHOCKING OYSTERS TO MAKE THEM GROW FASTER
description: The increase in Government financing for aquacultural research is helping to improve the productivity and profitability of fish farming. For instance, after ultraviolet light was shown in lab tests to stimulate spawning, some farmers began using it to control their production.

title: Bad Cops in Namibia
description: Namibia is proceeding bumpily on the road to elections on Nov. 1 that will lead in turn to a constitutional conference. As part of a U.S.-brokered deal, South Africa has agreed to end its illegal control of a vast territory, which is good. What's not so good is that South Africa is trying to tilt the vote to its political allies, using the roughhouse cops known as Koevoet. It's a tilt that has to be corrected if there's to be a level playing field in this contest.

title: Silicon Valley's Design Renaissance
description: At Synopsys, a small start-up company here in the heart of the Silicon Valley, Cindy Collart sits before a desktop work station. On her screen is a file written in familiar programming language.

title: The U.S. Can't Fight Terrorism Properly
description: LEAD: President Bush has been exploring the use of force for retaliation. He was prepared to order an air strike against suspected terrorist bases in Lebanon if kidnappers had carried out their threat to murder American hostage, Joseph Cicippio. While that might have satisfied domestic political demands to do ''something bold,'' it is not clear that such an action would be an effective blow against terrorism.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE IMPERIAL AGENT. By T. N. Murari. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) In an author's note that prefaces ''The Imperial Agent,'' the Indian novelist T. N. Murari admits that when rereading Rudyard Kipling's ''Kim'' 30 years after he first encountered it in childhood, ''the end still disappointed me.'' So Mr.

title: What's Government Doing in the Arts Anyway?; Last Laugh?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, Tony Spiridakis, You Can Go Home Again
description: The line between art and life ran down 19th Street in the Astoria section of Queens. Two old men sipped Greek coffee at the Perama Taverna. Six little girls played dodge ball beneath lines of fluttering laundry. Four boys pedaled home from the local swimming pool, shirtless and damp. And Eugenia Spiridakis strolled toward the brick bungalow surrounded by cameras and cranes and lights to see how her son Tony's movie was going.

title: A WAR AGAINST THE WORLD
description: THE CONTROL OF NATURE By John McPhee. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Get It First, But Get It Right
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cooperation Between Equals
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping the Blind Enjoy the Show
description: ''THE trapezoid shapes on stage are in various overlaying shades of brown. At the top of the rear platform begins the base of a large cross. This cross is made of Plexiglas and changes colors throughout the show to create shadows. Rolling platforms come in on the left and on the right, representing various parts of the city.''

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: In a piece distinguished for mean-spiritedness, Joseph Epstein has found a new way to blame the victim: for improper behavior.

title: Golf Pros Play 'Something Else'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
THE SUMMER REPORT;
Say It In EdSpeak
description: LEAD: WHAT WE'RE talking about here can be boiled down to the following: Teachers teaching students. Parents confused or intimidated by certain words in the accompanying glossary, compiled with the help of educators throughout the country, are advised to return to this simple axiom and all will make sense.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Divide overgrown clumps of bearded iris and replant firm rhizomes in groups of three; discard rhizomes that are old or rotted. Mail orders for bulbs that will be planted in fall. Cut to the ground stalks of perennials that bloomed. Prune hedges, especially privet, hemlock, yew. Last call to sow biennial seed outdoors in nursery beds. Good News

title: Dispute on Jay Site Enters a New Phase
description: A DEVELOPER and public officials have squared off again in their long battle to determine the future use of the developer's 23-acre property overlooking Long Island Sound.

title: The Time Has Come: Abolish Regents Exams
description: AS students prepare to sharpen their pencils, cover their books and hone their minds for the start of the new school year, they should resolve to work with parents, teachers, administrators and policymakers throughout the state to demand the abolition of the Regents exams. It is time. It is long overdue. It was time back in the 1960's, when I as a student sweated and fretted, combatted nausea and diarrhea, and crammed day and night to achieve a respectable score on this most sacrosanct imprimatur of the State of New York. It was then believed to be more important than anything that had transpired during the entire school year; even if you received 90's all year, a failing grade on the Regents doomed you to ignominy. A decent grade freed you of the inconvenience of summer school, as well as the humiliation of a red mark posted next to your name on the bulletin board.

title: POSTINGS: Wanted by New York; Design Dir., 80K
description: The New York City Housing Authority, the world's largest municipally owned and operated housing agency, is looking for a new director of design and capital improvement, which is considered one of the city's most demanding positions. The authority owns 318 projects of 178,000 apartments housing 570,000 people. ''Because of the volume and quality of the work that we do in new construction and modernization,'' said Emanuel P. Popolizio, the authority's chairman, ''it takes an unusually gifted professional with a background in management, architecture and engineering to fill the position.'' The design director oversees an annual budget of $500 million and a staff of 250 people, including 150 architects and engineers. Applicants for the $80,000-a-year position must be either a registered architect or a licensed engineer and have five years of administrative experience with an organization that has mounted a major construction program. Richard Rosenthal, the previous director of design, resigned to enter private industry.

title: Bush in a Crisis: Casting the Widest Net
description: Late Monday afternoon, with one American hostage reported dead and another facing death, President Bush sat at a small wooden desk with a typewriter in the study tucked behind the Oval Office. He had rushed back from Chicago, canceling stops in Las Vegas and Oklahoma City and waving off suggestions from some advisers that the action might give the Lebanese extremists the impression that they could manipulate the United States Government.

title: Giants Get Knepper
description: He started his career with the San Francisco Giants, and now, after spending the better part of nine seasons battling the Giants and other National League teams as a pitcher for the Houston Astros, Bob Knepper is getting a chance to finish his career with the Giants.

title: Getting High on Moral Indignation
description: Short of unhooking the telephone, canceling the newspaper, taking an ax to the television set and hiding under the sofa, it would by now be impossible not to have heard of the pseudo-controversy about the photographs of the late Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano, the intervention of Senator Jesse Helms on the floor of the Senate and the possible effects of it all on the future of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Miss Noyes Weds H. Edward Bilkey
description: Susan Noyes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Noyes Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church to H. Edward Bilkey, the son of Mrs. Ross McFarland of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Edward Bilkey. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: Votes in Congress; Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: SENATE

title: Staging Margaret Sanger's Return
description: ''SHE started the sexual revolution,'' the actress Eileen Heckart declared. The director Melvin Bernhardt added, ''And she has come back because she's needed.''

title: Constance Jewell Becomes the Wife Of S. H. Knox 4th
description: The marriage of Constance Marie Jewell, a daughter of Mrs. B. B. Voorhees of Olean, N.Y., and the late John M. Jewell, to Seymour Horace Knox 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Knox 3d of Buffalo, took place yesterday at St. Matthias's Episcopal Church in East Aurora, N.Y. The Rev. Michael E. Hartney performed the ceremony.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Penn State; Students Protest Loss Of Control Over Farm
description: A 176-acre student-run farm at Penn State University on which students had previously earned money has been shifted to university control, and some students as well as agriculture-college faculty and staff members are upset about it.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a wood end table that has a mark caused by a glass of water and a spot where paper is stuck to the finish. Can you advise me how to remove these blemishes?

title: Erica Jong Marries Kenneth Burrows
description: Erica Jong, the novelist and poet, and Kenneth David Burrows, a lawyer in New York, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Warren, Vt., by Nancy Colby, a justice of the peace in Warren.

title: Of Life and Death
description: It was supposed to be a test of the relationship between two people. It became a test of will and survival. Janet Culver and the man she had been dating, Nicholas Abbott, set sail July 13 from Bermuda to Long Island in a 37-foot sloop. Ms. Culver, a 48-year-old executive secretary from Passaic, N.J., went along to see how she liked long-distance sailing and Mr. Abbott. But the sloop sank and they barely escaped in a small rubber lifeboat with few provisions. After about 10 days adrift, Ms. Culver said, Mr. Abbott became irrational, jumped overboard and disappeared. Four days later she was rescued, suffering from dehydration and sunburn. Last week Ms. Culver, recovering in a Bermuda hospital, hired a lawyer to help her face media and investigative attentions.

title: A Headstrong Tenor Discusses Music and Critics
description: ''I don't think there's such a thing as a happy tenor,'' Rockwell Blake said during a brief stop in New York on the way home (to Plattsburgh, in upstate New York) from a run of opera performances in Chile. ''If he's not complaining that he isn't getting enough work, he's complaining that he doesn't have enough vacation.''

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: The articles on Spain brought back many happy memories. I want to suggest, however, that oranges on the trees lining the streets of Seville are unplucked for a simple reason: they are very sour. I know, because I incautiously bit into one. They are, in fact, marmalade oranges. NORMA JACOB Kennett Square, Pa.

title: Congress Frees Broadcasters to Restrain Themselves
description: NOBODY has successfully defined what constitutes violence on television, but Congress wants the owners of broadcast and cable channels to show a lot less of it anyway.

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: The Mets were in first place the day the trade was made and are now in fourth. What good is Samuel's speed when he does not get on base? He is hitting .230 since coming here while Dykstra is hitting .300 since going to the Phillies. Roger McDowell has 12 saves and a 0.00 earned run average while the Met bullpen flounders. DORIS BAUER Rego Park, Queens

title: 22 Artists Participate In Bruce's 'Biennial'
description: THE Sao Paulo Bienal, the Venice Biennale, the Whitney Biennial and now, at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, ''The Connecticut Biennial.''

title: A New Jerseyan on Patrol in a Royal Park
description: THE royal parks of London - where history comes to life in palace gardens, on crisply clipped Victorian lawns and throughout unspoiled acres of former royal hunting grounds - have added to that history by establishing a link with the parks of Morris County.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MUD SOLDIERS: Life Inside the New American Army. By George C. Wilson. (Scribners, $19.95.) ''Mud Soldiers'' begins with a reconstruction of a bloody fight between the Vietcong and Company C of the Second Battalion, 16th Infantry, First Infantry Division, in 1966; it then moves to Fort Benning, Ga., in 1987 to follow the training of new men for the same company during the first year of their enlistment in today's all-volunteer Army.

title: On China's Bustling Coast, Profit Outpaces Politics
description: The young money-changer beamed at the sight of a foreigner on the street of this bustling trading center, and excitedly quoted his black-market exchange rates for United States dollars and Taiwan dollars.

title: Plan to Revamp Special Education Draws Criticism
description: A PLAN that would fundamentally alter the approach to special education in New Jersey has fallen under sharp criticism from one of the state's largest advocacy groups for handicapped children.

title: Istanbul
description: To the Editor: Regarding Istanbul's street vendors (Travel, June 4), the cautionary note on the safety of eating or drinking anything on the streets was vastly understated.

title: 2 POSSIBLE CRACKS IN 3-MILE REACTOR
description: Workers at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg, Pa., have found two marks that could be cracks in the bottom of the reactor vessel.

title: A Volunteer Fireman, 91, Still Passes Muster
description: LEAD: THE last time Joe Delmerico rode to a fire on Dobbs Ferry's Resolute Hook and Ladder, it was 1978. The company had been called to a spectacular blaze that gutted an Irvington landmark, an 8O-room cut-stone castle, paneled in oak and teak and built in l927.

title: Gehrig's Tribute Short, Not Sweet
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title:
ART;
Video Synthesis: In Search of Reality
description: LEAD: IN recent years, technological advances have enabled artists to extend their scope beyond conventional media. Painters and sculptors who, a decade ago, would have shied away from electronics are now enthusiastically embracing video as a valid tool of visual expression.

title: Joan Babcook Weds Louis M. Jacobs
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Buffalo, Joan Babcook, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Babcook Jr. of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Louis Michael Jacobs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy Maurice Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., and West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. James M. Demske, the president of Canisius College in Buffalo, performed the ceremony.

title: Pool Long Closed to Blacks Ends Policy and Opens to All
description: A swimming club that was closed to blacks for 34 years began admitting both blacks and whites today following complaints by a church group.

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: Joseph Epstein wonders how Jesse Jackson can talk about victimhood when he's flying around the country in a fancy tailored suit. Has Mr. Epstein ever heard Mr. Jackson speak? He doesn't talk about being a victim. Quite the contrary. He tells young people: You can do it if you study, if you work, if you stay off drugs. And he stands in front of them as an example of one who did it. MICHAEL SCOTT Seattle

title: Myung Kang Weds Jonathan Huneke
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Myung Hee Kang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ho Ryun Kang of Lakewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Albert Huneke, the son of Mrs. Carl Strand and Albert Huneke, both of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Judith T. Baumer performed the ceremony.

title: Sports of The Times; For Tim Burke, a Different Kind of Save
description: When Tim and Christine Burke take their two children out in the double stroller, people peer at the youngsters and ask, ''Are they twins?''

title: Clare E. Brokaw, A Teacher, Weds
description: Clare Elizabeth Brokaw and Andrew John Speyer, both teachers, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Brian Lathrop officiated. Mrs. Speyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Brokaw of New Canaan, Conn., teaches gifted children at the North Street School in Greenwich, Conn. She graduated magna cum laude from Duke University and received a master's degree in education from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Her father retired as the director of corporate donations at Texaco Inc. in White Plains. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gunther Speyer of New York. Mr. Speyer is a computer-science teacher at the Horace Mann School in the Bronx, where he is also the assistant coach for football and track and field. A graduate of Macalester College, he is studying for a master's degree in computing in education at Teachers College of Columbia University. His father retired as a vice president of Bunzl Corporation, an import-export company in New York.

title: Child's Play
description: MANY PARENTS complain that their children spend too much time playing video games, thus neglecting homework and retarding healthy social development. It is a familiar complaint, having been leveled against television for years.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
If Its Tuesday, This Must Be Moscow
description: LEAD: ENCOURAGED by the new era of friendlier East-West relations, large numbers of college students are putting the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe on their travel itineraries.

title: Bolivian Patriarch Hands Reins to a Relative
description: The reclusive octogenarian Victor Paz Estenssoro is to give up the presidency on Sunday after having turned Bolivia back from part of the revolutionary process he started in his middle years.

title: HOME BREWS
description: The image of the lean, tall Westerner popping a can of Coors or nursing a long-necked cerveza Corona is as central to the mythology of beer as that of the yellow-slickered Marlboro cowpoke is to the selling of cigarettes.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
And Now, Miami Voice
description: LEAD: STUDENTS of language, and manners, conclude what you will. Here are some of the finer points of patois this semester at the University of Miami.

title: Airport Parking
description: To the Editor: Speaking of airport parking (Travel Advisory, June 25), some city agency should look into the parking fees at the city's airports. Short-term parking costs $1 an hour; fair enough. However, the minimum charge is $4. How often have you spent four hours at the airport meeting a friend or seeing someone off?

title: August in New York: It's the Little Things
description: Here are a few things New Yorkers can look forward to in the dog days of summer:

title: A Question Of Trust
description: TO WIN NICOLE'S AFFECTION, I take her canoeing. It's the first time just the two of us, my girlfriend's 10-year-old daughter and I, have gone on an outing. I have high hopes for the day: that we'll have a lovely heart-to-heart talk, that we'll trust each other with some secrets, that we'll have a great time. As we sit on the riverbank, waiting for the boathouse to open, we take turns reading to each other from ''The Wind in the Willows.'' I loved this book as a kid, and bringing it along today seems to link our two childhoods. Nicole has a crush on Water Rat, and can't look at an illustration of him without exclaiming, ''He's so cute!'' With her own round nose and sleek, dark hair, she reminds me of a sea lion pup.

title: The S.A.T. Puzzle
description: In standardized testing, there is a basic understanding: Gender differences in scores are diminishing. And there is a catch: the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Michigan State; Intern Program Provides a Taste Of Public Service
description: Renato Jamett hopes to be the governor of Michigan some day, and he is getting some early training for the job.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE fastest-growing intercollegiate sports for women are soccer and cross-country. Soccer, offered for women in 3 percent of schools in 1977, has grown to 38 percent in 1988. Cross-country was available in less than a third of the schools and is presently represented in more than 80 percent. - R. Vivian Acosta and Linda J. Carpenter, Brooklyn College, ''Status of Women in Intercollegiate Athletics.''

title: Local Role in H.U.D. Hearings
description: WHILE Joseph D. Monticciolo was administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development's New York regional office from 1981 to 1988, he frequently supported charity fund-raisers given in his honor. On the surface it sounds worthy.

title: Raiding the Mets
description: Mookie Wilson's departure from the New York Mets last week got scant attention - overshadowed, perhaps, by headlines celebrating the arrival from Minnesota of Frank Viola, a pitcher who's supposed to lift the team from its present doldrums.

title: Patronage Becomes Latest Hot Issue
description: The perjury indictment Friday of a former mayoral aide who ran the Talent Bank for Mayor Edward I. Koch has made patronage - the doling out of city jobs to political allies and people they recommend - the latest hot issue in the campaign for mayor of New York.

title: Southwestern Dining and a Witty Decor
description: ORDERING from the menu at the Coyote Cafe & Saloon in South Norwalk is a little like treading gingerly through the Mojave Desert, trying to avoid mistakes and emerge with your taste buds intact.

title: Filling Teachers With Energy
description: WHEN Marsha Barber told one of her students that she was going to be employed by Amoco Corporation in Denver this summer, he asked her which gas station she would be working at.

title: Jets Find Lots of Room for Improvement
description: The Jets' quest for the yin and yang of pro football - protecting the quarterback, and getting to him - continued erratically today.

title: Caddie Incident
description: After shooting a second straight 77 and missing the cut at the St. Jude Classic in Memphis, Mac O'Grady was apparently in no mood to be berated on Friday, not even by the father of his opening-day caddie.

title: Columbia, the Oldest Shuttle, Is to Orbit Again This Week
description: The countdown is on for the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia in three and a half years, to release a military reconnaissance satellite and a smaller scientific payload.

title: Q and A
description: Reunion Planning

title: Jean Parker Wed To Thomas Phifer
description: Jean Carlton Parker, an architect, was married yesterday on Gibson Island, Md., to Thomas McGehee Phifer, also an architect. The Rev. Frederick J. Hanna, assisted by the Rev. Charles E. Danner, performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Christopher's-by-the-Sea. Mrs. Phifer, who will keep her name professionally, is a partner in the New York firm of Buttrick White & Burtis. She is a daughter of Mrs. James Parker of Gibson Island and the late Mr. Parker, who was a lawyer in Washington. She graduated from Yale University and received a master of architecture degree from Columbia University.

title: Owner Tearing Down Addition at Historic Site
description: THE owner of a home in Tarrytown's historic district began tearing down a major addition to the building last week after a judge sentenced him to 10 days in jail for disobeying a court order to remove the wing.

title: 60,000 Strike Nynex As Talks Break Down
description: More than 60,000 Nynex telephone employees, including technicians, operators and repair workers, went on strike just before midnight.

title: Getting Your Tuition's Worth
description: A REVOLUTION of rising expectations among parents and students has come to America's college and university campuses. With the cost of a year at the most expensive and selective schools now having cracked the $20,000 barrier, parents are raising their sights about what to expect in return.

title: Law Office at a Flea Market
description: LEAD: MIDWAY down aisle two at the Collingwood Auction and Flea Market, the aroma of garlic and vinegar rises from the pickle barrels and mingles with the sugary scent of freshly spun cotton candy.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the playwright Rupert Holmes included an erroneous quotation. Mr. Holmes said his aim in ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' had been to ''make fun'' what had been a ''dark and somber book.'' He did not say he intended to make fun of the Dickens work.

title: It's a Bad Deal for the Model Debtor
description: After months of intensive negotiations, the Brady Plan has finally produced the Mexican debt reduction agreement. The accord, however, suffers from serious defects. The package covers the Government's $54 billion in medium- and long-term loans out of the country's $70 billion in total bank debt.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE BLIND CAUDILLO
description: IN THE MIDDLE OF A VILLAGE OF brightly painted wooden huts a helicopter touches down and a small, elderly, blind man, smartly dressed in a gray suit and gray fedora, is carefully helped out and guided into a long, black Lincoln. The limousine, license plate 0-1, immediately speeds 100 yards to a roped-off area of freshly turned earth and neat new concrete houses. Here, the blind man is helped out once again, then is led to a table where peasants stand, waiting restlessly behind a line of pot-bellied officers, in uniforms draped with braids.

title: They Write the Jokes
description: To the Editor:

title: Photo of an early-20th-century spider-web lamp from the Tiffany Studios, 28 1/2 inches high and 19 inches in diameter; Tiffany Lamps Make a Comeback
description: On the wane five years ago, the 35-year revival in collecting Louis Comfort Tiffany's stained-glass lamps has come alive with renewed vigor. The resurgence of interest is being seen in several museum exhibitions and in escalating prices at auctions.

title: QUIET! MOGULS ON THE SET!
description: THE GENIUS OF THE SYSTEM Hollywood Filmmaking in the Studio Era. By Thomas Schatz. Illustrated. 514 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: Budapest Weighs a Plan for Refugees
description: Opening a novel rift in the Warsaw Pact, Hungary has said it will consider granting political asylum to some East Germans, effectively assisting them in their flight from another Communist nation.

title: Ann Doyle Is Engaged
description: September wedding plans for Ann Forbes Doyle and George Stuart Kane, the son of Mrs. James K. Staley of Fair Oaks, Calif., and Franklin G. Kane of Edmonton, Alberta, have been made known by Miss Doyle's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Doyle of Hingham, Mass. Miss Doyle is a sales representative in Boston for Design Tex Fabrics Inc. in New York. Mr. Kane is a poet and editor and the marketing manager for books at the Appalachian Mountain Club in Boston. Both are graduates of Brown University.

title: Q and A
description: A Temporary C. of O.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Empire Games Heptathlon Athlete Wins Again: Caryl Senn of Massapequa, L.I., won the Empire State Games open women's heptathlon championship yesterday for the fifth time in eight years and her second successive year. But she failed in her bid for the event's heptathlon record for points, finishing with 4,552. The record is 5,061, set by Beth Sheehan of Western New York in 1982. Senn was first in the javelin, 800-meter race, 100-meter hurdles and high jump.

title: WHEN BODY AND SOUL PART COMPANY
description: LEAD: WAKE ME WHEN IT'S OVER A Journey to the Edge and Back. By Mary Kay Blakely. 273 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Zesty, Versatile Sauce
description: Sesame noodles are the chop suey of the 80's. Just about every takeout Chinese restaurant offers the dish. It is the rich taste of the sesame, freshened with ginger and sweetened slightly, that appeals to us. The taste is not unlike peanut butter. It is easy to have a version of the sauce on hand to use whenever the mood for that flavor strikes.

title: Luring 'Green' Consumers
description: For six months, Paula Young has been buying ''environment friendly'' products like cat litter made from recycled newspaper and trash bags and disposable diapers made with biodegradable plastic.

title: A Speck Between Sicily and Africa
description: WANDERING around the lunar landscape of Pantelleria one recent weekend, I found myself struggling to understand why this tiny speck on the map between Sicily and Tunisia should show a lot more character than you would normally expect from an island just 9 miles long and 5 miles wide.

title: Fund Follows a Tradition of Marian Anderson
description: WHEN Marian Anderson received the $10,000 Philadelphia Award in the 1950's, she used the money to set up scholardhips for young singers. ''If some of these people have gone out and brought pleasure and satisfaction to publics of their own and if the scholarship helped them climb another rung on the way to their goal, I feel that the people who have listened to me ofer the years deserve the credit,'' she wrote in her autobiography. ''Their faith opened the way for me to be useful to younger singers.'' Miss anderson, who has lived in Danbury since 1940 and was a prime mover in establishing the Charles Ives Center for the Performing Arts there, will be honored by the center with a gala concert on Saturday. The proceeds from the event will establish a Marian Anderson Award to promote the careers of promising American singers. The outdoor celebration, starting at 8 P.M., will feature the violinist Isaac Stern playing Mozart's G-major Concerto: the soprano Jessye Norman singing two arias from Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' three strauss songs and a number of the spirituals that Miss Anderson has performed, and Julius Rudel conducting the Ives Festival Orchestra in those works and other pieces by Wagner and Mozart. For Ms. Norman, the concert is almost a way of repaying an old debt. ''I first heard Marian Anderson on a recording at the age of 10,'' she said. ''It wasn't just a voice; it was a revelation, and I wept.'' ''She has meant so much to so many. It would have been completely impossible for me to have any kind of career if it hadn't been for people like Miss Anderson with such strength of character.'' Mr. Stern, a friend and neighbor of Miss Anderson's, said: ''Music was for her an expression, not a career. It reflected her simplicity and natural nobility as a woman; it came from her inner self. The uniqueness of her talent is what made her very special - the sheer magnificence of the voice, the intelligence of its use, and the true himility that you so rarely find in a major artist.'' Benefit tickets, which include tax-deductible contributions, are $50; $100 and $500. Unreserved lawn seating is $15. Next Sunday has been set aside as a raing date. For reservations or more information, call the Ives Center at 797-4002. At Music Mountain in Falls Village, the summer-long parade of top-notch international string quartets will continue today at 4 P.M. as the Franciscan performs Haydn's ''Rider'' Quartet, Beethoven's Opus 135 and George Rochberg's Quartet No. 5. Breaking the usual Saturday pattern of lighter concerts at the Mountain, the Quartetto de Venezia will give an 8:30 P.M. recital devoted to Puccini's miniature ''I Crisantemi,'' the Quartet No. 1 by Charles Strouse and Beethoven's E-flat Piano Quartet, with Marian Hahn the guest jartist. The Quartetto de Venezia will return next Sunday afternon at 4, for Bartok, Schubert and, again with Ms. Hahn, Mozart's E-flat Piano Quartet (496-1222). The Chestnut Hill Concert Series will continue at the Congregational Meeting House of Madison at 8:30 P.M. Friday as the violinist Ik-Hwan Bae, the horn player Robert Routch and the pianist David Oei gather for sonatas and tios by Beethove, Messaien and Brahms (453-1359). At the same hour, the Norfolk Festival will close its summer season with a final recital of Beethove, Ravel and Franck by the Tokyo String Quartet (542-5537). Instead of its usual orchestral session, the Summer Music Festival in Waterford will present a chamber music recital by the Empire Brass at 8 P.M. Saturday in Harkness Park. The quintet has prepared transcriptions of a dozen or more staples of the symphonic repertory, including excerpts from Copland's ''Rodeo'' and ''Appalachian Spring,'' the Ravel ''Pavane for a Dead Princess'' and Brahms's ''Hungarian Dance No. 5.'' There will also be selections from Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' and Bernstein's ''West Side Story,'' and a couple of Ellington's jazz classics (442-9199). Through much of its regular season, the nonprofit Sounding Board Coffeehouse brings a wide variety of folk performers to the Hartford area, but this month its focus will shift to the Connecticut Family Folk Festival, a free series of educatinal workshops, sing-alongs, children's programs and ballad concerts. Celebrating its 16th anniversary next weekend, the festival eill occupy several sites in Elizabeth Park, onthe Hartford and West Hartford border. The Saturday workshops - dealing with such topics as song collecting, vocal styles and the American ballad - will begin at 11 A.M.; the lcoal favorites Sally Rogers and Howie Bursen are planning a children's hootenanny around noon, and an adult-oriented concert is planned for 5:30 P.M. The Sunday schedule will begin at 10 A.M. with Helen Schneyer, Connecticut Valley Harmony and Joe Hickerson among theartists leading a group-sing of hymns, gospel tunes and other sacred pieces. Another large-scale concert will begin shortly after noon. Among the other folk notables to perform at the festival are Bridget Ball, Norman Kennedy, Christopher Shaw, Ed Trickett and the Little City String Band. For more information, call 583-0841.

title: KREMLIN DEPUTIES BASK IN NEW ROLE
description: Tired, exhilarated and rather proud of themselves, the deputies of the Supreme Soviet checked out of their hotels and went home today, having given birth to a new branch of government.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Improving the Minds at the Top
description: LEAD: SCHOOL PRINCIPALS are made, not born, at least in California. And the place they are made, at least since 1986, is the California School Leadership Academy. The program emerged from California's 1983 school-reform act, and with a little financial help from the Federal Education Department it currently operates 13 regional centers, at a cost of $4.8 million.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Reginald Pinder Weds Tanya Thomas
description: Tanya Yvette Thomas, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Alvin Thomas of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Reginald Samuel Pinder, the son of Valerie Pinder of the Bronx, at Scarborough Presbyterian Church in Scarborough Manor, N.Y. Bishop James I. Clark Jr. of Christ Temple Apostolic Church in New York, an uncle of the bride, officiated. He was assisted by the Rev. Garland L. Thomas, Pentecostal minister of the Church of God in Christ in Bridgehampton, L.I., a grandfather of the bride.

title: Urban Emergency Rooms: A Cocaine Nightmare
description: Crack has turned emergency medicine at Highland General Hospital here into a nightmare, a scene of chaos and despair that is crushing the spirits of all who encounter it.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a visit to Seville, Cordoba and Granada, I was surprised that you did not mention one of the best ways to visit the cities of Moorish Spain. We took the Andalusian Express, a restored 1920's train, which takes passengers on two-day, overnight trips beginning in Seville and ending in Malaga. We were taken sightseeing at the Mosque of Cordoba, walked through the Jewish sector and strolled the cobblestone streets. We dined on the train, slept comfortably in our cabins, then awoke to hot showers, followed by sightseeing at Granada's Alhambra Palace.

title: Park Avenue Joe Wins Hambletonian
description: History was made this afternoon at the Hambletonian, the most prestigious event in harness racing, when the raceoff, the deciding race to determine a winner, was declared a dead heat.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Revueltas, Ginastera, Villa-Lobos: String Quartets Cuarteto Latinoamericano. Elan CD 2218; CD only. Latin concert music of this century has tended toward the neo-Classical rather than the fiercely dissonant, with honorable attention paid to the varied folk traditions of the Latin countries. In the 1930's and 40's, the United States heard a good deal of this music, but those links have eroded in recent decades, and disks like this fine survey of Latin string quartets should help restore these composers to our repertories. Included are the Quartets Nos. 2 (''Magueyes'') and 4 (''Musica de Feria'') by the Mexican Silvestre Revueltas, the Quartet No. 1 by the Ar gentine Alberto Ginastera and the Quar tet No. 17 by the Brazilian Heitor Villa-Lobos. The performances, by an ensemble of varied Latin ancestry now in residence at Carnegie-Mellon Univer sity in Pittsburgh, are first-rate. - John Rockwell Hanson: Symphonies Nos. 1 and 2 The Seattle Symphony conducted by Gerard Schwarz. Delos D/CD 3073; CD only. To listen to Howard Hanson's symphonies is to feel America digesting the Romantic era. Hanson lived until 1981, and these pieces -the so-called ''Nordic'' and ''Romantic'' Symphonies - were written in 1922 and 1930 respectively. But this music is clearly about an older time as experienced by a newer coun try. Hanson's simple diatonic language, his strong, clean-shaven orchestration and his tendency toward un complicated heroism are never pretentious, always sincere, very American. Mr. Schwarz and his Seattle players respond in kind. - Bernard Holland Chopin: Sonatas Nos. 2 and 3 Mitsuko Uchida, piano. Philips 420 949; CD and cassette. The best things here are the palpable enthusiasm and the broad structural grasp that gives an unusually strong sense of arrival to the returns of big themes (especially the rising motif of the B minor finale, which wells up splendidly). The actual pianism is sometimes a little restricted in tonal palette, sometimes a little brittle; for some reason this seems more bothersome than it did when Ms. Uchida gave a joy ous, headlong rendition of the Third Sonata at Tully Hall last season. Perhaps the close miking has something to do with it; as so often in current piano recordings, the fortes are harsh and the bass overbalances the treble (try the big chords at the end of the exposition in the Second Sonata's opening movement). I enjoyed the Second less than the Third; the Funeral March sounds all too dogged, and its trio lacks lyricism. But the first movement of the Third has adventurous, expansive brio that I associate with this interesting artist's best work. - Will Crutchfield Alkan: Organ Works Kevin Bowyer, organ. Nimbus NI 5089; CD only. Charles-Valentin Alkan (1813-88) was a flamboyant and visionary composer of piano music, and from the evidence here, his organ music is just as flabbergasting. Although an organist in his youth, Alkan produced only a single work specifically for organ - a set of eight tantalizingly brief preludes. But the more substantial ''13 Prayers'' -with their astonishing harmonies, strange and often whimsical melodic de velopments and keyboard fireworks - are probably even more striking in their organ guise than in their original form for the now obsolete pedal piano. Still more spellbinding is the brilliant organ transcription of Alkan's two-piano ''Impromptu on the Luther Chorale,'' played with all the spectacular dazzle it can withstand by the superb British organist Kevin Bowyer. With the Salisbury Cathedral organ vividly captured, this disk should appeal to organ fanciers as well as to anyone with a taste for wonderfully extravagant music. - Mark Swed Stravinsky: Les Noces (1917 and 1923 versions) Alla Ablaberdyeva, soprano; Ludmilla Ivanova, mezzo; Alexey Martinov, tenor; Anatoly Safiulin, bass; Slovak Philharmonic Chorus; Savaria Symphony (1917); Adrienne Hauser, Zoltan Kocsis, Pi-Hsien Chen and Imre Rohmann, pianos, Amadinda Percussion Ensemble (1923); conducted by Peter Eotvos. Hungaroton HCD 12989; CD and LP. The composition of ''The Wedding'' cost Stravinsky much time and trouble. Though brilliantly conceived and seemingly spontaneous and inevitable, the roiling instrumentation of four pianos and percussion (1923) grew out of numerous false starts, including a com plete version with chamber orchestra (1917). Hungaroton offers that draft alongside the finished product, and it's fascinating to hear them side by side in comparable performances. This folkish work places scant premium on vocal refinement, and receives little here. The playing from both ensembles is gritty and incisive. Unfortunately, the performances together total only 46 1/2 minutes - perhaps not enough to attract the nonspecialist. - James R. Oestreich POP/JAZZ Harry Connick Jr.: 'When Harry Met Sally . . .' Columbia 45319; all three formats. The 21-year-old pianist and singer from New Orleans moves into challenging new territory on his third album with renditions of ''It Had to Be You,'' ''But Not for Me,'' ''Don't Get Around Much Anymore'' and ''I Could Write a Book,'' modeled after Frank Sinatra's recordings with Nelson Riddle. While Mr. Connick sounds a bit daunted by his co-producer Marc Shaiman's theatrically flashy arrangements, he still shows abundant promise as a band singer. Rounding out the album are smaller-scaled, jazzier versions of pop standards. Two of the best cuts are a lilting solo piano version of ''Autumn in New York'' and a voice-and- piano rendition of ''Where or When,'' which contains the disk's most relaxed, fluent crooning. The album is another step forward for an immensely gifted talent. - Stephen Holden New Winds: 'The Cliff' Sound Aspects 025 (import); all three formats. New Winds make fringes their home. The trio of Ned Rothenberg and J. D. Parran on saxophones, clarinets and flute, and Robert Dick on flutes and piccolo push their instruments beyond conventional technique, using double-stops, eerie whistle tones, percussive key thumps and cutting overblown notes. And New Winds can improvise or achieve a chamber-group precision, working on the fringe where the textures and twitterings of classical new music meet the sultriness of jazz. Collective improvisations and band members' compositions share the album with pieces by Duke Ellington and Ornette Coleman, balancing the earthy and the otherworldly. - Jon Pareles Joe Henderson: 'Inner Urge' Blue Note/CDP 7841892; CD only. ''Inner Urge,'' recorded in 1964, is one of the more brilliant documents from the period. The album seethes with intelligent experimentation, a reminder that the 1960's were full of political and esthetic promise as well as excitement. Backed by McCoy Tyner on piano, Bob Cranshaw on bass and Elvin Jones on drums, the saxophonist contrasts a granitelike bluntness with elliptical flowing lines. He'll break up a line with stuttering accents, drop a full-bloomed melody in the middle of things and then race off in sweeping be-bop lines. As a composer, he merged prairie-wide modal harmonies with sophisticated, rapidly changing harmonies that have made his tunes essential learning vehicles for fledgling jazz musicians, and a major part of jazz history. - Peter Watrous Jason and the Scorchers: 'Thunder and Fire' A&M 5264; all three formats Few bands can deliver clanging, stomping, crunching flat-out rock-and-roll like Jason and the Scorchers. The Nashville- based band uses three decades of technology to soup up its Chuck Berry twang, as Jason Ringenberg sings his pugnacious lyrics in a proud drawl and Warner Hodges plays zooming, skidding lead guitar lines; Mr. Ringenberg finds new ways to declare love, lust and automotive cravings. The slower songs lean toward self-consciously poetic soul-of-the-South pronouncements, but the band has regained its sense of proportion with its fourth album. Whenever pretension peeks out, another rock song blasts it away. - J. P.

title: TALKING: Testing; Impurities And Pests Persist
description: BEFORE approving a mortgage, lenders increasingly insist on testing the purity of the drinking water if the home relies on a private well and on checking for termites or carpenter ants.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'BARE' SHAKESPEARE

title:
GARDENING;
Safeguarding Irises and Peonies
description: LEAD: PLANTINGS of irises and peonies have been known to last for more than 50 years, especially those at family plots in old cemeteries. While not entirely free of problems, these durable perennials are extremely long lived and require relatively little care. Caretakers at cemeteries have had to do little more than the remove spent flowers or an occasional weed.

title: Day for Yastrzemski
description: For a guy who's supposedly retired, Carl Yastrzemski has been having lot of trouble getting in any fishing this summer. First there was his induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., two weeks ago. Now it's his old team, the Boston Red Sox, which has called Yastrzemski back from a fishing vacation in Canada.

title: Kathleen Connor Becomes a Bride
description: Kathleen Ann Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Connor of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Virgilio Del Col, a son of LaVonne Del Col of Demarest, N.J., and Peter Del Col of New York. The Rev. Edward R. Surwilo officiated at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Transcending the Rules of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Says Retarded Victim Couldn't Heed Officers
description: The family of a mentally retarded Brooklyn man who suffocated last month during a struggle with the police said yesterday that the man was too mentally impaired to understand what the officers wanted of him.

title: Sizzling With Gaiety and Spice
description: LARRY and the Redhead has taken Great Neck by storm. This new spot sizzles with spirit and excitement.

title: Shelley Duvall Tries Scaring Up A New Audience
description: Shelley Duvall stalks across the cobblestones of Universal Studios, arms folded against her chest. The midnight air is bone-chilling. The moon, two days shy of full face, rises in the cloudless sky. A horse neighs and a gush of wind topples a lamppost to the ground. The globe shatters. Actors and production crew members working on ''The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' emerge from the inky shadows to survey the damage.

title: FOOD: Western Flair; Come 'n' Get It
description: There really is a home on the range, and it looks just like you've always imagined. The cowboys sleep under the stars, they herd the cattle for branding and eat their meals around an open fire. The range cook, almost always a cowboy, gets up long before dawn to start the day's meals. It isn't an easy task: on the range, after all, there is no running water and no electricity - only a wood fire and 20 hungry cowboys.

title: Shame on the I.R.S.
description: Of all the scandals now rattling the Washington bureaucracy, none touches more Americans than wrongdoing in the Internal Revenue Service. Federal tax collectors regularly intrude on more citizens than any other arm of government. Such huge power requires scrupulous honesty. But a House subcommittee has spotlighted distressing laxity in staff supervision. It appears that the tax police need stronger policing.

title: Cape Cod's True Nature
description: LEAD: THE 65-mile-long strip of land known as Cape Cod is celebrated for its white beaches, its weathered houses and its plethora of antique shops. From early June to mid-October vacationers descend in droves. Yet, as the visitors cross over the canal that since 1914 has separated the Cape from the rest of New

title: AVARICE WAS A FAMILY TRAIT
description: CAPTAIN BENNETT'S FOLLY By Berry Fleming. 136 pp. Sag Harbor, L.I.: The Permanent Press.

title: Two Summer Blockbusters, One Busy Screenwriter a scene from ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' (Murray Close)-going for glib
description: It was the middle of the night when the screenwriter Jeffrey Boam was summoned from his San Fernando Valley home to a downtown police precinct. It wasn't for parking tickets.

title: Homesick for Hokum
description: FOR the 15 years that I lived abroad as a foreign correspondent, I don't think I missed too much of American culture, at least not much highbrow or middlebrow stuff. Books and magazines were sent to me, and I saw many of the movies and plays I wanted to see during visits home or to London. During the last few years I had access to videos. But in that time what I truly hungered for, and what I could not get enough of, was the shlock, the junk, the kitsch, the hokum, the hype and excess of my civilization.

title:
ART;
A Mix of Versatility and Novelty in Two Shows at Wave Hill
description: LEAD: JENE HIGHSTEIN, a near-legendary sculptor whose work is more talked about than seen around New York, has taken over Glyndor House at Wave Hill in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. But more spectacularly, he also occupies much of the Wave Hill lawn, sometimes interacting with the environment in dynamic ways.

title: Pulled Punches
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway Tunes Lead A Ligher Calvacade
description: IT is definitely light-listening time in the county this week, with only the Valhalla Wagnerfest and the Caramoor Festival left to uphold the honor of the classics. And even Caramoor is starting its week with a jazz concert by the Duke Ellington Orchestra today at 5:30 P.M.

title: '83 Strike on Lebanon: Hard Lessons for U.S.
description: The only time the United States sent its bombers over Lebanon, as President Bush was reportedly prepared to do again this week, the mission ended in a fiasco, with two planes shot down and one damaged, one pilot killed and and one crewman captured, and little to show for the effort.

title: Darling's Victory Recalls Some Past Drama
description: Too much of summer remains to sense the kind of urgency Ron Darling faced on that crisp October night in St. Louis nearly four years ago. The season had less than a week to go. The opponent was John Tudor. Darling's contribution was nine memorable scoreless innings that made an important victory possible.

title: Almost Everywhere, Construction Blocks the Way
description: WESTCHESTER residents are not likely to embark on excursions by car to many destinations within the county in the next year or two without encountering some highway construction.
