title: Anne Wenniger Weds
description: At the Farmers' Museum Church in Cooperstown, N.Y., Anne Miller deBuy Wenniger was married yesterday to Jonathan Douglas Herron. Lindley Garrison Miller, a village justice of Upper Brookville, L.I., and an uncle of the bride, officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mrs. Mace Louis deBuy Wenniger of Manchester, Mass., and the late William Wilson Miller 2d. Mr. Herron is a son of Dr. B. Bernie Herron and Mrs. Richard William Stapleford, both of New York. A graduate of Hampshire College, the bride is a freelance movie-set decorator, and her husband, a graduate of Dartmouth College, is a movie cameraman, both in New York.

title: Flags, Symbols and Substance
description: THIS is the way I remember the pledge to the flag as we used to give it in school. We fifth graders would stand up and face the flag. Right hand over heart we'd begin: ''I pledge allegiance to the flag...'' At that point we'd fling out the right arm, palm up, and continue, ''...of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.''

title: Correction
description: In an article July 16 about Los Angeles art, Luhring Augustine, a New York gallery, was misidentified. The article also misidentified Fran Seegull, the director of the gallery's New York office, who is moving to its California branch.

title: Night of Stars, Some Watched, Some Watching
description: Tuesday was a night for watching stars, off and on the screen. Cicely Tyson entered the Coronet Theater in Manhattan for the benefit preview of the Steve Martin film ''Parenthood'' with a garden of fragrant gardenias circling the neckline of her minidress. Dina Merrill and the junior committee of the New York City Mission Society were the hosts at the party for the society, the city's oldest human-service agency.

title: The Advantages Of Workers' Leave
description: The article by Senator Donald DiFrancesco and Assemblywoman Maureen Ogden, ''Needed: Workers' Leave'' (Opinion page, July 2), is splendid. It makes secure the position of the competent worker who relies on his or her job to take care of family units when it becomes necessary.

title: British Law Urged for Nazi War-Crime Trials
description: A report on a war-crimes inquiry has recommended changes in British law to allow prosecutions for Nazi war crimes said to have been committed by immigrants who have since become British citizens. The report said there was already enough evidence to convict three such people living in Britain.

title: Correction
description: An article on July 9 about the Games Gang Ltd. incorrectly described the genesis of the game Gender Bender. It was created by Loki Games Ltd. and developed by Chris Haney.

title: Neighbors Worry About the Garden That Sustains Them
description: LEAD: NINE-YEAR-OLD Tasi Spruill stood waist deep in tomato plants and sniffed the air with appreciation. ''I love the smell,'' she said. ''My mother takes me with her and makes me hoe rows and plant seeds. I feel like I'm doing something. I wouldn't mind coming down here every day.''

title: Special Education For the Gifted Disabled
description: We disagree with the anonymous ''special-education advocates'' who say there are ''no approved facilities that can academically challenge the small number of students who are both learning disabled and academically gifted'' (''Debate on Aiding Gifted Disabled Pupils,'' June 25). At the Newgrange School, we are providing an academically challenging program for some of the intellectually gifted and above-average learning-disabled students in the central New Jersey area. We provide a 1-to-3 staff-student ratio. Since our program is individualized, our gifted students can take calculus, discuss advanced literature, do challenging scientific experiments, learn computer programming and make optimum academic progress.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Mamaroneck, N.Y. $788,000 433 Claflin Avenue 3-bedroom, 3 full-, 2 half-bath, 67-year-old Tudor; fireplace, sun room, patio, porch, pool, greenhouse; taxes $11,971. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $316,000 Old Roaring Brook Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 69-year-old colonial; fireplace, patio, 1-car garage, 1.2 acres; taxes $4,802. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $450,000 Beech Hill Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 16-year-old New England barn; library, den, family room, loft, deck w/hot tub, brook, 3-car garage, 3.45 acres; taxes $6,622. Essex, Conn. $169,900 58 Lynn Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old Cape Cod; whirlpool bath, 2 decks, 0.75 acre; taxes $803. Stamford, Conn. $382,000 148 Skyline Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old ranch; in-ground pool, c/a, 1 acre; taxes $3,673. Wilton, Conn. $620,000 6 Fox Run 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 3-year-old colonial; stone walls on property, country setting, 2 acres; taxes $5,636. OTHER AREAS Seaford, L.I. $173,000 721 Arlington Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, 60- by 100-foot lot, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900. Williston Park, L.I. $217,000 28 Remsen Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old colonial; fireplace, attic, finished basement, mint condition; taxes $2,000. Howell, N.J. $147,900 28 Eric Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $2,379.

title: Gotland and Visby
description: To The Editor: Anne Matthews's piece on Gotland and Visby (Travel, June 25) was an excellent account of the town and the island from the point of view of one who teaches English. For the economic historian and the businessman, however, more could be said.

title: Artistry Is the Key to Copying 18th-Century Harpsichords
description: CARL DUDASH spends months researching, designing and building each harpsichord he makes in his Norfolk studio. But it is when he sits down at the keyboard to play that his face lights up, especially if the listener has never heard a fine harpsichord.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a wood end table that has a mark caused by a glass of water and a spot where paper is stuck to the finish. Can you advise me how to remove these blemishes?

title: Cris Evans and Gregory Cannon: Fashion Stylists
description: In 1980, Cris Evans, a teacher of fashion and costume design at the University of Cincinnati, yielded to the Midwestern yearning to test her mettle in New York.

title: Aeolians' Black Beaches, Fiery Peaks
description: TO the ancients, they were the islands of wind and fire. The Greek god Aeolus kept his winds imprisoned in a cave in the archipelago that takes his name, and flames leaping from the chain's volcanoes both terrified and guided Mycenaean, Greek and Roman mariners sailing the southeastern Tyrrhenian at night.

title: From Tchaikovsky to Heroin: A Brilliant Violinist's Decline
description: Anyone who thinks that the classical music business rewards musicians on the basis of talent alone should contemplate the case of Eugene Fodor.

title: Miss Torcellini, Reporter, Weds
description: St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Carolyn Alicia Torcellini, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Torcellini of Stamford, to John Farr Geer Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Geer of New York. The Rev. Benedict Tighe performed the ceremony. Cynthia Torcellini was her sister's maid of honor. Guillermo Bilbao served as his brother-in-law's best man.

title: Breakaway Priest Wins Few Followers
description: The breakaway effort by a black priest in Washington reflects a desire for assertion and recognition that has been prevalent among many black Roman Catholics in the last 20 years, black church members said. But many agreed that what was new was that it was a clergyman rather than a lay person leading the charge.

title: Service With A Smile
description: NATIONAL SERVICE has been one of the hot tickets in Congress of late, with legislators -most of them Democrats - virtually tripping over one another's schemes for involving large numbers of Americans in community service nationwide.

title: CONSUMER RATES
The Wanaque
description: To the Editor:

title: FLASHCARD
description: ABOUT half the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-A has been been penalized for breaking N.C.A.A. rules at least once since 1980. Division 1-A is the N.C.A.A.'s most visible competitive level, comprising 106 colleges and universities with big-time football programs. Most violations have occurred in basketball and football programs. Some schools are one-time offenders punished for relatively minor violations, while others have been penalized more often. Penalties range from public reprimands for minor procedural violations to bans on televised and post-season competition. The most seriously punishment has been leveled at Southern Methodist University, whose football program was suspended for a year. - National Collegiate Athletic Association

title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops
description: WILLIAM J. BENNETT never professed any vast knowledge about illegal drugs before President Bush named him the nation's first director of narcotics policy. But last week, after nearly six months of reading books and summoning hundreds of experts to ruminate on the subject, the former Education Secretary came forward with his first assignment: a strategy to halve in a decade the number of Americans who use drugs.

title: A Discerning Eye and a Democratic Outlook
description: More than anyone else except, of course, Frank Lloyd Wright, Edgar Kaufmann Jr. was responsible for Fallingwater, perhaps the greatest house of the 20th century. When the University of Pennsylvania gave Mr. Kaufmann an honorary degree two years ago, the citation called him ''both catalyst and witness in the creation of Fallingwater,'' which he very much was, but that is only the beginning.

title: THE NIGHT THE KAISER STRUCK NEW JERSEY
description: SABOTAGE AT BLACK TOM Imperial Germany's Secret War in America, 1914-1917. By Jules Witcover. Illustrated. 339 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill.

title: Planning a Weekend Group Trip: It's No Picnic
description: IN three years of organizing trips for members of her museum, Mable M. MacDonald, the curator of costumes at the Richmondtown Restoration on Staten Island, has learned a great deal about bus tours. What she has learned, sometimes the hard way, can assist people who put together trips for church groups, clubs or cultural organizations or family reunions.

title: One Man's List Of Golf's Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jennifer Marron To Be the Bride Of T. R. Eldridge
description: Announcement of the engagement of Jennifer Ann Marron to Thomas Rand Eldridge has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Donald B. Marron and Gloria Swope Marron, both of New York.

title: IT'S TACKY AT THE TOP
description: THE COST OF LIVING By Christopher Zenowich. 267 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Buying a Vacation Home Abroad
description: You've just come back from an idyllic stay in the south of France or on a secluded Caribbean island. Everything was perfect: the weather, the food, the pace of life.

title: Patti Paige: Cake Designer
description: If your vision of the perfect wedding cake involves stacks of snow-white layers strewn with flowers, then don't call Patti Paige. ''I'm not the flower queen,'' she said. ''When I get a call for a traditional wedding cake, I refer it to someone else.''

title: Jets Win Informal Affair
description: The Giants and the Jets drew a crowd of 8,500, at $6 a head, to watch the National Football League teams scrimmage at Lehigh University's year-old Murray H. Goodman Stadium today. Actually, it was a glorified practice. It started with 96 plays of 7-on-7 passing drills at one end of the field and 1-on-1 pass-blocking drills at the other. Then came a scrimmage in which each team ran 48 offensive plays.

title: Ebony Cargo, Transformed Into Classical Furniture
description: THE story behind ''On Board the Edna: Ebony,'' an exhibition of furniture at the Pritam & Eames Gallery in East Hampton, has the ring of a 19th-century tale of derring-do: A 90-foot, two-masted schooner sailing on the other side of the world, brings home a cargo of exotic woods from an island in the South Seas.

title: GUILT OR INNOCENCE ASIDE
description: FATAL ERROR The Miscarriage of Justice That Sealed the Rosenbergs' Fate. By Joseph H. Sharlitt. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title:
LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing;
A Leisurely Float Over the Treetops
description: LEAD: Poised somewhere between a sport and a pastime, ballooning has long captured people's imaginations, from the memorable scenes in ''Around the World in 80 Days'' to the publisher Malcolm Forbes's well-chronicled balloon adventures. When a balloon appears in the sky, earthbound spectators will watch transfixed.

title: Court Supports Ban on Driving by Dropouts
description: A judge has upheld a law that allows West Virginia to revoke the driver's licenses of school dropouds, Judge Paul Zakaib of Kanawha County Circuit Court said Friday that the law, a model for proposed Federal legislation, is based on an interest in keeping teen-agers in school, ''is not unreasonable and withstands any constitutional challenge.''

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: This deal was a panic move similar to the kind often made by that team across town. Not to take anything away from Juan Samuel, but Lenny Dykstra was the epitome of the Mets' scrappy style of play. DINO C.E. SCAROS Cliffside Park, N.J.

title:
The View From: Camp Mohawk;
A Summer Tradition, From Parents to Children
description: LEAD: ALISSA ROSEN, 12 years old, can't imagine a summer without Camp Mohawk. ''It's been so long, I don't know what else I'll do,'' she said recently.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Westminster; Visitation Policy Troubles Alumni And Local Church
description: When Virginia Douds attended Westminster College in the early 1960's, life at the small, church-related school had changed little since its founding in 1852. Students attended chapel services five days a week and men and women were banned from each other's dormitory rooms.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;
A Composer Luxuriating In the Shadow of Brahms
description: LEAD: When Brahms encountered Erno Dohnanyi's Piano Quintet in C minor in 1895, he was impressed. Small wonder. He might have thought he was looking in a mirror. From its opening bars, warm, burgeoning, taut and assured, the piece speaks with a lofty eloquence worthy of the German master. Striking on any terms, as the work of a 17-year-old the piece is astonishing.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Madison, N.H.; Motel Becoming Senior Housing
description: RENOVATIONS to be completed this fall will transform a motor lodge in this northern lakeside village into 21 housing units for the elderly.

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: The Samuel trade was a brilliant one. What better way to shake up a complacent team than to trade two solid, charismatic (and yes, streaky) former world champs for one mediocre strikeout king with no personality? DAN McGUIRE New York

title: Session on Rights in China to Be Test for U.N.
description: An international campaign to have China condemned by the United Nations for human rights violations in connection with its suppression of the democracy movement is expected at a meeting opening on Monday in Geneva.

title: DATABANK: Aug. 6, 1989
Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City
description: WILLIAM HOPKINS has been fighting drugs for more than 40 years, first as a Bronx narcotics officer and for the past 11 years as the supervisor of the street studies unit of the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services. He is retiring this year, as soon as a replacement can be named and trained.

title: Say It in EdSpeak: Word for Word
description: HERE is a report written by a school psychologist in California about a 9-year-old boy in the third grade whose teachers were concerned about his serious lack of academic progress. His name has been withheld.

title: Pros Who Know How to Get Rid of It All
description: THE tag sale was not to begin until 10 A.M. but some anxious customers were parked along the road the night before and had slept in their cars. More shoppers arrived at 7:30 A.M. and by 9:45, just before the sale was to open, dozens of people were lined up at the door hoping for the first crack at the advertised set of Mercedes tires, spinet piano and Oriental rug, as well as the hundreds of other items that are traditionally sold at low prices at such sales. Before the sale was over, hundreds of people would pass through the Stamford house on this Saturday.

title: 'El Coronel' Extended
description: Two unscheduled performances of the play ''El Coronel No Tiene Quien Le Escriba'' (''No One Writes to the Colonel'') will be given at 3 and 8 P.M. today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place. The play is in Spanish, with English translation available by headphone. Tickets are $15. Information: 598-7150.

title: Hostages Are the Victims Of Chaos as Well as Rage
description: ISRAEL'S kidnapping of a fundamentalist Shiite Muslim cleric nine days ago raised the curtain on a week of new horror and suspense over the fate of hostages in Lebanon. It started with a videotape of a hanged man that a terrorist group said was an American officer and with threats to kill more hostages. It ended with hints that half a dozen countries, perhaps even Iran, might be ready to work for an accommodation.

title: Corporate Takeovers?
description: FACT: The General Electric Foundation has committed $20 million over the next decade to help inner-city schools. Its goal: Double the number of college-bound youngsters from every school it goes into.

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: The Samuel trade is emblematic of the front office's inability to properly assess and address team needs. Dykstra and McDowell should have fetched more than the flawed Samuel, who is shaky on defense and not suited to his role as a leadoff hitter. RICHARD J. BRENNER Syosset, L.I.

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: The only time Samuel has helped the Mets was during the fight with the Reds. DAVE PELLAND Stratford, Conn.

title: Joan Hogan Wed to T. J. Gilman
description: Joan Lorraine Hogan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Hogan Jr. of New Haven, was married yesterday at the New Haven Lawn Club to Theodore Jones Gilman, the son of Mrs. George J. Halpern of Rye, N.Y., and Dr. Arthur E. Gillman of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Giles Dimock, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: An Incisive Look At Relationships
description: IT is well known to their friends that Trevor and Susannah are having a terrible time in the privacy of their bedroom. In fact, they are having a miserable time in every bedroom in which they find themselves, either together or separately.

title: Review/Ballet; French Dancers Star in London Troupe's 'Napoli'
description: Watching Patrick Armand's and Christine Camillo's terrific performance on Friday in August Bournonville's ''Napoli,'' one couldn't help wondering why so many visiting ballet companies put their best foot forward the second time around.

title: Harmony Envelops the DAT
description: The Last days of July profoundly altered the long-range outlook for audio. Obstacles that had hitherto barred the import of digital audio tape (DAT) decks were suddenly removed by an unexpected agreement between record companies and the manufacturers of DAT equipment. After three years of waiting and some bitter regulatory debates in Congress, American audio fans will at last have unhindered access to this superior method of home recording.

title: Prospects; Housing vs. the Economy
description: The Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes rose by 5.5 percent in June, the third consecutive monthly increase. The increase came after a sluggish first part of the year when sales fell to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. Seasonally adjusted, annual sales of new homes rose to 670,000 units, roughly the same as 1988. Housing sales are viewed by economists as an indicator of future economic activity. Three experts assess housing's forecast for the economy. Mickey D. Levy Chief economist, First Fidelity Bancorporation.

title: State Urged to Test Diesel Trucks For Emissions
description: LEAD: WITH increasing scientific evidence that exhaust from diesel-powered vehicles causes serious illness, including cancer, lawmakers and environmentalists are pressing the state to reverse its longstanding policy of not testing diesel trucks and cars for potentially hazardous levels of emissions.

title: Phelps And Hall Lift Yanks
description: The ball rose toward the afternoon sky today and then dropped quickly into Mel Hall's glove. There was, at that precise moment, a sense that the Yankees were going to crumble again, that their long, hot summer had reached another low.

title: Julie McC. Gilette Becomes a Bride
description: Julie McCarthy Gilette, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle P. Gilette Jr. of Minneapolis, was married there yesterday to Thomas Nelson Page Johns Jr., a son of Mrs. Johns and the late Dr. Johns of Richmond. Bishop Robert M. Anderson of the Diocese of Minnesota officiated at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Mark.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Sun Block Worship in Florida
description: LEAD: AT ONE TIME, 8-year-old Jennifer Scott of Coral Gables Elementary School in Florida maintained a deep, rich tan. Now, she protects her skin with sun blockers.

title: SOMEONE TO WALK OVER ME
description: DISAPPEARING ACTS By Terry McMillan. 384 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Earning More Than a Pat On the Back
description: EVERY time George Pina uses his Nikon 35-millimeter camera he thinks of his job at General Dynamics Corporation in New London. He does not take pictures for the company; he is an engineering chief in the Electric Boat Division. But five years ago, the company awarded him the camera as a result of his work, specifically detecting and later correcting a design deficiency he spotted during a submarine sea trial.

title: Elegy for the Underhill Oak, The Last of Four Giants
description: IT is always sad to lose a friend, one that you have known and admired for many decades. My dear departed friend was the Underhill Oak, a red oak, the largest and oldest in Yonkers. This arboreal giant stood 115 feet tall and had dominated the landscape near the foot of Underhill Street for at least 350 years.

title: S. L. Saxl Is Wed to Miss Goldberg
description: At Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia, Caroline Virginia Walter Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Goldberg of Philadelphia and Loveladies, N.J., was married last evening to Stephen Lawrence Saxl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman J. Saxl of New York. Rabbi Elliot J. Holin officiated. Mrs. Saxl, who was until recently curatorial assistant in the fine arts department at the Jewish Museum in New York, is a candidate for a doctorate in art history at the New York University Institute of Fine Arts. A graduate of Brown University, she received a master's degree in art history at the University of Michigan, where she was a Regents fellow. Her father is a trial lawyer in Philadelphia. Her mother, known professionally as Dr. Bettyruth Walker, is a writer and research associate at the University of Pennsylvania Law School.

title: A Painter of History Depicts Justices
description: WHEN Alton Tobey met with Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist last month, it was not to discuss legal issues. Mr. Tobey, the painter, had gone to Washington to complete his latest work, ''Equal Justice Under Law,'' a 6 1/2-by-9 1/2-foot mural depicting the 16 Chief Justices of the United States, from John Jay to Mr. Rehnquist.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: A SACRED cow is about to be gored here (or should I say ''clipped?''); food (fodder?) for thought. Fair warning. If your lawn is your life, if you thirst for the smell of clippings, live for the throb of John Deere under your seat, then pass this column by.

title: DEAL FOR A CAMPUS IN TEXAS COLLAPSES
description: A Sri Lankan woman has forfeited $75,000 worth of sapphires that she put up as a deposit and still owes $100,000 after failing to meet the deadline to buy a bankrupt college for $10 million, officials say.

title: What's Government Doing in the Arts Anyway?; The Censor's Psyche
description: To the Editor:

title: Insulting To Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: 60,000 Telephone Employees Stike Nynex
description: More than 60,000 telephone technicians, installers, operators and repair workers went on strike against the Nynex Corporation last night after contract negotiations broke down over whether emmployees will pay a share of health care costs.

title: A Fond Farewell For Lee Mazzilli
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Talking Your Way Out of College
description: AS GUARDIANS of the portals of American education, college admissions officers are threatened with lawsuits, offered bribes by parents and nonplussed at the antics of applicants. With the college-admissions season only a few weeks away, admissions officers recall incidents past and gird themselves for the autumn onslaught.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Raising the Nets
description: Would-be Michael Jordans on the playgrounds of Washington, D.C., and Alexandria, Va., call it slam-dunking, but local parks and recreation officials call it vandalism that destroys basketball rims. As a result the bureaucrats have ordered the rims raised by six inches. This could be a prime example of a well-intentioned reform with devastating side-effects.

title: Tara Powers Is a Bride
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., Tara Evan Powers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael John Powers of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Edmund Hausmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Jules Hausmann of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Patrick E. Brown officiated. A graduate of St. Lawrence University, as is her husband, the bride is a freelance copy editor. Mr. Hausmann is a management consultant for Environmental Resources Management in Exton, Pa.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Call Me Clitophon
description: LEAD: THE TERM ''ancient novel'' may sound like an oxymoron, or conjure up images of musty scrolls and cryptic scrawls, but modern experts have embraced the ancient Roman and Greek precursors of European novels as vital works with themes as universal as anything in contemporary literature.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Students Shoot for Third 'Nobel' Design Prize
description: LEAD: FOR THE DOZEN students in the Systematic Design Class at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago these are buoyant and tense days. They are one step away from again bringing worldwide design acclaim to their school.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Are to we to say the exchange is a church, that everything here is above-board all the time? And if so, name any business that is.'' A trading executive at a Chicago exchange, on last week's indictments.

title: After Savings and Loan Rescue, Lawmakers Go Home
description: At 12:06 this morning, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley announced to the chamber that it had given its final approval to President Bush's $166 billion rescue of the savings and loan industry, two hours after the Senate took similar action.

title: Driving Mobile Billboards
description: REGARDLESS of what we choose to do for our summer vacation, the majority of us will be traveling in our piece of the American dream: our cars.

title: Paige Robbins Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Robbins of Kings Point, L.I., and New Milford, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Paige Robbins, and Eric Nerenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Nerenberg of Rockville, Md. Miss Robbins, 23 years old, and Mr. Nerenberg, also 23, graduated from the University of Maryland. Mr. Nerenberg is a sales representative for Computer Graphics Distributing Company in Gaithersburg, Md., for which his mother, Beverly Nerenberg, is the vice president and his father is the president. Miss Robbins's father is the managing partner of the New York office of Kenneth Leventhal & Company.

title: Giants Silence the Astros and Extend Lead to 3
description: Mike LaCoss pitched seven shutout innings today and the Giants continued their mastery of the Houston Astros at Candlestick Park with a 7-0 victory.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: SPANISH DANCES

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: Joseph Epstein makes some valid points, but on one issue he is a victim of confused thinking.

title: A Glimpse of Victorian Era Social Life
description: LEAD: THE bonds between Victorian-era women - symbolized by the clothes they stitched in sewing circles, the foods they prepared and shared and the social traditions they kept - is the theme of a new exhibition at the Pound Ridge Museum.

title: Draftee Enlists Overseas
description: Usually, a top draft pick by a National Basketball Association team can start counting the money. Last week, Danny Ferry, the Duke basketball star who was the second player picked in the league's June draft, began counting his money, in lire. The 6-foot-11-inch forward passed up a chance to play for the Los Angeles Clippers and signed a reported one-year, $1 million contract to play for the Messaggero Roma team in the Italian professional league. N.B.A. officials said they could not recall another high ranked player who did not sign an N.B.A. contract. Mr. Ferry called it a ''once-in-a-lifetime offer'' to live in Rome and experience different cultures, ''all while playing the game I love.''

title: Ms. Campbell Becomes Bride Of Gary Shaye
description: Elizabeth Carter Campbell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin G. Campbell of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., was married yesterday to Gary Bruce Shaye, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Shaye of Albany. The wedding took place at the home of the bride's parents in Old Black Point. Joseph G. Lynch, a justice of the peace and a retired judge of the Probate Court in Portland, Conn., officiated.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Old Music Comes to Life at the Smithsonian
description: LEAD: With the Academy of Ancient Music, the English Concert and the London Classical Players, the original-instrument spotlight has been pretty well dominated by British performing groups. There are indications, however, that what began as a European phenomenon is finding the ground increasingly fertile in the United States: from Boston to San Francisco there are groups of growing importance playing 18th- and 19th-century music on original instruments.

title: New Services Target the Busy Pet Owner
description: LEAD: JUST as working parents need help with child-care and household responsibilities, pet owners often find it tough to juggle caring for their pets with other demands in their lives. Entrepreneurs looking for a niche and pet stores and suppliers trying to expand their services have seized on opportunities in the pet-care market, making life much easier for people with pets.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lakeville, Me.; Tribe Applies To Subdivide
description: A REAL-ESTATE concern acting on behalf of the Penobscot Indian Nation has applied for a permit to subdivide 2,100 acres of rolling hills and lakeshore in this barely developed town a couple of miles south of Springfield in northeastern Maine.

title: On Television: News, Lies and Videotape
description: ''What do you mean Felix Bloch might not be guilty - I saw him do it on television.'' The conversation took place at the Denver airport, and it was with a top editor of a major metropolitan newspaper. My friend, the editor, had heard the ABC News correspondent John McWethy report that the United States diplomat Felix S. Bloch was under F.B.I. investigation and had had his State Department passport revoked for allegedly passing top-secret information to a Soviet K.G.B. agent. My friend was aware that the F.B.I. had previously refused to comment, but what this experienced editor saw on the ''ABC World News Tonight'' was a videotape of ''Felix Bloch'' passing a briefcase to a ''Soviet agent.''

title: Montoya, 85, Playing Final Chords
description: LEAD: WHEN Carlos Montoya performs at the John Drew Theater in Guild Hall Saturday evening, it will be billed as a ''farewell concert.''

title: Rhode Island's Foursome of Wineries
description: THERE is something a bit perverse about the idea of making wine in Rhode Island. France and California seem more suited to the wine image. Traditionally the work ethic has been reserved for woolen mills and whaling ships in New England. But the contradiction is part of the allure of Rhode Island wines, even if the history behind it is a little fanciful: Colonial settlers tried to make wine from wild grapes, but gave up when they couldn't improve the taste.

title:
GARDENING;
Safeguarding Irises and Peonies
description: LEAD: PLANTINGS of irises and peonies have been known to last for more than 50 years, especially those at family plots in old cemeteries. While not entirely free of problems, these durable perennials are extremely long lived and require relatively little care. Caretakers at cemeteries have had to do little more than the remove spent flowers or an occasional weed.

title: Why Can't Grown-Ups Act Their Age?
description: ALL seemed wrong with the world, and that was as it should have been on Friday afternoon as I waited on the checkout line at the supermarket.

title:
FOCUS: Manufactured Homes;
Bankruptcy for Biggest Modular Maker
description: LEAD: THE nation's largest manufacturer of modular housing is struggling to lift itself out of bankruptcy in a case giving new evidence of the effects of the 1986 Tax Reform Act on a major housing producer.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Strides Made in Restoring an 1872 'Castle'
description: LEAD: A HISTORIC house in Ossining that has served the community in many forms is undergoing a $550,000 renovation to restore it to its original condition.

title: Runner at Half-Century Is Brought to Knees
description: LAST year I turned 50, and it didn't bother me a bit. I was in great shape. I weighed 20 pounds less than when I got married 23 years before. I had no gray hair, and from the front only a dignified receding at the temples was visible, suggesting, if anything, accumulating wisdom. It was fun assuring friends that indeed I was 50, and hearing ''You sure don't look it,'' and ''I never would have guessed.'' All this I owed to my jogging habit. Ten years ago I started jogging. My first route was a two-mile loop. On the first day, aiming for distance, not speed, I did the first almost completely downhill mile at a really slow trot. A slight rise in the middle almost stopped me, but it was short and I got over it. The second mile was rolling, ending with an uphill run back to the starting point. That first day I ran out of gas as soon as the downhill ended. Each run I tried to go a bit farther. After two months, I was able to jog the two miles, including the last uphill 200 yards, without stopping to walk. After that there was no looking back.

title: How the Poles Suffer Price Increases for Their Own Good
description: ''HE now takes milk, thin soups,''

title: VOUCHER, VOUCHER, WHO GETS THE VOUCHER?
description: PRIVATIZATION AND EDUCATIONAL CHOICE By Myron Lieberman. 386 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $12.95.

title: SHE SAW THE FUTURE AND IT FAILED
description: EMMA GOLDMAN IN EXILE From the Russian Revolution to the Spanish Civil War. By Alice Wexler. Illustrated. 301 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.

title: Catey Heller Wed to J. H. Terry 3d
description: Catherine Frances Heller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Heller of Winnetka, Ill., was married there yesterday to James Hendrick Terry 3d, a son of Kathryn P. Terry of New York and Dr. Terry Jr., of Brooklyn. The Rev David A. Donovan officiated at the Fourth Presbyterian Church.

title: Tennis Plan Roils Great Neck
description: LEAD: IN the affluent community of Great Neck, graphite tennis racquets and designer tenniswear seem to be everywhere and on any clear summer's day the thwak of tennis balls can be heard on hundreds of public and private courts.

title: On Terraces, Living Above It All
description: Even before the real-estate ads get around to mentioning the Panoramic Vu, the Wbfp, the Mble Bths, Wlkin Clst and Prewar Feeling, they announce - in large capital letters - that the living space for rent or sale has a TERR or ROOFTOP GDN.

title:
GARDENING;
Safeguarding Irises and Peonies
description: LEAD: PLANTINGS of irises and peonies have been known to last for more than 50 years, especially those at family plots in old cemeteries. While not entirely free of problems, these durable perennials are extremely long lived and require relatively little care. Caretakers at cemeteries have had to do little more than the remove spent flowers or an occasional weed.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Space for the 90's; Nurturing Productivity as Manhattan Offices Shrink
description: AS companies in Manhattan step cautiously into the 1990's, they are redesigning their quarters for fewer employees and smaller offices. Amid mergers, layoffs and growing fears of an economic downturn, office managers who only a few years ago were struggling to accommodate growth are looking for ways to reduce surplus space.

title: Mighty MITI
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Metropolitan Opera, No News Is Worrying News
description: This is the time of year when no news is the expected news from the Metropolitan Opera. It's the summer doldrums, with the theater turned over to ballet rentals, the solo artists off traipsing the festival circuit, and everyone else enjoying a bit of blessed vacation relief.

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: Questions. What is Samuel's on-base average? Are leadoff batters supposed to strike out often? Was McDowell responsible for the ground balls that his past teammates could not convert into outs? Is Dykstra still a hot dog with incredible marketability? Could Tom Edens possibly be related to Barbara Eden? Wasn't it Frank Cashen who acquired George Foster? Do you get the feeling Mets management watches but does not see? MICHAEL CARLSON New York

title: Time for the Jitters in Junk Bonds
description: For years financial Cassandras have warned of the dangers of ''junk bonds.'' The rapidly expanding market for these low-rated, high-yield securities was hastily erected on a small, fragile and inadequate foundation, they said, and sooner or later many companies issuing the bonds would be unable to meet their debt payments, leaving bond holders without buyers when they wanted to sell.

title: A Life Taken In Princeton
description: The article on the Sunday afternoon murder of an elderly Princeton woman (''A Life Taken, a Town's Illusion Lost,'' July 2), with its references to outsiders and drug addicts desperate for money, failed to mention that nothing was stolen and the murderer left the basement door locked, according to earlier reports. It's typically Princeton to project the evil onto strangers rather than looking closer to home. B. K. AUERBACH (Ex-Princeton resident) Millburn

title: Panel Formed to Seek Sites for Dredged Fill
description: LEAD: A NEW coalition has been established in Mamaroneck to address problems stemming from harbor dredging. Called Revitalize Our Waterways, it is made up of marinas, boatyards, yacht clubs, neighborhood organizations and individuals in Westchester, Fairfield and Nassau Counties.

title: A New Measure to Spur Private Housing
description: A 450-UNIT condominium complex in the Bronx is expected to be the first project in New York City to be built under a new state law that broadens the use of city capital-budget funds in assisting housing development on private land. The legislation was signed into law late last month by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: At a Summer Summit in Maine, Superpowers' Youth
description: Here in the Maine woods just west of Lewiston is a little summer youth camp on the shore of Worthley Pond where the campers say they like the food and spend their mornings discussing global politics.

title: TAMING THE WEST
description: The Western imprint on fashion is now much like a cattle brand - not too striking, but obvious enough to catch the eye. For city dudes, that means accents: a fringed jacket with black leggings; a shearling coat with a pin-stripe suit; a pair of lizard boots with almost anything. When in doubt about the mix, stride up to the mirror. If you're inclined to say, ''Yup,'' you've gone too far.

title: Maintaining Aluminum Siding
description: ALUMINUM siding is popular because of its easy installation, durability, good looks and affordable cost. However, to keep it looking its best, aluminum siding should be maintained regularly and repaired promptly if damaged.

title: Sarah Pracht Marries
description: Sarah Martin Pracht, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Pracht Jr. of Mechanicsburg, Pa., was married there yesterday to Stephen J. Geisler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Geisler of Murraysville, Pa. The Rev. Joseph Pease officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Geisler is a senior at the University of Pittsburgh. Mr. Geisler, a graduate of the university, is a software engineer for the Mentor Graphics Corporation in Beaverton, Ore.

title: Question Of the Week; Was The Samuel Trade Good For Mets?
description: It is not a question of whether Samuel is better than Dykstra or vice versa. Since 1986, the Mets' management in its wisdom has gradually sent away Mitchell, Knight, Backman, Dykstra, Mazzilli and Wilson. What is left is a fancy shell without a yolk. DAVID McMILLAN Richmond Hill, Queens

title:
SPECIAL SECTION: THE GENDER CARD;
Playing Favorites
description: LEAD: There is strong evidence today that nurture - in the role of parents, teachers and a society still influenced by sex stereotypes - plays an important part in determining how and what boys and girls learn. There is even stronger evidence that, particularly since the advent of the computer, the American education system is geared more closely to boys' learning styles than to those of girls.

title: Two Big Hitters Take Big Drops
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A CROP OF NEW AND EXOTIC SPECIES - FROM TALAPIA TO CRABS
description: In the last few years, farmers have been growing and experimenting with a host of new and exotic aquacultural species like talapia, abalone, sturgeon, hybrid striped bass, red fish, alligator, crab, crawfish and oysters. In many cases, these growers are trying to cash in on the dwindling supplies of these fish in nature.

title: '89 Taxes Shaping '90 Campaigns
description: LEAD: FOR most taxpayers, the $900 million in higher taxes imposed by the General Assembly and Gov. William A. O'Neill this year are still probably something of a mystery. Some of the taxes have not yet begun and some of the added costs to businesses have not yet been passed on to consumers. But for politicians and party leaders, the biggest one-year tax increase in state history is already the stuff of election strategy.

title: Don't Blame Reagan for Carter Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Recasting City Council To Make Room for More Minority Voices
description: NEW YORK CITY'S minorities are now thought collectively to have become its majority, but the local government does not yet reflect that demographic shift. All three citywide elected officials, the Mayor, Council president and Comptroller, are white. So are six of the eight members of the Board of Estimate, and three-quarters of the 35 members of the City Council.

title: The New York Area's Flat 'Move-Up' Market
description: THE weak market for homes in New York City's suburbs, where demand and prices have soured, is creating headaches for everyone trying to sell their houses - and migraines for sellers at the middle and high ends of the spectrum - according to economists and real estate brokers.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Villanova; Thrifty Students Learn to Shop From Catalogues
description: Students at Villanova University, like growing numbers of students at other campuses, are letting their fingers do the buying these days. Avoiding the crowds and costs of stores in their Main Line Philadelphia neighborhood, they are relying on catalogues instead.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Albertson $215,000 29 Dorset Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Holbrook $148,000 136 Huber Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 17-year-old ranch; dining room, den, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Mineola $191,000 397 Pennsylvania Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; new eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $2,200. Patchogue $159,500 473 South Ocean Avenue 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old, 2-family colonial; attic, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Seaford $173,000 721 Arlington Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, 60- by 100-foot lot, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900. Williston Park $217,000 28 Remsen Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old colonial; fireplace, attic, finished basement; taxes $2,000. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $450,000 Beech Hill Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 16-year-old New England barn; library, den, family room, loft, deck w/hot tub, brook, 3-car garage, 3.45 acres; taxes $6,622. Stamford, Conn. $382,000 148 Skyline Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old ranch; in-ground pool, c/a, 1 acre; taxes $3,673. Howell, N.J. $147,900 28 Eric Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,379.

title: Anchorless In the Desert
description: SITE preparation has begun on a $120 million retail and entertainment complex that developers and officials hope will be the cornerstone of this city's efforts to become the Beverly Hills of the desert.

title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION
description: AN INVISIBLE SPECTATOR A Biography of Paul Bowles. By Christopher Sawyer-Laucanno. Illustrated. 501 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $24.95.

title: Search to Resume for New Mail Site
description: THE United States House of Representatives has approved a measure that will temporarily block construction of a Postal Service General Facility on land adjacent to the Westchester County Airport.

title: From London, An ExplosionOf Dance Talent
description: The London Festival Ballet, which from now on will be officially known as the English National Ballet, has been the surprise hit of the dance season.

title: Cheap Power Is Misleading
description: The article ''2 Towns Warn of Power Demands'' (July 16) is very misleading.

title: Elsie Hamilton Becomes Bride
description: Elsie Cryder Hamilton, a daughter of Mrs. Ferris F. Hamilton of Englewood, Colo., and the late Mr. Hamilton, was married yesterday at the home of her mmother to Thomas Edward Judkins Hazard, a son of Mary Suzanne Sheppard of Towson, Md., and Robert Culver Hazard Jr. of Potomac, Md. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Albert Fay Hill, a Presbyterian minister. The bride, an artist, will keep her name professionally. She graduated from the Foxcroft School and Pitzer College. Mr. Hazard, who graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, N.J., and Goergetown University, expects to receive a J.D. degree in 1991 from the university's Law center. He was formerly a reporter and editor for the Congressional Quarterly in Washington.

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: I found Joseph Epstein's article a little disappointing. Lots of mental-health research has showed that the mistreatment of children leads to lasting emotional damage, including feelings of worthlessness, helplessness and anger - i.e., the perception of oneself as a victim, even decades after the abuse has stopped.

title: Less-Volatile Fuel Going Into L.I. Cars
description: LEAD: ENVIRONMENTAL agencies in much of the Northeast, including Long Island and New York City, are requiring gasoline suppliers to provide motorists with a less-volatile fuel this summer.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a wood end table that has a mark caused by a glass of water and a spot where paper is stuck to the finish. Can you advise me how to remove these blemishes?

title: Peter M. Pofshek and Nina Hofer Exchange Vows
description: Adeline Hofer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Arms Hofer of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Peter Max Polshek, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart Polshek of New York and Stone Ridge, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Chapel of at Colubia University by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, the Unitarian-Universalist chaplain at columbia University.

title: The Mortgage Is Paid Up. Hurrah?
description: DO people burn the mortgage anymore? Or even shred it? I was ready to do either because I had reason to celebrate. After 25 years, the last payment on the house was made.

title: Tettleton Out
description: The struggling Baltimore Orioles suffered a setback yesterday when their slugging catcher, Mickey Tettleton, was placed on the 15-day disabled list. Tettleton, who had 22 home runs this season, will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow to repair torn cartilage in his left knee and will be out at least three weeks, the club announced. The knee has been bothering him for several weeks. Jamie Quirk, a veteran catcher who was released by Oakland on July 24, was signed to replace Tettleton. (AP)

title: Emily A. Miller Weds J. S. Romm
description: Emily Anne Miller, the daughter of Thomas Moreland Miller of Wyland, Mass., and the late Mary Elizabeth Radle Miller, and James Sidney Romm, the son of Sydney Reed of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Richard Usen, and the adopted son of Alan Romm of New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's father. The Rev. Randall K. Wilburn, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Man Ejected From Pool Returns and Shoots 4
description: A man apparently angered by a lifeguard who ordered him out of city swimming pool in Washington Heights yesterday opened fire on the lifeguard, wounding him and striking three bystanders, one of whom was critically injured, the police said.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: ALL GOD'S CRITTERS GOT A PLACE IN THE CHOIR. Words and music by Bill Staines. Illustrated by Margot Zemach. E.P. Dutton. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 7) A witty and distinctive illustrator has set the words of a popular folk song in a rural, prairie Eden. Children and animals gather round a plain farmhouse in a choir where ''some sing low, some sing higher.'' A season passes in the increasingly rich pictures and the finale is wondrously crowded.

title: POSTINGS: Suit Over Non Sequitur; What's in a Digit?
description: Some residents of West 62d Street are annoyed by the floating address of a new apartment house in their neighborhood and are suing to try to anchor the number before it causes more confusion among people doing business in or visiting the area.

title: A Touch Of the Poet
description: MOLIERE WROTE, ''Anyone may be an honorable man, and yet write verse badly.'' This was in the 17th century, before personal computers and Michael Newman's Verse Perfect poetry processor. Using Mr. Newman's software for MS-DOS computers, anyone, honorable or not, can harness the algorithmic powers of the microprocessor to generate acceptable verse in forms ranging from iambic-pentameter sonnets to rap music lyrics.

title: The Society Race
description: Reviving a damaged, stultified society is a Herculean task.

title: A Shipping Clerk Reaches the Top
description: GOING from part-time shipping clerk to president takes a little more than luck, yet Ralph Frickel, the 34-year-old president of Benfield Electric International here, said he believes that simply being in the right place at the right time played an important part in his career.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GORKY: A Biography. By Henri Troyat. (Crown, $19.95.) This short, highly readable biography chronicles the tempestuous life of Maxim Gorky (1868-1936), the Russian novelist, dramatist and revolutionist. Based closely on Gorky's own autobiographical volumes, ''Gorky: A Biography'' vividly details the writer's humble beginnings and hellish, hyper-Dickensian childhood, in which the only solace came from books, chiefly French novels in Russian translation - Dumas, de Kock, Balzac.

title: Sharing a Screen - Long Distance
description: Ted has been in New York on business and his colleagues in Texas want to know how things are going. They can call or write or send a facsimile or electronic mail to him. But what they really need to be able to do is hold a conference with him, because the spontaneous exchange of information among executives is often the spark that leads to important decisions.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SLEEPING IN FLAME. By Jonathan Carroll. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Restless and unconvincing, Jonathan Carroll's fourth novel careers nervously from one genre to another. First, it's a putatively glamorous tale set largely in Vienna and centered on two Americans, the screenwriter and actor Walker Easterling and his wife, Maris York, once a supermodel and now a successful sculptor working with Lego blocks.

title: Senators Propose Federal Fees on Carriers at 4 Crowded Airports
description: Lawmakers and aviation groups, who have been fencing for years over how much airlines should be charged for the use of airports, are opening a new battlefront. A Senate committee has proposed charging Federal user fees next year at four of the nation's most crowded airports.

title: Are Airline Stocks Flying Too High?
description: The stocks of major airlines should have been grounded months ago in the view of many analysts. Airlines have had to raise their fares in recent months to make up for a decline in American travel. And airline stocks generally fare poorly in a recession.

title: Dorsett Has Surgery
description: The Denver Broncos' Tony Dorsett, the National Football League's No. 2 career rusher, underwent major reconstructive knee surgery in Colorado yesterday, leaving his football future in jeopardy.

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: Blaming victims is an all-American sport, and Joseph Epstein has made the A-team. In his article ''The Joys of Victimhood'' (July 2), he berates almost everyone who claims to be victimized but has no qualms when he decries his own victimization as a college-bill-paying parent.

title: Teen-Agers Get a Taste of 'What Graduate School Ought to Be'
description: LEAD: OBLIVIOUS to the 90-degree heat, 14 teen-agers clad in shorts, T-shirts and sandals ringed a table in a musty classroom and animatedly discussed the social and economic factors differentiating pre-Revolutionary France and England.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newtown, Pa.;
546-Unit Plan Faces Hurdle
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER who has a contract to buy a 74-acre sod farm is seeking a change in zoning to build on the site a condominium apartment and town-house project of 546 units, including about 80 condominium apartments that would sell for $25,000 to $70,000.

title: Nicaragua Plans to Urge Immediate End to Contras at Talks
description: Buoyed by agreements with its domestic political opponents, the Government of Nicaragua comes to a Central American meeting this weekend to press for the immediate demobilization of anti-Government rebels in Honduras.

title: Black University Fights Desegregation Order
description: Louisiana's largest black college, Southern University, has gone to court in an effort to block a Federal court order aimed at desegregating the state's colleges.

title: FICTION
description: TALENT. By Howard and Susan Kaminsky. (Bantam, $18.95.) The authors of this irritating novel are publishing veterans - he's the president of the Hearst Trade Book Group, she's a former editor - so presumably they know something about the world of talent agencies, which forms the backdrop for their breathless account of the glitzy activities of New York and Hollywood deal makers. Unfortunately, the story is trite, its dialogue filled with cliches and its heroine so obtuse it seems unlikely she could run a hot-dog stand, let alone ''the biggest and most powerful talent agency in the world.'' Allison Morton, a beautiful, young Harvard Law graduate, becomes the head of Universal Talent Management when her Uncle Gus dies of a heart attack after a mysterious fire in his home. In the course of fighting off a hostile takeover attempt by the sinister Frame family, Allison discovers that she's adopted - and that someone is trying to kill her. As ''Talent'' proceeds, Allison repels the Frames, unmasks her biological mother and the would-be killer and is reunited with her boyfriend, a gorgeous New York playwright who was alienated from her by the machinations of a treacherous U.T.M. subordinate. Since Allison is basically a stick figure in designer clothes, as are most of the other characters, it's unlikely that readers will be terribly thrilled by her triumph over adversity. The novel's implausible plot twists and relentless dropping of famous names finally become so tiresome that only those with an insatiable appetite for show biz sagas will find ''Talent'' worth their while.

title: POSTINGS: 37 Stories for Jersey City; On the Waterfront
description: Ground has been broken for the main office building in the Newport Center project in Jersey City, a $10 billion development that eventually will cover more than 300 acres along the Hudson River waterfront opposite lower Manhattan. The new building, a 37-story stone and granite structure, will contain a million square feet of rentable space. It will be the tallest structure in and the centerpiece of the development.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: NEWTOWN, PA.;
546-Unit Plan Faces Hurdle
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER who has a contract to buy a 74-acre sod farm is seeking a change in zoning to build on the site a condominium apartment and town-house project of 546 units, including about 80 condominium apartments that would sell for $25,000 to $70,000.

title: Mind Blowing
description: Where and when do differences between men and women begin - the ones that result in aptitude-test disparities and battles over relative ability in the sciences and verbal fields? Some researchers speculate that there are actual neurological distinctions between the sexes at birth, ranging from the anatomical to the biochemical. But how such differences could affect the way males and females think and learn is an even murkier question than whether the differences exist.

title: Bush Will Name Panel On '88 Pan Am Crash
description: President Bush has agreed to name an independent commission to investigate aviation security in the aftermath of the bombing of a Pan American airliner over Scotland last December, members of Congress say.

title: THE DISCREET ANXIETY OF THE BOURGEOISIE
description: FEAR OF FALLING The Inner Life of the Middle Class. By Barbara Ehrenreich. 292 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: THE JOYS OF VICTIMHOOD
description: Mr. Epstein writes that he knows lots of people who have been ''kicked very hard in the stomach by fate. Without denying or attempting to disguise the effects of this devastating kick, they neither whine about it nor protest it.'' Are we to believe that Mr. Epstein has a list of victims who suffer stoically?

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: Computers can be applied to bridge in a variety of ways. They do rather badly when they try to play the game, but perform quite well as teaching aids and very well indeed in simulating hands for theoretical study.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Regarding Joan Gould's article on the Great Mosque of Cordoba, which I visited many years ago: Each of the 850 pillars has a lead plate at the top. In case of earthquake, instead of stone rubbing against stone, the lead acts as a buffer.

title: So Far, Congress Comes Up Short on Ideas
description: RARELY has a summer vacation been so eagerly awaited. The 101st Congress broke for its August recess this weekend in a frustrated and uncertain mood. Yes, it was jarred by ethics scandals and slowed by the transition to new leadership in both houses. But with the leaders in place now and the turmoil receding, it is clear that some larger trouble is at work.

title: Britta L. Olson Becomes Bride
description: Britta Lynn Olson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Erik Olson of Portland, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Paul Konopka Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Konopka of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Hector LaChapelle performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Flat Earthers?
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y. Deli Southern Fried Style
description: LOOKING UP from a corned beef and pastrami on rye, a weary traveler on Interstate 95 sees the Manhattan skyline; Broadway show tunes are in the air. The skyline is painted on the window and the tunes come from stereo speakers - but it's not bad for St. Pauls, N.C.

title: Fertilizer Found to Rid Alaskan Shore of Oil
description: The apparent triumph of bacteria over oil in Alaska's Prince William Sound is one of the few pieces of good news to have emerged since the wreck of the tanker Exxon Valdez, the nation's environmental chief, William P. Reilly, said today.

title: NONFICTION
description: IT DID HAPPEN HERE: Recollections of Political Repression in America. By Bud Schultz and Ruth Schultz. (University of California, $22.50.) In 1949, Arthur Drayton, a postal worker, was suspended from his job after 25 years of service. His offense: the refusal to disassociate himself from an organization deemed subversive by President Harry S. Truman's loyalty boards. Mr. Drayton's account of political discrimination is included in ''It Did Happen Here,'' a collection of oral histories compiled by Bud Schultz, who teaches education and psychology at Trinity College in Hartford, and Ruth Schultz, an independent scholar. The turbulent course of the 20th century is traced in the harrowing stories of people like Jack Miller, who survived the 1916 Everett Massacre, in which at least half a dozen members of the Industrial Workers of the World were gunned down by local authorities in Everett, Wash., and Chuck McDew, the civil rights leader, who was beaten and jailed for his activities in the 1960's. Violations of constitutional rights are Government-sanctioned, the editors write, and perpetrated behind a ''veil of patriotism.'' It is their contention that repression is not confined to periods of political frenzy. Witness the case of the leftist writer Margaret Randall, whose deportation was ordered in 1986 under the McCarran-Walter Act. For all the outrages described in this book, it is not defeat that resounds but a steadfast defiance and the knowledge that the fight for civil liberties is a continuous one.

title: Towns Progressing on Landfill Deadline
description: LEAD: AFTER six years of pressure from the State Department of Environmental Conservation, political buck-passing and intensive community debate, Long Island's mountainous landfills are getting closer to closing.

title: Lyn and Karen Mandelbaum: Jewelry Designers
description: Lyn is the tall one who does all the talking. Karen is tiny and quiet, but you can't miss the fact that they are sisters. Their features are similar, and both wear their dark-blond hair in a casual tousle. They wear similar jewelry: elaborate drop earrings and multiple chains dripping charms and semiprecious stones.

title:
MUSIC;
At Zoo Concerts, Animals Listen Too
description: LEAD: THE ponies' ears perk up and the peacocks settle themselves close to the performers, but the cougars are somewhat oblivious to what is going on. Richard Ryan, director of the Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, said concerts in zoos are ''a 200-year-old European tradition.''

title: Ms. Range Weds D. R. Scheidemantle
description: Cheryl Lynne Range, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Range of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., and David Robert Scheidemantle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Scheidemantle of Nanuet, N.Y. were married yesterday at the Neighborhood Church in Palos Verdes Estates. The Rev. Karl A. Johnson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Lomax Won't Retire
description: One day after Neil Lomax, the Phoenix Cardinals' quarterback, seemed ready to retire because of an arthritic left hip, he instead announced yesterday that he would remain with the team.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Rome'' (Travel, June 18) provided a good summary of what visitors can see and do, but one very important bit of advice was missing. First-time visitors should be cautioned about the many pickpockets, including small groups of children. They seem to have an uncanny eye for spotting visitors from the United States. T. J. KLEIN Groton, Conn.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DONNA O'NEESHUCK WAS CHASED BY SOME COWS By Bill Grossman. Illustrated by Sue Truesdell. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: FICTION
description: THE NIGHT OF THE MOONBOW. By Thomas Tryon. (Knopf, $18.95.) The 1938 summer season is well under way at Friend-Indeed, a Bible camp in the northeastern corner of Connecticut, when a new boy, Leo Joaquim, arrives to take the place relinquished by another camper, Stanley Wagner (a definite ''spud'' according to fellow campers), who has departed under awkward circumstances. Hopes are high that Leo, an odd, gangly, unathletic orphan who plays the violin and collects spiders for a hobby, will do his bunkmates proud in their quest to win the camp's all-around trophy, given to the cabin that wins the most prizes in the summer's many competitions. And so, thrust into an unfamiliar world inhabited by kids with nicknames like Tiger and Bomber, a spoiled rich-kid counselor named Reece (Heartless) Hartsig and Ma and Pa Starbuck, the benign couple who run the camp, Leo does his best to fit in. Only his best isn't quite good enough. Soon Leo, who quickly earns the sobriquet Wacko, finds himself in the midst of what some might call a season in hell. In ''The Night of the Moonbow'' (a title that refers not only to the lake adjoining the camp but also to a local legend, complete with Indian warrior and maiden), Thomas Tryon, the author of ''Harvest Home'' and ''The Other,'' presents a tale that begins as an appealing account of life at summer camp and the trials and tribulations of a square peg trying to fit into a round hole. Mr. Tryon has a wonderful ear, and his writing is crisp and evocative. Unfortunately, in midstream he changes canoes, apparently feeling that his readers expect a touch of terror and suspense. This is provided by a secret concerning Leo's mother's death that the boy has so far managed to repress. But the secret and the tragic events its revelation sets in motion are neither particularly horrifying nor unexpected, and so a novel that began very promisingly falls somewhat flat in the end. Nevertheless, thanks in no small part to Thomas Tryon's skill as a writer, there is still plenty of offbeat fun to be had at Camp Friend-Indeed.

Roughly half of the sculptures are deployed over a substantial portion of the estate's 80 acres; the remainder are in the complex's Main Hall, known as the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art.

In a central area of the steps, dense with concentric circles of the press, stood a forest of microphones and television cameras. Fifteen minutes after the decision was announced, Faye Wattleton, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, took her place behind the microphones and began to speak.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE average base salary of public-school teachers was almost $10,000 more than that of private-school teachers during the 1985-1986 academic year, the latest for which figures are available. Nonsectarian private schools have higher average base salaries than religious schools. The salaries in Roman Catholic schools are not significantly different from those at schools with other religious orientations. There are about 23,500 private elementary and secondary schools in the United States, of which 40 percent are Catholic, 40 percent are affiliated with other religions, and 20 percent are unaffiliated with religions. - National Center for Education Statistics, ''Teacher Compensation: A Comparison of Public and Private School Teachers, 1984-1986''

They look like what occurs to you at 4 o'clock some morning when you have racked your brain to figure out what to play against a solid defense that has so far mocked all attempts to find something - anything - wrong with it.

title: 46 Face Charges In Chicago Inquiry
description: Forty-six traders were indicted on charges that they repeatedly defrauded customers at Chicago's two commodity futures exchanges. The indictments stemmed from a two-year investigation that put undercover Federal agents, posing as traders, on the floors of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. ''We are talking about hundreds of customers and thousands of trades,'' said Anton R. Valukas, the United States Attorney in Chicago. The Government said customers' profits were skimmed by traders through practices like falsifying records and arranging secret trades. Reports said that 14 of the indicted traders had agreed to plead guilty and cooperate with investigators. More indictments are expected. *

title: I Was Reborn at Hiroshima
description: LEAD: Forty-four long years have passed since that fateful day in Hiroshima.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Large Menu of Italian Favorites

title: Hal Hinson Wed To Henny Wright
description: Henrietta Wright, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Charles Alan Wright of Austin, Tex., and Hal Hinson, a son of Mrs. Claude Hedspeth of Jefferson, N.C., and Harold L. Hinson of Southern Pines, N.C., were married yesterday at Christ Church, Georgetown, in Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner performed the Episcopal ceremony. Henny Hinson Wright, as the bride will be known, graduated from Yale College. She worked on the White House staff under President Carter before receiving a J.D. degree from Yale Law School, where she was an editor of The Yale Law Journal. She is an associate at Goldberg & Spector, a law firm in Washington. Her father, who holds the William B. Bates chair at the University of Texas Law School, is the author of the 24-volume treatise ''The Federal Practice and Procedure'' and represented President Nixon in the Watergate tapes case.

title: The Folkloric and The Newfangled In Kenya
description: Many Americans will forever think of African music as folk music. Every year this becomes more of a mistake. In urbanized Africa, untainted folk music has grown as quaint and artificially preserved as it is in the cities of the West. The singing griots of Mali and elsewhere keep an oral folklore tradition alive, but Kenya best shows how folk styles can be both up-to-date and sustain ethnic and national identity.

title: SURREALISM FIT THE FASHION
description: The fashion photographs in MAN RAY: BAZAAR YEARS (Rizzoli, Cloth, $35; Paper, $19.95), shot for Harper's Bazaar between 1934 and 1942, meld commercialism with artistry of uncommon power. These pictures, most of which have not been reproduced since their original publication, do more than display pretty models filling out fabrics and styles by such celebrated designers as Chanel, Schiaparelli and Mainbocher. These are pictures to dream about - images that promote desires and provoke fantasies and emotions. And sometimes, like fractured dreams, they tell stories. A man's hand reaching for a fallen handkerchief, the closeness of a woman's jeweled sandal - bits of a larger drama - foretell an intimacy about to happen. Many of the photos, assembled by John Esten, the former art director at Harper's Bazaar, show women poised for sleep or nocturnal adventure in gauzy nightgowns and negligees, and that seems fitting. Isn't fashion itself the stuff of dreams, manufactured fantasies for the consumer? A model reclining as if asleep, in a beach coat that looks like pajamas - dreaming of what? Possibly the giant female lips floating in a landscape above her (the lips and landscape are actually one of Man Ray's Surrealist paintings). Man Ray was also a great innovator. A nude outlined in what appears to be ultraviolet light, his ''Rayographs'' - produced by placing objects on or near sensitized paper and exposing them to light - and his transmission of fashion silhouettes from Paris to New York via radio waves are just a few examples. Fashions may come and go, but the freshness of these classic photographs even today makes it clear why the artist's influence on fashion photography has spanned the decades.

title: Havana Imposes Ban on 2 Soviet Journals
description: The Communist Party has banned the circulation of two Soviet publications that it said promoted bourgeois democracy and the American way of life, the official newspaper Granma said Friday.

title: POSTINGS: $1,500 a Square Foot; The Rhinelander Mansion Resold
description: An Irish investment company has paid what may be a record price, on a square-footage basis, for a Manhattan commercial building purchased for investment, rather than redevelopment, purposes - $43 million, or more than $1,500 a square foot. The property is the old Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo mansion at 867 Madison Avenue, on the corner of 72d Street. The ornate French Renaissance-style structure was finished in 1898, landmarked in 1976 and extensively renovated in 1985 after it was leased to Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation as the fashion company's flagship store.

title: Mother Nature Will Provide
description: Insofar as erosion on Long Island's South Shore, I say, ''Don't mess with Mother Nature!'' If one looks back, say to the day the Fire Island Lighthouse was built, the water was literally a stone's throw away. There would be no Robert Moses State Park there today if it weren't for erosion. What the sea took away in other places, it gave back on Fire Island. This is because of a phenomenon known as the longshore current, which comes from the angle of the waves. Because of this angle, the current moves from east to west. (e.g., when swimming, after a while people have to walk a good ways back to their belongings).

title: Review/Opera; How Santa Fe Handles a Built-In Problem in 'Rosenkavalier'
description: Few roles in the opera repertory demand more stage presence, intelligence and psychological insight of a lyric soprano than that of the Marschallin in ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' This most complex of Strauss heroines is a princess from whom authority naturally radiates but whose power to command respect depends as much on her cultivation and brains as on her high position in the Viennese aristocracy. She is a beautiful woman whose sense of beauty's impermanence is sharply developed: although by no means as yet a faded flower, she foresees that her young lover, Octavian, will soon abandon her for a fresher face. She has the compassion to understand why that must be so and the good sense to give him up while he is still in love with her. No wonder sopranos dream of the day when they will be asked to sing the Marschallin.
