title: Call It Pi In the Sky
description: LEAD: I shouldn't have let the news upset me; it was cause for celebration. Two Columbia University mathematicians, using a powerful computer, had calculated the symbol pi to 480 million decimal places. Yet it has troubled me ever since.

title: Crack's Smallest, Costliest Victims
description: In a few months a new task force headed by Dr. James O. Mason, the Assistant Secretary for Public Health, is slated to tell President Bush what America should do about ''crack babies'' - the thousands born brain-damaged, malformed or seizure-prone because their mothers smoked crack during pregnancy. The answers aren't obvious.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Mahaffey Takes the St. Jude: John Mahaffey shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday for his first PGA Tour victory in three years as he rallied to capture the Federal Express St. Jude Classic in Memphis. The victory was the 10th of Mahaffey's pro career but his first since the 1986 Tournament Players Championship. Mahaffey finished at 12-under 272 and earned $180,000. (AP) Triumph for Daniel: Beth Daniel, shooting a 71, won for the first time in four years yesterday by making 18 successive pars for a four-stroke victory over Sherri Turner in the Greater Washington Open. The tournament was held in Potomac, Md. Daniel, who finished at eight-under-par 205, earned $45,000 to move past Pat Bradley and into third place on the L.P.G.A.'s earnings list this year. (AP) A First in Seniors: Tom Shaw sank a 2 1/2-foot par-saving putt on the 18th hole yesterday to win the U.S. West Showdown Classic in Jeremy Ranch, Utah, for his first victory on the PGA Senior Tour. Shaw, a 50-year-old Senior Tour rookie, finished with a final-round 70 for a nine-under-par 207 to earn the $52,500 first prize.(AP) CYCLING LeMond Is 4th as a Swiss Wins: Jorg Muller of Switzerland broke away on the final lap yesterday to win the Grand Prix of the Americas in Montreal. Greg LeMond, winner of the Tour de France, finished fourth. Muller finished in 6 hours 3 minutes 39 seconds. The race covered about 139 miles.(AP) BOXING Paez Retains Title: Jorge Paez suffered the first knockdown of his career but recovered to score a unanimous decision over Steve Cruz yesterday afternoon in El Paso to retain the International Boxing Federation featherweight title. Paez, who is from Mexicali, Mexico, raised his record to 30-2-2, as he defended the crown for the third time. Cruz dropped to 33-4. (AP) AUTO RACING Andretti Surmounts Mistakes: Michael Andretti overcame a handful of early mistakes yesterday on the way to his second successive Indy-car victory, winning the Marlboro 500 at Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich. The 500-mile race was marred by an accident in which the journeyman driver Phil Krueger suffered critical chest injuries and possible broken ribs. Andretti, who drove a Chevrolet-powered Lola, earned $129,359. He averaged 160.210 miles an hour in the race, which was slowed by eight caution flags for a total of 59 laps. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Unspectacular High Jump: Javier Sotomayor of Cuba and Hollis Conway of Lafayette, La., failed to exceed their world and American high jump records yesterday at the Jack in the Box Invitational track and field meet at U.C.L.A.'s Drake Stadium. Sotomayor, who on July 29 became the first man to clear 8 feet, won yesterday at 7 feet 8 1/2 inches. Conway, who on July 30 set an American mark of 7-10, was second yesterday at 7-6 1/2. (AP)

title: The Hostages: Where the Principals Stand
description: United States: Washington has refused to make concessions for the release of hostages but has said that Israel is free to do so. American officials have also said they are prepared for military action if hostages are harmed.

title: Bolivia Set to Join GATT
description: Bolivia has agreed to become the 97th member of the world's main trade forum, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which sets the rules for four-fifths of international commerce. In a ceremony on Friday at the organization's Geneva headquarters, the Bolivian Ambassador, Raul Espana-Smith, signed a protocol setting out the terms of his country's admission to GATT, after 21 months of negotiations with the pact's other member states. Formal admission will take effect in 30 days, subject to ratification by the Bolivian Parliament, the GATT secretariat said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The dollar is still showing surprising strength, traders and economists say, in what has been one of the most volatile periods of foreign-exchange trading in recent years. The resilience has led many forecasters to revise their outlook for the year. [ Page D1. ] U.S. steelmakers must sharply increase their spending on research and development, industry experts say, or they cannot hope to catch up with foreign competitors. [ D1. ] The indictment of 46 commodity traders in Chicago set the stage for legal wrangling on several fronts. One debate will center on what assets the Government may seek to freeze, under the Federal racketeering law, before the trial. [ D2. ] The airlines lack experienced mechanics as they seek to cope with aging fleets and rush to accommodate more travelers. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Telephone workers went on strike in 15 states and the District of Columbia as contract talks broke down with three of the country's seven regional telephone companies. Walking off the job were about 160,000 operators, technicians, installers, clerical and repair workers for Nynex, Pacific Telesis and Atlantic Bell. [ A1. ] Arthur Andersen and Price Waterhouse are still trying to iron out wrinkles in their plan to merge, with less than a month remaining before a deadline for completing the deal. [ D1. ] The union chapter representing Eastern's pilots considered ordering an immediate return to work before deciding to continue the five-month walkout, people close to the union said. [ D6. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Europe's air traffic control network is an unwieldy patchwork of incompatible national systems. Airline executives say the system could interfere with the deregulation of civil aviation. [ D10. ] Most Argentines have been surprised by the Government's alliance with Bunge & Born, a diversified grain and industrial company that has helped to write new economic policies. [ D10. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Knight-Ridder set a new five-year plan for its Philadelphia newspapers after months of ''brass-knuckle, white-knuckle debate.'' The plan tries to balance short-term profitability against such long-term needs as editorial quality. [ D1. ] Hearst has given up on The Los Angeles Herald Examiner. The company's decision to seek a buyer, and the possibility that it might close the paper after 20 years of losses, raises questions about news competition in the nation's second-largest city. [ D8. ] The Dallas Morning News gained exclusive local rights to ''Doonesbury,'' ''Cathy'' and other popular features in a joint venture to develop television programs around the Universal Press Syndicate's stable of strips and columnists. [ D9. ] Have mergers diminished publishers' willingness to put out controversial books? Several recent decisions by the big houses have highlighted the question. Publishing. [ D8. ] Sports Afield is abandoning its literary tradition in favor of charts, graphs and product comparisons - a sign of changing demographics. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Indictments of commodity traders signaled an expansion in the use of racketeering law. The charges mark the first time that people who work for themselves have been indicted under that law in a securities or commodities case. Business and the Law. [ D1. ] The trend toward lower interest rates has not ended, analysts and credit market participants say, even though rates jumped sharply Friday in response to a stronger than expected report on employment. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] A new financial instrument enables issuers of tax-exempt bonds to lock in today's low interest rates for bond issues years down the road. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Market Place; Bond Issuers Turn to RED's
description: NEW financial instruments that go by the unlikely name of RED's, or refunding escrow deposits, enable issuers of tax-exempt bonds to lock in today's low interest rates for bond issues years down the road. Introduced recently by the First Boston Corporation, RED's have since been used by Goldman, Sachs & Company (which calls its version ''municipal forwards'') and an affiliate of the Bankers Trust Company, and may become a common arrow in the quiver of all the big investment banking firms.

title: The Surgeon General vs. Foreign Smoke

Another, the U.S. Trade Representative, has successfully strong-armed Korea, Taiwan and Japan into opening their markets to American tobacco products, and may turn next to Thailand. Who is right?

title: New Charter No Nostrum
description: The new constitution proposed last week for New York City will not solve the problems of crime, drugs and poverty that plague it. Its bureaucracy will still have more than a quarter million workers, its streets will still have potholes and some of its citizens will still go homeless.

title: No More Soggy Clubs

title: Question Box
description: Age Extremes of PGA Q. Who were the youngest and oldest golfers to win the PGA Championship? A. The honors belong to a pair of members of the PGA Hall of Fame, Gene Sarazen, who was enshrined in 1940, and Julius Boros, inducted in 1974. Six years after the PGA Championship was instituted, and when it was still a match-play event (a format that lasted until 1958), Sarazen defeated Emmet French, 4 and 3, in the 1922 final at Oakmont, Pa. He was 20 years 5 months 20 days old, and no PGA winner has been younger. Sarazen also won the event in 1923 and 1933.

title: Review/Opera; 17th-Century Camp and Kinkiness
description: Early Baroque operas, composed in a pastoral tradition that modern audiences, separated from the idiom by three centuries, cannot reasonably be expected to savor, do not revive easily. So in a time when the old stunt of updating opera classics is again in fashion, Baroque opera is especially ripe for revisionism. Perhaps there is no more legitimate way to keep alive the seminal works of Monteverdi and the other 17th-century composers who assisted at opera's birth and nurtured it in infancy. The danger is that pitching the work toward the tastes of a casual operagoing public may utterly distort the original intent.

title: Tokyo's Top Official For Overseas Trade Is Critic of the U.S.
description: As Japan's politicians raced around Tokyo jockeying for power in the wake of the biggest electoral upset here in decades, Makoto Utsumi walked slowly around Japan's finance ministry, meeting old colleagues, smiling and bowing a lot, and modestly demurring when people suggested that in some ways he is now running the Government.

The court denied DD Acquisition's motion to block Dunkin' Donuts takeover defenses involving an employee stock ownership plan, a ''poison pill'' and the sale of preferred stock to the General Electric Capital Company. DD Acquisition, owned by the Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd., offered $43 a share for Dunkin' Donuts.

description: Solidarity mounted an effort today to oust the newly elected Prime Minister, Czeslaw Kiszczak, by appealing to small parties allied with the Communists in Parliament to swing their allegiance to an anti-Communist coalition.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The immensely expensive legislation that President Bush is expected to sign this week to rescue the savings industry will ultimately affect the pocketbooks and convenience of millions of American consumers. But the immediate noticeable impact is likely to be confined to somewhat lower interest rates for a relative few. The main short-term effect, analysts said, is likely to be the disappearance of premium rates that venturesome depositors have enjoyed at institutions in areas where the industry's distress has been greatest, mainly in Texas. [ Page D1. ] COMPANIES The stock of UAL soared 28 percent, or $46.25, after the company said it had received a takeover proposal from Marvin Davis, who earlier this year tried to buy Northwest Airlines. The offer is thought to be for more than $200 a share; the company's stock closed at $210.75 in heavy trading. The market's reaction suggested that there were expectations of a bidding war for UAL, parent of United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier. [ D1. ] Warren E. Buffett purchased $358 million of USAir's convertible preferred stock, in a move that gives the company protection against a takeover. [ D2. ] After years of fare wars, the nation's airlines are thriving. But for the millions of Americans who fly, the outlook is less cheerful. Fares rose more than 15 percent in the 12 months ended in April, according to a study by Salomon Brothers, and analysts see no return soon to the discounting wars. [ A1. ] A.T.&T. accused MCI of violating the Communications Act by providing large customers with services at prices not specified in its public tariffs. It was the latest thrust in the dispute over the pricing of long-distance services for business customers. [ D1. ] Jerrico, the owner of Long John Silver's, accepted a takeover offer from an investment group in a deal valued at $620 million, or $24.25 a share. Jerrico's stock rose $3.375, to $24. [ D4. ] First Interstate Bancorp agreed to sell its capital equipment financing subsidiary to Japan's largest leasing company. [ D4. ] Hewlett-Packard has agreed to license its computer design to Samsung Electronics. [ D4. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average surged 41.54 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2,694.99, nearing its record high of 2,722.42, reached on Aug. 25, 1987. The most dramatic action came in airline companies, and the Dow transportation index jumped 94.06 points, or 7.5 percent, to a record 1,344.06. The transport index's climb was led by UAL, which leaped $46.25, to $210.75. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading, as dealers readied themselves for the onset of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions. Congress cleared the way for the auctions over the weekend when it approved a temporary increase of $70 billion in the Federal debt limit. [ D14. ] Prices of crude oil and its byproducts continued to ease as the market's attention shifted from the latest Mideast hostage crisis to the increasing global supplies of petroleum being offered by both OPEC and non-OPEC producers. [ D16. ] The dollar edged higher against most currencies in thin trading, extending last week's rally. [ D16. ] Insider trading charges were filed against two former Merrill Lynch stockbrokers and a New York lawyer. The complaint stems from the Dennis B. Levine insider trading case. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Management proposals to shift some health-care expenses to employees have emerged as important sticking points in the stalled negotiations that prompted strikes at three regional telephone companies. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Stock prices of major New York banks have not been affected dramatically by the debt accord with Mexico. Market Place. [ D6. ] The industry's only all-comedy commercial-production house has been founded. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D17. ]

American steelmakers produced 1.9 million net tons in the same week last year, the institute said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 60.8 million net tons, 1.4 percent above last year's production at this time, the institute added.

title: In Hartford, A Hospital Ails And Services To Poor Suffer
description: For 65 years, this city's smallest and poorest hospital, Mount Sinai, has followed an unswerving credo to serve the poor. But economics and Medicaid cuts are forcing a wrenching change in that mission and causing consternation in the community and among other hospitals.

description: The Transit Authority made temporary repairs to 196 subway cars on the A and C lines over the weekend after four trains that used the cars broke down, the authority said yesterday.

I.B.M.'s Overview Of Rolm Products

The overview will include a strengthened PBX line and new features for the Rolm's Callpath telephone-marketing product.

Mr. Bush, Alone on Nicaragua
description: Five Central American Presidents ended their meeting in Honduras yesterday with a workable plan for demobilizing the contras and ending civil war in Nicaragua. They called for disbanding rebel camps in southern Honduras by Dec. 8. This would be 90 days after the stationing of international monitors in the jungles to oversee compliance and deter cross-border raiding.

title: U.S. Challenges Nicaraguans To Guarantee Contras' Rights
description: Bush Administration officials challenged Nicaragua today to guarantee safety and political rights to contras returning home under the agreement reached by five Central American leaders. But the officials acknowledged that they had little leverage to force concessions by Managua.

title: Asset Investors reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the latest quarter net income decreased primarily because of higher interest expense on the company's variable-rate liabilities and a $2,400,000 charge (in addition to a $2,800,000 charge in the latest first quarter) to operations resulting from portfolio carrying amount adjustments on three of the company's ownership interests in issuances of collateralized mortgage obligations. The company also said income decreased because of expenditures of about $1,712,000 related to hedging transactions and a one-time charge for the cancellation of an interest rate swap agreement and expenditures of about $577,000 for legal and management consulting services.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day yesterday misidentified the company that named S. Kent Rockwell as chairman. It is the Pittsburgh-based Astrotech International Corporation, not Rockwell International. Mr. Rockwell, who will also remain president and chief executive, succeeds his father, Willard F. Rockwell Jr., who is retiring.

title: Books of The Times; Piecing Together a Fragmented Poet
description: Bitter Fame A Life of Sylvia Plath By Anne Stevenson With additional material by Lucas Myers, Dido Merwin and Richard Murphy. Illustrated. 413 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95.

title: Iran Broke C.I.A. Spy Ring, U.S. Says
description: Early this year, Government officials say, Iran ended what was thought to be one of the Central Intelligence Agency's rare successes in that country: a network of agents who provided intimate details and documents about Iranian military planning.

title: TJ International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fruehauf Changes Name
description: The Fruehauf Corporation has changed its name to the K-H Corporation. The name change was required under terms of the July 14 sale of its truck-trailer and maritime operations to the Terex Corporation. K-H is the holding company for the Kelsey-Hayes Company, a maker of wheels, brake parts and other car and truck components. K-H will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol KH. The company, however, has agreed to be acquired by the Varity Corporation. That takeover is expected to be completed by the end of September.

title: U.N. Envoy Ends Visit To Beirut and Damascus
description: After five days of intensive talks here and in Damascus, Syria, on the hostage crisis, a senior United Nations envoy is returning to New York apparently empty-handed.

title: 10 Killed, 25 Injured As Rockets Hit Kabul
description: Anti-Government guerrillas struck Kabul with dozens of rockets again today, killing 10 people and wounding 25.

title: Market Place; Impact on Banks Of Mexican Pact
description: FOR American banks, whose stock prices have long suffered because of their heavy lending to Latin American countries, the Mexican debt accord of late July was a reminder that the troubled loans can be worked out without cataclysm, but not without sacrifice.

title: Lifeline Healthcare Asks for an Audit
description: Lifeline Healthcare Group Ltd. said it had hired the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand to review its financial statements and had asked the National Association of Securities Dealers to continue a trading halt in the company's stock. A 10-day suspension in Lifeline trading, ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission, expired on Saturday. The S.E.C., in ordering that halt, cited questions about the company's accounting for acquisitions as well as its handling of a stock split that affected some, but not all, of its shares.

title: White House Suggests Talks On Captives May Go Slowly
description: The White House indicated today that efforts to win the release of eight American hostages in Lebanon might take a long time. Administration aides said President Bush wanted to allow time for various initiatives to gel.

title: Buffett's Stake in USAir Seen as Takeover Move
description: In a move that would bring new takeover protections to a major airline company, Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., yesterday bought $358 million worth of newly issued convertible preferred stock in USAir Group Inc.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHTING Lack of Wind Stalls Fastnet Fleet: A lack of wind left the nearly 280 yachts in the Fastnet Race, the most prestigious portion of the Admiral's Cup regatta, floundering yesterday in the waters off the southwestern coast of England, having covered less than 150 miles in 24 hours. It was one of the slowest starts ever in the Fastnet Race, between England and Ireland, and many of the boats had to drop anchor overnight to avoid being carried in the wrong direction by tides. The 40 boats remaining in the regatta are participating in the Fastnet event. Denmark's Andelsbanken was leading the fleet on the water, with Japan's Will and Britain's Jamarella close behind. But the American one-ton yacht Sagacious V was leading on corrected time and the American 50-footer Great News was second. Sagacious had been a disappointment during the first five races in the Admiral's Cup. The Americans, in fifth place at the start of the Fastnet, faced a tough battle to reach the overall leader, Britain. (AP) TENNIS D'Allesandro Takes Lead: Laura D'Allesandro, an amateur from Spring Lake Heights, N.J., shot a one-under-par 71 to gain the first-round lead yesterday in the Metropolitan Women's Open championship in Locust Valley, L.I. Susie Berdoy, a pro at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains, is second with 72. The tournament concludes today. Rain Suspends Play: Rain suspended the only two matches to get under way yesterday in the Swiss Army Knife Open tournament in Livingston, N.J., forcing postponement of the remainder of the day's schedule. Nduka Odizor of Nigeria held a 6-3, 1-2 lead over Philippe Poch of France and Jeff Klaparda was ahead of John Ross, 6-4, 2-2, when rain stopped play at the Newark Tennis Academy. (AP) HORSE RACING Audio Cassette Wins: Audio Cassette came from off the pace to score a 1 1/2-length victory over Packett's Landing yesterday in the $89,550 Albany Handicap for 3-year-olds at Saratoga Race Track. The victory was the fourth in five career starts for Audio Cassette, who was ridden by Jerry Bailey and carried 113 pounds. The son of Talc-Cassette covered the mile and an eighth over a fast track in 1:52 to earn $53,730 for the owner, James F. Edwards.(AP)

title: Facing Jail, Ruiz May Be Vote Winner
description: Israel Ruiz Jr. was convicted of a Federal felony in February and expelled from the New York State Senate in May. Now, Bronx politicians say, a clear favorite has emerged in the election to fill his seat in November: Israel Ruiz Jr. While he still faces a six-month jail sentence, which he is appealing, neither the sentence nor his expulsion would prevent him from reclaiming the South Bronx seat, the counsel to the Senate majority leader said.

title: Dallas Comics Lawsuit
description: The Times Herald Printing Company, publisher of The Dallas Times Herald, filed suit today against the A. H. Belo Corporation, the owner of The Dallas Morning News, seeking to prevent Belo from acquiring exclusive Dallas-area rights to 26 comics, columns and other features. The lawsuit in state court contends that Belo and the Universal Press Syndicate will ''inexorably harm competition in the Dallas market'' if the rights are granted. Belo and the Universal Press Syndicate last week announced a joint venture to explore television programming for some of the syndicate's features, which include Doonesbury and The Far Side.

Hanson's investment bank, N.M. Rothschild, said it had acceptances representing 57.3 percent of Gold Fields' shares, including 29.6 percent committed by the South African-backed Minerals and Resources Corporation after its own bid failed earlier this year.

Topics of The Times; The Superpowers Come A-Courting
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have announced their readiness to accept binding arbitration by the International Court of Justice in cases involving the extradition and prosecution of aircraft hijackers, terrorists and narcotics traffickers. That could mark the start of a cooperative superpower effort to make better use of the World Court for peaceful resolution of disputes.

title: Goldin's Plan: Making Drama of His Record

Now he is running for mayor and, by his own admission, is having trouble making people notice him and his promise of a new vision for the government he has played a part in for so long.

They are divided between styles to be worn at warm-weather resorts and those to be worn up north under winter coats.

title: Insurers' Excessive Fear of AIDS

But health insurance companies are making a cruel situation worse by insisting on the right to test applicants for health insurance and, in some cases, by restricting coverage for the disease. The cost of AIDS is large and growing, but is still a very small part of the national health bill.

title: Stena May Sell Containers Stake
description: Stena Holding A.G., a Dutch ferry concern, said it might sell a portion or all of its 8.2 percent stake in Sea Containers Ltd. Stena is a partner with Tiphook P.L.C. in Temple Holdings Ltd., which has offered $50 a share, or $824 million, for Sea Containers. The bid is scheduled to expire on Wednesday. Sea Containers has rejected the offer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Temple said Stena had amended its agreement with the Temple group to allow the Dutch company to sell its 935,000 Sea Containers shares, provided that it did not sell those shares back to Sea Containers. Shares of Sea Containers fell $3.75 today, to $62.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Two days and nights of rehearsals, recitals, lectures, sing-alongs and even dancing in the lobbies were piled one on the other. All were centered on Roger Norrington and his London Classical Players and aimed at this evening's performance of Beethoven's last and most problematic symphony.

title: Topics of The Times; A Bolivian for All Seasons
description: One of the most colorful and remarkable political careers in modern Latin American history ended Sunday when Victor Paz Estenssoro completed his fourth term as Bolivia's President. His first term began in 1952 and was secured by a revolution of armed miners and peasants. His second marked the last time, until this week, that a democratically elected Bolivian President served out a full four year term. His third was brief, cut short by a military coup that ushered in almost two decades of military rule. And his fourth started amid the chaos of 24,000 percent hyperinflation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD A Notable Javelin Throw: The British javelin thrower Steve Buckley yesterday made the second-longest throw in the world this year at the 12th Hungalu Cup grand prix meet in Budapest. Buckley, the winner last weekend at the European Cup at Gateshead, England, threw 281 feet 8 inches. In the 1,000-meter run, Paul Ereng of Kenya won in 2 minutes 17.37 seconds. Yobes Ondieki of Kenya won the 1,500 meters, but ran the distance relatively slowly in 3:39.03. Andre Cason of the United States, the world junior record-holder, won the 100 meters in 10.27. Calvin Smith was second at 10.37. (AP) SKIING Season's First Goes to West German: Michaela Gerg of West Germany completed a downhill course in Las Lenas, Argentina, in 1 minute 30.48 minutes yesterday to win the first event of the 1990 women's World Cup season. Heidi Zeller of Switzerland was second in 1:31.23, and Veronika Wallinger of Austria was third with 1:31.47. (AP) TENNIS Yzaga and Pugh Upset: Sixth-seeded Jaime Yzaga of Peru and three other seeded players were upset yesterday at the United States Hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. Joining Yzaga on the sideline were No. 11 Jim Pugh, No. 12 Pieter Aldrich of South Africa, and No. 7 Peter Lundgren of Sweden. Yzaga, who received a first-round bye, was beaten, 6-2, 6-3, by Johan Carlsson of Sweden in second-round play. A tired Pugh strained his lower back in a 6-4, 3-6, 7-5 loss to Simon Youl of Australia. A qualifer, Barry Moir of Atlanta, No. 226 in the world, eliminated Aldrich, who is ranked No. 71, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2. Last night, fifth-seeded Jay Berger defeated Michael Robertson, 6-3, 6-3, and Lundgren was beaten by Andrew Sznajder of Canada, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Seeded Players Advance: Fourth-seeded Pam Shriver, fifth-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez and seventh-seeded Hana Mandlikova scored straight-set victories yesterday at the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tournament in Manhattan Beach, Calif. Shriver beat Stacey Martin, 6-2, 6-4; Fernandez topped Elizabeth Smylie of Australia, 6-3, 6-3, and Mandlikova, an Australian citizen, overpowered Pascale Paradis of France, 6-0, 6-1. In another second-round match at the Manhattan Country Club, eighth-seeded Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden rallied for a 6-2, 5-7, 6-2 victory over Sandra Birch. (AP) Chang Advances: Top-seeded Michael Chang overcame second-set returning woes and two third-set service breaks last night to score a 6-1, 3-6, 6-3 victory over Scott Warner in the opening round of the $125,000 Swiss Army Knife Open in Livingston, N.J. Chang, the French Open winner and the fifth-ranked player in the world, lived up to his billing in the 22-minute opening set, losing just 4 points on his serve and recording two service breaks on Warner, ranked 199th. But in the second set, the 6-foot-5-inch Warner got his big serve going and the 17-year-old Chang of Placentia, Calif., had lots of trouble handling it. In the final set, Chang dropped back 10 feet behind the baseline to receive serve and that proved the difference. In another match last night, second-seeded Brad Gilbert defeated Tim Wilkison, 6-4, 6-1. In the afternoon, seventh-seeded Paul Annacone won a marathon second-set tie breaker and defeated Tim Pawsat, 4-6, 7-6, 6-4. Fifth-seeded Robert Seguso trailed Jim Grabb, 5-2, then retired after injuring his left foot. (AP)

title: Missing Congressman's Mission: Ending Hunger Everywhere
description: As they waited for word of Representative Mickey Leland of Texas, who vanished in a small plane over the highlands of Ethiopia on Monday, his friends and colleagues kept their hopes alive with a shared vision: that he would be found when the clouds cleared, playing with the children in an isolated village.

title: Scanning the Video Universe In Rural America's Backyards
description: WHEN Charley Loops arrives home after a long day at work, he collapses into his La-Z-Boy recliner, hits the remote control and - zap! - live from New York, it's Channel 7 Eyewitness News. Or - zap! - live from Chicago, it's the Cubs game. Or - zap! - live from Los Angeles, it's Dr. Gene Scott, a televangelist who sports a Glengarry cap and puffs caber-size cigars.

title: Town Bans Plastic Food Wrap
description: The Legislative Council of Hamden has voted to ban the use of all non-biodegradable food packaging in Hamden starting March 1, 1990. The vote Monday makes Hamden the first community in Connecticut to ban material that does not break down in the environment, such as polyvinyl chloride and polystyrene food wrapping, bags, boxes, cups and plates.

title: Lessons
description: Most teachers of young children hold ''show and tell'' sessions that allow pupils to exercise their communication skills by bringing in some favored item like a pet frog and telling classmates about it.

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Startel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Profit Rises
description: The WPP Group announced yesterday that its pretax profits rose 61 percent in the first half of 1989, to $:26 million, or $41.6 million, from $:16.19 million, or $25.9 million, in the corresponding period last year. Earnings-per-share for the British company that owns J. Walter Thompson and the Ogilvy Group grew 53 percent, to 33.9 pence, or 54 cents, from 22.2 pence, or 35 cents. WPP said Ogilvy's results were only included for 11 days of the period.

title: Zytec Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Capital Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $194,041. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $143,874.

title: Savannah Foods & Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Lauder and Goldin Alter Ad Images
description: In new television advertisements to be broadcast in the New York area beginning today, Ronald Lauder bills himself as ''the real Republican'' and Harrison J. Goldin, a Democrat, says he will make it a crime to have drugs in one's system.

title: Warwick Insurance Managers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said loss in the latest 6 months was primarily due to the incurrence of $2 million of commercial property claims and the strengthening of its loss reserves by $5 million.

title: Dow Trades Above 2,700, Then Drops Back to 2,699.17
description: The Dow Jones industrial average traded above the 2,700 level yesterday for the first time since August 1987 before ending the day less than a point shy of that level.

title: D'Alessandro Captures Metropolitan Title
description: She might not be ready to challenge Nancy Lopez yet, but Laura D'Alessandro of Toms River, N.J., has shown in the last week that she has the qualities to be a contender some day on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: 18.25% of CS First Boston Is Sold to Group
description: In a move that may increase the influence of Japanese companies on Wall Street, CS First Boston Inc. told its employees yesterday in an internal memorandum that it had sold 18.25 percent of the firm to a group of international investors.

title: Bernard Barenholtz, Toy Manufacturer, 75
description: Bernard M. Barenholtz, co-founder of the Creative Playthings children's toy company, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Marlborough, N.H. He was 75 years old.

title: Cencor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $613,000 and $1,560,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Swank Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,466,000 for the quarter and $1,709,000 for the 6 months. The company said 1988 results were restated to reflect the sale of a division.

title: DEMOCRATS WARN U.S. MUST SUPPORT CONTRAS' EVICTION
description: Democrats in Congress warned today that a compromise with the Bush Administration on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels could collapse this year unless the Administration supports an agreement by five Central American Presidents to disband the guerrilla army.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, as credit market participants bid on $10 billion worth of new three-year notes, the first leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.

title: Chempower Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INSIDE
description: Shuttle Blasts Off The space shuttle Columbia soared into space on a secret military mission that is expected to deploy an advanced photo reconnaissance satellite. Page A14. Secrecy Debate Renewed Wide circulation of a paper on computer secrecy has renewed a dispute over academic freedom and national security. Page A16. A Question on Bank I.R.A.'s The Labor Department says I.R.A. deposits at banks could lose their special tax status if they are used to obtain free checking. Page D1. Girding for Battle Republicans lost the redistricting war after the 1980 census; they don't want it to happen again. Page D21.

title: United Medical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $510,000 for the quarter and $8,834,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary credit of $13,000 for both periods; the 6 months also included a charge of $390,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-After net from discontinued operations of $274,000 and $283,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $203,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 6 months.

title: ENSR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dravecky Is Back on Center Stage
description: The Dave Dravecky Story, which plays here Thursday with the return of the Giants' pitcher to the major leagues, could become a made-for-television movie, perhaps with Robert Urich in the title role.

title: Wilber Appleman, Inventor, 83
description: Wilber Appleman, inventor of the motor for the Jacuzzi whirlpool bath, died July 25 because of injuries suffered in an automobile accident, a spokeswoman for Mission Hospital Regional Medical Center said today. He was 83 years old.

title: Man Banished In Gotti Case
description: A man who placed a package resembling a bomb outside a Little Italy social club frequented by the reputed mob boss, John Gotti, was sentenced to a conditional discharge yesterday and told to get out of town. The man, Michael McCray, 37 years old, formerly of Queens and now a resident of East Liverpool, Ohio, was spared jail partly on the condition that he stay out of the state for a year unless he gets court permission to return. Mr. McCray said he planted the fake bomb as part of a one-man antidrug crusade.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Taking Measure; Surprises in Federal Work Force's Profile
description: A detailed look at the Government's work force provides some surprising statistics: Only one in 10 employees works in the nation's capital, for example.

title: Rose Appeals to Return Suit to State Court
description: Forging ahead on a second legal front, lawyers for Pete Rose, the embattled manager of the Cincinnati Reds, yesterday challenged the judicial ruling that would keep Rose's lawsuit against the baseball commissioner in Federal court.

title: Japan's Troubled Successor
description: It was dismissed as a forgiveably immature boast when, in 1960, a 29-year-old politician named Toshiki Kaifu became the youngest member elected to Parliament and enthusiastically told his supporters that if they supported him for 29 more years, he would become Prime Minister of Japan.

title: WINE TALK
description: There has been a quiet invasion going on here for some time, and the invaders are not American tourists. They are the reasonably priced and fresh-tasting wines of the Loire Valley.

title: HMO America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said in the year-ago second quarter and 6 months there were income tax provisions of $1,367,857 and $2,277,793, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
Meese Friend Guilty Of Receiving Payoffs In the Wedtech Case
description: E. Robert Wallach, a longtime friend of former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, was convicted yesterday of accepting payoffs for efforts to influence Government officials on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Petroleum Copter Stake Purchased
description: Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., the Hong Kong investment company controlled by the New Zealand investor Ron Brieley, has acquired a 5.02 percent stake in Petroleum Helicopters Inc.'s voting common stock. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Industrial Equity said it bought the Petroleum Helicopters shares for investment purposes only.

title: Computers Proliferating In Classroom
description: Computers continue to be rapidly added to classrooms around the country, but many are being used mostly to teach children how to use them, preliminary data from a national survey indicate.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Algoma Central Railway reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a special gain of $614,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carter to Monitor Elections Next February in Nicaragua
description: Former President Jimmy Carter agreed today to lead an international delegation to monitor elections next February in Nicaragua.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bowater Industries P.L.C., London, a paper and packaging concern, said its American unit, Rexham Corp, Charlotte, N.C., had sold its flexible packaging business to HP Packaging Holdings Inc. for $26 million.

title: E. H. Luckey, 69, Hospital Chief
description: E. Hugh Luckey, former president of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died of lung cancer Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Biotechnica International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grand Met to Buy Fast-Food Chain
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. has agreed to buy the restaurant, manufacturing and distributing operations of United Biscuits P.L.C. for $:180 million, or $288 million. United Biscuits, based in Britain, owns Wimpy hamburger restaurants, Pizzaland restaurants and Perfect Pizza outlets. It reported profits of $:11.2 million, or $18 million, on sales of $:147.4 million, or $236 million, in 1988.

title: Colonial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reviews/Music; A Tour Through 20 Years of Pop History
description: Todd Rundgren's show at the Ritz on Sunday night, his first in New York since 1987, confirmed his reputation as a gifted pop oddity, a white musician who's translated the black Philadelphia sound of Gamble and Huff into rock-and-roll.

title: P.L.O. Seeks to Sign 4 U.N. Treaties on War
description: In a bid for world support for its claim to represent a Palestinian state, the Palestine Liberation Organization is seeking to sign four United Nations treaties on the laws of war, diplomats say.

title: Secord to Blackhawks
description: Al Secord, who with Bobby Hull are the only players to score more than 50 goals for the Chicago Blackhawks in a N.H.L. season, has returned to the Blackhawks. They signed him as a free agent without compensation. (AP)

title: Best in Doubles Ends Partnership
description: Pam Shriver said today that she would no longer be playing doubles with Martina Navratilova, her partner for the last nine years.

title: Review/Opera; New Festival Of Wagner Begins With 'Siegfried'
description: An annual Wagner festival in Port Chester may not be so self-evidently necessary that you kick yourself for not having thought of it first, but Valhalla Wagnerfest is dedicated to establishing one. The fledgling company produced what was in most ways a surprisingly decent performance of ''Siegfried'' tonight at the Capitol Theater here, and as a decent performance of ''Siegfried'' is not something to be sneezed at, the group's aspirations must be taken seriously, if one problem that may prove systemic can be solved.

title: Bonn Closes Office to Would-Be Emigres
description: West Germany closed its mission in East Berlin to the public today. It said the mission, occupied by 130 East Germans seeking to emigrate to the West, could not function normally or accommodate more asylum-seekers ''under dignified, humane conditions.''

title: Ex-House Speaker Is Subject of Grand Jury Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury here is investigating former House Speaker Jim Wright of Texas, said lawyers for several organizations that have received subpoenas.

title: Sugarcoating Chips to Fight Disease
description: There is no talk yet of Hershey teaming up with Intel or of a joint venture between Mars and Motorola, but sugarcoated semiconductors may have a bright future. Researchers at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., have been mixing up sweet toppings for semiconductor wafers to study what it takes to make living cells adhere to each other. The research may one day lead to medical advances and improved industrial materials.

title: Gateway Bid Ends
description: Newgateway P.L.C., the vehicle backed by Wasserstein, Perella & Company and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said its bid for the Gateway Corporation, the British supermarkets group, had lapsed. Newgateway owned about 40 percent of Gateway shares.

title: Restoring the Crown to Chicken a la King
description: HOW could you write such awful things about chicken a la king? Where is the recipe for the chocolate torte that you wrote about so glowingly in your Soviet chef article? Why didn't you include the oldest thing in your freezer when you wrote about the oldest thing in people's refrigerators?

title: Inside Lascaux: a Sublunar Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Bring Americans Along on Terrorists
description: President Bush will make his toughest calls on terrorism and dealing with hostages in the coming weeks. Whatever he does will involve political risks - like yesterday's rejection of an Iranian feeler to help with the hostages in return for release of Iranian assets in the U.S. He will also need backing from Congress and the public. To earn that support he will have to provide clearer information on what he knows about the terrorists. Here are some of the questions in the air: What's the state of U.S. intelligence on terrorism? Statements, including a recent one by the President to the effect that Washington isn't playing with ''a full deck,'' suggest that the Administration feels its information is incomplete. Mr. Bush need not divulge his sources and methods, but has to be frank about what he knows and what he doesn't.

title: Gervin Arrested
description: George Gervin, the former scoring star of the Spurs who led the National Basketball Association in scoring four times, was arrested early yesterday in San Antonio on charges of driving while intoxicated and possession of marijuana. The five-time All-N.B.A. first team selection, who retired at the end of the 1985-86 season, was released on a personal recognizance bond. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about USAir Group's sale of $358 million in preferred stock to Warren E. Buffett, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, described the transaction incorrectly. It was seen as an anti-takeover move, not a takeover move.

title: N.F.L. Will Allow the Ickey Shuffle
description: The National Football League has decided not to muffle the Ickey Shuffle.

title: RE Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: During the latest quarter, the company said it received discounted proceeds of $4,482,000 from the prepayment of certain mortgage loans which resulted in a pre-tax loss of $464,000. This loss and a pre-tax gain from the sale of investment securities of $253,000 were included in net investment income. These transactions reduced earnings per share by 2 cents for the latest quarter and latest six months.

title: Inside Lascaux: a Sublunar Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Arbitron's 'Mediawatch'
description: The Arbitron Company said yesterday that its commercial monitoring system will become electronic in the second quarter of next year. The current manual system measures advertising expenditures and commercial occurrences on network, spot, cable and syndicated television franchises. The change will enable Arbitron's Broadcast Advertisers Reports to measure television commercials 24 hours a day in the top 75 television markets, compared with the 17 markets it now assesses on a full-time basis. Arbitron is calling the new system ''Mediawatch.''

title: King's Son Said to Quit Center
description: Only four months after taking over as president of the center created here to carry on his father's work, the 28-year-old son of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is reported to have submitted his resignation.

title: Las Vegas Papers Seek Approval for a Merger
description: The Las Vegas Sun, for nearly four decades the embodiment of a maverick newspaper, is trying to assure a half-century more of journalistic life by applying with its bitter rival, The Las Vegas Review-Journal, for an unusual joint operating arrangement.

title: U.S. Seeks Schools' Papers In Inquiry Into Student Aid
description: The Justice Department has asked several universities and colleges for documents in an anti-trust investigation, an official said tonight, and one of the schools, Harvard University, reported that the investigation dealt with possible collusion in financial aid to students.

title: College-Bound Immigrants Get Help
description: Samson Chan and Ulkira Sabino came here from different countries, speak different native languages and attend different schools.

title: 'Phantom Class' Report Investigated in Bronx
description: The Board of Education is investigating accusations that students at a Bronx high school were assigned to nonexistent ''phantom classes'' where they ran errands and did other chores.

title: New Jersey Closes Dump a Bit Too Late
description: Richard Bassi and Michael Harvan have a habit of placing trash where the state of New Jersey doesn't want it. The men are two of the three owners of the Hub Recycling and Scrap Company, which spread the mountain of garbage under Interstate 78 that caught fire on Monday and buckled the roadway, forcing its closing.

title: A 'Creepy' Filming of Levin's Death
description: There was a body sprawled beneath a tree. There were clusters of detectives and an ambulance parked behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And there was the suspect, graciously giving interviews.

title: JORDANIAN KILLED AT ISRAELI BORDER
description: A Jordanian soldier in uniform crossed into southern Israel today, opened fire on several kibbutz workers and took a woman hostage, Israeli officials and witnesses said. After several hours of negotiations, Israeli troops stormed the site and shot the Jordanian to death.

title: Tyson Is Fined
description: A judge in Albany fined Mike Tyson $300 yesterday and ordered him to conduct three youth clinics after the heavyweight boxing champion pleaded guilty to two speeding incidents, April 26 and May 5. Asked by Albany Traffic Court Judge Stephen Safranko if he felt the sentences were fair, Tyson mumbled, ''It's fair,'' and thanked the judge.(AP)

title: Uniforce Temporary Personel Inc(0) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $410,000 from an accounting change.

title: International Remote Imaging Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Net Off at Grey
description: Grey Advertising said Monday that its net income for the second quarter of the year fell by 2.4 percent, to $4.94 million, or $3.73 a share, from $6.3 million, or $4.82 a share, for the period in 1988. The company said that last year's second quarter included a net gain of $1.95 million, or $1.40 a share, from the sale of a foreign subsidiary.

title: President Resigns At Wang
description: Frederick A. Wang, president of beleaguered Wang Laboratories Inc., resigned yesterday, returning the reins of the company to his ailing father, Dr. An Wang. The move renewed speculation on Wall Street that the family that effectively controls the company is searching for a way to sell it.

title: Doman Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

Calcavecchia at Home
description: Mark Calcavecchia, who won the British Open last month, told officials of the PGA Championship yesterday that he would not compete in this week's final leg of the Grand Slam because he was going to Mesa, Ariz., where his wife, Sheryl, gave birth to the couple's first child, a girl, earlier yesterday. The PGA Championship begins tomorrow in the Chicago suburb of Hawthorne Woods, Ill.

title: Epsilon Data Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Called up Kevin Wickander, pitcher, from Colorado Springs of the Pacific Coast League. Sent Steve Davis, pitcher, to Colorado Springs. FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Signed J.R. Ambrose, wide receiver. JETS (AFC) - Waived Steve Collier, offensive tackle. PHOENIX (NFC) - Signed Gary Hogeboom, quarterback, to a four-year contract. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived Kevin Williams, cornerback. HOCKEY TORONTO (NHL) - Named Mike Kitchen assistant coach.

description: The company said share earnings are adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split in June 1989.

title: Rangers Approach Roger Neilson
description: The Rangers, apparently at this late date still expanding the field of coaching candidates, have most recently spoken with Roger Neilson about taking over the team.

description: b-Included net realized investment gains of $60,173 for the quarter and $1,711,817 for the 6 months. c-Included net realized investment losses of $22,815 for the quarter and $260,525 for the 6 months.

title: Sunderland, Mass.
description: IN rating Bub's Bar-B-Q ''the best barbecue joint in New England,'' Greg Johnson and Vince Staten, the authors of ''Real Barbecue'' (Harper & Row, 1988), acknowledge that such praise is ''akin to calling someone the world's tallest midget.'' Yet Bub's, the authors say, ''is not in this book just for geographical symmetry. Bub's belongs.''

title: Ex-Consultant's Dealings Provide Insider's View of Housing Awards
description: Jay Stone was a private Republican consultant in the mid-1980's when someone - he says he does not remember who -casually mentioned that there was some good money to be made from ''those Mod Rehab things'' handed out by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Goldsmith Offers to Place B.A.T. Insurer Unit in Trust
description: Sir James Goldsmith today offered to place the American insurance operations of B.A.T. Industries under the control of an independent trust if the investor group he heads succeeds in its $21 billion bid for the company.

title: New Zealand Plane Crash
description: A sightseeing plane crashed in the Southern Alps on Tuesday, killing nine American and Canadian tourists aboard, the police said. They said searchers recovered six bodies today from the wreckage of the plane, but the bodies had not yet been identified. A New Zealander was piloting the twin-engine plane, which went down near Mount Aspiring on South Island.

title: Chabrol Films a Henry Miller Tale
description: He looked like a stereotypical bookkeeper who had wandered by mistake into a bordello, this round-shouldered, graying man with a paunch and a pipe, poking mildly around a room run amok with flocked red wallpaper, bright flowers and a picture collection numbingly repetitive with aging photographs of exposed women.

title: Medicore Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $62,799 for the quarter and $142,200 for the 6 months. c-After a tax charge of $16,716.

title: Invitron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Jersey Motorists Take Road Closing in Stride
description: To the surprise of both traffic experts and commuters, the closing of a section of Interstate 78 damaged by a garbage dump fire that began here on Monday did not cause the traffic nightmare today that many had feared.

title: 4 Chinese Acrobats Vanish as Interpreter Seeks Asylum
description: Four members of a Chinese acrobatic troupe that has performed with a New York circus since last fall disappeared in Vermont Sunday night after the circus's last show of the season and days before the acrobats were to return to China, officials of the circus said yesterday.

title: The Pop Life
description: That Country Label

title: Markel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cubs Triumph To Lead By Two
description: The Chicago Cubs ended Dennis Martinez's winning streak, continued the Montreal Expos' slide and bolstered their own position today.

title: Another Insult to the Internees
description: One year ago, Congress authorized Federal reparation payments to some 55,000 Japanese-American survivors of World War II internment camps. But not one dollar has been paid, and the outlook for adequate funding is bleak. The national shame of putting these people behind barbed wire is now compounded by shirking on a promise to make amends.

title: CB Pak Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $28.2 million on the sale of Domglas Inc. assets for both the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings for the latest 6 months was not immediately available. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sanders Files A Counterclaim
description: Deion Sanders, a Yankee farmhand and the first draft choice of the Atlanta Falcons, has filed a counterclaim of assault against a baseball fan who Sanders said was harassing the player's girlfriend during a game in Richmond on Sunday.

title: Palo Cedro, Calif.
description: WALK in almost any food shop here and you may find California orange blossom honey, manzanita honey, wildflower honey, clover honey, star thistle honey, sage honey or raspberry honey. That's typical in this town about 160 miles north of Sacramento, which calls itself the Honeybee Capital of the World.

title: Tejas Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the improved results were primarily attributable to the addition of Gulf Energy Holding Inc.'s operations which were acquired in July 1988.

description: The shares of the UAL Corporation, parent company of United Airlines, jumped again yesterday - rising $8.50, to close at $219.25 - in advance of a meeting today at which UAL directors will consider a takeover offer from Marvin Davis.

title: Promotion at McCall's
description: John J. Beni, the publisher of McCall's magazine, was named yesterday to the additional post of president, in a management reorganization at the magazine, which The New York Times Company acquired last month.

description: The Government of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has joined efforts to arrange the release of Western hostages in Lebanon and has invited a senior Iranian official to Damascus for talks, Arab diplomats say.

title: Daylong Search Fails to Locate Congressman's Plane in Ethiopia
description: A daylong air search of a remote region of western Ethiopia today failed to find an aircraft with Representative Mickey Leland and eight other Americans on board.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about genetics referred incorrectly to genes that are chemically altered or ''imprinted'' before being passed to offspring. The genes are inactivated, not activated.

title: Equitable of Iowa Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $746,000 and a loss of $1,731,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Included a gain of $1,005,000 for the quarter and a loss of $2,144,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 6-month also included a gain of $11,555,000 from an accounting change. The company said as a result of its previously reported intention to seek buyers for its Younkers retail department store chain, its financial results have been restated to reflect Younkers as a discontinued operation.

description: b-Net loss

description: Share earnings are fully diluted. The company said included in the latest 6 months was a net pre-tax charge of $3.6 million, consisting of a $3.2 million writedown of the Valdez Creek Mine, a loss of $3.3 million on the sale of part of its interest in LAC Minerals Ltd. and a $2.9 million gain from an investment in Consolidated Gold Fields Plc.

title: Quaker Oats Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods included restructuring charges of $103.6 million for the quarter and $124 million for the year, and charges of $6.4 million and $26 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from accounting changes. Fiscal 1988 included a net charge equal to 18 cents a share resulting from a charge of $29.9 million for consolidation of certain operations and a $10.1 million gain from an accounting change.

title: Chip Licenses Granted By Sun and Hewlett
description: Two rivals in the work station business, Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company, stepped up their battle today by announcing licensing agreements for their chip designs.

title: '90's Political Turf War Promises to Be Fierce
description: The anticipated battles over how to draw the political map for the 1990's - the new district lines for Congress and state legislatures - will be more complicated, more litigious and more partisan than ever, specialists from both parties said here today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PORK has an undeserved image problem. Many health-conscious eaters assume that because some pork-based products are high in fat, like sausages, bacon, hot dogs and spareribs, they should avoid pork altogether.

title: Jan de Graaff, Tamer of the Wild Lily, Dies at 86
description: Jan de Graaff, a horticulturist whose hybridization of lilies helped make them a favorite garden flower, died of Parkinson's disease Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Leaving Post At Cataline Lighting
description: LEAD: The founder of Catalina Lighting Inc., David M. Moss, has resigned as the chairman, president and chief executive of the Miami-based importer and distributor of lighting and ceiling fans.

title: Dyatron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yanks Fail to Solve Candiotti's Pitches
description: Tom Candiotti's knuckleball jumped up and down, slipped in and out, and in short moved everywhere but anywhere near a Yankee bat.

description: The company said latest second quarter results included a loss of $520,000 on the sale of equipment; a charge of $607,000 from writeoff of refinancing costs; a charge of $200,000 for an addition to insurance reserves; a charge of $184,000 from writeoff of workers compensation and a charge of $433,000 from expenses related to the move of the company's headquarters.

title: NORTH'S FIRST DAY ON JOB CALLED OFF
description: The first day on a new job for Oliver L. North did not come to pass today after Federal probation officials became concerned that his work at a community service organization here might generate too much publicity.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Suzuki Narrows Search
description: The American Suzuki Motor Company, the domestic arm of the Japanese auto manufacturer, narrowed its ad agency search to three shops with offices in Los Angeles, Asher/ Gould Advertising; Wieden & Kennedy, whose base is Portland; and Hakuhodo, the Japanese ad agency. A spokeswoman for Suzuki said the review would take six to eight weeks and would include speculative creative work. Last year, Suzuki billed $30 million.

title: Reviews/Music; Reviving the Sound and Feel Of Jelly Roll Morton's Jazz
description: Jelly Roll Morton's music from the 1920's and 30's sounded anything but antiquated at ''Mr. Jelly Lord,'' the classical jazz concert that re-created Morton's music for solo piano, duos, trios and a seven-piece band on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. The New Orleans Hot Seven, led by Dr. Michael White on clarinet, brought Morton's wry, bluesy, playful yet tautly constructed music to swaggering life: listeners could marvel anew at Morton's innovations, but they were even more likely to be tapping their toes.

description: ''I don't want to force the contras back to Nicaragua against their will. But I would like to see aid to the contras ratcheted down as much as possible, as soon as possible.'' - Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island. [ A13:1. ]

description: The Dow Chemical Corporation is offering $133 million in extendible notes with a final maturity in 2015 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Columbia, Nation's First Shuttle, Is Launched on Pentagon Mission
description: The Columbia, the nation's oldest space shuttle, soared flawlessly into space today on a secret military mission that civilian experts said would focus on the deployment of an advanced photo reconnaissance satellite.

title: Talent Bank Chickens, Home to Roost
description: Mayor Koch was justly indignant at the bias against him in the state Commission on Government Integrity's report on his City Hall Talent Bank. He was also rightly annoyed that a segment critical of him was leaked last week to coincide with the perjury indictment of Joseph DeVincenzo, a former aide who ran the Talent Bank.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene: Bally Park Place in Atlantic City. Bonnie Wingate of Manhattan is walking by three women just as they spot a red neon sign that reads ''Baccarat.'' Ms. Wingate hears them speak. First woman: Oh, he's here! Second woman: Who's here?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. named Andrew B. Somers Jr. executive vice president and general counsel.

title: I-78 Damage Extensive, but a Few Lanes Appear Strong
description: Engineers taking their first close look at the charred underside of Interstate 78 today found the highway severely damaged by a raging trash fire, but with a few lanes that may be strong enough to open to traffic in a few weeks.

title: Reviews/Music; Deranged and Savvy Rock
description: Frenetic and offhand, deranged and savvy, funny and brutal, crisp and wayward, the Pixies brought their calmly schizophrenic, firmly dislocated rock to the Ritz on Friday night.

title: Coherent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1

Year-ago third quarter is after provision of $1.9 million for closing of San Juan Capistrano facility.

title: Bush's Torment: Save Hostages or U.S. Interests?
description: The challenge for President Bush in the Middle East hostage crisis goes beyond whether he can save eight Americans. It lies also in whether he should take the risky and perhaps cold-blooded steps that some people believe are essential to end hostage-taking. It is not clear whether

title: A Long Shot Shows Up At Saratoga
description: Long before the exacta and the $250-a-night motel room, pilgrims of another flock came to Saratoga for the oily, fizzy waters from the underground springs, thinking they had restorative power. Woody Stephens does not touch the stuff -his preferred clear liquid is vodka now that the doctors have made him give up brown hooch -but the 75-year-old trainer is living proof that Saratoga remains a fountain of youth.

title: Koch Will Press Private Housing To Evict Dealers
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it was poised to evict suspected drug dealers from 20 privately owned apartment buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn, with or without the landlords' cooperation.

title: U.S. Detains 29 in Panama
description: U.S. soldiers detained 29 Panamanians who entered a restricted military area today and released them after confiscating their weapons, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Southern Command said. She said that among those briefly detained were 10 officers and troopers of the Panama Defense Forces, including Maj. Manuel Sieiro. He is a brother in-law of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega who controls the Government.

title: Lincoln Journal; Approaching Sundown For the Dairyman's Life
description: In 1945, there were 46 working dairy farms in this town high in the mountains of western Vermont. Now there are two. ''Lincoln Center,'' as local people call it, is a store, a firehouse, a town hall and the United Church of Lincoln, which holds ecumenical services.

title: How to Dispose of the Contras
description: LEAD: ''Don't forget that we have a disposal problem,'' the Director of Central Intelligence, Allen Dulles, reminded President John F. Kennedy in 1961. They were discussing what to do with 1,500 armed Cuban exiles training for the Bay of Pigs invasion. On Monday, five Central American presidents grappled with the ''disposal problem'' left by Washington's latest covert war in Latin America - 10,000 Nicaraguan contras encamped in

title: For Bush and Congress, Some Spirited Battles But No Full-Scale War
description: The House of Representatives adjourned early Saturday morning after a nasty little spat with the White House over the details of legislation to rescue the savings and loan industry. It was typical, in some ways, of the fights between Congressional Democrats and the White House this year.

title: West Point Picks Woman to Lead Cadet Corps
description: More than a decade after the first woman was admitted to the United States Military Academy, the 20-year-old daughter of an Army colonel has become the first woman selected to be first captain of the Corps of Cadets, the academy's highest cadet honor.

title: Harare Journal; Where Elephants Roam, a Plea for Understanding
description: In the last month or so, Patrick Mavros, a carver of fine ivory objects and jewelry whose work adorns salons in the Middle East, Europe and the United States, has found a rush of collectors and eager tourists arriving at his studio in the bush on the edge of Harare.

title: Profit Kept Supermarkets From Redeeming Cans for Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Blind Ignorance
description: LEAD: In ancient times, a particularly brutal torture used for criminals and enemies was to make them stare at the sun until the blazing light destroyed their eyes. Nowdays, in a more civilized era, even the worst culprits are safe from such cruel and unusual punishment. Yet our most innocent and helpless fellow humans -premature babies - enjoy no such protection.

description: NEW YORK CITY and a private developer expect to sign a long-term lease agreement by fall that would initiate a $250 million redevelopment of a part of Coney Island, the Brooklyn oceanfront playground that has long been a symbol of summertime fun the world over.

title: 6 in Mayor's Race Split on Picking Chancellor
description: While there is little disagreement among the six major candidates for mayor that New York City's schools are in woeful condition, no candidate has offered a broad plan to remake the system nor has any promised a dramatic increase in spending.

title: Review/Television; Fighting Addiction to Drugs, Drink, Sex, Spending et al.
description: Tonight's NBC News Special, at 10 P.M., is titled ''Fatal Addictions,'' but it comes on like ''Life Styles of the Rich and Famous.'' Here's Betty Ford, the former First Lady, whose confessions of her problems with alcohol and prescription drugs made all the papers. There's Margaux Hemingway, the actress, who tells of her alcoholism and bulimia. Here's Steve Howe, the former Dodgers pitcher, whose cocaine habit got him suspended from major league baseball. There's Art Schlichter, whose career as a pro-football quarterback was ended by his taste for gambling. Other less famous men and women interviewed by Maria Shriver can also evidently afford high-priced treatment resorts.

title: Paper on Codes Is Sent Despite U.S. Objections
description: A paper describing fast and inexpensive ways of keeping computer information private has been distributed by computer around the world, over the objections of the secretive Federal agency that gathers electronic intelligence.

title: Abraham P. Conan, Lawyer, 91
description: Abraham P. Conan, a lawyer who specialized in labor and immigration matters and helped European refugees after World War II, died of pneumonia on July 26 following a stroke at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Get On With Disarming
description: The minute cynics stopped saying Mikhail Gorbachev's program was a mug's game, a charade to fool the naive West, they started saying he would soon fall. Then hard-liners would take over and catch the U.S. out.

title: For VW, the Future Is Its Past
description: In introducing a racy car called the Corrado last week, Volkswagen A.G. provided a reminder that it faces a long, difficult road back from the fringes of the American car market.

title: Reviews/Music; Philharmonic Fills a Park With Works of 2 Russians
description: ''Showers,'' said the predictions for Monday evening, but those who present and attend parks concerts affix a mental ''maybe'' even when the forecasters are as close as they get to certain. It drizzled intermittently during the day, and a few respectable raindrops were falling even as the New York Philharmonic tuned up and started to play on the Great Lawn of Central Park. But by then it seemed clear that the clouds were starting to break up, and the concert went off without a hitch, accompanied by cool breezes and appreciative quiet from the 30,000 listeners whose ''maybe'' attitude paid off.

Latest 6 months also included a pretax gain of about $11,910,000 from the sale of the company's Cable Television System in Beaufort County, S.C., and $3,320,000 of additional pretax income reported in the first quarter related to Land of Lincoln.

title: Bush Will Discuss Shoreham
description: President Bush will meet with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to discuss White House opposition to the Governor's plan to dismantle the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, aides said today. Mr. Cuomo's request for the meeting stemmed from a suggestion last month by White House chief of staff, John Sununu, that the Long Island nuclear plant be mothballed, not dismantled. Mr. Cuomo and officials of the Long Island Lighting Company, which owns the Shoreham plant, agreed earlier this year to have the state buy the completed $5.5 billion plant for $1 and have it dismantled.

title: Transportation
description: An airplane flying with nearly empty fuel tanks is in danger - the more so if it has no pilot. Some unhappy staff members of the National Transportation Safety Board, the Federal agency in charge of investigating air crashes and other accidents, say it is in a somewhat similar situation.

title: At Last, Hope for S & L's
description: Despite last-minute politicking over how to finance the savings and loan bailout, the President and Congress have worked out a promising plan to rid the industry of its rot and set surviving S & L's on a sounder path. The real showdown came when the Administration joined House Democrats to beat back furious lobbying for a weaker bill. The final product is less than perfect, but it's stronger than Mr. Bush's original plan. That's all the more remarkable because the industry has long had its own way in Congress, to the nation's detriment.

title: PPG-China Talks
description: PPG Industries has made progress in negotiations for a joint venture with a Chinese company and a Government agency, an executive of the Pittsburgh glass company said. But the executive added that a recent Japanese news report that PPG had reached an agreement to start the joint venture was ''extremely premature.'' A United States Embassy official in Beijing said PPG had been selected over two other foreign companies in late April to become the sole candidate for a venture to make glass sheets. The official said he believed that the venture would be capitalized at more than $30 million.

description: A group of pirates who stormed a boat carrying 84 Vietnamese stole valuables, raped women and sunk the vessel, and 71 of the refugees were feared dead.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Bozell President
description: Bozell said on Friday that David Bell would succeed Ronald DeLuca as president. Mr. Bell, 46, has been a vice chairman of the agency in charge of its New York, Atlanta and Detroit operations. The appointment, which was expected, makes Mr. Bell second in command of the nation's 14th-largest agency. Mr. DeLuca, 62, moves to the post of vice chairman of Bozell and will continue to help direct the agency's Chrysler account.

title: Canada's Supreme Court Rejects Ex-Lover's Effort to Halt Abortion
description: Ruling in a major test case, the Canadian Supreme Court yesterday unanimously rejected a man's attempt to prevent his former lover from having an abortion. Hours before the decision was announced, the woman's lawyer said she had had the abortion anyway.
