There were no share earnings in the year-ago second quarter because of preferred stock dividend requirements. The 1988 tax provisions were restated.

title: Enterra Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Field Guide To Nests Of the Chic
description: HERE is a field guide to this summer's popular Manhattan restaurants, the crowds that predominate and the dishes they prefer. 150 Wooster is a traffic jam of the fashionable and the famous. In the cool, stylish dining room, the favorite dishes are fennel seed gnocchi with prosciutto and basil and brook trout with French lentil salad and parsley coulis. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip, about $80. Allow a week for reservations. (150 Wooster Street, between Houston and Prince; 212-995-1010; 6:30 P.M. to midnight daily; all major credit cards.) Le Madri is the grand trattoria of the moment, especially in fashion circles. Models and retailers, Italian food fans and shoppers from Barneys crowd in, calling for thin-crusted pizza, white bean salad with shrimp and crab meat, or halibut braised with tomatoes and olives. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip, about $90. Allow a week for reservations. (168 West 18th Street, corner of Seventh Avenue; 212-727-8022; lunch Monday through Friday, noon to 3 P.M.; dinner seven days a week, 6 P.M. to 10; American Express only.) Sette Mezzo is a crush of power brokers. Publishing magnates and Smith Barney barons reserve tables three days in advance to order big salads, linguine with white clam sauce or veal Milanese. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip, about $60. (969 Lexington Avenue, between 70th and 71st; 212-472-0400; lunch Monday through Friday, noon to 2:30; dinner seven days a week 5 P.M. to midnight; no credit cards.) Restaurant Bellevues is a sliver of cheer on grimy Ninth Avenue, where the arty sit side-by-side with a midtown business crowd. Almost everybody orders grilled chicken with mounds of addictive french fries. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip, about $50. Two days for reservations. (496 Ninth Avenue, between 37th and 38th Streets; 212-967-7850; open seven days a week, 11:30 A.M. to midnight; no credit cards.) Alison on Dominick, a romantic enclave hung with velvet curtains, packed with an eclectic crowd of artists and writers, business people and bons vivants, whose favored meal is the salmon roulade followed by the braised lamb shank with fava beans and wilted chicory. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip, about $90. Two days for reservations. (38 Dominick Street, between Varick and Hudson; 212-727-1188; lunch Monday through Friday, noon to 2:15 P.M.; dinner Monday through Saturday, 6 P.M. to 11; all major credit cards.)

title: A. W. Wilson, Minister, 87
description: The Rev. A. W. Wilson, whose church became a rallying point for the 1955 bus boycott here that set off the civil rights protests, died Friday at his home after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Citicorp Rates Rise at Auction
description: Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp and 182-day commercial paper, the first increase in paper rates in three weeks.

description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were off sharply in the week ended yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Magazines Wage War For Revenue
description: HERE'S a tip for media trade publishing companies trying to contend with the slowdown in media trade advertising: make movies.

title: Join With Castro To Fight Drugs
description: For reasons that may be cynical and self-serving, Cuba's President Fidel Castro has formally invited the United States - for the first time - to join his regime in the ''common battle'' against drug smuggling. For reasons of American national interest, which likewise often requires self-serving cynicism, the Bush Administration would be well advised to at once take Mr. Castro at his word instead of responding with worn out legalisms and ideological foot-dragging.

title: Study Finds Female Athletes Play as Hard but Study Harder
description: Female basketball players in colleges with major programs spend as much time at their sport as their male counterparts, but the women study more, attend class more regularly and get higher grades, according to a study conducted for the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Kid Creole at the Seaport
description: A free concert series on Thursday nights at Pier 16 of the South Street Seaport continues this week with an appearance by the rock group Kid Creole and the Coconuts. Leon Redbone and Karla Bonoff are to perform on Aug. 17, and the Hooters, a rock group, on Aug. 24. All shows begin at 6:30 P.M. and are canceled if it rains. Information: 878-2435.

title: Woman, 34, Shot to Death In Her Home
description: A 34-year-old mother of three was killed early yesterday when at least five shots were fired through a bedroom window of her first-floor apartment in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Giuliani Pledges to Appoint A Panel to Fight Corruption
description: Shifting style and strategy, Rudolph W. Giuliani pledged yesterday that as mayor he would establish an anti-corruption commission to recommend changes in ''city practices and policies which currently make institutional corruption possible.''

title: Crown Buys Unit Of Texas Eastern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation said the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation, a Baltimore-based petroleum refiner and marketer, had agreed to buy its La Gloria Oil and Gas Company. Terms were not disclosed. La Gloria's assets include a 50,000 barrel-a-day refinery and terminal in Tyler, Tex., and three Midwest terminals on the Texas Eastern pipeline.

title: Consumer Credit Rose 5.1% in June
description: Consumer credit rose at an annual rate of 5.1 percent in June, down from a 7.3 percent pace in May, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Estonia Approves Law on Residency
description: The Estonian Parliament today approved the first law in the Soviet Union requiring that candidates and voters fulfill a residency requirement.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Education page last Wednesday about Japanese universities' buying of American campuses referred incorrectly to Tokyo International University of America. It paid $1.7 million for the land for its six-acre campus in Salem, Ore., opposite Willamette University. It did not pay for $1.7 million in landscaping.

description: Individual retirement accounts at banks could be disrupted by a recent opinion from the Labor Department that interest on I.R.A. deposits may lose its tax-deferred status if the deposits are used to qualify customers for free checking accounts, banking officials said yesterday.

Review/Film; 'Abyss': Undersea Life and Peril
description: The last of the summer's big-budget adventure movies, ''The Abyss'' is a gigantic sea monster of a film about marriage, death, nuclear war and alien life forms. Yet it can finally be described in these words: E.T. Underwater. The best way to enjoy this overwrought action film is to go in knowing it is spectacularly silly - something the writer and director, James Cameron, never concedes.

title: Quayle Plans 2d Asian Trip
description: Vice President Dan Quayle will travel next month to South Korea, Japan and the Philippines, his office announced today. The trip, Sept. 19 to 28, will include meetings with Presidents Roh Tae Woo of South Korea and Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines.

description: AS Wall Street cliches go, ''buy low, sell high,'' may be the oldest. It may also be the one least likely to be observed as investors rush to follow the latest Wall Street fad.

title: The Danger of a Firefighting Wonder
description: Responding to growing pressure from the Environmental Protection Agency and environmental groups, a wide range of businesses, military installations and cultural institutions are struggling to curb their use of halons, a highly effective family of firefighting chemicals believed by scientists to be even more destructive to the world's ozone layer than their better-known chemical cousins, the chlorofluorocarbons.

title: Presidential Life Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $164,000, or 1 cent a share, from investment gains. c-Included investment gains of $1,395,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,061,000, or 14 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Review/Theater; 'Shenandoah' Is Back, but the Era Has Changed
description: Many of the qualities associated with the term old-fashioned musical are abundant in the 1975 show ''Shenandoah,'' which is back on Broadway for a limited run at the Virginia Theater.

title: Gibson Out for Season
description: Kirk Gibson, the National League Most Valuable Player last season, will undergo surgery next Tuesday and be lost for the remainder of the season. The 32-year-old outfielder completes 1989 with a .213 batting average, 9 home runs and 28 r.b.i. while playing in only 71 games.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hitachi Cancels Microchip Ads
description: Hitachi Ltd., the Japanese computer company, has abandoned plans for an advertising campaign promoting itself as a future leader in microchips, partly because of fears of adding to trade friction with the United States, a company spokesman said today.

title: Special Prosecutor Is Urged in Man's Death
description: The family of a mentally retarded Brooklyn man who died last month after a struggle with police officers called yesterday for a special prosecutor to look into the case.

title: Atlanta Mayoral Candidate Drops Out
description: The sole announced opponent to Maynard H. Jackson, who was Atlanta's first black mayor, dropped out of the mayoral race today, virtually assuring that Mr. Jackson would return to office after an eight-year absence from politics.

title: Georgina A. Diaz Weds in Manila
description: Georgina Aspillera Diaz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jaime B. Diaz of Manila, and William Martin Balliett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fargo Balliett Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., were married yesterday at St. Augustin Roman Catholic Church in Manila. The Rev. James Donalandperformed the ceremony.

title: Pentech International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Homeless Man Dies on Rail Fleeing Pursuers in Subway
description: A 35-year-old homeless man was electrocuted yesterday when he ran onto subway tracks while trying to escape a group of teen-agers who had harassed him on an Upper West Side subway platform, the police said.

title: New Product Lifts Medtronic Shares
description: Medtronic Inc. shares rose $2.375 yesterday, to $116.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, on the announcement of a new product and on the heart pacemaker company's strong earnings outlook, analysts said. The Minneapolis-based company said on Monday that it would introduce a single-chamber cardiac pacemaker system.

title: SOVIETS BACK U.S. ON NUCLEAR PLAN
description: The Soviet Union has accepted a proposed American method on monitoring underground nuclear tests but has attached a condition unacceptable to the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Cineplex Expands
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it has bought a 50 percent stake in four cinema complexes in Suffolk County, L.I., for undisclosed terms. Cineplex will operate and schedule movies for the complexes, which were acquired in partnership with a group of New York real estate developers. The theaters are in Mattituck, Westhampton, Islip and Sayville.

title: Country Lake Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Economic Scene; Moscow Gamble: Butter Over Guns
description: WITH growth stalled and ambitious plans for market reforms on hold, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is playing his remaining economic card. For the first time since World War II, the Kremlin has ordered a reduction in spending on military equipment and capital goods. The resources freed in the cutbacks will go into consumer goods, easing pent-up demand for everything from blue jeans to disposable syringes and giving Mr. Gorbachev a few years' breathing space to put the failing economy back into gear.

title: Stanford Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Beyond Orientation: New Freshman Focus
description: Driven by a host of forces that are sharply changing higher education, the nation's colleges and universities are devoting more resources to the needs of a group of students they have traditionally paid the least attention to: freshmen.

title: A Man of the Earth Reaps the Good Life
description: STANDING in the middle of his garden one sunny morning, Angelo Pellegrini leaned on his ever-present walking stick and cast a grave eye over a dozen transplants of Swiss chard that he had set out from a seedbed earlier in the day. As transplants often do, the chard looked weary, flopped over on its side in the dusty garden soil, and the old man shook his head as if reprimanding naughty students.

title: Gateway Commun reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Colonial Gas reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an accounting gain of $2,014,000.

title: Mets Beat Phils and Return To Race
description: The Mets got back into hot pursuit tonight when they wiped out the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-0, on the six-hit pitching of David Cone, who has won six consecutive games since his last defeat two months ago.

title: Thomas Nelson Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $218,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Suez Seeks to Increase Its Insurance Holdings
description: Compagnie Financiere de Suez, the Paris-based bank holding company, announced today that it was making a bid to acquire full control of Compagnie Industrielle, the largest shareholder of Groupe Victoire, a major French insurance company.

title: California Earthquake Drill Is Jolted by the Real Thing
description: A moderately strong earthquake jolted the San Francisco Bay area early this morning, breaking windows and shaking people in their beds. But when Ed Bortugno's wife telephoned him at 1:15 A.M. to tell him about it, his first reaction was that someone was playing a joke on him.

title: Dining: Lowering the Volume to a Murmur
description: THE squat ex-garage at 150 Wooster Street sits at the edge of a dingy, apricot-colored haze cast by nearby street lights. Like gauze curtains hung for privacy, shadows sweep across the yellow brick facade. Yet swarms of people find the unmarked restaurant. ''Here?'' asked a young woman in a spandex dress and ponytail, pausing on the sidewalk. Yes. This summer in New York City, 150 Wooster Street is the place to be.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * The Mingo Group will move to new offices at 228 East 45th Street, New York, in September.

title: Meridian Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Community Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest fourth results included a $3.1 million increase in the company's provision for possible loan losses and a $2 million writedown of non-performing assets.

title: Coke Acquires French Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that it had completed the acquisition of a bottling and distribution subsidiary of Pernod Ricard S.A. of France, putting an end to a dispute over the marketing of Coke products in the country.

title: Realty Trust Bid Dropped
description: The Income Opportunity Realty Trust and two pension funds in Detroit said they had signed an agreement to end the funds' hostile takeover bid for the trust and to settle lawsuits between them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY A fundamental remaking of the savings industry was quickly set in motion as President Bush signed legislation intended to end years of staggering losses. Mr. Bush expressed pride in the bill passed by Congress early Saturday, saying it would ''put in place permanent reforms.'' The law calls for outlays of $166 billion over 10 years to close and merge insolvent institutions, and many more billions after that. [ Page A1. ] The nation's economy continues to grow slowly, the Federal Reserve said in its ''beige book'' on economic conditions. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Responding to Marvin Davis's offer, UAL's board said it would explore ''all possible financial and strategic alternatives.'' Mr. Davis said he was encouraged, and some analysts said United Airlines was now in play. Even before the announcement, UAL stock again rose sharply, climbing $24.625, to $243.875. [ D1. ] Bonwit Teller and B. Altman stores filed for bankruptcy protection, along with the American arm of Hooker, the Australian developer. The company hopes to open merchandise pipelines and to obtain relief from pressing debts. [ D1. ] Citicorp gave Hong Kong a vote of confidence, saying it would arrange $667 million in loans to build two office towers. It also said it might take an equity stake in the project. [ D1. ] Anchor Glass received an offer of $280 million, or $20 a share, offer from a large Mexican glass company, and its shares soared 61 percent, or $7.50, to $19.75. [ D1. ] Stock in Paramount Communications rose $2.50, to $62.125, on rumors that Cablevision's chairman, Charles Dolan, or Chris-Craft Industries was accumulating stock. [ D19. ] Chase Medical is to be delisted from the American Stock Exchange, the Amex said, because more than 90 percent of its shares are owned by its chairman, Stanley Chase, his family and the Securities Settlement Corporation. [ D4. ] Gtech agreed to be acquired by an investor group consisting of its management and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, in a deal valued at $16.625 a share, or a total of $290 million. [ D4. ] Coca-Cola completed the acquisition of a French bottling and distribution subsidiary of Pernod-Ricard, ending a dispute over the marketing of Coke products in France. [ D4. ] MARKETS The scandal in the commodity tradings pits appears to have dealt a serious blow to the prestige of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, but it is unlikely to put much of a dent in their business. [ D1. ] The Dow Jones transportation average soared 50.49 points, to 1,406.29, once again driven by UAL, which jumped 24 5/8, to 243 7/8. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 13.09 points, to 2,686.08. [ D8. ] A disappointing auction of 10-year notes sent prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds lower, and dealers questioned whether interest rates would have to move still higher to generate demand for today's sale of $9.75 billion of 30-year bonds. [ D15. ] Yields of money market mutual funds were down for the week ended yesterday. [ D13. ] Corn futures were lower and soybeans and wheat futures finished higher as traders maintained narrow price ranges in advance of the Agriculture Department's survey of crop production for the year. [ D16. ] The dollar turned narrowly mixed against key foreign currencies in sluggish trading. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Nineteen months after Public Service of New Hampshire entered bankruptcy, the outlines of a settlement are beginning to take shape. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Wall Street is beginning to applaud the early effects of Kroger's ''public leveraged buyout.'' Market Place. [ D8. ] The Revlon Group dropped Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/New York and Sudler & Hennessey from its agency roster. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: Electromedics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $11,000 and $197,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $80,000 for the quarter and $112,000 for the 6 months. The company said in the latest quarter the share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title: Cambior Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: DC-10 Lands in Denver With Engine Trouble
description: A Northwest Airlines DC-10 made an emergency landing today after one of its jet engines apparently began breaking up and the pilot turned it off, officials said.

title: First Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about a reorganization at McCall's magazine misstated the former position of Madelyn Alpert Roberts at McCall's. She was a team sales director.

title: The Health Crisis and Baby Bells
description: Over 150,000 telephone workers in 15 states and the District of Columbia are striking the so-called Baby Bells - Nynex, Pacific Telesis and Bell Atlantic. The major dispute is over health coverage.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 On the hostages, President Bush said that he was determined to make his approach flexible so that he does not ''miss a signal'' that could lead to their release. Page A1

title: Topics of The Times; Mrs. McGann's 'Vacation'
description: If Geraldine McGann wants to stay on the Department of Housing and Urban Development's payroll, she'll have to uproot from Long Island and move to Washington - at least temporarily. That, in effect, is what Secretary Jack Kemp of H.U.D. said Friday when he ordered Mrs. McGann, a key figure in the rigging of a subsidized home ownership program in Island Park, L.I., to Washington for a 120-day assignment.

title: Higher Cancer Risk Seen in Childhood Sunburns
description: Severe childhood and teen-age sunburns are more than twice as likely to lead to skin cancer as severe sunburns later in life, researchers say.

title: New York Takes Hard Look At Pension Expert's Taxes
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that New York City was investigating the personal income tax history of its highest-paid official, a newly appointed chief actuary, for possible irregularities.

title: Adams Resources & Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Freddie Mac Shareholders Now Have Voting Rights
description: By signing the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enhancement Act yesterday, President Bush automatically converted about 60 million nonvoting shares of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation senior participating preferred stock into voting common stock.

title: Wetterau Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
5 Israeli Soldiers in Lebanon Wounded by Suicide Bomber
description: A Shiite Muslim cleric carried out a suicide truck-bomb attack against an Israeli military convoy in southern Lebanon today, in what a statement issued in West Beirut described as retaliation for the kidnapping of another Shiite clergyman by the Israelis two weeks ago.

title: Once Again, Mack Lobell
description: Although Mack Lobell, the top trotter in the world the last two years, drew the No. 7 post yesterday for the International Trot at Yonkers Raceway on Saturday, he was immediately installed as the overwhelming 7-5 favorite. The race will be Mack Lobell's first in the United States since he went to stud in Sweden last year.

title: Citicorp Offering Preferred Stock
description: Citicorp is offering $125 million of graduated-rate preferred stock at $100 a share through the First Boston Corporation.

title: Rose Accuser Reports Evidence of Tax Evasion by Manager
description: While baseball's gambling case against Pete Rose remained stalled in Federal courts, a Federal investigation into possible income-tax evasion by Rose took on renewed interest yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Mostly Mozart (Mostly With Others)
description: On the Mostly Mozart program Gerard Schwarz led on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Mozart was vastly outnumbered, and seemed almost beside the point. The sole Mozart entry, the Symphony No. 28 in C (K. 200) wafted by blithely, in a performance that was often charming and even stately, but never gripping. It stood, in a way, as a hurdle the orchestra had to get over before settling into the evening's real business.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Chang Loses: Michael Chang was defeated by Jason Stoltenberg yesterday, 6-3, 7-6, in the second round of the Swiss Army Knife open at Livingston, N.J. Jim Courier continued his impressive play, winning 12 of the final 13 points to score a 6-1, 6-1 victory over Alex Antonitsch of Austria. Chris Bailey, the No. 2 singles player in England, also advanced with a 6-3, 7-5 victory over Rich Fromberg of Australia. Jim Grabb advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Jeff Tarango.(AP) McEnroe Returns and Wins: Recovered from a shoulder injury at Wimbledon that sidelined him for five weeks, John McEnroe routed Dan Cassidy yesterday, 6-2, 6-2, at the United States hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. In other second-round matches, Stefan Edberg of Sweden beat Danie Visser of South Africa, 6-4, 6-4, and Aaron Krickstein defeated Diego Nargiso of Italy, 6-1, 6-4. Todd Witsken advanced to the third round with a 7-6, 6-3 victory over Vijay Amritraj of India. (AP) Wilander Defeated in Upset: Andres Gomez of Ecuador upset Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-1, 6-4, in straight sets last night to win the United States pro championship in Brookline, Mass. The final was scheduled to be played 25 days ago but was delayed by rain and schedule conflicts.

title: Steven Jayson with a display of restoration glass, which simulates antique glass, at S. A. Bendheim. (NYT/Michelle V. Agins) WHERE TO FIND IT; Reproducing Windowpanes of Old
description: IF you are restoring an old house that has broken or missing windowpanes, you might use new or ''float'' glass, which lacks the distortion of old glass. But most purists balk at the idea. Faithful restorers will either replace the panes with old, salvaged glass or use new glass that is made to look antique.

title: Lesbian Struggles to Serve in Army
description: Miriam Ben-Shalom's troubles with the Army began on the day in December 1975 when she graduated from drill sergeant school in Milwaukee. As one of the first two women to serve as drill sergeants in the 84th Division of the United States Army Reserve, she attracted the attention of local reporters.

title: Bush Plans to Name Colin Powell To Head Joint Chiefs, Aides Say
description: President Bush will name Gen. Colin L. Powell of the Army to be the new Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, an appointment that would make him the first black officer to hold the nation's highest military post, Administration officials said today.

title: Currents; Biedermeier Reinterpreted for the 90's
description: FOR admirers of Biedermeier furniture, the neo-classical style that flourished in Austria and Germany from 1815 to 1830, the choices are few: scarce and expensive antique pieces and now, Milo Baughman's Biedermeier 90 collection for Thayer Coggin, a furniture maker in High Point, N.C.

title: Bush Signs Savings Legislation; Remaking of Industry Starts Fast
description: The largest remaking of America's financial system was set in motion today as President Bush signed a bill that will eventually marshal hundreds of billions of dollars in support of the Government's commitment to guarantee the safety of depositors' money.

title: Halifax Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Plush Course for P.G.A.
description: Public golf courses often come in for unfair scorn as the poor man's poorly conditioned playgrounds for the old game. But even the haughtiest of private club members could be jealous of the Kemper Lakes public course, where the 71st P.G.A. Championship will begin Thursday northwest of Chicago.

title: Core-Mark International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $1,824,000 and $1,596,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Who's Getting All the Money We've Been Throwing at Legal Aid?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba Plans to Try Rights Workers for Slander
description: The Cuban Government said today that it was taking steps to prosecute the country's most prominent human rights worker and two others on charges of spreading false information.

title: Tempers Flare in Comptroller Debate
description: The four main candidates in the Democratic primary for New York City comptroller debated issues like responsible investment of city pension funds last evening, but acrimony flared when two of the four lashed into each other's records.

title: Oak Hill Sportswear reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its results reflected additional pre-tax interest expense of about $278,000 and $545,000 in the latest second quarter and 6 months, respectively, related to treasury stock purchases made in 1988.

Kalamazoo's Mall Is 30 and Prospering
description: Thirty years ago, this city in southwestern Michigan took a daring approach when faced with the decline of its downtown.

title: Railcar Operations To Be Sold to G.E.
description: The Leucadia National Corporation said it and the Brae Corporation had agreed to sell their railcar-leasing businesses and Brae agreed to sell its railcar-management business to the General Electric Company for $178.5 million in cash, plus about $4 million in lease obligations.

title: First Golden Bancorp reports earnings for Year to June 30
COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Gtech Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by an investor group consisting of its management and the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Capital Corporation in a deal valued at $16.625 a share, or a total of $290 million.

2 Shutouts in a Row Put Mets on Right Track
description: Davey Johnson wouldn't exactly call it a drive or a comeback or a leap into the homestretch of a four-team race in the National League's East. ''More of a move in the right direction,'' he said. ''Everybody settling into a role, and carrying it off.''

description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Cummins Engine Amends 'Pill' Plan
description: The Cummins Engine Company, fighting off the latest potential takeover threat, said it had amended its ''poison pill'' defense. Under the plan, directors of the diesel-engine maker may grant shareholders the right to buy new shares for $1 each if someone acquires 15 percent of the company's stock. Initially, the plan, which could make a takeover prohibitively expensive, could not be exercised until an investor held 25 percent of Cummins' stock.

title: Vermont Research reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After tax credits of $120,000 for the quarter and $695,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: New Name in Search
description: A Federal judge with experience handling antitrust and labor disputes is a contender to succeed Pete Rozelle as National Football League commissioner, The Sacramento Bee reported yesterday.

title: Few Choices in Commodity Markets
description: The scandal that led to the indictment last week of 46 commodity traders appears to have dealt a serious blow to the prestige of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. But it is unlikely to put much of a dent in their business.

title: Energynorth Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NFS Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the latest quarter it added $625,000 to its provision for possible loan losses.

title: Transtechnology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $118,000 from a business held for sale. c-Net income and after a loss of $278,000 from a business held for sale.

title: DiIorio, Wergeles
description: DiIorio, Wergeles, the New York ad agency whose accounts include Kraft General Foods' Budget Gourmet line of frozen meals, has named Michael Drazen as president and creative director. A veteran of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, Mr. Drazen last year left HDM, New York, where he had been executive vice president and creative director, after the agency reorganized its creative department. At DiIorio, he will replace Julio DiIorio, who is retiring. The agency, a subsidiary of the Ross Roy Group, said it expected to bill $28 million in 1989.

title: Sun Unit and C3 Get Navy Contract
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said its Sun Microsystems Federal unit joined with C3 Inc., which integrates computer systems, and received a contract from the Navy with a potential value of $115 million.

title: McCaw Posts A Bigger Loss
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular telephone company, said today that its second-quarter loss had widened to $87.5 million, from $61.7 million a year earlier.

title: In Texas, the Candidates Try To Seem Like Jim Wright
description: An eclectic group of candidates is on the ballot in Saturday's special election for the 12th Congressional District here: a television doctor, a fence salesman, a car wash manager, a private investigator and a secretary for an aviation company, among others.

title: Durham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses of $1,880,000 and $2,677,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both reflecting the operations and loss from sale of Durham's state capital unit. c-Included a net of $484,000 for the quarter and a loss of $208,000 for the 6 months, both reflecting state capital items. The company said the current year included about $2 million lessin realized gains than the year earlier.

title: Bridge
description: If a clever defense defeats a contract, the defenders are entitled to hope for a profit. But the higher the standard of the event, the less likely the profit. It may well turn out that the rival defenders have been equally skillful.

title: McDonnell in Deal
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said two Spanish airlines had converted a total of 12 options on MD-80 aircraft into firm orders. Iberia S.A., Spain's national airline, which holds 24 options on MD-80's, converted seven of them into orders for MD-87's. Aviacion y Comercio S.A., the national domestic airline, converted five MD-80 options to orders for MD-88's. The MD-80 aircraft have an average delivery price of $30.7 million, McDonnell Douglas said. Delivery of the Iberia aircraft will begin in June 1991, with delivery to Aviacion beginning two months later.

title: Salvador Co-ops Succeed Despite Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Conviction on a Felony Won't Bar Steinbrenner
description: A former felony conviction would not block George Steinbrenner from taking ownership of Canterbury Downs race track in Minnesota, an assistant state attorney general said yesterday.

title: Michaels Stores To Be Acquired
description: Michaels Stores Inc., a retail chain specializing in materials for home decorating and crafts, has agreed to be acquired for about $130 million by a company formed to take it private. Under the accord, the holders of Michaels' nine million common shares will receive $9.50 a share in cash and $2.50 in liquidation value of preferred stock in the acquiring company, MSI Holdings Inc.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Moved Greg Swindell, pitcher, from the 15-day to the 21-day disabled list. Placed Luis Aguayo, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Steve Olin, pitcher, from Colorado Springs of the Pacific Coast League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Activated Gary Redus, outfielder-first baseman, from the 15-day disabled list. BASKETBALL WASHINGTON (NBA) - Signed Mel Turpin, center. FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Waived J. R. Ambrose, wide receiver. GIANTS (NFC) - Signed Lionel Manuel, wide receiver, to a two-year contract. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Waived Cedric Stallworth, defensive back. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Agreed to terms with Mike Elkins, quarterback, on a four-year contract. MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Louis Oliver, safety, to a four-year contract. Waived Ricky Phillips, guard. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Agreed to terms with Wayne Martin, defensive end. Signed Jumpy Geathers, defensive end, to a two-year contract.

title: Books of The Times; A Human Comedy, as Told by a Glib 99-Year-Old
description: Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All By Allan Gurganus 718 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95.

title: Modern Algerian Rhythms With Touches of the West
description: New Yorkers had their first chance to hear the impassioned singing and heady rhythms of rai - West Algerian rock - when Cheb Mami performed Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s. Rai arose in Oran, a port city, when musicians adapted traditional melodies to electronic instruments while letting in some Western musical influences. Song lyrics, in Arabic, often speak of forbidden love or assert the singer's independence, addressing a younger generation that is ambivalent about traditional ways. Rai singers call themselves ''cheb'' (or ''chaba'' for women), which means ''young''; Cheb Mami is 23 years old.

title: When Mercy Weakens Justice
description: LEAD: The recent clamor over a pardon for Oliver North, despite his not having received a prison sentence, was a noisy reminder that we, as a nation, do not really know what to think about pardons. Reasoned discussion is difficult because the issue brings two great American virtues - open-hearted generosity and devotion to justice under law -into open conflict.

title: Tseng Labs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ms. Dunkel Weds Alfredo Enriquez
description: Elizabeth Victoria Dunkel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Dunkel of Tenafly, N.J., and Alfredo Roberto Enriquez Ordonez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfredo Enriquez of Progreso, Yucatan, Mexico, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's uncle, Paul Dunkel, in Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Wilson T. Boots performed the United Methodist ceremony.

title: Q&A
description: Residue on Walls

title: Moore Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: A New Master Of Renovation On 'Old House'
description: When they learned in March that Bob Vila's commercial endorsements had cost him his position as host of ''This Old House'' on public television, more than 400 people applied to WGBH in Boston for his job on the popular home renovation program.

title: Parent & Child
description: STEVEN SILVA is dreading the day this month when he will wave goodbye to his 5-year-old daughter at the airport. Mr. Silva and his former wife have shared custody of Meghann since they divorced four years ago. She has been staying in Minneapolis with her father, who remarried, since the beginning of June. Meghann will return to her mother in New Hampshire in time to begin kindergarten in September.

title: Lobbyist Is Arrested in New York
description: Craig J. Spence, a Washington lobbyist who is a subject of a Federal investigation of male prostitution in Washington, is facing cocaine and gun possession charges in New York, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Home Capital Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Currents; A Decorative Touch Amid the Graffiti
description: IN June, Jed Zavon and Chuck Hettinger opened a home-furnishings store in the East Village and called it Home Boys.

title: Goldin Pledges Efforts to Keep $1 Transit Fare
description: Saying that being able to get around New York City quickly and safely was not just a matter of convenience but ''a matter of economic survival,'' City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday outlined initiatives to improve the city's transportation systems.

title: Home Owners Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,320,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and after extraordinary gains of $95,000 for the quarter and $2,837,000 for the 9 months, both from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Warnings About DC-10 Have Gone Unheeded; Engine Workings
description: To the Editor:

title: New York's Air, Washington's Duty
description: The latest surveys by the Environmental Protection Agency merely confirm what every sensate New Yorker knows just by going out the front door: New York City has some of the foulest air in the country. The city needs to reduce hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide emissions by a staggering 60 percent just to meet existing Federal health standards for ozone, the main component of urban smog. It needs almost as large a reduction to meet Federal standards for carbon monoxide.

title: Unresolved Issues
description: Jurisdiction A Federal judge ruled July 31 that Rose's lawsuit against Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti belongs in Federal court in Columbus, Ohio, where Giamatti wants it, and not state court in Cincinnati, where Rose wants it. On Tuesday, Rose's lawyers filed an appeal of that ruling with the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati. Giamatti's lawyers have until next Tuesday to respond. A three-judge panel will decide whether to hear the appeal. Hearings Judge John Holschuh of United States District Court has set a hearing for Monday on Rose's request for a preliminary injunction blocking Giamatti from hearing baseball-betting charges against Rose. Rose's lawyers filed a motion last Monday to halt that hearing pending the outcome of their appeal on jurisdiction. Giamatti's lawyers responded to that motion yesterday.

Depending on your sightline, he may be seen directly beyond one of the retired numbers on the row of painted baseballs on the fence, behind either No. 4 (Gehrig), 3 (Ruth), 5 (DiMaggio), 7 (Mantle), 37 (Stengel) a pair of 8's (Berra and Dickey), 16 (Ford), 15 (Munson), 32 (Howard), 9 (Maris), 10 (Rizzuto), or 1 (Martin).

title: Review/Theater; Ellen Burstyn Turns Liverpudlian in 'Valentine'
description: Willy Russell's ''Shirley Valentine'' is a monologue that becomes a monodrama, or, more accurately, a mono-comedy, offering a resonant portrait of a 42-year-old Liverpool housewife who learns to live more fully by taking a fugitive holiday in Greece. The title role was first played in London and in New York by Pauline Collins, who deservedly won a Tony Award as best actress last season. She has now been succeeded on Broadway by Ellen Burstyn. In the English tradition, one major actress has followed another in a role in which the original has left her imprint.

title: Corrections
description: An article and an illustration in Science Times on July 18 about tree planting to reduce global warming misstated part of the process in which trees absorb carbon dioxide and give off oxygen. The oxygen comes from the water taken in by trees. It is produced by photolysis, the light-induced splitting of water molecules.

First, there was the videotape of a man, identified as Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins, one of the American hostages in Lebanon, hanging from a rope. Then there was the videotape of another hostage, Joseph Cicippio, who had been threatened with death by his captors.

title: Reviews/Music; Benny Carter Is Celebrated In Own Notes
description: Lincoln Center's birthday tribute to the saxophonist, trumpeter and composer Benny Carter at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night truly started after intermission, with the arrival onstage of Mr. Carter, Dizzy Gillespie and a rhythm section of Hank Jones, Ray Brown and Bobby Durham. The rhythm section, which warmed up with Mr. Carter, during the first half of the concert, ripped into ''Another Time/Another Place,'' and for the next three numbers, the music was absolutely flawless, a performance that could be mulled over for the next century.

title: Israeli Shoots at Troops by Mistake; Son Is Killed
description: A Jewish settler driving home with his two small children late Tuesday night saw a spark of light in the trees beside the road. Thinking a Palestinian must be about to toss a firebomb, he stopped his car and began firing his pistol into the darkness.

Pierce Jr., according to internal H.U.D. documents and interviews.

Summer of the Booboisie
description: Mencken! Thou should'st be living at this hour. (With apologies to W. Wordsworth.) Through the 1920's and 30's H. L. Mencken savaged the follies of American life. His special targets were the narrow minds, the intolerant certainties of what he called ''the booboisie.'' He reveled scornfully in the trial of John Scopes for teaching evolution, describing the onlookers - who believed that God literally created the world in six days - as ''gaping primates.''

title: College Tuition to Be 5% to 9% Higher This Fall

title: At Least 85 Are Killed in Mexican Train Crash
description: A Pacific coast train plunged off a bridge into a rain-swollen river in northwestern Mexico today, killing at least 85 people and injuring 107, an official involved in the search said.

title: Topics of The Times; The Game of the Name
description: Say it ain't so, Joe. Not Shoeless Joe Jackson of Black Sox fame, but Joe DiMaggio, the living, breathing, nice-guy hero of yesteryear's Yankees. Joltin' Joe is not alone in taking money for his autograph, but his reported price of $30 per, is, well, jolting. Among today's stars, the slugger-outfielder Jose Canseco of the Oakland A's and Cincinnati's Pete Rose get $15, the Red Sox's Cy Young award-winning pitcher Roger Clemens gets $9, and there are many more in that range.

title: Bonwit's Owner Files for Bankruptcy
description: The Bonwit Teller and B. Altman stores filed for bankruptcy court protection yesterday, seeking to reopen merchandise pipelines and obtain relief from pressing debts.

title: Joule Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included a $400,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Dart Drug Files For Chapter 11
description: Dart Drug Stores Inc., a chain of 74 stores based in Landover, Md., has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Bilingual Union Ads
description: The AFL-CIO said yesterday that its first bilingual advertising campaign would begin on Sept. 14. The Spanish and English television ads, which will continue to employ the labor movement's ''Union Yes'' slogan, will feature the actor Edward James Olmos. The premier ad, in Spanish, will be broadcast on NBC's English-language ''Cosby Show.'' The AFL-CIO said it would spend $3.25 million on its fall advertising campaign.

title: Surf Casters Are Spinning Record Yarns
description: The best of this country's long-distance surf casters are now consistently exceeding 700 feet in major competitive events.

title: Father and Son Found Dead in Union Office
description: Two officials of a longshoreman's union local, believed to be a father and son, were found shot to death this evening, the police said.

title: Warnings About DC-10 Have Gone Unheeded
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Delays Its Payments
description: Finance Minister Mailson da Nobrega said today that the nation's foreign creditors had agreed to a delay in debt payments. He denied Brazil would begin a moratorium on such payments.

title: Influential L.I. Senator Quits
description: After 24 years as one of the most influential voices in Albany, State Senator John R. Dunne of Garden City said today that he would resign his seat next month. Although he is prominent among Republicans across the state, the 59-year-old Mr. Dunne is considered a maverick by the powerful Nassau County Republican organization because he often challenged its choices for offices. Throughout his career, he was denied its support for election to higher office.

title: Citicorp's Hong Kong Deal Called Vote of Confidence
description: Citicorp, the largest banking company in the United States, yesterday gave Hong Kong one of the strongest votes of confidence it has received since the upheaval in China in June shook its markets.

title: Universal Matchbox Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UAL Board Is Willing To Listen
description: Responding to a $5.4 billion takeover offer, the directors of UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, said last night that the company would ''explore all possible financial and strategic alternatives.''

title: Close to Home
description: THE first of the fall catalogues has arrived. Normally, I would have tossed it in the wastebasket, as I do most catalogues, and felt guilty about not having paid just a little bit of attention. All that work on the part of stylists, copywriters and photographers buried under coffee grounds and shrimp shells: ah, the waste. But I had a cold, and my eyes were streaming too much for anything but large print and big color pictures. So I stretched out on a couch and contemplated what the catalogue called, in elegant script, ''Autumn 1989.''

title: James M. Markham Is Dead at 46; Chief of The Times's Paris Bureau
description: James M. Markham, the New York Times bureau chief in Paris, died there yesterday, apparently of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 46 years old.

title: ILC Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included tax credits of $204,000 and $543,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Swiss Computer Fails
description: Dealers at Switzerland's fully automated options and futures exchange have gone back to doing deals by telephone because their $40 million computer system has failed. ''All our experts are working flat out to solve the problem. We don't know how long it will take,'' said Otto Naegeli, director of the Swiss Options and Financial Futures Exchange. He said sabotage was unlikely to have caused the failure but could not be ruled out. The exchange, the world's first fully automated options trading and clearing system, opened in May 1988 and trading volume has grown much more rapidly than originally expected.

title: San Francisco Bay Journal; One Man Organizes Pollution Patrol
description: Michael Herz's 26-foot outboard cut through the morning fog as he searched through binoculars for anyone fouling his beloved San Francisco Bay.

title: Hampton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said 1988 share earnings are restated to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend paid in July 1989.

title: The Next Generation Moving Up at Insteel
description: In recent years, Howard O. Woltz Jr., chairman and chief executive of Insteel Industries Inc., has been working to expand the company's business and trying to move a new generation of executives into key management positions.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
My Abortion, Then and Now
description: LEAD: In 1960, I had an illegal abortion.

title: Pornographic Theater Closed as a Crack Den
description: Tactical Narcotics Team police and city inspectors closed an Eighth Avenue pornographic theater last night, citing it as a public nuisance because 11 drug arrests had been made there this year.

title: Newmont Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Group Discloses EECO Discussions
description: A group of Minnesota investors, who control 5.5 percent of EECO Inc., said it had held talks with the management of the computer-equipment manufacturer in the last year about a possible sale. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group said it intended ''to monitor closely EECO's operations and may seek, at some point in the future, a more active interest in the management of the company.''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Executive Keeps in Shape To Play for Di Giorgio
description: LEAD: As the Rutgers University football team arrives in New Brunswick, N.J., this week to prepare for this fall's season, among the quarterbacks, wide receivers and linebackers will be a man training for another position - corporate raider.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Atlanta mayoral election misstated the candidates' entry deadline in some editions. It is Aug. 18.

title: Aritech reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
State Dept. Permits Return Of U.S. Dependents to China
description: About 260 dependents of United States Government personnel in China who were evacuated from that country two months ago have been authorized to return, the State Department said today.

title: A Hotel's Last Tenant Clings to Memories
description: Over the 25 years in which the Brooklyn Arms changed from a residential hotel favored by retired judges and doctors to a densely packed shelter for homeless families, only one man, Leon Horniker, remained. He stayed because he had work to do: he was writing scholarly articles on his specialties, Ottoman-Turkish diplomatics and Turkish warriors in the Middle Ages.

title: Home Improvement
description: FOR many construction projects, artificial sheet materials or panels, like plywood, particle board and flake board, offer advantages over lumber. But panels also have a major drawback: their large size, usually at least four by eight feet, makes handling and cutting difficult.

title: Dominion Textile reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $38.1 million for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and included gains of $200,000 for the quarter and $20 million for the year. The company said the charge in the latest fourth quarter and year represent the costs of the consolidation of certain facilities, plant closures, a business restructuring and the reevaluation of certain investments and assets. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Theater; A Play About Pollack, And a Show Set in Havana
description: ''I am in command of every drip I make,'' Jackson Pollock says in one of many seemingly endless sung monologues about the art world in the 80-minute one-act musical, ''Peggy and Jackson.''

title: Elco Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Judge Rules for Blazers
description: A judge in Portland, Ore., issued a temporary restraining order yesterday clearing the way for the Yugoslavian basketball star Drazen Petrovic to reach a contract agreement with the Portland Trail Blazers. The N.B.A., citing an agreement with the Spanish professional basketball league, had prohibited the Trail Blazers from negotiating with Petrovic, a guard.

title: Rumors Push Up Paramount Stock
description: Shares of Paramount Communications Inc. rose $2.50 each yesterday, to $62.125, amid rumors on Wall Street that the stock was being accumulated by Charles F. Dolan, chairman of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, or Chris-Craft Industries.

title: Novo-Nordisk reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results are in U.S. currency and had been translated at the June 30, 1989 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equals Dkr. 7.5930. The 1988 figures for the merged company are included in this statement for purposes of comparison and were calculated on a pro forma basis. Share earnings represented American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represented 1 B share.

title: Military Arrests Exacerbate U.S.-Panamanian Relations
description: The war of nerves between the United States and Panama intensified today as the Panamanian authorities arrested two American military policemen, apparently in retaliation for the arrest on Tuesday of 29 Panamanians by American forces in Panama.

title: Kimball International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Warehouse Club reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $244,000. c-Net loss

title: Market Place; Buyout Corner Turned by Kroger
description: LATE last year, the Kroger Company, one of America's largest supermarket operators, dodged a takeover attempt by the Dart Group and a leveraged buyout offer by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company by opting for a sweeping reorganization. When the dust settled on what analysts called a public leveraged buyout, 35 percent of the company's shares were in the hands of its employees, the dividend payment that had been made regularly since 1902 was discontinued and the company's debt jumped from $600 million to $4.7 billion.

title: Accel International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $44,000 for the quarter and $120,000 for the 6 months. c-Included tax credits of $6,000 and $56,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The latest quarter net included $172,000 of realized after tax gains from the final sale of Accel's interest in United Coasts Corp. Shares earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: Watts Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WASHINGTON TALK: Exact Words; If the Senate Were a Dessert . . .
description: Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, made these remarks about the United States Senate in Friday's debate over the bill to rescue failing savings and loan institutions: <n My friend from New York says it is good work and it could be better. I agree. It is good. It could be better. However, the only way it could be better, you and I would have to have faith in the U.S. Senate. I wish I had the faith of my colleagues in the Senate. However, I do not.

title: Earle Palmer Brown
description: Earle Palmer Brown's Richmond office was chosen by the Group Health Association, a Washington health maintenance organization, to handle its $1 million-plus ad account, while the agency's Atlanta office was awarded the $1 million account of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's printing paper division.

title: Child's Play: A Make-Believe Drug Stand
description: The police here have discovered a playground stand where children operated a make-believe drug ring offering bags of grass clippings and sugar, a Harrisburg newspaper reported today.

title: Ex-TV Ministry Aide Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: A former top aide to Jim Bakker, founder of the television ministry PTL, pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy Tuesday and agreed to testify against the evangelist. But Mr. Bakker's lawyer said the deal was suspect because the aide, Richard Dortch, had sold his soul.

title: Piedmont Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Article 503789 -- No Title
description: A major Mexican glass manufacturer yesterday announced a $280 million tender offer for the Anchor Glass Container Corporation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The life of every single one of these people is too precious for me to be sticking my head in the sand and miss some subtlety in this highly complicated corner of the world.'' - President Bush. [ A1:6. ]

title: Personal Health
description: Breast-feeding, widely hailed for its health benefits, economy and ''naturalness,'' has caught on among modern American mothers, two-thirds of whom now nurse their babies. As recently as 1970, only one mother in four breast-fed, so the change in infant feeding practices has been swift and dramatic despite the growing numbers of young married women in the work force.

title: With Killing, Neighbors Lose Heart for Drug War
description: All along Starr Street in Brooklyn, neighbors of Maria Hernandez said yesterday that her death by gunfire was a great sorrow, but not a great surprise.

title: Currents; Plates Transformed by Decoupage
description: MOST of the time, Jered Holmes is an actor and singer. But when he's between jobs, he is a decoupage artist.

INSIDE
description: Koch and Cuomo Offer Plan To Hire 4,000 Officers

title: MBIA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRESIDENT AFFIRMS A BROAD APPROACH TO HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: President Bush said today that he was determined to make his approach on the hostage issue flexible enough that he avoids ''sticking my head in the sand'' and missing ''a signal'' that could lead to the release of the eight Americans held in Lebanon.

title: Brookfield Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KMW Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said prior year earnings were reduced by a special after- tax adjustment of $595,000.

title: Endevco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $231,000 for the quarter and $398,000 for the 6 months. Latest second quarter and 6-month share earnings were less than one cent a share because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Pact for Directors and Choreographers
description: The Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers and the League of Resident Theaters announced Tuesday that they had reached agreement on a new contract providing fee increases of 26 to 32 percent over four years.

title: Price-Fixing Inquiry at 20 Elite Colleges
description: Invoking the Sherman Antitrust Act, the Justice Department is investigating whether elite colleges and universities are unfairly restraining trade in setting similar levels of tuition and financial aid.

title: Banks Seek I.R.A. Talks
description: Bankers said yesterday that they expect to meet with Labor Department officials later this month to discuss a department opinion that could cause cause considerable turmoil in the $231.8 billion of I.R.A. accounts at banks and savings institutions.

title: Garfinkel Joins BBDO, Leaving Levine, Huntley
description: Lee Garfinkel, a senior vice president and creative director at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, jumped yesterday to BBDO, New York, to become a senior vice president and senior creative director. Mr. Garfinkel, an 11-year veteran of Levine, was the creator of the Beneficial Corporation's consumer-loan television commercials, which had won a Gold Lion at the International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, France.

title: Taxi Panel Hears Plans To Raise Fare
description: Although officials insist that a formal decision is unlikely before November, there were signs yesterday that the cost of settling into the back seat of a yellow cab in New York City may be higher by Jan. 1.

title: For an Artist, It's Home Sweet Storefront
description: ANTHONY CHASE doesn't care for sheetrock apartments with whitewashed walls. Minimalism isn't his style either. And a fifth-floor walkup does not suit him at all.

title: KEY RATES
Article 420789 -- No Title
description: The Hubbard Museum of Ruidoso, N.M., announced yesterday the creation of a $250,000 annual award for new works of American representational and realistic art. The prize, to be called the Hubbard Art Award for Excellence, is one of the largest art awards ever bestowed, and the winner will be named on June 1, 1990.

title: Warnings About DC-10 Have Gone Unheeded; Airline Resistance

description: Compagnie Industrielle will resist a $2.5 billion offer made by Compagnie Financiere de Suez, its president said today.

description: b-Net loss

title: 20,000 Russians Strike for Voter Rights in Estonia
description: An estimated 20,000 Russian workers walked off their jobs in Estonia today to protest a new election law that will deny many of them the chance to vote or run for office in the Baltic republic, worker representatives and Estonian journalists said.

title: A General Who Is Right for His Time
description: In choosing Gen. Colin L. Powell to be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, President Bush would be turning to what many consider to be the very model of a modern Army general for a time when diplomatic finesse and foreign policy expertise may be as important as combat experience. As President Ronald

title: Union Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Preferred-share dividends totaled $1,389,000 in latest first quarter, compared with $332,000 for year-ago period. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 14 Killed in Northern India As Bomb Explodes on a Bus
description: A time bomb, planted by suspected Sikh terrorists, exploded in a bus in northern India today, killing at least 14 people and wounding 36, the police said.

title: Looking to the Company To Provide the Necessities
description: Corporate paternalism has long been in retreat in the West because it is largely viewed as an infringement on personal freedom.

title: Ford Studying Mazda Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company is studying the possibility of a joint venture with the Mazda Motor Corporation to produce vehicles in Europe, a Ford official said today. Speaking at a University of

title: Coeur D'Alene Mines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cuomo, Koch Agree on Plan To Add Police
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have agreed to propose legislation that would create a ''superfund'' to hire 4,000 additional police officers for New York City, Mr. Koch said yesterday.

title: Equipments Denis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Simms Still at Home As a Giants Holdout
description: Seventeen days ago, when the Giants opened training camp, Phil Simms stayed home. He is still there, holding out for a contract extension that would pay him a reported $1.6 million a year.

title: EMPLOYEES' WATER FOULED AT A-PLANT
description: More than 100 employees at a nuclear weapons plant here drank water contaminated with a highly toxic solvent for 15 months because of a plumbing mistake, but an official of the nuclear weapons plant says the workers were not harmed.

title: A Lada in Perestroika's Vanguard
description: When economic change began sweeping through the Soviet Union in the mid-1980's, the vast Volga Automotive Plant Association here was in the vanguard. Operating on a profit-and-loss basis and using management techniques common in Japan and the West, it was a leader in putting into effect perestroika, the restructuring that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is counting on to revive the Soviet Union's stagnant economy.

title: XL-Datacomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from Friday, Aug. 4.

title: Lomas Financial's Bankers Unit Sold
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation said it had completed the sale of its banking unit, the Lomas Bankers Corporation, to an investor group led by Merrill Lynch & Company's private equity group for $435 million in cash and $65 million in 10-year redeemable preferred stock. Under the agreement, Lomas Bankers, which has a credit card business with 1.7 million customers, will continue to operate as an independent financial services company with operations in Texas and Delaware.

title: Polymer International (N.S.) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: More Victims Sought in Fire That Killed 3 in Lynn, Mass.
description: Investigators searched a burned-out rooming house for more bodies today and followed the fire's path in an effort to learn its cause.
