title: Elmira Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
22 Arrested in Nuclear Protest
description: The authorities reported 22 arrests at the Nevada Test Site today as anti-nuclear demonstrators marked the 44th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Nagasaki, Japan. Nineteen people were cited on misdemeanor trespassing charges and released. Three were being held on Federal trespassing charges because they entered the office of the Los Alamos National Laboratory here.

title: San Salvador Journal; He's a Rightist (No Doubt About It)
description: Orlando de Sola makes no apologies for his right-wing radicalism. He wears it with unabashed pride, a badge of courage emphasizing that he will not brook compromise.

title: Impeachment: Time To Change the System?
description: Since the 14th century, when the English House of Commons sought to prosecute high officials of the Crown before the House of Lords, impeachment has been one of the most contentious and onerous duties of representative governments.

title: Mood in China: Hope Gains on Fear
description: China's jails brim with ''counterrevolutionaries,'' and its airwaves are full of calls for greater faith in Communism. But so far the worst fears of the democracy campaigners of early June have not come to pass, and there seems to be somewhat greater hope among them these days.

title: Article 798289 -- No Title
description: The future of Bonwit Teller and B. Altman & Company, two of New York's oldest retailers, brightened somewhat yesterday when the General Electric Company's GE Capital Corporation unit agreed to extend a $50 million credit line to the stores' parent company, the L. J. Hooker Corporation.

title: Hilton Seeking Buyers For Itself or Its Hotels
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation put itself up for sale today, telling its investment advisers to seek prospective buyers for the company or its hotel business.

title: TV Weekend; A Ghost Story by Henry James, on Showtime
description: Viewers of tomorrow night's version of ''The Turn of the Screw'' who are not acquainted with the original may be left wondering why Henry James's ghost story should have fascinated readers for almost a century.

title: Patrick Leaves Legacy Of a Free-Market F.C.C.
description: When Dennis R. Patrick stepped down as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission on Monday, he left behind a legacy of free-market policies that are widely expected to set the tone for regulation of telecommunications and broadcasting for years to come.

title: Pierre Matisse, 89, Art Dealer and Promoter, Dies
description: Pierre Matisse, the internationally known art dealer who was the longtime champion of Joan Miro, Marc Chagall, Jean Dubuffet, Balthus and Yves Tanguy in the United States, died Wednesday in a hospital near his home in St.-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, France, after a stroke. He was 89 years old.

title: Alternative Thrills For Other Wallets
description: For some New Yorkers, the idea of a cheap thrill is arriving back at an illegally parked car just as the meter attendant whips out the ticket book.

title: Free Chamber Concert
description: The Metropolitan Soloists are to play a free concert of chamber music by Swan Hennessy and Carl Nielsen, arrangements from Bizet's ''Carmen'' and Jerome Kern's ''Showboat,'' and a suite of George M. Cohan songs, Sunday at 1:30 P.M. at the Dairy in Central Park, near the 65th Street Transverse east of Center Drive. Information: 397-3165.

title: Concentration of AIDS Cases Posing Serious Problem for Some Hospitals
description: The nation's AIDS cases are concentrated in selected hospitals in major cities throughout the country, causing serious financial losses, forcing reduced care and threatening to crowd out other patients in those hospitals, a new study shows.

title: Kelly Uneasy at the Center of Debate
description: Playing as the center fielder for the Yankees isn't easy. Surviving as center of the latest controversy for the Yankees is plain scary.

title: Hoechst Celanese Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Overseas Shipholding Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains from the sale of vessels of $911,000 for the quarter and $1,294,000 for the 6 months. c-Included a gain of $651,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of vessels.

title: On Stage
description: 'Grapes of Wrath'

title: Dinkins Starts His TV Advertising Campaign
description: David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President and Democratic candidate for mayor, will begin his television advertising campaign today with a 60-second commercial that portrays him as a man whose career has been marked by perseverance, tolerance and ''quiet courage.''

title: Morris Shenker, 82, Lawyer in St. Louis And Hoffa Defender
description: Morris A. Shenker, a lawyer known for his defense of James R. Hoffa, the boss of the teamsters' union, in the 1960's died of pneumonia Tuesday at his daughter's house in Santa Monica, Calif., after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in St. Louis, Mo.

title: No on Shoeless Joe
description: Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti has turned down a request to consider reinstating Shoeless Joe Jackson to major league baseball, saying he did not ''wish to play God with history.'' Jackson, who died in 1951, had a .356 career batting average, but was one of eight Chicago White Sox players banned from baseball for their part in the 1919 ''Black Sox Scandal.''

title: Enough Of the Contras
description: After the 20-year Presidential tenure of Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman, Republicans produced an effective political slogan: ''Had Enough?'' That is an appropriate question to put today to Republicans themselves, particularly George Bush, as they contemplate the ruins of their ''contra'' policy in Nicaragua.

title: First Marathon Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Missouri Fetus Unlawfully Jailed, Suit Says
description: A Missouri law restricting abortions has been used by a pregnant inmate to file two lawsuits against the state for what she contends is the illegal imprisonment of her fetus.

title: Threat to Arts Is a Threat to All Our Freedoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcohol Gauged In Toran Death
description: Stacey Toran, safety for the Los Angeles Raiders, had a blood-alcohol level more than three times the legal limit when he was killed in an automobile accident Saturday night, the Los Angeles County coroner's office said today.

title: Hall (Frank B.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $50,000,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included the reversal of a tax credit of $820,000.

title: MGM Grand Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $352,000 for the quarter and $1,806,000 for the 6 months; the quarter also included a pre-tax gain of $26,482,000 on the sale of hotel-casino assets. c-After tax credits of $111,000 and $422,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: For Dravecky, a Triumph Over the Reds and Cancer
description: Dave Dravecky added a stunning chapter to his comeback story today, allowing four hits in eight innings and becoming the winning pitcher as the San Francisco Giants edged the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3.

title: Palmer's 68 Is Cheered Even by His Rivals
description: Ben Crenshaw walked out of the scorer's tent after signing his card for a round of four-under-par 68 today, looked back at the Kemper Lakes golf course and said, ''Go, Arnie!''

title: OFFICER WATCHED RAPE TAKE PLACE
description: A police officer working undercover in a drug investigation watched a group of men rape a woman but did not interfere because he did not want to reveal his identity, according to newspaper reports.

title: Two Mozart Operas
description: Gerard Schwarz is to conduct concert versions of two rarely performed Mozart operas, ''Thamos, King of Egypt'' and ''Apollo and Hyacinthe,'' at a Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8. The singers include Erie Mills and Andrea Matthews, sopranos; Laura Brooks Rice and Robbyne Redmon, mezzo-sopranos; Rockwell Blake, tenor, and Jake Gardner, baritone. The works are to be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $18.50 to $9. Information: 874-6770.

title: In Silence of Bushwick, Residents' Fear Is Heard
description: When the police held a community meeting in Bushwick yesterday to announce that they would bring a Tactical Narcotics Team back to the Brooklyn neighborhood, the audience of about 50 community leaders and residents sat silently. There were no questions or comments.

title: Cairo Frees Fundamentalist Cleric Pending Hearing on Role in Strife
description: An Egyptian court freed one of the country's best-known Islamic fundamentalists and 23 followers today pending further hearings into charges that he incited political violence.

title: U.S. Concern On B.A.T. Bid
description: Reacting to strong objections from more than 200 members of Congress, the State Department has conveyed concern at least twice to the British Government about the potential impact of the proposed hostile takeover of B.A.T. Industries, department officials said yesterday.

title:
CAUTION: THIS ART MAY OFFEND;
Theater
description: LEAD: In July, the Senate voted to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from using Federal funds to ''promote, disseminate or produce obscene or indecent materials, including but not limited to depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts, or material which denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion.

title: Goldin Offers a Plan to Cut New York City's Income Tax
description: Saying it was time to recognize that New Yorkers feel ''overtaxed and underserviced,'' the City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, yesterday unveiled a plan to cut the city's income tax by more than $100 million a year.

title: Fremont General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $562,000 and $100,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,632,000 for the quarter and $2,105,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary gains of $371,000 and $620,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restated. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results were adversely affected by a special provision of $13.7 million to cover potential losses on loans in its Fremont Financial Corp. subsidiary.

title: Mayoral Hopefuls Tiptoe Around Budget
description: New York City's next mayor may confront huge budget gaps, some of the most daunting social problems in decades and a local economy that is no longer generating substantial new tax revenue. All of this, warns Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, might make the fiscal crisis of the 70's seem ''benign.''

title: United Cities Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Metropolitan Airports to Bar Noisy Night Flights
description: In a major step toward easing the din of jets around New York City's three major airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that starting Jan. 1 it would begin phasing out flights between midnight and 6 A.M. by a whole generation of noisy aircraft.

title: TREATMENT FOUND FOR AN INFECTION
description: A previously untreatable bacterial infection usually resulting from cat scratches is apparently treatable with a powerful antibiotic, a new report says.

title: New Forensics Lab Joins War on Wildlife Crime
description: A new laboratory here in the dusty foothills of southern Oregon is applying forensic analysis to solving a growing number of crimes involving endangered species.

title: Threat to Arts Is a Threat to All Our Freedoms; Industry Dogma
description: To the Editor:

title: Theodore Kaghan, 77; Was in Foreign Service
description: Theodore Kaghan, a former Foreign Service officer and journalist, died of heart failure Wednesday at Brattleboro (Vt.) Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Brattleboro.

title: Painting
description: In July, the Senate voted to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from using Federal funds to ''promote, disseminate or produce obscene or indecent materials, including but not limited to depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts, or material which denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion.'' The bill, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, would also bar grants for artwork that ''denigrates, debases or reviles a person, group or class of citizens on the basis of race, creed, sex, handicap, age or national origin.''

title: 22 Die in Beirut in Artillery Duels
description: At least 22 people were killed and 140 wounded today in artillery duels between Syrian gunners and the Christian units of Gen. Michel Aoun, officials said. The police said the barrage began at 11 A.M. and lasted until dark, with artillery shells and rockets falling on Beirut at a rate as high as 40 a minute.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets on Panama at 11 A.M. General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: May Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7 million for the quarter and $6 million for the 6 months. c-After income of $7 million for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Breaking Away From the Humdrum
description: FAR beyond the familiar routines of metropolitan life and just this side of one's wildest fantasies, real-life adventure lurks.

title: Police Officer In Drug Case Shot in Bronx
description: A 24-year-old undercover narcotics officer was shot in the back and critically wounded yesterday afternoon, the police said, as he tried to buy cocaine from two men in a Bronx apartment building described by its residents as infected with drug dealers and violence.

title: KEY RATES
Gap Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oceaneering International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ford and G. M. Plan to End Use of Chlorofluorocarbons
description: The two largest American auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, said today that they planned to eliminate chlorofluorocarbons in manufacturing and in vehicles by the mid-1990's.

title: Auctions
description: It has, of course, been a while since baseball cards were simply ephemera for boys to trade and mothers to throw away during surreptitious cleaning sprees. With a 1909 Honus Wagner selling recently for $110,000 - hear that, Mom? - and with professional collectors taking over what used to be a children's pastime, individual baseball cards have come to be worth more than many players earned during their entire careers.

title: Reynolds Will Cut 1,640 Jobs
description: In a long-anticipated move to cut costs, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,640 jobs, or 11.5 percent of its work force, as part of a broad restructuring of its operations.

title: Rangers' Search Goes On And On
description: Jack Diller, the man who took 54 days and a couple of embarrassing public rebuffs on the way to naming a general manager for the Rangers, laughed softly when he was asked whether he was disappointed that Neil Smith has now gone 25 days without naming the team's next head coach.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL MILWAUKEE (AL) - Placed Rob Deer, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up Greg Vaughn, outfielder, from Denver of the American Association. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed David Evans, pitcher. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Activated Jim Lindeman, first baseman-outfielder, from the 21-day disabled list. Placed Leon Durham, first baseman, on the 15-day disabled list. YANKEES (AL) - Claimed Rich Gossage, pitcher, off waivers from the San Francisco Giants. BASKETBALL WASHINGTON (NBA) - Signed Doug Roth, center. FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Released Tony Miller, running back. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Signed Wayne Martin, defensive end, to a four-year contract. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Signed Roland Melanson, goaltender. RANGERS (NHL) - Signed Corey Millen, center. HORSE RACING RIVER DOWNS - Suspended Gilberto Laiz, jockey, for 60 days and fined him $250 after he was found to possess an electrical device in the gate before the start of the second race July 26. SOCCER ST. LOUIS (MISL) - Named Erv Pesek Jr. general manager; Robert J. Wilber vice president of marketing; David Yontz public relations director, and John Parks advertising and promotions manager. COLLEGES COLGATE - Named Bob Roth, Paul Aiello and Mike Lonergan assistant basketball coaches. COLORADO - Suspended Keith Pontiflet, cornerback, from the football team after he was charged with third-degree assault. INDIANA-Pa. - Named Owen Dougherty baseball coach. KANSAS STATE - Declared Greg Washington, wide receiver, academically ineligible for the upcoming football season. NAVY - Named Ron Lievendag men's gymnastics coach; Garry Yuen women's gymnastics coach; Richard Deladrier men's and women's fencing coach, and Kylor Whitaker assistant men's basketball coach. PENNSYLVANIA - Named Julie Soriero head women's basketball coach. SAN FRANCISCO - Named Mike Candau director of operations-ticket manager. SAN JOSE STATE - Named Benny White, John Coughran and Brad Winslow assistant basketball coaches. WASHINGTON - Named Paul Martel running backs coach; Rhod Reaves receivers coach, and Dan Allison defensive backs coach. WESLEY COLLEGE - Named Joe Wysock offensive line coach; Chip Knapp linebackers coach; Mike Drass defensive line coach, and Richard Biscayart receivers coach. Named Charles McGlinn head men's soccer coach. YOUNGSTOWN STATE - Announced that Jim Clemons, head basketball coach, resigned to become an assistant coach with the Chicago Bulls.

title: Estonia Prohibits Further Strikes By Russians Protesting New Law
description: The Estonian authorities reacted firmly today against angry Russians complaining of discrimination and banned further protest strikes as a threat to the Baltic republic's economy.

title: The Nights For Seeing The Stars (Real Ones)
description: When August showers may come your way, they're shooting stars that rain all day. The midsummer night's spectacular known as the Perseids is a shower of meteors that may achieve its most incandescent brilliance tomorrow night, streaking across the sky from the northeast at the rate of about one meteor a minute.

title: Dorsett Realizes The End Is Near
description: Tony Dorsett, who tore a ligament in his left knee last week, acknowledged today that ''it's probably my last year, but I'm still trying to stay optimistic.''

title: Group Acquires Gemcraft Homes
description: A group of Houston investors has bought the name and the assets of Gemcraft Homes Inc., a bankrupt homebuilder based in Houston, for $13.5 million from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The F.S.L.I.C. acquired the company's assets last December when it took over First Texas Savings Association, an ailing Houston savings institution. First Texas foreclosed on the insolvent homebuilder the previous summer. Gemcraft filed papers for bankruptcy protection from its creditors in March.

title: Robert E. Kaske, 68, A Professor at Cornell
description: Robert E. Kaske, a medieval scholar who taught at Cornell University for 25 years, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: Trash Hauler And Relative Killed on L.I.
description: A garbage hauler who assisted in investigations of organized-crime involvement in Long Island's garbage-collection industry was killed, along with his brother-in-law, in their company offices early this morning, the authorities said.

title: Drug Evictions Can't Be Halfhearted Measures
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank to Plead Guilty to Laundering Drug Money
description: A Panamanian bank has agreed to plead guilty to laundering drug money, in a case that discloses the complicated new electronic technology now used to transfer illegal profits from cocaine sales in the United States.

title: Dining Out Guide: Southern Fare
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. American Festival Cafe * (July 27, 1984), 20 West 50th Street (246-6699) - Rockefeller Center's plaza is the unlikely camping spot for a 100-year-old chuckwagon as the American Festival Cafe features San Antonio-style barbecue on the current menu. The wagon and its companion meat smokers, installed next to the fountain, were brought from Texas to lend authenticity and atmosphere to the $15.95 three-course dinner. Hand-shaped corn cakes topped with guacamole, salsa and cheese start the menu. Barbecue choices are brisket, pork ribs, smoked longhorn sausage or combination plate ($16.95) accompanied by beans, cole slaw and barbecue sauce. Dessert is pie, either pecan or deep-dish peach with ice cream. Barbecue menu through Sept. 10 at dinner only. Open 4 P.M. to midnight Tuesdays through Saturdays, until 10 P.M. Sundays and Mondays. Gage & Tollner * (July 7, 1989), 372 Fulton Street, Brooklyn (718-875-5181) - A new owner and a new menu designed by a renowned Southern cook have revived this Brooklyn landmark. The turn-of-the-century room remains the same: gas-fueled chandeliers light the dark mahogany panels and long rows of linen-covered tables. The house specialties include brisket of beef, pan-fried quail with spoon bread, and crab cakes with red rice and cole slaw. For a good shellfish starter, try cornmeal-coated fried oysters. Appetizers are $4 to $9.50, main courses $12 to $19.50. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Mondays through Fridays; dinner: 5 to 10 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays, until 11 P.M. Fridays, and 4 to 11 P.M. Saturdays. Closed Sundays in August. Jezebel ** (Aug. 28, 1987), 630 Ninth Avenue, at 45th Street (582-1045) - This theater-district restaurant is a stage set in itself, with the expansive room decorated with wicker and antiques, palms and piano shawls. Among the recommended starters are smothered garlic shrimp and Charleston she-crab soup. The chef's main course specialties include Southern fried chicken, Carolina shrimp creole, and roast chicken with waffles. Strawberry shortcake, made with fresh baking-powder biscuits, is the real thing. Appetizers are $5 to $7, main courses $14.75 to $21.75. Dinner daily at 6, 8 and 10:30 P.M. seatings. Sylvia's Diner's Journal (Nov. 4, 1983), 328 Lenox Avenue, at 126th Street (996-0660) - Extremely popular with both residents and tourists, this bustling restaurant dishes out calorie-packed main courses of fried chicken, smothered pork chops, barbecued ribs and short ribs of beef. Corn bread, collard greens and potato salad are the accompaniments. Sylvia's also serves a good sweet potato pie. Main courses are $6 to $10.95. Open 7:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays and, 1 to 7 P.M. Sundays. Yellow Rose Cafe Diner's Journal (May 11, 1984), 450 Amsterdam Avenue, at 81st Street (595-8760) - This popular source for Texas-style cooking is owned by a native of Fort Worth; the narrow space was recently expanded to include a bar (with converted Western-saddle bar stools) and seating area. Some New Yorkers get their first taste of chicken-fried steak here. The Southwestern oddity is well-pounded cube steak dipped in flour and buttermilk batter, then fried like chicken. Other choices are barbecued chicken or ribs; Southern fried chicken, and Mexican salad in a flour tortilla ''bowl.'' Side dishes include mashed potatoes with cream gravy, fried okra and butter beans. Appetizers are $3 to $5, main courses $8.25 to $11.50. Open noon to 11:30 P.M. daily.

title: Melanson Joins Devils
description: The Devils, with a surplus of young goaltenders, added a veteran yesterday when they signed Roland Melanson as a free agent without compensation. Melanson, 29 years old, who broke into the National Hockey League with the Islanders in 1981, played briefly last season with the Los Angeles Kings. He has a 3.65 goals-against average for 281 regular-season games.

title: Days Inns Is Sold To a Franchisee
description: A unit of Reliance Group Holdings Inc. said it had agreed to sell the Days Inns Corporation to the hotel chain's largest franchisee, Tollman-Hundley Hotels, for $90 million in cash and the assumption of $675 million in debt. Brian T. Martin, a spokesman for Reliance Group Holdings, owner of the limited partnership Reliance Capital Group, said Tollman-Hundley must arrange the financing to complete the deal.

title: Shakespeare in Park Becoming Less Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 463 money market mutual funds increased $1.24 billion, to $338.35 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased $954.00 million, to $86.53 billion. At the 227 general-purpose funds, assets were up $676.80 million, to $107 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds had an increase of $1.52 billion, to $144.80 billion, the institute said.

title: Tech-Sym Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $864,000 from an accounting change.

title: 'Judicial Error' Helped Owners Of Jersey Dump
description: New Jersey's efforts to clean up an illegal dump that was piling trash under Interstate 78 were frustrated in Federal and state courts for two years, first by the dump operator's filing for bankruptcy and, last spring, by a state court's decision that the Chief Justice of the state today called a ''serious judicial error.''

title: Guardian for de Kooning Agrees on Role for Daughter
description: An agreement was reached today between the court-appointed guardian for the artist Willem de Kooning, who is 85 years old and has Alzheimer's disease, and a lawyer for the artist's 33-year-old daughter, Lisa, that would allow the daughter and the de Kooning family lawyer, John L. Eastman, to be named conservators of the artist's assets at a court hearing next week.

title: Chamber at Caramoor
description: Mark Gould, the principal trumpeter of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, is to be the soloist with the New York Chamber Soloists in a program of 18th- and 20th-century works at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., tomorrow evening at 8:30. The other performers are Melvin Kaplan and Marc Schachman, oboists; Paul Dunkel, a flutist, and Elizabeth Metcalfe, a harpsichordist. The program includes music by C. P. E. Bach, Vivaldi, Baldessare, Telemann, Handel, Copland and Barber. Tickets are $10 to $30. Information: (914) 232-5035.

title: The Footsore Still Pursue Bloch's Story
description: After weeks of notoriety as an espionage suspect, Felix S. Bloch is demonstrating an increasing conviviality with his ever-present entourage of reporters, camera crews and F.B.I. agents. But that does not protect him from an occasional angry encounter with the public.

title: Near No-Hitter and a 35-Hit Game
description: Nolan Ryan took a no-hitter into the ninth inning tonight but lost it, and a shutout, when Dave Bergman singled with one out and Matt Nokes followed with a double, giving the Detroit Tigers their only run in the Rangers' 4-1 victory.

title: KV Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Treasury Auctions End Well
description: Successful auctions of more than $24 billion in new Treasury bonds and bills helped push the prices of outstanding issues higher in the credit markets yesterday.

title: LTV Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge from an accounting change of $2,263,000,000. The company said year-ago quarter and 6 month nets included an extraordinary charge of $30 million from discontinuance of the company's truck business. Year-ago 6 months also included a gain of $24.8 million from the sale of two vessels. Latest quarter included charges of $50 million for estimated cost increases in various aircraft programs and a $30 million special charge associated with canceling construction of a flexible composites center for the production of advanced aircraft components. Latest 6 months included $25 million of charges associated with fixed- cost development programs for military aircraft. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restated for an accounting change.

title: Illinois Central Transportation Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest 6 months included a special $76.2 million special charge for merger related expenses and restructuring, following the tender offer for the company in March. Prior year 6 months included a gain of $61.3 million from a change in accounting principle.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HARLEM FESTIVAL

title: Swim Programs With Dolphins Drawing Fire
description: Three times a day at Theater of the Sea, a marine mammal theme park in the Florida Keys, turquoise pools echo with the cheers of men and women being tugged in churning circles as they hang onto the dorsal fins of Atlantic bottlenose dolphins. In Hawaii, at the Hyatt Regency Waikoloa, guests can frolic with dolphins in saltwater lagoons carved from lava.

title: Mets Sweep Cards to Cut Gap to 3 1/2 Games
description: The Mets rocked Shea Stadium and a sellout crowd of 48,712 fans last night when they took two giant strides toward the top by sweeping a doubleheader from the St. Louis Cardinals and drawing to within three and a half games of first place in the National League East.

title: How Big East Threatens Civilization
description: It was clear that American civilization was doomed when they showed the film clip a few months back. The Vice President of the United States, off on one of his educational field trips, stopped to shoot hoops at a military base.

title: Piccadilly Cafeterias Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain from an accounting change of $2,551,000.

title: Southwest Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Reserve for preferred dividends exceeded net in the latest second quarter.

title: Laurentian Group Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the year- earlier quarter share earnings was less than 1 cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Exar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included 19 percent of the loss from the company's former Exel subsidiary; subsidiary was sold April 1.

title: The Bushwick Terror
description: The issue posed by the killing of Maria Hernandez in Brooklyn on Tuesday is stark and basic: Who will control the neighborhoods of New York City, the police and law-abiding citizens or drug dealers and their armed enforcers?

title: Loan Granted To Colombia
description: President Virgilio Barco has signed a $1.65 billion loan accord, paving the way for payouts from a group of international banks to begin in September.

title: Newmont to Add To Peabody Stake
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation agreed to pay $57.5 million for the 5 percent of the Peabody Holding Company held by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: Emulex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Charles E. Robbins, Executive, 83
description: Charles E. Robbins, a co-founder and first president of the Atomic Industrial Forum, an industry association seeking peaceful uses of atomic energy, died Wednesday at a retirement center in Sarasota, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and had recently moved to Sarasota from Westport, Conn.

title: Preborn Children or Blastocysts?
description: Mary Sue Davis wants to have a baby. But since 1979, when she married Junior Lewis Davis, she has suffered several ectopic pregnancies, a ruptured fallopian tube and the tying off of the second. She and Mr. Davis have participated in an in vitro fertilization program too, but the implantation of two out of nine fertilized eggs was unsuccessful. Now the marriage has turned unsuccessful as well: her husband has filed for divorce.

title: Judges Overturn Mesa-Bid Ruling Sears to Cut Jobs
description: A Federal appeals court has set aside a decision that had cleared T. Boone Pickens's investment group of violating securities and racketeering laws in its attempt to acquire the Phillips Petroleum Company five years ago. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit vacated a lower court's summary judgment in favor of the Mesa Partnership and sent the case back to Federal District Court in Delaware.

title: Corrections
description: A map in some copies on Wednesday with an article about shootings in southern Israel misidentified the geographical feature on the southern Israeli-Jordanian border. It is the Wadi Araba, not the Jordan River.

title:
CAUTION: THIS ART MAY OFFEND;
Opera
description: LEAD: In July, the Senate voted to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from using Federal funds to ''promote, disseminate or produce obscene or indecent materials, including but not limited to depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts, or material which denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion.

title: A.B.A. Dons Aloha Shirts and Eats Macadamia Nuts in its Annual Flirtation with Frivolity
description: The American Bar Association could hold its annual meeting in Shangri-la - or Beirut, for that matter -and some things wouldn't change. There would still be the office-seekers, the glad-handers, the networkers working the crowds. There would be the awards ceremonies and the cocktail parties, the parliamentary debates and the prayer breakfasts.

title: All-Vivaldi Program
description: Trevor Pinnock is to lead an orchestra of period instruments in an all-Vivaldi program at Mostly Mozart on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. The program includes ''The Four Seasons'' - with Simon Standage, the concertmaster of Mr. Pinnock's English Concert ensemble, as violin soloist - and the Gloria in D (RV 589). The soloists in the Gloria are Nancy Argenta and Ingrid Attrot, sopranos, and Jean Stilwell, a mezzo-soprano. Tickets: $18.50 to $9. Information: 874-6770.

title: New Owners for 3 Savings Units
description: The new Government body formed to purge the savings industry of insolvent institutions announced new owners for three of the nation's most hopelessly distressed savings and loan associations tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: GAF Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company also represented pro forma results for all prior periods as the latest quarter was its first complete quarter since completing a management buyout. The company reported a pro forma loss of $28.9 million on sales of $266.8 million for the year-ago second quarter.

title: Sears to Cut Jobs
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it would lay off 120 employees in the catalogue unit of its Merchandise Group and 104 workers at a telemarketing operation in Downers Grove, Ill. Last June, Sears announced plans to eliminate 400 management positions from its Merchandise Group.

title: Another Up-and-Comer Joins Italian Team
description: Brian Shaw was the Boston Celtics' first-round choice last year in the National Basketball Association college draft. He had been graduated from the University of California at Santa Barbara after having attended St. Mary's College for two years. By the end of his rookie season with the Celtics, Shaw had won a starting role.

title: Bloch Case Makes A Poor Spy Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: Candela Laser Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: California Air Standards Are Strictest
description: California's standards on automobile emissions, which eight Northeastern states plan to adopt, are the strictest in the nation and are credited by environmentalists and car makers alike with spurring the development of vehicles that emit far less pollution.

title: Sentences in Steroid Case
description: Three former South Carolina assistant football coaches were sentenced today for their convictions stemming from the use and distribution of steroids within the athletic department. Their sentences ranged from three months to six months in a halfway house.

title: Economic Watch; The Uneasy Case for Subsidy Of High-Technology Efforts
description: Should Uncle Sam play Uncle Sugar to high technology?

title: Signals Heard in Search for Lost Legislator
description: Searchers for the missing aircraft of Representative Mickey Leland learned tonight of a faint emergency signal picked up by an American weather satellite from an aircraft in southeastern Ethiopia.

title: Review/Film; Dreams and Nightmares On a Well-Traveled Street
description: All of Elm Street fears Freddy Krueger, the mass murderer with the scarred face and razor blades on his gloves. In ''A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child,'' we learn the villain has his own fears. Freddy is afraid of his mother.

title: NORTHEAST STATES MOVE TO RESTRICT POLLUTION BY CARS
description: Officials of eight Northeastern states have agreed to adopt strict emission controls on automobiles and light trucks in a long-term, multibillion-dollar effort to reduce air pollution.

title: Japanese Report Confession Of Man in Slaying of Girl, 5
description: The Tokyo police said today that a 26-year-old man had confessed to the kidnapping and slaying of a 5-year-old girl in June and that the man could be linked to other killings of girls that have shocked Japan.

title: Chairman of Avon Talks With Jacobs
description: Avon Products Inc., the direct-sales cosmetics company, said its chairman and chief executive, James E. Preston, met with Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor who is Avon's largest shareholder. Last week, Avon rejected an offer by Mr. Jacobs to buy the company for $41 in cash, or $2.2 billion, but Mr. Preston agreed to meet with Mr. Jacobs.

title: Check Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $11,000 and $219,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and the quarter included the reversal of a tax credit of $30,000.

title:
CAUTION: THIS ART MAY OFFEND;
Dance
description: LEAD: In July, the Senate voted to bar the National Endowment for the Arts from using Federal funds to ''promote, disseminate or produce obscene or indecent materials, including but not limited to depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts, or material which denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion.

title: Babbage's reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income and share earnings was less than 1 cent a share.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foot Locker Campaign Reaches New Heights
description: In AC& R Advertising's newest commercial for the Foot Locker chain of athletic-shoe stores, a young man flies through the air with the greatest of ease - on a surfboard towed by a helicopter.

title: Soldier, Leader, Black American
description: America's armed forces face a different but no less daunting task today than they did after the Vietnam War. Then, military leaders had to restore respect for the uniform after a war for which they took an unfair public pounding. Now, they need to shape a new strategy to fit a complicated strategic environment in a time of declining budgets.

title: Ravitch Details Efforts to Help The City's Poor
description: The inner city, once a ''staging ground for upward mobility,'' has become a wasteland for thousands of New Yorkers trapped in a cycle of poverty, despair and crime, Richard Ravitch, a Democratic mayoral candidate, said yesterday. Breaking that cycle, he added, is a key to the city's future.

title: Jet Kickers Don't Fret About Getting the Boot
description: A football player without competition will not improve. He will develop slovenly habits if he doesn't have the threat of another player beating him out of a job.

title: Man Held in Writer's Death
description: A man wanted in the death of a television writer was arrested in New York City Wednesday night on an unrelated drug charge, the police said today. The man, John Doherty, 27 years old, of Jersey City, is charged with felony murder and first-degree robbery in the death of the writer, Robert Stevens, 68 years old, of New York City, who was robbed and beaten early Monday in a Westport home he had rented, the police said. He died a short while later of cardiac arrest.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 To reduce Soviet grain imports and increase harvests, the Government announced that it would begin paying farmers in foreign currency for part of their crops. Page A1

title: Soo Line Picks A Chairman
description: The Soo Line Corporation, which operates the nation's 10th-largest railroad, has electd Donald F. Swanson its chairman, effective Sept. 20.

title: Economic Scene; The Opportunity For Lasting Peace
description: ALL the items on the United States foreign policy agenda are heavily affected by economic factors.

title: At the Movies
description: New York Film Festival

title: American Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $693,000 and $1,555,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: National Health Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Top Officer Appointed For Call Interactive
description: The American Express Information Services Company yesterday named J. Michael Parks president and chief executive of Call Interactive, a new telephone marketing concern that is a joint venture of the American Express Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Transco Energy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods included an after- tax gain of $13.7 million from the sale of 50 percent of Transco Energy Ventures Co.'s interest in certain power generation projects. Results for the year-ago periods included an after-tax charge of $15.8 million for the settlement of litigation.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Heartland Blues

title: Belding Heminway Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Unit of N.L.R.B. Rejects Bid To Bar 3-Day Hospital Strike
description: The National Labor Relations Council yesterday rejected a request by many of New York City's private hospitals seeking to block the state's largest hospital workers union from mounting a three-day strike starting Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Every boy wants to please his mother. Every kid wants Mom's approval. The dad can never make that much money so in a sense it's emotional incest. The kid becomes the husband.'' - Dr. Peter Pinto, a psychologist, on the influence of crack. [ A13:2. ]

title: Tesoro Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the quarter included a $32 million pre-tax gain from the sale of certain assets. The latest quarter and 9 months included a $1 million charge related to the sale of assets and a $4.8 million writeoff of an overseas investment.

title: McCarron and Alydar Enter Hall of Fame
description: Reactions ranged from spontaneous tears to longstanding bitterness today when two men and three horses became the newest members of the Racing Hall of Fame.

title: Our Towns; On the Sad Trail Of Street Youths, Drugs and AIDS
description: Just as the driver nosed the big blue and white Covenant House van around a corner onto Ingham Avenue on the city's north end, George Wirt, a Covenant staff member, pointed toward a corner of the street. ''There,'' he said. ''There's a guy with money right there, doing a deal right on the street.''

title: Chase Medical Trading
description: Trading in Chase Medical Group resumed yesterday, with more than 50,000 shares changing hands over the counter at prices of $4 to $6.50 each. The south Florida medical centers chain, whose shares were the subject of an alleged corner, had last traded officially on Jan. 12, at $13 a share. The American Stock Exchange delisted the stock on Wednesday.

title: Reuter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Diner's Journal
description: Ca'Nova

title: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: AlaTenn Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oneita Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Colleges and Costs; Price-Fixing Inquiry Turns Spotlight On the Ethical Issues in Financial Aid
description: It may be coincidental, but it is also significant, that the Justice Department announced its investigation of scholarship policies on the same day the College Board released its annual survey of the cost of a year of higher education.

title: Computer Changes Jolt Route 128
description: The powerful technological center known as Route 128, which has driven the economic revitalization of Massachusetts for more than a decade, is undergoing convulsive changes that may determine whether the area will remain a competitive force in the computer industry.

title: Review/Art; The Rollicking Red Grooms, Without All the Noise
description: It may be that Red Grooms, past and present master of the rollicking walk-in environmental cartoon, is a better artist in two dimensions than in three. This is one idea to be gleaned from the artist's print retrospective, a traveling exhibition currently at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.

title: Review/Music; Ellington Bill Closes Classical Jazz Series
description: A modest title, ''Duke Ellington: Suites and Blues,'' opened a trove of superb, rarely heard material, mostly from the 1950's and 60's, in the closing program of Classical Jazz, on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. Ellington's work in those years left behind song forms for more elaborate, rhapsodic, experimental and playful structures. While his music from earlier decades is rightfully venerated, his later works are well worth rediscovering - especially when played with the aplomb, precision and gusto that the 15-piece Classical Jazz Orchestra brought to them. David Berger, the conductor, also transcribed the music, including many re-creations of solos.

title: Skywest Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Backup Net for Giants' Safeties
description: When the Giants meet the New England Patriots in Foxboro, Mass., on Saturday night in their first preseason game, they will unveil a young corps of safeties who may not offer all the safety the Giants would like.

title: Management of Gtech Leading Investor Group
description: Guy B. Snowden and Victor Markowicz say they have never accepted the possibility of failure and that has helped make the Gtech Corporation a success.

title: Nordstrom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings in the latest periods for the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. were $1.94 for the quarter and $4.60 for the 6 months, compared with $1.39 and $3.15 for the year-ago periods, respectively. The share earning for the Shell Transport and Trading Co. in the latest periods were $1.08 for the quarter and $2.56 for the 6 months, compared with 77 cents and $1.75 for the year- ago periods, respectively. Sales represented sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport & Trading are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Lone Star Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Second Best Close for Dow

title: Dekalb Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains from disposal of discontinued operations of $9,678,000 and $16,589,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After gains from discontinued operations of $1,454,000 and $3,026,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary charges from the early extinguishment of debt of $4,600,000 for the quarter and $3,902,000 for the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a tax credit of $698,000.

title: ARC International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The 1989 results included a non-cash charge of about $112,000 bookes as an equity accounting loss for the 6 months. The 1988 figures do not include consolidated results for Canrad, interest expense on the Canrad acquisition debt, nor amortization costs related to the acquisition.

title: Two Traders Plead Guilty
description: Two futures traders pleaded guilty today to making fraudulent deals and committing other violations in the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Swiss franc pit. Another Swiss franc trader pleaded not guilty to racketeering charges.

title: Charter Papers on the Way to Washington
description: A van crammed with more than 11,000 pages of transcripts, newspaper clippings, telephone logs, mailing lists, correspondence and advertisements is to leave an office in lower Manhattan today and head for Washington, with New York City's political future riding on the trip.

title: Restaurants
description: The Odeon ** 145 West Broadway, at Thomas Street, 233-0507. Ambiance: No-frills Art Deco cafeteria; lively late-night scene. Service: Young, friendly and competent staff. Recommended dishes: Cornmeal-coated calamari, tuna and lentil salad, fennel and white bean salad, cold black-bean soup, steak au poivre, grilled flank steak, roast chicken and mashed potatoes, grilled salmon with tomato and basil, grilled mahi-mahi, apple tart, profiteroles, coffee parfait. Wine: Fine selection of moderately priced bottles. Price range: Lunch: appetizers $4.50 to $7.50, main courses $6.50 to $17; dinner: appetizers $5.50 to $7.75, main courses $13.50 to $20. Credit cards: All major cards. Hours: Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 7 P.M. to midnight daily; late supper: until 2 A.M. Sunday to Thursday, until 3 A.M. Friday and Saturday; Sunday brunch: noon to 3:30 P.M. Reservations: Recommended. Wheelchair accessibility: Dining on ground level; restrooms downstairs. Da Tommaso * 908 Eighth Avenue, near 54th Street (265-1890). Ambiance: Simple, comfortable, with well-spaced tables. Service: Extremely accommodating and warm. Recommended dishes: Pasta with white clam sauce; fettuccine with shrimp and radicchio; penne with tomato and basil; penne with tomato sauce and vodka; spiedino alla romana; grilled mushrooms; swordfish in white wine and olive oil; lamb chops; veal chops; chicken cooked in white wine, lemon and herbs; calf's liver; pear sorbet. Price range: Appetizers $5.50 to $8.50, main courses $9 to $21. Credit cards: American Express, Mastercard and Visa. Hours: Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5 P.M. to midnight Monday to Friday, 4 P.M. to midnight Saturday, 1 to 11 P.M. Sunday. Reservations: Suggested. Wheelchair accessibility: Everything on ground level. What the stars mean: (None) ... Poor to satisfactory * ... Good ** ... Very good *** ... Excellent **** ... Extraordinary

title: Cagle's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $155,000 loss from discontinued operations. Year-ago quarter included a gain $1,814,000, 79 cents a share, on the sale of Select Laboratories stock.

title: Review/Art; Some Masterly Work of Microcosmic Stature
description: One of the rewards of high summer in midtown is ''Miniature Environments'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, just across from Grand Central Terminal. As the title indicates, the objects on view are small. Just over 30 of them have been got into the little room, and almost everything in the show asks to be looked at as a watchmaker looks at a watch - at close quarters and with eyes alert.

title: Mobile Telecommunications Technologies Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Public Enemy Rap Group Reorganizes After Anti-Semitic Comments
description: Public Enemy, a rap group whose disbandment had been announced by its record company in the wake of anti-Semitic statements by its designated ''minister of information,'' is ''back in action,'' according to a statement released by the group on Wednesday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pfizer Tries To Answer Plax's Critics
description: PFIZER Inc., the New York pharmaceutical company that makes Plax dental rinse, is putting the final touches on an advertising campaign intended to minimize the damage from an article in Consumer Reports magazine that questioned the effectiveness of the mouthwash.

title: John Forsyth Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Threat to Arts Is a Threat to All Our Freedoms; Forged in Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Donizetti's 'Anna Bolena' Is Revived by City Opera
description: Donizetti's ''Anna Bolena'' belongs as much to modern history as to the age into which it was born. The composer wrote it for the Teatro Carcano in Milan where the opera had its premiere in 1830. Giuditta Pasta sang the title role.

title: MOSCOW WILL PAY ITS OWN FARMERS IN FOREIGN MONEY
description: In a novel attempt to slash grain imports and increase domestic harvests, the Soviet Government announced today that it would begin paying farmers in foreign currency for part of their crops.

title: Zambian Chief to Meet Head of Pretoria Party
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, chairman of the so-called frontline states opposing South Africa, said today that he would meet soon in Zambia with F. W. de Klerk, who is expected to be Pretoria's next President.

title: Court Rejects Appeal on Pollution Cleanup
description: The California Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by insurance companies over a ruling requiring them to pay for cleaning up toxic pollution.

title: Namibia Rebels Say Pretoria Is Rigging November Election
description: Charging that South Africa is interfering in the preparations for Namibian independence, the South-West Africa People's Organization, the territory's leading nationalist movement, warned today that it might not accept the results of Namibia's first free elections.

title: Missing Chinese Denies Seeking Asylum in U.S.
description: The interpreter for a Chinese acrobatic troupe who left the group a day after four of the troupe's performers disappeared, emerged yesterday to say that she wanted to return home and had not sought political asylum in the United States.

title: Vista Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $500,000 representing severance benefit to a former officer and director of the company.

title: Davis, UAL Meet on Terms of Bid
description: Representatives of the UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, and Marvin Davis, who has made a $5.4 billion takeover offer, met last night at an airport in New York to discuss the terms of the $240-a-share proposal for the first time, people familiar with the situation said.

title: P.&G.'s Profit Rises by 22.1%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company today reported a 22.1 percent rise in its profit for the fourth quarter as the costs of closing and consolidating some operations were more than offset by income gains from higher unit sales. For the three months ended

title: Trans Canada Glass reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $2.9 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-After gains of $600,000 for the quarter and $3.2 million for the 6 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Bridgehampton Group
description: The resident ensemble of the Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival is to perform at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., tonight at 9 o'clock. Among the performers are Ani Kavafian and Carmit Zori, violinists; Fred Sherry and Ronald Thomas, cellists; Marya Martin, flutist; Nancy Allen, harpist, and David Shifrin, clarinetist. The program: Brahms Clarinet Quintet, Ravel's Introduction and Allegro, Villa Lobos's ''Choros'' No. 2, and John Corigliano's ''Voyage.'' Tickets: $20. Information: (914) 232-5035.

title: Merton P. Stoltz, 76, Professor of Economics
description: Merton P. Stoltz, an economics professor and former provost of Brown University, died of lymphoma Monday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 76 years old and lived in Providence.

title: Extradition Raises Troubling Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about New York City's effort to restrict the space reserved by those attending concerts on the Great Lawn in Central Park misstated the policy of the city's Parks and Recreation Department. It no longer confiscates blankets or bedspreads left unattended on the lawn before the concerts.

title: Helmsley Lawyer Is Reported To Be in Line for Federal Post
description: A lawyer for Leona M. Helmsley in her tax-evasion trial is expected to oversee tax prosecutions at the Justice Department, sources in the department said today. The lawyer, James A. Bruton 3d, is the choice of the head of the tax division, Shirley Peterson, to run the criminal-tax section, the sources added.

title: Market Place; Circle K's Many Difficulties Obstruct the Company's Sale
description: Making money in the convenience-store business involves selling groceries and other goods rapidly and at high prices.

title: Zymos Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $1,490,000 on the sale of equipment.

title: Celebrating France's Directors Who Rode the New Wave
description: ''WE were the first for whom cinema had a past,'' Jean-Luc Godard said this week about the period 30 years ago when he and his cinephilic critic colleagues Francois Truffaut, Eric Rohmer, Claude Chabrol and Jacques Rivette were in the process of changing the face of the movies. ''For a director at Paramount 50 years ago, the cinema had no history. But we knew that it had a past; we were children who realized we had parents.''

title: Harold Barger, Professor, 82
description: Harold Barger, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, died of pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Kinderhook, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: White House
description: Early last week, when the Administration was immersed in deciding how to respond to the threat to American hostages in Lebanon, a Bush aide was asked how the President was spending his day.

title: About Real Estate; Sales Lag at Complex for the Elderly
description: A decade ago, officials of the affluent town of Bedford, N.Y., began seeking ways to create affordable housing for a growing population of older residents. Now 76 new one- and two-bedroom lakeside condominum units for the elderly are on the market at prices as low as $138,500 each, with occupancy to begin next month. The demand for them has been sluggish.

title: Standex International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Port Everglades Tax-Exempts
description: The Port Everglades Authority in Florida is offering $117.4 million of tax-exempt refunding revenue bonds for port projects, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Review/Pop; Bee Gees With Songs Of the Past
description: The Bee Gees - the brothers Barry, Robin and Maurice Gibb -have had one of the most dramatic roller-coaster careers of any contemporary pop group. Originally touted as Beatles sound-alikes in 1967, the three had a string of hits in the late 60's and early 70's in which they applied their trembling close harmonies to a series of weepy ballads.

title: Todd Shipyards Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net loss

title: New Proposal By Allegheny
description: Allegheny International Inc., which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances, said today that it had filed a new reorganization plan with a Federal court to allow it and its subsidiaries to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: National Convenience Stores reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $6,531,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Washington Warns P.L.O. To Soften Its Tone on Israel
description: The Bush Administration criticized the largest faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization today for proposing to ''escalate armed action'' against Israel. American officials warned that such militant attitudes undermined the quest for a negotiated settlement to the Middle East conflict.

title: Profits Rise At Shell, B.P.
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies and the British Petroleum Company each reported today that its second-quarter profits were sharply higher because of higher crude oil prices and gains in refining and petrochemicals. Royal Dutch/Shell, based in

title: Sharp Rise in Corn Crop Seen
description: The Agriculture Department today estimated this year's corn harvest at 7.35 billion bushels, a sharp rise of 49 percent over last year's drought-shriveled crop of 4.9 billion bushels.

title: Henley Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,000,000 for the quarter and $172,000,000 for the 6 months. The company said the loss from discontinued operations for the year-ago second quarter and 6 months included a gain of about $165,000,000 on the January 1988 sale of M.W. Kellogg. The share earnings were restated to reflect the distribution of 0.225 of a share of Henley common stock for every old share. The company also said revenue for 1988 has been restated to reflect the results of Wheelabrator Group Inc., M.W. Kellogg Co., New Hampshire Oak Inc., and other manufacturing companies as discontinued operations, and to reflect the consolidation of Signal Landmark Holdings Inc. The 1989 results reflect the consolidation of PA Holdings Corp. effective June 1.

title: Medellin Cartel's Top Chemist Lured to New York and Held
description: The chief chemist of a powerful Colombian drug cartel, who is responsible for the quality of thousands of tons of drugs sold in the United States every year, was arrested yesterday after he was lured to New York to check on what he thought was a bad shipment of heroin, a spokesman for the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration said.

title: Andres Wines Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Washington National reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods' revenue and net losses have been restated.

title: LTV Says Its Net Fell 75% in Second Quarter
description: The LTV Corporation, the struggling steel giant now entering its third year of reorganization, said today that its net income fell by 75 percent, to $30.3 million, for the second quarter that ended on June 30.

title: Notre Dame Depletions
description: Not long after Coach Lou Holtz's Notre Dame team won the national championship last season, he knew at least two of his eligible members were unlikely to be back this season: Braxton Banks, a senior fullback who had surgery on his knee over the summer, and George Williams, a defensive tackle, who had been declared scholastically ineligible.

title: Books of The Times; Africa as Backdrop for a Comic Adventure
description: Malaria Dreams An African Adventure By Stuart Stevens 236 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Angels Take Turns Playing the Hero
description: The California Angels scored their first run of the season on a home run by Devon White in the first inning of the first game. As omens go, it was a crystal-clear peek into the future.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING Stewart Ties a Record: Alex Stewart of Brooklyn tied the record of 24 consecutive knockouts at the beginning of a heavyweight career when he stopped Terry Armstrong in the third round last night at Felt Forum. Referee Arthur Mercante Jr. stopped the bout at 1 minute 25 seconds of the third round of the scheduled 10-round bout. Armstrong's record fell to 9-9. Stewart shares his record with Mac Foster, who set the record in 1970. TENNIS Unheralded Players Advance: Tim Donovan, Mike Brown, Ramesh Krishnan and Brad Gilbert yesterday advanced to the quarterfinals of the $125,000 Swiss Army Knife Open in Livingston, N.J. Donovan, ranked No. 547 in the world, upset seventh-seeded Paul Annacone, 6-4, 6-2. Brown topped Jeff Klaparda of Los Angeles, 6-1, 6-4. Gilbert, seeded second, eliminated Nduka Odizor of Nigeria, 7-5, 6-4. Krishnan of India beat Chris Garner, 6-3, 6-0. (AP) Navratilova and Sabatini Win: Martina Navratilova and Gabriela Sabatini breezed to straight-set victories yesterday in third-round matches of the Virginia Slims of Los Angeles in Manhattan Beach, Calif. Navratilova eliminated Terry Phelps, 6-3, 6-1. Sabatini defeated Mary Lou Daniels, 6-0, 6-2. In other matches, Mary Joe Fernandez beat Gretchen Majers, 6-2, 6-3; Nathalie Tauziat of France upset Helen Kelesi of Canada, 6-2, 2-6, 6-2; Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden beat Tami Whitlinger, 7-6, 4-6, 6-4, and Zina Garrison defeated Monique Javer of Britain, 6-1, 6-2. (AP) McEnroe Overcomes Slow Start: John McEnroe shrugged off a slow start and routed Michiel Schapers, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday to earn a quarterfinal berth in the United States hardcourt championships in Indianapolis. In other matches, Stefan Edberg of Sweden beat David Pate, 6-3, 6-1; Tim Mayotte advanced with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over David Wheaton; Pete Sampras beat Johan Carlsson of Sweden, 6-3, 6-4; Aaron Krickstein eliminated Wally Masur, 7-6, 7-5; Jay Berger routed Barry Moir, 6-1, 6-1; Todd Witsken defeated Gary Muller of South Africa, 7-5, 6-3, and Richard Matuszewski beat Andrew Sznajder of Canada, 6-2, 3-6, 6-1. (AP) YACHTING Britain Wins Admirals Cup: A 20th-place finish by its final boat gave Britain a victory in the Admirals Cup yesterday off Plymouth, England, restoring the host nation to the top spot it has held for most of the regatta's 34-year history. When Indulgence, a one-tonner skippered by Eddie Warden Owen, crossed the finish line, it gave Britain 748 points, 17 1/2 more than Denmark. It was Britain's ninth victory in 17 Admirals Cup regattas. The defending champion, New Zealand, was third with 667.5 points. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Year's Best for Kingdom: Roger Kingdom turned in the best performance of the year in the men's 100-meter hurdles, leading a 1-2-3 United States finish last night at the City of Grosseto meet in Italy. Kingdom, who was timed in 13.10 seconds, edged Renaldo Nehemiah and Keith Talley. Nehemiah was clocked in 13.24, Talley in 13.59.(AP)

title: Man Charged in Bleecker Street Sniping
description: The leader of a militant Jewish group was arrested yesterday after he sprayed a lower Manhattan street with gunfire, injuring a 69-year-old man, and barricaded himself in his apartment, the police said.

title: American-Music Series To Open Merkin Season
description: A series of music from the American Revolution to the present is to open the 1989-90 season at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The first concert, on Sept. 11, is to feature Odetta and the Hutchinson Family Singers in songs of abolition, temperance, civil rights and suffrage. Other programs in the series are ''War and Peace'' on Sept. 14, ''Workers of the World'' on Sept. 20, a folk-music showcase on Sept. 23 and ''American Songfest'' on Sept. 24.

title: Peasant Party: New Kingmakers for a New Poland
description: The newly complicated task of forming a Polish cabinet has turned a little-noticed political party that was a steady satellite of the Communists into a maverick force familiar to millions of Poles.

title: U.S. Indicates Its Terms For Talks With Teheran
description: The White House sent new diplomatic signals to Iran today, leaving open the possibility of direct talks to resolve the hostage crisis.

title: Linton Journal; From Milking Cows To Running Computers
description: By nature, Debbie Ibach is as practical as the rubber boots she dons to milk the cows, so she was skeptical about the reports that the computer revolution might come to these empty hills where deer outnumber people and drought, frost and wind vie for control over an eroding farm economy.

title: Procter & Gamble Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year nets were reduced by a $78 million provision for closing a Chicago plant and consolidating certain other operations.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Theodore Bikel

title: Mercantile Stores Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Time for Compromise in Poland
description: Solidarity says it will try to topple Prime Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak's Cabinet later this month. It is openly competing for the votes of the Peasant party - once the Communists' docile satellite, but today a decisive swing bloc. At first blush that seems a healthy sign of pluralism. Appearances deceive.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Dun & Bradstreet Corp. named Dennis G. Sisco president of D & B Enterprises, a new division.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: * Banponce Corp., San Juan, P.R., is continuing to evaluate the unsolicited $50-a-share merger proposal made by Banco Popular de Puerto Rico. Banponce's board also authorized an increase in the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share, from 37.5 cents, payable Sept. 29, to holders of record Sept. 14.

title: Finevest Foods reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article yesterday about Gen. Colin L. Powell misstated the source of his Army commission. General Powell was already commissioned as a second lieutenant, through the Reserve Officer Training Corps program at City College in New York, when he went to Fort Benning, Ga. There he attended officer courses at the United States Army Infantry School.

title: Nintendo Plans Network System
description: Nintendo of America Inc. has set up a unit to develop its Nintendo Entertainment System as a home computer terminal for services like news, home banking, and long-distance video game playing. It wants to have an entertainment and informational network on the market in 1990. Nintendo said Jerry Ruttenbur, a senior vice president with Home Box Office's video division, was named vice president of network products.

title: Marshall B. Davidson; Culture Writer Was 82
description: Marshall B. Davidson, a writer on American history and culture who was an editor of Horizon and American Heritage magazines, died of pneumonia on Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: Rudy Mikeska, Restaurateur, 68
description: Rudy Mikeska, a restaurateur who served barbecue to Presidents, governors and millions of others for more than three decades, died of cancer Wednesday at his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: Exchange's Fines Raised
description: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to increase the fining authority of the exchange's directors to $250,000 for each violation, from $75,000. The move is the latest effort by the exchange's membership to strengthen public confidence in the board after the indictment of 46 commodity traders here last week. ''This demonstrates to our customers, Federal regulators, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, to Congress and to the world the commitment that our members have to maintaining the long tradition of integrity established at the C.B.O.T. over 141 years,'' said Karsten Mahlmann, the board's chairman.

title: The Starr Street Murder
description: In Brooklyn, Maria Hernandez got up very early on Tuesday morning, about 4 o'clock. She had a long way to travel to work - all the way to New Jersey.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''PLAY TO WIN,'' free performances by Theaterworks/U.S.A., about the baseball player Jackie Robinson, for children 8 and older, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. today and 11 A.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets, distributed on a first-come first-served basis, at 9 A.M. on the day of each performance. Last performances. Information: 677-5959. PROFESSOR PUTTER AND HIS GADGETORIUM, a program of magic, science and music, by Mike Makman, 3 P.M. Sunday, at Channel Video, 472 Columbus Avenue, at 83d Street. Admission is free. Information: 765-2068. TWILIGHT LAWN CONCERT, with music by the Banjo Rascals, a family group, and sing-along songs, 5:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road, off Central Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y. Visitors may have picnics on the lawn with their own chairs and blankets. If it rains, the concert is to be held indoors. The concert is free, with $1 admission to the center for children and $2 for adults to support its education programs. Information and directions: (914) 723-3470. ''KNIGHTWARE LIMITED,'' a workshop for children ages 5 to 11 and their families, to learn how to design and make helmets and shields, 1 to 4 P.M. tomorrow, at Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, south of the Great Lawn at 79th Street, in Central Park. Reservations and information: 772-0210. ''IT'S PERFECTLY TRUE,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen, as told by Trudy Betcher, 11 A.M. tomorrow, at the Andersen Statue in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 72d Street. Free. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828.

title: Old Republic Intl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: An $875 million issue of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The issue surpasses in size the record $786 million Remic deal that was priced in June by the agency.

title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die
description: Crack is rapidly accelerating the destruction of families in poor urban neighborhoods where mothers are becoming increasingly addicted and children are selling the drug in greater numbers than ever before.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the search in Ethiopia for a plane carrying Representative Mickey Leland carried an erroneous passenger-list entry in some copies, based on information from the State Department.

title: Rangers Sign Olympian
description: The Rangers announced yesterday they had signed Corey Millen, who led the 1988 United States Olympic team in scoring with 6 goals and 5 assists. Millen, 25 years old, who also played on the Olympic team in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, in 1984, was the Rangers' third-round selection in the 1984 draft.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Guide Decision
description: TV Guide concluded its search for a publisher yesterday by not hiring anyone. The position has been vacant since April, when Valerie B. Salembier left the Rupert Murdoch-owned magazine to become the president of The New York Post. Joseph W. Cece, TV Guides's president, said that he and Mary Berner, the magazine's advertising director, will take on the duties customarily assumed by a magazine publisher.

title: Sallie Mae Offers Fixed-Rate Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $70 million of fixed-rate notes due 2000, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Link to Mafia Is Investigated In Union Deaths
description: Investigators said today that they were exploring a possible mob link to the shooting deaths of a father and son in the headquarters here of a local of the longshoremen's union.

title: Paine Webber Opens an Inquiry Into Its Role in H.U.D. Bond Sales
description: Paine Webber Inc. said today that it had opened an internal investigation of its management of Department of Housing and Urban Development bond transactions that involved a former chief aide to Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Paine Webber was selected to assist in the sales of hundreds of millions of dollars in Government bonds last year, in Mr. Pierce's last year as Housing Secretary, despite a staff recommendation that another company do the job, according to department documents disclosed Thursday. Lance Wilson, a former aide to Mr. Pierce and a first vice president at Paine Webber, helped prepare Paine Webber's proposal for the $1.3 million contract.

title: Imperial Metals Corp.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included gains of $93,000 for the latest year and $304,000 for the year- earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The End of a Long Run
description: After 8 years, 6 months and 15 days, John O. Marsh Jr. plans to give it all up on Friday, leaving behind the record as the longest serving Secretary of the Army in the history of the republic.

title: Terrorism's New Found Enemy
description: LEAD: In a news conference this week, President Bush let drop a tantalizing hint that certain countries that had remained silent or ambivalent about the American hostages were beginning to have second thoughts. So offended were they by the murder of Lieut. Col. William Higgins, the President said, that they were now willing to help resolve the hostage situation.

title: Polish Prelate Assails Protests By Jews at Auschwitz Convent
description: Expressing bitterness over recent Jewish protests, the Cardinal who oversees the diocese that includes the site of the Auschwitz death camp announced today that he was abandoning plans to construct a center for Christian-Jewish dialogue near the site.

title: MAI Allows Offer For Prime to End
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. said it had allowed its $525 million bid for Prime Computer Corporation's minicomputer business to expire, leaving a friendly bid from J. H. Whitney & Company as the only offer on the table. MAI, based in Tustin, Calif., first began its bid in November 1988. Whitney has offered cash and stock worth about $1.22 billion, or $18.50 a share, for the company.

title: Dow Rises To 2,712.63, Up 26.55
description: The Dow Jones industrial average traded above its record high yesterday afternoon before settling back to close at 2,712.63. That was its second-highest close, following the 2,722.42 it reached on Aug. 25, 1987.

title: Anti-Abortion Group Restricted at Clinics
description: A Federal judge late Wednesday ordered Operation Rescue members to stop blocking women from entering Binghamton abortion clinics, which officials said today were being used as a ''training ground'' for new demonstrators.

title: Datascope reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings are reported on a fully diluted basis, because it reflects the dilutive effect of the assumed conversion of convertible subordinated debentures in 1988 and first quarter 1989.

title: Ouster of Life Editor Focuses Attention on Editorial Chief
