description: The dismissal of Patricia Ryan on Monday as the managing editor of Life magazine by Jason McManus, the editor in chief of Time Warner Inc., has placed Mr. McManus at the center of yet another controversy in his short tenure as the company's top editorial figure.

title: Saturday And Sunday In the Park With Music
description: For some of the best music in New York City this weekend, the place is the great outdoors - and with free admission, the price is just right, too.

title: Strain of War at Kabul's Gates Pervades Red Cross Hospital
description: In a war in which Western countries have backed the rebels, the Red Cross hospital for war victims here is an island of impartiality.

title: 2 Days in Office, Japan's Leader Defuses a Potential Sex Scandal
description: Two days after taking office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu became momentarily entangled today in a report that he had fathered a child outside marriage. But he later appeared to free himself of the rumors and avoid a sex scandal like the one that dogged his predecessor.

title: Mack Lobell Favored
description: Mack Lobell, the harness horse of the year in 1987 and 1988, is the overwhelming favorite in a field of eight in the $350,000 International Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Letter: On Medicaid; The Poor Need Access to Prenatal Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Simms Went From Top To Bottom
description: A sublime pleasure of spectator sports is counting other people's money. Nowhere does it matter so much to the watchers what the doers are earning than in sports.

title: Entergy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bishops Map Strategy in Abortion Battle
description: Calling the recent Supreme Court decision on abortion ''the beginning of a new debate,'' a committee of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops has drawn up a broad strategy for abortion opponents.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am ready to help free the Western hostages provided Western countries help release Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners in Israel.'' - Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah of the Party of God. [ 1:3. ]

title: Syms Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Automated Planes Raising Concerns
description: Airlines are starting to fly a new generation of highly automated jets, raising concerns among safety researchers that pilots will rely too much on the technology and will lose or never learn the sharp skills and reflexes needed in emergencies.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included realized investment gains of $25,012,000 for the quarter and $79,825,000 for the 6 months. c-Included realized investment gains of $24,939,000 and $46,161,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago 6-month included a gain of $3.7 million from a reversion of assets from a terminated pension plan, and a gain of $3.3 million related to bond interest arrearages received when Texaco Inc. emerged from bankruptcy.

title: Larger Farms, but Fewer of Them
description: The United States has slightly fewer farms this year than in 1988, but they are slightly larger than they were last year. The Agriculture Department estimated the number of farms at 2.17 million. That is a drop of 1.1 percent from 1988, when the department said there were 2.19 million farms. The decline continues a slide that began in 1982, when there were 2.4 million farms.

title: British Columbia Telephone Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said some year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Job Cuts Are Set By Smith Corona
description: The Smith Corona Corporation said it would lay off 10 percent of its work force, or 450 workers, at its Cortland, N.Y. and Singapore plants by Aug. 28 in order to adjust portable-typewriter inventories and respond to softening domestic retail demand. The company provided no further details. Smith Corona is controlled by Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate.

title: Great Swamp Formed From Glacial Waters
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. Reaffirms Right To Fight Against Israel
description: The main P.L.O. group, Al Fatah, issued a new statement today reaffirming the principle of armed struggle against Israel but dropping some of the anti-Israel invective criticized by Israel and the United States.

title: Vincent P. Mallon, Missionary, 79
description: The Rev. Vincent P. Mallon, a Maryknoll missionary and teacher, died from complications of kidney disease Aug. 4 at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Maryknoll, N.Y.

title: Pillsbury Unit Sale
description: The Pillsbury Company said it had agreed to sell its Van de Kamp Frozen Seafoods division to the Whitman Corporation for about $140 million in cash. The transaction is expected to be completed by mid-September, it said in a statement. Van de Kamp has annual sales of more than $100 million. The statement gave no further details. Pillsbury was acquired by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. earlier this year. Pillsbury had sales of $6.2 billion in fiscal 1988.

title: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Russ Berrie & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a one-time before tax restructuring charge of $9.5 million, which reduced net income by $6.2 million, or 41 cents a share. c-Net income

title: American Government Income Portfolio reports earnings for As of July 31
description: Comparable figures are not available since the fund began operation in September 1988. Assets represent net assets.

title: Seaman Furniture Seeking Debt Relief From Creditors
description: The Seaman Furniture Company, the second-largest furniture retailer in the United States, said yesterday that it is having difficulty making interest and principal payments and is seeking a restructuring of its debt because of higher interest rates and particularly weak store sales in the New York City area.

title: Merrill's Real Estate Units To Be Sold to Prudential
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and Fine Homes International Limited Partnership announced yesterday that they have agreed to sell Merrill Lynch Realty, Merrill Lynch Relocation Management, and some related businesses to the Prudential Insurance Company of America for more than $300 million.

title: Auschwitz, the Poles and the Jews; Shared Losses
description: To the Editor:

title: Power to 30 Houses Doubles And All Appliances Burn Out
description: Videocassette recorders started smoking, light bulbs exploded and ceiling fans raced as if they were going into orbit when a power company mistakenly doubled the normal amount of electricity in 30 houses.

title: New Policies Critically Ill Collect On Life Insurance
description: A new kind of life insurance, which pays part of the death benefits while the policy holder is still alive, is attracting attention these days.

title: Suburbia Is Subdividing The Single-Family House
description: At a time when the New York metropolitan region faces a severe shortage of affordable housing, tens of thousands of suburban homeowners are carving apartments out of extra rooms in their houses.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Angio-Medical Corp., a maker of intravascular and related products, said it might have to curtail the scope of its operations because of expected losses. The company also said that its license agreement with Helene Curtis Industries Inc., Chicago, a holding company, was being terminated because Helene Curtis did not introduce Angio-Medical's hair products as required.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe Trounces Witsken: Second-seeded John McEnroe lost only 12 points on his serve to defeat Todd Witsken, 6-1, 6-0, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the United States hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. The eighth-seeded Witsken, from Carmel, Ind., lasted just 69 minutes. Earlier, fourth-seeded Aaron Krickstein beat Pete Sampras, 7-5, 6-3. No. 5 Jay Berger beat No. 3 Tim Mayotte, 7-6, 7-5.(AP) Stoltenberg Advances: Jason Stoltenberg, who upset Michael Chang on Wednesday, defeated Tim Donovan, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Swiss Army Knife Open. In other matches, Chris Bailey defeated Mike Brown 6-3, 3-6, 6-3; Brad Gilbert beat Ramesh Krishnan of India, 5-7,6-3,6-2, and Jim Courier defeated Jim Grabb, 7-5, 6-2.(AP) Navratilova and Sabatini Move Up: Martina Navratilova, Gabriela Sabatini, Zina Garrison and Pam Shriver scored straight-set victories yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Virgina Slims of Los Angeles tournament in Manhattan Beach, Calif. Top-seeded Navratilova beat seventh-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Australia, 7-5, 6-4. Second-seeded Sabatini overpowered eighth-seeded Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4. Garrison, seeded third, whipped 12th-seeded Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-4, 6-2, and Shriver, seeded fourth, defeated No. 5 Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) HORSE RACING 42-1 Shot Wins Ballerina Stakes: Proper Evidence, a Canadian invader dismissed at odds of 42-1, stormed down the stretch at Saratoga Race Track yesterday to win the $121,800 Ballerina Stakes. Aptostar, coupled with Topicount as an entry and sent off as the 3-5 favorite, was up for second by a neck over Lake Valley. Proper Evidence, a 4-year-old daughter of Stiff Sentence and the Prince Blessed mare Catch a Blessing, paid $87.20 for $2 to win and ran the seven furlongs under Chris Antley in 1:23.31. Proper Evidence is owned by Harry Gampel and trained by John Dalton. GOLF Cain Ahead in Seniors Event: John Paul Cain, a 53-year-old rookie on the PGA Senior Tour, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the Rancho Murieta Senior Gold Rush tournament in Rancho Murieta, Calif. Ken Still was second at 68 after the first day of the 54-hole event. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about negotiations between New York City hospitals and their workers misidentified a Federal agency that refused to block a strike next week. It is the Office of the General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, not the National Labor Relations Council.

title: No 'Public Giveaway' in 42d St. Redevelopment
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hampshire Utility Is Near Bankruptcy Pact
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday told the Federal judge overseeing its bankruptcy that it was nearing an agreement that would allow it to satisfy the demands of its creditors and equity holders.

title: Bloch Toys With Interviewer on Spy Rumors
description: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department diplomat under investigation for espionage, has broken his silence to give tantalizing hints, but no denials, about what American officials say they suspect was a long career of spying.

title: The Basics of School Reform
description: The economic and social health of New York in the year 2000 and beyond depends on the ability of the school system to educate today's youngsters. But while the mayoral candidates are talking about education, they remain preoccupied with how quickly or slowly the search for a new schools chancellor ought to proceed and, more generally, with how to make the 20-year-old decentralized system work better.

title: Coping: With Camera Batteries
description: As photography has become increasingly involved with electronic automation, batteries have assumed a crucial role in the lives of picture takers. Most of today's cameras will not operate without battery power, and all consume much more current than earlier snapshot models.

title: G.M. Raises Car Prices 3.4% for 1990
description: The General Motors Corporation today priced its 1990 cars 3.4 percent higher than its 1989 models, with nine-tenths of 1 percent of the increase covering the cost of new passive restraints required by the Government.

title: Objections Raised to Private Iran-Contra Hearing
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has objected to a court decision to hold a private hearing on Government secrets that might be disclosed in the trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency official.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Grand Jury in Queens Rejects Bid To Indict Officer Again in Assault
description: A Queens grand jury yesterday refused to reindict a New York City police officer whose first indictment on an assault charge was dismissed by a judge because of improper conduct by prosecutors.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Aug. 4 about Mollie Orshansky, an economist who developed the index known as the poverty line, misidentified a Federal agency. It is the Wage Stabilization Board, not the Weight Stabilization Board.

title: Afghan Rebels, Divided but Resolute, Fight On From Peak Above Jalalabad
description: From a rebel bunker on Samarkhel Mountain, the ancient city of Jalalabad is visible eight miles away, a sprawl of mud-walled homes shimmering beneath a canopy of flame trees that stretch to the horizon. But a line of the Government's Soviet-built tanks sits in the plateau between the city and the rebels, their barrels trained on the enemy's redoubts.

title: The Wall-to-Wall Emergency at City Hospitals
description: The emergency room was painfully crowded.

title: Newsy Hankie Panky
description: Television showed you the news and you didn't like it.

title: Frisbee Tossing Isn't an Elitist Invention
description: To the Editor:

title: Actuary Resigns Amid Tax Inquiry
description: New York City's highest-paid official, its chief actuary, resigned yesterday rather than testify under oath and give city investigators permission to examine his official income-tax records amid an inquiry that found he failed to file returns on time, city officials said.

title: Trimac Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax gain of $419,000 for the quarter and a special gain for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after a charge of $6,905,000 for the quarter and a charge for the 6 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Mother Nature, the Pest Killer
description: Concern for the environment is making steady inroads on the use of chemicals in the battle against garden pests and plant diseases.

title: West Point-Pepperell reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $693,000 and a charge of $28,530,000 on the loss from debt refinance. c-After a loss of $1,156,000 from discontinued operations and included a gain of $16,961,000 on sale of a 50 percent owned foreign affiliate. d-Net income and after income of $13,750,000 from discontinued operations, a gain of $3,112,000 from the sale of discontinued operations, and a charge of $7,865,000 from an accounting change.

title: Chicago Schools Chief in Center of Storm, Again
description: This much is certain: Manford Byrd will be a finalist in the selection of Chicago's next superintendent of schools.

title: 2 Women Sexually Assaulted in Central Park
description: Two women were attacked yesterday as they jogged around the Central Park Reservoir, and a homeless man was arrested nearby and charged with sexual abuse, the police said.

title: Trade Surplus Of Japan Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus declined 16.5 percent in July, to $5.99 billion, the Government announced today.

title: Scholarly Review of Eisenhower Began in 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Capital Investment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results included a charge of $24.2 million made to increase loss reserves and to provide for changes resulting from the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 Fierce fighting broke out in Lebanon, with some 20,000 shells and rockets striking towns and villages across a third of the nation's area on Thursday and Friday. Page 1

title: Krueger Is Moved
description: Phil Krueger, the Indy-car driver who was severely injured Sunday when his car struck a wall in the CART Marlboro 500 race in Brooklyn, Mich., was transported yesterday by a private plane from St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., to Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where he was admitted to the neuro-critical care unit and pronounced in good condition. Krueger, 38, has been unconscious since the accident, in which he suffered broken ribs, a broken left arm and head injuries. (AP)

title: A Phone Card in Braille
description: U S Sprint Communications Company has introduced a Braille version of its calling card, making long-distance credit service easier for people who are blind or partly blind.

title: Second Stealth Test Planned
description: The Stealth bomber is scheduled to make its second test flight in California in the next few days, the Air Force announced today. The first test flight, on July 17, was a success, but the House voted the next week to order a reduction of the 132-plane program. The Senate approved most of the request for the bomber but also passed a resolution saying it was not committed to the fleet now planned. A compromise will be worked on when Congress returns from its summer recess next month.

title: Patents; An Oral Contraceptive Without Estrogen
description: Michael Cohen, scientific director of Applied Medical Research Ltd., a start-up company in Washington, patented a proposed oral contraceptive this week that the company believes could replace current birth control pills.

title: Many Jets Are Missing As Play Begins Today
description: The exhibition season starts for the Jets on Saturday, a day when fine-tuning under game conditions is supposed to begin. And, everyone agrees, the Jets need all the time they can use.

title: Krelitz Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $36,000 and $182,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $67,000 for the quarter and $66,000 for the year.

title: Senate in Poland Condemns Invasion of Prague in 1968
description: The Solidarity-dominated Polish Senate today condemned the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and asserted that the armed forces of Poland took part against the will of the nation.

title: A New Mood, at Least, on Civil Rights
description: Given their differences over the failed nomination of William Lucas and the Supreme Court's recent civil rights decisions, President Bush's speech to the National Urban League could have been a tense, awkward occasion. Instead, the atmosphere was one of mutual ease and respect.

title: Geo International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: F.D.A. Revokes Approvals At 2 Generic Drug Makers
description: The Food and Drug Administration has revoked its approval of generic drugs made by two pharmaceutical companies, and an internal memorandum from the F.D.A. Commissioner, Frank E. Young, implied that further disciplinary moves in the generic drug industry may soon be needed.

title: Martha Graham Troupe To Open With Premiere
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will perform at City Center from Oct. 3 to 22. The season will include ''American Document,'' a new work based on Miss Graham's 1938 dance of the same name, and five revivals: ''Cortege of Eagles,'' ''Dark Meadow,'' ''Plain of Prayer,'' ''Frescoes'' and ''Steps in the Street'' from ''Chronicle.''

title: Finevest Foods reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday.

title: Abbott Labs President Resigns
description: Jack W. Schuler, the president and chief operating officer of Abbott Laboratories, resigned yesterday over ''differences in philosophy'' with Robert A. Schoellhorn, Abbott's chairman and chief executive, a spokesman for the $5 billion diversified health-care concern said.

title: PANAMA URGES U.N. TO SEND OBSERVERS
description: The Panamanian regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega asked the Security Council today to send observers to monitor what it called its growing military confrontation with the United States.

title: Louisiana General Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $562,000 and $1,280,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a provision for discontinuance of operations of $11,372,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $632,000 for the quarter and $1,636,000 for the 9 months. Results for the prior periods have been restated.

title: MUCH OF LEBANON POUNDED BY SHELLS
description: In the worst round of fighting since a new wave of violence in Lebanon's civil war began five months ago, some 20,000 shells and rockets struck towns and villages across a third of the nation's area in fierce exchanges from Thursday afternoon until daybreak today.

title: William J. Prater Is Dead at 70; In Prison for Yablonski Killings
description: William J. Prater, a former official of the United Mine Workers serving life sentences for his role in the slayings of a union dissident and his family, died in his cell today, apparently of natural causes, officials said. He was 70 years old.

title: Koch Borrows $200,000 to Keep Ads on TV
description: Having difficulty raising funds under the terms of New York City's new campaign-finance law, Mayor Edward I. Koch has had to borrow $200,000 from five businessmen to keep his television commercials on the air.

title: The Pentagon's Farewell to NASA
description: The space shuttle Columbia is now in orbit on a military mission, said to be the deployment of a KH-12 reconnaissance satellite. But it's one of the last military missions the shuttle will fly.

title: Aide in Housing Deal Tells Of Link to Pierce's Ex-Firm
description: A former Federal housing official promoted the use of Samuel R. Pierce Jr.'s old law firm in bond sales for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, a former Paine Webber Inc. executive involved in the sales said today.

title: Lucas Named to Justice Job; Search On to Fill Rights Post
description: William C. Lucas, whose nomination to be the nation's top civil rights enforcer was rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee, was named today as Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's ''personal representative'' to law-enforcement groups, civil rights groups and state and local governments.

title: About New York; Nervous Rookie Ready for Debut In Peale's Pulpit
description: Billy Hester was 4 years old when his father died in their hometown of Savannah, Ga. He ached and ached but knew boys aren't supposed to show it. So Billy would sit alone staring at his father's sports trophies. And when he went to the barber, he presented a dogeared photo he otherwise kept hidden. ''Please cut it like his,'' Billy whispered.

title: Pay Cut Is Accepted By Detroit Symphony
description: To keep the orchestra alive, musicians for the Detroit Symphony voted, 82 to 8, on Wednesday to take a pay cut of nearly 10 percent in a four-year contract.

title: Review/Music; Preview of Commission By Out-of-Doors Series
description: Lincoln Center has presented a good deal of contemporary music in its free Out-of-Doors series, but until this year it had not commissioned new works for it. For its first foray in that direction, it has found a co-commissioner (the American Music/Theater Group) and an underwriter (the Mary Flagler Cary Charitable Trust) and has turned to David Borden, a composer who directs the electronic music program at Cornell University.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Thursday about ''The Rivals'' on the Arts & Entertainment channel gave an incorrect figure, provided by the show's producers, for the time allotted to commercials. The commercials in the 2 1/2-hour program amounted to 28 minutes, not 45.

title: Schofield Injures Hand
description: Just before the California Angels began an important three-game series against the Oakland Ahtletics last night at Anaheim Stadium, the Angels announced that Dick Schofield, their starting shortstop, suffered a fractured bone in his left hand when he was hit by a pitch on Thursday night while batting against Scott Bankhead of Seattle. Schofield is not expected to return for about three weeks. Kent Anderson, a rookie, is expected to replace him, just as he did for 17 games in April while Schofield was on the disabled list with a strained muscle in the right side of his chest.(AP)

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about ''Oh! Calcutta!'' misstated the publication date of Kathleen Tynan's biography of her husband, ''The Life of Kenneth Tynan.'' It was 1987, not 1967.

title: Steeplechase Leader Is Dead
description: Census, an 11-year-old gelding who had earned more money than any other steeplechaser, suffered a fatal heart attack today during a morning workout at Saratoga Race Track.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Prices in Bond Market Rise and Then Plunge
description: Treasury securities prices tumbled and yields soared yesterday as the credit markets were whipsawed by a new batch of economic reports and by a Federal Reserve move that many traders interpreted as an effort to prop up interest rates.

title: Producer Prices Fell 0.4% in July
description: In another sign of slowing inflation, the Labor Department announced yesterday that producer prices fell four-tenths of a percent in July.

title: 4 Dolphins Captured Despite Florida Protest
description: Employees of a marine park have captured four dolphins off Florida's Gulf Coast, despite earlier efforts by environmentalists to stop them.

title: Review/Theater; Growing Menace, Without Words
description: Learning is what ''No + (No More)'' is all about, but who - including the audience - learns what, is anybody's guess. Taking his inspiration from ''The Students Want to Teach,'' a short story about role reversal by the Austrian writer Peter Handke, the Chilean playwright Raul Osorio has created a wordless play that repeatedly tempts a viewer into imagining he knows what is going on and then makes him question his own judgment.

title: INSIDE
description: Solidarity Recalls 1968 The Solidarity-controlled Polish Senate condemned the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia. Page 5. High Technology in the Air New, highly automated jets are raising fears that pilots will rely on the technology and not on skills. Page 6. Eastern Strike Weakening Pilots have been returning to work in sharply higher numbers, setting back organized labor. Page 31. At the Front in Afghanistan The Afghan rebels' Jalalabad offensive has fizzled, exposing tactical and political shortcomings. Page 3. Rose Hearing Delayed A judge ordered that baseball's hearing on gambling charges against Pete Rose be put off again. Page 43.

title: Auschwitz, the Poles and the Jews; Le Juif Inconnu
description: To the Editor:

title: Zentec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Party of God Mentor Offers Help In Promoting a Trade of Captives
description: The spiritual leader of pro-Iranian Shiite Muslims believed to be holding hostages in Lebanon said today that he would help free the captives if Western countries used their influence to obtain the release of Arab prisoners in Israel.

title: Israelis Lengthen Detention For Arabs Held in Uprising
description: The Defense Ministry issued an order today extending the period that Palestinians can be held in detention without formal charges or a trial from six months to a year.

title: Solidarity Begins Strikes to Push for Polish Change
description: The Solidarity union today began the first of a series of one-hour work stoppages planned throughout Poland to press the Communist Government to step up political and economic change.

title: Connaught Biosciences reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $3.5 million for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: LSI Lighting Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its results included the operations of SGI Integrated Graphic Systems from the effective date of its acquisition, April 1.

title: Anchor Glass
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation urged shareholders not to take any action on a $280 million tender offer by a subsidiary of Vitro Sociedad Anonima, until a special board committee announces its findings by Aug. 23. The offer is for up to 13.9 million Anchor shares at $20 each. Vitro Sociedad, a glass maker based in Monterrey, Mexico, is making its bid through a subsidiary, the THR Corporation. The board established the committee of outside directors to study the unsolicited conditional tender. The committee will meet with Anchor's financial and legal advisers, Morgan Stanley & Company and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the company said.

title: Patents; A New Material For Metal Sculptures
description: Raymond E. Wiech, an expert in thermoplastic materials, who died in May, was granted a patent this week for a metal sculpturing material for artists.

title: Four Seasons Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Joining Suit to Block Sale of Shoreham
description: The Federal Energy Department called on a New York State court today to overturn a settlement in which the Long Island Lighting Company agreed to sell its Shoreham nuclear-power plant to the state.

title: Suit Challenges Arrest Tactics
description: A Federal judge today allowed the police to continue using painful methods in the arrest of anti-abortion protesters.

title: KEY RATES
Teacher Who Defaced Mao Portrait Gets Life
description: A court sentenced a primary-school teacher to life in prison today for splattering paint on the huge portrait of Mao that hangs above Tiananmen Gate in central Beijing. The teacher's accomplices were given terms of 16 and 20 years.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Corn on the Cob
description: Now is the season for fresh local sweet corn. Yellow, white and a mix of yellow and white are available. Buy corn that has been picked the same day because the longer an ear of corn is off the stalk, the less sweet it will be; the sugar starts turning to starch as soon as it is picked. Very fresh corn will have a dewy moistness about the husk and silk, and the stem will not be brown. Refrigerating corn until cooking will help keep it in good condition. Sugar or milk (or both) can be added to the water if the corn is boiled, but they will have little effect if the corn is boiled as briefly as it should be. Here are some tips on cooking fresh corn. Method Preparation Timing Boiling Remove husks and silk Place in boiling water to cover; when water returns to boil, remove from heat; let stand 5 to 20 minutes. Grilling Turn back husks, remove silk, Grill over or in hot rewrap corn in husks and soak coals 20 to 30 minutes. in cold water 30 minutes. Roasting Remove husks and silk, Roast at 350 degrees for butter ears, wrap in foil. 20 minutes.

title: Nord Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kremlin Aide Calls Disputed Estonian Law Illegal
description: The Kremlin signaled its sympathy with the protesting Russian minority in Estonia today as the Soviet Justice Ministry said a new voting residency law was unconstitutional and would violate human-rights standards.

title: American Government Income Fund reports earnings for As of July 31
description: Assets represented net assets.

title: Voyager 2 Finds Rings at Neptune (But Not All the Way Around It)
description: In its first major discovery at Neptune, the Voyager 2 spacecraft yesterday detected two partial rings of debris around the planet, providing the first direct evidence that Neptune has rings and that they are strikingly different from those of any other planet.

title: Williams Is Lost to Bengals For at Least Two Weeks
description: Reggie Williams, a Cincinnati linebacker since 1976, has undergone emergency arthroscopic surgery on his right knee and will be lost to the Bengals for at least two weeks.

title: Swindall Loses a Bid to Void Conviction or Get New Trial
description: A Federal district judge has denied a motion by former Representative Pat Swindall to overturn his conviction on nine counts of lying to a Federal grand jury or to get a new trial.

title: Francois Colos, Illustrator, 60
description: Francois Colos, an illustrator whose work appeared in many publications, died of encephalitis Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 in Officer's Shooting Face Attempted Murder Counts
description: Three men were charged yesterday in the shooting of an undercover narcotics officer Thursday in a vacant Bronx apartment during a drug deal that went bad.

title: American Group Finds Obstacles To Free and Fair Vote in Namibia
description: A group of prominent Americans concluding a weeklong visit to Namibia said today that they had found ''major obstacles'' to the free and fair elections scheduled in November as part of the territory's transition to self-rule.

title: Farmers Win Insurance Suit
description: Nearly 9,000 farmers in 10 states will receive $4.93 million from a New York insurance agency that the farmers accused of overselling drought insurance before and during last year's drought.

title: AMR Revises Takeover Guards
description: Directors of the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, strengthened the company's anti-takeover provisions even though the company said it was unaware of any imminent takeover attempt. Under the amended plan, if a person or group buys 10 percent or more of AMR's outstanding common shares, stockholders would be entitled to buy additional shares at half price. The original plan, adopted in 1986, called for the option to go in effect after a 20 percent acquisition.

title: Koch Is Lone Voice in Debate For Tax Rise to Add Police
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch was the lone candidate prepared to support higher city taxes at a debate among the four Democratic contenders yesterday. He defended his plan to use the revenues to add 4,000 police officers.

title: Voit Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The second quarter loss included a $100,000 writedown of its inventory of latex gloves and a provision of $125,000 to settle a lawsuit.

title: Panmunjom Journal; For North Korea Still, the Americans Started It
description: The northern half of this small village, full of soldiers and photographs of war, is devoted to a single proposition: that the Americans started a war against the Korean people and are still dividing the country into North and South.

title: Jewish Groups Angered By Rappers' New Start
description: Jewish groups responded angrily yesterday to the announcement by the rap group Public Enemy that it was rehiring Richard (Professor Griff) Griffin.

title: Giants Prepare to Run Through the Motions
description: Do not expect anything fancy Saturday night when the Giants open their preseason campaign by playing the New England Patriots in Sullivan Stadium.

title: Family of 5 Dies in Blaze
description: A fire started in a garage and spread through a wood-frame house early today, killing a family of five as neighbors frantically pounded on doors and honked car horns to alert them, the authorities said. The victims were Bill Fullerton, 51 years old, his wife, Marylyn, 42, and their children, Lori, 14, Justin, 10, and Curtis, 3, said the Lawrence County Sheriff's Department. The cause of the fire was not determined, an investigator said.

title: Auschwitz, the Poles and the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Southland Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $56,047,000 from a debt exchange.

title: Interlake Restructures To Fight a Takeover
description: The Interlake Corporation, an industrial manufacturer fighting a takeover threat, today announced a restructuring under which it intends to pay a special dividend, sell operations and repurchase stock. The restructuring is expected to cost the company at least $550 million.

title: Wrapping Up: 4 Contenders' Statements
description: Following are the closing statements from the debate yesterday among candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York City: David N. Dinkins

title: 5 Accused of Working on Missile for I.R.A.
description: Five people accused of working to develop anti-helicopter missiles for the Irish Republican Army have been indicted on Federal charges of conspiring to violate arms export regulations.

title: Patents; A Machine to Relieve Air Congestion in Mines
description: Aerovironment Inc., a small company in Monrovia, Calif., has patented a machine that tries to relieve air congestion with electrically charged mist.

title: Dow Retreats From Record Territory
description: After advancing to a record high in the first hour of trading, stocks bounced downward following a precipitous decline in bond prices. Heavy futures-related selling also helped puncture several attempts to rebound.

title: Atkinson (Guy F.) Co. of Caliornia (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Edward Gordon Retires As Ravinia Festival Head
description: Edward Gordon has announced his retirement after 22 years as executive director of the Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Ill. The 59-year-old Mr. Gordon, a concert pianist, said he was leaving to pursue personal interests, including the piano, writing and traveling. He will serve on the search committee for a successor, he said, and will remain in his post until a ''qualified successor can be engaged.''

title: Auschwitz, the Poles and the Jews; A Terrible Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Reid Is Leader in P.G.A. Championship
description: Ponce de Leon was looking in the wrong place. The Fountain of Youth is at Kemper Lakes Golf Course, just northwest of Chicago, where the 71st P.G.A. Championship is in progress.

title: Hollywood's Truly Golden Oldies
description: The movie that claimed 24th place at the box office early this month is 27 years old. The movie in 35th place is celebrating its 50th anniversary.

title: No Help For Viola In Debut At Shea
description: The Mets produced no runs and a grand total of three singles in Frank Viola's Shea Stadium debut last night, and the result was a 3-0 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Reed Moves From Bench to Front Office
description: After a season and a half as head coach of the hapless Nets, Willis Reed abruptly relinquished the position at the request of the team's owners yesterday and accepted a long-term contract as a club vice president.

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the rise in revenue and operating profit reflect major acquisitions in October 1988 and April 1989. Depreciation and amortization charges also rose because of those acquisitions, and totaled $32,203,000 in the 1989 quarter, compared to $25,203,000 a year-earlier.

title: Dollar Surges Despite Effort By Central Banks to Stall It
description: The dollar surged yesterday, prompting a concerted round of central bank intervention that was unable to stall the rally.

title: Savings Withdrawals Rise
description: Net deposit withdrawals at the nation's savings and loan institutions more than doubled in June, to $4.6 billion, the Government said today.

title: When Politics Became Show Biz
description: LEAD: History is replete with proofs, from Cato the Elder to Kennedy the Younger, that if you scratch a statesman you find an actor, but it is becoming harder and harder, in our time, to tell government from show business.

title: Xoma In Pact To Acquire Ingene
description: The Xoma Corporation, a biotechnology company in Berkeley, Calif., agreed to acquire International Genetic Engineering Inc., more commonly known as Ingene. Each of Ingene's 7.9 million shares would be exchanged for 0.278 shares of Xoma stock, giving the transaction a value of about $40 million. Xoma specializes in monoclonal antibody technology and has applied for permission to market two drugs: one for treatment of septic shock received from hospital infections and the other for graft-versus-host disease, which strikes recipients of bone marrow transplants. The company is also working on treatments for rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Your Money; Is Small Investor Late for the Rally?
description: Many small investors are wondering, now that the broad measures of the stock market are at their all-time highs and the Dow Jones industrial average is flirting with its August 1987 peak, if they, too, could realize profits in the stock market.

title: The Candidates Grandstand on Crime
description: LEAD: The nature of candidates is that, whatever issue they're pushing, the immediate dream, goal and ultimate ecstasy is to get elected. If abortion is the issue, and the candidate knows that a majority of the voters favor it, the candidate will scuttle even his religion to scoop up the ''choice'' vote.

title: Trans World Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said 1989 results do not include approximately $87 million in unrealized gains in TWA's investment portfolio as of June 30. Revenue represented operating revenue.

title: Yankees' 18 Hits Overwhelm Twins
description: The Yankees came into tonight's game looking for a strong pitching performance from Walt Terrell and some consistent offense. They got both and whipped the Minnesota Twins, 11-3, at the Metrodome.

title: MAI Basic Expects a Loss
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. said today that it expects to report a ''significant'' third-quarter loss because of write-offs associated with its abandoned tender offer for Prime Computer Inc. In addition, the company said it was restructuring and would cut 10 percent of its work force in the next three months.

title: Central Park Victim Learns Fundamentals of a New Life
description: There is not much time for sadness at Gaylord Hospital. Each of the 121 men and women being treated at this medical rehabilitation center has survived a traumatic event: a stroke, a car accident, a fall, a shooting or, in the case of one patient, the Central Park jogger, rape and a beating. Now they must somehow rebuild their lives.

title: Organic Bean Crop Is Accidentally Sprayed
description: A farmer who spent years developing organically grown beans saw his effort wasted when his field was accidentally sprayed with pesticides last month.

title: Rewards Offered in Campaign to Stem Murders in the Capital
description: With the murder rate in the capital one of the highest in the nation, the police here announced a program today to give cash rewards of up to $10,000 to people who provide tips that lead to the arrest of murder and assault suspects.

title: Inmate Freed in Arson Is Arrested
description: A man who was freed by a judge in November after spending nearly 10 years in prison in a 1978 supermarket fire that killed six firefighters in Brooklyn, was arrested Thursday on charges of rape, robbery and drug possession, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Stellick Quits Post With Maple Leafs
description: Gord Stellick, who at 32 became the youngest general manager in National Hockey League history when he was appointed in April 1988, announced his resignation from the Toronto Maple Leafs yesterday. At a news conference in Toronto, Stellick cited interference from Harold Ballard, the 86-year-old owner.

title: Bridge; World Junior Championships Prove A Double Success For the British Hosts
description: The second World Junior Championships ended yesterday in Nottingham, England, and proved a double success for the host country. The first world bridge championship ever to be played in Britain was excellently organized, and the British team captured the title, defeating Argentina in the 96-deal final by 90 imps.

title: Books of The Times; Hypothesis Meets History in Nicaragua
description: The Circus Master's Mission By Joel Brinkley 403 pages. Random House. $18.95.

title: Doing Battle Amid the Fog of Statistics
description: At one point in yesterday's mayoral debate, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin took an aerosol spray can from his lectern and shot gray mist into the air.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Dominican Day Parade, the Avenue of the Americas between 44th and 59th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 12:30 P.M. to about 3:30 P.M.

title: Patents; Reducing Wood Stove Pollutants
description: It may not be true that trees cause pollution, as former President Reagan once asserted. But pollution certainly results when logs are burned in traditional wood stoves, which belch an average of 22 grams - three-quarters of an ounce - of particulate matter an hour.

title: 'Killing Fields' Draws Crowds in Cambodia
description: Thousands of Cambodians have thronged to see ''The Killing Fields,'' the film that brought to Western screens the horror of life under the Khmer Rouge, since its premiere in Phnom Penh a week ago, an American relief worker reports.

title: Pilot Accord At Northwest
description: Northwest Airlines has reached tentative agreement on a long-term contract covering its 5,000 pilots, it was announced today.

title: RETAIL SALES SHOW UNEXPECTED SURGE FOR LAST 3 MONTHS
description: In a report that shows the economy has been considerably stronger than had been thought, the Commerce Department said today that retail sales surged by nine-tenths of 1 percent in July and were also buoyant in the late spring and early summer.

title: Mental Exams Ordered
description: Thomas P. Gioiosa, a former friend of Pete Rose who is awaiting trial on Federal cocaine-distribution and tax charges, was ordered yesterday to undergo two mental examinations next week.

title: Ye Varmints! Tom's Horse Is Gone Agin!
description: If Tom Mix were still here, he'd know how to handle the low-down varmints who stole his favorite horse.

title: Pilot Strike At Eastern Faltering
description: The strike at Eastern Airlines, hailed by organized labor as an important test of union power, is weakening significantly after five months.

title: Dump Owners Arrested After Huge Fire
description: The owners of Hub Recycling Inc. were arrested today on charges stemming from the trash fire under Interstate 78 that buckled part of the elevated highway on Monday.

title: Dinkins TV Ad Criticizes Koch On High-Rises
description: David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign yesterday fired an unexpected shot in its opening round of television commericials, with a 30-second spot that accuses Mayor Edward I. Koch of favoring high-rise luxury apartment buildings at the expense of affordable housing.

title: Benefits of Aspirin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Beethoven On Original Instruments
description: Having completed a weekend of Beethoven lectures and performances to close the final Summerfare Festival in Purchase, N.Y., Roger Norrington brought his London Classical Players to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening for an all-Beethoven concert that was part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: A Walk Around The World
description: LEAD: For a man who spent four years walking around the world, Steven M. Newman has an odd confession. ''I don't really like walking that much. I just knew if you wanted some stories, go for a walk.''

title: Homeless Respond to Aid at Terminal
description: A five-day experiment to help the homeless in Grand Central Terminal has resulted in 169 people agreeing either to go to shelters or into drug or alcohol treatment programs, transit and social service officials said yesterday.

title: Madison Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Boom on Wall St. for Printers
description: While the stock market reaches new highs, the crash of 1987 is still taking its toll on the financial printing business.

title: Mira Trailovic, Director, 65
description: Mira Trailovic, a Yugoslav theater director and founder of the Belgrade International Experimental Theater Festival, which invited many American theater groups to Europe, died of cancer on Monday in Belgrade. She was 65 years old and lived in Belgrade.

title: Sandra L. Read Marries in Aspen
description: Sandra Lynch Read, a daughter of Signa L. Read of Peru, Vt., and Alexander D. Read of Dorset, Vt., was married yesterday in Aspen, Colo., to John Paul Foley Jr., the son of Lieut. Col. Foley, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Foley of Durham, N.C. Judge Brooke A. Peterson of the Municipal Court in Aspen performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

title: DEFAULTS ON LOANS TO STUDENTS DROP
description: The Education Department has reported that defaults on student loans have declined.

title: Staff of Lost Lawmaker Calls U.S. Search Slow
description: Representative Mickey Leland's staff accused the State and Defense Departments today of not doing enough to find the Congressman, whose plane was reported missing in Ethiopia on Monday, and urged President Bush to give it his personal attention.

title: ISS International Service Sysems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results reflect the sucessful acquisition of the ADT maintenance division on Dec. 29, 1988.

title: New Job for Robinson
description: In his 49 years at Grambling University, Eddie Robinson has served as coach in basketball, baseball and football and as athletic director. Now he will take on another assignment at the school in Louisiana, vice president for athletic relations. Joseph Johnson, the university president, said Robinson had requested the move. Fred Hobdy, the assistant athletic director for the last five years, will take over Robinson's post as athletic director in mid-August.(AP)

title: Salant Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All periods included results of Manhattan Industries, which the company acquired in April 1988 and Denton Mills Inc., acquired in February 1989. Year-ago quarter and 6 months' results were restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 96. The latest quarter included a previously announced one-time charge of $6.5 million for the closure of its Perry Ellis portfolio for women business and the disposal of its Perry Ellis collection for women business.

title: Nissan Workers in U.S. Test Union and Industry
description: Workers at the Nissan automobile plant here were called in for overtime work on a recent Saturday to meet brisk orders for Sentra cars and Pathfinder trucks. At the midday break that Saturday, about 1,000 workers who had been called in for the day shift were greeted by the sight of their supervisors grilling a hamburger lunch for everyone.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 12, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Prospect Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $52,355,000 for the quarter and $61,131,000 for the 6 months. The company said results for the latest second quarter and 6 months show sharp differencies from a year ago principally because of the inclusion of Illinois Central Transportation Co. and discontinued operations at Murray Bakery Products Inc. Illinois Central was acquired in March, and contributed significant revenue and earnings in the reporting periods.

title: Orioles, Red Sox Win One Apiece
description: Roger Clemens, limited to 11 pitches in his previous start, threw 123 this time, allowing three hits in seven innings tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 6-4, in the first game of a doubleheader. Baltimore won the second game, 4-1, behind a three-hitter by Pete Harnisch, his first complete game ever.

title: Big British Company Says Kohlberg, Kravis Has Stake
description: BTR P.L.C., a London-based conglomerate whose products range from concrete to Slazenger tennis rackets, said today that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company had bought BTR shares and might purchase up to 15 percent of the company.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 'Deers of Our Lives'

title: POSTINGS: Low-Income Apartments; 30 Lucky Families
description: Late this month the first of 30 low-income families will move into a renovated apartment house at 1427 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. The building is a joint project of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the nonprofit Flatbush Development Corporation and the private Affordable Dwelling Units Inc. Funds for the $2 million project also stemmed from a third private group, the Community Preservation Corporation, a consortium of New York banks and investment groups involved in improving housing.

title: Garcia Marquez: Words Into Film
description: Three years ago, as he was working on the novel ''The General in His Labyrinth,'' Gabriel Garcia Marquez found himself with extra time on his hands. Every morning he would sit down at his word processor to write, and at night he pored through letters, books and documents about Simon Bolivar, the Great Liberator of Latin America who is the central figure of the book. But during many an afternoon, the Nobel laureate ended up doing duty as a screenwriter - simultaneously crafting scripts for not one but six films.

title: City Youths Meet Nature at Fresh Air Camp
description: Its name is Camp Pioneer, but it might be more aptly called Nature 101.

title: One Record Left For Summer Rally
description: Stock prices surged but the best-known indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, could not quite make a daily close above its all-time high. Other indexes, like the Standard & Poor's 500, reached record levels in late July. At times last week, the Dow did trade above the peak of 2,722.42 it set on Aug. 25, 1987. And it did manage one close above 2,700, when it finished Thursday at 2,712.63. But on Friday the Dow ended at 2,683.99, up 30.54 for the week. The reasons given for the rally included heavy corporate-takeover activity, a revival of computerized program trading and an environment of declining inflation and lower interest rates in an economy that is growing slowly but is, nonetheless, growing. The Dow transportation index had a record one-day surge on Monday, when a bid for United Airlines was announced. The index jumped 94.06 points that day, to 1,344.06. Bond yields had a tumultuous week. On three days, the Treasury auctioned new securities, causing enough nervousness to push the yield on the 30-year bond up to 8.14 percent.

title: FICTION
description: AUGUST HEAT. By Beth Lordan. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Beth Lordan paints the small-town atmosphere of her first novel in sumptuous prose; she refers, for example, to the ''wide generosity of the day's breeze,'' the ''cicada-laden silence.'' Out of this setting a potentially compelling story struggles to rise. A young woman named Rachel, recently widowed, returns home with her big-city ways, catching the eyes of the local men and the ire of their wives. She has come back to care for her much-troubled brother, Jacob, who has suffered an emotional breakdown after the death of their mother; he cleans the house obsessively and walks, often cursing along the way, ''like a pack of dogs was worrying at him from all sides.'' But rich prose alone does not a novel make, and Ms. Lordan's characters are weighted down not only by small-town intrigues but also by her writing, whose artfulness becomes at times self-conscious, even confusing. The novel could withstand these excesses if Jacob evolved into a real character. A figure who can be placed in that literary tradition that attributes to derangement special lyrical powers, he takes to the roads at nightfall, his lunacy charged with allure, his ''sweet singing voice . . . mysterious and beckoning.'' But by the end of ''August Heat,'' the mythic hold Jacob's madness has on the townspeople feels like Ms. Lordan's writing itself: elaborate, but not wholly genuine.

title: FIRST, LAST AND ALWAYS A DANCER
description: A CHORUS LINE And the Musicals of Michael Bennett. By Ken Mandelbaum. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. WHAT THEY DID FOR LOVE The Untold Story Behind the Making of ''A Chorus Line.'' By Denny Martin Flinn. Photographs by Martha Swope. Illustrated. 213 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: ITALY: Where Connections Unlock the Till
description: Censorship, in the form of a government official telling artists what they may or may not do, is not an issue in Italy. But it hardly means that politics and the arts are not intertwined. This is a country where party connections determine who becomes the doorkeeper at a government ministry, and the same principle applies to public funds for the arts.

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: The pitching staff is no better than last year's. They traded away a good prospect in Don Schulze for the so far disappointing Walt Terrell and did not pursue the recently released Bob Knepper, who they could've claimed for nothing.

title: Glasgow
description: To the Editor: I was thrilled to see ''What's Doing in Glasgow'' (Travel, June 25). As a Glaswegian, I and my birthplace have been the butt of some cruel jokes, especially from citizens of that other famous Scottish city.

title: FOCUS: Freshwater Dunes; Battlelines Form on Michigan's New Rules
description: A NEW state law designed to restrict construction on 60,000 acres of sand dunes on Michigan's lakefront shores is expected to result in court challenges to the power of state regulators over private landowners' development rights.

title: Democrats, Too, Benefited From H.U.D. Programs
description: As well-connected Republicans obtained millions of dollars in grants and subsidies from the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the 1980's, Democrats were using their Congressional power and political ties to help friends and constituents benefit from many of the same H.U.D. programs, documents from the department and Congress indicate.

title: Distant Fan Sees Anti-Rose Bias
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SOVIET UNION: Full-Frontal Glasnost Can Be Breathtaking
description: The Soviet artist is so beholden to state subsidy, from quality of shelter to critical imprimatur, that the government's interference in the arts is a given. The real issue for many artists is how to minimize personal cravenness in accepting state help.

title: Power Lines And Cancer Risks
description: Readers of the recent article on residents' opposition to Jersey Central Power and Light's transmission project in Monmouth County could easily be led to false conclusions on cancer risk (''Neighbors Oppose Plan for Power Lines Along Railway'').

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Illinois; Student Leaders Embroiled in Fight Over Elections
description: The jobs don't pay anything, but the student political leaders at the University of Illinois are still fighting over them months after the elections were held in April.

title: Unfair Portrait
description: To the Editor:

title: RADICAL TRANSFORMATIONS
description: One would think their experiences might have humbled them, but David Horowitz and Peter Collier appear to be as certain as they once were that they possess the truth. So, though they proudly boast of their capacity for critical reflection, this seems to extend only to their past politics: now they have got it right and need not concern themselves with asking hard questions.

title: Barbara Heckelman Marries
description: Barbara J. Heckelman the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Jack Heckelman of Ambler, Pa., and Dominick Maffei a son of Mrs. Michael Maffei of Chula Vista, Calif., and the late Mr. Maffei, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of Germantown in Philadelphia by the Rev. Dr. Kenydl Gibbons. Mrs. Maffei is the director of social services at the Beverly Nursing Home in Escondido, Calif. Mr. Maffei is the production manager of Walker Wood Products in Valley Center, Calif.

title: Mother Hurls Three Children To Their Deaths Off a Bridge
description: A former mental patient apparently threw her three children 100 feet off a bridge to their deaths and then jumped into the Tombigbee River herself, the police said today.

title: There's Far to Go In Cleaning Up The H.U.D. Mess
description: AT his confirmation hearing in January 1981, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. promised the Senate Banking Committee that as Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, he would improve management to ''deliver a higher quality service with less money.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?

title: A Struggle To Shrink the Work Force
description: The dramatic declines in the railroad industry's operating expenses have resulted in large part from reductions in its work force. Although they are hauling more freight, the railways have decreased their payrolls since 1977 by more than half, to 230,000 workers last year.

title: Outdoors; Duck Limits Likely to Stay
description: Breeding populations of ducks in prime nesting areas of this country and Canada were at near-record lows this spring, and the Fish and Wildlife Service's proposed regulations for the forthcoming 1989-90 waterfowl seasons are much the same as last year's regulations, which included fewer days in which to hunt and lower bag limits.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Fantasies of Reform

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LYNDON JOHNSON'S WAR: The Road to Stalemate in Vietnam. By Larry Berman. (Norton, $18.95.) Although America's military involvement in Vietnam would not end until 1973, by 1968 many of the principal architects of United States policy had become convinced of the futility of the war effort. In ''Lyndon Johnson's War,'' Larry Berman, a professor of political science at the University of California, Davis, provides a window on the world as seen by those who shaped Vietnam policy in the critical years from 1965 to 1968.

title: Relativism and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Lindsay Scott Weds Richard Maider
description: The Presbyterian Church of Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Lindsay Nevin Scott and Richard Crowell Maider. The Rev. C. Vincent Wilson performed the ceremony.

title: Foster Care in State Is Facing a 'Crisis'
description: NEW JERSEY'S foster-care system is on the verge of running short of foster parents, say foster-care advocates and the head of the agency that oversees foster care in the state.

title: No Headline
description: CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER By Tom Clancy. 656 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: H.U.D. -- No Big Surprise
description: LEAD: I've been watching the House hearings on the Department of Housing and Urban Development. They are being televised on C-Span and they are riveting.

title: Savings and Loans Are Bailed Out, but Will They Float?
description: DESPITE predictions of the thrift industry's demise, some of which pre-date the catastrophic financial and political losses the savings and loans have suffered in the past few years, the business seems likely to endure.

title: Defects Reported in Babies of Cocaine Users
description: Women who use cocaine early in their pregnancies are nearly five times as likely as women who do not to have children with urinary tract birth defects, Federal health officials say.

title: Reader's Digest Grants Go to 32 Composers
description: Thirty-two American composers have received commissions this year from the Meet the Composer/Reader's Digest Commissioning Program, which has given $429,500 to 19 consortia comprising 52 symphony and chamber orchestras, opera and theater companies, choruses, soloists, public radio stations and other musical ensembles. The groups are required to perform the commissioned works at least six times within three years of the awards, which range from $10,000 to $80,000.

title: 'Are You O.K.?' Plan Is Good but Too Little
description: The new ''Are You O.K.? Program'' recently introduced in Ossining [ ''Computerized Calls to Check on Elderly,'' July 23 ] is a wonderful idea and has obviously proved itself in Iowa and elsewhere. If the total price to monitor 1,500 elderly residents is less than $7,000, it is a wonderful bargain as well.

title: Marion S. Briggs To Marry Dec. 9
description: A Dec. 9 wedding is planned by Marion Shepley Briggs and Harold James Berry 3d, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Briggs Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Manset, Me., have announced. Mr. Berry is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Thomas Berry of Darien, Conn.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Do Colleges Spend Too Much on Athletics?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Fond Memories Of Guidry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Japanese May Purchase Land For a Country Club in Somers
description: LEAD: A 239-acre parcel in the center of this community is for sale by the Lincoln Hall School and could mean an infusion of cash for the 126-year-old, nonprofit institution and the 200 delinquent boys it serves.

title: Now, Space on Rail Cars Goes to the Highest Bidder
description: Imagine the problems American Airlines would have if it knew it had 13,000 passengers traveling on its planes tomorrow, but didn't know where any of them were going. That is essentially the situation that most railroads are in, said Todd Burger, a senior transportation consultant at Arthur D. Little. Most customers call just a few days ahead for rail cars.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Quebec
description: Quebec City's French heritage and 400-year history create a Continental air, never more apparent than during the brief coveted summer.

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: Dallas Green appears to be totally unable to provide any off-the-field inspiration while his on-the-field managerial tactics are appalling. He has consistently failed to relieve starting pitchers until games have gotten well out of hand. MICHAEL HOWARD Woodbury, L.I.

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: Last year Martin had one starter and no bullpen and had the team 15 games above .500. Yes, he had Clark, Henderson and Winfield but don't forget Balboni and Hall have 70 r.b.i. Barfield is doing just great, Kelly is getting on base, Sax counts for a lot, and the team is better off without Henderson. Dallas Green stinks. JOHN A. GIRONDA New York

title: RADICAL TRANSFORMATIONS
description: I do not consider myself a member of a Second Thoughts ''group.'' And if I have ''distanced'' myself from the activities of Peter Collier and David Horowitz, it was not because I preferred them ''to organize the grass roots'' rather than to remain ''an intellectual current.'' I simply found that I did not belong to that current as their actions and statements seemed to define it. ROBERT S. LEIKEN Cambridge, Mass.

title: THE CONSCIENCE OF THE FLIMFLAM MAN
description: THE HANGMAN'S CHILDREN By Donald Hays. 425 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/ The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Military Milestone
description: With an Army colonel for a father, 20-year-old Kristen M. Baker calls herself an ''Army brat.'' This month she received West Point's highest honor when she became first captain of the Corps of Cadets, the first woman selected for the position. West Point has accepted women since 1976, but Col. James N. Hawthorne, a spokesman for the academy, conceded that some older alumni are still getting used to the idea. ''To have a woman as first captain is almost more than some can bear,'' he said.

title: THE WEST: Great America - Santa Clara, California
description: The noise is a giveaway that something special is around the next bend, that particular kind of shrieking at the intersection of fun and fear.

title: Showdown For 2 Rivals
description: It is being billed as the race that never happened, and when it happens today at the 100th Amateur Athletic Association championships at Alexander Stadium in Birmingham, England, there will be more than nostalgia at stake.

title: Using Bacteria, Mamaroneck Begins to Triumph Over Mosquitos
description: LEAD: A MOSQUITO-CONTROL program in which bacteria are used to kill mosquito larvae has been judged a success in the village of Mamaroneck in two trial seasons. The project, believed to be the only one of its kind in the county, uses bacteria that are toxic only to the larvae of mosquitoes and a handful of fly species.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: INTERIOR. By Justin Cartwright. (Random House, $17.95.) The title of Justin Cartwright's fourth novel (which condenses the book's epigraph, a quotation from Joseph Conrad's ''Lord Jim''), when coupled with a discursive plot about an aging son searching for news of his father in the wilds of Africa, would seem to promise a journey into a latter-day heart of darkness.

title: Today's Hits Yearn for Old Times
description: ''Tradition, honor, discipline, excellence:'' the motto of the fictional Welton Academy, carried on banners in the ceremonial opening scene of ''Dead Poets Society,'' reverberates softly through Peter Weir's misty-eyed prep school drama. Periodically during a movie that reverently re-creates the cloistered atmosphere of a Vermont boarding school in the late 1950's, the camera draws back to admire the austere academy's snow-swept lawns, evoking a purer, more well-ordered era.

title: Some New Twists in Life Insurance
description: Recent tax and demographic trends are changing the role of life insurance. Traditionally, the insurance has provided family protection: in case of an untimely death, the proceeds help pay the rent, buy groceries, take care of college bills. The need for such insurance was reduced or eliminated once the insured's children were grown.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Dominican Day Parade, the Avenue of the Americas between 44th and 59th Streets will be closed today from 12:30 P.M. to about 3:30 P.M.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: The most ordinary things often set off the most extraordinary research efforts. Witness machine cancels.

title: Darien's Summer Spoof
description: DESPITE what might have possessed the Darien Dinner Theater's producer, Jane Bergere, to put on a summer-stock season of three musicals, so far it is not working.

title: Lisa A. Schneider Becomes the Wife Of A. B. Field 4th
description: Lisa Ann Schneider and Augustus Bradhurst Field 4th were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Bradford Duff Clark, a cousin of the bride.

title: PRAGUE WAS NEVER LIKE THIS
description: A SEASON IN THE WEST By Piers Paul Read. 238 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: U.S. Helicopters Join Search for Leland
description: Four American helicopters joined the search today for Representative Mickey Leland and 15 others missing since their flight vanished in western Ethiopia on Monday. But the day ended with no sighting of the plane or its passengers.

title: Review/Film;  'Distant Voices, Still Lives,' a Reminiscence
description: ''Distant Voices, Still Lives,'' was shown as part of the 1988 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on September 29, 1988. The film opens today at Cinema Third Avenue, at 60th Street.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CLEARWATER FESTIVAL

title: Miss Romanoff Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Michelle Robyn Romanoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Romanoff of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Alan Scott Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Cohen of Rochester, took place last evening at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Peter Weintraub officiated.

title: Babes in Makeup Land
description: Isabelle French is preparing to go out. She dabs her lips with lip gloss and checks her well-lacquered fingernails. She loads her purse with perfume, blusher and lipstick, and skips out the door. Isabelle French is 6 years old.

title: 'People Are Living So Much Longer'
description: FOR 43 years, Louise Bernstein, a social worker, has focused her energies on the elderly, working to create and improve services for older people in Fairfield County. Now, as a senior citizen herself, the 66-year-old Ms. Bernstein has created a program in which able-bodied elderly people help those who are not.

title: Susan Glarum Becomes Bride In New Jersey
description: Susan Classens Glarum and Leo John Kelser were married yesterday. The Rev. Patrick O'Neill, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Teaching the Lessons of Montessori
description: RICHARD W. BANGERTER of Orem, Utah, has been here for three weeks learning management strategy. He is a student at the Center for Montessori School Management, which is based this summer, along with the Center for Montessori Teacher Education, at the College of New Rochelle. When Mr. Bangerter returns home he will begin a new career.

title: Laurie Harrison Marries
description: Laurie Harrison, the daughter of Judith Lachter Wardwell of Miller Place, L.I., and Melvin Eugene Harrison of Miami Beach, was married last evening to Richard Jay Smith, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Helene Smith of Brooklyn. Rabbi Gerald Weider performed the ceremony at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. The bride, who will keep her name, was formerly an assistant librarian at the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library at New York University. The bridegroom is an optician in Manhasset, L.I.

title: MEXICO: The Nourishing Hand Can Also Undermine
description: When Mexico City's Museum of Modern Art held a show of young artists in 1988, it incurred the wrath of conservative Mexicans by including a montage that superimposed the face and bared breasts of Marilyn Monroe over an image of the Virgin of Guadalupe. Other works showed a pair of boots trampling the Mexican flag and the actor-singer Pedro Infante in Christ's place at the Last Supper - all of which made some religious and civic groups so irate that they stormed the museum and forced the exhibit's suspension.

title: GOVERNMENTS, CENSORSHIP AND THE ARTS
description: The relationships between governments and the arts around the world can be strikingly different from the American pattern, but some of the same underlying issues - appropriateness and scope of government financing, the way grants are given, censorship - are familiar. And, according to reports from New York Times correspondents and bureaus around the world, these relationships are changing - in some places, such as the Soviet Union, dramatically so.

title: Anti-Pollution Campaigns Declare War on Old Cars
description: EIGHT Northeastern states said last week that they would join California in a plan to clean up the nation's dirtiest air. The strategy is not only aimed at tightening emission standards for cars rolling off the assembly lines. In an attempt to put the squeeze on the country's two largest pollution sources -the Los Angeles basin and the Northeastern megalopolis - officials on both coasts are turning their attention to a problem that had gone largely unregulated: old cars.

title: CONSUMER RATES
POSTINGS: Bursting the Seams; Chinatown Condos
description: A growing demand for housing in New York City's Chinatown is pushing the neighborhood north and west. The Mandarin Plaza condominium apartment project is the latest example of this trend fostered by the increase in the number of Asians. Developers of the 25-story building at 378 Broadway, which also faces White Street and Cortland Alley, said they have already sold half of the 164 units, mainly to Asians who have either moved to the United States or plan to do so soon.

title: Hundreds Mourn Brooklyn Drug Fighter
description: Hundreds of mourners and residents of the drug-torn Bushwick section of Brooklyn came out yesterday to bury a slain woman who had fought against drugs in her community. They marched and chanted in a two-mile funeral procession from the church to the cemetery.

title:
ART;
Landscape Themes Clarified
description: LEAD: ''PAINTING HORIZONS,'' the new offering at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, combines three major artists in a way that helps to clarify contemporary approaches to landscape themes.

title: Rating: 1 Silver Star
description: The usual fare at Texas Stadium includes hot dogs and soft drinks, but no alcohol. Now the new Dallas Cowboys owner, Jerry Jones, and the stadium's management are seeking to skirt the alcohol ban by persuading the city of Irving that the stadium could qualify as a ''fine restaurant.''

title: Charles S. Lyon, Retired Law Professor, 72
description: Charles S. Lyon, professor emeritus of New York University Law School and a former United States assistant attorney general, died Friday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan, where he lived. He had suffered complications from a series of strokes. He was 72 years old.

title:
ART;
Dutch Marine Works in Mystic
description: LEAD: THE Mystic Maritime Gallery is like an attic, but a very single-minded one, for it is completely devoted to the sea.

title: Training Hospital Chaplains
description: LEAD: ''MOST people relish a visit from someone who is not there to punch, probe or poke them,'' the Rev. Marvin Carney said. ''I give them a sense of freedom. They can throw me out if they don't want to talk. Fortunately, I haven't been thrown out yet.''

title: A Scandal Raises Serious Questions at the F.D.A.
description: When faced with the most serious crisis so far as Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Frank E. Young found solace in the Bible. Turning to the Book of Romans, Dr. Young produced a quote that summed up his thoughts: ''All have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God.''

title: INSIDE
description: Leland Search Continues

title: TODDLERS' TALES
description: TWO TO FOUR FROM 9 TO 5 The Adventures of a Daycare Provider. By Joan Roemer as told to Barbara Austin. 294 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: Prosecutors Want Rehearing Of Nofziger Case Dismissal
description: The prosecutors in the case against Lyn Nofziger have asked a Federal appeals court to reconsider its decision overturning the former White House aide's conviction for illegal lobbying.

title: Precision Paying Off For Reid
description: Mike Reid did not major in physics or even math at Brigham Young University. But he knows better than any other golfer in the world that theorem of plane geometry: The shortest distance between two points is a straight line. In his case, right down the middle of the fairway.

title: MEANS, NOT GOALS, SHIFT IN BASIC TRAINING
description: A Greyhound bus rumbles along beneath the Kentucky moon, through the gates of a mysterious new world, leaving a young man to step off into the darkness, alone.
