title: Sally Yeates Weds Stuart Cartwright
description: Sally Elizabeth Yeates, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur N. Yeates of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Stuart Andrew Cartwright, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alton S. Cartwright of Hague, N.Y., and John's Island, Fla. The Rev. Richard Broderick performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Hague.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The people that got burned are the banks and the smaller guys, who were a little more desperate and shipped clothes with their fingers crossed.'' Howard Bloom, president of Chetta B, a dress maker, on the bankruptcy filings by Bonwit and B. Altman.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Plant crops for fall harvest: seedlings of broccoli, cabbage and kale plus seed for rows of spinach, mache, peas, beets and leaf lettuce. Transplant azaleas, rhododendrons, abelias, hollies and conifers. Pinch back overgrown petunias for rebloom in early fall. Remove faded flowers of geraniums to prevent disease. Dry herbs and rose petals for potpourri. Meadows

title: A Woman Sent To Do A Boy's Job
description: As if the medium of opera were not bizarre enough, many composers further confused matters by introducing the element of sexual ambiguity. Their reasons were not always immediately clear. Why, for instance, should Mozart decide to put trousers on a mezzo-soprano and have her sashay about as the love-crazy adolescent Cherubino? Vocally, the role would not exceed the capabilities of a good male alto or, with some adjustments, a light tenor. There was another factor, of course: Since 18th-century audiences seldom got a clear look at a feminine ankle under normal circumstances, pants parts catered to certain furtive needs.

title: The Road to City Hall: A New York Voter's Guide
description: WITH the Sept. 12 New York City primary fast approaching, the candidates must distinguish themselves in unusual municipal circumstances. The 1989 race is the first with campaign spending limits, and is made more significant because the next mayor will have to deal with a redesign of city government and a new schools chancellor.

title: RADICAL TRANSFROMATIONS
description: Sharon Churcher writes that once a young Communist, I am ''now a historian intent on exposing leftist bias in the college curriculum.'' As a lifelong opponent of McCarthyism of both the right and the left, I believe firmly in academic freedom, faculty autonomy and the right of scholars of differing persuasions to have complete freedom in determining course curriculum. I have never sought in any way to ''expose'' what she calls ''leftist bias in the college curriculum.'' RONALD RADOSH New York, N.Y.

title: THE MIDWEST: Worlds of Fun/Oceans of Fun - Kansas City, Missouri
description: No one could say we were not forewarned. There were highway signs aplenty warning, ''The Timber Wolf is out to get you.'' It did.

title: Here She Is, 'Miss Little New York City'
description: The judge's request was not what you would expect to hear at a beauty pageant. ''Let me see your teeth,'' he said to the seven lovely contestants seated before him. They dutifully offered their smiles. He checked their incisors. When you are six years old and a reigning beauty queen, you cannot wait for Christmas for those two front teeth. Fortunately, Stephanie Elizabeth Feehan has hers.

title: Pope's Remarks on Jews Raise Controversy
description: With Roman Catholic-Jewish relations already strained by the continued presence of a Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, a Jewish organization has complained that recent comments by Pope John Paul II suggested that God's covenant with the Jewish people had been superseded.

title: State Reverses Decision on Removing Rail Ties
description: METRO-NORTH Commuter Railroad officials may not have to dig up thousands of old railroad ties treated with cancer-causing chemicals that are buried along the Hudson River, state officials said last week.

title: There Is a Loser and It's the Traveler
description: Let's assume that you wish to fly from New York to Cleveland and back, without staying away over a Saturday night. When you call either of the two dominant carriers in the market - Continental or USAir - you will be informed that the cheapest fare is an appallingly high 54 cents per mile for the 850-mile journey. And, on these two carriers, it doesn't matter whether you buy your ticket in advance or not. If you don't like it, and cannot buy a ticket in advance on Pan Am or TWA's limited service - at $318 return, still no bargain - Amtrak, car or bus are the only alternatives.

title: Relativism and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Seaport Rowing Team is Set for a Challenge from Australia
description: EVERY weekday morning, a group of hardy rowers plows through the waters of the Mystic River in sturdy whaleboats, the kind in which 19th-century whalemen pursued their quarry. The group is training for Sept. 17, when Americans and Australians will meet in a race quite different from the America's Cup - the 1989 International Whaleboat Race.

title: Sand Art, on Deadline
description: The young man arrived on the Massachusetts beach early carrying a portable radio, a shovel and an odd assortment of tools. There were a bricklayer's trowel, a palette knife, spatulas, spoons and a spray bottle.

title: Late Entrant Wins International Trot
description: A Lobell captured the 31st International Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway, but it was not Mack Lobell, the premier trotter in the world the last two years.

title: Hamden Is First Town to Ban Plastic Foam
description: LEAD: HAMDEN last week became the first town in Connecticut to outlaw the use of plastic foam packaging by fast-food restaurants, grocery stores and other retail food establishments. The ban will start on March 1.

title: From Income Lost to Real Estate Gained, The Savings and Loan Crisis Leaves Scars
description: In signing the savings and loan rescue bill on Wednesday, President Bush recognized that the nation has lost more than $100 billion in wealth, perhaps forever.

title: Cubes of Fruit, Slices of Life
description: THE season of fresh fruits is also the time of fine hot weather and of outdoor entertaining. Put them all together - they spell picnic. The other weekend I made a fruit salad to take to a potluck picnic. Watermelon, cantaloupe, honeydew, peaches, plums, grapes, cherries, nectarines, apricots and blueberries were piled in displays at the supermarket. Strawberries were already finished, but there were the perennial banana and the pear - yellows and greens. I bought some of everything.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
In Today's World, It's Shape Up or Ship Out
description: LEAD: THE American medical community has concluded that walking (which you do from age 2 until senility) is less traumatic and, in general, is healthier than jogging (which you do until you impress everyone at work or you rip your Achilles tendon. Or until you run a marathon, which accomplishes both at once).

title: Golf Iron Ban Prompts Suit
description: The Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, maker of the Ping Eye-2 golf clubs, is suing the United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrew's in Scotland to prevent them from banning the use of the company's square-grooved irons in their competitions next year.

title: A Drive to Compete With Trucks
description: Back in the 1970's, America's railroads were in sad shape. Plagued by rising costs and burdensome regulations, nine of the major freight carriers - controlling about a fifth of the nation's tracks - were bankrupt. Many of the remaining 56 railroads were barely profitable.

title: Behind a Corporate Courtship
description: It was a merger that billed itself as a model of compatibility: Time-Warner, the company forged by combining Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. Synergy - that buzzword of mergers and acquisitions - would create a global media giant for the 21st century. A merger with any other suitor, Paramount Communications Inc., for example, was deemed unthinkable.

title: AIDS-Test Rules In 29 Countries
description: THE State Department issued on July 25 a list of 29 countries requiring, or planning to require, evidence of tests for HIV, the AIDS virus, from some or all visitors. The list is based on inquiries sent to United States embassies around the world. Michael M. Mahoney, the director of the State Department's Citizens Emergency Center, said that the list was prepared because many travelers had asked the department for information about countries' requirements; it will be brought up to date on a regular basis, he said.

title: Would-Be Jetport Fails to Lure Major Airline
description: Despite the efforts of Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, Stewart International Airport will remain without the services of American Airlines for the foreseeable future.

title: Saba
description: To the Editor: Further to Randall Rothenberg's article about Saba in the Netherlands Antilles (Travel, July 9), your readers might like to know that Saba has established a tourist information office in the New York area. The address is the Saba and St. Eustatius Tourist Information Office, c/o Medhurst & Associates, 271 Main Street, Northport, N.Y. 11768; the telephone number is 516-261-7474 or 800-344-4606. JOAN MEDHURST Northport, L.I.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the mutual funds table last Sunday carried incomplete figures. The table failed to take account of trading on Friday, Aug. 4. That day's figures were, however, published in Business Day on Aug. 5. Readers wishing copies of the Saturday table may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Saratoga
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Saratoga Springs'' (Travel, July 9) omitted mention of the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame and the National Museum of Dance, two collections that have proved popular with many visitors.

title: Class of '72 May Have Just the Know-How for the 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEST: Knott's Berry Farm - Buena Park, California
description: When Cordelia Knott served her first chicken dinner to paying guests at Knott's Berry Farm in 1934, she and her husband, Walter, could not have realized that 55 years later guests would follow the dinner by being zipped from 0 to 55 miles an hour in Montezooma's Revenge or by piloting their own cockpit in the new XK-1 airplane ride. But the Knotts, one of the pioneers of the modern-day theme amusement parks, have had to keep up with the Disneys. So today what started out as a restaurant and then a fabricated ghost town for tourists 30 miles south of Los Angeles is now 150 acres of rides, restaurants and entertainment. It is not the biggest park and the rides are not the scariest, but Knott's is a pleasantly landscaped park with its own character and one that is especially good for small children with its Camp Snoopy section of games and shows.

title: Israelis Capture Palestinian On Raid Near North Border
description: A Palestinian guerrilla who was trying to cross into northern Israel was shot and captured today in a clash with Israeli troops and allied militiamen about a mile and a half north of the border, the Israeli Army said. No group has claimed responsibility for the raid.

title: A Kentucky Town's Polished Crafts
description: WHILE the artisanship of the settlers who made their homes in the nearby Cumberland Mountains had its origins in utilitarianism and thrift, in 1893, William G. Frost, the third president of tiny Berea College foresaw a broader potential in encouraging practical training among the students. Nearly a century later, college workshops, along with an array of independent studios and galleries, have turned the small central Kentucky town into a center for traditional American crafts.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Balancing Growth in Marlboro Township
description: LEAD: THE residential building boom that for much of this decade drew people into the suburbs of western Monmouth County has waned, giving communities a chance to assess the impact of development and prepare for the next round of growth.

title:
TV VIEW;
Designing A Video Mask Of Many Faces
description: LEAD: To help attain his overriding goal in life - getting the American public to take him seriously - Vice President J. Danforth Quayle has been reading biographies of Great Men like Winston Churchill and Douglas MacArthur. There is no indication he has been reading the works of Marshall McLuhan, the late media guru.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Arizona State; Restoring a Cross: Separating School And Church
description: The cross that has sat atop Arizona State University's Danforth Chapel since its opening 42 years ago has sparked a church-and-state controversy involving the administration, the faculty, the American Civil Liberties Union and various religious groups.

title: Now, Seniors Boxing
description: Are you ready for George Foreman vs. Gerry Cooney? That battle of the past-their-prime-time punchers could happen, according to Ron Weathers, an adviser to Foreman, the 40-year-old former heavyweight champion.

title: New League Plots to Take Mound
description: Early next April, teams in eight cities, some that have never had major league baseball, will begin a five-month schedule of 154 games. In the sixth month, next September, they will engage in three rounds of playoffs that will produce the first champion of the first major league outside the baseball establishment in 75 years.

title: New York Returning Wampum Belts to Onondagas
description: New York State has agreed to return 12 wampum belts, some of which have been in the State Museum since 1898, to the Onondaga Nation of Indians.

title: Susan Perkoff Plans Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morton Perkoff of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Perkoff, to William J. Bass, a son of Perkins Bass of Peterborough, N.H., and the late Katherine Jackson Bass. A September wedding is planned.

title: Sorting Out Lotus's New 1-2-3's
description: After months of delays, the Lotus Development Corporation has finally released not one, not two, but three new versions of its Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet, the financial modeling program that may be the most widely used computer application program in the business world. Customers who have been waiting for a new 1-2-3 may be confused by the sudden plethora of choices. In the end, the choice will probably depend on which computer the user has.

title: A Memorial Underscores Division Among Firefighters
description: A BITTER dispute has erupted over a memorial to honor Westchester's 47 fallen firefighters. To resolve the matter, it may be necessary to build two monuments, separately honoring the county's professional and volunteer firemen who have died while fighting fires.

title: Scores Killed in Ethnic Violence in Northeast India
description: Scores of people have been killed in a wave of ethnic fighting sweeping parts of the northeastern state of Assam, and the fighting has sent thousands of people fleeing into refugee camps and into a neighboring state, The Press Trust of India news agency reported tonight.

title: Sheik Offers Hope and Warning on Hostages
description: The country's most influential Shiite Muslim cleric said today that the hostage issue would ''move in the direction of a rational solution.'' But he warned that it could take a long time and that any American military move would backfire.

title: Page A. Chisolm, Student, Is Wed To R. A. Hughes
description: Page Anderton Chisolm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Chisolm of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Andrew Hughes, a son of Robert Hughes and Kathleen Hughes, both of Haverfordwest, Wales. The Rev. James N. Lodwick performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. Mrs. Hughes, who will begin her third year at the New York University School of Law next month, graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and Princeton University. The bride was a member of the Junior Assembly in 1981. Her father recently retired as a managing director of the First Boston Corporation in New York; her mother, Frances Wyatt Chisolm, is a photographer.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Kent, Conn. $505,000 Howland Road 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, new colonial; library, artist's studio, 4,500 square feet of space, 7.6 acres; taxes not yet available. Sherman, Conn. $178,000 Brinsmade Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; hardwood floors, 2 fireplaces, deck; taxes $1,378. Wilton, Conn. $385,000 128 Deer Run Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; screened porch, updated kitchen, 1.8 acres; taxes $3,250. Chappaqua, N.Y. $565,000 7 Berrybrook Circle 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old contemporary; library, den, screened porch, greenhouse, 2-car garage w/loft, 2 acres; taxes $6,930. Cross River, N.Y. $340,000 Schoolhouse Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old split-level; fireplace, deck, 3-stall barn, pond, 1-car garage, 2.8 acres; taxes $4,717. Larchmont, N.Y. $550,000 50 Beach Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, beach and mooring rights; taxes $9,995. OTHER AREAS Short Hills, N.J. $365,000 13 Lakeview Terrace 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; fireplace, screened porch, 2-car garage; taxes $4,699. South Orange, N.J. $395,000 320 Tillou Road 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, c/a, porch; taxes $6,925. Selden, L.I. $98,000 119 Highview Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, attic; taxes $749.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?

title: Cemetery Is Accused of Improper Cremations
description: A lawsuit has been filed against a cemetery in suburban Pomona, accusing it of mingling the remains of several people who were cremated, returning the wrong ashes to some relatives and dumping excess ashes in a vacant lot.

title: A Mystery Thriller That Is Not So Mysterious
description: IF the mark of a good play is how well it withstands the indignities of a mediocre production, then Richard Harris's ''The Business of Murder'' ranks low in the ratings.

title: FASHION: At the Track; Saratoga Style: Breezy Cottons, Casual Linens
description: The horse at right, Easy Goer, is a natural for leafy Saratoga, where the scene is relaxed, even at post time. Though for Saratoga's clubhouse area and its tree-shaded paddocks, there is a dress code - dresses for women, jackets and ties preferred for men - no one seems to get too excited if it is occasionally ignored, as it was for the woman in the elegant white pants suit, center right. The air is casual, a far cry from, say, the glossy, high-fashion spectacle of Ascot in England or Longchamps in France.

title: Q and A
description: Jewish Barcelona

title: Hospital Counselors Relieve Emotional Scars of Violence
description: There didn't seem to be enough words for the patient to tell her story. The sentences tumbled out long and, at times, unintelligible, but with an urgency punctuated by a pounding fist, a shake of the woman's head and a stream of insults directed at her boyfriend, whose repeated beatings had finally brought her to Harlem Hospital.

title: Past and Present Struggle Over Faded Hotel
description: Its potted palms wilted and its crystal chandeliers powdered with dust, the Ambassador Hotel, the last of Southern California's grand hotels, is at the center of a tug of war between preservationists and city officials who want to tear it down to build a school.

title: Relativism and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN: Recognition Is Hard When Faces Are New
description: Japan's cultural budget of $290 million this year is augmented by funds from other government agencies plus substantive business and local financial support. The nation spends 0.068 percent of its total government budget on culture, whereas France spends 0.86 percent, according to the Dentsu Institute for Human Studies, a think tank set up by a major advertising agency.

title: Measles Cases Prompt a Campaign
description: LEAD: A MEASLES outbreak in Yonkers has prompted the County Health Department to issue guidelines on measles immunization, offer free vaccinations and teach the public about the disease.

title: Two Shows: One Works, the Other Bogs Down
description: With only a few months remaining in the decade, it is high season for curators itching to define what the art of the 1980's has been about. In photography this exercise has a special significance, since in the last 10 years the medium has played a broad and invigorating role in the art world.

title: Democrats Appear Among Benefactors of H.U.D. Largesse
description: As politically well-connected Republicans procured millions of dollars in grants and subsidies from the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the late 1980's, Democrats were using their power in Congress to take advantage of many of the same H.U.D. programs, documents indicate.

title: Exercising the Mind as Well as the Eye
description: IN their revolt against tradition, Modernists took their cues from art by the uncivilized, the unformed and the deranged - ''natural'' man, in a word.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about the closing of landfills quoted Mardythe DiPirro, Supervisor of the Town of Southampton, incorrectly. She advocates recycling garbage and opposes incineration.

title: Dunston Drives in 6 As Cubs Beat Phils
description: Shawon Dunston drove home a career-high six runs and the Chicago Cubs held off the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-7, today in another wild outing between the teams at Wrigley Field.

title: Baseball's Other Subversives
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: HITCHCOCK PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH;
A New Sanctuary Is Rising From the Ashes
description: LEAD: THE sun streams through the huge crucifix-shaped window at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church here, but there is no glass yet. The cross is still an open space. It is the shape formed by the surrounding steel framing and plywood.

title: Kim Tripp Marries
description: Kim Elizabeth Tripp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Tripp of Huntington and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to David John Fickbohm, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Fickbohm of St. James, L.I. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor by the Rev. Eliot G. Frederic. The bride, who will keep her name, is a candidate for a Ph.D. in horticultural science at North Carolina State University. She graduated from Cornell University, where she also received a master's degree in plant science. The bridegroom, a Cornell graduate, is a doctoral candidate in neurobiology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Review/Theater; Relationships Questioned, In 'Friends'
description: In ''Best Friends,'' John Voulgaris toys with scores of questions about the nature of friendship, the rewards and perils of fame, the futility of intelligence, the emptiness of self-satisfaction and many other ordinary concerns that fill the dialogue of soap operas and romantic fiction - but he provides no answers and doesn't even make the questions very interesting.

title:
GARDENING;
Overcoming Pests at Harvest Time
description: LEAD: TO some gardeners, raspberries and blueberries are literally for the birds. About the time they ripen to that mouthwatering stage when they are ready to pick, every bird in the neighborhood with a taste for the fruit zeros in on the patch, and a gardener will be lucky to get even a taste for all the effort expended in pruning, fertilizing, watering and mulching.

title: A Lively Composer Escapes the Reference Books
description: When a name becomes music, the results can be intriguing. Marcel Landowski's name can be found in all reference works devoted to 20th-century French music, but seldom in programs outside France.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Iowa; T-Shirt Included In AIDS Display Leads to Protests
description: A display case put up by a conservative newspaper at the University of Iowa that contained a T-shirt depicting a homosexual act has drawn protests from homosexual and feminist groups on campus.

title: 20 More Killed in Lebanon In 3d Day of Heavy Shelling
description: For the third day in succession, Beirut and other areas of Lebanon came under savage artillery and rocket barrages today, keeping residents pinned down in bomb shelters.

title:
GARDENING;
Overcoming Pests at Harvest Time
description: LEAD: TO some gardeners, raspberries and blueberries are literally for the birds. About the time they ripen to that mouthwatering stage when they are ready to pick, every bird in the neighborhood with a taste for the fruit zeros in on the patch, and a gardener will be lucky to get even a taste for all the effort expended in pruning, fertilizing, watering and mulching.

title: Former Fighter Backs Neumann
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Exotic Indian, Light Italian, French, Elegantly Formal
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Bukhara

title: NONFICTION
description: STEVIE SMITH: A Biography. By Frances Spalding. (Norton, $19.95.) ''Stevie Smith is an unusually difficult subject for biography.'' So begins this book by Frances Spalding, the British biographer of Roger Fry and Vanessa Bell. The problem is that there is not much to go on: days spent as a secretary in London, evenings eked out in a household of spinsters in a suburb so outer it was virtually outre. Stevie Smith (1902-1971) seemed to have been doomed from day one to live life most fully in her work. Through ''Novel on Yellow Paper,'' Ms. Spalding traces the writer's childhood and creative influences; between the lines of her poetry and short stories, she uncovers her arguments with Christianity, her early passions and her later, more circumspect affairs. The personality that emerges is one of contradiction, an eccentric whose mantel of naivete served as both protection and weapon. This is the sort of sensitive, scholarly work that is important simply because it has been undertaken, and will no doubt delight Stevie Smith devotees by being well carried out. For the lay reader, though, the book is too respectful to make good reading. Why, with such obvious talents, did Smith choose to remain unmarried and solitary? That is what her friends wondered, and Ms. Spalding does, too; then, with typically British tact, she simply calls it rather astonishing, and leaves it at that. For all the careful detail, this biography never seems to close in on the central mystery of this life: what made Stevie Smith so afraid of it to begin with?

title: When Congress Returns
description: The nation's elected representatives left Washington last weekend in dire need of a vacation, which, by their own admission, they had done little to earn. The first seven months of the 101st Congress were filled with distraction and turmoil, yielding little of substance. Yet a demanding agenda looms ahead, and for that, a brief period of rest and reflection is surely in order.

title: Russians in Estonia Pledge To Continue Strike Over Law
description: Striking Russian workers in the Soviet Baltic republic of Estonia pledged today to continue their protest against a new local voting law.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps; Correction
description: The Stamps column last Sunday referred incorrectly to an anniversary next May. It will be the 150th anniversary of the introduction of the first postage stamp, the British Penny Black, not the centenary.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Asbury Park $59,850 1239 Munroe Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; fireplace, enclosed porch; taxes $1,823. Lakewood $79,900 123 Governors Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old condominium town house; w/w carpeting, den; monthly charges $110; taxes $1,004. Linden $175,000 43 Edgewood Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, full basement; taxes $1,278.
