title: Downpour Ties Up Trains, Buses and Planes
description: With all the rain that New York has seen this year, it was going to take something close to a flash flood to startle the city. It happened yesterday, when the afternoon sky turned dark and the rains moved in with a fury, stopping buses, delaying planes and turning back subway trains in their tracks.

title: THE MIDWEST: Kings Island - Kings Island, Ohio
description: Each year, millions of visitors brave the Beast at Kings Island in Ohio. And brave they need to be. This entire wooden coaster is secluded - hidden from the rest of the park by dense, towering trees and rugged terrain that cuts off views from one part of the ride to the next. The result: You never know until the last minute what surprises await you. Horrors might be a better word.

title: Messages From Our Baby
description: I SPENT most of my first year in New Haven being pregnant. It was a full-time job, with doctor and midwife visits, queasiness and food labels that need to be scrutinized for potentially harmful ingredients. During eight and a quarter months I looked forward to my second year in New Haven.

title: Julie O'Brien and John Dorsey Marry
description: At the Sage Chapel at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., Julie Marie O'Brien, a daughter of Virginia L. O'Brien and Stephen J. O'Brien, both of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to John Luke Kurkpatrick Dorsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Dorsey of Cincinnati. The Rev. Michael Mahler, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: No-Frill Lobster On Maine's Coast
description: LOBSTER is a Maine cliche. The jaunty dancing crustacean on the state's license plate leaves scant doubt in the matter. Rare is the visitor who leaves without having savored the lobster's delicate flesh. Still, there is snobbery, mainly in the contention that until you've had lobster at a bona fide lobster shack, you haven't really had Maine lobster at all.

title: The Geo Prizm: Bread and Butter
description: Face it, most people don't drive Ferraris. Oh, really? you say.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: A CENTURY and a half ago, the place to go in New Jersey during the summer was the unpolluted waterfront at Hoboken and Weehawken. There, a short ferry ride from Manhattan, day-trippers could stroll and picnic in the scenic countryside.

title: All the Way From A to B
description: To the Editor:

title: David Marc Weil, a Law Clerk, Married To Susan Hollis Zimmerman, a Banker
description: Susan Hollis Zimmerman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Zimmerman of New York, was married last evening at the Union League Club in New York to David Marc Weil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Weil of Andover, Mass. Rabbis Everett Gendler and Martin Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Getting Into the Swing of Baseball
description: LEAD: JOE BROCKHOFF, the head baseball coach at Tulane University in New Orleans, was pacing before the batting cages.

title: Six Countries, Six Visions
description: For ''Amores Dificiles,'' Gabriel Garcia Marquez gathered half a dozen directors from Latin America and Spain, anchoring a quartet of new talent with a pair of blue-chip names, and found the means to get their work produced.

title: Charges of Abuse Revived at Turkish Prisons
description: A weeks-long hunger strike by hundreds of inmates, and the death of two of them last week, have rekindled longstanding complaints about human-rights abuses in Turkish prisons.

title: A Koch Road Show Seeks New Businesses
description: Having had mixed success in guarding the Hudson River border, Mayor Edward I. Koch plans to stretch New York City's economic development campaign even farther westward, to the shores of Lake Michigan.

title: Roslyn Tom Wed To Mark Mason
description: Roslyn Tom a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton Tom of New York, and Mark Mason a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Mason of the Georgetown section of Washington, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: William Burke, 84; Led St. Patrick's Parade
description: William B. Burke, executive secretary of the St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee in New York City from 1978 to 1984 and grand marshal of the 1980 parade, died Friday at the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital in the Bronx, where he had lived since May. He was 84 years old and had resided in the Inwood section of Manhattan before moving to Yonkers in 1977.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Riverside Units Going Co-op
description: LEAD: A NEW YORK developer has begun converting 396 rental apartments into what will become one of the area's few co-ops.

title: Miss Cooper Wed To a Law Student
description: Margo Lynn Cooper, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Cooper of Middletown, N.J., and Bruce Elliott Bershstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald B. Bershstein of Edison, N.J., were married last evening at the Grand Marquis in Old Bridge, N.J., by Rabbi Alfred B. Landsberg.

title: Good Times Again for Carbide?
description: If Robert D. Kennedy were the type of man to brood, he'd probably be pretty miserable right now.

title: General Sees End to U.S. Troops in Korea in 90's
description: The commander of United States forces in South Korea, Gen. Louis C. Menetrey, says there would be no military need to keep American forces there after the mid-1990's if present trends continue.

title: FICTION
description: HORTENSE IS ABDUCTED. By Jacques Roubaud. Translated by Dominic Di Bernardi. (Dalkey Archive, $19.95.) A dark Parisian night, an eerie mansion, midnight bells. A shot rings out and a life ends. A conventional detective story? No, no, a significant 37 times no. Although ''Hortense Is Abducted'' is a mystery with a plot literally as intricate as a sestina, its real fascination lies in Jacques Roubaud's conversational asides, inside jokes and self-referential word play. What detective story, for example, makes allusions to Monte Carlo computer simulations, Bertrand Russell's barber paradox and the philosopher Saul Kripke's concept of a rigid designator? The story features Hortense, who is a Madame Bovary parody; six almost identical-looking princes from the imaginary country of Poldevia; a cat who communicates with his whiskers; ''twins'' with different birthdays and different fathers; an innkeeper obsessed with infinity; and an assortment of standard Gallic types. It is appealing even if (or maybe because) many of its jokes are a little puerile. Some of the book's allusions probably resonated better with its French audience, but most work fairly well in English - and a few, I suspect, are scarcely comprehensible (despite Dominic Di Bernardi's adept translation) in either language. A member of France's Oulipo school of experimental, quasi-mathematical literature, Mr. Roubaud includes within his novel querulous letters to his publisher, as well as logic and number puzzles. Also a good deal of enjoyment. By the way, I'm not revealing much if I tell you that the murder victim is a dog.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'RUSTIC OUTINGS'

title: 'DO YOU HAVE THE COURAGE TO CRY?'
description: THE PILGRIM'S RULES OF ETIQUETTE By Taghi Modarressi. 279 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Central America Goes Its Own Way
description: AFTER eight years, millions of dollars and thousands of casualties, it has come to this: Nicaragua's contra rebels, the ''freedom fighters'' who have been an essential element of American policy toward the Sandinista Government throughout the 1980's, are to be forced to disband. In a ringing declaration of independence from the United States last week, the leaders of five Central American countries ignored Washington's objections and came up with a plan that promises to eliminate the rebels as a military force before the year is out.

title: Brian De Palma Explores Vietnam and Its Victims
description: At some point in their careers, most top motion-picture directors turn to the broad canvas of war, a subject that has within it the elements - action, character and conflict - that make for commercially successful, sometimes even estimable, films. With his 19th movie, ''Casualties of War,'' scheduled to open Friday, Brian De Palma at last brings his sanguineous style to the battlefield. And the result is likely to leave Mr. De Palma in a place familiar to him - the middle of an imbroglio.

title: The Thrill Factor: Rating the Rides
description: We asked correspondents of The New York Times to rate the thrill factor of the most exciting rides at the parks they visited, using a scale of 1 of 5 (scariest), respresented by scream faces below. Here are their reports. PARK: New Jersey: Great Adventure RIDE: Great American Scream Machine (roller coaster) RATING: 3 screams COMMENTS: All the fear is in the anticipation. - Nick Ravo PARK: Pennsylvania: Dorney Park RIDE: Hercules (roller coaster) RATING: 3 screams COMMENTS: You can be nonchalant until the killer drop, and after that it's just survival. RIDE: Tie between: Thunderhawk and Laser (roller coasters) RATING: 2 screams COMMENTS: So many parks have upside-down loops that the thrill is gone. - Glenn Collins PARK: Virginia: Water Country U.S.A. RIDE: Double Rampage (water slide) RATING: 5 screams COMMENTS: Beautifully orchestrated for heart-stopping pleasure. RIDE: Jet Stream (body flume) RATING: 4 screams COMMENTS: You surge up the side of the chute like an Olympic luger. - Maureen Dowd PARK: Florida: Adventure Island RIDE: Tampa Typhoon (water slide) RATING: 4 screams COMMENTS: Scarier than free-falling through a waterfall. - Jeffrey Schmalz PARK: Georgia: Six Flags Over Georgia RIDE: Free Fall (free fall) RATING: 5 screams COMMENTS: A horrific jolt that could scare the dead. RIDE: Mind Bender (roller coaster) RATING: 4.5 screams COMMENTS: A disorienting sense of vertigo. - Peter Applebome PARK: Texas: Astroworld RIDE: Texas Cyclone (roller coaster) RATING: 5 screams COMMENTS: I could feel my brain mushing against the top of my head. RIDE: Sky Screamer (free fall) RATING: 4 screams COMMENTS: I've always wanted to know how it felt to jump from an eighth-story window. - Lisa Belkin PARK: Ohio: Cedar Point RIDE: Magnum XL-200 (roller coaster) RATING: 5 screams COMMENTS: Riders look like condemned convicts heading for the gallows. - Eric N. Berg PARK: Ohio: Kings Island RIDE: The Beast (roller coaster) RATING: 4.5 screams COMMENTS: It's enough to make you permanently clench your teeth. - Eric N. Berg PARK: Missouri: Worlds of Fun/Oceans of Fun RIDE: Tie between: Orient Express and Timber Wolf (roller coasters) RATING: 4.5 screams COMMENTS: The Orient Express tosses you around a lot, but the Timber Wolf creaks and groans. RIDE: Typhoon (water slide) RATING: 2 screams COMMENTS: Makes an old codger feel like a kid again. - William Robbins PARK: California: Knott's Berry Farm RIDE: Montezooma's Revenge (roller coaster) RATING: 4 screams COMMENTS: It took me 15 minutes to recover my balance. - Robert Reinhold PARK: California: Great America RIDE: The Edge (free fall) RATING: 4.5 scream COMMENTS: Leaves passengers with their stomachs where their foreheads used to be. RIDE: The Demon (roller coaster) RATING: 3 screams COMMENTS: Could knock the loose teeth out of a 7-year-old's mouth. - Jane Gross PARK: Washington: Wild Waves RIDE: Cannonball (enclosed tube) RATING: 4 screams COMMENTS: Spits out swimmers like peas from a straw shooter. RIDE: Bonzai (water slide) RATING: 3 screams COMMENTS: A long, slippery slide with great turns. - Timothy Egan

title: State Readies Court Reply to Desegregation Suit
description: THE state has until next Monday to put on the public record its arguments against the school desegregation lawsuit begun last April.

title: Linda Cummings Married to Dentist
description: Linda Lenore Cummings, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. DeForest Cummings Jr. of Buffalo and Bay Beach, Ontario, was married yesterday in Buffalo to Dr. James Patrick Murphy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy of Flushing, Queens, and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Thomas P. Stewart, assisted by Msgr. George T. Deas, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: Should Gym Be Required?
description: In response to the Opinion page articles entitled ''Ending Required Gym: 2 Views'' (July 9): I believe that both views presented missed the point. Has economics become the yardstick by which we measure whether we cancel gym class? If so, our children and our future may be in serious trouble.

title: Higher Rank
description: Last week President Bush named as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff a man whose combat experience has included stints at the White House and the Pentagon.

title: Grenade Attacks in Guatemala
description: Terrorists hurled grenades in three separate attacks around Guatemala City, killing a woman on a bus and injured eight other passengers in one attack, the authorities said today. The other explosions damaged buildings but caused no casualties. The police said they had not determined who had carried out the attacks. They said no individual or group claimed responsibility.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Think of it this way: there may be worse things in life than the first days back at work after vacation. In fact, there are - lots of them - but somehow they don't come to mind as Cape Cod, Vermont, London and Singapore fade into the mist and visions of the office become increasingly vivid.

title:
BASEBALL;
For Cubs and 2 Rookies, a 'Gorgeous and Nice' Season
description: LEAD: Shortly after the Chicago Cubs beat the Montreal Expos one day last week, a reporter asked Manager Don Zimmer if he has had to pinch himself to make sure that his ball club is for real. Zimmer adjusted the chaw in his mouth, then looked innocently at his questioner before deadpanning, ''You know, I don't ever believe I've ever pinched myself.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Patty Hearst 1988. Media Home Entertainment. 1 hour, 48 minutes. $89.95. Laser disk (Image Entertainment), $39.95. Closed captioned. R. Though made on a comparatively modest budget, this is a beautifully produced movie, seen entirely from Patty Hearst's limited point of view - stylized at times, utterly direct and both shocking and grimly funny. Natasha Richardson is ''absolutely smashing'' in the title role, with not a gesture or word wasted. Paul Schrader's direction avoids imposing any kind of reassuring order on the harrowing, real-life story of the Hearst publishing company heiress in her entanglements with the Symbionese Liberation Army. A study in the fragility of personality, this is a ''a model of swift, spare, unsentimental film making about a character who can never be known . . . and about a specific time and circumstances that, with hindsight, seem incredible.'' (Vincent Canby) Tap 1989. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 1:50. $89.95. LD (Image), $39.95. CC. PG-13. Written and directed by Nick Castle, the son of a choreographer who collaborated with Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly, and starring Gregory Hines, a fine, sinuous dancer, this should have been the kind of superior movie that evokes the exhilaration of dance; instead, it just talks about it. The supporting cast includes seven of the greatest tap specialists still alive - Harold Nicholas, Jimmy Slyde, Sandman Sims, Bunny Briggs, Steve Condos, Arthur Duncan and Pat Rico - as well as the 14-year-old Savion Glover (of Broadway's ''Black and Blue'') and the beautiful actress-singer-dancer Suzzanne Douglas. But almost every time the film gets around to the dancing, it cuts away to pursue the romantic melodrama that passes for a story. '' 'Tap,' according to the production notes, 'is more than a pretty musical spiced with tap dancing.' It sure is, and that's what's wrong with it.'' (Canby) The Wash 1988. Academy Entertainment. 1:34. $79.95. Not rated. Set in a Japanese section of San Jose, Calif., this story of an older couple's painful separation and funny new romances is less about any ethnic community than it is about confused feelings between two individuals, played by Nobu McCarthy (Masi) and Mako (Nobu). The great strength of the film, written by Philip Kan Gotanda from his own play, is that, through Masi, who has left her husband but still stops by every week to do his laundry, we see the overbearing Nobu sympathetically, as the victim of his own intolerance. Though it threatens at times to slide into cliches, the picture is emotionally honest at core and blessed with first-rate performances across the board. In its best moments it is ''a triumph of intelligent acting and film making.'' (Caryn James) The Burbs 1989. MCA Home Video. 1:42. $89.95. LD, $34.98. PG. This is a big unfurnished movie about some very small characters living in a suburbia that is consciously designed to look like sitcom land. Tom Hanks, Bruce Dern and Carrie Fisher, as suburbanites loudly suspicious of a weird household of new neighbors, do nothing here to bolster their reputations. For a while the movie threatens to become a minor plea on behalf of people who do not conform, but in the end, ''the best thing that can be said for Joe Dante, the director . . . , and Dana Olsen, who wrote the script, is that they don't try to stuff 'The Burbs' with a worthy message. The movie is as empty as something can be without creating a vacuum.'' (Canby) I Am the Law 1938. RCA/Columbia. 1:23. $69.95. Not rated. When this film was released, B. R. Crisler of The Times found Edward G. Robinson ''slightly miscast'' as a beloved law professor drafted into service as a special prosecutor against the rackets: ''He, or his authors, really didn't have to pull that smoking-pipe-in-the-pocket stuff on us, his old friends, who are all for him, so long as he keeps his place. And that place, we can't help feeling, is sociologically on the other side of the tracks.'' Wendy Barrie, too, is ''simply too charming and well-mannered as an ex-newspaper woman higher-up in the rackets.'' At that, the film was ''still the liveliest melodrama in town. . . . Somebody is kayoed, rubbed out, arrested or blown up, during every five or ten minutes of the action, and anybody who can sit through a series of such incidents without a sphygmometric reaction - even if it is only a movie - is just abnormal. We recommend it as a practically sure cure for low blood pressure.''

title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town
description: I HAD just turned 22 that eventful summer of 1969. My husband, 20-month-old son and I were living with my parents in their summer home on Kauneonga Lake, in Bethel, N.Y.

title: 4 Arraigned in Police Shooting
description: Four men arrested in connection with the shooting of a New York City police officer in the Bronx on Thursday were arraigned yesterday on charges stemming from the shooting.

title: Proof That All That Glitters Is Not Vulgar
description: This city has always been a curious mix of gentility and toughness, of refinement and bluntness. And that is exactly the way to describe the new skyscraper just finished at 75 State Street in the center of downtown, for this unusual tower, designed by Graham Gund Associates with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, reflects the city's complex character. It is at once decorated and straightforward, at once garish and well mannered. It does not look like anything else in Boston - but nonetheless manages to be as Boston-like as any building the city has seen in years.

title: Orders for Divac
description: So many Eastern European athletes have been signing contracts with American teams lately that it's easy to forget that in the Communist world, there is no such thing as a free agent, even, it now appears, when an athlete has been bought and paid for.

title: Ina Sue Kaplan Wed
description: Ina Sue Kaplan and James Samuel Felman were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Morris W. Barzilai. Mrs. Felman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Kaplan of New York, is a senior accountant at Arthur Andersen & Company, accountants in New York. She is a graduate of Cornell University. The bridegroom, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Felman of Coral Springs, Fla., graduated from Cornell and the State University of New York at Buffalo Law School. He is a tax consultant at Price Waterhouse & Company, accountants in New York.

title: Drunken Drivers Pay Own Way in Innovative Jail
description: Like many local governments, Summit County has more people it wants to jail than it has cells. Like many local governments, Summit County is building a larger jail.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SHINING THROUGH, by Susan Isaacs. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Susan Isaacs' novel about a Wall Street secretary who becomes a spy in Nazi Germany is ''not just a 1940's period piece, but as close to a 1940's movie as a book can get,'' Anne Tolstoi Wallach said in The Book Review last year. ''It's like the kind of big, exciting movie we loved best then, in which someone pretty much like us takes incredible risks for unimpeachable motives and wins just what we wanted.'' IN SEARCH OF J. D. SALINGER, by Ian Hamilton. (Vintage, $8.95.) The final pages of ''Franny and Zooey,'' with all the meditations on the evils of ego and fame, seem to make it pretty clear why J. D. Salinger chose to slip through a tear in the Veil of Maya and disappear into the silence of New Hampshire. But his relentless efforts to block publication of Ian Hamilton's story of his life appeared most un-Zenlike. This very unauthorized biography is a ''rich and subtly dramatic book,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. Ian Hamilton ''has conjured a substantial portrait more or less out of thin air, and it has much to recommend it to a public also hungry to possess the famously elusive J. D. Salinger.'' SWORD POINT, by Harold Coyle. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) Antagonized by the two great Satans, the Soviet Union and the United States, Iran decides to end it all with a nuclear Armageddon. Last year our reviewer, John Glenn, said, ''Mr. Coyle knows soldiers, and he understands the brotherhood-of-arms mystique that transcends national boundaries.'' DARKNESS AT NIGHT: A Riddle of the Universe, by Edward Harrison. (Harvard University, $12.95.) With an infinite universe presumably filled with stars in every direction, why is the sky black and not blazing at night? ''Mr. Harrison has an answer,'' Timothy Ferris wrote in The Book Review in 1987, ''but to state it here seems as unfair as giving away the final chapter of a mystery story.'' HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Despite their good intentions, four generations of daughters find it impossible not to repeat the mistakes their mothers made. ''Though 'Her Mother's Daughter' suffers from problems that are often found in sprawling page-turners . . . Ms. French continues to write about the inner lives of women with insight and intimacy,'' Alice Hoffman said here in 1987. ''What she's given us this time is a page-turner with a heart.'' ON ACCOUNT OF SEX: The Politics of Women's Issues, 1945-1968, by Cynthia Harrison. (University of California, $10.95.) A historian of the women's movement explains why there was a decades-long dark ages between the suffrage movement of the 1920's and the feminism of the 1960's. Last year our reviewer, Deirdre English, said this ''perceptive new volume . . . focuses on the deep conflicts among women that shaped women's politics from the mid-1940's to the mid-60's.'' SILVER, by Hilma Wolitzer. (Ivy, $4.95.) On her silver wedding anniversary a household-hints columnist who always wanted to be a poet decides to leave her husband and Long Island for the writer's life in New York. Though the plot feels contrived, Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year, Hilma Wolitzer has an ''unerring sense of the daily rhythms of domestic life, [ an ] ability to describe the ordinary in terms that remake the familiar.'' NUCLEAR FEAR: A History of Images, by Spencer R. Weart. (Harvard University, $14.95.) A historian shows that the best gauge of how the public conceives and misconceives of nuclear energy, whether in a reactor or a hydrogen bomb, is in novels and movies, from ''Madame Curie'' to ''The China Syndrome.'' '' 'Nuclear Fear' is a good and useful book, an intellectual treat for anyone who still believes that there is such a thing as 'the spirit of the age,' '' Alfred Kazin said here last year. JACK OF DIAMONDS: And Other Stories, by Elizabeth Spencer. (Penguin, $6.95.) When this collection of short fiction was published last year, our reviewer, Madison Smartt Bell, said Elizabeth Spencer's strong sense of locale makes each of her stories ''substantial enough to make up an entire novel.'' STRENGTH FOR THE FIGHT: A History of Black Americans in the Military, by Bernard C. Nalty. (Free Press, $12.95.) Since the American Revolution, when Virginia slaves were offered freedom if they would fight on the side of the Crown, blacks have been treated well by the military only in time of war. ''Mr. Nalty's book suggests that it may require another war to correct the armed forces' latest mistakes,'' Russell F. Weigley said here in 1986. He ''makes optimism about his subject difficult to muster.'' MEN, by Margaret Diehl. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $7.95.) In this novel about Stella James, a woman obsessed with the need for anonymous sex, some of the best moments come when the author explores her heroine's gallery of memories, Howard Coale said here last year. ''Stella's description of losing her virginity at 15 in a freezing New Hampshire backyard, after sitting nude in an orgone box, is particularly wonderful.'' SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE: The Chappaquiddick Cover-Up, by Leo Damore. (Dell, $4.95.) This account of the accident that killed Mary Jo Kopechne the night she left a party on Chappaquiddick Island with Senator Edward M. Kennedy is fascinating for ''its wealth of detail,'' Jo Thomas said here last year. ''Mr. Damore has re-examined many of the stories that have floated around in reporters' notebooks for years, too plausible to discard but too shaky to print, and he has unearthed new material as well.''

title: Ms. Dougherty Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. James F. Dougherty of Sea Girt, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., have announced that their daughter Kathleen Elizabeth Dougherty is to be married next month to Dr. James Aloysius Boozan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Boozan of Elizabeth, N.J., and Sea Girt.

title: RADICAL TRANSFORMATIONS
description: ''Radical Transformations'' was a good reminder of how the 1960's generation divided into the unlucky and the lucky.

title: Review/Music; 'Apollo' and 'Thamos,' A Pair of Mozart Rarities
description: Even in the case of Mozart, the examination of child prodigies has an extra-musical air to it. We shall never, for example, hear ''Apollo et Hyacinthus'' without mentally placing that asterisk beside it - ''the work of an 11-year old.'' It is Mozart's music in juxtaposition with Mozart's age that makes us gasp. Take the music alone, assign it to some obscure contemporary and I doubt that we would give it a second thought.

title: GREENING THE WHITE HOUSE By Trip Gabriel; Trip Gabriel is a New York City-based author who writes frequently about the outdoors.
description: THE ENVIRONMENTALISTS GATHERED in the East Room of the White House on June 12 thought they had died and gone to heaven.

title: THE SOUTH: Six Flags Over Georgia - Near Atlanta, Georgia
description: All roads in the South don't really lead to Six Flags Over Georgia - 12 miles west of downtown Atlanta - but it sometimes feels that way.

title: Cofield Stars but Jets Lose to Packers
description: The Jets opened their exhibition season with a 28-27 loss to the Green Bay Packers today, but the outcome was not as important as how Tim Cofield played the game.

title: Dealer Kills New Jersey Man Buying Drugs, the Police Say
description: A New Jersey man who the police say was trying to buy drugs near Times Square early yesterday was held by one man while another plunged a knife into his chest, killing him, the police said.

title: Cuba Dreams of Tourists and Better Service
description: Short on income and worried that aid from the Soviet Union may be cut, President Fidel Castro is dreaming these days of making Cuba a playground for foreign tourists once again.

title: Works in Progress; A Venerable Haunt Returns
description: ''I HAD SEEN ENOUGH OF MY American colleagues of the press,'' says the narrator of Graham Greene's 1955 novel, ''The Quiet American.''

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: How would you like being a field general under the command of Attila the Hun and be given a group of chocolate soldiers to win the day? How would you like to receive a 1989 major league calendar with the month of August missing from the pages? Dallas Green is doing the best job possible. JACK MARSHALL New York

title: STREETSCAPES: The Czech Gymnastic Association Clubhouse; A 2-Story Survivor Amid Upper East Side High-Rises
description: IT'S one of a vanishing species, an element of the ethnic Upper East Side that used to be the stronghold of Central and Eastern European nationalities. The New York Sokol's 1896 building at 420 East 71st Street is one of the survivors, a two-story intermission amid a growing forest of high-rises.

title: What's the Price of Commercials in Classrooms?
description: Even though most high school students will be returning to their classrooms only next month, a 15-minute daily newscast designed expressly for them by Ted Turner's Cable News Network will begin to be broadcast tomorrow at approximately 3:45 A.M. The program, ''CNN Newsroom,'' will be made available free to all high schools in the United States. Next spring, Whittle Communications will offer its news program for high school students, ''Channel One,'' which has just finished a controversial seven weeks of field testing in six schools across the country.

title: Nathan Levine Dies; Film Executive Was 89
description: Nathan Levine, who worked with Gene Autry and John Wayne and headed Republic Pictures in a career spanning the silent and sound eras of movies, died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital. He was 89 years old.

title: In the Limelight With Lyme Disease
description: I GAINED notoriety overnight after contracting Lyme disease. Suddenly thrust into the limelight, I was a star. I was famous the moment I walked out of the examining room. ''Oh, so you have the dreaded disease,'' a secretary at the doctor's office said when she read the diagnosis.

title: Appellate Judge Is Retiring
description: Spottswood Robinson of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia is retiring on Aug. 31 after 25 years in the Federal judiciary, court officials have announced. His retirement brings vacancies on the 12-member court to three. Clarence Thomas, formerly chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, has been nominated to fill the seat of Robert H. Bork, who left after being rejected for the Supreme Court. The other vacancy is that of Kenneth W. Starr, now Solicitor General.

title: Patricia Shiland: Unconventional Portraitist
description: Patricia Shiland calls them ''miniature life-style portraits,'' and although the name may not immediately evoke an image, that's exactly what they are. The finished product is framed, protected by glass and hung on a wall, but instead of a painting or drawing it's a three-dimensional portrayal of an individual in miniatures that reflect the person's style of living.

title: Battlelines Drawn on Michigan's Lakefront-Dune Law
description: A new state law designed to restrict construction on 60,000 acres of sand dunes on Michigan's lakefront shores is expected to result in court challenges to the power of state regulators over private landowners' development rights.

title: Letitia Barroll to Wed James Frederick
description: Letitia Humphreys Barroll and James Bradley Frederick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Frederick of New Britain, Conn., plan to marry in September, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. W. Barroll of Baltimore, have announced.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RIGHTFULLY MINE. By Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $18.95.) The international world of art dealers, collectors, auction houses and antiques fairs is the setting for Doris Mortman's third novel. ''Rightfully Mine'' is a love story with as many characters as there are figures in the elaborate set of Brussels wedding tapestries that is central to the plot.

title: Ex-School Head Keeps Children As Her Focus
description: JOAN POUNDS of Wilton, the former owner and director of the Hamilton School, used to snap pictures of her nursery school and kindergarten students and give them to parents at Christmas time. In the six years since she sold the school, Mrs. Pounds has turned what had been a public relations gesture into a full-time career as an award-winning children's portrait photographer.

title:
MUSIC;
Campers Write an Opera
description: LEAD: AT the Appel Farm Arts and Music Center here, 11 campers have written an opera, 12 more are busy in rehearsals, and the entire camp is taking the project, and the message of the opera, very seriously. In fact, through music, dance and drama, the youngsters, aged 10 to 15, plan to open the eyes of the adults in their audiences to some very serious social and environmental issues.

title: Virgin Atlantic
description: To the Editor: In response to Victoria Csakany (Letters, July 23), who complained about Virgin Atlantic's one-day sale, New York to London, round trip for

title: Chimney, Fireplace Checkup
description: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces. But if you neglected the task this year or have not examined these items within the last 12 months, you should do so before fall to make sure they are in safe working condition before the next heating season begins.

title: Toni Silver: Clothing Designer
description: Toni Silver loves to travel. Two years ago she went to Asia, visiting Korea, Singapore, Thailand, Nepal and Bali. She loved the Balinese people, their culture, their food. She stayed two months and she now believes she may have found her life work.

title: SHADES OF GRAY/GREY
description: In discussing the usage of between and among, Mr. Safire again offers his support for those teachers of grade-school English whose rules reach back to the conceit that only the Latinist has the right to prescribe the rules of English grammar. My own teacher, I suspect, would have had us write that Pennsylvania is situated among New York, New Jersey, Maryland, West Virginia and Ohio. HILLEL A. FINE New York, N.Y.

title: Gail Collins Wed To Fellow Editor
description: The wedding of Gail Ann Collins, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Stewart Collins of Evansville, Ind., and Joseph Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Williams of Jamaica, Queens, took place yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan. The bride's father, the pastor of the Holy Trinity Church of God in Christ in Evansville, officiated.

title: Chicago Must Modernize or Perish
description: Tension is running high at the Chicago futures exchanges. So far, 46 traders have been charged with trading practices that the Federal Government says systematically robbed the trading public on a major scale. More indictments are expected. But in the midst of the turmoil, it is important not to lose sight of another crucial and more important challenge facing the Chicago exchanges - competing with foreign markets There is a major battle looming over who will control the international 24-hour market for futures and options contracts. There is no shortage of foreign rivals ready to exploit any weakness in the Chicago pits. There are now active futures and options exchanges in Australia, Brazil, Canada, France, Britain, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, Sweden and Switzerland. A decade ago none of them existed.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 6 on a new law to spur private housing in New York City omitted the name of the architectual firm responsible for the Fordham Landing condominium complex to be built in the Bronx. It is Gruzen Samton Steinglass.

title: 'The Rainbow Stories'
description: Halfway between Tom Wolfe's journalism and Thomas Pynchon's fabulism, William T. Vollmann's ''Rainbow Stories'' search for a new form. In stories that blend colorful documentary evidence with a novelist's dark imagination, Mr. Vollmann offers images no ordinary reporter could glimpse, no typical novelist invent: a 16-year-old skinhead called Bootwoman Marisa bites her lip while a dragon is tattooed on her thigh; a bag lady carries around black plastic sacks filled with her most prized possessions, dead pigeons; a murderer called The Zombie preys on homeless people, feeding them crystal-blue Drano before he decapitates them; a legendary practitioner of thuggee kills for the goddess Kali.

title: Belle Potter Wed To John B. Marks, English Teacher
description: Helena Belle Potter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Potter of Plattsburgh, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Bennett Marks, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Marks of Princeton, N.J. Dr. Ned Wolfe Edwards, a cousin of the bride and a Presbyterian minister, and the bridegroom's father, also a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Keene Valley (N.Y.) Congregational Church.

title: As Pitch in Opera Rises, So Does Debate
description: A LITTLE-KNOWN New Jersey opera company is playing an active role in an international debate to lower the reference pitch by which orchestras tune their instruments. The issue is that the reference pitch, the tone A, has gradually risen over the last 200 years and the consequences may be severe for performers and instruments.

title: Packing Memories For Summer Camp
description: TWO days to go. I had started counting in the middle of final exams. When I made that announcement at the breakfast table, my son looked up in surprise and said, ''I can't believe you're actually counting.''

title: No Place Like Home To Operate a Business
description: LEAD: WITHOUT leaving her home, Toni L. Goldfarb publishes a medical newsletter that is read by thousands of subscribers in this country and abroad.

title: Deborah Lee Stashower Has Wedding
description: Deborah Lee Stashower, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Stashower of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Michael Joseph Missal, a son of Judge and Mrs. Harold Missal of Bristol, Conn. Rabbi Robert J. Orkand officiated at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Somalia's Massacres Aren't on TV
description: LEAD: As China's experience demonstrates, a Government that crushes its own people in view of the world's TV cameras will pay the price in international revulsion. The Government of war-torn Somalia, in east Africa, where another human rights disaster is unfolding, took no chances. Journalists have been barred.

title: Hack Wilson, A Big Man
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Churchill
description: To the Editor: A reader requested information about places in England relevant to the life of Sir Winston Churchill (Q & A, May 21). Your interesting response covered sites from his early and career years. May I make Churchill's volume complete by adding a final chapter?

title: Review/Theater; 'Chinese Charade' by Puerto Rican Troupe
description: The New York most visitors never get to is the playing field for the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, an agile bilingual troupe that is spending August performing in mostly working-class neighborhoods of all the boroughs as well as Westchester and New Jersey.

title: Canada
description: To the Editor: If the weather permits, those planning a journey to gain an impression of the unusual flora and landscape of the near Arctic should also plan to engage transport on a power canoe to the shores of James Bay. This can be done during a four-hour visit to Moosenee, the last stop on the Ontario Northland Railroad (''Riding the Polar Bear Express,'' Travel, July 9).

title: Nastiness Is Not a Fantasy In Movie Theme Park War
description: When officials at Universal Studios heard that the Walt Disney Company had ordered three day care centers here to destroy unauthorized murals of Mickey Mouse and his pals, they were ecstatic.

title: Should Gym Be Required?
description: In response to the two Opinion page articles on the issue of continuing the requirement for physical education in schools:

title: Tracking Trains by Computer
description: Introduced in the 1930's, the diesel locomotive revolutionized the rail industry by enabling railroads to run faster trains with smaller crews.

title: Advertising Mail: People Really Want It
description: In response to a letter in the Long Island Weekly of July 16, 1989, regarding receiving too much advertising mail, I realize the frustration with having to discard unwanted mail, especially with Long Island facing serious disposal problems. The courts have held that censoring or otherwise refusing to deliver such mail is beyond the authority granted to the Postal Service by Congress.

title: Fish Decoys Aren't Fooling Collectors
description: As a collectible, the fish decoy has surfaced. It had been a popular item for several years, especially since the publication in 1986 of ''The Fish Decoy'' by Art, Brad and Scott Kimball (Aardvark). Then, on July 9 at the Oliver auction house in Kennebunk, Me., a rare New York piece by an anonymous carver set a world auction record for a fish decoy of $6,600.

title: NOT QUITE ON TOP OF THE WORLD
description: THE NOOSE OF LAURELS Robert E. Peary and the Race to the North Pole. By Wally Herbert. Illustrated. 395 pp. New York: Atheneum. $22.50. A BLACK EXPLORER AT THE NORTH POLE. By Matthew A. Henson. Illustrated. 195 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. Paper, $6.95.

title: Terence Davies Faces His Life a scene from the film with Susan Flanagan, Sally Davies and Nathan Walsh playing three children caught in an air raid during World War II (pg. 23) .
description: ''It's like a foreign country now,'' says the British film maker Terence Davies. ''We must be the most uncivilized, dirtiest, most aggressive, foulmouthed nation in Europe. We are pigs, and we live in a pigsty. Because I love my country, I loathe what it has become.''

title: Alpha and Omega Of Late Van Gogh
description: One of the most spectacular of recent museum acquisitions, and in its field beyond a doubt the most envied, is the portrait by Vincent van Gogh of the postman Joseph Roulin that has just been bought from a Swiss private collection by the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Vinaigrettes Add Variety, Sometimes Sans Vinegar
description: TASTES in salad dressings have shifted in this country. Several decades ago they were primarily sweet and thick. Recently, however, vinaigrette dressings have become extremely popular.

title: Hostetler in Control as Giants Win, 20-17
description: The Giants opened their preseason tonight with a 20-17 victory over the New England Patriots. More important for the Giants, they showed signs of becoming a good pro football team.

title: Bolivia to Seek Anti-Cocaine Money
description: The new President of Bolivia, Jaime Paz Zamora, is expected to insist on more financial aid from the United States and other cocaine-consuming countries to help peasants switch to crops other than coca, the raw material of the drug.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: COCOA BEACH, FLA.;
Old Warehouse Now 96 Condos
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, Arnold Lieberman decided to do something about an eyesore - an office and warehouse building that had stood vacant for 20 years a block from the ocean and a few blocks from the Intracoastal Waterway.

title: Turning Children Into Readers
description: As a public librarian I was greatly interested in the July 9 article ''Developing Children Into Avid Readers.'' I believe that public libraries play a vital role in turning children into avid readers.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: CHINA IS PLANNING 2 YEARS OF LABOR FOR ITS GRADUATES
description: In an effort to rekindle Communist values, the authorities disclosed today that most college graduates will have to work for a year or two in villages or factories before being permitted to enter graduate school.

title: Boston Parents Sue to Block Closing of 5 Schools
description: Furious parents and teachers have filed suit seeking to overturn a Boston School Committee decision to close five schools and consolidate four others. They say the move will leave 4,000 students and 500 teachers unassigned just as the academic year approaches.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending July 29 MANHATTAN Chelsea $275,000 241 West 23d Street 1,700-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; separate kitchen and bath, high ceilings, north exposure; maintenance $518, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Inwood $70,000 585 West 214th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; sunken living room, renovated kitchen and bath, Hudson River view; maintenance $340, 49% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) TriBeCa $300,000 26 Beaver Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; large kitchen, two exposures; maintenance $1,022, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti) Upper East Side $658,000 829 Park Avenue (76th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,700-sq-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, large kitchen, fireplace; maintenance $1,335, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Upper East Side $475,000 111 East 85th Street (Savoy) 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, terrace; maintenance $1,061, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: M.J. Raynes) Washington Heights $139,000 140 Cabrini Boulevard (Castle Village) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, renovated kitchen, Hudson River view; maintenance $599, includes gas and electricity, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: J.H. Taylor) BRONX Riverdale $207,500 301 West 259th Street 2-family, detached frame house; 1 bedroom, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; 1,740-sq. ft. of commercial space on the first floor, 25- by 107-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Charles G. Brophy & Associates) Wakefield $170,000 3624 Bronx Boulevard 2-family, attached frame house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit, 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; full basement, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $995 (Broker: Tryax Realty) BROOKLYN Midwood $265,000 1259 East 35th Street 3-family, semi-attached brick house; 3 bedrooms in 3d floor unit; 2 bedrooms in 2d, 1 bedroom in 1st floor unit; dining room in 3d and 2d floor units; 1 bath, large kitchen in each, 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,539 (Broker: Dwork & Korn) Park Slope $315,000 397 16th Street 3-family, attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each unit; finished basement, 21- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: John P. Barry Realty) QUEENS Forest Hills Gardens $132,500 20 Continental Avenue (Forest Hills Inn Apartments) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 760-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, fireplace, terrace; maintenance $603, 58% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) Jackson Heights $268,000 32-33 92d Street 2-family, attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, dining room in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; finished basement, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,567 (Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Bay Terrace $165,000 90 Bay Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, semi-attached frame house; dining room, sunken living room, finished basement, 21- by 115-ft. lot; taxes $1,175 (Schlott Realtors) Livingston $142,000 104 Delafield Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semiattached frame house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $613 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: Colorama
description: To the Editor:

title: Relativism and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
The Twain Meet in Mamaroneck
description: LEAD: EAST and West certainly meet at this new kind of Japanese restuarant, open little more than a month. Situated near the Mamaroneck Train Station in the building last occupied by Casa de Nicola, the place has been more or less gutted, a tiny five-person sushi bar carved out of a wall and a fresh white coat of paint applied throughout.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Builders Cut Prices as Inventories Grow
description: LEAD: TAKING their cue from private owners who are slashing house prices, builders have begun price-reduction sales to clear out their swelling inventories.

title: What causes accidents and how to stay safe
description: People like to be scared on amusement rides: no one expects real danger. But accidents do occur.

title: Shadow of McCarthyism Still Darkens the Land
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING GOOD IN THE PROMISED LAND
description: KAFFIR BOY IN AMERICA An Encounter With Apartheid. By Mark Mathabane. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Towson, Md.;
Rejuvenating Towson Plaza
description: LEAD: THE rejuvenation and expansion of the Towson Plaza shopping center in this old county seat just north of Baltimore promises to help bring its commercial core back to the prominence it enjoyed before the first rush to the suburbs 30 years ago.

title: Pursuing Pipe Organs of Note
description: WHENEVER I find myself in a city for the first time, I find that the best way to start learning about its history is to visit its churches. In most countries of Europe, historic ecclesiastical masterpieces allow a visitor, for a few moments, to see the world the way the age of faith saw it nearly a thousand years ago. But I have another reason. As Willie Sutton might have said, I go to church because that's where the organ is.

title: A Lockup at the Mental Hospitals
description: ALL 87 criminally insane patients at the state's three mental hospitals, confined to their wards since Aug. 3, are being evaluated by special psychiatrists who will determine which may regain their off-ward privileges.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FIESTA TIME

title: Anne O'Connor, Student, Weds Broker
description: Anne Maura O'Connor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. O'Connor of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter McCargo Standish Jr., a son of Mr. Standish of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Carolyn R. Standish. The Rev. James Halligan officiated at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church.

title: REPTILE, RUN
description: LEAD: DYNAMICS OF DINOSAURS AND OTHER EXTINCT GIANTS By R. McNeill Alexander. Illustrated. 167 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $30.

title: L.I., Growth Years Over, Looking Beyond Defense
description: LEAD: WHEN the United States Department of Labor released figures earlier this month that showed a loss of jobs on Long Island for the first time in 14 years, the numbers were taken as further proof, if any was needed, that the growth years of the 1980's have ended.

title: No Sign of Atomic Reaction Found at Rocky Flats
description: The Energy Department says investigators have found no evidence that an uncontrolled nuclear chain reaction occurred at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant.

title: Ickey and Gizmo and Other Extravaganzas
description: Something weird was happening to the Suspension Bridge that connects Cincinnati to Covington, Ky., and is close by Riverfront Stadium. I was told this last January by a Cincinnati cabdriver on the way to the Bengals' conference championship game against the Buffalo Bills.

title: PLAY IT SMART
description: Kids can be kids this season without looking like their parents or oversized dolls. As the designer interest in children's wear grows, so do the options for stylish young customers. They can play it straight with modern classics, romantic with retro looks, cavalier with casual separates. Cute's out. Attitude's in. Individuality is everything. For children of the city, only the smart stuff goes back-to-school.

title: A Romantic Cellist With a Subversive Bent
description: ''Unfortunately, and unbelievably, Mozart wrote concertos for just about every instrument but the cello,'' lamented the cellist Mischa Maisky, musing on his first appearances at Mostly Mozart, scheduled to take place Friday and Saturday evenings at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Buffalo; SUNY Hopes Shopping Mall Makes Life Easier for Students
description: In an attempt to improve campus life and provide students with services, a $6 million retail complex will be built on the Amherst campus of the State University of New York at Buffalo. But not all the students are thrilled at the prospect.

title: THE SOUTH: Water Country U.S.A. - Williamsburg, Virginia
description: A few miles down the road from Colonial Williamsburg's blacksmiths and craftsmen is a celebration of a 20th-century technological triumph: the plastic water slide. Water Country U.S.A., a 40-acre park, elevates chutes and inner tubes to Disney proportions. Assuming you don't mind parading for hours before strangers in a soggy bathing suit with your stomach bloated from cotton candy and snow cones, you'll enjoy a wondrous variety of ways to be slippery when wet.

title: RADICAL TRANSFORMATIONS
description: David Horowitz and Peter Collier are opportunists of the very worst type, and the attempt to legitimize them as ''born again'' is ludicrous. Particularly revolting is the mental image of Mr. Horowitz ''squeezing back tears'' at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. He, and others of his ilk, shouldn't even be allowed near the place. GEORGE K. SARGENT 3d Chicago

title: Photography Isn't Art
description: To the Editor:

title: RADICAL TRANSFORMATIONS
description: As a former 1960's activist myself (I was a member of Students for a Democratic Society at Columbia University during the student strike of 1968), I find the whole business of born-again anti-Communism to be an elaborate hoax designed to gain attention for a small group of unrepresentative, burnt-out cases (''Radical Transformations,'' by Sharon Churcher, July 16).

title: 'THE DARK FORCES OF LUST': PLATH AT CAMBRIDGE
description: LEAD: By Oct. 2, 1955, Sylvia Plath was writing to her mother from Cambridge, a cloistered community sprawled gracefully along the fennish banks of the Cam. Sylvia was enchanted with its groomed courts and crooked streets. As a foreign graduate at Newnham College, she was an ''affiliated'' student and lived with other outsiders and older students in Whitstead, a small building set apart from the college, on Barton

title: The Many Paths of the H.U.D. Investigation
description: The Reagan years at the Department of Housing and Urban Development were marked by widespread mismanagement, influence peddling and favoritism, recent Congressional hearings and Government reports have revealed. At the center of the investigation is Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Housing Secretary in Mr. Reagan's two terms. He and several H.U.D. officials, particularly an aide, Deborah Gore Dean, awarded some subsidies and lucrative consulting contracts to friends and influential Republicans. Other people used their connections to serve as consultants, helping to secure subsidies or grants for clients or themselves. No Administration figures have been charged with criminal wrongdoing. In other areas, the agency's lax management resulted in losses of funds to bad loans and in some cases fraud. Here is a guide to the main programs under scrutiny, and to many of the former officials and others involved in the inquiries. PROGRAMS WITH PROBLEMS

title: Q and A
description: Removing a Tenant

title: U.S. Health Officials Hopeful On Total Eradication of Polio
description: Rapid progress has been made over the past three years toward eliminating polio from the Western Hemisphere, and leading health officials are optimistic about eradicating it worldwide, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reports.

title: NICARAGUA FACING SHORTAGE OF FOOD
description: When the rainy season comes each May to these rich farmlands, they explode in the brilliant green of Nicaragua's basic food crops - rice, beans, and tall cornstalks that loom over the field workers that tend them.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Bittner Captures Slalom: Armin Bittner of West Germany clocked the fastest time in the first run and held on for the victory yesterday in a World Cup slalom race at the Australian resort of Thredbo. Bittner, 24 years old, the defending World Cup slalom champion, clocked 1 minute 2.52 seconds in the first run over a 74-gate course with a 205-foot vertical drop, and 59.41 seconds in the second, with 72 gates. His combined time was 2:01.93. Ole Kristian Furuseth of Norway was second, .31 seconds behind. Bernhard Gstrein of Austria was third in 2:02.35, and the defending World Cup overall champion, Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg, was fifth in 2:02.81. This weekend's races were the first World Cup events held in Australia.(AP) Tennis Stoltenberg in Final: Jason Stoltenberg of Australia advanced to his first grand prix final last night by defeating Chris Bailey of England, 6-4, 6-3, in the rain-delayed semifinals of the Swiss Army Knife Open in West Orange, N.J. Stoltenberg, ranked No. 113 in the world, scored the biggest upset of the tournament in the second round when he ousted top-seeded Michael Chang in straight sets. (AP)(AP) Navratilova Defeats Garrison: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova swept the last five games to beat Zina Garrison yesterday, 6-1, 6-4, in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tournament in Manhattan Beach, Calif. In today's final, Navratilova will face second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, who defeated fourth-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Skoff and Filippini in Final: Second-seeded Horst Skoff of Austria and fourth-seeded Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay advanced yesterday to the final of the Czechoslovak Open in Prague. Filippini beat Michael Tauson of Denmark, 6-2, 2-6, 6-3. Skoff beat Franco Davin of Argentina, 6-2, 6-2, in the semifinals.(AP) McEnroe and Berger Win: John McEnroe took another step toward regaining the top spot in the tennis ranking by defeating Aaron Krickstein, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday in the semifinals of the United States hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. He won the tie breaker, 8-6.

title: Peter J. Mongeau, Student, Is Wed To Kelley Smith
description: At St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass., Sarah Kelley MacGregor Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Smith 4th of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Chatham, was married yesterday to Peter John Mongeau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice G. Mongeau of Attleboro, Mass., and Narragansett, R.I. The Rev. Paul S. Hunt and the Rev. Mark S. Anschutz performed the ceremony.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?

title: Geraldine Baum, Reporter, to Wed
description: The engagement of Geraldine Emily Baum to Michael Oreskes has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Louise Baum of Fairfield, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Labor of Love
description: One of the most puzzling aspects of the labyrinthine Wedtech affair has been the friendship of former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and his old law school buddy E. Robert Wallach, who once tried to run for the Senate on a platform advocating gay-rights legislation and the decriminalization of marijuana. From the beginning, Mr. Wallach told prosecutors that his letters to Mr. Meese on behalf of Wedtech, a small minority-owned company seeking Government contracts, were part of his lifelong fight against racism. Last week, Mr. Wallach and two co-defendants were convicted of receiving more than $1.5 million in illegal payments from the company.

title: Despite Shoreham's Closing, Energy Alternatives Exist
description: NOW that Shoreham is closed, we must get on with the job of providing Long Island with all the energy it needs for a healthy economy. Five steps can be taken in the months ahead to guarantee new sources of energy for the growth of Long Island into the 21st century.

title: SHE'D RATHER BE IN DANGER
description: VOICES FROM HOME By Neil Caudle. 286 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Judith Miller Ferrell Marries
description: Judith Miller Ferrell, a daughter of Elizabeth Ferrell of Richmond and Robert Ferrell of Houston, was married yesterday in Rockville, Md., to Andrew Firman Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Clark of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Richard W. Burton performed the ceremony at St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Clark, an account executive at PRC, a planning research company in McLean, Va., graduated from Virginia Commonwealth University. The bridegroom, a special agent with the Richmond office of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, graduated from the University of Richmond.

title: Kelly D. MacNeal Becomes a Bride
description: Kelly D. MacNeal, a lawyer who is due to join the New York City Department of Law in September, and Milton L. Williams Jr., an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Tabernacle Missionary Baptist Church in Detroit. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Sampson, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Michael C. LeFevre, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MARRIED LIFE. By David Vogel. Translated by Dalya Bilu. (Grove, $19.95.) Written in Hebrew and published in Palestine in 1929, David Vogel's only novel is the frightening story of the destructive relationship between a penniless Jewish writer and a debased Austrian aristocrat. Rudolf Gurdweill is Baroness Thea von Takow's ''Rabbit,'' willingly suffering humiliation, torment and abuse.

title: THE ANTIQUITIES BOOM
description: One wonders why a smart investor would get into the antiquities market (''The Antiquities Boom: Who Pays the Price?'' by William Grimes, July 16).

description: While major mints turn out dozens of different medals, it's easy to forget that many medals are struck by small organizations.

title: Cat Mutilations Spread Fear of Cults in Suburb
description: The reports of horrible new nocturnal mutilations come almost weekly, the latest last weekend, when a tiger-and-white striped tabby was found in two pieces. Oddly, no one ever hears any noise, and dogs do not bark. There is never any blood on the ground, just a torn feline carcass on the front lawn when the sun rises over Orange County.

title: 3 Farmers Beaten as Youths Leave Nightclub
description: Three farmers setting up their stands at the Union Square Greenmarket yesterday morning were attacked by a group of youths who had left an all-night discotheque, the police said.

title:
GOVERNMENTS, CENSORSHIP AND THE ARTS;
FRANCE: It Is Astute To Favor Creativity

Some families with small children did not go in but no one suggested that the government had abrogated its responsibility by financing the show, which originated in

title: East Berlin Restricts Shooting of Fugitives
description: East German soldiers who have recently deserted to the West have confirmed that East Berlin has ordered border guards not to shoot at escaping civilians except in self-defense.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Saturday Afternoon in Crisis; Colleges Fight To Pay for a U.S. Tradition
description: Well before the first classes of the fall semester, thousands of college football players are beginning their work to extend one of the most traditional, emotional and successful illusions in the American sporting landscape: the weekly sensation that nothing has changed.

title: Why Would Anyone Want to Die in a Hospital?
description: To the Editor:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Lighthouse Hill
description: MOST New Yorkers probably would be surprised to learn there are ''no hunting'' and ''no trapping'' signs within their city. But most New Yorkers have not visited Lighthouse Hill, a pleasant, wooded neighborhood in the center of Staten Island that would be invisible to the rest of the world if it were not for the working lighthouse that crowns the hill, 230 feet above sea level.

title: Cromartie Batting Over .400 in Japan
description: Warren Cromartie, a former Montreal Expo, went 2 for 4 today to raise his batting average to .401, the best in Japanese baseball.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: Nowadays it is quite common to hear the retort, ''that's like comparing apples and oranges,'' to dismiss a speaker out of hand. But chess requires such comparisons of dissimilars in almost every game situation.

title: THE WAY I LIVE NOW
description: As a writer and member of the gay community, and as a person diagnosed with AIDS, I am deeply ashamed of David Leavitt and his belated apology for not becoming involved in the fight against AIDS until now, until 1989, when ACT-UP became famous and it suddenly became fashionable to join the club (''The Way I Live Now,'' July 9). His apology strikes me as a little too late. Mr. Leavitt will be remembered for ignoring our plight and for his hypocrisy. He should have said something years ago. JOEL REDON

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Katherine Solley, Businesswoman, Plans to Marry
description: Katherine Harris Solley, the owner of Biarritz, a dress shop, and David Nathans, a vice president of consumer marketing services at Merrill Lynch & Company, both in Princeton, N.J., are planning a September wedding. Nina Lockwood Solley of Washington, and Thomas Treat Solley of Bloomington, Ind., announced the engagement of their daughter to a son of Twyla Nicklin Nathans of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Dr. Sydney Nathans.

title: Lower Fares, More Service - It Works
description: There is no significant support for a return to the thoroughgoing cartelization and incompetent government management of the airline industry that was practiced before 1978. But one active question remains: Has the reconcentration of the industry at the national level exposed travelers to monopolistic exploitation requiring governmental reintervention?

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Fairfield; New Yearbooks With Live Action Vie for Honors
description: These days college yearbooks can't just sit there; editors believe the productions have to move to attract attention. This has given rise to video yearbooks - enough to occasion a national competition by the Associated Collegiate Press to find the best ones.

title: ABORTION'S 2 SIDES CROWD THE CENTER
description: Legislators and strategists who are playing leading roles on each side of the abortion issue are trying very hard to cast themselves as moderates, hoping the public will conclude that their foes are extremists.

description: For summer interns at the World Bank, the official language isn't German, Spanish, Japanese or English. It's economics and politics, with a slight sociological accent.

title: THE EAST: Great Adventure - Jackson, New Jersey
description: Before me stood the Great American Scream Machine, a long loopy roller coaster that rises like a serpentine monster above the entrance to the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson, N.J. Already, I was hoarse. See, speed is fine. Heights, too. But turning completely upside down? Seven times? While traveling 68 miles an hour?

description: LEAD: BEYOND the clematis-draped antique wood wine press in Tom Skinner's backyard in New Canaan is a vineyard transplanted from California.

title:
Hers;
The Ring Cycle
description: LEAD: I WAS A NORMAL PER-son until my friends started getting engaged. I was happy with simple things like having the uptown bus arrive as soon as I stepped off the crosstown. I was happy if water didn't leak from my bathroom light switch when my neighbor upstairs took a shower. I never needed things that some of my friends claimed they couldn't live without: a car, a dishwasher, a microwave oven.

title: Mary E. Coffey Becomes Bride
description: Mary Elizabeth Coffey and David Michael Solomon were married last evening at the Stronghold Mansion at the Gill/St. Bernard's School in Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Dennis Hogan, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Abraham Krantz officiated.

It provided upsets in the middle rounds, with all the top four seeds going down to defeat, and minor annoyances and major dramas in its concluding stages.

Bernard Kettler, the Mayor of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., officiated. Mrs. Grubb is the daughter of John Kennedy of Warren, Ohio, and the late Margaret Kennedy. Mr. Grubb is the son of Elizabeth Grubb of Walton, Vt., and the late Craig Grubb. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom.

description: LEAD: OLDEST LIVING CONFEDERATE WIDOW TELLS ALL By Allan Gurganus. 718 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.95.

title: Angered by Tax Increases, Residents Seek an Investigation
description: FOR Ada Erik and her extended family, there are certain expectations: a roof over one's head, food on the table and, of course, death and taxes. But in this rural Passaic County community, she says, there are some things she refuses to accept without a fight.

title: OLD GODS AND NAKED WOMEN
description: RUSSIAN FOLK BELIEF By Linda J. Ivanits. Illustrated. 257 pp. Armonk, N.Y.: M. E. Sharpe Inc.

title: Prospects; Behind the Bailout
description: The largest Federal Government bailout in American history was signed into law last week. The rescue of the nation's savings and loan institutions is projected to cost $166 billion over 10 years as insolvent institutions are closed or merged. To raise this money, the Treasury Department will issue bonds. Four experts assess the impact of the bailout on the nation's interest rates. Ralph Nader Consumer Advocate.

title: NONFICTION
description: IMAGINING THE PAST: East Hampton Histories. By T. H. Breen. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) ''We are what we were even when we most passionately reject our own history,'' says T. H. Breen. The Long Island seaside community of East Hampton would seem the last place in America in danger of rejecting its past. ''Share Our Traditions,'' reads the sign in front of a local real-estate agent, and everywhere - in the style of its new homes, in the local shops, in the periodic wars against developers that flare up - can be read the persistence of the past, or, as Mr. Breen sees it, of an image of the past. Brought in as ''Resident Humanist'' to work with the East Hampton Historical Society, Mr. Breen, a professor of American history at Northwestern University, has written less a history of East Hampton than ''a book about history in East Hampton.'' Contrary to the pastoral vision of self-sufficient yeomen advanced by town historians, Mr. Breen traces in the growth and depletion of the local whaling industry a prosperous and often troubled commercial history. The author's deductions - for example, his demonstration of how lawsuits work as a means of establishing social standing in a community - are an interesting behind-the-scenes construction of how historians work. He is particularly adept at drawing broader applications from seemingly narrow issues. ''A little village had proven unable to control the petty animosities among its inhabitants that surely occurred in other towns,'' Mr. Breen observes, after surveying a 17th-century attempt by the town to align itself with Connecticut rather than with New York. ''This is a disturbing thought for anyone who believes that individuals in small groups, expressing their wills through democratic procedures and having access to resources sufficient to maintain their families, can coexist in peace and mutual understanding.''

title: Mayoral Candidates Splurge on TV
description: With less than a month left in a primary campaign constrained by new curbs on fund raising and spending, all four Democratic candidates for mayor have turned to television advertising to widen their appeal to what they agree is a volatile electorate.

description: LEAD: MORE than 300 years after the state's first sawmill was built on the meandering Peconic River and at least a decade after its last duck farm and cranberry bog disappeared, a dispute has arisen over the future of industrial development along the river.

title: THE WEST: Astroworld - Houston, Texas
description: Houston is filled with people who pass Astroworld every day and don't go in. It's just too familiar, sitting there in the middle of residential Houston. Like New Yorkers and the Statue of Liberty, they think of Astroworld as something for someday or something for tourists.

title:
GOVERNMENTS, CENSORSHIP AND THE ARTS;
WEST GERMANY: 'Invariable Backfires' Keep Politicians Away

''Experience has taught them that getting involved in matters of artistic taste, by labeling something pornographic or saying it isn't art, invariably backfires.

description: WITH style, energy and instruments that include the gankogui and the atsimevu, a group called Talking Drums is bringing authentic West African music and dance to auditoriums and classrooms.

title: Dominique Adair Weds
description: Dominique Adair, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Adair of Brooklyn and New Paltz, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Ryker O'Hara, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. O'Hara Sr. of Scranton, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Harvey Marsland, a retired United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the vineyards of the bride's parents in New Paltz. Ms. Adair, who will keep her name, is an account executive with Blumenfeld and Associates, a New York public-relations concern. Mr. O'Hara is a playwright and screenwriter.

The program will go into effect throughout the state beginning in September.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: THE REV. PETER U. LAROM;
