title: A Congenial Chinese Newcomer
description: CHINESE restaurants have traditionally offered good value for families dining out. Even today, when restaurant prices are steadily rising, this continues to be true, as Uncle Dai's, a new Chinese restaurant in downtown Stamford, demonstrates. Uncle Dai's does not put a lot of emphasis on decor. A few pictures, a lacquered screen masking flowers do their bit to dress up a long, drag storefront with red plastic chairs and booths and matching carpet. But what Uncle Dai's lacks in accouterments, it more than makes up for in the congeniality of its service. The menu is described as Sichuan-Hunan, but if you prefer really incendiary food, you will have to request it with insistence. The red-starred ''hot and spicy'' dishes are pleasantly seasoned, but in no way fiery. True to the form of so many other Chinese restaurants in Connecticut, Uncle Dai's breaks no new culinary ground. But within the framework of the all-too-familiar menu, it does a serviceable job of preparing and serving many standbys. It does add one welcome touch, illustrating its willingness to please its customers: it brings dishes in sequence, rather than serving all the appetizers, and then all the entrees at one time. We had requested sequencing the courses Chinese style so that dishes (which all the diners wanted to share) could be savored and enjoyed one or two at a time, without getting cold. Lo and behold! Uncle Dai's complied with our request, a signal that an effort it being made to please the diner, and not simply cater to the convenience of the staff. There is a long list of chef's specialties, similar to other chefs's specialties to be sure, but after trying many of them and other dishes on the regular menu, we would advise following the chef's lead. Surprisingly, they are the same price of just one or two dollars more expensive than the regular entrees. The clear winner among the entrees was dried sauteed beef Sichuan style, which had excellent flavor, and the spicy meat strips played off well against the shredded carrots. Capital chicken, tender white meat pieces with shiitake mushrooms and broccoli, needed more seasoning and additional vegetable textures to overcome its blandness even the crunchy sour taste of its watercress bed was not sufficient help. The seasoning was perfect in the sesame chicken, though - a pleasantly spiced medley of chicken chunks rolled in sesame seeds and served with al dente broccoli. Crispy prawns (jumbo shrimp) with caramelized walnuts were prepared with a light touch, as was a generous portion of sliced duck with scallions in a brown sauce. Tasty appetizers included lively seasoned Sichuan dumplings in red hot oil with a minced port filling, and well-prepared dim sum (tiny steamed dumplings filled primarily with chopped shrimp and water chestnuts). Warm noodles with sesame and hot sauce were also competently prepared. The only serious misstep was an order of scallion pancakes that tasted deep-fried to a tough, tasteless crisp. Tofu Sichuan style with minced pork, deceptively red-starred for hot and spicy, proved innocuously free of spice or flavor and was formless as well. Desserts are mnimal at Uncle Dai's - lichee, pineapple and ice cream. The fragrant pistachio ice cream was studded with pistachios and very tasty. Four appetizers and four entrees came to $54.60, with items left on the platter for the doggy bag. The tax and tip were extra. It is possible to eat for even less, as many entrees run between $6.95 to $8.95. A glass of white wine is offered without charge, as Uncle Dai's does not have a liquor license. While there is nothing exceptional about Uncle Dai's, it serves acceptable Chinese fare at prices that make it possible to feed the family and even assorted guests for modest cost. A few extras - caramelized walnuts served gratis when you arrive and fresh orange wedges and pineapple chunks accompanying forturn cookies at the meal's end - add to the sense of welcome that Uncle Dai's extends. Uncle Dai's Good 109 Atlantic Street, Stamford (between broad and Main Streets). 327-0182. Atmosphere: A long, plain storefront decorated with Chinese art, a lacquered screen and silk flowers, with red booths, chairs and carpet. Service: Cheerful and accommodating. Recommended dishes: Noodles with sesame and hot sauce; Sichuan dumplings in red hot oil; dim sum; dried sauteed beef Sichuan style; sesame beef; sliced duck with scallions; crispy prawn with walnuts; pistachio ice cream. Price range: Lunch entrees $4.25 to $5.75; dinner entrees $5.95 to $13.95. Credit cards: All major cards. Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 10 P.M. Monday through Thursday, 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M. Friday, 1 to 11 P.M. Saturday and 1 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Reservations: Accepted. Wheelchair accessibility: Street-level access. Ratings: Poor Satisfactory Good Very Good Excellent Extraorinary

title: FICTION
description: IN EXTREMIS: And Other Alaskan Stories. By Jean Anderson. (Plover/Talman, $16.95.) The Alaska of Jean Anderson's first collection of short stories is a magical place whose remoteness and harshness make its inhabitants' emotions and relationships stand out in great relief. Many of the characters in ''In Extremis'' discover this truth only after having fled other, seemingly more complicated lives in states such as Texas or California, Ohio or Michigan. But once they've come north, they find that the uncompromising quality of Alaskan existence forces them into strange alliances, bridges that are ultimately as fragile as the ice over a crevasse. The title story, for instance, is narrated by a disgruntled cook on an oil rig who falls in love with an odd young woman. On the night he attempts to seduce her, she reveals a secret that has transformed her life, and that will prevent him from ever again seeing her - or himself - in the same way. Three of the most affecting stories - ''Distance,'' ''Hitchhikers'' and ''Fixing Blame'' - also include encounters, either violent or bizarre, that permanently alter the characters' images of themselves and the people they love. Although these catalysts give Ms. Anderson's work much of its power, they are sometimes so obscure or whimsical (a woman, for example, deciding to divorce her husband because of a blessing given her by a vagrant) that they seem mere literary devices. But at its best, this collection captures the heartbreak that afflicts only those who have already traveled as far as they can go.

title: Anne McDonald, Student, Is Bride
description: Anne Marie McDonald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McDonald of Jersey City, and Edward Hartnett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hartnett of Jersey City, were married there yesterday at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Kenneth R. Letoile performed the ceremony.

description: A New Airline Will Take Off In Hawaii

Coverage Tops In Cycling Tour
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Relativism and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaching for the Roller Hall of Fame
description: While heading the other day toward the Racer, a monstrous wooden roller coaster at Kings Island amusement park near Cincinnati, Donald Helbig's pace quickened and his expression brightened noticeably. ''It's like a second home for me,'' Mr. Helbig said.

title: Folks, Where Did You Go?
description: FIRST they pull the rug out from under you. Then they sell it at a garage sale.

title: FLOOR WARS
description: When I was a child, I used to dig for worms in the garden.

title: Nancy P. Trout, Physician, Weds
description: St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dr. Nancy Patricia Trout, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Trout of Old Greenwich, Conn., to Dr. Peter Joseph Doelger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Doelger of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Charles Stubbs performed the ceremony.

title:
LIFE STYLE;
Enlarging The World Of Disabled
description: LEAD: About a year and a half ago, Julie Brown, who is now 7 years old, was becoming nervous, depressed and unsure of herself. Born with spina bifida, she was afraid to use her wheelchair on the slightest uneven ground and even worse, her mother said, she sometimes worried that she might never be able to drive or have a job.

title: What's In It For Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Brokers
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MINNEAPOLIS;
Inner City Bargains
description: LEAD: IN an attempt to revive and stabilize its deteriorating Hawthorne neighborhood, this city is subsidizing the below-cost sale of 21 new single-family homes there.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office Construction; Despite High Vacancy Rates, Buildings Keep Going Up
description: EVEN though cities across the nation are burdened with too much vacant office space, developers are continuing to put up new buildings. And they have a good shot at success because many existing buildings are easy prey for new competition.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: GEORGE STERNLIEB;
Unorthodox Views on State's Economy
description: LEAD: KNOWN for an independent outlook unfettered by bureaucratic thinking, George Sternlieb has some unorthodox views on New Jersey's economy. A professor of urban and regional planning at Rutgers University and founder of that university's Center for Urban Policy Research, he is a prolific writer and a widely sought consultant on economic issues involving the state, the region and the nation.

title: Poland's Foreign Fix
description: In December 1987, William D. Hanna arrived here with Yogi Bear and Magilla Gorilla. Accompanied by employees dressed as the cartoon characters, Mr. Hanna came to Warsaw to inaugurate a joint venture that his company, Hanna-Barbera Productions Inc., the American cartoon giant, set up with American and Polish partners. The idea was to make cartoons in Poland for sale in the West.

title: THE LATE GREAT AWAKENING
description: LEAD: WOMEN TOGETHER, WOMEN ALONE The Legacy of the Consciousness-Raising Movement. By Anita Shreve. 275 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Polish Premier Calls For Talks to Break Impasse on Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak called today for talks with the Solidarity leadership to try to break the deadlock over his efforts to form a Communist-led coalition government.

title: Shuttle Crew Prepares for a Landing Today
description: Astronauts on the shuttle Columbia ended experiments and checked flight controls today as they prepared to land in California Sunday.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. JOHNSBURY, VT.;
Industrial Park Picks Up Steam
description: LEAD: AFTER a five-year lull, development appears to be picking up at the industrial park in this former railroad city about 40 miles from Canada.

title: A Pitch for Japanese Pines, Or They May Not Be Around
description: WITH the aid of a chainsaw blade longer than our fireplace mantle, we have achieved around our A-frame home the elusive ''feeling of space'' that architects, landscape designers and psychotherapists all agree is so crucial to our sense of well-being. One of Long Island's favorite, albeit non-indigenous, trees is to blame.

title: CALIFORNIA SCREAMING
description: THE RAINBOW STORIES By William T. Vollmann. 541 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: POSTINGS: An Ice Storm Casualty; Restoring a 1680's Tidal Grist Mill
description: When a group of people from Lynn, Mass. - led by a woman named Nan Heatherton - settled on Long Island's North Shore in the 1680's, one of their first tasks after planting crops was to erect a mill to grind their grain. At what came to be known as Mad Nan's Neck, now called Saddle Rock, the settlers dammed a pond adjoining Little Neck Bay and built a tidal grist mill. Flood tide filled the pond, and the sluice gate was closed. As the tide ebbed, the gate was opened and the water was led through the mill race, turning its wheel.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Low-Fat, Low-Guilt Pasta
description: In 1977, an event called Food Day was celebrated at the White House with a vegetarian meal. It gave some Americans the idea that a meatless meal was not just for vegetarians.

title: Please, May I See the Doctor?
description: SO you're not feeling well? Feverish? Dizzy? Nauseous? Poor thing. Want to make an appointment with your doctor? Of course. Ask yourself first if you're ready to do battle with your doctor's office receptionist for a decent appointment.

title: ATLANTA WEIGHING TRANSIT EXPANSION
description: Ten years after gleaming silver trains started rolling on the South's first rapid-transit system, a quarter of a million passengers a day travel on a 1,582-mile network of 150 bus routes and two rail lines with 29 stations.

title: Women As Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Tambo, A.N.C. Head, Is Said To Have Suffered a Stroke
description: Oliver Tambo, president of the African National Congress, has had a stroke and has been flown to Britain for treatment, people close to the movement said today.

title: Shoreham: The Story That Won't Go Away
description: What is it that keeps the Shoreham power plant all over the newspapers, radio and television? Why won't the story die?

title: ON THE LOOSE IN THE HOLY CITY
description: AMERICA'S ROME By William L. Vance. Illustrated. Volume One: Classical Rome. 454 pp. Volume Two: Catholic and Contemporary Rome. 498 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $30 each.

title: Mary Kay Lacey Marries
description: Mary Kay Lacey, a daughter of Mrs. Patrick Lacey of Fresno, Calif., and the late Mr. Lacey, was married yesterday to Stephen Frederick Henry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Henry of Waccabuc, N.Y. Judge Donald Rosenberg of Oakland, Piedmont and Emeryville Municipal Court in Oakland, Calif., officiated at the ceremony at Grammas Bed and Breakfast in Berkeley, Calif. The bride, who will keep her name, and bridegroom are lawyers; she is an associate with Sonnenschein, Carlin, Math & Rosenthal, and he is an associate with Thornton, Taylor & Downs, both in San Francisco.

title: Eleanor Scott Wed to Eric Lombardi
description: Eleanor Wells Scott, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. Denman Scott of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday to Eric Volk Lombardi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Lombardi of Dallas. The Rev. Daniel Burke, assisted by Canon Delbert W. Tildesley, performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church.

title: SHADES OF GRAY/GREY
description: Is it grey or gray (On Language: ''Shades of Gray/ Grey,'' July 16)? William Safire could have spared himself the extended exercise if he had simply followed the dictum of Andrew Jackson: ''It is a damned poor mind indeed which can't think of at least two ways of spelling any word.'' SID ESTEROWITZ Brooklyn

title:
Body and Mind;
Fixing a Child's Heart
description: LEAD: THIS IS HER 13TH year. Puberty has barely touched her.

title: Turning Children Into Readers
description: There is an excellent and often under-used resource for combating illiteracy - the children's department of the local public library.

title: Judith Stern Is Betrothed
description: September wedding plans for Judith Deborah Stern and David Stanton Lobel have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gershon Stern of Montreal and New York. Mr. Lobel is a son of Esther Lobel and the late Bernard Lobel of Johannesburg. Ms. Stern will be an associate in October with the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Mr. Lobel is a general partner of First Century Partners, a venture capital and leveraged buyout affiliate of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York.

title: Learning the Language of Dudicals and Dweebs
description: ADULTS who try to bridge the gap with teen-agers by using a phrase like totally awesome, risk sounding more like a dweeb than a dudical, says Karen Forcade, president of Youth Research, a marketing research company in Brookfield.

title: ILL, OR JUST THE BLAHS?
description: Sorry, but I don't buy Bruce H. Dobkin's program of physical reconditioning and antidepressant therapy (Body and Mind: ''Ill, or Just the Blahs?'' July 16). Chronic Fatigue Syndrome sufferers aren't merely tired, they're sick, with an attendant bag of insidiously persistent flu-like symptoms. Dr. Dobkin's comparing his own faltering steps after a self-limiting viral illness (Hong Kong flu) with the protracted debilitation of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome is as unfair as suggesting polio (also a virus) victims get out of their wheelchairs and take a hike.

title: Violent Crimes Increase by 5.5% For 1988, Establishing a Record
description: The number of of violent crimes reported nationwide in 1988 increased 5.5 percent from the previous year to a new high, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has said.

title: For a Summer Spoof, Darien's 'Dames at Sea'
description: DESPITE what might have possessed the Darien Dinner Theater's producer, Jane Bergere, to put on a summer-stock season of three musicals, so far it is not working.

title: McPherson Stars for Eagles
description: Don McPherson threw two fourth-quarter touchdown passes, giving the Philadelphia Eagles a 23-17 preseason victory over the Atlanta Falcons tonight.

title: American Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan, the Next Middle East Crisis?
description: LEAD: King Hussein of Jordan spent 10 days last month in a London clinic, undergoing medical exams. The royal palace in Amman was quick to report that ''no pathological findings'' were discovered. The Palace pronounced the King's health as ''fine.'' This only stirred speculation.

title: Susanna Leonard To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Susanna Leonard to Eric J. Hill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Hill of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and Fort Pierce, Fla., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. E. Deane Leonard of New York and Stanfordville, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: Skitch Henderson in an Informal Recital
description: WHEN pianists come to Merryall Center, the performance hall on the banks on the West Aspetuck River in New Milford, they perform on a Steinway grand borrowed for the season from one of the center's neighbors, the conductor Skitch Henderson. On Saturday, Mr. Henderson and his piano will be reunited for ''An Evening With Skitch Henderson,'' as he plays and reminisces about his life as concert performer, television performer, symphony conductor and New York Pops founder.

title: Magazine Writer Enters the Ring
description: WILLIAM PLUMMER makes a wonderful guest at a dinner party. He can speak informatively about the breakup of Sean Penn and Madonna. He has walked the Inca Trail. Interested in the psyche of a Vietnam veteran who hunts panthers in the Everglades? Ask Mr. Plummer.

title: William Mitty Jr., Physician, 67
description: Dr. William F. Mitty Jr., professor of surgery at New York University School of Medicine, died of a heart attack Wednesday while vacationing in Puerto Rico. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes
description: Long reviled by American music critics, Soviet ideologists and parents everywhere, the thundering hordes of Western heavy-metal rock found respect today in Lenin Stadium - as ambassadors of peace and temperance.

title: Looking for Chemistry and Good Omens
description: On Oct. 25, 1986, at 3 P.M. Los Angeles time, I got married. Two hours later, as I toasted my new bride, Heather, at the reception, Game 6 of that year's World Series was beginning back home in New York. How I wanted to be there!

title: PERUVIAN FARMERS RAZING RAIN FOREST TO SOW DRUG CROPS
description: Driven by American and European demand for cocaine, Peruvian coca growers have chopped down large stretches of Amazon rain forest and are dumping millions of gallons of toxic chemicals into its highlands and headwaters.

title: After the Races, Partygoers Speed Saratoga's Pace
description: In August, partygoers in Saratoga run almost as fast as the horses. Two of the splashiest events are for the benefit of museums in Saratoga, the National Museum of Dance and the National Museum of Racing.

title: On Language; The Elision Fields
description: Gunna sometimes >gonna) is epidemic in spoken English,'' reads a postcard from John Jakes, the novelist. ''I hear it in everyday conversation (my own included, alas). I hear it from esteemed TV commentators. It will be in the dictionary soon.''

title: Blazing Unfamiliar Trails
description: IT was a peaceful Sunday morning in the Alsatian town of Barr. A fine rain was falling on the vineyards covering the long slope down to the Rhine. Trains, cars, river boats and planes, incessant traffic, passed in the misty distance.

title: Open Mind Does the Impossible
description: Marshall Cassidy, the announcer at Saratoga Race Track, got the stunned reaction of the crowd just right today when he announced the results of the $232,400 Alabama Stakes.

title: Disagrees on Roots Of Dependency
description: A statement by Sandra Bernabei [ Westchester Q&A, July 23 ] requires a massive correction. In answering whether chemical dependency running in families is ''genetic or environmental,'' she comes down unequivocally on genetic, based upon the incidence in children of drug- and alcohol-users.

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: Patrick Smith is to be the timpani soloist with the Bronx Arts Ensemble in the Timpani Concerto in D by the Italian Baroque composer Giuseppe Jacchini, today at 2 P.M. at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and Mosholu Avenue in the Bronx. The program is to be repeated at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall at the Bronx Rose Hill campus of Fordham University. Free admission. Information: 549-1899.

title: Why Not a Festival of Balanchine Discards?
description: The works of George Balanchine are the treasures of the New York City Ballet. And because Balanchine was a prolific choreographer who bestowed his creations upon many troupes, his ballets can be seen from coast to coast; they are among the glories of American dance. Yet, our dance scene could be even richer in Balanchine.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: St. Johnsbury, Vt.;
Industrial Park Picks Up Steam
description: LEAD: AFTER a five-year lull, development appears to be picking up at the industrial park in this former railroad city about 40 miles from Canada.

title: Homeless Enabled to Vote
description: To insure the voting rights of the homeless, Maine has adopted a policy allowing people to register to vote even if they have no residence other than a park bench. ''To the best of our knowledge, Maine is the only state to handle it in this manner'' without pressure from the courts, said Richard Pinner of the New York-based National Coalition for the Homeless. The estimates of homeless people living in Maine range from 500 to 2,000.

title: Affordable Homes Without State Help
description: LEAD: MAKING an end run around a state program that they say is too costly, officials in this industrial city of 40,000 people about 50 miles west of Boston have joined with private developers to build low-cost housing and sell about 100 units at below-market rates.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CAPITAL CRIMES. By Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $19.95.) In his latest novel, the author of ''The Fourth Deadly Sin,'' ''The Eighth Commandment'' and ''The Timothy Files'' sets a sex-crazed faith healer in the midst of Washington society, where he casts a spell over the nation's first family, whose son he seems to have cured of hemophilia.

title: POSTINGS: Warring Owners Agree; Brokerage for Sale
description: The owners of Douglas Elliman - a leader in the business of selling Manhattan co-ops and managing expensive apartment buildings - have decided to settle their differences by selling the 78-year-old company. The sole shareholders, Lawrence P. McGauley and Edwin J. Gould, fell into battle after Mr. McGauley, the hands-on chief for more than a decade, sparked upheaval and defections by dismissing a top executive a year ago. Mr. Gould, a resident of Palm Beach and descendant of the 19th-century railroad baron Jay Gould, first put his support behind Mr. McGauley, but then began exploring legal maneuvers to oust him. Now the two men have made peace and retained Lambert Brussels Capital Corporation of Manhattan to find a buyer.

title: Folk Festival and Dance at Wave Hill
description: IN Riverdale, the Wave Hill Performing Arts Series is off to an early start, with dance programs and a daylong folk festival this week and next.

title: Search Methods Make a Difference In Picking VCR's
description: To find a particular scene or segment on a video cassette, many viewers just run the tape back and and forth until they find the spot. This method is slow, frustrating, rough on the tape and hard on the hardware. With all the search and indexing devices available on modern VCR's, such haphazard hunting isn't necessary. Yet, oddly enough, many viewers don't realize that there are easier ways. That's why a brief rundown on various search methods might prove helpful.

title: Glasgow
description: To The Editor: ''What's Doing in Glasgow'' mentions Saturday mornings ''on Byres Road, a bustling byway near the 15th-century towers of Glasgow University.'' While Byres Road is filled with activity, often that of university students, the towers of Glasgow University are not 15th century.

title: ATHLETICS WIN 2D GAME IN A ROW FROM ANGELS
description: Mark McGwire belted a home run and drove in three runs as the Oakland Athletics beat California, 8-3, today for their second consecutive victory over the Angels. Oakland took a two-game lead in the American League West.

title: Milestones for a Modern Teen-Ager
description: WHEN the children were little, really little, we worried, as do all young parents, about their attaining the ''milestones'' that were set forth in the learned texts. Achievements like turning over in the crib, crawling and the first tooth were all supposed to happen at precisely specified times. If little Jeffrey or Melissa missed one of the milestones, intense pediatric reassurances were required to prevent the parents from breaking down.

title: When Old Players Raise Some Hackles
description: Mike Shannon remembers the day he suddenly found himself lumped into that species known as journalisticus electronicus jockus.

title: The $6 Million Man
description: Larry Bird, who missed most of last season after foot surgery, will become the first athlete in any team sport to earn more than $6 million in a year, sources told The Associated Press yesterday.

title: Margaret Frances Picotte Is Married To Thomas MacClarence in Albany
description: At the Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart in Albany, Margaret Frances Picotte, a daughter of John W. Picotte of Albany and Mrs. William D. Hassett Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Hoagland MacClarence, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. MacClarence of Westport, Conn. The Rev. John H. Mealey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Ins and Outs of New York
description: Why is Elmont outside New York City, while St. Albans, on the other side of the city line, is in? Why did Douglaston become a part of the metropolis while the adjacent area called University Gardens remained part of Great Neck?

title: Cone Defeats Cardinals 2 Ways
description: Davey Johnson has enough trouble trying to figure out how to cut the Chicago Cubs' 4 1/2-game lead; he doesn't need another problem. But he has one: what to do with David Cone.

title: RAGE AND SADNESS IN NIGERIA
description: STARS OF THE NEW CURFEW By Ben Okri. 194 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Father Confesses to Killing His 4 Children
description: A man has confessed that he intentionally crashed his family's car through a barrier and into the Detroit River to kill his wife and children, the police said on Friday. All four children drowned.

title: The Television Europeans Love, And Love to Hate
description: ARE reruns of ''The A Team'' giving European children belligerent attitudes? Is ''Falcon Crest'' spreading the gospel of American materialism? Those are some of the questions the European Community is considering as it debates whether to impose quotas on the number of American programs that can be shown on European television.

title: When the Neighbor Is a Theater With a Vision
description: It is tempting to think of New York theater largely in terms of Broadway and Off Broadway. But another aspect of theater has been quietly asserting itself; less glamorous, it aims to have deeper consequences. This is theater as teacher, attempting to raise the quality of life (and often the consciousness) of a community or group of people, and through them reaching out to the rest of New York.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Last month I had a chance to test my action-stopping prowess at a day-long gathering of mountain bikers. The activities involved such odd diversions as pulling a sled loaded with cement blocks and attempting to pedal through a bog without dismounting. But my personal favorite, in photographic terms, was a time-trial circuit that featured a mud-puddle finale.

title: BASEBALL: Notebook; The Pennant Dash: Who Has the Resources to Finish Strong?
description: A year ago, the Mets ran away from the rest of the National League East with a six-week sprint. But they began that short race, baseball's version of the 100-yard dash, with an advantage: They already had a 3 1/2-game lead.

title: American Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; An Update on Caring for the Lawn
description: This has been an unusual year for lawns. Spring started out dry and there were dire predictions of drought. Then the rains came, and more rains, and cool growing weather. This turn of events was followed by an unusual summer, which so far, has had more than an adequate amount of rainfall. In ordinary seasons, lawns go dormant and turn brown at this time of year, but the grass has remained green.

title: Children's Food; Test Cases
description: My wife, Nancy, has a great job. I know this because whenever she mentions it to people they always say, ''What a great job!'' She's a recipe-tester, and, well, it is a good job. I mean, who's to complain about having to eat lobster and corn soup, shrimp in black bean sauce, tea-smoked duck breast, tuna carpaccio, chicken curry Portuguese style or strawberry and blueberry tart with almond cream?

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; In Connecticut, a Valley of History
description: A drive through the meandering back roads and clapboard villages of the Connecticut River Valley reveals an area rich in maritime history, largely undisturbed by the flow of time. But unlike its neighboring cities in southeastern Connecticut, where large museums and shopping areas are the main attractions, the valley's top tourist asset is a natural one, the long tidal Connecticut River, which snakes down from Canada for 410 miles and spills into the Long Island Sound.

title: THE EAST: Dorney Park - Allentown, Pennsylvania
description: Uphill or down, wherever you wander in Dorney Park, you're never far from The Sound: that primordial squeal, accompanied by a percussive clatter and ratchety basso profundo, that is the aria of passengers caught in the killer drop of a classic wooden roller coaster.

title: Allene R. Smith Becomes Bride
description: Allene Robinson Smith and Peter Alexander Cooley, who are planning to attend the Stanford Graduate School of Business next month, were married yesterday at St. James's Episcopal Church in Wilmington, N.C., by the Rev. Robert D. Cook.

title: Twins Escape From the Yankees
description: In many ways, today's Yankee game followed the pattern of the club's entire season. The Yanks let an opposing pitcher who looked ready to be beaten escape with a victory. In doing so, they squandered an opportunity to win 2 consecutive road games and to build momentum on a crucial 10-game road trip.

title: Tougher Reggae Puts Jamaica Back on the Map
description: The death of Bob Marley in 1981 was a great equalizing event in reggae. His music, a mixture of bass-heavy rhythms, lovely and lilting melodies and often overt political messages presented a monolithic vision of Jamaican culture to the world.

title: After 60 Years, Stratford Finds a Use For Its Airport
description: IN the early 1920's, Stratford welcomed the City of Bridgeport's purchase of 800 acres on Lordship Point for an airport. At the time, there was little use for the flat land, much of it salt marsh. But in recent years the relationship has not been so rosy.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Utah; Burning of Flag Leads to Fight And Court Case
description: A former vice president of the student body at the University of Utah who took part in the burning of an American flag has accused a Vietnam veteran of assault. The veteran, Dale H. Osborne, was found to be carrying a loaded .38-caliber revolver.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Kings Park $190,000 83 Orchid Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, basement, attic, 2-car garage; taxes $4,500. Massapequa $206,000 115 Massapequa Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old split level; new kitchen, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. Seaford $169,000 3860 Lincoln Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. Selden $98,000 119 Highview Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, attic; taxes $749. Smithtown $179,000 5 Parnell Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; den w/fireplace, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,900. Westbury $175,000 15 Walnut Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; basement, attic, enclosed porch; taxes $2,700. OTHER AREAS Sherman, Conn. $178,000 Brinsmade Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; hardwood floors, 2 fireplaces, deck; taxes $1,378. Larchmont, N.Y. $550,000 50 Beach Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, beach and mooring rights; taxes $9,995. Ocean Grove, N.J. $164,000 18 New York Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old Victorian; patio, 2-car garage, w/w carpeting; taxes $975.

title: Abby Sher: Museum Founder
description: Abby Sher, daughter of a developer who built shopping centers in Orange County, Calif., remembers conversations about ''tenant mix'' at the family dinner table. So when visitors attend the inaugural show of the Santa Monica (Calif.) Museum of Art on Sept. 15 - a museum she founded within a shopping complex she developed - they can, for example, browse at a shop among artifacts from Indonesia, India and Egypt and switch on art lights at the Gallery of Functional Art.

title: A Palladian Journey in Vicenza
description: PALLADIO himself could not have designed a better view of the subtle symmetry of his 16th-century Villa La Rotonda than from a four-seater plane high in the sky above the province of Vicenza in northeastern Italy. La Rotonda, the architect's most celebrated building, appears as a giant crab grasping its Berici hillock at its highest and most logical point. Nearby, some of the province's other Palladian villas - Pisani, Malinverni, Piovene, Poiana and Saraceno - nestle naturally into the landscapes. Sublime architecture, they are also brilliant sculpture. (Vicenza's villas are among 25 that are scattered throughout the larger Veneto region.) Flying high in this judgmental fourth dimension, one almost hears the music of Mozart's opera ''Don Giovanni,'' filmed at La Rotonda in 1981. Suddenly, there's another voice, that of the pilot, Maurizio Perolin, who regularly flies the nine planes of Vicenza's Aero Club that are available to tourists on sightseeing flights and to licensed pilots..

title: Lilco Annuls Accord That Allowed Fox Hunt
description: LEAD: THE fox hunt may still be on, but the Long Island Lighting Company will no longer be a party to such pursuits. A Lilco spokesman, Ray Golden, said the utility has annulled a recently-negotiated agreement with the Smithtown Hunt Club to allow a modified form of fox hunting on its properties in Shoreham and

title: Shenandoah
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a week around the Shenandoah Valley, we were glad to see ''Roaming the Shenandoah Valley'' (Travel, June 25).

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: It is difficult to determine to what extent the Yankees' losing record and poor pitching can be attributed to Dallas Green. But it is incomprehensible to have Roberto Kelly, with the team's highest batting averge as well as its highest on-base percentage, bat ninth. Surely, a .330 hitter batting further up in the lineup will have more at bats and, therefore, increase his team's run production. Do Wade Boggs, Tony Gwynn, or Carney Lansford bat last? DAVID I. KASS Washington

title: Japan Intl.
description: To the Editor:

title: Seizing the Sheik: A Tragic Blunder Or a Key to Solutions?
description: ISRAELI reporters were laying in wait when Marrack Goulding, the United Nations special envoy in the hostage crisis, left Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin's office last Tuesday.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 13, 1989
Jennifer Meagher to Wed K. P. Convery
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Coupe Meagher of Hyde Park, N.Y., and Waitsfield, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Crimmins Meagher to Kevin Patrick Convery, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Convery of East Brunswick, N.J. A Sept. 9 wedding is planned.

title: The Sweater Girl's Back (in a Cardigan)
description: The cardigan sweater is enjoying a resurgence of popularity among young women who are adapting its simple, classic look in new contexts.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE FRONTIER OF LOYALTY: Political Exiles in the Age of the Nation-State. By Yossi Shain. (Wesleyan University, $25.95.) Political exiles are, arguably, the most passionately committed of all political dissidents. Unlike members of a ''loyal opposition'' seeking political reform from within a nation's borders, or refugees who attempt to create a new life in a new country, political exiles are suspended in a kind of ideological limbo. While they are removed from their homelands, their activities are all directed toward the old country with one singular goal: overthrowing the existing regime. Unfortunately, Yossi Shain's study captures little of the force that drove people into exile and caused them to dedicate their lives to their causes. ''The Frontier of Loyalty'' fails to delineate any underlying theme that ties together the groups it purports to study, such as Cuban exiles in Miami and Loyalists in the Spanish Civil War. More glaringly absent is any sense of the intense human passion that drove these exiles. Mr. Shain's overuse of secondary sources may be responsible for the essentially lifeless character of this book. It originated as a doctoral dissertation and, as such, it is bogged down with attempts to fit the information into theoretical concepts. Mr. Shain, now a lecturer in political science at Tel Aviv University, apparently felt his professors looking over his shoulder. The story of political exiles deserves a far more engaging treatment than it receives here.

title: 'The Wizard of Oz,' in Toto
description: The powerful hold THE WIZARD OF OZ exerts on adults and children alike owes much to the fact that it blends the best of two film worlds - children's movies and musicals - with an astonishing naturalness. For the 50th anniversary of the movie, MGM/UA Home Video has released a limited-edition videocassette ($24.95) in which the Kansas prologue and epilogue are hued in the sepia used in the first theatrical prints of the film, and the Oz scenes in juicy, restored Technicolor.

title: Catherine A. Midkiff Wed
description: Catherine Ann Midkiff, a daughter of Shirley Midkiff of Silver Spring, Md., and John Midkiff of Nashville, was married yesterday to the Rev. Irwin M. Lewis Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. Charles Vache, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Southern Virginia, performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Church in Newport News, Va., assisted by the Revs. Edwin Gulick and James L. Hutton 3d. Mrs. Lewis, a cum laude graduate of Marshall University, is the marketing director of Sierra Communications in Norfolk, Va. Mr. Lewis, a graduate of the College of William and Mary where he also received a master's degree in special education, has a master's degree in divinity from the Virginia Theological Seminary. He is the rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Hampton, Va.

title: For South Africa, a Diplomatic Riddle
description: A potential diplomatic breakthrough from South Africa's regional isolation has set off a debilitating new crisis in the governing National Party three and a half weeks before national elections.

title: Domestic Architecture in Yonkers
description: A DOCUMENTARY composed of photographs, maps, diagramatic drawings and books, ''Yonkers Architecture'' at the Hudson River Museum, sounds like parochial ''filler.'' But it is not, and the reason is the book that it is based on - ''Landmarks Lost and Found: An Introduction to the Architecture and History of Yonkers'' by Michael Rebic.

title: BRITAIN: The Censorship Of Omission
description: Many in the arts say that government philistinism is unraveling a vibrant tapestry of artistic treasures and creativity.

title: MGM/UA Gives A Menu to Hungry Viewers
description: Ralph Tribbey sounds hard pressed. ''They want whatever we can release,'' he says, ''and they want it now.'' Mr. Tribbey is a vice president of MGM/UA Home Video. ''They'' are us, and what we want are movies, scores of them, all kinds of movies never released on video and just sitting in MGM/UA's library of some 4,000 titles. ''The Prisoner of Zenda,'' for instance, ''Moulin Rouge,'' ''The Blackboard Jungle,'' ''Sweet Bird of Youth,''

title: Joan Fitzgerald Marries C. V. Clarke
description: Joan Reid Fitzgerald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Fitzgerald of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Vincent Clarke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Clarke Jr. of Southport, Conn. Msgr. Donald Pryor performed the ceremony at Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Rye.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
SUBWAYS WERE FOR PAINTING
description: LEAD: Bums gathered around the fountain in Union Square Park and young working women riding the subway acquire a Rubenesque grandeur in the paintings, drawings and etchings assembled in ISABEL BISHOP (Rizzoli, $45). In his foreword to this collection of the major works of Bishop, who died last year at the age of 85, John Russell, chief art critic for The New York Times, praises Bishop's unique ability to blend the monumentality of 17th-century European painting with a distinctly

title: THE MIDWEST: Cedar Point - Sandusky, Ohio
description: ''When they hit the seat - that's when they chicken out.'' Jack T. Falfas, director of operations at Cedar Point, was describing how dozens of people wait nearly two hours on weekends to ride the theme park's newest roller coaster, the Magnum XL-200, only to bail out at the last minute. What sends them scurrying down the exit ramp is the sight of the Magnum's first hill - a stomach-churning, 20-story incline followed by a sheer, 60-degree drop that hurtles riders through the coaster's dips and curves at 70 miles an hour. It's no wonder many riders look like condemned convicts heading for the gallows when the Magnum begins its initial awesome ascent. ''Sometimes, people are so afraid that they scream bloody murder and I have to stop the ride and pull them off,'' Mr. Falfas added.

title: CRIME
description: Pounding home on his fourth Thoroughbred mount, THE KING OF THE NIGHTCAP (Bantam, $16.95), William Murray bumps Dick Francis at the three-quarter pole and prances into the winner's circle to the ecstatic cheers of his fans.

title: 5 Topless Sunbathers Arrested
description: LEAD: THE beaches in Southampton Village enjoy a fine reputation. Some are well known and easily accessible; others are secluded and tucked away from major arteries.

title: U.A.W. Has Trouble Shifting Gears
description: THE recent failure of the United Auto Workers to organize at Nissan Motor Manufacturing USA's assembly plant in Smyrna, Tenn., raises issues that are troubling for both the union and the Big Three automakers. Can workers and management develop the cooperative strategies necessary to compete with the Japanese on American soil?

title:
GARDENING;
Overcoming Pests at Harvest Time
description: LEAD: TO some gardeners, raspberries and blueberries are literally for the birds. About the time they ripen to that mouthwatering stage when they are ready to pick, every bird in the neighborhood with a taste for the fruit zeros in on the patch, and a gardener will be lucky to get even a taste for all the effort expended in pruning, fertilizing, watering and mulching.

title: Waiting for a Nursing-Home Bed
description: IN virtually every community hospital in Westchester, elderly people no longer in need of hospitalization are living in a setting intended for acutely ill patients.

title: Center-Right in Chile Agrees on a Candidate
description: The major parties of the center-right and the right have agreed to unite behind the presidential candidacy of former Finance Minister Hernan Buchi.

title: TALKING: Insiders; Inheriting The Right To Buy
description: WHEN the tenant of a rent-regulated apartment in New York City dies while a building is being converted to cooperative or condominium ownership, does the tenant's estate retain the right to buy that apartment at the below-market insider price? And if someone was living in that apartment with the tenant at the time of death, does that person inherit the right to purchase at the insider price?

title: Inner (and Lesser) Circles
description: WHEN George Bush was running for for President, he held a gathering in Farmington to which the faithful from around Connecticut were invited - provided they donated $1,000 to the cause. They got to meet the Bushes before sitting down to a haphazardly prepared lunch at which Mr. Bush gave a ringing speech exhorting the faithful to turn out the vote.

title: A Robin's Nest: Equilibrium Lost
description: MORE rain had been predicted for the rest of the day and the sky outside my bedroom window was indeed gray. But I awoke contented and ready to tackle whatever came my way. Then, glancing out a daughter's window, I discovered that the robin's nest and its three newly hatched nestlings was gone.

title: High Jumping Into the Past
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Apologies To the Kirov
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Titus Andronicus,' A Pursuit of Horror
description: IT'S the summer of ''Titus Andronicus.'' No longer relegated to obscurity, Shakespeare's earliest and bloodiest tragedy is currently slaying them, as the saying goes, at the New Jersey, New York and Stratford (Ontario) Shakespeare Festivals after a recent production by the Royal Shakespeare Company.

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: Dallas Green is doing an excellent job considering that he must deal with George Steinbrenner. It truly matters not who manages the Yankees or how much money is spent on the players. As long as ''Mr. Megalomania'' has the least bit of influence on the organization, the Yankees are doomed to failure. WILLIAM BLANKENSHIP New York

title: The Longevity of a Car for the Masses
description: LEAD: DESIGNED by Ferdinand Porsche and introduced as ''the people's car'' by Adolph Hitler in 1937, the Volkswagen Beetle, with its Kafkaesque shape and daunting dependability, has become an icon among automobiles, the quintessence of utilitarianism that has moved generations.

title: Julia H. M. Smith Becomes a Bride In Woodstock, Vt.
description: Julia Herrick Macaulay Smith and Arthur Robert George Solmssen Jr. were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt., by Canon Donald E. Boyer.

title: CANADA: From Mutual Pride To Deep Suspicion
description: The relation between the Canadian Government and the country's arts community is one of extremes - from mutual pride and gratitude to deep suspicion. In a country where corporate sponsorship of the arts has caught on relatively recently and where there are few of the deep-pocketed private endowments found in the United States, Canadian artists are much more dependent on government for financial support than their American counterparts.

title: THE REGION: The Road to City Hall: A New York Voter's Guide; Fits and Starts Along the Way
description: WITH the Sept. 12 New York City primary fast approaching, the candidates must distinguish themselves in unusual municipal circumstances. The 1989 race is the first with campaign spending limits, and is made more significant because the next mayor will have to deal with a redesign of city government and a new schools chancellor.

title: On Not Starting Work in Designer Clothes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Beginning of Something Big
description: A few years ago, a friend and I were ambling down the main street of an English town in Oxfordshire called Woodstock. A microbus with Belgian plates pulled up, and the driver poked his head out the window to ask, ''Excuse me, do you know where ze festival was?'' I told him he was on the wrong side of the Atlantic; luckily for him, he drove off before I could add that I'd been at the festival. But for an event so swathed in myth, a little fiction would have been more appropriate than the facts.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Factory Outlet Centers Keep Growing
description: THEY are strung out along the Connecticut shoreline, spaced about 25 miles apart in Norwalk, Milford and Branford, the cut-rate pearls of apparel shopping - factory outlet centers.

title:
INVESTING;
The Tanker Business Takes Off
description: LEAD: Despite problems with oil spills, companies that ship oil are enjoying a strong year. With American imports of oil climbing, international tanker fleets are operating at full capacity. In December, large tankers raised their rates to levels not seen since 1973. Although rates have since dipped a bit, they still remain high.

title: Coming Full Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAN IS SAID TO TRY TO OBTAIN TOXINS
description: Attempts by Iranian researchers to buy poison-producing strains of fungus from Canada and the Netherlands have been disclosed for the first time by Western intelligence officials.

INVESTING;
Why Pharmacy Stocks are Climbing
description: LEAD: After languishing last year, stocks of some leading drugstore chains have surged in recent months, as investors have moved into stocks that are considered recession resistant.

title: 40 MEANS YOU CRY OVER SPILT LOVE
description: LEAD: FORTY-SEVENTEEN By Frank Moorhouse. 175 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: Measles Directives Puzzling Parents
description: CONFLICTING messages from pediatricians and health authorities on the immediate need for a second dose of measles immunization have generated growing confusion and concerns among many parents in recent weeks.

title: Let's Hear It for 14th Street!
description: A million-dollar baby in a 5-and-10-cent store once merited a hit song, and now a $200 million-a-year shopping center is trying to get one for itself, too.

title: An Omission
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 362189 -- No Title
description: A custodian has been declared the winner of a $3 million Lotto jackpot even though he has no winning ticket to show for it.

title: Kid Stuff
description: When Josh Baskin, the protagonist in the movie ''Big,'' moves into a sunny Manhattan loft, he fills it with all his favorite things. There are video games and a jukebox, a trampoline and a bunk bed. Never mind the wonderful open space, it is the objects here that count. Indeed, Baskin, a 13-year-old lurking inside a man's body, put together a personal playland, one that has become the envy of teen-age America.

title: Burmese Opposition Leader No Longer on Hunger Strike
description: The Burmese opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has ended her hunger strike after assurances from the Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, that her followers would not be subjected to ''inhuman interrogation,'' her husband told British officials today.

title: ISRAEL: Politics as Usual, But Not Over the Arts
description: In Israel, where politics seems to be part of every issue, arts administrators and government officials say public support of the arts is free of political coloration. That doesn't mean Israeli politicians are reluctant to criticize plays or exhibits that fail to suit their ideology. And Israel does occasionally censor the arts, for what the government calls ''security reasons'' (though theater censorship has been abolished for a two-year trial period). But the chief censor and political opponents have no control over the government's purse strings, arts administrators say.

title: Question Of the Week; Has Dallas Green Done a Good Job?
description: With only a handful of players returning from last year and an erratic pitching staff with more members than American Express, Dallas Green should be commended for having such a team positioned so close to the leader in August. THOMAS SEREMBA Jersey City

title: Shadow of McCarthyism Still Darkens the Land; The Loss of China
description: To the Editor:

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: On a street corner in a poor neighborhood of New York, a 12-year-old boy sits on a milk crate and sells crack. His mother stands by, patting his head. Other boys, as young as 7, 8 and 9, hang out nearby. They have most of the crack to be sold, so the 12-year-old will not be caught with it in his possession.

title: Jennifer Ann Levin Weds
description: Jennifer Ann Levin a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Levin of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. William Paul Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Carter of Arlington, Mass., at the summer home of the bride's parents in Purchase, N.Y. Caroline K. Simon, who retired as a judge of the New York State Court of Claims, officiated. The bride is a fourth-year student at the Harvard Medical School. She graduated summa cum laude from Yale University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. The bridegroom is an intern in psychiatry at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass. He graduated from the Harvard Medical School and magna cum laude from Brown University.

title:
DINING OUT;
One of the Better Bets on the Boardwalk
description: LEAD: BIG-DEAL Atlantic City restaurants, they say, have an even higher turnover of chefs and their support staffs than most other eating places. According to one executive chef there, the average stay is just over a year and a half. With that much volatility, it's not easy to get a fix on a restaurant's performance that will still be valid two months later.

title: Runoff Election Needed to Fill Wright Seat
description: Dr. Bob Lanier, a Republican, and Pete Geren, a Democrat, were the two top vote getters today in a Fort Worth-area election to fill the seat vacated by Jim Wright, the former House speaker toppled by ethics charges.

title: Film Buffs Get a Taste of 'the Process'
description: LEAD: FILM buffs who like their entertainment straight - with or without popcorn - should not necessarily put ''The Movie Makers,'' the current series at the John Drew Theater in Guild Hall, East Hampton, on their ''must do'' list.

title: Review/Music; Seattle Opera Pulls All the Stops Out On a New 'Meistersinger' Production
description: New productions of ''Die Meistersinger'' remain scarce even in a time when radically rethought stagings of Wagner's most formidable music drama, the ''Ring,'' no longer qualify as rarities. A comedy on a distinctly Wagnerian scale, it deals at marathon length in heavyweight, Breughel-like humor. The work consumes more than five hours of an audience's time and can strain the resources of any opera company. A decision to stage it is never taken lightly.

title: Helen G. Howell Weds C. A. Wray
description: Helen Garrison Howell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Howell of Atlanta, was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip to Christopher Asher Wray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Wray Jr. of New York. The Rev. Peter J. Gorday performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Hays H. Rockwell.

title: Mayoral Race In Detroit Turns To Bitter Battle
description: The Detroit mayoral race, usually a yawner easily won by the city's longtime Mayor, Coleman A. Young, has turned into a bitter contest pitting the Mayor against a former ally, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE WHISTLEBLOWERS: Exposing Corruption in Government and Industry. By Myron Peretz Glazer and Penina Migdal Glazer. (Basic Books, $19.95.) This is a study of one of the newest and worthiest varieties of American hero: people who defy their employers, risking job and reputation, to call attention to lapses in safety or ethics.

title: Running the Little Man's Bank
description: The blazing-hot heat was already rippling up from the pavement outside, as the cars began to swing into the pawnshop's lot and pieces of households emerged from trunks and back seats.

description: International

title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango
description: THE Bush Administration reacted with suspicion when Fidel Castro offered last month to join the United States in the fight against narcotics traffickers.

description: ''All the screaming you've done at a kid in basic training doesn't do him any good when there are bullets flopping all around.

title: New York Is No. 1 . . . in Test-Taking
description: SUMMER vacation will be interrupted for about 10,000 high school students in New York State on Thursday when they report for a three-hour Regents examination in chemistry. The test was canceled in June when The New York Post, dramatizing what it said was a black market in pilfered exams, printed the answers on its front page.

GARDENING;
Overcoming Pests at Harvest Time

The Rev. Joseph Michael Quinlan officiated.

title: THE ANTIQUITIES BOOM
description: William Grimes offers a number of explanations for the higher-than-market rates of return earned on investment in the archeological market; however, he overlooks the fact that nonprofit and state-owned museums have acted as black holes of archeological artifacts.

title: Stellick Denies Pact
description: A Toronto radio station reported that Gord Stellick, who resigned as general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs on Friday, would join the Rangers as assistant general manager, but Stellick denied yesterday that an agreement has been reached.

title: Fall Footwear: Suede, Low Boots and High Vamps
description: Manolo Blahnik sees a return to really feminine shoes with a hint of whimsy. Maud Frizon has always favored such styles, but for fall she has added some down-to-earth walking shoes. Walter Steiger's low, thick heels now have rounded edges and a thin coating of gold. Diego Della Valle sticks to the classics, and Giorgio Armani puts softening touches on tailored styles. Chacun a son gout.

title: THE ALMIGHTY RUBLE
description: PERESTROIKA IN PERSPECTIVE The Design and Dilemmas of Soviet Reform. By Padma Desai. Illustrated. 138 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $14.95. GORBACHEV'S STRUGGLE FOR ECONOMIC REFORM The Soviet Reform Process, 1985-88. By Anders Aslund. 219 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. Cloth, $37.50. Paper, $12.95.

title: Good Timbre Lies Flat
description: Midsummer has settled over the audio scene, and all is seasonally indolent. The customers are away, and what is heard in the shops is mostly the sound of the air-conditioner. A similar lull pervades the manufacturing precincts of the trade as the workers head for the hills or the beaches.

title: The Battle for the National Forests
description: THE struggle over the last remnants of the ancient virgin forests of the Northwest is the latest battle in a fierce centurylong contest for control of the nation's publicly owned woodlands.

title: SUCCESSFUL MISFIT
description: SEMINAR ON YOUTH By Aldo Busi. Translated by Stuart Hood. 292 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: THE BOXER THE CHAMPS WON'T FIGHT
description: IN A SPANKING NEW GYM IN VAN NUYS, Calif., Michael Nunn, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion, is working the heavy bag. A left-handed fighter, Nunn sets, plants and throws the big hook, then skips back nimbly to repeat it from a different angle. With each punch, his eyes light up, the brows arching, much in the manner of Muhammad Ali, to whose legendary ring style his own is often compared. Before long, the cross beams above are groaning from the heavy bag's sway. Hearing the echoes of the blows, Nunn's trainer, Joe Goosen, looks up from a far corner of the gym to yell, ''Michael, not too hard for now.''

title: 2 Companies Punished
description: Two West German companies have been denied United States export privileges for nine years because of their relationship to a German businessman who was convicted of exporting a mustard gas ingredient to Iran, the Commerce Department said Friday. The companies, Chemco and Colimex, both of Cologne, were added to a previous order denying similar privileges to the businessman, Peter Walascheck of Cologne, because of their ''affiliation, ownership, control or portion of responsibility'' to Mr. Walascheck, the department said. Mr. Walascheck pleaded guilty on Aug. 26, 1988, in Federal District Court in Baltimore to illegally exporting thiodiglycol from Singapore to Iran, the department said. Thiodiglycol is an ingredient of mustard gas used in chemical warfare.

title: In Ulster After 20 Years, Hopes Are Nearly Gone
description: Twenty years after British soldiers were deployed to restore order to the riot-torn streets of Northern Ireland, deep sectarian divisions and devastating violence appear to have a stranglehold on faint hopes of peace.

description: The company said revenue in the latest second quarter included a $750,000 one-time milestone payment by a corporate partner.

description: b-Net loss and after a special gain of $1,028,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The sales figures for the year-ago periods were restated. Results are in Canadian funds.

Anderson of Ann Arbor, Mich. The Rev. Daniel O'Shea performed the ceremony.

description: LEAD: I know you don't want to hear this but we have yet another problem to worry about.

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,500,000 and a gain of $188,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago results included special loss provisions of $15.4 million.

title: Question Box
description: Stealing Home Q. An answer last week to a question about Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig's steals of home reported that Ty Cobb, with 50, and Max Carey, with 33, head the career list for this feat. Where does Jackie Robinson rank? A. He placed ahead of Tinker and behind Evers once he got the chance to play in the major leagues. For the record, Robinson shares ninth place on the career list for swiping home plate with Frankie Frisch, each with 19. Also for the record, Robinson did his swiping in a significantly shorter amount of time than any of those ahead of him, and he did it with powerhouse Brooklyn Dodger teams from 1947-56 that hardly had to steal home to score runs.

title: Strongbow Never Got to Northern Ireland; A Good Irish Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Sorry, Right Number
description: As the latest of the college bowls to succumb to the trend toward corporate commercialism, the former Orange Bowl has been fastidious about giving its new title sponsor its corporate due.

description: WITH several high-technology stocks apparently on the comeback trail, some analysts are looking with favor at a company that manages a diversified portfolio of lesser-known technology companies.

Soccer Player Collapses and Dies
description: Sam Okwaraji, a top Nigerian soccer player, collapsed and died Saturday in a World Cup qualifying match against Angola. Seven fans died of suffocation during the match.

description: For the first time since the present round of violence began in Lebanon five months ago, large-scale ground fighting broke out today, with Muslim and Christian forces battling for control of a strategic area in the hills above Beirut.

title: Campaign Matters; Does It Matter Who Is Mayor? Definitely Maybe
description: Does it matter who's mayor?

title: Help the Homeless, and Win Votes
description: As New York's homeless grow ever more visible and its citizens ever more irritated, New York's mayoral candidates grope ever more awkwardly for solutions. But a plausible strategy for helping the most pitiful of the homeless - the mentally ill -is within easy reach of any candidate. It requires expanding upon an existing city project that combines aggressive outreach with the development of cost-effective, humane new housing.

title: Short-Term Interest Rates Seen Rising
description: Credit market analysts predict that short-term interest rates, which have been in a fairly constant decline since late March, are likely to move higher in coming weeks.

description: Bird, Kansas By Tony Parker 327 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Japanese Buy More Realty
description: Japanese purchases of American commercial real estate have surged since 1986, and in 1988 the $10.02 billion holding of Japan was far bigger than any other country's, the General Accounting Office has said.

title: William B. Shockley, 79, Creator Of Transistor and Theory onn Race
description: William Bradford Shockley, who shared a Nobel Prize in physics for his role in the creation of the transistor and earned the enmity of many for his views on the genetic differences between the races, died of cancer of the prostate at his home in California on Saturday. He was 79 years old and lived on the campus of Stanford University.

title: Telos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
West Germans to Shut Embassy in Budapest Today
description: West Germany will close its embassy in Budapest on Monday because it is filled to capacity with more than 180 East Germans trying to emigrate to the West, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Colonial Commercial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The latest second quarter and 6-month share earnings were less than 1 cent a share because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. The latest quarter and 6 months both included earnings and revenue from Devon Stores Inc, which was acquired on Nov. 28.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Vast sums of illegal drug profits are being clandestinely sent from the United States, hidden by electronic money transfers through computers and facsimile machines. Although many U.S. banks are being used unwittingly in these transfers, estimated to total as much as $100 billion a year, at least two are under investigation to determine whether they knowingly assisted drug operations. Some drug operators have become specialists in modern banking, learning to shift money to take advantage of changing interest rates and currency exchange fluctuations. [ Page A1. ] Legislation to bar discrimination against the handicapped is likely to cost businesses hundreds of millions of dollars a year. [ A1. ] Communications workers went on strike against telephone companies in five Midwestern states, but a tentative agreement averted a walkout in 14 Western states and talks continued past a strike deadline in five other states. No progress was reported in strikes in 15 states that began a week ago. [ A12. ] A Federal small-business program favors companies in certain geographic areas, some minority-owned businesses contend. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Harcourt Brace has narrowed the list of potential buyers for its entertainment properties, including four Sea World parks, and it plans to sign a deal soon, people close to the company said. [ D1. ] A merger of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross has been approved by the United States partners of both firms. [ D2. ] The F.D.I.C. will recognize ''netting agreements'' at banks and savings and loans, under a provision in the savings rescue bill. Under the agreements, the value of all interest-rate and currency swaps with a customer are reduced to a single net value. [ D5. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The percentage of viewers watching channels other than the big networks reached an all-time high for three straight weeks. But the networks' ratings, on which advertising sales are based, were not down as much as their audience share. Television. [ D1. ] Free-distribution weekly newspapers are forcing dailies and established weeklies to refine their strategies in suburban areas. Partly in response to the success of a community newspaper group, The Boston Globe will introduce a weekly section. [ D1. ] Jim Durfee has returned to advertising's mainstream after running a small agency. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D7. ] Men have been buying more hardcover novels, and publishers are bringing out more books intended to appeal to both sexes. [ D6. ] Central Newspapers plans to sell 3.6 million shares of stock to the public. The newspaper chain is owned by the family of Vice President Dan Quayle. [ D6. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Bankers say that China will have difficulty making debt payments, possibly by the end of this year, and that its deteriorating economy will force the refinancing of some loans. [ D1. ] A Brazilian judge indicted the nation's largest speculator, eight stockbrokers and the former presidents of the Rio and Sao Paulo exchanges in connection with a market crash in June. [ D8. ] Gilbraltar aspires to become Europe's Hong Kong, an offshore financial center and safe haven. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Analysts predict higher short-term interest rates in coming weeks, although no one is forecasting a sharp rise. New reports have quieted talk of a recession. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] Failure to classify contractors as employees may result in steep penalties if I.R.S. criteria governing independent contractors are not met. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] The primary attraction of Safeguard Scientifics is its understated book value of the lesser-known technology companies in its portfolio, investors say. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Tax Watch; Contractor Status Vs. Employee's
description: SOME people are clearly employees: the secretary or manager who works when scheduled, uses the company's equipment at a company office and does what the boss says. Others are clearly outside contractors: a consultant who agrees to do a task for company A one week and company B the next, setting his or her hours, hiring a staff and deciding on the methods and priorities for accomplishing a task.

title: Cowboys' Coach Wins Debut
description: Troy Aikman threw a touchdown pass in his Cowboy debut and Everson Walls returned an intercepted pass 72 yards for another score today as Dallas defeated the San Diego Chargers, 20-3, in an exhibition game.

title: Deborah S. Klein Is a Bride on L.I.
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., Deborah Sue Klein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Klein of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to David Barnet Sokol, the son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Marvin Sokol of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Alan Flam performed the ceremony.

title: Amy Reiss, Lawyer, Weds Gary Jacobs
description: Amy Lynn Reiss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Reiss of New York and Redding, Conn., and Gary Howard Jacobs, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Jacobs of Lynbrook, L.I., were married yesterday at the Reisses' home in Redding. Rabbi Robert Summer performed the ceremony.

title: British-Irish Hopes Are High For 32d Walker Cup Matches
description: ALTHOUGH they were not intended to be a competition between just two teams, the biennial Walker Cup matches started and still remain the premier amateur team competition in golf.

title: BILL BARRING BIAS AGAINST DISABLED HOLDS WIDE IMPACT
description: Legislation to bar discrimination against the disabled in the workplace, public accommodations, transportation and communications services is likely to cost businesses hundreds of millions of dollars a year, representatives of trade and industry groups say.

title: Arson Blamed in a Fatal Fire
description: Arson caused a fire in a rooming house last Tuesday in which three people died, investigators said today. About 10 people representing local, state and Federal agencies met for two hours to discuss the fire and concluded that ''it was arson involving the use of an accelerant,'' like gasoline, said Howard Whitehead, Assistant District Attorney for Essex County. The rooming house had no fire escape and a substandard sprinkler system.

title: Stance on Debt By Venezuela
description: Venezuela will insist on a 50 percent cut in its foreign debt in negotiations with creditors, its Minister of Coordination and Planning, Miguel Rodriguez, told the state news agency Venpres.

title: Congress
description: Hearing the cries of anguish from the American arts community, a visitor might conclude that masterpieces, and maybe even a few artists, were being burned on the Capitol steps.

title: Sri Lankan Editor Is Killed; 38 More Are Slain in Unrest
description: Two Sinhalese radicals assassinated a prominent broadcaster in his house near the capital today during political violence that also killed 38 other people across the country, officials said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Track Record Strong For Grauer & Wheat
description: LEAD: The co-chairmen of Grauer & Wheat Investments Inc., which last week announced an agreement to take over Michaels Stores Inc., have developed a strong track record working together. Peter T. Grauer of New York and Douglas D. Wheat of Dallas were formerly with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: 2 Israelis Are Dead, Captive Shiite Cleric Reportedly Suggests
description: The Shiite Muslim cleric captured by Israeli commandos early this month in hopes he could be exchanged for three Israeli soldiers held in Lebanon has suggested to his interrogtors that two of the soldiers are already dead, informed Israelis said today.

title: Chip Index Off Last Month
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator slipped again in July as United States semiconductor orders and shipments declined, a trade group reported last week. The Semiconductor Industry

title: Review/Music; 'Mefistofele' by Boito, A >City Opera Golden Oldie
description: Arrigo Boito's ''Mefistofele,'' in Tito Capobianco's staging, has been a popular fixture at the New York City Opera since 1969. Twenty years is a long life for an opera production, but this ''Mefistofele'' was touched up after its costumes were destroyed in a warehouse fire in 1985. It returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday afternoon, and remains a powerful rendering of Boito's quirkily innovative work.

title: The Attraction of United Airlines
description: In some ways, the UAL Corporation, which owns United Airlines, does not seem a particularly attractive takeover target. United's market share has steadily eroded in recent years, and in December, United lost its claim as the nation's largest airline, falling behind American Airlines.

title: Mullah as Mystic
description: This is William Chittick's translation of the poem by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini that was published in the Iranian newspaper Kayhan on June 21. The poem, which will appear in the Sept. 4 issue of The New Republic, is used here with the permission of the magazine. I have become imprisoned, O beloved, by the mole on your lip! I saw your ailing eyes and became ill through love. Delivered from self, I beat the drum of ''I am the Real!'' Like Hallaj, I became a customer for the top of the gallows. Heartache for the beloved has thrown so many sparks into my soul That I have been driven to despair and become the talk of the bazaar! Open the door of the tavern and let us go there day and night, For I am sick and tired of the mosque and seminary. I have torn off the garb of asceticism and hypocrisy, Putting on the cloak of the tavern-haunting shaykh and becoming aware. The city preacher has so tormented me with his advice That I have sought aid from the breath of the wine-drenched profligate. Leave me alone to remember the idol-temple, I who have been awakened by the hand of the tavern's idol.

title: Bronx Hospital and Union Settle As Three-Day Strike Approaches
description: The Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, breaking with the League of Voluntary Hospitals, has reached agreement with about 1,800 employees, the union for the workers said yesterday.

title: Amy R. Haimoff Marries a Lawyer
description: Amy Robin Haimoff, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Haimoff of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Jay Alan Soled, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Soled of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Barry Hewitt Greene officiated at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills.

title: Transit Supervisor Assaulted
description: A Transit Authority supervisor was critically injured yesterday when she was beaten by a fellow worker at the authority's headquarters on Jay Street in Brooklyn during a hallway dispute, the transit police said. The woman, whose age was given as 44 and whose name was withheld until her family could be notified, was taken to Long Island College Hospital. The transit police arrested Steven Trowel, who lives at 1469 West Avenue in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, and charged him with assault.

title: 39,500 More Telephone Workers Strike
description: Nearly 40,000 telephone workers went on strike in five Midwestern states yesterday, but two of the nation's seven major regional telephone companies reached tentative agreements, averting walkouts by 83,000 employees in 19 other states.

title: Networks' Share of Summer Viewers Drops
description: For three straight weeks, the percentage of television viewers watching channels other than the three networks has reached an all-time high.

title: Prudential's Review
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced on Friday that it had retained William M. Weilbacher to conduct its advertising agency review. A former DFS Dorland executive, Mr. Weilbacher was an early and ardent foe of advertising's 15 percent commission system. It is said, however, that compensation is not an issue for Prudential, which has been a full-commission client. The account, estimated to be worth $60 million to $70 million in annual billings, has been at Backer Spielvogel Bates and Ted Bates Worldwide for 19 years.

title: Debate Over Course of the King Center Surfaces After Son Resigns as Chief
description: He was crowned this spring in an emotional four-hour ceremony at Ebenezer Baptist Church, hailed in soaring homilies as the new champion destined to recruit fresh armies to fight his father's unfinished battles.
