2 Girls Are Shot in Brooklyn; One Is Killed, One Wounded
description: Two Brooklyn girls were shot, one fatally, in two separate shooting incidents yesterday, the police said. A man was killed in the second shooting.

description: Kent Anderson hit a two-run triple with two outs in the sixth inning and Claudell Washington followed with a single as the California Angels beat the Oakland Athletics, 4-3, today to avert a sweep in the last meeting of the season between the American League West leaders.

description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. has narrowed the list of potential buyers for its four Sea World parks and the other properties in its entertainment unit and plans to sign an agreement soon, people close to the company say.

description: No one, not even Roy Orbison, who co-wrote the song and made it a hit in 1961, has given ''Crying'' the emotional kick in the pants that the Canadian country-pop singer K. D. Lang imparted to it at the Beacon Theater on Friday evening.

title: Fiction Publishers Seek Male Readers
description: For many years the book-publishing industry has regarded women as the most avid readers of hardcover fiction. Novels deemed too heavily oriented toward men were sometimes rejected outright and other times relegated to the back shelf.

title: Legalized Aliens Seen as Unprepared
description: Two recent surveys of newly legalized immigrants in California have found such low levels of education, employment and fluency in English that investigators warn that current levels of Federal and state assistance will prove inadequate in assimilating them.

title: Thompson Gets Wisk
description: After more than 30 years of ads from BBDO, New York, including the notorious ''Ring Around the Collar'' campaign, Wisk detergent is leaving for J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. Lever Brothers had given Thompson the new Wisk powder account in April. Wisk liquid has an ad budget of more than $13 million annually, according to Leading National Advertisers. Once the nation's leading liquid detergent, Wisk and Procter & Gamble's Liquid Tide have been battling for market share in recent years.

title: In Soviet Asia Backwater, Infancy's a Rite of Survival
description: This is the dying season here, the time of year when the flowering birth rates in Soviet Central Asia are tempered by the number of babies who die before reaching their first birthdays.

title: Strikes and Accord In Phone Industry
description: Workers struck telephone companies in five states yesterday, but tentative accords averted walkouts in 19 other states. Nearly 200,000 workers in 20 states are striking, with wages and health benefits among the issues.

description: Payne Stewart, best known for the plus fours he wears, birdied four of the last five holes at the Kemper Lakes Golf Course today. His strong charge of five-under 31 over the back nine wasn't quite enough to win the 71st P.G.A. championship at the moment he sank a birdie putt on 18. He still needed some help to get his first major victory.

title: As Summer Programs Grow, Year-Round School Is Arriving
description: Summer session enrollment is rising sharply in New York City public schools, a sign that the city is, in effect, moving toward an 11- or even 12-month school year, educators say.

title: Review/Television; James Baldwin Portrait, Self- and Otherwise
description: ''James Baldwin: The Price of the Ticket'' begins and ends with the funeral of its subject, who died in December 1987. Despite the eulogistic tone that invades the 90-minute documentary, on Channel 13 at 9 tonight, it succeeds remarkably in getting into the mind and spirit of the most celebrated black American writer of his time.

title: Outdoors: Fly Rodding On the Hot and Misty Ocean
description: FLY rodding on the ocean is a sometime thing. It seems there's always a wind blowing or the fish are just beyond casting range or they're too deep or they're just not there. There are times, though, when a fly rod is the right tool at the right time. During the recent hot spell, I hit one of those times with Jim Clark out on Gardiners Bay on Long Island's East End.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Internationalk A3-10 Mickey Leland's aircraft was found crashed on a rocky mountainside in a remote region of western Ethiopia. The Pentagon said there were no survivors among the nine Americans who had been aboard. Page A1

title: Rachel Milliken Marries
description: At Central Synagogue in New York, Rachel Sue Milliken, a daughter of Linda Botton of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Lloyd Gordon Milliken, was married yesterday to Jon Jacob Romer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Romer of Longmeadow, Mass. Cantor Richard Botton, the bride's stepfather, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Romer, a cum laude graduate of Tufts University, is a fashion coordinator in Hartford for G. Fox & Company, a department store chain. Mr. Romer, a graduate of the University of Massachusetts, is a sales training consultant for the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company in Hartford.

Fortune's 'Trophy Wives'
description: Carolyne Roehm, wearing a size 4 dress of her own design, graces the cover of the Aug. 28 issue of Fortune magazine. She looks like 10 million bucks, which is the annual revenue of her apparel company.

title: An Unexpected Khomeini Reveals Himself in a Poem
description: The New Republic will publish in its next issue a poem written by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The 14-line poem appeared on June 21, several weeks after the Ayatollah's death, in an Iranian newspaper, Kayhan, which is published in Teheran.

title: Nuevo Laredo Journal; Did Setting the Clock Ahead Turn It Back as Well?
description: When daylight time was introduced to Mexico's northeastern border states last summer after years of debate, commercial sales and industrial productivity increased, while crime, automobile accidents and energy use dropped. But this year, to much resentment, the region is again being forced to live on Mexico City time.

title: British Tabloid Pay Damages to Eastwood
description: Britain's weekly tabloid, The News of the World, said today that it had agreed to pay a large sum in libel damages to Clint Eastwood.

title: Elise L. Lerner, Artist, Is Married
description: At the Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., Elise Lee Lerner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Lerner of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Jeffrey Wiener, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Wiener of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda performed the ceremony.

title: Jets' Offensive Line Is Still a Problem
description: Without that mysterious chemistry that seems to have been perfected only by the Rockettes, it is difficult to get people in a line to move together at the snap of a finger or the snap of a ball. The Jets know all about it. How many years is it now that they have been struggling to put together an offensive line that will protect a quarterback, move in unison, go to the right spot?

title: SHUTTLE COLUMBIA RETURNS TO EARTH
description: The space shuttle Columbia made a smooth landing here early this morning, ending the longest shuttle mission dedicated solely to military purposes.

title: Banking's Technology Helps Drug Dealers Export Cash . . .
description: Facsimile machines and computers have so rapidly expanded the volume of electronic money transfers among banks throughout the world that they are effectively hiding vast sums of illegal drug profits being clandestinely sent out of the United States.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Officers Getting Stakes In Unit Sold by Lomas
description: LEAD: John C. Tolleson, the chairman and chief executive of the Lomas Bankers Corporation, will remain at the helm of the financial services company, which was sold last week for $500 million in cash and notes to an investment group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc.

title: Roberta Worrick Dies; Wrote Tales of Africa
description: Roberta Worrick, who wrote under the pen name Maria Thomas, was among the eight Americans killed last Monday in the crash of the airplane carrying United States Representative Mickey Leland of Texas. She lived in Addis Ababa; her age could not be learned last night.

title: Organogenesis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Film
description: Love is never far from death in these six films based on stories by Gabriel Garcia Marquez, originally produced for Spanish television and gathered under the wildly understated rubric ''Dangerous Loves'' (''Amores Dificiles''). Though Mr. Garcia Marquez's name instantly brings to mind ''One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' in which a woman too pure for this world simply ascends to the heavens, he uses magic realism sparingly here.

title: Rolling Stones' Surprise For Fans in New Haven
description: At 6 P.M., it was a rumor. By 8 P.M., it was a sellout. By midnight, it was a memory. The Rolling Stones took over a Connecticut club called Toad's Place on Saturday for a surprise start to the 1989 tour, ending an exile at a vacant girls' school by playing a greatest-hits set for 700 who paid $3 each.

Bedrick of Simsbury, Conn., and West Dover, Vt. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Mansion.

title: Spire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said second-quarter earnings from operations were reduced by $105,000, or 3 cents a share, for non-recurring engineering charges from certain manufacturing equipment sales.

title: Weeklies Challenging Boston Globe
description: Russell Pergament has spent 10 years trying to get under the skin of The Boston Globe, using his publisher's column in The Weekly Tab newspaper as his needle.

title: Ivan Tillem, 32; Lost in Ethiopia
description: Ivan L. Tillem, a New York investment banker, lawyer and philanthropist, was among those lost in the crash last week of the Ethiopian plane carrying Representative Mickey Leland of Texas. He lived in Manhattan and would have been 33 years old yesterday.

title: Census Takers Count Trunks, Not Heads
description: A new kind of census taker took to the streets of Manhattan yesterday, one armed not only with pencils and enumeration sheets but with measuring tapes and a book showing how to tell an oak leaf from an elm leaf and a bark shedder from a fungus victim.

title: China's Ability to Pay Debts: Damaged but Under Control
description: As the Chinese Government scrambles to repair its credibility after the military crackdown on June 4, when soldiers gunned down civilians, the world's bankers will be focusing on how it handles one of the country's toughest challenges: repaying its loans in the next few years.

title: Barkley and Nunn Square Off
description: Iran Barkley may be a 10-1 underdog when he fights Michael Nunn, the International Boxing Federation champion, here Monday. But in the war of words, Barkley showed he could hang in there with Nunn.

title: Brazil Indicts 11 People After Market's Crash
description: In the wake of this summer's crash of Brazil's stock markets, a federal judge has indicted Brazil's largest speculator, eight stockbrokers, and the presidents of the Rio and Sao Paulo exchanges at the time of the crash.

title: Critic's Notebook; Pioneering Graham Technique in British Dance
description: Modern dance can develop in many ways. For much of the brief, tumultuous history of this 20th-century art, ideas about form and content have come first, and choreographers have then invented ways of moving to express them.

I get the sense that all the celebrating is being done for them, by media, by musicians and producers and, for better and for worse, by all the marketers of boxer shorts and air fresheners with the Woodstock logo on them.'' -Joel Makower, on the 20th anniversary of a historic weekend. [ B3:1. ]

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Wallace First at Watkins Glen: Rusty Wallace came from far off the pace twice and drove away to an easy victory yesterday in the Budweiser at the Glen Nascar race in Watkins Glen, N.Y. The hard-charging Wallace, who finished second to Ricky Rudd last year after winning in 1987, survived being caught in the wrong place on a caution flag and a flat tire under the green flag to win for the fourth time this season. The victory on the 2.48-mile, seven-turn Watkins Glen International circuit was his fourth road-course victory and the 13th triumph in his Winston Cup career. Wallace crossed the finish line 1.06 seconds ahead of second-place Mark Martin, with Dale Earnhardt, Davey Allison, Bobby Hillin Jr. and Morgan Shepherd following at the end of the 90-lap, 218.52-mile event. Wallace won $56,400 after averaging 89.242 miles an hour in a race slowed by six full-course cautions for 21 laps.(AP) Mansell Wins in Budapest: In a race he described as one of his career's best, Nigel Mansell, driving a Ferrari, swept to victory in the Hungarian Grand Prix in Budapest yesterday. It was the Briton's second victory this season. He started the year by winning the Brazilian Grand Prix in March. Ayrton Senna of Brazil, in his McLaren Honda, was second, followed by Thierry Boutsen of Belgium, driving a Williams Renault. Mansell finished the 77-lap race in 1 hour 49 minutes 38.650 seconds.(AP) TENNIS Filippini Overpowers Skoff: Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay overpowered Horst Skoff of Austria, 7-5, 7-6, yesterday to win the $170,000 Czechoslovak Open grand prix tournament in Prague. Skoff missed two break points in the second game of the first set and both players held their serve with powerful baseline strokes. Filippini broke Skoff in the 11th game with spectacular volleys, winning the set in 60 minutes. Filippini started coming toward the net more often in the second set, and Skoff, sending most of his passing shots wide, lost the ninth game, struggled back, but succumbed in the tie breaker.(AP) SOCCER Two-Way Tie for Second: Trinidad and Tobago tied El Salvador, 0-0, yesterday in a qualifying match for the 1990 World Cup and moved into a second-place tie with the United States in the North and Central American and Carribean region. The game was played in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. It was scheduled for San Salvador but the Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's world governing body, ordered it played in a neutral country after disturbances by fans at the El Salvador-Costa Rica match on June 25. Costa Rica (5-2-1) has completed play in the double round-robin group with 11 points and is virtually assured of advancing to the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy. The top two teams in the region advance. The United States (2-1-1) has five points but has played one less game than Trinidad and Tobago (1-1-3). (AP)

description: From a ramshackle office set behind a row of houseboats here, it looks as though Marshall McLuhan got it wrong.

title: Brain's Design Emerges As a Key to Emotions
description: THE power of emotions to override even the most rational decisions may be explained by a new discovery about the brain, researchers say. The data suggest that the brain is arranged so key aspects of emotional life, like primitive fears, can operate largely independent of thought.

title: Cutbacks at Harrods
description: In a cost-cutting move, Harrods, the famous London department store, has eliminated the jobs of 15 senior managers, a company spokesman said. Harrods, owned by House of Fraser P.L.C., said that high interest rates and strikes by public transport workers had resulted in lower sales. ''We looked at the management structure, which had become a little top heavy, and rationalized it,'' a Harrods spokesman, Michael Cole, said. Harrods has 3,600 full-time employees.

title: Samuel Is Making an Impact
description: In case you're wondering what kind of impact the ''impact player'' is making on the Mets these days, you are not alone: The three California teams in the National League will begin their final march of the summer through Shea Stadium tonight, with pennant races in both the East and the West, and they will be getting their first look at the Mets and their recast team.

title: Hospital Partners Makes Bid for HEI
description: Hospital Partners, a limited partnership controlled by Dana F. McGinnis, a San Antonio broker, has offered to acquire the HEI Corporation for $4.25 a share in cash, or a total of $20.82 million. In a letter to HEI, Hospital Partners said that the offer was subject to obtaining sufficient financing, negotiating a friendly agreement and receiving the approval of the company's shareholders.

title: Ukrainian Tries 'American' Skills for Hawks
description: In the Soviet Union, they like to say that the basketball star Aleksandr Volkov plays the game like an American.

title: Handy & Harman reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coal Strike: Armageddon for U.M.W. and Leader?
description: The four-month strike by the United Mine Workers of America against the Pittston Coal Group increasingly has a make-or-break look about it for the 100-year-old union and its aggressive president, Richard L. Trumka.

title: Algo Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bush's Deft Hostage Policy
description: Constructive clarity. Constructive ambiguity.

title: Resort Income Investors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Comparable year-ago periods' results were not available as the company began operations in November 1988.

title: New Offer For Mining Company
description: Falconbridge Ltd., the large Canadian mining company that agreed two weeks ago to be acquired by Amax Inc., received a competing offer yesterday from its largest shareholder, Noranda Inc. of Toronto, bidding jointly with Trelleborg, a large Swedish industrial concern.

title: Metro Datelines; New York Buys Land Near Tidal Wetlands
description: New York State has acquired 341 acres on a peninsula extending into Northwest Harbor in East Hampton, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced yesterday.

title: Gilbert Finds Winning Ugly Can Be Beautiful
description: LEAD: Brad Gilbert, who has been more successful than any other American tennis player this summer, admits to having a lousy second serve and an ineffective lob. When he's playing his best, he says, he makes his opponents play badly. He is the self-described master of ''winning ugly.''

title: Otra Securities Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results were restated for a 10-for-1 reverse stock split that took effect in June.

title: Flow of Turks Leaving Bulgaria Swells to Hundreds of Thousands
description: In endless caravans of cars, buses and trains, more than a quarter of a million Bulgarians of Turkish descent have streamed into Turkey in the last three months, forming one of Europe's largest refugee flows since World War II.

title: Bush Signs Bill Providing Farmers With $900 Million in Crop Relief
description: President Bush today signed legislation providing nearly $900 million in relief for farmers whose crops were hurt by bad weather this year.

title: Koch Declines (Young) Goldin's Ride
description: Yesterday, on the steps of City Hall, Mayor Edward I. Koch declined an invitation from the 17-year-old son of City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin to take a bicycle ride through Central Park.

title: Moscow Scales Back Space Shuttle Program
description: Soviet officials told American visitors today that they had significantly scaled back their space shuttle program and deferred a manned shuttle mission until 1992.

title: Shishi Journal; Dispatches From a Chinese Frontier of Capitalism
description: As her fingers played with her gold necklace and her eyes wandered about the displays of bright clothing that fill her small shop, Chai Miliang looked a bit bored as she explained that the folks here are really not that interested in the political upheaval in the capital.

title: Genesco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; One Europe, But for TV, One Tongue?
description: THE contest for the Pan-European television viewer is turning into a battle between Babel and the British way - between a cable-television service sending signals in many tongues across the Continent and a satellite broadcaster that thinks English will be the European market's chosen language.

title: Prosecutors Drop Charges of Rape 4 Years After Accuser Recanted
description: Prosecutors dropped rape and kidnapping charges against Gary Dotson today, 10 years after he was convicted on the basis of testimony later recanted by his accuser.

title: Hadson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest second quarter was primarily due to a lack of contract awards in its Defense Systems Group.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Top Executive Announced by Tosco
description: LEAD: Tosco Corporation, an independent oil refiner based in Santa Monica, Calif., will have a new chairman, chief executive and president by year's end when Clarence G. Frame relinquishes those titles and retires. Tosco's new top executive will be Thomas D. O'Malley, an investor and former vice chairman of Salomon

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * A & B-Hawaii Inc., a subsidiary of Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, a transportion and investment concern, said it had purchased two shopping centers and an office building in the Western U.S. for about $50 million.

title: White House Acts to Ease Fed Criticism
description: The Bush Administration sought today to minimize differences with the Federal Reserve, after the budget chief, Richard G. Darman, accused it of running unnecessarily big recession risks by keeping interest rates up.

title: Chancellor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said its loss in the latest secone quarter was due mainly to costs of severance agreements with certain former employees, the write- down of an investment in a real-estate partnership and restructuring costs.

title: KEY RATES
Treasury Securities Fall Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled and yields rose sharply in light trading yesterday. The new bellwether 30-year bond, for example, the 8 1/8 percent issue of 2019, was offered in late trading at 98 26/32, down nearly 1 1/2 points, or $15 for each $1,000 face amount, to yield 8.23 percent, up from 8.10 percent on Friday.

title: Seize the Initiative From Terrorists
description: The Middle East hostage drama is President Bush's first crisis, but it is not a new one for Americans. Fortunately, Mr. Bush so far has avoided making the worst mistakes.

title: Inventories Rose in June As Sales Fell
description: Business inventories rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in June as business sales fell by three-tenths, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Playboy Posts Deficit for Year
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. reported today that it had a net loss of $3.8 million for its 1989 fiscal year that ended June 30.

title: Heavy Flooding Disrupts Service In the Subways
description: Subway service on the West Side of Manhattan was disrupted for three hours last night when heavy rains flooded tracks on the IND and IRT lines, a Transit Authority spokesman said.

title: Bridge
description: Players who use conventions are not always as careful as they should be in giving explanations to the opposition. If an opponent opens one no-trump and your partner bids two clubs, you should not respond to an inquiry by saying ''Landy.'' Your opponents may not wish to appear ignorant by inquiring further, or they may have a misconception. You should announce ''spades and hearts,'' or better still, ''Landy - spades and hearts.''

title: Arden Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $16,000 from repurchase of debentures. The latest second quarter included pretax gains on sale of property of $1,117,000 while the year-ago second quarter included similar pretax gains of $682,000.

title: Reliability of DNA Testing Challenged by Judge's Ruling
description: In a case with possibly important implications for scores of criminal and paternity cases across the nation, a Bronx judge ruled yesterday that sophisticated genetic tests that had linked a murder suspect to a victim were not scientifically reliable.

title: Integon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income In the year-ago 6 months, share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title: George Washington Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the primary areas of loss in the latest 6 months were $377,000 in legal fees from litigatin in connection with the shareholders' derivative suit and $935,000 of losses from one block of the company's group life, health and accident line of business.

title: Pro Athlete Commits Suicide
description: Ricky Berry, a forward with the Sacramento Kings and the club's top draft pick last year, shot himself in the head today and died at his suburban home after a quarrel with his wife, authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Friday referred incorrectly to Stars to Go Inc., a supplier of videotapes and rental equipment.

title: A Philosopher Who Shattered Our Complacency
description: To the Editor:

title: But Why Blame Israel When Israel Is Right?; The Court in the Case
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Lets World Court Try Iran Air Case
description: The Bush Administration agreed today to take part in a World Court case brought against it by Iran over the American downing of an Iranian airliner last year, Administration and World Court officials said.

title: U.S. PRESSES P.L.O. ON ISRAEL'S PLAN TO HOLD ELECTIONS
description: The United States stepped up its efforts today to persuade the Palestine Liberation Organization to agree to Israel's proposal for elections in the West Bank, while also encouraging a new Egyptian initiative to bridge the gaps between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Disney Sues Over Cassettes
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had filed an anti-piracy lawsuit against a Pennsylvania company, accusing it of producing and selling bootleg copies of numerous Disney animated films not officially available on videocassette.

title: Bush Picks Savings Crisis Adviser To Succeed Ruder as S.E.C. Chief
description: President Bush said today that he would nominate Richard C. Breeden, his troubleshooter in the savings and loan crisis, as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Co-Chief Set For Integrated
description: Stephen D. Weinroth will take a leave of absence as a managing director of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to allow him to assume the duties of co-chief executive of Integrated Resources Inc., the brokerage firm announced yesterday.

title: ARMAND HAMMER PARDONED BY BUSH
description: President Bush pardoned Armand Hammer today for making illegal contributions to President Richard M. Nixon's re-election campaign 17 years ago.

title: Kodak Defense In Camera Trial
description: Colby Chandler, chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company, testified today that he realized that entering the instant photography field could mean a lawsuit from the Polaroid Corporation.

title: MCI Gets Contract
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said Montgomery Ward & Company had awarded it a three-year, multimillion-dollar contract to provide a private communications network linking 400 Montgomery Ward stores, offices and distribution centers to its Chicago headquarters. Montgomery Ward said it selected MCI after a six-month comparative test against other vendors and that it expected cost savings from the agreement.

title: Southern Hospitality reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net loss Fiscal 1989 included an extraordinary gain of $2,962,849 for forgiveness of debt in connection with the company's Chapter 11 filing and a writeoff of deferred costs of $889,954.

title: Chinese College Freshmen to Join Army First
description: As part of an effort to reshape the attitudes and values of university students, the Chinese authorities will require most freshmen this fall to undergo military training, possibly for as long as one year, before they enter their four-year study programs.

title: West Bank Firebomb Hurts 4 Tax Collectors
description: Four Israeli tax collectors were wounded today when a gasoline bomb smashed through the windshield of their car as they drove through the West Bank city of Ramallah, the army said.

title: Sonesta International Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue for 1988 periods has been restated to reflect reclassification of certain revenue.

title: Why So Slow to Cut Missiles?
description: A rare window has opened in Soviet-American negotiations to control nuclear weapons. How is the United States responding? By dithering.

title: Nunn Retains Title and Runs Streak to 34-0
description: Michael Nunn, it seems, can't punch enough to do anything but win.

title: Officer Shot in Leg As He Foils Robbery Near Port Authority
description: A plainclothes police officer was shot in the leg last night during a scuffle with two men who were attempting to rob a family in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in mid-Manhattan, the police and witnesses said.

title: Next Tyson Opponent May Be Buster Douglas
description: It looks as if James (Buster) Douglas may be next in line for a shot at Mike Tyson.

title: Turner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Revenue represented the value of construction completed which represented the cost of the work put in place and materials fabricated during the year and related earnings pursuant to Turner's construction and management contracts, together with fees and reimbursed expense from consulting contracts. It is essentially a measure of construction activity during the year rather than sales or revenues in the sense that the term is used in a typical manufacturing company.

title: Everything for the Macintosh User
description: It seemed as if everyone at the Macworld Exposition trade show here was looking for clues about Apple Computer Inc.'s long-awaited portable Macintosh, but it appears that they will have to wait at least another month.

title: Banponce Offer Remains Open
description: The Banco Popular de Puerto Rico said it would keep open indefinitely its offer to merge with the Banponce Corporation. Last week, Banponce said it needed more time to evaluate the offer.

title: Elscint Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Included a loss of $10,800,000 from the settlement of securities litigatin and $2,179,000 from liquidation of Italian assets. Share earnings in the latest quarter was less than one cent a share.

title: Striking Phone Worker Hurt
description: A striking telephone employee was critically injured in a picket line accident yesterday outside the New York Telephone Company's Columbus Avenue Center in Westchester County. The accident occurred when the worker, Edward G. Horgan, a 34-year-old cable splicer and member of Local 1103 of the Communications Workers of America, and several other people surrounded a car driven by Particia McNamara, 18, the authorities said. Ms. McNamara's car brushed Mr. Horgan, the police said. Mr. Horgan, who climbed on top the car's hood and was pounding on the windshield, slid off and hit his head, the authorities said. No charges were filed.

title: Doctors Test Vaccine Against AIDS-Like Illness in Monkeys
description: RESEARCHERS reported yesterday that another experimental vaccine can apparently protect animals against a form of AIDS.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the ''Your Money'' column in Business Day on Aug. 5 misstated the extent to which some ''golden parachute'' payments would be affected by proposed Treasury regulations. For executives whose companies are taken over, the proposals clarify which compensation counts as part of a ''golden parachute.'' Under the proposal, many people who receive payment for stock options held in an acquired company could shelter a significant amount of those payments from ''golden parachutes'' taxes. But not all such payments could be sheltered.

title: Aifs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter included a non- recurring after-tax gain of $810,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Review/Art; Exploring Dadaism's Legacy As Words and Images Collide
description: Long before the Dadaists, words played an integral role in the visual arts. Inscriptions of one kind or another were carved into antique statues and monuments and texts accompanied everything from medieval panel paintings to Cubist collages. But what happened between words and images early in this century was the replacement of description with confusion, order with chaos, edification with obfuscation.

title: George Andreasen, 55, Orthodontics Inventor
description: Dr. George F. Andreasen, an orthodontist who introduced an alloy of nickel and titanium for use in arch wires to straighten teeth, died of multiple myeloma Friday at Mercy Hospital in Iowa City. He was 55 years old and lived in Iowa City.

title: Will New Helmsman at Joint Chiefs Weather Tricky Policy Crosswinds?
description: In the twilight of the Reagan Administration, Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell often seemed like a preacher with a single sermon: the United States must never negotiate with hostage-takers.

title: Although Free to Dismiss Rose, Reds Probably Won't, Lawyer Says
description: The Cincinnati Reds, legally free to dismiss Pete Rose if they so desire, plan to take no action against the embattled manager of their struggling team, the club's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Think Before Seceding
description: To the Editor:

title: Vari-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Picturetel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Walker Telecommunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $88,293 for the quarter and $177,117 for the 6 months, equity in loss of MSM Associates of $174,814 and $410,137 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a gain on the sale of Mutual Signal Corp. of $2,626,636 for both periods. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $77,159 for the quarter and $157,275 for the 6 months, and equity in loss of MSM Associates of $258,968 and $506,198 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Exchanges Set Options Study
description: Three stock exchanges announced today that they would study the possibility of linking equity options markets electronically.

title: Our Towns; Asbestos Cloud Hanging Over Uneasy Workers
description: ''I've got to take care of my family,'' said 26-year-old Anthony Kelly, explaining why he took a job at Friction Division Products Inc., a brake-lining manufacturer that has been cited by OSHA as a potentially deadly place to work.

title: Walshire Assurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rise of a Law Firm Headed by Senator D'Amato's Brother
description: In less than a decade, the law firm headed by Armand P. D'Amato, the brother of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, has blossomed from a modest partnership into one of the most flourishing legal practices on Long Island.

title: Lobbyists, Unmasked
description: Shaken by the confessions of well-connected lobbyists who made a bundle for housing developers, Congress has groped for ways to curb their excesses. The Senate whisked a bill through, and the House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, has endorsed it. They're on the right track, but they could do much better if they're really serious.

title: Galaxy Cheese reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corona Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $500,000. c-After charges of $3.5 million and $3.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said results excluded the operations of the Page-Williams Gold Mine near Hemlo, Ont. As reported, the Supreme Court of Canada awarded ownership of the mine to Corona and Teck Corp., last Friday. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Music; 'Joan of Arc at the Stake,' A Honegger Extravaganza
description: If shared traits had been a test of membership, France's famous group of post-World War I composers would have been called Les Cinq, not Les Six. Clear-eyed simplicity in the face of Romantic obfuscation was a common idea among Francis Poulenc, Darius Milhaud, Germaine Tailleferre, Georges Auric and Louis Durez. Understatement and discretion were their methods.

title: Salonen to Head Los Angeles Philharmonic
description: Esa-Pekka Salonen, a 31-year-old Finnish conductor, has been appointed music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic as of September 1992. He replaces Andre Previn, who abruptly resigned from the post in April.

title: Politics
description: Michael Harrington did with one book what research centers spend millions trying to do: he got the attention of two Presidents and changed the direction of government policy.

title: Metalclad Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Metro Datelines; Living Will Measure Approved by Senate
description: The State Senate narrowly approved a measure yesterday that would allow residents to say in advance whether they want life-sustaining medical treatment withheld if they become seriously ill and incapacitated.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Peter Scarperi was named general manager of United States operations and Edward Harrigan was named chief financial officer at Ogilvy & Mather U.S.A.

title: As an Urban Rite, Stoop-Sitting Endures
description: The stoops along 46th Street in Manhattan between Ninth and Tenth Avenues satisfy a variety of interests. Prostitutes primp on the stoops, making of them concrete dressing tables for their cosmetics. Drunks nod off there, crack addicts get high and, often on these summer evenings, neighbors carry down pillows from their apartments to sit together on the stoop as neighbors did in the days before television eclipsed the show on the street.

title: Poll Finds Public Favors Tougher Laws Against Drug Sale and Use
description: William J. Bennett, director of the Bush Administration's anti-drug effort, today sought to bolster his case for stepped-up law enforcement by releasing a public opinion poll showing that most Americans favor tougher sanctions against those who sell and use illegal narcotics.

title: Oak Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included $920,000 of non-recurring income for the quarter and a gain of $3.5 million from non- recurring items for the 6 months. The latest quarter loss included $2 million of proxy expense, $945,000 in corporate reorganization expense and a $2 million expense resulting from asset re-evaluations and required reserves. The loss also included an expense of $1.5 million from the operation and liquidation of the company's discontinued telephone advertising business. The latest 6 months included $6.4 million of non-recurring expense booked in the second quarter, partially offset by a $970,000 gain on the sale of land in the first quarter.

title: But Why Blame Israel When Israel Is Right?; A Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Campbell Is Replaced
description: John Campbell, the top money-winner in harness racing history, was removed as the driver of Mack Lobell yesterday and will be replaced by Veijo Heiskanen of Finland for Saturday night's Challenge Cup Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Kean Rejects License Plates
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean today sent back to the Legislature a bill requiring reflectorized license plates, calling the proposed design ''ugly'' and saying the fee to cover costs of production was too small. In his conditional veto of the license-plate bill, the Governor said the proposed 25 cents in added registration fees would be too little to pay for the new plates which are considered safer because they would be more visible. He suggested a 40-cent fee instead.

title: Chance of Making Jets Improves for Mackey
description: After being dropped by three National Football League teams, Kyle Mackey turned to selling health-club memberships in Dallas two years ago. He was rediscovered during the 1987 strike, however, and now has a chance to be a quarterback with the Jets.

title: American Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter and 6-month losses are the result of a non-recurring pretax writeoff of $14.3 million relating to the termination of the proposed acquisition of Amerifirst Bank in Miami, losses incurred by the companies mortgage banking subsidiary and the company's real estate operations.

title: Telecom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
From China With Contempt
description: We will never be able to say we did not know.

title: Rig Count Falls in Week
description: After posting several increases in recent weeks, the number of oil and gas rigs exploring for oil in the United States declined by 16 last week, to 858, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count the week before stood at 874, a rise of four from the previous week. In the last 11 weeks, the rig count has increased eight times. A year ago, the count totaled 940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500.

title: American Home Shield reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRISTIANS BRACE FOR SYRIAN DRIVE
description: Syrian troops were reported to be massing near an important Christian garrison today for what the Christian forces said might be a new ground assault on their defenses. New artillery exchanges between the Syrian soldiers and the Christian side killed eight people, the police said.

title: Bank in Panama to Forfeit $5 Million in Cocaine Case
description: A Panamanian bank pleaded guilty today to helping South American cocaine traffickers launder $411 million from drug sales in the United States. It is the largest money-laundering scheme ever uncovered by Federal authorities.

title: Justice White Blocks Desegregation Order
description: Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court today blocked a Federal court order intended to desegregate Louisiana's 17 public colleges and universities.

title: Nobel Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months included $6,879,000 charge for unrealized investment losses in foreign currency bonds.

title: Botha, Rebuffed by His Party, Quits South Africa Presidency
description: P. W. Botha quit under pressure tonight as South Africa's President, complaining that his Cabinet ministers were ignoring him.

title: North Canadian Oils reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Gold Fields Sells 30% Stake
description: Consolidated Gold Fields, which was recenty acquired by Hanson P.L.C., said it had sold a 30 percent stake in its Gold Fields of South Africa for $:368 million ($585 million) to an industrial holding company.

title: Ignored AIDS Drug Shows Promise in Small Tests
description: As AIDS patients and their advocates go to the ends of the earth to obtain unapproved drugs, an approved drug that is already on the market has languished in neglect, even though it shows some signs of effectiveness in delaying the onset or progress of the disease.

title: Orient-Express Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a net of $1.5 million for the latest 6 months and year-ago period from discontinued operations. The net from discontinued operations in both periods was related to the write-back of a surplus provision for loss on disposal of containership operations.

title: Bearing Right Can Make You Go in Circles
description: To the Editor:

title: Perini Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moscow Invites Wallenberg Relatives to Visit
description: The Soviet Union has invited relatives of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who disappeared in Soviet-occupied territory near the end of World War II, to visit Moscow. The invitation comes amid signs that the Kremlin may be ready to disclose the fate of the man credited with saving tens of thousands of Jews during the war.

title: Arson Blamed in a Fatal Fire
description: Arson caused a fire in a rooming house last Tuesday in which three people died, investigators said Sunday. About 10 people representing local, state and Federal agencies met for two hours to discuss the fire and concluded that ''it was arson involving the use of an accelerant,'' like gasoline, said Howard Whitehead, Assistant District Attorney for Essex County.

title: Iverson Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
John P. Nielsen, 77, Professor of Metallurgy
description: John Phillip Nielsen, an emeritus professor of metallurgy at the Polytechnic Institute of New York and co-founder of the International Precious Metals Institute, died Saturday at the Slovene Home for the Aged in Cleveland, Ohio. He was 77 years old and had moved to Cleveland from Manhattan two weeks ago after suffering a stroke.

title: Gitano Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
K Mart Profit Down 10.9% In Quarter
description: Hurt by unexpectedly low sales in May, the K Mart Corporation said yesterday that its earnings declined 10.9 percent in the second quarter, to $145 million, or 72 cents a share, from $162.8 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: But Why Blame Israel When Israel Is Right?; Once a Terrorist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deus ex Machina
description: YOU have always wanted to play God. Admit it. Now you can.

title: I.B.M. Acquires Share in Bachman
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a minority equity interest in Bachman Information Systems Inc., a developer of advanced software. Bachman is privately owned and based in Cambridge, Mass. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will invest in Bachman in exchange for newly issued Bachman voting convertible preferred stock. Other terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Retail Sales Fall in Britain
description: British retail sales fell in July, the Government said today, an apparent sign that high interest rates were halting a consumer-led inflationary boom.

title: Market Place; More Bad News For Drexel Trusts
description: THE story of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''junk bond'' unit trusts is ending with returns that are even more disappointing than first appeared to be the case.

title: Hewlett Sees Lower Profit
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that based on preliminary estimates, operating results for its third quarter, ended July 31, would be below Wall Street analysts' forecasts.

title: Leucadia National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $2.4 million reflecting the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: Drexel Reaches Settlements With Regulators in 10 States
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has negotiated settlements with 10 state securities regulators as part of a nationwide effort to resolve any difficulties with state regulators arising from the firm's 1988 agreement to plead guilty to six felony counts.

title: Norris Darrell, Lawyer And Tax Expert, 90
description: Norris Darrell, a New York lawyer and tax expert, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Musical Tribute to a Legend: Marian Anderson
description: Braving threats of thunderstorms, some 2,500 concertgoers gathered here on the soggy lawns of the Charles Ives Center for the Arts tonight to pay tribute to an artist who became a legend: Marian Anderson.

title: Fitchburg Gas & Electric Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included charges of $974,594 incurred in defending against an unsolicited offer by Eastern Utilities Associates and costs related to the proposed merger with Unitil Corp. for the quarter, and 6-month was reduced by non-recurring costs of $1,102,330 related to the Eastern Utilities offer and the Unitil Corp. merger. c-Net income

title: General Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $300,000 and $400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included an $18.3 million gain from an accounting change and a $3.3 million loss from early retirement of debt.

title: Careers; Salespeople Also Trained In Marketing
description: JOHN T. THOMAS, a partner in the Chicago office of Ward Howell International Inc., a management recruiting firm, has an interesting sideline that alerts him to trends. He is the founder and president of the Procter & Gamble Marketing Alumni Association, which has 1,210 members.

title: But Why Blame Israel When Israel Is Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines Reduce Fall Ticket Prices
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it would offer lower prices on heavily restricted tickets bought before Sept. 1. Other airlines quickly matched the fares.

title: Medical Action Indus reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Isolation of AIDS Prisoners Ends
description: The state of Connecticut has agreed to stop segregating AIDS-infected inmates from the general prison population, settling a 1988 Federal lawsuit and establishing guidelines that could have nationwide impact.

title: Patterns
description: The Other Geoffrey

title: Phonemate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $152,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Eugene R. Sullivan, Lawyer, 85
description: Eugene R. Sullivan , a retired Wall Street lawyer, died after a long illness Sunday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old. Mr. Sullivan, a graduate of Holy Cross College and Harvard Law School, was a partner in Fruehaff, Farrell, Sullivan & Bryan. He represented the Cities Service Company in the divestiture of its gas utilities, and then many of the utilities. He retired in 1974.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Is Appointed At Revitalized Gemcraft
description: LEAD: When Thomas A. Falik, a Houston lawyer, decided last winter to go into business for himself instead of working on other people's deals, Gemcraft Inc. a bankrupt home builder that had been taken over by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, caught his eye.

title: K mart Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
Ravitch Tries for Identity as Outsider
description: In the final weeks of the primary race for mayor of New York City, Richard Ravitch will try to portray himself as the lonely outsider, much like a hero in a western who rides into town to clean up the place.

title: Pauley Petroleum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Candelaria May Return
description: John Candelaria, who has missed most of the season recovering from knee surgery, pitched five scoreless innings for the Yankees' Rookie League farm team in Sarasota, Fla., yesterday and may rejoin the Yankees by this weekend.

title: Ritual Killing Laid to Liberian Official
description: Eleven people, including Liberia's Defense Minister, have been arrested and charged with the ritual murder of a policeman as part of a plot to overthrow the Government.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Harken Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months included $1,785,000 of preferred stock dividends. The Latest second quarter and 6-month results included a gain of $7.9 million from the sale of the company's 80 percent stake in its Hawaiian retail unit and $10 million in trading losses at another unit. Horn & Hardart Co (A) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Revenue 142,460,000 138,759,000 Net loss 1,528,000 b37,000 6mo rev 261,712,000 238,774,000 Net loss 3,439,000 1,638,000 b-Net income ICH Corp(A) Qtr to June 30 1989 1988 Net inc b7,230,000 c6,493,000 Share earns .15 .13 6mo net loss b11,137,000 c9,627,000 b-Included capital losses of $2,059,000 for the quarter and $7,827,000 for the 6 months, respectively. c-Included capital gains of $5,061,000 for quarter and $1,756,000 for the 6 months. The company said both the year-ago quarter and 6-month periods are restated.

title: Dealers Will See New Ford Truck
description: A new truck from the Ford Motor Company called the Explorer will be shown to dealers this week in advance of its formal introduction next spring, the general manager of the Ford division, Thomas Wagner, said.

title: Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Declines 6.07
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday after an early and feeble rally attempt.

title: Packages for Helmsley 'Appeared to Have' Cash
description: A former personal aide to Leona Helmsley testified yesterday that Mrs. Helmsley had envelopes with what ''appeared to be money'' after two meetings with a co-defendant in her tax-fraud and extortion trial.

title: Environmental Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month included gains from the sale of stock of $263,375 and $481,438, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 6-month included losses of $75,000 and $154,297, respectively, from the sale of stock.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Biotech Research Laboratories, Inc., Rockville, Md., named Anthony C. Nicholls executive vice president.

title: Q&A
description: How Alarm Watches Make Their Noise Q.What makes the noise in an electronic alarm watch or clock? A.The noise in many watches and clocks relies on the piezo-electric effect, discovered by Pierre Curie.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Comedy Channel Ads
description: To advertise a new all-comedy cable channel, where else to go but to an ad agency that specializes in laughs? That was the thinking of the Comedy Channel, the Home Box Office service set to make its debut in November, which yesterday gave its advertising account to Cliff Freeman & Partners, a Saatchi & Saatchi subsidiary. Mr. Freeman penned the Wendy's hamburger slogan ''Where's the beef?''

title: MLX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday about Senate impeachment hearings on a Federal judge, Alcee L. Hastings, misstated the date of the picture. It was July 10, not Aug. 10.

title: POLAND'S PREMIER OFFERING TO YIELD TO NON-COMMUNIST
description: Under increasing Soviet pressure for an end to Poland's Government crisis, Prime Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak said today that he would resign and ask that the leader of a small party traditionally allied with the Communists be allowed to form a cabinet.

title: Anacomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,775,000 and $5,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,950,000. c-Included tax credits of $3,930,000 for the quarter and $11,050,000 for the 9 months.

title: At McDonnell, Growing Pains
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation's sprawling Douglas Aircraft plant here testifies both to the recent success of the company at selling its planes and to the perils of rapid growth.

title: Astronomers Strain to Hear Voyager's Last, Weak Signals
description: GROPING in the dim vastnes far from home, arthritic and partly deaf, feeble of voice and prone to memory lapses, the aging Voyager 2 is resolutely heading for a rendezvous next week with Neptune, its last planet of call at the edge of the solar system.

title: Golden Nugget reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The latest second quarter loss included an $11,134,000 non-cash charge related to certain amendments under the company's Executive Retirement Plan. The second quarter loss also reflected an increase in the company's net interest costs related to financing for the development and construction of the Mirage, the company's new resort-casino project on the Las Vegas strip, and the April 1989 financing related to Golden Nugget-downtown. The year-ago second quarter loss is after a pretax expense of $5.6 million from a judgment against the company in a lawsuit, and unspecified financing costs associated with the Mirage. The company attributed the latest 6-month net income to unspecified gains on the sale of certain equity investments in the first quarter.

title: Quest Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,027 for the quarter and $17,132 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $78,293 for the quarter and $100,271 for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a tax credit of $113,679. The latest 6 months also included a pre-tax gain of $2,581,706 from the sale of assets.

title: Statesman Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses of $22,000 for the quarter and $34,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $204,000 for the quarter and $780,000 for the 6 months.

title: Brewers Deliver Bitter Pill To Yanks
description: More than 30 minutes after tonight's game, Dave Righetti sat solemnly in the Yankees' clubhouse, staring blankly into his locker. Righetti had just lost a two-run lead in the ninth inning. The Yankees had just lost a 5-4 heartbreaker to the streaking Milwaukee Brewers at County Stadium. And now Righetti, feeling the weight of the crushing defeat on his shoulders, was almost at a loss for words trying to explain what had happenned.

title: Review/Music; Two Make City Opera Debuts in 'Rigoletto'
description: Four new singers have taken over principal roles in the New York City Opera's staging of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' since the production returned to the New York State Theater a few weeks ago. Of the newcomers who were heard on Sunday afternoon, two were making their company debuts.

title: UGI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Petroleum Heat & Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Finally, a Guide for Voters
description: In red, white, blue, English and Spanish, the first voter guide distributed by New York City was published yesterday. The booklet, published after voters endorsed the idea in last year's election, includes information about the Sept. 12 primary election and sketches of the candidates.

title: Bull Run Gold Mines reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fulton Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said its second quarter loss reflected a decrease of $4.1 million in its net interest margin, which resulted from the increase in the cost of liabilities. This increase was not sufficiently offset by an increase in interest income.

title: Vishay Intertechnology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of about $560,000 to cover the cost of reimbursing the government for certain resistors recalled by Vishay's Dale Electronics subsidiary and for certain related administrative expenses. c-Included an after-tax charge of $560,000. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Nov. 18, 1988. The company attributed the significant increase in sales for both periods primarily to acquisitions made by it in the second half of 1988.

title: Review/Ballet; Some Sunny Pyrotechnics By Newest Chicago Troupe
description: Chicago has not been a ballet city historically. It has had its teachers, and has been hospitable enough to touring ballet troupes. But home-grown companies have not flourished there. Ballet Chicago is the newest entry into the ranks. Founded last year and directed by Daniel Duell, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, the company performed this week at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in its East Coast debut.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Poland's Prime Minister will resign, he said, and ask that the leader of a small party traditionally allied with the Communists be allowed to form a cabinet. Page A1

title: Orioles Triumph With 3 In the 10th
description: Craig Worthington's three-run homer in the 10th inning tonight gave the Baltimore Orioles a 4-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Avnet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included after-tax net gains of $4.6 million, or 13 cents a share, arising from the $7.6 million gain on the sale of the company's Cable Television System business and its Hybritek operation for the quarter and the year included a net after-tax gain of $1.3 million, or 4 cents a share, representing the fourth quarter gain of $4.6 millin and a third quarter loss of $3.3 million on the sale of Sertech-LSI testing. The $7.6 million gain was offset by a reserve of $3 million in connection with the intended sale of the firm's FMI operation.

title: Leland and Companions Mourned on Capitol Hill
description: Congressional staff members and others on Capitol Hill paid their respects today to Representative Mickey Leland of Texas and the three aides who died with him in Ethiopia.

title: QVC Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: QVC said its latest second quarter's net was reduced by a $265,000 pro- forma tax provision.

title: INSIDE
description: 2d Lawmaker Is Killed Larkin Smith, a freshman Congressman, died in a plane crash in Mississippi as another air crash victim, Representative Mickey Leland, was mourned in Washington. Page A16. Judge Rejects DNA Tests In what may be the first challenge to DNA ''fingerprinting,'' a judge said that tests linking a murder suspect to a victim were not reliable. Page B1. At Seabrook Plant: Waiting Operators labor over control panels and emergency workers stand by, but the nuclear plant in New Hampshire is still not providing power. Page D1. Mixed Signals in Teheran Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said no one in Iran would talk with Washington, further muddying the hostage picture. Page A12.

title: Velcro Industries NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After non-recurring charges of $151,000 for the quarter and $773,000 for the 9 months.

title: Greyhound Lines of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter net included a non-recurring gain on the sale of property of $786,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A First Step Toward Clean Racing
description: rrPerhaps all the tough talk about drugs in horse racing at the Jockey Club's annual Round Table Conference here Sunday was only the usual hot air. But it could have been a first step on an addict's road to recovery: an end to denial and an acknowledgment that a terrible problem does exist.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Quick Victory for Graf: Top-seeded Steffi Graf needed only 32 minutes to ruin the pro debut of Kim Kessaris and post a 6-0, 6-0 victory last night in the opening round of the United Jersey Bank Classic at Mahwah, N.J. Kessaris, 16, was not scheduled to play in the tournament at Ramapo College but received a late invitation when Hu Na withdrew in the afternoon because of an ankle injury.(AP) Chang Wins: Michael Chang needed only 57 minutes to dispatch Neil Broad of South Africa, 6-1, 6-1, in the second round of the A.T.P. championship in Mason, Ohio.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Barnes Has 72-9 1/4 Shot-Put: Randy Barnes, an American who already has this year's best indoor shot-put distance, put the shot the longest distance of the outdoor season, 72 feet 9 1/4 inches, yesterday at the Gugl International meet in Linz, Austria. (AP) HORSE RACING Glowing Honor Wins: Glowing Honor, ridden by Jerry Bailey, was placed first yesterday by disqualification in the $127,000 Diana Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Saratoga Race Track. Wooing, a 32-1 long shot ridden by Antonio Nunez and the original first finisher, was dropped to second by the stewards after bearing out and impeding Glowing Honor in the stretch run. Glowing Honor ran the mile and an eighth in 1:50 1/5 to record her second victory in three starts this year. She earned $76,200 for Rokeby Stables and returned $9 for $2 to win. (AP) FOOTBALL Bears 28, Dolphins 20: All three quarterbacks battling for the Chicago starting job directed touchdown drives last night, but Mike Tomczak had the best statistics in the exhibition victory in Miami. Tomczak completed 7 of 8 passes for 122 yards and 2 touchdowns. Jim McMahon hit 4 of 6 passes for 47 yards and directed an 84-yard touchdown drive. Jim Harbaugh drove the Bears 89 yards for their final touchdown and finished with 5 of 8 for 52 yards.(AP)

title: 'Killing Fields' Escapee Visits Refugee Camp
description: Dith Pran, whose escape from Cambodia's Khmer Rouge regime was portrayed in the movie ''The Killing Fields,'' had a tearful reunion today with relatives he left behind.

title: Lockheed Asks Cleanup
description: The Lockheed Corporation said it has proposed to the Government spending $52 million over six years to help remove contaminants from groundwater in Burbank, Calif., site of the company's aeronautical systems division.

title: Bridges Rise Over Gaps of Ignorance As Polish Priests Experience Judaism
description: When 100 people gathered in Chicago's Anshe Emet synagogue last week for the somber service of Tisha B'Av, commemorating the ancient Babylonian and Roman destructions of the First and Second Jewish Temples, 21 of the congregants wore Roman collars as well as yarmulkes.

title: UAL Stock Turnover Off
description: Trading in shares of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines slackened yesterday, as no further news emerged to confirm or deny the rumors that new takeover offers would emerge to challenge the bid made last week by Marvin Davis, the California investor.

title: Nelson Holdings Intl reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a reversal of a $1,236,000 provision for losses on disposal of discontinued operations and a reversal of a tax credit of $428,000. c-Net income and after income from disposal of discontinued operations of $2,374,000 and a tax credit of $159,000. There were no share earnings in the year-ago 6 months because the net did not cover preferred stock dividends.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is evident to me that after all these years of my best efforts for the National Party and for the Government of this country as well as the security of this country, I am being ignored by ministers in my Cabinet. I consequently have no choice other than to announce my resignation.'' -President P. W. Botha of South Africa. [ A12:1. ]

title: Shock Hazard Leads To Hair Dryer Recall
description: Four companies voluntarily agreed to recall about 250,000 hair dryers that can cause electrocution when dropped into water even when they are not running, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: Lilco to Make First Payout In Five Years
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday that it would resume paying dividends on its common stock, a sign that it is beginning to move beyond the painful abandonment of its Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: NBC News Is Planning To Shut Its Paris Bureau
description: NBC News, which is being significantly restructured under Michael G. Gartner, the president of the division, will close its bureau in Paris, Mr. Gartner said on Friday. The Paris bureau chief, Ted Elbert, is to direct a bureau in Moscow that is to be jointly operated by NBC News, the BBC and Visnews, an news organization partly owned by NBC.

title: Wholesale Club reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Rocky Mount Undergarment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $656,000 for the quarter and $677,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $61,000 for the quarter and $80,000 for the 6 months.

title: El Paso Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $65,119,000. c-Net income and after a loss of $3,321,000 from discontinued operations. Results for the latest 12 months included a loss of $15,487,000 after-tax regulatory disallowance. Results for the year-ago 12 months included a $24.4 million after-tax regulatory writeoff of plant costs.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about the financial performance of the UAL Corporation, which owns United Airlines, referred incorrectly to the earnings figures shown, culminating in 1988 with $8.98 billion. The figures are for revenue, not profit.

title: Book Sparks Dispute
description: A lawyer for Contemporary Books has asserted that a lawyer for the Nebraska football coach, Tom Osborne, has tried to ''intimidate both the author and the publisher into not publishing'' a book about Nebraska football.

title: Air Quality Bonds For Ohio Power
description: A $50 million bond refunding by the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority was tentatively priced yesterday, through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Face-Off in Italy: What Killed the Dinosaurs?
description: SCIENTIFIC rivals in a bitter dispute over the extinction of the dinosaurs have agreed to a hammer-wielding showdown in the mountains of central Italy next month.

title: Too Daring for Moscow of the 50's
description: This week in New York, Oleg Tabakov will complete a circle begun in Moscow in 1958 when, as a young actor, he had two parts in ''My Big Land,'' a play about a Jewish father and son, written by the poet Aleksandr Galich.

title: Lunar Eclipse for Four Continents
description: PARTS of four continents will be treated to a total eclipse of the moon Wednesday night, and astronomers say the show will be the best of its kind New Yorkers will see until 1996.

title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists
description: SOME young Alaskan Eskimos are illegally shooting hundreds of walrus, using chainsaws to cut off their heads and trading the great beasts' ivory tusks for cash and drugs.

title: Helen Lyons, 79, Dies; Jewish Studies Leader
description: Helen Hadassah Lyons, a pioneer in Jewish education for women, died of a brain tumor on Sunday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Scientists Find Abundance of Viruses in Water
description: Sea water and natural fresh water contain up to 10 million times as many viruses as had previously been thought, scientists reported last week. Other experts say that the discovery raises important questions about the marine environment and its effect on human health.

title: Buffett Puts Limit On USAir Shares
description: Warren E. Buffett, the investor who purchased a 12 percent stake last week in USAir Group Inc., said today that he had agreed to hold no more than 14 percent of the company for 10 years.

title: The Drug Battle Doesn't Need Martyrs
description: LEAD: For years, police have urged citizens to help fight the war on crime.

title: KOCH CAMPAIGN RETURNS $25,000 FROM BUILDER WHO GOT VARIANCE
description: A real-estate developer's $25,000 loan to pay for Mayor Edward I. Koch's television commercials violated new campaign finance laws, and Mr. Koch returned the money yesterday as one of his challengers, Richard Ravitch, denounced the loan.

title: Ashton-Tate Plans Layoffs; Operating Loss May Rise
description: Citing reduced revenues and increased losses, the Ashton-Tate Corporation announced today that it would lay off at least 15 percent of its 1,700 employees and take other cost-cutting measures.

title: SYRIA HOLDS TALKS TO BOLSTER ALLIES IN LEBANON STRIFE
description: Syria and Iran summoned their Lebanese and Palestinian allies here today for what Syrian officials called a council of war to ''bring down'' the Christian general who leads Lebanon's army.

title: Di Giorgio Rejects Offer
description: The Di Giorgio Corporation said today that its board had unanimously rejected as inadequate an unsolicited $32-a-share tender offer from an organization headed by Arthur M. Goldberg, a New Jersey businessman.

title: New Tools Aid Oil Hunt in U.S.
description: Experts on energy thought for years that oil production in the United States would shrink to insignificant levels by the middle of the next century, making imports the nation's only meaningful supply. Now they are finding that steady advances in the technology for finding oil from large but hard-to-reach reserves discovered years ago seem likely to stretch the nation's era of oil production, possibly well beyond the year 2100.

title: Women and Physics
description: To the Editor:

title: Donnelly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zahringer and Zabriski Tied for Met. Open Lead
description: The 74th Met. Open, the nation's second oldest district tournament, started its three-day event here today by breaking away from tradition.

title: Sports People: BASKETBALL; Top-Level Meeting
description: The president of the University of North Carolina system met yesterday with Jim Valvano and others involved with charges of wrongdoing in the basketball program at North Carolina State University.

title: Nature's Bounty reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $13,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $39,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $102,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $78,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Date Is Set for Hearing on North's Appeal
description: Oliver L. North's appeal of his convictions in the Iran-Contra case will be heard on Feb. 6 before a three-member panel of judges.

title: Accounts
description: Aaron Rents Inc., a furniture rental company, to Bozell Atlanta, with a budget of $1.5 million.

title: Joss Energy Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Datapoint Corp. Names Its 4th Chief in 5 Years
description: LEAD: The Datapoint Corporation, a maker of computer hardware and networking systems that is based in San Antonio, has appointed Michael M. Michigami president and chief executive, its fourth chief executive since Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, became chairman five years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about indictments in a Brazilian stock scandal misstated the ensuing loss reported by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. The company reported a loss of less than $4 million after taxes for the second quarter of this year from all activities involving Banco de Investimento Planibanc S.A., a Brazilian bank of which it owns 49 percent. Spokesmen for Bankers Trust and Planibanc have declined to provide Planibanc earnings details that would indicate how much Bankers Trust or Planibanc lost because of the scandal.

title: INSIDE
description: Amnesty in Nicaragua

title: Quarex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sallie Mae Sets $100 Million Offer
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $150 million of fixed-rate notes due in 1994 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and a co-manager, Daiwa Securities America Inc.

title: PETER LONG, 66, FORMER THEATRICAL PRODUCER
description: James (Peter) Long, a former theatrical producer, promoter and artists' manager, died of a heart attack Aug. 11 in Los Angeles. He was 66 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Criminals Would Clamor for Exile in Australia
description: To the Editor:

title: Bread for All
description: To The Living Section:

title: North-West Stock
description: The stock price of North-West Telecommunications Inc. surged $4.25 today, to $30.75, after the Wisconsin telecommunications company announced on Monday that it had turned down a friendly merger offer from an unidentified bidder. The 16 percent gain was the fifth largest among over-the-counter issues. The offer was highly conditional and was withdrawn after being rejected by North-West's director's on Aug. 14, said Peter Allen, a spokesman for the La Crosse, Wis., operator of telephone companies and cellular phone systems. He said the company had hired the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley & Company to value North-West, although he added, ''The company isn't for sale at this point.''

title: Home Resale Drop Posted
description: Sales of existing homes declined in the second quarter in 41 states and the District of Columbia, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: In Shift, Gay Men's Health Group Endorses Testing for AIDS Virus
description: Gay Men's Health Crisis, New York City's largest private organization providing AIDS services, has reversed a long-held position and endorsed widespread voluntary testing for the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Resorts International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fitch Reported Nets Candidate
description: Bill Fitch, the former coach of the Houston Rockets, can reportedly take over the Nets' coaching position if he wants the job.

title: No One Group Blamed For Jones Beach Fights
description: State park officials investigating a huge fraternity-sponsored party at Jones Beach last month that ended in violence say they have not been able to assign responsibility for the party to any one person or group.

title: The Hospital Bill
description: The phone strike is about the high cost of medical care. The company wants workers to pay more of the bill. It believes this will make them think twice before buying the first thing some hospital or doctor tries to sell them.

title: Irish in West Indies Went There as Slaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Tronic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago fourth quarter and year losses included a provision for a $4.2 million settlement of a toxic landfill matter, a $2.7 million writeoff in equipment, a $2.3 million inventory markdown, and $1.6 million in costs of an investee corporation financed by the company.

title: Linett & Harrison Gains
description: Linett & Harrison, the new agency in Springfield, N.J., founded by two former executives at Keyes Martin, announced three small new accounts yesterday: Weight Watchers of Suffolk County, L.I., and the Edward S. Gordon Company, a commercial real estate broker, with combined budgets of $500,000, and New Jersey Focus, a new Sunday magazine supplement that will be distributed in several New Jersey newspapers, with no announced budget.

title: Tiffany & Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid in July.

title: Patrick Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Real Estate
description: IN the last few years, huge developments like the International Design Center of New York and the Citicorp office tower have been the driving force for the transformation of Long Island City from a manufacturing stronghold into a varied commercial district. Many property owners have exploited their proximity to these projects by remodeling the neighborhood's factories and warehouses into offices and showrooms.
