And for a number of years the area has been a haven for artists seeking relief from high Manhattan rents.

title: Doughtie's Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter net included a gain equal to 6 cents a share from the settlement of a real estate claim.

title: Market Place; Integrated Calls Outlook Worse
description: PERHAPS it should be called the case of the vanishing value. Integrated Resources Inc., a syndicator of tax-shelter partnerships that sought to grow into a major financial services company, said yesterday that its financial condition was even worse than it had previously disclosed.

title: Indiana Man Is Found Dead In a Truck Parked for 9 Days
description: The body of a trucker has been found in the cab of a tractor-trailer that sat in a parking lot for nine days with its engine running.

title: Charles T. Coiner, 91, Ex-Art Chief at Ayer
description: Charles T. Coiner, a painter and former art director of the N. W. Ayer Inc., advertising agency, died, apparently of natural causes, Sunday at home in Mechanicsville, Pa. He was 91 years old.

title: Sunshine-Jr. Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago 6 months results restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: Rangers Pick Neilson as 25th Head Coach
description: It took four and half months, but the Rangers finally appointed a head coach yesterday when they named Roger Neilson, a 55-year-old former coach of four other National Hockey League teams. In the words of Neil Smith, the team's new general manager, the new coach is a ''teacher, developer, innovator with extensive hockey experience.'

title: Louise Varese Is Dead; Literary Translator, 98
description: Louise Varese, an American biographer and translator of French and the widow of the composer Edgard Varese, died on July 1 in Eugene, Ore. She was 98 years old.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Capital
description: President Bush said something today that neither of his two immediate predecessors would have dared to say quite so bluntly.

title: ROBERT B. ANDERSON, EX-TREASURY CHIEF, DIES AT 79
description: Robert B. Anderson, the Texas-born lawyer who was Secretary of the Treasury from 1957 to 1961, died Monday at New York Hospital, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.

title: Better Uses for Our Money Than the Dubious B-2
description: To the Editor:

title: The Trouble With Mall Interviewing
description: SHOPPING malls have in recent years become a preferred site for companies to acquire market research, generating a debate in the communications industry over whether the malling of research is leading to the mauling of research.

title: Review/Pop; College Circuit's Nostalgia Is Not Nostalgia
description: It's confusing, but some combination of the 1960's, 70's and 80's inflicted itself, in the form of the Royal Cresent Mob and the B-52's, on a willing audience at the Palladium on Friday night. The audience, homogeneous and collegiate - many of whom probably hadn't hit their teens when the B-52's first started appearing at Max's Kansas City and CBGB in the late 70's - went wild.

title: Better Uses for Our Money Than the Dubious B-2; Stealthy Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Soviets Are Eager to Open Ball Field of Their Dreams
description: The Soviet Union rolled out a green carpet of plastic grass today, hurrying to complete the nation's first baseball stadium and apply the Soviets' patented sports-lab techniques to the subtleties of the hit and run.

title: PARENTS AND TEACHERS SPLIT ON SPANKING
description: A Gallup poll taken earlier this year showed that 56 percent of teachers support the right to physically punish children in school, but a Harris poll released this week shows that 53 percent of American parents are against the practice.

title: In Pretoria: New Man, New Hope
description: P. W. Botha's resignation as President of South Africa merely advanced by a few weeks a transition ordained six months ago. The important question now is whether F. W. de Klerk, sworn in yesterday as Acting President, will advance South Africa's transition from apartheid to democracy with protected minority rights. There's reason to answer with a cautious yes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 Syria and Iran called for the defeat of the Christian Lebanese army. It was Iran's most conspicuous show of support for the Syrian side in the Lebanese conflict. Page A1 The Pope called the shelling of Beirut an attempt at ''genocide,'' and he directly accused Syria of seeking Lebanon's destruction. A10 The U.S. could foresee asking Iran back into ''the family of law-abiding, non-terrorist-sponsoring nations'' if it helped arrange the release of hostages, President Bush said. A8 The Capital: Bush's new approach to hostages and Iran B6 Israel helped 61 Armenians injured during their region's earthquake obtain free artificial limbs. Israel hopes the American-financed gesture will foster good will from Moscow. A1 To end Poland's political stalemate, President Wojciech Jaruzelski called for a meeting of the nation's leading powers. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa welcomed the proposal. A7 South Africa swore in F. W. de Klerk as Acting President. He said the country was about to enter an era of change and reaffirmed promises to phase out white rule. A3 Some Namibian special policemen are confined to bases A3 Vast amounts of algae in the Adriatic continue to spread, sullying some of Europe's finest beaches and killing marine life in that part of the Mediterranean. A6 Release of up to 1,500 Nicaraguans who have been imprisoned for taking part in or supporting the rebels was announced by President Ortega in a gesture of conciliation. A11 General Noriega can stay in Panama so long as he surrenders power, a U.S. official said. ''Our position is that he should leave power,'' the official said. ''Everything after that is up to the Panamanian people.'' A9 New Yorker seized in Ulster A5 National A14-22, B6-8 Leaded gasoline will be replaced at ARCO pumps in California with a ''reformulated'' fuel that could cut pollution from old cars by up to 15 percent, the company said. A1 Miami is bitterly debating a Cuban whom the Government accuses of terrorism and plans to deport. One of his supporters is a G.O.P. Congressional candidate for whom President Bush will campaign today. A1 Cuban-born Democrat loses primary for Florida seat B8 Tougher local anti-drug enforcement and less focus on world traffickers was called for by President Bush. He pledged to find money for the program without raising taxes. A1 A Federal drug agent was arrested Monday on charges of transporting 62 pounds of cocaine from Miami to Boston. The arrest was a result of an internal investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration. A14 A new class of anti-AIDS chemicals appears to have been discovered. Scientists have found some chemicals derived from blue-green algae to be ''remarkably active'' against the virus, they are reporting today. B6 The extension of health benefits to people employees live with outside marriage has been making headway in some states. The potential cost of such benefits has begun to worry employers. D1 Job study on disabled finds work and good pay are scarce A22 The development of Atlantic Beach, S.C., founded as a summer resort for blacks, is being planned. Some blacks fear the plan will not allow for continued black control of the town. A14 Eastern adds flights; sets new discounts D1 Trident 2 missile explodes after sea test A14 Alaska sues 7 oil companies A18 Quayle tells rights leaders Administration backs thier goals A20 Washington Talk B6 August recess means foreign travel for many lawmakers Regional B1-4 AIDS testing is being encouraged for the first time by New York City's largest private organization providing AIDS services, the Gay Men's Health Crisis. A main reason for the policy shift is the promise of new drugs. A1 Rudolph Giuliani and Ronald Lauder are running on divergent paths for the Republican mayoral nomination. Mr. Giuliani, ignoring Mr. Lauder as much as he can, is assuming victory in the upcoming primary. B1 Cuomo denies backing Koch or anybody else for mayor B1 Mayor Koch's campaign returned a loan to a developer B4 Twenty years after the Woodstock festival's first day, hundreds of people visited the site of the concert, pointing out features of the terrain as if they were revisiting a historical battlefield. B1 Leona Helmsley overpaid her taxes and is owed a refund, according to a new audit that her lawyers said exists. The claim contradicts the indictment in the case, which says $1.2 million in taxes was evaded. B1 Labor talks are breaking down between representatives of a New York City hospital union and the League of Voluntary Hospitals over the union's bid for a new contract. B3 Hudson County will transfer inmates today to New Jersey's newest correctional center: an encampment of Army tents in a field of mud in the Hackensack Meadowlands. B3 New Jersey G.O.P. is rebuffed in dispute over spending limits B2 Tax money for Long Island schools, like those in the Five Towns area of Nassau County, is becoming a more divisive issue. High property taxes and aging populations have eroded support for school spending. B2 Cuomo's arguments on Shoreham rejected by U.S. B2 Police find similarities in toddlers' disappearances B3

title: Sports People: BASEBALL; Freehan to Coach
description: The University of Michigan hired the former Detroit Tiger catcher Bill Freehan as baseball coach yesterday.

title: CONGRESSIONAL TRIPS: POLITICAL 'JUNKETEERING' OR SERIOUS BUSINESS
description: It's the August Congressional recess and a lawmaker's fancy turns to travel -to foreign travel, in particular.

title: The Pop Life
description: Music of America

title: Section of Interstate 78 To Reopen to Traffic
description: Emergency repairs to an elevated fire-damaged section of Interstate 78 should open to traffic at 6 A.M. Wednesday, New Jersey officials said today.

title: Manhattan National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Music; A Vivaldi Treatment Without Kid Gloves
description: The prolific Antonio Vivaldi has always had detractors who believe the old joke about his having written one concerto 500 times. And now that classical radio stations are using Baroque music as all-purpose aural wallpaper, the composer's advocates find it even harder to persuade unreconstructed Romanticists that there is more to this music than pretty figuration.

title: Sports People: FOOTBALL; Sloan Resigns
description: Steve Sloan resigned yesterday after two and a half years as athletic director at the University of Alabama because of differences of opinion with the school's new president.

title: LVI Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $2,893,000 for the quarter and $3,420,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary losses of $594,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 6 months.

title: Tim Richmond, 34, Auto Racer
description: Tim Richmond, a former Indianapolis 500 rookie-of-the-year driver whose subsequent stock-car racing career was cut short by controversy and illness, died Sunday. He was 34 years old.

title: Xonics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., a computer graphics company, said General Business Investment Corp., had called off a merger in which General Business would have owned 58 percent of the combined company.

title: Ventrex Labs reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wadkins and Watson on Ryder Team
description: Tom Watson and Lanny Wadkins, a pair of 39-year-old pros with considerable Ryder Cup experience, were named to the United States Ryder Cup team today by their long-time friend and fellow touring pro, Raymond Floyd, who is the nonplaying captain of this year's squad.

title: New Yorker Defying British Is Seized in Ulster
description: A New York lawyer who is a leading fund-raiser for Irish nationalists was arrested in Northern Ireland today after breaching a Government order banning him from Britain.

title: Home Depot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The share earnings reflected a 3-for- 2 stock split in June.

title: Review/Film; An Uncouth Uncle Against the Suburban Grain
description: Uncle Buck (John Candy) is the sort of character that no American suburb should be without. Everything about him offends middle-class manners, fashions and aspirations. Though his ancient automobile needs a muffler and travels around in its own permanent cloud of exhaust smoke, Uncle Buck is a breath of fresh air.

title: Kiddie Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RPS Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said earnings in the latest 6 months included $1,950,000, or 7 cents a share, from the receipt of additional contingent interest and cccrued interest income on the prepayment of a mortgage loan received in the first quarter.

title: Dravecky Injured But Beats Expos, 3-2
description: Dave Dravecky suffered a fracture of his left arm, the one he pitches with and the one on which he had cancer surgery 10 months ago, but got credit for the San Francisco Giants' 3-2 victory tonight over the Montreal Expos.

title: Once Again, Yanks Can't Beat Higuera
description: A pitcher as good as Teddy Higuera doesn't need much to work with. Tonight against the Yankees, the Milwaukee Brewers gave Higuera one run. That was all he needed.

title: JARUZELSKI URGES A POLISH SUMMIT
description: President Wojciech Jaruzelski called today for a meeting of Poland's leading forces to break a government deadlock.

title: Dow Advances 9.86, to 2,687.78; Investors Await U.S. Data
description: Stocks ended moderately higher yesterday as investors remained on the sidelines.

title: Study of Dorfman Reported
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether USA Today's financial columnist, Dan Dorfman, was used, wittingly or unwittingly, by people who gave him information in order to manipulate stock prices, U.S. News & World Report said in its Aug. 21 issue published today.

title: Trident Missile Explodes in Test; Failure Is 2d of 3 Sea Launchings
description: A Trident 2 missile exploded shortly after it was launched today from a submerged submarine off the Florida coast. It was the second time the missile had failed in three test launchings.

title: Suitor Challenging Dunkin' E.S.O.P.
description: The DD Acquisition Corporation said it would challenge Dunkin' Donuts Inc.'s employee stock ownership plan in the Delaware Chancery Court. DD said that if the plan, which Dunkin' Donuts established as a takeover defense, is invalidated, it will raise its offer for the company, based in Randolph, Mass., to $45 a share from $43.

title: Of the Moment, Yes, But Still Momentous
description: Once more, we Angelenos have managed to generate a national guffaw, this time over a citizen attempt to have a city carwash named a landmark.

title: Bach to Bach
description: A new star of anthropomorphism has flashed across the heavens and unlike C3PO, R2D2 and other machines invested with human qualities, it is real. Voyager 2, which left Earth 12 years and 2.8 billion miles ago, is nearing Neptune. After so monumental a journey, it's understandable that people now refer to it as brave little Voyager 2, describe its creaky joints as arthritic and thrill at the thought that it may still be talking to us from interstellar space for 25 more years.

title: Homeowners Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Israel Tends to Quake Victims, and Soviet Ties
description: On their own if they were able, in pairs if they were not, 61 Armenians stepped off an El Al jetliner onto an Aeroflot stairway this afternoon, smiling and waving at nearly 1,000 friends and family members who cheered and threw carnations from the terminal balcony a short distance away.

title: MORE YOUTHS TAKE TOUGHER COURSES, STUDY FINDS
description: The number of high school students taking advanced mathematics and science courses increased significantly from 1982 to 1987, the Educational Testing Service says.

title: Sara Lee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Sara Lee said its full-year earnings included a pre-tax gain of about $87 million, or 40 cents a share, from the sale of three subsidiaries. Full year results also included a provision for restructuring of $55 million.

title: U.N. Council Calls for Cease-Fire And Arab Mediation in Lebanon
description: The United Nations Security Council called for an immediate cease-fire in Lebanon late Tuesday and urged the Arab League to resume mediation efforts it discontinued last month.

title: Putting My Money Where My House Is
description: In 1988, my Federal taxes were two and one-half times greater than the taxes I paid to Maine, my state taxes were three times larger than my local property taxes to Waterville, and the ratio of Federal to city taxes was nine to one.

title: MAYORAL HOPEFUL CLAIMS TRAIN TURF
description: Looking for a certain audacity in a mayoral candidate?

title: Bush Endorses Strategy Outline For Drug Battle
description: President Bush endorsed the outline of a national strategy to attack the drug problem today, placing more emphasis on local law enforcement and less on international drug trafficking. He pledged to find money to pay for the program without raising taxes.

title: Salvador: Finally A Gleam?
description: The Administration's decision not to oppose the Dec. 8 deadline for disbanding the Nicaraguan contras offers hope for El Salvador. If President Bush will agree to try political compromise to end the Salvadoran civil war as well, he will likely find the leftist guerrillas in a cooperative mood.

title: Treasury Securities Move Higher
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in moderately active trading yesterday as dealers snapped up securities at yield levels they had not seen in weeks.

title: ARCO Offers New Gasoline to Cut Up to 15% of Old Cars' Pollution
description: In a first step in its strategy to make gasoline environmentally competitive with cleaner alternatives, ARCO announced today that it would replace leaded gasoline at its California pumps with a ''reformulated'' fuel that could cut pollution from cars manufactured before 1975 by as much as 15 percent.

title: Interco Names A New Chief
description: Interco, the St. Louis-based diversified company, said today that it had named Richard B. Loynd chief executive, replacing Harvey Saligman, who announced that he would retire next May.

title: Lionel M. Gelber, Historian, 82
description: Lionel M. Gelber, a historian and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Aug. 10 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Toronto, where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Eastex Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hoechst Profits Decline
description: Hoechst A.G., the large West German chemical company, said today that its pretax profits in the second quarter slipped 1.8 percent, to 1.1 billion marks, or $565 million, after a 23 percent gain in the first quarter. Hoechst said its profits were squeezed because it was unable to pass the entire rise in raw material costs on to consumers.

title: Rudolf Nureyev, Actor and King
description: The rehearsal pianist launches into the opening bars of ''Shall We Dance.'' Suddenly the actress who plays Anna, the English governess who is hired to tutor the crown prince of Siam in ''The King and I,'' coaxes the new actor playing the King into trying the polka. The lip-biting monarch with two left feet takes a few tentative steps, then the two of them sweep off, circling the battered studio floor at a ferocious pace to the laughter, cheers and whistles of the other cast members.

title: Synergistics Indus() reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Captain Video Bringing Mike To Big City
description: What the heck. Roger Neilson has already coached for Bick's Pickles and for Harold Ballard, the ogre of Maple Leaf Gardens. He might as well coach for the Rangers, too.

title: TJX Cos reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After gains of $1,942,000 for the quarter and $7,074,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $30,758,000 for the quarter and $38,771,000 for the 6 months. This is the first time that the company is reporting its earnings since the completion of its restructuring and its name change from Zayre Corp. to TJX Cos.

title: Federal Home Loan Banks Price $2.88 Billion in Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday priced $2.88 billion in bonds at par through various securities dealers.

title: Better Uses for Our Money Than the Dubious B-2; Save Minds Instead
description: To the Editor:

title: Narcotics Agent Held in Boston On Drug Charge
description: A Federal drug agent was arrested here Monday by fellow agents and charged with trafficking in cocaine.

title: Junk Bond Defaults at 11.2%
description: A new study released yesterday found that 11.2 percent of the high-yield, high-risk junk bonds issued since 1980 have defaulted.

title: Israeli Army Imposes Curfew After Attack in West Bank
description: Israeli troops, reacting to a Palestinian firebombing attack, imposed a curfew, welded shut Arab stores and sealed off an alley in an occupied West Bank town, Ramallah.

title: Economic Scene; Old Games, New Rules
description: THE postwar world economy prospered for decades with the United States in charge. But how do you keep the show on the road with three, five or a dozen bosses?

title: Executive Leaving ABC For a Post at CNN
description: Pamela Hill, an executive at ABC News whose documentaries have won several broadcast journalism awards, said yesterday that she would leave ABC to head a new documentary unit for the Cable News Network. At CNN, she will be a vice president and executive producer, titles she has held at ABC since 1979.

title: Services for Leland
description: The family of Representative Mickey Leland announced today that a burial Mass would be held at 10 A.M. Saturday at St. Anne's Catholic Church in Houston. A community memorial service was scheduled for Friday at Texas Southern University.

title: That Other Wine Country, Sonoma, Celebrates Itself
description: Joy Sterling, who is a partner in Iron Horse Vineyards, was the high bidder on the Old-Timers Collection at the Sonoma County Wine Auction on Saturday. She paid $820 for 13 bottles of California wine, many of which, in their heyday a half-century ago, probably sold for less than $1.

title: Discounts Spur Sales Of Vehicles
description: Steep discounts aimed at clearing bloated inventories of 1989 models lifted sales of domestically made cars to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.9 million in early August, the strongest level in six months, the auto makers reported today.

title: McClain Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHEMICALS STOP GROWTH OF AIDS VIRUS IN TEST
description: Several chemicals derived from blue-green algae have been found to be ''remarkably active'' against the AIDS virus in test-tube experiments, Federal scientists are reporting today.

title: KEY RATES
Hospitals Sue Massachusetts Over Back Bills
description: A private hospital association filed suit today to force the state to speed the payment of Medicaid bills and pay $350 million in back bills.

title: WINE TALK
description: The secret of great wine is selection. When a famous chateau blends its wine each year, only the best batches are kept. The rest used to be sold off to a negociant, or shipper, who would blend it with the discards of other chateaus and sell it under the name of the region the wine comes from: Margaux, St.-Julien, Pauillac. Now these leftovers are kept at the chateau and, more often than not, sold under the chateau's second label.

title: Atlanta Journal-Constitution Names Two News Executives
description: Glenn McCutchen, managing editor of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution since 1985, has been promoted to executive editor of the newspapers, they announced over the weekend.

title: Football; Soft-Spoken Monk Adjusts to Role as Redskins' Leader
description: Art Monk, after avoiding the news media for much of the past six seasons, has shed his reclusive image at the Washington Redskins' training camp.

title: Black Resort in South Splits Over Developing
description: Tucked among the condominium glitter of South Carolina's Grand Strand beach front, Atlantic Beach is an oddity: an enclave of small cottages, overgrown lots and 800 year-round residents, virtually all of them black, that has intentionally avoided development.

title: APL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,674,000. c-After net of $445,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,256,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error a diagram in some editions with an article in Science Times yesterday about the lunar eclipse tonight incorrectly described the path of the Moon through the shadow of the Earth. To a viewer looking south, the Moon appears to move from left to right over the horizon. During the eclipse tonight, the shadow of the Earth will also move from left to right, eventually overtaking and passing the Moon. As a result, the Moon will appear to be moving through the shadow from right to left.

title: Irvine Sensors reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
H & H Oil Tool reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Quayle Tells Civil Rights Leaders White House Backs Their Goals
description: Vice President Dan Quayle told civil rights leaders today that they and the Bush Administration might differ over ''the course the nation must travel'' on racial issues but agree on ''the ultimate destination.''

title: DETECTIVES DISCOVER 6 SIMILARITIES IN DISAPPEARANCES OF 2 TODDLERS
description: Six similarities in recent separate disappearances of two toddlers in Harlem have led the police to believe that the cases are linked, the chief of Manhattan detectives said yesterday.

title: JMB Group Gets TV Concern Stake
description: An investment group led by the JMB Realty Corporation, the Chicago real estate concern, has acquired a 6.6 percent stake in the American Television and Communications Corporation, the Stamford, Conn., cable concern, for $66 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the JMB group said it had acquired the American Television shares for investment purposes.

title: Murder-Trial Juror Slain in California; Suspect Is a Suicide
description: A juror deliberating in the trial of the man accused of being the ''Night Stalker'' serial killer was found dead Monday, and the police said today that a man sought in her slaying committed suicide and admitted in a note to killing the juror during a domestic dispute.

title: Investigation in Venezuela: Catharsis or a Witch Hunt?
description: Six months after Carlos Andres Perez was inaugurated on Feb. 2, South America's largest oil exporting nation seems to be speaking with two tongues to foreign investors.

title: Better Food Labels
description: To The Living Section:

title: Collagen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $241,000 from a tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Choice in East Village Is Comfort for Few or Survival of Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Soviet Union is to be competitive, we must hit the inside curveball.'' - Aleksei L. Nikolov, at the Soviet Union's first baseball stadium. [ A1:6. ]

title: EDUCATION: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Nancie Atwell, an experienced teacher in Maine who believes in encouraging children to express themselves on paper at an early age, practices with her own 3-year-old Anne what she has been preaching in the classroom. Recently, she found a note pinned to Anne's room: ''KEP OT.''

title: Identifying Bacteria? Check Their Breath
description: The old maxim, ''You are what you eat,'' seems to apply to even the smallest life forms. A new technology can identify microorganisms by feeding them various substances and then analyzing their breath.

title: Exxon Valdez Moving To Giant Repair Dock
description: Shipyard workers today began moving the Exxon Valdez from a pier to a dock where the tanker that caused the nation's worst oil spill will be repaired over the next nine months.

title: A Top Official Quits Turner
description: Robert J. Wussler announced today that he would resign from Turner Broadcasting System Inc., after 10 years in which the senior executive vice president helped guide the international expansion of the cable television concern.

title: Cable Group's Loss Widens
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest operator and developer of cable television systems, today reported a second-quarter loss of $63.6 million, almost three times its loss of $21.9 million a year earlier.

title: Mechanical Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $671,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $182,000 for the quarter and $317,000 for the 9 months.

title: Eating to Beat the Band at Tanglewood
description: AS the musicians of the Boston Symphony gather backstage at the Music Shed at Tanglewood in anticipation of the evening's concert, the curtain has already risen for Charles Voos, the chef at the Seranak Supper Club.

title: Housing Bill Offers a Cleanup of H.U.D.
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods' net per senior participating preferred shares were $1.59 for the quarter and $3.17 for the 6 months, compared with $1.41 a share and $2.82 a share for the same year- ago periods, respectively. The latest periods' net per non-voting common shares were $105.99 for the quarter and $200.36 for the 6 months, compared with $94.12 a share and $177.18 a share for the same year- ago periods, respectively. The company said its year-ago per share figures have been restated.

title: ICO Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $1,259,000 from refinancing of secured bank indebtedness. c-Net income and included a extraodinary gain of $11,807,000 from restructuring of subordinated debentures for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference here today, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: 'Cocktail Hour' Is Closing
description: ''The Cocktail Hour,'' a semi-autobiographical comedy by A. R. Gurney, will close on Sunday after the matinee at the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street. Directed by Jack O'Brien and starring Nancy Marchand, Burt Edwards, Holland Taylor and Richard Buckus, the play will have run for 15 previews and 351 regular performances.

title: Furor Over Castro Foe's Fate Puts Bush on Spot in Miami
description: When President Bush comes here Wednesday to campaign for a Republican Congressional candidate, he will find himself in the middle of a bitter debate that has split Miami and raised the issue of whether there is such a thing as a good terrorist.

title: Artist Who Outraged Congress Lives Amid Christian Symbols
description: ''There are dangers faced by artists who deal provocatively with religious symbols,'' said Andres Serrano, the photographer whose picture of a crucified Christ submerged in urine has helped set off probably the strongest Congressional attack on the National Endowment for the Arts in that agency's 25-year history.

title: ITT Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: ITT Financial is a wholly owned subsidiary of ITT Corp.

title: Some Namibia Special Policemen Confined to Bases
description: Moving to defuse a major issue of contention in Namibia's transition to independence, the territory's South African administrator today ordered 1,200 members of a counterinsurgency unit back to their bases in the northern part of the territory.

title: 20th Century Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter net included a charge equal to 12 cents a share representing the company's estimation of potential liabilities arising from the passage of Proposition 103. The latest periods included pre-tax realized investment gains of 3 cents a share for the quarter and 4 cents a share for the 6 months, compared with 7 cents a share and 22 cents a share for the same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Book Notes
description: Roth Changes Houses

title: Medar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $140,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operation of $664,331 and $757,574 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Maxco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $156,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $838,000.

title: In the Supermarket, a Long, Hard Search for Quality Produce
description: ONE morning last month, at an hour when less compulsive souls on vacation are still asleep, four Americans armed themselves with large straw baskets and invaded the Marche Forville, the large central market in Cannes on the French Riviera. Three hours later, after a shop-till-you-drop spree, they emerged, baskets brimming with spectacular produce.

title: New Tenor in 'Davidde'
description: The tenor Frank Lopardo will replace Vinson Cole in the Mostly Mozart performance of ''Davidde Penitente'' next Tuesday and Wednesday. Patricia Schuman, a soprano, is the other soloist. Also on the all-Mozart program are Divertimento in D (K. 2251), and the Violin Concerto No. 4 in D with Midori as soloist. Gerard Schwarz will conduct.

title: De Klerk Becomes Pretoria President
description: F. W. de Klerk was sworn in today as Acting President of South Africa and said that the country was about to enter an era of change.

title: Agency Review Will Be on TV
description: Television viewers will get a rare opportunity to peek inside a company's advertising agency review on Friday, when CNBC, the cable-television network, shows final creative presentations in Playboy magazine's agency search.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Quebecor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Results Plus
description: SWIMMING

title: Agencies to Merge
description: Gearon Hoffman, a Boston agency, and Conlon & Nye in New York have said they will merge their accounts, names and futures at the end of August, creating a $40 million agency named Gearon Hoffman Conlon & Nye. Its accounts will include indigenous representatives of the agency's two home ports: the Boston Beer Company, brewer of Samuel Adams beer, and The Daily News in New York.

title: HELMSLEYS DUE TAX REFUND, DEFENSE SAYS
description: As the prosecution finished its case in the Leona Helmsley tax fraud and extortion trial yesterday, lawyers for the defense asserted that they had commissioned a new audit showing that the Helmsleys had overpaid their taxes and were owed a refund.

title: Personal Diagnostics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fischbach Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $10,433,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago 9 months included $6.9 million of interest income on a tax refund.

title: Note From William Safire: A Follow-Up on Mr. Rappaport
description: On July 27 and Aug. 3, I reported that the State Department had notified U.S. investigators into the Iran-contra diversion of new information: It had heard from Swiss officials that the unidentified recipient of $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei was a Swiss financier named Bruce Rappaport. My report of State's notification to investigators was accurate.

title: Gannett Names New Managers
description: The Gannett Company today announced several management changes in its newspaper division, including the appointment of Craig A. Moon as president and publisher of The Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Information Company named Robert M. Scott president of its WATS Marketing Group subsidiary.

title: Atlanta Teams Are Lacking Winning Tradition
description: Pearl Sandow believes in accentuating the positive, but after attending every home game in the dismal 23-year history of the Atlanta Braves, she knows there's a fine line between being optimistic and being foolish.

title: Signal Apparel Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The net in the latest 6 months included a gain of $585,000, or 19 cents a share, resulting primarily from termination of pension plans, and a gain of $292,000, or 9 cents a share, from a change in accounting methods.

title: Pro Bono
description: BBDO Atlanta is creating a broadcast campaign for Literacy Action Inc., a nonprofit organization in Atlanta that teaches adults to read.

title: Review/Film; Arousing the Old Populism For a New Antiwar Protest
description: ''Rude Awakening,'' opening today at the Embassy 3 and other theaters, is hapless but endearing, much like its principal characters. They are a small group of 1960's flower children who come together in the 1980's, determined to reawaken the old populism that began as protest to the Vietnam War.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: U.S. Is Easing Its Terms for the Ouster of Noriega
description: Administration officials said today that the United States was backing away from demands that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega leave Panama and was willing to let him stay if he surrendered power.

title: LOUIS THAYER, 82, SAFETY OFFICIAL
description: Louis M. Thayer, who was a member of the National Transportation Safety Board for nine years after retiring as a rear admiral in the Coast Guard, died of a heart attack Aug. 9 at his home in St. Augustine, Fla. He was 82 years old and had lived in the Washington area for 25 years before moving to Florida last year.

title: Corrections
description: A section of the Business and Health column in Business Day yesterday was obliterated in some copies by a misplaced drawing. Readers wishing corrected copies of the column may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: TALKS APPEAR AT STALEMATE IN 2d DAY OF HOSPITAL STRIKE
description: As thousands of hospital workers in metropolitan New York stayed away from their jobs yesterday on the second day of a planned three-day strike, management and labor appeared close to a total breakdown of their three- month-long negotiations.

title: LAWYER EASILY WINS NOMINATION TO REPLACE PEPPER IN THE HOUSE
description: Gerald Richman, a lawyer who drew sharp criticism for remarking that he was running for ''an American seat,'' decisively captured the Democratic nomination today in the race to succeed the late Representative Claude Pepper.

title: Neco Enterprises Inc reports earnings for 12mos June 30
Strong Gains For Retailers In Quarter
description: Buoyed by strong sales in the last two months, the J. C. Penney Company, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, posted an increase in net income of 21 percent in its second quarter, while the Dayton Hudson Corporation doubled its profits.

title: HUDSON COUNTY IS TRANSFERRING INMATES TO TENTS
description: Under a court order to ease overcrowding at its jail, Hudson County is to transfer 100 inmates Wednesday to New Jersey's newest correctional center: an encampment of Army tents in a field of mud in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Northern Trash
description: LEAD: This newspaper may well end up wrapped around the tombstones of Confederate soldiers in Alleghany County, Va. That's what happened here five months ago, when March went out like a lion, blowing a blizzard of trash over the chain-link fence around the Kim-Stan Sanitary Landfill and laying it down in the Oakland Presbyterian Church

title: Russian Life Is a Cabaret Again, With New Chums
description: In refuge from 70 years of official mirthlessness, Muscovites are scurrying once again after the Bat, the historic Russian cabaret of irreverence routed from this city in 1920 and resurrected now as the hottest ticket in town.

description: Moving into the final month of the primary campaign, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ronald Lauder are running on widely divergent paths for the Republican nomination for mayor of New York City.

title: Navy Is Sued by an AIDS-Devastated Family
description: A marine has filed a $55 million lawsuit against the Navy, charging that malpractice forced his wife to have a blood transfusion that infected her with the AIDS virus, which she passed on to him and their son.

title: SPANISH STATIONS INVITE, BUT CANDIDATES BEG OFF
description: Unless Mayor Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins change their minds, there will be an empty place at each of two upcoming debates on Spanish-language radio and television. And that makes it unlikely that there could be another debate with all four Democratic candidates.

title: Times Co. Cable TV Sale
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced sale of its cable television system, NYT Cable TV, for $420 million to a limited partnership owned by Garden State Cablevision Inc., the Comcast Corporation and Lenfest Communications Inc. The Times Company said it expected an after-tax gain of about $193 million, or $2.46 a share, in the third quarter.

title: Pandick Sells Unit
description: Pandick Inc., a large financial printer, said it had agreed to sell its Pandick Technologies division to Pitney Bowes Inc.. Terms of the sale were not disclosed, but people close to the purchase said the Stamford, Conn., business supplies company would pay slightly less than $100 million. Pandick, which was taken private in a $250 million leveraged buyout in December 1986, will use the the proceeds from the sale to reduce debt, said Anthony K. Moulton, its chairman and chief executive.

David Miller, Mayor, 52
description: David Miller, the Mayor of Tonawanda, N.Y., and an official of the Western New York Economic Development Corporation, suffered a heart attack and died on his way to work Monday at the development corporation's office in Buffalo. He was 52 years old.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WARM seafood salads, which have become quite popular in restaurants, are ideal for home cooks. They are light, healthful and attractive. Shrimp and scallops are particularly well suited for them because they cook so quickly.

title: Iowa Vote on River Gambling: 2 Counties Yes, 1 County No
description: In the first referendums on Iowa's new riverboat gambling law, two Mississippi River counties voted today to let floating casinos land at their docks and voters in a third county said no.

title: BANK FUNDS AND C.D.'S SHOW DROP
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly down for the week ended yesterday, as the slide in bank deposit rates entered its 15th week.

title: Pope, Addressing Syrians, Labels The Shelling of Beirut 'Genocide'
description: Pope John Paul II today called the latest shelling of Beirut an attempt at ''genocide,'' and he directly accused Syria of seeking Lebanon's destruction.

title: Mets Gamble and Win in 9th Against Padres
description: The Mets won a gamble, a foot race and a ball game last night in Shea Stadium when they rallied for two runs in the ninth inning to edge the San Diego Padres, 3-2, and moved into second place, three and a half games behind the Chicago Cubs.

title: Time to Replace Spofford
description: New York City's Department of Juvenile Justice has prepared a sensible plan to replace the inaccessible, inadequate Spofford juvenile detention center with two smaller, better designed facilities. The plan deserves the Board of Estimate's backing. There is broad agreement on the merits. Juvenile Justice managers find Spofford poorly designed - long walks between dormitories and dining hall, for example, require a heavy investment in supervision, and program space is limited. In addition, Spofford's location, in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, makes it difficult for inmates' families and lawyers to visit and requires costly transportation of offenders to and from court.

title: Union Asks Pilots' Support in Bid for UAL
description: Leaders of the pilots' union at United Airlines told its 7,000 members in a letter yesterday that they should prepare to participate in an attempt to take over the UAL Corporation, the airline's parent company.

title: G.O.P. IS REBUFFED ON FLORIO SPENDING LIMIT
description: New Jersey's Republican Party was rebuffed today in an attempt to have the cost of an extensive advertising campaign in support of abortion rights counted toward the spending limit of the Democratic candidate for governor, Representative James J. Florio.

title: Playing Sports Dosen't Lift Grades, Study Finds
description: Although participating in high school athletics tends to keep student-athletes in school, leads them to participate in other extracurricular activities and makes them feel more popular than nonathletes, it has virtually no immediate effect on academic achievement for most minority-group students. And it has even less impact on their later success in college and the work force.

Bridge
description: In one matter of bidding style, there is a wide gulf between European and North American experts. On this side of the Atlantic, the strong jump shift is rarely used and is sometimes shelved altogether in favor of the weak jump shift. In Britain, the bid is used freely to suggest slam possibilities, and it helped British players reach the final of the World Women's Team Olympiad in Venice last October.

title: THIS TIME, A PERSONAL WOODSTOCK

title: Study on Disabled and Jobs Finds Work and Good Pay Are Scarce
description: Disabled Americans are less likely to hold jobs now than they were earlier this decade, and those who work have lost earning power, the Census Bureau reported today.

Fourteen years of civil war have killed more than 100,000 of tiny Lebanon's people, destroyed its economy and left its communities in ruins. Now five months of artillery battles between Christian and Syrian forces have almost emptied Beirut of its 1.5 million residents.

Dry beer was first produced in Japan in 1987, and then American, Canadian and European brewers got into the act. At least 19 imported and domestic dry beers have been introduced in the United States in the last year or so, many just in time for the summer surge in beer drinking. title: Lebanon's Warring Factions
description: SYRIANS AND ALLIES Syria, whose troops entered Lebanon in 1976, has about 40,000 soldiers there. They control about 70 percent of Lebanese territory. After initiallay seeking to curb Muslim factions, they began fighting Christian forces in later years. The Lebanese Army's Muslim units are commanded by Maj. Gen. Sami Khatib and number about 22,000 Druse, Shiite and Sunni soldiers. The Druse militia of the Progressive Socialist Party, led by Walid Jumblat, numbers about 4,000 fighters, and has been fighting alongside the Syrians. The Druse community is an offshoot of Islam and its military base is in the Shuf mountains southeast of Beirut. The Party of God, a pro-Iranian Shiite militia and rival of Amal, has about 3,500 fighters. It controls Beirut's southern slums but has its main base in the Baalbek area of easters Lebanon. Supplied by Iran. it also received military training from 2,000 Revolutionary Guards sent into Lebanon from Iran in 1983. The Palestinians involved in the fighting, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, and the Fatah Uprising, consist of about 1,000 radical pro-Syrian dissidents out of the mainstream Palestine Liberation Organization of Yasir Arafat. The Popular Front Guerrillas are commanded by a former Syrian army captain, Ahmed Jabril, and those of the Fatah Uprising by Saed Musa. ANTI-SYRIAN FORCES The Lebanese Army's Christian units are commanded by Gen. Michel Aoun, a Maronite Catholic, and numbers about 20,000 soldiers, among whome the Maronites dominate. They are the main force defending the Christian districts in and around Beirut. The Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia, is led by Samir Geagea. It numbers some 6,000 fighters, many trained and equipped by Israel. The South Lebanon Army is also backed by Israel, the army, mainly Christian, numbers about 2,500 fighters who, with 1,000 Israeli troops, patrol a 50-milke-long and 6-mile-deep area immediately north of the Israeli border that Israel calls its security zone.

title: Vietnam experience has made the Joint Chiefs cautious about using military force.
description: The Pentagon contends that the primary role of the armed forces is to deter war, not to fight one. Since Vietnam, a succession of military officers making up the Joint Chiefs of Staff has elevated that policy to a fine art.

description: The Congressional Budget Office projects the Federal deficit at $141 billion in the next fiscal year, figures obtained today show.

title: L.I. Bank Challenging Part of Savings Bailout
description: A savings bank has challenged the provisions of the legislation signed last week by President Bush that impose tougher capital requirements on savings associations, asserting that the new rules violate contracts it signed with Federal agencies.

title: Bumble Bee Seafoods Sold to Thai Concern
description: The Pillsbury Company, a subsidiary of the British conglomerate Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said today that it had sold its Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. division to a Thai company for $269 million in cash.

title: LAWYER NAMED TO E.P.A. JOB
description: A member of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, has been appointed head of the Environmental Protection Agency's New York region.

title: Africans Ask U.N. to Scrutinize Namibia Vote
description: African countries renewed charges today that South Africa is seeking to stop the South-West Africa People's Organization from taking power in an independent Namibia and asked the Security Council to intervene in election preparations.

title: PEACE PLEAS FAIL TO QUIET LEBANON
description: Warring factions fought more artillery and rocket duels today despite urgent calls for an end to the bloodshed from the United Nations Security Council and from Arab mediators.

title: E. Mark Beckman, Gynecologist, 53
description: Dr. E. Mark Beckman, professor of clinical obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University School of Medicine, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center after being injured in a bicycle accident. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Business Digest

The company also said second- quarter earnings were hurt by late delivery of vessels to the company and the withdrawal from service of two product tankers for upgrading and maintenance.

title: MURDER TRIAL JURY TOLD TO CONTINUE
description: The judge in the trial of a man suspected in the ''Night Stalker'' serial killings ruled today that the jury should continue its deliberations despite the killing of a juror, prompting a dramatic outburst from the defendant.

title: INFORMER WARNED POLICE BEFORE OFFICER WAS SHOT
description: The supervisors of an undercover narcotics officer shot last week in the Bronx in a drug deal that went sour were warned that the dealers planned to rob the officer but went ahead with the operation anyway, the Chief of Organized Crime Control said yesterday.

title: Wang Labs Plans to Default on Debt
description: In a surprise move, Wang Laboratories said yesterday that it would default on almost $1 billion in long- and short-term debt while discussions with its bank lenders continued.

title: PARTENT & CHILD
description: OF the thousands of adolescents who will be going off to college in the next month, a disturbing number will not graduate. For many of those students, the freshman year will be a watershed. Within days of starting their first classes, they will find themselves facing rigorous academic and social challenges unlike anything they have ever experienced. All too often their response to these challenges will be to drop out of school.

CURRENTS;
At Last, a T-Shirt That's Properly Serious
description: LEAD: CURTIS WAGNER, a designer, decided that the T-shirt deserved more graphic inventiveness than the name of one's exercise club or favorite motto. It should be an art form, or rather an architectural form.

Kingdom Sets World Record In Hurdles With 12.92
description: Battling history and a mild strep throat, Roger Kingdom ran the 110-meter hurdles in 12.92 seconds tonight to break the world record set by his idol and friend, Renaldo Nehemiah, eight years ago here at the Weltklasse meet in Letzigrund Stadium.

title: Housing Starts Rose 0.8% in July
description: Driven down for four months by high mortgage rates, housing starts rose for the second consecutive month in July, the Government reported today. Analysts said single-family construction should continue at a moderate pace the rest of the year.

title: WQXR Concert Series
description: The radio station WQXR is presenting a series of free concerts at the Damrosch Band Shell at Lincoln Center through Sept. 12. The concerts are to take place from 7 to 8 P.M., and are to be broadcast over WQXR (96.3 FM and 1560 AM). Performers are the Amherst Saxophone Quartet on Tuesday; the Paragon Ragtime Orchestra on Aug. 30; the pianist Abbey Simon on Sept. 5, and the Composers String Quartet with the cellist Carlos Prieto on Sept. 12. The concerts will take place whatever the weather.

title: Review/Music; A Joyful Jazz From Al Grey And His Band
description: It has often been forgotten, given the political and esthetic upheavals of the last 25 years, that joy is one of jazz's great pleasures. Joy reigned at Fat Tuesday's Tuesday night during the veteran trombonist Al Grey's show. It was a joy that was linked to an obvious pleasure in creating, in replacing the blank spaces of silence with well-detailed ideas.

title: Baraka and Son Are Arrested In Confrontation With Police
description: The playwright and poet Imamu Amiri Baraka and one of his sons were arrested today on assault charges following an argument with the police, officials said.

Results for 1988 have been restated.

Korean Growth Outlook
description: After three years of rapid growth, the South Korean economic pace is steadying, making continued growth dependent on a stable currency and increased corporate investment, a research group said today. The group, the Korea Development Institute, predicted that the gross national product this year would grow by 7.7 percent, a respectable figure by global standards but far lower than South Korea's 12.2 percent growth in 1988.

title: Aird Journal; At the Fringe of the World, a Dour Land to Farm
description: Working a tiny tenant farm on the sandy soil of a remote wind-battered island scarcely seems an occupation with a future. Yet crofting, long dismissed as an economic and social anachronism, is enjoying a quiet resurgence.

title: Loomis Stake In Texas Air
description: A Boston money management firm, Loomis Sayles & Company, said yesterday that it had acquired 12 percent of the Texas Air Corporation.

title: As Vote Nears, Dissent Racks Gandhi's Party
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's leadership is coming under increasing criticism from members of his own party as concern grows about the party's prospects in general elections a few months away.

GENERAL MINORU GENDA, 84, DIES: PLANNED ATTACK ON PEARL HARBOR
description: General Minoru Genda, who planned the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died of heart disease in a Tokyo hospital Tuesday on the 44th anniversary of the end of the World War II. He would have been 85 years old yesterday.

title: Darling Keeps Mets' Momentum Going
description: The Mets kept barreling through August last night, bowled over the San Diego Padres with old-time pitching and power hitting, won for the 13th time in their last 16 games and stayed on the heels of the Chicago Cubs, three and a half lengths in front.

title: Salem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Pulitzer to Sell Station
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company said today that it had agreed to sell its television station in Fort Wayne, Ind., to the Granite Broadcasting Corporation. The station, WPTA-TV, is an ABC affiliate. The sale price is $26.5 million in cash. Granite, a private company, owns NBC-affiliated television stations in Duluth, Minn., and Peoria, Ill. Pulitzer said it would receive a special tax consideration in the deal under Federal rules governing sales of broadcast properties to companies controlled by members of a minority.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BCE Inc., Montreal, said it was still seeking buyers for its 65 percent stake in BCE Development Corp., Vancouver, British Columbia, a real estate development concern. Olympia & York Developments terminated its offer for the concern earlier this week.

title: Dravecky Was Told He Risked Fracture
description: Dave Dravecky, the Giant pitcher whose throwing arm snapped as he was delivering a pitch Tuesday night, had been warned that he would be risking just such a fracture if he returned to the mound so soon after surgery to remove a cancerous growth from his left arm, his surgeon and the Giants' team doctor said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe that under the leadership of Lech Walesa a parliamentary coalition of Peasants, Democrats and Solidarity is capable of forming a government of national responsibility in which there can be represented all the political forces of our country that have decided to act toward political and economic reforms.'' - A caucus of opposition members of Poland's Parliament. [ A14:1. ]

title: 2d Border Dispute Adds to Senegal's Troubles
description: The Government of Senegal, already embroiled in a bitter border dispute with Mauritania, its northern neighbor, now faces another confrontation on its southern frontier.

title: KEY RATES
Results Plus
description: CYCLING Ekimov Regains Lead: Vyacheslav Ekimov of the Soviet Union returned to the top of the amateur individual pursuit competition with a victory yesterday at the world championships at Lyon, France. But he said he wants to turn professional soon. ''I have had a number of proposals from teams from France, the United States, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain.,'' he said. ''I don't want to say which one it will be. But it is certain I will turn professional and concentrate on the road races.''

title: The Battle Over Medical Costs
description: Several large employers have been stymied in their efforts to shift some of the soaring costs of medical care to unionized workers in contract settlements this year. Organized labor has in some significant cases successfully resisted concessions already made by nonunion employees.

title: Union and Hospital in Talks
description: As a three-day strike against 53 hospitals ended yesterday, the head of the hospital workers union said that an ''understanding'' had been reached with a Brooklyn medical center. Dennis Rivera, the president of Local 1199 of the Health and Hospital Workers Union said talks are underway with the Interfaith Medical Center on ''technical details to make a contract possible.'' Theodore R. Jamison, the president of Interfaith, called the talks fruitful, but said that an agreement depends on resolution of financial problems threatening the hospital. He said that Mr. Rivera offered to use the union's influence to assist Interfaith in encouraging the state to release monies due for care of uninsured patients.

title: Anti-Apartheid Leader Slain After Release From Custody
description: An anti-apartheid youth leader freed from detention last week was shot and killed outside his home today, his family said.

description: Politicians have been blowing the whistle on each other in Supreme Court in Manhattan and Brooklyn in the last week. Some sordid political tales have been told.

title: From Vermont Maples Tiny Parthenons Grow
description: LEAD: TO Ron Bower and many of his customers, building blocks are more than toys. And at $49 to $219, his maple Archiblocks, which museum shop operators say are the only wooden architectural blocks made in the United States, hardly seem ordinary playthings.

title: Islanders Sign Healy
description: Glenn Healy, a free-agent goalie who played with the Los Angeles Kings last season, has signed with the Islanders. The Kings will receive a fourth-round draft choice as compensation. Healy, 26 years old, was the Kings' starting goaltender for most of the season before Los Angeles acquired Kelly Hrudey from the Islanders in late February. Healy played 48 games with a 25-19-2 record. (AP)

description: The city will be allowed to tear down seven apartment buildings but must provide new units under an agreement settling a challenge of the nation's largest planned demolition of public housing, a Federal official said today.

title: Services for Leland
description: The family of Representative Mickey Leland announced Tuesday that a burial Mass would be held at 10 A.M. Saturday at St. Anne's Catholic Church in Houston. A community memorial service was scheduled for Friday at Texas Southern University.

JAMBALAYA PASSION FEEDS LENGTHY LINES ON BROADWAY
description: Lilly Bunn, a third-grade student at the Spence School, waited in a two-and-a-half-hour line for dinner on lower Broadway the other night. It was not the usual thing for her, or for her 10-year-old sister, Palmer. ''Maybe for the movies but not for dinner,'' Lilly reflected, sucking on a strawberry Mento.

title: Scotsman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Scotsman was spun off to holders of Household International Inc. on April 14. Second quarter and 6-month earnings included the first two weeks of the quarter prior to the spin-off date.

title: Hunt Declines To Enter Race Against Helms
description: Former Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina announced today that he would not challenge Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican, in 1990.

title: Racial Concerns Taint Political Clash in St. Louis
description: A drama involving efforts by white city and state officials to oust one of the few blacks holding office in St. Louis has been playing out in City Hall here in recent months, complete with name-calling and death threats that at one point forced Mayor Vincent C. Schoemehl and his family into hiding.

title: Americans Trail in Walker Cup
description: A dozen amateur golfers from Britain and Ireland threatened today to make it a clean sweep of the three oldest international golf trophies when they took a surprising 7 1/2-4 1/2 lead on the first day of the Walker Cup competition at the hot and humid Peachtree Golf Club.

title: Readying a New Production of 'Dido and Aeneas'
description: ''I love scandal and I thrive on controversy,'' said Eric Fraad, the 36-year-old founder and producer of Opera at the Academy. ''But this company is not painting mustaches on any Mona Lisas. It's championing a better type of theater - opera that is more theatrical and thought out, and that reflects the social, political and esthetic aspirations of this generation. We want visceral, sexual, violent, theatrical performances. It's the real thing. And we drive people crazy with it.''

title: Forum Re Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said second quarter results were largely affected by the effect of interest rate fluctuations on the valuation of an interest rate swap transaction which the company entered into at the end of 1988.

title: Salman Rushdie Remains In Hiding and on the Move
description: Salman Rushdie, the Indian-born author whose novel ''The Satanic Verses'' prompted Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to call for his death, has spent the past six months living in British intelligence safe houses, cut off from friends and protected by armed guards, friends have said.

title: Books of The Times; War, Described as the Hell That It Really Is

title: Mountings That Turn The Prosaic Into Art
description: TO be displayed properly, some artwork, like sculpture and folk art, needs a base or wall mount. Because mounting requires considerable skill and a trained eye, the work should be done by a professional.

title: Toys 'R' Us Income Up
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that its earnings were $23.5 million, or 12 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with $23.1 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago. The per-share figures were adjusted to reflect a three-for-two stock split on May 26, 1989. The large toy retailer, which is based in Paramus, N.J., said revenues were $775.5 million in the quarter ended July 30, compared with $686.8 million a year ago. In a statement, Charles Lazarus, chairman and chief executive of the company, said he was pleased with the results because they were based on a comparison to a period last year in which sales and earnings were strong.

title: TRIDENT FAILURES IN TESTS ARE TIED TO FLAWED DESIGN
description: The Navy believes designers made a fundamental miscalculation in building its biggest nuclear missile, the Trident 2, which has failed in two of its three undersea tests, a Navy official said today.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: THE restaurant we had planned on - cheap, decent food and Ella Fitzgerald on the stereo - was closed for August. So we wandered along a street near the waterfront. ''Here,'' my friend said, stopping. ''Here's the place I ate in last week. I hope we're too early for the jukebox.''

title: Hostage Situation Straining Washington's Ties to Israel
description: Late on the evening of July 31, only a few hours after White House officials got their first glimpse of a videotape purporting to show the hanging of Lieut. Col. William Higgins, the Bush Administration fired off a cable to the Israeli Government demanding to know what Israel was up to in Lebanon. Israeli officials, who found the tone and content of the American cable offensive, declined to respond.

title: King Excludes Dokes
description: Don King, the promoter, said yesterday that Michael Dokes would not be Mike Tyson's next opponent. Tyson's promoter insisted that it would be either Razor Ruddock or Buster Douglas and that the Las Vegas Hilton contractually had first shot at the world championship fight, targeted for October. ''After that,'' said King, ''depending on how Mike feels, he could fight again in December and there's a February date in Tokyo.''

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Renaissance Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Vietnamese Portray Their Enemy
description: A quarter-century ago, when Doan Chau Mau was one of Vietnam's best-known movie actors, he played, he said, ''the heavy, the bad guy, the Vietcong's colonels.'' Now, Mr. Doan is again playing a Vietcong officer -on a made-for-television film - but it is a gentle, humane officer, a sympathetic character. Between the two roles there lies a vast gulf of time, distance and perception.

title: Research Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-After a reversal of tax credits of $525,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $2,495,000. c-After a tax credit of $100,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $2,002,000. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,880,000 for the quarter and $6,482,000 for the 6 months. e-Net loss

title: Evert to Play in Open
description: Chris Evert has decided to take part in a record 19th United States Open championship, the Women's International Tennis Association announced yesterday.

title: National Gas & Oil reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect 7 percent stock dividend issued in December.

title: Obligatory Pro Bono
description: To the Editor:

title: Great American Communicaions Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2,182,000 for the quarter and $3,904,000 for the 6 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,096,000 and $2,573,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said year-ago second quarter and 6-month revenue included $8.3 million and $17.2 million from Worldvision Enterprises, which was sold in 1989.

title: DINKINS CAMP PUTS EDGE INTO MESSAGE
description: So far, in his campaign to be mayor, David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, has played it safe and still kept ahead of expectations in endorsements, in fund raising and in the polls. Now, as the tempo picks up before the Sept. 12 primary, the Dinkins team is zeroing in on its chief obstacle to the Democratic nomination -Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: In the Bloch Case, Who Leaked, and Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers and Philippines Agree on Debt Proposal
description: The Philippines and its commercial bankers, after a week of negotiations, announced yesterday that they had agreed on a proposal that includes new loans and some reduction of the country's debt.

title: Aged War Detainees Still Unpaid for Lost Freedom
description: For more than 40 years, Kinuyo Hokoda has waited - waited for the humiliation of her years in a detention camp to fade, for some acknowledgment that her adopted country was wrong to confine 112,000 Japanese-Americans in World War II.

title: Trader Pleads Not Guilty
description: A Chicago Mercantile Exchange yen trader pleaded not guilty to fraud and racketeering charges. James M. Marren, 39, was the 14th trader to plead not guilty to charges stemming from the Federal Government's investigation of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade. He was accused of racketeering conspiracy, mail and wire fraud, and violations of the Federal Commodities Act. Mr. Marren is among 46 traders accused of defrauding customers at the futures exchanges.

title: BLACK JOURNALISTS SEEK NEW GAINS IN NEWSROOM
description: The National Association of Black Journalists began its annual convention at the New York Hilton yesterday in an atmosphere of collective self-confidence and optimism, despite continuing frustration over the level of minority representation in news organizations.

title: DI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Case Is Closed
description: The state of North Carolina will not sue over the publication of the book ''Personal Fouls,'' which contains allegations of wrongdoing in North Carolina State's program, state officials said yesterday. ''Essentially, he has read the book and finds no basis for any libel suit on behalf of the state,'' said John Simmons, spokesman for Attorney General Lacy Thornburg. ''Any individual would have to make their own decision regarding a lawsuit.'' (AP)

title: Estonian Election Law Rejected by Kremlin
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Kremlin leadership rejected as unconstitutional today a new Estonian law that denies some Russian residents of the Balitic republic the right to vote.

title: Crazy Eddie Closings
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the retailer of consumer electronics products, said it would close eight of its 26 stores in early November as part of its business reorganization plan. The company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, said it would reorganize around its 18 remaining stores, which operate in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Egypt's Useful Smoke
description: To contemplate the prospects for an Israeli-Palestinian peace is to sink into sadness. Every avenue to negotiations seems too complicated or too risky. No approach pans out. In April, Prime Minister Shamir of Israel sketched out a plan with a measure of plausibility. The idea was to hold elections on the West Bank and Gaza Strip to establish limited Palestinian self-rule. But like almost all past plans, it has foundered on endless killings and political intransigence.

title: Guilty Pleas in Parts Fraud
description: A New York airplane parts distributor and the company's president pleaded guilty to Federal charges that they conspired to sell doctored airline parts to governments, manufacturers and airlines.

title: Corrections
description: A table on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Congressional travel misidentified the home state of Senator Frank H. Murkowski and, in some copies, that of Senator Ted Stevens. They are from Alaska.

title: Wilfred American Educational Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Hialeah Journal; Animal Sacrifices: Faith or Cruelty?
description: When Ernesto Pichardo opened his church just two blocks from City Hall here, he felt free at last, going public with the santeria religion, a faith that for years had been practiced underground by thousands in South Florida.

title: PHM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $3,045,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a loss of $379,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both periods. The company said net income in the latest second quarter was favorably impacted by a one-time $3 million land condemnation award; a reduction in mortgage foreclosure related losses due primarily to the reversal of $3.9 million of reserves provided in prior years; increased gains from the sale of mortgage-backed securities of about $3.6 million related to the early redemption of certain long-term debt; and by the inclusion of the net income and tax benefits attributable to thrift operations which were acquired in September 1988.

title: Delay in Lawsuit By B.A.T. Bidder
description: A lawsuit against the State of California filed by the investment group trying to take over B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. has been delayed for two weeks, creating a potential roadblock to the buyout bid. A preliminary hearing has been rescheduled to Sept. 11 from Aug. 28. It will consider whether the California Insurance Commissioner's jurisdiction over B.A.T.'s Farmers Group insurance companies extends to the takeover offer.

title: Review/Theater; Comedy of Self-Acceptance And a Portrait of Its Writer
description: In ''The Quintessential Image,'' a jaunty one-act comedy by Jane Chambers, photography and a telegenic appearance become pointed metaphors for the masks assumed by people who wish to conceal homosexual identities.

title: Empire of Carolina Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Aug. 21.

Mary Hunter Wallace, Executive, 61
description: Mary Hunter Wallace, a former vice president of Ogilvy & Mather, a New York-based advertising concern, died Sunday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. She was 61 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Industrial Production Climbed by 0.2% in July
description: Industrial production rose in July for the first time in three months, the Federal Reserve reported today.

CURRENTS;
