The company said the year-ago second quarter net from continuing operations is after a favorable foreign tax settlement that increased earnings by $7 million.

title: U.S. Visitors See Soviet Laser Firing
description: Soviet scientists fired up a high-powered laser today and blasted a sheet of metal in an unusual demonstration of their laser technology for American experts.

title: METRO-NORTH REPORTS A RISE IN RIDERS
description: After a shaky performance last year, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has seen ridership increase sharply in recent months, largely because more people are traveling between suburbs rather than commuting into Grand Central Terminal, railway officials said yesterday.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: If you are over 65, black, pregnant, or of Hispanic or native American descent, there is a greater-than-average chance that your blood pressure is dangerously elevated and you do not know it. Or, if you know it, there is a greater-than-average chance that it is not being properly treated, recent studies have shown.

title: Dow Up 5.51, to 2,693.29, as Volume Rises
description: Stocks advanced moderately again yesterday on slightly higher volume.

title: Laser Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WLR Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $1,112,000.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 5 about the aftermath of a Pink Floyd rock concert in Italy misidentified the site.

title: Chevrolet Cutting Some Base Prices
description: The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation said today that it was cutting the base price of 1990 versions of its top-selling cars in a bid to regain market share lost to its chief competitor, the Ford Motor Company. The price cut comes as the auto makers announced overall increases in 1990-model prices. The prices of G.M.'s 1990 cars are tentatively set to rise 3.4 percent, while those at Ford are set to rise 4.8 percent. The Chrysler Corporation has announced a 5 percent rise.

title: Bush Plans First TV Speech Devoted to Drug War
description: President Bush has agreed to a suggestion by his director of drug policy, William J. Bennett, to deliver his first nationally televised address on the subject of drugs.

title: Not the Right Desk To Carve a Name In
description: BOB OWEN'S work as a master carver has come into great demand since June 3, when a circa-1760 Newport desk and bookcase attributed to John Goddard was sold for $12.1 million, the most paid at auction for anything but a painting.

title: COURT TO HEAR APPEAL OF 3 IN ATTACK CASE
description: New York State's highest court decided yesterday to hear the appeals of the three young men who were convicted of manslaughter in the Howard Beach racial attack. A lower court unanimously upheld the convictions just two weeks ago.

title: Permit to Be Sought for Plutonium Incinerator
description: In an agreement long sought by environmentalists, the Department of Energy has agreed to submit a plutonium-burning incinerator at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant to outside regulation.

title: Triton Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $534,000 from tax benefits. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $6,594,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: The Deadly Syrian Gamble: Lebanon Is the Stake
description: Over the past two weeks, fighting in Beirut has spiraled to unparalleled heights of destruction and intensity, further battering the Lebanese city, forcing hundreds of thousands to flee and raising a pair of questions among some Westerners: why has Syria chosen this moment to turn the screws on a land it regards as part of its natural fiefdom, and what does President Hafez al-Assad hope to achieve?

title: Fund Yields Edge Higher
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report edged up for the week ended yesterday, as a result of economic reports and large government security sales last week.

title: Review/Theater; A Couple On the Run Want Their Own Baby
description: ''The Year of the Baby'' is vaguely reminiscent of ''Raising Arizona,'' but has little of that movie's vagrant humor. This new Quincy Long play, at Home for Contemporary Theater and Art, aims for shagginess and settles for loose ends.

description: b-Included tax benefits of $465,000 and $2,860,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax benefits of $1,801,000 for the quarter and $4,789,000 for the 6 months.

title: Rolling Stones' New York Dates
description: The Rolling Stones' ''Steel Wheels'' tour will reach New York City in late October with two concerts at Shea Stadium, on Oct. 26 and 28th. Opening for the Rolling Stones will be Living Colour, a New York rock group.

description: LEAD: When last heard from, Dick Levy had left Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman for parts unknown. Turns out that for the last year and a half, he has been squirreled away at his father-in-law's ad agency carefully plotting his return.

Family Decorating: Living Room Last
description: BERNARD and Ellen Marson have taken an approach to decorating that some traditionalists might call reverse gear. Instead of beginning with the public spaces in their Manhattan apartment - the living room and dining room - they have thrown their attention into the private spaces - the kitchen, bedrooms and bathrooms.

title: Liberty Homes reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the 6 months included a credit of $661,000 from an accounting change.

title: Talking Deals; Will Asset Sales Hurt 'Bad Banks'?
description: AS the Government prepares to sell or liquidate hundreds of savings and loan associations with upward of $400 billion of assets, bankers are watching closely to see what impact the sales will have on similar assets held by banks.

title: South African Signals
description: A few hours after F. W. de Klerk became its Acting President, South Africa substantially eased a problem threatening the transition of neighboring Namibia to independence. Its officials recalled to base 1,200 policemen, former members of a brutal paramilitary unit, who were accused of harassing civilians.

title: Unitrode Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
2 of 3 Counties in Iowa Pass Riverboat Gambling Measure
description: Voters in two counties have approved a state plan to allow riverboat gambling, but those in a third county defeated the idea by a wide margin.

title: Raleigh Verne Bond, An Actor, Dies at 54
description: Raleigh Verne Bond, an actor who performed on stage, screen and television, died of complications from lymphoma on Saturday at the Norris Cancer Hospital at the University of Southern California. He was 54 years old.

title: Clemson Investigated
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is conducting a formal investigation of the Clemson program that could result in the ''death penalty'' if major rules violations are found, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported yesterday. The paper quoted unidentified sources close to the investigation as saying it became a formal inquiry after N.C.A.A. investigators found leads on recent major recruiting violations.

title: Hemingway Typescripts And Letters Are Found
description: Ernest Hemingway may be the most picked over American writer of the 20th century, but any new revelation illuminating a dim corner of his life is still cause for interest.

title: U.N. Panel Is Asked to Condemn China
description: A Chinese student leader, wanted by the authorities of his country, asked a United Nations human rights meeting here today to adopt a resolution condemning the killing of democracy demonstrators in June at Tiananmen Square.

title: Ex-Gibraltar Officer Indicted
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has arrested a former San Francisco savings and loan manager after a Federal grand jury charged him with embezzling $3.5 million. Richard A. Mariucci, 30 years old, managed a branch of Gibraltar Savings from 1985 to April 1989, when he was dismissed for reasons unrelated to the embezzlement investigation, the F.B.I. said.

description: The Soviet Union has notified the Red Cross that it has ratified the two 1977 protocols to the Geneva Convention. The protocols strengthen the protection of civilians in international conflict and civil wars.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE mortar joints in nearly all brickwork eventually deteriorate. Prompt repair is essential, because even small cracks and crumbled areas let moisture in between bricks, setting the stage for major damage.

description: Nearly two years after ordering a routine shutdown of a nuclear plant, executives of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation are caught in a financial and management crisis arising from the utility's inability to restart the plant.

description: Five days after the resignation of Gord Stellick as general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, George Armstrong was relieved of his duties as head coach. He replaced John Brophy as coach last Dec. 19 and had a record of 19-26-4.

description: The former chief executive of Allegheny International Inc. has filed an $80 million libel suit against Business Week magazine, contending that a defamatory cover article cost him his job and reputation.

title: Cracks in House That Debt Built
description: The biggest game on Wall Street in the 1980's has been borrowing money - lots of it - to buy up big chunks of corporate America. And usually the biggest winners have been the firms that set up the deals, which earn huge fees for their troubles.

title: Is Syria Declining as a Power?
description: LEAD: With his army's shells pounding Christian sections of Beirut, and with Pope John Paul II broadly accusing him of genocide, Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, has to be wondering where things all began to go wrong.

title: DRUGS FOR PROSTATE CANCER PROLONG LIFE
description: A drug that blocks the effects of the male hormone testosterone prolonged the survival of patients with fatal prostate cancer when combined with conventional therapy, American researchers reported today.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Trouper's Anecdotes And Parodies
description: Phyllis Newman's new cabaret act is whimsically titled ''The First Hundred Years.'' Although the singer and comedian has several decades to go before actually celebrating her show-business centennial, the title reminds one that the star is indeed a trouper with vaudevillian roots.

title: Treasury Securities Rise Again
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher again yesterday, regaining more ground lost in the big selloff on Friday and Monday.

title: Jets Taking Cautious Approach With O'Brien and Ryan
description: The classic question around the Jets used to be, ''How's the knee, Joe?''

The latest periods also included a pre-tax gain of $700,000 for the quarter and a pre-tax loss of $1.1 million for the 6 months on investment and marketable securities. The year-ago periods included pre- tax gains of $13.8 million for the quarter and $17.8 million for the 6 months, both on investment and marketable securities.

title: Bite the Bullet Wins the Sanford
description: On July 7 at Belmont Park, a pair of unheralded 2-year-olds named Graf and Bite the Bullet made their debuts and finished first and second in that order in a $22,000 maiden race. Yesterday, in the $91,200 Sanford Stakes, they met again, and this time the order of finish was reversed.

title: Sea Containers Rejects Higher Bid
description: Sea Containers Ltd., a container, ferry and port operator, said it had rejected the enhanced $63-a-share offer made Tuesday by Temple Holdings Ltd., a bidding partnership formed by Tiphook P.L.C. of Britain and Stena A.B. of Sweden. The previous Temple bid had been $50 a share. Sea Containers said the bid was inadequate and not in the best interests of its shareholders.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Admiral Transportation Group, Raleigh, N.C., named Kennedy C. O'Herron chairman and chief executive, replacing Robert E. Watson, who resigned as chairman.

title: Festival Sets Goal For Black Theater: New Togetherness
description: August Wilson was sitting in the lounge of a downtown hotel the other night talking about the 1989 National Black Theater Festival under way here.

title: JUDGE ALLOWS NEW EVIDENCE ON HELMSLEYS
description: The judge in Leona Helmsley's tax-fraud trial ruled yesterday that Mrs. Helmsley's lawyers could present new evidence said to show that she and her husband overpaid income taxes during the same years in which they are charged with evading taxes.

title: Founder Relinquishes Management at Carver
description: The Carver Corporation, a manufacturer of high-performance stereo components based in Lynnwood, Wash., has appointed Robert R. Dougherty president and chief executive. He succeeds Robert W. Carver, the company's founder, who will remain chairman and assume the new title of vice president for advanced research.

title: Jews' Refuge in Caribbean Becomes a Resort
description: When Felix Koch, a young radio repairman from Vienna, reached the northern coast of the Dominican Republic nearly 50 years ago, he found a raw, wild land with patches of jungle and rolling stretches of dry scrub brush.

title: The Cricket's Contralto Announces Autumn in August
description: PEOPLE who don't garden have their own definitions of the seasons, sometimes revolving around food. One non-gardening friend of mine claims that no matter what the calendar says, autumn has arrived the day that his plans for the evening meal turn from a chilly bowl of gazpacho to a mess of hot chili.

title: Winchell's Donut Houses L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter included a provision of $61,575,000 to reflect impairment in the carrying value of certain assets.

title: Hills Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $3,642,000.

title: Eugene O'Malley, 87; Priest Inspired Movie
description: The Rev. Eugene F. O'Malley, considered the inspiration for the character of the same name portrayed by Bing Crosby in the movies ''Going My Way'' and ''The Bells of St. Mary's,'' died Monday of cardiac arrest at the St. Joseph Hospital and Health Care Center. He was 87 years old.

title: For Voting Rights, a Clear Triumph
description: The 15 weary, patient New Yorkers who have just drafted a new city charter knew from the start they would have to please three masters. One is the public, which must pass on it in November. The second is the U.S. Supreme Court, which in March effectively invalidated the current charter. The third is the Federal Justice Department, guardian of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

title: Review/Theater; 'My Big Land,' a Jewish Tale, by a Soviet Troupe
description: ''My Big Land,'' the Soviet play being presented in Russian by the Moscow Art Theater School at the Public Theater, is so thought-provoking that the mind continually flits from the play on hand to the heavy-handed world in which it was created 30 years ago.

description: b-Net income

title: Commodities Boards Plan Computers to Avert Abuses
description: Moving to bolster investor confidence following the indictment of 46 of their members, the nation's two largest commodities exchanges announced today that they would develop new tamper-proof hand-held computer terminals that would prevent the sort of abuses that occurred under their decades-old pencil-and-paper system.

title: Kathleen Maguire, Actress, 64
description: Kathleen Maguire, an actress who won an Obie Award in 1958 for her performance in ''The Time of the Cuckoo,'' died of cancer of the esophagus on Aug. 9 in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CAPTAIN PLEADS GUILTY IN RHODE ISLAND OIL SPILL
description: A shipping company and a tanker captain pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of causing a 300,000-gallon oil spill off Rhode Island on June 23 and agreed to pay fines totaling $510,000. Each pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor violation of the Clean Water Act.

title:
CURRENTS;
Keeping James Beard's Ghost Happy
description: LEAD: ''THIS is our first historic-preservation job for a kitchen,'' said Belmont Freeman, a partner in the architectural firm of Freeman & Pizer in Manhattan. The kitchen belonged to the chef James Beard, who died in 1985.

title: United States Cellular Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
To Many, Campaign in New York Is Invisible Except for Mail and TV
description: With only 25 days left before the mayoral primary, most New Yorkers have yet to see a campaign poster, a button or a bumper sticker, much less a candidate.

title: Accounts
description: * Barlow & Eaton Inc., a jewelry store chain, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Ripken Lifts Orioles Over Blue Jays
description: Cal Ripken moved into third place on the career list for consecutive games played and hit a two-run homer tonight in Baltimore's eight-run fourth inning as Jeff Ballard and the Orioles beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 11-6.

title: The Communist Roller Coaster
description: Nowhere has the ride been jumpier than in Poland. Communist reforms, prodded by popular pressure, have moved even faster there than in the Soviet Union. Just weeks ago, Poland's Solidarity union was illegal. Now, President Wojciech Jaruzelski is ready to ask Solidarity to lead the next government. Astonishing change - and the ride ahead will be riskier still.

title: Latvian Family Farm Is Back, Challenging Soviet Collective
description: A homesteading rush is on in Latvia as hundreds of young urban families join in the republic's challenge to Moscow to plow under four decades of Soviet collective agriculture by bringing back the small family farm.

title: A Polish Affair, Soviets Say
description: The Soviet Union reacted with deliberate equanimity to developments in Poland, saying they were strictly an internal affair. Page A6.

title: Auctions
description: It was probably not long after it became clear that rock-and-roll was here to stay that some enterprising enthusiast dusted off the box of memorabilia in his attic and offered the contents to the highest bidder.

title: Informational International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year-ago quarter both included net gains of $775,000 from a lawsuit settlement.

title: Diner's Journal
description: From Spain ''Catalan-Mediterranean'' cuisine is how Paradis, a striking new restaurant on East 50th Street, describes its food. This 150-seat restaurant in the Kimberly Hotel building is the first American outpost of a Spanish chain called Paradis Barcelona, which has five restaurants in Catalonia and a major catering company.

title: ANIMATED ADVENTURE FANTASY FROM JAPAN
description: ''Laputa: Castle in the Sky'' is an animated adventure story from Japan that illustrates the extraordinary quality of that country's animation as well as a minor cultural diffrence between Japanese and American audiences. Part science fiction and part fable, the film is the product of a culture where cartoons and comic books have a huge appeal for adults as well as children.

title: Bogota Magistrate Is Slain; Ruled Against 2 Drug Chiefs
description: A court magistrate who ruled against two leaders of the Medellin cocaine cartel was shot dead as he left work, the police said today.

title: Iowa Court Upholds Curfew
description: The Iowa Supreme Court has freed local governments to impose curfews on minors to fight drug abuse and crime. In a 5-to-4 ruling Wednesday, the court held that a curfew is only a minor infringement on the rights of children and parents. It upheld a curfew set in Panora that barred those under 18 from being out from 10 P.M. to 5 A.M.

title: Claiborne's Approach to Today's Man
description: IF the old man went to John Ford westerns, drank double Scotches and splashed himself with colognes named for brutes, Liz Claiborne Inc. reasons that the new man who attends Rob Reiner romances and tipples kir royales might also want to take an introspective and vulnerable approach to the way he smells.

title: It's Paperwork Time for Hunters and Fishermen
description: New York State's 1989-1990 hunting, fishing and trapping licenses are now on sale at sporting goods stores and other license-issuing outlets, and applications for deer management permits are also available at the same locations.

title: Leafs Hire Carpenter
description: Calling it another challenge in his life, Doug Carpenter, a former coach of the New Jersey Devils, was hired yesterday as coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs, for whom the challenges have been monumental recently. Carpenter replaces George Armstrong, who was dismissed on Wednesday. Last week, Harold Ballard, the owner, released Gord Stellick as general manager.

title: Raytech Corp reports earnings for 13wk to July 2
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $58.9 million from the sale of Raytech's Raymark Industries unit for both periods and charges of about $7.5 million for the quarter and $15.5 million for the 6 months from asbestos-related expenses.

title: Millicom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday.

title: Suspension & Parts Indus reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wajax Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net income figures represented net from continuing operations. Year-ago figures have been restated. The company did not break out results on its discontinued operations, which comprise the loss-making Pitman Manufacturing Group unit. Losses by the unit do not affect the latest quarter and first-half results, as provisions were made at the end of 1988 against any future losses by Pitman. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: A CONFIDENT GENERICS INDUSTRY
description: Until recently, manufacturers of generic drugs, low-priced versions of prescription drugs whose patents have expired, thought nothing could stop soaring demand for their products. Now, with the Food and Drug Administration and Congressional investigators delving into reports of violations of Federal standards for testing and manufacturing of generics, the companies are girding for a slowdown but remain confident about their long-term prospects.

title: Simmons Bid Seen For Georgia Gulf
description: Shares of the Georgia Gulf Corporation jumped $5 late today, to close at $51, after Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas billionaire, said he might seek control of the Atlanta chemical producer. The $51 price gives the company a market value of $125 million.

title: VMS Mortgage Investment Fund reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ivaco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,163,000 and $3,250,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $934,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included a gain of $82,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,117,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Silence Is Ordered in Case of Drug Official
description: A Federal magistrate in Boston today barred prosecution and defense lawyers from speaking publicly about the case of Edward K. O'Brien, a Drug Enforcement Administration official accused of cocaine trafficking. His lawyers had complained that Government sources were tainting their client's case in statements to the press.

title: Western Investment Real Esate Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $12,000 on the sale of real estate investments for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a $47,000 gain on the sale of real estate investments.

title: Pega Capital Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a tax gain of $421,888. c-Net loss and after a loss of $4,592,727 from the writedown of investments. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Milken Foundations Cleared
description: A nine-month investigation has cleared four charitable foundations created by the indicted financier Michael Milken and his family, the state Attorney General's office said Wednesday.

title: Aliens Testing Positive for AIDS Are Said to Be Giving Up on Legalization
description: Hundreds of immigrants in the New York metropolitan region who began applying for legalization under the Federal amnesty program are believed to have chosen instead to remain illegal because they have tested positive for the AIDS virus and fear deportation as a result.

title: Gantos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Old and New Worlds Collide Over Spray Plan
description: A utility company's plan to spray chemical defoliants along miles of power-line rights of way in central New Hampshire has touched off protests here and exposed the limited ability of old-fashioned village government to deal with modern environmental issues.

title: Lintas New York Cuts Nearly 10% of Its Staff
description: Lintas New York eliminated between 75 and 80 jobs yesterday, or nearly 10 percent of the agency's staff, in a cutback that agency executives said was made necessary by the reduction of clients' budgets.

title: Bronx Borough Chief Backs Dinkins
description: In a mayoral race that may hinge on the choice made by Hispanic voters, Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan received yesterday what could be a critical endorsement -from the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, the top Hispanic elected official in New York City.

title: The Law; Inmates Sue to End Ban on Computers in Cells
description: Twenty-seven years after Clarence Earl Gideon made legal history from a Florida prison cell as he persuaded the Supreme Court to hear his case and later grant indigents accused of a felony the right to a lawyer, inmates here are following in his tradition. They are writing similar pleas, but with a tool that the state now has taken away. It is the personal computer.

title: Polonia to Plead No Contest to Sex Charge
description: Luis Polonia, the Yankee outfielder, today agreed to plead no contest to a charge of having sexual intercourse with a child under the age of 16.

title: Live Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Police Corps Proposal Only Creates Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Helmsley Judge Rejects New Effort to Bar Audit
description: The judge in the Leona Helmsley tax-fraud and extortion trial last night rejected a last-ditch prosecution attempt to keep newly developed defense evidence from being presented to the jury.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for 12mo July 31
Basic American Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1.4 million for both the latest 6 months and year-earlier period.

title: Dizzy Afloat
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie is leading a group tonight on Musicruise (496-7070), a concert aboard the Hudson River Dayliner. The boat leaves Pier 81, at 41st Street, at 9 P.M. and returns at midnight; boarding begins at 8 P.M. Tickets are $25, available through Ticketron (399-4444).

title: THE TUMULT AND DRAMA OF MUGHAL ART
description: THE exhibition of ''Mughal Paintings'' at the Brooklyn Museum is not large - 30 paintings in all -but it is stimulating and provocative out of all proportion to its size. Moreover, it begins with two paintings - in opaque watercolor on cotton - that should once and for all dispose of the idea that Mughal painting is just a matter of complicated images that make us reach for a magnifying glass.

title: A CHEETAH, TWO TEEN-AGERS AND MICKEY
description: This is a cat-and-mouse story.

title: International American Homes reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest first quarter included income of about $37,000 from the sale of land. The year-ago first quarter included income of about $245,000 from land of sales.

title: IGI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Aspen Ribbons reports earnings for Year to June 30
California Poker Parlors Struggling to Stay Legal
description: Amid the clicking of poker chips and a haze of cigarette smoke, hundreds of gamblers huddle around green felt tables every night at the Bicycle Club, where stakes have reached $42,000 a hand.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 5 about the conductor Antonia Brico misidentified a film on her life and credited it incompletely. The film was ''Antonia: A Portrait of the Woman,'' and Jill Godmilow was a co-director with Judy Collins.

title: Farragut Mortgage Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dancing Out of Doors
description: A dance work composed by the jazz violinist Leroy Jenkins and choreographed by the dancers Felicia Norton and Mark Dendy will be performed at the Lincoln Center Fountain Plaza, as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors series, this afternoon at 5:15. Music by Robert Aldridge, a composer, will be performed on the North Plaza at 6:30 P.M. Among the performances offered on the series tomorrow are a concert of African and African-American dance, at the Fountain Plaza at 5:30 P.M., and a salsa concert by the Johnny Colon and Ray Barretto orchestras.Admission is free. Information: 877-1800.

title: Harvey Eligible to Play
description: Jack Kaiser, the St. John's University athletic director, announced yesterday that Greg (Boo) Harvey, a starting guard on the Redmen's 1987-88 basketball team who sat out last season for academic reasons, will be scholastically eligible to compete in the coming season. Two seasons ago, Harvey averaged 11.9 points and led the team in assists with 131.

title: Mabaie Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Kaneb Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $72,300,000 and $77,114,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains on debt extinguishment of $4,668,000 for the quarter and $6,509,000 for the 6 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,653,000 for the quarter and $15,739,000 for the 6 months. The company said both the latest second quarter and 6-month losses from continuing operations included a writedown of $2,450,000 from investments in unconsolidated affiliates. Results for 1988 have been restated to reflect the June 1989 sale of offshore drilling assets.

title: MADE IN N.Y.: EXHILARATING MUSIC BORN OF DIVERSITY
description: Some of the things that make New York an exhilarating place to live -its diversity, its energy, its sophistication, its unpredictability - have the same salutary effect on its music. And some of the things that make New York a hard place to live - its noise, its competitiveness, its tensions, its unpredictability - pay off, ironically, in the music that survives them.

title: INSIDER TRADING SETTLEMENT IN BUSINESS WEEK INQUIRY
description: A former salesman for the company that prints Business Week magazine settled Federal insider trading charges today. The Government had charged that he had bought stocks based on articles in advance copies of the magazine.

title: Key Officer Quits Wang
description: Financially troubled Wang Laboratories lost another key executive yesterday when Ian W. Diery resigned as executive vice president for worldwide operations.

title: Japan Easing Its Restrictions Against China
description: In a step that could lead to re-establishing normal relations with Beijing, Japan today dropped its recommendation to business executives not to travel in China and said it was ready to lift a freeze on economic aid projects imposed after China's crackdown on dissidents in June.

title: Deborah L. Rose, A Student, Weds
description: Deborah Lynn Rose, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Rose of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Robert Todd Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Greenberg of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., and Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Peter Kasdan officiated at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J.

title: Investors Hold 18% Amdura Stake
description: An investment group, Cilluffo Associates, said it had acquired an 18 percent stake in the Amdura Corporation and would seek to replace the company's board. Amdura, based in Denver, is a hardware-distribution and equipment-manufacturing company formerly known as American Hoist and Derrick. Cilluffo Associates is made up of investors from New York and New Hampshire.

title: Goldin Keeps Hammering at His Three Pet Proposals
description: In his latest television commercial - a 30-second spot that began airing this week -Harrison J. Goldin leans toward the camera and makes three points: he is the mayoral candidate who wants to make drug use a crime; he would send drug users to upstate work camps, and he would give New Yorkers a $100 million tax break.

title: A SOPRANO MAKES DEBUT IN CITY OPERA 'BOHEME'
description: Mimi is a good debut role and Renee Fleming made a good debut in it at the New York City Opera Wednesday evening, when ''La Boheme'' was given for the first time this season. Ms. Fleming is a young soprano from Pennsylvania whose career is taking off quickly (her program biography detailed operatic engagements in Salzburg, London, Houston, Seattle and San Francisco), and on this showing she seems poised to make a worthwhile contribution. She has a natural, generous way with a phrase and her high notes blossom without turning hard or tremulous.

title: Canadian Energy Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Is Felled Forest a Mess or a Part of Nature?
description: Here in the Litchfield Hills, forests have long been accorded a shrine-like status. That was especially true for the Cathedral Pines, a patch of towering 200-year-old hemlocks here felled by the powerful line of thunderstorms that ravaged the New York metropolitan region last month.

title: Defiant Pakistani Crowd Marks First Anniversary of Zia's Death
description: In the face of the most elaborate security precautions since Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto took office nine months ago, about 80,000 people gathered today to observe the first anniversary of the death of the military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: Cablevision Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a one-time gain of $104,837,000 on the sale of interests in the company's programming businesses to NBC, offset by additional interest and depreciation and amortization expenses related to the company's acquisitions in 1989 and 1988. c-Net loss

title: Article 581289 -- No Title
description: More than $2 million in private donations to help restore Bryant Park, including a million-dollar gift from the philanthropist Enid A. Haupt, were announced yesterday by the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation.

title: Tires for Keye/Donna
description: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein New York was given Bridgestone U.S.A.'s tire advertising account yesterday. The account, which may be worth $10 million in annual billings, is a shot in the arm for the struggling agency. The account is moving, apparently without a review, from Lintas Campbell-Ewald's office in Nashville, the home base of the company, which is the American unit of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan.

title: Jamesway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included LIFO provisions of $300,000 and $700,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Included LIFO provisions of $500,000 for the quarter and $600,000 for the 6 months. The company said sales for both the quarter and 6 months excluded sales by leased departments of $6,818,000 and $11,812,000 in the 1989 quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $5,930,000 in the 1988 quarter and $10,520,000 in 1988's 6 months.

title: Douglas & Lomason reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $660,000 from an accounting change.

title: Let's Take a Look at This Right to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: H. W. Fuller, 81, Dies; Decorated Ex-Marine
description: Horace W. Fuller, a retired United States Marine Reserve brigadier general who served at Guadalcanal and with the French Resistance in World War II, died of cancer Wednesday in a clinic on the Greek island of Spetsai. He was 81 years old and lived on Spetsai.

title: On Europe's (Military) Theater
description: LEAD: It is diverting, though not often, to cast a Stanislavskian eye upon the political scene.

title: The League That Bans Tall Tales
description: Everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it. For years, the same was true for basketball. With 7-footers plopping the ball through the hoop, there was often talk of raising the baskets to 11 or 12 feet.

title: Crossing the Ocean for Dollars
description: Two basketball players crossed the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday, one seeking a multimillion-dollar contract in Europe and the other pursuing the opportunity of playing in what he called the best league in the world, the National Basketball Association.

title: Priscilla Buckley, Writer, Is Married To Alain Illel, an Actor and Director
description: Priscilla Langford Buckley, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. James L. Buckley of Washington, was married yesterday to Alain Illel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Illel of Paris. The Rev. James Pilon, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with the bridegroom's father at the Sharon, Conn., home of the bride's aunts, Priscilla L. Buckley and Jane Buckley Smith.

Abiomed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
EXPERTS PREDICT STUBBORN DEFICITS
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that despite efforts by the Congress and the White House to cut Government spending, the Federal deficit would average $140 billion over the next several years.

title: A Top Trader at Goldman, Sachs Pleads Guilty to Insider Charges
description: A partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of Wall Street's most venerable firms, pleaded guilty yesterday to a felony charge of insider trading.

title: Realty Refund Trust reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Five Horses to Challenge Easy Goer
description: If the $1,088,500 Travers Stakes at Saratoga Race Track on Saturday were a winner-take-all event, Easy Goer might enjoy the first Grade I walkover in American racing since Spectacular Bid raced alone in the 1980 Woodward. But prizes of $239,470 for finishing second, $130,620 for third and $65,310 for fourth were compelling enough to draw five other horses into the race this morning.

description: b-Included a tax benefit of $3,700,000. c-Included tax benefits of $10.3 million for the quarter and $25.9 million for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $22,700,000.

title: Carter to Bring Together Ethiopian Foes
description: The Ethiopian Government and rebels fighting against it for nearly three decades have agreed to meet here with former President Jimmy Carter for peace talks next month, Mr. Carter said today.

description: Two environmental groups affiliated with the Greenpeace organization today threatened to sue the Environmental Protection Agency for what they called lax regulation of toxic incinerators.

title: Egghead Software In S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Egghead Discount Software, said a shareholder suit filed last month had apparently prompted the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate activities of the company from January through June 1988. The Ossaquah, Wash., company said it was assisting the S.E.C. staff in its investigation.

title: Viola Falls To Hurst In Padres' Fast Rally
description: For the 40,406 fans in Shea Stadium on a rare afternoon, it was a marquee matchup between Frank Viola and Bruce Hurst, two left-handed pitching stars from the American League. For the San Diego Padres, a chance to leave town without being swept. For the Mets, after winning 4 straight games and 13 in their last 16, a dose of reality.

BUSINESS PEOPLE;

description: LEAD: James A. Thomson, an expert on military and arms control issues and a former staff member at the National Security Council, has been named president and chief executive of the Rand Corporation, a research center supported by the Government.

title: WESTCHESTER DINING IN LE STYLE FRANCAIS
description: The bosky exurbs of Westchester County offer recreational activities other than hiking, climbing, swimming and trotting: a number of noteworthy restaurants have taken root in scattered hamlets throughout the region. For whatever reason - perhaps it is the topographical resemblance to parts of Burgundy - many of the best are French.

title: National Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest second quarter included a charge of $1,630,000 for closure of the company's Denver-based student loan systems operations.

description: Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, said today that he expected the chamber to ''sharply modify'' a program to protect the elderly from the catastrophic costs of extended illnesses.

description: F.B.I. agents say they raided two electronics companies and confiscated up to 18,000 illegal devices for unscrambling pay television signals.

description: ''Eddie and the Cruisers II: Eddie Lives!'' may come as a surprise to the millions of people who didn't know he was supposed to be dead.

title: Operator of Day Care Center Is Arrested in Child's Death
description: The operator of a Bloomfield, Conn., day care center where a 3-year-old girl died of heat prostration after having been left alone inside a car was arrested today, the police said.

title: Rose's Suit to Remain A Federal Court Case
description: A Federal appeals court today denied Pete Rose's latest effort to shift his lawsuit against Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti from Federal court back into an Ohio state court.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Amanda Blake, 60, Saloonkeeper On TV's 'Gunsmoke' for 19 Years
description: Amanda Blake, who played the kindhearted saloonkeeper Miss Kitty in the ''Gunsmoke'' television series for 19 years, died of oral cancer on Wednesday at Mercy General Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 60 years old.

title: New York Can End Ocean Dumping of Sludge
description: To the Editor:

title: Nice Way to Shea
description: The fare is steep - $15 each way. But then again, the new ferry service inaugurated earlier this month between Manhattan and Shea Stadium in Queens offers gentle river breezes and spectacular sunsets denied car or subway travelers. The ''baseball ferry,'' run by a private operator, American Skimmer, is a promising addition to New York City's expanding waterborne transit system.

The Man at the Window
description: On Monday a trial is scheduled to take place inside a prison in a city called Perm in the Soviet Ural Mountains. It is not a very big story, but it could be.

description: Northwest Airlines said today that it had agreed to buy up to 30 more jetliners from Airbus Industrie in a deal valued at $2.7 billion.

description: Share earnings amounts presented are for the company's series A common stock.

title: Shagging
description: LEAD: After ''Shag, the Movie,'' opened, two film critics - obviously natives of some sterile inland territory - described shagging as apparently a dance craze in the Carolinas in the 60's and a minor dance phenomenon of the 60's. This is like describing the waltz as a minor dance phenomenon among 19th century Viennese - well, it is if you grew up in South

description: In this fisherman's state, it's shocking to learn from the estimable White River Valley Herald that ''every species of fish in waters used for food is now fished at, or above, its capacity to replace itself.''

title: Tight-End Depth Helps Giants' Running Game
description: Most pro football teams carry three tight ends. A few try to get by with two. The Washington Redskins, who often line up a tight end in the backfield, carry four.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Rhinebeck Town Houses Circle Ponds
description: LEAD: The Rhinebeck area of northern Dutchess County in New York State, rich in history and scenery, is a 90-minute train ride or a 95-mile drive from Manhattan. And across the Hudson River, in Kingston, is the International Business Machines Corporation's Data Systems division with 6,200 employees.

title: Gastineau Plans Career in the Ring
description: Mark Gastineau, holding hands with his girlfriend, Brigitte Nielsen, said yesterday that he wanted to become a professional boxer.

title: Treasury Security Prices Fall
description: Treasury securities prices tumbled yesterday, despite a morning rise in response to a smaller-than-expected June trade deficit. The 30-minute rally after the opening was suddenly halted by a Government report that the number of jobless claims fell to 317,000 in the week ended Aug. 5 from 330,000 in the preceding week.

title: Hewlett-Packard Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9-month results reflect the acquisition in May of Apollo Computer, which reduced net earnings per share by 13 cents.

title: 'VIEWS OF ROME,' AT THE COOPER-HEWITT MUSEUM
description: When Thomas Ashby died in 1931, after falling from a train, he left behind a collection of prints and drawings that was the product of a lifetime of scholarship. Ashby served between 1906 and 1925 as director of the British School at Rome and during that time he established himself as one of the principal experts on the history and topography of the Italian capital and its surroundings.

title: Trident 2 Failures Laid to Early Success
description: The designers of the Trident 2 missile in some ways were prisoners of their own successes when they failed to foresee a problem that has spoiled the weapon's first undersea tests, Government officials and other missile specialists said today.

title: 2 Officers Held As Robbers In Drug Inquiry
description: Two New York City housing police officers who had been honored by their department for outstanding duty were arrested Tuesday evening when they tried to rob a man of two kilos of cocaine at a fast-food restaurant in Queens, the housing police said yesterday.

title: Campus Conspirators?
description: The Justice Department has asked about 20 elite colleges and universities to explain why their tuition levels and financial aid packages are so similar, year after year. Presumably the department wants to know whether the schools are fixing prices. If schools are conspiring on tuitions, that's wrong. The practice of setting uniform financial aid levels, however, may well be justified.

description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $5,136,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a credit of $6,395,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income The company said its loss for the year was attributable to lower government hardware sales, which fell $34 million from fiscal 1988. An $11 million charge at the company's BBN Communications Corp. unit relating to a Japan air lines contract overrun and significant costs associated with the introduction of a new computer at the company's BBN Advanced Computer Inc. unit.

title: Election Set for Wright Seat
description: A special runoff election to fill the unexpired term of the former Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, will be held Tuesday, Sept. 12, Gov. Bill Clements said Wednesday. In the special election for the 12th Congressional District Bob Lanier, a Republican, drew 39 percent of the vote, and Pete Geren, a Democrat, drew 32 percent in the eight-candidate race. A runoff is required because no candidate in the special election received a majority of votes cast.

title: Sico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a special charge of $280,000 for the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Anti-Apartheid Groups Call Restrictions Void
description: Opponents of apartheid said today that their organizations planned to resume operating Sunday ''openly and without the shackles of unjust restrictions'' in defiance of bans the Government imposed in a crackdown on dissent in February 1988.

title: Marcia W. Schott, 66, Owner of Race Horses
description: Marcia Whitney Schott, a prominent figure on the American horse racing scene for almost 30 years, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 66 years old.

title: Winners Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest periods' results included charges of $11,750,000 for the quarter and $12,130,000 for the 6 months from a provision for losses on disposition of restaurants.

title: Wings for Omon
description: Little Omon New York said it had reached $25 million in billings with the acquisition of the Buffalo Bucket chicken wings account from Great Wings Inc. Buffalo Bucket wings are frozen chicken wings prepared with hot sauce, often served with blue cheese dressing and sold in supermarkets. The account bills $2 million, Omon said.

title: Dining Out Guide: Near Ward Pound Ridge Reservation
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Westchester section of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. The Arch

title: Market Place; Timely Disclosure Of Insider Trades
description: THE requirement that corporate insiders report their purchases and sales of company securities on a timely basis is observed more often than laws prohibiting speeding and jaywalking. But that is about the best that can be said for compliance with the rule.

title: IN MOSCOW, TONE IS A STUDIED CALM
description: The Soviet Union reacted with deliberate equanimity today to Poland's movement toward a government led by non-Communists, declaring that developments there were strictly an internal affair.

title: Corrections
description: A Company News article in some editions of Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the investment group that reduced its stake in the Von Companies. The Investment Limited Partnership, a group led by Richard E. Rainwater and Dort A. Cameron of Fort Worth, sold a million shares in Vons, reducing its holding to 4.6 percent. The Robert M. Bass Group has not reduced its stake in Vons and continues to own 8.9 percent.

title: Broncos Sign Humphrey For Estimated $2.3 Million
description: Bobby Humphrey, the highly regarded running back from the University of Alabama, signed a contract with the Denver Broncos today and was expected in training camp. Barry Hawkins, a spokesman for the team, declined to announce terms of the agreement, which The Denver Post estimated would be worth about $2.3 million.

title: Back at Grass Roots, Congressman Is All Ears
description: Ruby A. Graham, 80 years old, looked her Congressman dead in the eye, handed him a stack of carefully clipped newspaper articles and told him firmly, ''I want you to read all those.''

title: Vintage Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Net income The year-ago quarter revenue included $2,623,000 attributed to the company's retail division, which was sold in July 1988.

title: President Resigns At Columbia Savings
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association said yesterday that Lawrence K. Fish, its president and chief operating officer, had resigned after 18 months with the company.

title: A Pause in the King-Duva Feuding
description: When Seth Abraham of Home Box Office first conceived of a three-bout series matching fighters connected to the promoter Don King and his manager-son, Carl, against fighters linked to the promoter Dan Duva and his manager-father, Lou, he proposed to call the setup ''Family Feud'' and pay a $1 million bonus to the victorious promoter.

title: Venezuela's Debt Stance
description: President Carlos Andres Perez said today that Venezuela would seek a 50 percent reduction of its estimated $20.3 billion debt with commercial banks.

title: Irvin S. Taubkin Is Dead at 82; Led Public Relations at The Times
description: Irvin S. Taubkin, director of public relations for The New York Times before his retirement in 1971, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where he was being treated for a fractured arm. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Drug War
description: When somebody says it's not the money but the principle, it's almost certainly the money.

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 40 Years of Communism in Poland: Stalin's House on a Soft Foundation
description: Stalin said that imposing Communism on Roman Catholic Poland was as absurd as putting a saddle on a cow. But after World War II, he went ahead and imposed it anyway, even though the roots of Communism in Poland had never run very deep.

title: Union Square Rag?
description: Beat, beat, beat them feet! / Beat them straight to 14th Street!. Nah, forget it, the lyricist mutters. Sounds as if I'm copying ''42nd Street.''

title: Drug Said to Help AIDS Cases With Virus but No Symptoms
description: The drug AZT can delay the onset of AIDS in people who are infected with the virus but have no symptoms, the Government announced yesterday.

title: Heart Risks Linked to Big Drop in Blood Pressure
description: People whose treatment greatly reduces their high blood pressure apparently suffer far more heart attacks than those whose treatment results in moderate declines, researchers have found.

title: Mozart in the Bronx
description: Stephen Somary will conduct the Bronx Arts Ensemble in Mozart's Serenade for Winds (K. 375), Milhaud's Dectet, and Strauss's Suite in B flat (Op. 4) at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park, near Broadway and Mosholu Avenue, in the Bronx, on Sunday afternoon at 2. The program will be repeated at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall, on Bronx Rose Hill campus of Fordham University. Admission is free. Information: 549-1899.

title: THE LAW: At The Bar; The bar examination is an ordeal that bears little resemblance to the real practice of law.
description: Long before she would have to confront dozens of crimes and torts, a young woman one morning last month took several deep breaths and shreiked in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City.

title: After Bastille Day: Liberty, Equality and Royalty
description: The citizens of this proud republic would never admit a fascination with royalty. Indeed, in planning last month's bicentennial celebrations, the guardians of the French Revolution made it clear that kings and queens were cordially disinvited.

title: Energy Ventures reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest year's figures reflect the consolidation of Grant Oil Country Tubular Corp. effective Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions
description: Lawrenceville School, the prominent, private boarding academy near Princeton, N.J., was accused in a lawsuit yesterday of being responsible for the alcohol and drug abuse of a former student.

title: Debates Over the Hometown Hero
description: Joe Dunn's barber shop is squeezed tightly among the taverns, chili parlors, bingo halls and hardware stores of Glenway Avenue, the busiest street in the gritty Cincinnati neighorhood known as Price Hill.

title: Roanoke Electric Steel reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflected the 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept. 20, 1988, and stock options exercised.

title: Charges Are Dismissed
description: Assault charges involving Deion Sanders, an outfielder for the Yankees' Columbus Clippers farm team, and two fans of the Richmond Braves were dismissed yesterday in Richmond after Sanders agreed to make a donation, whose amount was not revealed, to benefit Braves fans with disabilities. The altercation between Sanders and the fans occurred Aug. 6.(AP)

title: Alabama Man Is Executed for Killing of Girl
description: Herbert Lee Richardson, 43 years old, was electrocuted early today for the 1977 pipe-bomb killing of an 11-year-old girl.

title: WHEN NATURE PALES, THERE ARE MANSIONS, MUSIC AND ART
description: There is a delightfully anomalous, pre-suburban quality to northeastern Westchester County. Just beyond the bedroom communities of the early-and mid-20th century, and barely 50 miles from Manhattan, a surprising sense of rural gentility still reigns in such communities as Katonah and Bedford. Along the heavily wooded country roads that string together a patchwork of still-quiet hamlets are such noteworthy house museums as Caramoor and the John Jay Homestead, not to mention the Katonah Gallery, that suggest a world far away in spirit from metropolitan New York, 1989. Caramoor's Splendor

description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a jury's $9.4 million award that Soldier of Fortune magazine had been ordered to pay to the relatives of a murdered woman. She was killed by a man hired through an advertisement in the magazine.

description: The team of amateur golfers from Britain and Ireland, which built a huge lead over the American amateurs, was forced to go to the last hole of the last match today to gain a thrilling and rare triumph in the biennial Walker Cup competition.

Winn of Roslyn Heights, L.I., to Robert Alan Pruzan, a son of Linda Pruzan of New York and Joseph Pruzan of Yardley, Pa., took place last evening at the Old Westbury Country Club in Old Westbury, L.I Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated.

description: Syrian gunners and their Lebanese Muslim militia allies shelled four Christian seaports today, refusing to lift a blockade of areas under control of their opponents despite a cease-fire call by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Chicago: Hog Butcher for the World, City of . . . Nudes?
description: It may be art, but Illinois tourism officials didn't believe their eyes when an ad featuring a watercolor of a nude woman beckoned Europeans to visit Chicago.

title: Giuliani Getting A Lion's Share Of Public Funds
description: New York City's Campaign Finance Board yesterday gave 19 municipal candidates $584,613 in matching funds for their campaigns, with one candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, receiving almost 40 percent of the money.

description: b-After a tax credit of $37,896. Year-ago revenue included nonrecurring earnings from 50 percent ownership of Viral Technologies Inc.

title: Irish Trio
description: Camillus Hiney on button accordion, Don Meade on tenor banjo and fiddle, and Steve Johnson on guitar will play traditional Irish music tonight at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Kings Road Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
ORDEAL OF A CAPTURED SPY ON EVE OF D-DAY
description: For most of its 90 minutes, ''Breaking Point'' is a neat psychological thriller, World War II vintage. Stanley Greenberg's teleplay, on the TNT cable channel at 8 o'clock tonight, is a tense account of the ordeal of an American intelligence officer who is captured by the Germans five days before the Allied invasion of Europe. Maj. Jefferson Pike (Corbin Bernsen) knows all there is to know about where the Allies plan to attack. Will the Nazis be able to get it out of him before D-day?

title: Palestinian Uprising Seeks to Stop Rash Of 'Traitor' Killings
description: In leaflets distributed in the occupied territories this week, the underground leadership of the Arab uprising is urging Palestinians to step up their rebellion while trying to regain control of a vigilante system of justice.

title: 'A CHORUS OF DISAPPROVAL,' A MISFIT MAKES GOOD
description: The following was overheard at a preview screening of ''A Chorus of Disapproval,'' before the film began.

title: 2-Part High-Yield Financing Is Offered by Horace Mann
description: The Horace Mann Educators Corporation is making a two-part offering of high-yield securities, totaling $314.9 million, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

description: b-After a gain of $55,000 from tax- loss carryforwards. c-After a tax benefit of $161,000.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SHAKESPEAREAN COMEDY

title: NEARBY IN WESTCHESTER, A WILDERNESS (YES, A WILDERNESS)
description: JUST one hour north of midtown Manhattan is a large patch of wilderness on the edge of suburbia. It is a place that has been left to develop without the aid of man, where bobcats slink through rocky outcroppings and ring-necked pheasants and wild turkeys roam the underbrush. The only sounds are the rustling of leaves, the rush of water over rocks and the maddening chant of katydids.

title: Our Towns; Neighbors Await Group Home, And Hire Lawyer
description: When Carole Dougherty was directing movers carrying furniture into a newly rented house on a quiet street in this small suburb one evening a month or so ago, she remembered that she had several phone calls to make.

title: Continental Bank Shares Are Active
description: The heavy trading in the stock of the Continental Bank Corporation was caused by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's public offering of 8.6 million Continental shares, traders said. Continential was the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with nearly 2.4 million shares trading. The stock gained 25 cents, to $25. Traders said institutional demand was strong.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT NARROWED IN JUNE TO A 4 1/2-YEAR LOW
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in June to $8.2 billion, the lowest level in four and a half years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DOW DROPS 13.66, TO 2,679.63, ON INTEREST RATE WORRIES
description: Stock prices fell widely yesterday in the wake of a broadly lower bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 13.66 points, to 2,679.63, after being down about 25 points in the early afternoon. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded advances by 887 to 561.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page on Aug. 11 about the retirement of the Secretary of the Army, John O. Marsh Jr., misstated his tenure in Congress. He served four terms in the House, from 1963 to 1971.

title: Rockets Sign Lucas
description: John Lucas, a first-round draft choice of the Rockets in 1976, signed a two-year contract with Houston yesterday. Lucas was waived by the Rockets after he failed a drug test in the 1984-85 season. He returned for the 1986 season but was again waived in March 1986.(AP)

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of Vestron Picked For a Top Post at Fox Film
description: LEAD: It is not just firefighters, figure skaters and baseball players who do the work they dreamed of as children; there are also movie producers.

description: b-Net loss Latest second quarter share earnings was less than one cent a share because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. The company on Aug. 1, 1988 acquired retail and printing businesses in exchange for common and preferred stock.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD PROFIT DOWN BY 2.6% IN QUARTER
description: As it projected on Monday, the Hewlett-Packard Company today reported a decrease in third-quarter earnings.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 462 money market mutual funds increased by $2.29 billion, to $340.5 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 140 institutional funds decreased by $1.05 billion, to $85.48 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were up by $1.74 billion, to $108.76 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.61 billion, to $146.26 billion, the institute said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 Solidarity appeared to gain control of Poland's Government as the Communist Prime Minister resigned and the President said that he would ''urgently consider'' a proposal for a Solidarity-led cabinet. Page A1 40 years of Communism in Poland A6 The Soviet Union reacted to Poland's movement toward a government led by non-Communists with equanimity, declaring that Polish developments were strictly an internal affair. A6 In Latvia, the small family farm is replacing collective agriculture. Under a government program, families are reinhabiting farms that were abandoned during the republic's recent decades of urbanization. A1 The fighting continued in Lebanon though its intensity has markedly decreased since last week. The Muslim side shelled four seaports, and Christian forces retaliated by bombing seaside quarters in Muslim West Beirut. A3 The Arab uprising's underground is urging Palestinians to step up their rebellion while trying to regain control of a vigilante system of justice, in leaflets distributed in the occupied territories this week. A8 Relations between Japan and China may soon return to normal. Japan dropped its recommendation to business executives not to travel in China and said it was ready to lift a freeze on economic aid projects. A9 The anniversay of Gen. Zia's death was observed by about 80,000 people who assembled at his graveside. The gathering occured without serious incident, though the government had feared otherwise. A8 For peace talks about Ethiopia, the Ethiopian Government and rebels fighting against it for nearly three decades have agreed to meet with former President Jimmy Carter. A3 In defiance of South Africa's bans imposed in a crackdown on dissent in February, opponents of apartheid said that their restricted organizations planned to resume operating. A5 National A10-18 AZT can delay the onset of AIDS in people who are infected with the virus but have no symptoms, a new study has shown, the first evidence that the drug AZT could help this group. A1 The nation's trade deficit narrowed in June to $8.2 billion, the lowest level in four and a half years, the Commerce Department reported. Exports climbed 1.5 percent, while imports tumbled 3.6 percent. A1 A Wall Street partner pleaded guilty to a charge of insider trading. In announcing the plea, the Government also said it was ending its investigation against two other traders. A1 Between Congress and the heartland, the gap is wide in the summer of 1989, judging from a two-day swing with an Oklahoma lawmaker through 12 towns and cities. A1 The Trident 2 missile's designers may have been prisoners of their successes and should have rethought some of the basic design elements that worked in the past, Government officials and experts said. A10 People suffer far more heart attacks when their treatment greatly reduces their high blood pressure rather than when treatment results in a moderate decline, researchers say. A18 A plan to spray chemical defoliants along miles of land under power lines in New Hampshire has stirred protests and presented an old-fashioned village government with a very complex environmental problem. A10 Environmental groups seek to block incinerators A16 Appeals court overturns award in case of killer hired by ad A12 Ex-trafficker tells of ease in smuggling cocaine A14 Teen-ager in Lukens case jailed on juvenile charges A14 Washington Talk A14 At the F.B.I., William Sessions refused to discuss the Bloch case but defended the bureau's approach on counterintelligence cases. The 59-old lawyer from Waco has claimed credit for several successes. The Drug War: Should drug bonds be sold? Regional B1-4 A campaign by mail, phone and TV is being waged in the mayoral race. Economic regulations have limited spending, often to the exclusion of some traditional political paraphernalia. A1 Aliens may be remaining illegal by choice, rather than pursuing legalization under the amnesty program, because they have tested positive for AIDS and fear deportation. B1 In his campaign, Harrison Goldin has been stressing that he would make drug use a crime, send criminals to work camps and give New Yorkers a $100 million tax break. B1 Municipal candidates received $584,613 from New York City's Campaign Finance Board for their campaigns, with Rudolph Giuliani getting almost 40 percent of the matching money. B4 A Connecticut forest that was felled by thunderstorms last month is owned by an environmental conservation group that doesn't intend to restore it. The decision angers residents who consider the devastation an eyesore. B1 Two housing officers were arrested early Tuesday for trying to rob a man of two kilos of cocaine at a fast food restaurant. They had been honored by their department for outstanding performance on duty. B1 The razing of public housing in Newark will be curbed under a court settlement. The city agreed to scale back its planned destruction of 39 high-rises and to put up replacement housing. B2 Lawrenceville School was accused in a lawsuit of being responsible for the alcohol and drug addiction of a former student. The suit was filed by the student's father. B2 Two American rabbis are retiring after influential careers in the Conservative rabbinate, although neither ever led a congregation. B3

title: NAVISTAR SETS OUTPUT CUTS AT OHIO PLANT
description: Faced with a downturn in truck orders, the Navistar International Corporation said today that it would cut by 15 percent the output of its plant in Springfield, Ohio.

title: SWEETENED PROPOSAL LIFTS UAL STOCK 6%
description: Shares of the UAL Corporation jumped 6 percent yesterday on the news that Marvin Davis was willing to raise his offer for the company.

title: LANDS' END DRIFTS INTO DOLDRUMS Special to The New York Times
description: Beset by big cost increases for its cotton shirts, wool sweaters and other natural-fiber clothing, the catalogue merchant Lands' End Inc. today reported a big drop in second-quarter earnings that sent its stock price skidding.

title: Heins Wins the Met Open by 2 in Playoff
description: Bobby Heins, the head professional at Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., captured his second consecutive Metropolitan Open, winning by two shots in a three-hole playoff today with George Zahringer 3d.

title: Trotsky Works Printed In a Soviet Magazine
description: An official Soviet magazine published works by Trotsky today for the first time since he was exiled and slain, presumably on Stalin's orders.

title: HORACIO GUTIERREZ AND JOSHUA BELL ARE SOLOISTS IN MOZART
description: George Cleve conducted the Mostly Mozart orchestra in a program of Mozart favorites on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. There were some lovely moments, but for the most part, it was an evening of honorable averageness. The orchestra played like the competent modern freelance ensemble it is, and Mr. Cleve offered readings that were always tasteful but often flavorless, and which did not trouble with either rhetorical stances or stylistic pretentions. For many in the audience, that was sufficient.

description: Depression, which afflicts nearly 10 million Americans, is more disabling than many other ailments, like arthritis, ulcers, diabetes or high blood pressure, that are often taken more seriously, a new study says.

title: 24 Indian Soldiers Are Killed in a Sri Lanka Raid
description: Tamil militants ambushed and killed 24 Indian soldiers outside a hospital in northwest Sri Lanka today. It was one of the most severe losses that the Indian Army has suffered in a single encounter in more than two years of fighting.

description: A principal who cut his own job so teachers would not be laid off is back at work after an outpouring of support from townspeople.

Now both men are retiring after two remarkable and influential, but very different, careers in the American rabbinate.

title: Restaurants
description: The mirthful Manhattan parlor game of find the restaurant has a formidable new challenger - Alison on Dominick Street. Even if you are lucky enough to get a cabby who knows the Hudson from the East River, chances are he will need your help ferreting out Dominick Street, an easy-to-miss spur off Varick Street just north of the Holland Tunnel. The quest should be worth it, though, for this unpretentious little outpost is serving some of the most seductive southwestern French fare around.
