description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,493,816 for the latest year and $1,350,971 for the year- earlier period. The company said the latest year loss from discontinued operations included a $779,562 loss on disposal.

title: New Potential UAL Suitors Emerge and Stock Climbs
description: The prospects of a bidding war for the UAL Corporation heated up yesterday as two new potential suitors appeared.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Jumbo C.D. Rates
description: The Federal rescue bailout of ailing savings and loan institutions is expected to reduce the rates on some jumbo certificates of deposit ($100,000) by as much as 1 percentage point. Most of the ailing thrifts in Texas, California and Florida were paying rates as high as 11.02 percent to attract desperately needed funds. Some of the highest bank C.D. returns continue to be paid on jumbo certificates. The Bank Rate Monitor's national index for a 6-month minimum-amount certificate ($250 to $1,000) is 8.25 percent. The following institutions offer the highest rates on jumbos in these short maturities and have a top three-star financial rating from Veribanc of Wakefield, Mass., a bank rating service. $ 90-day 180-day 1-year California Thrift & Loan, Santa Barbara 8.75% 8.75% 9.00% First Trident S & L, Columbia, S.C. 8.72 8.67 8.67 American Fed. Savings, Rockville, Md. N.A. 8.50 8.75 (Source: Jumbo Flash Report, North Palm Beach, Fla.)

title: On Erie Canal, Where Mules Once Toiled
description: As dusk came to the Mohawk Valley today, Peg and Paul Weiss pulled in on the way home from vacation in the Finger Lakes. It had been a long day: 53 miles. On the Erie Canal, that is a long way.

title: Sahara Casino Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 More Charged in Glen Ridge Attack
description: Two more Glen Ridge teen-agers, including the son of the town's chief of detectives, were accused today of participating in a sexual assault on a retarded 17-year-old girl on March 1.

title: Dow Advances 8.34 to End at 2,687.97
description: Stocks advanced yesterday in continued subdued trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average tacking on 8.34 points to close at 2,687.97.

title: Guard Is Killed As Holdup Fails At Queens Mall
description: An armored car guard was shot and killed and another guard was critically wounded yesterday in a botched robbery attempt in Queens. Dozens of police officers using helicopters and bloodhounds searched in Flushing for three men observed leaving the scene.

title: Woman Shoots an Intruder After Her Husband Is Knifed
description: A 67-year-old woman foiled a robbery attempt today when she burst from her bedroom and fired a pistol at two prowlers who had forced their way into her apartment in the city's North End and were attacking her 72-year-old husband, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: STEEPLECHASE Victory for a Weak Link: Double Bill, considered the weakest part of a three-horse entry trained by Jonathan Sheppard, took the lead early and held off Uptown Swell by 1 1/2 lengths yesterday to win the $115,400 New York Turf Writers Cup, the richest steeplechase race at Saratoga. Uptown Swell ran well in his first steeplechase stakes to be second as the 4-5 favorite. Polar Pleasure and Jimmy Lorenzo, both coupled with the winner, ran third and fourth. TENNIS Wilander Defeats Gomez: Andres Gomez of Ecuador, who was seeded 12th, lost to third-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-0, 7-6, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Association of Tennis Professionals championship in Mason, Ohio. After a rain delay of almost two hours, Wilander won the first nine games of the match. In the semifinals, he will meet the winner of the match between two other Swedes, Stefan Edberg and Jonas Svensson. Edberg won the first set, 6-4, and was trailing in the second, 1-0, when the rain resumed, halting play. (AP) Lendl Rolls: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl used a flawless third set to beat Grant Connell of Canada, 7-6, 4-6, 6-0, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $900,000 Player's International Canadian Open tournament in Montreal. Second-seeded John McEnroe defeated Alex Antonitsch of Austria, 7-5, 2-6, 6-3, and sixth-seeded Jay Berger beat unseeded Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela, 6-7, 6-1, 6-3. Third-seeded Andre Agassi defeated Andrew Sznajder of Canada, 6-1, 6-0.(AP) Graf Gains Semifinals: Steffi Graf played at the peak of her game yesterday and defeated Hana Mandlikova, 6-0, 6-1, to advance to the semifinals of the United Jersey Bank Classic tournament in Mahwah, N.J. Joining Graf, who has lost only three games in three matches in the tournament, in the semifinals were three unseeded players: 110th-ranked Stacy Martin of Largo, Md., 47th-ranked Linda Ferrando of Italy, and 56th-ranked Andrea Temesvari of Hungary.(AP) GOLF Barber Leads: Miller Barber birdied the first four holes and shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday for a three-stroke lead after the first round of the $350,000 GTE Northwest Classic in Seattle. Barber, winner of 26 events in his seasons on the PGA Senior Tour, including two this year, had six birdies on the first seven holes. Don Massengale, Dave Hill and Al Geiberger, were tied for second with 68s.(AP) AUTO RACING Fittipaldi Breaks a Record: Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, driving a Chevrolet-powered Penske PC18, shattered the Pocono International Raceway qualifying record yesterday, racing around the bumpy two-and-a-half-mile tri-oval at Long Pond, Pa., at 211.715 miles an hour to beat Rick Mears in the pole battle for the Quaker State 500 tomorrow. The previous official track record, 205.724, was set by Michael Andretti in 1986.(AP) SWIMMING Winning Day for an American: Janet Evans easily won the 400-meter individual medley at the Pan Pacific championships yesterday in Tokyo. Americans won six of nine events for the second consecutive day. In the individual medley, Evans beat Lin Li of China by about 10 meters and set a meet record with a time of 4 minutes 39.38 seconds. Evans then pushed the 800-meter freestyle relay team to a meet-record 8:03.33 and a 20-meter victory at the 50-meter Yoyogi National Olympic pool.(AP) Briton Sets and Ties a Record: Nick Gillingham of Britain set a European record and matched the world mark in the 200-meter breast-stroke yesterday at the European championships in Bonn. Gillingham's time was 2 minutes 12.90 seconds, equaling the record set three weeks ago by an American, Mike Barrowman, at the United States championships in Los Angeles.(AP)

title: The New Old World
description: The integration of Europe and the disintegration of the Stalinist imperium have long been distant goals of American policy. Now that both are hurtling within view, the United States seems strangely unprepared. Washington still hasn't decided whether or not it wants to help Mr. Gorbachev. Like the rest of the world, it awaits with some trepidation the birth of the colossus now gestating in Europe.

title: Saturday New Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: 3 Concerns in Pact On Hepatitis Tests
description: Johnson & Johnson, the Chiron Corporation and Abbott Laboratories today announced an alliance in several diagnostic fields. They have agreed to collaborate in developing and supplying the first hepatitis C diagnostic products for blood banks, hospitals and laboratories. Formerly known as hepatitis non-A, non-B, the hepatitis C was isolated and identified by Chiron.

title: Treasury Issues Mixed in Active Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities finished narrowly mixed yesterday, although trading was active as many market participants squared their books before going on vacation. Dealers said retail buying of Treasury coupon issues was evident even before the Government announced a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for July in midmorning, a figure that was in line with expectations.

title: Seahawk Oil Intl reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Copland School Head
description: Hubert Howe, who heads the Electronic Music Center at Queens College, has been named director of the Aaron Copland School of Music at the college. Professor Howe, a member of the Queens faculty since 1967, is a former president of the American section of the League of Composers of the International Society for Contemporary Music. He is also a composer, whose piano concerto will receive its premiere this fall at the Juilliard School.

title: Sea Galley Stores reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $78,000 for the quarter and $140,000 for the 6 months.

title: S.A.Y. Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Pronouncing The Names
description: JACEK AMBROZIAK, legal adviser to the Polish bishops: YAHT-sek ahm-BRO-zhak.

title: Tense Days for Nicaragua Opposition
description: Having waited years to challenge the Sandinista Front at the voting booth, Nicaragua's political opposition has reached what its leaders say is a moment of truth: the choice of a presidential candidate.

title: Westmin Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There were no share earnings in the latest periods after preferred share dividends. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Stratamerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $574,000, or 12 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $159,000, or about 4 cents a share, for the year-ago period. The latest quarter's income before extraordinary item included a pre-tax gain of $1,183,000 on the sale of Shari's Management Corp.

title: Ex-Housing Official Refuses To Comply With Subpoena
description: A former top official at the Department of Housing and Urban Development refused today to appear before a Congressional subcommittee investigating the agency or to comply with a subpoena of records of his dealings with the department after he left it.

title: Price Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Americanization of Emily
description: Two years ago, Emily Lloyd might have been dismissed as one of those minor storm systems that rattle the showbiz barometers, stir the moviegoing public and evaporate as suddenly and inexplicably as they arrived. After all, she was only 16 and had appeared in a single low-budget film. She'd played the brazen adolescent who scandalizes a sedate British seaside town with her sexual bravado in ''Wish You Were Here,'' and she'd done nothing else whatsoever. Yet here she is still, 18 years old and altogether unabated.

title: Review/Theater; Life at the Crossroads, In 'Parabola del Camino'
description: The world intrudes on the habitues of a Colombian crossroads tavern in ''El Paso o Parabola del Camino'' (The Parable of the Path), and they learn in a brutal moment that they might be fortunate, after all, to live where ''news comes from other places,'' as the innkeeper says.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: DAYS AT WILDWOOD

title: Yankees Lose Lead and Game in a Messy 8th
description: The Yankees proved tonight that they don't play favorites. They showed that they can lose games for Bucky Dent just as easily and just as excruciatingly as they did for the deposed Dallas Green.

title: John Wingate 2d Wed to Miss Dobson
description: Elisabeth Noelle Dobson, a daughter of Dr. Joanne A. Dobson and David E. Dobson of Goldens Bridge and Canaan, N.Y., was married yesterday in Pittsfield, Mass., to John Williams Wingate 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Wingate of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Dale Lock performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church.

title: Rains Take a Toll On L.I. Produce
description: LEAD: SHOPPERS in the market for Long Island's bounty of summer produce may find some unpleasant surprises at their favorite farm stands.

title: Lawmakers Caught in Utility Refund Dispute
description: An organization of the nation's state legislators, which usually steers clear of controversy, recently found itself caught in a battle between utilities and consumer groups over $19 billion.

title: U.S. Seeks Extraditions
description: President Bush said today that he would work with President Barco to coordinate the extradition of narcotics traffickers to the United States so that they can be brought to justice as swiftly as possible.

title: Review/Music; The Lyric's the Thing in Recital by Tenor
description: Robert White's brief song recital at the Frick Collection Wednesday afternoon was as much about words as about the music that bore them along. Everything was in English, and the preponderance of composers was from Britain and America. At the end came arrangements by Beethoven, Weber and Bruch of traditional Scottish songs.

title: WITH CAUTION, U.S. OFFICAILS EXPRESS SUPPORT ON CHANGE IN POLAND
description: Bush Administration officials welcomed the selection of a non-Communist Prime Minister in Poland today, but reacted with sobriety rather than jubilation, noting that the new leader faces immense economic challenges.

title: Don't Blame Just the Rain
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Elisha B. Cohen Becomes a Bride
description: Elisha Beth Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin R. Cohen of Westfield, N.J., and Lenox, Mass., was married yesterday at Cranwell in Lenox to David Glenn Monzella, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Monzella of Westfield. Judi Patti, a justice of the peace in Pittsfield, Mass., officiated.

title: Four Composers Vie For Friedheim Awards
description: Four chamber works by American composers have been chosen for the final round of the Friedheim Awards of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. They are Michael Daugherty's ''Snap! Blue Like an Orange'' for chamber ensemble and synthesizer; David Lang's ''Orpheus Over and Under'' for two pianos; George Tsontakis's String Quartet No. 4, and Chinary Ung's ''Spiral'' for cello, piano and percussion.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: DR. JAMES A. POLLOWITZ;
Good News for Hay Fever Sufferers
description: LEAD: The rains ths spring and summer may have been less than pleasing to people who enjoy the outdoors, but it was apparently good news for sufferers of hay fever. This according to Dr. James A. Pollowitz, a physician who lives in Hartsdale and is chief of the alllergy section at White Plains Hospital Medical

title: Rumania Accuses One of Its Diplomats of Spying
description: The Rumanian Government is preparing to place one of its veteran diplomats on trial for treason, possibly on charges of spying for the United States, Rumanians and Americans say.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
For Yellowstone Bears, Nature Works
description: LEAD: IN the late 1960's, when the Park Service started protecting tourists by forcing grizzlies to stay away from the campground garbage they had become addicted to, some conservationists feared the animals would not last long in the wild.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about Bermuda misstated the locations of St. George's and Somerset. St. George's is on the east end of the island, Somerset on the west end.

title: Union Station
description: To the Editor: The recent interest in refurbished Union Station in Washington prompts me to write of an annoyance that seemingly could be remedied. Locomotives of trains traveling through Washington are changed there, electric to diesel or vice versa, and usually the train stands in the station a half-hour or more. The locomotives appear to be the source of electric power, and while they are detached, which is almost the entire time the train is in the station, the lights in the cars are out. One is left in the dark in the daytime if one's car is in the covered portion of the station; at night the whole train is dark. A long dull wait. One wishes one could read.

title: Jim Dale Taps a Bawdy Tradition for Inspiration
description: Imagine you're a Malayan soldier in 1948. You don't speak a word of English and you don't understand the war that strange Englishmen have come to fight. But some of them have hacked out a clearing in the jungle and told you, ''Sit here and wait.'' At last, the ceremony begins, and - lucky you! - it's Jim Dale, dancing and prancing in a flamboyant drag impersonation of Carmen Miranda. Aren't you glad you came to this war?

title: UNCLE SAM IS THE HEAVY
description: THE CONFESSION OF JOE CULLEN By Howard Fast. 282 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: Health-Care Cures
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Forget the Poems
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing Justice To the Subjects
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about commercially sponsored television programming in high schools misstated the ownership of the Discovery Channel. It is jointly owned by Cox Cable Communications, the New Channels Corporation, the TCI Development Corporation, United Artists Entertainment Inc. and the Discovery management. The article also misstated the relationship between the Discovery Channel and Whittle Communications. The Discovery Channel has not sold any programming to Whittle, nor does it plan to. The article further misidentified an organization that cooperated in the development of ''CNN Newsroom.'' It was the National School Boards Association.

title: 'The Catalog of Lost Books'
description: To the Editor:

title: After Drought, Weather Tries New Quirk: Rain for the Record Book
description: Rarely in the last century has it rained so much on the Middle Atlantic, Appalachian and Gulf states as it has this year.

title: Program Pirates
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Dayton Company Out-of-Doors
description: The Dayton Contemporary Dance Company is an American dance institution. Founded in 1968 by Jeraldyne Blunden, its current director, this immensely engaging modern dance company has managed, however, to stay young at heart. Or so it seemed on Friday when the company performed in the Damrosch Park Band Shell as part of the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival.

title: UNNERVING ART
description: The doorbell to Francis Bacon's ramshackle mews house in South Kensington, London, has not worked for some time. Visitors knock loudly and then cling to a rope bannister while climbing the steep, narrow stairs that lead to the kitchen, bedroom and studio.

title: Look for Salvador's Killers in Ruling Party
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Buy the Piece, Never the Story'
description: The past is a foreign country rich in treasure but poorly defended. Pillagers can readily plunder its tombs and chapels. Eager buyers abound in a booming antiquities market notorious for lack of scruple.

title: Taiwan Pulls In a Hand Extended to the Mainland
description: ALONG the prosperous streets of this small island, listening to private vendors making deals in Taiwan accents and listening to Taiwan songs blaring from new stereos, it is hard to escape the feeling that this must be Taiwan soil. But the shores of Taiwan are still 130 miles away, across the Taiwan Strait. Gulang Island and the rest of Fujian Province are part of China.

title: Jeryl Lynn Kaye, Executive, Weds
description: Jeryl Lynn Kaye, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert D. Kaye of Saddle River, N.J., was married last evening to Eric A. Kaye, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Kaye of Smithtown, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: Elizabeth Knapp Engaged
description: Elizabeth Knapp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. P. Knapp of Bronxville, N.Y., and Nicholas Paul Hotchkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Hotchkin of Macclesfield, Cheshire, England, plan to marry in September, the prospective bride's parents have announced. Miss Knapp and Mr. Hotchkin are cum laude graduates of Harvard University. She is a fund raiser and a program planner at the Westside Cluster, a nonprofit agency serving homeless people in New York. Her father, who retired as managing director and a senior vice president at Chubb & Son in New York, is the executive director at the Excess Line Association in New York, an organization of licensed insurance brokers. The bridegroom is a planner in the international service parts division of General Motors in Detroit. His father is an air traffic controller in Manchester, England.

title: Hot Dogs, History And Haddonfield
description: The hot-dog vendor in Haddonfield was dead wrong when he stated in the Haddonfield Journal article on July 23 (''Vendor Wins Fight to Sell Hot Dogs on the Street'') that ''97 percent of the town is for me.'' All the evidence contradicts this pronouncement, and as executive director of the Haddonfield Preservation Society, which offers free counseling on matters pertaining to our historic district, established in 1971, I feel compelled to set the record straight.

title: Going Up for 5?
description: The insider-trading case against Robert A. Freeman has ended with his conviction, but it was hardly a shining hour for Federal prosecutors. Mr. Freeman, a partner in the firm of Goldman, Sachs, was arrested along with two other brokers in 1987 and, amid much ado, charged with a broad insider trading conspiracy. When the charges against the men were dropped a month later, Rudolph W. Giuliani, then the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, found himself accused of overzealousness. That was it until last week, when Mr. Freeman pleaded guilty to one count of insider trading in which he sold stock to avoid $930,000 in losses. Experts said that the one-count plea showed the Government had a weak case. Nevertheless Mr. Freeman could get five years in prison.

title: 'Tailspin' Is Longer on Docu Than on Drama
description: Like those cartoon characters who get shot, drowned, clobbered and blown up, only to reappear a second later ready to be demolished yet again, the docudrama is back. Having done their stuff on Oliver North and Baby M., its practitioners are even now mucking about in the lives of Hedda Nussbaum and Joel Steinberg, of the fatal child-abuse case, and Robert Chambers and Jennifer Levin, of the Central Park strangling.

title: Jill A. Greenberg Becomes a Bride
description: Jill Alison Greenberg and Michael Jay Weinstein were married last evening at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J. Rabbi Z. David Levy officiated.

title: Mozart in the Bronx
description: Stephen Somary will conduct the Bronx Arts Ensemble in Mozart's Serenade for Winds (K. 375), Milhaud's Dectet, and Strauss's Suite in B flat (Op. 4) at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park, near Broadway and Mosholu Avenue, in the Bronx, at 2 P.M. today. The program will be repeated at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall, on Bronx Rose Hill campus of Fordham University. Admission is free. Information: 549-1899.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are planning to install a new kitchen floor of vinyl tiles. The existing floor is vinyl tile that still is well secured and has a smooth surface. But one corner of a tile near the refrigerator has lifted slightly, and the dealer says that the old flooring must be ripped up and new plywood put down before the new tiles can be laid. However, a flooring contractor says that he can install the new tiles over the existing floor. Who is correct?

title: THE JUDGE WHO HAD EVERYTHING
description: HONORABLE JUSTICE The Life of Oliver Wendell Holmes. By Sheldon M. Novick. Illustrated. 522 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Steven H. Carey, 43, Poet in Acting Family
description: Steven Harry Carey, a poet and grandson of the late Harry Carey, the Western star who appeared in over 300 films, died of a heart attack Aug. 13 in Spring Lake, N.J., while visiting relatives. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Fewer Travelers Place New York On the Itinerary
description: Tourist and business travel to New York City has declined this year, several major indicators show. This is the first such drop in eight years.

title: U.S. Cuts Estimate of Untapped Oil Reserves
description: The Government has lowered by 40 percent its estimate of untapped and undiscovered American oil resources, reflecting in part the recent failures of promising drilling prospects in the West and offshore.

title: Caren Lesser Is Married
description: Caren Lynn Lesser and David P. Schnesel, both 26 years old, were married last evening at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Daniel Fogel and Rabbi Stephen Pearce officiated. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Lesser of Woodbury, L.I., is a sales executive at Alex Sport, a New York clothing manufacturer. Her husband, the son of Ernest Schnesel of New York and Mrs. Arthur W. Saftler of Merrick, L.I., is a vice president of Crimson Air Services, a courier concern in New York.

title: Phyllis Newman: '100' and Still Counting
description: TO Phyllis Newman, time is a riff. Now that she is about to begin her ''101st year'' as a performer, Ms. Newman says that she is ''still doing the things I've always tried to do - to really entertain and, also, somewhere, I hope there's a point of view that comes across.''

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; An Office Park Lures Hewlett
description: LITTLE FALLS CENTER, a 157-acre office park being developed by Hercules, an international chemical company, has managed to woo a division of the Hewlett-Packard Company. The park, in the unincorporated countryside just west of Wilmington, the state's largest city, has been under development since 1984.

title: Roth Honored
description: Among the six men named last week to the National Soccer Hall of Fame in Oneonta, N.Y., was Werner Roth, the former captain of the Cosmos, who grew up in Brooklyn and was one of the first American pro soccer stars. He was also the captain of the United States National Team from 1968 to 1975.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BLOODSTREAM. By Joel Redon. (Knights Press/Lyle Stuart, Paper, $9.) A semi-autobiographical, four-month slice of life as experienced by a young AIDS victim named Peter, this rough-hewn first novel burns with guilt and horror - and a 25-year-old man's determination to live with the disease instead of waiting for it to kill him.

title: Mariellen Sullivan to Marry in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry F. Sullivan of Chicago and Amagansett, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mariellen Margaret Sullivan, to Noble Olds Carpenter Jr., a son of Mr. Carpenter of Canton, Ohio, and the late Ann L. Carpenter. An October wedding is planned.

title: Special Today; Fashions of The Times
description: Section 6

title: Truffaut's Janine Comes at Last to the Screen
description: When one thinks back to Francois Truffaut's classic first feature, ''The 400 Blows,'' the image that comes to mind is Antoine Doinel, the rebellious adolescent played by Jean-Pierre Leaud and based on the director's own difficult childhood. What most filmgoers don't know, however, is that ''The 400 Blows'' was originally conceived with a dual focus, namely Antoine and a female counterpart named Janine. Realizing he had too much material, Truffaut deleted Janine, a little thief, intending to devote an entire film to her someday.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Raymond, Me.; Soft Market Sweeteners
description: BUILDERS and brokers in the Greater Portland area are offering incentives to bolster a sagging residential market.

title: A Broker Is Wed To Holly Harrison
description: The wedding of Constance Knox Harrison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Thomas Harrison of Stevenson, Md., and Wianno, Mass., and David McLay Crosby, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thompson Crosby of Wilmington, Del., took place yesterday in Garrison, Md. The Rev. William P. Baxter Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church. Hope Harrison Wright was the matron of honor for her sister. Paul Courtright was the best man.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold $184,500 44 Ramon Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,580. Jackson $144,900 91 Leesville-Siloam Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car garage, fireplace, enclosed porch; taxes $2,567. Howell $124,900 26 Oakwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, carport, Florida room; taxes $1,298. Maplewood $187,000 20 Warren Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,683. Pompton Lakes $170,000 389 Stiles Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; full basement, fenced yard, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,064. Trenton $83,000 1411 Chambers Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old colonial; dining room, enclosed porch, remodeled kitchen; taxes $1,263. OTHER SALES Pound Ridge, N.Y. $245,000 88 Rolling Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old saltbox; fireplace, dining room, pond, 1 acre; taxes $3,056. Avon, Conn. $328,320 521 West Avon Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; skylights, whirlpool bath, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,504. Greenlawn, L.I. $210,000 22 Bartel Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, Florida room, 0.25 acre; taxes $4,600.

title: Union Station
description: To the Editor: I must report a distressing incident that happened recently during a wait of several hours at Union Station.

title: Works in Progress; A Bath Every Century, Need It or Not
description: PRACTICE, PRACTICE, PRAC-tice. Carnegie Hall, which turns 100 in 1991, predates the old joke - surely you've heard it: A tourist on the street asks, ''How do you get there?'' - but probably not by much. Tchaikovsky conducted on opening night, and the stature of America's grandest music venue was thenceforth entrenched. Aside from legend, what has accrued at Carnegie Hall in the past century is grime and soot, which, in advance of the centennial season that begins next fall (and following the interior renovation of three years ago) is now being scoured from the exterior.

title: Keeping Kids in School and Mothers Off Welfare
description: In June, less than an hour before adjourning for the summer, the South Carolina Legislature adopted ''Target 2000: School Reform for the Next Decade.'' The measure is an extension of the Education Improvement Act of 1984, which identified 61 ways to improve school performance and has already helped lift S.A.T. scores and lower dropout rates in the state. Target 2000 hopes to build on those accomplishments by, among other things, providing funds to schools who devise their own improvement plans.

title: Ending a Common Danger
description: IN SOVIET-AMERICAN ARMS control we find ourselves at a moment of hope - not only that much can be achieved during the next few years but also that such achievement can open the way to a stronger and more stable peace than we have had since 1945.

title: Corrections
description: An article last week about Union Carbide referred incompletely to the price history of the company's stock since the 1984 Bhopal accident. The article noted that the stock traded at $50 before the accident and that it is now trading at below $30. But the comparison failed to take into account a 3-for-1 stock split in 1986.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. JOHN R. SUSSMAN;
'I'd Love to See All Pregnancies Planned'
description: LEAD: THE number of women having their first babies after age 30 has quadrupled in the last 16 years, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. As a result, according to the center, women having their first babies are better educated than in years past and are seeking out prenatal care earlier.

title: A Chunk of Lava in the Sea
description: ON the east end of one of Iceland's neighboring islands there is a vast hill. It is a hill as dark as the melt of minerals in the earth's heart, and burns with all of their fires. It sprawls toward the sea and reaches the town. And from its surface, every few yards, come breaths of steam.

title: The Welcome Woods Is a Friend No More
description: MY 8-year-old son came galloping down the cellar steps to find me. His eyes were wide with hope. ''Dad, can me and Kate go play in the woods?''

title: DATA UPDATE: August 20, 1989
Statewide Testing in Education
description: I couldn't agree or disagree more with Donald J. Ryan. I agree that there is enormous need for ''a greater sense of community with our schools, increased autonomy for teachers and much more time to meet within their respective disciplines and 'across the curriculum.'''

title:
DINING OUT;
Victorian Character in Cold Spring
description: LEAD: THE name has changed slightly, to the Plumbush Inn - the establishment now offers overnight accommodations - but the beautiful sprawling house set among the ancient trees of serene, park-like grounds still retains its original Victorian character. Old draperies, paneling and wallpapers have been renewed and restored.

title: THE SISTERS BRONTE AND THE SISTERS COLLINS: A STUDY IN STUNNING LITERARY PARALLELS
description: LEAD: ''Sometimes . . . the cheap stuff works just as well as the expensive [stuff].'' -- Jackie Collins, ''Lucky.''

title: Bigger and Older: Super Trout Arrives
description: New York State's record for brown trout - 29 pounds, 14 ounces, caught in Lake Ontario in 1986 - may be surpassed in the next few years by a strain of the species that has been imported from West Germany.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Grand Central Terminal; Replacing a Retail Hodgepodge With Urban Chic
description: DAYS are numbered for the jumble of stores, restaurants and other commercial establishments in Grand Central Terminal. As leases expire, tenants are moving out or accepting month-to-month extensions from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is completing plans for a retail complex more akin to a chic urban mall.

title: In Chile, It's Ski Season
description: THE thermal hot springs of Chillan have been a tourist attraction for 150 years. Only since the mid-1980's, however, has a cooler diversion - skiing - taken hold from June through October at this resort in the Chilean Andes. Poised on the flank of a smoking volcano, the Termas de Chillan Ski Center enjoys a dual appeal. By day, skiers take the longest chairlift in South America to some of the finest open-slope skiing in the Andes. In the evenings, they soak in four thermal swimming pools, as well as private baths, filled from subterranean volcanic springs.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: For much of the summer I've been taking pictures with two medium-speed color-print films that are new to the market this year. One, Agfa's Agfacolor XRC 100, is a general-purpose film intended to appeal to a broad band of snapshooters. The other, Kodak's Ektar 125, is a high-end ''premium'' film that Kodak says delivers especially high-quality results.

title: Bars to Equality of Sexes Seen as Eroding, Slowly
description: A quarter-century after the start of the women's rights movement, American women say that despite their gains, it is still a man's world.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WITHIN THE RIBBONS: Nine Stories. By Frank Manley. (North Point, $17.95.) Small moments provide major revelations in the poet and playwright Frank Manley's ''Within the Ribbons,'' a collection of stories set in the South and mainly featuring female protagonists. All of these stories share a religious undercurrent as they explore the part that mercy, grace and forgiveness play in ordinary life.

title: Question Of the Week; Do Colleges Spend Too Much on Athletics?
description: Colleges are supposed to prepare people for a lifetime career or job. How long does a football career last? How many are left with lifetime vexation of injuries?

title: An Indian City Begins to Suffer From Success
description: Almost everything about Bangalore, the country's fifth-largest and fastest-growing city, makes it different from the rest of India.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: Most of the top-ranked American bridge players are professionals, who make all, or nearly all, of their income playing tournaments. There are no corporate sponsors, at least on this side of the Atlantic, and no prize money. So how do they live?

description: LEAD: THE GLASS BRIDGE. By Marga Minco. Translated by Stacey Knecht. (Peter Owen/Dufour, $19.95.) To its credit, ''The Glass Bridge'' belongs to a category of Holocaust fiction that favors the subtle unraveling of plot over lurid scenes of torture. However, a flooring contractor says that he can install the new tiles over the existing floor. Who is correct?

Pearls and cheerful, summery colors were the clothes of choice for cocktails, buffet and dancing.

By overturning Brookhaven's original restrictions on the number of unrelated persons in a single family home, the State Court of Appeals has indeed destroyed zoning restrictions in New York State and has made it infinitely easier for boarding houses to be established anywhere.

title: NONFICTION
description: BEFORE THE BULLDOZER: The Nambiquara Indians and the World Bank. By David Price. (Seven Locks Press, $18.95.) In 1980 David Price, an American anthropologist, was solicited by the World Bank to assess the impact of a $1 billion development proposal on the Indians of central Brazil. The Polonoroeste project, which the World Bank helped to fund, would include the paving of a 1,000-mile highway through this remote region; its effects on the Indians promised to be dramatic. With considerable trepidation and a strong desire to aid the Indians - particularly the Nambiquara, a tribal society barely acquainted with the modern world - Mr. Price consented. ''Before the Bulldozer'' is his gripping account of that experience, which was marked by bureaucratic corruption, lack of foresight and downright ignorance at every turn. The reader follows Mr. Price through the byzantine bureaucracy of the National Indian Foundation (known as FUNAI), the Brazilian agency charged with devising an acceptable plan for allocation of resources to the Indians, then to the remote and dwindling Nambiquara settlements. The author, who contends that the Indians were viewed as mere obstructions to economic development, found the FUNAI proposal grossly inadequate. His report was virtually ignored by the World Bank, and the loan was approved. Today, much of the area has been deforested; settlers have flocked in, encouraged by the new highway, only to find their promised land practically barren; new diseases have plagued the Indians; one Nambiquara tribe has mysteriously disappeared. More than an anthropological study, Mr. Price's book is a passionate appeal to preserve cultural diversity and to re-examine the concept of development in light of the cultural and environmental havoc that frequently follows.

title: The Alps
description: To the Editor: I was enchanted with Paul Lewis's account of Talloires and neighboring town (''Beside the Alpine Lake of Annecy,'' Travel, June 11). My two children, ages 7 and 10, my husband and I rented a chalet in Talloires for the month of July last year and it was an unforgettable holiday.

title: NONFICTION
description: IRWIN SHAW: A Biography. By Michael Shnayerson. (Putnam, $24.95.) In the course of his long career, Irwin Shaw seems to have almost had it all - early literary success as a socially conscious playwright and short-story writer for The New Yorker, then even greater financial success as a Hollywood screenwriter and the author of such blockbusters as ''The Young Lions'' and ''Rich Man, Poor Man.'' The richer Shaw grew, however, the lower his literary reputation fell and the glitzier his life became, leading Michael Shnayerson, in ''Irwin Shaw: A Biography,'' to see the writer's life as ''an ethical allegory, a deep and implacable struggle between art and money in mid-twentieth-century America.'' Mr. Shnayerson, a contributing editor at Vanity Fair, portrays the writer as a complex personality who could be extraordinarily generous to his friends and at the same time psychologically abusive to his wife. Born to Russian Jewish immigrant parents in 1913, Shaw came of age in a modest home in Depression-era Brooklyn. He went on to lead a glamorous life, first in New York and Hollywood, then as an expatriate in Paris and Switzerland. As Shaw's womanizing escalated and his marriage deteriorated, the outwardly idyllic life at his Swiss chalet became increasingly sordid. Mr. Shnayerson, who conducted more than 200 interviews for this book, does not shy away from the squalid details of Shaw's heavy drinking and compulsive infidelity, but when told at such length, they begin to border on the voyeuristic. ''The intellect of man is forced to choose / Perfection of the life, or of the work,'' Yeats wrote. To judge by Mr. Shnayerson's cautionary account, Shaw's inner demons seem to have got the better of both the life and the work.

title: NONFICTION
description: BLOOD SEASON: Tyson and the World of Boxing. By Phil Berger. (Morrow, $18.95.) For many people boxing is an odd sport, a gladiatorial throwback. It is different from team sports like baseball in that fans must identify with an individual who may disappear from the sport as quickly as it takes to count 10. While an occasional champion in a lighter weight classification, like Sugar Ray Leonard, captures fans' imaginations, it is the heavyweight division that garners most of the attention. It is on this division that Phil Berger, the boxing reporter for The New York Times, focuses in his fine book, ''Blood Season.'' Beginning in 1978, when Leon Spinks snatched the title from an aging Muhammad Ali, and taking us through the present reign of Mike Tyson, Mr. Berger charts the course of professional heavyweight boxing. Through his experienced eyes the reader begins to understand the personalities of those who pull the strings, men like the promoters Don King, Butch Lewis and Bob Arum and the manager Dennis Rappaport. These men are often far more interesting than the fighters they send into the ring. Writing knowledgeably, compassionately and with remarkable insight, Mr. Berger offers a bird's-eye view of the machinations of the sport. He is especially strong when dealing with the controversy centering on Mike Tyson; his former wife, Robin Givens; and his managers, Bill Cayton and Jimmy Jacobs. The only quibble, and it is a small one, is Mr. Berger's arch choice of referring to himself in the third person. Otherwise, he has produced a valuable, clear-headed and much needed overview of the sport.

title: Zucchini With an Italian Accent

As a child in England I remember how each year local gardeners would compete to grow the biggest, pointing with pride at specimens the size of a man's riding boot. The marrows, as they were called, were cooked with the typical English solicitude toward vegetables: Boiled, stuffed and then baked until they were reduced to a watery pulp.

title: Getting a Refund From Eastern
description: WHEN the air travelers' hall of fame is built, perhaps a special wall will be dedicated to the people who held Eastern Air Lines tickets in March. First a strike canceled thousands of flights. Then the airline filed for bankruptcy protection. After four months the airline announced a procedure for people seeking refunds. But ticket holders will probably have to wait until January to get their money back.

title: A COURAGE BORN OF BROKEN PROMISES
description: In Michael Blumenthal's references to broken promises and shattered dreams, he seems to have bought the Cinderella story, hook, line and sinker (About Men: ''A Courage Born of Broken Promises,'' July 23). The handsome prince sweeps the maiden off to the castle and cares for her the rest of her life. I suggest he reacquaint himself with reality. We are not fairy-tale maids and princes. We are human, with human merits and failings. And sometimes we make the wrong choices about partners.

title: Young Musicians Sell Their Wares Door to Door

The Van Cliburn Competition means more money and more concerts, the Tchaikovsky and the Chopin more prestige; but Affiliate Artists - by making limited opportunity a virtue - may be offering its selected young musicians things of value that its opulent competitors in the contest world cannot. These are low pressure, low profile and time to grow.

title: New Look at Indian Art

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Last call to order bulbs for fall planting, particularly the lesser-known kinds. Continue transplanting woody shrubs so their roots are well established by winter. Take cuttings of geraniums, impatiens, begonias and other flowering annuals to root and grow as house plants. Select herbs in good condition and dry them for potpourri and culinary needs. Carry On

title: FICTION
description: NEVER QUITE DEAD. By Seymour Shubin. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) There are no really likable people in Seymour Shubin's seventh novel, a tense, driven tale of a man dedicated to tracking down the murderer of a 3-year-old boy who was beaten to death and dumped on the street 20 years earlier. The searcher, a thriller writer named David Kyle, is obsessed with the hunt, partly because no one ever claimed the boy's body. The plot of ''Never Quite Dead'' is based on an actual, still unsolved crime that was committed in Philadelphia, where much of the action takes place. In addition to being a good mystery, the novel also seems grimly topical, now that national attention has become increasingly focused on child abuse. The people involved in Kyle's search are middle-aged former hippies who have made conventional lives they want to preserve - but they know what happened to the boy, and Kyle is relentless. About a third of the way into the story, it's reasonably clear who did the killing, and in the next 50 pages the motive is revealed, though not the actual circumstances. Still, Mr. Shubin is able to sustain the novel's drive with good plot twists. It's disconcerting, however, suddenly to find all these people, including Kyle, starting their sentences with words like ''Hey'' (presumably replacing ''Oh, wow!''). They also whine and cavil; occasionally Mr. Shubin also describes the hydraulics of their sex. And there's an annoying amount of inelegant narrative padding: Kyle not only makes phone calls, he sits down on the bed and taps out the numbers. He not only gets dressed, he tucks his shirt in and zips up his pants. He not only orders crab cocktail and blackened redfish, he eats them with a fork. Still, as the end of the novel approaches, the padding disappears and the action becomes rapid, convincing and compelling. Despite the story's flaws, the emotion Kyle feels for the boy is touching, and the finale comes with a fine, satisfying snap.

description: LEAD: THIS beach-resort community near the Mexican border, where condominiums and hotels are abundant and occupancy rates low, has begun to look to a new springboard back to prosperity - a convention center.

title: Another World at End of the Fishing Line
description: ONE of my early memories is of walking down a country road with my cousin, each of us holding onto one end of a string of fish. I couldn't have been more than 7 or 8. My uncle had taken us; our rods were twigs with string attached.

title: Basketball Talent: Imports Are Up
description: Six weeks from the opening of training camp, executives of the National Basketball Association find themselves with much more pressing concerns than trimming rookies and free agents from their rosters. As a result of what Commissioner David Stern calls ''a shrinking basketball world,'' routine summer tasks have been overshadowed by an international chess game, played out in courtrooms, government agencies and basketball arenas around the globe.

title:
GARDENING;
Improving Drainage in Plant Containers
description: LEAD: It is remarkable how fallacious procedures for growing plants become established as fact. An example is the universally proclaimed practice of putting drainage in the bottom of a plant container. In this context, drainage refers to the handful of shards from broken clay pots or the in ch or so of gravel placed in the bottom of the container before soil is added.

title: Carole Donovan Becomes a Bride
description: Carole Joan Donovan, a registered nurse at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York, and Anthony A. Spinelli, the director of program sales for the New York Stock Exchange, were married yesterday at Grace and St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Martin F. Hauser performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Halborg, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Astros Defeat Cubs By 8-4
description: Glenn Davis became the first Houston player to hit 30 homers in three different seasons and the Astros beat the Chicago Cubs, 8-4, tonight to move within two games of first-place San Francisco in the National League West.

title:
GARDENING;
Improving Drainage in Plant Containers
description: LEAD: It is remarkable how fallacious procedures for growing plants become established as fact. An example is the universally proclaimed practice of putting drainage in the bottom of a plant container. In this context, drainage refers to the handful of shards from broken clay pots or the in ch or so of gravel placed in the bottom of the container before soil is added.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: South Carolina; Few Students Sign Up For Stricter Visitation
description: When the University of South Carolina administration decided last spring to designate two freshmen dormitories where rooms would be off limits to the opposite sex, it didn't know how students would react.

title: A Celebration To Touch the Heart Of a Tin Man
description: It was less a tornado of attention than an outpouring of affection, but that befits the mellowness of a golden anniversary. ''The Wizard of Oz,'' the movie, turned 50 years old the other day, and locally the event did not lack for commemorations, promotions, parties, hoopla and happiness.

title: U.S. Seeks Closed Hearing in Iran-Contra Case
description: The Justice Department said Friday that it wanted a closed hearing in the Court of Appeals to discuss Government secrets that could be disclosed in the trial of Joseph F. Fernandez, a former Central Intelligence Agency official in Costa Rica.

title: Even After Misfirings, Trident Is Well Liked
description: DESPITE two test failures this year for the Trident 2, the $5.7 billion program to build the submarine-launched ballistic missiles seems likely to escape the sort of political repercussions that have dogged other new American strategic weapons.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Polenta That Is Satisfying Without Being Too Heavy
description: Things Italian have become wildly popular in the last few years, and we should all be grateful. The food can be enormously satisfying without being stupefyingly rich. It can be hearty and still seem appropriate in warm weather.

title: Katy Lawrence To Be Married To L. F. Bryan
description: November wedding plans have been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Harding Lawrence of Dallas, New York, St.-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, France, and Mustique, West Indies, for their daughter Kathryn Gibson Lawrence and Lawrence Frederick Bryan, the son of Sir Arthur and Lady Bryan of Tittensor, Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, England.

title: Powder Plant Blast Kills 2
description: The second explosion this year at a commercial powder factory killed two workers and injured six on Friday. The blast, at the Atlas Powder Company, came as employees poured molten primer, an igniting substance, into a mold. An explosion on March 22 injured two employees in a unit that turns nitric acid and ammonium into ammonium nitrate.

title: Ears Weary? Here's a Cause
description: Sailors called them the dog days because Sirius, the Dog Star, stood high in midsummer nights. Usually there wasn't much wind; things went slowly.

title: Salli Skahan Is Married
description: Salli Skahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Skahan of Hague and Somers, N.Y., was married yesterday to Drew Johnroe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Johnroe of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio. The Rev. Helenmarie Sunkenberg, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Grace Memorial Union Chapel in Sabbathday Point, N.Y. Mrs. Johnroe, formerly a legal assistant with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, graduated from St. Lawrence University and received an M.B.A. degree from the University of Colorado. Mr. Johnroe, a graduate of Duke University and the University of Denver Law School, is a partner in the law firm of Johnroe, Claassen & McCarger in Steamboat Springs, Colo.

title: William Henagen And Babette Mills Planning to Marry
description: Barbara Louise Mills and William Floyd Henagen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Henagen Jr. of Atlanta, plan to marry in September, the prospective bride's parents, Elizabeth L. Mills and Bradford Mills, both of Princeton, N.J., have announced.

title: Turkey Wants More Pity and Less Criticism
description: OVER the last few weeks, two distinct yet subtly linked developments have inflamed resentments here over how Europe regards Turkey on issues of human rights. The events provide fresh perspectives on the country's often muddled relationship with the West, especially with the European Community to which it wants desperately to belong.

title: A Reminder
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language; Diluting the Awe By Some
description: THE GREENHOUSE effect may or may not be heating up the atmosphere, but there is no doubt the human propensity for hot words is raising the temperature of language.

title: Bush and Cuomo Firm on Shoreham
description: LEAD: IN their nearly hourlong meeting in the Oval Office of the White House last week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented President Bush with 10 questions about Federal intentions for the Shoreham nuclear-power plant.

title: An Appointment Made for a Murder
description: IT was a dark and stormy night when the bizarre sex crime that forms the basis for ''Murder By Appointment'' was committed. It was also a dark and stormy night when the killer was caught.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A MASCULINE ENDING, by Joan Smith. (Fawcett, $3.50.) A feminist professor visiting Paris to deliver a paper on the oppressive nature of masculine grammatical forms stumbles across the murder of an Oxford don. This novel ''offers a pleasant look at the world of British academe,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review last year. ''Ms. Smith is a literate writer who, in this accomplished novel, manages both to educate and to entertain.'' IN THE AGE OF THE SMART MACHINE: The Future of Work and Power, by Shoshana Zuboff. (Basic Books, $11.95.) Thanks to the computer, work is becoming less a matter of manipulating things than manipulating symbols, and the distinction between blue- and white-collar labor continues to dissolve. Thus it is managers more than workers who are threatened by the information revolution, a sociologist argues, and many of them will do their best to subvert it. Last year our reviewer, Robert Howard, called this book ''a work of rare originality and engrossing complexity that defines the choices new technology frames for us, even as it documents how we so often misunderstand them.'' AT RISK, by Alice Hoffman. (Berkley, $4.95.) A middle-class family must decide what to tell themselves and everybody else about an 11-year-old daughter who comes down with AIDS. ''In its simplicity and directness and restraint there is very often a compelling power'' to this novel, Jim Shepard said here last year. In LOVING RACHEL: A Family's Journey From Grief (Signet/New American Library, $4.50), another novelist, Jane Bernstein, tells how she learned to accept the fact that her daughter was born blind. ''Her prose is incisive and vivid; it rings with truth and flashes of humor,'' our reviewer, Heather Vogel Frederick, said last year. ''Parents of disabled children, or any parents for that matter, will find this an inspiring tale.'' THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $5.95.) The author of ''The Hunt for Red October'' turns the Soviet-American ''Star Wars'' competition into another of his high-tech thrillers. ''While his prose is no better than workmanlike (the genre does not, after all, attract many budding Flauberts), the unmasking of the title's secret agent, the Cardinal, is as sophisticated an exercise in the craft of espionage as I have yet to encounter,'' Robert Lekachman said here last year. OUTRAGEOUS CONDUCT: Art, Ego, and the ''Twilight Zone'' Case, by Stephen Farber and Marc Green. (Ivy, $4.95.) Two journalists recount how the director John Landis's desire for dramatic footage in the movie ''Twilight Zone'' resulted in the deaths of Vic Morrow and two child-actors. ''The assumption of their crisply reported, deeply moral book is that no movie is worth risking lives for,'' Carrie Rickey said here last year. EVA LUNA, by Isabel Allende. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. (Bantam, $4.95.) Moving from one surrealistic romance to another, a Latin American peasant becomes a revolutionary and a writer. Last year our reviewer, John Krich, said that this novel is excessively sentimental and operatic but that Isabel Allende shows ''an evident affection for words, compassion for the oppressed and the inarticulate, the daring ambition to draw cross sections of whole societies and a nearly maternal approach to narrative that bathes characters in a warm, milky light.'' IN AFRICA WITH SCHWEITZER, by Edgar Berman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon from Baltimore tells what it was like to operate in Gabon with Albert Schweitzer. ''By approaching him professionally instead of journalistically, Dr. Berman provides a refreshing perspective in this memoir about one of the inspiring figures of the 20th century,'' Herbert Mitgang said in The Times in 1986. ''Listening in on surgeons as they talk to each other under pressure can be more revealing than trying to fathom what spiritual elements make up sainthood.'' THE BODY IN THE VOLVO, by K. K. Beck. (Ivy, $3.50.) A tenureless professor running an auto repair shop is accused of murdering his old department head. ''The story is imaginative, the presentation lighthearted, the characters believable,'' Newgate Callendar said here in 1987. THE MAKING OF McPAPER: The Inside Story of USA Today, by Peter S. Prichard. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) USA Today may be the paper for people who don't have time to watch television news, but Peter S. Prichard, one of its editors, considers it a journalistic success. In 1987 The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said he was surprised at the candor of this authorized corporate biography. It is, he wrote, ''a cleverly packaged drama of brilliantly clever packaging.'' BLOOD RUN, by Leah Ruth Robinson. (Onyx/New American Library, $4.50.) An emergency room physician suspects that her colleague's drug overdose was not really suicide. Last year Alan Caruba said here that this novel by a former medical technician is ''a thrilling blend of cold medical facts and heated emotions, a portrait of a place where death is an everyday event - until, with a murderer on the staff, it strikes so close that no one is safe.'' THE SEARCH FOR OMM SETY: A Story of Eternal Love, by Jonathan Cott with Hanny El Zeini. (Warner, $9.95.) Convinced that she had lived before as an Egyptian priestess, Dorothy Eady changed her name to Omm Sety and embarked on a career as an Egyptologist, irritating colleagues with her claim that her discoveries were based on memory, not secondhand scholarship. In 1987 our reviewer, John Anthony West, said this book about her life was ''readable, fair and always lively.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is an incredible success for our struggle. But now let us see it in practice. This is just the beginning.'' - Lech Walesa. [ 12:1. ]

title: In Danger of Losing Arms Race, Zimmer Revamps Rotation
description: As if the season hasn't been exciting enough on the North Side of Chicago, Don Zimmer is providing Cubs fans with fodder for winterlong debate. The results of his effort may also induce a few baseball people to join the second-guess brigade.

title: Question Of the Week; Do Colleges Spend Too Much on Athletics?
description: Being competitive is the name of the game in Corporate America and whether we like to admit it or not, college athletic departments operate off the same profit and loss statements as do the IBM's of the world. I fear and often ridicule the big business philosophy that dominates college athletics today, but I'm also the first to rush home and overdose on the N.C.A.A.'s March Madness or to act like an escaped lunatic cheering on my favorite college football team. It bothers me to no end to think that a college athlete might be competing for something more than the pride of his school, but I also seriously wonder whether March Madness would exist today if colleges didn't spend as much as they do to remain competitive in the entertainment business. RICHARD P. SMYTH Jr. Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Post office employees, often accused of lacking wit, exhibited a great deal of inventiveness in the early days of stamps, creating often elaborate cancels to obliterate stamps and prevent their re-use.

title: POSTINGS: Artemus Ward's Farm; Luxury Sites
description: Forty-eight housing sites on 254 acres once owned by Artemus Ward have been put on the market in Pound Ridge, N.Y., adjoining the town of Bedford in northeastern Westchester County. Ward, a humorist whose real name was Charles Farrar Browne, greatly influenced Mark Twain and was as famous in his time as Twain was later. He farmed the property for several decades and died in 1867.

title: Military Satellite Is Launched
description: An unmanned Delta 2 rocket blasted off Friday morning to deploy an advanced military guidance satellite. After four delays in 10 days, the rocket, carrying a $65 million Navstar Global Positioning System satellite, thundered from its launching pad at 1:59 A.M.

title: LESSONS FROM THE SANDBOX
description: Robert L. Fulghum's book found its way into the personal-skills seminar I teach at the University of Virginia (''Lessons From the Sandbox,'' by Patricia Leigh Brown, July 23). As part of a final presentation, students were required to plot a course for pursuing their goals after graduation. One young woman in the class concluded her presentation by asking that we all read a passage from ''All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten . . .'' - out loud, in unison (in true Fulghum style).

title: Capping a Career
description: To the Editor:

title: Sally George Wed To R. S. Cramer Jr.
description: Sally Lynn George, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles D. George of Brunswick, Ga., was married last evening to Robert Stanley Cramer Jr. at the First Presbyterian Church in Brunswick. The Rev. James Beaty officiated. Mr. Cramer is the son of Mrs. Robert Feer of New York and Robert S. Cramer of Washington.

title: A Neighborhood Wins in Capital's Drug War
description: Green Hornet to Elevator Slim, Green Hornet to Elevator Slim. Anything in sight? Over. Elevator Slim to Green Hornet. Nothing. Nothing. Over.

title: Living in a Curious Time ... And in Long Island City
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Rutgers; 800 at Camp Learn the ABC's Of Rah, Rah, Rah
description: Stunts, sideline chants and, of course, cheers are the crowd-control tools of cheerleaders at America's college campuses. And last week more than 800 from 59 schools got together at the Kilmer campus of Rutgers University to hone their skills.

title: Stavro Skendi, 82, a Professor at Columbia
description: Stavro Skendi, professor emeritus of Balkan languages and cultures at Columbia University, died of Parkinson's disease Thursday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Body and Mind; When Baby Has a Fever
description: I'VE BEEN ON THE TELEPHONE now for two hours, trying to track down a 1-year-old boy with a positive blood culture. He came to the emergency room two days ago with a fever of 103.4. The doctor diagnosed an ear infection but, before sending the child home with a prescription for amoxicillin, he drew a blood sample and sent it to the laboratory. Now, with the aid of a telephone operator enlisted in this medical emergency, I finally reach the mother at work. ''Bring the boy back in today, please,'' I say. ''We need to check his blood again.'' She does. But now he has no fever. He wants only to run back and forth at high speed in the hallway, making a noise like a fire engine. So why has all the fuss been made over a simple ear infection? Because of the fever. Meanwhile, another baby has been brought into the emergency room, and I glance at the nurse's clipboard - at the age of the child, 3 weeks, and the vital signs: the temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate and blood pressure. I call Admitting and book a bed even before examining the baby. Why? Because of the fever. Children seem to get fevers from almost anything (execpt, contrary to common belief, teething): from colds, sore throats -and yes, ear infections. Fevers can spike high, as we say, in these very young, very hot tots. A 2-year-old with an ear infection and a temperature as high as 104? Happens all the time. But you rarely see a 12-year-old with a temperature that high. As a consequence, I often find myself reassuring parents of infants: no, the fever itself won't do him any harm, his brain won't melt (this was my own private anxiety when my own son was going through the ear-infection stage), give him Tylenol every four hours and sit him in a lukewarm bath.

title: As Season Ends, Free Events Call
description: SOME of the last musical events of the summer season take place this week and next, and many are free.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Swimming Another Record for Barrowman: An American, Mike Barrowman, broke the world record for the 200-meter breaststroke during today's qualifying heats at the Pan Pacific championships in Tokyo. Barrowman, 20 years old, was clocked in 2 minutes 12.89 seconds in his heat at the Yoyogi National Swimming Pool on the final day of the championships. Barrowman set the world record of 2:12.90 on July 3 at the United States national championships. It was the first world record so far in the Pan Pacific meet, which began Thursday. Nick Gillingham of Britain last week equaled Barrowman's world mark of 2:12.90 in the European championship. Yesterday, Janet Evans extended her streak to 21 victories by winning the 400-meter freestyle for her third gold medal at the Pan Pacific championships in Tokyo. Evans was timed in 4 minutes 4.53 seconds, shattering her meet record of 4:09.32, set in 1987. She holds the world record of 4:03.85. Doug Gjersten of the United States won his third gold medal, swimming on the 400-meter freestyle relay team with Brent Lang, Jon Olsen and Tom Jageralso. The Americans won in 3:17.75. (AP) East German Women Win: East Germany swept all three women's races at the European championships in Bonn yesterday and Martin Lopez-Zubero of Spain scored a thrilling victory in the men's 100-meter backstroke. The Olympic champion Daniela Hunger of East Germany won the 200-meter individual medley in 2 minutes 13.26 seconds. Her teammates Anke Moehring and Astrid Strauss placed one-two in the 800 freestyle. And the East Germans won the women's 400-meter medley relay in 4:07.40, the best time this year. But the biggest surprise was the dramatic photo-finish victory by Lopez-Zubero. Ranked 88th in the world, Lopez-Zubero caught Sergey Zabolotnov of the Soviet Union, Dirk Richter of East Germany and Frank Hoffmeister of West Germany at 50 meters and charged to the finish in 56.44, a hundredth of a second ahead of Zabolotnov.(AP) Diving Titleholders Triumph: Wendy Wyland and Matt Scoggin successfully defended their United States 10-meter platform titles yesterday at the United States outdoor championships in Raleigh, N.C., with both events decided on the final dive. Wyland, of Boca Raton, Fla., outscored Courtney Nelson of Concord, Calif., by 0.18 points to earn her seventh United States platform title. The score was 412.68 to 412.50. Wendy Lian Williams, the 1989 World Cup champion from Bridgeton, Mo., was third with 387.39. Diagnosed with viral meningitis and hospitalized one month ago, Wyland had trained for only two and a half weeks before the championships. Scoggin, of Great Falls, Va., held off Scott Donie of Houston, who led by 1 point going into the final round, to win his third United States platform championship. The score was 612.45 to 605.70. Patrick Jeffrey of Madison, N.J., a 1988 Olympian, was third with 537.12.(AP) Cycling 2d Gold Medal for Longo: Jeannie Longo of France and Claudio Golinelli of Italy each won a second gold medal yesterday at the world championships in Lyon, France. Longo won the women's 30-kilometer points race after Golinelli took the men's professional keirin title. The keirin is a high-speed event with the cyclists vying for position behind a motorized pacer. Then, with 1 1/2 laps to go, the pacer goes off the track and it's a race to the finish for the final 500 meters. Golinelli previously won the professional sprint. Longo, winner of the individual pursuit title Friday, has won seven world championships since 1985. Marathon Swimming Australian Wins Again: Yesterday, as expected, Shelley Taylor Smith of Australia won her third consecutive Manhattan Island Marathon Swim, circling the island in 7 hours 32 minutes. Smith, a 28-year-old high school teacher from Perth, battled rain and cold as she won the event for the fourth time in five attempts. In 1985 she set a course record by swimming the 28.5 miles in 6 hours 12 minutes. Unlike in recent years, the eighth annual marathon was fairly close. The top five swimmers all arrived at the Battery Park finish line within 30 minutes of each other. James Barber, a 29-year-old marketing agent from Indianapolis and a fourth-place finisher last year, was second. He was followed closely by David Strasburg of Sterling, Ill., and Susie Maroney, a 14-year-old from Australia who won the United States nationals earlier this month. Karen Farnsworth, a lawyer from New York City, placed fifth. Golf Geiberger Leads by 2: Al Geiberger shot his second successive 68 yesterday to take a two-stroke lead over Mike and Dave Hill in the G.T.E. Northwest Classic in Seattle. Geiberger's total of 136 is eight under par for 36 holes on the 6,501-yard Inglewood Country Club course. Mike Hill had a 66, matching the lowest round of the day. His older brother, Dave, had a 70. Bob Erickson also shot a 66 and was tied at 139 with Frank Beard and the first-round leader, Miller Barber. Beard shot a 70, but Barber slipped to a 74. (AP) Eagle Sends Norman to Finals: Greg Norman scored an eagle on the 17th hole yesterday to advance to the finals of the International, the PGA Tour tournament in Castle Rock, Colo. A field of 72 was reduced to the 24 who will compete today. No scores are carried over. All players start at zero under the modified Stableford scoring system, in which an eagle is worth 5 points, a birdie scores 2, bogeys cost 1 point and double-bogeys and higher cost 3 points. Pars are worth nothing. It took 6 points yesterday to make the final round. Jack Nicklaus made it to the finals for the first time, on the strength of a 4-foot putt on the final hole of the Castle Rock Golf Club course, which he designed. He finished with 7 points. Norman was at 6 points through 16 holes, then hit a 6-iron second shot eight feet from the cup and made the putt for eagle-3 on the 17th. He ended with 11 points, as did Chip Beck and Ben Crenshaw. Ted Schulz led the field with 14 points.(AP) Harness Racing Victory for Mack Lobell: Mack Lobell, driven by Veijo Heuskanen of Finland in place of the dismissed John Campbell, successfully defended his title in the $100,000 Challenge Cup last night at Yonkers Raceway. Mack Lobell was coming off a third place finish in last Saturday's International Trot at Yonkers. Two days after that race, owner Jan-Erik Magnusson dismissed Campbell, Mack Lobell's regular driver until the 5-year-old was sold to Magnusson by Lou Guida and moved to Sweden. Mack Lobell covered the mile and a quarter last night in 2:34 4/5, equalling his own track record set last year at the International. Heiskanen, leaving from the rail, drove Mack Lobell to a near-perfect performance. In the stretch, Mack Lobell pulled away from the six-horse field to win by three and three-quarters lengths over Indus of Denmark, with Hans Svensson, who went on the outside to run down Senic Regal. Mack Lobell won $50,000, boosting his lifetime earnings to $2,668,318. He has 47 victories in 64 starts. As the 2-5 favorite, Mack Lobell paid $2.80, $2.10 and $2.10 for $2 across the board.(AP)

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Steinbrenner Sell the Yankees
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: At Least 45 Die in Sri Lanka As Political Violence Flares
description: At least 45 people were killed in Sri Lanka in the 24-hour period ending this morning, officials said. The attacks marked some of the worst political violence this island nation has seen.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE: Finger Lakes
description: Nature, culture and creature comforts bump elbows in the Finger Lakes, which rake the rolling countryside between Rochester and Syracuse. Cayuga Lake, at 38.1 miles, is the longest of the 11 lakes created when glaciers gouged the land eons ago. Named for the Iroquois tribe that inhabited its shores, Cayuga embodies the region's diverse charms.

title: Back to Beauty Basics
description: IT IS THE FASHION equivalent of cleaning house. Women are tossing out the clutter, stripping away the superfluous and streamlining their beauty and fashion collections to the lean, spare essentials. Take many of the new handbags. Not only have they shrunk from Samsonite-luggage size to mere specks on a chain, they can't possibly carry the usual gear: a powder compact, blusher brush, comb, four lipsticks, mirror, wallet, appointment book, newspaper, paperback and gym clothes. Something has had to go. And many women are ready to part with a few pounds.

title: Huge Azerbaijani Rally Asks Moscow to Free Prisoners
description: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Azerbaijan today to demand that the Communist authorities free jailed members of an independent group and accept its political demands.

title: Woman Struck by Stray Bullet on 31st Floor
description: A woman who was hit in the arm by a stray bullet while dining in a 31st-floor apartment says she is uneasy that the police have no clue to where the shot came from.

title: EASTERN GODS DANCE GAMELY IN THE WEST
description: When the world is too much with us, there is a lot to be said for getting off the street and into a museum where we can move on the instant into another time, another place and another culture. That was always one of the functions of a museum, and although it is now sometimes contested as wrongheaded, patronizing and imperialistic it still seems to have its untroubled adherents.

title: A COURAGE BORN OF BROKEN PROMISES
description: Michael Blumenthal perpetuates the image of women as victims. His article presupposes that men are the ones who terminate marriage and that life is a hopeless void without a man. Might not single mothers find satisfaction in their own intellectual and athletic pursuits, in friendships and, most plainly, in themselves? Or would Mr. Blumenthal prefer to keep that kind of satisfaction, which men have enjoyed for thousands of years, as a uniquely male experience? CHRISTINE M. EISEMANN Uniondale, L.I.

title: Gathering Hand-Painted Rosebuds
description: A refreshing retreat during these dog days of August is the Gottesman Exhibition Hall of the New York Public Library. For an exhibition of botanical prints, its venerable marble and carved-wood expanse has been transformed into a virtual garden, complete with trellises and gazebo. ''Nature's Mirror,'' which runs through Sept. 2, combines original drawings and watercolors, prints and printed books from the last 200 years.

title:
DINING OUT;
Continental Fare With Italian Influence
description: LEAD: FIFTEEN months ago, Perretti's in Carlstadt, about four blocks from the Meadowlands racetrack, was bought by a corporation called Peers V. The name was changed to Pratos - Italian for meadows - and the menu and most of the staff have also changed.

title: Interest in Reducing Accents Grows
description: IT was like the scene from ''My Fair Lady'' in which Henry Higgins drilled Eliza Doolittle on proper diction. ''Won't, quote, smoldered,'' Gloria Ashby said slowly and purposefully over and over as Meryl W. Aronin, a speech and language pathologist, sat across from her listening to each and every letter.

title: Trained in the Bottom Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Playwright Gets Her Act Together
description: LEAD: SIX years after she won the Pulitizer Prize for drama with '' 'night, Mother,'' Marsha Norman says she has stopped ''complaining about my parents'' and started dealing with ''the world I made with my own hands.''

title: Stylish Fare in the Hamptons
description: RESTAURANT roulette in the Hamptons continues. The two-room storefront on Main Street in Bridgehampton that housed Mel's last summer is Karen Lee's this season.

title: Profiting From Puts and Calls
description: FOR several weeks, the California Technology Stock Letter has been recommending an unusual way to profit on the stock of the 3Com Corporation, a computer networking company.

title: Lendl and McEnroe to Square Off
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe reached the final of the $900,000 Player's International Canadian open with three-set victories today.

title: Delicate Silk Lingerie From Hong Kong
description: BEFORE the Great Revolution, the Cultural Revolution and the Beijing Spring of 1989, Shanghai was China's most Westernized city, supplying foreigners and Chinese alike with the finest in handmade clothing. Somber-hued pajamas and gray serge Mao jackets were not enough to keep Shanghai's custom tailors in business during the succeeding decades, and a number emigrated to Hong Kong, where many of the best tailors are Shanghainese. But Shanghai has managed to hold onto its market for silk underwear, hand-embroidered silk blouses and bed and table linens, presumably in part because they are highly transportable and do not depend on multiple custom fittings for perfection. And according to the Hong Kong Tourist Association, Hong Kong department stores expect to be able to continue to stock silk underwear from China.

title: Judge Curbs Yacht Inspections
description: The owners of five yachts that are leased for party cruises around Manhattan have obtained a preliminary injunction to prevent the Coast Guard from boarding the vessels for routine mid-voyage inspections to check safety features or documents.

title: Coming Out of Shadows, Torture Victims Are Finding Help
