description: LEAD: INCREASINGLY, New Jersey is becoming a haven for political refugees, among them those who have been tortured by their governments.

title: When Setting a Table Takes On a Message
description: LEAD: LYNN CHASE, an artist and businesswoman, sets both an agenda and a beautiful table with the chinaware she designs and sells through her company, Chase Ltd., based in Ridgefield.

title: Namibian Legal-Aid Center Fighting for Survival
description: This territory's only legal-aid center, which gained renown for its dogged monitoring of civil rights in the territory, has been threatened with closing by the South African administration.

title: Cultivating Future Workers
description: IN May, more than 200 executives from New Jersey's leading companies convened in Princeton to form a coalition called ''Invest in Children.'' Their mission: to decide how best to use their financial and political clout to improve the health and education of the state's youth.

title: FIGHTING HIS WAY TO THE TOP
description: I ALWAYS LIKEN MY CAREER TO THAT SCENE IN 'ON the Waterfront,' '' says James Woods, an actor who doesn't sound or look anything like a young Marlon Brando. Gaunt, tense, chain-smoking Marlboros and peering at his food through heavy black-framed glasses, he could be Sean Penn's smarter, older brother. ''You know the scene,'' he says. ''Terry Malloy has testified against the longshore Mafia, and the pressure is on to put on a good face and make sure everybody has a job. The guy walks out of the ship and says, 'Everybody works today.' And everybody walks into the ship except Malloy. They even try to give his job to a bum - anyone but him.''

title: When Women Got the Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Agency Sees a Turn Toward Acceptance
description: IN the early 1970's, Logan Lewis, a young man from the Bronx, had just started rehabilitating drug addicts on the Island, but he often encountered a problem: Communities told him that, although his work was worthwhile, they did not want addicts as neighbors.

title: Life in Suburbia, as Artists Dream of It
description: Ideally, suburbia is a place that has the benefits of both rural and city living but none of their drawbacks. Books taking issue with that run from the socially scientific to the comic, and there are many of them. But even more abundant is art about the subject, which invariably takes the form of caricature, be it an affectionately witty cartoon in The New Yorker or a cruel photograph by Diane Arbus.

title: Maine Finds Promise in Fish Wastes
description: Fish processing companies and researchers in Maine have developed techniques to turn fish wastes that have been a malodorous disposal problem into compost, animal feed and a biological pesticide.

title: An Intrepid Opera House Ripe for Bigger Things
description: Seattle has steep hills like San Francisco, a peninsular shape like Manhattan and major summertime opera like Santa Fe, but it is a city not likely to be confused with anyplace else in America. In no other major city does one find a concern for the fine arts existing so comfortably and un-self-consciously alongside vestiges of the Old West. Within a few steps of one another on the main midtown streets can be found multifloored, exhaustively stocked, thickly peopled bookstores and equally impressive emporiums where guns of every size and caliber vie for the custom of deadly weapon connoisseurs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Prospects column last week, about the impact of the savings and loan bailout plan on interest rates, misstated Ralph Nader's assessment of the plan. Speaking about one effect of the bailout, he said: ''Nonprofit groups will get the first crack at taking over the residential property of the Resolution Trust Corporation.''

title: The Writer's Meditative Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article in The Times Magazine on June 11 about Louisiana's economic, environmental and racial problems referred incorrectly to lung cancer rates. A recent letter from the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals points out that in 1986, according to the latest figures from the Centers for Disease Control, the state ranked fifth, not first, in lung cancer deaths. It is New Orleans that has the highest rate among black males, and the rate refers to incidence, not mortality.

title: Going for Broke in Lebanon's Proxy War
description: AS chaotic as Lebanon may have seemed to outsiders in the past 14 years, the civil war there actually followed certain unwritten rules. What is new about the violence today is that those long-established rules are being shredded. The political and military boundaries that no one had dared breach - call them ''red lines'' - have now been crossed, and the combatants are entering a new game whose rules are as undefined as its outcome.

title: New York City's Housing Pace Slows
description: AFTER a three-year construction surge in many of Manhattan's most expensive neighborhoods, the pace of residential development in New York City has slowed. Its focus, moreover, is shifting to lower-cost housing, most of it in the other boroughs and much of it dependent on government support.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Looks Inspired By the Classics
description: In some beach towns, the summer uniform consists of a bathing suit, flip-flops and a T-shirt with a suntan lotion logo or ''Greetings From . . . '' on the front.

title: Apartheid Protest at 2 Beaches
description: The South African police dispersed hundreds of blacks during protests today at two whites-only beaches.

title: Santa's Off-Season Home
description: EVERY parent who has ever been detoured by a whining child into a Story Book Village, a Frontier Land or a Dinosaur World, can blame it on one man: Julian Reiss, creator of Santa's Workshop. Built in 1949, when Disneyland was but a gleam in Uncle Walt's eye, Santa's Workshop bills itself as the first theme park in the United States, and within a few years it was siphoning 12,000 people a day off the Adirondack roadways through its gingerbread portico. The park - at the foot of Whiteface Mountain, 11 miles north of Lake Placid - is a small, Alpine-style village with a huge parking lot, a footnote in the history of family entertainment. And Santa and his elves are still frolicking, albeit to smaller audiences, in a summery Yuletide celebration.

title: Common Complaints, Spoken in 26 Tongues
description: In the far northern reaches of Manhattan lies a territory where the steep hills and deep valleys have not been flattened by bulldozers, where streams of immigrants have mixed without melding and where everyone is a Westsider because a river runs just east of Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on July 30 with an article about a camp for the blind misidentified a counselor. She is Tanya Chin.

title: Picnic Becomes Chance for 200 to Flee West
description: More than 200 East Germans used a symbolic picnic on the Austrian-Hungarian border today as a cover to flee to the West.

title: In Beleaguered Sri Lanka, Fear Is Taking Hold
description: A weeklong strike by medical workers has virtually emptied the main hospital here and others elsewhere in the country and led to the deaths of several people who could not get adequate medical care. It is a grim reflection of the growing power of an anti-Government force and the seeming helplessness of President Ranasinghe Premadasa's Administration in confronting it.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Richard C. Sheldon, Executive, 70
description: Richard C. Sheldon, a retired Ford Foundation executive, drowned in a boating accident Wednesday off Mount Desert Island, Me. He was 70 years old.

title: Despite a Hendrix, One Woodstock Fizzles
description: The sanctioned Woodstock commemorative concert, the one with the permits, the Port-o-Sans and the liability insurance, fizzled. But a spontaneous gathering at the hayfield that was the site of the Woodstock Arts and Music Fair 20 years ago here attracted thousands of people, who came with tepees, tents, blankets and sleeping bags.

title: Game Remains Young In the Over-30 League
description: LEAD: IT was 9 A.M. Sunday. The game would not start until 10, but the Ramapo Royals had already been warming up for close to an hour. With a doubleheader scheduled - up to six hours of baseball - the 13-man roster was playing healthy for the first time in many games, after suffering early-season tendinitis and torn muscles.

title: Marcos Holdings Shedding Web of Intrigue
description: AFTER more than three years of turmoil, the real estate empire of Ferdinand Marcos, the ousted Philippine President, and his wife, Imelda, appears to be emerging from a web of international intrigue and competing claims by Federal prosecutors, a foreign government, local developers and an international arms dealer.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
To Improve Environmental Protection, Reorganize
description: LEAD: WHO will protect our environment if not our government? This year's election of a new governor of New Jersey is an important one. The new governor must be committed to maintain the quality of our environment as well as improve it, and this responsibility must not be for a four-year impact for re-election, but a long-term commitment.

title: Public Schools On Corporate Campuses
description: Every Saturday morning for 10 weeks during the fall and spring, 60 seventh graders in Washington assemble for four hours to participate in the Saturday Academy. Designed for bright students who nevertheless have a potential for dropping out, the program aims to keep them in school by building their self-esteem and skills through individualized instruction and reinforcement by the adults in their lives, who are required to accompany students to at least 6 of the 10 sessions.

title:
ART;
Reality and Illusion, Those Old Antagonists
description: LEAD: ''REAL AND REPRESENTED,'' the summer exhibition at the Jersey City Museum, is prosaically subtitled ''Selected From the Slide Registry.'' This signals that the exhibition is something of a tour de force.

title: NINE MONTHS THAT SHOOK THE WORLD
description: CHRISTOPHER UNBORN By Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam and the author. 531 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: Newest Oriole
description: When it comes to negotiating a major league contract, a rookie's best friend could be a competing offer from a phantom rival league. That appeared to be the case yesterday after the Baltimore Orioles finally signed Ben McDonald, the Louisiana State University pitching sensation who was the No. 1 selection in the June draft.

title: What to Expect in the Brave New World of Credit Card Phoning
description: To the Editor:

title: HE WAS THEIR LAST RESORT
description: PUBLIC JUSTICE, PRIVATE MERCY A Governor's Education on Death Row. By Edmund G. (Pat) Brown with Dick Adler. 171 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Knicks' Pick Signs
description: There aren't many experimental psychologists who can nail down a $110,000-a-year job before finishing graduate school, but then there aren't many such scholars who can hit the 3-point shot from the pro distance.

title: Why Not Wear Black?
description: BLACK WAS THE ONE color I was never allowed to wear as a child. ''You look peaked enough,'' my mother would tell me, or worse, ''pea green,'' another phrase she used to describe my sallow complexion. How vividly I remember the ballroom of Delmonico's Hotel in New York, where I went to dancing school. While other girls fox-trotted or waltzed in black velvet party dresses that showed off their blond manes, I felt out of step, always clad in red or pink. Not only did my mother believe that little girls should not wear black, but she thought that reds and pinks gave me color. They were the right shades to complement my brunet bob. Back then, I never could have imagined that 20 years later my closet would be full of black.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: LYNDHURST;
Learning History From the Ground Up
description: LEAD: BRAD POLLOCK, the foreman, worries about the members of his ground crew. Do they appreciate the historic significance of the property they're working on? What about the esthetic value? And will they learn the right way to compile a resume?

title: Linda Sherman Is Wed
description: Linda Jill Sherman and Brian Keith Bernstein were married last evening at the Rainbow Pegasus Suite at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York by Rabbi Dennis Math. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul S. Sherman of Ventnor, N.J., graduated from Syracuse University and received an M.A. degree in journalism from Northwestern University. She is an associate producer at Hal Riney & Partners, a New York advertising agency. Mr. Bernstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Bernstein of Kew Gardens, Queens, graduated magna cum laude from Hunter College, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a law degree from Yeshiva University. He is a partner in the New York law firm of Horwitz, Toback & Hyman.

title: Did the War on Poverty Fail?
description: Twenty-five years ago today, several hundred Government officials and community leaders faced Lyndon B. Johnson as he signed into law the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964, launching the ''war on poverty.'' Today, it is painfully clear that the war has not been won.

title: A Life-Saving AIDS Strategy
description: The drug AZT, already used to treat people with overt symptoms of AIDS, has now also proved effective in delaying the onset of those symptoms. To exploit this clear advance requires a major shift in public policy toward AIDS: more testing, and more financial help for the many who now stand to benefit from the expensive treatment.

title: Question Of the Week; Do Colleges Spend Too Much on Athletics?
description: Of course. But a more pertinent question would be: since everyone else is making megabucks off big-time college sports, isn't it about time that college athletes enjoyed a slice of the economic pie? NICHOLAS D. DeCURTIS New York

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE NAKED HEART. By Jacqueline Briskin. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Jacqueline Briskin's ninth novel may never become part of the literary canon, but it's sure to adorn many a night table. A standard tale whose characters have all the complexity of cartoon figures, ''The Naked Heart'' is nonetheless powered by a strong plot.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Recycling Is An Old Idea
description: LEAD: THE word recycling has a modern sound to it. It's a plan to act. It is something we have to think about, consider, remember, then do. But long before there was the word ''recycling'' or that modern symbol of arrows forming a circle on the sides of our aluminum cans, before there even were aluminum cans - there was recycling.

title: A GREETING FROM THE GOVERNMENT
description: Louis Jay Herman's letter (July 23) in response to William Safire's On Language column ''The Mulvihill Perplexity'' (June 25) is fine, except for one thing. Our draft notifications read Greeting, not Greetings.

title: Clash of Views On Jets' Top Pick
description: As negotiations with the Jets' No. 1 one draft pick, Jeff Lageman, bog down, an interesting pattern has emerged between the men who represent opposite sides in the talks.

title: Where Rural Ohio Shows Off
description: EVERY summer, with sheep firmly grasped by the throat, in groups of 10 or so, classed by age or category (such as yearling ewe or grand champion ram), anxious youths line up before the judge in the middle of the large red show barn at the Medina County Fair in Medina, Ohio. Hours before, back in the stables, the animals were carefully cleaned, clipped and groomed. Nothing, however, can keep them still - a few even wriggle loose from their captors and dash for the door - or quiet. Their insistent braying echoes through the cavernous barn. On the second day of the fair this year, held from July 30 to Aug. 6, Bonnie Farren, a self-described fourth-generation farmer's wife, is intent on the sheep judging - both to keep score of the winnings captured by the Chatham Farmers, her community's 4-H group, and to keep a close eye on the progress of her two sons and their farm's two prize ewes.

title: Robin Truesdell Wed in Colorado
description: The marriage of Robin Suzanne Truesdell, a daughter of Carolyn G. Truesdell of Houston and Leonard C. Truesdell Jr. of Carbondale, Colo., to Jeffrey Edward Sher, a son of Rabbi Arnold I. Sher of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Judith B. Sher, took place last evening at the Castle in Redstone, Colo. Rabbi Stanley Brav, the bridegroom's maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony.

title: Four New Series Elect to Go to Washington
description: The city of Washington, the capital of not only the nation but of the nation's murder rate, has become a subject of fascination for many of the people who tell stories in prime time.

title: Nocturne in St.-Tropez
description: ARRIVING in St.-Tropez in the late afternoon - my Pan Am flight was six hours late - I had to do something to fill up the time until the clubs opened. So I dropped into the bar of the Byblos Hotel and spent several hours trying to decide whether to jump off the balcony. Diving off this balcony into the Byblos pool is one of St.-Tropez's sacred rituals. I walked out on the balcony and looked down at the water a dozen feet below. It looked like a pool of mouthwash.

title: A Way to Force Noriega Out
description: The crisis in Panama seems to have come to a deadlock. Only a completely different approach will enable the U.S. to find a way to accomplish its goals of dispatching the strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and creating a democratic government without interfering in Panama's internal affairs.

title:
Mens's Style;
THE LURE OF IT ALL
description: LEAD: They've been known to crawl belly down toward a creek bank when stalking their prey, a fish with good eyes, skittish ways and a taste for fancy-looking flies. If the approach is the first thing a serious trout angler considers, clothing might well be the second. Traditionalists, anxious to blend in with their surroundings, dress to match the muted browns and greens of the river bottom.

title: Treasury's Depreciation Finding: Old Tuxedos Don't Wear
description: The Treasury Department's depreciation analysis division has issued what may be the first Federal tuxedo report.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Roger Zelazny is not comfortable with rigid categories. He writes about science as if it were magic and magic as if it were science. His characters are conversant with Chaucer and Nietzsche and thermodynamics and Hart Crane and molecular biology. His eclectic enthusiasms add sparkle to his new collection of stories, FROST AND FIRE (Morrow, $16.95). My reservations have to do with what is going on beneath the surface.

title: John Wooden: Basketball Is Fouling Out
description: Recently, the Big East Conference voted to increase the number of fouls allowed players from five to six, the number allowed in the National Basketball Association.

title: Stevenson and the Missile Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridal Is Planned By Miss Treacy
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Treacy Jr. of Scarsdale, N.U., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Marie Treacy to Kevin Francis Driscoll, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Driscoll of Westlake, Ohio. A September wedding is planned.

title: Ellen Speer and Gary Davis to Marry
description: September wedding plans for Ellen Beth Speer and Gary Davis have been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Speer of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Mr. Davis is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Davis of Montreal.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are planning to install a new kitchen floor of vinyl tiles. The existing floor is vinyl tile that still is well secured and has a smooth surface. But one corner of a tile near the refrigerator has lifted slightly, and the dealer says that the old flooring must be ripped up and new plywood put down before the new tiles can be laid. However, a flooring contractor says that he can install the new tiles over the existing floor. Who is correct?

title: An October Bridal For Susan Gilbert
description: Dr. and Mrs. George J. Gilbert Jr., of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Dataw Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Gilbert to Stuart Simmons Lovejoy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lovejoy of Sewickley, Pa. An October wedding is planned.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The wide receiver Hart Lee Dykes, the first-round draft choice of the New England Patriots out of Oklahoma State, agreed to a four-year contract with the team yesterday. Terms were not immediately announced. . . . Eric Metcalf, the running back from Texas who was the Cleveland Browns' No. 1 draft pick, said he would sign today. . . . The former University of Kentucky swingman Eric Manuel, barred from N.C.A.A. play as part of the penalties levied against the Wildcat basketball program this year, has enrolled at Hiwassee College in Madisonville, Tenn., and plans to transfer next year to an N.A.I.A. school for his final two years of eligibility, said Don Richardson, Manuel's former high school coach in Macon, Ga.

title: Professor Tries to Stir Interest in the Humanities
description: EDUCATORS have forgotten the history of the humanities, according to a Connecticut College professor, who says that a liberal arts education in America is not what it should be - a quest for wisdom and virtue.

title: A BRONX MAN DIES AFTER POLICE FIGHT
description: A Bronx man who told ambulance attendants that he had been using cocaine died early yesterday, shortly after four police officers who were trying to place him into an ambulance pushed him to the ground and handcuffed him, the police said.

title: 3 Top-Ranked Players Set for Hamlet Tennis
description: LEAD: WHILE organizers of the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup look forward to this week's tournament at the Hamlet East in Jericho, they are also looking ahead to next year, when changes in format and a new location will turn the tennis event into a whole new ballgame.

title: Major Accord Likely on Indian Remains
description: The Smithsonian Institution has reached a tentative agreement with American Indian leaders that is likely to lead to the return of the skeletal remains and burial artifacts of hundreds of Indians to their modern tribal descendants.

title: Why China's Students Aren't Ready for the Masses
description: CHINA is glorifying manual labor again, this time as a way to deal with troublesome young intellectuals. Last weekend, the Government announced that college graduates who want to enter graduate school - useful for getting good jobs and especially for arranging an opportunity to study abroad -should work first for one or two years. A separate and so far unpublished requirement will oblige those who have graduated from college since 1985 to work at the ''grass roots,'' typically at a factory or farm, for a year before taking white-collar jobs in the city, say Chinese with access to official information.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES POLL
description: A WOMAN'S PLACE: VIEWS OF TWO GENERATIONS

title: A Foundation in the Corporate Arena
description: ''IN 1872 we were the first company to produce high-performance microscopes in large numbers and our binoculars went with Amundsen to the South Pole,'' said Dr. Dieter Blennemann, president of Carl Zeiss Inc., whose headquarters are here.

title: Summers of Wonder in Early Childhood
description: TO a child, a summer is longer than a year. For David, my 2-year-old son, this is his first boyhood summer. Innocence and wonder surround everything he does.

title: First, Admit Past Policies Are Bankrupt
description: The United States may have to rethink its relationship with Japan in the wake of that country's recent political upheavals. Two separate scandals have brought down two Prime Ministers since the start of the year. As a result, Japan now has a new Government and the Liberal Democratic Party is seriously weakened. On Aug. 9, Japan's new Prime Minister, Toskiki Kaifu, took office. Although many expect business as usual between the two countries, Clyde Prestowitz, a former Commerce Department official and now a fellow at the Carnegie Foundation, says it is time to act. In an interview with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, Mr. Prestowitz said the United States must now develop a new policy toward Japan. Question: Where does the responsibility for setting a new policy lie? Mr. Prestowitz: I think it lies with the President. We have an incredible superstructure for dealing with the Soviet Union. We have policy planning; there are centers for naval analysis; there is the Rand Corporation, and the Aerospace Corporation - a huge superstructure of official Government and quasi-official centers for dealing strategically with the Soviets. But there is virtually no one in the Government who is thinking about how to deal with Japan outside of the Commerce Department.

title: Claire Townsend Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Claire Trumbull Townsend to Edward Victor Bacher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Bacher of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mrs. Harold P. Salembier of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Charles C. Townsend of Germantown, N.Y. An Octorber wedding is planned.

title: A Line Missing In Their Resumes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tourism Officials Report a Statewide Slump
description: LEAD: FROM the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium to the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, the tourism industry in the state is in a slump, say tourism officials, who attribute the decline to the economy.

title: Ex-Smokers Don't All Overdose on Caffeine; Standardize Warnings
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SOUTHLAKE, TEX.;
Village Center For I.B.M. Staff
description: LEAD: AS its first phase nears completion, I.B.M. and Maguire Thomas Partners' 900-acre office development in the tiny southeast Tarrant County towns of Southlake and Westlake - their combined population is about 6,400 - is slowly coming to life.

title: 14 Rockets Hit Kabul
description: Fourteen rockets slammed into Kabul today, and hospital officials said at least 18 people were wounded. Kabul has been hit almost daily by rocket attacks since late June, and Islamic guerrillas have claimed responsibility for some of the attacks.

title: Corruption Is Charged in Chicago Sheriff's Office
description: The sheriff of Cook County pressed for the dismissal of two of his officers today as a newspaper reported allegations that the department had suppressed investigations of murders and internal corruption for years.

title: Hospice Care at Home: Another View
description: Senator C. Louis Bassano probably never had to care for a terminally ill patient (''Helping With Hospice Benefits,'' Opinion page, July 23). He probably never had to worry about soiled beds, adult diapers or the unreasonable demands of those who are about to die. I'm sure he never emptied a commode or a bedpan, or worried about how to care for an elderly parent 24 hours a day and still have time for a job and a young family.

title: Colombia Crackdown Follows Murder Spree
description: Thousands in Colombia mourned a presidential candidate slain by drug traffickers, the latest in a series of assassinations. President Bush welcomed a move by Bogota to reinstate an extradition agreement. Article, page 14.

title: New Drug Study Heralds A Hopeful Realignment In the War Against AIDS
description: ANY lingering doubts that it makes sense for members of risk groups to be tested for the AIDS virus were dispelled last week when the Government reported that the drug AZT can prolong the lives of infected people who have not yet developed symptoms of the disease.

title: American Interns Are Glasnost's Gift To Journalism
description: When Dawn Smith graduated from New York University in May hoping to land a job in journalism, she decided that political ideology would not limit her employment prospects. So when one of her professors dangled before her the prospect of interning in the New York bureau of Tass, the Soviet press agency, she jumped at the chance.

title: Aaron B. Schwarz: Architect
description: Although accepting a commission from a bureaucracy as vast as the New York City Board of Education may seem like agreeing to run a marathon in heavy boots, Aaron B. Schwarz said he was delighted to lead a team of architects in designing three public elementary schools in the Bronx.

title: Text of Polish Statement
description: Following is the text of the statement issued today by the office of President Wojciech Jaruzelski nominating Tadeusz Mazowiecki for the post of Prime Minister. The text was provided in translation by the official Polish press agency.

title: POSTINGS: Next to Office Park; 84-Unit Condo in Norwalk
description: A fourth condominium project, named Glenrock, is rising next to the mammoth Merritt Seven Corporate Park office center along the Merritt Parkway in Norwalk, Conn. The 84-unit project of one- and two-bedroom condominiums in the Silvermine section of Norwalk is being built on three acres adjacent to the Metro North Merritt Seven station. The area is noted for the Silvermine Tavern and the Silvermine Guild Arts Center, which are a mile from Glenrock. The project also is one mile north of the center of Norwalk.

title: WHERE MEN ARE BOYS EVEN NOW
description: TEMPORARY SOJOURNER And Other South African Stories. By Tony Eprile. 222 pp. New York: Fireside/Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Courtenay Alexandra Sacco to Marry Dr. W. D. Adams, Resident in Surgery
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gregory E. Sacco Jr. of New York and Rumson, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Courtenay Alexandra Sacco, to Dr. William Dean Adams, a son of Dr. and Mrs. W. J. Adams of Washington.

title: DISGUISED ISRAELIS BLAMED IN SLAYING
description: Three Israelis posing as tourists in Bethlehem opened fire today on a group of Arabs who threw rocks at a nearby army jeep, killing one of the Arabs, Palestinian witnesses said.

title: Carol Greenberg Marries
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., Carol Greenberg and Robert Silverstein were married last evening by Rabbi Stanley Steinhart. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Greenberg of Manhasset Hills, L.I., is a nursing supervisor at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Mr. Silverstein is the vice president of Marketing East Industries Inc., a New York company that represents electronics manufacturers. He is a son of Myra Silverstein of New York and Edward Silverstein of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Fight's Stop 'Not Justified'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Work on it a little bit more, Dick. I want to refinance my home.'' Clayton K. Yeutter, Agriculture Secretary, to Richard G. Darman, the budget chief, who had accused the Fed of keeping interest rates unnecessarily high.

title: Pronouncing The Names
description: JOZEF CYRANKIEWICZ, a former Prime Minister: YOO-zeff tsee-rahn-KYEH-vitch.

title: CART Finds Fault With Pocono Oval
description: Pocono International Raceway, the site of the Quaker State 500 Indy-car race today (NBC-TV, 4-6 P.M. Eastern time), is considered a challenging track, for good reasons and bad.

title: A Hot Computer Technology Cools
description: ''THE Network is the Computer'' is a slogan Sun Microsystems Inc. has used to emphasize the ability of its computer work stations to link up and communicate with other computers. Several other companies, however, take that notion closer to heart. Their business is based on developing the connections themselves rather than the computers.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Two Years Later, Just One Guilty Plea
description: LEAD: A partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company agreed to plead guilty to one felony charge related to insider trading. In announcing the arrangement with Robert Freeman, one of the firm's top traders, the Government also said it was ending its investigation of two others, Richard B. Wigton and Timothy L. Tabor, who had been traders for Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Tolls or No, Traffic Gets Worse
description: THE rationale for tolls was simple when the first American turnpike opened in Virginia in 1785: it was an effective way for settlements to raise funds to build more roads, which helped transform struggling towns into bustling cities.

title: Correction
description: Because of a concert sponsor's change, a listing today in the Week in Connecticut column of the Connecticut Weekly misstates the site of a Hartford appearance by the Tannahill Weavers. The concert, at 7:30 P.M. today, will be at the Summit Hotel, not at Lloyd's Restaurant.

title: Voyager Cameras Discover a Turbulent Blue Neptune
description: As Voyager 2 closes in for the first fly-by of Neptune on Thursday night, its cameras are already giving scientists a clear view of the planet, a beautiful blue orb in dark space, and discovering it to be a surprisingly dynamic world of thick gases roiled by 400-mile-an-hour winds and a storm system the size of Mars.

title: Choice of Slopes in South America
description: IT'S no wonder, since the advent of Portillo as a premier ski resort in Chile, that North American skiers have looked longingly toward South America during the heat of the summer. The Andes mountain range, running in a long spine down the western edge of South America in Argentina and Chile, has high peaks that extend well above the tree line. Snow begins to fall in these mountains in June and extends into October.

title: From Young Veterans, Jazz as It Should Be
description: ''Excellence'' is a word that changes its definition as often as a culture decides to change the way it looks at art - which is fairly often. In jazz, in 1989, excellence is defined by precision, a playing out of classic ideas, and hard-driving swing. Two of the young veterans on the New York scene, the 32-year-old tenor saxophonist Ralph Moore (who has worked with Horace Silver, J. J. Johnson, Freddie Hubbard and more) and the 28-year-old drummer Marvin ''Smitty'' Smith (who's worked with Sonny Rollins, David Murray, and Art Farmer and Benny Golson, among others) have just released albums that sum up much of what's happening on the jazz scene among younger musicians.

title: No to Betting For Win or Lose
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cause of Thefts May Be Internal
description: Alan Fortunoff (''A Retailer Who Followed the Customers to the Suburbs,'' July 23), in discussing his store's theft problems, stated: ''We had large losses...caused by people with drug abuse problems.'' Q. ''What were the thefts like?'' A. ''Sophisticated. They took the time and trouble to understand our inventory control system and our internal accounting system and they developed a way to beat it.''

title: JARUZELSKI, MOVED BY 'NEEDS AND ASPIRATIONS' OF POLAND, NAMES WALESA AIDE PREMIER
description: The Communist President, Wojciech Jaruzelski, today designated a senior Solidarity official, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, to be the first non-Communist Prime Minister of Poland since the early postwar years.

title: Lebanon Muslims Warn Paris Against Intervention
description: As fighting continued in Beirut, Lebanese Muslim leaders warned France today of dire consequences if Paris interfered militarily in Lebanon.

title: Recession? Maybe Yes, Maybe No
description: SINCE the beginning of the year, there have been conflicting indicators about an approaching recession. When inflation rose above a 5 percent annual rate, suggesting that the economy was overheating, the Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates and banks followed suit. Interest rate-sensitive sectors of the economy like housing, autombiles and some retail sales, slowed and inventories began to accumulate.

title: Wendy Owens Becomes Bride Of Peter Gibian
description: Gwendolyn Jane Owens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gwinn Owens of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Peter Andrew Gibian, a son of George Gibian and J. Catherine Gibian, both of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. Beverly Edwards performed the ceremony at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Review/Opera; McKee (R.) In Title Role Of 'Mikado'
description: ''The Mikado'' was great fun Friday evening at the New York City Opera, thanks largely to the uncommonly attractive sets and costumes of Thierry Bosquet and to those members of the cast who know how to handle some of the best comic dialogue -really, some of the best dialogue of any shade - written in the English language.

title: Youths Discover Careers at Fresh Air 'Camp'
description: Most 13- and 14-year-old New Yorkers are not grappling with career questions this summer. They are consumed with more immediate concerns, like the route of the Mister Softee truck and the fate of the Mets.

title: Matisse's 'Backs': Endless Beauty
description: While the back wall of the Museum of Modern Art sculpture garden was being rebuilt last spring, Kirk Varnedoe, the museum's director of painting and sculpture, installed Matisse's ''Backs,'' the most familiar feature of that wall, indoors.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Neighbors Try to Derail Montclair Connection
description: LEAD: ONCE a grubby wedge of Montclair, the Bay Street neighborhood has made a comeback in the last 10 years. But now a tug-of-war has broken out over its future.

title: Frank J. DeFrancis Is Dead at 62; Lawyer and Horse-Racing Leader
description: Frank J. DeFrancis, a prominent Washington lawyer who became a Maryland government official and a giant in the state's horse-racing industry, died of heart failure Friday at the Miami Heart Institute in Florida. He was 62 years old and lived in Clarksville, Md.

title: DATA BANK: Aug. 20, 1989
Giants' Meggett Gets 2d Chance
description: Dave Meggett played college football at Morgan State and Towson State, which are not exactly powerhouses. He is 5 feet 7 inches, which is not exactly tall for an athlete other than a jockey or a flyweight boxer. He made his debut as a Giant last weekend by misplaying three punts, which is not exactly the way to win a job in the National Football League.

title: FICTION
description: STRANGER AT THE GATE. By Malcolm Bosse. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Indonesia in 1965 was a country in turmoil. On one side was the P.K.I., the third-largest Communist Party in the world; on the other, the country's Muslim majority and its army. Caught in the middle was the increasingly ill President Sukarno, who, in an attempt to maintain power and a semblance of order, was performing a delicate balancing act between opposing factions. Into this cauldron of escalating violence and political intrigue, Malcolm Bosse, the author of ''The Warlord,'' has tossed two Americans, Vern Gardner, a builder, and his anthropologist wife, Maggie. Vern has come to Indonesia to construct a hotel; Maggie is studying the culture. When things get too hot in riot-torn Jakarta, Maggie travels into the countryside. This separation, it turns out, is not the best prescription for a happy marriage. Away from the capital, Maggie begins to lose her identity as a Westerner, slowly donning the cloak of Javanese culture. She even falls in love with a respected dalang, an Indonesian puppet master and interpreter of the ancient Hindu religious classic, the Mahabharata. As one might imagine, this torrid affair doesn't go over well, either with the locals or with Vern. And here lies one of the major problems with ''Stranger at the Gate'': there simply aren't any surprises. Instead, Mr. Bosse, who has spent a good deal of time in Southeast Asia and has obviously studied his subject well, substitutes endless descriptive details. As a result, his characters become little more than puppets themselves. Eventually his tale, which lumbers along at an infuriatingly slow pace, sags under the sheer weight of its local color, proving that what works as a travelogue doesn't necessarily make for a successful novel.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Penn Station Service Building; A 1908 Structure Survives A 'Monumental Act of Vandalism'
description: THEY missed something and it is a rather big something. When the Pennsylvania Railroad demolished Penn Station in 1964, it was described by The New York Times ''a monumental act of vandalism.'' Many New Yorkers and architectural historians still regret the loss of the station, and aficionados search the lower depths of the present station for remnants of the old one - handrails, elevator doors, lighting fixtures and the like.

title: A COURAGE BORN OF BROKEN PROMISES
description: Almost all the single mothers I know have expressed the improbability of meeting a man who is as lovable, giving and generally delightful - in short, as nice to be around - as their children are. Thus, Mr. Blumenthal's arrogant pity for women, whom he describes as ''except for their children, alone,'' would be infuriating were it not so sadly conceived. SUSAN J. HALIO Brooklyn

title: About Men; Giving Up Guns
description: I VIVIDLY RECALL THE first time I held a gun. My father was a New York City cop. One day when I was 10, he returned from his annual trip to the firing range and let me and my brother watch him clean his .38 caliber Smith & Wesson revolver. Dad sat on the kitchen table as the biting odor of gunpowder and gun oil filled the room.

title: Underground Kentucky
description: ''VERY early in the last century,'' wrote the eloquent advocate for the national park system, Freeman Tilden, in 1951, ''Mammoth Cave was one of the things the traveler had to see. Foreign visitors went inevitably to Niagara Falls; there they were told not to fail to go to Kentucky and see 'the greatest cave that ever was.' Then they could go back to Europe or die.''

title: State Parks Are Campers' Summer Resorts
description: LEAD: AH, the joys of a summer place. A stroll along the beach or a walk in the woods. And after the surf and turf, maybe a wienie roast. For a lot of people, a state park campsite is a summer resort. Ten state parks in Connecticut have overnight camping but only two - Hammonasset State Park in Madison and Rocky Neck State Park about 15 miles east in East Lyme - offer campsites within walking distance of Long Island Sound beaches.

title: WOMEN DID WHAT THEY COULD
description: LEAD: BORN FOR LIBERTYA History of Women in America. By Sara M. Evans. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: Networking Without the Wires
description: PERHAPS the worst thing about computer networking is the actual physical wiring. Whether the computers are connected with coaxial cables, twisted pair cables, fiber-optic cables or jumper cables, the cabling itself is usually a logistical, physical and financial nightmare. Adding a computer to the network, or even just moving someone's desk, is a major ordeal.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: HAROLD A. ACKERMAN;
Seeking a Raise for Federal Judges
description: LEAD: HAROLD A. ACKERMAN is one of 21 Federal judges in New Jersey. In recent months, their judicial reserve has given way, in the words of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist of the United States Supreme Court, to a ''quiet crisis'' that has the making of a ''cataclysmic disaster'' for the Federal court system.

title: New Jersey Thinks Again About Its Hard Line on Trash
description: THE trash fire that buckled a portion of Interstate 78 in Newark earlier this month cast new attention on the problems of illegal dumping in New Jersey and may have hastened the collapse of the state's strict regulation of solid waste disposal.

title: STREET CHIC
description: The fashion avant-garde has gone back into the woods for a new, home-grown style based on the functional garments of hunters, fishermen and equestrians. As fashion moves into a new decade, its followers are finding that it is better to have their boots waterproofed, their pockets roomy and their collars deep enough to shields off winter blasts. Designers, however, have not dispensed with flattery in this return to rugged style. Using many of the classic hunter's clothes, they have lengthened jackets, reshaped waists, widened collars and recolored fabrics. But while the looks seem familiar, the wearer will appreciate the new elements, which retain the down-home honesty of the original. Shown are New Yorkers who discovered this realism last winter.

title: The Shuttle
description: To the Editor: Reading about Donald Trump's new airline colors and refurbishment (Travel Advisory, June 18), one could only conclude that the restroom ''burgundy porcelain sink, fake-marble vanities . . .'' were trompe l'oeil. HERBERT WISE New York, N.Y.

title: Design; PURE AND NOT SO SIMPLE
description: It was a dilemma that even purists have trouble grappling with: whether to faithfully preserve a historic house in need of repairs by restoring it so it looks just the way it originally did, or to take a more practical tack and renovate the building to make it work for a family living in the 20th century. ''Preservation was as important as renovation,'' says one of the owners of this Massachusetts house. ''Whenever possible, we preserved what was original.''

title: Poland's Break
description: The new order in Poland, and sharp changes in neighboring countries, suggest the start of a new order for all of Eastern Europe - the first real break with Moscow's orthodoxy in 40 years. The Week in Review, section 4.

title: When a Small Town Put Architecture to the Vote
description: As one walks along main Street in this 248-year-old town in the northwest corner of Connecticut, everything is almost as it was: the library, the Congregational church and the town hall. Sloping up gently behind the town hall is the Old Burying Ground, where since Memorial Day small American flags have marked the graves of Revolutionary and Civil War soldiers. Fragrant linden trees and a white board fence border this green hillside where the tombstones are askew with age. The Connecticut composer Charles Ives knew best how to capture in words and musical phrases the spirit of this symbolic New England scene, especially in the song ''The Things Our Fathers Loved,'' which includes Main Street, the village band and summer evenings.

title: Mary E. Bartlett Weds G. L. Petrini
description: The Congregational Church of the Pilgrimage in Plymouth, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Mary Eaton Bartlett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Bartlett of Boston and Plymouth, and Gregory Lee Petrini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary W. Petrini of Needham and Manomet, Mass. The Rev. Gary Marks performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. George T. O'Neil, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Jayne N. Millard Engaged to Marry Milton L. Clark Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Whittemore Millard of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Jayne Nesbitt Millard and Milton Lee Clark Jr., the son of Mr. Clark of San Antonio and Benja Leta Clark of Houston.

title: ADVICE MY BROTHER NEVER TOOK
description: There recently arrived in my mailbox a billet-doux from my little brother. More specifically, this was a five-page letter to him, from me, with his Post-it self-stick memo stuck to page 1. The letter was dated ''13/xi/63'' - a la European mode - and postmarked Cambridge, England, mailed to an 11th grader. Single-spaced elite, without margins, it was typed with such manifest urgency that words fly truncated off the right edge of the tissue-thin foolscap; the keys must have been righteously rapped - o's are little holes.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; On the Trail, Harmony With Nature
description: To anyone coming from the raucous streets of Manhattan, the quiet, domesticated aura at the Mohonk Mountain Preserve may seem surreal.

title: POLITICS IN BALCK AND WHITE
description: READING AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHS Images as History, Mathew Brady to Walker Evans. By Alan Trachtenberg. Illustrated. 326 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $25.

title: Move to Ban Offshore Oil Drilling Debated
description: THE one-year moratorium on oil and gas drilling within 50 miles of the New Jersey coast that was recently passed by the House of Representatives has dismayed Federal officials and elated environmentalists.

title: Review/Dance; 'Angle of Ascent,' Creative Time Collage
description: Program notes described ''The Angle of Ascent,'' presented on Wednesday afternoon at the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival, as ''a metaphoric collage addressing the variedness of life, its transformations, its mysteries, its impermanence, and its eternal continuance.''

title: Statewide Testing In Education
description: I can appreciate, though not agree with, Donald J. Ryan's opinions about New Jersey state testing in education (Letters to the Editor, July 23). What I can't appreciate and what I have to take issue with is the heightened vocabulary he uses in constructing a specious case for his position.

title: A COURAGE BORN OF BROKEN PROMISES
description: Michael Blumenthal seems to be unaware that marriage is a two-way street. Instead of praising these women for being so forgiving, he might advise them to look at how they, too, may have played a part in ''broken promises.'' The former husbands of these women may deserve better, too. That's why they remarry - hoping. Maybe Mr. Blumenthal should thank his lucky stars that he is not marrying one of these women. S. POPOVIC Birmingham, Mich.

title: Question Of the Week; Do Colleges Spend Too Much on Athletics?
description: Colleges not only spend too much money on athletics, but also too much emotional capital as well. A college president attending a football or basketball ame is a cliche; when was the last time you saw a president attending a classroom lecture? What message does that send to students about what is important on campus?

title: 2 Cold Towns Settle Suit
description: Ending a costly rivalry, Fraser has surrendered the title ''Icebox of the Nation'' to International Falls, Minn.

title: World's Fair A New World In Andalusia
description: Restoration of the 14th-century Carthusian monastery where Columbus planned his trip westward in 1492 is one sign that Spain has not entirely forgotten why it is holding a world's fair in 1992.

title: To Build for Tomorrow, Take Care of Babies Today
description: As a member of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, created by Congress in 1987, Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat from New Jersey, is part of a broad-based effort to link boardrooms with babies. ''Our national productivity is threatened unless we act now to foster the healthy development of our children,'' he said recently.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Schubert: Piano Sonatas (D. 959, 960) Melvyn Tan, fortepiano. EMI/Angel CDC 7 49631 2; CD only. We have had many period performances on records of early Beethoven and his predecessors. Now we have Schubert - two of his last three sonatas - on a replica of an 1814 Streicher fortepiano made in 1983. Both pieces are heard a half-tone below modern pitch. This Streicher is a robust-sounding instrument, much closer to the sound of today's pianos than are the Stein and Walter instruments of Mozart. Mr. Tan plays the great sonatas in a competent, not very imaginative manner. Period instrument or no, his training is of today's school, which means strict rhythms and an avoidance of personality. Thus both slow movements emerge in a distressingly matter-of-fact manner. Why should expressivity these days be incompatible with ''musicianship''? - Harold C. Schonberg Sibelius: Songs (27) Ritva Auvinen, soprano; Gustav Djupsjobacka, piano. Ondine ODE 728-2; CD only. Sibelius composed 92 songs, mostly in Swedish. Though more rarely essayed than his orchestral works, they are hardly new to disks: Jorma Hynninen recorded two exemplary sets (Finlandia and Harmonia Mundi France LP's), and Tom Krause and Elisabeth Soderstrom collaborated on the full canon (Argo LP's) to fine effect. The songs run the gamut from chilly desolation to steamy, passionate longing, with occasional bursts of frivolity to lighten the mood. The Finnish soprano Ritva Auvinen offers a healthy, rounded selection in her 70-minute recital. Her timbre is not always ingratiating, and on balance I would more highly recommend the sets listed above. Still, she does generally get to the emotional heart of the music, and Gustav Djupsjobacka proves a magnificently expressive, colorful pianist. - Allan Kozinn Dvorak: Piano Trio ('Dumky'), Piano Quintet (Op. 81) The Nash Ensemble of London. Virgin Classics 90736; CD and cassette. This is a magnificent recording. The quality of the playing is first-rate - sensitive, assured and loving - and the ensemble work is as close to perfection as one could desire. Yet for all the obvious labor that went into the Nash's achievement, the performances are as spontaneous as if both of these familiar compositions were being played for the first time. Moreover, the engineering results in clean, natural, well-balanced sound, neither artificially close nor too distant. Founded in 1965, the Nash is one of Britain's pre-eminent chamber ensembles today, and this disk amply shows why. - Barrymore L. Scherer Franck: 'Symphonic Variations'; Prelude, Chorale and Fugue; Prelude, Aria and Finale Jorge Bolet, piano; Concertgebouw Orchestra conducted by Riccardo Chailly (Variations). London 421 714-2; CD only. On this disk of Franck's piano music, the Prelude, Chorale and Fugue and ''Symphonic Variations'' are well known. The Prelude, Aria and Finale is seldom played. It is a long work that wanders a great deal, though the fugue is as stunning as the one in its companion piece. Mr. Bolet, who performs it as a labor of love, is in top form here. That means playing of refinement and elegance, with supple technique and nuanced sound. In the ''Symphonic Variations'' he gets solid cooperation from Mr. Chailly and the great Concertgebouw Orchestra. No better performance is available. - H. C. S. Chopin: Preludes, Op. 28 (orchestrated by Francaix) Berlin Radio Symphony conducted by Karl Anton Rickenbacher. Koch Schwann Music Mundi CD 311 060; CD and LP. It's every orchestration student's worst nightmare: having to rescore perhaps the most felicitously pianistic music ever written, utterly self-contained yet grandly expansive. For reasons best known to him, the French composer Jean Francaix embraced this thankless exercise in 1969 unforced, picking up where others had mercifully left off in the Chopin-derived ballet ''Les Sylphides.'' His inflations go beyond the gratuitous to the grotesque, with gong and snare drum inflicted on the great D flat Prelude and bass drum and cymbals heralding the B flat minor. The inept performances seal the devastation. - James R. Oestreich POP/JAZZ The Pogues: 'Peace and Love' Island 91225; all three formats. Ireland's turbulence and romance, its rage and its boozy pratfalls, echo in the music of the Pogues, who sandwich Irish traditional instruments (pennywhistle, accordion, banjo) between a rock rhythm section and Shane MacGowan's gruff, punky singing. But ''Peace and Love'' is a letdown after last year's gutsy ''If I Should Fall From Grace With God.'' The band tries to broaden its style with fuzz-toned rock and bits of klezmer and flamenco, but the better Celtic-based songs sound uncomfortably close to previous Pogues material, and only ''Tombstone'' moves the group into new territory. - Jon Pareles Bee Gees: 'One' Warner Bros. 25887; all three formats. The Bee Gees' strength - one they periodically resist in attempts to prove they can be funky and hard-edged - is atmospheric ballads. And their second album for Warner Bros. points them back in the right direction, toward the warm and soft. The album's title song and its strongest cut suggests a more metallic echo of the group's Caribbean-flavored dance music for ''Saturday Night Fever.'' So do the chiffon-textured songs, ''Bodyguard'' and ''Wish You Were Here.'' But even the most tuneful numbers lack the melodic sweep of the trio's best ballads from the 60's and 70's. - Stephen Holden Johnny Hodges: 'The Complete Johnny Hodges Sessions 1951-1955' Mosaic MR6-126 (35 Melrose Place, Stamford, Conn. 06904); six LP's only. Johnny Hodges was in many ways the most minimalist of all of jazz's saxophonists. His command of nuance - the shading of a tone so that its colors bleed into significance; the way a beat, rushed or turned to molasses, was meant to indicate mood - made him one of jazz's finest blues musicians. And his solos, never hectic, have the feel of real attention. Mr. Hodges, who played most of his career with Duke Ellington's orchestra, left from 1951 to 1955. The material here, recorded during that period, is masterful, but it's been overlooked, partly because it hasn't always been available, partly because some of it, intended for the rhythm-and-blues market, is simple blues. Mr. Hodges ate it all up; and while the blues are magnificent, the small group arrangements are stunningly beautiful miniatures. - P. W. World Saxophone Quartet: 'Rhythm and Blues' Elektra-Musician 60864; all three formats. With short selections and most of them familiar soul hits, ''Rhythm and Blues'' may be the World Saxophone Quartet's most overtly commercial album; it opens with ''For the Love of Money.'' But it takes only minor adjustments for the group to move from jazz to (nominally) pop. There are more pieces driven by Hamiet Bluiett's baritone-saxophone riffs and more bluesy chords; there's slightly less improvisation. But the quartet - Mr. Bluiett, Julius Hemphill, Oliver Lake and David Murray on saxophones - moves six soul hits into its own domain (alongside three original pieces), with arrangements full of gutsy chromaticism and untrammeled counterpoint. It's not the quartet's wildest work, but few groups of any kind, in jazz or chamber music, are so luxuriant and precise. - J. P. George Benson: 'Tenderly' Warner Bros. 25907; all three formats. The newest album by the buttery-voiced singer and guitarist is an aurally delectable, emotionally detached collection of pop standards in lush, romantic settings. Four of the eight cuts are vocal, the others instrumental. Mr. Benson croons ''You Don't Know What Love Is,'' ''Stardust,'' ''Here, There and Everywhere'' and ''This Is All I Ask,'' with glossy orchestral arrangements by Marty Paich contributing to the dreamy atmosphere. The instrumentals, especially a diaphanous solo guitar version of ''Tenderly,'' have a light, easygoing charm. Backing the singer on most of the album is a jazz trio that includes McCoy Tyner (piano), Ron Carter (bass) and three alternating drummers. - S. H.

title: Pirates Get Hatcher
description: Stymied in his attempt to trade Glenn Wilson to the Houston Astros for Alan Ashby during the spring, General Manager Larry Doughty of the Pirates had to take another avenue, especially after Ashby was released by Houston in May. On Friday night, Doughty traded Wilson to the Astros for another outfielder, Billy Hatcher.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Communities Voting to Protect Environment
description: LEAD: SEVERAL Westchester municipalities have recently enacted or are contemplating laws regulating development of environmentally sensitive lands, a move developers say could reduce housing opportunities and increase costs.

title: Despite Olivier's Death, A Rich Acting Tradition Lives
description: In Richard Eyre's production of ''Hamlet'' at the National Theater (starring Daniel Day-Lewis in the title role), Polonius (Michael Bryant) was giving instructions to his aide Reynaldo. Suddenly Mr. Bryant stopped speaking, then said, as if in a daze, ''I was about to say something,'' and searched his mind for his place in the play. Finally, after an extended pause, he asked, ''Where did I leave?'' The actor playing Reynaldo reminded him, ''At 'closes in the consequence,' at 'friends or so,' and 'gentlemen,' '' and Mr. Bryant picked up the thread of the conversation.

title: Avant-Garde Film Maker Receives MacDowell Medal
description: Stan Brakhage, an avant-garde film maker, is to receive the 1989 Edward MacDowell Medal today at the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H. The award is given to a writer, composer or visual artist who has made an outstanding contribution to American culture.

title: CHARITY AT A PRICE
description: IN SICKNESS AND IN WEALTH American Hospitals in the Twentieth Century. By Rosemary Stevens. 432 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.

title: Brooklynites Balk at Relocation Deal
description: ''This is occupied Berlin,'' said Peggy Hill, a choreographer, peering out of her rear window at 375 Jay Street in downtown Brooklyn. ''I'm living with rubble, with debris, rodents and scavengers as the result of the demolition for Metrotech here.'' Ms. Hill, whose water pipes have been stolen twice and electricity disconnected once, has filed two lawsuits against the city.

title: Waiter, There's a Joke in My Soup
description: Some weeks ago I was in a Mexican restaurant in Los Angeles. It was the kind of eatery that could be part of a chain - Formica tables, plastic chairs, foam-rubber plants and fiberglass bricks.

title: Fin de Siecle Vienna Summers On Long Island
description: Those people who feel that the art of fin de siecle Vienna is the last word in early European modernism should plan to pass through Roslyn Harbor, N.Y., sometime between now and Oct. 7. There they can visit the Nassau County Museum of Art, located in the former Childs Frick mansion - an institution in transition, with a messy recent past and an uncertain future, but also an aggregate exhibition of turn-of-the-century Viennese art that, despite a certain curatorial casualness, is quite satisfying.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $220,000 33 Seaman Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 68-year-old colonial; dining room, great room, finished basement; taxes $3,300. East Williston $410,000 24 East Willis Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, landmarked 1893 Victorian; fireplace, attic, basement, wraparound porch, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,500. Farmingville $168,500 226 Horse Block Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old high ranch; family room, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Greenlawn $210,000 22 Bartel Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, Florida room, 0.25 acre; taxes $4,600. Northport $140,500 97 Little Plains Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, basement, deck; taxes $2,300. Rocky Point $127,250 21 Yucca Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; basement, private beach rights; taxes $2,400. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $245,000 88 Rolling Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old saltbox; fireplace, dining room, pond, 1 acre; taxes $3,056. Avon, Conn. $328,320 521 West Avon Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; skylights, whirlpool bath, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,504. Pompton Lakes, N.J. $170,000 389 Stiles Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; full basement, fenced yard, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,064.

title: Question Of the Week; Do Colleges Spend Too Much on Athletics?
description: Academicians and researchers afford colleges a name and prestige commensurate with their scholarly doings. Students attend college to participate in a range of activities, including the athletic program. Athletics is as important as the traditional academic offerings. Colleges can never spend enough on academics or athletics, because these are two of the most vital aspects of the college experience. ROBIN M. ROSENTHAL New York

title: Going 1 for 3
description: Armand Hammer, the 91-year-old chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, has made no secret of his remaining ambitions: to help achieve peace between East and West, to sponsor a successful search for a cancer cure and to get a Presidential pardon. Last week, that list shrank by one-third when President Bush pardoned him for making illegal contributions to President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign. Dr. Hammer, known for his longstanding commercial ties to the Soviet Union, was fined $3,000 and sentenced to a year of probation in 1976 after he admitted making a secret $54,000 contribution to the Nixon campaign. After all was forgiven last week, he said, ''This vindication reinforces my abiding faith in the American system of justice.''

title: Review/Music; Cleve, Ax and Maisky In Mozart-Haydn Bill
description: It was Mozart and Haydn in geometric proportion at Friday's Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall. George Cleve conducted the Festival Orchestra; Emanuel Ax and Mischa Maisky were the soloists, respectively, in concertos for piano and cello.

title: City Center Offerings For the 1989-90 Season
description: The Alexandrov Red Army Song and Dance Ensemble will open the new season at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, on Sept. 12. The Martha Graham Dance Company is scheduled for Oct. 3-22; the Joffrey Ballet, Oct. 24 to Dec. 2; the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Dec. 6-31; Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, Feb. 6-18; the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company, Feb. 27 to March 4; the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, March 13-25; the Paul Taylor Dance Company, April 17 to May 13, and the Dance Theater of Harlem, May 15 to June 3.

title:
ART;
A Private and Passionate Taste for the Contemporary
description: LEAD: BY all accounts, Dr. Marc Straus never throws anything away. This includes the collection of baseball cards he had by the time he was 5 years old and the antique apothecary bottles he amassed in college.

title: Heidi Hardenburg, Graduate Student, Weds W. E. Evenson 3d in New Jersey
description: Heidi Holt Hardenburg, a Merrill Lynch Fellow at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, and William Ellsworth Evenson 3d, who will enter the same school in September, were married yesterday. The Rev. Alfred L. Salt officiated at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Millington, N.J.

title: 2 Dead and 19 Hurt in Blast Of a Submerged Steam Pipe
description: A 24-inch underground steam pipe exploded with a thunderous roar in the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan yesterday evening, killing two people and injuring 19 others, the police said.

title: Investing After the Crackdown
description: IN an unruffled voice, Zhang Xiaobin explains that not much has changed at his venture capital firm since the dramatic crackdown in Beijing two months ago. His employees come to work, his profit targets are within grasp, he still travels.

title: Food; ACID ANGLES
description: Just a generation ago, vinegar was considered little more than a modest kitchen staple, like baking powder or salt - and just about as interesting. No one really knew much about it except that it came in two colors, red and white, and when mixed with oil, it made a basic salad dressing.

title: Pieces of Sport Fantasy Fetch High Prices in the Real World
description: The business and romance of collecting and dealing baseball cards has turned corporate.

title: POSTINGS: Trade's Grandson's Estate; 59 Houses
description: A 45-acre section of an estate once in the family of the Smith brothers of cough-drop fame is being developed into 59 three-bedroom houses in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Named Coachlight Estates, the project is two miles north of central Poughkeepsie on a property once owned by William W. Smith 2d, the grandson of William Wallace Smith.

title: Estee Einstein: Hat Designer
description: Her name is Estee Einstein and hats are her mission: she wants to persuade women to wear hats again.

title:
GARDENING;
Improving Drainage in Plant Containers
description: LEAD: It is remarkable how fallacious procedures for growing plants become established as fact. An example is the universally proclaimed practice of putting drainage in the bottom of a plant container. In this context, drainage refers to the handful of shards from broken clay pots or the in ch or so of gravel placed in the bottom of the container before soil is added.

title:
ART;
Irving Penn's Skull Photographs: Exotic but Pristine
description: LEAD: WITH a small, boxy gallery space like that of Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing here, one must consider many subtle factors. One of these, according to Mrs. Galasso, is what visitors will see first opposite the door through which they enter.

title: Daniel Gallagher And Miss Boslet To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. George C. Boslet of Annapolis, Md., and Emerald Isle, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Hardin Boslet, to Daniel James Gallagher, the son of Daniel R. Gallagher of Ardmore, Pa., and Mary Ann Gallagher of Fresh Meadows, Queens. An October wedding is planned.

title:
MUSIC;
Bluegrass Festival, Shorter, to Resume
description: LEAD: BLUEGRASS has had its ups and downs in popularity and is now considered by many of its performers and fans to be on the upswing again.

title: Susan E. Berner Weds an Officer In the Air Force
description: Susan Elizabeth Berner and Second Lieut. Mark Franklin Wenger, U.S.A.F., 1988 graduates of Princeton University, were married yesterday at the Waverly Road Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Matthew Ristuccia performed the nondenominational evangelical ceremony. Karla Turekian was the maid of honor. Andrew Littmann was the best man.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STONE WORK: Reflections on Serious Play and Other Aspects of Country Life. By John Jerome. (Viking, $17.95.) Readers of John Jerome's ''Truck'' will enjoy his new book, because he brings the same dispassionate examination to building a stone wall at his western Massachusetts home that he brought to restoring the engine of an aged truck.

title: Even 'Flat' Companies Need Leaders
description: NOT long ago, I met with the chief executive and the top human resources officer of a company with annual sales in excess of $5 billion. The chief executive complained that his top managers had not accepted his vision and strategy for the company. What the three of us discussed was what I call alignment - how to achieve harmony within a modern, highly sophisticated organization.

title: Congress Acting to Bar Future Influence Scandals
description: Hoping to hobble consultants like those involved in inquiries at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, Congressmen are seeking to ban the use of Federal money to pay lobbyists who use influence to help clients obtain Government grants, contracts and loans.

title: Grudge Dash
description: He may have shocked purists by taking steroids to enhance his performance at the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, but Ben Johnson has race promoters licking their lips over the prospect of a million-dollar grudge dash between the Canadian sprinter and Carl Lewis, the American who inherited the gold medal after Johnson's disqualification in the Olympic 100 meters.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $450,000 3 Kavey Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2 1/2-car garage, 1.67 acres; taxes $5,184. Bronxville, N.Y. $897,000 21 Oriole Avenue 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, den, 2-car garage; taxes $16,346. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $245,000 88 Rolling Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old saltbox; fireplace, dining room, pond, 1 acre; taxes $3,056. Avon, Conn. $328,320 521 West Avon Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; skylights, whirlpool bath, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,504. Bloomfield, Conn. $110,000 17 Glenwood Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, updated kitchen; taxes $972. West Hartford, Conn. $361,000 60 Beechtree Lane 3-bedrooom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; solarium, security system, wooded lot; taxes $3,996. OTHER AREAS Greenlawn, L.I. $210,000 22 Bartel Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, Florida room, 0.25 acre; taxes $4,600. Northport, L.I. $140,500 97 Little Plains Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, basement, deck; taxes $2,300. Pompton Lakes, N.J. $170,000 389 Stiles Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; full basement, fenced yard, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,064.

title: 119 Homes Plus a Preserve
description: THE last major undeveloped parcel in Highland Park, a suburb 23 miles north of Chicago's Loop, has been proposed for a 132-acre project of 119 single-family homes around a 23-acre nature preserve.

title: Clare MacIntyre Becomes the Bride Of David Ross, Washington Lawyer
description: Clare Alden MacIntyre, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm A. MacIntyre of McLean, Va., and Quechee, Vt., was married yesterday to David Anthony Ross, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nathan F. Ross of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Elizabeth Ellis-Hagler performed the ceremony at the All Souls Unitarian Church in Washington.

title: Battling It Out for Airport Control
description: IN the world of air travel, where airlines and passengers are buffeted by the effects of deregulation, a new battle is looming: the fight for control of the nation's airports.

title: Katonah Family Keeps a Treasure-Trove of Local History
description: ''DOESN'T anybody stay in one place anymore?'' asked Carole King in a song some years ago. Katharine Barrett Kelly has stayed in one place. She has lived all of her 81 years in Bedford - more specifically, in Katonah, a hamlet in the town.

title: William K. Beckers, 89, Investment Banker
description: William K. Beckers, an investment banker who was a partner in Spencer Trask & Company for four decades and later was a vice president of Shearson, Lehman, Hutton, died of a brain tumor on Aug. 10 at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Texas Barrier Island Pins Hopes on Convention Center
description: LEAD: This beach-resort community near the Mexican border, where condominiums and hotels are abundant and occupancy rates low, has begun to look to a new springboard back to prosperity - a convention center.

title: Jazz and Folk to Close Ives Summer Festival
description: ''MUSIC,'' Charles Ives said, ''is the art of speaking extravagantly,'' and it will be an extravagant weekend of music that closes the Summer Festival of Charles Ives Center for the Arts, at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury.

title: Ex-Smokers Don't All Overdose on Caffeine
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellite Link For Cable TV Is Under Study
description: FOR almost as long as there has been cable television, the question of how to provide the service to isolated rural residents has nagged at franchise owners, regulatory agencies and scores of would-be subscribers throughout the nation. Now, in the northwestern corner of Connecticut, a Salisbury-based franchise believes it has the long-sought answer: satellite dish antennas.

title: Sunhee Juhon Marries
description: Sunhee Juhon, a daughter of Nansoo Lee Juhon of Denver and the late Hongkyoo Juhon, was married yesterday to Arthur C. Hodges Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hodges of Essex, Mass. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Baptist minister, performed an Episcopal ceremony at the First Parish Congregational Church in Manchester, Mass. Mrs. Juhon Hodges, as the bride will be known, graduated from Harvard University and received a J.D. degree from the University of California at Berkeley. In September she will become a clerk to Judge Richard L. Williams of Federal District Court in Richmond. Mr. Hodges, also a Harvard graduate, was, until May, a reporter for The Times Tribune in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Leland's Mourners Urged to Carry On Anti-Hunger Fight
description: Representative Mickey Leland was eulogized today as a martyr for the cause of world hunger, and mourners were urged to honor his memory by carrying on his work.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE SACRED GRAFFITI OF THE SOUL
description: LEAD: Some inmates of Auschwitz left a record of their existence on the walls of cells, latrines, barracks and washrooms. In LAST TRACES: The Lost Art of Auschwitz (Atheneum, $29.95) the photojournalist Joseph P. Czarnecki takes readers into the place where the Nazis murdered two million people. Now a museum, Auschwitz has a catalog with a list of all the art on its walls.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS BACK JETLINERS' ENGINES
description: In the month since a jet engine's disintegration caused a fatal crash of a DC-10 airliner in Iowa, cases of engine failures in flight have been publicized with frightening regularity.

title: WHAT THEY'LL BE WEARING IN THE FALL By Alison Moore
description: What will these 24 women in the limelight choose from the fall collections? Here and on the following pages they say where they are headed. Among the fall choices of these media leaders are short skirts, sleek lines, bright colors and variations on the suit.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's difficult to believe, but there are actually people in this world who don't go around saying, even to themselves, ''Someday I'm going to learn French . . . take up skiing . . . fly a plane . . . read all the classics.'' These people don't carry over wishes, plans and good intentions from year to year. If they think about learning to play bridge, or snorkel, they learn, if not that very week, certainly that month or year. They're a rare breed, deceptive to the naked eye; they look like everyone else, but there the resemblance ends.

title: Jennifer Paley Is a Bride
description: At the Harvard Club in New York, Jennifer Michelle Paley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marc L. Paley of Englewood, N.J., was married last evening to Gerald Laurence Tobias, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tobias of Suffern, N.Y. Rabbi Louis Frishman and Cantor George Weinflash officiated. Mrs. Tobias, a graduate of the University of Vermont with a law degree from Yeshiva University, is to become a law clerk to Judge Roger Kahn of the New Jersey Superior Court in Hackensack, N.J., next month. Her father is a dentist in Fair Lawn, N.J. Mr. Tobias, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a vice president of the Richwood Brokerage, an insurance agency in Hawthorne, N.Y., of which his father is president.

title: Jessica Meltsner Weds Brian Britt
description: Jessica Meltsner and Brian Michael Britt, graduates of Oberlin College, were married yesterday at the Rockport, Mass., home of the bride's grandfather, Dr. John Spiegel. Fred Fritsen, a Rockport justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Avoiding a Merger at Coopers
description: MERGER mania is sweeping the nation's biggest accounting firms, but it is not a clean sweep. Coopers & Lybrand, once the world leader in revenue, plans to sail into the 1990's alone. Coopers may soon be the smallest of the top firms, its management acknowledges, but it has the worldwide presence and the expertise needed to remain competitive, they maintain.

title: A PILGRIM AT THE POTTERY WHEEL
description: LEAD: THE ROAD THROUGH MIYAMA By Leila Philip. Illustrated. 264 pp. New York: Random House.

title: LESSONS FROM THE SANDBOX
description: There are many Southern dishes that I hold dear. But, in the article on Robert Fulghum, y'all mentioned a dish I've never head of.
