What, in the name of Southern cuisine, is chicken hyphen fried steak? Where I come from in Mississippi (pronounced Missippi), no one uses a hyphen between chicken and fried. When you do that it becomes some Yankee dish, akin to blackened cod or steamed chitlins. Please give us back our chicken fried steak or soon we'll be eatin' regional kale (my suggestion for what you might call collard greens), Kentucky-fried chicken and maybe even hush-puppies. HODDING CARTER 4th Brooklyn

title: U.S. Debates Selling Supercomputers to 3 Nations
description: The Bush Administration is sharply divided over whether to permit the sale of American-built supercomputers to Brazil, India and Israel, Administration officials say.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Imagination Under Attack

title: Lawyer Is Wed To Ms. Shlufman
description: Suzanne Joy Shlufman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Shlufman of Plainview, L.I., was married in Huntington, L.I., yesterday to Mitchell Schuster, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schuster of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Earl Kideckel officiated at the South Huntington Jewish Center.

title: On a Bread Line, Poles Carry Hope Like an Empty Sack
description: As the politicians gathered to debate the nation's future, Poles gathered to debate the price of bread, eyeing the loaves from long wary lines where the talk was as crusty as their quest.

title: All Sounds Blend in a Rich American Mainstream
description: No less than European music from Bach through Brahms, American symphonic music in the 20th century has a mainstream. The style is broad enough to take in jazz and 12-tone effects, the pastoral and the urban, optimism and (less frequently) melancholy, but it is grounded in tonality and independence of spirit. Walt Whitman caught its essence in ''Song of Myself,'' when he heard ''all sounds running together, combined, fused or following;/Sounds of the city, and sounds out of the city - sounds of the day and night.''

title: Barbara Page Marries
description: Barbara Ann Burger Page a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nelson Page of Hackettstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan David Glatt, the son of Edward Glatt of Cranbury, N.J., and the late Claire Naar Glatt. The Rev. Roland Ghirlando, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Frederick Dworkin officiated at Miller Chapel at the Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary. The bride, an account executive at the advertising agency Lintas New York, graduated from Syracuse University. Mr. Glatt, an associate at the investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, graduated from the University of Maryland.

title: W. A. Casselman, 86; Ex-Daily News Editor
description: William A. Casselman, a former executive editor of The Daily News, died of complications from pulmonary fibrosis yesterday at the Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital in Plattsburgh, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Elizabethtown, N.Y.

title: Residential Resales

Sopher) Woodlawn $290,000 436 East 240th Street 2-family, attached brick; 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, dining area in each; 450-sq.-ft. hospitality suite with bath, 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,100 (Broker: Charles B. Peck) Park Slope $312,500 374 5th Street 2-family, attached 3-story brick home; 2 bedrooms, dining area in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other unit; 1 bath in each; 15- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $873 (Broker: F. J. Kazeroid Realty Group) QUEENS Forest Hills Gardens $525,000 30 Summer Street 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, brick side-hall colonial; dining room, 2-car garage, fireplace, powder room, finished basement, 40- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $2,200 (Broker: Terrace Realty) Woodside $360,000 48-40 59th Street 3-family, semiattached brick home; two units with 2 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, dining room; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in third unit; large kitchen in each; 1-car garage; 21- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,900 (Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Graniteville $130,000 20 Peter Street (Holiday Villa) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 22- by 34-ft. condo in a 3-year-old building; large kitchen, mirrored dining room, pool, common charge $83, $250 with tax abatement (Schlott Realtors) St. George $130,000 10 Bay Street Landing (Bay Landing) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,045-sq.-ft. co-op loft, 1910 converted warehouse; 24-hr. doorman, Manhattan view, 14 closets, outdoor tennis courts; maintenance $595, 58% tax-deductible (Broker: J. P. Walsh Realty)

title: Taking the Kids, Israel's Museums
description: The Museums of Israel By Nitza Rosovsky and Joy Ungerleider-Mayerson. Illustrated. 256 Pages. Harry N. Abrams. Paper, $14.95.

title: Living in a Curious Time
description: To the Editor:

title: An Office Park Lures Hewlett
description: LITTLE FALLS CENTER, a 157-acre office park being developed by Hercules, an international chemical company, has managed to woo a division of the Hewlett-Packard Company. The park, in the unincorporated countryside just west of Wilmington, the state's largest city, has been under development since 1984.

title: HIGH PRIEST OF THE PIANO
description: AN ARTIST'S JOURNEY Lettres d'un Bachelier es Musique, 1835-1841. By Franz Liszt. Edited and translated by Charles Suttoni. Illustrated. 260 pp. Illinois:: The University of Chicago Press. FRANZ LISZT Volume Two: The Weimar Years, 1848-1861. By Alan Walker. Illustrated. 626 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $39.95.

title: A Gambler Becomes a Producer
description: LEAD: ''I'm in a tricky business,'' said Roberta R. Becker, an independent television producer. ''Networks may be going through a phase when they only want to do romances. Then suddenly tastes change. Timing's important. You just might be holding that card in your hand.''

title: POSTINGS: Jersey Expanding Loan Plan; Special for Handymen
description: New Jersey plans to expand and promote an unusual program that lends to the buyer of a dilapidated house the money to both buy and renovate it. The so-called Buy-It-And-Fix-It Program has been little used since it was started two years ago, and to date only 20 homeowners in the state have taken advantage of its provisions, which include a fixed mortgage interest rate, currently 8.82 percent.

title: Chargers Beat Bears With Big 2d Half
description: A rookie, Billy Joe Tolliver, threw two touchdown passes, and another rookie, Elliot Smith, returned an intercepted pass 49 yards for a touchdown tonight as the San Diego Chargers beat the Chicago Bears, 24-7.

title: THE STRUGGLE CONTINUES
description: As a black who grew up under Southern segregation, now living and working in New York, I am tired of sanctimonious Yankee hypocrites trooping down South to pontificate about racism.

title: TALKING: Transfer Taxes; The Bill On Sales Goes Up
description: THIS summer both New York State and New York City have extended several real estate transfer taxes to scoop up new revenues from thousands of formerly exempt buyers and sellers, such as owners of co-op apartments. Particularly hard hit will be properties selling for more than $1 million, which will now be subject to the so-called ''mansion'' tax.

title: Ford Mason, Gum Ball Seller, 95
description: Ford Mason, whose penny gum ball machines have been a fixture in stores and service stations across the United States for the last half century, died Wednesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 95 years old.

title: Company Is Teaching The Business of Law
description: JOSEPH SCUTELLARO, who teaches a seminar in business management, will admit that he sometimes has trouble maintaining a certain level of interest and attention in his classroom.

title: This Year, The Beach Problem Is Sewage
description: LAST year, the beaches in the metropolitan region were besieged with small amounts of medical waste and waves of negative publicity. This year, beaches are still being closed but this time, experts say, the problem is more chronic and dangerous: high counts of bacteria that make swimming potentially hazardous.

title: Mets Continue To Cruise
description: Having survived Orel Hershiser the night before, the Mets had no great trauma surviving pitchers of less renown yesterday afternoon as they continued their August stampede with a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Actors Who Turn Director May Be Miscast
description: ''Kevin Costner, about to direct his first film, ''Dances With Wolves,'' got an endorsement from the director Tony Scott. ''He knows his lenses and his lights,'' Mr. Scott said in a recent magazine article. ''He's ready.'' The co-executive producer of Danny DeVito's second film, ''The War of the Roses,'' commented on his use of a sophisticated sort of crane. ''I'd never used it in 10 years; Danny uses it three or four times a week.'' And Bill Murray, who will star in and co-direct a bank robbery film called ''Quick Change,'' has said: ''I've got to get closer to the mechanics behind the camera. As for the other basics, I've had a lot of experience with comedy and tempo, and I know I understand performance.''

title: Jeffrey Ward Wed To Miss Broaddus
description: Margaret Broaddus, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Broaddus of Andover, Mass., was married there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to Jeffrey Hill Ward, the son of Josele S. Ward of Albany, Ore., and the late Frederick H. Ward. The Rev. Margaret Bullitt-Jonas performed the ceremony.

title: Prospects
description: Advice for Breeden

title: These Are Not Your Father's Socks
description: For men who think they have got things covered if their socks are the same color and conceal their calves at a business meeting, there's news from the fashion front.

title: Ms. Kupin Plans to Marry in '90
description: The engagement of Stephanie Kupin to Mark Greenwald, a son of Jenny Greenwald of New York and the late Jay Greenwald, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kupin of New York and Yonkers. A March wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: A Travel Advisory report on July 30 about the Chautauqua Institution in Chautauqua, N.Y., misstated its location. It is on Chautauqua Lake.

title: 'Cocktail Hour' Closing
description: ''The Cocktail Hour,'' a semi-autobiographical comedy by A. R. Gurney, will close today after the matinee at the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street. Directed by Jack O'Brien and starring Nancy Marchand, Burt Edwards, Holland Taylor and Richard Backus, the play will have run for 15 previews and 351 regular performances.

title: A. C. Kemper Jr. And Miss Shiland To Marry in Fall
description: Tracy Hedges Shiland, an analyst at the investment advisory firm of Douglas, Noyes & Company, and Antoine Claude Kemper Jr., an institutional equities trader for Rochdale Securities, both in New York, are planning to be married in November.

title: ORIGINS OF CASUAL STYLE
description: Today's new luxurious casual look has a special vocabulary of its own, reflecting its various historical roots. Whether the style is full and features voluminous folds for warmth, or is sleekly tailored for sport, these articles of clothing often derive from the native dress of a specific culture. In their original shape and material, they served a practical purpose, and were designed for ease of movement or protection in extreme climates. Adapted first as informal sportswear, they have now been further transformed into high fashion, with the addition of luxurious details or substitution of an expensive fabric. A glossary of terms follows. A

title: Maine
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article on Mount Desert Island by Eleanor Dwight (''A Breezy Summer in Acadia,'' Travel, July 9) and thought I might offer some additional information.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We are planning to install a new kitchen floor of vinyl tiles. The existing floor is vinyl tile that still is well secured and has a smooth surface. But one corner of a tile near the refrigerator has lifted slightly, and the dealer says that the old flooring must be ripped up and new plywood put down before the new tiles can be laid. However, a flooring contractor says that he can install the new tiles over the existing floor. Who is correct?

title: Attaching Items to Walls
description: WALLS in most homes are hollow. That is, they consist of an inner framework of widely spaced, narrow pieces of lumber called studs, which are covered on each side by a layer of wall material like wallboard, plaster or thin paneling.

title: COUSINS IN EXTREMIS
description: THE LOOKING-GLASS LOVER By Ursula Perrin. 287 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: They Are Stardust. They Are Golden. They Are Boring.
description: I AM 25 years old and my mother was at Woodstock. It's taken me more than a decade of self-therapy to overcome the initial shock and subsequent awkwardness that accompanied that revelation.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: In the early 1800's Britain was in no mood to trifle with trouble from its colonies. War with the United States and then with France had sapped her wealth and massive economic changes were changing Britain's social fabric. The Irish were trying to lift the British yoke and England's criminal class was growing.

title: Charlotte Look Marries Peter Szuch
description: At the Elijah Kellogg Congregational Church in Harpswell, Me., Charlotte Townsend Look, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Look of Brunswick, Me., was married yesterday to Peter Allen Szuch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Szuch of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Grover Cleveland, an uncle of the bride who is an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: IRAN'S CHIEF SEEKS TO OUST HARD-LINER FROM NEW CABINET
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran sought the removal of his hard-line Interior Minister today in proposing a new Cabinet. The action sharpens a power struggle whose outcome is expected to mold Teheran's relations with the West and influence the fate of Western hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Pristine Island Caught in a Legal Labyrinth
description: LEAD: WHEN Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin announced in June that the county had signed a contract to buy Robins Island for $9.2 million, a 10-year struggle to preserve its nearly pristine 445 acres seemed all but won.

title: Kissinger and China
description: Anyone still interested in the views of Henry Kissinger, who once exercised much power in this country, should look at a recent article of his in The Los Angeles Times. The subject was China, but the more interesting subtext was the mind of the author: his attitude on issues of authority and freedom.

title: Jennifer K. Smith Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Jennifer Keyler Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Smith of John's Island, Fla., and Watch Hill., R.I., to Edward J. Matthews 3d, a son of Mrs. Matthews Jr. of Mendham, N.J., and Weekapaug, R.I., and the late Mr. Matthews, took place yesterday. The Rev. Donal R. Kehew performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: Ms. Ames Is Wed To Jack W. Prince
description: Cathi-Lynne Ames, the daughter of Dr. Martin Ames of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Lenore K. Ames, was married last evening in New York to Jack William Prince, the son of Margaret L. Prince of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late David J. Prince. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch performed the ceremony at the Pesca restaurant.

title: In Atlantic City, Less Is More, Sometimes
description: ASK a visitor to list the lures of the casino hotels here, and Broadway or Off Broadway musicals are not likely to be among them.

title: Live Pictures of Fly-By Are to Be on TV
description: Voyager 2's images of Neptune are scheduled to be shown live on television early Friday morning as the spacecraft skirts the planet, on its way out of the solar system into deep space.

title: WILLIE HORTON AND ME
description: I am a black man. I am a young black man, born, let's say, between Brown v. Board of Education and the murders of Schwerner, Chaney and Goodman. Or, in the years that followed the murder of Emmett Till, but before the murder of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. I am one of the young black Americans Dr. King sang of in his ''I Have A Dream'' speech: ''I have a dream that . . . the sons of former slaves and the sons of former slave owners will be able to sit down together at the table of brotherhood . . . that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character. . . . I have a dream today!''

title: Sally P. Zimmer, A Teacher, Weds
description: The marriage of Sally Paine Zimmer, the daughter of Nancy C. Zimmer of Portland, Conn., and the Rev. Layton P. Zimmer of Wailuku, Maui, Hawaii, to Peter Runkel Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Thomas Knight of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Wesleyan Memorial Chapel at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn. The Rev. George R. McKelvey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: So Where Can You Find a Pool in Manhattan?
description: Denise Courtney and Sheri Lawler have spent the morning dabbling their very tan toes and fingers in the water while their children slip, slide and splash all around them. Chances are they will spend the rest of the day, and the rest of the week, doing pretty much the same thing.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Harlem Week celebration, 125th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Fifth Avenue will be closed today from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M. between St. Nicholas Avenue and Fifth Avenue.

title: Loss of Border Battle to Khmer Rouge Signals Trouble for Cambodian Army
description: In three weeks of heavy fighting recently between the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and the troops of the Phnom Penh Government, the Government soldiers did not perform well, fleeing their positions under heavy artillery barrages from the guerrillas and retreating up to six miles, diplomats and Government officials say.

title: Katharine Cullison, Actress, Is a Bride
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., Katharine Gates Cullison, the daughter of Martha L. Cullison of Nyack, N.Y., and George Bennett Cullison Jr. of Harlan, Iowa, was married yesterday to Yoshiki Shimada, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Naoki Shimada of New York. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins and the Rev. Mark R. Wood officiated.

title: Northrop's 'Awesome' B-2 Gamble
description: AS Kent Kresa, the president of the Northrop Corporation, stood beside an Air Force runway in the California desert last month and watched the B-2 Stealth bomber take off on its maiden flight, he kept saying ''awesome'' and thinking about all the hard work the company and its subcontractors had put into building the radar-evading plane. ''It was a very moving experience,'' Mr. Kresa said.

title: Modern Dance: A Harmonious Melting Pot
description: Modern dance has become an art with an international passport. This summer, both the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the American Dance Festival featured performances by French modern dance troupes. The American Dance Festival also offered productions by Italian, Finnish, Indonesian and South American choreographers. Last spring, works by Swiss modern dancers living in New York were presented at the Swiss Institute on West 67th Street; a comparable season by Spanish choreographers took place at Casa de Espana on East 39th Street.

title: They Are in Growing Demand, But Workers Are Settling for Less
description: TWO weeks into the telephone workers' strike, a familiar pattern is evident: while American unions battle hard, and often successfully, to maintain health insurance and other benefits, they are quietly giving ground on wages.

title: Michael H. Ruby, An Editor, Is Wed To Louisa Wood
description: Louisa Bronson Wood, a daughter of William P. Wood of West Grove, Pa., and Manchester, Mass., and the late Mia Atherton Wood, was married yesterday in Manchester to Michael Handler Ruby, the son of Mrs. Eli M. Pearce of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Myron M. Ruby. Justice of the Peace Barbara Peterson officiated at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Sara Wadsworth Wood.

title: FASHION: Big Enough for Two; Fashions for After the Baby, Too
description: When a woman becomes pregnant her body changes, but her style of dressing can remain constant. Pregnancy shouldn't stop a woman from looking fashionable. Designers like Gordon Henderson, Romeo Gigli and Matsuda include in their collections roomy shirts, sweaters or dresses that can serve as maternity outfits.

title: Changes in Zoning Weighed to Foster Day-Care Centers
description: LEAD: WITH the shortage of child-care centers reaching crisis proportions in the county, local municipalities are discovering that their zoning laws can either help or hinder local corporations and developers who want to meet the need.

title: Blueberry Flavor As It Used to Be
description: I read the article on blueberries with interest (''Picky About Blueberries,'' Opinion page, July 16) and would wish to be in the author's shoes. I'm about to plant blueberries extensively, but am wary of the new, disease-resistant, large and copious berries that are bland in taste. I hope someone can guide me to domestically grown blueberries that still preserve the old, wild flavor. (I'm over 60.) WALTER LUIKART Leonia

title: Lore North Plans To Wed A. N. Yao
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold M. North of East Berlin, Pa., have made known the September wedding plans for their daughter, Lore Alison North and Andrew Nicholas Yao, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. T. Yao of Fairfield, Conn.

title: George and the Yankee Doghouse
description: In canine terms, the headline read: ''Dog Bites Man.'' In baseball language, it was:

title: Red Sox Stop Brewers' Streak at 8
description: Ellis Burks's two-run single with the bases loaded and one out in the 14th inning today gave the Boston Red Sox a 3-1 victory over Milwaukee, ending the Brewers' winning streak at eight games. The Red Sox stopped a losing streak at six games.

title: Democracy for Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Learning Where the Trees Grow
description: LEAD: What could be more pleasing for a college or university campus than a stand of fine trees, perhaps even rare ones? Some of these institutions grow not only trees, but shrubs and herbaceous plants in wetlands and dry areas. They are used for pleasure and instruction and often for research. Among the colleges and universities in the Northeast, the following, selected at random, have arboreta worthy of note.

title: Going 2 for 2
description: Ten months after doctors removed a tumor from his throwing arm and told him he would never pitch again, Dave Dravecky returned triumphantly to baseball. Last week, five days after Mr. Dravecky's first comeback victory for the San Francisco Giants and six innings into his second, the arm gave out, breaking with a loud crack as Mr. Dravecky released a fastball. The 33-year-old pitcher will be out for the rest of the season, but his doctors said they saw no reason he should not have a second comeback next year. They said the bone was weakened by the surgery, but was expected to heal stronger than ever. As Mr. Dravecky was carried from the stadium on a stretcher, he said to a teammate, ''Win this game. I want this game.'' The Giants did.

title: Francesca Di Blasi: Wall Finisher
description: As a child in Italy, Francesca Di Blasi painted wall murals with her three sisters. These days, Ms. Di Blasi still decorates walls, using a sophisticated range of traditional Italian finishes like lime wash, fresco and her specialty, stucco lustro Veneziano. ''In reality, I'm a plasterer,'' she said. ''I'm also an artisan. I want to do wall finishes the right way, the way they used to do them during the Renaissance.''

title: Ronni Sue Weiss Weds
description: Ronni Sue Weiss and Marc David Churchman were married last evening at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Nathan Goldbery.

title: Bridal Is Planned By Lisa Ferguson
description: Elizabeth Tally Ferguson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mead Ferguson of Woodward, Okla., and James Price Stoeffel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stoeffel of Milwaukee, are planning a September wedding, the prospective bride's parents have announced.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Minnesota; Three Professors Face Discipline Over Purchases
description: Three professors in the computer science department at the University of Minnesota are facing disciplinary action on charges that they used university funds to buy furniture and electronic equipment for use in their homes and that they received inappropriate salary payments.

title: I'm Searching For Some Life
description: EVERYDAY I'd walk home from elementary school and just before turning the corner to cross the ''big street,'' I'd peer up to the top window of a small framed house in Brooklyn where I'd see my grandmother and grandfather looking out the window. Like two bookends on opposite sides of the small picture window, which I remember had a little stained glass jalousie that was broken, they'd look down and wave at me as I skipped or ran by.

title: GREAT LEADER TO DEAR LEADER
description: NORTH KOREA IS NOT SO much a nation as a religion.

title:
GARDENING;
Improving Drainage in Plant Containers
description: LEAD: It is remarkable how fallacious procedures for growing plants become established as fact. An example is the universally proclaimed practice of putting drainage in the bottom of a plant container. In this context, drainage refers to the handful of shards from broken clay pots or the in ch or so of gravel placed in the bottom of the container before soil is added.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Therapists Start To Address Damage Done by Therapists
description: LEAD: AMID growing concern about psychologists, psychiatrists and social workers who have sex with patients, therapists around the country are devising new strategies to confront a problem they say has been neglected for too long.

title: Power of Hispanic Vote Is Evident In Courtship by Koch and Dinkins
description: The acknowledged front-runners for New York City's Democratic mayoral nomination, Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan and Mayor Edward I. Koch, are aggressively courting Hispanic voters, who make up what many politicians expect to be a pivotal bloc in the Sept. 12 primary.

title: IN THE SCUZZY HEART OF GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: THE CHRISTOPHER PARK REGULARS By Edward Swift. 239 pp. Latham, N.Y.: British American Publishing. $18.95.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: How can you tell a dangerous player? There is more than one answer.

title: John L. Ross Wed To Dr. Friedman
description: Dr. Lainie Sue Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Friedman of Jericho, L.I., was married there last evening to John Louis Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ross of Jericho. Cantor Mark Horowitz and Cantor Barbara Horowitz, who are husband and wife, performed the ceremony at the Fountainebleau.

title:
ART;
Luminous Coloring Proves Rewarding
description: LEAD: DURING the last 10 years, the painter Herman Cherry has been developing and refining a luminous approach to color that gives his canvases a characteristically sensuous, vibrant quality.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE GILDED LEAF: Triumph, Tragedy, and Tobacco. Three Generations of the R. J. Reynolds Family and Fortune. By Patrick Reynolds and Tom Shachtman. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Many in the Reynolds clan probably will hope that ''The Gilded Leaf'' disappears in a puff of cigarette smoke. With the journalist Tom Shachtman, R. J. Reynolds's grandson, the antismoking activist Patrick Reynolds, chronicles three generations of one of the South's best-known and most dysfunctional families. The same entrepreneurs who two generations ago founded RJR Tobacco Company and Reynolds Metals also sired heirs whose exploits smack of bad television drama: palatial homes, world-class drinking, adultery, threats of murder, a suspicious suicide, lawsuits, abandoned children. Family eccentrics range from the third wife of R. J. Reynolds Jr. - who, we are told, wears turbans, carries a dagger and consults occult treatises - to R. J. Reynolds Jr.'s son Zach, whose primary interests, according to the authors, are sex, motorcycles and guns. The writers make no claim to complete objectivity. Before R. J. Reynolds Jr., a heavy smoker, died of complications from emphysema in 1964, he disinherited his six sons, including Patrick. Perhaps as a consequence, Patrick Reynolds and his co-author were denied access to many important family papers. If the team's research has not successfully uncovered the minutiae of every Reynolds scandal, ''The Gilded Leaf'' is nonetheless a courageous and worthwhile book. More than an entertainment, it documents the danger of parents who confuse money with love.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: ''SEE if you can pick out the right one,'' Linda challenged.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Plans Expanded For the New Grossinger's

title: Gretchen Ervin Becomes a Bride
description: Gretchen Dickson Ervin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hauer Ervin of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Nicholas van der Grinten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johan van der Grinten of St. Albans, Hertfordshire, England. The Rev. Elwood Stark officiated at St. Michael's Lutheran Church.

title: Wine; THE BATTLE OF 1855
description: The late Alexis Lichine spent much of his professional life arguing for a revision of the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux. He didn't succeed. When he died, earlier this year, the 1855 classification remained much as it had always been - and probably will be for a long time to come.

title: Appeals Court Grants Stay Of Execution in '74 Killings
description: The man who has been on death row for 15 years, longer than any other prisoner in the nation, won a stay of execution today, only three days before he was to die by injection for three killings in a 1974 robbery.

title: Around the World With Peter Gabriel
description: The world of popular music - indeed, the world of music in general - is filled these days with cross-cultural communication. This communication can travel every which way, from Paul Simon's South African township jive to David Byrne's French-African dance music and Brazilian exotica to Youssou N'Dour's electric guitars.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DARK WATERS: Essays, Stories and Articles. By Russell Chatham. (Clark City Press, 109 W. Callender, Livingston, Mont. 59047; Paper, $14.95.) Russell Chatham describes with bold eloquence the pleasure and pathos of ''the so-called blood sports.'' While he defines his subject as ''any of the activities involving an outdoor chase of some sort,'' the focus of ''Dark Waters'' is hunting and fishing, with emphasis on the latter.

title: Altbier, Dark Brew In Dusseldorf Pubs
description: WHEN a bar sells an average of 4,000 glasses of beer on a weekday and up to three times that during the weekend, it must be doing something right. Especially when there are plenty of other places in the neighborhood to quaff a brew. So how should one react on learning that this popular bar, Zum Uerige in the university town of Dusseldorf, West Germany, sells such a heady volume of suds specifically because the beer is old?

title: Iran Hangs 79 in Drug Cases
description: Iran today hanged 79 ''notorious and professional'' drug smugglers, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the convicts were hanged in Teheran and in 21 cities after being found guilty by the Islamic Revolutionary Court, which runs the nation's anti-narcotics campaign. About 900 drug smugglers have been executed since Iran started a crackdown at the beginning of the year with a new law mandating jail sentences for addicts and the death penalty for possessing drugs.

title: The New and Nervous Face of Polish Communism
description: ''The world does not end for us,'' the Communist spokesman insisted, holding his smile steady as his party limped into retreat from four decades of monopolistic power.

title: The Latest Thing On Wheels
description: ''Sometimes outside the bike shop people look down on me for being a mechanic, and that's upsetting,'' said Nathan Dean, a 34-year-old bike mechanic at Bicycle Habitat in SoHo.

title: Linda Van Voorhis, 87, Poet Called 'June'
description: Linda Lyon Van Voorhis, a poet, died yesterday at her home in Irondequoit in suburban Rochester. She was 87 years old.

title: Thefts of Patent Information Puzzle University Librarians
description: Recent thefts from at least 13 university libraries of microfilm containing United States patent information have baffled librarians and prompted an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Dent's Record Is 0-3 As Tigers Edge Yanks
description: Not that any aspect of being the Yankees' manager is easy, but playing the Tigers was supposed to be the easy part of Bucky Dent's initiation.

title: Wendy Banner Becomes Bride
description: The wedding of Wendy Jill Banner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Banner of Larchmont, N.Y., to Kyle Robert Gordon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Gordon of Glencoe, Ill., took place yesterday at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller officiated.

title: CLOSEOUT CHAINS' COSTLY GROWTH
description: It was a satisfying, if unpredictable, afternoon of bargain shopping for Nancita Remias at Pic 'N' Save, the end of the line for discounted merchandise.

title: Question Box
description: PGA Earnings Q. Each week, the PGA Tour lists its leading money winners based on what each golfer has earned for the year, without regard to how many tournaments he entered. Among the top earners this season, who would be the leader on the basis of earnings per tournament? A. Through 33 tournaments this season, not counting this weekend's event in Colorado, the per-tournament leader in winnings is Tom Kite, who is second on the overall earnings list. Kite has entered 18 events and picked up $726,614, an average of $40,367 every time he plays an event. Next in average earnings but third on the tour list is Curtis Strange, whose $630,420 comes out to $35,023 for each of the 18 events he has competed in. Last year, when Strange became the first member of the tour to top $1 million in one year, his average was $47,802 for 24 tournaments.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Durable Goods July Thursday None Friday None

title: Randolph's Homer Stuns Mets in 9th
description: The Mets were marching magnificently through August yesterday with a 3-1 lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers in the ninth inning. Two were out and nobody was on base. Then it happened: on the longest of long shots, the Dodgers snatched the game on a pinch-hit single, a bunt single and a three-run home run by Willie Randolph, who hadn't hit one since the Yankees exiled him after 13 years in New York.

title: Communists Assess Change
description: Among the amazing images of Poland in transition was a smiling Communist Party spokesman, who greeted the change as one in which 'Our days will be broader.' Page A6.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an insider-trading case on Wall Street misstated a step taken by Robert M. Freeman, who had been under investigation by the Government. Mr. Freeman said on Thursday that he would plead guilty to one count of mail fraud; he has not yet entered the plea. He also resigned as a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We sang today at the church, 'Poland lives, Poland is growing.' We must believe that this nation, a wonderful nation, can reach the stage where life will be better in Poland, so that no one lacks anything in Poland, that no one leaves it.'' -Tadeusz Mazowiecki, designated as Poland's Prime Minister. [ A1:6. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about dry beer misidentified the business school at Washington University in St. Louis. It is the John M. Olin School of Business.

title: The Film Forum Will Rise Again, On Houston St.
description: After Film Forum, the two-screen movie theater in lower Manhattan, is demolished next month, a new, larger theater will open next spring on West Houston Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Varick Street.

title: NEW JERSEY MAN KILLED ON VISIT TO HIS DAUGHTER
description: A 68-year-old New Jersey man was stabbed to death Saturday evening in the entrance of his daughter's apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, apparently a victim of an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: Charles A. Schoeneck Jr., 77, a Politician
description: Charles A. Schoeneck Jr., a stalwart in New York State Republican politics, died Saturday at Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: NASA Speeding Plans to Rescue Science Satellite Losing Its Orbit
description: As an 11-ton scientific satellite slips back toward earth faster than expected, the space agency is racing to retrieve it before it crashes.

title: Steel Imports Up in June
description: Steel imports in June rose for the third consecutive month, up 5.2 percent, to 1.55 million tons, but the total for the first half of the year is sharply below the 1988 period, the American Iron and Steel Institute said last week. Steel exports in June continued substantially ahead of recent years, totaling 403,000 tons, compared with 355,000 tons in May and 126,000 tons in June 1988. For the first half, exports totaled 2.2 million tons, compared with 670,000 tons in the first six months of 1988, the institute said. First-half imports totaled 8.7 million tons, down 21 percent from 11.03 million tons in the 1988 period.

title: Helene Schlackman, a Lawyer, Is Wed
description: At the Westbury (L.I.) Manor, Helene Schlackman, a daughter of Mrs. Milton Schlackman of Lynbrook, L.I. and the late Mr. Schlackman, was married yesterday to Jonathan Robert Rod, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester S. Rod of Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi Arnold Shevlin officiated.

title: Politics
description: There has been much talk in political circles in recent years about the rapid shift in voter opinion that often takes place days before an election. These sudden shifts, usually in response to some news event or a last-minute attack, trouble many politicians who see the democratic process reduced to something as whimsical as a coin toss.

title: Bridge
description: Few expert players are willing to take the trouble to assist in the adminstration of the game. As a result, nearly all of the members of the American Contract Bridge League's board of directors are enthusiasts with little claim to national or international distinction.

title: The Midgetman Money Game
description: The armed services and defense contractors have developed an elaborate game for selling expensive military hardware to Congress. The armed services begin by grossly underestimating the cost of new programs. Defense contractors play along, charging a little less overhead here, assuming a little less inflation there. That allows the services to get the camel's nose under the tent.

title: F.B.I. Only After the Facts in Bloch Case; Lauder Defamed
description: To the Editor:

title: FAILED HUNT MAY END TREASURE BOOKS AND VIDEOS
description: Four years ago, Richard Baker of Gatlinburg, Tenn., set out on a treasure hunt based on a puzzle that had promised to bring the winner $500,000 and a miniature golden horse.

title: Strategy of King Is to Raise Demand For Tyson-Holyfield
description: TO most boxing insiders and to a growing number of just plain fight fans, there is only one man these days who represents a credible challenge to Mike Tyson, and he is the former undisputed cruiserweight champion, Evander Holyfield.

title: PUERTO RICO ESTABLISHES INTERNATIONAL BANKING
description: Puerto Rico has adopted legislation to promote international banking on the island, hoping to compete with banking centers in the Caribbean and the United States.

title: The Jewish Museum Preparing for a Move West
description: In a novel East-West arrangement, the Jewish Museum is to move across Central Park into one floor of the New-York Historical Society on the Upper West Side for two years while its own Upper East Side home is closed for renovations and expansion.

title: Catching a Wiff Of Homey Fenway
description: Growing up in Boston as an avid Red Sox fan, Rick Ferroli dreamed of playing in Fenway Park and taking aim at the famed Green Monster. Though he pitched in high school and college and as a semipro, Ferroli never made it to Fenway as a player.

title: Canada About to Sign Major Land Agreement With Eskimos
description: The future inhabitants of Nunavut are preparing for a bonanza.

title: Giving New Meaning To 'Around the Town'
description: Shelley Taylor Smith hears the same question every time she mentions her favorite pastime: ''Why?'' When she explains how much she enjoys circling Manhattan armed only with goggles and a tetanus shot, she is confronted by the same stares, the same head-shaking disbelief.

title: Beirut Captors Say French Move Imperils Hostages
description: A pro-Iranian group threatened today to harm its American hostages if the United States did not bring pressure to bear on France to call back warships it is sending to Lebanon.

title: Export Case Indictments
description: Five people have been indicted after what the Commerce Department described as an attempt to ship high-technology equipment of military value to the Soviet Union.

title: Tow-Yourself Waterskis
description: A new water-ski craft eliminates the need for a tow-boat driver. Instead, the skier operates the boat with remote controls.

title: Arabs Kill Gaza Man For Not Yielding Card
description: Palestinians armed with knives and axes hacked a Gaza man to death when he refused to hand over his Israeli-issued identity card, Arab reports said today.

title: Car-Crash Filmmaker Killed As Tower Collapses Too Soon
description: A film producer was killed tonight when a water tower he was planning to topple while shooting a movie fell prematurely, the police said.

title: AIDED 1986 INCOME TAX CHANGES
description: Joseph A. Pechman, a leading scholar of tax policy and the director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution for more than 20 years, died Saturday after suffering a heart attack while playing tennis in Potomac, Md. He was 71 years old and lived in Bethesda.

title: Pamela Lippmann Marries
description: Pamela Linde Lippmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lippmann of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Adam Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Roth of Peekskill, N.Y. Rabbi William P. Kloner officiated at Maison Lafitte in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Mrs. Roth is an English teacher at the Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood, N.J. Mr. Roth is a sales representative at the Modern Group, a printing and packaging design company in Smithtown, L.I.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
Round 1: Tennis
description: LEAD: Donovan Ruddock, a heavyweight boxer, wields a snappy jab, a robust hook, a prompt uppercut. He also has a backhand, a forehand and a smash.

title: J. B. Tropp Weds Lauren M. Lublin
description: Lauren Michelle Lublin and Jonathan Bruce Tropp, 22-year-old graduates of Harvard University, were married yesterday at Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn. Cantor Jonathan Ben Gordon officiated.

title: Accounts
description: * Tristar Automotive Group, New Rochelle, N.Y., to North Castle Partners, Stamford, Conn., to advertise its 10 automobile dealerships, with a budget if $3 million to $4 million.

title: HIGH TOLL FEARED IN THAMES SINKING
description: For more than 100 young people enjoying a summer night's boat party on the Thames, the dancing and chatting turned to a desperate struggle for survival early today when their pleasure vessel was sunk by a barge while cruising off central London.

title: Valvano as Sports Impresario
description: HARD to believe, but a newly released book - ''Personal Fouls'' by Peter Golenbock - a book with binding and a hard cover and actual print and pagination from 1 through 311 has come out and attempts to portray the unthinkable, the virtually unutterable, the resoundingly outrageous:

title: Now, Soft Grounders
description: Depending on the point of view, a new commercial initiative can be seen either as a magnanimous gesture aimed at curbing a cruel tradition and preventing rampant brain damage among American youngsters, or as a sinister plot designed to sabotage their proper development, rob them of their birthright and turn them into a bunch of spineless softies too timid to handle a hot one.

title: Poll Finds Women's Gains Have Taken Personal Toll
description: Over the last 20 years, the women's movement has transformed the American workplace. In increasing numbers, women are on the job in the offices of corporate law firms and the shuttles in outer space. Not just working; they are giving orders on factory floors and on the drill fields of West Point.

title: Finance Experts Help To Sell Off America
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe Beaten By Lendl in Final
description: Ivan Lendl used masterful shot-making today to score a lopsided 6-1, 6-3 victory over John McEnroe and win the Player's International Canadian Open tournament.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Bush's Vacation: No Maine Carnival
description: Things haven't gotten out of hand - yet.

title: SEARCHING FOR THE HOLY GRAIL AT AN ADULT HEALING CAMP
description: Like modern-day knights of the Round Table, a band of adults came here on a recent weekend in search of the Holy Grail. But instead of riding mighty steeds, carrying lances and wearing armor, they arrived in station wagons and Jeeps, donned jeans and carried knapsacks and notebooks.

title: Foley Shows He Is Speaker for Both Washingtons
description: Representative Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, leader of the Democrats, point man on issues from the Federal deficit to the bailout of the savings and loan industry, partook of watermelon, coffee and cookies on the Schwerin farm the other night.

title: Good Translation Might Have Prevented Hiroshima; Truman Was Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Row Takes On a Higher Profile
description: It was an unfamiliar sight: a Southern Governor commuting the death sentence of a man he believed to be guilty.

title: EASTERN PILOTS ARE REBUFFED ON A NATIONWIDE WALKOUT
description: Unionized pilots of Eastern Airlines were set back twice late Friday night, as the executive board of the Air Line Pilots Association refused to call for a national work stoppage in support of their walkout and declined to allow the pilots to keep their seniority if they move to other carriers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8 Hard bargaining on Poland's Cabinet appears to be beginning. The Solidarity leader designated to be Prime Minister said he would consider giving the Communist Party more cabinet seats. Page A1

description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 20, 1989: MONDAY BancFlorida Finl Corp First Instst Chem Waste Mgmt Inc Standard Prods Co Crane Co TUESDAY Century Tel Enterp Inc Kellwood Inc EDO Corp TambrandsInc Gannett Inc Tucson Elec Pwr Co Gap Inc Westvaco Inc WEDNESDAY Belding Hemingway Inc Scana Corp Bowater Inc Square D Co First Va Bks Inc Unionfed Finl Corp Northern Pwr Co Minn Wolverine World Wide Inc Penn Pwr & Lt Co Wrigley WM Jr Co THURSDAY Amcast Indl Corp Interlake Corp Amrican Med Intl Inc Laclede Gas Co Arvin Inds Inc Raymond James Finl Inc Carsn Pirie Scot&Co New FRIDAY Dexter Corp Piedmont Nat Ga Inc Edwards A G Inc Scottys Inc Harris Corp Del Uslico Corp Huffy Corp

title: New York City Striving to Achieve Full Access for the Disabled; Law's Premise
description: To the Editor:

title: Symbol of Unity Is Returned To Indians After 101 Years
description: A sacred pole topped with a human scalp was returned to the Omaha Indians today after being in a Massachusetts museum for 101 years.

title: Miss Davidson, Lawyer, Marries
description: Christine Bruce Davidson, an associate at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, and Robert Jay Goldstein, a third-year student at the Brooklyn Law School, were married yesterday at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass. Rabbi Allen Press and Canon Jonathan Young, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Tangier Journal; As in Old Days, the Jet Set Comes In for a Landing
description: As police sirens led air-conditioned buses and dark-windowed limousines through the streets of Tangier on Saturday night, few people here seemed to care whether the big bash at the palace on the hill was a real birthday party or simply a huge marketing extravaganza.

title: 'SENSE OF MUSCLE' FOR BLACK JOURNALISTS
description: Amid the lavish receptions and feverish recruiting at the convention of the National Association of Black Journalists, there was a feeling that the group has come of age as an institution of power and confidence.

title: Review/Theater; A Serial Killer With a Grudge Against Performers
description: Remember those M-G-M musicals in which Mickey Rooney and Judy Garland found love, happiness and a Broadway or Hollywood future by putting on a show in a barn? Actually several of those movies starred Gene Kelly and Judy Garland, but the spirit was similarly ingenuous and in the end show business conquered all.

title: Photo of construction in San Pedro de Alcantara (NYT/Alan Riding INTERNATIONAL REPORT; SPAIN FAILS TO PROTECT ITS COAST
description: Conservationists were hopeful and developers fearful in July 1988 when the Government enacted a law intended to reverse the chaotic urbanization that has scarred much of Spain's coastline in the last 25 years.

title: Fed Not Expected to Lower Rates
description: Credit market analysts say the Federal Reserve Board is not at all likely to push interest rates lower in the near future, despite exhortations from the Administration to do so.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Namibia General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION, SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M., 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Resolution Trust Names Director for Southwest
description: LEAD: The Resolution Trust Corporation, the new agency managed primarily by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that will conduct the sale and liquidation of the nation's weakest savings institutions, has named Carmen J. Sullivan director of its Southwest region, which includes Texas and Oklahoma.

title: Review/Dance; Into the Woods with Wind and Rain in 'Touch'
description: Artistry, weather and the environment all came together to make a spellbinding event at Wave Hill in the Riverdale section of the Bronx early Saturday evening, when Forti and Troupe presented the world premiere of Simone Forti's ''Touch.''

title: Telephone Strikers in West Reach Tentative Agreement
description: Striking telephone workers in California and Nevada tentatively agreed today to return to work, and a union spokeswoman said they could be back on the job by the end of the week.

title: New York Minstrelsy and a Film That Captured It
description: As an independent film maker scrambling for contributions, Karen Goodman felt a certain kinship, she says, with the street performers in her documentary ''No Applause, Just Throw Money.''

title: Power Chief Sees Gain For His Nuclear Plants
description: Donald Mazur says he did not know which mountain to climb first in 1983 after the Washington Public Power Supply System, of which he is managing director, defaulted on $2.25 billion in bonds on two canceled nuclear plants.

title: The Hush in Moscow; Gorbachev Accepts Poland's New Reality, But Not Without a Few Discreet Warnings
description: The Kremlin's pregnant silence these days, as Poland prepares to install its first non-Communist government since the early postwar years, is widely taken for tacit acceptance of the new Polish reality.

title: NBC JOINS GROUP W TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM
description: NBC and Group W announced Friday that their stations were jointly developing a weekday, hourlong entertainment and news program.

title: Homeless Man's Death Leads to Two Arrests
description: Two teen-agers have been arrested in the death of a homeless man who was electrocuted earlier this month after four youths accosted him in an Upper West Side subway station, the police said yesterday.

title: BOOK CLUBS ARE DEVELOPING MORE TITLES ON THEIR OWN
description: Even though more than 50,000 new books are published each year, they are not enough to feed the insatiable appetites of the large book clubs. So, more than ever, the clubs are now originating their own book titles.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., named Jeffrey W. Dentz executive vice president of store operations, a new position.

title: Justice Dept. Investigating 1,000 H.U.D. Cases
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Justice Department was investigating about 1,000 cases of possible wrongdoing at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Ronald Reagan's Administration.

title: Convicted N.A.A.C.P. Leader Is Re-elected
description: A longtime leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who was convicted on Federal extortion charges in 1988 won re-election Saturday to head the Alabama chapter of the civil rights group.

title: Market Place; Branching Out From Auto Parts
description: Among the host of companies looking to cash in on the renewed emphasis on environmental issues, the SPX Corporation is in a fairly unusual situation.

title: Nets to Name Fitch
description: The Nets have scheduled a news conference for this afternoon at which they are expected to name Bill Fitch their head coach.

title: Good Translation Might Have Prevented Hiroshima
description: To the Editor:

title: Libyan Accord By Husky Oil
description: Husky Oil Ltd. and two partners have signed an agreement with Libya to share oil production. The three, including OMV

title: Insurance for Long Term Protection?
description: LEAD: Representative Claude Pepper had a dream.

title: Ellen Rubinstein, A Chemist, Weds
description: Ellen Robin Rubinstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob K. Rubinstein of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Ernest Paul Guenzburger, a son of Mrs. Heinz Guenzburger of Toms River, N.J., and the late Mr. Guenzburger. Cantor Daniel Greene performed the ceremony at the Tarrytown (N.Y.) House, a conference center.

title: POLICE TACTICS ANGER NEW JERSEY BOATERS
description: Captain Peter Pawlikowski has plied the Navesink River for more than 20 years and knows its shallow, fast-moving waters as well as any sailor. So when he was ticketed by the state marine police in June for speeding, he suspected that something was not right.

title: William Hunt In Court Filing
description: William Herbert Hunt, a former billionaire, has filed a reorganization plan in bankruptcy court that would pay less than half of the $300 million in back taxes the Government says he owes.

title: Canseco Given Another Ticket
description: Jose Canseco was cited Saturday for darkened windows on his Porsche, not carrying a driver's license and having no proof of auto insurance.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NEW POLISH LEADER WEIGHS INCREASING COMMUNIST POSTS
description: The Solidarity leader designated to be Poland's Prime Minister said today that he would consider giving the Communist Party more high-level Government posts than envisioned earlier, as the two sides appeared headed toward a period of hard bargaining on the new Cabinet.

title: Easy Goer Facing Date-Book Problem
description: Easy Goer's victory in the $1,088,500 Travers Stakes at Saratoga on Saturday was a lot easier than the decisions his handlers face as they plot his fall campaign.

title: JAPAN GROUPS SEEK REPEAL OF SALES TAX
description: After Japan's political leadership won passage of a 3 percent sales tax last year, it seemed that Parliament had written the final chapter in a battle raging for more than a decade. Little did anyone here expect a tax revolt.

title: Orioles Top Jays To Keep Slim Lead
description: The Orioles, who have been in first place since May 26, maintained a half-game lead over the Brewers in the American League East by defeating the Toronto Blue Jays, 7-2, today.

title: Lauren Tarshis Weds Hillel Katzeff
description: Lauren K. Tarshis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julius Tarshis of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Hillel T. Katzeff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Katzeff of Cape Town. Rabbi Raphael Butler officiated at the Water Club in New York.

title: Vermont Journal; 2 Poets (and Art) Survive Storm Over Frost's Title
description: Miriam Herwig says she has no quarrel with Galway Kinnell, the man or the poet.

title: People
description: Frank Assumma and J. Edmund Keating have been appointed executive vice presidents of Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: Gray Areas For the Silver And Black
description: THE young man stepped out of his white Camaro, which was stuffed with his belongings. He stood squinting under the brilliant sunlight here last week outside the Los Angeles Raiders' training camp, where cool weather and distant, awesome mountains form an appeasing setting. At first glance, all here appears serene, but even the vistor knew of the Raiders' turmoil.

title: Asher/Gould Selected By Baskin-Robbins
description: Baskin-Robbins U.S.A., the ice cream store chain, on Friday selected Asher/Gould Advertising in Los Angeles as its agency. Asher/Gould was chosen after a two-month review that, in the end, also included the Los Angeles offices of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS; N. W. Ayer, Admarketing Inc., and J. Walter Thompson, the incumbent.

title: Eight-Year-Old Boy Is Shot By His Brother by Accident
description: An eight-year-old boy was accidentally shot and killed yesterday by his 14-year-old brother while playing with a gun in the apartment of a family friend in the Melrose section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: KOCH FACES 2 OPPONENTS IN LAST DEBATE
description: In his last scheduled joint appearance with his Democratic opponents, Mayor Edward I. Koch discounted the two candidates he debated yesterday, Harrison J. Goldin and Richard Ravitch. Instead, Mr. Koch insisted that the race for the nomination was between himself and the man who was not there, David N. Dinkins.

title: Good Translation Might Have Prevented Hiroshima; Bloodless Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: M. E. Flatte Wed To Jennifer Kirsch
description: Jennifer Beatrice Kirsch, a third-year rabbinical student at the Hebrew Union College in Los Angeles, and Michael Edward Flatte, a doctoral candidate in physics at the University of California at Santa Barbara, were married yesterday at Temple Emeth in Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Louis J. Sigel and Cantor Annie Lynn Bornstein officiated.

title: Scholar Thinks a Neglected Poem Was Written by a Doleful Dante
description: A scholar here believes that a long and pessimistic poem about the untrustworthiness of mankind is very likely a previously unrecognized work by Dante Alighieri, the 14th-century author of ''The Divine Comedy.''

title: Investment in Egypt
description: Egypt attracted the most private Arab investment of any Arab nation last year, according to a report issued by the Arab Investment Guarantee Organization. An article about the report was carried by the Emirates News Agency on Thursday. The report said Tunisia, Morocco, Algeria and the United Arab Emirates followed as markets for such investments, estimated at a total of $232 million. The report said Arab investments in Egypt rose 63.7 percent in 1988, compared with 1987.

title: Campaign Matters; Is 'Liberal' A Dirty Word In New York?
description: Last year it took Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential candidate, months before he would admit to being a ''liberal,'' proving just how dirty the ''L-word'' had become in national politics.

title: Rutledge Helps Giants Rout Chiefs, 45-7
description: Almost everything was great for the Giants tonight as they overran the Chiefs, 45-7, in a preseason game.

title: Longstreet, Hitler and Chiang
description: In the South during World War II, a wistful Confederate joke went like this: ''If Longstreet had come up in time at Gettysburg, there wouldn't have been no Hitler.'' In a letter to The Times published Aug. 13, Nicholas C. Cummins of West Chester, Pa., similarly invoked the distant past to damn the inconvenient present.

title: Review/Theater; 'Titus Andronicus,' Grisly Stew
description: The first sight to greet the audience at the Central Park ''Titus Andronicus'' is a small, flaming barbecue grill propped up on a slender tripod at center stage. ''Titus Andronicus'' is a revenge-begets-revenge tragedy of rape, dismemberment and decapitations whose body count runs so high even scholars don't always jibe on the final tally. It ends with a cannibalistic feast in which a mother unwittingly eats a pie containing the innards of her sons. So why are we greeted by a wimpy barbecue that is less evocative of the barbarous human stew of Shakespeare's ancient Rome than of last weekend's hot-dogs-and-marshmallows cookout in Great Neck? The answer arrives soon enough. What the New York Shakespeare Festival has decided to present is a genteel ''Titus Andronicus,'' which is kind of like doing ''The Texas Chain Saw Massacre'' without the chain saw or ''Sweeney Todd'' with an electric razor. Not particularly heartfelt or grotesque or long (the text is butchered more persuasively than the play's victims), this is a ''Titus'' that serves little purpose beyond filling another slot in the Shakespeare marathon and reconvening the increasingly numbing debate about the marathon's purpose and direction. It's a routine sandal-and-toga recital of an early, infelicitously written work that, more than its betters in the canon, demands extravagant imagination and passion to rouse audiences.

title: THE BASIC SPEECH: HOUSING, SCHOOLS AND CRIME
description: LEAD: Candidates seeking to become mayor of New York City make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech,'' which summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Outdoors: In August, Cast a Wide Seine
description: THIS is the time of year when I am persuaded to pursue easily gathered aquatic quarry: steamer clams, mussels or quahogs rather than striped bass or bluefish; tautog, sand eels or blue claw crabs rather than trout.

title: Pretoria Cracks Down on Defiance Campaign
description: South African authorities stifled a plan by anti-apartheid groups to resume open political activities today in defiance of restrictions imposed on them under a continuing state of emergency.

title: Colombia Arrests 10,000 After Slaying
description: The police and military authorities rounded up nearly 10,000 people in a nationwide search for drug traffickers suspected in the slaying of a presidential candidate, officials said today.

title: Graf Provides A Double Treat
description: It was not a day of formidable opponents or close matches for Steffi Graf. Her remarkable ability seemed to dwarf the portable stadium at Ramapo College, built for the United Jersey Bank Tennis Classic.

title: Jets Defeat Eagles, But Ryan Is Injured
description: The Jets' quarterback situation worsened tonight when Pat Ryan, the back-up, suffered a sprained knee in an exhibiton game against the Philadelphia Eagles that will keep him out for from six to eight weeks. The loss of Ryan marred the Jets' 19-10 victory.

title: Aouita Sets Mark For 3,000 Meters
description: Said Aouita of Morocco broke the oldest world record in a major running event today, clocking 7 minutes 29.45 seconds for the men's 3,000 meters at the Weltklasse meet.

title: Trade Deficit Wider in China
description: Soaring imports contributed to a $3.8 billion deficit in trade and tourism for China last year, official reports said Friday. The State Administration of

title: The Power Of the Sound Of Speech
description: IN a dark and smoky chamber two floors above 10th Avenue and 56th Street, Tony Schwartz roosts behind a music stand, a solo performer in New York's oddest cabaret act. A master of political advertising, Mr. Schwartz ignores the grand piano to his right, playing instead a small tape recorder as he sings the body electronic.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING Four Americans Set Marks: Janet Evans, Mike Barrowman, Dave Wharton and Tom Jager of the United States raced to world records yesterday in the Pan Pacific championships in Tokyo. It was the first time in modern swimming history that American swimmers had set four world records in one day, United States team officials said.

title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs
description: Drug testing of transportation workers is an increasingly popular idea, but programs to begin the testing are moving at a crawl.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Oughts, Naughts, Zeros and Ohs
description: The pace quickens. The millennium won't come for 10-plus years but ever more people are drawn to the challenge of naming the first decade of the 21st century.

title: Books of The Times; A Stroll, American Style, Through Italy's Heritage
description: America's Rome Vol. I: Classical Rome Vol. II: Catholic and Contemporary Rome By William L. Vance 454 pages; 498 pages. Illustrated. Yale University Press. $30 each. Emerson in Italy Text by Evelyn Barish Photographs by Evelyn Hofer. 116 pages. Henry Holt. $45.

title: Iranian Parliament Delays Showdown Over Hard-Liner
description: Iran's Parliament delayed a showdown today over the rejection of a leading anti-Western minister from the new President's Cabinet, but the hard-liners won a skirmish by voting down a motion to impeach a another minister.

title: New York City Striving to Achieve Full Access for the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: China Halts Payments
description: China has delayed payment of interest and principal on some loans from Japanese banks, a leading financial newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday misstated the position of the American Anthropological Association on returning bones and other relics from museums to Indian tribes. The Association, most of whose members are cultural anthropologists who do not work with physical materials, has designated a commission to recommend a policy position for adoption at its annual meeting in November, 1990.

title: Andrew Feldstein And Jane Veron, Students, Married
description: Jane Elizabeth Veron, who is to start studies at Harvard University next month for a joint M.B.A. and law degree, and Andrew Todd Feldstein, a second-year law student at Harvard, were married yesterday. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated at Stouffer's Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: F.B.I. Only After the Facts in Bloch Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Report Due on Japan Openness
description: After a year of modest concessions by the Japanese Government and a difficult operating environment in Tokyo that has made profits scarce, the Wall Street firms and members of Congress who had vigorously fought to pry open Japan's financial markets have backed away from their demands.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday about health care and the strike at the Nynex Corporation referred incorrectly to a contract offer by the company, which is proposing payroll deductions to help cover premium costs. In the first year of a new contract, the proposed deduction would be $10.27 weekly, not monthly. In addition, the company proposed the establishment of a ''preferred provider'' network that would cover mental-health care, not visits to hospitals or doctors.

title: Angola Says Rebels Are Mounting New Attacks, Jeopardizing Pact
description: The guerrilla forces led by Jonas Savimbi have mounted a major offensive here, according to a high Angolan Government official. The offensive, the official indicated, has jeopardized a cease-fire agreement between Angola and the rebels.

title: 3d VICTIM DIES IN AN EXPLOSION OF A STEAM PIPE
description: A third person died yesterday from injuries caused by an underground steam-pipe explosion that rocked the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan on Saturday night, causing millions of dollars in property damage.

title: Shaping the Foreign Aid Hulk
description: When famine strikes abroad, American purses fly open at ''Live Aid'' concerts. Now many of the same citizens are asking why U.S. foreign aid can't do more to end global poverty as well as serve U.S. national interests. This has spurred useful reform proposals for what is likely to be Congress's first formal foreign aid bill since 1985.

title: 5 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week consists of bills and notes. Today the Government will hold its regular sale of three- and six-month bills. The sale of two-year notes will be tomorrow.

title: INSIDE
description: Resort Adjusts to Fame While things haven't yet gotten out of hand in Kennebunkport, Me., being a vacation home for a President can have its tacky aspects. Some think these ''George and Barbara'' slippers are among them. Page A12. New Threat by Captors Against U.S. Hostages A pro-Iranian group threatened American hostages in a demand that Washington press France to recall ships headed to Lebanon. Page A8. Roundup in Colombia Nearly 10,000 people were arrested as the Colombian authorities sought the killers of a presidential candidate who was slain on Friday. Page A3.

title: Lorimar and Disney Suits
description: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation and the Walt Disney Company exchanged multimillion-dollar lawsuits on Thursday, each accusing the other of violating an agreement to jointly operate the Metrocolor film processing laboratory.

title: Review/Television; TV News in Schools and the Missing Alternative
description: There are two main differences between ''CNN Newsroom,'' Turner Broadcasting's daily 15-minute current affairs program for junior high and high schools, which made its debut last week, and ''Channel One,'' the offering from Whittle Communications, which had a tryout in six schools last spring. One is that ''CNN Newsroom'' carries no commercials, while every edition of ''Channel One'' contains two minutes of advertising. The Whittle effort is frankly for profit, from advertisers, some of which goes to pay for video equipment that is given without cost to schools that carry its 12-minute daily program. The provision of the television hardware is the other big difference. Whittle hopes to have 8,000 schools signed up by March, when ''Channel One'' begins in earnest. Turner estimates ''Newsroom'' will reach 1,000 schools at the beginning of the approaching school year.

title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP
description: In an auditorium in the Bronx one recent evening, the air was sour, the acoustics were abominable and the crowd was small and sleepy.

title: IN BROOKLYN, 3 FIGHT TO BE PROSECUTOR
description: By the end of last week Charles J. Hynes had already given out 15,000 miniature sewing kits and 3,000 boxes of cookies, each kit and box carrying a message asking people to vote for him. Norman Rosen had given out 8,000 ballpoint pens, 6,000 emery boards and 4,000 pocket combs, asking voters to support him. And while Daniel L. Feldman has not given out election mementos, his supporters have mailed about 140,000 pieces of campaign literature.

title: ...And a Chinese Scientist's
description: I didn't get your letter of June 9 until about 20 days after. I thought of answering your letter sooner, but I didn't feel like picking up my pen because I have been in low spirits.

title: Europeans Unite to Compete With Japan and U.S.
description: Governments and companies across Europe are teaming up on a large and fast-growing number of projects aimed at making Europe a more formidable competitor for the United States and Japan.

title: Japanese Put Up $100 Million To Back Films in Hollywood
description: In the most striking example yet of Japan's growing financial interest in the American motion picture business, a leading Japanese consumer electronics company has agreed to provide a Hollywood producer with more than $100 million to make films.

title: The Chinese Ambassador's Version . . .
description: LEAD: The world has been watching closely the unfolding of events in China in recent months and the unfortunate trends in China-U.S. relations. The inevitable questions on everyone's minds are: What happened in China? And, as a result, where are China-U.S. relations headed?

title: Piniella Rejected Steinbrenner Offer
description: Before he named Bucky Dent manager of the Yankees on Friday, George Steinbrenner wanted to create Lou Piniella III.

title: Tatars Speak Tatar
description: To the Editor:

title: Slam by Riles Rallies Giants
description: Ernest Riles hit a grand slam with two out in the ninth inning today, rallying the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Tax Watch; How I.R.S. Taxes Employee Benefits
description: EMPLOYERS who would like to do a little something extra for their employees - say, a bouquet of flowers for someone who is ill or a Labor Day picnic for the staff - may do so without incurring any tax liability, under final regulations on the taxation of fringe benefits recently issued by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: KEY RULING ON 'BASKET' SECURITIES
description: A Federal appeals court panel has ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission was wrong in deciding that a new type of financial instrument traded on three exchanges was a security, not a futures contract.

title: KOCH WILL REQUEST MITCHELL-LAMA SITE BE KEPT TAX EXEMPT
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and city housing officials said yesterday that they would ask the Board of Estimate to approve a real-estate tax exemption for the Kings Bay 1 apartment complex, a Mitchell-Lama development in Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay section.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
What 4 Pros' Defeats Show About Coping With Pressure
description: LEAD: WHEN Mike Reid's 10-foot birdie putt slid past the final hole of the P.G.A. championship, an unfortunate grand slam was completed. Reid lost the P.G.A. in August, just as Greg Norman had lost the British Open in July, as Tom Kite had kicked away the United States Open in June, as Scott Hoch had three-putted the Masters in April.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Forgotten Plath, Remembered
description: Sylvia Plath, a suicide at 30 in 1963, is the subject of several biographies - most recently, Anne Stevenson's ''Bitter Fame'' - and will doubtless be the subject of more. So complicated a character, it seems, invites continual reinterpretation. As Michiko Kakutani said in her New York Times review of the Stevenson book, the poet ''has been dismissed as a case study in female neurosis and Freudian guilt, held up as a victim of a male-dominated society, enshrined as a tragic heroine . . . explicated as a symbol of contemporary angst.''

title: From Betsy to Clunker, 1 in 9 Iowans Name Their Cars
description: The Iowa Poll, known in the past for probing respondents' expectations of going to heaven or hell, their attitude toward baldness and their favorite cold drinks, has done it again: it has found that one out of every nine Iowans names his or her car.

title: Former Congressman Gives Himself $345,000
description: Five months after he retired from a 16-year career in the House of Representatives, Gene Taylor of Missouri reached into his old campaign account and took home $345,000.

title: Polish Army: Enigma in the Soviet Alliance
description: Soviet and other Warsaw Pact military leaders are keeping close watch on the developments in Poland because of its military importance to the East bloc.

title: Kroger Denies Accusation That Juice Was Adulterated
description: The Kroger Company, one of the nation's largest supermarket chains, denied an accusation made in a television report tonight that it knowingly sold adulterated orange juice produced by a Chicago company.

title: France Says It Plans No Military Role in Lebanon
description: France sought to assure Lebanese Muslims today that it had no plans for military intervention in the strife-torn country, and emphasized that the decision to send warships toward Lebanon was only a precautionary measure.

title: A Plan to Save Iguanas, and the Rain Forests in the Bargain
description: DESPITE their forbidding appearance, iguanas have been hunted as a delicacy in Latin America for thousands of years. But the herbivorous lizards have become one more victim of the deforestation and overpopulation that are ravaging the region's rain forests.

title: Fabri-Centers of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Polish Expatriates Torn by 2 Dreams
description: Along the tree-lined streets and in the small shops and simple brick houses of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, Polish-born storekeepers and residents debated the triumph of the Solidarity union, the merits of the man who will be Poland's Prime Minister and the chances for freedom in a new Poland.

title: Tech Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FITCH IS PICKED TO COACH THE NETS AND BRINGS A WINNING RESUME
description: Wearing a Boston Celtic championship ring on one hand and a smile, Bill Fitch today was named the Nets' head coach.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball CHICAGO (AL) - Recalled Sammy Sosa, outfielder, from Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. CLEVELAND (AL) - Placed Scott Bailes, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list, retroactive to Aug. 13. YANKEES (AL) - Announced that Dave LaPoint, pitcher, had undergone shoulder surgery and would be lost for the rest of the season. CHICAGO (NL) - Optioned Paul Kilgus and Jeff Pico, pitchers, to Iowa of the American Association. Recalled Joe Kraemer and Dean Wilkins, pitchers, from Iowa. Basketball MINNESOTA (NBA) - Signed Gary Leonard, center, to a three-year contract. NETS (NBA) - Named Bill Fitch head coach. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Signed Kevin Holmes, forward, to a one-year contract. Football ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Joel Williams, linebacker, to a series of two one-year contracts. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Released Charles Buchanan, linebacker. DENVER (AFC) - Traded Bill Contz, offensive tackle, to the Indianapolis Colts for an undisclosed conditional draft choice. Waived Kerry Goode and Reggie Ware, running backs, and Corris Ervin and Daniel Hunter, defensive backs. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Released Doug Hudson, quarterback. MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Tom Toth, guard. Waived Ricardo Cartwright, wide receiver, and Travis Simpson, center. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Waived Henry Brown, defensive lineman, and Will Johnson, linebacker.
