Signed Morten Andersen, place kicker, to a four-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Reached contract agreement with Reggie White, defensive end. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Signed Wayne Davis, cornerback, to a one-year contract. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Waived Erick Harrison and Bobby Bankston, wide receivers, and Albert Thomas, defensive back. Hockey ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Signed Richard Pion and Michel Mongeau, forwards. WASHINGTON (NHL) - Signed Kent Paynter, defenseman. Soccer CLEVELAND (MISL) - Signed Michael King, midfielder, to a one-year contract. Colleges ARIZONA STATE - Named Denise Gaztambide assistant track and field coach. Suspended Leland Adams and Lynn James, wide receivers, for violating team policy. CLARION - Named Gie Parsons women's head basketball coach. MERCY - Named Steve Balsan sports information director and assistant athletic director. PRINCETON - Named David Metzbower assistant lacrosse coach. ST. FRANCIS, Pa. - Named Mike Bollinger running backs coach; Michael Dalli defensive backs coach; Audie Nelson quarterbacks coach; Andy Paronish linebacker coach, and Joe Lombardi assistant head basketball coach. Announced the resignation of Tim Bowman, men's track coach.

title: Leland's Body to Come Home
description: The bodies of Representative Mickey Leland of Texas and eight other Americans killed in a plane crash in Ethiopia on Aug. 7 will arrive in the United States on Wednesday, Ethiopian and American officials said today. Mr. Leland and 15 others, including 7 Ethiopians, died when the plane taking them to a refugee camp hit a cliff in bad weather.

title: British Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; results have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.55 to the pound, for both 1989 and 1988, the rate prevailing on June 30, 1989, the last date of the reporting period. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents ten shares of British Telecom ordinary stock.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Chess
description: There never was a more casual player than Anatoly Karpov, the 38-year-old former world champion from the Soviet Union. While everyone else burns the midnight oil in the frantic search for the opening novelty that will turn the game to his advantage, Karpov seems most of the time to be totally unconcerned about whether he achieves any opening superiority or not.

title: Turkey Closing Borders to Refugees From Bulgaria
description: In an important policy reversal, Turkey announced today that it was closing its borders to restrict the recent exodus of ethnic Turks who have fled Bulgaria saying they are the victims of religious and ethnic repression.

title: Dean Buying Cates
description: The Dean Foods Company, the second-largest dairy company in the country, has agreed to acquire a pickle maker for about $29 million in stock. Dean Foods, based in Franklin Park, Ill., said it would exchange 865,000 shares of its stock for all the shares of Charles F. Cates & Sons Inc., a privately held pickle processor based in Faison, N.C. Cates, reported $84 million in sales for its most recent fiscal year, mostly in the East and Southeast. Dean Foods had $1.68 billion in sales for its fiscal year ended May 28, 1989. Cates, Charles F.

title: Ethel Danzig, Justice, 58
description: Ethel Danzig, a New York State Supreme Court Justice, died of colon cancer Sunday at New York Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bayou Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'
description: When a deranged man brandished a knife on Fifth Avenue at 45th Street one recent Monday, a man in blue quickly responded. Over the next 48 hours he helped subdue two more disorderly people, one of them half naked, quelled a robbery, witnessed a drug deal, chased a street peddler and called in two fires.

title: Poseidon Pools reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ENERGY TEAM LEAVES KIDDER
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company lost three of its nine investment bankers specializing in energy to the First Boston Corporation yesterday. William J. Kimmel, who had been the head of Kidder's natural resources group, joined First Boston as a managing director. William M. Wicker, who specializes in the refining, marketing and oil field services industries, was named a First Boston director and Carl H. Rudnick, who worked in Kidder's oil and gas area, was named a vice president.

title: DEFENSE AGAINST CHIEFS DISPLEASES GIANTS
description: In many respects, the Giants' performance Sunday night against the Chiefs in Kansas City was overwhelming.

title: 'Plaff' Wins Festival Latino Film Award
description: ''Plaff,'' a 1988 film by the Cuban director Juan Carlos Tabio, won the best feature film award at the Festival Latino at the Public Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival, it was announced Saturday night.

title: DARLING AND METS DISMISS A MEMORY
description: The Mets shook off the memory of Willie Randolph and his shattering home run and rebounded with flourishes last night as Ron Darling pitched them to a 4-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants, the team most likely to surface in the West in the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday showing the yield on tax-exempt bonds misstated the yields for two types of bonds. The average yield on 20 general obligation bonds was 7.09 percent; the average yield on 25 revenue bonds was 7.39 percent.

title: In Men's Wear, The 1990's Have Arrived
description: American men's wear designers showed their first styles for the 1990's last week, and while much of the high glamour of women's fashion shows was absent, there was plenty of glitz, perhaps too much for the average man. One designer even showed plunging necklines on the runway, a kind of mohair chest look. No one panted.

title: Ravitch Tries to Hearten Supporters
description: ''Look,'' said the woman to Richard Ravitch, candidate for mayor of New York City. ''I like you. I don't want Koch to get in, but I'm afraid a vote for you would be a vote for Dinkins.''

title: Perfection vs. Cleaner Air
description: Nobody expected industry to love President Bush's clean air bill. It will cause great aggravation and cost billions. What's far more surprising is the passionate complaining of the environmentalists, who seek a more perfect bill. Yet especially in Congress, perfection has a way of becoming the enemy of the good.

title: Plessey Acts Against Bid
description: Plessey P.L.C., the British military contractor, urged shareholders today to reject a hostile takeover offer from the General Electric Company of Britain and Siemens A.G. of West Germany. The offer values Plessey at $:2 billion, or $3.15 billion, a price that Plessey said was too low.

title: Justice O'Connor Halts Lucky Stores Merger
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the United States Supreme Court issued a last-minute order today blocking the $2.5 billion merger of Lucky Stores Inc. of Dublin, Calif., and the American Stores Company of Salt Lake City at least until October.

title: Linda L. Van Voorhis, A Poet, Is Dead at 87
description: Linda Lyon Van Voorhis, a poet, died Sunday at her home in Irondequoit in suburban Rochester. She was 87 years old.

title: By Design; Straddling Seasons
description: Summer is nearly over, but there is still the big Labor Day weekend and its farewell-to-summer parties to think about. At this time of year, you have to think about what to wear that is neither too summery nor too autumnal.

title: A Dinosaur and Its Head
description: THE American Museum of Natural History has unveiled an exhibition announcing to visitors that the wrong skull has adorned its brontosaur for the last 84 years, but that the skull will stay right where it is.

title: Tandy's Posts Flat Earnings
description: The Tandy Corporation, a leading consumer-electronics manufacturer, today reported virtually flat earnings for the fourth quarter and only a 2.2 percent gain for the 1989 fiscal year.

title: People
description: * Dominick F. Rossi Jr., executive vice president and director of national operations at N. W. Ayer, has been appointed to the additional post of president of the agency's Middle Western division.

title: Beneath the Streets, Steam Pipes Give No Hint of Impending Disaster
description: In contrast to the city's network of electric cables and transformers, where a sudden jump in temperature can be a tip-off to trouble, the pipes carrying high-pressure steam beneath the streets of Manhattan give no clues of a catastrophe in the making, Con Edison officials said yesterday.

title: Whittaker Selling Chemical Coatings
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Chemical Coatings Group for an undisclosed amount to the Sherwin-Williams Company, a Cleveland-based manufacturer of paints and building materials.

title: Honecker Has Operation
description: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, has undergone surgery to remove gallstones and is recovering in the hospital, the East German press agency A.D.N. reported today. It said that Mr. Honecker, who will be 77 years old on Friday, had the operation last week.

title: GOODEN IS BACK AT 'SPRING TRAINING'
description: Three days after his latest medical scan, the Mets gave a guarded report on Dwight Gooden yesterday, saying that the tear in his right shoulder showed ''marked improvement.''

title: Chemical Leaman reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a charge of $1,472,347 from an accounting change.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up 14.4% on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered rose 14.4 percent in the four-week period ended Aug. 15.

title: Kohl Replaces Party Official After Losses to the Far Right
description: With general elections a year away, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is replacing a longtime leader of his conservative political party after severe losses to the far right in elections this year.

title: Gas Canister Mailed To the N.A.A.C.P. In Atlanta Goes Off
description: A gas canister in a parcel detonated at the regional office of the N.A.A.C.P. when the package was opened today, injuring 15 people.

title: BEHIND UNION'S REBUFF TO THE PILOTS AT EASTERN
description: In refusing to allow pilots honoring a strike at Eastern Airlines to transfer their seniority to other airlines, the Air Line Pilots Association is holding fast to a rule that protects the interests of most of its members.

title: Iran Will Turn to the West, in Time
description: LEAD: The list of 22 cabinet nominees submitted to Iran's Parliament by President Hashemi Rafsanjani is noteworthy for the absence of two names: the previous Interior Minister, Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, and the former Prime Minister, Mir Hussein Moussavi. Both figures are known for their support of radical economic policies at home and hostility toward the United States.

title: EX-POSTMASTER, WILLIAM BOLGER, IS DEAD AT 66
description: William F. Bolger, the nation's Postmaster General from 1978 to 1984, died yesterday at Arlington Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Springfield, Va.

title: Patterns
description: Zoli South

title: Moscow Circus Tour Includes 26 U.S. Cities
description: With all the promotional eclat of the old-fashioned American three-ring circus, the one-ring Moscow Circus announced yesterday the details of its tour of 26 American cities starting in November. The circus is to play Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan for a whole month beginning Jan. 10.

title: Open the Golden Door
description: To the Editor:

title: What I Meant to Say . . .
description: MANY, if not most, word-processing programs include spelling checkers and thesauruses or have provisions for adding them. These can be extremely helpful. Even good spellers make typographical errors, and even facile writers are occasionally at a loss for words.

title: Officer Kills Man in Brooklyn
description: A gunman was shot and killed by an undercover narcotics officer yesterday after the man fired four shots in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, the police said. At 5:30 P.M. officers from the Brooklyn North Narcotics Unit pulled up in their unmarked car in front of 378 Greene Avenue and saw a man with a gun shooting at an unknown target, said Officer Edward Feeney, a police spokesman. As the officers got out of their car, the gunman fled into the building. The officers ran after him. The man aimed his gun at them and one officer fired one shot, striking the suspect in the chest, Officer Feeney said. The unidentified man was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: In China, the Purge Is Still Going On
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Offers A Housing Plan To Lower Costs
description: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan proposed yesterday that developers of commercial property be required to build or help finance housing affordable to low- and middle-income tenants.

title: Warhol Museum Planned in Pittsburgh
description: Negotiations are under way to open an Andy Warhol museum near downtown Pittsburgh, the city where Mr. Warhol was born and reared.

title: UEBERROTH GROUP TO BUY HAWAIIAN AIR
description: A group including Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner whose deal to acquire Eastern Airlines collapsed earlier this year, has agreed to acquire control of the financially troubled Hawaiian Airlines.

title: Animal-Rights Suits Opening Up Research Panels
description: The State University at Stony Brook caught the attention of animal-rights advocates in 1987, when someone distributed a three-year-old videotape of a student's experiment on predatory behavior in which a ferret slowly killed a rabbit and several rats.

title: Utility Executive Ready To Roll Up His Sleeves
description: On election night in November, a power failure blacked out The Idaho Statesman newspaper office in Boise, which had been serving as the headquarters for reporting the state's computerized election returns. Joseph W. Marshall, then the Idaho Power Company's executive vice president, went to the scene to help workers restore electricity.

title: Put Pact Into Effect, Budget Chief Warns Congress
description: Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that unless Congress puts into effect the bipartisan agreement reached in April, the Government faces cuts in military and domestic spending of $16.2 billion for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

title: NOW, IT'S REMEMBER THE OIL BUST!
description: There is yet another myth in the making here in Texas.

title: Clubs Back Drug-Fighter Gun Permit
description: A few days after his wife was fatally shot through the window of their Brooklyn apartment, Carlos Hernandez received a condolence call from Gerald Preiser of the Federation of New York State Rifle and Pistol Clubs.

title: Breakwaters Can Help Control Beach Erosion
description: To the Editor:

title: SNAGS ON ERNST TIES ARE REPORTED
description: Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young, two large accounting firms that are already operating jointly in the United States as Ernst & Young, are having trouble lining up the approval for their merger in Canada and in Japan, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Decades Of Historic Falsehood
description: The existence of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is based on historic falsehoods. So is the Warsaw Pact.

title: Struggle for Work and Family Fueling Women's Movement
description: Despite much talk about the decline of feminism and the women's movement, American women very much want a movement working on their behalf as they try to win equal treatment in the workplace and to balance the demands of work and family.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Ease
description: Prices of most Treasury maturities eased yesterday after the Federal Reserve moved to bolster interest rates in midmorning. Before then, dealers said, prices had trended higher largely on scattered buying by overseas investors and a firmer dollar. Stock traders rushed to sell equities in response to the threat of higher interest rates, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 40.97 points at an even 2,647.00.

title: Phone Strike Is Concluded For California and Nevada
description: Striking telephone workers in California and Nevada returned to work today after a tentative three-year contract agreement was reached, offering modest wage increases and health-care cost controls.

title: Accounts
description: * General Motors Corp.'s Oldsmobile division to Leo Burnett, for its ''owner loyalty'' direct-marketing program.

title: Rohr Chairman Plans to Retire
description: Rohr Industries, a maker of aircraft components based in Chula Vista, Calif., said yesterday that Harry W. Todd, its chairman and chief executive for nine years, would retire on Jan. 1. Mr. Todd, who is 67 years old, planned for several months to step down, the company said. Mr. Todd will be replaced by

title: Pacific National Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Our Towns; Vietnam Veteran Moves the Wall Across the Land
description: When John Devitt first saw the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington in 1982, he expected to hate it, or worse, to feel nothing. ''I'd read about it,'' he said. ''It's a gravestone. That's the way I felt about it before I walked up to it. It was black, it was in the ground, it wasn't designed by a Vietnam vet. Symbolically, I didn't like it.

title: A Critic Gets Forceful Responses
description: Many advertising and marketing executives and professors responded forcefully to an interview in this column earlier this month in which John Philip Jones, the chairman of the advertising department at Syracuse University's Newhouse School of Communications, questioned some of the foundations of the advertising industry.

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Block New Medicaid Limits
description: A lawsuit seeking to prevent New York State from limiting the number of visits by Medicaid recipients to physicians and medical laboratories was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Doubts Raised About a Heart Attack Treatment
description: SODIUM bicarbonate, routinely given to heart attack patients for more than 60 years, may do more harm than good, researchers at the University of California at San Francisco say.

title: Death in Gramercy Park
description: It's become the standard sequel to New York City tragedies. The street barricades go up, the crowds gather and the police urge the curious onlookers to ''Keep moving . . . Nothing to see . . . Nothing to see.'' In truth, there is always something to see, as the mind's eye imagines what time or the weather or an ambulance have already erased. And at Gramercy Park, even on Monday morning, there was still very much to see.

title: Grow Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After income from discontinued operations of $3.5 million and $6,289,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $568,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter included additional IRS after-tax interest expense of $2.3 million.

title: Witness Says The Helmsleys Overpaid Tax
description: The last witness in the Leona Helmsley trial, a tax expert, testified yesterday that Mrs. Helmsley and her husband had overpaid $591,000 on their Federal income tax returns from 1983 to 1985, the period in which the Government contends the couple evaded $1.2 million in Federal income taxes.

title: PRIME COMPUTER TAKEOVER IS SEEN NEAR COMPLETION
description: After a nine-month struggle to elude a hostile tender offer from MAI Basic Four Inc., Prime Computer and J. H. Whitney & Company are expected to announce today the completion of a $1.13 billion takeover bid, analysts said.

title: Profile of Neptune's Main Moon: Small, Bright, Cold, and It's Pink
description: Voyager 2 sharpened its aim on Neptune and its major moon today as scientists reported a quickening tempo of discoveries.

title: Review/Pop; Theatrical Images Invoked By an English Band, the The
description: Matt Johnson, the singer and songwriter who is the creative center of the English band the The, is a musician obsessed with big issues. On the band's newest album, ''Mind Bomb,'' most of the songs have a do-or-die urgency as they grapple with love, politics and religion.

title: A Promotion at ABC
description: Marvin F. Goldsmith has been pushed even further into the front lines of network television's battle for advertiser awareness with his promotion, announced yesterday, to senior vice president and general sales manager for the ABC Television Network Group. In the new position, Mr. Goldsmith, a 16-year veteran of ABC, will be responsible for advertising sales for the network's prime-time programming. George Cain will replace Mr. Goldsmith as senior vice president and national sales manager in charge of the network's news, sports and daytime sales.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Namibia. General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA PREPARATORY COMMISSION - PLENARY - 10 A.M. LAW OF THE SEA PREPARATORY COMMISSION - SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M., 3 P.M. and 3:30 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 Colombia seized 134 aircraft suspected of belonging to drug traffickers and captured a top figure in the Medellin drug cartel, police officials said. Page A1

title: New Service For Subways On West Side
description: A new subway service - the No. 9 train - made its debut yesterday on the West Side of Manhattan. And for awhile, even a subway train was confused.

title: Constitutionality of Legal Services Program Not a Trivial Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Prizes for Ideas on Ruble
description: If anyone has a better idea for easing the Soviet Union's transition to a convertible currency the Soviet-American Exchange Program of California's Esalen Institute wants to hear about it. And if the institute likes what it hears, it will pay $25,000 for a share of the glory.

title: In Battling Dengue Fever Mosquitos, Expert Enlists Public's Assistance
description: THE Government's chief expert on dengue fever has warned that the public must take a more active role in eradicating mosquitos to curb the spread of the infection.

title: Review/Opera; Daunting Proposition for 'Don Giovanni'
description: The New York City Opera's second cast for its new ''Don Giovanni'' production took the stage Sunday afternoon with mixed results.

title: SEES SHIITE PLOT
description: The Egyptian authorities say they have arrested 41 people believed to be members of what they call a clandestine Shiite Muslim movement whose members trained in Iran and Syria to attack American and Israeli targets and overthrow the pro-Western Government of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Why Insiders Are Mourning DeFrancis
description: The death Saturday of Frank J. DeFrancis at the age of 62 was appropriately noted at the beginning of ABC-TV's national telecast of the Travers Stakes. But because DeFrancis was merely named and not further identified, many in the viewing audience probably did not know who he was or why racing insiders were mourning his death.

title: Shermag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $85,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Self Magazine's Editor in Chief Resigns
description: Anthea Disney, who gave Self magazine a dramatically more sophisticated appearance after becoming its editor in chief in July 1988, is leaving the life-style publication.

title: Steel Output Off 2.1%
description: Domestic raw steel production in the week ended Aug. 19 totaled 1,773,000 tons, down 2.1 percent from the previous week, when the industry produced 1,811,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. Steelmakers operated at 79.8 percent of their production capacity last week, down from 81.5 percent the previous week, the steel institute said. A year earlier, the industry produced 1,836,000 tons, or 86.1 percent of capacity.

title: General Nutrition Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 22
description: Latest quarter and 6 months included a gain of $704,000 from sale of company's mail order unit on March 16.

title: Westward Tide of East Germans Is a Popular No-Confidence Vote
description: Sitting on a bench in the sunny main courtyard of the central reception camp for East German immigrants in this quiet town north of Frankfurt, the East German did not look like someone about to begin a new life.

title: Insurers to Set Aside Money
description: Two California insurance companies said today that they would set aside provisions against earnings in case they are required to return money to customers to comply with Proposition 103, a state ballot initiative that called for 20 percent insurance rate rollbacks.

title: Hunslet Acquires Hungarian Unit
description: The British engineering company Hunslet Holdings P.L.C. bought a 51 percent stake in the railroad car manufacturing division of Ganz Mavag of Hungary. Edward Duke, the chief executive of Hunslet, said the acquisition, worth $:12 million, or about $18.8 million, was ''a natural marriage.''

title: Toshiba To Buiild Big TV's in U.S.
description: Toshiba Display Devices yesterday became the first television manufacturers to make ''super size'' television screens in the United States. Several other companies also have plans to make the large sets in American plants.

title: Dennis Resigns Seat at F.C.C.
description: Patricia Diaz Dennis said today that she would resign her seat at the Federal Communications Commission on Sept. 30 to return to private law practice.

title: YANKEES EDGE BOSTON FOR DENT'S FIRST VICTORY
description: About three hours before last night's game, Jesse Barfield walked into Yankee Stadium and was welcomed by about 100 fans lined up at the players' entrance, seeking autographs. Barfield stopped, signed as many as he could, then went inside and gave his fans something else to remember him by.

title: TOYOTA LEXUS LURES BUYERS FROM CADILLAC AND LINCOLN
description: Sales of the Lexus luxury cars from Japan appear to be off to a fast start, and one surprise is that the cars are stealing buyers from the increasingly costly top of Detroit's line, not just from Mercedes-Benz and BMW.

title: Video-Audio Sony Camera
description: The Sony Corporation has introduced an electronic still video camera for consumers that also records audio, a spokesman said today.

title: KEY RATES
Bridge
description: This column receives hundreds of letters from readers who are proud of their skill in playing the dummy. But when two letters arrive about the play of the same deal, one from the dummy and one from a defender, it is time to pay attention. The diagramed deal was played July 10 in the Monday night team game at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan. It was reported by Leonard Harmon, who sat North, and Jack Sonnenblick, who sat East. Both were impressed by the play of Andrew Arkin as South.

title: Pittsburgh Journal; Changed City Is Trying To Save Steel Heritage
description: In this city that was once the heart of the steel industry, the reminders of that heritage are abundant, from the Steelers football team to Iron City beer. But steelmaking has declined dramatically in Pittsburgh, and some organizations, local businesses and historians are working to preserve the history before the wrecking ball demolishes what is left of the idled mills.

title: A Japanese Print Ad From Ammirati & Puris
description: Ammirati & Puris this week takes its first step toward becoming an international advertising agency -without leaving New York. On behalf of W. L. Landau's Ethan Allen furniture stores in River Edge, N.J., and Hartsdale, N.Y., the agency has created a print ad, entirely in Japanese, aimed at attracting Japanese customers living in the New York area. The ad begins this Thursday and will run every Thursday through Sept. 28 in The New York Times.

title: Radio System Uses Fiery Meteor Trails to Transmit Data
description: FROM remote valleys in China to the wind-blasted plateaus of Antarctica, engineers have begun to exploit the blazing trails left by meteors to relay messages reliably over great distances.

title: Soviet Official Asserts Czech Invasion Was Required at the Time
description: The Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 must be seen in the political context of the time, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Ross Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Market Place; A Ticking Clock Is B.A.T.'s Ally
description: SIR JAMES GOLDSMITH is getting no respect. Arbitragers fear he will lose in his no-money-down effort to buy B.A.T. Industries, and B.A.T. seems to think it can fight off the bid without doing much of anything except extolling its own accomplishments.

title: Review/Art; Jean Fautrier, France's Caustic Outsider
description: Jean Fautrier, who is being honored by a long-awaited retrospective at the Musee d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, is a peculiar case. From time to time, both during his life and after his death in 1964 at the age of 66, he has been almost a cult figure in France. His World War II ''Hostages'' - patches and clots of matter suggesting stumpy, maimed bodies that almost seem to have been shot at the canvas - drew the attention of eminent French writers like Andre Malraux and Francis Ponge.

title: Officer's Son Denies Charges
description: Richard E. Corcoran Jr., the 19-year-old son of a Glen Ridge, N.J., police lieutenant and one of seven teen-agers accused of sexually assaulting a slightly retarded 17-year-old girl on March 1, pleaded not guilty today at his arraignment. Mr. Corcoran, who was released on $2,500 bail, entered his plea at a five-minute proceeding before Judge Michael J. Degnan of New Jersey Superior Court. After the arraignment, the suspect's father, Richard E. Corcoran Sr., who is also chief of detectives in Glen Ridge, posted the bail.

title: INSIDE
description: Bakker Trial Begins Jury selection was completed today in the trial of the former television evangelist Jim Bakker on fraud and conspiracy charges. Page A14. Crowding in Intensive Care Intensive care units in hospitals are overflowing and are shortchanging the people they were intended to serve. Science Times, page C1. Change in Animal Rights Animal-rights advocates are using freedom-of-information laws to force public universities to disclose details of proposed experiments. Page B1. Remember the Alamo! For many Texans, the economic troubles of recent years in their state have become the latest source of myth-making. Page D1.

title: JETS LOOK FOR BACKUP QUARTERBACK
description: Coach Joe Walton began the task of planning a Jets' football team without Pat Ryan today.

title: George Adamson, Lions' Protector, Is Shot Dead by Bandits in Kenya
description: George Adamson, protector of lions and their environment, was killed here on Sunday in an ambush a few miles from his isolated camp in northern Kenya, officials said today.

title: JOHN D. SIMPSON, A FORMER LEADER IN TRANSIT AGENCIES, IS DEAD AT 52
description: John Duncan Simpson, former executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and former president of the New York City Transit Authority, died of cancer yesterday at Hoag Hospital in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 52 years old and lived in Laguna Hills, Calif.

title: Met Pro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Corrections
description: An article and a chronology on Friday about the history of Communism in Poland misstated the date for a provisional government in Chelm. It was proclaimed on July 22, 1944.

title: Integra-A Hotel & Restaurant Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $45,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-Included a loss of $212,000 for the quarter and income of $1,195,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: EDITOR, 97, HELPED START YIDDISH DAILY
description: Paul Novick, a founder and longtime editor in chief of The Morning Freiheit, a left-wing Yiddish daily, died yesterday of congestive heart failure and kidney deficiency at Peekskill (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 97 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Croton-on-Hudson.

title: Mustang Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies Lyphomed said that Fujisawa Pharmaceutical, a leading Japanese drug concern, had made an acquisition offer that valued the company at almost $1 billion. Lyphomed, a generic drug company, was purchased for $2.7 million in 1981. [ Page D1. ] A group including Peter Ueberroth, whose deal to buy Eastern Airlines collapsed earlier this year, has agreed to acquire control of another financially troubled carrier, Hawaiian Airlines. [ D1. ] In deciding not to let Eastern pilots transfer their seniority, the pilots' union held fast to a rule that protects most of its members. [ D2. ] B.A.T. Industries began its formal defense against an unfriendly $21 billion takeover bid by an investor group led by Sir James Goldsmith, calling the offer an attempt at ''asset stripping'' and saying the investor group was made up of ''destroyers.'' [ D1. ] Toyota's Lexus luxury cars appear to be off to a fast start, and surprisingly they are stealing buyers from the increasingly costly top of Detroit's line, not just from Mercedes and BMW. [ D1. ] Toshiba Display Devices began making ''super size'' TV screens in the United States, the first of a series of Japanese and European manufacturers to do so. [ D4. ] Prime Computer and J. H. Whitney are expected to announce the completion of a $1.13 billion takeover bid. Prime struggled for months to elude a hostile offer from MAI Basic Four. [ D4. ] Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young are having trouble lining up approval for their merger in Canada and in Japan, industry sources said. A spokesman for the firm, which has already merged in the U.S., denied the reports. [ D6. ] The merger of Lucky and American Stores was blocked at the last minute by Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. [ D4. ] Kroger denied a report by CBS News that it knowingly sold adulterated orange juice produced by a Chicago company. [ D4. ] Wang Laboratories said it had agreed on a new debt package with its banks and would immediately make some payments. [ D4. ] The Economy

title: Texfi Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the effect on its 1989 results of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 96 prior to its mandatory adoption is to reduce income taxes by a credit of $1,102,000 and $3,233,000 for the 3 months and 9 months ended July 28, respectively. Simiarly, income taxes for 1988 have been reduced by $1,252,000 and $3,149,000 for the 3 months and 9 months ended July 29, 1988, respectively. Previously, the tax benefit resulting from utilization of prior years' operating losses was reported as an extraordinary credit.

title: First American Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's obvious that public opinion in Colombia is outraged, and the executive branch there is intent on doing something.'' - Melvyn Levitsky, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters. [ A11:2. ]

title: 32 Alligators Shot and Killed On Lake Okeechobee's Shore
description: Thirty-two alligators were killed and left to rot on the shore of Lake Okeechobee in what may have been an effort for revenge against a game officer, wildlife officials said today.

title: Japan Is Said To Be Richest
description: Japan became the world's richest nation on paper in 1987, surpassing the United States in national assets for the first time with $43.7 trillion worth of land, factories, stocks and other wealth, a leading Japanese newspaper said today.

title: Affectionate or Aloof, Tame or Wild, The Enigmatic Cat Yields Its Secrets
description: THE inscrutability of the cat, long a creature of mystery to humans, is slowly yielding to a vigorous new effort among scientists to fathom this wildest and most independent of domestic animals.

title: ECONOMIST PICKED TO HEAD MEDICARE
description: Dr. Gail R. Wilensky, a health economist who conducted a Federal study that found that the Government spent the same amount on health care for the rich as for the poor, has been selected to administer the $130 billion Medicare and Medicaid programs, agency officials said.

title: Addenda
description: * Art Direction magazine will sponsor Ad Directions '89, a conference for visual arts professionals, in New York from Sept. 26 to 28.

title: ORIOLES TOP BREWERS TO STRETCH LEAD TO 1 1/2
description: The Baltimore Orioles held onto first place in a head-to-head confrontation for the second straight day, beating the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-0, tonight as Stan Jefferson and Cal Ripken hit homers to support Jeff Ballard's seven-hit pitching.

title: Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Income-Tax Case
description: A criminal lawyer who has defended major narcotics dealers in a number of noted cases pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he failed to file tax returns and pay his taxes for several years.

title: Tandy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Northwest Pilots
description: Northwest Airlines' pilots have ratified a tentative contract with the airline. The vote ratification ends two-and-a-half years of bargaining by the airline company, which is being taken private by Wings Holdings and the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: First Lady Is to Leave Maine To Have an Eye Examination
description: Barbara Bush will return to Washington Tuesday for ''a routine eye checkup'' related to her thyroid condition, the White House announced today.

title: 'Wanderers' Author in New Book Deal
description: Richard Price, the novelist and screenplay writer, has signed an agreement with Houghton Mifflin Company for his first novel in five years, a spokesman for the publisher said today.

title: 2 Years After Fall of PTL Empire, Bakker Trial Begins
description: Two years after his religious empire collapsed in sex and financial scandals, Jim Bakker returned here today to stand trial on fraud and conspiracy charges.

title: DOW TUMBLES 40.97 POINTS, TO 2,647
description: Stock prices took their biggest tumble in almost two months yesterday as late program trading and weak bond prices combined to batter the market.

title: Attack on Fruit Flies Is Begun
description: A batch of sterile Mediterranean fruit flies was released from the air and from trucks in the center of Los Angeles today in an attempt to wipe out the crop-destroying pest, which was recently found in Elysian Park. In the next two months, 300 million sterile flies will be released over a 60-square-mile area. The operation will cost $1 million, said Leon Spaugy, Los Angeles County Agricultural Commissioner.

title: TWO MEN CHARGED IN KIDNAPPING PLOT
description: Two Virginia men have been arrested in an apparent conspiracy to kidnap a boy who was to be sexually abused and murdered in the filming of a pornographic movie, Federal officials said today.

title: Goldin School Plan Would Cut 1,000 Board Jobs
description: Harrison J. Goldin called yesterday for eliminating 1,000 jobs on the New York City Board of Education's administrative staff as part of an education-improvement plan. He also called for higher pay for teachers who work in less desirable schools, dropout prevention programs in all elementary schools and increased autonomy for principals.

title: Chancellor Quits Post at N.C. State
description: The chancellor of North Carolina State University resigned today, the first official to step down since accusations were made against the school's basketball program in the recently published book ''Personal Fouls.''

title: Hoesch Purchase
description: Hoesch A.G., the steel and engineering company, said it had taken over Schroff G.m.b.H,, a privately owned West German electronics company. Terms were not disclosed. A Hoesch statement said Schroff specializes in making electronic instruments for the engineering industry. Founded in 1960, the company employs around 1,200 and has third-party sales of about $111.9 million. Hoesch said the acquisition strengthened its electronics business, enabling it to produce complete systems in the automation-technology field.

title: American Pioneer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included tax credits of $12,000 and $23,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said in both the year- ago quarter and 6-month periods there were no share earnings because preferred stock requirements exceeded net income.

title: Amway Halts Animal Tests
description: The Amway Corporation has switched from animal tests to test tubes in its studies on new products but says it may use animals if ordered to do so by the Government.

title: Entertainment Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $835,000 for the latest year and $900,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Jerseyan Who Survived Crash Of Airliner Dies in Hospital
description: Harlon (Gerry) Dobson, a retired New Jersey state trooper who was injured in the crash of United Airlines Flight 232 in June, died Saturday at the Crozier Chester Medical Center here. He was 44 years old.

title: Brascade Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is owned 70 percent by Brascan Ltd. and 30 percent by Caisse De Depot Et Placement Du Quebec. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Diplomacy
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, comes back to haunt the Bush Administration this week as the Organization of American States wrestles again with the question of his ouster.

title: Engineered Support Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 9-month included a $500,000 gain related to the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: With 2 Leaders Quitting, U. of Maryland Is Shaken
description: The abrupt resignation last week of the president-designate of the Baltimore campus of the University of Maryland, five months before he was to take office, has sent shock waves through one of the nation's largest public university systems.

title: Vietnamese Author Who Advocated Ties With Hanoi Is Shot
description: A Vietnamese author who told interviewers three years ago about threats on his life was wounded seriously over the weekend by two men who opened fire on him as he walked near his home.

title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR
description: When he was playing tennis, Bjorn Borg was known for never showing emotion on the court and rarely revealing any off it. Yet even now, seven years after he stopped playing the professional circuit, the man from Sweden who was the world's No. 1 player from 1978 to 1980 and a five-time Wimbledon champion continues to intrigue tennis fans: they follow every report of his behavior, from a mysterious alleged suicide attempt to assorted romantic difficulties to the recent financial troubles of his designer clothing line.

title: Talking Business with Habakuk of Estonia; Estonian Quest For Joint Ventures
description: Estonia, a small and relatively wealthy part of the Soviet Union, is eager to take advantage of the plan endorsed late last month by the Soviet legislature, the Supreme Soviet, to develop market-oriented economies in Estonia and Lithuania independent of the central plan that now governs almost every aspect of Soviet business.

title: Catfish Farms Raise Output
description: Catfish farmers continue to increase production, but their harvests are bringing lower prices than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Freshman Legislator Girds for Bruising Campaign
description: After the salmon balls and the cheese and crackers, after the citrus punch and the easy conversation, after all the amenities of a political fund-raiser, Representative Jolene Unsoeld got down to business.

title: Pansophic Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Carriage Industries Inc reports earnings for 13wks to July 2
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ameritech Bell Group, Chicago, named Ramon L. Humke president of Ameritech Services, Bruce R. DeMaeyer president of Ameritech Mobile Communications and Richard C. Notebaert president of Indiana Bell.

title: Basic Ravitch Speech: Using Talent for Change
description: New York City's mayoral candidates make dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often they use a ''basic speech,'' which varies little from one occasion to the next.

title: B.A.T. TELLS WHY IT RESISTS BID
description: With ''Batman'' T-shirts, ''no deal'' buttons and a strong six-month earnings report, B.A.T. Industries today began its formal defense against an unfriendly $21 billion takeover bid by an investor group led by Sir James Goldsmith.

title: Careers; Recruiters' Trade Group Is Revitalized
description: SEVERAL years ago, Russell Reynolds Associates Inc., a management recruiting firm, joined several large management recruiters to form a professional group called the Executive Search Council. The idea was that because these firms were large and focused on high-salaried jobs, their interests differed from those of the many smaller recruiting firms that belonged to the Association of Executive Search Consultants.

title: FEARS OF RECESSION ARE FADING
description: In early summer, each new economic sounding pointed to feebler growth and perhaps a not-too-distant recession. Now, however, those concerns have faded.

title: Streak Ends For Walton
description: Jerome Walton's hitting streak ended at 30 games tonight and the Cincinnati Reds scored the tie-breaking run in the 10th inning on a throwing error by the third baseman Domingo Ramos for a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Koch Calls for Report in Nazi Slogan Inquiry
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday asked the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Benito Romano, to release an internal report about an allegation that a concentration camp survivor had to face a Nazi slogan while being questioned in the prosecutor's office in 1986.

title: First Step Taken Toward Raising $1 Transit Fares
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority took the first step yesterday toward raising New York City's $1 subway and bus fare, an increase that the chairman of the state agency has said is all but inevitable.

title: Pe Ben Oilfield reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Crowding Causes Agonizing Crisis In Intensive Care
description: INTENSIVE care units across the country are overflowing, often crowded with hopeless patients who will derive no long-term benefit from their stays while shortchanging the people they were intended to serve, critically ill patients who need temporary support to survive a medical crisis.

title: LaPoint Out for Season
description: Dave LaPoint, the left-handed Yankee pitcher, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair a small tear in his left rotator cuff and will miss the remainder of the season, the club announced yesterday.

title: John H. Heminway, Stockbroker, Dies at 75
description: John Hylan Heminway, a stockbroker in New York for more than 40 years, died Friday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Watch Hill, R.I.

title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure
description: While the Colombian Government has clashed with its drug barons before, Bush Administration officials say that the latest crackdown indicates deeply felt outrage in Bogota and, perhaps, a turning point.

title: Primary Colors
description: Q.Why do photographers talk about red, green and blue as the primary colors? A.There are really two kinds of primary colors, subtractive primaries and additive primaries.

title: Thinking of Cats as One 'Super Predator'
description: FOR the family of Peter B. Churcher, the first one downstairs on summer mornings faced an unpleasant chore: The early riser often had to clean up the remains of whatever prey the family cat had brought in overnight.

title: Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 14.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: The latest fourth quarter comprised 12 weeks, while the year-ago fourth quarter had 13 weeks. The latest fiscal year had 52 weeks, and the prior fiscal year 53 weeks. The company said the latest fourth quarter was helped by a year-end adjustment to reflect actual experience compared to the estimate of inflation used in the calculation of the LIFO inventories and the determination of income in the first three quarters of the year. The estimated annual inflation rate used in the calculation of LIFO inventories for the first three quarters of 1989 was about 3.8 percent, while for the full year the company had an inflation rate of about 2.7 percent. The latest fourth quarter was also helped by a change from a cumulative 1.0 percent used for the first three quarters to 0.8 percent for the full year. The fourth quarter earnings also reflected a change from an estimated effective tax rate of 33.2 percent to 32.0 percent for 1989 and 34.5 percent to 30.9 percent for 1988.

title: Obsession With Test Scores Distorts Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Watch; Soviet Fear of Inflation Brings Retreat on Plan to Free Ruble
description: Frustrated by chronic food shortages, Moscow has announced that it will pay foreign-currency bonuses to the most productive farms. But even as the Kremlin dangles Levi's and Sonys in front of Soviet farmers, it is shelving more ambitious plans to let free markets decide who may earn dollars and how they may be spent.

title: Republic Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Goldman, Sachs's Stake in Anchor
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has acquired a 9.7 percent stake in the Anchor Glass Container Corporation for investment purposes. Vitro S.A., a Mexican glass maker, has offered to buy Anchor Glass for $20 a share, or $280 million. The board of the Tampa, Fla., glass concern has urged its shareholders not to take any action until it studies the Vitro offer. It is expected to respond by Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday about the Yankee-Tiger game on Sunday misstated the number of innings pitched by the three Yankee starters against Detroit over the weekend. It was 10Y, not 20Y.

title: South Africa Rebel Blueprint Backed by Regional Leaders
description: The Organization of African Unity today endorsed the framework put forward by the African National Congress for negotiations and elections leading to majority rule in South Africa.

title: MAI Basic Has Deficit
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. today reported a loss of $46.2 million, citing its failed attempt to buy Prime Computer Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amerihost Properties Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., said its board had approved a reverse stock split in which shareholders would receive one share for each 50 shares.

title: Birth Control Wins An Ominous Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Cruise America
description: An investment group led by Interstate Properties Inc., a New Jersey development concern, and one of its general partners, Russell B. Wright Jr., has acquired a 6.1 percent stake in Cruise America Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Wright said he ''has had discussions with the management of the company concerning its prospects and plans to continue such discussions.'' Cruise America, based in Miami, rents and sell motor homes.

title: PEC Israel Economic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue figures for the year-ago 6 months have been reclassified. Provisions for income taxes in 1989 were $414,905 in the second quarter and $1,070,217 in the 6 months, and in 1988 were $853,992 in the second quarter and $1,956,343 in the 6 months.

title: LAM Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain from tax loss carryforwards of $50,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $219,000 for the year.

title: Ice and the Atmosphere
description: The advance and retreat of massive landscapes of ice, which has been repeated in cycles for eons, may be governed at least in part by the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmophere, researchers at the University of Chicago have reported.

title: LYPHOMED SOUGHT BY FUJISAWA
description: Lyphomed Inc., a generic drug company purchased for $2.7 million in 1981, said yesterday that it had received a takeover offer that valued the company at almost $1 billion from a major Japanese drug concern.

title: FED LETS JAPANESE FIRMS STAY AS PRIMARY DEALERS
description: The Federal Reserve Board voted, 5 to 1, yesterday to allow Japanese firms to continue operating as primary dealers in the Treasury securities markets, but said it would continue urging Japanese authorities to encourage more activity by foreign firms in Japan's markets.

title: G.M. to Shut 3 U.S. Plants
description: The General Motors Corporation has said it will shut three domestic plants that make light trucks for a week, beginning next Monday, laying off 7,200 people. The plants are in Pontiac, Mich., Moraine, Ohio, and Shreveport, La. General Motors has excessive inventories of these models.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft subsidiary of United Technologies said that Northwest Airlines had ordered 12 of its PW-4000 jet engines worth $162 million for six new Airbus Industrie A330's. Last February, Northwest became the first American carrier to buy A330's when it ordered 10 of the aircraft, also powered by PW-4000 engines. The latest order means Northwest has firm commitments to buy 16 A330's. The airline also has options on four more. Wings Holdingsd (northwest)

title: Strong Quakes in East Africa
description: Several strong earthquakes shook Ethiopia and caused some damage in neighboring Djibouti, officials reported today. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties in Ethiopia. The first temblor registered 6.4 on the Richter scale and occurred on Sunday aftrnoon 320 miles northeast of Addis Ababa and about 100 miles northwest of Djibouti.

title: New Life for an NBC Castoff As a New York Cable Staple
description: When NBC canceled ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd'' last summer, despite good ratings and almost universal praise from the critics, the show was snapped up by Lifetime Television, a young, New York-based cable network.

title: Canadian Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus declined to $127 million (Canadian) in June from a revised May surplus of $543 million, the Government agency Statistics Canada said last week. The surplus for May had originally been calculated at $394 million. The surplus in June 1988 was $1.39 billion. Exports in June 1989, seasonally adjusted, were $11.12 billion, down from $12.45 billion in May. Imports were $10.99 billion, down from $11.91 billion in May. The Canadian dollar is worth about 85 cents in United States currency.

title: WALESA CRITICIZES COMMUNIST DEMAND
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, today criticized Communist demands for more power in Poland's new coalition Government and warned that the party would have no political future if it chose a path of ''threats and blackmail.''

title: Brooklyn Candidate For District Attorney Knocked Off Ballot
description: A state judge yesterday removed Norman Rosen, one of three Democrats running for Brooklyn District Attorney, from the Sept. 12 primary ballot.

title: Faster Ways to Mix and Match Data
description: SEQUELS were in vogue this summer, not only in movie theaters but also in the software booths at the Macworld Exposition in Boston last week. Updated versions of many popular programs made their debuts at the show.

title: 2 Exchanges Curb Baskets
description: The Philadelphia and American stock exchanges limited trading today in their new ''stock basket'' products because of legal uncertainty over which Government agency should regulate them.

title: On Landing Like a Cat: It Is a Fact
description: EVERY year, scores of cats fall from open windows in New York City. From June 4 through Nov. 4, 1984, for instance, 132 such victims were admitted to the Animal Medical Center on 62d Street in Manhattan.

title: Plea Made in Rite Aid Case
description: The president of the Rite Aid Corporation pleaded not guilty on Friday to charges of bribing a member of the Ohio Pharmacy Board and of possessing criminal tools.

title: Obsession With Test Scores Distorts Education; Pay More, Get More
description: To the Editor:

title: The Black Poor Are Different
description: Of all the problems on the racial landscape, none seems harder than helping the people called the ''black underclass.'' Some conservatives argue against policies aimed at a specific race and instead for programs targeted at the poor generally. This view is erroneous.

title: AIDS Plan At Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. said today that it had raised $72.5 million through a private partnership to finance research, development and clinical trials of a potential therapy for AIDS.

title: Chip Manufacturer Links with A.T.&T
description: Terry Holdt's company, one of numerous semiconductor start-ups in California's Silicon Valley, emerged from obscurity yesterday.

title: Killing of Civilians Haunts Sri Lankan Village
description: This pretty, small fishing village on the northern tip of Sri Lanka is nearly deserted now, tense and fearful nearly three weeks after Indian soldiers are reported to have beaten and shot civilians after a group of soldiers was ambushed.

title: Critic's Notebook; Examining T. S. Eliot And Anti-Semitism: How Bad Was It?
description: In the wake of the centennial celebration of T. S. Eliot's birth, questions about the poet's anti-Semitism persist. The issue spawned a fierce controversy in England last year, when a British weekly, The Jewish Chronicle, questioned the participation of several prominent Jewish intellectuals in the creation of the T. S. Eliot Centenary Fund at the London Library. Now further questions have been raised by Christopher Ricks's new book, ''T. S. Eliot and Prejudice,'' which was recently excerpted in the Times Literary Supplement, where it led to a spirited exchange of letters. It is to be published next month by the University of California Press.

title: Integrated Computer Graphcs reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,329,942. c-Net income and after a loss of $699,056 from discontinued operations. In fiscal 1989 about $5,192,000 of receivables were written off. The company said that during fiscal 1989 several of its customers filed for bankruptcy or sharply curtailed their business activity resulting in losses of $2,486,000.

title: Citizens Union Backs Ravitch After Backing Koch 3 Times
description: Yes, there were politicians. Yes, there were reporters. And yes, they swarmed in front of City Hall. But yesterday's political endorsements by the Citizens Union of the City of New York also offered some surprises.

title: Artra Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $1,275,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and included losses from discontined operations of $1,387,000 and $1,642,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectivley.

title: Carolco Pictures reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the latest quarter it recognized $840,000 as its 55 percent share of income of Live Entertainment Inc. for the period. In the 1988 second quarter it recognized income of $829,000 from Live Entertainment.

title: Books of The Times; Drabble's Archetypes of the 80's
description: A Natural Curiosity By Margaret Drabble 309 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Plutocrats and Moralizers
description: Two extravaganzas this month, one on Long Island and one in Tangiers, have exposed two deep social nerves: the need of some rich people to sponsor opulent entertainments, and the need of the non-rich to recoil in disgust.

title: Once a City Kid
description: A 4 1/2-year-old Manhattan girl we know recently returned from a five-week vacation in the country with plenty to tell her city friends about the great outdoors beyond Central Park. And tell it she does, about the day she visited a horse farm and got to pet the newborn colts, about the blossoming tomato plant that somehow survived her generous watering. And, most enthusiastically, she tells of her sightings of ''wild'' animals: countless rabbits, a giant turtle, six deer, one raccoon, two skunks and two possum (one alive, and one dead, sadly, by the side of the road).

title: Walesa's Role: Kingmaker, Not King
description: It was Lech Walesa who decided last Wednesday, in the face of mounting political and economic chaos, to seize the moment and set in motion the process that would lead to the nomination of Eastern Europe's first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early postwar years.

title: Tainted Blood Ravaged Family, Marine Says
description: A marine whose wife and son died of AIDS testified today that Government doctors botched his wife's pregnancy and gave her an AIDS-tainted transfusion that ravaged his family.

title: Kompong Speu Journal; The Princess and 'the Peacock': A Cambodia Tale
description: ''I'm a museum piece in this country,'' said Lyda Sisowath, doing a sort of pirouette as she ministered to a war widow, offering mosquito netting and incense for the Buddha.

title: New York City's Water: Down the Drain
description: New York City is presiding over the slow but sure destruction of its drinking water supply, long touted as the highest quality of any city in the world.

title: Edythe Gilfond, Costume Designer, 79
description: Edythe Gilfond, a costume designer for dance companies, theater and television, died yesterday at her home in Southampton, L.I., after a long illness. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Gilfond, a native of Brooklyn, designed costumes for Martha Graham's dance company - including those for the world premiere of ''Serpent Heart'' (1946) and ''Deaths and Entrances'' (1953) - and for several television series, including ''As the World Turns'' and ''Edge of Night.''

title: JAMES TERRELL, STORE ARCHITECT, 45
description: James Terrell, an architect who developed designs for many of the nation's leading stores, including Saks Fifth Avenue, Macy's and Bloomingdale's in New York and Marshall Field in Chicago, died of AIDS at New York Hospital on Saturday. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SENTENCE POSTPONED
description: Luis Polonia, the outfielder for the Yankees, was convicted today of having sexual intercourse with an under-age girl, but the judge postponed sentencing until after the baseball season.

title: Judge Is Disciplined Over Punitive Jailing
description: A state conduct commission has disciplined a civil court judge from Brooklyn for throwing a suspected drug seller in jail because his lawyer didn't show up for a hearing.

title: Trooper Is Shot; 3 Are Questioned
description: A 25-year-old state trooper was shot and critically wounded on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday afternoon after halting a car with three men inside, the police said.

title: Ammirati Loses a Bit Of BMW
description: BMW OF NORTH AMERICA yesterday pulled a small portion of its prestigious advertising account from Ammirati & Puris, its sole agency since 1975, awarding the advertising for its motorcycle division to a tiny New York ad firm, Burkhardt & Christy.

title: Lowe's Cos reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Datelines; 19-Year-Old Seized In Fatality on I-91
description: 19-year-old Hartford man was arrested yesterday on charges that he drove a stolen car the wrong way on Interstate 91 last month and killed a Hartford woman in a head-on collision, the state police said.

title: United Iraq, Divided Iran
description: A year after their eight-year war ended in a cease-fire, Iran is preoccupied with its transition to a post-Khomeini era while Iraq displays increasing assertiveness in a region fearful of its ambitions.

title: Workingmens Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter results included an increase of $250,000 in the provision for possible loan losses by the corporation's subsidiary, Workingmens Co- Operative Bank.

title: Agitation by Farmers Is Challenging Gandhi
description: Indian farmers across the country's rich western and northern agricultural belts are asserting themselves with demands for better prices and a bigger say in their future under the leadership of two men who are trying to weld their supporters into powerful political constituencies.

title: The Blight of Black Racism
description: LEAD: Blacks in America justly condemn apartheid in South Africa and white racism in this country, yet many turn a blind eye to the equally repugnant phenomenon of black bigotry. Some even deny the existence of such a thing; others unwittingly condone it under the names of black power, black pride and black solidarity.

title: Kellwood Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dinkins Is Customizing His Stock Message
description: As David N. Dinkins left a mayoral forum at Co-op City in the Bronx Monday night to generally cordial applause, an elderly white woman stopped him to pay what, for her if not the gray-haired but vigorous candidate, might have been the ultimate compliment. ''You look great for 62,'' she shouted. But of the several dozen supporters who enthusiastically followed Mr. Dinkins out of the auditorium and down a flight of stairs to his car, many were young and, more significantly, most were black.

title: 3 Young Palestinians Killed In Unrest in Occupied Lands
description: Two young Palestinians died in violence in the occupied territories today, and a third died of a gunshot wound suffered in a clash with troops last week.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES DOWN 1.9% IN JULY
description: Orders to American factories for durable goods tumbled 1.9 percent in July to the lowest level in nine months, the Government said today. The report provides further evidence that the economy is weakening.

title: De Niro Is Trying Life Behind the Camera
description: When Robert De Niro appeared some years ago in the title role of ''The Last Tycoon,'' a role based on the life of the legendary Hollywood producer Irving Thalberg, he had no idea that by the time he turned 46 this year he would venture into the world of film production himself.

title: How to Select and Care for Peaches...and Where to Pick Your Own
description: PEACHES fall into two categories, white and yellow, with many varieties of each color. A ripe white peach will be creamy gold, while a ripe yellow peach will be a deep, rich yellow. Both may be blushed with red, but neither will be tinged with green when truly ripe. The flesh of a ripe peach will yield to slight pressure and be tantalizingly aromatic.

title: A Johnson Verdict
description: Ben Johnson, the suspended Canadian sprinter, received a conditional discharge and 12 months' probation yesterday for pointing a starter's pistol at a motorist in a traffic dispute last October. Johnson, who earlier pleaded not guilty to charges of common assault and possession of a dangerous weapon, agreed yesterday in Toronto to change his plea to guilty after the Crown dropped the weapons charge, and Judge Ian MacDonnell sentenced him on the assault charge.

title: The Pop Life
description: Minnelli Breaks Jinx Liza Minnelli, a singer who has never had a hit single on the pop charts, has finally broken the jinx with an innovative dance-pop recording of Stephen Sondheim's ''Losing My Mind,'' from the Broadway musical ''Follies.''

title: WINE TALK
description: CHATEAU HAUT-BRION was probably the first famous wine of Bordeaux to achieve success in the export market in the middle of the 17th century. Just when the first vineyards were planted there is unknown, but it must have been in Roman times.

title: EATING WELL
description: SWEET dreams of guilt-free ice cream binges and all the cream cheese you can eat danced in consumers' heads when the Nutrasweet Company and Procter & Gamble announced many months ago that they had discovered low-calorie fat substitutes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday, about a recording of conversations between an air traffic controller and the pilot of the jetliner that crashed last month in Sioux City, Iowa, misidentified the controller, who was shown listening as the tape was played. He is William Kevin Bachman.

title: Propane Tank Explosion Injures Two on L.I.
description: A 1,000-gallon propane tank exploded in a fireball today, injuring two people and burning out of control for three hours.

title: Bermuda Account
description: The Bermuda Department of Tourism yesterday left FCB/Leber Katz Partners, its agency for 17 years, and gave DDB Needham, New York, its advertising account, which is worth more than $10 million in annual billings. The agency review took several months, and in its final stages was rumored to include the then-incumbent, the new winner and the New York offices of Ogilvy & Mather and HDM.

title: INSTRUCTION COMES FIRST FOR BEGINNING HUNTERS
description: If you are planning this year to go hunting for the first time, you will have to complete a hunter education course successfully before you can purchase a license in all but 11 states.

title: But What Do You Really Think?
description: Ogden Phipps did not conserve his family wealth by being a sentimentalist, so maybe he was just using the press to send a message to some desert chieftain that Easy Goer's genes will not come cheap.

title: Beijing Journal; A Weekly Bath, and a Good Brain-Scrubbing Too
description: It is less verdant and spacious than Beijing University, and far more isolated and gloomy than Tiananmen Square: a guarded compound in the southwest part of the capital that may be the next home for many leaders of China's democracy movement.

title: Evert Saying Farewell
description: Chris Evert says she will retire from serious competition after this year's United States Open. ''No more 'maybes,' no more 'probablys,' '' Evert said in an article she wrote for the Aug. 28 issue of Sports Illustrated. ''The 1989 U.S. Open will be my final tournament.'' Evert, 34 years old, will still represent the United States in the Federation Cup in Tokyo in October. She and Martina Navratilova will play exhibition matches this fall and winter.(AP)

title: Form of Cortisone Prescribed For First Lady's Eye Ailment
description: Doctors today prescribed a daily treatment of a form of cortisone for Barbara Bush to help relieve nagging eye irritation caused by a thyroid ailment.

title: Help Colombia Fight Back, Now
description: A flyblown, ramshackle building, no more than a large lean-to, is home to the 10 men who defend a provincial air base of Colombia's anti-narcotics police. Their headquarters is a small, stifling office nearby. Their fuel depot consists of two dangerously exposed rubber bladders. But worst of all is the shortage of helicopters.

title: Hot as a Chili Pepper, Cool as a Coconut
description: AS interest in Thai cuisine grows, the ingredients necessary to produce it are becoming widely available. Fresh coriander, or cilantro, and ginger root, for example, have become staples in many supermarkets.

title: Westvaco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The declaration of the People's Assembly of 21 July 1940 on the entry of Lithuania into the U.S.S.R., and the law of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. of 3 August 1940 on the incorporation of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic into the U.S.S.R. are illegal.'' - Declaration by a commission of the Lithuanian Parliament. [ A5:1. ]

title: In Western Europe, Soft Applause for Poland
description: Western European nations are happy about the moves in Poland toward a Solidarity-led cabinet, but they are talking softly for fear of unsettling Poland or offending the Soviet Union.

title: Lord Hill, 85, Doctor And Ex-BBC Chairman
description: Lord Hill, a former chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation and a household name in World War II as the Radio Doctor, died today. He was 85 years old.

title: The Capital
description: Was there ever the remotest chance that American troops would be sent to Colombia to help in the ''war'' against its powerful drug cartels?

title: North Comes South for Barbecue Cookoff
description: What was the nice Brooklyn Heights dentist and his party of 11 family members and friends doing in this barbecue bastion? Why, drinking Lone Stars with the Texas ''bubbas'' and judging the 12th annual Taylor International Barbecue Cookoff. And, of course, cutting a wide barbecue-eating swath through the rest of central Texas.

title: Genisco Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $14,152 from use of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter and the 9 months included a tax credit of $86,587. c-Net loss

title: D'Amato Staff Aided Brother's Client
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's brother, Armand P. D'Amato, used the Senator's staff in an effort to obtain information for a client about a $100 million Navy contract, a former aide to the New York Senator said yesterday.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Position Is Filled At Prime Computer
description: LEAD: When the New York investment firm J.H. Whitney & Company concludes its acquisition of Prime Computer Inc. next month, a new president and chief executive will be installed at Prime. He is James F. McDonald, the former chairman, president and chief executive of Gould Inc.

title: Review/Pop; Brown and Gillespie Bring Festival Latino to a Finale
description: The annual closing event of the Festival Latino, a pan-American concert at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, became unexpectedly provincial this year when the State Department denied visas to a Cuban pianist, Gonzalo Rubalcaba, and his ensemble, Grupo Proyecto. As a result, the concert Monday night featured two New York groups, Roy Brown with his septet and the Dizzy Gillespie Quintet. Mr. Gillespie had been scheduled to play with the Cubans.

title: Review/Television; 'FM': The Scenes Behind What Is Heard
description: The basic elements of a durable comedy series - likeable people in lively situations getting lightly involved with one another - make up the staff of ''FM,'' NBC's new entry in the sitcom stakes. After a mildly promising preview last week, it returns tonight at 9:30 in what, the network hopes, will be its regular spot for the new season.

title: Dinkins Speech: Retaking the City
description: New York City's mayoral candidates make dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often they use a ''basic speech,'' which varies little from one occasion to the next.

title: Witness in Hastings Trial Is Ordered Jailed
description: A Federal District Court judge ordered the jailing of a disbarred lawyer today for refusing to answer questions from a Senate panel gathering evidence in the impeachment trial of Judge Alcee L. Hastings.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about James Terrell misattributed the 1979 design of the main floor of Bloomingdale's. Although Mr. Terrell designed projects for Bloomingdale's, the new main floor of the department store was designed by Barbara D'Arcy.

title: VENEZUELA SQUINTS WARILY AT FUTURE
description: Six months after the worst riots here in 30 years, President Carlos Andres Perez continues to push his free-market approach on a wary populace, pressing on largely alone.

title: Sigma Designs reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Theater; Comically Carrying Culture to the Colonies
description: With his gymnastic wit and droll body, Jim Dale places his signature on whatever character he chooses to play, as he demonstrates anew in the New York premiere of Peter Nichols's ''Privates on Parade.'' In the comedy, which opened last night at the Roundabout Theater Company, he is Acting Capt. Terri Dennis, a vaudevillian who specializes in female impersonation. It is an exceedingly flamboyant role that benefits from Mr. Dale's bold brand of clowning.

title: Developer Plans 52-Story Hotel Atop 2 Theaters
description: A 52-story hotel would rise over the Mark Hellinger and Neil Simon Theaters in midtown Manhattan and a large restaurant and catering hall on the Harlem Meer in Central Park would grow even larger under plans that are being reviewed by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Sea Containers Takeover Fight
description: Sea Containers Ltd. has asked the European Community's executive body to block a hostile $63-a-share takeover bid by Temple Holdings Ltd., contending that the offer would violate the community's competition laws. Sea Containers, a Bermuda-based cargo, ferry and port operations company, has rejected the Temple offer as inadequate and has hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to develop a restructuring plan as a defense.

title: Oxdon Drops Steinberg Bid
description: A Toronto company seeking control of Steinberg Inc., the Montreal grocery giant, today abandoned its five-month, $1.33 billion (Canadian) takeover bid after strong political pressure from the Quebec government. The move came after Oxdon

title: Kohl Names a New Manager Of Party for 1990 Elections
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl moved to tighten control over his Christian Democratic Union today by naming a new party manager in advance of elections next year.

title: UAL Holder Files Suit
description: A shareholder filed a lawsuit against the UAL Corporation today, seeking to compel the parent of United Airlines ''to bargain in good faith with all interested acquirers and auction UAL to the highest possible bidder.''

title: McCartney Is Planning Concerts in New York
description: Paul McCartney is to give his first New York concerts since 1976 at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 11, 12, 14 and 15. The performances are part of his world tour, scheduled to begin Sept. 26 in Oslo. The North American part of the tour is to begin on Nov. 23, Thanksgiving Day, in Los Angeles and will include concerts in Chicago, Montreal and Toronto.

title: Court Drops Contempt Case
description: The Delaware Supreme Court today dismissed contempt proceedings against Barbara Robbins, a partner with the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. The court said it was convinced she mistakenly released confidential documents to The New York Times concerning the Paramount Communications Inc. bid for Time Inc. The court chastised Herbert

title: Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
