description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $3,158,000 and $5,233,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, as well as an extraordinary charge of $2,993,000 for both periods. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $558,000 and $2,454,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: How Zia's Death Helped the U.S.
description: It's now generally suspected that the K.G.B. either had prior knowledge of, or actually planned, the Aug. 17, 1988, plane crash that killed Pakistan's President, Gen. Zia ul-Haq, most of his top generals, the U.S. Ambassador to Pakistan, Arnold Raphel, and an American military attache. What isn't so widely recognized, however, is how little the assassination has helped the Soviet Union. If anyone has benefited, it's the U.S. A report on the technical causes of the disaster by the Pakistan Government's Board of Inquiry - aided by six U.S. Air Force specialists - indicated that the crash was not an accident. Explosives were found in the wreckage, the investigators said, and the plane was likely brought down by the deliberate contamination of the main hydraulic system and its back-up, which would have made the plane almost impossible to control. The board concluded that ''the use of ultra-sophisticated techniques would necessitate the involvement of a specialist organization well versed with carrying out such tasks and possessing all the means and abilities for its execution.''

title: Book Notes
description: Malcolm vs. McGinniss

title: How Couriers Stitch The Rural Fabric
description: As a freelance writer and editor Allen Gilbert spends long hours alone, facing his word processor and his deadlines in a small, book-lined office in his house at the top of a steep, winding dirt road here, about 10 miles north of Montpelier. His wife is at work, his small son in child care.

title: Philips Selling Military Units
description: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics manufacturer, said today that it hoped to transfer major parts of its military activities to the French state-owned group Thomson-CSF by the end of this year.

title: On the West Side, Race For Council Is Crowded
description: It's not easy running for the City Council on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Foreign Students Find Abuses in Recruiting
description: As demand for foreign students continues to grow on American campuses, education associations are sending out warnings about unethical recruitment practices at both the high school and college level, and are sharpening their efforts to spot them.

title: Harry Schneider, Lawyer, 81
description: Harry Schneider, a lawyer in New York for 60 years, died Monday at a Mamaroneck, N.Y., nursing home, after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says
description: A virtual doubling of Federal drug law-enforcement money has failed to stem marijuana use in the United States, according to a study by a Harvard University researcher.

title: 'Uncle Buck' Is No. 1 At the Movie Box Office
description: ''Uncle Buck,'' starring John Candy, earned $8.8 million in its opening weekend that ended Sunday to take over the No. 1 spot at the box office from ''Parenthood.''

title: AM GENERAL AWARDED ARMY VEHICLE CONTRACT
description: AM General, a division of the LTV Corporation, today won a contract valued at $1 billion from the Army to produce 33,000 Hummers, the replacement for the jeep.

title: Washington (D.C.) Federal Savings (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary charge of $634,000 from tax expense due to provisions for loan losses. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $166,000 from a tax credit.

title: A.L. Van Houtte reports earnings for Qtr to July 22
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Arthur Wittenstein, 63, Tax-Law Specialist
description: Arthur Wittenstein, a lawyer and certified public accountant, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 63 years old.

title: Team Sets Out to Study Great Lakes Wreck
description: Explorers set out for the wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald today, hoping to use an underwater robot to get new explanations for a disaster that occurred almost 14 years ago.

title: A Long Island Wine Goes National
description: CHARDONNAY made from grapes grown just 22 miles from midtown Manhattan will soon become the first Long Island wine to be available in all 50 states.

title: Change at Mozart Concert
description: Daniel Stepner is to replace Stanley Ritchie as a violinist in a Mostly Mozart concert of chamber music on period instruments at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Ritchie injured his shoulder. The other musicians to perform are Anner Bylsma, cellist; Malcolm Bilson, fortepianist; David Miller, violist, and Michael Willens, violinist. The program is Mozart's Trio in B flat (K. 502); Beethoven's Cello Sonata in A (Op. 69), and the Schubert ''Trout'' Quintet. Information: 874-2424.

title: Barden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 9 months included a non- recurring charge of about $840,000 from the termination of a foreign distributor.

title: There Can Be an Excess of Life, as of Wine
description: To the Editor:

title: Optical Coating Laboratory reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago 9-month period included a gain of $553,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Performing Whale Dies in Collision With Another
description: A killer whale was killed in a performance at a marine entertainment park in San Diego late Monday, causing renewed criticism by environmentalists and animal rights advocates who contend that whales should not be kept in captivity for the amusement of humans.

title: Poland Needs West's Economic Guidance
description: To the Editor:

title: Pact Frees Petrovic
description: The Portland Trail Blazers signed an agreement with the Spanish club Real Madrid yesterday, clearing the way for Drazen Petrovic, the Yugoslav star, to play for the National Basketball Association team this season. Under the agreement, Real Madrid will be paid for the remaining three years of the 6-foot-3-inch guard's contract with the Spanish team.

title: Oberlin, Ohio
description: EACH week Jeffrey Slocum drives 250 miles, looking for fresh produce, meat and fish for the week's menu at the tiny, nine-table Main Street Mercantile Store and Tea Room here, where he presides as chef.

title: Sculpture Comforts Grieving Mother
description: Solitude overwhelms Suse Lowenstein's newest sculpture. Anguish, too.

title: Deborah Norville to Be 'Today' Anchor
description: NBC News announced yesterday that Deborah Norville will replace John Palmer as news anchor of the ''Today'' show, beginning Sept. 5. The change, said Michael G. Gartner, the president of NBC News, is one of several the division plans to make to increase news coverage on the morning program.

title: Symbolics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss 1988 fourth quarter and year results included pretax charges of $13,226,000 and $24,924,000, respectively, related to corporate restructuring, and the year also included a $1,810,000 charge related to a buyout of interests in a research and development joint venture.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
ISLAMORADA, FLA.
description: LEAD: THERE'S not a restaurant between Miami and Key West, Fla., that does not claim Key lime pie as its specialty, but the fact is that Key limes, a small yellow variety, have become a rare commodity and most professional as well as home pie bakers must rely on either regular green limes or on bottled Key lime juice.

title: Irving E. Hankin, Commodities Economist, 79
description: Irving E. Hankin, a commodities economist, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 79 years old and was a longtime resident of Syosset, L.I.

title: Tandy Posts Flat Profits
description: The Tandy Corporation, a leading consumer-electronics manufacturer, has reported virtually flat earnings for the fourth quarter and only a 2.2 percent gain for the 1989 fiscal year.

title: LESSONS
description: Bill Honig, the Superintendent of Public Instruction in California, is an education research junkie. There is nothing he likes better than to curl up with a regression analysis showing how some new teaching method can increase student learning.

title: Hurricane Threatens Shipping
description: Hurricane Erin moved across the North Atlantic today, posing a danger to ships but having little chance of reaching land with its 75 mph winds, forecasters said. The hurricane's center was about 1,050 miles southwest of the Azores in the central north Atlantic, at 6 P.M., eastern time.

title: 2 Investment Bankers Join Bear Stearns Panel
description: Building a larger corporate finance practice to supplement its strength in securities trading and sales, Bear Stearns Companies Inc. yesterday promoted two investment bankers to its 10-member executive committee.

title: Deere Shows Gain of 21.2%
description: Deere & Company reported today that earnings for the third quarter rose 21.2 percent on a sales gain of 21.6 percent.

title: The Greenhouse Effect: 'Hardly Apocalypse'
description: Dixy Lee Ray, former Democratic Governor of Washington and onetime chairwoman of the Atomic Energy Commission, believes that the effects of global warming have been exaggerated and that its causes are misunderstood. Her remarks appeared in an article titled ''The Greenhouse Blues'' in the summer issue of Policy Review. The article was excerpted from her forthcoming book on the excesses of environmentalism.

title: Hechinger Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included a gain of $3,200,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Plymouth Notch, Vt.
description: IN 1890, in a plain clapboard building up the road from the humble quarters where Calvin Coolidge was born, in central Vermont, the future President's father opened a factory making wheels of Cheddarlike curd cheese. Today, Plymouth Cheese is still made using 19th-century methods. And a Coolidge - the former President's son John - is still in charge.

title: Amdura Requests Delay on Voting
description: The Amdura Corporation, the Denver-based hardware distribution company, urged its shareholders to refrain from voting on Cilluffo Associates Inc.'s proposal to unseat its board. Amdura asked that shareholders give it an opportunity to state its position.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Recalled Steve Davis, pitcher, from Colorado of the Pacific Coast League. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Placed Franklin Stubbs, infielder, on the 60-day disabled list, effective Aug. 21. Called up Dave Hansen, infielder, from San Antonio of the Texas League. MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Spike Owen, shortstop, on a three-year contract. Placed Andy McGaffigan, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, effective Aug. 21. Called up Marquis Grissom, outfielder, from Indianapolis of the American Association. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Agreed to terms with Mike Gann, defensive end, on a four-year contract. DENVER (AFC) - Announced that Mark Jackson, wide receiver, has left training camp. Waived John Javis, wide receiver. DETROIT (NFC) - Released Ali Haji-Sheikh, kicker; Steve Baack and Todd Irvin, offensive linemen; Tom Baldwin and Derek MacCready, defensive linemen, and Byron Hunt and Mike McCray, linebackers. Signed Jim Arnold, place-kicker, to a three-year contract. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Acquired Zefross Moss, tackle, from Dallas in exchange for an undisclosed draft choice. Traded Chuck Ehin, nose tackle, to Dallas for an undisclosed draft choice. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Signed Albert Lewis, cornerback, to a four-year contract. GIANTS - Waived Jerome Rinehart and Rod Lowe, defensive ends; Dave Hudson and Dayne Williams, fullbacks; Lish Adams, linebacker; Jeff Fryer, offensive tackle; Mike Perez, quarterback, and Stan Howard, wide receiver. JETS (AFC) - Signed Mark Malone, quarterback. Waived Irvin Smith, defensive back. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Agreed to terms with Charles Haley, linebacker. HOCKEY PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Signed Mario Lemieux, center, to a five-year contract. SOCCER SAN DIEGO (MISL) - Signed Ralph Black, defender. COLLEGES SUNY-ALBANY - Named Lowes Moore men's junior varsity basketball coach and chief recruiter. COLGATE - Named Lew Mongelluzzo assistant hockey coach. DUKE - Promoted Jim Collins and Bob Sanders, defensive coaches, to co-defensive coordinators. IVY LEAGUE - Named Chuck Yrigoyen assistant director for public information, effective Sept. 11. PROVIDENCE - Named Kevin Sheehan and Ray Tessaglia assistant baseball coaches.

title: Stifling an Iran-Contra Yawn
description: The Justice Department, the Iran-contra special prosecutor and a lawyer for a former high C.I.A. official face an important hearing today before the Federal Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va. They will argue over Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's right to intervene in the special prosecutor's case against Joe Fernandez, the former agency station chief in Costa Rica, charged with lying to investigators of the scandal.

title: Buyback Extended By Bell Atlantic
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said its board had extended the company's stock repurchase program through Dec. 31, 1991, from Dec. 31, 1990, and increased the authorized amount from $450 million to $1 billion.

title: Judge Bars Action on Panel Plan to Close Boston Schools
description: A Superior Court judge today overturned the Boston School Committee's recent decisions to close or consolidate nine schools.

title: Switzer Open to Offers
description: Barry Switzer, the former Oklahoma coach, says that if an offer comes from the professional ranks, he would consider returning to coaching. ''I would be interested, no question about it,'' Switzer said Monday night on ''Sportscene,'' a cable-television talk show in Tulsa, Okla. ''Obviously, you don't have the problems you have in the college game today. You don't have to recruit. You don't have to deal with alumni.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: LITTLE LEAGUE Connecticut Team Wins: Andy Paul hit a bases-empty home run and Dave Galla singled and scored on a walk in the fifth inning to give Trumbull, Conn., a 4-3 victory over Davenport, Iowa, yesterday in the opening round of the Little League World Series at Williamsport, Pa. Trumbull, the Eastern Regional champion, will play the winner of the game today between San Pedro, Calif., and Tampa, Fla. Trailing, 4-2, going into the bottom of the fifth, Davenport, the Central Regional champion, rallied for a run when a pinch-hitter, Mike Rizzo, reached base on a fielder's choice, advanced on an error and scored on Matt Jacobs's single. Chris Drury went the distance for Trumbull, allowing four hits while striking out six and walking three. Earlier in the day, the Far East champion, Kaohsiung, Taiwan, defeated a mostly American team from Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, 9-4. The game featured the first female umpire at a Little League World Series game, Betty Speziale of Dunkirk, N.Y., at first base. (AP) TENNIS Pernfors Upsets Mansdorf: Unseeded Mikael Pernfors of Sweden upset seventh-seeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel last night and Anders Jarryd of Sweden gave up only four points in nine service games while beating Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia in the first round of the Hamlet Challenge Cup tournament in Jericho, N.Y. Pernfors beat Mansdorf, 6-2, 6-4. Jarryd won, 6-2, 6-4, breezing past Zivojinovic, a last-minute replacement for the injured Jakob Hlasek.(AP)

title: Coast Guard Leader Backs Plan For Tanker-Free Zone Off Florida
description: The head of the Coast Guard has agreed to support a proposal by Gov. Bob Martinez to create a 10-mile tanker-free zone off Florida's coast as a protection from oil spills.

title: Bogota Says It Plans to Extradite Major Drug Financier to the U.S.
description: As soldiers and policemen searched ranches and city mansions for cocaine traffickers, Colombian officials indicated today that they would soon extradite a drug suspect to the United States for the first time since an extradition treaty was suspended in 1987.

title: Sex Abuse Is Alleged at West Point
description: The authorities at the United States Military Academy are conducting hearings over charges by three women that they were subjected to sexual abuse by a West Point gynecologist while under his care earlier this year.

title: Medtronic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a litigation settlement of $4 million which was offset by a non- recurring charge of $17.6 million. The company said per share earnings of presplit stock were restated to reflect its 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100-percent stock dividend, payable Aug. 31 to shareholders of record Aug. 10.

title: WITH INVESTIGATION DROPPED, TRADER OFFERS CANDID VIEW
description: After the Government announced last week that it was dropping its two-and-a-half-year investigation of two Wall Street traders, Richard B. Wigton and Timothy L. Tabor, with nary an apology, many securities lawyers and deal makers expressed outrage over the high-handed way that the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan had victimized two innocent men.

title: GORBACHEV CALLS, THEN POLISH PARTY DROPS ITS DEMANDS
description: Polish Communist Party leaders retreated today from threats not to share responsibility in the new coalition Government after the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, held a 40-minute telephone conversation with the Polish party leader.

title: Sugar Moves Up Sharply On Rumor of Indian Buying
description: Sugar futures prices rose sharply yesterday amid rumors that India had made a long-expected purchase of refined white sugar on the world market to offset partly its projected shortfall of nearly a million metric tons.

title: U.S. SHIFT SEEN ON PAY FOR MILKEN
description: In a reversal of strategy, Federal prosecutors have decided to allow Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to pay Michael R. Milken compensation for 1988, which could amount to $100 million, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
About New York; Varied Scenes From World In Five Boroughs
description: Everything happens all the time. Unfathomable light years away, a star just died. A baby was conceived in Katmandu, another born in Queens. In the pre-dawn netherworld of Times Square, a man said to a companion yesterday, ''I'm gonna cut him good.'' .

title: The Man Who Loved Lions
description: Though he once wrote that lions ''have been designed and perfected by nature to kill,'' George Adamson spent the better part of his life in Africa happily and safely in their company. With his wife, Joy, the author of the spectacularly popular ''Born Free'' and its sequels, Mr. Adamson raised lion cubs, taught them to survive and released them into the wild. Only once was he attacked.

title: Auto Dealers' Profit Rate Dips
description: Profits at United States auto dealerships have dropped from 2.4 percent of sales in 1984 to 1.7 percent last year, the National Automobile Dealers Association said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Airlines Told to Modify Some Planes to Lessen Fire Danger
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered airlines to tighten fire safety measures on many aircraft in light of a study of the 1987 crash of a South Africa Airways Boeing 747 that caught fire in the air.

title: RYAN STRIKES OUT HENDERSON FOR 5,000th
description: On Nolan Ryan's night of glory, one game summed up his 23-year career.

title: Lemieux Is 2d Member Of $2 Million Club
description: Mario Lemieux yesterday became hockey's second $2 million man, signing a five-year contract with the Pittsburgh Penguins worth almost $12 million. ''This is much too much to be paying Mario, but we will live with it,'' Edward J. DeBartolo, owner of the Penguins, said at a news conference in Pittsburgh at which Lemieux signed his new contract.

title: But Can It Locate a Taxi in the Rain?
description: A computerized vehicle-inspection system that checks everything from the level of pollution emitted by a car to the accuracy of a taxi's fare meter has been developed by the Hamilton Test Systems unit of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Deere & Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $8,700,000 and $27,700,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a one-time gain of $28,700,000, or 42 cents a share, from the adoption of new accounting rules.

title: New Lutheran Group, Facing Problems, Opens Chicago Assembly
description: Like anxious parents, leaders of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America are hovering over the one-and-a-half-year-old denomination, trying to fend off serious trouble while this ecclesiastical infant learns to walk on steady feet and, someday soon, they hope, to run.

title: Datelines; 19 Are Charged In Heroin-Ring Case
description: The New York Drug Enforcement Task Force arrested 19 people yesterday, cracking a heroin ring that the authorities said grossed as much as $2 million a week.

title: 370 Reported Held in Prague Protest
description: The authorities said today that 370 people were arrested in Prague on Monday as they demonstrated on the 21st anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

title: ANNEXATION VOID, LITHUANIANS SAY
description: In a move that could lay the legal foundation for eventual secession from the Soviet Union, a commission of the Lithuanian Parliament declared today that Moscow's annexation of the republic in 1940 was invalid.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about the use of private security guards in midtown Manhattan misidentified the guard giving directions to tourists. He was Darren Kittrell.

title: Review/Film; Father and Daughter, in and Against the Mob
description: Dapper Dino (Peter Falk), as he is called by the tabloids, is a Brooklyn Mafia boss in a bind. After serving a 13-year sentence in Sing Sing for labor racketeering, Dino returns home to find himself the target of mob pals, who want him dead, and of the Feds, who want him back behind bars.

title: Cuomo Advice On Tax Cut: 'Put It Off'
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who for several months has been flirting with a proposal to defer the final phase of New York State's income tax cut, finally suggested Monday night that the state do just that.

title: Riverboat Gambling Mix-Up; 2 Iowa Counties Reject Plan
description: A vote-reporting error caused Iowa election officials to announced last week that only one of three Iowa counties had voted down riverboat gambling, when in fact two of three had done so.

title: Judge Lifts Restriction on Abortion Protest
description: A Federal judge has scheduled a hearing for Sept. 21 on whether he has jurisdiction to restrict the anti-abortion demonstrations that have plagued a Binghamton abortion clinic.

title: Reform Can't Wait for New York City Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: VALVANO IS EXPECTED TO RESIGN POST AS N. CAROLINA STATE ATHLETIC DIRECTOR
description: Bruce R. Poulton, who resigned Monday as the head of North Carolina State University, said yesterday that he expected Jim Valvano, the Wolfpack's basketball coach, to resign as the school's athletic director when a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into the basketball program is completed.

title: Datelines; Truck Guard Is Shot In $500,000 Robbery
description: Three people robbed an armored truck in the Bronx of an estimated $500,000 yesterday and critically wounded one of its guards, the police said.

title: Beirut Shelling Intensifies, Ending Lull
description: Artillery exchanges between pro-Syrian Muslim militias and mainly Christian units intensified, today, and the police and hospital records said 4 people were killed and 61 wounded.

title: FEELING RIGHT AT HOME ON BOSTON FARM CLUB
description: Chants of ''Mo, Mo, Mo'' reverberated through Beehive Field as Maurice Vaughn, the power-hitting first baseman of the New Britain Red Sox, stepped to the plate with the home team trailing the Harrisburg Senators late in a recent Eastern League game. Through the collective chanting of his nickname, Vaughn heard one particular vocal message loud and clear - ''Think about it, Babe!'' - delivered by his mother, Shirley, seated with her husband, Leroy.

title: Aircoa Hospitality Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mariners Are Sold
description: An agreement has been reached to sell the Seattle Mariners baseball team to a group of investors from Indianapolis, George Argyros, the team's owner, said today.

title: African Talks on Angola Peace Seem to Bog Down
description: As leaders of eight African nations met here today, there were increasing signs that their efforts to resolve Angola's long civil war were foundering.

title: James River Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: In the latest quarter results, net reflected a $3,500,000 charge related to defaults by the lessee of the company's Hyde Park, Mass., mill. Also in the latest quarter, a credit of $5.9 million was recorded to reverse federal income taxes which had been previously accured on reinvested earnings of foreign subsidiaries.

title: Youmans Is Out
description: Floyd Youmans, who has been on the disabled list for much of his first season with the Philadelphia Phillies, had arthroscopic surgery on his pitching shoulder yesterday in Los Angeles and will not play again this season, the team physician, Dr. Phillip Marone, said. Youmans was 1-5 with a 5.70 earned run average in 10 games, all as a starter. (AP)

title: Airline Flight Is Aborted
description: A burned-out cabin light on a United Airlines 727 emitted smoke shortly after takeoff today, prompting the plane to return to the San Francisco airport. ''There was no fire, just smoke,'' said Joe Hopkins, an airline spokesman. Earlier reports from officials at the airport tower had said there was a fire. The smoke stopped when the plane's captain turned off the electricity in the area of the light, Mr. Hopkins said.

title: There Can Be an Excess of Life, as of Wine; Against One's Will
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Wine: An In-Depth Study Two new wine programs are being offered, one in New York and the other in the Napa Valley of California. While they are intended for professionals, they are open to anybody interested in wine.

title: Market Place; Brighter Outlook For Natural Gas
description: FOR years, natural gas has been one of the dullest performers in the energy business. But that may be changing.

title: Plan to Assess Valdez Damage Is Criticized
description: Three Federal agencies and the State of Alaska yesterday released a blueprint for determining the extent of environmental damage caused by the Exxon Valdez oil spill, but environmentalists immediately criticized the plan for failing to commit the governments to long-term studies.

title: TREASURIES SLUMP AMID BIG SUPPLY
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slumped yesterday, sending the yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond to a 10-week high of 8.24 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Big Fraternities Decide To End Pledging Rituals Tau Kappa Epsilon and Zeta Beta Tau are ending traditional pledge periods, criticized for hazing and other abuses. They are also telling chapters not to spend their money on alcohol. Education, page B8. Hundreds Held in Prague Czechoslovakia arrested 370 people protesting on the 21st anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion. It said foreign instigators were to blame. Page A3. A Church's Growing Pains The Evangelical Lutheran Church of America, created when three denominations merged last year, is trying to fend off troubles. Page A12. Ryan Strikes Out No. 5,000 Texas' Nolan Ryan retired Oakland's Rickey Henderson in the fifth inning to become the only pitcher to attain 5,000 strikeouts. Page D22. Slurps, Worms and Nerds? The candies that appeal to children these days are the ones most likely to be unappealing to parents. The Living Section, page C1.

title: MITCHELL'S NO. 40 FOILS VIOLA
description: Frank Viola made few mistakes last night, but he made a big one in the sixth inning. He made a bad pitch to Kevin Mitchell.

title: Companie Compete to Put Products on Market
description: SEVERAL companies are developing calorie-free and calorie-reduced fat substitutes that could be available in 5 to 10 years.

title: Dell Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
LOSSES STILL HIGH AT SAVINGS UNITS, U.S. AGENCY WARNS
description: While Congress rushed to complete work on the mammoth savings and loan bailout bill, the industry was piling up some of its biggest losses in history from April through June, Government officials said today.

title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that he had given Colombian authorities a list of 12 people described as ''drug-trafficking kingpins'' wanted for trial in this country, as the United States began talks with Colombia to arrange new extradition procedures.

title: New Light on Loans
description: The new public campaign financing system has worked well to reduce the influence of big money in this year's New York City election campaign, even for something that looks like a notable exception.

title: Remember, It Pays To Compare Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Couple Accused of 'Imprisoning' 9 Children
description: A Bronx man and his wife have been arrested and accused of raping, sodomizing or beating nine of their children in a trash-strewn, unlighted apartment where they kept them virtually imprisoned for at least three years, the police said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Meandering Through the Inner and Outer Italy
description: Italian Days By Barbara Grizzuti Harrison Weidenfeld & Nicolson. 479 pages. $22.95.

title: Judge Upholds Election Petitions for Lauder
description: A state judge yesterday upheld Ronald Lauder's Conservative Party nominating petitions despite assertions by Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Lauder's opponent in the Republican mayoral primary, that the petitions were ''permeated with fraud.''

title: Mexico Selling 25% of Airline
description: A partnership that includes the British investor Sir James Goldsmith and a Mexican investor group are jointly buying 25 percent of Mexico's state-run airline, Mexicana, the Government said today.

title: Utility Delays Sale of Bonds
description: A planned offering of $450 million of tax-exempt refinancing bonds from the Washington Public Power Supply System has been postponed until after Labor Day, the utility announced yesterday.

title: 2 Lists Available
description: For information on foreign student recruitment:

title: Xerox to Sell Unit to Du Pont
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Medical Systems business to the Du Pont Company.

title: Baker J.  Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Defends Law on Monitoring Dolphin Killings
description: The United States Government and the tuna fishing industry told a Federal judge Monday that United States trade would be hurt and few dolphins would be saved if observers were required to monitor every foreign tuna boat to reduce the killing of dolphins.

title: Michigan Curtails New Rights Policy
description: The University of Michigan has suspended part of a new antidiscrimination policy that the American Civil Liberties Union says violates rights to free speech.

title: The People's Non-Choice
description: One of the discouraging aspects of the New York election campaign concerns a race that is failing to take place. John Santucci, District Attorney of Queens, is running unopposed for a fourth four-year term, despite incidents that raise questions about his judgment and ethical standards.

title: STATE'S ATTORNEY, IN A DEAL, RESIGNS
description: State Attorney General Charlie Brown abruptly resigned late Monday in exchange for an end to a grand jury investigation into allegations that he lied under oath and into his campaign financial records.

title: Hot and Cold Blend In a Thailand Duet
description: IN Bangkok, Thailand, where it is August all year round, people know how to eat: hot and cool.

title: START-UPS JOIN ALZHEIMER RACE
description: A flood of start-up companies is rushing to attack the degenerative brain disease called Alzheimer's, betting that gathering leading scientists in well-financed enterprises can produce breakthroughs. But skeptics say a cure for the illness is far too distant a goal for such companies and that the efforts could provide a difficult lesson about the limits of venture capital.

title: 20 Arrested on Drug Charges
description: The police arrested 20 people in a drug sweep today, charging them all with narcotics-related felonies. A statement from the state police in Loudonville, near Albany, said the state police, Warren County sheriff's deputies and the Saratoga Springs police arrested the group after a four-month investigation. The 20 were arrested on charges of selling cocaine and crack, the statement said. The arrests were made in Saratoga, Warren and Albany counties in New York, and in Rutland, Vt., the statement said. During the arrests the police seized unspecified amounts of drugs and two vehicles.

title: Real Estate; Ritz-Carltons In Two Cities Plan Changes
description: The Ritz-Carlton hotels in New York and Washington will undergo multimillion-dollar renovations later this year as part of the effort of their new owner to restore them to the top ranks of the country's most luxurious.

title: Counseling Center Seeks To Bridge Cultural Gulfs
description: Since the 1970's waves of exiles and refugees from Afghanistan, Central America, Vietnam, Ethopia and other war-torn places have arrived in this once largely monolithic city. And while they have brought various cultural traditions, many have also brought an array of emotional or mental problems.

title: Two National Fraternities End Pledging System
description: In a move to eliminate hazing and other abuses that have provoked sharp criticism of their organizations, two of the nation's largest fraternities announced yesterday that starting this fall they would replace the system of pledging with new rules that emphasize positive behavior.

title: RED SOX EDGE YANKEES WITH HOMER
description: The fifth day of Bucky Dent's first term as Yankee manager seemed to move in slow motion. There were runs, but not enough of them. There were hits, but seldom at the right time. There were chances, but they were invariably wasted. In the end, as he wiped his brow and recalled the moments that had passed, Dent began to sound like the manager that had already come and gone this season.

title: MALONE IS FINALLY PLAYING FOR THE JETS
description: Almost 10 years after the Jets nearly made him their first draft choice, Mark Malone joined them today in a very different role.

title: Stewart & Stevenson reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dow Up 3.99, but 835 Stocks Fall as 629 Rise
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday as a mini-rally carried the Dow Jones industrial average into plus territory after it languished on the down side the entire day.

title: ORIOLES PREVAIL BY 4-2 TO PUT BREWERS IN 3d
description: Dave Johnson pitched a five-hitter tonight for his third complete game of the month as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-2.

title: Los Angeles Journal; The Road to Amnesty Being Paved With Grit
description: Guadalupe Avila, an illegal alien who has enrolled in a government amnesty program, knows that her first act in her adopted country was to break its laws, stealing through the mountains at its southern border.

title: August's Gift To Sweetness: Ripe Peaches
description: FROM Maine to Florida, Maryland to California, people can always find fault with August. It's too hot, it's too wet and if it's not too humid, then there is a water shortage.

title: Offshore Logistics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $506,000 and $613,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; net for prior year included an extraordinary credit of $1,459,000. The company said the extraordinary credits were related to the retirement of debt.

title: Private Brands reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share net figures included preferred dividend requirements.

title: ANCHOR GLASS REJECTS $20-a-SHARE OFFER MADE BY VITRO
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected as inadequate an unsolicited tender offer from Vitro S.A., a Mexican glass producer, and that it had held talks with third parties interested in the company.

title: Scientists, Coming Full Circle, Say Neptune Ring Is Complete
description: Challenging observations made only 11 days ago, the Voyager 2 spacecraft transmitted new photographs today showing a tenuous but complete ring of dusty debris circling Neptune.

title: Dare to Contemplate the Woman Gymnast
description: To the Editor:

title: Polish Communists Condemn 1939 Pact
description: The Communist Party Politburo today condemned the Nazi-Soviet pact that carved up Poland as invalid and a violation of international law.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, the paper products subsidiary of Olympia and York Developments Ltd., said it wants to sell its building products division, which has its operations in the United States and includes makers of hardboard, siding and shelving.

title: SOVIETS PLANNING NEW SPACE EFFORT
description: The Soviet Union will send an unmanned spacecraft to the Martian moon Phobos in 1996 and will visit Mercury at the turn of the century, a Soviet scientist said today. Two Soviet missions to Phobos failed in the last year.

title: Graphic Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Intensifies Asbestos Drive, Filing 13 Suits
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, in an intensified crackdown on faulty asbestos removal, sued the New York City Board of Education today and also filed a dozen other lawsuits around the nation charging violations of the Clean Air Act.

title: Rostislav Hlopoff, Art Conservator, 86
description: Rostislav Hlopoff, an art conservator and a professor emeritus of art conservation at the State University College at Oneonta, N.Y., died of bone cancer on Friday at the Tolstoy Foundation Nursing Home in Valley Cottage, N.Y. He was 86 years old. Mr. Hlopoff restored 18th-century French furniture for such museums as the Frick Collection, the Toledo Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., as well as for private clients. He was born in Russia, and worked as a sculptor in France before beginning his career as a restorer of porcelains, sculptures and furniture in the United States in the late 1930's.

title: There Can Be an Excess of Life, as of Wine; Drugs' Side Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana Vreeland, Editor, Dies; Voice of Fashion for Decades
description: Diana Vreeland, the legendary fashion editor and creator of spectacular fashion exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, died of a heart attack yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was believed to be in her late 80's and had been in failing health for several years.

title: Groups Plan to Protest Malt Liquor Campaigns
description: A coalition of 22 public interest groups involved in minority issues is scheduled to hold a news conference in Washington this morning to criticize what they say is an emphasis on black and Hispanic consumers in advertisements for malt liquor.

title: West Germany Closes Its Embassy in Prague
description: West Germany announced today that it was closing its embassy in Prague. It is the third diplomatic mission Bonn has ordered closed because of occupation by East German refugees.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CSC Industries, Warren, Ohio, named W. Lawrence Weeks president and chief executive, replacing John G. Roberts, who retired but will remain a director.

title: Review/Rock; For the Cure, Size Is All
description: The Cure's concert at Giants Stadium tonight was about size. In the huge arena, where nuance, subtlety and personal human drama vanish, the Cure's pieces took their time to develop and expand, slowly revealing new slabs of texture and color.

title: KEY RATES
Nuclear Power Plants Remain Unsafe as Ever
description: To the Editor:

title: THAT 'CLEANER FUEL' MAY BE GASOLINE
description: The oil business, faced with government proposals to clean the air by replacing gasoline with methanol, compressed natural gas or electricity, is suddenly espousing a previously overlooked substitute: cleaner gasoline. The reformulated fuel announced by ARCO last week for older cars that run on leaded gas is only the beginning, the industry says.

title: Charlotte Simon, 70, Health-Care Executive
description: Charlotte B. Simon, a former executive director of the Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center of New Jersey, died of complications of emphysema yesterday at Bayonne (N.J.) Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Bayonne.

title: Too Far From West Egg
description: The woman is near tears. A few days ago she read about the birthday party created on Long Island by rich, rich Saul Steinberg's wife, Gayfryd.

title: About 30 Visitors Hurt On an Aircraft Carrier
description: A huge elevator on the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy ruptured a hydraulic line during an open house today, spraying oily fluid on visitors and causing a panic that resulted in dozens of injuries.

title: LINEUPS UNDECIDED AS GIANTS RELEASE 8
description: The Giants released eight players today, reducing the squad to 67, but deciding little of the team's makeup for the opening game Sept. 11 in Washington.

title: Bridge
description: One tournament in two sites is an idea that makes sense, cutting down driving time for many who would like to participate. One disadvantage, affecting the experts, is that it is impossible to have a knockout team championship with a single winning team.

title: Joseph La Shelle, 89, Cameraman of 'Laura'
description: Joseph W. La Shelle, a cinematographer who was nominated for Academy Awards eight times and won an Oscar for his work on ''Laura,'' died Sunday. He was 89 years old.

title: Federal Charges Describe Money-Laundering Plot
description: Eduardo Martinez Romero, captured in Colombia, is accused of being a major launderer of enormous sums of money earned illegally in United States from the sale of South American cocaine.

title: Canada Retail Sales Flat
description: Canadian retail sales, seasonally adjusted, totaled $14.5 billion, or $12.3 billion (United States), in June, unchanged from May, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. Excluding sales of new and used automobiles, however, retail trade was ahead six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: C.H. Heist reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the war in Cambodia misstated several black-market exchange rates. They were in riels to the dollar.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Polish Communists backed off from threats not to share responsibility in a new coalition Government after Soviet President Gorbachev held a phone conversation with the party leader. Page A1

title: Police Accept Suspect's Alibi in Green River Case
description: The authorities now say the man they characterized as a ''viable suspect'' in the Green River killings was out of town when the series of murders began.

title: Com Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss was attributable to special promotional rebates made in connection with public payphone presubscription marketing and a substantial increase in fraud primarily associated with the company's operator service business.

title: G&K Services Inc reports earnings for 13wks to July 1
Huey Newton Symbolized the Rising Black Anger of a Generation
description: With the most vivid image of him a poster - the Black Panther defense minister poised on a throne-like rattan chair, a spear in one hand, a rifle in the other - it would be easy to see Huey Newton living and dying by the gun. A fuller picture is more complex. Huey Newton, the son of a Louisiana sharecropper who had also been a rebel, was, in his own words, ''a street kid with an education.'' And as hard-won as his street wisdom had been, so too had come his book learning. Streetwise to Book Smart

title: Death Toll on Thames Boat Probably 57, Police Believe
description: A spokeswoman for Scotland Yard said today that 57 people are now believed to have died Sunday in the sinking of a pleasure boat on the Thames River.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY AND SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 and 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION PLENARY - 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 a.M. and 3 P.M.

title: San Francisco Blacks Found Progressing at Slow Rate
description: The results of comprehensive skills tests that have been released here show black students progressing slower than the national norm and at a rate that is less than any other ethnic group in the city, causing concern among educators.

title: 60-MINUTE
description: LABOR DAY is fast approaching, prompting thoughts of autumn menus. Of course, several months of temperate weather remain, so I'm not about to start whipping up hefty roasts and casseroles. But a recent dinner of sauteed lamb with garlic and lentils seemed a nice way to begin the transition to autumn.

title: 2 Questions For G.O.P In Primary
description: For many Republicans, the New York City mayoral primary now boils down to two questions: Is Rudolph W. Giuliani a real Republican? Is Ronald Lauder a real candidate?

title: Yields Mixed On C.D.'s and Bank Funds
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts were up at commercial banks but down at many savings institutions for the week ended yesterday.

title: Comarco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $4,800,000, or $1.22 a share from the exchange of common stock for convertible debentures.

title: Review/Film; For Tourists and Papuans The Exploitation Is Mutual
description: Among the many absurd images in ''Cannibal Tours,'' the most ridiculous is that of a European face elaborately painted in the ritual makeup of a Papua New Guinea tribe. The stark white face filled with swirling brown lines emerges from behind a Nikon camera, photographing similarly decorated Europeans and Americans dancing on a luxury cruise ship. They are touring an island where cannibalism has been replaced by commerce. As the director, Dennis O'Rourke, has described his documentary, these ''bourgeois tourists'' have bought ''the packaged version of 'Heart of Darkness.' ''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Farah Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss of $1,587,000 from the sale of its Generra Sportsware unit for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and and 9 months included a $1,262,000 charge from a change in accounting.

title: City in Texas Seeks to Halt Plan For Explosions Near Water Supply
description: A South Texas city is fighting to protect its source of drinking water from the possible effects of a Pentagon proposal to conduct underground explosions nearby.

title: GEORGIA GULF STOCK SOARS ON PROPOSAL
description: Shares of the Georgia Gulf Corporation surged $7.25 today, to $58.75, after the Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons, who has accumulated a 9.9 percent stake in the Atlanta-based chemical company, made known his intention of acquiring it.

title: Boy Found With Pure Cocaine
description: A 14-year-old boy was arrested on drug charges after the police found him carrying $50,000 worth of pure cocaine, the authorities said today. The boy and a companion were spotted Monday afternoon engaging in a drug transaction, the police said. Both youths fled after noticing the police. The 14-year-old was captured near his home. He was charged with possession of narcotics, possession of narcotics with intent to sell and conspiracy to sell narcotics.

title: Poverty Is Perceived as Increasing And State of the Poor Unimproved
description: The American public overwhelmingly perceives poverty to be increasing and the living conditions of the poor unimproved, the latest Gallup Poll has found.

title: Candy to Frighten Your Parents With
description: WITH Labor Day just around the corner, supermarkets and stores across the country are crammed with fresh spiral notebooks, sparkling new lunch pails and shiny new shoes, as the traditional back-to-school push begins.

title: Economic Scene; Are Banks Broke, Too?
description: NOW that President Bush has signed $100 billion-plus bailout legislation for the savings and loan industry, Washington can take time out for a little self-congratulation.

title: Not to Be Believed
description: LEAD: A couple of weeks ago, around six in the evening, I was crossing through the Times Square station near the Grand Central shuttle area heading for the IRT uptown. The place was crowded but not at pain threshold. Walking toward me, I saw a young woman with long wavy blonde hair who was reminiscent of both Julie Christie and Farrah

title: Doughnuts That Dare Anyone in Aroma Range to Pass On By
description: CUPCAKE CAFE is on the southeast corner of Ninth Avenue and 39th Street in Manhattan. It is next door to Cuzins Meat Market, a place that stocks chicken, veal, rabbit and tripe. Diagonally across the street is Vinnie's Fruit Market, a store that usually has wilted bunches of flat-leaf parsley, browning bulbs of fennel, and melons and figs that are too ripe. Produce just doesn't move the way it used to when this stretch of Ninth Avenue was an Italian stronghold.

title: Panel Overruled on Freeing Mother in Capital
description: A three-judge panel of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals ruled Monday that a mother who will not reveal her daughter's whereabouts to her former husband should be freed after nearly two years in jail. But the full nine-judge court immediately overturned that decision, calling for a new hearing on the contempt of court citation against Dr. Elizabeth Morgan.

title: Diplomacy
description: A senior Israeli official was ruminating recently about what was behind the Bush Administration's anger with Israel's abduction of the Shiite cleric, Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid. It was simple, the Israeli official explained, ''We suddenly forced the President to face a no-win situation.''

title: Wellman Plans Fiber Merger
description: Wellman Inc. and Fiber Industries announced today that they had agreed to merge in a deal worth $560 million.

title: Elegant Roost For Collector's Caged Prizes
description: ROBERT WOOLLEY craves beautiful things, and as director of the decorative arts division of Sotheby's, he has access to them. His eight-room apartment on Fifth Avenue at 96th Street is crammed with antique china, architectural drawings, maps, furniture, wooden walking sticks and more. But some of his favorite objets d'art came not from auction houses but from pet stores.

title: Congressional Office Raises Its Estimate Of Health Plan Cost
description: The Congressional Budget Office has further increased estimates of the cost of the program to insure the elderly against the catastrophic expenses of serious illnesses under Medicare, a Congressional aide said tonight.

title: What Next for a Notable Wright House?
description: LEAD: THE quiet, residential neighborhood of Parkside in Buffalo was laid out by Frederick Law Olmsted and is on the National Register of Historic Places. Yet it is the 1904 Darwin D. Martin House, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, that stands out today amid the collection of late-Victorian and early-20th-century houses.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Centel Cable Television Co., Chicago, said its shareholders had approved the company's merger with a new subsidiary that will allow Centel Cable to complete the sale of its operations.

title: Broadbeach Puts Pressure on McGill
description: Broadbeach Associates Inc., a private Los Angeles investment company, said it would be willing to raise its $89.8 million offer for the McGill Manufacturing Company if McGill were ''able to demonstrate to us that such additional value exists.'' McGill, based in Valparaiso, Ind., makes anti-friction bearings and electrical specialty items. Last week, the company rebuffed the $62-a-share cash offer from Broadbeach, and it has refused to meet with its representatives.

title: In the Bronx, a Shadowy Tale of a Family's Abuse
description: It was a world of darkness, a world where grunts took the place of words, a world of shadowy middle-of-the-night rituals illuminated only by candles. It was a world where sleep was put off to go marching in the snow, 11 people in ill-fitting parkas and dirty blankets shuffling along single-file, Herman Carlie McMillan at the head of the line shouting ''TEN-hut!''

title: Review/Music; Midori, Violinist, Seeks Out Romantic Roots of Mozart
description: The myth that child prodigies generally come to no good end satisfies some deep need in the public psyche. In truth, though famously sad exceptions could be cited, most go on to fulfill the expectations aroused by their preternaturally early promise. It is still much too soon to predict with confidence where her musical gift will lead Midori, the young Japanese violinist who performed at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Tuesday evening, but her technically polished and surprisingly interesting performance suggested that she is on the track toward mature artistry.

title: Africans Set Debt Seminar
description: African officials are scheduled to meet in Cairo Monday to step up pressure for an international conference on the continent's $240 billion foreign debt, which they say their countries are unable to repay.

title: Wyse Scraps a Job
description: Wyse Advertising said yesterday that it had abolished the position of president of its New York office. Allan D. Gardner, who had been president of the office for a year, will leave the Cleveland-based agency in November. A Wyse spokesman, Howard Landau, said the decision was part of an agency-wide management reorganization and did not reflect any dissatisfaction with Mr. Gardner. Indeed, he said, Mr. Gardner had played a central role in the reorganization. Wyse's New York office will be run by John Lippman, executive vice president of account services.

title: Let's Save Our Lungs at the Tollbooth During Ozone Alerts; A New Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip C. Horton, 78, Editor and a Professor
description: Philip C. Horton, a former editor who was a professor of public diplomacy at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy before his retirement in 1977, died Sunday at his home in Danbury, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: 250 East Germans Escape
description: Hungarian guards used dogs to tighten border control, but 250 East Germans still reached Austria overnight in the tide of escape from their Communist homeland, witnesses said today. Flight from East Germany through Hungary started in May, after the liberal Communist regime in Budapest began removing barbed wire and other obstacles from its border with Austria. Permission to visit the West is rare for East Germans, but they can travel to neighboring Hungary with ease.

title: Treasury Securities Rise Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury securities rallied yesterday as credit market participants responded favorably to the sale of $7.75 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL 49ers 17, Chargers 14: Terrence Flagler scored on a 90-yard kickoff return as San Francisco beat San Diego yesterday in a preseason game at Candlestick Park in San Francisco. Jim McMahon was unimpressive in his first start for the Chargers, who acquired him from the Chicago Bears last Friday. Playing into the third quarter, McMahon completed 7 of 13 passes for 26 yards. He was loudly booed by the 54,471 fans.

title: DISGUISED ISRAELIS KILL ARAB YOUTH
description: Israeli troops, apparently disguised as Arabs, shot and killed an 18-year-old Palestinian tonight as he painted grafitti on a wall in the Gaza Strip, Palestinians said. Two other youths were reported wounded.

title: Helmsley Jury Hears Closing Arguments
description: A Federal prosecutor in the tax-fraud trial of Leona Helmsley called yesterday for her conviction, declaring that the self-styled hotel queen had brazenly cheated the Government out of over a million dollars in taxes by putting herself above ''those little people'' who paid their taxes.

title: J.P. Morgan Search
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, another former client of the defunct agency Doyle Graf Raj, yesterday narrowed its search for an agency to handle its $10 million account to three finalists: Della Femina, McNamee WCRS; Backer Spielvogel Bates, and TBWA. Canter Achenbaum Associates is handling the search.

title: Officer in New Jersey Is Shot
description: - A South Orange Village police officer was shot tonight while chasing two burglary suspects, village officials and witnesses said. The officer, whose name was not released, was taken into surgery at University Hospital in Newark, the Village President, Roger Ross, said. Residents of Holland Road, where the shooting occurred, said an officer was chasing two men suspected of robbing a home when one turned and fired, striking the officer. A police officer on the scene said the police had caught one suspect but the other was at large.

title: Abortion Rights Are Pressed in Jersey
description: Two groups supporting abortion rights announced plans today to try to make abortion the overriding issue in New Jersey's gubernatorial and legislative elections on Nov. 7.

title: Lebanese Muslims Warn Approaching French Navy
description: As a French naval task force assembled off Lebanon today, a military command of Muslim and leftist militias threatened to treat the French vessels as a ''military target.''

title: Glass as Only Lalique Could Make It
description: LEAD: Most everyone knows that Lalique glass is good, but how good is a revelation. For connoisseurs, the retrospective exhibition ''A Century of Glass for a Modern World'' at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York is a must.

title: Chevrolet Ends Disney Use in Ads
description: The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation will stop using Walt Disney characters in advertising for its Lumina cars and mini-vans.

title: INSIDE
description: Voyager's Remarkable Aim After traveling for 12 years and 4.4 billion miles, Voyager is a mere 21 miles off target as it streaks toward its Neptune fly-by today. Page A18. Asbestos at Blast Site Asbestos was found at a Manhattan apartment building damaged in a steam-pipe blast Saturday, and residents were evacuated. Page B1. Stores Bar Some Milk Five of the nation's largest chains took steps to bar dairy products made with milk from cows treated with an experimental drug. Page A18.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Analysis and Technology Inc., North Stonington, Conn., named Jay W. Ryerson senior vice president and John P. Cretella vice president.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Fighting Drugs, Wholesale
description: There is no telling how Colombia's current arrests of drug traffickers will affect cocaine exports - removing top executives of a business need not damage it if lieutenants are waiting to take over.

title: Babies of Uninsured Parents Found to Be at Risk
description: Babies whose parents have no health insurance are about 30 percent more likely than those from insured families to die or be seriously ill at birth, a study concludes.

title: BRITISH TRADE DEFICIT GREW SHARPLY IN JULY
description: Britain's balance-of-payments deficit in July deepened to $:2.06 billion, or about $3.25 billion, its second worst monthly figure ever, the Government said today.

title: Algeciras Journal; Spain's Quibble With Success: Moroccan Migrants
description: For more than a generation, the dream of many poor Moroccans was to reach France and Belgium, where they understood the language and could easily disappear among the huge communities of North Africans long resident there.

title: Court Reinstates Rosen on Brooklyn Ballot
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Norman J. Rosen, one of three Democrats running for district attorney in Brooklyn, should be reinstated on the ballot for the Sept. 12 primary.

title: TAKING A STANCE AGAINST STEROIDS IN THE N.F.L.
description: There appears to be growing sentiment in the National Football League -among management, players and possibly even the union - to require year-round testing for anabolic steroids in an effort to reduce their use.

title: NEW 'GREEN CARD' TO TACKLE FRAUD
description: The ''green card,'' which has not actually been green for years, is taking on a new color and other characteristics, largely as part of a Government effort to stem a black market in alien certification.

title: Colombia Is Confiscating Drug Property
description: President Virgilio Barco Vargas is preparing decrees aimed at confiscating most of the ranches, estates, yachts and airplanes impounded by the police in the last week.

title: Bone Scan for Finley
description: The results of a bone scan of Chuck Finley's injured left foot were abnormal and the California Angels left-hander might have a stress fracture, a spokeswoman for the Angels said yesterday.

title: AIDS Disclosed
description: Tim Richmond, the stock car driver who died Aug. 13, contracted AIDS from an unknown woman and died of complications caused by the disease, a physician close to the driver's family disclosed yesterday.

title: 4,500 JOBS TO BE CUT BY KODAK
description: Three weeks after reporting a sharp drop in second-quarter profits, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 4,500 jobs this year, or about 3 percent of its work force, and sell some businesses.

title: POLAND CONDEMNS NAZI-SOVIET PACT
description: Fifty years after the signing of the Soviet-Nazi pact that paved the way for the Nazi invasion of Poland and led to the start of World War II, a resurgent Polish Parliament condemned the pact today as an ''infamous'' violation of Polish autonomy.

title: Vitro's Strategy In Anchor Offer
description: The battle for the Anchor Glass Container Corporation has just begun, and despite the company's resistance, many analysts say Vitro S.A., a giant Mexican glass manufacturer, stands a good chance of success with its $20-a-share tender offer for Anchor.

title: Deutsch Wins Ikea Account
description: Ikea yesterday awarded its coveted advertising account to Deutsch. The Swedish furniture chain chose the New York agency in a highly competitive review process, winnowing 100 agencies down to 4 finalists. Deutsch edged out Berenter

title: Text of Secret Protocols to 1939 Hitler-Stalin Pact
description: The secret protocols to the August 1939 nonaggression treaty between the Soviet Union and Germany are cited by residents of the Soviet Union's Baltic republics in support of their argument that the Soviet annexation of the area was illegal. Here are the texts of the protocols, as translated by the United States Government from microfilm copies of the original German Foreign Ministry documents, which were turned over to the Allies at the end of World War II: Secret Additional Protocol

title: Campaign Matters; Why Is This Man Forcing Himself To Suffer Fools?
description: Earlier this week, Charles J. Hynes stood in the middle of a swirling morning rush-hour crowd in a Brooklyn subway station. He figured the temperature was in the 90's, and right above his head a piercing buzzer sounded every time a train entered the station. ''This is madness,'' Mr. Hynes mused, as he kept his smile in place.

title: Books of The Times; The Civil War of a Black Leader and a White Soldier
description: Frederick Douglass' Civil War Keeping Faith in Jubilee By David W. Blight 270 pages. Louisiana State University Press. $27.50. The Civil War Notebooks of Daniel Chisholm A Chronicle of Daily Life in the Union Army 1864-1865 Edited by W. Springer Menge and J. August Shimrak 202 pages. Orion Books. $18.95.

title: Lilco Chief Got Raise After Shoreham Deal
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company was awarded a $149,000 bonus and a $25,000 raise the day after the utility's shareholders approved Lilco's plan to sell its Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Market Place; Goldsmith Sees U.S. Snag Ending
description: A BUOYANT Sir James Goldsmith voiced confidence yesterday that his problems with American insurance regulators were close to being resolved. He seemed to hint that it was those problems that had prevented him from putting up any cash in his bid to take over B.A.T. Industries.

title: Man Says McKinneys Broke Promise on Will
description: A 34-year-old man says the family of Representative Stewart B. McKinney, the Connecticut Congressman who died of AIDS two years ago, has reneged on a promise to let him keep property willed to him if he kept quiet about his gay relationship with Mr. McKinney.

title: NEW I.B.M. CHIP
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said its scientists had demonstrated new chips that are able to transmit and receive data over fiber-optic lines at speeds of a billion bits a second. The new optoelectronic chips are 50 times denser than earlier components. The new I.B.M. parts are fingernail-size devices that contain 8,000 transistors.

title: DEALS
description: Baseball KANSAS CITY (AL) - Placed Steve Farr, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to Aug. 22. Purchased the contract of Jerry Don Gleaton, pitcher, from Omaha of the American Association. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Acquired Ed Romero, infielder, from the Atlanta Braves for a player to be named. Placed Billy Bates, second baseman, on the 15-day disabled list. Moved Jim Gantner, second baseman, from the 15-day to the 60-day disabled list. YANKEES (AL) - Recalled Hensley Meulens, third baseman, from Columbus of the International League. Placed Steve Kiefer, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Basketball DALLAS (NBA) - Signed Randy White, forward, to a five-year contract. Football ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Scott Fulhage, punter. MIAMI (AFC) - Waived Jerry Brown and John Fruhmorgen, guards, and Michael Scott, offensive tackle. JETS (AFC) - Agreed to terms with Jeff Lageman, linebacker, on four one-year contracts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The lowest handicap I've ever had was 11, and now I couldn't play with that at all. The lowest I've had is 81 in July, and I expect to be there before we leave. I'm not a golfer. I'm a tennis player.'' - President Bush. [ B8:3. ]

title: Mavericks Sign White
description: The forward Randy White signed a guaranteed five-year contract with the Dallas Mavericks yesterday for $4.1 million and a bonus.

title: Swapo Invites Investigation Into Detainees
description: Officials of the South-West Africa People's Organization invited the International Committee of the Red Cross and Amnesty International today to visit Zambia and Angola to investigate allegations that it has imprisoned some of its own members. One of the officials acknowledged that some detainees had been tortured.

title: Massachusetts Electric Offering
description: The Massachusetts Electric Company, a unit of the New England Electric System, is offering $50 million of 9 3/4 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2019 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: CBS BID OF $300 MILLION GETS '94 WINTER GAMES
description: Just 15 months after winning the United States broadcast rights to televise the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France, CBS prevailed again yesterday, securing the rights to the Lillehammer Games of 1994 for $300 million, the minimum figure set by the International Olympic Committee.

title: A Desk For Out In the Field
description: MODERN FARM, a mail-order catalogue, has just the thing for keeping track of cow-milking schedules or breeding records. The folding Barn Desk, below, can also be used in the kitchen or garage.

title: Exhibits That Move And Moo
description: PEDESTRIANS strolling past the former Rhodes School at 212 West 83d Street in Manhattan might not be aware that lurking inside is the ''sound of moo'' and the ''land of pitter-patter.''

title: Go West, Mr. Eames
description: BY his own admission, Douglas Peix, a New York architect, is ''fairly flexible about using different materials and methods to solve a problem.''

title: U.S. Is Faulted on Military Maneuvers in Panama
description: Delegates of an Organization of American States negotiating team asserted today that military maneuvers by the United States armed forces in Panama were partly responsible for the failure of their effort to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to give up power.

title: Clash of Experts Blurs Policy on Central America
description: In an Administration where senior officials boast of being team players, efforts to articulate a new policy on Central America are being hampered by a conflict between rival experts on the region.

title: JOHNSON PLEASES HIS TOUGHEST CRITIC
description: In Howard Johnson's mind, he is like the stern, demanding father for whom no achievement is ever good enough, no success worthy of a knowing smile, a pat on the back, a handshake of congratulations. But then, perhaps Sparky Anderson is the secret driving force behind Johnson's success.

title: CHASE GROUP GETS STAKE IN A MEXICAN AIRLINE
description: A group of foreign and Mexican investors, led by Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, has bought a share of Mexico's largest airline and has an option to gain majority ownership.

title: RUMORS FLY ON BUNDESBANK RATES
description: The Bundesbank's policy makers returned from a monthlong recess today to a familiar refrain in the foreign exchange market: speculation that the West German central bank will raise interest rates to bolster the value of the mark and rein in inflationary pressures.

title: Bridge
description: The annual team championship of the Westchester Contract Bridge League, with a Swiss qualifying round leading to knockout play, is named for Shirley Hewitt, a much-loved organizer who died three years ago.

title: Harold M. Olmstead, Engineer, 98
description: Harold M. Olmstead, a retired engineer who specialized in public utility work, died Aug. 9 in the infirmary of the Virginian, a residence for the elderly in Fairfax, Va. He was 98 years old.

title: Robert Edward Anderson; Advertising Executive, 77
description: Robert Edward Anderson, a retired advertising executive who was a vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne, died of cancer Monday at Seton Medical Center in Austin, Tex. He was 77 years old and lived in Hico, Tex.

title: Group Drops Bid For HEI Concern
description: A group led by the former chairman of the HEI Corporation said it would no longer seek control of the Houston-based acute-care hospital concern. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, HEI's former chairman, Dr. George G. Alexander, said the group had abandoned its efforts because the HEI board rejected its bid for $3.25 a share, or $15.9 million.

title: An Algerian Hijacker Fails to Divert Jetliner
description: An Algerian expelled from France hijacked an Air France jetliner with more than 100 people aboard today, threatening to blow up the plane over the Mediterranean, but he was armed only with soap and toilet water and surrendered peacefully.

title: Court Drops Contempt Case
description: The Delaware Supreme Court on Tuesday dismissed contempt proceedings against Barbara Robbins, a partner with the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. The court said it was convinced she had mistakenly released confidential documents to The New York Times concerning the Paramount Communications Inc. bid for Time Inc. The court chastised Herbert

title: Steinbrenner Criticizes Green
description: Dallas Green's dismissal as Yankee manager took place six days ago, but there is apparently some lingering anger over remarks he is reported to have made in its aftermath. Lou Piniella and Billy Martin, former Yankee managers, issued statements yesterday criticizing Green, and George Steinbrenner, the team owner, said he was severing future ties with the former manager.

title: Subtle Protests You Can Hang on the Wall
description: NORTH American folk-art collectors and museums have discovered the arpillera, a South American wall hanging that depicts particular events as well as the hardships and joys of daily life. Arpillera is the Spanish word for burlap or sackcloth, the material used as the foundation for the needlework, which is executed in embroidery and appliques of gaily colored scraps of cloth.

title: The Black Panthers' Two Paths
description: When Huey Newton, co-founder and minister of defense of the Black Panther Party, went to jail in 1968 for the killing of a police officer, a single chant erupted on the nation's campuses: ''Free Huey!'' A California appeals court, citing judicial errors, eventually let him go.

title: Phone Workers Can't Shoulder Health Crisis Alone; A Corporate Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Big Chains Bar Milk Produced With Aid of Drug
description: Five of the nation's largest supermarket companies announced today that they had taken steps to make sure that dairy products that carry their stores' brands do not contain milk from cows treated with an experimental genetically engineered drug.

title: Saudi Report On Economy
description: Saudi Arabia reported today that its economy overcame a fall in oil prices to achieve solid growth last year, but independent economists said the Government would keep a tight rein on spending to insure stability.

title: Companies That Will Dye Clothing
description: FINDING someone to dye clothing can be a daunting task. While there are numerous companies that specialize in bulk dyeing (''We do 500 to 1,000 pounds at a time,'' said one employee) and those that specialize in dyeing clothes for the theater, few will accept one piece of clothing.

title: By Moonlight, A Dream Of a Garden
description: LEAD: THE white garden may well shine brightest on late summer nights, when bunched Iceberg roses catch the moonlight like corsages for ghosts, pale datura angels' trumpets play tropical music and the warm air is heady with intoxicating fragrance: nicotiana, jasmine, night-scented stock.

title: China Replaces Head of Beijing University
description: The Government today replaced the president of Beijing University, China's most prestigious academic institution and the vanguard of the democracy movement last spring. The president, Ding Shisun, was regarded as a protector of his students, and his dismissal was widely forecast by students and faculty.

title: Wang Laboratories Names Chief Executive
description: Richard W. Miller, who yesterday was named president and chief executive of Wang Laboratories Inc., considers himself a ''team builder'' who thinks the computer maker can reverse its poor fortunes by concentrating on improving service and cutting costs.

title: Colombia Adds Teeth To Drug Crackdown
description: President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia is preparing legislation allowing drug suspects whose property has been impounded three months to reclaim it, but only by personally appearing in court and proving that the property was obtained with profits from legitimate businesses. It is expected that few will make the effort.

title: A Catholic Film on a Salvadoran Murder
description: Early one morning last week, several hundred Roman Catholic priests gathered in a Manhattan movie theater to preview ''Romero,'' a film about the life of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador, who was assassinated in 1980 by a gunman believed to have been a member of a right-wing death squad. The assassin has not been found.

title: A Modernist Whose Landscape Artistry Redefined Gardens
description: TO everything horticultural there is a season. A garden that registers neither winter nor summer contradicts the order of nature - no wilting of blooms, no browning of leaves, no changing from the bright bulbs of spring to the mauve-tinted hydrangeas of fall.

title: Davis to Seek Union Backing
description: Marvin Davis, the California investor trying to take over the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, will seek support from the airline's largest union, the machinists, at a meeting tomorrow.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: B.A.T. SUITOR WOULD SELL FARMERS UNIT
description: Sir James Goldsmith said today that he would sell the American insurance subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries to a French insurer for $4.5 billion if his bid for B.A.T. succeeded.

title: Bond Offering Priced By Farm Credit Banks
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced $3.4 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds with maturities of three months, six months, one year, three years and five years.

title: Bird in a High Seat
description: People who keep tabs on nature report big crops of milkweed in coastal meadows, bushels of maple seed pods in driveways and, in city parks and summer hedgerows, a lot of catbirds.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ''I'M looking for the type of baby sitter I was when I was in high school,'' Joanne Reilly Lamb said recently. She had arrived late for her job as a part-time bookkeeper in Minneapolis because her 17-month-old son's sitter had canceled at the last minute.

title: Decisions on Recycling
description: To The Home Section:

title: Personal Health
description: Your child is about to leave home for college and you hope all the essentials for survival without your guidance have been packed: proper attire for cold and rainy days, aspirin and bandages, enough underwear and socks to last three weeks without doing the laundry, a computer and a credit card or checkbook.

title: Nabokov Is Portrayed in His Own Words
description: Writing to publishers or relatives, friends or perceived philistines, Vladimir Nabokov took meticulous care with wording, as he did with his novels and other works.

title: Phone Workers Can't Shoulder Health Crisis Alone; Nationalize the System
description: To the Editor:

title: Grant for P.S. 122
description: Performance Space 122 has received a $225,000 grant from the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund to expand its Field Trips Program, a touring program that offers showcases of work by emerging performance artists in alternative theater spaces throughout the country. The grant, which will be given over three years, will enable P.S. 122 to expand the program to include performances in additional, established theater spaces.

title: Rose, in Deal, Is Said to Accept Lifetime Ban for Betting on Reds
