description: Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, today will be declared permanently ineligible to work in baseball for betting on Reds games, people close to the Rose investigation said last night.

title: Chairman of Regents At U. Maryland Quits
description: The chairman of the University of Maryland's Board of Regents has resigned over his role in causing the resignation of the new president of the system's Baltimore campus.

title: Time Warner Discloses Stock Plan
description: After weeks of negotiations, the directors of Time Warner Inc. yesterday announced the financing for the purchase of the remaining shares of Warner.

title: JETS LOSE ONE AND WIN ONE: O'BRIEN IS HURT AND LAGEMAN FINALLY AGREES ON A CONTRACT
description: The Jets received bad news and good news today on a very busy afternoon at their training camp at Hofstra University. But when the dust settled, the bad news wasn't so bad, and the good news was very good.

title: Why Japan Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Seeks To Be Nomimee Of a New Party
description: Trying to insure that he will have two lines on the November ballot, Rudolph W. Giuliani has filed nominating petitions for a newly created party - the Independent Fusion Party.

title: Review/Art; Elaine de Kooning's Telling Portrait Drawings
description: A bygone period of American art history and some of its most prominent participants are evoked in a small memorial exhibition of portrait drawings by the artist Elaine de Kooning, on view at the Guild Hall Art Museum here through Oct. 1. In this show one can see striking portrayals of the young artist Willem de Kooning, whom she met in 1938 and married in 1943, as well as of the art critics Thomas Hess and Harold Rosenberg.

title: WIDER CAPITALISM TO BE ENCOURAGED BY POLISH LEADERS
description: The Solidarity supporter who is expected to become Poland's Prime Minister said today that he would move to broaden capitalism in Poland.

title: You File Scarfs Under D, for Design
description: THE Burdick Group of San Francisco is well known for designing exhibits for clients like the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago and the Primate Center of the San Francisco Zoo.

title: Trader Pleads Not Guilty
description: A Treasury bond trader at the Chicago Board of Trade pleaded not guilty today to charges resulting from a Federal investigation of corruption at the world's largest futures markets. The trader, Howard Goberstein, 33 years old, is charged with mail fraud and violations of the Commodities Exchange Act. Federal District Judge William Zagel set a Dec. 4 trial date.

title: No Proof Links Light to Infant Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Offers a 42-Point Fiscal Plan
description: Charging that the Koch administration is largely to blame for an ''economic standstill'' in New York City, David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would steer tax abatements and other incentives to companies that employ city residents and are in its more distressed neighborhoods.

title: Intensive Effort By Thornburgh On Press 'Leak'
description: In an unusual and intense attempt to stop unapproved disclosures of Justice Department investigations, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has stepped up efforts to find and prosecute Government officials who told a reporter about a Federal inquiry involving a Pennsylvania Congressman.

title: Review/Dance; Students From Tokyo Twin The Old Arts With the New
description: Summer Sunday afternoons are not generally a prime theater time in New York City. But the Schimmel Center of Pace University was filled for a matinee performance on Sunday by the Tamagawa University Dance and Drama group. And it was clear that the program charmed just about everyone in an audience whose age span ranged over some 60 years.

title: Boston Ballet Staff Changes
description: Anna-Marie Holmes has been named assistant to Bruce Marks, artistic director of the Boston Ballet. Ms. Holmes, the first North American ballerina to study and perform with the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad, has served as the Boston company's ballet mistress since 1985.

title: KEY RATES
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with increases for tax-exempt funds and declines for taxable funds.

title: Grumman to Shut Tachonics Unit
description: The Grumman Corporation said it would close Tachonics, a division based in Plainsboro, N.J., that makes gallium arsenide computer chips. Tachonics, which had 47 employees and has been unprofitable since its start in 1985, is the third gallium arsenide company in a year to be shut down. Gallium arsenide is a material that can be used to make chips that are faster than those made with silicon. But the market has not grown as quickly as some predicted, and there has been a glut of capacity.

title: Bush Says No on Troops to Colombia
description: President Bush said today that he would not send American troops to Colombia and complained that the interpretation of the remarks of his Attorney General on the subject had gotten ''out of whack.''

title: Entire Mail-Room Staff Is Dismissed by Ogilvy
description: Two months after its takeover by the WPP Group, Ogilvy & Mather has dismissed its entire mail-room staff and hired an outside service to do the job. Robert Bou, a former mail-room supervisor, said the staff of 18 were summoned to a meeting on Monday and told their services were no longer needed. ''Supposedly, it was a money matter,'' he said.

title: Phone Workers Can't Shoulder Health Crisis Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Society Appointment
description: The Japan Society in Manhattan has announced the appointment of Cora Mirikitani as director of performing arts and film, effective Oct. 1. Ms. Mirikitani was previously managing director of the Japanese-American Cultural and Community Center in Los Angeles.

title: U.P.S. Plans to Widen Its Deliveries Abroad
description: In a move to meet the challenge of the recently completed merger of the Federal Express Corporation and Tiger International, United Parcel Service of America Inc. said yesterday that it would expand its package delivery service to 175 countries and territories, starting Monday.

title: Correction
description: The Design Bookshelf column in The Home Section on Aug. 3 referred incompletely to the publishers of the book ''Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.'' The co-publisher, with the M.I.T. Press, was the Architectural History Foundation.

title: Veternas Say Of New Film On Vietnam, 'It's A Lie'
description: Leaders of two Vietnam veterans organizations today criticized Brian De Palma's new film, ''Casualties of War,'' as a false portrayal of the soldiers who fought in that war.

title: TRW Revamps Space Sector
description: TRW Inc. said today that it had reorganized its Space and Defense sector into four operating groups.

title: New Jersey Fear Of Toxic Metal Rises After Tests
description: Elevated levels of chromium have been found in the urine of 35 of 97 children tested after their elementary school was ordered closed in May because of the presence of the toxic metal.

title: Willie Sternberg Becomes a Bride
description: Wilma Susan Sternberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sternberg of Brooklyn, and Charles D. Mooney, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Mooney of Brooklyn, were married last evening at the Sign of the Dove in New York. Edward Thompson, a retired Chief Administrative Judge for the New York City Civil Court, officiated.

title: EX-DREXEL EMPLOYEE GETS JAIL TERM AND FINE FOR PERJURY
description: A former trading assistant at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was sentenced yesterday to 18 months in prison and ordered to pay $50,000 in fines and other penalties. The Drexel employee, Lisa Ann Jones, was convicted in March on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: BOND RALLY HELPS DOW CLIMB 27.12, TO 2,678.11
description: Stock prices surged yesterday, bolstered by stronger bond prices, a firmer dollar and some program buying.

title: CHEMISTRY FAILS METS BUT FUELS THE GIANTS
description: The San Francisco Giants are doing the things that keep a team in first place. They are getting excellent pitching. They are hitting with power. And when their opponents make mental or physical errors, as the Mets did yesterday afternoon, the Giants are quick to capitalize.

title: Splish, Splash, How They Took a Bath
description: LONG before there were designer shower curtains, bathrooms reflected the latest fashions. In a 1935 sales brochure, reprinted in Gail Caskey Winkler's new book ''The Well-Appointed Bath: Authentic Plans and Fixtures From the Early 1900's,'' a claw-footed bathtub was described as ''old-fashioned - unsightly - an irritation to the family.''

title: Seeing Poland Clear
description: Bronislaw Geremek is a Polish historian, a medievalist, who sees the contemporary politics of his country with uncanny clarity. Sixteen months ago he analyzed the Polish situation in terms that are now, to our astonishment, coming to life day by day.

title: Moves On in Congress to Lift Secrecy at the Federal Reserve
description: For the first time since the early 1980's, Congress is considering sweeping legislation to force the Federal Reserve to shed some of its secrecy and be more accountable to Americans for its decisions that for better or worse steer the economy.

title: The Talk of City Island: The City, Uninvited, Comes to City Island
description: The people of City Island have long been delighted to note that despite its name and despite where it is, hardly anything about the island is city-like.

title: After a Decade of Expansion, L.I. Economic Bubble Bursts
description: As the economy slows across the New York metropolitan region and much of the Northeast, economists say Long Island is on the leading edge of the downturn. After a decade of explosive growth, the Island's bubble has burst.

title: Baltic Citizens Link Hands to Demand Independence
description: Hundreds of thousands of Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians were reported today to have linked hands across their Baltic homelands and demanded the right to ''restore their independent statehood.''

title: Critic's Notebook; Candidates' Advertising Exposes Shortcomings
description: As most television watchers must have noticed by now, the battle of the mayoral commercials is under way. Of the four Democratic and two Republican contenders, only Rudolph W. Giuliani has yet to show his stuff on the tube. One may not learn much about the issues in 30 or 60 seconds - except that all parties agree on the need to be tough - but the way the candidates are using television exposes their weaknesses even while celebrating their strengths.

title: Order on Merger Amended
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the United States Supreme Court today amended an order she had issued on Monday, blocking the $2.5 billion merger of American Stores Inc. of Salt Lake City and Lucky Stores Inc. of Dublin, Calif, until the court decides whether to hear an appeal by California's Attorney General, In her amended order, Justice O'Connor reinstated a requirement that the state post a bond to appeal the case. The district court had earlier ordered the state to post a $16.3 million bond. The state, which opposes the merger on antitrust grounds, said it could not pay and appealed the bond order. The court of appeals denied that appeal.

title: Digital Plan For Cutbacks
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had asked a number of its departments to plan for a 25 percent reduction in staff and a 10 percent cut in spending, but a company spokeswoman insisted the company was not planning layoffs.

title: Report on Peru Shows Rising Tide of Rights Abuses
description: The disappearance, torture and killings of citizens by security forces and guerrillas in Peru have steadily risen the last 18 months, Amnesty International said today.

title: Slask, Polish Folk Ballet, To Perform in 29 Cities
description: Slask, the National Folk Ballet of Poland, will perform at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Sept. 19 to 24, in the first performance of a 10-week tour of the United States and Canada. Formed in 1953, the 100-member company will present a program of 25 pieces of dance and music from the regions of Silesia, Krakow and the Tatra Mountains.

title: Taiwan Stock Market
description: Direct foreign investment in Taiwan's booming stock market is still years away, blocked by the fast pace of the island's financial success, a senior regulatory official said today. Lu Tung-ying, vice chairman of Taiwan's Securities and Exchange Commission, said regulation of the securities industry had to catch up with the rapid growth of the market before foreigners could be allowed in. Currently the only way foreigners can legally invest in Taiwan is to join one of four funds. Its stock market has been among the world's strongest in recent years.

title: INSURANCE CUTS IN CALIFORNIA ARE FALLING SHORT OF PROMISE
description: Nine months after California voters approved an initiative mandating sweeping cuts in auto and other insurance rates, the measure is proving less onerous to insurers and less beneficial to consumers than either side expected.

title: Scientists Find Hope for Victims of Cystic Fibrosis by Discovering Its Gene
description: Prospects for saving the lives of people with cystic fibrosis have been greatly enhanced by the discovery of the gene that causes it, experts said yesterday.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: IT is damp, and sometimes the rain is a downpour. One Saturday afternoon it was literally thrilling, the way it pounded the gardens and bounced off the fence beyond my bedroom windows. The basements over on the next block have flooded; I am afraid to go downstairs and check ours. Even so, I love this weather. When the heat breaks in New York, I am reminded of those old movies in which the doctor and the parents hover over the ailing child waiting for his temperature to drop. A New York that's 20 degrees cooler than it was a day earlier wakes at dawn as that child always did: smiling and clear-eyed.

title: Former Greek Official to Be Tried for Graft
description: Parliament voted tonight to try a former Socialist Cabinet official on charges of corruption. The decision is the most definitive step yet by the coalition of Conservatives and Communists to press corruption charges against members of the previous Government.

title: Evacuation For Asbestos Near Blast Site
description: More than 200 residents of a Gramercy Park apartment building that was heavily damaged in a steam-pipe explosion over the weekend were ordered from their homes last night after tests showed what a Consolidated Edison official called ''extremely high'' levels of asbestos fibers throughout the building.

title: Account
description: * Ellesse, the tennis and active sportswear division of Reebok International, to Tarlow Advertising, with an undisclosed budget.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BALKY or drafty double-hung windows can often be repaired and sealed quickly by replacing window channels, a project best done now, while the weather is still mild. Various styles are available, the simplest being shallow metal troughs that fit vertically into the window frame, creating smooth, close-fitting channels in which the sashes can slide.

title: Review/Dance; Where Jazz and Dance Meet
description: It seemed like a good idea when the Lincoln Center Out of Doors summer arts festival announced it would present a two-part program on the relationship of American jazz and dance. The program was to open with ''Scat Dancing,'' developed by Larry Ridley and C. Scobey Stroman for the American Dance Festival in 1981 and 1982. ''Tap Blast'' was to follow on the next evening, featuring a roster of top tap artists. But the first program, presented Tuesday night on a stage next to the Damrosch Park band shell, was drearily second-rate.

title: Autism Study Finds a Higher Risk of Recurrence in Families
description: The most extensive survey to date of the incidence of autism shows that the risk for a family with one autistic child of having another is far higher than had been thought.

title: Harken Makes Bid for Tesoro
description: The Harken Energy Corporation, an energy development company, today offered to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation of San Antonio for $11.75 a share, or about $190 million, in cash.

title: New York Post Endorses Koch
description: Calling Mayor Edward I. Koch, ''the best in a class field'' of Democratic mayoral candidates, The New York Post yesterday endorsed Mr. Koch in the Sept. 12 Democratic primary. It was the first of the four major daily newspapers in New York City to make an endorsement in the mayoral primary.

title: Joliet Journal; A Florida-Style Village For Those Liking Snow
description: Louis and Joan Vitullo wanted to live in one of those Florida-style retirement villages, the ones with tennis courts, swimming pools and golf courses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17, B6 Capitalism will expand in Poland, said the Solidarity supporter who is expected to become Poland's Prime Minister. The statement came a day after Lech Walsea was quoted as making similar remarks. Page A1

title: Truce Imperiled, Angola Leader Says
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola asserted today that the country's two-month-old cease-fire is in jeopardy because the United States and South Africa continue to arm guerrilla forces.

title: Democrats Double-Deal on Nicaragua
description: The Administration and the members of Congress who have supported Nicaragua's liberation from Marxist totalitarian rule learned long ago that Sandinista promises are worthless. We must now learn a more difficult and much more discouraging lesson: We cannot depend upon the Democratic leadership in Congress to honor its commitment to a bipartisan foreign policy.

title: Ph.D., Translated, Means 'Piled High, Densely,'
description: LEAD: No one in the United States seems to know where to put solid waste - except the universities. The universities put it in the campus library, and call it scholarly research.

title: EDA Systems Fills Job Of President and Chief
description: EDA Systems Inc. said yesterday that Andre O. Schwager had joined the Santa Clara, Calif., company as president and chief executive.

title: U.S. Expands Generic-Drug Inspections
description: As part of its crackdown on the generic drug industry, the Food and Drug Administation announced today that it would inspect the plants of 20 additional large manufacturers of generic drugs.

title: Q&A
description: Removing Wallpaper Q.I am in the process of removing three layers of wallpaper from a ceiling. The last layer of paper was painted over, and I cannot use a steamer because I want to preserve the finish on the walls. I bought a can of a liquid wallpaper remover, but I find that it does not penetrate the painted wallpaper very well and thus does not soften it enough for easy scraping. Any suggestions? A.The easiest way to solve this problem is to buy some of the coarsest sandpaper you can find. The type used for sanding floors is best for this purpose. Rub the sandpaper over the painted paper, scoring and scratching the paint as much as possible.

title: The Message From Neptune
description: At the edge of the solar system, in the twilight before the interstellar dark, floats a giant bubble of eggshell blue, girdled by delicate rings and a mottled, pale pink moon. That's the stunning vista now being transmitted by Voyager 2 as it enters the realm of the planet Neptune. Early tomorrow morning, 12 years and 5 days out from Earth, after a flight of nearly four and a half billion miles, Voyager will scud across Neptune's cloud tops, its last landfall before the stars.

title: Panel Rejects Plan to Shift Grand Central's Air Rights
description: An extraordinary plan to transfer development rights from Grand Central Terminal along a subsurface route to a site four blocks away, where they would have been used to construct one of the biggest buildings in New York City, was rejected unanimously yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission.

title: Calendar of Events: A Festival of Crafts
description: Originals All, Fordham University Plaza at Lincoln Center, 62d Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues; 212-677-4627.

title: Hong Kong Is to Abolish Use Of Floggings for Punishment
description: The Government said today it would abolish flogging, a punishment in which a male offender is beaten a maximum of 18 times with a cane in the presence of a doctor.

title: IT'S S.R.O. AT UNITED REPAIR SHOP
description: The United Airlines maintenance center here is the largest aircraft repair shop in the world, so big that it has been able to work on planes owned by more than 60 airline and military customers.

title: BONWIT AND ALTMAN TRY TO RECOVER
description: Bonwit Teller Inc. and B. Altman & Company appear to be on the road to recovery two weeks after they filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, Sanford C. Sigoloff, the new chief executive of the L. J. Hooker Corporation, said yesterday.

title: HOUSE PANEL SEEKS H.U.D. TESTIMONY
description: A House panel investigating favoritism and mismanagement in Federal housing programs said today it had asked the chairman of Paine Webber Inc. to testify about the firm's consulting arrangements with the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: UNEASY LIES THE HEAD OF NO. 3 QUARTERBACK
description: A month ago, Jeff and Laura Rutledge decided that today would be Reunion Day, the day Laura and their three children would leave their home in Mission Viejo, Calif., and fly east to join Jeff for the winter.

title: Lauder Declares He'd Phase Out The Income Tax for New York City
description: Calling New York City ''an economic basket case,'' Ronald Lauder, a contender for the Republican mayoral nomination, promised yesterday that if elected he would rescue the economy by phasing out the city's income tax.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies Eastman Kodak said it would eliminate 4,500 jobs, about 3 percent of its work force, and sell some businesses. The company also said it would cut management salaries by up to 40 percent. The announcement came three weeks after Kodak reported a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings. [ Page D1. ] Sales of domestic cars rose 5.4 percent in mid-August, as incentives helped cut into inventories before the introduction of the 1990 models. The increase resulted in the highest seasonally adjusted annual selling rate in seven months. [ D1. ] Chevrolet will stop using Walt Disney characters in advertising Lumina cars. [ D4. ] Bonwit Teller and B. Altman appear to be on the road to recovery two weeks after they filed for bankruptcy protection. [ D1. ] Sir James Goldsmith said he would sell the American insurance subsidiary of B.A.T. to a French insurer for $4.5 billion if his bid for B.A.T. succeeds. [ D1. ] Wang Labs named Richard W. Miller chief executive. He is a former head of G.E.'s consumer electronics operations. [ D4. ] CBS won the right to broadcast the Winter Olympics in 1994 with a bid of $300 Million. [ D24. ] Foreign and Mexican investors led by Chase Manhattan have bought a share of Mexico's largest airline. [ D2. ] Time Warner's directors announced the financing for the purchase of the remaining shares of Warner. [ D18. ] U.P.S. will expand its package delivery service to 175 countries and territories, starting Monday. [ D4. ] Harken Energy offered to acquire Tesoro Petroleum for $11.75 a share, or about $190 million, in cash. [ D4. ] The Economy Insurance rates in California are proving harder to cut than was envisioned when voters approved an initiative last year. The state's insurance commissioner has exempted many companies from any rollbacks, noting a court decision that the companies are entitled to a fair profit. [ D1. ] The F.D.A. will begin plant inspections of 20 additional large manufacturers of generic drugs. [ D5. ] Markets A former trading assistant at Drexel Burnham Lambert was sentenced to 18 months at a minimum-security Federal prison and ordered to pay $50,000 in fines and other penalties. Lisa Ann Jones was convicted in March of perjury and obstruction of justice. [ D2. ] Stock prices surged, bolstered by stronger bond prices, a firmer dollar and some program buying. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 27.12 points, to 2,678.11. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury securities rallied, as credit market participants responded favorably to the sale of $7.75 billion worth of five-year Treasury notes. [ D13. ] Yields of money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday. [ D13. ] The dollar recovered from some of its sharp losses earlier in the week. [ D16. ] Rumors of foreign interest in American sugar prompted a flurry of late buying. [ D16. ] International Speculation continues that the Bundesbank will raise interest rates to relieve inflationary pressures. [ D14. ] Britain's balance of payments deficit in July deepened to $:2.06 billion ($3.25 billion), its second-worst monthly figure ever. [ D15. ] Today's Columns Anchor Glass may not be able to fend off a hostile offer much longer, analysts say. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Sir James Goldsmith voiced confidence that his problems with American insurance regulators were close to being resolved. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] The wine industry has never done much advertising. But with sales down in the U.S., vintners are interested. Advertising. [ D18. ]

title: Violations at Indiana
description: Indiana University has released a 64-page report to the National Collegiate Athletic Association concerning what Athletic Director Ralph Floyd called inadvertent and unintentional violations in its basketball recruitment of Lawrence Funderburke.

title: A Hot Day And the Mets Were Melty
description: Scoreboard watchers, like everyone else, were having a slow day at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon, and not only because the hot sun made even moving one's eyeballs an effort. But also, there was only one other afternoon game being played in the major leagues, Cincinnati at Chicago. Everything else on the center field scoreboard began with ''N,'' or ''Nothin' till night.''

title: Barneys Plans Chicago Store
description: Barneys New York, the big clothier based in Manhattan, confirmed today that it planned to open a large store in Chicago as part of an ambitious expansion.

title: Drug Gang Chief Charged in Officer's Killing
description: Howard (Pappy) Mason, the reputed leader of a violent narcotics ring in southern Queens, was indicted yesterday on Federal racketeering and conspiracy charges that include his ordering the 1988 murder of Police Officer Edward Byrne.

title: U.S. AUTO SALES AT HIGHTST RATE IN 7 MONTHS
description: Sales of domestic cars rose 5.4 percent in mid-August, bolstered by incentive campaigns to clear inventories before the introduction of the 1990 models.

title: 2 Networks to Carry Live Neptune Pictures
description: The Public Broadcasting System and the Cable News Network plan to carry live pictures of Neptune taken by Voyager 2 as the spacecraft passes the planet early tomorrow morning.

title: Ocean Grove Memories
description: To The Home Section:

title: Let's Save Our Lungs at the Tollbooth During Ozone Alerts
description: To the Editor:

title: Deng Ill, but Ailment Is Called No Threat to Life
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, who turned 85 years old on Tuesday, is ill and is receiving special medical care in a beachside resort, Chinese officials and an East European diplomat say.

title: TEAR GAS IS FIRED AT TUTU AT RALLY
description: The police fired tear gas today to disperse thousands of anti-apartheid demonstrators, including Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and stone-throwing crowds in several townships outside Cape Town.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY AND SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 and 10:30 A.M. and 3:30 and 4 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Bush Is Yipping and Chipping in Wedge City
description: To achieve Vic Damone in a dog-eat-dog match, Mr. Smooth must avoid Wedge City, control the yips and chips and steer the ball to the dance floor.

title: CHENEY CRITICIZES CUTS IN MILITARY
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today assailed his former House colleagues for cutting the military budget, saying they acted on the mistaken assumption that the Soviet military threat is diminishing.

title: YANKS SINK DEEPER
description: They are down to this: hope. It is all the Yankees have left now, the only thing they can grab and hold in the season's final weeks. But it is fading quickly.

title: Hickman Price Jr., Executive, 78
description: Hickman Price Jr., a former assistant secretary in the United States Department of Commerce and a business executive, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 78 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Brewers Acquire Romero From Braves
description: The Milwaukee Brewers acquired the veteran Ed Romero from the Atlanta Braves yesterday.

title: 2 Abortion Rights Advocates Lead in South Carolina Race
description: Two advocates of abortion rights will face each other in a runoff election after outpolling an abortion opponent Tuesday in a Republican primary for a State Assembly seat.

title: R.D. Laing, Rebel and Pioneer On Schizophrenia, Is Dead at 61
description: R. D. Laing, the British psychiatrist who broke with traditional psychotherapy and sought new treatments for schizophrenia based on a concern for the rights of mental patients, died suddenly yesterday while vacationing in France. He was 61 years old.

title: Experts Finding New Hope On Treating Crack Addicts
description: Drug experts now believe that the extreme difficulties they face in treating crack addiction stem far more from the setting and circumstances of the users than the biochemical reaction the drug produces.

title: Solo Duo: Bill Murray Directing Bill Murray
description: He's sitting on the sidewalk, sipping iced tea and leaning against the gate of Public School 316 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. A block away, on the elevated tracks of Broadway, a J train roars by, largely unnoticed. A bunch of neighborhood kids pass him, stare, and smile at the guy in the green bowling shirt.

title: J.C. Addonizio, Medical Academy Chief
description: Dr. Joseph C. Addonizio, a urologist who was chairman of the department of urology at the New York Medical College and president of the New York Academy of Medicine, died of heart failure Sunday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Boy-Girl Family Found To Be 'American Norm'
description: For American parents, the preference for boys seems to be giving way to a desire for a child of each sex. Parents with two boys or two girls are quicker to have a third child than are those with one of each gender, Dr. Paul T. Schollaert and Dr. Jay D. Teachman report in the August issue of Demography, the journal of the Population Association of America.

title: Wine Makers Get a Pitch To Publicize
description: WITH the exception of Ernest & Julio Gallo and a few other giants, the American wine industry has never done much advertising. Most wineries cannot afford it, and others say word of mouth remains the best way to promote prestigious products.

title: A Drug Personality? Experts Answer 'No'
description: What kind of person becomes addicted to crack, or drugs in general?

title: Uncannily Precise, Voyager Bears Down on Neptune
description: After a journey of 12 years and 4.4 billion miles, Voyager 2 streaked with astonishing accuracy tonight toward its planned rendezvous late Thursday with Neptune.

title: Panel Closes Hearings in Iran-Contra Case
description: Despite the pleas of a number of news organizations that had sought an open hearing, a Federal appeals court panel today closed its proceedings in the case of Joseph Fernandez, a former C.I.A. station chief in Costa Rica accused of lying to investigators about his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: DODGERS BEAT EXPOS WITH HOMER IN THE 22d
description: Rick Dempsey's leadoff homer in the 22d inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 1-0 victory over the Montreal Expos tonight in the second-longest shutout in major league history.

title: Guest List of the Masters Who Summer at the Met
description: EVERY summer, while their owners spend a few months in the South of France or some similar locale, paintings by artists like Canaletto, Gauguin and Rembrandt take up residence on the walls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. These seasonal guests are distinguishable from works in the permanent collection only by labels that describe them in small print as belonging to an anonymous collector, although it is impossible for the casual observer to know which of the paintings are on long-term loan and which are just passing through.

title: KICKBACK INQUIRY BY U.S. SEEN
description: The Government is investigating whether some mutual fund managers who bought slow-selling securities for their funds from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. received what might have amounted to kickbacks - warrants for their own accounts - people close to the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Anti-Alcohol Campaign
description: The Alcoholism Council of Greater New York is about to start telling pregnant women, ''If you choose to drink, here's to birth defects.'' In a new pro bono ad campaign scheduled to begin after Labor Day, the powerful television and outdoor advertisements play off the act of toasting in a dark and sinister way. ''The idea was to turn a horrifying result into a horrifying proposition,'' said Jeff DeJoseph, a senior vice president at Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, which created the campaign.

title: SEARCH FOR BODIES SWITCHING TO BRONX PLAYGROUND
description: The children of Herman and Frances McMillan have told officials their father buried their two dead brothers in a playground a short walk from their apartment in the Bronx, not in an embankment on the Major Deegan Expressway, as Mr. McMillan said after his arrest on Monday.

title: Sodarcan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds. Included in the latest quarter and 6-month results was a gain of $780,000 on the sale of an investment.

title: Worry Grows for Russians in Estonia
description: A Russian in Estonia does not have to know the local language to read the signs that his welcome has worn thin.

title: White House
description: ''Now-nowism.''

title: BASS P.L.C. TO ACQUIRE HOLIDAY INN
description: The Holiday Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Holiday Inn hotel chain to Bass P.L.C., a British brewer with interests in the restaurant and lodging industries. Bass will pay Holiday's shareholders $125 million in Bass stock and assume about $2.1 billion of debt.

title: TEXAS AIR MAY SELL CONTINENTAL
description: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, said yesterday that the company was considering the sale of a controlling or a minority interest in Continental Airlines and had already talked with parties interested in buying it. Airline analysts interpreted the move as an effort to raise cash and bolster the stock price of Texas Air.

title: Early Draws Differ For Lendl and Graf
description: If tough early-round opponents can sharpen a tennis star's game, Ivan Lendl should be in top form and Steffi Graf should be ripe for upset by the time the United States Open reaches its late stages in a couple of weeks.

title: IS 1989 LIKE 1987? NO, BY MOST ANY MEASURE
description: Although the Dow Jones industrial average reached a high yesterday, Wall Street remains a far more subdued place than it was at the 1987 peak. Enthusiasm for stocks is far less, brokerage house profits are down, and many of the thousands of people laid off by Wall Street have not returned to the industry. A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sells for less than half what it fetched at the 1987 peak.

title: Dining Out Guide: Trattorias
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Chelsea Trattoria Italiano

description: b-Net income

title: Astrex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains from the repurchase of debentures of $482,000 for the latest quarter and $313,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: ABC Names Anchor For Sunday Program
description: Forrest Sawyer, a co-anchor of the ABC News program ''World News This Morning,'' has been named an anchor of ''World News Sunday.'' He will replace Sam Donaldson, who has been the news anchor of the program since its premiere 10 years ago.

title: La-Z-Boy Chair Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said the decrease in net is a result of soft retail demand for furniture and higher production and material costs.

title: American Steel & Wire reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extrordinary credit of $3,878,000, or 69 cents a share.

title: Blues, Folk And Gospel
description: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors series ends this weekend with the Blues and Gospel Festival tomorrow and the Folk Heritage Festival on Sunday, both in Damrosch Park. Information: 877-2011. Here is the schedule of the free concerts. Tomorrow REVEREND DON SMITH, noon. BOB BROZMAN: THE BLUE HULA STOMPER, 1 P.M. DRINK SMALL, 2 P.M. MARCIA BALL, 3 P.M. MOSES RASCOE, 4 P.M. FAIRFIELD FOUR, 5 P.M. MIGHTY JOE YOUNG, 6 P.M. THE CHAMBERS BROTHERS, 7:30 P.M. KATIE WEBSTER: THE SWAMP BOOGIE QUEEN, 9 P.M. Sunday THE HUDSON RIVER BOYS, noon. THE PATON FAMILY, 1 P.M. PRISCILLA HERDMAN, 2 P.M. SI KAHN, 3 P.M. THE BRUCE DAIGREPONT CAJUN BAND, 4 P.M. TOWNES VAN ZANDT, 5 P.M. ALISON KRAUSS AND UNION STATION, 6 P.M. BUSKIN AND BATTEAU, 7 P.M. THE CLANCY BROTHERS WITH ROBBIE O'CONNELL, 8 P.M.

title: The Zones of Freedom
description: Three years and six months ago, Natan Sharansky was freed from the Soviet prison cells in which he had spent almost a decade - more than one-fourth of his life.

title: Boston Five Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1.4 million from the sale of a building.

title: Such a Nice Guy
description: David Dinkins is a soft-spoken gentleman of moderate manner and views, the experienced Borough President of Manhattan, and the favorite to win the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York City in the primary on Sept. 12.

title: Henszey & Albert Gains
description: With the appointment of Henszey & Albert to handle advertising promotion for The New York Post, the 16-month-old agency has quickly rolled up more than $11 million in annual billings. The budget for The Post has not been set, but the agency estimated that it would be at least $1 million. And just yesterday, Henszey & Albert won another new piece of business: Carol Dauplaise, a costume jewelry manufacturer, worth another $500,000. The agency was started by Cathy Henszey, a former art director with Arnell-Bickford, and Rick Albert, a veteran of Kenyon & Eckhardt and Chiat/Day.

title: Continental Health Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
R.D. LAING, REBEL AND PIONEER ON SCHIZOPHRENIA, IS DEAD AT 61
description: R. D. Laing, the British psychiatrist who broke with traditional psychotherapy and sought new treatments for schizophrenia based on a concern for the rights of mental patients, died suddenly Wednesday while vacationing in France. He was 61 years old.

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for 12mo July 31
