description: b-Net loss

title: Club-Wielding Police in Kiev Attack Protest on 1939 Pact
description: Policemen with riot sticks attacked demonstrators in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, on Wednesday, wounding dozens of them, to break up a protest marking the 50th anniversary of the 1939 German-Soviet pact dividing Eastern Europe, protesters said today.

title: The Challenge in Bensonhurst
description: Add the name of Yusef Hawkins, a black youth from Brooklyn, to the list of victims, black and white, of racial violence in New York City. The growing list challenges the city's political and moral leadership, but first and foremost it challenges law enforcement. In that sense, Mayor Koch's call for a special prosecutor is premature.

title: Addenda
description: * The Art Directors Club has donated its collection of award-winning television commercials to the Museum of Broadcasting. The museum will screen the commercials from Sept. 5 to Jan. 6.

title: High-Level Officials of U.S. and Colombia Meet on Drug Issue
description: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger met today with Colombia's Foreign Minister to discuss the tide of drug-related violence in Colombia and its latest efforts to combat narcotics traffickers.

title: What Giamatti and Rose Said on the Agreement and Disagreements
description: Following are the texts of statements made yesterday in New York by Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti and in Cincinnati by Pete Rose, the manager of the Reds, as recorded by The Associated Press: Giamatti's Statement

title: Like a Family Parting
description: Behind the scenes of Voyager 2's encounter with Neptune, a scientific family is breaking up after 17 years of conflict and triumph. Page A12.

title: YOUTH'S KILLING DEPLORED BY MAYORAL CANDIDATES
description: Candidates in the New York City mayoral race yesterday deplored the slaying Wednesday night of a 16-year-old black youth in Brooklyn and said the incident should not be exploited for political purposes.

title: Son of Loews Chairman Advances at Lorillard
description: Andrew H. Tisch climbed another step in the family business yesterday, becoming chairman and chief executive of Lorillard Inc., the tobacco company owned by the Loews Corporation. Mr. Tisch, 40, is the son of Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of Loews, and the nephew of its president, Preston R. Tisch.

title: What Presidents Did Before They Had Pensions; Wilson's Benefactors
description: To the Editor:

title: CalFed to Sell Card Portfolio
description: CalFed Inc. agreed to sell its $125 million credit-card portfolio to Household Bank N.A. CalFed said it expected to report an after-tax gain of $10 million to $15 million from the sale. Household Bank, a unit of

title: Essex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Gould Investors L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said this year's third quarter loss included a gain on dispositions on properties, mortgages and investments of $3,000 and the 9 months included gains of $4,163,000. The company also said the 1988 third quarter included $159,000 and the 9 months included $1,848,000 from these gains.

title: Next Wave Director Named To New York Festival Post
description: Joseph V. Melillo, director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival since its inception in 1983, has been named president and artistic director of the New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: The Legend of Charlie Hustle: Peter Edward Rose
description: Above all else, above his many records and his few clashes with opponents in the heat of ball games and the early charges of his ''hot-dogging,'' Pete Rose was known for his devotion to baseball.

title: Wilson Hits And Steals As Toronto Halts Tigers
description: Mookie Wilson hit three singles, drove in two runs, stole two bases and scored twice as the Toronto Blue Jays crushed the Detroit Tigers tonight, 11-3, and swept the three-game series.

title: LAWYER PLEADS FOR HELMSLEY'S ACQUITTAL
description: The chief lawyer for Leona Helmsley implored the jury yesterday to ''end the long, terrible suffering of Mrs. Helmsley'' and ''let her walk out of this courtroom a free woman.''

title: Reviews/Film; 'Wired,' in Which Belushi Hails a Cabbie From Heaven
description: Unlike the grimly detailed Bob Woodward book on which it is based, the movie ''Wired'' seems to want to be an upbeat, funny, maybe even life-affirming biography of John Belushi, the television and screen comedian who died of a drug overdose seven years ago at the age of 33.

title: Don't Politicize Health Services for Poor Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunrise Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASBESTOS PERIL ROUTS MORE AT BLAST SITE
description: Alarmed by high asbestos readings in and around Gramercy Park, the New York City Health Department declared a health emergency last night and ordered tenants in a second apartment building - about eight remaining families - to evacuate their homes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a speech by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney on the military budget incorrectly characterized his comments about his former colleagues in the House. He criticized them for shifting funds from programs given priority by President Bush to programs favored by members of the House, not for cutting the budget.

title: BKW Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hungary Lets East Germans go
description: Hungary allowed 108 East Germans who had taken refuge in the West German Embassy in Budapest to leave the country today.

title: Central Guaranty Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $4,796,000, or 7 cents a share, and $8,082,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $2,767,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,237,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months. The company said share earnings are fully diluted and reflect a 2-for-1 stock split. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Film; Hackman And Chicago In 'Package,' A Thriller
description: ''The Package'' is a feeble attempt to keep the old-fashioned cold-war thriller alive in this era of glasnost.

title: Political Memo; Iowa Abortion-Rights Voters Altering Electoral Equation
description: The Supreme Court's decision allowing states to put limits on abortion is energizing abortion rights supporters in Iowa, creating a powerful new variable in a state so often considered a political laboratory.

title: Review/Cabaret; Christine Andreas Recalls Era of Musicals
description: The Broadway and Hollywood tradition of the unblemished leading lady with a lyric soprano that conjures fairy-tale romance may be in its twilight. But as long as singers like Christine Andreas continue to come along, there is little chance of its completely fading away.

title: Orioles Give and Take As Yanks Fall 10 1/2 Out
description: There is life in the Yankees, but not much anymore. They are losing games, and if they still have hope, it is only a fading and failing sense that something will suddenly happen.

title: Court Backs Extraditing Greek
description: A fugitive Greek banker who faces embezzlement charges that helped bring down the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou may be extradited to Greece, a Federal magistrate ruled today.

title: Toronto Dominion Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Per-share figures reflected the 100- percent stock dividend paid in July. Included are losses on loans to less developed countries of 7 cents a share versus 5 cents a share in the third quarter and 10 cents a share versus 6 cents a share in the 9 months. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Restaurants
description: La Reserve Amid the hubbub and hustle of Rockefeller Center, La Reserve, as the name implies, is a sedate sanctuary. Colorful murals in the dining room depict a marshy wildlife reserve, and indeed, the gastronomic game warden here, Jean-Louis Missud, keeps a vigilant eye on his well-feathered flock.

title: Sony Corp of America () reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen, for convenience only, at the rate of Yen 144 to $1, the approximate Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of June 30, 1989. Each Depositary Share represents one share of common stock. Primary net income per Depositary Share is computed based on the average number of common shares outstanding during each period after consideration of the dilutive effect of common stock equivalents which include warrants and certain convertible bonds. Fully diluted net income per Depositary Share further assumes that all other convertible bonds and debentures were converted into common stock.

title: Whitman Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: 3 at Knitting Factory

title: As a Treat, Walk 897 Steps
description: For centuries, vandals have scratched their initials in the stones of great monuments or chipped pieces as souvenirs. So, too, at the Washington Monument, where visitors are not allowed to use the stairs because of damage to the stones in the 555-foot obelisk.

title: Brighton Beach Festival
description: The 13th Brighton Beach Jubilee in Brooklyn will take place on Sunday on Brighton Beach Avenue, between Coney Island Avenue and Corbin Place. Sponsored by the Brighton Neighborhood Association, the street festival will be held from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., rain or shine, and will feature crafts, food, rides and entertainment. Information: (718) 891-0800.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Traded Jim Acker, pitcher, to the Toronto Blue Jays for Tony Castillo, pitcher, and a player to be named later. Traded Paul Assenmacher, pitcher, to the Chicago Cubs for two players to be named later. Called up Mike Stanton, pitcher, and Ed Whited, third baseman, from Richmond of the International League. BOSTON (AL) - Activated Eric Hetzel, pitcher, from the 21-day disabled list. Optioned Tom Bolton, pitcher, to Pawtucket of the International League. CHICAGO (NL) - Sent Joe Kraemer, pitcher, to Iowa of the American Assoication. CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Tommy Helms interim manager. COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE - Suspended Pete Rose, Cincinnati Reds manager, for life for gambling. He may apply for reinstatement after one year. FOOTBALL INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Cut William Mackall and Joey Clinkscales, wide receivers; William Dubose, running back; Chris Carrier, halfback; Paul Riley, tight end, and Cornelius Southall, defensive back. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Agreed to terms with Derrick Thomas, linebacker. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Creighton Incorminias, offensive tackle, and Mike McGee, fullback. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Released Florian Kempf, place-kicker; Clarence Woods and Spencer Cotten, wide receivers; Jerry Dunlap, cornerback, and Elliott Eley, running back. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Signed Louis Lipps, wide receiver, to a three-year contract. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Donald Igwebuike, kicker, to a two-year contract. HOCKEY TORONTO (NHL) - Signed Doug Carpenter, head coach, to a two-year contract. HORSE RACING OHIO STATE RACING COMMISSION - Suspended Mark Gorfido, Bill Popio, Craig Stein, Jerry Randall and Tom Randall, driver-trainers, for one-year, effective Sept. 8, and fined them $250 each after their horses tested positive for prohibited drugs. COLLEGES ALLEGHENY - Named Missy Vogel women's assistant basketball and softball coach. BROWN - Named Stuart Le Gassick squash coach. UC DAVIS - Named Frank Perez men's assistant basketball coach. FAIRFIELD - Named George Carl head golf coach and Anita D'Ascenzo head field hockey coach and club sports coordinator. IVY LEAGUE - Named Douglas Q. Davis 2d athletic-administration intern and Paul Prox sports-information intern.

title: Britain Paved Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael A. Diana, 80, Doctor and Missionary
description: Dr. Michael A. Diana, a Manhattan surgeon who served for many years as a volunteer in hospitals in Afghanistan, India and Nicaragua, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington. He was 80 years old and lived in Ferrisburg, Vt.

title: What's at the Modern? All the New That Endured
description: AT this moment, the Museum of Modern Art has no major loan exhibition. Helen Frankenthaler has just been taken down. Braque and Picasso do not open to the public until Sept. 24.

title: Review/Theater; Guided Missives, In 2-Person Gurney Play
description: In ''Love Letters,'' A. R. Gurney has written an evocative epistolary account of two charter members of the privileged set. In less than two hours, we see Andrew Makepeace Ladd 3d and Melissa Gardner over a period of 50 years, as the author carries them from second grade through the trauma of adulthood, marriage, divorce and middle age. Despite the scope of the story, this is a work of modest intentions and modest achievement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of California, San Francisco, appointed Jones M. Castro Jr. senior vice president of its international banking division.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on July 25 about seven species of North American bird that are declining misstated the views of Gregory S. Butcher, director of bird population studies at the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology. Dr. Butcher has written a letter pointing out that he said the birds should be given immediate consideration for the Federal endangered species list; he did not say they should be listed.

title: PGI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included for the 6 months tax credits of $49,000; net for periods equals less than 1 cent a share after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Treasury securities prices were essentially unchanged yesterday as trading activity slackened after the Government wound up its auctions this week of more than $40 billion of new debt issues. Dealers said that with the bulk of the new issues now in retail portfolios, many market makers considered it time for a vacation.

title: Review/Film; El Salvador's Slain Hero Of the Cloth
description: ''Romero'' is an earnest, straightforward reconstruction of the life, political education and assassination of Oscar Arnulfo Romero, the liberal Archbishop of San Salvador, as he was celebrating Mass in 1980.

title: Insider Inquiry On Squibb Deal
description: Squibb Corporation officials said today that Federal investigators were looking into possible insider trading violations concerning Squibb's proposed merger with the Bristol-Myers Company.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I have concluded that he bet on baseball.'' - A. Bartlett Giamatti. ''Regardless of what the commissioner said today, I did not bet on baseball.'' - Pete Rose. [ A1:4. ]

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY 'INFERNAL MACHINE'

title: Books of The Times; Small-Town Lives and a Sinister Mystery
description: Eden Close By Anita Shreve 265 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: GIULIANI TV AD STRESSES SUCCESS AS A PROSECUTOR
description: The Rudolph W. Giuliani campaign last night began running its first television commercials. They attack three other mayoral contenders and underscore Mr. Giuliani's image as a prosecutor by using photos of a mob figure and a politician he helped send to prison.

title: Fans Are Puzzled and Dismayed
description: They were glad it was over, but they weren't sure exactly how it ended. They voiced strong opinions, then asked for clarifications on the ruling. They read newspapers and listened to morning radio reports, but they still couldn't figure out just what had happened to Pete Rose.

title: On Stage
description: Beating the Film to the Theater David Brown is going to produce the movie of ''A Few Good Men,'' a new play by Aaron Sorkin, who is a fairly new playwright. But Mr. Sorkin wanted the work to be done first in a theater, so Mr. Brown and an impressive group that includes Lewis Allen, Robert Whitehead and the Shubert Organization have put together $600,000 for a production that will star Tom Hulce and Roxanne Hart and will open in November at the Music Box.

title: Dale Berra Is Indicted
description: Twenty-five people, including the former major league infielder Dale Berra, have been indicted in connection with a five-county drug raid, officials said.

title: Connor's Late Tuneup Cut Short by Courier
description: Jimmy Connors, who has not played in a tennis tournament since Wimbledon, agreed to enter the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup Wednesday night when Stefan Edberg withdrew from the competition because of a severe case of hives.

title: GENERIC-DRUG GUIDELINES SEEN LACKING AT F.D.A.
description: Some makers of generic drugs received preferential treatment in the Food and Drug Administration's approval process because the agency failed to establish adequate guidelines for reviewing the drugs, a new Federal report says.

title: HUNT FOR SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR PAUSES UNTIL PRIMARIES END
description: Hoping to keep from being ''swept up in the politics of the primary,'' the committee searching for a new schools chancellor in New York City has decided not to release a list of finalists until after the Sept. 12 mayoral primaries.

title: ON SLAIN YOUTH'S BLOCK, SORROW AND BITTERNESS
description: Sorrow and rage washed over Hegeman Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday as the block mourned the slaying of a neighbor, 16-year-old Yusef Hawkins.

title: What Presidents Did Before They Had Pensions; Not Like Truman
description: To the Editor:

title: William Constable,83, Painter and Designer
description: William Constable, an Australian painter and set and costume designer for ballet, opera, theater and film, died Monday of pneumonia at his home in Melbourne. He was 83 years old.

title: Arthur F. Ackerman, Pediatrician, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Arthur F. Ackerman, a pediatrician, died Sunday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Neutrogena Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $345,000.

title: Washington Journal; Driving on the Beltway Is Life in the Slow Lane
description: Here in the nation's capital, you can be ''inside the Beltway'' or ''outside the Beltway.'' Or you can be on the Beltway. The last is where you don't want to be.

title: Ruling Draws Mingled Sadness and Praise
description: The last time Tim McCarver spoke with Pete Rose, the two men were standing around the batting cage in Cincinnati earlier this season. Rose was reluctant to discuss the allegations that he gambled on baseball, but he did tell McCarver what he thought of A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball.

title: Airship International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the decrease in earnings was due to the damage of the company's Airship by a tornado on June 11. The company also said it had signed a contract with Airship Industries Ltd. to purchase a 600 series airship for about $5 million.

title: Fed Clears Savings Mergers
description: The Federal Reserve Board today opened the door for banking companies to acquire healthy savings and loan institutions in a move that supporters said would help bring needed capital to the savings and loan industry.

title: ALEKSANDR YAKOVLEV, 84, DESIGNER OF WARPLANES AND PASSENGER JETS
description: Aleksandr S. Yakovlev, who designed World War II warplanes and modern passenger jets in a career of more than 60 years, died Tuesday after a long illness, Tass said today. He was 84 years old.

title: Stipanovich to Retire
description: Steve Stipanovich, the Indiana Pacers center, will retire because of a ''dead spot'' in his left knee that forced him to miss all of last season, according to a published report. The Indianapolis Star reported that an official announcement could come early next week, after Stipanovich meets with General Manager Donnie Walsh and other team officials. The Star quoted an unidentified source close to the team as saying: ''It's a done deal. He will not play again.'' Neither Stipanovich nor the Pacers would confirm or deny the report. (AP)

title: Interlake Promotes Official As It Fights a Takeover Bid
description: In the midst of an expensive reorganization intended to ward off a takeover threat, the Interlake Corporation promoted W. Robert Reum, 47, to the post of president and chief operating officer. Mr. Reum, whose background is in finance, joined Interlake in 1982 as chief financial officer and was made a director in 1987, and an executive vice president last year.

title: 2d Rebel Group Joins Carter's Ethiopia Talks
description: A second Ethiopian rebel group said today that it had accepted former President Jimmy Carter's offer to play a role in peace talks with the Marxist Government in Addis Ababa.

title: Vitro Fights Rights Plan
description: Vitro S.A. has filed an amended complaint in Delaware Chancery Court seeking to block the Anchor Glass Container Corporation's shareholder rights plan. Vitro, a Mexican glass maker, bid $20 a share, or $280 million, for Anchor earlier this month. It later filed suits in three Federal courts seeking preliminary injunctions against Anchor's anti-takeover measures.

title: Portage Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company attributed the decrease in its second-quarter results to its largest customer installing its own extrusion equipment in the fourth quarter.

title: Top Mcorp Executives Offer To Quit in Reorganization
description: Gene H. Bishop, Mcorp's chairman and chief executive, and John T. Cater, the president, have offered to step down as part of a bankruptcy reorganization approved today by the bank holding company's board.

title: Brock Exploration Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Reviews/Film; A King, a Very Big King, Battles the Rhino Menace
description: In ''Babar: The Movie,'' an animated feature based on the well-known storybook characters created by Jean and Laurent de Brunhoff, the peaceable kingdom of Elephantland is threatened by Lord Rataxes and his raging rhinoceros horde. Only a clever last-minute ruse, dreamed up by the bright young king, scares off the barbarians and saves Elephantland from destruction.

title: Aquanautics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $75,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DOW AND REASON: DISTANT COUSINS?
description: When the Dow talks, Wall Street listens. And yesterday many traders thought they heard a shout of confidence in the economy.

title: Saratoga May Save Its Best for Last
description: The Saratoga season sometimes slowly fades to black after the Travers Stakes on the 16th day of the 24-day meeting, but this year the final Saturday of the meeting might be the best.

title: The 2 Rules in the Rose Case
description: Pete Rose was suspended by A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball, under the provisions of the rules of Major League Baseball. Here are excerpts from the relevant rules. Rule 21 Misconduct

title: Peoples Jewellers reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said its loss from equity in Zale Corp. was $4,418,000 versus $3,404,000.

title: Cargo Door Latches Sought
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has recommended the use of ''fail-safe'' mechanisms on airliner cargo door latches to prevent the doors from popping open in flight and to assure that they are properly closed before takeoff.

title: Jersey Sewer Bonds Yield Up to 7.29%
description: A $124.99 million sewer revenue bond issue by the Hoboken-Union City-Weehawken Sewerage Authority in New Jersey was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. The tax-exempt issue offers investors a maximum yield of about 7.29 percent for an issue due in 2019. For shorter maturities, the issue includes serial bonds that yield from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1994 to 6.85 percent for those due in 1999. Another longer-term bond due in 2008 is offered at a price to yield about 7.22 percent.

title: Ex-Governor Sells Used Cars
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton, who served a two-year prison term for extortion after leaving office in 1979, has taken a job selling used cars and trucks. The 60-year-old Mr. Blanton said he has been in training at Bolton Ford-Mercury for about two weeks. ''I'm healthy as a horse, broke, but not broken,'' he said Tuesday.

title: Review/Pop; Heavy Metal, True to Genre, In a Triple Bill
description: It was a battle to the adenoidal death at Pier 84 Monday night. A triple bill of Badlands, Tesla and Great White faced off against one another, and true to the genre - heavy metal - each of the groups' lead singers screeched, screeched and then did it some more.

title: A Sunburst of Jazz, Blues and Fold
description: AS the summer winds down with hardly a whimper, the festival season is still exploding. New York is determined to entertain its citizens, and entertain them well. There is an abundance of musical programs to sort through this weekend, from the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival to blues and folk festivals at Lincoln Center and a Celebrate Brooklyn Women's Music Festival. The Village Jazz Festival and the Women's Music Festival are really tributes to the normal goings-on here in New York, while the blues and folk festivals are relying on imported talent.

title: American City Business Jourals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months included a gain of $20,020,000 on the sale of assets. The company said the latest 6-month share earnings were less than one cent a share after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Bishop Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Negatively impacted by $144,000 of additional repositioning costs associated with resolution of pending legal action. c-Included tax credits of $51,000 for the quarter and $115,000 for the 9 months.

title: Trident II Doesn't Fly
description: An unarmed Trident II missile recently flew out of control during a test launch and exploded.

title: Finley on Disabled List
description: Tests on Chuck Finley's injured left foot were inconclusive but the pitcher will be placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to Tuesday, the team announced yesterday.

title: Our Towns; The Tube Man: It's 'Surf's Up' In the Catskills
description: Even without the ponytail, 36-year-old Harry Jameson does not look the part of a corporate mover and shaker. He wears faded jeans that got there the hard way, without stone-washing, a T-shirt that left its sleeves at home, granny glasses and the kind of boots you use for pouring cement.

title: Petries Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included gains of $48,800,000 and $57,100,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the exchange of 7 1/2 percent and 8 percent subordinated exchangeable debentures for about 14,200,000 common shares of Toys 'R' Us Inc. owned by the company.

title: KOCH'S CAMPAIGN: THE MAYOR AS UNDERDOG
description: The man who once seemed a candidate to be mayor for life spent much of a recent dank day walking through Hispanic neighborhoods, looking for votes and dodging the rain. By his third stop, La Caridad restaraunt in upper Manhattan, Mayor Edward I. Koch had honed an almost plaintive appeal.

title: INSIDE
description: Continental Air in Sale Talks Texas Air said it might sell a controlling or minority interest in the airline.

title: For Voyager 2's 'Family' of 17 Years, It's the Last of the First Encounters
description: Behind the scenes of Voyager 2's encounter with Neptune, a family is breaking up. Most of its members have been together 17 years through adversity and conflict, feverish creativity and sweet moments of triumph.

title: Snag in Nuclear Arms Plant Settlement
description: A dispute is threatening to wreck a $78 million settlement in a case that marked the first Federal acknowledgment that a nuclear weapons plant might have harmed people who live near it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Federal lawsuits involving faulty asbestos removal included an erroneous report from the Environmental Protection Agency about two companies accused of violating demolition and renovation rules. The companies, the Big Apple Wrecking Company of the Bronx, and the J. Y. Arnold Company of Central City, Ky., have not been barred from participating in contracts, grants, loans or any other use of Federal funds. The agency has proposed such action but has not completed hearings and appeals required before a company can be barred.

title: Stena Cuts Stake In Sea Containers
description: Stena A.B. has lowered its stake in Sea Containers Ltd. to 5.9 percent from 6.3 percent. In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Stena gave no reason for the stock sale. Stena, a Swedish ferry operator, and Tiphook P.L.C., a British cargo concern, have offered to buy Sea Containers for $63 a share, or $1.03 billion. But Sea Containers has rejected the offer as inadequate.

title: Auctions
description: No one pretends that golf memorabilia constitute a major field of collecting. ''There are probably 20 million golfers, and if you've got 3,500 collectors, that's good,'' said Morton W. Olman, an amateur golfer and avid collector whose Old Golf Shop in Cincinnati specializes in collectibles and emblems of golfing history.

title: Economic Scene; Reasons to Fear A Recession
description: THE pickup in retail sales and employment has led the Federal Reserve to stop easing monetary policy for the present. But anxieties about the risk of the economic slowdown's turning into a recession will keep pressures on the Fed from the White House, Congress and private business to push interest rates down further.

title: Cabot Medical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Music; Rick Astley's British Soul
description: Among the artists whose recording careers have been nurtured by the English songwriting and producing team of Stock-Aitken-Waterman, Rick Astley, who performed at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening, may be the most promising.

title: THE LAW: For the Record; E Has a Modest Proposal on Ungendered Personal Pronouns
description: The following letter offering gender-neutral suggestions appears in the current issue of the CBA Record, the official publication of the Chicago Bar Association:

title: Accounts
description: * Eaton Corp., to Della Femina, McNamee WCRS/Chicago, for its truck components operations, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Charming Shoppes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
ISI Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Worried Over Fighting in Angola
description: The cease-fire declared in Angola two months ago is crumbling, and American officials expressed concern today about increased fighting between Government forces and guerrillas there.

title: Ari Bahat, Architect, 48
description: Ari Bahat, an architect who was noted for his use of glass block for furniture and interiors, died of pulmonary arrest Wednesday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 Radio Stations Face F.C.C. Disciplinary Action
description: Three radio stations face Federal Communications Commission action for allegedly airing indecent broadcasts during daytime hours, the agency said Thursday.

title: First City Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Crenshaw Avoids Pond and Takes Lead
description: Ten years ago, Ben Crenshaw had a real hacker's experience playing the par-5 16th hole at the Firestone Country Club's South Course: he took an 11. This happened during the 1979 World Series of Golf as Crenshaw put three balls in the pond fronting the green at that renowned 625-yard hole.

title: Paul McCartney Gets Ready to Take It on the Road
description: Outside the Lyceum Theater late Wednesday afternoon, a crowd of Paul McCartney fans, many too young to have known the Beatles when they were a going concern, gathered behind police barricades to catch a glimpse of the 47-year-old songwriter making his way from the stage door to his limousine. Mr. McCartney had been rehearsing with his new band at the theater on West 45th Street in Manhattan. In fact, he has been resident there all week, preparing for his first world tour in 13 years.

title: What Presidents Did Before They Had Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: LABOR LEADERS ARRESTED AT RALLY BACKING UNION WORKERS ON STRIKE
description: The presidents of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the United Mine Workers and a dozen other unions were arrested Wednesday as they took part in a sit-in at a courthouse to show support for striking coal, telephone and airline workers.

title: Chesapeake Phone Accord
description: Striking members of the Communications Workers of America reached tentative agreement today with the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company, officials said. Agreement between the union and the Bell Atlantic Corporation was reached a week ago, but bargaining with subsidiary companies has prevented employees from returning to work. The C. & P. agreement left Bell of Pennsylvania and Diamond State Telephone in Delaware the remaining unsettled units.

title: Review/Dance; 'Corpographics,' Works From the Otteco Troupe
description: Gerald Otte was a leading performer with the Nikolais Dance Theater before setting out on his own career as a choreographer. But the major influence on the dancer and choreographer would seem to be that of Murray Louis, Mr. Nikolais's longtime colleague, to judge from a program Mr. Otte and his Otteco company presented on Wednesday night at the Theater at St. Clement's Church.

title: I.B.M. Buys Stake
description: The Policy Management Systems Corporation said the International Business Machines Corporation had acquired a 19.8 percent stake in the company for $116.8 million. Policy Management said that under an agreement signed July 26, I.B.M. had bought 3.7 million newly issued shares of voting convertible preferred stock. I.B.M. may raise its stake to a maximum of 30 percent. Policy Management shares rose 25 cents today, to $33.75, in over-the-counter trading.

title: In Tokyo, Ballet Theater Opens Its 50th Season
description: American Ballet Theater began its 50th-anniversary season tonight with a performance of Mikhail Baryshnikov's staging of ''Swan Lake'' here.

title: SUBSTANCE HARDER THAN DIAMOND SEEN AS POSSIBLE
description: Upsetting a long-accepted view that nothing could rival the diamond in hardness, scientists are predicting that even harder substances may soon emerge from laboratories.

title: Harnischfeger Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $4,675,000 and $12,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $18,111,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the quarter also included a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $5,025,000.

title: About Real Estate; A Troubled Port Chester Project's Second Effort
description: To create an apartment with a loft area, a builder needs residential spaces with tall ceilings. At the old green and white Life Savers building on Route 1 in Port Chester, N.Y., which a developer was turning into condominiums, the ceilings turned out to be lower than expected. Because of that, the offering plan had to be amended last year and most of the 170 original buyers backed out of their contracts.

title: For Richmond's Confederate Home for Women, It's Finally Appomattox
description: One day after a Federal judge rejected a request for an injunction, seven daughters and granddaughters of Confederate soldiers were moved Wednesday from the Confederate Home for Women to a new health care center.

title: Israeli Kidnapped in West Bank; Troops Seal Off and Search Town
description: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers searched tonight for an Israeli jeweler who was kidnapped by several masked Palestinians this morning in the West Bank town of Tulkarm, where he had gone to collect debts, the army said.

title: Helms Managing Reds
description: The Cincinnati Reds appointed Coach Tommy Helms as interim manager today. Helms will run the club while the Reds look for a permanent replacement for Pete Rose.

title: CLOSINGS SET, 2,800 JOBS CUT AT CAMPBELL
description: In a bid to shore up its sagging market share amid increasing competition, the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,800 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force. The company also said it would close four factories in the United States, including its flagship plant in Camden, N.J.

title: Frank Paxton Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION 10 A.M. LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION SPECIAL COMMISSION - 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Study Doesn't Support Estrogen-Cancer Link
description: To the Editor:

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Surge 8.99% on the Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a surge of 8.99 percent in short sales oustanding, on active trading of over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended Aug. 15.

title: London Journal; Fun or Profit? Black Festival Tries to Have Both
description: At the Flamboyan, where culture and community are celebrated in a whirl of glitter, life is a masquerade.

title: Lebanese Muslims Shell Foes' Port
description: Syrian-backed Muslim forces shelled Junieh, the main Christian seaport, today as a flotilla of French ships took up positions off the Lebanese coast.

title: Review/Reggae; Soul Vibrations at S.O.B.'s
description: Across the third world, reggae is the international musical language -even in Nicaragua, the home of Soul Vibrations. The seven-piece band, which adds timbales to a standard reggae lineup, played heartfelt, assured, tuneful reggae on Tuesday at S.O.B.'s. Except for a song in Spanish, the lyrics were in English, and the word that kept popping up was ''history.'' The band sang about war, cultural continuity and solidarity with Africa; there were also love songs and reggae-style references to Zion and Babylon.

title: Lageman Takes a Private Course, With the Special Teams to Come
description: Jim Vechiarella, a 52-year-old coach, imitated a younger, slimmer wide receiver today as he chugged through pass routes against the Jets' No. 1 draft choice, Jeff Lageman.

title: Jordan Is Jordan, and Palestine Is Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: New Clashes in Cambodia
description: Fighting between rival Cambodian factions flared again along the Thai-Cambodian border, aid workers and Thai officials said today. Residents reported hearing heavy exchanges in the central sector of the frontier and foreign aid workers said there had been sporadic clashes over the past five days. The final round of peace talks on Cambodia is to open next week in Paris to try to hammer out an overall settlement before Vietnam withdraws its troops from the country by Sept. 26.

title: Dinkins Is Endorsed By Two Gay Groups
description: Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins yesterday accepted the endorsement of two gay political groups in his race for the Democratic mayoral nomination, saying he would fight for legal recognition of gay and lesbian domestic partnerships.

title: Transgenic Sciences reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Latest year included Transgenic's first revenues since the company began operations July 12, 1987. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: All That Jazz: Who, What, Where and When
description: The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival begins today and runs through Sept. 4. For ticket information, call the individual clubs. A $15 pass available at Sweet Basil and the Village Gate will allow 50 percent discounts on music charges; table minimums will still apply. title: Diberell Brothers Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Diner's Journal
description: K-Paul's Future

title: Inquiry in Westchester Finds No Wrongdoing
description: The Westchester District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said today that a grand jury investigating allegations of corruption at the county-owned Playland Amusement Park in Rye has found no evidence so far linking political contributions to favored treatment in awarding contracts.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Robert Edward Anderson, a retired advertising executive, omitted the list of his survivors. They are his wife, Zelda, of Hico, Tex.; two daughters, Molly Garcia of San Antonio and Joan Anderson of Austin, Tex.; two sisters, Mary Gardner of Mulberry, Fla., and Ann Tracy of Lake Worth, Fla.; three brothers, Ernest, of Palm Beach Shores, Fla.; Norman, of Port Charlotte, Fla., and Joseph, of Clinton, N.Y., and 11 grandchildren.

title: As the number of paralegals grows, they are challenging notions about the practice of law.
description: Twenty years ago hardly anyone had heard of a paralegal. Now there are about 100,000 of these legal assistants across the nation, and it is hard to envision many law firms functioning without them.

title: All American Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock split declared Feb. 10.

title: American Drug Screens reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company was formed in February of 1988 during its initial period as a development stage company, its only revenues were interest payments.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9, A30 Colombian drug traffickers burned the homes of politicians, dynamited offices of the nation's two largest political parties, placed bombs in two radio stations and issued a communique declaring war on the Government. Page A1

title: Leon Becker, 70, Dies; An Acting State Justice
description: Leon Becker, a lawyer and acting justice in New York State Supreme Court, died of lung cancer Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Doctors Who Maim and Kill . . .
description: LEAD: A doctor performs surgery on the sexual organs of women without their consent. The procedure, totally unnecessary and without any medical basis, ruins the lives of his patients. The hospital knows about it and other doctors in the community know about it. However, nobody acts on behalf of the patients.

title: FOLEY DENIES CONGRESS IS NAIVE ON SOVIET PERIL
description: Taking issue with a stinging attack by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney over military spending priorities, Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley denied today that his colleagues were underestimating the Soviet military threat.

title: PROGRAMS URGE VIEWERS TO TURN OFF THEIR SETS
description: San Francisco may have the only television program that encourages viewers to turn their sets off.

title: Soviet Congratulations Sent To New Premier of Poland
description: The Soviet Union moved quickly today to establish cordial relations with the new Polish Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, and introduced the Solidarity adviser to the public here as a political novelty but not a threat to the current order in Eastern Europe.

title: Integrated To Sell Units
description: Struggling to raise cash, Integrated Resources Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a substantial proportion of its businesses for $297 million, about $20 million less than it had hoped for when it announced plans for a reorganization earlier this month.

title: Berry Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Architect on Planning Panel Quits as He Pursues Project
description: Stuart K. Pertz, a member of the New York City Planning Commission since 1987, has resigned to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest, after the choice of his architectural firm as a potential participant in an enormous development project by the Federal Government in lower Manhattan.

title: Fewer Women in Parliaments
description: Women are finding it harder to get into parliament, the Inter-Parliamentary Union said today. The group said the percentage of women in the world's legislatures fell to 12.7 percent in mid-1989, down from 14.6 percent at the beginning of 1988. In 1975, the first year of the United Nations' Decade for Women, the figure was 12.5 percent. In mid-1989, in the 130 parliaments responding to a survey, 3,937 of 31,055 legislators were women, compared with about 4,167 of 28,544 in 133 parliaments at the start of 1988. The union groups 112 of the world's 145 national legislatures.

title: William A. Steele, 89; Headed Steel Concern
description: William A. Steele, former president and chairman of the Wheeling Steel Corporation, died of an aortal aneurysm Aug. 15 at the Lee County Hospital in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in Shell Point Village, Fla.

title: Letter: On Lobbying; A New Disclosure Law Is Desirable
description: To the Editor:

title: K Mart Stock Up
description: Shares of the K Mart Corporation rose $2.375, to $43.875, on market rumors that it might be taken over or restructured, traders said. Although analysts discounted the speculation, they acknowledged that K Mart was vulnerable to a takeover. ''Bigger companies have been taken over,'' said Monroe Greenstein, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. ''It's vulnerable because earnings have not been good, and the stock is cheap.''

title: Connecticut Natural Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Included a gain of $1,269,000 from a change in accounting. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restate to reflect a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Bankers Trust Preferred Stock
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is offering $250 million of fixed- and adjustable-rate preferred stock through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Proceeds from the sale will be used to make an equity investment in its wholly owned subsidiary, the BT Securities Corporation.

title: PASSING NEPTUNE, VOYAGER FINISHES A 12-YEAR MISSION
description: Out in the twilight of the solar system, far from the warmth of the Sun and the vitality of Earth, Voyager 2 cruised over the cold blue clouds of Neptune tonight, its cameras snapping pictures and its sensors gathering data on the composition and dynamic forces of the giant planet.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When Innocent People Are Sentenced to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Giamatti Plays by the Rules
description: Baseball, A. Bartlett Giamatti said yesterday, is an enduring American institution ''with a purchase on our national soul,'' and is thus under special obligation to uphold integrity and fair play. The Commissioner's decision to banish Pete Rose from baseball for life, and the deliberate manner in which he reached it, stoutly reaffirm those ideals.

title: Bakker Aide Receives 8-Year Fraud Sentence
description: Richard Dortch, former vice president of the PTL television ministry, was sentenced today to eight years in prison and a $200,000 fine for helping to bilk millions of dollars from the ministry's followers.

title: First Federal Bancorp (Pontic) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the prior year share earnings only reflect earnings since the time of the company's conversion, in accordance with SEC regulations.

title: Stock Averages Reach New Highs; Dow, Up 56, Erases '87 Mark
description: The stock market surged to historic highs yesterday, as investors focused on declining interest rates and the rising dollar and put memories of the 1987 crash further behind them.

title: COMMODITY EXCHANGE FINES TRADER AND FIRM
description: The Commodity Exchange took disciplinary action yesterday against a trader, Preston Semel, and the firm he heads for violations of the exchange's rules and for ''disreputable and fraudulent conduct.''

title: Cons TVX Mining reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $800,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $700,000 for the 6 months. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $600,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Debt
description: * Federal-Mogul Corp., an auto parts manufacturer, announced the completion of a $150 million revolving credit facility with 10 domestic and foreign banks.

title: CAMPAIGN LAUDER-STYLE: A MIX OF PATRICIAN POPULISM
description: While he was still a young man struggling to find his place at the family cosmetics business, Ronald Lauder confided in several company executives that he would someday be the first Jewish President of the United States.

title: Williams Revises Primerica Merger
description: The Primerica Corporation and the A. L. Williams Corporation said a special committee of Williams's independent directors had approved the revised terms of the proposed merger of the two companies. Under the revision, 82-hundredths of a Primerica share will be exchanged for each Williams share. The previous exchange ratio was 80-hundredths of a share. If Primerica shares trade below $25 at the time of the stockholder vote on the merger, the ratio will be increased to 85-hundredths.

title: People
description: * Fred Abatemarco has been named editor in chief of Popular Science magazine, a Times Mirror publication.

title: Prime Motor Inns reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Catalina Lighting Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Rose, Regrets but No Confession
description: He walked into Riverfront Stadium wearing a blue suit, to match his mood. ''This is a very sad day,'' Pete Rose said. And with that, he paused, close to tears.

title: Gasps for the Big Sloops
description: Sailors who have grown up with fairy tale stories of the golden age of yachting had the chance today to see it for themselves. For the first time in half a century, two J-class sloops that once competed for the America's Cup returned here to race again.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Record on Wall Street

title: Conner Reaches Terms
description: Lester Conner, a free-agent guard, has reached agreement on a new contract with the Nets, the team announced yesterday.

title: ABM Gold reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said included in the year-ago second quarter and 6 months is equity in unusual charges of affiliates of $13,685,000.

title: Environmental Power reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McCann's Hilton Work
description: The Hilton Hotel Corporation sweetened its relationship with McCann-Erickson yesterday to the tune of $5 million. The company awarded the account for its Flamingo Hilton hotels in Nevada to the Los Angeles office of McCann, which has been its agency of record since 1967. McCann will create advertising for three hotels in Nevada: the Flamingo-Hilton Reno, the Flamingo Hilton-Laughlin and the giant Flamingo Hilton on the Las Vegas strip.

title: TV Weekend; 'Open House,' New Sitcom
description: If the doings of some devious dimwits who work in a real estate office sounds like an unpromising premise for a sitcom, wait until you see the result - though that should not be taken as an invitation. ''Open House,'' which joins Sunday's Channel 5 lineup at 9:30 P.M., lives up uncompromisingly to its unpromise.

title: The Challenge of Poland; Bush Facing Problems and Opportunities In Bridging Gaps Between East and West
description: The election of a non-Communist Prime Minister in Poland has confronted the Bush Administration with a conflicting set of challenges and opportunities, which, for now, have combined to produce a strikingly restrained American response to what could be a turning point in East-West relations.

title: Martin Marietta Gets NASA Job
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today awarded a $1.8 billion contract to the Martin Marietta Corporation to produce 60 fuel tanks that would power the space shuttle in the 1990's.

title: RON HOWARD: A WALL ST. STAR, TOO
description: To television fans, Ron Howard will always be the actor who played Opie on ''The Andy Griffith Show'' and Richie Cunningham on ''Happy Days.'' To film buffs he is known as the director of ''Splash,'' ''Cocoon'' and this summer's latest hit, ''Parenthood.''

title: War Continues for Vietnam Refugees
description: Some of the last skirmishes of the Vietnam War are being fought, sometimes with words and occasionally with bullets, within the sharply fragmented Vietnamese refugee population of the United States.

title: Culp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Zarzuela in the Bronx
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble and members of Repertorio Espanol are to perform excerpts from Francisco-Asenjo Barbieri's ''Barberillo de Lavapies'' (''Merry Barber of Laviapies''), a zarzuela, on Sunday at 2 P.M. at Rockwood Drive Circle, Van Cortlandt Park near Broadway and Mosholu Avenue, in the Bronx. Pablo Zinger is to conduct, and the soloists are to include Ana-Gloria Vazquez, a soprano; Brenda Feliciano, a mezzo-soprano; Ulises Espaillat, a tenor, and George Maldonado, a baritone. The performance is to be repeated at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall, on the Bronx Rose Hill Campus of Fordham University, at Southern Boulevard. Admission is free. Information: 549-1899.

title: Justice Department Investigating Swimming Antitrust Allegations
description: The antitrust division of the New York office of the Department of Justice has begun an inquiry into activities of United States Swimming, the national governing body for the sport.

title: Atlantis Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $347,000 and $930,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $791,000 for the quarter and $1,612,000 for the 6 months.

title: Before Our Eyes, the Bloc Splinters
description: By the day, almost by the hour, the cold war's tides recede ever further and old assumptions founder. The West has grown accustomed to Mikhail Gorbachev's startling changes in the Soviet Union. It was known that the rigidities in Eastern Europe would soften. But the pace of change just this week defies Western imagination. Consider three certainties of Western belief: Under the ''Brezhnev Doctrine,'' the Soviets are sure to intervene if the Poles go too far.

title: Herbert Vogler, Stage Manager, 47
description: Herbert Vogler, a Broadway stage manager, died of AIDS Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old.

title: Review/Film; Cat and Dog Are Friends In a Tale of Real Animals
description: In ''The Adventures of Milo and Otis,'' the Japanese author and film maker Masanori Hata's tale of the friendship between a golden-haired cat named Milo and a snub-nosed dog named Otis, the camera contemplates the world with the wide-eyed curiosity of a child.

title:
THE LAW;
ETHICS SPECIALISTS, NEW BACKSTOPS FOR PROFESSION
description: LEAD: Lawyers and law firms, buffeted by rising malpractice judgments and the accelerating use of ethical rules as weapons in litigation, are increasingly turning to ethics specialists to keep them out of trouble.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Choice Drug Systems Inc., Inwood, L.I., said it was studying the possibility of acquiring an unidentified pharmaceutical supply company.

title: Black Youth Is Killed by Whites; Brooklyn Attack Is Called Racial
description: A 16-year-old black youth was shot to death Wednesday night in an attack by 10 to 30 white teen-agers in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday about Wang Laboratories Inc. misstated the position of Richard W. Miller. He is the company's new president and chief operating officer.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 463 money market mutual funds increased by $2.68 billion, to $343.22 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $51 million, to $85.58 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds rose $1.04 billion, to $109.78 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.59 billion, to $147.85 billion, the institute said.

title: Barnwell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $300,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Cepha P. Kindig, 79, a Social Worker, Dies
description: Cepha Pasek Kindig, a social worker for more than 30 years, died of brain cancer on Aug. 17 at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Englewood.

title: A Ford Shutdown
description: The Ford Motor Company said its Chicago assembly plant would end production of 1989-model Taurus and Sable cars on Sept. 1, a week earlier than planned, because orders from its dealers had dropped. The company said the 2,500 employees there would return to work on Sept. 11, the first day of production of the 1990 models. Ford began slowing production earlier this summer. Before then, the company had been running its domestic plants at full capacity.

title: OPENING NEW ERA, POLES PICK LEADER
description: Opening a fresh chapter in the nation's political life, Poland's Parliament ended more than 40 years of one-party rule today by electing Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a devout Catholic and Solidarity supporter, to be the country's first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early postwar years.

title: Surgery to Sideline Redskins' Williams
description: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, will be sidelined for 8 to 10 weeks after surgery today, the team announced yesterday.

title: At the Movies
description: Double and Double Question: What could be better than the prospect of a movie co-starring Michael Caine and Roger Moore?

title: Pete Rose Got What He Deserved
description: The evidence is that Pete Rose never knows when to stop. He would bet and he would bet until he owed too much money, and then somebody would cut off Rose's credit or even threaten ''to burn my house down and break my kid's legs if I didn't pay him,'' as Rose has admitted under oath.

title: HARVARD WILL SELL A FOREST, A LEGACY FROM AN ALUMNUS
description: After years of uneasiness over the fate of Harvard's Black Rock Forest, the university has agreed to sell the land to a private foundation that will lease it to a consortium of 15 scientific and educational institutions.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Doing the Fugs The Fugs, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). The Fugs, the once-notorious, now-venerated East Village band led by the poet Ed Sanders, still makes seriously zany mischief. The group's show tonight is likely to include excerpts from Mr. Sanders' anti-Pentagon opera, ''Starpeace,'' anarchistic broadsides by Tuli Kupferberg, and a medley of the group's smutty underground hits from its earliest days in the mid-1960's. The more elegiac, straightforward songs, like Mr. Sanders's ''Dreams of Sexual Perfection,'' which traces the rise and fall of the sexual revolution, are hard-headed and cutting. Show time is tonight at 8:30; seats are $13.50. Balladeer Bryson

title: MICKEY LELAND IS BROUGHT HOME
description: Representative Mickey Leland, the Texas Democrat who was one of nine Americans killed in a plane crash as they were headed for an Ethiopian refugee camp this month, was buried here today in a private service attended by family members and a few friends.

title: Barry's Jewelers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Warner Books Merging With Time's Little, Brown Unit
description: Time Warner Inc. yesterday announced the first merger of operations since Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. joined last month.

title: KOCH SPEECH: COURAGEOUS CHOICES
description: New York City's mayoral candidates make dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often they use a ''basic speech,'' which varies little from one occasion to the next.

title: Armada Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of $100,000 and $210,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $816,000 for the quarter and $1,935,000 for the 6 months, and tax benefits of $358,000 and $440,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: An Unscheduled Offering Of Fannie Mae Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $750 million of 10-year debentures in an unscheduled offering.

title: Sanctions, and a Chance, in the Accord
description: Following is the text of the agreement yesterday between A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball, and Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, that resulted in Rose's suspension from baseball:

title: Soviet Visitors Learn From Congress
description: Konstantin Lubenchenko led six Soviet legislators and aides through the halls of Congress this week, a line of neat gray suits threading through the Day-Glo outfits of summer tourists.

title: SoHo Theater Delayed
description: The Angelika Film Center, a six-screen SoHo movie theater, will not open today as had been announced. Ted Albert, a spokesman for the theater, which is at Mercer and Houston Streets, said the owners hope to open it within the next few weeks. The opening has been delayed several times.

title: Rose Is Out, but He Says Wait Till Next Year
description: Saying he believed that Pete Rose had bet on baseball games, including those of the team he managed, Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti announced an agreement yesterday that bans Mr. Rose permanently from baseball.

title: Cominco Resources Internaional Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Film; A Woman In Rebellion And the Life She Hates
description: It would be easy to wrap ''The Little Thief'' in nostalgia, to treasure it as the last legacy of Francois Truffaut. Before his death in 1984, Truffaut had written, with Claude de Givray, a brief scenario for the story of Janine, a neglected, spirited, imaginative adolescent of the 1950's. He had invented the girl more than 20 years before as Antoine Doinel's companion in ''The 400 Blows,'' but had cut the character from that film and carried her image to the end of his life.

title: Ernst's Canadian Affiliates Shun Merger and Pick Peat
description: Ernst & Whinney's Canadian affiliates have opted out of Ernst's merger with Arthur Young and instead plan to join KPMG Peat Marwick, the parties involved said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Jones and King Ahead at Six-Under Par: Betsy King shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to share the first-round lead with Rosie Jones in the World Championship of Women's Golf at Buford, Ga. King and Jones, the defending champion, were the first twosome to complete play in the select international field of 16 golfers competing for a first prize of $83,500 from the $265,000 purse.(AP) Hayes Ties a Record: Mark Hayes polished off a record-tying eight-under-par 62 yesterday with an eagle-3 at the 17th hole and led by one stroke after the first round of the rain-plagued Hamilton County-Chattanooga Classic in Chattanooga, Tenn. Hayes held a one-stroke lead over Brad Faxon, who shot a seven-under 63. Play was suspended because of lightning and rain, and 58 golfers will have to complete the round this morning.(AP) LITTLE LEAGUE Trumbull to Face Kaohsiung in Final: Andy Paul allowed only four hits - three of them bases-empty home runs -as Trumbull, Conn., defeated San Pedro, Calif., by 6-3 yesterday to earn a spot in the 43d Little League World Series championship game. Trumbull, the Eastern Regional champions, will play Kaohsiung, Taiwan, tomorrow in the title game. The Taiwanese team beat Maracaibo, Venezuela, 13-0.(AP) HORSE RACING Hodges Bay Wins Seneca in Upset: Hodges Bay, who had lost eight successive races and had never won a stakes, ran down the leaders through the stretch to post a one-and-three-quarter-length upset victory yesterday in the $92,400 Seneca Handicap at Saratoga Race Track. Lord Bud, the 5-2 favorite, was up for second with the filly River Memories fading to third in a field of 10. Hodges Bay, a 4-year-old Vigors gelding owned by the Plandome Stable and trained by Mike Freeman, paid $14.60 for $2 to win after running the one and five-eighths miles under Jean Cruguet in 2:39 4/5. BOXING Dokes Stops Watson: Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, stopped Wesley Watson at 2 minutes 25 seconds of the third round last night at the Felt Forum. Watson, who weighed 231 pounds to Dokes's 229, lost his mouthpiece and then his footing when a series of body shots and combinations to his head pushed him through the ropes and onto the ring apron. Referee Arthur Mercante Sr. ended the bout after the count of three. Dokes, 31 years old, improved his record to 39-2-2 with 25 knockouts. He is ranked No. 12 by the W.B.A., No. 6 by the International Boxing Federation and No. 4 by the World Boxing Council. Watson, 27, fell to 15-2.

title: Hathaway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $5,000 and a gain of $200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from divested operations. c-Included losses from divested operations of $154,000 for the quarter and $236,000 for the year.

title: Deb Shops Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months both included a 3 cents a share loss on investments.

title: A Ringing Defense of Mass Media
description: RESPONDING to recent predictions by communications executives of the imminent demise of mass media, a leading advertising executive has issued a ringing defense of the strength of network television and other communications organs aimed at mass audiences.

title: Mets Begin 9-Game Trip
description: The Mets begin a nine-game West Coast trip tonight in San Diego. They will play three games against the Padres, three at Los Angeles and three at San Francisco.

title: Eastco Industrial Safety reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect retroactive effect of a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 22.

title: Devcon International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $34,000 tax credit. Share earnings reflects a 3-for-2 stock split effective Aug. 8.

title: Top Executive Named By Nikko's U.S. Unit
description: Nikko Securities International, the American arm of Japan's third-largest securities firm, named Hideo Suzuki chairman and chief executive yesterday. He replaces Toshio Mori, who will return to Japan after seven years at the head of the unit. The change was not a surprise. Mr. Suzuki, who has overall responsiblity, and Tsuneo Iida, the new president, who will manage day-to-day operations, have been in New York since September 1988. After arriving, Mr. Suzuki said his first challenge was to make the firm profitable.

title: Dynatronics Laser reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $23,001 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $21,800 for the year. c-Included extraordinary credits of $62,788, or 1 cent a share, and $198,056, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: DRUG TRAFFICKERS IN COLOMBIA START A COUNTERATTACK
description: Striking back against a Government crackdown, drug traffickers dynamited offices of the nation's two largest political parties today, burned the houses of two politicians, placed bombs in two radio stations and issued a communique declaring war on the Government.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SOME DAY BEEN DEY,'' a storytelling program including the Pickney Players, J. California Cooper and Raye Dowell, 4 to 7 P.M. tomorrow, with arts and crafts and food, at the Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, at 141st Street. Admission: students and the elderly, $5; others, $10. Information 969-0779. ''A ROYAL BALL,'' a workshop for children ages 5 to 11 and their families to learn how to make a cape and a crown and to dance with Princess Belva, 1 to 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in Central Park, at Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, south of the Great Lawn at 79th Street. Reservations and information: 772-0210. ''IN THE NICK OF TIME,'' a musical by Thomas Dougherty and William Toscano, with music by Sid Cherry, presented at 10:30 A.M. today by the Penny Bridge Players, 520 Clinton Avenue, near Fulton Street, in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn. Admission: children, $4; adults, $5. Final performance. Information: (718) 855-6346. ''THE NIGHTINGALE,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen, as told by Kathryn Farnsworth, 11 A.M. tomorrow, at the Andersen Statue in Central Park, Fifth Avenue and 72d Street. Free. ''TOY BOOKS EXHIBITION,'' a show of century-old toy books - small-format publications for children - printed by stationers in the South Street Seaport, on view through Labor Day, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, at Bowne & Company Stationers, 211 Water Street. Free. Information: 669-9419. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. THE INTREPID, the aircraft carrier sea-air-and-space museum, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays, with the last tour at 4 P.M., at Pier 86, 46th Street and the Hudson River. Admission: children, $2.50, the elderly, $4; others, $4.75. Information: 245-2533. #46TH ANNUAL CHILDREN'S ART EXHIBITION, work by children in the New York metropolitan area and in Israel, with the theme ''We Want a Perfect World, Not a Wasteland,'' 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Friday and 8:45 A.M. to 6:45 P.M. Sunday, Central Queens Y Fine Arts Gallery, 67-09 108th Street, Forest Hills. Free. Information: (718) 268-5011. BOSCOBEL RESTORATION, the refurbished, authentically restored 18th-century home of States Morris Dyckman, surrounded by fruit groves and gardens, open daily except Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; last tour, 4:15 P.M. In Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y. Admission: ages 6 to 14, $2.50; under 6 free; the elderly, $4; others, $5. Information: (914) 265-3638. NEW CANAAN (CONN.) NATURE CENTER, a 40-acre site, with trails open from sunrise to sunset, exhibition buildings and greenhouses, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. Sundays, at Oenoke Ridge. Free. Information: (203) 966-9577. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden, 8:30 A.M. to sunset daily, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971.

title: JAPANESE OFFICIAL QUITS OVER AFFAIR
description: A prominent Cabinet member said today that he will resign over his involvement in an extramarital affair, according to Japanese news reports.

title: Ericsson and G.E. Set Joint Cellular Venture
description: L.M. Ericsson A.B., the giant Swedish telecommunications company, said yesterday that it and the General Electric Company would form a joint venture to produce cellular telephones, mobile radio equipment and communication systems.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific will produce an advertising and marketing campaign to increase support for live theater in the San Francisco area.

title: Anchor Glass Named In Suit
description: A class action suit has been filed against the Anchor Glass Container Corporation over its rejection of a $280 million takeover proposal from Vitro S.A. The shareholder suit, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, seeks to block Anchor Glass from taking any defensive action to thwart the Vitro tender offer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 Page 1

title: Valvano Is Asked to Quit as Athletic Director
description: The president of North Carolina's public university system today asked Jim Valvano to resign as athletic director at North Carolina State because an investigation of the school's basketball program had revealed extensive academic abuses that broke ''the spirit, not the letter of the law.''

title: New Data on Steroids Used Before Olympics
description: An Olympic official said that a more sophisticated examination of 1,100 urine samples has shown that more than 50 male athletes who took part in the Games last fall at Seoul, South Korea, were found to have used anabolic steroids in the six months before the Games. Article, page 43.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Mayor Edward I. Koch's campaigning in the Bronx misidentified a center for the elderly. It was the Castle Hill Senior Citizens Center, not the Parkchester HAND Senior Citizens Center, which he also visited.

title: Patents; Now, Team Chess, With Double the Pieces
description: Getting bored with chess? Looking for a game that would be more fun at parties? Richard A. Carlson has patented an alternative: chess played by two-member teams, with a bigger board and twice as many pieces.

title: No Conflict Discerned in Soybean Curb
description: Top officers of the Chicago Board of Trade did not benefit from the exchange's decision last month to order an emergency liquidation of positions in the soybean market, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said in a preliminary report today.

title: Stocks Fail To Extend Advance
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday, as weaker bond prices and profit taking after Thursday's record-setting close squelched a feeble attempt to extend the rally, which left the widely watched Dow Jones industrial average with a net gain of 44.39 points for the week, to 2,732.36.

title: Police Statistics Show a Drop in Bias Crimes
description: Bias crimes in New York City have dropped in the last year, according to statistics from the Police Department's bias incident investigating unit.

title: KEY RATES
Casino Owner Loses License In Wake of Loan Allegations
description: The Nevada Gaming Commission has voted unanimously to revoke the license of the Japanese businessman Ginji Yasuda, head of the financially troubled Aladdin hotel and casino in Las Vegas.

title: Salman Rushdie and Wife Living Apart
description: Salman Rushdie, the British author who has been living under an Iranian death threat since February, and his American wife, the novelist Marianne Wiggins, have separated.

title: Helmsley Judge Tells Jurors To Ignore Personal Feelings
description: The judge in the trial of Leona Helmsley and two co-defendants told jurors yesterday that in trying to reach a verdict they should not be swayed by emotions or any personal feelings they might have about the defendants' backgrounds and life styles.

title: CONTINENTAL'S FUTURE NEEDS SAID TO PROMPT IDEA FOR SALE
description: An adviser to Frank Lorenzo said yesterday that the Texas Air Corporation's chairman had decided to give serious consideration to the sale of Continental Airlines primarily because he thinks the parent company will find it difficult to afford the investment needed to keep the carrier competitive with the huge airlines forming under deregulation.

title: Mumbling Won't Move Noriega
description: The Panama crisis offered the Organization of American States a rare opportunity to demonstrate the advantages of cooperative hemisphere diplomacy. Instead, by its fumbling, mumbling response, the O.A.S. has discredited multilateralism, undermining the very principle it needs to sustain in order to play a meaningful role.

title: Computer Maker's Glamour Fades
description: Klaus Luft, the chairman of Nixdorf Computer A.G., was given a tough act to follow when he unexpectedly succeeded Heinz Nixdorf, the founder of the West German computer concern, as chairman in March 1986.

title: Gains for U.S. Securities Erased by Late Selling
description: Late selling sent the prices of Treasury securities tumbling yesterday. The sales, which dealers said came in two waves, quickly erased the modest gains posted early in the session, which were attributed largely to European demand.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a kidnapping and other developments in Israel and the occupied territories characterized the shooting death of a Palestinian-American youth incorrectly. The youth, Amjad Hussein Jabril, was the first American shot and killed there since the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987; at least two Americans have died in other circumstances related to the conflict.

title: Patents; Gout Drug May Help To Curb Cockroaches
description: Physicians have long prescribed allopurinol for people who suffer from gout. Now three entomologists think it may be a formidable weapon against cockroaches.

title: Leeco Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: New York Poorer for Vanishing Private Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: One Hat Too Many
description: When the Citizens Union of the City of New York announced its choices this week in the upcoming primary elections, the spokesman for the 92-year-old organization was its chairman, Robert F. Wagner Jr. It is a decidedly incongruous role for the president of the city's Board of Education.

title: Patents; Big Backlog At Agency Stirs Concern
description: What started as a minor paperwork delay at the Patent and Trademark Office has grown into a large backlog in the publication of patents.

title: Salespeople Are Getting Incentives for Service
description: The fall shopping season is just about here and commission selling in department stores is likely to be a big part of it.

title: Animal Eye-Test Data Is Useless for Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: Pole Urges Bush to Speed Economic Aid
description: On his first full day in office, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki met with American Congressmen today and urged President Bush to accelerate economic aid for Poland.

title: Eugene Robel, 78, Dies; Fought a Security Act
description: Eugene Frank Robel a labor advocate who won a Supreme Court ruling against a law that barred Communists from working in military plants, was killed when he was struck by a train last Sunday. He was 78 years old.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Wet Soil
description: It has been a wet year. Lawns have seldom been greener, and trees and shrubs have grown like weeds. But flower and vegetable gardens have been the victims. Most of the vegetable crops along the East Coast are late.

title: Keewaunee Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Restated to reflect adoption of tax accounting change of $146,000.

title: The Lap-Top Computer Goes to College
description: As students stream back to colleges across the country, a good many will be carrying lap-top computers in their gear. These were once expensive gadgets with limited use in business, but for $1,000 or so they now compete in price and power with full-size personal computers.
