title: Lofty Dow Gives Individuals Pause
description: Only two years after the frenzied bull market days of 1987, the stock market has scaled new peaks, but the euphoria is gone. Retail investment still trails the 1987 record.

title: Nutrasweet Plans Increased Output
description: The Nutrasweet Company announced plans to double the production capacity for its artificial sweetener products, which are marketed in more than 70 countries.

title: Fool Me Twice, Shame On Me
description: Ronald Reagan ended the political usefulness of paranoia when he won election by promising to save the country from government, then failed to do it.

title: Fed Voted for Lower Interest Rates
description: The Federal Reserve's policy makers voted to nudge interest rates lower in July, but they worried about reigniting inflation by going too far, according to a summary of the meeting that was released today.

title: Sony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen, for convenience only, at the rate of Yen 144 to $1, the approximate Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of June 30, 1989. Each Depositary Share represents one share of common stock. Primary net income per Depositary Share is computed based on the average number of common shares outstanding during each period after consideration of the dilutive effect of common stock equivalents which include warrants and certain convertible bonds. Fully diluted net income per Depositary Share further assumes that all other convertible bonds and debentures were converted into common stock. Corrected from editions of Aug. 25.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Reluctant Texas Judge Allows Use of Confederate Symbols
description: A high school in a Dallas suburb can continue to use Confederate symbols for its sports teams after a Federal judge ruled that the symbols are legal, even though they may be distressing.

title: Woodward Is Next for Easy Goer
description: Easy Goer, who won the Travers at Saratoga last Saturday, will make his next start in the Woodward Handicap at Belmont Park on Sept. 16, his handlers announced today. That decision means that any rematch between Easy Goer and Sunday Silence will not happen until at least November.

title: Infinite Graphics reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 12 months included a tax credit of $180,000.

title: Life of Indiana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mattingly Flails at Plate As Yanks Fail Once More
description: Don Mattingly showered and dressed, but the frustration did not wash away. He struck out three times last night, and the Yankees lost again. When the night was done, their new manager even suggested that some players were pressing.

title: Precision Drilling reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bridge
description: Some hands provide interesting points at three levels, for beginners, intermediate players and experts. The diagramed example was noted by Morton Kaplan of Cedarhurst, L.I., in a duplicate game at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan. He will conduct beginners' lessons there starting Sept. 11 and intermediate lessons starting Sept. 7th.

title: Maverick Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Concurrent Computer reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $3.6 million from the sale of 40-percent interest in the company's Japanese unit. c-Included a reversal of tax benefit of $100,000 taken on net operating loss in 1988 and a one-time restructuring charge of $8.2 million. The latest year sales results do not include three months of former Concurrent's operations due to the timing of the merger, and operations of former Concurrent are not included in year-ago results.

title: U.S. GIVING BOGOTA $65 MILLION IN AID TO FIGHT DRUG WAR
description: President Bush said today that he would send $65 million in emergency aid to Colombia to help fight the drug dealers who have declared war on the Colombian Government.

title: Falconbridge Holders Urged to Take FL Bid
description: In the continuing battle for what mineral experts say are some of Canada's richest mining assets, the board of directors of Falconbridge Ltd. recommended today that shareholders accept last week's offer of $37 (Canadian), or $31.45 (United States), a share from the FL Acquisition Corporation. FL was formed by two mining giants, Noranda Inc. of Canada, and Trelleborg A.B. of Sweden, to acquire Falconbridge's assets jointly.

title: Energy Chief Rebuffs Ohio Judge
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that he would reject a Federal judge's request that he join a dispute in Ohio on the terms of a proposed $78 million pollution settlement between the department and neighbors of the nuclear weapons plant in the town of Fernald.

title: Technical 'Magic' Converts A Puny Signal Into Pictures
description: The conversion of whisper-faint pulses of radio energy from the outer reaches of the solar system into spectacular color pictures of Neptune have put communications technology to an extraordinary test that it has triumphantly passed.

title: Mother on Cocaine Sentenced For Passing Drugs to Infants
description: A mother convicted of delivering drugs to her two babies through the bloodstream was sentenced today to 15 years of probation and completion of a drug treatment program.

title: No NASA Delay of the Shuttle
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration says it has no plans to ask the Defense Department to delay one of its space shuttle missions so that the rescue of an errant satellite can take place in November rather than December.

title: Shrinking Pagers
description: James Bond has had toys like these for years, but in the real world, wristwatch communications systems are brand new. Motorola Inc. and the Timex Corporation have now introduced what they call the world's smallest pager.

title: A Sensible Compromise on Indian Bones
description: After more than two years of prodding by American Indian leaders, the Smithsonian Institution promises a more humane policy on returning skeletons and burial artifacts of Indians taken as anthropological specimens. The change deserves to be widely copied.

title: HQ Office Supplies Wareouse reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago figures are not applicable; company began operations in February 1989.

title: South African Chief in Zaire to Discuss Angola
description: In his first summit meeting since becoming Acting President of South Africa, F. W. de Klerk met here today with President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire for discussions that focused on how to rescue the foundering cease-fire in Angola.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: Speaking Aramaic
description: To the Editor:

title: Conner Signs Contract
description: After signing a four-year contract yesterday, Lester Conner said he felt confident the Nets would be a playoff contender next season. Conner, who was a free agent, also had contract discussions with Milwaukee, Cleveland, Denver, Houston and Indiana. But Conner, a 29-year-old point guard, wanted to return to New Jersey. Sources said Conner signed for almost $1 million a season.

title: Wavemat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Primages Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: COLOMBIANS SEIZE TWO DRUG FIGURES
description: Tens of thousands of heavily guarded students marched through the capital today in support of the Government's crackdown on narcotics traffickers as the Government reported the arrest of two close associates of a leader of the Medellin cocaine ring.

title: Abducted Israeli Man Found Alive in a Well
description: After a wide search using troops and helicopters, soldiers found an Israeli jeweler alive and healthy today at the bottom of a 20-foot well in a West Bank village, a day after he was kidnapped by masked Palestinians, the army said.

title: Group to Buy Avis Europe
description: A consortium including the General Motors Corporation and Avis Inc. agreed to buy Avis Europe P.L.C. today in a deal that values the European car rental and leasing concern at $1.4 billion.

title: Heroux Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 26, 1989
description: Markets

title: Tiny Hydraulic Crack Caused B-2 Problems, Air Force Says
description: The Air Force said today that a hairline crack in the hydraulic support system caused the shortened test flight of the B-2 Stealth bomber last week.

title: Home Resale Rise Posted
description: Sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in July, posting the first back-to-back increase after high mortgage rates produced consecutive declines in the first five months of 1989, a real estate trade group said today.

title: CINCINNATI HEADLINES ARE ALL ROSE
description: Despite all the assurances to the contrary, the sun did not rise here today. In fact, it has not been out since the baseball commissioner, A. Bartlett Giamatti, announced Thursday morning that a baseball icon, Pete Rose, had been banned from the game.

title: Soybean Case Pleas Entered
description: Two soybean traders and a clerk pleaded guilty today to charges of improper trading practices, while 12 other people pleaded not guilty to charges arising from the Government's investigation of practices at the world's largest futures exchanges.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Pete Rose's appearance on a television shopping program to sell baseball souvenirs misidentified him in some editions. Mr. Rose was at the left; Alan Skantz, the host, was at the right.

title: Jail Term in Horses' Deaths
description: A Plymouth, Conn., man convicted of starving his four horses to death has been sentenced to one year in prison, but prison overcrowding may result in his release after 10 days, the authorities said today. The man, Raymond M. Bilosz, 56 years old, was also fined $750, and he must pay $1,350 in burial and veterinary fees and $200 in probation costs.

title: Crenshaw Manages To Retain the Lead
description: Ben Crenshaw didn't play nearly as well today as he did Thursday. But he still managed to hold on to the lead in the NEC World Series of Golf halfway through this $1 million tournament with a 45-man select field of winners from around the world.

title: Music School's Rule Found Discriminatory
description: A music school's requirement that students sight-read music before being allowed to graduate discriminated against the blind, the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights has ruled.

title: Raymond Harris, 70, Geriatric Cardiologist
description: Dr. Raymond Harris, founder and first president of the Council on Geriatric Cardiology, died of stomach and liver cancer yesterday at his home in Albany. He was 70 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cambridge Bioscience Corp., Worcester, Mass, announced it had agreed to purchase certain assets of Angenics Inc., a Cambridge, Mass., developer of technology for diagnostics tests, for an undisclosed amount.

title: ARREST IN MURDER OF HUEY NEWTON
description: A man described by police as a drug dealer has admitted killing Huey P. Newton, the co-founder of the Black Panthers, the police said tonight.

title: Casualties of Change in Italy: The Old People Left Behind
description: In the August heat, with most Romans having fled the city, calls come in to a small office, bringing stories from people left behind.

title: Sprouse-Reitz Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Net income

title: Patents; An Easier Way To Light a Cigarette
description: For smokers who find lighting cigarettes inconvenient, Richard Mawby of Alexandria, Va., has designed a cigarette pack that does the job for them.

title: Police Search for 18-Year-Old In Killing of Brooklyn Youth
description: The New York City police yesterday searched intensively for an 18-year-old white youth who they believe may have shot to death 16-year-old Yusef Hawkins in a racial attack Wednesday night in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: Rose Facing More Scrutiny In Former Associate's Trial
description: Pete Rose will apparently not have much time to recover from the announcement of his banishment from baseball before he will again come under potentially intense public and law-enforcement scrutiny.

title: INSIDE
description: Fishing Accord for Taiwan American observers will be allowed on Taiwan vessels to monitor nets that kill marine animals, in what may be a precedent for agreements with other Asian countries. Page 29. Arrest in Huey Newton Case The police in Oakland say that a drug dealer has admitted killing the former Black Panther leader but maintains it was self-defense. Page 7. Sales Commissions Return Department stores are increasingly turning to commissions for their salespeople to lure more customers with better service. Consumer's World, page 41. Tinkering at Carnegie Hall Acoustical changes are under way in response to complaints from musicians and critics about a lack of warmth of sound in the hall. Page 11.

title: Giuliani, on the Stump and on the Phone
description: There are two Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigns for mayor - the public speeches and street campaigning, and the much more difficult private hours on the telephone or at small gatherings trying to raise money in a mostly Democratic city.

title: Margaret E. Boorman, Missionary, 78
description: Margaret E. Boorman, who was awarded the Medal of Freedom in 1946 for her service in China, died on Wednesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. She was 78 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: William Constable, 83, Painter and Designer
description: William Constable, an Australian painter and set and costume designer for ballet, opera, theater and film, died of pneumonia Monday at his home in Melbourne. He was 83 years old.

title: U.S. Clears Eastern Air On Safety
description: The Government has concluded that a walkout by machinists, pilots and flight attendants has not affected the safety of Eastern Airlines' flights.

title: 4-Day Workweek Plan at Chrysler
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers at a Chrysler Corporation plant here have voted to allow the union to start bargaining with the company over a four-day workweek, the union said. If the plan is approved, the mini-van assembly plant would become the first Chrysler plant in the United States to operate on such a system.

title: Gramercy Is Worried as Asbestos Cleanup Begins
description: As anxious residents pressed vainly for information about what was happening to their neighborhood, Consolidated Edison workers and a team of toxic-waste specialists yesterday began vacuuming asbestos-contaminated mud from a 100-yard zone of streets, sidewalks and stoops in Gramercy Park.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. A card that, to the surprise of many, is off-white in color will soon have a pinkish tinge. What card is it and what is at issue? 2. According to research, the greater the height from which a cat falls, the more likely its chance of survival. Why is that? 3. An unusually large number of East Germans have recently been vacationing in Hungary. Why is that an embarrassment for the East German Government? 4. An agreement between Baseball Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti and Pete Rose bans Mr. Rose permanently from baseball but also stipulates that he may apply for reinstatement after a year. Why is reinstatement unlikely? 5. Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, apparently received some indirect support from an unlikely ally in his effort to form a coalition Government. What happened? 6. According to transmissions from the Voyager 2 spacecraft, the rings around Neptune are strikingly different from those of any other planet. What is the difference? 7. Drug experts have reached some unexpected conclusions about treating crack addicts. What do studies show? 8. The discovery of a long and pessimistic poem about the untrustworthiness of mankind generated both excitement and controversy among scholars. What is at issue? 9. In Colombia, drug traffickers started a counterattack to a Government crackdown that included the reactivation of a policy narcotics experts say is the drug lords' greatest fear. What policy is it? 10. Recent thefts from at least 13 libraries have baffled librarians and prompted an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. What has been stolen? 11. The Smithsonian Institution and American Indian leaders reached a tentative accord about the disposition of the Indian artifacts and remains now in the Smithsonian's possession. To what did they agree? 12. San Francisco may have the only television program that encourages viewers to turn their sets off. What are the circumstances? 13. Experts say they fear that AIDS is spreading in the nation's poorest neighborhoods through heterosexual contact, as it has in Africa. What combination of factors is causing this?

title: California Educators Taking New Leaf From Book Exchange
description: When the boxloads of books forced her husband's car out of the driveway and into the street, it was time for Marilyn Levin Nemzer to make a decision about her new project.

title: U.S. Embassy Reports Torture In Burmese Jails
description: The American Embassy in Myanmar, formerly Burma, says it has ''credible, first-hand reports'' of routine and sometimes fatal mistreatment of pro-democracy figures in custody there. The abuses reportedly include beatings and torture.

title: Legalizing Drugs - Step No. 1
description: LEAD: In December 1988, I pronounced the death by gunshot of an 18-year-old Hispanic male as his younger brother sobbed and his mother looked on in great pain. This is nothing out of the ordinary for a physician at Kings County Hospital, located in one of New York City's drug combat zones, the Flatbush section of

title: Police Unit in Namibia Not 'Paramilitary'
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistani Plane Carrying 54 Is Lost in Mountainous Area
description: A Pakistani airliner carrying 54 people disappeared in bad weather today over mountainous northeastern Pakistan.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Driving a Child Safely
description: For all car travel, even short trips to and from the local grocery or pool, the safest way to transport young children is in a safety seat in the rear of the car. Small children, usually up to the age of 4, are required by law in every state to ride in approved seats designed for children, and the seats must be secured by safety belts. Find a seat that fits your child and your car and use it for every trip. Here are some safety tips from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Position: Place the child's carrier in the middle of the back seat to prevent injury in sideswipes. Face infants toward the rear of the car. Belts: Thread the car's belt through the safety-seat frame according to the manufacturer's instructions. Fasten the child-seat harness snugly over the shoulders. Quality: Buy and use only child safety seats that meet Department of Transportation requirements and carry approval labels. The date of manufacture should be after Jan. 1, 1981. Some seats are also certified by the Federal Aviation Administration for use on airplanes.

title: OPPOSITION LEADER INDICTED IN SEOUL
description: The opposition leader Kim Dae Jung and two legislators in his party were indicted today on charges stemming from a lawmaker's secret and illegal trip to Communist North Korea.

title: Davis Details Money Plan For UAL Bid
description: Marvin Davis said yesterday that he would be willing to commit $1 billion of his family's money and that he hoped to arrange $7 billion in bank loans to finance his $6.2 billion proposal to buy UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines. He asked UAL's board to reply by next Thursday.

title: Big B Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Flow International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain of $79,000 from operating loss carryforward. c-Included a gain on restructuring certain Admac obligations and from operating loss carryforward totalling $4,341,000.

title: Cineplex Odeon
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had agreed to buy 56 Canadian movie theaters with a total of 153 movie screens from Carena Developments Ltd. for $55.3 million. The 56 theaters are part of a group of 57 theaters that Cineplex had sold to Carena in September 1988 for $51.4 million. Cineplex had continued to operate the theaters. Cineplex said it had repurchased the theaters because of renewed box office strength in Canada.

title: Wanted: Airport Terminal (Nothing Too Modern, Please)
description: East Hampton had planned for some time to do something about its airport terminal, built as a World War II barracks. ''You name a code, and it wouldn't pass it,'' said the manager of the town-run airport, Patrick Ryan.

title: Padres Halt Mets on James's Homer in 11th
description: The Mets lost an argument, a manager, a ball game and one full length in the standings tonight when they opened a nine-game trip to the West Coast with a 5-3 loss to the San Diego Padres in 11 innings.

title: Whittaker Selling Battery Group
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its Battery Group to a group led by the operation's management. The amount of money involved was not disclosed. The Battery Group is made up of the Yardney power systems and power storage systems units. Whittaker said the sale was part of a divestiture plan that will leave it with six of its former operating units.

title: Horror-Film Publicity Horrifies Recipents
description: Hundreds of video rental shops today received promotional kits for a horror movie that included live garter snakes, and outraged animal-protection officials called the stunt ''cruel and irresponsible.''

title: HDR Power Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Johnson Is Charged
description: Eddie Johnson, a two-time National Basketball Association All-Star who spent most of his career with the Atlanta Hawks, has been charged with burglarizing two Marion County, Fla., homes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Wow! What a way to leave the solar system!'' - Dr. Laurence Soderblom, geologist on the Voyager team. [ 1:6. ]

title: On Issues For Women, It's a Matter Of Nuances
description: On women's rights and family issues, it may well be hard to tell some of the mayoral candidates apart.

title: Talks on a Cambodian Agreement Are Deadlocked, U.S. Says
description: The United States said today that an international conference on Cambodia, convened in Paris a month ago, had made no progress on the most important issue: the sharing of power between the Phnom Penh Government and its rivals, including Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: Nortek Clearance On Federal-Mogul
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation said Nortek Inc. had received antitrust clearance from the Federal Trade Commission to acquire more than $15 million worth of its stock. Barry Murphy, investor relations officer for Federal-Mogul, said his company did not know how many shares Nortek owns, but that $15 million worth would represent about 2.5 percent of the company.

title: Acoustical Tinkering at Carnegie
description: Carnegie Hall has been quietly tinkering with the acoustics of its historic main hall during its annual August closing. It is an attempt to smooth a harshness of sound that many musicians and critics say followed a major restoration three years ago.

title: Forger Apparently Writes His Own Ticket
description: A counterfeiter who has spent about 30 of the last 50 years behind bars walked away from a court-ordered supervised residency by forging a pass to a hospital, Federal officials said today.

title: Metro-Richelieu reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Long Putters Are Legal
description: The United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, Scotland, agreed last Saturday to continue to permit use of the long-shafted putters most commonly employed by members of the Senior PGA Tour. Orville Moody won the United States Senior Open championship in July putting with a club that had a 48-inch shaft.

title: Charles Impaglia, PBS Programmer, 39
description: Charles Impaglia, director of program scheduling for the Public Broadcasting Service, died of AIDS on Sunday at the Hospice of Washington. He was 39 years old.

title: Sex, Lies and Commercials
description: On a recent Saturday, a New Yorker tired of summer prime-time television braved the lines to get a seat for ''Sex, Lies and Videotape.'' What she got instead was a shock. No sooner had she settled into her seat than there appeared an all-too-familiar American Express ad, big-screen-sized and in stereo. And this in a theater for which she had just paid $7.50 for her ticket.

title: Giants vs. Jets: Sort First, Win Later
description: The Giants will play the Jets Saturday night, a matchup that once excited every pro football loyalist in the metropolitan area. This time, midway through the preseason, winning will be secondary to sorting.

title: The Women's Movement: Here to Stay
description: ''I'm not one of those women's libbers.'' The sentence sounds like a joke now, a laugh-getter out of ''All in the Family.'' But not so long ago it was a sentiment shared by millions. Many men felt they had nothing to gain from feminism - and many women felt they had everything to lose. To the latter, the women's movement that began in the 1960's was more a threat than a promise.

title: Voyager's Heartbeat Is Nuclear 'Battery'
description: The stunning pictures of Neptune being transmitted to Earth from the Voyager 2 spacecraft are coming courtesy of an unusual form of nuclear power that runs the craft's cameras, computers and radio transmitters that beam the pictures over.

title: About New York; Reject All Limits: A Blind Athlete Competes Boldly
description: A guide dog would have seen the danger and prevented Tony Candela from walking into a bent traffic sign Thursday morning, an accident that left a nasty gash in his forehead. His cane provides surveillance only of the lower altitudes.

title: Sandwich Co-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Singer Elects Chairman
description: The Singer Company said today that Walter A. Drexel had been elected chairman. Mr. Drexel was most recently vice chairman of Burlington Northern Inc. Singer said Paul A. Bilzerian had resigned as chairman June 29. In June, Mr. Bilzerian was convicted of securities fraud.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Sheehan Takes Lead: Patty Sheehan birdied three of the last four holes to complete a six-under-par 66 and take the lead halfway through the L.P.G.A. world championship of women's golf yesterday in Buford, Ga. Sheehan held a one-shot lead over Betsy King, who shot a 71 for 137.(AP) O'Connell Upset in Amateur Event: Michael Brannan of Trumbull, Conn., upset the medalist winner, Eoghan O'Connell of Ireland, 4 and 3 yesterday and advanced to the third round of the United States Amateur championship in Ardmore, Pa.(AP) One-Stroke Lead for Schulz: Ted Schulz rolled in a 40-foot eagle putt on the eighth hole yesterday to cap a seven-under-par round of 63 and take a one-stroke lead over Don Shirey after two rounds of the Hamilton County-Chattanooga Classic in Tennessee. Schulz had a two-round total of 129.(AP) Charles and Coody Tied: Bob Charles and Charles Coody each shot six-under-par 66 yesterday to share the first-round lead of the $300,000 Sunwest Bank-Charley Pride Senior tournament in Albuquerque, N.M.(AP) BASKETBALL U.S. Routs Poland: The United States basketball team, led by Larry Johnson's 21 points and 13 rebounds and helped by a strong bench, overwhelmed Poland, 128-75, at the World University Games yesterday in Duisburg, West Germany.(AP) TRACK Aouita Slowed by Elements: Driving rain, a sudden drop in temperature and a quick early pace last night thwarted Said Aouita's bid to break the world mile record. Running in the Ivo van Damme Memorial meet in Brussels, Aouita, a Moroccan, clocked 3 minutes 50.09 seconds, well outside Steve Cram's world record of 3:46.32.(AP) SOCCER Americans Top Soviets: The national team of the United States, inspired by 43,356 spectators, the largest crowd to attend a soccer game in Philadelphia, defeated Dnepr of the Soviet Union by 1-0 at Franklin Field last night. Eric Eichmann scored the lone goal in the 12th minute of the game. PRO FOOTBALL Redskins 35, Dolphins 21: Willard Reaves scored two touchdowns and Mark Rypien completed 13 of 16 passes for Washington in the decisive first half last night. Rypien directed three long scoring drives to help Washington (3-1) take a 21-7 halftime lead.(AP)

title: Smith Hires Smith As a Rangers Coach
description: Ron Smith, a former assistant coach of four National Hockey League teams, was named assistant coach of the Rangers yesterday. The announcement was made by Neil Smith, the team's vice president and general manager.

title: City Council Members Ought to Be Full Time
description: To the Editor:

title: At Hamlet, Crowd Sees Why Lendl Is the King
description: Designed to give players a chance to hone their skills just before the United States Open - and fans a chance to watch the stars at close range - the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup has been serving its dual purpose well this week.

title: Despair Comes Twice To a Brooklyn Family
description: For Sharon Sylvester, a 23-year-old nurse's aide, the killing of Yusef Hawkins in Bensonhurst has been a cumulative blow, a final proof of racism that, she says, will drive her from New York despite the promise of good pay that drew her here.

title: Giuliani Speech: Eliminating the 3 C's
description: New York City's mayoral candidates make dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often they use a ''basic speech,'' which varies little from one occasion to the next.

title: A Memoir Is Created From Pain Of Disability
description: Reynolds Price, the author of ''Clear Pictures,'' a memoir about growing up in North Carolina, is a literary triple-threat man; or make that quadruple- or quintuple-. He writes novels, poems, essays and plays, translates stories from the Bible and teaches students at Duke University about the power and glory of the English language, especially in the poetry of John Milton.

title: Mexican Executive Testifies In Killing of U.S. Drug Agent
description: Granted limited immunity in secret testimony, the brother-in-law of former President Luis Echeverria of Mexico appeared on Thursday before a Federal grand jury investigating the slaying of an American drug agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar.

title: G.E. Job Cuts In Louisville
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would lay off 500 factory workers in Louisville, Ky., in October because of the sharp decline in appliance sales.

title: Herbert Vogler, Stage Manager, 47
description: Herbert Vogler, a Broadway stage manager, died of AIDS Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old.

title: Recollections of Green: A Sprinkling of Regrets
description: Some people have suggested that New York City, its pressures and politics, even its polluted air, hastened the death of Dr. Richard R. Green, the Schools Chancellor, three months ago at 52 years of age. But while Gwendolyn Green says that perhaps too much was expected of her husband she feels no bitterness, only pained regret over what he might have done.

title: However, He Belongs In the Hall
description: Bob Welch, Oakland pitcher, was watching Bart Giamatti and Pete Rose on television the other afternoon when a momentous thought occurred to him: There might be something in this for the kid.

title: Ex-Lawyer Is Jailed in Impeachment Case
description: William Borders, a once-prominent defense lawyer who is now disbarred, was jailed today for refusing to answer the questions of a Senate committee in the impeachment case against Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings.

title: Mortgage Rate Rises
description: The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 10.21 percent for the week ended today, from 10.09 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said. The average adjustable-rate mortgage was 8.69 percent, unchanged from the previous week, the agency said.

title: Knight-Ridder Officers Shifted
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced today that Alvah Chapman, 68 years old, would step down as chairman, effective Oct. 1, and would be replaced by James K. Batten. 53, the chief executive.

title: First Pennsylvania Deal Set
description: Meridian Bancorp of Reading, Pa., announced plans yesterday to acquire the First Pennsylvania Corporation of Philadelphia, the oldest bank in the country and one of the largest before it fell on hard times in the late 1970's.

title: The Myopic New China Lobby
description: LEAD: Only weeks after the bloody repression of the democracy movement in Beijing, the voices of a new China lobby already urge a return to business-as-usual.

title: Gendis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said some year- earlier figures have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: John Nelson Resigns As Caramoor Director
description: John Nelson has resigned as the music director of the Caramoor Music Festival, the management announced yesterday. He left to ''pursue other interests,'' said Susan Spier, a spokeswoman for the festival. A decision as to a replacement has not yet been made.

title: Towle in Chapter 11
description: Towle Manufacturing said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Towle, a maker and seller of giftware, said it had made the filing because of excessive debt. The company had a previous Chapter 11 reorganization that ended in November 1987 but it said its revenues had failed to meet the forecasts on which that reorganization was based. Towle said it failed to pay about $1.8 million on a creditor's note due July 15.

title: Woman Gets High Post After Tokyo Aide Quits
description: Japan's new Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, chose a woman for one of the country's top Cabinet posts today in a scramble to quell yet another sex scandal engulfing the governing party.

title: International Cogeneration reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pakistan Day Parade, Madison Avenue between 23d and 42d Streets will be closed tomorrow from noon to 3 P.M. The avenue between 23d and 26th Streets will remain closed until 7 P.M. for the Pakistan Day Fair.

title: Training Center Planned As an Arm of Drug War
description: The Justice Department plans to build a center to train agents of the Drug Enforcement Agency as part of President Bush's campaign to combat illegal narcotics, Administration officals said today.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Pretoria's Choice: An Empty School
description: The city of Johannesburg was little more than a year old when the Johannesburg High School for Girls admitted its first pupils in 1887. Now, 102 years later, the Government plans to close the landmark institution at the end of December, not because there are too few local applicants, but because the applicants are not white.

title: Bruncor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Meredith Manni Weds in Chicago
description: Meredith Lee Manni and Dr. James Meserow were married last evening at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago. The Rev. Dr. John Boyle performed the ceremony.

title: Imtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Boston Is to Close or Consolidate 9 Schools
description: Reversing a lower-court decision, a three-judge panel of the state appeals court ruled today that the Boston School Committee may close or consolidate nine schools.

title: In Russia of 1800's, Reform Benefited the Czar; Glasnost Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: In Russia of 1800's, Reform Benefited the Czar
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; A Reporter Reminisces About a 'Good War'
description: The Violent Decade By Frank Gervasi Illustrated. 639 pages. W. W. Norton. $25.

title: Reports of Mercenaries in Colombia Worry Israel
description: The Israeli Government is trying to distance itself from Israeli mercenaries who were reported to have been supervising Colombian drug traffickers' assassination squads.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Battle of Impersonations
description: Even when not impersonating Kirk Douglas, Richard Burton or a host of other well-known actors, the impressionist Frank Gorshin has one of those malleable faces that continually suggests other people. And in his act at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street), which continues through Sept. 9, the comedian, who once played the Riddler in the ''Batman'' television series, likes to play his living legends against one another in amusing rapid-fire dialogues.

title: Rep. Frank Acknowledges Hiring Male Prostitute as Personal Aide
description: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts said today that without his knowledge a male prostitute he had hired to do personal errands had run a prostitution service from the Congressman's Washington apartment.

title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers
description: The State of Texas is wagering that there is something drug dealers fear more than prison: the tax collector.

title: M.T.A. Turns Down Volume On Subway Platform Music
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to forbid musicians and others from using amplifiers on New York City subway platforms, saying the excessive noise they produce can ''interfere with transit operations'' - not to mention drive some people crazy.

title: American Realty Trust Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stock Surge in Thailand
description: Thailand's stock market, fueled by optimism over the country's surging economy, has reached record highs. The index of the Securities Exchange of Thailand today passed the previous record of 670. Most analysts see further advances over the next month.

title: Reds Lose First Game After Ban of No. 14
description: The Cincinnati Reds, playing their first game since Pete Rose was banned from baseball for life, lost to Pittsburgh tonight, 12-3. Gary Redus, a former Red, hit for the cycle for the Pirates, who had 17 hits.

title: Williams Has Surgery
description: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, was listed in good condition yesterday after undergoing surgery to repair a herniated disk, the team announced.

title: Voyager Thrills Scientists in Farewell to Solar System
description: Speeding away from its fourth and last planetary encounter, Voyager 2 today left jubilant scientists agog as they viewed new photographs showing in dazzling clarity Neptune and especially its largest moon, Triton, where frozen lakes and ridges bespeak a past of slow-flowing icy volcanism never before seen in the solar system.

title: Shakeup From Housing Police Drug Arrests
description: In the wake of last week's arrest of two New York City Housing Authority police officers on drug and robbery charges, the third-ranking officer in the housing police has retired and four senior officers have been transferred.

title: Your Money; Helping Students Learn to Budget
description: Going to college is the first big step into an adult world for most students, and not all of the lessons are academic. Some concern day-to-day financial responsibilities.

title: New Data On Steroid Use by Olympians
description: More than 50 male athletes who competed in the Olympics last fall in Seoul, South Korea, have been found to have used anabolic steroids in the six months before the Games.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 28 about applicants for Federal housing grants contributing to Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato's campaigns misstated the role of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, L.I. Individuals and companies working on housing projects sponsored by the diocese contributed; the diocese did not.

title: Breast Cancer Death Rate Found Increasing
description: The rate of death from breast cancer in the United States is increasing and it is highest in the Northern states, Federal health officials say.

title: Steve's Homemade Ice Cream reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.N. and O.A.S. Form Panel To Help the Contras Disband
description: The United Nations and the Organization of American States agreed today to create a joint commission to oversee the disarming and resettlement of the American-backed Nicaraguan rebels based in Honduras.

title: Grieving for Dead Girl, Town Asks: Should Boy, 10, Face Murder Charge?
description: A 10-year-old Pennsylvania boy was charged as an adult yesterday in the fatal shooting of a 7-year-old neighbor. Experts in juvenile law say that if the case goes to trial, he will be the youngest person tried as an adult in a homicide case in this country in the 20th century.

title: New Role for Allison
description: Bobby Allison, out of racing since he was injured more than a year ago, plans to return to the sport next year as the owner of a Winston Cup team on the Nascar circuit. He has not named a driver or secured a sponsor, but the team will race Buicks and be based at Charlotte, N.C.

title: Lewis Conn, 73, Business Publications Head
description: Lewis Conn, a former newspaper publisher and labor union leader, died after life support systems were removed from him at the request of the family Tuesday at the Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis, Md.

title: Oppenheimer Capital LP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Free Dance Performances
description: Dancemobile is to present the Charles Moore Dance Company in free outdoor performances Aug. 29 through Sept. 2. The company will present dances by George Faison and Gary DeLoatch. Performances are to be at 8:30 P.M. on Tuesday at Balcom Avenue between Dewey and Schley Avenues, in the Bronx; on Wednesday at Springfield Park, 147th Avenue between 183d and 184th Streets, in Queens; on Thursday at Grant's Tomb, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, Manhattan; on Friday at Manhattanville Houses, 133d Street and Old Broadway, Manhattan; on Saturday on 115th Street between Manhattan and Morningside Avenues, Manhattan. Information: 316-6277.

title: Security Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Film; A Time Traveler Returns
description: ''This is not the end. This isn't the beginning of the end. This is the end of the beginning.''

title: Taiwan to Let U.S. Monitor Drift-Net Fishing Practices
description: The Government of Taiwan, seeking to avoid threatened trade sanctions, has agreed to allow American observers to board its fishing vessels to monitor huge drift nets, which kill marine animals and sea birds.

title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks
description: LEAD: As the citizens of the Republic tremble with anticipation, a governmental body, created last year by an act of Congress, is wrestling with one of the most momentous decisions of our time. Within a few days, the 13 members of the National Film Preservation Board will announce their long-delayed selection of 25 films as official, bureaucratically sanctioned ''National Treasures.

title: Review/Pop; Ziggy Marley Carries On In His Father's Tradition
description: Ziggy Marley has used his inheritance well. As the son of the late Bob Marley, who made reggae music an international force, he had the inside track to reach reggae fans. He has capitalized on his physical and vocal resemblance to his father, but he has also followed through with serious-minded lyrics and assured music, and in a surprisingly short time he has reconvened the large reggae audience that fragmented after his father's death in 1981. Mr. Marley and his band had a fully integrated full house up and dancing at Riverstage on Thursday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about asbestos contamination in Gramercy Park in Manhattan misidentified the synagogue at 28 Gramercy Park South. It is the Brotherhood Synagogue.

title: Shells Hit Beirut Again as Envoys Seek Cease-Fire
description: Beirut resounded with the crash of artillery and rocket fire again today as Lebanon's warring factions ignored new diplomatic efforts to arrange a cease-fire.

title: A Whiff of Fame
description: Claudell Washington, 36 times. Rod Carew, 29. Andre Dawson, 26. Dale Murphy, 23. Reggie Jackson, 22. Carleton Fisk, 21. Jim Rice, 19.

title: At the Neuberger, a New Director Sureveys the Possibilities
description: A NEW era begins at the Neuberger Museum tomorrow when Dominique Nahas assumes his post as director of the 15-year-old institution here, on the campus of the State University of New York.

title: Swimming Across the Rockies
description: IT'S 6 o'clock of an uneven day in the Elk range south of Aspen, Colo., and two outdoor junkies are showing symptoms of exercise deprivation. A few hours ago we were on the iron flank of the Maroon Bells, high above the summer heat, wedging across steep little chutes of snow that here and there clung to the scree. Late start and all, my wife and I figured we could hike out nearly to West Maroon Pass and back to the trail head, covering about 12 miles, before dusk.

title: Trucking
description: To the Editor: I'm sure you know how dangerous it is on the highways when it rains. Most of the hazard is created by trucks, which frequently go beyond the speed limit and throw a heavy spray onto passenger cars. This is particularly troublesome when the trucks are large and their wheels high. In a heavy storm, and at night, there can be long moments when visibility for drivers of smaller cars is almost nil.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of dancers on the Arts/ Reviews page last Sunday was captioned incorrectly and adjoined the wrong review. The picture showed the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company; it should have appeared with the review of ''Prophets in Black Dance,'' not ''The Angle of Descent.''

title: Nathan Susskind, 91, Tax Law Specialist
description: Nathan Susskind, a New Jersey lawyer and philanthropist, died of cancer Friday at Bayonne (N.J.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Bayonne.

title: Inconsistency a Hurdle For U.S. in World Cup
description: The road to Italy is becoming more and more treacherous for the World Cup team of the United States and the pressure is beginning to mount, now that Trinidad and Tobago has joined Costa Rica in surpassing the Americans in the final round of the regional qualifying.

title: Reviews/Music; Klien and Upshaw In Mostly Mozart Finale
description: Walter Klien has played in America for 20 years without exactly becoming a central figure in our concert life. He is not a showy interpreter, for one thing, and for another he sticks in the memory as a library-style recording artist (the complete piano music of Brahms, of Mozart, of Schubert. . . . ), an image that tends to drive out, in this listener's mind at least, recollection of individual performances. But at Mostly Mozart Friday night, in the last program of the season, he gave the most imaginative and specific performance of the evening in the great B-flat Concerto (K. 595).

title: Slayings Put Renewed Focus On Cartel Case Against Carters
description: LEAD: AFTER two officials of an East Northport garbage-carting company were shot to death there earlier this month, speculation spread quickly that the men were victims of an organized-crime cartel that state and Federal prosecutors say controls the carting industry on Long Island.

title: Cancer STrikes and Neighbors Bring Warmth
description: HOW do I thank them? How do I tell them how their thoughtfulness has bolstered and nurtured this family through seven months of sorrow, fear and sometimes overwhelming pain? Women I've known more than 20 years, women I've known only a short time, women I have never met - dozens of women who have responded to a woman's catastrophic inability to care for her own family.

title: Ex-Harvard Student Gets 10 Years in Jail Over Six Robberies
description: A young man from a poor Hispanic neighborhood who went to Harvard University was sentenced Friday to 10 years in prison for six armed robberies during school breaks.

title: Dennis L. O'Connor, Lawyer, 76
description: Dennis L. O'Connor, a lawyer, died of cancer Wednesday at the home of his sister in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 76 years old and was a longtime resident of White Plains.

title: Trekking
description: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler column about Trek Preparation (July 30) summarized realistically the appropriate preparation for such trips.

title: Pamela Stevens, Executive, Weds Stevens F. Alcock
description: The wedding of Pamela Murray Stevens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Stevens Jr. of New York and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to Stevens Frederick Alcock, a son of Warren Joseph Alcock Jr. of Manalapan, Fla., and the late Ethel Stevens Alcock, took place yesterday in Saratoga, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Park performed the ceremony at the Bethesda Episcopal Church.

title: From a Glorious Past To a Conspicuously Bright Future
description: The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford has a glorious past, where our century is concerned, and it might have had an impossible present. Happily, for reasons that will shortly appear, its future is conspicuously bright. How can anyone, or any set of human beings, compete with the legendary directorate (1927-44) of A. Everett Austin Jr.? Chick Austin (as he was universally called) was first with everyone and everything, from French and Italian 17th-century painting to the ideas of R. Buckminster Fuller, the movies of Eisenstein, Rene Clair and Salvador Dali, the operas of Virgil Thomson, the potential of George Balanchine as choreographer and the paintings - fresh from the studio - of Picasso, Miro, Mondrian and many another.

title: CRIME
description: Someone is killing off all the writers on the Puerto Rican island paradise of Vieques in MAY'S NEWFANGLED MIRTH (Bantam, Paper, $3.50). The first victim is a Pulitzer Prize-winning American poet. An alcoholic author of pornographic trash is the next scribbler silenced. Shortly after Detective Balthazar Marten, the ''unnervingly competent'' hero of four earlier procedurals in this wonderful series, arrives from San Juan to investigate, a travel writer disappears. Something quick and deadly has slithered into paradise. Mary Jo Adamson works the classical whodunit format with great ingenuity. She writes like a dream, this one, threading into her tale of revenge and retribution ravishing descriptions of the tropical locale and piercingly acute characterizations of the resident locals.

title: Beth Hunter Wed To Patrick Smith
description: Elizabeth Gayle Hunter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan V. Hunter of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Patrick Joseph Smith, a son of Joan D. Smith of Hauppauge, L.I., and Raymond D. Smith of Midlothian, Va. The Rev. George C. Bland Jr. officiated at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: Treasury's Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Folz Weds J. C. Ballantyne
description: Ruth Folz, a daughter of Lea Seluque Folz of Rio de Janeiro, and Joseph Cox Ballantyne, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Merrill Ballantyne of Ithaca, N.Y., were married yesterday at the temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Manti, Utah. Wilbur Wallace Cox, the bridegroom's grandfather and past president of the Manti temple, officiated.

title: For a Busy Lyricist, Four Routes to Broadway
description: On the fourth of July, when most of us were exercising our freedom to do absolutely nothing of significance, Susan Birkenhead got up at 6 A.M. to work on four Broadway musicals. Actually, the lyricist's schedule called for her to work on only two shows that day; but she worried some about the other two.

title: Connecticut Team Wins Little League Crown
description: Taiwan's three consecutive Little League World Series victories did not intimidate Little Leaguers from Trumbull, Conn.

title: History at the Tip of Long Island
description: MONTAUK, at the eastern tip of Long Island's South Fork, 125 miles by highway from Manhattan, has the mystique of places at the end of the road. Here, past the endless coiled circuits of midisland suburbs, beyond the clipped expensive foliage of the Hamptons, the wind blows harder, the waves curl higher, the light reflects with a scouring whiteness off the restless back of the Atlantic. At Montauk Point, the land takes a plunge at the raw clay and gravel bluff of Turtle Hill and the sea rears back and throws itself against the land. With every breaker, the mighty sandstone lighthouse that George Washington authorized stands a few grains closer to the brink.

title: Ms. Silfen Becomes a Bride
description: Dana Joi Silfen and Michael Alan Blum were married last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Lawrence Colton. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Silfen of Baldwin, L.I., graduated from the University of Maryland and is employed by CBS Records in New York. Her father is a lawyer in New York. The bridegroom, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Blum of Merrick, L.I., graduated from Emory University and the National Law Center at George Washington University. Next month, he is to become an associate at Baer, Marks & Upham, a law firm in New York. Mr. Blum's father is an endodontist in Westbury, L.I.

title: In Phnom Penh, Vietnam's 'Puppet' Is Finding His Voice
description: LATE last month, just before the international conference on Cambodia opened in Paris, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former king and leader of the opposition coalition dominated by the Khmer Rouge, accused Prime Minister Hun Sen of being untrustworthy. ''You're a former Khmer Rouge,'' the Prince said.

title: Keeping the Faith
description: At the height two years ago, 13 million people watched Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker on ''The Jim and Tammy Show'' on 200 television stations, and their television ministry, PTL, was taking in $129 million a year. Last week, near the depths, Mr. Bakker went on trial to face fraud and conspiracy charges, and Mrs. Bakker went on the television program, now carried by fewer than a dozen stations, trying to raise $1 million for his legal defense. With the collapse of his empire in sex and financial scandals, Mr. Bakker was charged with defrauding his followers by offering bogus vacation partnerships in the ministry's 2,300-acre Christian theme park. Said the evangelist, ''Our faith is in God.'' Said Mrs. Bakker, ''I don't see how possibly Jim can get a fair trial in Charlotte, N.C., with the circus they're making of it there.''

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Shopping by Catalogue: So Easy, Eh?
description: LEAD: JUST about the time I began to believe all the reports touting catalogue shopping as the wave of the future, I ordered shirts from a department store and found out otherwise.

title: Lost Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Benjamin F. Rogers, Publisher, 59
description: Benjamin F. Rogers, a medical publisher, died of cancer Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and lived in Huntington, L.I.

title: Young Skeet Shooter Conquers Nervousness
description: LEAD: SUCCESSFUL trap and skeet shooting depends 80 percent on mental ability, 17 percent on physical ability and 3 percent on luck, said Roger Shapiro of Chappaqua.

title: How to Manage a Holiday Crowd gfdefwait>
description: WHEN I was a young married woman, family holidays were pretty near-perfect, but until recently I never thought of analyzing the reason. My spouse and I simply drove upstate to one of our parents' houses, where we joined other jolly relatives for days of carefree fun and legendary meals.

title: More On L.I. Are Working At Home
description: LEAD: MORE and more Long Islanders are abandoning the Long Island Expressway, learning to cope with their child-care problems, escaping corporate politics and staying home to work. And Long Island businesses are taking notice. The N.P.D. Group, a Port Washington-based marketing-research corporation has had a work-at-home program since 1984.

title: After Dream Season, Irish Return to the Strict Realities
description: Long before the start of those Saturday afternoons when time seems to stand still in and around Notre Dame Stadium, before the first playing of ''The Victory March'' signifies the coming of autumn, before the invasion of stuffed automobiles and rented U-Hauls delivers the majority of the Class of 1993, and even before the first football practice earlier this month, a group of about two dozen new and muscular students gathered to hear about changes in their lives that they had already begun to face.

title:
ART;
Architecture and Mythology Combine at Storm King Center
description: LEAD: IT is hard to overpraise the ideal mesh of art and nature at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville in Orange County. The landscape is robust and varied, like the strong sculptures set into it, which feature mostly clearly etched forms in dynamic relationship.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a ''What's Doing'' article in the Travel section on Aug. 6 about Edinburgh carried an erroneous restaurant listing. The restaurant, Handsel's, closed last December. The exchange rate was also misstated; it is $1.60 to the pound. And the birthplace of James VI of Scotland, later James I, was misidentified; it was Holyrood House.

title: Q and A
description: Tipping the Guide Question: How does one tip adventure travel guides? - J. M., Stowe, Vt. Answer: Tipping on such trips is never mandatory but almost always appreciated if participants feel a guide has done a good job. The best approach is before you leave to to ask the tour company for guidelines on tipping. For example, Wilderness Travel of Berkeley, Calif., tells clients that $25 a person is a base tip for its 10-day or two-week tours, though $50 or more is not unusual. Other companies say that tips for a weeklong or 10-day trip generally range from $25 to $75 a person.

title: In the Bronx, Gardens Yield Harvests of Plenty, and Hope
description: ''There is something going on in the South Bronx that is not all crack, burned-out buildings and poverty,'' Karen Washington said the other day as she looked out over a blooming garden she helped cultivate in what was once a rubble-strewn lot. ''We are doing something with nature and giving it back to the community. We are turning the desert back into an oasis.''

title: Remedy for a Lazy Summer Afternoon: A Slow, Wet Trip in an Inner Tube
description: It may be the shank of summer, but it is never too late for indolence. The Esopus River here in upstate New York offers an escape from late-August heat and from any inclination to develop a fall agenda.

description: Rough wear. Animal prints. Classics. Quilted bags with chain-link handles. No, it's not designer sportswear; it's the back-to-school department.

title:
Focus: Growth Control;
Florida Law Begins to Influence Development
description: LEAD: A LONGSTANDING joke in Florida has it that the state bird is the construction crane. But the bird appears to be flying somewhat lower as the state's four-year-old growth-management law starts to influence development.

title: Donna J. Silbert,A Student, Weds

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST TIFFANY: A Biography of Dorothy Tiffany Burlingham. By Michael John Burlingham. (Atheneum, $22.50.) Charles Tiffany, the jeweler, and his son, Louis, the famed glass designer, were risk-takers and rebels, both revered and resented by their offspring. This also could be said of Louis's daughter Dorothy (1891-1979), the last of this talented family to bear the Tiffany name.

title:
MUSIC;
What It Takes To Join a Chorus
description: LEAD: FOR those interested in becoming a member of a chorus, selecting the right one from the many ensembles in the state may be difficult. Membership auditions now taking place for two well-known choruses, the Bergen Chorale, an amateur group celebrating its 10th season, and the Princeton Pro Musica, a professional ensemble beginning its 11th season, are illustrative.

title: A Russian Fantasy, Hewed of Wood
description: LEAD: IN the summer of 1904, Ivan Bilibin - painter, illustrator, stage designer, champion of Russia's fast-disappearing folk arts - caught his first glimpse of the tiny island of Kizhi, set in the lake of Onega, some 200 miles to the northeast of Leningrad. He was enraptured: ''Never have I beheld such an architectural vision .

title: 5 Arraigned in Killing of Black Youth
description: Five young whites were arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday in connection with the murder of Yusef Hawkins, a black teen-ager who authorities said had been shot to death solely because of his race.

title: County Hotels Initiate Training Classes
description: IT is a familiar scenario: John Jones, businessman, walks confidently to the sun deck of a leading Westchester hotel and announces his arrival. Instead of being handed a key, he receives an indifferent glance from the desk clerk, who informs him curtly that the hotel is completely full and, what's more, there is no record of a reservation for a John Jones.

title: drawingHOME CLINIC; Tending to Flat or Nearly Flat Roofs
description: FLAT or nearly flat roofs are usually built up of several layers of roofing felt and either coal tar or asphalt. A layer of gravel or marble chips is often spread over the surface to protect it and reflect heat.

title: Types of Ambiguity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who First Asked for Lox?
description: Two archeologists have recently joined in the quest for the elusive homeland of the Indo-Europeans, speakers of the ancient mother tongue of English and half the other languages of the globe. Their arguments are fascinating but their conclusions discordant. One, J. P. Mallory, places the ancient homeland firmly in the southern steppes of Russia, between the Black Sea and the Caspian. The other, Colin Renfrew, locates it in central Turkey.

title: Elizabeth Barton Lippincott Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Barton Lippincott, a daughter of Barton Hirst Lippincott of Philadelphia and Mrs. Anthony N. B. Garvan of Spring House, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles David Rosen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Rosen of La Jolla, Calif. Justice of the Peace Glen Nippert of Newport, R.I., performed the civil ceremony at Marble House, a mansion in Newport.

title: In France, the Remembrance of Things Present
description: Although we talk about the Roaring Twenties and the explosive 60's, who can say what a decade really means, and when an era actually begins and ends? We have been living in the 1980's for almost 10 years, yet they show no signs of ending. Then there is the problem of how to judge a decade - especially one that is still happening.

title: Shearling's New Flair
description: A new coat can bring a wardrobe into focus. Though the weather is still warm, many women are already eyeing the new, chic shearlings.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a letter to the editor on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today about John Hirsch omits the writer's signature in some copies. It was written by M. Elizabeth Osborn.

title: A Movie Maker Preserves Those Who Preserved Him
description: The first thing to know about Pierre Sauvage's documentary film ''Weapons of the Spirit,'' which tells the story of a small village in France where the lives of 5,000 Jews were saved in World War II, is that it is not the work of a dutiful child fulfilling, as the film maker put it, ''the deepest aspirations of his parents.''

title: AMERICANS FROM THE FARTHEST WEST
description: STRANGERS FROM A DIFFERENT SHORE A History of Asian Americans. By Ronald Takaki. Illustrated. 570 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Ueberroth Tries For Hawaiian Air
description: Control of Hawaiian Airlines would be acquired by a group that includes Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner whose deal for Eastern Airlines collapsed earlier this year, under an agreement set with HAL Inc., which owns the financially troubled airline. The group is headed by J. Thomas Talbot, former chairman of Jet America, a California-based airline. The deal, which values the company at $44 million, is far below what Wall Street speculators had expected, and Hawaiian Airlines' stock price has fallen more than 20 percent since the announcement. *

title: Jennifer A. Stone Weds J. W. Potter
description: Jennifer Appleton Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Stone Jr. of Middletown and Madison, Conn., was married yesterday in Middletown to Jeffrey Weightman Potter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Winslow Potter of Woodbury, Conn., and Long Lake, N.Y. The Rev. William A. Spurrier, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Chapel of Wesleyan University.

title: 110-Year-Old Store Keeps to Its Old Ways
description: LEAD: ON the bustling upper Boston Post Road here, near the center of the village, stands a store that defies time.

title: MOSCOW CONDEMNS NATIONALIST 'VIRUS' IN 3 BALTIC LANDS
description: In its strongest response yet to the growing calls for independence in the Baltic republics, the Communist Party today condemned nationalist movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and declared that the agitation had caused alarm and hysteria and raised the prospect of ''civil conflict.''

title:
GARDENING;
Renewed Interest in Insecticidal Soaps
description: LEAD: INSECTICIDAL soaps that promise control of insects without further contamination of the environment by much more toxic chemicals have been receiving much attention lately. Actually, various soaps have been used for insect control since the late 1800's.

title: Residents Fault Report on a Project for the Homeless
description: WHEN more than 700 Greenburgh residents gathered at a public hearing in February last year to comment on a housing project for the homeless that was to be built on six wooded acres in their town, they had little information to rely on but knew they were against it.

title: FICTION
description: TROPHY FOR EAGLES. By Walter J. Boyne. (Crown, $19.95.) Walter J. Boyne, the author of 10 books on aviation, has written an 11th book on aviation, thickly disguised as a novel. It concerns airplanes and people, real and imaginary, of the period 1927-37, a glorious era for aviation but for Western humanity a slog through the sloughs of depression and totalitarianism, emerging in war. Mr. Boyne's hero pilot, an American engineer named Frank Bandfield, is not immune to history; his fortunes rise and fall, as do those of Mr. Boyne's villain pilot, the German plane maker Bruno Hafner. Like all pilots, Frank gets gobs of sex, some of it pretty technical. (''Their first kisses had . . . a sort of rasping, sucking urgency that shot Bandfield's testosterone gauge past the red line.'') Odious Bruno gets even more, though as a German and a rotter he is less potent and more kinky. In a scene I certainly hope to see in the movie - I will pay plenty - Frank and his sweetheart, Patty (''when she unbuttoned her blouse the moon caught her breasts tumbling out in an avalanche of beauty''), go the distance in the front seat of a hurtling Beechcraft biplane over Arizona. I will not fully reveal the whole astonishing conclusion of the climactic Spanish Civil War dogfight between Frank and the Nazi opportunist Bruno because Mr. Boyne, who intends a sequel, doesn't reveal it himself. But I will say that Mr. Boyne's planes are livelier than his people and I miss them more when they crash. Not every plane is perfectly characterized - there was no such thing as a Messerschmitt Bf 109 V5, only the one and unique Bf 109 V5, and the real Howard Pete racer had a Wright Gypsy engine, not a Menasco - but they fly. Everything else in this book sinks.

title: Ruth Brown Finds Rhythm Again LBy BARBARA DELATINER
description: THINGS could not be going any better for Ruth Brown these days.

title: Streep and Barr Grapple in 'She-Devil'
description: ''This movie is about contrasts,'' says the director Susan Seidelman, and indeed it's hard to imagine a more contrasting pair of stars. One is tall and sleek; the other is, well, fat. One is refined; the other, outrageous. One trained at Yale; the other, in biker bars. One does accents; the other, wisecracks. One is Streep, the other is Barr.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I.;
description: LEAD: THE state's largest developer, the Downing Corporation of Providence, has begun the first phase of a $20 million residential project that includes both free-standing and semi-attached single-family homes built around a 200-acre lake.

description: The thing baseball fans seemed to forget all along was that this was really harder on Pete Rose than it was on the fans themselves.

title:
DANCE;
Choreography on an Island
description: LEAD: WHILE many vacationers on Martha's Vineyard sport slacks and shorts of Nantucket red, the ubiquitous terra-cotta color that signifies island haute couture, Carolyn Dorfman confines her use of that hue to leotards and leg warmers. Shunning sailboats and windsurfers, the choreographer, who spends most of her year in New Jersey directing the Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company, has chosen to submerge herself in the creative waters of the

title: Anti-Noriega Plan Is the Same: Wait
description: THE Bush Administration is casting about for new ways to dislodge Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega after the Organization of American States failed last week in its diplomatic effort to negotiate the transfer of power to a democratically elected government in Panama. But there are no obvious new ways to bring about his departure, and the Administration appears to have tried everything it is willing to try at this point.

title: If You're Image Conscious, Give Your Tapes a Long Life
description: Laura, who is 7 years old, may want to show her children the tape I made of her today. Will the tape last long enough?

title: The Politics Of a Killing In Brooklyn
description: IT took only hours for the killing of a black teen-ager in Brooklyn last week to turn into a political issue, not least for the six men running for mayor of New York City.

title: Attacking the Sovereign State of Cocaine
description: THE elected Government of this struggling Andean nation went to war last week against men often described as the world's wealthiest criminals. It is a fight in which the resources are uneven and the outcome uncertain, a new and strange kind of civil war.

title: Ms. Baker Weds Dr. Peter Clement
description: Nancy Lynne Baker and Dr. Peter T. Clement were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Ithaca, N.Y., by the Rev. David Shew.

title: To American Women: Sayonara
description: Working women in the U.S. had better start thinking seriously about what the increasing affluence of the Japanese means to us.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks. How can we restore the original brick color?

title: Energy-Improvement Loans Eased
description: One of the nation's largest suppliers of funds for mortgages is changing its rules to help prospective homeowners increase the energy efficiency of the houses they want and pay for these improvements. The revisions were put into effect this month by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the privately owned but Congressionally chartered company that is more commonly known as Freddie Mac.

title: STAMPS
description: With a certain inevitablity, Mickey Mouse has joined the galaxy at the United States Postal Service. To promote World Stamp Expo '89, in Washington between Nov. 17 and Dec. 3, the post office ran a cartoon contest involving a space-suited Mickey and a cute green extraterrestial.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
Town Houses On Schuylkill
description: LEAD: A TOWN-HOUSE development called Fitler's Walk has become the latest to try to cash in on the proximity of the Schuylkill, this city's ''other'' river, as a selling point for new construction.

title: Refine RICO, Don't 'Reform' It
description: Industry groups have demanded ''RICO Reform'' for several years. So far, they haven't proved that the 1970 Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act needs more than fine-tuning. But the returning Congress faces new pressure for special relief from an unlikely assembly of ''reformers'' - the National Association of Manufacturers, the Securities Industry Association, commodities traders, accountants and organized labor.

Wright Rumbough Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Ronald T. Evans officiated.
