title:
DINING OUT;
Charming Atmosphere in Bay Head
description: LEAD: A SPACIOUS, wicker-filled veranda greets visitors at the Grenville Hotel on Bay Head's main street a couple of blocks from the beach. Built in 1896, the four-story building is the town's oldest remaining hotel, and now it has been spruced up with a fresh, tricolor coat of paint.

title: Confusion as a Relief From Mosquitos
description: AS soon as I had heard the reports of an impending infestation of mosquitoes, I instinctively went out to buy some citronella. It was the sovereign remedy against mosquitoes back when my early instincts were forming.

title: Ms. Tamarkin, Reporter, Weds
description: Roxanne Tamarkin, a daughter of David Tamarkin of New Britain, Conn., and Dr. Toby Tamarkin-Dowd of Bloomfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Donovan of West Babylon, L.I. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by Dr. David Gidman, a Justice of the Peace in Manchester, Conn., at the Unitarian Meeting House in Hartford.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks. How can we restore the original brick color?

title: 'Travel Writing: Why I Bother'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Vain, Tigers Test Clemens
description: Roger Clemens settled down after a shaky start and won his 13th game as the Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers this afternoon, 5-2, for Boston's fifth successive victory.

title: A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned
description: LEAD: WHEN Maggie McCool refused to dissect a frog in her Woodstown High School biology class, she did more than dramatically demonstrate her belief in the sanctity of animal life.

title: TV Unites, And Divides, Hispanic Groups
description: LEO ESTRADA'S grandmother, an immigrant from Mexico, sits in her living room watching soap operas from Argentina and Presidential pronouncements from the Rose Garden. Like millions of other viewers, she is being pulled in two directions by one of the strongest cultural influences on Hispanic America, the growing power of Spanish-language television.

title: Israeli Arabs: Israelis First
description: LEAD: The impression the outside world has of the Arab problem inside Israel is that both sides are in full confrontation, emotionally if not militarily, and that the only thing that prevents outright internal war is Israel's controlling force.

title: PROGRAM KEEPS INMATES ON TRACK
description: As the four-week race meeting at Saratoga nears its end each year, everyone at the track begins looking forward to coming back the next summer. Few have ever held that hope more dearly than Benny Vazquez and Davis Hudson did here Friday.

title: Workers At Home Warned Of Fraudulent Schemes
description: LEAD: THE market for home-based work is growing so rapidly that it has spawned a large number of consultants, networks, organizations and publications to help those who want to establish home-based businesses or homework programs. But it has also produced some charlatans.

title: Fire Department Seeks Tips From Fire Victims
description: FIREFIGHTERS in Fairfield have a new piece of protective equipment that they bring to fires. It is a roll of plastic to cover rugs when responding to minor fires, so they do not muddy the carpet on rainy days. It is the first innovation to come out of a fire department program that offers fire victims a chance to evaluate firefighting techniques.

title: C. A. Sadler Wed To Miss Knowles In New Jersey
description: Katherine Lunt Knowles, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Knowles of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Alan Sadler, a son of Anne Forrest of Featherston, New Zealand, and Alan Sadler of Masterton, New Zealand. The Rev. Dr. William R. Lutz performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Rewarding Guests For Their Loyalty
description: These days, a loyal guest of a hotel gets more than a bed and a bath. Such ''regulars'' receive everything from scarves and Tiffany stationery to all-expenses-paid vacations.

title: Lynn E. Wise Is Married
description: At the West Side United Methodist Church in Clearfield, Pa., Lynn E. Wise, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glen E. Wise of Clearfield, was married yesterday to Wesley W. Oliver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Wesley Oliver Jr. of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Kenneth Linfield officiated. Mrs. Oliver is a vice president of Admiral Packaging, a division of Union Industries Inc. of Providence, R.I. The bridegroom is the international production director for the Reader's Digest Association Inc. in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Dana Smith Is Married
description: Dana G. Smith, 25 years old, and Richard A. Cooksey Jr., 29, were married yesterday by the Rev. Vance E. Polley, a Presbyterian minister, at Wainwright House, a conference center in Rye, N.Y. The bride, who expects to graduate from Columbia University in October, is the daughter of Jane Treuhold of Larchmont, N.Y., and Richard A. Smith of San Francisco. Mr. Cooksey, a financial adviser at Prudential-Bache Securities in White Plains, is the son of Betty-Gail Colburn of East Hartford, Conn., and Mr. Cooksey of Manchester, Conn.

title: Still the Stones, but There's a Catch
description: The Rolling Stones announce that they're back with the two triumphal chords that start ''Sad Sad Sad'' and open the album ''Steel Wheels'' (Columbia 45333; all three formats). Those two syncopated chords, like a rock ''Amen,'' are the ones that kicked ''Jumping Jack Flash,'' ''Honky Tonk Women'' and ''Start Me Up'' into gear; they're a Stones trademark, and Keith Richards's guitar makes them sound brash, slick, edgy, poised, offhand, jubilant and nasty, all at once. Within seconds, the Stones reclaim their music from dozens of ''roots-rock'' bands that have lately taken advantage of the Stones' apparent breakup.

title: Agency Seeking to Speed Recycling
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH nearly half the state's towns and cities are already recycling some trash, the January 1991 deadline to begin a mandatory statewide recycling program is still more than 16 months away. That may seem like a lot of time to homeowners who must still learn to sort their garbage, but to William R.

title: Beyond Reconnaissance
description: The next phase in the golden age of exploration of the solar system involves second, and longer, looks. The Week in Review, Section 4.

title: Nicholas Osborne And Miss Gates Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mark T. Gates Jr. of Woodside, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Lenaghan Gates to Nicholas de Jongh Osborne, a son of of Mr. and Mrs. Richard de Jongh Osborne of Princeton, N.J., and Little Compton, R.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: HOMEENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Rain Man 1988. MGM/UA Home Video. $89.95. Laser disk, $29.95. 2 hours, 15 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Dustin Hoffman takes hold of a ''star's dream of a role'' (which won him the Oscar) as Raymond the autistic savant, and Tom Cruise is his brother, Charlie Babbitt, a fast-talking, fortune-hunting (Raymond's fortune) auto salesman from Los Angeles. In a ''decently thought-out film'' (which also won the Oscar), Mr. Hoffman gives a performance of sustained virtuosity, but the ''true central character is the confused, economically and emotionally desperate Charlie, beautifully played by Mr. Cruise.'' (Vincent Canby) Wings of Desire 1988. Orion Home Video. $79.98. 2:10. Subtitled. PG-13. Two angels, Damiel (Bruno Ganz) and Cassiel (Otto Sander), come to earth in stark, cold Berlin to observe people and to ''serve as silent partners in almost all forms of human experience, be they physical or cerebral, violent or serene.'' Wim Wenders's film is startlingly original, but the ''unyielding whimsy [ has ] the effect of wearing the audience down.'' For a time, though, there is a ''loveliness of conception that, for a time, keeps it feathery as an angel's wing.'' (Janet Maslin) Beaches 1988. Touchstone Home Video. $89.95. LD, $29.95. 2:07. Closed Captioned. R. C. C. Bloom (Bette Midler) and Hillary Whitney Essex (Barbara Hershey) go from bitter feuds and tearful recriminations to loving affirmations in a story about friends that is pure soap from beginning to end. Much of the relationship is in flashback, tracking their lives together as young women making their way in New York, with C. C. as the singer on the way up and Hillary looking the demure debutante. As opposites, they ''make an appealing if pat combination . . . .Together, they make the friendship convincing and the story a lot more interesting than it otherwise would be.'' (Maslin) The Naked Gun: From the Files of the Police Squad! 1988. Paramount Home Video. No suggested retail price. 1:25. CC. PG-13. This ''proudly sophomoric'' comedy is at its funniest when it's hardest to second-guess what will happen. Calamitous pratfalls are the sine qua non of this kind of humor, but the film gives it an unexpected sophistication, thanks to Leslie Nielsen, who as Lieut. Frank Drebin manages to make himself a perfectly oblivious fall guy. The director David Zucker has given it a cheerfully messy style, but ''high spirits may be all that a film like this really needs.'' (Maslin) Bert Rigby, You're a Fool 1989. Warner Home Video. $89.95. LD, $24.98. 1:34. CC. R. When a strike shuts down the coal mine, who should emerge from the shaft, singing ''The Continental,'' but the miner of the title, played delightfully by Robert Lindsay. New employment ensues as, successively, pizza delivery man, assistant gardener in Hollywood and finally as an English butler who manages to set fire to an Impressionist painting. Career detours notwithstanding, Bert bursts exuberantly into song at the least mishap, giving Mr. Lindsay opportunity to perform ''Puttin' on the Ritz'' and a brief medley from ''Singin' in the Rain.'' (Maslin) Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure 1989. Nelson Entertainment. $89.98 suggested. 1:30. CC. PG. ''We are about to fail egregiously,'' Ted says to Bill, and so they do almost totally in this painfully inept comedy about two high-school pals who upon entering a magic phone booth are able to transport themselves back to key moments in history. Enter Socrates, Napoleon, Joan of Arc and Abraham Lincoln, among others. Meant to be funny, the film ''only swells the sinus passages.'' (Canby)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Things have gone far. The fate of the Baltic peoples is in serious danger. People should know into what abyss they are being pushed by the nationalist leaders.'' - Soviet Communist Party Central Committee. [ 18:3. ]

title: Winter Wedding Is Being Planned By Miss Connolly
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Connolly of North Falmouth, Mass., and St. Petersburg, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Connolly to Robert L. Alexander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Alexander of Stamford, Conn. A January wedding is planned.

title: From Baronial to Barnyard Casusal
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: On Fire Island, Justice Is Meted Out With a Dose of Patience
description: LEAD: 'GO ahead, it's all right,'' said Judge Benjamin Mehlman as the Village Clerk tried to quiet the sound of children crying by the open door of the courtroom. The defendant, mother of the two clamorous culprits, proceeded to state her case.

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS in the Mayor's Race When Mayor Edward I. Koch took office in 1978, no one had heard of AIDS.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about day-care centers misstated a requirement of a proposed zoning ordinance in Greenburgh. In office districts, a center's building plans would need approval from the Planning Board, not the Zoning Board.

title: CRANKY INTEGRITY ON THE LEFT
description: THE LIBERAL CONSPIRACY The Congress for Cultural Freedom and the Struggle for the Mind of Postwar Europe. By Peter Coleman. Illustrated. 333 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.

title:
Hers;
Bonus Baby
description: LEAD: T HEY HAD LABELED me ''Older Mother.''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: REUNION: A Memoir, by Tom Hayden. (Collier/Macmillan, $12.95.) The Chicago Seven defendant who married Jane Fonda tells about a time long ago when children of the affluent briefly found common cause with Black Panthers and thought they could start a revolution. Last year our reviewer, Paul Berman, said this autobiography is ''evocative, wordy, sometimes inconsistent. But what a story! . . . I turned the last page feeling a wary admiration for its author.'' REVOLUTIONARY ROAD, by Richard Yates. (Vintage, $8.95.) When Frank and April Wheeler left Greenwich Village for the Connecticut suburbs, they were convinced that they could insulate themselves from their dispiriting surroundings with alcohol, a well-honed sense of ennui and the knowledge that they were somehow different. It didn't seem to occur to them that their supposedly benighted neighbors might be thinking much the same thing. ''The excellence of 'Revolutionary Road' lies in the integrity with which its author depicts the Wheelers' disintegrating marriage,'' Martin Levin said here in 1961. His characters reveal themselves ''with an intensity that excites the reader's compassion as well as his interest.'' Vintage has also republished Mr. Yates's novel THE EASTER PARADE ($8.95), the story of two sisters whose parents' divorce twists their lives in two very different directions. Sarah becomes trapped in a marriage, Emily in a search for the perfect man. In 1976 one reviewer called Mr. Yates ''an unexcelled documentarian of sadness. . . . The details of [ the sisters' ] suffering are exact, indisputable, and moving.'' Also available from the same publisher is a new edition of ELEVEN KINDS OF LONELINESS ($8.95), a collection of short stories published in 1962. THE MAKING OF ''THE WIZARD OF OZ'': Movie Magic and Studio Power in the Prime of MGM - and the Miracle of Production N1060, by Aljean Harmetz. (Delta, $12.95.) The introduction to this behind-the-scenes look at what was once the height of special effects wizardry was written by the Wicked Witch of the West, Margaret Hamilton. ''Now at last I know how I flew,'' she says, ''how I melted, how I wrote in the sky 'SURRENDER DOROTHY OR DIE.' '' In 1977 our reviewer, Nora Ephron, called this ''an extremely jolly book . . . full of absolutely fascinating details.'' It has been republished for the movie's 50th anniversary. TRACKS, by Louise Erdrich. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) In the early years of the century, the Chippewa ancestors of the characters in Louise Erdrich's novels ''Love Medicine'' and ''The Beet Queen'' fight winter, smallpox and a conquering alien culture. ''Her sure sense of the way people think and talk keeps it hard to remember she is making them all up,'' Jean Strouse said here last year, ''and her lithe, athletic prose makes wildly improbable events seem as natural as the weather.'' GENERATION OF SWINE: Tales of Shame and Degradation in the '80s, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Vintage, $8.95.) A series of columns published in The San Francisco Examiner massacres George Bush, Pat Robertson and Dan Rather (to pick a few targets at random) with the chain saw prose Hunter S. Thompson developed in books like ''Hell's Angels'' and FEAR AND LOATHING IN LAS VEGAS, which Vintage has also republished ($7.95). He combines ''name-calling, bomb-throwing and sardonic humor,'' Herbert Mitgang said in The Times last year. ''He's a little more strident this time out, but if you happen to share his public enemies, Mr. Thompson's your man. Nearly everything he writes makes yellow journalism pale.'' COLLECTED STORIES: 1948-1986, by Wright Morris. (Nonpareil/Godine, $10.95.) Wright Morris's fictional realm is peopled by ordinary folk, often from Nebraska, who suddenly find their lives upset by something unexpected: a meeting with hippies, a trip to New York, a drowned child frozen in a pond. In 1986 our reviewer, Rosellen Brown, praised the author's ''unique voice - a touch irritable, adorned almost affectionately with his characters' cliches, unsympathetic to pretension, quirkily independent in the face of received opinion.'' THE CONTROL REVOLUTION: Technological and Economic Origins of the Information Society, by James R. Beniger. (Harvard University, $12.95.) The Industrial Revolution begat the Information Revolution, James R. Beniger argues, by producing a society so complex that it requires computers to keep it from inevitably slipping toward entropy. In 1986 our reviewer, Langdon Winner, said he thought Mr. Beniger put too much faith in the value of this high-tech nervous system, but he praised the book as a ''skillful cross-disciplinary synthesis'' and a ''challenging, highly readable work.'' THE LAST FARMER: An American Memoir, by Howard Kohn. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A former editor of Rolling Stone goes home to the family farm and uses the story of his hard relationship with his father to write about the crisis in American agriculture. The result is ''an intense and disturbing personal journey,'' Ben Logan said here last year. The book ''ruthlessly examines the new meanings that surface when past and present are freed from the linear mind and given the right to merge.'' THE MIDDLEMAN AND OTHER STORIES, by Bharati Mukherjee. (Fawcett, $3.95.) From Vietnam, the Caribbean, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka to Queens, Ann Arbor and Cedar Falls, the modern immigrants in Bharati Mukherjee's short stories create a multiplicity of new worlds. ''They're not tired, huddled or even poor: they own motels, work scams, teach in college, breeze through on private funds,'' Jonathan Raban said here last year. The book is ''a romance with America itself, its infinitely possible geography, its license, sexiness and violence.''

title: Q and A
description: Terrace Cookout Question: I have seen newspaper articles recently about people cooking outdoors on apartment terraces and on balconies and in back yards. I thought terrace cooking was illegal. Is it? . . . B. K., Manhattan Answer: Yes. According to a spokesman for the New York City Fire Department, fire rules prohibit the use of grills of any kind inside houses, apartments or garages or on any apartment balcony, terrace or roof. Backyard cooking, however, is permissible as long as other fire regulations are obeyed. Smoky Air Question: I live in a rent-stabilized building with 200 apartments. There are 14 units on my floor. The tenants in one are very heavy smokers and often leave their door open to air out their apartment, so the stale, smelly air from their apartment pollutes the common areas and often seeps into other apartments nearby.

title: East Side, West Side
description: The Fleming School, which occupies two buildings on East 62d Street, will sell them and use almost $6 million of the proceeds to buy the four buildings that now house the Notre Dame School on the West Side. Fleming's two buildings, at 10 and 35 East 62d, have been put on the market. The school's headmaster, Ray-Eric Correa, said the buildings were expected to fetch about $18 million.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Merge the Market Watchdogs
description: Last week, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Illinois, overturned a Securities and Exchange Commission order approving the introduction by the American Stock Exchange of an innovative financial instrument called an Equity Index Participation. In determining that the instrument was as much a future as it was a security - no more, no less - the court held that it nevertheless fell within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and could not be traded on a securities exchange in its present form.

title: In Poland's Wary Farm Belt, A Sobering Wait for Change
description: The mill was grinding fine as it has for over a century, and the miller, his beret and brow thoroughly dusted with flour, showed more concern than exuberance at the great moment of Poland's turning toward democracy.

title: Newport Coaching
description: Coaching, as it is known, was all the rage at the turn of the century. At least, it was with Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Harry Payne Whitney's crowd. Splendidly turned-out drivers atop gleaming coaches pulled by superbly trained horses - here was a sport that combined precision, protocol and style.

title: Style Makers; CYNTHIA STEFFE: SPORTSWEAR DESIGNER
description: Cynthia Steffe is moving briskly through the ranks of women's sportswear designers. When she graduated from the Parsons School of Design in 1981 she was named the school's Designer of the Year.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q & A: ELLI STREIT;
'A Personal Trade Mission From Israel'
description: LEAD: ELLI STREIT is an Israeli who believes in the power of personal attention. On and off for 10 months, Mr. Streit has been in the county trying to help Westchester businesses develop trade with Israel. Working from a desk provided by the county's Office of Economic Development, Mr. Streit, who is not being paid for his work, said he believed he could, with a hands-on approach, open doors and tear down red tape - at times better than official

title: Japanese Students Learn Lacrosse From the Experts
description: Can the Japanese take a purely North American product - lacrosse - and make it their own, the way they have done with cars, televisions and even baseball? Don Zimmerman, the head lacrosse coach at Johns Hopkins University, thinks so, and he is doing his best to export the sport to Japan.

title: Marchers and Brooklyn Youths Trade Racial Jeers
description: When 300 black demonstrators marched through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday to protest the racial shooting of a black youth, they were met by scores of jeering young whites who chanted, ''Niggers go home,'' yelled obscenities and held up watermelons to ridicule the demonstrators.

description: Almost to a man, the Mets reacted to Pete Rose on two levels today: They saluted him for high achievement on the field, but criticized him for not anticipating or accepting the consequences of his actions as a gambler who violated one of the prime rules of baseball.

description: LEAD: AS Jaqueline Zachary, a national board member of the National Organization for Women, was shopping for running shoes in Rocky Hill one recent day, she and another shopper got into a discussion of the Missouri abortion case the United States Supreme Court decided in July.

The new Kona Kai will be on a par with five-star resorts around the country, said Eric Levy, who tracks the local hotel market for the San Diego office of Laventhol &

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Astoria
description: LEAD: ON hot summer days, the Astoria Pool, the largest in New York City, becomes a microcosm of the mythic American melting pot, with thousands of neighborhood youngsters of all imaginable backgrounds splashing in the heavily chlorinated water. The immense pool - 495 feet by 276 feet - is framed by the Triborough and Hell's Gate Bridges and has as a backdrop the turbulent waters of the East River, which separates Queens from Manhattan.

title: A New Generation of Racism Is Seen
description: The killing of a black teen-ager Wednesday night in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn is but the most searing example of what sociologists and civil rights groups say is a renewed and rising tide of racial intolerance among teen-agers and young adults across the country.

A recent addition, though, is Cogburn's, which occupies space formerly belonging to another restaurant, St. John's River Cafe. Close to Norwalk's commercial downtown for lunches and a block from the city's major movie theaters, Cogburn's seems to be well-positioned for dropping by.

description: AccordinG to a recent Department of Labor study, the number of black Americans in the work force increased from approximately 8 million in 1965, to 12.4 million in 1985; and the number of Hispanic workers nearly doubled between 1975 and 1985, to 7.7 million from 4.2 million. million. Moreover, it is estimated that during the coming decade minorities will constitute one-third of all new entrants into the labor force.

title:
INVESTING;
How Two Food Processors Stack Up

description: After years of hestiation, the Pentagon is preparing to take on a major role in the fight against drugs. The shift is not just in devoting more resources to the battle, but in a new convictin that illegal narcotics are a genuine threat to national security.

''It's back to a little bit of civilization,'' said Ms. Dexter, who operates the tearoom and an antiques shop in her home, which faces the town green in the little Windham County community of Scotland.

title: DATA UPDATE
Works in Progress; Sew Red
description: ONE PECULIAR THING ABOUT the contestants in this year's Miss America Pageant is that, overall, they're smaller than usual. ''There are a lot of petite girls,'' says Julie Duroche. ''Last year, there were a lot of size 8s and size 10s. This year there are of lot of 4s and 2s.''

title: U.S. Calls Iranian Cleric Leading Backer of Terror
