title: Joseph H. Weiss, Architect, Weds Holly G. Nelson
description: Holly Grace Nelson, a daughter of Donald W. Nelson of Temple, Tex., and Joseph Hobart Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Weiss of Chicago, were married last evening in Pomfret, Conn. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Freeman R. Nelson, the bride's grandmother. The bride is also the daughter of the late Carol W. Nelson.

title: No Headline
description: The wedding of Marjorie Lyn Howard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Howard of Westport, Conn., to Douglas Mark Evans, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Evans of Sudbury, Mass., took place last evening in Old Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Robert J. Orkand officiated at the Hyatt Regency.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Did I Miss My Children?
description: LEAD: I STOOD in the middle of the parking lot at Leonard's of Great Neck, jumping up and down like a kangaroo in heat. Flailing my arms, I watched anxiously as the buses came to a halt. The moment had arrived. Camp was over. The summer was over. My vacation was over. My children were home.

title: 11 Armenians Leave Prison, Find Celebrity
description: When the Soviet authorities jailed the leaders of the most prominent Armenian nationalist group last winter, they hoped to quell and discredit the growing movement that these men were directing.

title: Body and Mind; Challenge of Gravity
description: FIFTY FEET ABOVE dirt and talus, I plaster myself to a vertical wall of rock. I lift my way against the unfamiliar demands of gravity, calling on joints and muscles that suddenly seem inflexible and weak. My novice's eye can hardly make out the slender juts of stone above me that must serve as holds for hand and foot - and it requires a great leap of faith to believe in them. In the Rockies, I feel like a weak, old man. But if I fall, my brother, an expert climber, will grab me by the seat of my harness with the belay rope, and I'll hang safely, like a dangling puppet. As diapered toddlers, most of us threw our muscles and joints against the challenge of gravity with similar disregard for safety. Short, unsteady steps would lead to nosedives, sometimes broken by a belaying parental arm.

title: More Views On the Turnpike
description: I've just been reading Anthony DePalma's July 30 article, ''About New Jersey,'' on the subject of the New Jersey Turnpike. He gives a lengthy recitation on the ugliness, bleakness and wretchedness of the road.

title: Past Neptune, Voyager Sights Still More Rings
description: One and possibly three more rings have been discovered circling Neptune like multiple halos of sparkling debris, as scientists today analyzed the flood of pictures and data coming from Voyager 2, the spacecraft now departing the Sun's family of planets.

title: Politics Sharpen Theater Festival in Hamburg
description: The biennial theater of the World festival, recently on view in Hamburg, is one of several heavily subsidized, extremely selective European festivals aimed at the audience of connoisseurs that has been created by the easy availability of first-rate European theater. It visits a different West German city on each occasion - Frankfurt four years ago, Stuttgart two years ago, Essen next.

title: Style Makers; DAVID LANCE GOINES: POSTER ARTIST
description: In 1964, David Lance Goines was expelled from the University of California at Berkeley during the Free Speech Movement and went to work in a small print shop, producing leaflets for the cause. Today he designs and prints posters for purveyors of the California style of life - he is best known for his series for the culinary temple Chez Panisse - and has lately turned his attention to wine labels for three California wineries: Mount Veeder, Neyers and Ravenswood.

title: Norwalk Athlete Plays Close to Home
description: LEAD: MAURICE VAUGHN excelled at a lot of sports when he was growing up, but it wasn't until three years ago that he decided to concentrate solely on baseball. It was a good decision, for in May he was picked in the first round of the professonal baseball draft by the Boston Red Sox.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: From the fan's point of view, the answer is obviously yes, resoundingly so. From George Steinbrenner's position, the question must be more accurately targeted to the psychoanalytic profession to arrive at the reasons as to what drives such a man to endure -and inspire - his paying customers' deep-felt enmity. STEVEN P. SCALICI Staten Island

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Historic Trenton Area Tries a Comeback
description: LEAD: SINCE the start of this decade, local groups have worked to brighten the face of Old Trenton, a neighborhood ravaged by suburban flight and neglect. Many of its once-fashionable 19th-century homes stand rotting and abandoned, and empty lots make ugly holes in the streetscape.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Khmer empire ruled southeast Asia for centuries, but in the last two hundred years the Khmer homeland, Cambodia, has been torn apart by its former vassals. In the 1960's Cambodia tried to strike a balance between the forces of Vietnam and the United States by playing her China card.

title: FIGHTING THE BATTLE OF DIRTY MONEY
description: It was all so easy - and that's the problem.

title: U.S. Is Cautioning Americans To Avoid Travel to Colombia
description: The State Department today advised Americans to avoid traveling to Colombia, where a crackdown on drug traffickers has increased the level of violence.

title: THE GREAT MIDDLE EAST GAME, AND STILL NO WINNER
description: LEAD: A PEACE TO END ALL PEACE Creating the Modern Middle East 1914-1922. By David Fromkin. Illustrated. 635 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $39.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE UNOPPOSITE SEX: The End of the Gender Battle. By Elisabeth Badinter. Translated by Barbara Wright. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $22.50.) Elisabeth Badinter's thesis -that society is fast approaching a state of companionable androgyny - takes on an ironic tone in light of recent events on the American political scene, most notably the United States Supreme Court's decision to approve drastic restrictions on women's reproductive freedom.

title: Four Seasons
description: To the Editor:

title: As a Mayoral Candidate, You Can't Be Too Rich Or on Televsion Too Much
description: IN the final days of a political campaign, television is like a monstrous maw gobbling up campaign money as fast as it can be raised. The Democratic and Republican mayoral primary campaigns in New York City that will end in two weeks are no exception, even under the restraints of the city's new campaign finance law, which is supposed to keep big money and fat cats out of municipal campaigns.

title: G. S. Rafshoon And Ms. Glaser To Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of Ellen Glaser to Gerald Scott Rafshoon, the son of Betty Garrett of Atlanta and Gerald M. Rafshoon of Washington, has been made known by her parents, Dr. Joy and Jack Glaser of Scarsdale, N.Y. A November wedding is planned.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: I'm afraid that the signs are not good. Steinbrenner seems to feed on hate. The more Yankees fans detest him, the tighter his reins will become. And his stock has never been lower. Moreover, the latest move was more significant than the others, which were usually the switching of one broken spirit for another. Dallas Green, however, is a strong and independent baseball man. His replacement with one of the sycophants demonstrates that Steinbrenner still feels he has the answers and that he is in for the long haul. And a long haul it will be. CARL WEINSCHENK Kew Gardens, Queens

title: CONSUMER RATES
L.A. FIGHTS FOR BREATH
description: California's South Coast Air Quality Management District may be calling for a car-pooling requirement in southern California. But whatever progress might be made in reducing the number of cars will be offset by the numbers of new tenants in the many high-rise buildings under construction. The City of Los Angeles and the Community Redevelopment Agency have approved this new construction without regard to the effect it will have on air quality in the downtown area. There are no fewer than six buildings under construction; no new freeways or alternative-transportation methods will be available when these buildings are occupied. ANDREW KO Long Beach, Calif.

title: On Language; Succinctly Spoken
description: F OUR PEOPLE GAZE at a steeple. A minister sees a religious monument. A mechanical engineer sees a balance of forces and materials. A psychoanalyst sees a Freudian symbol. The person who has to climb 70 steps to clean the belfry sees something else. The same object, but each observer has a different take, depending on his or her deformation professionelle.

title: Should Rose Be Reinstated Next Year?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: An Update on the Glorious Tomatoes of Yesteryear
description: IT was the largest of all the tomatoes that survived the foraging raids of the deer on my garden this summer. I found it almost hidden from view among the drooping branches of a withered tomato plant. It was huge, this beefsteak tomato, ripe, red and luscious. The kind that drips down your chin when you take a bite. I carried it up to the kitchen where I rinsed it and patted it dry and placed it in the refrigerator.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: Yes! Furthermore, he should be forced to do so. The City of New York should declare Yankee Stadium a disaster area, invoke the power of eminent domain, claim the Yankees, and give Steinbrenner their market value - and his walking papers. MICHAEL BROWN KEN LINDLEY New York

title: Stealth Bomber Takes Its Longest Test Flight
description: The B-2 Stealth bomber had its longest and most secretive test flight today over the Mojave Desert, an Air Force spokeswoman said.

title: Fashion; The Paris Couture: Shaping Up
description: AS USUAL, KARL LAGERFELD WAS RIGHT. COMMENTING before the fall couture collections in Paris last month, Chanel's never-at-a-loss-for-words designer declared, ''This will be the season of identities.''

title: Understanding Illness Heals a Marriage
description: TWELVE years ago, at the age of 30, Joanna Baumer Permut of Guilford was diagnosed with lupus. She suffers from slurred and delayed speech, intense pressure in her head, arthritis and drawn out fevers. The unpredictability of her symptoms, which last anywhere from weeks to months, is the worst part of the disease, she and her husband, Steven Permut, agree, and it nearly ruined their marriage.

title: The Job Is to Solve the Crime
description: IN a section of the State Police Forensics Laboratory, an investigator cautiously removes fingerprints from a series of bombs. In another room, a photographer takes pictures of a telephone receiver that has been dusted for fingerprints. In one of the other 14 divisions, three scientists examine tiny bits of glass and hair, while nearby in the arson room, fire debris is analyzed. Upstairs, in serology, a criminologist analyzes blood from a rape case.

title: Outdoors; Bay's Striped Bass Stage a Comeback
description: After nearly a decade of poor spawning years, the Chesapeake Bay's striped bass have produced a host of offspring.

title: Reviews/Music; Summergarden Concert Series Ends
description: Summergarden, the Museum of Modern Art's July and August series in the Sculpture Garden off 54th Street, has based this year's concerts on two composers and one theme. Debussy and Bartok have been the men, politics the premise: nationalism and a shared abhorrence of foreigners.

title: No Eagles for Eddie
description: As a golfer, Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards turns out to be at least as good as he is as a ski jumper.

title: Beirut Quiet as Soviet Envoy Pursues a Cease-Fire
description: Beirut was quiet except for occasional gunfire today as a Soviet envoy pursued efforts for a cease-fire.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: No. He should be forced to obey the Constitution and emancipate them. ASHLEY SIMMONS New York

title: An Amish Vacation for New York City Children
description: As they waited behind a protective barricade at the George Washington Bridge Bus Station on a recent Thursday, 67 children who had been staying with Fresh Air Fund families in southeastern Pennsylvania's rural Lancaster County might have been coming from a foreign country.

title: Karen McCready Marries
description: Karen Marie McCready and Jean-Yves Noblet were married in New York yesterday in the St. James Chapel at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Canon Michael Kuhn performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Noblet, the daughter of Mrs. Robert R. McCready of Dallas and the late Dr. McCready, is a graduate of Austin (Tex.) College. She is the director of Crown Point Press in New York. Mr. Noblet is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Noblet of Grenoble, France. He attended L'Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Grenoble, where he was also a teacher. He is the director of the Pamplemousse Press, a poster concern that is to open in January in New York.

title: What's Doing In Tulsa
description: Tulsa, a young, sophisticated city on the edge of the prairie, revels in its heritage, the Indian, the cowboy, but predominantly in oil, which propelled it from cow town to ''oil capital of the world.'' Today, that boastful sobriquet is more nostalgia than fact. The oil business is both depressed and headquartered elsewhere. Tulsa's economy, by necessity, has diversified. But the spirit endures in an impressive legacy of architecture and art.

title: Michele Pincus To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Pincus of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Michele Amy Pincus, to James Frederick Eller, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Milton Eller of North Woodmere, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: OH, WHAT A LOVELY WAR
description: WAR NEWS A Young Reporter in Indochina. By Robert Sam Anson. 317 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Stieb Produces His Fifth One-Hitter
description: Dave Stieb pitched his fifth career one-hitter today, allowing only a two-out infield single to Robin Yount in the sixth inning, while Mookie Wilson went 4 for 5, scored two runs and drove in one as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 7-0.

title: Jurors' Deliberations Begin In Helmsley Tax-Fraud Trial
description: The jury in the Helmsley tax-fraud trial began deliberating yesterday.

title: Koch's Record on AIDS: Fighting a Battle Without a Precedent
description: No one had ever heard of AIDS when Mayor Edward I. Koch took office in 1978, although the deadly virus was already silently spreading through New York City. Today, the scourge of AIDS poses a citywide health-care crisis and has emerged as a sharply disputed issue in the mayoral campaign.

title: We Need an International Court on Terrorism; The Captors' Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: College Kicker Loses His Tee
description: The placement kicker had become so adept that his successes were unduly inflating the scores of college football games. That was the opinion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Football Rules Committee, which then took away the kicker's crutch, the tee.

title: Dispute at Coachlight Leads to Non-Union Cast
description: AFTER the Aug. 13 performance of ''They're Playing Our Song'' at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor, the eight-member cast quit the show. Three day later, a new company took over in the Marvin Hamlisch-Neil Simon musical, which is scheduled to run through Sept. 17. What sets the two casts apart is that the first consisted of members of Actors' Equity, the union of professional actors and stage managers; the new cast does not.

title: Linda C. Buchin, a Consultant, Is Wed To Michael Hobart Sullivan in Boston
description: Linda Chase Buchin and Michael Hobart Sullivan were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston by the Rev. Steven Wade. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Buchin of Boston, and her husband is a son of Maria G. Sullivan of Berwyn, Pa., and Dr. Hobart B. Sullivan Jr. of Philadelphia.

title: Summer Squall Surges to Take Hopeful
description: Summer Squall maintained his perfect record and his standing as the nation's leading 2-year-old by squeezing through a narrow opening in midstretch to win the $234,000 Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: THE POOR MAN'S ATOM BOMB
description: CHEMICAL WEAPONRY A Continuing Challenge. By Edward M. Spiers. Illustrated. 218 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $45.

title: Surplus Security
description: To the Editor:

title: 8-Year-Old Nuclear Plant Spill Is Investigated
description: For eight years, spilled radioactive waste has remained in a sub-basement at an upstate New York nuclear power plant. Last week, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission started to investigate.

title: The Power Of History
description: Of all the changes made by Mikhail Gorbachev in the name of glasnost, the most important may be his steps toward truth in history. Important, and unsettling in their consequences.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: EGREMONT, MASS.;
Accord Reached On Resort Plan
description: LEAD: THE rural Town of Egremont has negotiated a settlement that is expected to let a Boston developer build a vacation-home resort, but with extensive land-use guidelines.

title: Pizza
description: To the Editor: Queen Margherita may have sung the praises of pizza after tasting it for the first time in 1889 (''Pizza for Purists from Naples Ovens,'' Travel, June 25), but one well-known English travel writer of that period detested it. Augustus J. C. Hare (1834-1903) in his ''Cities of Southern Italy and Sicily'' wrote that a ''horrible condiment called Pizza (made of dough baked with garlic, rancid bacon, and strong cheese) is esteemed a feast'' in Naples.

title: Excerpts From Soviet Statement on Baltic Unrest
description: Following are excerpts from the statement on Baltic nationalism issued yesterday by the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee, as provided in translation by the official Tass press agency:

title: ARE YOU A PERSON?
description: MIND IN ACTION Essays in the Philosophy of Mind. By Amelie Oksenberg Rorty. Illustrated. 378 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $27.50.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BUTTERFLY TAGGING DAY

title: Four Seasons
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Renewed Interest in Insecticidal Soaps
description: LEAD: INSECTICIDAL soaps that promise control of insects without further contamination of the environment by much more toxic chemicals have been receiving much attention lately. Actually, various soaps have been used for insect control since the late 1800's.

title: U.S. Agent Pleads Not Guilty in Drug Case
description: Edward O'Brien, a Federal drug agent arrested on cocaine trafficking charges here last week, pleaded not guilty Friday and a United States magistrate said she would decide Monday whether he should be freed on bail.

title: ARAFAT VISA ISSUE AGAIN VEXING U.S.
description: The Bush Administration is bracing for what it fears could be a new diplomatic crisis over whether to grant the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, a visa to attend a forthcoming session of the United Nations this fall.

title: A Foreign Policy on Crack
description: President Bush has responded swiftly and wisely to Colombia's cry for help in its war against the drug cartels. His decision to dispatch helicopters, arms and other equipment to Bogota meets an urgent need. It could also mark the start of a sound, and essential, foreign policy on drugs.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: Steinbrenner has extinguished the spark from Don Mattingly's eyes and created an environment that caused Yogi Berra to refuse to enter Yankee Stadium.

title: What Happens When What's Under Manhattan Breaks
description: IT is a jungle down there. Beneath the 23 square miles of Manhattan are 11 million miles of telephone wire, 19,000 miles of electrical cable, 6,000 miles of water mains, 4,000 miles of gas lines, 100 miles of cable television wiring and 105 miles of steam pipes. And that is not all that is stretched over, under and around subway tunnels, sewage lines and passages barely big enough to crawl through.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Lost at Sea, for a Cause

title: Jennifer Brown Marries
description: At Our Lady of the Snow in Woodstock, Vt., Jennifer Findlay Brown and Richard Scott Freeman Strabley, 1986 graduates of Hamilton College who are sales representatives at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. John Krogin, the Roman Catholic chaplain of the college. The bride is a daughter of James Kenyon Brown of Boston and Mary Findlay Banks of New York. Mr. Strabley's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard Strabley of Great Barrington, R.I.

title: Decorative Boxes House Secrets and Surprises
description: Purely ornamental as they may seem now, decorative antique boxes hold the key to the social customs of an older culture. Stored within their intricate interior fittings was the paraphernalia that served both men and women in the tasks and pleasures of daily life - particularly as they traveled abroad. Whether it was a vanity box for the morning toilette, a fold-up lap desk for writing letters or a game box for cards at night, these boxes are artifacts of a more civilized day, when compartmentalization was an art as well as a science. Today, plastic sewing kits and soft luggage with zippered pockets are only the vestiges of skills that have faded away or been lost.

title:
KENILWORTH JOURNAL;
Award in Accident Leaves Residents Facing Higher Taxes
description: LEAD: ON Nov. 17, 1982, Mark Waldorf, a rear passenger in a van, was involved in a traffic accident here at the intersection of 14th Street and Monroe Avenue, at which it was later determined a traffic light had malfunctioned. The accident left him a quadriplegic.

title: E. B. Bland Wed To Miss Robbins
description: The wedding of Juliette Laddon Robbins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Robbins of Troy, N.Y., to Edward Bingham Bland, a son of Mrs. Richard H. Downes of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late James Edward Bland, took place yesterday at the Braintree Hill (Vt.) Meeting House. The Rev. Richard H. Downes, an Episcopal priest and the stepfather of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: THE JUDAS CASE
description: LEAD: THE WORK OF BETRAYAL By Mario Brelich. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 238 pp. Marlboro, Vt.: The Marlboro Press. $21.95.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Pakistan Day Parade, Madison Avenue between 23d and 42d Streets will be closed today from noon to 3 P.M. The avenue between 23d and 26th

title: Giants' Backs Are on the Run
description: Of the 67 players on the Giants' roster, seven are running backs. All seven will probably survive when the roster is cut to 60 on Tuesday. One or two will go when the final cut to 47 is made the following Monday.

title: Vermont Resists Some Progress in Dairying
description: ALONG Center Road three miles out of Vermont's capital, Richard Atkinson's dairy farm unfolds across a hill, where streams rush cold and clear and gnarled sugar maples are just starting to turn the colors of autumn. Twice a day, the tall farmer leads his 40 Jersey cows down the hill to be milked in a bright yellow barn. Spider webs shine silver in the corners of open windows. The breeze smells of manure and damp earth.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Hawaii Plans New Center After Fire

title: Susan Jameson to Wed
description: Susan Jameson, an associate in the law firm of Chadbourne & Parke, and Darren Joseph Corrao, a tax lawyer for Morgan Stanley & Company, both in New York, plan to be married next month. Dr. A. Gregory Jameson of New York announced his daughter's engagement to a son of Mrs. James Corrao of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Corrao. Miss Jameson, 30 years old, is also the daughter of the late Dr. Jean Jameson. Miss Jameson graduated from Phillips Academy and Wesleyan University and received a law degree from Yeshiva University. Mr. Corrao, 30, a magna cum laude graduate of New York University where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, received a law degree from Cornell University and a master's of law degree from New York University.

title: Foe of Nazis and Communists Being Invited Back to Poland
description: For Jan Nowak, who slipped out of Nazi-occupied Warsaw several times as a courier for the underground Polish Home Army, the last round-trip journey was the longest: 44 years and 8 months by his reckoning.

title: When Human and Other Animals Interact
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects; Restructuring Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced a major restructuring aimed at paring costs following a weak second quarter. The company will cut 4,500 jobs this year and will sell some of its business units. There will also be a wage and salary freeze for 1990. Kodak's poor showing comes after its $5.1 billion purchase of Sterling Drug Inc. last year. Two customers, an analyst and a corporate strategist offer advice to Kodak. Michael L. Horowitz Vice president, Kenmar-Camera Corporation, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Zucchini And Corn in a Sauce For Pasta
description: The white corn is in; the zucchini are flourishing. The question was how to combine them and turn them into a dish that, for a change, did not require tomatoes, a dish that would make a meal with little effort and a minimum of pots.

title: Hmong Refugees Import A Near-Record Birthrate
description: Yia Yang, who promotes birth control among his fellow Hmong refugees from the mountains of Laos, says he plans to set an example for them by stopping after just four children.

title: Now Pauline Collins Puts Her Valentine's Message on Film
description: ''Theater is an engagement between the actor and the audience,'' says Pauline Collins. ''Film is a different sort of medium. It's not immediate, but in some ways it's more involving. I think you can lose yourself more easily in a film than in the theater.''

title: What Illinois Gave to Keep Sears
description: THE search by Sears, Roebuck & Company for a cheaper location for its headquarters ended this summer after Illinois officials assembled a generous bundle of incentives to keep the company in Illinois in the face of overtures from other states offering tax breaks and cheap land.

title: FICTION
description: HANNAH. By Paul-Loup Sulitzer. Translated by Christine Donougher. (Poseidon, $18.95.) Since Paul-Loup Sulitzer has already published novels entitled ''Cash,'' ''Money,'' ''Fortune'' and ''The Green King,'' it seems safe to say that he's not uncomfortable airing his personal preoccupation with wealth. His latest effort, ''Hannah,'' is a rags-to-riches tale chronicling the adventures of a peripatetic Polish girl who rises from her humble origins to become an international cosmetics queen. Having dutifully announced that his book is based on the life of Helena Rubinstein, Mr. Sulitzer then offers the reader an outrageous, wildly imagined yarn that corresponds in only a cursory fashion to any of the details of Mme. Rubinstein's own story. Mr. Sulitzer's Hannah is a headstrong, manipulative creature who will stop at nothing in her globe-trotting pursuit of tycoondom. In a flat-footed prose style translated from the French with occasionally awkward results, the plot doggedly traces Hannah's exploits as she manages to gratify her every desire, from business deals to sexual conquests. What she cannot acquire with finesse, she buys outright. The book is liberally sprinkled with the names of her many illustrious friends, the celebrated writers, artists and musicians of her day. But these figures always remain just outside the narrative. With cold-blooded, calculating business acumen, Hannah succeeds in parlaying her mother's homemade beauty remedies into a worldwide empire. When asked if they really work, she replies, ''I haven't a clue.'' Like Hannah's overhyped cold cream, Mr. Sulitzer's novel panders to an audience more awed by celebrity than quality.

title: Carol B. Willner Marries
description: Carol Beth Willner, a mutual funds research analyst at the Bank of New York in Manhattan, and Blair Robin Zwillman, a partner at an Irvington, N.J., law firm bearing his name, were married last evening at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman officiated. Mrs. Zwillman, a graduate of Oglethorpe University, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Willner of South Orange, N.J. Her husband, who graduated from Lafayette College and cum laude from the New England School of Law, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving J. Zwillman of Maplewood, N.J.

title: Braves Beat Slumping Cubs, 5-3
description: Jeff Blauser had the first two-homer game of his career, and Sergio Valdez earned his first major league victory today as the Atlanta Braves beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-3.

title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes
description: Corruption is a major factor in the drug trade, north and south of the border. It involves United States agents, the Mexican police and private citizens in many different ways.

title: County Takes to the Road With Its Own Portable Truck Scales
description: WHAT has 10 wheels and flies and owes the county more than $2,000 in fines? Answer: an overweight garbage truck.

title: NONFICTION
description: ''ELDER OF THE JEWS'': Jakob Edelstein of Theresienstadt. By Ruth Bondy. (Grove, $26.95.) History rarely forgives those who fall, eyes closed, into its traps. Ruth Bondy makes this point in ''Elder of the Jews'' with the story of the commissioner of the International Red Cross during World War II, a man who emerged from a stroll through the Theresienstadt concentration camp convinced the Jews there had reached safe haven. So one might also expect Ms. Bondy to condemn Jakob Edelstein, the Czechoslovak Zionist who founded Theresienstadt in 1941 and from there unwittingly helped ship other Jews to the gas chambers. But she does not. Ms. Bondy defends men like Edelstein against charges of complicity and naivete, against those who accuse European Jews of abetting their own murderers. She retraces the events that forced Edelstein, a leader of Prague's Jewish community, first to beg favors of Adolf Eichmann, then, with his followers, to erect Theresienstadt - intended as a model Jewish community - out of an old fortress. This is not really a biography; Edelstein is more a unifying principle for a series of digressions - on Czechoslovak nationalism, Czechoslovak Jewry, Eastern European Zionism and international indifference to the Holocaust - than a presence. Given so loose a structure, it is not surprising that Ms. Bondy, who is a writer and teacher in Israel, loses the thread of her argument. We must sift through half the book (competently translated from the Hebrew by Evelyn Abel), through the minutiae of prewar Zionist politics, before arriving at the real story, Theresienstadt itself. As a child, Ms. Bondy survived both that camp and Auschwitz, and the most engrossing parts of her book are her observations of camp life and death; they are obsessively complete and completely brutal.

title: August Conflict At Saratoga
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: Let us credit George Steinbrenner with genius for a particular time in the history of baseball: the 1970's, when free agency began. Steinbrenner's financial generosity and lively competitiveness brought our community the Golden Years of 1976-81.

title: U. of Michigan Curb on Bias Struck Down
description: A University of Michigan policy aimed at harassment based on racial discrimination is unconstitutional, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: DESIGN CAN'T HEAL, BUT IT SHOULDN'T MAKE YOU WORSE
description: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in the middle of Manhattan is one of the great medical and research institutions of the world. It is also one of the least appealing sets of buildings in New York: a complex sprawling over one full city block on the Upper East Side and much of two others, Memorial Sloan-Kettering is an architectural potpourri, a confused mess of buildings whose only common denominator has been their nearly total lack of architectural quality.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: It could have been almost any day this summer because the rain fell in such quantity it was like being sloshed with buckets of water. But actually it was just a short time ago, and Benedicte de Vleeschauwer was at a cocktail party at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park looking elegant and cocktail-partyish, a slender stalk in a turquoise, burgundy and white silk kimono balanced on a pair of black and white patent pumps. That was all very lovely, but the party was ending and the rain wasn't. What to do?

title: Hernandez Is Eager For Full-Time Role
description: Keith Hernandez, the symbol of the Mets' summer of pain, conceded today that this had been a year of trial both for him and his teammates and admitted that he was concerned about his future. But he said, ''I know I can play, and I'd like to finish my career in New York.''

title: Abundant Salmon From Irish Rivers
description: ON the day we arrived in Ireland, there were too many salmon. We had driven from Shannon Airport through the counties of Kerry and Cork to a Georgian mansion called Longueville House on a hillside overlooking the Blackwater, a 70-mile-long river crowded with salmon rushing to their spawning grounds.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: Continue planting, harvesting and ordering bulbs, perennials and shrubs for fall planting, which will go on as long as the good weather holds. Pruning

title: Islands of Evergreen and Granite
description: MENTION the Thousand Islands and most people think of salad dressing, and, yes, there is a connection between that and the most magnificent stretch of freshwater scenery in the world. At the eastern neck of Lake Ontario, where all the freshwater tonnage of Niagara Falls and the five Great Lakes pinches itself into the St. Lawrence, the river is a lordly 10 miles wide and rushes by at a pace of 235,000 cubic feet a second. There are 1,000 miles of waterway between this point and the mouth of the vast estuary where the river slides by the Gaspe Peninsula into the North Atlantic. But it is in the small stretch of water between the city of Kingston, which stands at the confluence of lake and river on the Canadian side, and Brockville, about 50 miles downstream, that the Thousand Islands may be sought. Tradition says there are about 1,800 islands; geographers can map only about 1,000, depending on seasonal water levels.

title: Turning to Teaching As a Second Career
description: LEAD: THE participants in a new program, the Manhattanville Program for Second-Career Teachers, belie the old adage that those who can, do; those who can't, teach.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks. How can we restore the original brick color?

title: New York City Hospitals Still Crowded, but Less So
description: After suffering unmanageably high occupancy rates for two years, New York City's hospitals are becoming less overcrowded, according to State Health Department data.

title: Rose Case Is Itself An Impact Player
description: No young boy stood outside Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati last Thursday and said plaintively, ''Say it ain't so, Pete.''

title: Correction
description: An article about Los Angeles art on July 16 incorrectly characterized the change in location of the Richard Green Gallery. It has moved from SoHo to 24 West 57th Street, not from Los Angeles to New York.

title:
ART;
8 East End Artists Saluted
description: LEAD: THE highlighting of East End artists whose work warrants recognition is the primary motivation behind Guild Hall's annual ''Artists of the Region'' invitational exhibition.

title: Belize
description: To the Editor: In David E. Pitt's article on diving in the Caribbean (Travel, July 9), St. George Cay in Belize was mentioned. Did you know that this was the site of the Sept. 10, 1798, Battle of St. George's Cay, which started Belize as a nation? Also do you know that this battle is being investigated by a team of nautical archelogists from Nov. 21, 1989, to April 4, 1990, under the auspices of the Andover Foundation for Archeological Research, Box 83, Andover, Mass. 01810 (508-470-0840)? The team is looking for certified divers to make contributions to this research. RICHARD S. MACNEI SH Andover, Mass.

title: 'Tailgate Terrorists': Another Opinion
description: In ''Those Tailgate Terrorists'' (Opinion page, July 2), Terence M. Ripmaster spun a tale of terror largely the result of the supposed driving habits of young drivers in sports cars. While I agree with him on the emotional effect that such automotive encounters can produce, I cannot let stand his assertion that these ''terrorists'' are largely in the under-21 set.

title: A Housing Renaissance Sweeps Central Harlem
description: WHEN construction of Towers on the Park, the twin-building condominium complex that hugs the northwest corner of Central Park, was begun in 1986, it was hailed as the start of a housing initiative that would put home ownership within reach of many more Harlem residents.

title: Miso Soup for Breakfast, 'Happu Coats' for Bed
description: With occupancy rates sliding, smart hotel companies are looking beyond the bread-and-butter leisure and business travelers to attract new kinds of guests.

title: New HQ For Jaguar
description: Flush with a surge in demand for its luxury automobiles, Jaguar Cars Inc. is building a new North American headquarters in the 20-acre Ramapo Ridge corporate park in Mahwah, N.J. The $25 million construction project, due to be completed next spring, will consolidate the British motor company's current corporate operations in Leonia and Teaneck, N.J., into one building of 200,000 square feet, more than double the current space. The site is on MacArthur Boulevard near Route 17 about 20 miles northwest of the George Washington Bridge and a mile south of the New York State line.

title: Annie Laidlaw Becomes Bride
description: Christian Pierce Laidlaw, the daughter of Mrs. Winthrop S. Emmet of West Stockbridge, Mass., and Francis W. Laidlaw of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Whitney Floyd Selke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Selke of Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Donald T. Oakes performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox, Mass.

title: COMRADE ENGVER GOES TO MOSCOW
description: BY 9:30 A.M., THE DEPUTIES HAVE ALREADY BEGUN drifting into the semicircular chamber of the Supreme Soviet, half an hour before the bell signals the beginning of the session. The meeting place is contemporary and, by the grandiose norm of this country, intimate. Banks of wooden desks, sleek marble walls adorned by the gilt Soviet insignia, but none of the heroic Lenin statuary that lends an air of secular idolatry to almost every other auditorium I have seen in this country.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q & A: MARV ALBERT;
The Voice of the New York Knicks, Rangers, and...
description: LEAD: MARV ALBERT has been a sportscaster with the National Broadcasting Company since 1977. He has broadcast college and professional basketball and football games and professional boxing matches, and has been the host of the N.B.C. pre-game show, ''Major League Baseball: An Inside Look.''

title: Different Products Need Different Rules
description: In 1982, when futures markets came up with the idea of stock index contracts, the securities industry said it was a silly idea that would not work. Later, when it did work, the industry said it was the work of the devil and ought to be banned. Later, when most academicians lauded these contracts as indispensable risk-management tools, the securities exchanges decided that maybe it was a good idea after all. You would think that this was the end of the story, right? Wrong. The American Stock Exchange and Philadephia Stock Exchange went about creating their own versions of stock index futures, the so-called index participation contracts. So far so good. But then they brashly stated that these were not copycat futures, but their own innovative new securities. How silly can you get?

title: FICTION
description: OPHELIA AND THE GREAT IDEA. By Deborah Levy. (Viking, $16.95.) In the title story of this collection by the young British playwright Deborah Levy, one character glosses the eponymous ''great idea'': ''To invent a time and place of your own.'' To this end, Ms. Levy has discarded the traditional props of plot and unified setting. Instead, she has produced a series of dreamlike miniatures in which ideas, images and characters endlessly collide, pick themselves up and head off in their own directions. That's the good news. The bad news is that Ms. Levy's imagination, and often her prose, trail far behind her formal inventiveness. In story after story, she submerges the reader in a porridge of staleness and cliche: ''Preparing for Life'' is an inept rehash of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, ''Heresies'' trots out all the old inverted sentimentalities about art and madness and in ''The Sinful Twins'' a randy painter takes up with a Spanish girl ''famous for her lustrous coil of black hair, whom he devoured and deflowered with all the passion of his vermilion tube of paint.'' In a few cases, Ms. Levy experiments with more success. ''Flush'' is a well-turned surrealistic cartoon about capitalists and corruption; ''Proletarian Zen'' is a kind of extended and amusing dialect joke. On a more ambitious plane, the title story opposes love and science, atoms and personalities, and derives from these oppositions a genuine sense of mystery, which Ms. Levy calls the ''fundamental emotion that stands at the cradle of true art and true science.'' Here, at least, the author's associative instincts pay off: it's the atypical peak of a rather dismal collection, whose wholes more often add up to distinctly less than the sum of their parts.

title: Heidi J. Sorvino and John McGowan, Lawyers, Are Married in New Jersey
description: Heidi Jan Sorvino and John Spencer McGowan, both 26 years old, were married yesterday by the Rev. Kenneth E. Lasch at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Mendham, N.J. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. Ronald Sorvino of Mendham. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McGowan of East Haven and Branford, Conn.

title: '88 Presidential Candidates Spent $210 Million
description: The 16 candidates who received public money in last year's Presidential primary elections raised $213.8 million and spent $210.7 million, a final tally by the Federal Election Commission shows.

title: Stroessner's Son Is Sought
description: Paraguay asked Brazil on Friday to extradite Gustavo Stroessner, son of the deposed Paraguayan dictator Alfredo Stroessner, to face charges of extortion and other crimes. An official at the Paraguayan Embassy said his country formally petitioned Brazil to turn over the 46-year-old former air force colonel, who is assumed to be living in Brasilia. He flew to exile in Brazil with his father after a coup in February.

title: Victories of the Spirit in St. Louis, 3,500 Athletes Go For the Gold.
description: With the second national senior olympics coming up, Tony B. Quici decided he'd better get rolling. So back in May, the 64-year-old retired Air Force jet mechanic hopped on his bicycle and began pedaling the 1,403 miles from his home in Roswell, N.M., to St. Louis, the site of the games. Twenty days later, he pulled into town, ready to compete, complaining that he would have made better time, but ''it rained all the way from eastern Texas to just east of Joplin, Mo.''

title: Bradley Simmons Weds Susan Stearns
description: Susan Caleb Stearns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy B. Stearns of Augusta, Me., was married yesterday to Bradley Lewis Simmons, a son of Mrs. William S. Cook of Greenwich, Conn., and Naples, Fla., and James L. Simmons of New York and Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by Rev. Angelo Levasseur at the Bowdoin College Chapel in Brunswick, Me.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: The only nerve endings still functioning in George Steinbrenner are the ones attached to his pocketbook. To successfully purge George would require Yankee fans to turn off their TV sets and boycott the season's remaining home games. Considering the Yanks' cellar-dweller standing in the least competitive division race of recent memory, we all would sacrifice little. WARREN SALTZMAN Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. DONALD A. DEIESO;
Looking Back at Environmental Battles
description: LEAD: THE event was billed as if it were destined for television. ''Phil Donahue, move over'' read the announcement that Dr. Donald A. Deieso, an assistant commissioner at the Department of Environmental Protection, would moderate a panel discussion at an annual meeting of the New Jersey Recycling Forum in

title: Leftist Ideology Lives On Only as the Opiate of the Intellectuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Operatic Rarities From a Farsighted Italian Label
description: Even in a record industry newly energized by the CD revolution, the emergence of the Italian Nuova Era label as a potent force, particularly in the field of complete operas, counts as an extraordinary phenomenon. While the company's rapid growth from modest beginnings in 1985 to its substantial catalogue today may stem from having the right manufacturing and distributing facilities at the right time, its success owes just as much to a combination of marketing skill, imagination and dedication.

title: CASPAR MILQUETOAST, THESE ARE YOUR LIVES
description: CHANGING THE PAST By Thomas Berger. 285 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $18.95.

title: U.S. Mediates Students' Claims Of Police Brutality
description: Federal officials have been meeting with city officials, representatives of the N.A.A.C.P. and others to resolve a dispute over whether the police used excessive force against black students after a dance that ended in looting on the city's main street.

title: Huck Finn and Jim Travel the River
description: WHILE the all-American ''everyboy'' image of Huckleberry Finn, who befriends and helps free the runaway slave Jim, may still be popularly held, it is the emergence of the teen-ager's conscience and independence of thought, against the backdrop of a nation's disgrace, that accounts for the ongoing resonance and relevance of Mark Twain's classic.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: And a Lightning Conductor

title: WHEN ALL THE STARS ARE GONE
description: Fred Waitzkin's poignant remarks about his homeless friend convey a sense of hopelessness in dealing with the homeless who suffer from chronic mental illness (''When All the Stars Are Gone,'' July 16). Homelessness, in this case, seems to have followed the onset and gradual worsening of mental illness. The complaint of ''many ideas warring for his attention'' is called ''flight of ideas,'' known to be a sympton of bipolar (manic-depressive) disorder, perhaps curable and most likely treatable.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DORUNTINE. By Ismail Kadare. Translated by Jon Rothschild. (New Amsterdam, $15.95.) It's safe to say that Albania is Europe's most reclusive society. This alone would make the publication of a contemporary Albanian novel an event in the West. But ''Doruntine,'' a magical parable of love, death and the power of familial bonds by Albania's leading literary figure, Ismail Kadare, is more than a curiosity.

title: Maine
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article on Mount Dersert Island by Eleanor Dwight (''A Breezy Summer in Acadia,'' Travel, July 9) and thought I might offer some additional information.

title: Joanne Wise Is a Bride
description: Joanne Amy Wise, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerold Wise of Newton, Mass., and Franconia, N.H., and Carlo Resta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Remo Resta of Rome and San Felice Circeo, Italy, were married yesterday. Justice of the Peace Edward English of Newton performed the ceremony at the Newton home of the bride's parents. Mrs. Resta was until recently the manager of recruiting for Spicer & Oppenheim, an accounting and consulting firm in New York. Her husband is an international banking officer at the New York branch of the San Paolo Bank of Italy.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MURDER KEEPS A SECRET. By Haughton Murphy. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The skyscraper offices, art-stuffed homes, privileged campuses and, last but not least, exclusive restaurants that form the meeting ground for the East Coast Establishment provide the scenes of the crimes - and the tables for the tete-a-tetes that solve them - in Haughton Murphy's detective novels.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
The Rabbi's a Truck-Drivin' Man
description: LEAD: WHEN did I first know that I wanted to drive a truck? The year was 1959, the same year I entered the seminary to prepare for a lifetime career as a rabbi. I was chugging along U.S. 1 on my Vespa, when an 18-wheeler hit me with a blast of exhaust fumes and then forced me off the highway. From that day on,

title:
GARDENING;
Renewed Interest in Insecticidal Soaps
description: LEAD: INSECTICIDAL soaps that promise control of insects without further contamination of the environment by much more toxic chemicals have been receiving much attention lately. Actually, various soaps have been used for insect control since the late 1800's.

title: Watch Out Macy's, Here Comes Norstrom
description: IT IS SUNDAY morning at the Bel Air Presbyterian Church in Los Angeles, and the subject of the Rev. Carolyn A. Crawford's sermon is the Nordstrom department store chain.

title: THE ECSTASY OF GERARD MANLEY HOPKINS
description: It is just 100 years since the death of Gerard Manley Hopkins, S.J., and about 60 years since I first read him. Those were the days when to read ''Ulysses'' was to break the law. Modernism was dangerous, and one of the marks of modernism was strangeness of language. Hopkins, like James Joyce, had bizarre compound words like ''beadbonny'' and ''fallowboot-fellow''; he seemed to be dragging the Germanic roots of English out of freshly dug earth. Yet how could a Jesuit priest, who died in the same year as Robert Browning, be a modernist? By an accident, the fact of his not being published until 1918, he was forced into joining that tide of literary innovation on which T. S. Eliot rode, also Ezra Pound, above all James Joyce. The poet Robert Bridges, the closest friend of Hopkins, had done wrong, I still think, in delaying the publication of Hopkins's small poetic oeuvre until the end of World War I. Young poets died in that war, and they would have been glad to take that thin volume of Hopkins into the trenches. But the world, according to the highly conservative, not to say timid, Bridges, was not ready for the Hopkinsian hand grenade, and it is true that the 1918 edition of his work was slow to sell out.

title: Touring Native Ground
description: ''WHEN are you coming home this summer?'' asked my mother. ''Home'' is Lansing, Mich., and it has not really been my home for nearly 25 (Is that possible?) years. No matter. Most adults approach these journeys home with a mixture of anticipation and boredom - anticipation (at least on my part) of seeing much-loved relatives, boredom at the prospect of being stuck in a place frozen in memory as an incubator of youthful dreams rather than a living community.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: HE was a young lawyer, comfortably ensconced in his family's law firm in Trenton. Yet he yearned to make his imprint in a less contentious way. It was the challenge of book collecting that had often distracted him from his studies in college and law school. So in 1972, Joseph J. Felcone recalled, ''I began to devote all my free time - away from contracts, depositions and wills - to the business of antiquarian bookselling.''

title: More Funds Sought to Aid Rape Victims
description: LEAD: FOR the first time since 1981, when the State Department of Health established a rape-care program, all 21 counties will receive state money for local rape crisis centers in the next fiscal year. But administrators for such centers say that calls to rape-care hot lines are increasing each year and that financing continues to fall short of needs.

title: In Memoriam
description: The Times obituary announcing the death of John Hirsch says Hirsch was best known as artistic director of Canada's Stratford Festival. At least for the nonprofit professional theater community in the United States, the real story is quite different.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I lied because I needed to support myself. I was a young girl and there was no one to support me.'' Lisa Ann Jones, former trading assistant, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Robyn B. Weiner Marries
description: Robyn B. Weiner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Weiner of Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric S. Finger, a son of Anita Finger of Lido Beach, L.I., and the late William Finger. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I. The 23-year-old bride, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a creative merchandising coordinator in New York for the Amcena Corporation, a retail concern. Mr. Finger, 24, who graduated from the University of Marlyand, is a third-year student at the Queens College Law School.

title: About Cars; Concept for Headlights That Don't Blind
description: My friend Marty is something of an inventor. He has come up with a lock that makes casement windows burglar proof, and he is working on a pop-up barrier to keep bags and packages from flying off the passenger seat of his car.

title: Commercial Property: Nonprofit Groups; Vacancies Create Wide Options for Manhattan Space
description: NONPROFIT groups that in the mid 1980's were overwhelmed by the price of Manhattan office space are finding relative bargains today as landlords struggle to fill vacant floors.

title: Now, Call Room Service for a Domino's Pizza
description: It's late. You're hungry. You pick up the telephone, dial room service, and order - a Domino's pizza?

title: Judging 'Post-History,' The Theory to End All Theories
description: FIRST came postmodernism, which stems from the idea that there can no longer be anything newer in the arts than what has already been created. Now a State Department official, Francis Fukuyama, has caused a stir among intellectuals with his thesis that the period of ''post-history'' has arrived. With the decline of fascism and Communism, he argues, Western liberal democracy has triumphed and mankind has reached its highest wisdom. History has come to an end.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Nicaraguan contra presence in Florida misidentified a rebel leader who planned to return to Nicaragua. He is Roberto Ferrey, not Azucena Ferrey.

title: Tyson Too Tough
description: Being invincible may have its strong points, but Mike Tyson seems to be too good for his own good, not to mention Don King's pocketbook.

title: Lauren M. Felsen Weds D. M. Klein
description: Lauren Michele Felsen and David Martin Klein, graduates of Ithaca College, were married last evening at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens, by Rabbi David I. Franzel. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Morry Krantz of Randolph, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Klein of Secaucus, N.J.

title: Father and Son Show Opens A New Westport Gallery
description: THREE months ago, Westport's old library building, at 7 Post Road East, acquired violet doors and a new lease on life as the Old Library Antiques and Art Center. The paint work continues to blare, as does ''Legacy: A Father and Son,'' the exhibition inaugurating the center's art gallery, known as L'Atelier.

title: With Poland's Change, Its Balance of Power Is Next to Impossible
description: TADEUSZ MAZOWIECKI'S first visit to the 19th-century Prime Minister's palace was like a foray into enemy territory.

title: Newport
description: To the Editor: Margaret Lamb, in her story on Newport, R.I. (''The Gracious Airs of Newport,'' Travel, July 30), told about the Old Colony and Newport Railway ride, which shows off much of the western part of the island and Narragansett Bay very well.

title: Fashion; The Three Who Are Key: Couture's Future
description: BY THE SEVENTH NUMBER, THE DIRECTION WAS CLEAR.

title: Why Laughter Is Often a Dancer's Partner
description: Dancers are often called frivolous. Over the centuries, stern moralists have deplored them for being so. Yet, the seeming lack of serious intent of dancers may be a sign of a virtue, rather than a vice.

title: Career-Counseling Seminars Focus on Building Confidence
description: ''NOTHING will ever be attempted if all possible objections must be first overcome.'' This aphorism, attributed to Samuel Johnson, could make someone's day. In fact, it is the kind of encouragement often given in a career-counseling service that is provided free of charge through the Westchester Library System.

title: The Bailout's Ripple Effect
description: Washington's savings-and- loan bailout plan is intended to restore that industry to health. But in the process, the market for securities that are backed by home mortgages may suffer some ill effects of its own. The dramatic consolidation of savings institutions is causing a wave of selling of those securities. This kind of activity, mortgage experts say, could persist for two years, though they are divided about the extent to which such selling could drive down the prices of the securities, or even throw the market into a slump.

title: Steering Your Way to a Car Vacation in the Soviet Union
description: Even with the new openness, the Soviet Union is not the sort of place where you can jump in a car and drive off into the sunset. You need to plan a car trip well ahead of time, and to stick to the itinerary you have agreed to. All this is worth a trip with no parking meters or toll booths, some beautiful countryside, intriguing places and a sense of unmapped adventure.

title: Perspectives: Residential Design; Two-Family Houses a Success in Queens
description: A STRONG case is being made by the Bluestone Organization in the Jamaica section of Queens for the two-family semi-attached house as an ideal for-sale housing product for New York City's moderate- to middle-income home buyers.

title: From the Burmese, Lustrous Lacquerware
description: PEOPLE usually go to Pagan just to admire and photograph the dead city's glorious temples and pagodas. Said to number as many as 5,000, they date from the 11th to the 13th centuries. Pagan, stretched out across the plain on the east bank of the Irrawaddy River, 350 miles north of Yangon, formerly Rangoon, is one of the most spectacular archeological sites in the world.

title: Summit of Sorts on Global Warming
description: Top Soviet and American scientists, environmentalists, policymakers, industry leaders and artists today urged President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to form an ''environmental security alliance'' to reverse what they fear could be a catastrophic warming of the planet.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NEW CANAAN;
Where Wildlife Feels The Call of the Suburb
description: LEAD: GETTING back to nature after a grueling day at the office is what makes life in New Canaan worthwhile for many residents. With its 20,000 inhabitants spread over 22 square miles and its success in avoiding the commercialism that has spread through other Fairfield County towns, New Canaan has retained a comfortable rural atmosphere.

title: 3 Lead World Series Of Golf
description: Payne Stewart, who won the P.G.A. championship two weeks ago, overcame a bogey followed by a double bogey by getting two back-nine birdies and tieing Paul Azinger and David Frost of South Africa for the lead going into Sunday's final round of the N.E.C. World Series of Golf. Playing one of the most difficult courses on the PGA Tour, the Firestone Country Club's 7,136-yard, par-70 south course, Stewart shot two-under-par 68 today despite those mishaps at seven and eight to get into the shared lead at 207.

title: BROADER VIOLENCE STRIKES SRI LANKA
description: With bombs, grenades and gunfire, extremist members of the ethnic Sinhalese majority have stepped up an anti-Government campaign, attacking military patrols and vehicles and prompting countermeasures by the army.

title: In an Inhospitable French Town, Muslims Struggle to Rebuild Their Mosque
description: As his long white prayer robe hung limply in the late summer heat, Mohammed Mezgualdi stepped carefully over the chunks of concrete, broken timbers and shattered roof tiles. ''Here was where I used to teach the children,'' the Muslim cleric said, pointing to a room that looked as if it had been ravaged by war.

title: DANCING INTO THE DREAM
description: THE MAMBO KINGS PLAY SONGS OF LOVE By Oscar Hijuelos. 407 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Back to the Stores and Back to School
description: IT has already started; the pressure is on. The question being asked now on an hourly basis is, ''When are we going school-clothes shopping, Mom?''

title: Promises and Candlelight
description: ON Long Island, a $35 candlelit dinner for two with live music, dancing, four courses, a glass of wine and coffee served at a cloth and flower-bedecked table sounds like dream dust.

title: CAMERA
description: It defies logical explanation, but there's something irresistible about pictures that are long and skinny. They're commonly called panoramas, since they include a wide sweep of scenery. Photographers have been making them almost from the moment that photography entered the world 150 years ago.

title: Vick Aims to Make an Impact By GERALD ESKENAZI
description: Like so much of the Jets' team around him, Roger Vick is an unknown quantity with the season two weekends away.

title: Barbara K. Pond Weds Tylor Field 3d
description: At the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I., Barbara Kirkland Pond was married yesterday to Tylor Field 3d. The Rev. Beverly Edwards, an United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest.

title: A Glut of Rooms Spurs a Battle for Guests
description: It may not be war yet, but the battle lines have been drawn in the hotel business.

title: Pope Sees Nazism and Marxism as False Religions
description: Pope John Paul II today marked the 50th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II by condemning Nazism and Marxism as ''substitute religions'' and hailing democratic change in his native Poland.

title: Behind the Wheel in the Soviet Union
description: TRAVELERS driving through the Soviet Union can easily distinguish foreign tourists' cars from those of Soviet citizens. The latter don't have windshield wipers. The former do - but not for long.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: EGREMONT, MASS.;
Accord Reached On Resort Plan
description: LEAD: THE rural Town of Egremont has negotiated a settlement that is expected to let a Boston developer build a vacation-home resort, but with extensive land-use guidelines and other restrictions.

title: Polish Prime Minister Meets With Head of Soviet K.G.B.
description: The head of the Soviet K.G.B. met with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki today and said the new Polish leader was ''a solid man'' who will succeed in solving the nation's problems.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AUTO ELEGANCE

title: Eccentric Roots, Humorous Touches
description: JULIA HEALY comes well recommended by John Perreault, who, formerly director of Snug Harbor's Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, remains the eminence grise of the Staten Island scene. Indeed, in his introduction to the artist's show at the Museum of the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, he frankly applauds her painting.

title: CONNECTICUT Q & A: Dr. Edward F. Zigler; 'We Need a Good Child-Care Program'
description: INADEQUATE child-care and parental leave programs coupled with major changes in the American life style are pushing the family to the breaking point, according to Edward F. Zigler, Sterling Professor of Psychology at Yale and the director of the Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy, also at Yale.

title: COACH ON THE LINE
description: PERSONAL FOULS By Peter Golenbock. Illustrated. 311 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $18.95.

title:
FOCUS: Growth Control;
Florida Law Begins to Influence Development
description: LEAD: A LONGSTANDING joke in Florida has it that the state bird is the construction crane. But the bird appears to be flying somewhat lower as the state's four-year-old growth-management law starts to influence development.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CHARLES H. TIBBITS PARK;
In White Plains, a Microcosm In a Thin Green Line
description: LEAD: THREE hundred years ago it was the Town Commons, a meeting place for all manner of people from the fledgling village that is now the city of White Plains. Today the Charles H. Tibbits Park on North Broadway is still a gathering spot, an eight-block-long verdant stretch in the middle of a street that is both strolling boulevard and busy corporate thoroughfare, a route for numerous older people who chat on their way to and from the market and for young professionals scurrying off to pressure-cooker jobs.

title: Getting on Top From Down Under
description: The recent success of ''Dead Poets Society,'' by the Australian director Peter Weir, brings to mind the trove of talent that has come out of that part of the world - and is available on cassette.

title: NONFICTION
description: During the summer of 1986, Joe Friedman, an architectural historian and consultant, was asked by James Ivory and Ismail Merchant to find Edwardian period locations, dating from around the turn of the century, for the film adaptation of E. M. Forster's novel ''Maurice.'' INSIDE LONDON: Discovering London's Period Interiors (Prentice-Hall, $29.95) is one result of his search. It is a collection of 125 beautiful, very detailed photographs by Peter Aprahamian of some astounding interiors from different periods, with accompanying text by Mr. Friedman relating historical anecdotes and information about architecture and design. We are taken behind closed doors to buildings that are well known - Harrod's Meat Hall, a splendid example of Edwardian design; the geometric and oval Art Deco artistry of Claridge's Mayfair Hotel - and many that are unknown - for example, the old operating theater in the attic of St. Thomas's Hospital, Southwark, the oldest surviving interior of its kind. We enter shops, restaurants, theaters, town houses, pubs, banks, embassies, Government buildings. Some of the interiors are by such well-known designers and artists as Christopher Wren and Robert Adam, others by unrecorded craftsmen. The book includes a useful gazetteer explaining how to reach the buildings and giving historic information and hours of business. ''Inside London'' is more than a coffeetable addition; it is an earnest plea to halt the wrecker's ball and to preserve the heritage of London's architectural treasures.

title: NEUHARTH STILL A POWER
description: On March 22, his 65th birthday, Allen H. Neuharth resigned from the board and bid farewell to the Gannett Company. Although his retirement as chairman of the company did not take effect for a week, this was his moment of benediction.

title: Gout Drug May Augment AZT, Study Says
description: The anti-AIDS drug AZT apparently stays in the body longer when combined with a drug commonly used to treat gout, researchers say.

title: On Stage, The British Field A New Lineup
description: Tim Albery, Nicholas Hytner and Richard Jones may not be theatrical names Americans know right now, but at the rate their directing careers are progressing in England, familiarity cannot be far away.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HOME FOR THE SUMMER. By Georgina Kleege. (Post-Apollo Press, 35 Marie St., Sausalito, Calif. 94965; Paper, $9.95.) Few novels are more disappointing than those that promise much and deliver little. Georgina Kleege's first work of fiction has almost the opposite problem; the novella begins in melodrama, slowly redeems itself with intriguing portrayals and dialogue, and ends just when Ms.

title: ESCAPE FROM THE PERFECT FATHER
description: MR. FIELD'S DAUGHTER By Richard Bausch. 347 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Israeli Publishers Are Balking at 'Mein Kampf'
description: Dan Yaron, a 70-year-old Israeli whose parents died in Nazi concentration camps, has translated Hitler's ''Mein Kampf'' into Hebrew for Israeli youth. But in so doing he has touched feelings that run so deep here that he cannot find anyone who is willing to publish it.

title: New Head of V.F.W. Elected
description: Delegates to the Veterans of Foreign Wars 90th annual convention elected Walter Hogan on Friday as their commander-in-chief. Mr. Hogan, a Greenfield, Wis., resident who served in the Korean War as an Army infantry squad leader, replaced Larry W. Rivers as head of the 2.1 million-member veterans' organization. He vowed to continue V.F.W. efforts to get better medical care for America's 27 million veterans.

title: The Sound of the Symphony Is Fading From the Airwaves
description: When the New York Philharmonic was first broadcast live over radio station WJZ, Newark, in 1922, it was heralded as an event of enormous significance. An article in Popular Radio (October 1922) reported: ''For the first time in history the music of one of the greatest of orchestras, the New York Philharmonic, of 85 pieces, was transmitted by special wire from the City College Stadium in New York to a distant broadcasting station and sent out by radio to probably the biggest number of auditors that have ever listened in on a musical program.''

title: Kenya's Government Fights for Control In a War That Endangers Tourism
description: THE adventurous, the rich and the hardy have long come to Kenya for safaris, dreaming of the 1930's grand tradition of the Prince of Wales and his favorite white hunter, Bror Blixen. More recently, movies like ''Out of Africa'' and ''White Mischief'' helped Kenya's standing as an exotic destination that was also accessible.

title: Suspect Admits Shooting Newton, Police Say
description: The police said late Friday that an admitted drug dealer had acknowledged killing Huey P. Newton, co-founder of the Black Panther Party.

title: Why Training Is Worth the Cost
description: Too few people gave much thought to training when personal computers arrived in offices. ''Here it is,'' a technician said, patting the contraption that replaced the typewriter. ''Call if you need help. Good luck.'' But today no company can afford to be casual about training, for computers and software are tools used for competitive advantage.

title: Political Violence Sweeping Once-Quiet Honduras
description: Salomon Vallecilo, a 34-year-old factory worker and labor leader, left his house in a working-class neighborhood here on July 4 to take a 6 A.M. bus to work. He passed a nightclub on his left and, on his right, an assassin, who was reading a newspaper in the shade of a small almond tree.

title: Tabletop Stereo Sets Make the Grade on Campus
description: Whether it serves as an aid to education is debatable. But for the class of '93, now heading for the campus, a stereo system counts among the required scholarly paraphernalia, like a library card or a tennis racquet.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: APPLE-PICKING

title: 25-Year Land Plan
description: WITH more than $50 million in public and private funds committed thus far, city planners in this Michigan city have outlined a 25-year development plan for land adjacent to the downtown business district along the Saginaw River near its mouth on Lake Huron.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Stamford's Commercial Outlook Brightens
description: AMBITIOUS plans for expanding the Town Center mall and building a new Lord & Taylor mall outside the central business district, plus moderating office vacancies and a major refinancing of the city's oldest office tower, are lifting the clouds that have hung over Stamford's commercial real estate for more than a year.

title: DATA BANK: Aug. 27, 1989
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Utility Does Pay Taxes to Village
description: Morris Seldin's letter ''Cheap Power is Misleading'' (Aug. 6) is itself misleading and misinformed. His statements that ''publicly owned utility plants pay no taxes'' and that the taxes on the residents of Rockville Centre ''have to be increased to make up for the loss'' are simply wrong.

title: Slowing the Rat Race to a Saunter
description: Darrell Blow hooked a four-inch-long crayfish with a worm he had dug from the banks of the pond. In Central Park.

title: Elizabeth B. Emmons and T. M. Dunn, Lawyers, Are Wed in Massachusetts
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass., Elizabeth Brooks Emmons, a daughter of Diane Neal Emmons of Manchester, Mass., and Robert Wales Emmons Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to Terrence Michael Dunn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Dunn of Mountain Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Cynthia Briggs Kittredge performed the ceremony.

title: CHESS
description: There is no problem playing against a man who has just published a book on an opening. If the work is at all honest, you know where you have him. Paired with him, you obviously don't choose to confront the variations where you agree that his side stands better, but only those where you have uncovered a loophole, a sincere error that he does not know exists.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: Of course not. We Brooklyn Dodger fans haven't had this much fun since the '55 World Series. We thoroughly enjoy watching those proud Yankee followers squirming and sweating over their team's misadventures. WILLIAM J. ASH Westhampton, L.I.

title: MY WHITE WHALE, OR THE GREAT NEWSPAPER NOVEL
description: I started collecting journalism novels six years ago, just for fun at first, or maybe because I was flattered that fiction writers would find my chosen career so alluring, so full of possibilities. But what had begun as little more than a vague attraction soon took hold of me, tightened its grip and turned this meandering, benign pursuit into an obsession. I wanted something from these books, although for a long time I could not have told you just what it was. I began combing bookstores for them, reading dozens of book reviews each week, looking for tip-offs that a journalist might be playing a new fictional role. I scanned every publisher's catalogue I could get my hands on. Fellow journalists, book dealers, friends and relatives learned to keep their eyes open and report their findings to me.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Dauber
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard G. Dauber of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Dauber, to Michael Louis Lewittes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Lewittes of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A January wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: SUSSEX AIR SHOW

title: Review/Dance; Eclectic Bill of 'Danzas de la Tierra'
description: ''Danzas de la Tierra,'' presented on Friday at the McGinn/Cazale Theater, was a thoroughly enjoyable evening of flamenco, tap and Near Eastern dance, scheduled, sadly, for only one performance. It would be nice to see it as a fixture in this ideally small theater, particularly during the summer doldrums. For this was a show whose verve, intimacy and lack of pretension were reminiscent of the original ''Tango Argentino'' at City Center.

title: The Summer Book Helps Us Realize Summer's Promise
description: NOW is the time for the summer lament. Well, time nor tide, they say, waits for no man, and while this is undoubtedly true generally, it is especially true of summers present. Before you can say Houdini, you find yourself saying, Wow, it's gone again. The great summer disappearing act. Where did it go? Well, the difficult thing with summer is getting a hand on it while it's still around. And this is where I've had an odd revelation. This is where the Summer Book comes in handy, because it's the Summer Book that holds within it the possibility for acute season perception.

title: 500-Year-Old Pine Is Felled
description: A tree nine feet in diameter, believed to be the world's tallest Ponderosa pine, has been cut down in a central Idaho forest, producing a 112-foot log. The pine, which died three years ago, was more than 500 years old. Sections of the trunk, with historical dates marked on its growth rings, will go to parks in Boise, Donnelly and Pocatello, Idaho, and a botanical garden in Dortmund, West Germany.

title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE
description: LEAD: THE COCAINE KIDS The Inside Story of a Teenage Drug Ring. By Terry Williams. 140 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $16.95. ADDICTED Kids Talking About Drugs in Their Own Words. By Joel Engel. 174 pp. New York: A Tom Doherty Associates Book/Tor. $15.95.

title: The New Priorities in the Solar System
description: WHEN they ponder their good fortune to be living and working here and now, planetary scientists sometimes speak of this as the golden age in the exploration of the solar system. Planets once no more than points of light have finally been visited by spacecraft and photographed in striking detail. For the first time, they have emerged as distinct and varied worlds.

title: We Need an International Court on Terrorism; Symptom and Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking: Rent Rises; New Rules On Way for Stabilized
description: TENANTS who live in the 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City are accustomed to rent increases every year or two. This year will be no exception, but there are some changes in place or in prospect.

title: Catherine Sandler Becomes a Bride
description: Catherine McFarland Sandler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sadler of Columbia, S.C., and Capt. Thomas Cornelius McFadden Jr., U.S.A.F., Medical Corps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McFadden of Basking Ridge, N.J., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Trinity Cathedral in Columbia.
