The Rev. Lloyd Edwards, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Hilary O'Leary, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: In a Corner of Italy, A Rare, Lonely Tomb
description: ITALY is a country of arches. Walking through nearly any Italian city or town, the eye glides across the scenery not in straight lines but in gentle arcs, weaving patterns of dramatic shadows in the abundant sunlight and slowing the eye down to Italy's leisurely pace.

title: In East, A Clean Outlook
description: Darnell Dickerson, the dandy quarterback, has been declared academically ineligible to play this season for Pitt, a signal that in the East academic missions retain some priority in major-college football.

title: A 'Mickey Mouse' Class - For Real
description: ''Please turn to page 14,'' announced the teacher, a man in a blue suit, waving an opened textbook in his hand. ''Take a look at our formula for pixie dust.''

title: The Carmelization of the Hamptons
description: ONCE, years ago, I was on a bus tour out of San Francisco that stopped for a halfhour in Carmel. In that brief exposure to the resort's main shopping street, I was bombarded with beauty: Venetian glass, Scottish cashmere, Chinese jade, French porcelain . . . everything in unrelentingly exquisite taste.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 6 about aquaculture misstated production projections for Abalone Unlimited Inc. It expects to produce a million pounds of abalone in three to four years. The article also misidentified the company's chairman; he is Michael Gault.

title: Yankees' Chances Slip By
description: There was no sound in the clubhouse, no movement, no sign of life. The players lost the game, then lost any sense that they still have time. Even with five weeks left, the Yankees are finished.

title: INQUIRY ON FRANK IS LIKELY IN HOUSE
description: Two leading Democratic strategists said today that members of Representative Barney Frank's own party are likely to ask for a formal House investigation in the aftermath of his admission of an 18-month association with a male prostitute.

title: Expansion Of Medicare Is Painful For Congress
description: THE Congressional recess has brought the nation's lawmakers scant relief from the anger of older Americans who resent being taxed for new Medicare benefits intended to protect them against catastrophic medical expenses.

title: We Need an International Court on Terrorism; U.S. and Israel Agree
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraternity, Ending Pledge System, Closes Two Chapters
description: A national fraternity, Zeta Beta Tau, has closed two of its chapters, including one at the Columbus campus of Ohio State University, for rules violations that include drinking, drug abuse, physical hazing and maintaining unsafe facilities.

title: Threats Terrorize Colombia's Courts
description: Pausing between signing documents in his chambers here, Judge Alvaro Medina Moreno today recalled a recent telephone call to his unlisted home number.

title: Court Rebuff
description: When Adella Gray was dismissed as the academic adviser to the University of Arkansas football team shortly after Ken Hatfield took over as coach in 1985, Gray, who had held the position for three years, was convinced she was the victim of sex discrimination.

title: De Klerk Warns Protesters to Avoid Wide Violence
description: South Africa's Acting President, F. W. de Klerk, declared today that the Government would not allow the current wave of protests to widen into the kind of violence that shook the nation from 1984 to 1986.

title: Quilts to Carpets, Needlework That Stretches the Imagination
description: LEAD: CONTEMPORARY needle expressions, from small beadworks to quilts and large carpets, are changing the look of the three-story Rotunda Gallery at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk, a 50-room Victorian house that is a national historic landmark more commonly the venue of the artifacts of ages past.

title: Black Americans Hold a TV Mirror Up to Their Life
description: ''Black in White America,'' the hourlong ABC News documentary on Tuesday night at 10, opens with a sequence that shows young black children taking part in a study in their preschool in Atlanta. The youngsters are shown pictures of identically dressed children, one white, one black, and asked to pick the pretty one, the ugly one, the dirty one, the stupid one.

title: Project Helps China Modernize Eye Surgery
description: Project Orbis, a program that uses an airplane equipped as a teaching hospital to train eye surgeons in developing countries, has reached an agreement with China to establish a permanent relationship.

title: A Search for the Best-Laid Schemes
description: AS Elizabeth Mills Brown searches through the cities and towns of Connecticut, she knows just what she wants. ''I want everything of distinction,'' she says. Mrs. Brown's task is to find the state's best architecture.

title: A Need to Avoid Irrational Responses to Irrational Acts
description: TWO police sharpshooters knelt on nearby rooftops, rifles ready to protect David R. Peterson from the angry crowd that waited for him outside the courthouse where he was arraigned on a murder charge Aug. 1. The crowd screamed obscenities at Mr. Peterson, and, as the police drove him away, the crowd ran after the car, shouting: ''Lynch him!''

title: Faithful Helpmates In a Storm
description: THE lights flicker ominously. My electric typewriter sputters and recovers. Outside the wind blows. Fallen branches thump on the roof. I must prepare quickly for another power failure, run water in the tub before the pump ceases, fill bottles with drinking water, find emergency candles, holders, matches.

title: Student Is Wed To Miss McGrath
description: The Church of Christ at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Catherine Hale McGrath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gregory McGrath of Rochester, to William Lee Kissick Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kissick of Philadelphia. The Rev. Margot Pickett, an associate pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Secrets of an Unsuccessful Dieter
description: LEAD: I AM writing this column with one hand - and eating brownies and Haagen-Dazs chocolate-chocolate chip with the other. Later, I'll have a pizza. Perhaps fried onions, steak Diane, Rocky Road on pecan pie. Why not? Don't I worry about the calories? Do convicts on Death Row ordering their last meal say, '

title: Lendl Edges Chesnokov
description: It would be unfair to say Ivan Lendl was toying with Andrei Chesnokov in the first semifinal match here today at the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup. But every time his Soviet opponent drew close to him today, Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, shut the door.

title: 5,000 March to Protest Court Action on Rights
description: ''Give unto this day a miracle that will renew our strength,'' Dr. Fred C. Lofton, president of the Progressive National Baptist Convention, said in prayer today on the steps of the United States Supreme Court.

title:
INVESTING;
Jostens Broadens Its Reach
description: LEAD: In recent years the number of high school students has declined. But Jostens Inc., a manufacturer of products like yearbooks and class rings for college and high school students, has not stumbled. The company's sales rose 21 percent, to $696 million, in the fiscal year ended in June over the year before.

title: The Wrong Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Alison J. Bailes Becomes a Bride
description: Alison Jane Bailes and Christopher Bowditch Huntington were married yesterday in St. James, L.I., at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother Mrs. Prescott Huntington. The Rev. Francis C. Huntington, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Closing at the Open
description: It was at the United States Open in 1971 that Chris Evert burst onto the tennis scene, reaching the semifinals as a 16-year-old, and it will be after this year's Open that she will close out serious competition as a 34-year-old. ''No more 'maybes,' '' Ms. Evert wrote in Sports Illustrated. She has won more matches and more tournaments than any other player, male or female, including the United States Open six times, Wimbledon three times, the Australian Open twice and the French Open a record seven times. She will still represent the United States in the Federation Cup in Tokyo in October and will make a cameo appearance at a tournament in Boca Raton, Fla., where she lives. ''But as for Chris Evert, serious competitor,'' she wrote, ''yes, I guess I really am outta here.''

title: Elizabeth Pruett Weds J. K. Herbert 3d
description: Mary Elizabeth Pruett, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Pruett of Beverly Farms, Mass., was married yesterday to John K. Herbert 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Jr. of Milton, Mass. The Rev. James Harrington performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass.

title: Summer Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: Jubilee Gains Audiences but Loses Aid
description: JUST as it's beginning to take off, the New Jersey Theater Jubilee may be coming to a halt.

title: A Newport That Never Dies
description: Social gallantry still rules in Newport, R.I. When the Preservation Society realized that its fund-raising dinner and ball would conflict with a debutante party, the society gave its party at the Breakers on Friday, Aug. 18, instead of that Saturday. The opulent rooms were filled with trees of purple petunias and other flowers from the Breakers greenhouse. The 72-room mansion, completed in 1894, was built by Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr. His great-granddaughter, Countess Sylvia Szapary, who lives on the top floor, received guests with the chairwomen, Diana Slocum and Bonnie Matheson.

title: Laura Pease Is Married
description: Laura Pease, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Pease of Kent Island, Md., and Adam Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Weiss of Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Bear Cafe in Woodstock, N.Y. The Rev. Shara Kerr officiated at the nondenominational service. Mrs. Weiss, who is 34 years old, is the director of 220 East, a private party concern in Manhattan. Mr. Weiss, 29, is a vice president and the director of sales for Bridgewaters, a banquet concern at the South Street Seaport.

title: Administration Moves to Curb Prison Furloughs
description: The Bush Administration, which came into office with prison furloughs as one of the new President's major emotional campaign issues, is now moving to restrict furloughs in the Federal prison system.

title: Defining the 80's? No Easy Task
description: When the all-day succession of New Year's Day bowl games ends the 121st season of college football and begins another decade, how will the last 10 years be defined?

title: U.S. Move on Firefighter Test Criticized
description: AN attempt by the United States Justice Department to invalidate hiring lists for firefighters in 12 New Jersey municipalities has drawn criticism from fire officials. The officials say the move will intensify an already critical manpower shortage in some of the state's larger cities.

title: When a Member of the Tour Takes Ill
description: LAURANCE AND JOAN WINKLER of Greenville, S.C., signed up with two old friends from New Jersey for a three-week tour of China early this spring. The tour, organized by Pacific Delight, left New York on April 18 on Northwest Airlines and returned May 7, before the political troubles in China. But the tour group had its own troubles, health troubles, which underline considerations for travelers joining a tour. An assessment of the experience also provides some guidelines.

title: TOTALING UP THE THRIFT BAILOUT PLAN
description: Less than two weeks after President Bush signed the monumental bailout bill for the savings and loan industry, Federal regulators are suggesting that the money provided by taxpayers and the industry might not be enough.

title: Question of the Week; SHOULD STEINBRENNER SELL THE YANKS?
description: A resounding yes! But before he has a chance to resign as principal owner of the Yankees, I would like to tender my resignation as a Yankee fan. CHRIS LOSCALZO Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Colombia Welcomes Aid; Long Struggle Seen
description: Colombian leaders today welcomed a $65 million anti-narcotics aid package from the United States but predicted that it would be the opening volley in a long, bloody battle.

title: Christopher French, A.P. Editor, Dies at 49
description: Christopher W. French, a journalist and administrator with The Associated Press for 23 years, has died at the age of 49.

title: Design; Furniture That Provokes Fantasy
description: SOME OF IT FEATURES KISSING BIRDS, SOME OF IT DANCING BEARS. There are also undulating dragons and sea horses languishing beside giant shells. At once whimsical and bizarre, humorous and macabre, ''fantasy furniture'' is the stuff of wild dreams and fertile imaginations. ''It's seductive and magical,'' says Bruce M. Newman, president of Newel Art Galleries in Manhattan.

title: State's Role in Aiding Minority Firms
description: The article ''New Efforts Made to Help Minority Firms'' (July 23) notes, ''In 1988, New Jersey state agencies set aside 25 percent of all their contracts, some $30.3 million worth of business, for small, minority- or female-owned companies.''

title: Ms. Rosenberg Becomes Bride
description: Lauren Monica Rosenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerry M. Rosenberg of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Robert Marsh Hepner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hepner of Sharon, Conn., were married last evening. The outdoor ceremony in the foothills of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains in Santa Fe, N.M., was performed by Rabbi Lynn Gottlieb.

title: Correction
description: A chart last week with the Investing column erroneously included stock prices for the Network General Corporation in 1988 and January 1989. The stock did not trade publicly before February 3, 1989.

title: Obscure No More: Espinoza Making Good Contact for Yanks
description: The irony would probably be too much for Willie Randolph to tolerate. In his 13 seasons with the Yankees, Randolph played second base next to 31 different players at shortstop, from Aguayo and Alomar to Zeber and Zuvella. Bucky Dent served the longest of the horde (nearly six seasons), but after he departed in August 1982, 18 of those 31 players served as Randolph's double-play partners.

title: Lisa Gould Weds Wendel Wurzweiler
description: Lisa Higginson Gould and Wendel Wolfe Wurzweiler were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Denver. Canon Richard Shackelford performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
There's More to Bulbs Than Meets the Average Eye
description: LEAD: The efforts of individuals who have made gardeners aware of the endangered state of some species bulbs can certainly be applauded. But it is unfortunate that the idea has come across that all or most of the species, or wild, bulbs are endangered and should be avoided or boycotted by gardeners.

title: In Cambodia, an Ex-Leader Calls for End of Khmer Rouge
description: A respected former Prime Minister of Cambodia, In Tam, who has returned here often from the United States to advise the Government, says he cannot understand why, in his view, the world demands a share of power for the Khmer Rouge, under whose rule more than a million Cambodians died.

title: Making Nice to Your Stockbroker
description: The current market rally may prompt more investors to call their stockbrokers for advice. Unfortunately, most brokers pay serious attention to only a handful of clients, and chances are you are not one of them - even if you have $50,000 or more in securities. Further, if you don't know how to work with a broker, even paying a steady flow of commissions won't necessarily win the broker's constant attention.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: I recognize that the July 16 article on the Grampian area of Scotland, ''Castle Country Along the River Dee,'' didn't pretend to be comprehensive, but for readers who intend to use it as a guide for touring, may I put in a good word for Crathes Castle? Crathes is a short drive east of Banchory Lodge Hotel. It is of the same style and period as the more famous Craigievar Castle, but alterations have been made so that Crathes is slightly less pristine architecturally (it gets two stars in the Michelin green guide against Craigievar's three).

title: In Pop, Whose Song Is It, Anyway?
description: The title came from the Troggs, and the guitar riff was snatched from a Van Halen record, but the rapper Tone-Loc gets credit for a rock milestone. His first hit, ''Wild Thing,'' is the second-best-selling single in the history of popular music, after the charity record ''We Are the World.'' With two million singles sold, as well as five million copies of his debut album, Tone-Loc has found that familiarity pays.

title: BRIDGE
description: The Soviet Union has long been the last frontier of bridge, where the game has few players and virtually no organization. Glasnost has helped make 1989 a turning-point with a series of events both actual and potential.

title: Vera Trojan Wed To Mark P. Carthy
description: Vera Maria Trojan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myroslaw Trojan of Watertown, Conn., and Mark Patrick Carthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Carthy of Dublin, were married yesterday at St. Michael's Ukrainian Catholic Church in New Haven, Conn. The Rev. Roman Golemba performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dermot Carthy, a cousin of the bridegroom.

title: End of Women's Office Becomes Primary Issue
description: LEAD: AMONG the telephone calls received recently by the Suffolk County Office for Women was an inquiry from a woman who wanted a ring appraised.

title: LOOKING FOR LOVE IN THOSE NEW YORK PLACES
description: A BAD MAN IS EASY TO FIND By M. J. Verlaine. 240 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

title: Reggae and Rock Inspire Music Group
description: LEAD: IN the Hamptons, where big-name blues acts and local bands that play other people's music dominate the scene, Terry Winchell and her new group offer something else: original music from many sources.

title: Dr. Chantal Stern, Neuropsychologist, Married to Dr. Michael E. Hasselmo
description: Dr. Chantal E. Stern, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter H. Stern of Rye, N.Y., and Dr. Michael Erik Hasselmo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Nils Hasselmo of St. Paul, were married yesterday at St. John's Lutheran Church in Mamaroneck, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Marvin Henk, assisted by the Rev. Robert Nordlander, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort
description: After resisting such a role for years, the Defense Department is preparing to play a major part in combating the flow of drugs into the United States. The change has been brought about in part by legislation last year giving the military a role in controlling drug traffic and in part by a change in attitude in the leadership at the Pentagon.

title: East Africa
description: To the Editor: In her article about coffee-growing and -roasting in East Africa (''Vintage Coffee From East Africa,'' Travel, July 30), Florence Fabricant stated that coffee had been introduced into Europe by the mid-19th century. To my knowledge coffee was well established in Europe by the end of the 17th century. In early 18th-century Germany, numerous coffeehouses existed in major cities such as Leipzig, where, between 1729 and 1741, Johann Sebastian Bach conducted his Collegium Musicum at Zimmermann's Coffee House every Friday evening from 8 to 10. The delightful ''Coffee Cantata,'' poking fun at the addiction of Leipzig's middle-class ladies to the outlandish beverage, was written during this time. It is most likely that its first performance took place at one of the coffeehouse concerts.

title: Food; Distinctive Italian Fare Liguaria
description: HIGH ABOVE GEN-oa in the Ligurian Apennines, Celeste Martini cooks a frittata in her pot-bellied stove fueled by fruit-tree cuttings. In Genoa, her son Gianni makes his frittata on top of the stove, inverting the omelet onto a plate after the eggs have set and sliding it back into the skillet to complete the cooking. This dish is taken on mushroom hunts in the early fall, when the second porcini season begins and the woods are filled with foragers. The country omelet - often filled with the last of the summer greens that grow in the rocky soil - is more closely akin to Spain's tortilla filled with potatoes than to its loftier French cousin. It is a hallmark of Ligurian cuisine.

title: Miss Woodward Becomes Bride
description: Jean MacMaster Woodward, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Woodward of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Michael John Maher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Maher of West St. Paul, Minn. Msgr. Paul J. Schierse performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's-on-the-Brandywine Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del.

title: A Preview For Early Subscribers
description: WHILE one waits for the musical agenda to be replenished next month, a preview might be in order. What follows is by no means a complete listing of the fall schedules, but a sampling for early subscribers - who do get the best seats.

title: Megan J. Lawler Becomes a Bride
description: Megan Joy Lawler and Gene Johnson were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Lawler, in Larchmont, N.Y. Joseph Clifford, Village Justice of Larchmont, performed the ceremony.

title: Subscriptions That Bring Corn and Arugula
description: THE demand for organically grown vegetables coupled with a desire to help local farmers has prompted some consumers to try a new approach to produce shopping. They are in effect buying a subscription to the crops. A result is a guaranteed supply of fresh vegetables during the growing season and an assured income for growers.

title: Gannett After Neuharth; WILL PROFITS STILL GROW?
description: In a moment weighted with symbolism, John J. Curley's first official act after becoming chairman of the Gannett Company this spring was to banish the two life-size sheep with golden faces that guarded the threshold of the executive offices at the newspaper chain's headquarters here. Allen H. Neuharth, Mr. Curley's flamboyant predecessor, had taken wicked delight in watching visitors reach for chocolates wrapped in gold foil arranged beneath the tails of the sheep. An enticing display of golden dung was quintessential Neuharth humor, which usually tended to emphasize who was boss. Mr. Curley has a decidedly different style. A self-declared maverick within the nation's clubby newspaper establishment, Mr. Neuharth drinks martinis and dresses in high-fashion clothes of black, white and gray. As chairman, he wrote what he ironically termed ''love notes'' to subordinates on signature peach-colored stationery. He was notorious for temper tantrums.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the review of A. Zee's book ''An Old Man's Toy'' on July 30 misstated the age of Albert Einstein in 1955. He was 76, not 67.

title: Recent Sales
description: Blue Point$200,000 133 Blue Point Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, sun porch, den, basement, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,300. East Patchogue $130,000 13 Laura Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, den, 1-car garage; taxes $1,500. Islip $227,000 1778 Spur Drive South 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 0.5 acre, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500. Massapequa Park $197,000 1 Jackson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, 1-car garage; taxes $4,400. Mineola $205,000 165 Andrews Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, basement, brick exterior, 1-car garage; taxes $2,500. Sayville $166,000 5 Lilac Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,900. OTHER AREAS Manasquan, N.J. $153,500 73 Minnesink Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; dining room, h/w floors, fenced yard; taxes $1,450. Bethany, Conn. $172,000 50 Francis Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; hot tub, pool, 1-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $1,626. Bedford, N.Y. $346,000 59 Brundage Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old raised ranch; family room w/fireplace, 2-car garage, 2.2 acres; taxes $5,695.

title: For a Quick Change of Personality, Curry Powder
description: THE heat of curry seems to wake summer appetites. Spicy seasonings are often characteristic in regions with hot climates, and curry - or the spices like pepper, cumin, turmeric, ginger and others that make up the blend - is no exception.

title: Paying the Price
description: In the Government's insider-trading investigation of Wall Street, the first person convicted by a jury was Lisa Ann Jones, a runaway at age 14 who become a $117,000-a-year trading assistant for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. at age 26. Last week, a Federal judge sentenced her to 18 months in prison and imposed $50,000 in fines, not for securities law violations but for perjury and obstruction. Unaware that the authorities had tape recordings to undermine her story, she denied to a grand jury that she knew about trades the Government said were illegal.

title: Understanding Virginia Woolf
description: To the Editor:

title: Sigrid A. Mendel, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Sigrid Arlene Mendel and Peter James Usen were married last evening at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia by Rabbi Elliot J. Holin.

title: Getting to the Top In the Caucasus
description: THE man in the street, the man in the woods, even the top-notch travel agent have probably never heard of Europe's highest peak. But the obscurity of this Russian volcano is undeserved; any strong hiker with an ice ax and a pair of crampons can reach the summit at 18,481 feet, and look down on 30,000 square miles of mountains, high plains and inland seas.

title:
GARDENING;
Renewed Interest in Insecticidal Soaps
description: LEAD: INSECTICIDAL soaps that promise control of insects without further contamination of the environment by much more toxic chemicals have been receiving much attention lately. Actually, various soaps have been used for insect control since the late 1800's.

title: Tower for Nippon Club
description: As New York has drawn an increasing number of Japanese businessmen, so, too, has the Nippon Club, their paramount social and financial club here. The club, which had grown to the point where it seemed ready to burst out of its old clubhouse, is now building a 21-story tower in which to house itself.

title: MARY POPPINS, FORCE OF NATURE
description: Upper-class English culture is securely rooted in the nanny. If you lunch in a Pall Mall club, you will find the menu degenerating, as it reaches the sweet course, into nursery food - bread and butter pudding, jam roll and custard, suety lumps covered with treacle - and you can almost hear nanny's voice ordering you to eat it all up. When in Evelyn Waugh's ''Brideshead Revisited'' Sebastian Flyte wishes to show Charles Ryder his magnificent home, the only human being he introduces is his old nanny. And the continuing dominance of Margaret Thatcher over right-wing English society demonstrates the terror a brisk, bullying woman from the lower middle class can instill in the hearts of men from Eton and the Guards.

title: Pamela A. Furlong Weds
description: Pamela A. Furlong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfrid M. Furlong of Massapequa, L.I., and Guy C. Raimondi Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Raimondi of Lewiston, N.Y., were married there yesterday at the Niagra University Chapel. The Rev. John Maher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Raimondi, 25 years old, is a nurse at Syosset (L.I.) General Hospital. Next month, the bridegroom, 24, is to join the criminal defense division of the New York Legal Aid Society as an attorney.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS OF AN EXILED AFRIKANER
description: ''I CANNOT SEEM TO SHAKE AFRICA,'' BREYTEN BREYTENBACH said to me one afternoon earlier this summer. He said it in a soft, even voice, without theatricality. We were finishing lunch in Paris, in an unassuming bistro off the Place des Vosges. Africa - this thing he could not seem to shake -shadowed him from far away. ''It seeps into everything I write,'' he said. ''However long I'm in Paris, however hard I try to set it aside. I can't not write about it.''

title: Streetscapes: Congregation Derech Emunoh Synagogue; Turn in Fortunes for a Struggling Arverne Survivor
description: LONG isolated on an urban renewal wasteland of 150 vacant blocks, the seaside synagogue of Congregation Derech Emunoh has just barely survived. Slated for demolition, gradually decaying and its landmark designation overturned by the city, its congregation now is so small that services often cannot be held.

title: FICTION
description: QUITE THE OTHER WAY. By Kaylie Jones. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Although we've got used to second-generation actors equaling or surpassing the accomplishments of their parents, the same hasn't happened with second-generation novelists. Nonetheless there are a few, like Martin Amis and Susan Cheever, who are making names for themselves - and added to their small number ought to be Kaylie Jones, the daughter of James Jones, whose second novel, ''Quite the Other Way,'' is a look at the particulars and peculiarities of glasnost. Clinton Gray, the daughter of the famous American correspondent Alexander Clinton Gray, spends a college semester in Moscow - with side trips to Tbilisi and Leningrad - formally studying the culture and informally but compulsively searching for information about her now-deceased father's sojourns, when he was about Clinton's age, in Russia during World War II. She begins an affair with a fellow student, the opaque Phil Chase, gets chummy with two other students, Isabel and Ceppie, and is befriended by a line of Muscovites as long as any outside a Soviet grocery store. Although every single day of Clinton's stay is not described, ''Quite the Other Way'' includes coverage of the quotidian that sometimes seems to have been included simply because it happened and not necessarily because it is dramatically cogent. Nonetheless this account of Clinton's quest for fragments of her father's past and her coming to terms with life and love in today's Soviet Union is touching, disturbing, funny, frustrating and as charming, in its way, as that of the more innocent earlier adventures of Americans-abroad Emily Kimbrough and Cornelia Otis Skinner in ''Our Hearts Were Young and Gay.''

title: Longo Takes World Title
description: Ending the slight suspense early, Jeannie Longo of France jumped away in the third of six laps and cruised to a solitary and easy victory today in the world championship road race for female bicycle riders.

title: My Hero May Be Your Stoolie
description: The real-life model for private Eriksson, as the character is identified in Brian De Palma's new Vietnam film, ''Casualties of War,'' is still living under an assumed name somewhere in mid-America. It is now 25 years since Private Eriksson, at immense personal risk, testified against four of his Army buddies involved in the 1963 abduction, rape and murder of a young Vietnamese woman. The cost of conscience: permanent anonymity. As originally reported by Daniel Lang in The New Yorker magazine in 1969, Private Eriksson's story remains as vivid and disturbing to read today as the De Palma movie is to watch. This says something not only about our continued preoccupation with the meaning of the Vietnam War, but also about our gut reaction to people who, for one reason or another, blow the whistle on former friends. Stool pigeons or heroes? Depending on the circumstances, there should be no doubt.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Rentals for the Elderly in Woodbury
description: LEAD: A 98-UNIT town-house project in Woodbury called Stonewall Farms, on which construction starts next month, will offer older couples and singles lifelong guaranteed occupancy.

title: Leftist Ideology Lives On Only as the Opiate of the Intellectuals; Lattimore of the C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: New Season Concert to Celebrate Space
description: THE concert lineup for fall is becoming known, and it will include a special nonsubscription concert by the Hartford Symphony to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the first manned moon landing.

title: Cost of Shoreham Put at $25,000 Each
description: The outcome of the Shoreham controversy is a foregone conclusion. Despite the apparently never-ending controversy, there is really no question about the ultimate outcome. The old adage that ''money talks'' holds true in this case. And the people of Long Island have ''voted'' with their pocketbooks.

title: NONFICTION
description: JAPAN: In the Land of the Brokenhearted. By Michael Shapiro. (Holt, $19.95.) Perhaps no country makes a foreigner feel more conscious of his foreignness than Japan. For foreigners who seek fulfillment by submerging themselves in another culture, it represents the ultimate challenge. As Michael Shapiro shows in his insightful book, ''Japan,'' it is a challenge they can never entirely meet. Mr. Shapiro, a writer who accompanied his wife when she was sent to Tokyo by her newspaper, never had high expectations about his ability to fit in. He became fascinated, however, by those who did, who believed that through hard work, patience and love they could become truly accepted by their Japanese friends and colleagues. This book tells the stories of five contemporary Americans and a turn-of-the-century journalist, Lafcadio Hearn. Each progressed through an emotional dialectic of infatuation followed by extreme disillusionment, culminating in a realistic acceptance of his role and identity. Mr. Shapiro's technique, jumping back and forth among the stories of Hearn and the contemporary Americans - a baseball player, a businessman, a missionary couple and a young woman who defies the fingerprinting required by Japan's alien registration law - is somewhat artificial and occasionally disconcerting. But the stories are compelling, particularly that of the baseball player, who discovers that in Japan he will never be accepted as part of the team. Mr. Shapiro adds a few of his own offbeat experiences, such as trying to explain to Japanese Christians what it means to be a Jew.

title: John Hancocks Not Up for Sale
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks. How can we restore the original brick color?

title: HOMEENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.
description: South American cocaine cartels have transformed this desert town and other seemingly bucolic points along the cactus-dotted Mexican border into international drug passageways that now rival those of south Florida.

title: Following Carlton
description: For almost as long as he can remember, the St. Louis Cardinal pitcher Joe Magrane has had one baseball dream.

title: Neighbors Fight Plan for a Hotel On a Wooded Lot
description: Emory University and its neighbors seem to agree on only two things these days: that the university's 28-acre wooded lot is the best in the state and that despite strong local opposition, Emory is going to build an 18-story hotel on a six-acre piece of that lot. That is 13 stories higher than DeKalb County zoning laws generally allow.

title: Charlie Hustle Wears a New Suit
description: Jackie Mason tells a story about a man who finds his wife in bed with another man. ''It's not what you think,'' she says to her husband. ''He's just teaching me to dance.''

title: Earth to NASA
description: Voyager 2 is heading for the stars after transmitting to Earth a vast treasure of scientific information about the distant planets of our solar system. Simultaneously, another space probe is on its way to Venus to learn why a planet so near and similar in size to Earth suffers 900 degree temperatures underneath its veil of sulfur rain. No one is aboard either craft; no one is needed.

title: The Dark Side of Schubert
description: Many people who love music feel it is not only vulgar but pointless to pry into the lives of the great composers. Who cares if Wagner was a deadbeat, that Mozart used foul language, that Beethoven tried to sell scores to different publishers simultaneously, that Chopin loved a woman who dressed like a man and smoked cigars? The music they left us is all that counts. If it were to be discovered tomorrow that Rossini liked to tie up cats and pull out their whiskers one by one, would the reputation of ''The Barber of Seville'' be much affected? No. Genuine art seeks to shed itself of its creator, ideally in time achieving anonymity of the sort enjoyed by the authors of the ''Iliad'' or the Egyptian ''Book of the Dead.''

title: New Jersey Car Insurers Profited on Their Waste
description: New Jersey's expensive automobile insurance system, a target of motorists' anger since it was established in 1983, has also become a fertile ground for fraud investigations by Federal and state agencies.

title: More Views On the Turnpike
description: Enough is enough! The joke could have been funny, but those telling it never knew its origin. While the recounting of the building of the New Jersey Turnpike (''About New Jersey,'' July 30) brought some interesting historical facts to light, once more the turnpike has been erroneously credited as the inspiration for the talk-show hosts and comedians' question ''What exit?''

title: Touched by an Angel
description: MY family and I touched an Angel last summer. For years I had been fascinated with the Fresh Air Fund's concept of taking children from the city and exposing them to the country and to different values and customs. Now, for the first time, we were able to participate in the experience of welcoming a city child into our home.

title: Madeline Guyon Wed to a Banker
description: Madeline Hunter Guyon and William Berryman Morrow Jr. were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Haven, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Sagamore Hotel in Bolton Landing, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. Susan Husted, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Nicaragua Foes Come Face to Face and Chat
description: A Nicaraguan Army unit and a contra guerrilla group reportedly drew their guns on Thursday when they met in northern Nicaragua, but then decided to hold an informal half-hour peace parley that included an exchange of cigarettes.

title: Angola Truce Is as Deadly As Civil War
description: It was shortly past midnight the other night when a mortar shell ripped through the roof of Felismina Castilho's adobe hut. Shrapnel from the explosion tore a hole in her right thigh. Her parents, sleeping in a room next door, were killed.

title: Murder Convictions Voided in Gay Man's Death
description: A state appeals court has overturned the murder convictions of three men in a case of violence against homosexuals that stirred this city five years ago.

title: Ilise Grossman Is Married
description: Ilise M. Grossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore D. Grossman of New York, and Marshall P. Stover, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stover of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Synagogue in New York. Mr. and Mrs. Stover, who are 23 years old and graduates of Georgetown University, are the owners of Hold It!, a manufacturer of women's accessories in New York.

title: McGirt Outpoints Jacobs As Forum Shuts for 2 Years
description: LEAD: In the last bout at Felt Forum before it goes dark for two years, a weary James (Buddy) McGirt scored a unanimous decision over Gary (Kid) Jacobs in a 10-round welterweight bout yesterday afternoon.

title: What to Look for If You Decide to Go
description: TicketsAll day sessions and most night sessions are sold out. The only tickets still available are for night sessions on Aug. 31, Sept. 1, Sept. 5. Tickets are $10. To order, call Ticketron or go to the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center ticket office at Flushing Meadow Park. Night play begins at 7:35 P.M. Day sessions begin at 11 A.M. Transportation From Manhattan: Take the IRT No. 7 subway to the Willets Point-Shea Stadium stop. From Connecticut, Westchester or New Jersey: By car, I-95 to Whitestone Bridge to Whitestone Expressway south, to Shea Stadium/National Tennis Center exit. From Long Island: Take Grand Central Parkway west to Shea Stadium exit. StadiumMain arena, 20,662 seats. When it's full, nothing compares to the lions vs. Christians atmosphere created by an exciting match. GrandstandSe cond show court. 6,100 seats. A cozier, cooler place to watch; basically first-come, first-serve seating. Court 3One of the ''upset'' courts. 1,562 seats. Court 16Third show court. Expanded to 4,000 seats. Courts 9-11, Courts 23-24Practice courts; good for getting autographs and a glimpse of players relaxed and up close. ScoreboardOv ersized drawsheet updated every day by a man with a paintbrush on a stepladder. Matches in Progress BoardVideo monitors provide scores of the day's ongoing and completed matches. The Metsare at Shea for a homestand from Sept. 4-10, which overlaps the final week of the Open. All Mets' games are night games except for Thursday, Saturday and Sunday afternoons. There is no night play at the Open on Monday, Sept. 4 or Friday, Sept. 8. ConcessionsE verything from racquets to tenniswear to cameras to sunglasses from 16 manufacturers (Adidas to Yonex) are hawked at 31 booths run by Feron's. Among the big sellers are United States Open T-shirts ($14.99) and sweatshirts ($26.99). FoodServed at 60 booths, many included in the International Food Village, plus 4 membership restaurants, and corporate hospitality areas on the 16-acre site. The fare includes hotdogs, $1.75 (with or without sauerkraut); 1/2 lb. hamburgers, $5.75; stuffed potatoes with choice of toppings, $4.00; beef or chicken fajitas, $5.95; marinated chicken with radish sprouts, $7.50; seafood salad, $8.50; corn-on-the-cob, $2, washed down by Evian water, $1.25; wine, $3.50 a glass; beer $3.50 (imported), $2.75 (domestic); and chased by double dip ice cream cones, $2.75, or peach pie, $3.25.

title: Whittle Names a Board To Advise Channel One
description: Christopher Whittle, chairman of Whittle Communications, has assembled a board of 12 educators and public figures to provide ''advice and direction'' for Channel One, his advertiser-supported news program for students in junior and senior high schools.

title: Risa Rabinowitz Marries
description: Risa Rabinowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rabinowitz of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Goldberg, a son of Norma Goldberg of Philadelphia and the late Sidney Goldberg. Rabbi Sheldon Thall and Cantor David Abikzer officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. The bride, a magna cum laude graduate of Boston University, is the eastern sales manager in New York for Elle magazine. Mr. Goldberg, the chief financial officer of JMW Consultants, a management consulting firm in New York, is a magna cum laude graduate of Pennsylvania State University.

title: Goal in Chile: Fiscal Change With Stability
description: A recent newspaper cartoon here showed a group of South American presidents -from Brazil, Peru, Venezuela and Argentina - struggling not to drown in a sea of economic woes, while one man stood on the shore, undecided about jumping in.

title: Back to Where It All Began
description: CHRIS EVERT, whose 19th United States Open will be her last, panicked for only a moment upon waking up last Wednesday morning in Toronto and learning that her plan to ease into retirement following her favorite tournament had been trumpeted worldwide while she slept.

title: 5 Weeks, 5 States, 9 Major Drug Arrests
description: Recent sizable drug seizures as reported by state law enforcement officials. 1. June 13: Louisiana State Police seized 34 grams of Mexican brown heroin on I-20 in Bossier Parish from two men in a 1970 Cadillac with Louisiana license plates. Passenger threw bag containing balloons of heroin out of window. 2. June 16: Texas Department of Public Safety seized 136 kilograms of marijuana on U.S. 59 in Nacogdoches County from an Illinois resident. Marijuana discovered inside trunk of 1978 Chevrolet Monte Carlo with Illinois Plates. 3. June 21: New Jersey State Police seized 85 grams of heroin, four ounces of cocaine and $31,516 on New Jersey Turnpike in Bergen County from three in a 1985 Chrysler with New York plates. 4. July 3: Georgia State Patrol seized 6 kilograms of cocaine on I-75 in Crisp County from a couple in a 1978 Chevrolet with Illinois plates. 5. July 4: New Jersey State Police seized 49 grams of heroin on New Jersey Turnpike in Hudson County from two New Jersey men. Heroin concealed inside glove box of 1988 Chevrolet Blazer with New Jersey plates. 6. July 9: Louisiana State Police seized 227 kilograms of marijuana on I-12 in St. Tammany Parish from two men. Marijuana concealed in 1986 Chevrolet motor home with Mexican plates. 7. July 14: Delaware State Police seized 6 kilograms of cocaine on I-95 in New Castle County from two Florida men. Cocaine discovered inside rear quarter panel compartments of 1984 Oldsmobile Cutlass with Pennsylvania plates. 8. July 14: Georgia State Patrol seized 9 kilograms of hashish and $800 on I-95 in Effingham County from two men in a 1979 Ford van with Ontario, Canada, plates. 9. July 17: Georgia State Patrol seized 20 kilograms of cocaine and $1,711 on I-75 in Dooly County from a Georgia man. Source: State Police records.

title: PRIVATE COMPANY LOFTS A SATELLITE INTO EARTH ORBIT
description: A privately owned rocket fired a payload into orbit yesterday for the first time in the history of the space age.

title: Italy Easing Japan Trade
description: Italy has raised import quotas on some Japanese goods in the first of a series of steps to liberalize trade between the two countries, an Italian news agency has reported.

title: Insuring AIDS Victims and Others at High Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Errors Cost Yanks A Defeat by Orioles
description: The games are beginning to run together now, each day and each defeat weighing more heavily on the Yankees than the one before. There is a growing impatience in the stands, a growing loss of heart on the field and a sense that the new manager, just 10 days into his first term, is already working on borrowed time.

title: F.B.I. Drops Rose Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation office here has dropped out of the investigation of Pete Rose, satisfied that the former Cincinnati Reds manager wasn't involved in a cocaine-trafficking ring.

title: Account
description: * Merrin Gallery, to Lois/GGK, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Raise Cigarette Prices, Save Lives
description: Let somebody experiment with crack, and chances are good that his dealer has gained a steady customer. Let that person experiment with cigarettes, and chances are even better that the tobacco industry has one.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. promoted Bernard J. Hamilton to executive vice president and director of strategic business systems.

title: Nathan Susskind, 91, Tax Law Specialist
description: Nathan Susskind, a New Jersey lawyer and philanthropist, died of cancer Friday at Bayonne (N.J.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Bayonne.

title: Police Hiring Trails Crime Rise, Report Says
description: Police departments in the country's largest cities employed only slightly more policemen in 1987 than a decade earlier, but at the same time the rate of violent crimes jumped by 43 percent, the Justice Department said today.

title: Hunt for Golden Horse Finally Ends
description: The six-year treasure hunt for a golden horse is finally over, and the only winner is a Philadelphia-based charity, the Big Brothers/ Big Sisters of America.

title: New Faces
description: Some of the young players who have begun to make their mark, and could begin making an impact at the Open this week. MONICA SELES 15 years old, Yugoslavia, 5-4, 99 lbs. Left-handed, hits with two hands on both sides. Reached semifinals of French Open, beating Zina Garrison and losing in three sets to Graf. Reached 4th round of Wimbledon, losing to Graf. Won Virginia Slims of Houston beating Chris Evert in the final. Coached by Nick Bollettieri. Ranked No. 12. AMY FRAZIER 16, Rochester Hills, Mich., 5-8, 130 lbs. Right-handed with two-handed backhand. Won the Virginia Slims of Kansas this winter and the semis of the Virginia Slims of Albuquerque this summer. Ranked No. 40. CONCHITA MARTINEZ 17, Spain, 5-7, 130 lbs. Right-handed. Won Eckerd Open in Tampa this spring, beating Sabatini in the final. Best results to date have been on clay; she is unproven on hard courts. Ranked No. 15. ANN GROSSMAN 18, Grove City, Ohio, 5-3, 110 lbs. Right-handed with two-handed backhand. Reached 4th round of French Open this summer. Won U.S. National Girls 18's in 1987. Ranked No. 46. JENNIFER CAPRIATI 13, Wesley Chapel, Fla., 5-3, 106 lbs. Right-handed with two-handed backhand. Won U.S. National Girls 18's and the French Open Juniors this year at age 13. Too young to play in main draw of Open (minimum age is 14), but will be in Juniors there playing on her favorite surface, the hard courts. JIM COURIER 19, Dade City, Fla., 6-1, 173 lbs. Right-handed with two-handed backhand. Reached fourth round at French, beating Agassi and losing to Chesnokov from 2 sets to love up. Reached quarterfinals at Stratton this summer. Ranked No. 34 on A.T.P. computer, a career high. Coached by Nick Bollettieri. ALBERTO MANCINI 20, Argentina, 6-3, 164 lbs. Right-handed. Won Italian Open beating Agassi and Monte Carlo beating Wilander and Becker consecutively. Ranked No. 12. Has faded in last three to four months, but has five victories over top 10 players this year, including Wilander twice. This is his first U.S. Open. NICOLAS PEREIRA 18, Venezuela, 6-2, 189 lbs. Right-handed. Won French, Wimbledon and U.S. Open juniors last year. Took Lendl to five sets in first round at Wimbledon this year. Reached quarters of Canadian Open this summer, beating Tim Mayotte. Ranked No. 100. Fred Perry has grouped him with McEnroe, calling them ''the only real tennis players. . . . All the others just swing their arm and hope the ball falls between the lines.'' DAVID WHEATON 20, Minneapolis, 6-3, 171 lbs. Right-handed with two-handed backhand. Semifinalist at Stratton where he beat Agassi. Ranked No. 62. Played one year for Stanford (1988) and was member of its N.C.A.A. championship team; won Brasilia Challenger satellite event in April. GORAN IVANISEVIC Yugoslavia, 16, 6-4, 161 lbs. Left-handed. Reached Australian Open quarters in January, runner-up at Florence and semifinalist at Nice this spring. Fourth round at French. Ranked No. 49. Has 1989 victories over Leconte, Chesnokov and Agassi. Member of Yugoslav Davis Cup team. All court player.

title: New Trend In Auto Ads: Understated
description: WHEN he was awarded the advertising account for the General Motors Corporation's Saturn division, the largest new account in advertising history, Hal Riney, the rumble-voiced San Francisco ad man, told the world last year, ''I don't think we'll ever shoot a picture of a car going down a wet, windy road with pylons.''

title: Little Heroes Put Their Town on the World (Series) Map
description: To Harold Jensen Sr. it was ''unbelievable, just unbelievable,'' even more so, he said, than when his son, Harold Jr. led Villanova to an upset victory over Georgetown in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship in 1985.

title: Crack Arrives in Chicago
description: Crack is beginning to turn up more and more in the Chicago area, which until recently has not seen much of the smokable form of cocaine, the police say.

title: Theme Song For Zoom Lens
description: When Aretha Franklin sings ''Who's Zoomin' Who?'' on television in the next few weeks, that enigmatic phrase will refer to something understandable - video camcorders.

title: Sihanouk Resigns as Leader Of Faction, but Not Coalition
description: On the eve of the final round of talks aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk resigned as president of one of the main political factions seeking to oust the Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia, his aides said today.

title: Seeds of Controversy Lie in West 61st Street Roadbed Plan
description: You would never know it to look at the stub end of West 61st Street, a public cul-de-sac off Amsterdam Avenue, but within its modest roadbed lie the seeds of 21 extra stories for a proposed apartment tower.

title: LeMond Captures World Title
description: Greg LeMond did it again. Continuing his remarkable comeback from a hunting accident that left him near death about two and a half years ago, LeMond surged in a sprint today to win the professionals' world championship in the bicycle road race.

title: Crowd Pays Respects to Newton
description: More than 2,000 mourners came to pay their respects to Huey P. Newton today, waiting in a long line to file past the open coffin containing the body of the slain co-founder of the Black Panther Party.

title: Laytonville Journal; Where a Rainbow Ends And Circus Visions Live
description: Nearly every child who ever saw a circus has harbored the fantasy of running away to join one. And here in the wooded groves of Mendocino County, 200 miles north of San Francisco, a camp combines that fantasy with another vision: building a peaceful, harmonious world.

title: Bill Could Shift Control Over Pension Funds
description: A little-noticed section of the House budget reconciliation bill, if passed, could lead to profound changes in the way the nation's $1 trillion in pension assets are invested. The legislation would give 30 million employees control over one of the nation's largest pools of capital.

title: Down the Right Road To a Triathlon Victory
description: DANIEL GLICKENHAUS was not quite convinced that he won the Central Park Triathlon on Saturday, even though he was first to break through the finish line.

title: Insuring AIDS Victims and Others at High Risk; Catch-22
description: To the Editor:

title: Lendl Tested in Final But Prevails as Usual
description: Ivan Lendl's matches at the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup were close enough to make fans occasionally think they were going to witness a rare Lendl loss. But every time his opponent would start to roll, and the crowd would start to buzz, Lendl would turn up his game and remind everyone that he is the world's best tennis player.

title: Target of Four Spacecraft: Edge of the Solar System
description: No one knows exactly where the solar system ends and interstellar space begins, but Voyager 2 and three other American spacecraft are moving out to get the answer.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Radio Group's Owner Uses Baseball Research
description: LEAD: Jeff Smulyan is a fervent baseball fan; his hero is Willie Mays. His company, the Emmis Broadcasting Corporation, owns WFAN-AM in New York, the nation's first all-sports radio station and the flagship station of the New York Mets, as well as 10 other stations around the country.

title: Campaign Matters; Political Polls: Some Snapshots Come Out Blurry
description: Who's ahead?

title: Brierley Chief Plans to Retire
description: Sir Ron Brierley, a New Zealand corporate raider, is to retire as chief of the investment company he founded 28 years ago.

title: 250 Whites Jeer Marchers In Brooklyn Youth's Death
description: Racial tensions from the killing of a black youth on Wednesday flared again in Bensonhurst yesterday as 60 to 70 marchers clashed with about 250 white residents who screamed obscenities and racial slurs.

title: Jury Continues to Deliberate In Helmsley Tax-Fraud Trial
description: The jury in the tax-fraud and extortion trial of Leona M. Helmsley deliberated for a second day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: Sikh Militants Are Suspected In Killing of 20 in Train Raid
description: Suspected Sikh militants killed at least 20 people and wounded 30 today in a shooting rampage on a passenger train in the northwestern state of Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Angry Cordero Suspended
description: Angel Cordero Jr., after being suspended 10 days for careless riding and fined $1,000 for an outburst against a Saratoga Race Track official, denounced the New York track stewards today as incompetent to judge race-riding because ''they have never even ridden a pony.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Exact Words; Title X Is Hereby Cured; May It Rest in Peace
description: From the Federal Register of Friday, Aug. 11, concerning termination of a Department of Housing and Urban Development program known as Title X. The program was designed to provide Government insurance for affordable development projects, but rules were bent to serve luxury and resort projects. Loan defaults ended up costing taxpayers $90 million.

title: Citizen Lawsuits on Environment Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; What Kids Love
description: ''It's so exciting when the product and the concept come together,'' says John Sullivan, a candy manufacturer. ''And with Boogers, we've hooked into something culturally significant.''

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Technique Is All in Exercise-Walking
description: LEAD: ASK most joggers, bicyclists, and tennis players about walking, and they'll probably say it's an activity best left to the infirm or the confirmed nonathlete. Walking, however, can make for a serious workout, if you apply dynamic walking techniques that turn walking into exercise-walking, a full-fledged aerobic and calisthenic exercise.

title: Argentina Is Trying to Rescue the Art of Its Past
description: Forgotten in remote mountain churches, Argentina's colonial art has barely survived centuries of neglect. Canvases flap free of their frames. Images of Roman Catholic saints are dim with grime and soot and scorched with candle burns.

title: For Forbes, a Party on the Edge of Deductibility
description: Because of the media industry's very nature - high public visibility and overwhelming dependence on advertisers - it seemed at least plausible that the publisher Malcolm S. Forbes might contend that his highly publicized birthday party in Tangier, Morocco, qualified for heavy subsidy by taxpayers.

title: Harlem Crowd Panics; Dozens at Festival Hurt
description: At least 45 people were hurt and one woman was shot in the foot as a crowd gathered for a festival at the State Office Building in Harlem last night suddenly panicked and began running.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the beginning of a whole new era in space for America. We're now aggressively entering the world competition to launch satellites.'' -Stephanie Lee-Miller, director of the FederalTransportation Department's commercial space office. [ A1:6. ]

title: AZT's Inhuman Cost
description: AZT is the only drug approved for use against AIDS. It's now known that AZT also postpones the onset of AIDS in people infected with the virus. Yet there's a massive obstacle to wider use of this life-saving drug - its extraordinary cost. At $8,000 a year for users, AZT is said to be the most expensive prescription drug in history.

title: Pro Bono
description: * J. Walter Thompson/New York will create a campaign for the Council of Independent Colleges, an association of small liberal arts colleges based in Washington.

title: 50-Year Salute to American Theater Wing and Its Tonys
description: One of Broadway's most venerable organizations is to be saluted in an exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. ''The American Theater Wing: 50 Years of Education Through Theater,'' celebrates the golden anniversary of the organization that founded the Tony Awards and that provides a variety of theater-related community services.

title: ICN Sets Venture in China
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. said on Friday that it had agreed to form a venture in China to produce the antiviral drug Ribavirin to be sold in that country to treat hepatitis.

title: 'The Gulag' Goes Home
description: Fifteen years after Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn was exiled, a Soviet magazine has begun publishing portions of ''The Gulag Archipelago.'' Page A7.

title: Baltic Nationalists Voice Defiance But Say They Won't Be Provoked
description: Leaders of nationalist movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania said today that the Soviet Communist Party's scathing denunciation of their actions would not deter them from pursuing their goal of independent statehood and would not provoke them to mass demonstrations.

title: Ricoh Account Moved
description: Citing dwindling financial support for the account, Chiat/Day/Mojo announced yesterday that it had parted ways with the Ricoh Corporation, a manufacturer of copiers, after handling the company's advertising for two years. The account, which includes broadcast, print and outdoor advertising, is worth $6 million. It will now be handled by Justamere Associates, a small agency in Andover, N.J.

title: Topics of The Times; Intimate Strangers
description: It may have started when Gloria Vanderbilt plastered her name across millions of back pockets. In time, Americans began accepting strangers' signatures not just on their jeans but their shoes, purses, cosmetics and furnishings. Signed, labeled or otherwise trademarked, almost everything now seems to be a designer item.

title: Israelis Bomb South Lebanon Base Of Hostages' Captors, Killing Two
description: Israeli Air Force fighters bombed and significantly damaged a headquarters of the Party of God in southern Lebanon this evening, killing 2 people and wounding at least 10 others, the army and the police in Lebanon said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY The huge agency set up to manage the assets of failed savings associations is getting entangled in disputes between banking regulators and Administration officials charged with overseeing them. Since President Bush signed legislation two-and-a-half weeks ago to create the Resolution Trust Corporation, its oversight board has stepped in several times to alter regulators' plans. [ Page A1. ] Orders for U.S.-made tools dropped 20.7 percent in July from the June level, as a slowdown in the automobile industry continued to hurt manufacturers of factory machinery. The Association for Manufacturing Technology said the July figures represented the lowest monthly level of new orders this year. For the first seven months of the year, orders for machine tools were down 18.5 percent from the first seven months of 1988. [ D1. ] A provision of the House budget reconciliation bill would change how the nation's $1 trillion in pension assets are invested. The legislation would give 30 million employees control over one of the nation's largest pools of capital. The measure has not yet been approved by the House and no comparable legislation has been introduced in the Senate. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela are looking with envy on the debt-relief plan won recently by Mexico. But many officials in Buenos Aires, Brasilia and Caracas increasingly admit that the need for relief begins at home. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Meridian Bancorp hopes to bolster its market share in Philadelphia and become one of the largest banks in Pennsylvania by acquiring First Pennsylvania, whose executives are willing to recommend the deal to shareholders. [ D1. ] Ohio Bell and Wisconsin Bell reached tentative agreements with their striking union as talks continued with the other three companies that make up Ameritech. [ A11. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS CBS wants viewers to make a date to watch Connie Chung. The network is putting the focus of its promotions on her rather than on her new program. Bill Carter: Television. [ D1. ] Malcolm Forbes's birthday party not only generated publicity for his magazine, but the hundreds of corporate titans who attended could be seen as a source of advertising dollars and as possible subjects for articles. [ D9. ] Whittle has signed up a board of 12 to provide ''advice and direction'' for Channel One, the advertiser-supported news program for students in junior and senior high schools. [ D8. ] The Spanish Government has awarded three commercial TV licenses, marking the beginning of the end of a state monopoly over television broadcasting. [ D9. ] Nissan Motor's campaign for its Infiniti features no windy roads, pylons, sexy models, jingles, slogans and, most significantly, no cars. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The fixed-income securities market is bracing for a week of volatile price moves in what is normally its slowest period of the year. With many market participants on vacation until after Labor Day, market liquidity is sharply reduced, causing exaggerated price moves. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] The evolving definition of insider trading underwent some refinement after the Government recently concluded its investigation of three arbitragers, with one pleading guilty to mail fraud and the others not being charged. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Grim news helped knock down the stock prices of Carolco Pictures and Live Entertainment. But analysts expressed some confidence in the outlook for both companies. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Only bills Scheduled This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues during this pre-Labor Day holiday week is confined to an auction of three- and six-month bills today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 27, 1989:M$02,30,30 MONDAY San Diego G&E Watkins Johnson United Illum TUESDAY Angelica Corp Ipalco Ent DQE Inc Reece Corp MA Fuqua Inds WEDNESDAY Deere & Co Stanley Works THURSDAY Times Mirror Co Washington Nat Van Dorn Co FRIDAY Davis Water & Waste

title: Early Rounds Are the Prime Time For Discovering the Future Stars
description: WHEN Ion Tiriac, the mustached former Davis Cupper from Rumania, first saw Steffi Graf play, he knew he was watching someone special. Graf had ''much more athletic ability than any other woman I ever saw on a tennis court,'' Tiriac said of the defending women's champion and top-seeded female player at the United States Open.

title: Mayoral Rivals Face Questions: Education and the Family
description: In separate interviews last month, The New York Times asked the six New York City mayoral candidates to discuss some of the major problems facing the city in 1989 and how they would deal with them. This is the first of six articles comparing their responses. Excerpts from the interviews appear [ below ] .

title: Just When Beijing Needs It, Farmers Have Bumper Crop
description: Yang Guojun, a tall, plump man who buys grain for the state, smiles shyly as he talks about the summer's bumper harvest that he and his crew collected over 10 days from the baskets of the local peasants.

title: The Talk of Gramercy Park; In the Wake Of Asbestos: Many Fears, No Answers
description: Although most residents of Gramercy Park have always regarded their tranquil, tree-shaded neighborhood as a refuge from the rest of New York City, few had ever imagined themselves as refugees.

title: Books of The Times; Author Rises Briefly From His Typewriter
description: The Afternoon of a Writer By Peter Handke Translated by Ralph Manheim. 87 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Savimbi Ready to Resume Angola Truce
description: The Angolan guerrilla leader, Jonas Savimbi, said today that he was prepared to restore the cease-fire that has broken down in his country 's civil war amid confusion over what was agreed to in a June accord.

title: 8 Former Champions In This Year's Field
description: THERE are new seats at Court 16, new flooring at the concession area and new scoreboards everywhere.

title: Erica A. Grody Is Married
description: Erica A. Grody, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin H. Grody of New York, was married yesterday to David J. Levens, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Levens of Massapequa, L.I., at Beth El Temple in West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Stanley Kessler officiated. Mr. and Mrs. Levens, both 28 years old, are the senior audio engineer and production associate, respectively, for the ''Today'' show on NBC-TV in New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Mayoral Candidates Talk About Children's Problems New York City's 4 Democratic and 2 Republican candidates offer general and specific answers on issues in the home and at school. Page B1. Israeli Raid on Lebanon Israeli jets bombed a base of the Party of God in southern Lebanon, killing 2 and wounding 10. Page A6. Irving Stone, Writer, Dies Irving Stone, a master (some say the inventor) of the modern biographical novel, is dead at 86. Page B6. U.S. Open Starts Today Tennis's top players begin competition in Queens. Full coverage, including the draw. SportsMonday.

title: P.L.O. Aide Explains A Possible Arafat Visit
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's spokesman in Washington said today that a possible visit by Yasir Arafat to the United States was not meant as a challenge to the Bush Administration but rather to discuss Palestinian peace initiatives with the United Nations and the American people.

title: Polls And Policies
description: Richard Ravitch is a serious candidate for mayor of New York City in the way that all candidates ought to be serious - in the substance of the positions he takes and the policies he proposes. Unfortunately for him, it's an American political cliche that the only truly ''serious'' candidate is one who looks like a winner.

title: Troubled Indian College Eager for Its New Leader
description: Robert G. Martin, a 42-year-old educator with a history of rescuing troubled institutions, will arrive here next month to take command of the Haskell Indian Junior College.

title: Who Invited Football So Early?
description: A DENTIST on West 57th Street, probing with long steel instrument the opened and cotton-filled mouth of his patient, wondered aloud, ''Are the football seasons starting earlier these days, or am I going wacko?''

title: Bridge
description: The Split Regional Championships, played simultaneously in Albany and Parsippany, N.J., continued over the weekend. These were winners of events played Friday and Saturday: Flight A Pairs, William Hunter, Stoneham, Mass., and John Albanese, Quincy, Mass.; Flight B, Henry Ruston and Richard Bresnick, both of Brooklyn; Flight C (Albany), Joe Tamancy, Hyde Park, N.Y., and Chandler Gibbs, Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; Flight C (Parsippany), Gary Benner, Stroudsburg, Pa., and Chen-Yi Lin, East Stroudsburg, Pa.; Master Pairs, Wesley Trutt, Central Islip, L.I., and Kenneth Moss, New Paltz, N.Y.; Non-Master Pairs, Pat Feulner and Jessica Harpine, both of Ballston Spa, N.Y.

title: Moves in China To Cut Incomes
description: A northeast China province regarded as a pioneer of market-based economic reforms is moving to cut the ''unfair'' high incomes of entrepreneurs, China's official newspaper said Friday. The government of Liaoning

title: Frost Captures The World Series
description: David Frost came out of the right rough at the second playoff hole, then chipped from the fringe and sank a 3-foot putt for par today to beat Ben Crenshaw and win the N.E.C. World Series of Golf.

title: New Singer Chairman Is a Railroad Retiree
description: Walter A. Drexel, who was named chairman of the Singer Company on Friday, is a former railroad and oil executive who is coming out of retirement to try to help calm the troubled waters at the military contractor.

title: In the 80's, Birmingham Is Still a Racial Barometer
description: It is a story that seems too good to be true: how an industrial city that came to symbolize the ugliest violence of the civil rights era in the South was transformed into a harmonious, economically diverse city under enlightened black leadership.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Battle nationalist movements said the Communist Party's denunciation of their actions would not deter them from pursuing independence for Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and would not provoke them to demonstrate. A1

title: Jean Robertson Becomes a Bride
description: Jean Margaret Robertson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kelley Robertson of Lynn, Mass., and Andrew David Getraer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Getraer of Greens Farms, Conn., were married yesterday. Rabbi Barbara Penyner performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Merchandise trade 2d qtr. Tuesday G.N.P. 2d qtr. New home sales July Corporate profits 2d qtr. Wednesday Personal income July Thursday Farm prices Aug. Factory orders July Friday Employment Aug. Leading indicators July Construction spending July

title: The Next Wave of Diagnostics
description: Biotechnology companies are getting ready to sell a new class of products that will greatly increase the ability of doctors to detect and diagnose cancer, heart ailments and other diseases.

title: Baseball, Apple Pie and Paid Autographs; Worth Less, Not More
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Ann Bass Weds Kevin Kostyn
description: Nancy Ann Bass, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Bass of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Kevin Francis Kostyn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Kosztyn of Edison, N.J., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Hoag at the Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor.

title: People
description: * Bob Cox has resigned as executive creative director of Hal Riney & Partners/New York.

title: MOON OF NEPTUNE SHOWS GEOLOGISTS SIGN OF VOLCANOES
description: Explosive volcanoes fueled by liquid nitrogen or possibly methane may well account for the rugged terrain around the south pole of Triton, Neptune's largest moon, scientists reported today after further analyzing photographs from the Voyager 2 spacecraft.

title: Business and the Law; Cases Illustrate Wall St.'s Edge
description: THE recent conclusion of a Government investigation of three arbitragers, with one pleading guilty to mail fraud and the two others not being charged, has Wall Street lawyers debating what the cases reveal about the evolving definition of insider trading.

title: Article 991889 -- No Title
description: When two old friends have a falling out, things sometimes get nasty, the more so when the fight involves a $3.5 billion takeover battle for France's second-largest insurance company, Groupe Victoire.

title: Public Record
description: The treasures await in a small suite of offices on the 10th floor of the headquarters building of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, just down the hall from the office of Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp.

title: Question Box
description: Yankees and Mets Q. When Walt Terrell joined the Yankees from San Diego last month, he also joined a list of major leaguers who have been with both New York teams, the Yankees and the Mets. How many pitchers are in that group? A. Terrell is the 18th pitcher among the 39 players to have donned both New York uniforms in a regular season, meaning that more than 45 percent of those with Met-Yankee backgrounds have been pitchers. Besides Terrell, the pitchers still active are Don Schulze, Neil Allen and John Candelaria. The 14 others were: Jack Aker, Ray Burris, Rob Gardner, Bob Friend, Dale Murray, John Pacella, Hal Reniff, Bill Short, Tom Sturdivant, Ralph Terry, Dick Tidrow, Mike Torrez, Doc Medich and Dock Ellis. Tidrow has one other distinction: He is the only pitcher in major league history to have worked not only for both New York teams, but also for both Chicago teams, the Cubs and the White Sox. Two Outs, One Run Q. With the bases loaded and none out, the batter grounds sharply to the shortstop, who feeds the ball to the second baseman for one out, and the second baseman relays it to first base for the out there. On the double play, the runner from third scores, and the batter is charged with a time at bat, but not credited with a run batted in. In the same circumstance several innings later, the same batter hits a fly ball to the right fielder, who catches it for one out, then makes a strong throw to first base to catch the runner who strayed too far for the second out. On this double play, the runner from third scores by tagging up after the catch. Does the batter get credit for an r.b.i. this time? Is he charged with a time at bat? A. Yes and no. Even though the circumstances were the same - with the batter twice hitting into a double play with the bases loaded and none out - the responsibility for the outcomes was different. When the batter in the first example grounded into a double play, he provided the source of the force at second base and he failed to beat the relay to first base, so he fully deserved to be deprived of an r.b.i. and fully earned a time at bat. When the batter flied into a double play the next time up, though, the effect was a sacrifice fly that made it pretty certain the runner from third would be able to scoot home. So the batter deserved the r.b.i. But he had nothing to do with the runner on first being caught off first and doubled up; that runner was not forced to leave the base, so his out was his own fault, not the batter's. Under the rules, the batter who drives in a run on a sacrifice fly does not get charged with a time at bat. So the batter in the second example did not have an official time at bat, even though his time up led to two outs for his team. DiMaggio's Streak Q. When Joe DiMaggio set a major league record by hitting safely in 56 consecutive games, in how many of the games did he get more than the one hit necessary to extend the streak? A. There were 22 multiple-hit games and 34 one-hit games during the streak, which ran from May 15 to July 17 in 1941. Four times DiMaggio got four hits in a game and five times he got three, including the day before the streak ended, against Cleveland. Only twice over the 56 games did DiMaggio manage not to be retired in a game. He went 3 for 3 each time, once against the St. Louis Browns in Game 4 of his streak, and once against the Chicago White Sox in Game 32. He wound up batting .408 with 91 hits in 223 times at bat during his record run. Age and U.S. Tennis Q. In men's and women's singles, who are the oldest and youngest players to win the United States Open tennis championships? A. Among the men, these extremes go back almost a century, to a time when the event was known as the United States championships, when it was held at the Newport Casino in Rhode Island and when a challenge-round format made it easier for a defending champion to repeat because he had to play only the winner from the elimination rounds.
