After Oliver Campbell won the first of his three consecutive titles in 1890, he became the youngest men's singles winner, at 19 years 190 days, and he remains the youngest ever. After William Larned, at 38 years 242 days, captured his fifth successive title at the 1911 championships, he became the oldest ever, and no man has passed him. That victory was the last one for Larned and the last time the challenge round was employed.

title: Nothing Succeeds Like Excess
description: In the last few days, the normally adverse August social mood has been relieved by comment, press and private, on two rather spectacular social events. One was the million-dollar party sponsored by Saul Steinberg for his 50th birthday by his fiscally attentive wife, Gayfryd.

title: Jets' Toon to Report Today
description: Just in time, Al Toon will be joining the Jets.

title: Turmoil in Colombia
description: Nine Colombian bank offices were bombed, and the nation's Justice Minister reportedly resigned after receiving death threats. Page A10.

title: Puerto Rico Eyes The 2004 Olympics
description: The International Olympic Committee has brought its annual sessions to many exotic places since they began 95 years ago in Paris, but never before to an island in the Caribbean.

title: Padres Dismantle Mets, 13-7
description: In one of their shabbiest performances of the season, the Mets took a 13-7 thrashing from the San Diego Padres this afternoon and were swept out of town three and a half games out of first place and fading fast. And, for an extra shot of bad news, they probably lost Bob Ojeda for a couple of weeks with sprained ligaments in the left knee.

title: M. S. Flynn Wed To Martha Levin
description: Martha Levin and Matthew Stuart Flynn were married yesterday at the Old West Church in Calais, Vt. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: Insuring AIDS Victims and Others at High Risk; Insurers' Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Wants To Get 'Dates' For Chung
description: When viewers tune into CBS this week, they will not hear about how Connie Chung will change their lives. Instead, they will hear about how she may change their social calendars.

title: Medellin Banks Bombed; Justice Chief Said to Be Near Quitting
description: Nine bank offices, seven of them Government-owned, were dynamited today, presumably by drug traffickers, as indications grew that the Minister of Justice was resigning in the face of death threats.

title: Filbert Estimate Down
description: The filbert harvest in Oregon and Washington is estimated at 13,500 tons, down 18 percent from 1988 and the smallest output since 1984. An Agriculture Department report said severe cold in early February interfered with pollination. The Oregon crop of filberts, or hazelnuts, was forecast at 13,300 tons, compared with 16,300 tons in 1988. The Washington harvest was indicated at 200 tons, the same as last year.

title: Latin America Pursues Recovery on 2 Fronts
description: In the club of Latin America's largest debtors, Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela are looking with envy on the debt relief plan won recently by Mexico.

title: Federal Savings Industry Rescue Is Entangled in Agency Disputes
description: The huge agency set up to manage the assets of the nation's failed savings associations is getting entangled in disputes between banking regulators accustomed to being insulated from political pressure and Bush Administration officials charged with overseeing them.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
The Sage of the Ring
description: LEAD: Ray Arcel, who turns 90 years old on Wednesday, accumulated 20 world champions and worked with over 2,500 fighters in his 65 years as a trainer. And one of his champions is still in the ring.

title: Swings Seen In Treasury Issue Prices
description: The fixed-income securities market is bracing for a week of volatile price moves in what is normally its slowest period of the year.

title: Tool Orders Fell 20.7% Last Month
description: Orders for American-made machine tools dropped by 20.7 percent in July from the June level, as a slowdown in the automobile industry continued to hurt manufacturers of factory machinery.

title: Baseball, Apple Pie and Paid Autographs
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Amigos' Brings Hispanic Culture to TV
description: The leading character on the show is a six-foot Spanish-speaking dog named Perro Pepe who usually sports a furry orange costume, a green floppy hat and a purple tie. But in the scene being filmed, he is dressed to the ''nueves'' in top hat, cummerbund and bow tie.

title: Spain Is Moving to End State's TV Monopoly
description: The Spanish Government has awarded three 10-year commercial television licenses, marking the beginning of the end of a state monopoly over television broadcasting.

title: Blue Jays Stretch Victory Streak to 6 As Brewers Lose
description: The Toronto Blue Jays are on a roll and when that happens, as the Milwaukee Brewers found out, the lucky bounces seem to follow.

title: U.S. VISITORS LEARN LIMITS OF GLASNOST
description: During a recent visit by the House Armed Services Committee to Sevastopol, a Soviet admiral disclosed significant details about a new aircraft carrier being built near there.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the reaction of Poles and Polish-Americans in the United States to the political events in Poland misidentified a Brooklyn church. It is St. Stanislaus Kostka Church in Greenpoint.

title: Ruth Seligman, Editor, Marries
description: Ruth A. Seligman, an editor in the public information department at the United Nations in New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Mark, an associate editor of New York Jewish Week, a newspaper. Rabbi Avraham Weiss, assisted by Rabbi Marvin J. Spiegelman, performed the ceremony at the Washington Hotel in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: Melinda Stolley and Craig Snider Wed
description: Melinda Ruth Stolley and Craig Jonathan Snider were married yesterday in an interfaith ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Thomas L. Stiers, a Congregational minister, and Cantor Raymond Smalover.

title: Refurbished 'Nevsky' Film Shown
description: A newly restored version of Sergei Eisenstein's 1938 film classic, ''Alexander Nevsky,'' is delighting audiences on a world tour that its producer hopes will carry the film triumphantly back to the Soviet Union.

title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.
description: A Federal narcotics intelligence center here sent out a confidential cable last month to state police officials across the country with this alert:

title: The Teacher Corps, Reborn
description: The expected loss of a million teachers from the nation's classrooms in the next five years has prompted Washington and New York City to revive a useful idea from the 1960's: the Teacher Corps.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Student Takes Amateur Title: Chris Patton, a Clemson senior who at 300 pounds looks more like a football lineman than a golfer, beat Danny Green, a businessman from Jackson, Tenn., 3 and 1, yesterday to win the United States Amateur golf championship at Ardmore, Pa.

title: Joy Verschleiser Weds Craig Pearl
description: Joy Rebecca Verschleiser and Craig Irwin Pearl were married last evening at the New York Hilton by Rabbi Haskel Lookstein.

title: Israel Deports 5 Palestinians For Their Roles in Uprising
description: Israel deported five Palestinians accused of leading the Arab uprising in the West Bank today.

title: Beth Ann Solomon Is Wed
description: Beth Ann Solomon, 23 years old, and Steven Barry Glazer, 28, were married yesterday by Cantor Raymond Smolover at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Mrs. Glazer is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Solomon of Harrison, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Florence Glazer of Yonkers, and Bill Glazer of Newport Beach, Calif. The bride is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Glazer, a graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, is a director for American Trails West in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Somalia Took Necessary Steps to Maintain Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt and Jordan Criticize Syria Indirectly for Its Role in Lebanon
description: Egypt and Jordan indirectly criticized Syria over the weekend for its role in Lebanon's conflict, highlighting differences between the Syrians and neighbors usually described as moderates in the Arab world.

title: Jets Might Not Win But They'll Be Slim
description: No potato chips for the Jets on their chartered flights this year. No Reese's Pieces either.

title: From Soup to Court
description: The 10 victorious British and Irish amateur golfers and their large entourage of officials, family and friends, joined their American hosts in the traditional dinner last Thursday night in Atlanta to celebrate the end of another Walker Cup match.

title: Giants Unbeaten But Hardly Perfect
description: Although he is the coach of a team that has played three preseason games and has won them all, Bill Parcells of the Giants is not ready to celebrate.

title: Irving Stone, Author of 'Lust for Life,' Dies at 86
description: Irving Stone, a prolific author whose exhaustively researched and often immense biographical novels included ''Lust for Life,'' based on the story of van Gogh, died of heart failure on Saturday night at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 86 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Exchange Expels Firm
description: The commodity trading firm Capcom Financial Services Ltd. has been expelled from the Chicago Board of Trade in response to its indictment on charges involving a multimillion-dollar scheme to launder drug profits, the Board of Trade said Thursday. London-based Capcom, which had been a member since 1985, agreed to the expulsion and to never reapply for membership. The firm was suspended July 17 for violating exchange rules requiring member firms to maintain and produce accurate records of customer accounts.

title: Agassi Is Seeking the Strength to Seize the Top Honors
description: THE only catch in being a tennis phenomenon at age 18 is what happens when you turn 19 and begin to suspect your audience is wondering whether you will follow up your act or fold it. It's a unique anxiety. Just ask Andre Agassi, the lion-maned tennis player who roared for a year and is now struggling to make good on the great expectations attendant on his rising star.

title: Pension Fund Deal Cleared
description: Participants in the retirement funds for most of the nation's college faculty members will have more investment opportunities under a settlement approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Tuesday misidentified the president and chief operating officer of General Motors and the banking company that appointed him to its board. He is Robert C. Stempel; the company is the NBD Bancorp.

title: Insuring AIDS Victims and Others at High Risk; Cultural Sanction
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about reports of a rebel offensive in Angola misidentified the Angolan Foreign Minister. He is Pedro de Castro Van-Dunem; Loy is his nickname.

title: Alaska Fisherman Who Sued After Oil Spill Wins $7,700
description: A fisherman won a $7,700 settlement from the Exxon Corporation and the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company after filing a complaint in small-claims court that he lost wages because of the nation's largest oil spill.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Bush Bats .500 and Settles Old Score
description: President Bush stepped up to bat with a score to settle.

title: Ms. Froom Weds A Fellow Student
description: Mignon Froom and Brian Jeffrey Benjamin, both third-year medical students at the University of Rochester, were married yesterday at the Country House, a restaurant in Stony Brook, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Topek officiated. The bride, who is 29 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Froom of Stony Brook. Her husband, who is 24, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey P. Benjamin of Voorhees, N.J.

title: Gym Bag Trimmed To Fit
description: A new gym bag that fits into standard-size lockers is designed to provide easy access to gear.

title: Critic's Notebook; Hot in London: Play and Weather
description: On one of the hottest nights of the summer, the tiny pub theater in the East Dulwich Tavern was filled to overflowing. Without a hint of air-conditioning or ventilation, the temperature rose as if someone were turning up the steam in a sauna. The play, ''In Lambeth,'' written and directed by Jack Shepard, dealt with a meeting between William Blake and Tom Paine, after Paine had helped foment the American Revolution.

title: Meridian Bank Aims at Philadelphia
description: With its announcement on Friday of plans to acquire the First Pennsylvania Corporation of Philadelphia, the oldest bank in the country and one of the largest before it fell on hard times in the late 1970's, Meridian Bancorp hopes to bolster its market share in Philadelphia and become one of the state's largest banks.

title: Film Catalogue
description: Rick Prelinger is a pack rat extraordinaire. The archivist has collected more than 20,000 industrial, public service and educational films - most of which had languished forgotten in vaults for decades. Now, to ease the access of producers to this and other collections, Mr. Prelinger has published a guide to every significant storehouse of film and videotape footage in North America. The 1,600 public and private collections are itemized in an 800-page tome, called Footage '89, which also lists copyright limitations for their use. Footage '89, which costs $95, can be ordered from Prelinger Associates, 430 West 14th Street, Room 403, New York, N.Y. 10014-9943.

title: Outdoors: The Fathomless Dazzle of Night Fishing
description: LEAD: THE thing about night fishing is that you, well, fish at night.

title: London Journal; In Umbrella Land, Sunshine Gets Mixed Reviews
description: For Michael Fish, the British Broadcasting Corporation's veteran weatherman, who has a weather-obsessed nation waiting on his every word, it has been a disappointing summer.

title: Mayoral Aspirants Address Ideas for Helping Children
description: David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, has called for increasing spending on services and benefits for poor children and troubled families as a way of helping people and saving money.

title: In Bensonhurst, Grief Mixed With Shame and Blunt Bias
description: At St. Dominic's Church in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, a few blocks from where a black teen-ager was murdered last Wednesday by a gang of bat-wielding youths from the neighborhood, the Rev. Charles S. Fermeglia opened the 9:30 Mass yesterday by touching on raw nerves.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Nancy E. King, Editor, Is Wed
description: At the Harvard Club in New York, Nancy E. King, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. King of New York, was married yesterday to Robert B. Bernstein, a son of Sara June Bernstein of Lincoln Park, N.J., and the late Alfred Bernstein. Rabbi Burt Siegel and the Rev. John A. Buehrens, a Unitarian minister, officiated. The bride, who is 31 years old, is a senior editor at the Foreign Policy Association in New York. She is a graduate of Cornell University, as is her husband, and holds a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University. Mr. Bernstein, 33, is a senior litigation associate at the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler. He received a law degree from the University of Virginia.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section on Thursday about the new Children's Museum of Manhattan misstated the scheduled opening date. It is Oct. 15.

title: Mutually Assured Arms Reductions
description: The Soviet Union may be signaling to the U.S. a willingness to engage in a complete, mutual halt in production of the essential elements of modern nuclear weapons: plutonium, enriched uranium and tritium.

title:
Market Place;
Effect on Stocks Of Grim News
description: LEAD: WITHIN 24 hours hours last week, the chairman and chief executive of Live Entertainment Inc. was murdered, along with his wife, in their home in Beverly Hills. A co-chairman of Carolco Pictures Inc., which holds a stake in Live Entertainment, was discussing selling his 36 percent holding in Carolco to the other co-chairman.

title: No Headline
description: Virginia Taggart quit her job earlier this month as a secretary, sold her four-bedroom house in Anaheim and moved to rural Washington State after living here for 50 years. Life here, once wonderful, had become just too difficult, she said, with ''gridlocked'' traffic and smog. She will miss little about the Los Angeles area ''except my daughter and grandchildren.''

title: 3 Sheriff's Deputies Found Shot to Death in California
description: Three off-duty sheriff's deputies were found shot to death in a murder-suicide, a sheriff's spokesman said Saturday.

title: 115 Nominations Wait and Fingers Are Pointing
description: Getting the right people in the right jobs is always a priority for a new President, but for a variety of reasons, the task has been especially difficult for President Bush.

title: Drivers Cast Doubt on Test For Drinking
description: Drunken-driving prosecutions in New York City are being jeopardized in increasing numbers because of newly successful defense challenges to incriminating Breathalyzer tests, law-enforcement officials say.

title: The Maazel Evolution: Prodigy To a Potential Karajan Heir
description: Lorin Maazel made his New York conducting debut 50 years ago this month. Since Mr. Maazel is by no means one of the older conductors in the international upper echelon today, that may be found surprising -but not nearly as surprising as his initial appearance at the 1939 New York World's Fair must have been. Who ever heard of a 9-year-old conductor?

title: Forum for Solzhenitsyn And Other Discontents
description: Fifteen years after Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn was banished from the Soviet Union and from its press, the magazine Novy Mir, long the sober center of the Soviet literary world, this week published the first chapters of his prison-camp epic, ''The Gulag Archipelago.''

title: 2 PHONE COMPANIES AND UNION AGREE
description: The Ohio Bell Telephone Company and the Wisconsin Bell Telephone Company reached tentative agreements with their striking union over the weekend, and talks continued today with the other three companies that make up Ameritech, officials said.

title: Mobile-Home Owners Win New Rights
description: Here at Valkill Park East, a Dutchess County community where ornamental shrubs grace neatly mowed lawns, the precarious life of the mobile-home owner suddenly feels secure.

title: Philippines Arrests Guerrilla In Slaying of a U.S. Colonel
description: Troops on Sunday arrested a Communist guerrilla who admitted taking part in the slaying of a United States Army colonel in April in a Manila suburb, the military announced today.

title: Eagles Make Quick Among Highest Paid
description: Mike Quick, the star wide receiver of the Philadelphia Eagles, signed three one-year contracts yesterday, ending a holdout just in time for one game of preseason football. Terms of the contracts were not disclosed. Quick previously had a three-year pact for $700,000 a year.

title: Lauder's Speech: Restoring Quality of Life
description: New York City's mayoral candidates make dozens of speeches. Sometimes they address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often they use a ''basic speech,'' which varies little from one occasion to the next.

title: INSIDE
description: Rep. Frank Urges Inquiry Representative Barney Frank said the House ethics panel should investigate his association with a male prostitute to clear the record. Page A12. South African in Zambia South Africa's Acting President, F. W. de Klerk, met with President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, a relentless critic of apartheid. Page A3. Big Bank Merger in Japan Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank said they will merge next April in a deal that will create the world's second-largest bank. Page D1.

title: Gilbert Is First Upset Victim as Open Begins
description: Steffi Graf and the weather were equally undemonstrative on opening day of the 109th United States Open, with Graf appearing invincible but unimpressed with herself and the sullen sky threatening a washout but holding off. And in keeping with custom at Flushing Meadows, the airplanes roared overhead so interminably yesterday that even the guttural grunts of the noisome teen-ager Monica Seles of Yugoslavia were drowned out.

title: Ernst H. Krause, 76, Aerospace Executive
description: Ernst Henry Krause, a nuclear physicist and aerospace executive, died of heart failure at his home Wednesday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Racism, Accomplice to Murder
description: Anyone who thought the murder of Yusef Hawkins in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn was an isolated incident had to wait only three days to learn differently. When scores of mourners, led by ministers, paraded in the streets Sunday to express their outrage, they were confronted by a crowd so angry and insulting it had to be restrained behind police barriers.

title: Soviet Dancer Joins San Franciscans
description: Yuri Zhukov, a member of the Kirov Ballet, has signed a nine-month contract to dance with the San Francisco Ballet. Mr. Zhukov, who is 24 years old, signed as a soloist with the company, which is directed by Helgi Tomasson. Mr. Zhukov has not defected to the United States, and is joining the San Francisco company with the permission of Oleg Vinogradov, the director of the Kirov.

title: Chinese Student Gets 9 Years for Role in Protest
description: Reporting the first sentencing of a student participant in the spring democracy movement, an official newspaper said today that a student had been given nine years in prison for spreading rumors to the Voice of America.

title: Palestinian Uprising Prompts Both Arabs and Jews to Leave
description: Salma Fababji and her family are fed up. They want out. And so, like an ever-growing number of Palestinians, she and all her immediate relatives are trying to move to the United States.

title: Who Really Killed Yusef Hawkins?
description: LEAD: We are told that the person who killed Yusef Hawkins - the black teen-ager who was surrounded by whites and shot to death Wednesday night in Brooklyn - is still at large. But who really killed Yusef? Who loaded the weapon and encouraged the trigger finger? The legacy that produces the killings of Yusefs was written centuries before the present killers were born.

title: East Bloc Could Use an Economic Community; Turkey and Bulgaria
description: To the Editor:

title: Love Canal Defense Setback
description: A Federal judge has eliminated one of the Occidental Chemical Corporation's main defenses in a lawsuit over liability for cleaning up the Love Canal toxic dump, according to a decision made public today.

title: Postage Stamps' Cost Likely to Rise in 1991
description: The cost of a first-class postage stamp will probably rise, to between 28 and 32 cents, early in 1991, Postmaster General Anthony Frank said today. That means two more Christmases at the current 25-cent rate for first-class letters, Mr. Frank said on NBC-TV's ''Today'' show. Mr. Frank had previously said the Postal Service would apply for a rate increase next year, to take effect in 1991, but had not specified the amount. He said today that the increase would be 20 to 25 percent, later specifying a range of 28 cents to 32 cents for the new rate. The cost of mailing a letter rose from 22 cents to 25 cents in the spring of 1988 and a new increase effective in 1991 would continue the recent policy of increases every three years. Any increase must be approved by the independent Postal Rate Commission.

title: OMI Stock Bought
description: Storebrand A.S., a Norwegian insurance company, has acquired 6.9 percent of the OMI Corporation, a cargo-fleet operator based in New York. OMI's stock slipped 25 cents a share today, to $9.50, on the American Stock Exchange. At current stock prices, the company's is valued at $303 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Storebrand said it had made net purchases of 1.8 million OMI shares since December for $6.525 to $10.30 each.

title: Zambian Leader Meets South African
description: In a meeting as significant for its symbolism as its content, South Africa's Acting President, F. W. de Klerk, introduced himself today to President Kenneth D. Kaunda, a relentless critic of apartheid, on the Zambian side of Victoria Falls.

title: Helmsley Jury Is Deliberating
description: A Federal District Court jury in Manhattan deliberated for a third day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the trial of Leona Helmsley, the hotel executive charged with income-tax evasion and extortion. The jurors, who deliberated for almost 9 hours, asked to rehear testimony from two liquor salesmen that they had been forced to kick back a percentage of their sales to keep accounts at Helmsley hotels. The testimony relates to the most serious charge against Mrs. Helmsley, conspiracy to commit extortion.

title: Pilots to Meet on UAL Plans
description: The governing body of the pilots' union at United Airlines will be briefed today and tomorrow on proposals that could involve union participation in a management buyout of the airline, people connected with the union said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Keye/Donna Gets Playboy
description: Despite spurning a request from Playboy magazine to appear on a television program documenting its search for an ad agency, Keye/Donna/Pearlstein, New York yesterday won the high-profile $2 million account. The agency edged out two other New York shops, Buckley/DeCerchio and John Emmerling Inc., both of which appeared on the CNBC cable network program.

title: Christopher W. French, 49, Editor at A.P.
description: Christopher W. French, an Associated Press newsman and administrator for 23 years and editor of the A.P. Stylebook since 1980, has died at age 49.

title: Jersey Bell and a Phone Union Say Their Local Strike Is Over
description: Officials of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and the striking Communications Workers of America said today that the last remaining local issues have been resolved and the 23-day-old walkout is over.

title: Innovators and Investors Hindered In the Business of Pollution Control
description: The nation's effort to overcome its pressing environmental problems is being slowed by barriers that discourage technologically innovative companies and the people who invest in them, Government officials, investors and executives at the companies say.

title: Leningrad Journal; Sudden Ascent to Power for a Not-Quite-Outsider
description: Boris V. Gidaspov seems the very model of a modern party candidate in a day when Communists want their power ratified at the ballot box.

title: Remarks By Cardinal
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks in Czestochowa on Saturday by Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, as published today in Gazeta Wyborcza, the Solidarity daily, and translated by The New York Times:

title: Treasury Securities Prices Continue Down
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved lower in very sluggish trading yesterday.

title: Yanks Have Meeting, But Outcome Is Same
description: On his 11th day as the new Yankee manager, Bucky Dent tried a different direction. In the late afternoon, he held a pregame meeting, calling his players into a back room and presumably delivering a talk aimed at reversing August's slide.

title: Bargain Basement
description: ALTHOUGH you can spend a fortune on software, you don't have to. I recently ordered programs from four advertisers in Compute!s PC Magazine, at prices ranging from $1.99 to $3.25 a disk. Some programs take more than one disk.

title: Books of The Times; Tracking the Unexplained in a Life on the Move
description: What Am I Doing Here By Bruce Chatwin 367 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Owners Fear New Jersey Casino Ruling
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission has made it more difficult for institutional investors to own large stakes in casino companies.

title: Mayoral Hopefuls in New York Assess the City's Health Crisis
description: While New York's mayoral candidates agree on many public health matters, sharp differences have emerged among them on the proper response by municipal hospitals to the health crisis.

title: Cubs Beat Astros, 6-1,
description: Jerome Walton's mistake helped his team, the Chicago Cubs, score four first-inning runs today. And the Cubs went on to beat the Houston Astros, 6-1.

title: Guilford Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Unitog Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Metro Datelines; Goetz' Jail Release Delayed Over Razor
description: Bernard Goetz, who was originally scheduled to be released from Rikers Island Sept. 6 after serving at least eight months of his one-year sentence for possessing an unlicensed handgun, has had his release date pushed back to Sept. 20 because of a prison infraction, correction officials said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Rigolletto Campaign By Buckley/DeCerchio
description: If a new ad campaign for Rigolletto Sportswear spoofing the traumas of teen-age dating seems particularly authentic, it might be because the campaign's creators are not far removed from those times in their own lives. Bryan J. Buckley, 25 years old, and Thomas L. DeCerchio, 29, the co-chairmen of Buckley/DeCerchio, designed the ads to appeal to ''the AC/ DC listeners,'' the heavy-metal rock aficionados who are Rigolletto's best customers.

title: New Hope for Those Who Tear Their Hair
description: An experimental drug can help women conquer an overwhelming urge to tear out their hair, a surprisingly common disorder that affects millions of Americans, leaving some bald, researchers say.

title: Tom and Tony Still Ride in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs
description: With its long nose and bulbous cockpit, the Turbo-Thrush looks like an airplane designed by a committee. But the plane's ungainly features make it a high-performance crop duster, with promising potential in the drug fields of Colombia.

title: Astro-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Apogee Robotics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A Bid for Power In Motion for Beijing
description: When members of the International Olympic Committee vote later this week on several changes to the executive board, the 11 officers and members who virtually run the organization, He Zhenliang of China is widely expected to gain a position as vice president.

title: Lomas Expects Delay on Debt
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation, a troubled mortgage banking concern, said today that talks with lenders on a restructuring of its senior debt were continuing, but the company added that it did not expect its restructuring to be completed by Friday, when $145 million in senior public debt matures.

title: Whittaker to Sell Metals Subsidiary
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Whittaker Metals unit to Rio Algom Inc. of Minneapolis for an undisclosed amount.

title: Barney Frank's Judgment
description: Representative Barney Frank, one of the House's brightest and most effective members, is in serious trouble for some appalling mistakes. By his own account, he patronized a male prostitute and hired the man for household errands. When Mr. Frank was away, the prostitute, a convicted drug and sex offender, used the Congressman's Washington apartment to run a sex service.

title: Profit Up 1.5% At Matsushita
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that its consolidated profit in the first quarter rose 1.5 percent from the period a year earlier, as domestic sales weakened. For the period ended June 30, Matsushita's net income was 52.6 billion yen, or about $365 million, up from 51.8 billion yen in the period a year ago. Per-share income was 24.69 yen, or about $1.71, up from 24.27 yen.

title: Review/Concert; At Tanglewood, a Contrast in Musical Gravity
description: Tanglewood ended its summer concerts on the kind of weekend that has endeared this event to so many people for over half a century. Dignified yet inviting, august but benign, this expanse of great trees and greenness was at its best. A light breeze rustled now and then; the sun was strong, the air cool. That there was music attached to all this seemed almost beside the point.

title: Foremost Stake To Australians
description: An investment group led by the FAI Traders Insurance Company, an insurance concern based in Sydney, Australia, has acquired 5.1 percent of the Foremost Corporation of America. Foremost, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., insures mobile homes and recreational vehicles.

title: Carter Ends Holdout
description: Another Pro Bowl receiver, Anthony Carter of the Minnesota Vikings, ended a 28-day holdout, but he is without a new contract. Carter, who has been fined $42,000 for being away, wants to get a raise from his current $400,000 salary to about $1 million a season in an extended pact.

title: Two Banks Set Merger In Japan
description: Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank said today that they had agreed to merge next year, creating the second-largest bank in the world.

title: A New Prime Number
description: After more than a year of computation, six researchers at a California computer company have found the largest known prime number, which is 65,087 digits long and would fill more than 32 double-spaced typed pages.

title: Cox Finds His Niche With the Giants
description: With the start of the National Football League season two weeks away, Greg Cox has found a job with the Giants. The problem is defining the job.

title: The Capital
description: Lech Walesa, who plans to visit Washington in mid-November, will no doubt tell President Bush what he told Senator Bob Dole of Kansas in Gdansk last week: If Poland's nascent experiment in democracy should fail, this country will be as much to blame as Solidarity.

title: Papp Hastens Uptown Move For Hare's 'Secret Rapture'
description: Joseph Papp said yesterday that he had dropped plans for a five-and-a-half-week run of ''The Secret Rapture'' at the Public Theater and would instead open the show more quickly on Broadway.

title: Mercenaries' Role Scrutinized
description: A senior police official said today that foreign mercenaries had been helping rival drug cartels here sharpen their killing skills, and may have played a role in the assasination of Colombia's leading presidential candidate 10 days ago.

title: Belmont's Bizarre Boycott
description: Another Saratoga season is history, and the results and rubble from the 24-day meeting have a familiar look. Angel Cordero Jr. won the riding title again. Mary Lou Whitney gave the biggest party. The D. Wayne Lukas outfit topped the trainers. Attendance and handle reached new highs. Everybody ate and drank too much and stayed out too late.

title: Top Colombians Meet U.S. Officials on Curbing Drugs
description: A delegation of Colombian officials, including the Justice Minister, met under a veil of security with State and Justice Department officials today to discuss their crackdown on narcotics cartels.

title: Careers; A Shortage Of Nuclear Chemists
description: THERE is a serious shortage of graduate students studying to become nuclear and radio chemists, according to Ivor L. Preiss, a professor of chemistry at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. ''We're only graduating a few every year in the country,'' he said. ''Yet we need about 100 in the next five years.''

title: Healthcare Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Solar System's Coldest Spot
description: Scientists say Neptune's surprising moon Triton appears to be the coldest place in the solar system. Science Times, page C2.

title: Childbearing Women Cautioned on Measles Shot
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness Ordered Held In Drug Agent's Death
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the brother-in-law of former President Luis Echeverria must remain in jail so he can continue testifying before a grand jury as a material witness in the murder of the United States drug agent Enrique Camarena Salazar.

title: New Ecolab Record
description: Ecolab Inc.'s stock today rose to a new high for the year on renewed rumors that the company was a takeover target, analysts said. Stock in the St. Paul-based cleaning and maintenance company rose $2 a share, to $32.50, eclipsing its previous high of $30.50. More than 193,000 shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Market Place; Boom in Stocks In New Zealand
description: WITH foreign investors pouring in, the New Zealand stock market has been the hottest in the world for most of August, but the market may have started to cool. The Barclays industrial index of share prices has fallen in each of the past three sessions, losing a total of 2.7 percent, but it remains up 19.2 percent for the month of August, making it the best performer among the major markets for that period.

title: BALTIC COMMUNISTS PRESS MIDDLE ROAD ON INDEPENDENCE
description: Facing a crisis with Moscow over the growing nationalist movements in the Baltic republics, Communist Party leaders in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania issued statements today that straddled the line between the Kremlin's demand for restraint and local cries for more radical change.

title: Joseph Alsop Dies at Home at 78; Political Columnist Since the 30's
description: Joseph Alsop, the syndicated Washington columnist whose robust opinions appeared in newspapers around the country for five decades, died yesterday morning in his house in the Georgetown section of Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: Review/Dance; First New York Show by a New Troupe
description: Ballet Asia took a vigorous first step on Saturday afternoon with a program of dances choreographed by Miguel Braganza 2d and Max Luna 3d. This was a first formal appearance in New York by the company, formed in March by Mr. Braganza.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ametek Inc., Paoli, Pa., which makes equipment for the automotive and aircraft industries, said it would acquire the Weston cockpit instrument business of Schlumberger Industries, a unit of Schlumberger Ltd. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Easing the Grocer's Burden
description: The Federal Trade Commission has amended its rules that required retail food stores to provide adequate stocks of items that are advertised for sale. The agency says the costs of complying exceed the regulation's benefits.

title: Correction
description: Two picture captions with the theater listings in the Arts and Leisure Guide on Sunday were reversed. The upper photo showed ''The Aching Heart of Samuel Kleinerman,'' which opened yesterday; the lower picture showed ''Before Dawn,'' which runs through Sept. 17.

title: Texas Teacher Fatally Stabbed
description: A teacher was fatally stabbed today outside her elementary school classroom on the city's southeast side, the police said. The 24-year-old teacher's name was being withheld pending notification of her relatives, said Sgt. Billy Samuels. He said the woman, who taught at Glenn Park Elementary School, had been stabbed several times in the face and neck.

title: 300 Reported Killed in Afghan Rebel Feud
description: About 300 people have been killed in fighting between two rival guerrilla groups in northern Afghanistan and the conflict is spreading to other provinces, one of the groups said today.

title: Muppets Join Disney Menagerie
description: Miss Piggy and Mickey Mouse may have more pressing concerns than mergers and high finance, but their corporate masters have other ideas.

title: FORMER LAWMAKER GIVEN YEAR IN JAIL
description: Former Representative Patrick L. Swindall was sentenced today to a year in Federal prison for lying to a grand jury that was investigating the laundering of money obtained from drug profits.

title: Thrift's Position Shakier As Yanks Continue to Fall
description: George Steinbrenner's lingering unhappiness with the Yankees could next affect his senior vice president, Syd Thrift, who may be dismissed soon if he does not resign first.

title: Lebanese Muslims Warn of Final Battle
description: Leaders of Syrian-backed Lebanese Muslim forces warned today that they were preparing for a final battle with their Christian foes if current diplomatic efforts fail to produce a political solution to the country's 14-year-old civil war.

title: California Judge Rules Telephone Notice on Toxic Products Is Inadequate
description: A California judge has ruled that a toll-free telephone number set up by manufacturers so consumers can find out about toxic substances in products does not meet the requirements of state law.

title: Ex-Panthers, as if at a Rally, Honor Slain Leader
description: Former comrades remembered Huey P. Newton today as a ''minister from the street'' and a ''courageous prophet'' who fought tirelessly for the rights of blacks and the poor.

title: Helicopter Crash Leaves 4 Dead; Inquiry Centers on Fight Aboard
description: A wounded Canadian fugitive being airlifted by a medical helicopter apparently tried to commandeer the aircraft in flight, causing it to crash and killing him and the three-member crew, the authorities said today.

title: 8 Bronx Youths Held in Attack on Woman
description: Eight youths, the youngest of them 12 years old, were arrested Sunday and were charged with assaulting and trying to rape a 22-year-old woman in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: As Crack Moves Inland, Ohio City Fights Back
description: This clean, bustling Midwestern city is fighting back. The police, the Mayor, the City Council and neighborhood citizens have made a vow: They are not going to lose one portion of their city to crack dealers.

title: Triton May Be Coldest Spot in Solar System
description: Surprising Triton, the largest moon of Neptune, appears to be the coldest place in the solar system, Voyager 2 scientists reported today. It also displays a glowing aurora caused by bombarding radiation trapped by Neptunian magnetic fields.

title: Block (H&R) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
China, in Crackdown, Orders Many Companies to Close
description: Continuing a crackdown on private enterprise that began after the crushing of the democracy movement in June, China announced today that it would close a large number of privately owned companies.

title: Daewoo Gets Role In Navy Project
description: Daewoo Heavy Industries Ltd. of South Korea signed a contract worth as much as $108 million with the Lockheed Corporation to supply the outer wing of the United States Navy's P-7A long-range anti-submarine aircraft.

title: Metro Datelines; Request to Block 3 Bonuses at Lilco
description: The state's consumer chief said yesterday that he is asking the Public Service Commission to prevent the Long Island Lighting Company from paying more than $250,000 in bonuses to three top executives.

title: 76ers Trade Cheeks
description: The Philadelphia 76ers traded Maurice Cheeks, David Wingate and Chris Welp to the San Antonio Spurs yesterday for Johnny Dawkins, a guard, and Jay Vincent, a forward.

title: Dumagami Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company began commercial production Oct. 1, 1988 and there are no year-earlier comparable figures. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: First Federal Savings Bank (Montana) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Albertson's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
Switch for McDonald
description: Lanny McDonald, the Calgary Flames' forward, announced his retirement yesterday after 16 years in the National Hockey League.

title: On-Again Off-Again Jefferson Airplane Is On Again
description: Just because every rock band anyone remembers from the 1960's and 1970's has chosen this summer to regroup and tour doesn't mean the reunited Jefferson Airplane planned to jump on some bandwagon.

title: Koch Says Tests Show No Spread of Asbestos
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and other New York City officials told anxious residents of Gramercy Park last night that they still were not sure how widely the neighborhood had been contaminated by high levels of potentially hazardous asbestos. But they said ''hundreds of tests'' so far had shown no cause for alarm.

title: Comptrac reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Thief Dies by His Own Arrow
description: A burglar died after he apparently stumbled down a stairway and fell on a hunting arrow he was carrying, investigators said today. Greg Moore, 25 years old, of Tulsa, was found dead in his truck not far from a house that had been ransacked early Sunday, the Osage County Sheriff's Office said. Investigators said Mr. Moore was found with a wound in his lower chest. Goods stolen from the house and cocaine were discovered in the truck.

title: Chess
description: Although tournament winners generally don't win the brilliancy prizes - it isn't clear just why not - one of the winners of the 1989 National Open Tournament, June 9-11, in Las Vegas, Nev., broke the jinx. Larry Christiansen, a 33-year-old former Californian who is now a New York grandmaster, tied for first place with his fellow grandmasters Michael Rohde of Queens, Maxim Dlugy of Englewood, N.J., and Sergey Kudrin of Stamford, Conn., and the international masters Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., Eugene Meyer of Arlington, Va., and Victor Frias of New York.

title: Consumers Can Shop to Protect Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Edmond P. Bartnett, Editor, 98
description: Edmond P. Bartnett, a New York reporter and editor for more than 51 years, died Saturday at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center after a long illness. He was 98 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Bank Building & Equipment Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $156,000. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss from continuing operations included pretax reorganization expenses of about $360,000 and the 9 months included a pretax reorganization costs of $440,000.

title: Holocaust Memorial Unveiled
description: Fairfield County's first Holocaust memorial was unveiled and dedicated Sunday before about 100 people in Norwalk. The memorial is in the wall of the Norwalk Jewish Community Center and includes hundreds of tiles made by children who attended the center's summer camp. The memorial was inspired by the life of Charles Mittel, who escaped from Auschwitz. Mr. Mittel, an engineer who lived in Norwalk, died in January at 69 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, an energy company that is a subsidiary of Petrofina S. A. of Brussels, named H. Patrick Jack vice president of American Petrofina and its principal division, Fina Oil and Chemical Co.

title: By Design; Not for Riding
description: The woman was wearing crisply tailored, beautifully pressed jodhpurs. She was slim and had narrow hips - the right body for pants of any cut. But with the jodhpurs she was wearing a dressy jacket, a fussy hat and high-heeled shoes - all the wrong accessories. She was an object lesson: it isn't enough to latch on to the latest style. It's how a style is worn that separates the fashion winners from the also-rans.

title: East German Rulers' Fate: Clinging to the Old Faith
description: While neighboring Poland celebrated the ascent of non-Communists to national leadership, East Germany's aging leaders have stubbornly clung to their Marxist faith, evidently convinced that for them any surrender to the new winds would mean extinction.

title: Explosive Fabricators reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Shaw's Birthplace for Sale
description: The birthplace of George Bernard Shaw is for sale, and his admirers are trying to raise money to turn the yellow brick row house into a museum.

title: A Sinister Bias: New Studies Cite Perils for Lefties
description: IN French the left is gauche, and in Latin it is sinister, but researchers studying left-handedness have come to a more ominous meaning: left-handed people, on the whole, may die younger than right-handers.

title: Stella Madrid Triumphs, And Cordero Is Top Rider
description: Angel Cordero Jr. rode Stella Madrid to a 4 1/2-length victory today in the $234,600 Spinaway Stakes, clinching his 14th riding title at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Galanos Mines the Riches of Persia
description: James Galanos is sorry he isn't having a formal fashion show this season. ''There's so much richness in this collection,'' he said at a private viewing last week, ''it really should be shown on a runway.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * TBWA completed its acquisition of Kurlick Switzer, a St. Louis agency. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Managing Your Money
description: USING computer-based accounting to handle household finances is like using a combine to mow the yard. But there are simpler programs available that manage household, home office or small business finances with relative ease. Three of the best are Quicken, Checkwrite Plus and Managing Your Money. Which one to use depends on which type of user you are.

title: Review/Television; ABC Examines Lives Of Blacks in the U.S.
description: The middle segment of the hourlong three-part report that constitutes ''Black in White America,'' on ABC at 10 tonight, is so strong that it makes the rest of the program seem frivolous by comparison.

title: F.D.A. May Withdraw Another Drug Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration today proposed withdrawing approval of one of the best-selling generic drugs because the agency found irregularities in earlier tests of the compound.

title: Make Concerts in Park Neighborly Once Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Toon Signs Contract And Happily Joins Jets
description: The best thing that could possibly happen to the Jets' offense happened today at their Hofstra University training camp. Al Toon, the gifted receiver, who had not reported to camp, signed a contract this morning, and joined the team for an afternoon workout.

title: Resorts Suspends Bond Payments
description: Resorts International Inc. said yesterday that it had stopped paying interest to its bondholders.

title: Seoul Will Aid Shipbuilders
description: South Korea approved a plan today to revitalize its ailing shipbuilding industry through loans and tax incentives to three companies, including the huge Daewoo Group's debt-ridden shipyard, trade ministry officials said today.

title: PHH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and included net from discontinued operations of $2,433,000.

title: Ally Sought By Plessey
description: The Plessey Company P.L.C., the British electronics group fighting a hostile takeover offer, has disclosed it is seeking an alliance with a leading Japanese semiconductor company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Mike Gold has been named executive vice president, management supervisor of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/ Pacific.

title: Racial Link in Brooklyn Killing Divides the Mayoral Candidates
description: The community response to the racial killing of a black youth in Brooklyn has become an issue in the New York City mayoral election, with candidates clashing over how to keep racial polarization from spreading.

title: Duty Free International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. Sailors Scramble for Sponsors
description: The frantic search by United States sailors for a place in the coming Whitbread Around-the-World Race has spawned campaign efforts that defy all odds.

title: Re-exploring Holes Drilled in Ocean Floor
description: TWO devices, one American and the other French, have successfully found holes drilled earlier into the sea floor under more than two miles of water and have lowered strings of instruments into them.

title: Quarterly Trade Deficit at 4-Year Low
description: The United States trade deficit dropped 2.3 percent in the second quarter, to its lowest level in more than four years, the Government reported today.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball BOSTON (AL) - Placed Wes Gardner, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Activated John Dopson, pitcher, from Pawtucket of the International League. MINNESOTA (AL) - Traded Jim Dwyer, outfielder, to the Montreal Expos for a player to be named later. Called up Tim Drummond, pitcher, from Portland of the Pacific Coast League. Basketball INDIANA (NBA) - Signed Detlef Schrempf, forward, to a multiyear contract. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Traded Maurice Cheeks and David Wingate, guards, and Christian Welp, center, to the San Antonio Spurs for Johnny Dawkins, guard, and Jay Vincent, forward. Football ATLANTA (NFC) - Announced that Rick Donnelly, punter, will undergo back surgery and miss the entire 1989 season. Waived Michael Hooper and Mitch Young, defensive ends; Chris Dunn and Maury Metcalf, linebackers; Charles Martin, nose tackle; Garry Frank, offensive guard; John Thomas, offensive lineman; Chris Clauss, punter; Paul Singer, quarterback; Keith Griffin, running back; Norris Blount and Robert Jones, safeties; Danzell Lee, tight end, and Greg Harris and Paco Craig, wide receivers. CHICAGO (NFC) - Waived Alex Armenteros and George Streeter, defensive backs; John Buddie, defensive end; Joe Nelms and John Kropke, defensive tackles; Greg Gilbert and LaSalle Harper, linebackers; Don Shrader and Mike Husar, offensive guards; Kent Sullivan, punter; Byron Sanders, running back, and Fred Weygand, Mike Sellar, Randy Marriott, Sammie Archer and Tony Buford, wide receivers. Placed Steve O'Malley, defensive tackle, on injured reserve. DENVER (AFC) - Placed Tony Dorsett, running back; Billy Bryan, center; Andrew Provence, nose tackle, and Randy Thornton, linebacker, on injured reserve. Waived Jeremiah Castille, cornerback; Shawn Knight, defensive end; Blake Peterson, linebacker; Matt DeFrank, punter, and Pat Hegarty, quarterback. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Waived Stan Shiver and Thomas King, defensive backs; Doug Bartlett, defensive end; George Cooper, fullback; Tim Inglis and Tim Moore, linebackers; Toby Williams, nose tackle; Scott Kirby and Thomas Flesher, offensive guards; Jeff Lucas, offensive tackle; Brian Shulman, punter; Kerry Brady, place-kicker; Jeff Smith, running back, and Brent Novoselsky, tight end. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Waived John Holt, cornerback; Roy Banks, wide receiver; Jim Thompson, offensive tackle; Aaron Sam, running back, and Jeff Garnica, center. LOS ANGELES (AFC) - Waived Stephen Starring and James Lofton, wide receivers; David Greenwood, defensive back; Clyde Glover, defensive lineman; Linden King and Ron Brown, linebackers; Larry Lee, offensive lineman; Mike Gillette, punter; Anthony Mosley, running back, and Jimmie Giles, tight end. MIAMI (AFC) - Waived Billy Davis and Glenn Holt, wide receivers; Ralph Malone and Scott Mason, defensive ends; Jason Cooper, tight end; Tony Furjanic, linebacker; Steve Gage, defensive back; Mark Royals, punter, and Eric Starr, running back. Placed Charles Bennett and Greg Ross, defensive ends, and Chris Conlin, offensive guard, on injured reserve and Mark Dennis, offensive tackle, on the physically-unable-to-perform list. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Announced that Anthony Carter, wide receiver, has reported to camp. Waived Ryan Bethea, Gary Couch and James Miller, wide receiver; Matthew Fitts, offensive guard; Robert Martz, defensive end; Pat Thompson, punter, and Shawn Woodson, linebacker. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Eric Lindstrom, Boo Merritt and Peter Wilkins, linebackers; Darron Norris and Lon Bankston, running backs; Darryl Darling, defensive lineman; Chuck Pellegrini and Brett Wiese, offensive guards, and Todd White, wide receivers. Placed Aaron Chubb, linebacker, on injured reserve and Russ Francis, tight end, on the physically-unable-to-perform list. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Signed Mike Quick, wide receiver, to a series of three one-year contracts and Matt Darwin, offensive tackle, to a two-year contract.

title: Doctors Find Key Diabetes Molecule
description: RESEARCHERS in Minnesota and Sweden have found a molecule that may be important in the development of the most common variety of diabetes.

title: Maurice C. Dreicer, 78; Was Radio Entertainer
description: Maurice C. Dreicer, a radio personality and program developer who engaged in such novel pursuits as recording a verbal cocktail-mixing manual and pursuing a 40-year search for the perfect steak, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla. He was 78 years old. In the late 1930's and early 40's Mr. Dreicer conducted several news and talk shows over New York City radio stations. He originated ''Where Are You From?'' for WOR. in which a linguist told studio guests where they were born by listening to them talk; ''Find the Phoney,'' the radio predecessor of ''To Tell the Truth,'' and ''What's It Worth?,'' which foreshadowed ''The Price Is Right.''

title: Arts Groups Gird for Battle in Capital
description: While most of Washington has vacated the capital this month, Anne Murphy is working the telephones in a downtown office, preparing for what is expected to be an arduous legislative session for the National Endowment of the Arts.

title: Brown-Forman reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
J. Wallace Hopkins Jr., Energy Executive, 58
description: J. Wallace Hopkins Jr., deputy executive director of the International Energy Agency, died of cancer on Sunday at the American Hospital in Paris. He was 58 years old and lived in Paris. Mr. Hopkins was a legal adviser to the United States State Department for a year before joining the energy agency in 1975.

title: Mail Boxes Etc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Champlain Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ethnic Split Fuels Miami Campaign
description: Fourteen weeks after the death of Representative Claude Pepper, the two candidates for his Congressional seat concluded their campaigns today amid the same air of bitter ethnic division that has dominated the race.

title: Budd Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Imperial Metals reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $1,049,000 for the latest quarter and $3,725,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Deion Sanders 'Fed Up'
description: Deion Sanders, the No. 1 draft choice of the Atlanta Falcons, said he was ''fed up'' with the team's stance in a contract dispute and may sign a long-term contract to play for the Yankees.

title: Bridge
description: The conclusion of a Regional Championship usually features two major team events, but the Split Regional during the past weekend set some kind of record with eight. This occurred because the tournament was held in two locations, and in each there were two levels of knockout as well as two levels of Swiss. Winners in Parsippany, N.J., were: Knockout Teams Flight A, Martin Seligman of Philadelphia, Bob Goldman of Highland Village, Tex., Ruth Stober of Great Neck, L.I., Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., and Richard Colker of Wheaton, Md.; Flight B, Helen Wallach of Spring Valley, N.Y., Barbara Taylor of Amherst, Mass., Paul Bacon of Waldwick, N.J., and Shirley Ladin of Montvale N.J.; Swiss Teams Flight A, Debbie Zuckerberg of Flushing, Queens, Jim Becker, Howard Chandross and Phillip Martin, all of Manhattan; Flight B, Jim Daniel of Edison, N.J., Bonnie Britton of, Staten Island, Michael Lordi of Kenilworth, N.J., and Mark Kinder of Kinnelon, N.J. Winners in Albany were: Knockout Teams, Flight A, Gregg Deitch of Gloversville, N.Y., Al Roth of Guilderland, N.Y., Tony Prindle of Schenectady, N.Y., and Harry Kaufmann of Bennington, Vt.; Flight B, Helmut Augenstein of Warwick, R.I., Peter Nassiff of Framingham, Mass., Edward Boyko of East Providence, R.I., and A. B. Buffington of North Kingstown, R.I.; Swiss Teams Flight A, Pamela and Matt Granovetter of Ballston Spa, N.Y., and Bob and Cindy Bernstein of Auburn Ala.; Flight B, John Talarico, Verne Wooley and R. W. Samsel, all of Pittsfield, Mass., and Renate Redfield of Williamstown, Mass.

title: Petrolite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
East Bloc Could Use an Economic Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Enduring Homage: Cocteau's Last Patron
description: In this domain of canyons by the sea where the art collections of the wealthy are housed in buildings overlooking the surf, the sight of a corporate headquarters that is also a museum of 20th-century art should come as no surprise.

title: Collins Foods reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
Digital to Use Bonding Technology
description: In one of the first important commercial developments by the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it would use the consortium's tape-automated bonding technology to connect silicon processing chips in its computers.

title: Lethal Weapons, or Lifesavers?
description: Iranian researchers tried recently to buy a poison-producing wheat fungus in Canada and the Netherlands. U.S. officials, fearing Iran would turn the material into weapons, stymied the effort. But the Iranians could also have used it to design an antidote, and an American citizen could have lawfully sold it to them. Those are some of the contradictions facing the Bush Administration as it works to stop the spread of biological weapons.

title: Wheaton Journal; Unmarried Couples Sue Over Landlord's Policy
description: Mary Mister and Robert Keene found the perfect apartment in this Chicago suburb last month: two bedrooms, close to work, tons of closet space, $675 a month.

title: Falcon Cable Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
East Bloc Could Use an Economic Community; Finland's Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines; Five Hurt by Debris In Building's Razing
description: Five bystanders were injured Sunday when a former industrial building was deliberately demolished by implosion to make way for a $15 million warehouse.

title: New Executive Team Moves Up at Unisys
description: The Unisys Corporation yesterday named James A. Unruh as president and chief operating officer, putting him in line to succeed W. Michael Blumenthal, the chairman and chief executive In addition, the company named Curtis A. Hessler vice chairman. Mr. Hessler, who had been a senior vice president, will continue as chief financial officer.

title: Save Money: Help the Disabled
description: Astonishingly, it is legal under Federal law for a restaurant to refuse to serve a mentally retarded person, for a theater to deny admission to someone with cerebral palsy, for a dry cleaner to refuse service to someone who is deaf or blind. People with disabilities - the largest minority in the U.S. - were left out of the historic Civil Rights Act of 1964. Twenty-five years later, discrimination against disabled people is still pervasive.

title: Dow Up 11; Other Indicators Also at Highs
description: Stocks survived an early round of selling yesterday to close again at record levels.

title: Davis Water & Waste Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Our Towns; Festival Fosters The Creativity Of Young Artists
description: When Andrew Reed is asked how old he is, he proudly holds up three fingers, one, then another and another, unfolding them with all the care that three years of living deserve. On this day, each finger was a different color, blue, red and purple.

title: Accord in India Halts Drive by Tribal Militants
description: Militant tribal people fighting to set up a separate country in the northeastern state of Assam called off a one-year agitation campaign today after the state government agreed to end its crackdown against militants.

title: Sundstrand Suit Is Revived
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a shareholder lawsuit against the Sundstrand Corporation can be brought to trial, reversing his March ruling that the claims should first be submitted to the company's board, Sundstrand announced today.

title: F.D.I.C. Deputy Leads New Savings Agency
description: David C. Cooke has never worked for a bank, but he knows banks and the banking industry inside out. For all his career, Mr. Cooke has been employed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and now he has been given the job, as chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation, to lead the cleanup of the savings and loan industry.

title: Lynx Revival Plan Set Back by Auto Deaths
description: CARS, not bobcats, are proving to be the greatest enemy of a group of Canadian lynx released in the Adirondack Mountains of New York last winter, wildlife experts say.

title: Fight on Quick Pizza Delivery Grows
description: Critics of a policy of Domino's Pizza Inc. that guarantees delivery within 30 minutes plan to try to hit the company where it hurts this autumn. They are moving their campaign onto college campuses, where take-out pizza is synonymous with study breaks and where the company recruits a large proportion of its drivers.

title: Ties to G.O.P. Are Stressed By Lauder In Campaign
description: On a recent afternoon, the event on Ronald S. Lauder's campaign schedule was a visit to Bellevue South Park, a patch of tree-shaded concrete on 26th Street between First and Second Avenues.

title: Central Co-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Former Senator From the Bronx Is Off the Ballot
description: A Manhattan appeals court has ruled that Israel Ruiz Jr. may not run for reelection to the State Senate because his expulsion from the Senate in May for a Federal felony conviction made him ineligible as a candidate for election to his unexpired term.

title: American Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $713,000, or 5 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
International Rectifier reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest fourth-quarter results included a non-recurring gain of $1 million, while year-ago quarter results included a nonrecurring gain of $1.4 million. Latest full-year results included a gain of $1 million, while the prior year included a nonrecurring gain of $5.6 million.

title: Evolving Theory Views Earth as a Living Organism
description: Two decades ago, a British scientist named James Lovelock put forth an imaginative and poetic view of how the Earth functions. The planet's living organisms, he said, act together to regulate the global environment: Life interacts chemically and physically with the air, the waters and the rocks to maintain optimum conditions for itself.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ammirati Loses Writer To Hal Riney
description: HELAYNE SPIVAK, an award-winning copywriter at Ammirati & Puris, is leaving that agency to become executive creative director of the New York office of Hal Riney & Partners.

title: Chrysler's Progress in Labor Moves
description: The Chrysler Corporation made progress on two labor fronts today, actions that should help increase both its share of the domestic vehicle market and its overall profitability.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro-Football Players Gear Up for Diet Coke
description: Coca-Cola is promoting Diet Coke by corralling the largest number of professional football players ever assembled for an ad campaign. The campaign, which starts next week, will feature 31 players from the National Football League, including stars like Boomer Esiason of the Cincinatti Bengals and Eric Dickerson of the Indianapolis Colts.

title: To Buoy Premier, Solidarity Urges a Halt to Strikes
description: Solidarity plans to begin an effort to support the new Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, by appealing to workers for a moratorium of at least six months on work stoppages.

title: Healthco Holding Disclosed in Filing
description: Two investment firms have acquired a combined 8.2 percent stake in Healthco International Inc., a Boston-based dental supply concern. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the firms, led by the same chairman, Gerald B. Cramer, said the stake was purchased for investment purposes. Marvin M. Cyker, Healthco's chairman and chief executive, declined to comment on the filing.

title: Two Palestinians Die in Uprising; Strife Flares at Jerusalem Funeral
description: Two Palestinians died today of wounds sustained in clashes with Israeli soldiers and policemen, and four policemen and a television cameraman were wounded when a demonstration by Arab mourners in Jerusalem turned into a melee, the police and the army said.

title: Shortage Grows As Strike Starts At Blood Center
description: About 400 hospital workers started a four-day strike yesterday at the New York Blood Center, forcing hospitals throughout the metropolitan region to consider curtailing some elective surgery.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $14,240,000 and a gain of $1,800,000 from an accounting change.

title: Q&A
description: The Dial Tone Q.Why is the dial tone an A on the musical scale all over the country? A.It isn't really a pure A, but a composite of two frequencies: 350 hertz, or cycles per second, and 440 hertz, American Telephone and Telegraph Company spokesmen said; most symphony orchestras tune to an A of about 440 hertz.

title: Business and Health; The Pressure On Generic Drugs
description: MANY of the major pharmaceutical companies want it both ways. Although they have moved aggressively to produce low-priced generic versions of drugs whose patent protection has expired, some of them campaign vigorously against the generics when their own more profitable brands are threatened.

title: Patterns
description: Wanted: Senior fashion director. Must be willing to make six-figure income, travel to London, Paris and Milan, Italy, at least twice a year, stay at chic hotels, eat in the finest restaurants. Should love clothes and have great style while being a good corporate soldier. Prefer candidate not wear Chanel in public.

title: U.S. at World Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Poland's Primate Denounces Jews In Dispute on Auschwitz Convent
description: Asserting bitterly that national sovereignty and the ''feelings of all Poles'' are under attack, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate has accused Jews of fomenting anti-Polish feeling by objecting to a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Broadview Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank said the current year second quarter results were affected by a $9,758,000 provisionj for possible loan and real estate losses, higher money costs and the continuing effect of foregone interest on non-earning real estate assets.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION PLENARY - 3 P.M. LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M. and 3:30 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Giants Waive Welch and 6 Others
description: Last summer, Herb Welch tore a knee ligament on the first day of training camp, underwent reconstructive surgery and sat out the season. Today, though the fifth-year safety had made an amazing recovery, he was one of seven players waived by the Giants.

title: Mayoral Rivals Face Questions: Health and Hospitals
description: In separate interviews last month, The New York Times asked the six New York City mayoral candidates to discuss some of the major problems facing the city in 1989 and how they would deal with them. This is the second of six articles comparing their responses. Excerpts from the interviews appear [ below ] .

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Viola Defeats Hershiser in First Duel of Cy Young Winners
description: The Mets ended their losing streak at five games in high style tonight when Frank Viola outpitched Orel Hershiser and stopped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 1-0, with a performance that was three singles short of perfect.

title: Tourism Plan In France Fails
description: Efforts to form Europe's third-largest tourism company broke down today, as officials of the companies involved -Club Med Inc. and the air-charter group, Nouvelles Frontieres S.A. - backed away from a preliminary agreement reached in April. Under the accord, Club

title: KEY RATES
New Jersey Factory to Create Coffee Cups and Industrialists
description: Even as New Jersey's traditional mills and foundries waste away, a factory of the future is rising here.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Capitol Tune, a Precision Tune franchise in Washington, to DDB Needham, with a budget of $1 million.

title: Police Arrest Sixth Suspect In Racial Attack in Brooklyn
description: A sixth suspect was arrested last night in the killing of 16-year-old Yusef Hawkins in a racial attack in Brooklyn last week as investigators continued to examine the possibility that the suspected gunman, Joseph Fama, has fled to Italy.

title: For Babies, 'Liquid Air' May Spare Fragile Lungs
description: IN a dramatic effort to save a premature baby, doctors in Philadelphia recently put an oxygen-carrying liquid into the baby's lungs to give them a rest from breathing air. Although the baby died 19 hours after ''breathing'' the liquid, the procedure promises to renew interest in the issue of how early a premature baby can be delivered and still survive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8, A10-11 Baltic Communists straddled the line between the Kremlin's demand for restraint and local cries for more radical changes in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Page A1

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss of $71.0 million from discontinued operations. c-Included income of $8.1 million and $38.7 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: Prosecutor Paints Picture of a Greedy Jim Bakker
description: Jim Bakker used his P.T.L. television ministry to ''cheat people out of their money,'' Federal prosecutors said today in opening arguments in the former evagelist's trial on fraud and conspiracy charges.

title: Remarks Made by Giamatti Leave Rose 'Dumbfounded'
description: Pete Rose feels that he was double-crossed by A. Bartlett Giamatti because of the commissioner's public statement that he believed Rose had bet on baseball.

title: BIRTH OF GALAXY SEEN IN GAS CLOUD
description: Astronomers have discovered what they believe is a galaxy in the throes of birth, the first such proto-galaxy to be found in a state of gestation, researchers at Cornell University and the Arecibo radiotelescope in Puerto Rico said today.

title: Needs of Civil Society
description: There was a meeting in early August at Pope John Paul II's summer palace in Castel Gandolfo on civil society and what it means. It isn't a new concept, but it has a new immediacy and importance as people in various parts of the world come to grips with the wrenching problems of transformation and advancing humane values.

title: Automotive Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Latest quarter and 9 months included a $1,390,000 charge to provide for the anticipated costs of closing certain facilities.

title: Arthur Schoenhaut, Former U.S. Official, 64
description: Arthur Schoenhaut, a retired Federal official, died of a heart attack Saturday at Peninsula General Hospital in Salisbury, Md. He was 64 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Fortune Financial In Standstill Plan
description: A private New York-based investment firm that owns 9.6 percent of the Fortune Financial Group said that the board of the savings and loan holding company would allow it to raise its stake to 24.9 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the investment group, the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, said the agreement was subject to the signing of a standstill agreement.

title: Wellington Leisure Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: The company said share earnings reflect a public offering of 819,945 shares in December 1988.

title: Empire Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When the Rapist Is Not a Stranger: Studies Seek New Understanding
description: RESEARCHERS trying to understand the relative frequency of rape between acquaintances are focusing their attention on the radical differences in how men and women interpret each other's interest in a sexual encounter.

title: N.F.L. to Announce Suspensions for Steroids Today
description: The National Football League said today that approximately two dozen active players had tested positive for anabolic steroids in training camp and would be suspended for a month.

title: Dr. C. L. Fox Jr., 81, Creative Microbiologist
description: Dr. Charles Lewis Fox Jr., a microbiologist who developed a widely used treatment for severe burns, died of a heart embolism yesterday at New Milford (Conn.), Hospital. He was 81 years old and had homes in Sherman, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Income Opportunity Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rep. Frank Asks For Full Inquiry By Ethics Panel
description: Representative Barney Frank today asked the House ethics committee to investigate his relationship with a male prostitute who operated from the Congressman's town house on Capitol Hill.

title: Tampa, Hoping to Lure Tourists, Joins Rush to Build Aquarium
description: Officials here have announced plans for an $84 million aquarium that would be among the largest in the world.

title: Co-Operative Bank of Conord reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter results included a one-time expense of $1,128,000 from the restructuring of the company and settlement of certain employment agreements.

title: How Convent Became Focus Of a Dispute
description: Five years ago, a group of Carmelite nuns moved into a building on the perimeter of the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp site. The convent was designated a place of prayer and meditation for the souls of the millions who died there at the hands of the Nazis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People in the Baltics are indignant about what happened.

title: Canada Pork Ruling in U.S.
description: An independent Government agency that investigates trade issues ruled today that subsidized exports of Canadian pork financially injure American hog producers.

title: Glum Mood at Cambodian Talks
description: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France called on ministers from 19 nations today to make one last effort to agree to a peace plan before a monthlong conference on Cambodia ends on Wednesday.

title: A Leader of the Arab Revolt Is Killed in Gaza
