description: A Palestinian identified by relatives as a leader of the uprising in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip was killed today in a clash with soldiers, witnesses said.

title: Court Curbs Dallas News
description: The Dallas Times Herald was granted a temporary restraining order on Monday that forbids its rival, The Dallas Morning News, from publishing syndicated cartoons and columns, including the Far Side and Dear Abby, that now appear in The Times Herald.

title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job
description: The Jet careers of two young players, Bobby Riley, a receiver, and Vince Amoia, a running back, came to an end today when they were suspended for testing positive for steroid use.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Smuggled Rights Report Indicts Ceausescu
description: A denunciation of the Rumanian Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, smuggled out of Bucharest by a former Rumanian official, is causing a stir at a meeting of human rights specialists here.

title: 'Auld Firms' Break Down Old Barrier
description: When Sal Maglie came over from Cleveland in 1956, there was some question whether he would be accepted by Brooklyn fans or by Carl Furillo, at whose rugged skull Maglie had pitched a few baseballs in his time.

title: Evert's Farewell Will Have To Wait
description: The clouds stopped spritzing, there was a hush between planes, and Chris Evert, dressed in purple, made a regal entrance to her 19th and final United States Open yesterday afternoon accompanied by the comforting swell of a standing ovation.

title: Lower Rating For Australia
description: Moody's Investors Service has cut Australia's credit rating to AA-2, from AA-1, but the news was largely brushed aside today by Government officials and people in the financial markets.

title: Silver Worth $200,000 Stolen From a Mine
description: Investigators frustrated by a bold theft from a mine of more than a ton of silver shaped like chocolate kisses are hoping the thieves brag, and they are watching smelters capable of melting it down.

title: First Cuban-American Elected to Congress
description: Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Cuban-born Republican state legislator, was the winner tonight in the race for the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of Representative Claude Pepper, a Democrat who had held the seat for 26 years.

title: To Make Bottle Redemption Workable, Set Up a Reward System
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Too Far With the Winfrey Diet
description: An editor of TV Guide said yesterday that diet or no diet, Oprah Winfrey's head does not belong on Ann-Margret's body.

title: Crime Is the Crucial Issue for New York's Mayoral Rivals
description: For politicians seeking support, crime plays. Each of the six major party candidates for mayor of New York City has made crime prevention and punishment the cornerstone of his campaign, although some of their siren songs may be more apt to capture votes than criminals.

title: Illinois School to Extend Drug Tests to All Interscholastic Activities
description: The school board here has endorsed a plan to test students for drugs in all interscholastic activities, from the marching band to the math team.

title: E. Gail Macandrew; TV Producer Was 45
description: E. Gail Macandrew, a producer for public television, died of complications from diabetes on Friday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. She was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Garden City, L.I.

title: Satellite in Star Study Is a Failure, Italy Says
description: An Italian satellite launched to collect data on the stars has failed to reach orbit, an official here said today, and the authorities are prepared to ask the European Space Agency for funds for a second satellite.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No more drug trafficking, no more war, no more assassinations, no more bombs, no more arson. Let's sit down and talk.'' - Fabio Ochoa Restrepo, patriarch of a cocaine clan, to Colombia's president, Virgilio Barco Vargas. [ A1:6. ]

title: Lorenzo Said To Have Met With Trump
description: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, has met privately several times over the last month with Donald J. Trump in an effort to persuade him to buy Continental Airlines, executives from both sides said yesterday.

title: Layoffs at Norsk
description: The Norwegian computer concern Norsk Data A.S., which had reported a loss in the first half of the year, said it would cut another 600 jobs by the end of the year as part of its plan to shrink the company. Norsk cut 800 jobs earlier this year.

title: Sheriff Doubts Copter Scuffle
description: A sheriff said today that a wounded and handcuffed Canadian fugitive had been strapped to a stretcher aboard a medical helicopter and that it was therefore doubtful that he had caused the crash late Sunday that killed him and the three crew members.

title: Suns Pact for Battle
description: Kenny Battle, a first-round choice acquired by the Phoenix Suns in a draft-day trade with the Detroit Pistons, signed a two-year contract yesterday with the Suns for an estimated $350,000 in his first season and $375,000 in his second. The 6-foot-6-inch Battle, known for his aggressive, hustling defense, is expected to replace Tyrone Corbin, the Suns' small forward, who was claimed by Minnesota in the expansion draft in June.(AP)

title: Amdura Offers Dissenters a Role
description: The Amdura Corporation, a Denver hardware distribution company, has offered to expand its eight-member board to include two representatives of the New York investment group Cilluffo Associates, which owns 18.6 percent of Amdura's shares.

title: In Apartheid Protest, Lutherans to Divest Millions
description: Leaders of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America have voted to divest $84.9 million in pension money in companies doing business in South Africa, but pension board officials say they may not be able to comply with with the 1991 deadline.

title: U. of Vermont President To Head Arizona State
description: Lattie F. Coor will leave here in December as president of the University of Vermont to become president of Arizona State University, in Tempe.

title: World and U.S. Growth Estimates
description: The International Monetary Fund has cut its estimates for United States and world economic growth this year, monetary sources said today.

title: Sales of New Homes Rose 14.4% Last Month
description: Bolstered by falling mortgage rates, sales of new homes rose by 14.4 percent in July, the fastest pace in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said today. The steep increase also reflected a downward revision in June sales.

title: Prague Sentences Dissident
description: A court today sentenced a prominent dissident, Stanislav Devaty, to 20 months in prison for backing a petition calling for democracy, the Charter 77 human rights group said. Mr. Devaty, 37 years old, was convicted by a court in Gottwaldov of incitement and verbally abusing a police officer.

title: Muslims Hit Tanker Near Beirut, Killing at Least 7 Crew Members
description: An oil tanker bound for a Christian port north of Beirut was set on fire today by shelling from Syrian and Lebanese Muslim positions, the Lebanese police said.

title: Strong Growth in Quarter Viewed As Sign Economy No Longer Lags
description: In a widely expected upward revision, the Commerce Department reported today that the economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, considerably higher than the 1.7 percent rate estimated last month.

title: LeMond Outdistancing Pack On the Financial Front, Too
description: Five years after he signed a contract that revolutionized the salary scale in professional cycling, Greg LeMond is ready to repeat the feat. ''It's a very good contract,'' he said with a soft laugh about the reported $1.5 million-a-year offer. ''More than I ever expected.''

title: Ardent Computer Link To Stellar Is Disclosed
description: In the face of slow sales and a keenly competitive market for the most powerful computer work stations, Ardent Computer Inc. and Stellar Computer Inc., will announce merger plans today, company executives said.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Four years ago, when a group of public school teachers from isolated rural districts and small towns came together here to reminisce about their experience at the Bread Loaf School of English, one of them said: ''I was able to find my own voice. I now own myself.''

title: Cardinals' Lomax Out For the Entire Season
description: The Phoenix Cardinals placed Neil Lomax on the injured-reserve list yesterday, making the two-time Pro Bowl quarterback ineligible to play with the team this season.

title: Gazpacho: Theme And Variations
description: VINE-RIPENED tomatoes, bursting with flavor and succulence, are at their peak around about now, but many gardeners have more fresh tomatoes than they know what to do with.

title: Rijo's Season Is Over
description: A bone scan undergone by the Cincinnati Reds' pitcher Jose Rijo yesterday revealed a stress fracture in his spine that the team said would keep him out for the rest of the season.

title: Fernanda Kellogg, 69, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Fernanda Wanamaker Munn Kellogg, a philanthropist interested in wildlife, conservation and other concerns, died of heart failure Sunday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 69 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Lessons
description: Until recently, questioning the value of advanced placement courses in high schools was tantamount to knocking Bambi or Snow White.

title: Dramatists Guild Writes A Contract for Its Members
description: The Dramatists Guild announced yesterday that it had drawn up a contract that its 7,000 American and British members are expected to use when their plays are produced in playhouses associated with the League of Resident Theaters.

title: Bursa Journal; Turks Are Back Among the Minarets, but as Exiles
description: In better days, six centuries ago, this city of sultry breezes and minarets was the capital of the Ottoman Empire.

title: No Headline
description: NOT long ago, skyscrapers sprouted on the Columbus horizon, finally dwarfing the double Ferris wheel at the Ohio State Fair. Sprawling below, the midway that was once rutted and dusty was given a wide swath of asphalt. Thirty-two acres of corrals were roofed; most were air-conditioned. ''The fair doesn't smell the same as it did,'' said Dorthea Burkhardt, who at age 78 has been going to the Ohio State Fair since 1929.

title: When Fizzies Left, So Did the Sparkle
description: WHEN I was a child and my family had a house on the Jersey Shore, summer was a time of long days at the beach, secret hiding places and fireflies we would catch in a jar. But the best treat of all was piling into my father's car on Saturday night and going to the Dairy Queen, where I always ordered a shake so thick it was impossible to slurp through a straw. It was called a Blizzard.

title: Imperiled Colombian Pleads for Drug Aid
description: Colombia's Justice Minister asked the State Department today for $14 million more in assistance to protect judges and court officials from assassination by drug traffickers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES U.S. Defeats Soviets: The United States won its first major men's international basketball competition in three years yesterday with an 88-80 victory over the Soviet Union in the gold medal game of the World University Games at Duisburg, West Germany.

title: Down Melancholy Lane
description: Do you ever think about 1903? I don't except when the 1989 news is full of anniversaries. Then I remember what the old folks always said.

title: Mexico to Get Citibank Loans
description: John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, says Citibank will offer loans to Mexico as part of the debt restructuring and reduction plan agreed to last month.

title: 50 Years After Europe Plunged Into Hell
description: LEAD: The following letter, excerpted here, was sent Aug. 23 by Richard von Weizsacker, West Germany's President, to Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's President. As a 19-year-old, Mr. Weizsacker participated in Hitler's invasion of Poland; his older brother Heinrich was killed on the second day of the invasion.

title: Addenda
description: * Manning, Selvage & Lee has acquired Intercommunication Ltd., a British travel marketing and public relations firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Edith Park Martin, 72, Needlework Authority
description: Edith Park Martin, an authority on contemporary needlework, died Saturday at Northern Westchester County Hospital after a brief illness. She was 72 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y.

title: John Cotter, 85, Dies; A Hardware Executive
description: John M. Cotter, who began working in a Minnesota hardware store as a clerk and later founded the True Value hardware chain, died of cancer on Monday. He was 85 years old and lived in Evanston.

title: CAMBODIA TALKS SAID TO COLLAPSE
description: A monthlong international conference aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia appears to have collapsed, with officials predicting today that there will be large-scale fighting between the warring Cambodian factions before serious negotations can resume.

title: Review/Television; Of the Rise in Violent Crimes Committed by Women
description: It has long been murmured, no doubt unjustly, that some reformers who undertake the redemption of wayward women may not always be moved by the purest impulses. This canard comes to mind while watching ''Bad Girls,'' an NBC News special being shown at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Review/Film; Shirley Valentine Talks With Others
description: A heroine whose dialogue can be packaged in a tiny publicity pamphlet called ''The Wit and Wisdom of Shirley Valentine'' is probably spouting shallow aphorisms rather than anything witty or wise. Banality is precisely the problem with ''Shirley Valentine,'' the one-woman stage play that has been turned into a misguided, fully cast film.

title: Beach Fee Revision Is Ordered
description: Beach fees in the Monmouth County town of Belmar are excessive and discriminatory, a judge ruled today in a decision that could affect how much other seashore communities charge for access to the ocean.

title: Kohlberg In Dispute Over Firm
description: In a legal skirmish that pits one founder of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the world's largest leveraged buyout firm, against the other two, Jerome Kohlberg Jr. filed suit yesterday against Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, accusing them of enriching themselves at his expense.

title: Lincoln Inquiry Reopening Due
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee said today that he would reopen his panel's investigation of the failure of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which is expected to require the Government's largest savings-institution rescue. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, said that the collapse of the savings and loan assocation, based in Irvine, Calif., was a ''mini-Watergate'' and that his committee had suspended its inquiry only to pass emergency legislation to help the savings and loan industry.

title: Sea Containers May Be a Buyer
description: Sea Containers Ltd. said it had held talks about buying an unidentified company that is ''complementary to certain of Sea Containers's current operations.'' In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sea Containers said there was no assurance that an agreement would be reached.

title: How About Taxing Pension Fund Profits?
description: Should we tax pension funds? If a tax could be designed to counter the funds' bias toward short-term investment, it should be strongly considered.

title: Strong Unions Can Exercise Wage Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Alabama is tentatively offering $351.4 million in zero-coupon general obligation refunding bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The capital appreciation bonds, which pay no interest to the bondholder, are priced to yield from 7 percent for an issue due in 2000 to 7.35 percent in 2002 and 7.40 percent in 2003 through 2008.

title: Eating Well
description: ''LOSE weight safely and quickly without cutting calories - or even counting them.'' That is the promise of ''The T-Factor Diet'' by Martin Katahn (W. W. Norton, $18.95), a best-selling diet book. Dr. Katahn, a psychologist, maintains that as long as you reduce the fat in your diet to about 20 percent of total calories, you can eat as much food as you want and still lose weight.

title: Politics
description: Members of Congress are loath to accept criticism, especially from those they thought they had helped. Small wonder, then, that some appear ready to wash their hands of the problems of the elderly.

title: Top Yield 7.25% For Illinois Issue
description: Illinois yesterday priced a $70 million bond issue through competitive bidding. It was awarded to an underwriting group led by First Chicago Capital Markets Inc.

title: O'Connor Deplores Remarks by Poland's Primate
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, disassociated himself yesterday from the remarks of the Catholic Primate of Poland, who was critical of Jews for objecting to a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Shriver Plays Sloppily And Loses
description: The capitulation was shockingly casual, and so the explanation for it afterward was agonizingly involved.

title: A's Crush Yankees With 10 In the 5th
description: The door to the manager's office remained closed. Behind it, Bucky Dent sorted out another day and another defeat, this one the most agonizing in the 12 days he has been the Yankee manager.

title: Bankruptcy Filing For Aladdin Hotel
description: Ginji Yasuda, the Japanese businessman, filed Monday to put his ailing Aladdin Hotel under Federal bankruptcy protection, citing debt that outstripped the resort's assets by more than $38 million.

title: U.N. Demands End of Namibia Police Unit
description: The Security Council adopted a resolution today demanding strict compliance, ''especially by South Africa,'' with the United Nations independence plan for Namibia and the disbanding of all paramilitary forces in the territory, particularly a unit whose members are accused of pre-election harassment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 8 about the effect of Medicaid cutbacks on Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford misstated the percentage of its patients enrolled in Medicaid, the Federal health insurance for the poor. Medicaid insures 20 percent of Mount Sinai's patients; an additional 8 percent have no insurance.

title: Billy Wilder Decides to Sell Some of His Art Collection
description: ''I wanted the fun of having empty walls for once,'' Billy Wilder joked. So the 83-year-old director has arranged to sell 94 paintings and sculptures from his personal collection at an auction at Christie's in New York in November.

title: Hostile Bidder Raises Dunkin' Donuts Offer
description: A Canadian partnership raised its hostile bid today for Dunkin' Donuts Inc. to $308 million despite a lawsuit pending in Delaware Chancery Court.

title: G.M. Cutbacks
description: The General Motors Corporation said it plans to lay off 600 assembly line workers in November at its Arlington plant, a union official said. The G.M. plant builds the Chevrolet Caprice, the Cadillac Brougham and Chevrolet, Buick and Oldsmobile station wagons.

title: Maurice C. Dreicer, 78; Was Radio Entertainer
description: Maurice C. Dreicer, a radio personality and program developer who engaged in such novel pursuits as recording a verbal cocktail-mixing manual and pursuing a 40-year search for the perfect steak, died of cancer last Wednesday at his home in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla. He was 78 years old. In the late 1930's and early 40's Mr. Dreicer conducted several news and talk shows over New York City radio stations. He originated ''Where Are You From?'' for WOR. in which a linguist told studio guests where they were born by listening to them talk; ''Find the Phoney,'' the radio predecessor of ''To Tell the Truth,'' and ''What's It Worth?,'' which foreshadowed ''The Price Is Right.''

title: Boeing to Cut Aerospace Jobs
description: Boeing Aerospace and Electronics, a unit of the Boeing Company, has told employees it will eliminate about 800 secretaries, engineers and managers from its space and missile programs.

title: Strong Unions Can Exercise Wage Restraint; A Negative Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Schlumberger In Joint Venture
description: Schlumberger Ltd., a large industrial concern, and the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation of Japan announced they were forming a company to develop advanced testing for integrated circuits. Schlumberger said that under the terms of the agreement, the concern, called Verisys, would develop, manufacture and market the testing systems worldwide.

title: Alaska Airlines Head Seeking Soviet Link
description: Bruce Kennedy, the 51-year-old chairman and chief executive of Alaska Airlines, believes it is the manifest destiny of his company and Alaskans who have ties of kinship and history to the Soviet Union to establish an air link across the Bering Strait.

title: Cairo Accused of Torturing 52 Seized During Strike
description: Egyptian rights campaigners accused the authorities today of beating and torturing a group of 52 journalists, lawyers, students and workers detained after a strike at the country's biggest steel plant.

title: Louisiana Opens Door To College for the Poor
description: A virtual one-man crusade by a New Orleans oil company owner to extend free public education beyond high school for the academically prepared will benefit more than 1,000 Louisiana freshman this fall.

title: INSIDE
description: What's New? (Not the Dots) Man in the Midwest says he's got a new knot; neckwear authorities agree. The Living Section, page C1. Brooklyn Bishop Questions Marches to Protest Killing Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn wondered ''what was accomplished'' by marches protesting the racial killing of a black youth in Bensonhurst. Page B1. Afghan Rebel Infighting The Afghan rebels show no signs of ending bitter internal feuds that severely limit their chances of defeating the Kabul Government. Page A8. Victory for Rafsanjani Iran's Parliament approved the new President's Cabinet, disappointing hard-liners and possibly indicating more pragmatic policies. Page A3. Labor Turmoil in Mexico By closing the nation's largest mine, the Government has set off a strike by thousands of miners. Page D1. Setback for Colorado Dam The Government took another step toward killing the disputed Two Forks dam project. Page A14. Another Yankee Departure Syd Thrift, the Yankees' senior vice president for baseball operations, resigned after just five months in the position. Page D19.

title: Books of The Times; How One Good Teacher Can Matter
description: Among Schoolchildren By Tracy Kidder Houghton Mifflin. 340 pages. $19.95.

title: People
description: * Nancy Budd has joined BBDO Los Angeles as a senior vice president and management supervisor.

title: Failure Data Show a Drop
description: Business failures fell by 14.5 percent in the first half of 1989, the biggest drop in more than 10 years, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation says in a report that suggests the economy is not tumbling into recession.

title: 'Into the Woods' to Close
description: ''Into the Woods,'' a musical based on fairy tales with music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, will close at the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, after Sunday's matinee performance. Written and directed by James Lapine, the show will have played 43 previews and 764 regular performances.

title: KEY RATES
Metropolitan Life Backs Oil Merger
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it supports the Dallas-based Harken Energy Corporation's proposed merger with the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation. Last week, Harken offered to pay Tesoro shareholders $11.75 a share in cash, or about $190 million. The insurance company owns about 25 percent of Tesoro, which is based in San Antonio.

title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison
description: In a red brick house on the grounds of a community health center here, Massachusetts is experimenting with a way to break a cycle of crime and drug use before it is passed on to a new generation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, a provider of insurance, health care and employee benefits, completed the sale of its Horace Mann insurance companies to a new corporation formed by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a private investment banking firm. The sale price was put at $484 million.

title: Mercenaries Shown Training Drug Gangs
description: The videotape flickers on the screen showing Colombians in combat gear, directed by Israeli mercenaries, conducting mock raids on houses, breaking up ambushes and attacking across an open field in infantry formation.

title: Bogota's Hottest Tour: Pleasure Domes of the Cartels
description: For years, Colombians walked quickly past the forbidding walls and unblinking electric eyes guarding estates of the nation's cocaine cartels. But with the police raids of the last 10 days, the gates have swung open.

title: Wanted by the U.S.: 12 From Colombia
description: Among the Colombian drug-trafficking suspects being sought for extradition to the United States are these 12 men, described by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh as the ''dozen most wanted.'' PABLO EMILIO ESCOBAR GAVIRIA ''The Godfather'' Age: 39 Considered the leader of the Medellin cartel. Has created good will for the cartel in Medellin by donating money to the poor. Believed to be worth $2 billion. Indictments: Three in Miami, one in Los Angeles. JORGE LUIS OCHOA VASQUEZ ''The Fat One'' Age: 40 Considered the No. 2 man in the Medellin cartel, he is the leader of a group of brothers who belong to the Ochoa family of smugglers. Believed to be a billionaire. Indictments: Two in Miami. FABIO OCHOA VASQUEZ Age: 32 A leader of the Medellin cartel, he was entrusted with cocaine distribution in Miami in the 1970's. Borther of Jorge Luis Ochoa Vasquez. Indicted in New Orleans in the murder of an informer. Indictments: Miami, New Orleans. JAIME RAUL ORJUELA CABALLERO Age: 46 Among the leaders of the Cali cartel. Indictment: Brooklyn. GILBERTO JOSE RODRIQUEZ Age: 50 Considered the leader of the Cali cartel. Indictments: Manhattan, Los Angeles, New Orleans, Miami. MIGUEL ANGEL RODRIQUEZ ORJUELA Age: 45 Considered the No. 2 man in the Cali cartel. Indictment: New Orleans. JOSE GONZALO RODRIQUEZ GACHA ''The Mexican'' Age: 42 Considered the No. 3 man in the Medellin cartel. Indictments: Miami, Detroit. JOSE SANTACRUZ LONDONO Age: 45 Considered the third-ranking member of the Cali cartel. Indictment: Manhattan. JOSE DUARTE ACERO Age: 37 One of the leading figures in the Medellin cartel, he is believed to have been a gunman involved in the 1981 abduction and attempted murder of two Drug Enforcement Admnistration officers. Indictment: Miami. GERARDO MONCADA Age:42 A top member of the Medellin cartel believed to be deeply involved in money laundering. Indictment: Atlanta. JUAN DAVID OCHOA VASQUEZ Age: 41 Older brother and a top lieutenant to Jorge Luis Ochoa Vasquez in the Medellin cartel. Indictment: Miami. GUSTAVO DE JESUS GAVIRIA RIVERO Age: 42 Among the leaders of the Medellin cartel. Indictment: Miami. Source: Drug Enforcement Administration

title: Plant Cited in Canyon Haze
description: The Environmental Protection Agency concluded today that a nearby coal-fired power plant causes up to 70 percent of the air pollution over the Grand Canyon. The agency said it expected a final decision by February on how to curb emissions from the plant, the Navajo Generating Station in Page, Ariz. The operators have argued that much of the pollution comes from elsewhere.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Bicentennial; Curtain Up on Celebration
description: The 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights is two years away, but as part of its preparation for the celebration the National Archives has hit on a dramatic idea: to commission a play.

title: Feliks Topolski, 82, a War Artist
description: Feliks Topolski, a Polish-born artist and writer who painted battle scenes and portraits of British royalty for the Government, died Thursday. He was 82 years old and had heart trouble and diabetes.

title: Alan Hevesi for Comptroller
description: New Yorkers, distracted by the mayoral race, haven't been paying much attention to the campaign for city comptroller. Too bad. They're missing something. The race includes four high quality candidates, each of whom could do the job. The best is Alan Hevesi.

title: Scholars Creating Archives of China Unrest
description: Scholars and universities around the world are setting up archives to collect pamphlets, posters and other items created during the democracy movement in China last spring.

title: Treasury Debt Prices Hold Steady
description: Treasury note and bond prices were unchanged to slightly higher yesterday in very light trading, as two economic reports were met with little enthusiasm by credit market participants.

title: Algeria Bars Israel Role in Poison-Gas Talks
description: Algeria has blocked the admission of Israel to an international conference negotiating a ban on the making and possession of chemical arms, diplomats said today.

title: Iran's President Wins Approval of His Entire Cabinet
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran won a major triumph and cemented his political authority today when Parliament approved his entire list for the first new Cabinet since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Dinkins Reveals a 1985 Heart Attack
description: David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, was hospitalized for four days in January 1985 after suffering a mild heart attack, his doctor said in a statement released yesterday.

title: What the Mayor Didn't Say
description: Mayor Edward Koch of New York has always had a troubling propensity for sending the wrong message. He did that again Monday, in the wake of the racial murder in Bensonhurst.

title: High School Experiment? No! State Pollution Study
description: Atop lampposts on West 65th Street near Avery Fisher and Alice Tully Halls sit a conglomeration of instruments that look like a high school science fair experiment.

title: Food Notes
description: Picnic Fare

title: John H. Steinway Is Dead at 72; Headed Family's Piano Concern
description: John Howland Steinway, the retired chairman of Steinway & Sons piano makers, died yesterday at the Jordan Hospital in Plymouth, Mass. The cause of death was not immediately available, but Mr. Steinway, who was 72 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Plymouth, had had cancer surgery several weeks ago.

title: Gerald J. Weber, Federal Judge, 75
description: Gerald J. Weber, a retired United States District Court judge who was the chief Federal judge in western Pennsylvania from 1976 to 1982, died of cancer on Monday. He was 75 years old and lived in Erie.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about perils facing left-handed people misstated the affiliation of Dr. Diane Halpern. She is at California State University at San Bernardino.

title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY
description: With a Government crackdown continuing, leaders of two of Colombia's largest cocaine rings have offered to get out of the drug trade in return for an amnesty and truce in Colombia's war on drugs.

title: Cubs Rally From 9-0 to Stun Astros
description: Dwight Smith hit a base-loaded single in the 10th inning today to cap the Chicago Cubs' rally from a 9-0 deficit to a 10-9 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Florida Seeks Boating Limits For Its Congested Waterways
description: The abundance of sun, water, money and newcomers in this state has brought an explosion in the number of boats, jamming waterways and sharply increasing boating accidents and deaths.

title: Bus Bomb in Assam Kills 12 Despite Truce
description: Tribal militants detonated a bomb in a bus in northeast India today, killing at least 12 passengers a day after tribal leaders agreed to suspend a campaign of separatist violence, news reports said.

title: Kellogg May Use Disputed Ingredient
description: The Kellogg Company is expected to become the second manufacturer to introduce a cereal containing psyllium, an ingredient that led to a dispute this summer over advertising claims made for a General Mills cereal. Kellogg is expected to announce its new cereal at a news conference in Manhattan this morning.

title: Rejoining the Chapters Of Yiddish Life's Story
description: This is a tale of two cities, and of a sundered literary collection finally on the way to a reunification that until recently seemed impossible.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 Two Colombia drug kings would quit the drug business in exchange for amnesty and a cease-fire in the nation's war on drugs, they say. The appeals became public as bombs shook Colombia's two largest cities. Page A1 Drug traffickers have lived well in Columbia. Recent police raids have found homes containing marble corridors and gold-plated faucets, along with a stable of prize-winning walking horses. A10 Imperiled Colombian appeals to U.S. for anti-drug funds A10 Mexico closed its largest mine, spurring nationwide criticism and setting off a strike by several thousand copper mine workers. D1 Cambodian peace talks are faltering, and officials predict large-scale fighting between the warring factions before negotations can resume. A1 Afghan rebels have been hampered in their efforts to capture Kabul and other Government-held cities by internal rivalries. In a recent attack, 31 rebels, including seven commanders, were killed by fellow rebels. A8 Iran's President gained approval from Parliament for his entire Cabinet. Diplomats say that the action gives him a mandate to pursue new policies toward the West. A3 Muslims hit tanker near Beirut, killing at least seven A6 Cairo accused of torturing 52 seized during strike A12 Moscow's scolding of Baltic lands for their nationalistic clamor was approved by President Gorbachev, an official said. A statement critical of Baltic politics had been issued in the name of the Central Committee. A3 Rights report smuggled out of Rumania indicts Ceausescu A13 O'Connor deplores remarks by Poland's Primate A5 Bulgarians fleeing to Turkey are often settling in Bursa, a historic city where aging mosques and monuments stand beside factories and other modern intrusions. A4 Japan's leader will visit the U.S. this week to offer assurances about the country's dependability and its willingness to negotiate thorny trade and security disputes. A9 Japanese banks plan merger to cope with a new world D1 National A14-24 The economy grew by 2.7 percent in the second quarter, considerably higher than the 1.7 percent annual rate estimated by the Government last month. A1 A proposal for a $1 billion dam for the South Platte River near Denver was criticized by a regional E.P.A. officer, who said that it would ruin one of the West's premier fishing and recreational areas. A14 Pressure to restrict Florida boating is growing. A sharp increase boating-related accidents and deaths has prompted officials to contemplate a 30-mile-an-hour speed limit and mandatory training courses. A1 Central Florida is booming with new residents, creating one of the nation's fastest-growing Congressional districts. Growth in Florida and other states is starting a major change in Congressional politics. A20 Voyager 2's mission was a success. Scientists said the spacecraft's exploration of Neptune provided answers to key questions they had about the gaseous planet. A21 Residents in Barney Frank's district in Massachusetts expressed a mix of sympathy, embarrassment and disgust over reports about his relationship with a male prostitute. A16 Students would be tested for drug use if they participate in interscholastic activities at a high school near Chicago. The A.C.L.U. said it would probably challenge the policy. A14 A founder of Kohlberg, Kravis, Jerome Kohlberg, has filed suit against the other two founders, accusing them of enriching themselves at his expense. D1 Lorenzo said to have met with Trump D1 AMR stock jumps 12.6% on rumors D3 Alaska seeks to coordinate plans for Soviet exchanges A17 Kirkland laments nation's current labor laws A20 In apartheid protest, Lutherans divest millions A15 Washington Talk A18 Trying to make better bureaucrats is the chief mission of the Federal Executive Institute, the Government's version of a General Motors-style executive training program. Politics: A plan to protect elderly backfired on lawmakers Regional B1-4 So that patients qualify for Medicaid, Bellevue Hospital employees have altered background information of hundreds of patients, they say, under pressure from supervisors. A1 Crime has been a campaign theme for all of New York City's mayoral candidates. But while each favors increasing the police force, they differ on how many to add, how to deploy them and how to pay for them. B1 The candidates are using their time to raise money for television ads and to hold press events to get on the evening news, more than to campaign the old-fashioned way - by shaking hands in neighborhoods. B1 Dinkins reveals a 1985 heart attack B2 The decision to march in Bensonhurst in the wake of the murder of a black youth was questioned by a Brooklyn Bishop. He seemed to agree with Mayor Koch, who has said the protest may have inflamed tensions. B1 Thousands mourn at Brooklyn funeral home B4 Federal inquiry into the murder begins B4 Youths in New Jersey vandalized the main business district of Vineland on Monday night. It was a reaction to the fatal shooting of a black man by a white police officer a day earlier. B1

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Bishop Questions Protest Marches in Racial Slaying
description: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday questioned the decision of some clergymen to conduct protest marches last weekend in Bensonhurst, where a black youth had earlier been shot to death after being chased by a white gang.

title: Dow Falls 16.73 as Transports Set Record
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday, weighed down by profit taking, a moderate decline in interest rates and a spurt of mid-afternoon program trading.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Anne Klein Apparel Group, a subsidiary of Takihyo Inc., named Andrew Rosen president and chief operating officer.

title: Testimony Cites Rose
description: The accountant for Pete Rose's former housemate implicated the former Cincinnati Reds manager today in an alleged tax-fraud scheme involving a race-track parimutuel ticket.

title: Major Questions About Neptune Are Answered
description: As Voyager 2 approached Neptune, scientists had six key questions they hoped to answer about the huge, gaseous planet at the farthest reaches of the solar system. With satisfaction, they said today that they had found answers to all of them.

title: Mencken Changed Targets Over the Years
description: To the Editor:

title: The Princely Macadamia: Too Precious to Eat by the Handful
description: LEAD: THE ear-splitting drone of shells being cracked between steel drums began in this Hawaiian city this month, signaling the start of the first macadamia nut harvest of the season. Hawaii leads the world in macadamia production, and the remaining 49 states lead the world in the precious nut's consumption.

title: Review/Film; On the Trail of a Murderer Who Wanted to Be a Cop
description: William Lustig, the director of ''Relentless,'' has been quoted as saying he had no desire to make ''a mean-spirited slasher film,'' and he hasn't.

title: Graduate Students In Berkeley Union Win Concessions
description: The University of California at Berkeley has agreed to recognize the Association of Graduate Student Employees and meet with the group in ''good faith,'' averting a strike by the 3,000 members who serve as teaching and research assistants on the campus.

title: Indonesia Nutmeg Shift
description: Indonesia which produces 80 percent of the world's nutmeg, has abandoned five foreign companies and appointed a locally controlled company to handle overseas sales. ''Prices have fallen remarkably, and foreign trading houses that used to handle our nutmeg marketing failed to stabilize them,'' said Yantje Worotitjan, chairman of the national nutmeg association. First Pacific Commodities, a Singapore trading house controlled by Indonesians, began marketing the spice last month. Two Dutch companies, two from Singapore and Comspices, an American concern, had previously controlled the nutmeg sales.

title: Wine Talk
description: YOU'RE inching down the road from Asti to Alba, looking at the vineyards and wondering idly if the fellow creeping along in front of you actually knows about second and third gear. But the sun is shining; the birds are singing, and the grapes look good. So you relax.

title: Body of Stabbed Girl Found
description: The body of a 14-year-old girl who had been stabbed in the chest, was found in the first floor hallway of a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday afternoon, the police said. The girl was identified by the police as Maria Urbistondo, of 2946 Fulton Street in the East New York section of Brooklyn. She was declared dead at the scene, at 18 Ashford Street, two blocks from her home, said Sgt. Peter Berry, a police spokesman. The police found the girl's nude body at 4:15 P.M. near the entrace to the building while responding to a call to 911 saying that a person was in need of aid.

title: Shift by U.S. in Insider Case
description: Federal prosecutors have backed off some of their accusations in an insider-trading case against a former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who leaked secret information on interest rates to a brokerage.

title: Strange Is Fined
description: Curtis Strange was fined for on-course, on-camera remarks directed at a photographer during the P.G.A. championship, the PGA Tour said yesterday.

title: U.S. Joins in Suing Fairchild
description: The Justice Department has joined a former employee of Fairchild Industries in accusing the company of defrauding the Air Force of $5 million to $10 million on a contract to make test equipment for fighter planes, the lawyer for the former employee said today.

title: Employees at Bellevue Say They Falsified Medicaid Data
description: Three employees at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan say that for more than a year some hospital employees, under pressure from supervisors, have been altering the background information of hundreds of patients so that they will qualify for Medicaid coverage.

title: Real Estate; More Leasing Of Midsized Office Space
description: DESPITE a stagnant office market that has kept vacancy rates in Manhattan at the 12 to 13 percent level for more than a year now, brokerage companies report an encouraging increase in the number of leases that have been signed by midsized tenants for the first half of this year.

title: Jordan Helps Pick Up Pace For Rockport
description: WHEN the Rockport shoe company departed from Chiat/ Day in April for Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, it left an agency in advertising's avant-garde for one versed in the old-fashioned craft of sloganeering. The new Rockport ads are making their debut this week in national magazines, and they indeed hew to Jordan's trademarks, including a slogan that features the client's name.

title: Finally, a Falkland Thaw
description: The dispute over the islands that Britain calls the Falklands and Argentina calls the Malvinas has been encased in permafrost since the two countries warred in 1982 in the frigid South Atlantic. So it's welcome news that they are putting aside rival claims to begin talks on normalizing relations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, far higher than the 1.7 percent rate estimated last month, the Commerce Department reported. The widely expected change reinforced the view that the economy is no longer slowing and might, in fact, be gaining fresh momentum. [ Page A1. ] Sales of new homes rose by 14.4 percent in July, the fastest pace in nearly three years, the department said. [ D5. ] Futures traders may find it harder to conceal fraudulent transactions under procedures proposed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. At issue are the cards on which trade information is kept, which are stamped with the time of the trade. [ D1. ] COMPANIES One founder of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, Jerome Kohlberg Jr., filed suit against his former partners, accusing them of enriching themselves at his expense. [ D1. ] Frank Lorenzo and Donald J. Trump have met privately, with Texas Air's chairman trying to persuade Mr. Trump to buy Continental Airlines, executives from both sides said. [ D1. ] AMR stock leaped 12.6 percent after reports that the parent of American Airlines had retained Goldman, Sachs and Salomon Brothers to advise it on preparing anti-takeover defenses. [ D3. ] Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank, in planning to merge and form the world's No. 2 bank, have an eye on both the new world of deregulation at home and competition abroad. [ D1. ] Ardent Computer and Stellar Computer plan to merge, company executives said. [ D2. ] A Canadian partnership raised its bid for Dunkin' Donuts to $308 million despite a lawsuit pending in Delaware. [ D3. ] Boeing Aerospace and Electronics will eliminate about 800 secretaries, engineers and managers. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL When Mexico closed a copper mine considered the birthplace of the nation's labor movement, it spurred nationwide criticism and set off a strike by several thousand mine workers. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stocks fell broadly, weighed down by profit taking, a moderate decline in interest rates and a spurt of program trading. The Dow Jones industrials dropped by 16.73 points, to 2,726.63. [ D6. ] Treasury note and bond prices were unchanged to slightly higher in light trading. [ D12. ] Copper futures prices fell sharply, after a dramatic monthlong rally, amid signs that miners' strikes in Canada and Peru may be nearing settlement. [ D13. ] The dollar fell sharply in active trading, and gold and silver prices rose. [ D13. ] Yields on C.D.'s and money market accounts at banks were mixed, while those at savings institutions declined. [ D15. ] TECHNOLOGY In a search for a low-cost substitute for nickel, which tripled in price last year, a British maker of auto parts turned to the buried secrets of the Luftwaffe. [ D1. ] Don't judge a cantaloupe by its cover. An infrared device that calculates a melon's sugar content takes away guesswork. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A 'soft landing' appears to be at hand, but it may be difficult to distinguish from hard times. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Investors looking at new bonds from the Washington Public Power Supply System are learning that the support of a Federal agency is not a sure road to a triple-A rating. Market Place. [ D6. ] When Rockport quit Chiat/Day for Jordan, McGrath, it left an agency in the avant-garde for one versed in the old-fashioned craft of sloganeering. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D15. ]

title: Cone Gives the Mets Another Pitching Gem
description: It wasn't exactly another classic, but it was close enough, as the Mets got more of that oldtime pitching tonight and edged the Los Angeles Dodgers again, 2-1.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article and its headline on Sunday about the previous day's Washington march protesting Supreme Court limits on affirmative action reported that 5,000 people had taken part. That proved to be a premature estimate. The National Park Service later estimated the crowd at 35,000, and some organizers said the number was 75,000 to 100,000.

title: Giants' Anderson Is Defying Critics
description: By next Monday, when all National Football League teams must be down to the regular-season limit of 47 players, Ottis Anderson will know if he will still be a Giant.

title: Norris H. Hoyt, Book Publisher, 83
description: Norris H. Hoyt, retired editorial director of Houghton Mifflin's educational division, died of coronary artery disease Monday at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 83 years old.

title: Gorbachev Said to Have Backed Attack on Baltic Movements
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev personally worked on and approved a Communist Party statement vehemently attacking nationalist activities in the Baltic republics, an official Soviet spokesman said today.

title: U.S. Seeks New Proof On Trades
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission took steps today to make it more difficult for futures traders to conceal fraudulent transactions. The Justice Department has brought indictments against 46 traders and brokers in Chicago, accusing them of such practices.

title: A Daring Idea: Leaving Paradise Behind
description: WHEN the first of our friends decided to leave Los Angeles and go back to the land - specifically Oregon - some 15 years ago, we who loved them secretly laughed. In front of them, we were encouraging, supportive, mock envious. They were making the great escape while we had to go on toiling in this teeming place.

title: Afghan Rebels Losing Against the Enemy Within
description: From the walls of mosques and bazaars throughout this old frontier city, posters showing Afghan guerrillas with turbans stare out at passers-by. By night, supporters of a rival guerrilla faction rip and disfigure the posters, but thousands remain in view.

title: New Pandick President Has 20 Years in Printing
description: Pandick Inc., one of the companies hurt by a downturn in financial printing, has named James P. Alexis, a seasoned industry executive, as president and chief executive.

title: Finale for 'Anything Goes'
description: ''Anything Goes,'' a revival of the 1934 musical with music and lyrics by Cole Porter, will end its run at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center, following the Sunday matinee performance. Directed by Jerry Zaks, the show will have run for 44 previews and 804 regular performances.

title: Alaska Seeks to Coordinate Plans for Soviet Exchanges
description: So many proposals are being made for trade, cultural and scientific agreements between Alaska and the Soviet Union that Gov. Steve Cowper has taken steps to keep track of them.

title: Where Migrant Children Learn to Love Learning
description: Along California's central coast in Monterey County, where more than 10,000 children of migrant farm workers live, extracurricular activities can often mean hoeing fields, picking crops or packing crates.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: EXCEPTIONALLY wet and cloudy weather has taken a toll of tomato crops, and as we head into September, pickings are still lean in my backyard garden. Some farm stands are finally selling good-looking beefsteak tomatoes, and I plan to take advantage of them before the fleeting season ends.

title: Police Charge Three in Bronx With Offering $10,000 Bribe
description: Three Bronx men were arrested last night and charged with offering two police officers a bribe of $10,000 and five ounces of heroin after the officers found drugs in their car during a routine traffic stop, the police said.

title: F.B.I. Begins Inquiry on Brooklyn Youth's Slaying in Racial Attack
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun a preliminary inquiry into the killing of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins in a racial attack in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn last week, the office of United States Attorney Andrew Maloney said yesterday.

title: Winds of Change Blow Toward Prague
description: LEAD: Czechoslovakia is next.

title: No Verdict on Helmsley After Jury's 4th Day
description: The jury in Leona Helmsley's tax-fraud and extortion trial deliberated for its fourth day without reaching a verdict yesterday, spending the nine hours apparently discussing the most serious charge against her, conspiracy to extort kickbacks from hotel suppliers.

title: Honor Leland's Memory With Foreign Aid Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: An unusual sex discrimination suit that began in 1987 is working its way through the courts in California. It concerns the traditional scheduling of the American Contract Bridge League's tournaments, which include a minority of events in which the sexes are separated and a smaller number in which men and women must play as partners. But in the majority of events, sex is irrelevant.

title: At Youth's Wake, Grief, Anger and Talk of Racism
description: Thousands of mourners filed past the body of Yusuf K. Hawkins yesterday at a Brooklyn funeral home, as his family sought to deal with their grief amid unceasing public attention.

title: Dry-Docked Tanker Inspected by Parties to Suits
description: Investigators looking into the Alaska oil spill and parties to litigation arising from it have started an inspection of the Exxon Valdez, now in dry dock for a nine-month repair job estimated to cost $25 million.

title: A Polish Cardinal's Surly Sermon
description: World War II was catastrophic for Poland, and for the Jews of Europe. Yet Jozef Cardinal Glemp's insensitive and untimely remarks last weekend will do little to bring two suffering peoples together -and could well drive them apart.

title: Nathan Kolodner, 38, Ex-AIDS Group Head
description: Nathan K. Kolodner, former president of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, died of AIDS-related causes Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 38 years old.

title: As Neckwear Goes, This Knot's News
description: IT began, simply enough, at a television studio here, when a 92-year-old man showed up one day to tell Don Shelby, the 42-year-old anchor of WCCO-TV, that Mr. Shelby did not know how to tie his necktie straight.

title: President's Daughter Is Said To Separate From Husband
description: Dorothy LeBlond, the 30-year-old daughter of President Bush, has separated from her husband, sources close to the family said today.

title: Mexican Mine Closing Stirs Deep Emotions
description: By closing the nation's largest mine, considered the birthplace of the Mexican labor movement, the Government has spurred nationwide criticism and has set off a strike by several thousand mine workers.

title: KAIFU TO VISIT U.S. TO SHOW STABILITY
description: Barely three weeks after taking office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is to leave for the United States this week to offer assurances that Japan's recent political turmoil has not undermined its dependability or willingness to negotiate thorny trade and security disputes.

title: Abortion Foes Found Guilty
description: A Federal judge found the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue and 12 of its members guilty of civil contempt today for blockading women's clinics last spring in violation of his court order. The judge, U.S. District Judge Wallace Tashima, said the defendants knew of his March order barring the blockades in several cities but went ahead with the protests. He ordered them to pay $111,000 in legal fees and imposed a suspended fine of $10,000 each to be levied if they disobeyed the court again.

title: Time to Recognize the Soviet Military Cutback
description: To the Editor:

title: Dress Code for Teachers?
description: If students are expected to conform to a dress code, as Baltimore high school students will have to when school begins, why not their teachers?

title: From Luftwaffe, a New Idea for Steel
description: Most technological change occurs first in small niches and, more often than is widely recognized, it starts with a creative look at yesterday's innovations in light of new predicaments.

title: California Delays Food Store Merger
description: The $2.5 billion merger of the Lucky and Alpha Beta supermarket chains was held up today when a Federal District Judge allowed the California Attorney General to post a $10,000 bond while appealing to the Supreme Court to overturn the merger.

title: Economic Scene; 'Soft Landing' Hard for Some
description: A ''SOFT LANDING'' appears to be at hand. Although the statistics bounce around a bit, the American economy is clearly growing more sluggishly than it was last year, much to the relief of the Federal Reserve and many economists. Now, the question is whether a slowly growing economy is really a blessing.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Chief Laments State of Labor Laws
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that he would prefer what he called ''the law of the jungle'' to the nation's labor laws, which he said were tilted toward business.

title: In a District of Transplants, New Roles for New Politics
description: Cliff Stearns moved here from Massachusetts in 1977 and was elected to Congress 11 years later. But he says he never had to worry about the dreaded charge of carpetbagging.

title: Rosy Hams Of Parma Near End Of Exile
description: PROSCIUTTO from Parma, Italy, prized for its sweet flavor and silken texture, will finally be sold again in the United States after an absence of 22 years.

title: Stong Unions Can Exercise Wage Restraint; U.S. and Soviet Strikes
description: To the Editor:

title: 26 Arrested In Rampage In Jersey Town
description: Scores of youths roamed the main business district here for about four hours Monday night and early today, hurling rocks and bottles at cars and storefronts in the tense aftermath of the fatal shooting of a black man by a white police officer on Sunday.

title: More Soviet Troops Are Sent To Disputed Armenian Area
description: More troops have been sent to the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh after a death in renewed clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis.

title: U.S. Move on Jet May Spur Grumman Cuts
description: The chief executive of the Grumman Corporation, John O'Brien, said today that 5,600 workers could lose their jobs within three years if the aerospace company loses its fight with the Defense Department to continue financing its new F-14D Tomcat jet fighter.

title: The Pop Life
description: Eurythmics and Fame

title: U.S. Recalls Bulgaria Envoy; Plight of Turks Is Protested
description: The Bush Administration said today that it was recalling the United States Ambassador to Bulgaria to protest rights abuses by the Bulgarian authorities against that country's ethnic Turkish minority.

title: AMR Stock Jumps 12.6% On Rumors
description: Stock of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, leaped 12.6 percent yesterday after reports that the company had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc. to advise it on preparing anti-takeover defenses.

title: Bruce Gould, 91; Edited Women's Magazine
description: Bruce Gould, co-editor with his wife, Beatrice Blackmar Gould, of the Ladies' Home Journal from 1935 until 1962, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Hopewell, N.J. He was 91 years old. Mr. Gould was on the editorial staff of the Saturday Evening Post in 1935 when he and his wife were made co-editors of the Journal. In their 27 years as co-editors, the Journal became the largest-selling women's magazine in the world. Mrs. Gould died on Jan. 30.

title: Old-Fashioned Campaigning, Just for TV
description: With two weeks to go to the New York City primary election, the candidates for mayor are spending far more time raising money for television advertisements, or holding events to try to get on the evening news, than they are campaigning the old-fashioned way - shaking hands in neighborhoods across the city.

title: Market Place; Investors Wary Of Utility's Bonds
description: INVESTORS looking at a proposed $450 million bond issue by the Washington Public Power Supply System are learning that the support of a Federal Government agency is not a sure road to a triple-A rating and might even be a weak link in the financing.

title: Security for Florida Governor
description: Security for Gov. Bob Martinez has been tightened amid threats of political violence by Colombian drug lords, the Governor has confirmed. ''There has been a general warning, a general concern of high-profile public officials on the subject of drugs,'' Mr. Martinez told reporters Monday.

title: Colorado Dam Would Ruin Wildlife Area, an E.P.A. Official Says
description: A regional officer of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that a $1 billion dam proposed for the South Platte River south of Denver would ruin one of the West's premier fishing and recreation areas and that the project should not be built.

title: From Sympathy to Condemnation: People in Frank's District React
description: People in his district are expressing a mixture of sympathy, embarrassment and distaste over the disclosure last week of Representative Barney Frank's relationship with a male prostitute from 1985 to 1987.

title: Money Fund Yields Finish Week Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks were mixed, while those at savings institutions declined for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Rowena Wyant, Executive, 72
description: Rowena Wyant, the first woman to be named a vice president of Dun & Bradstreet, died Aug. 23 at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital of injuries received in an auto accident a few days earlier. She was 72 years old and lived in Centerport, L.I.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Acquired Francisco Cabrera, catcher, from the Toronto Blue Jays to complete an earlier trade for Jim Acker, pitcher. Assigned Cabrera to Richmond of the International League. BOSTON (AL) - Placed Randy Kutcher, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up Carlos Quintana, outfielder, from Pawtucket of the International League. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Activated Bill Schroeder, catcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Optioned John Orton, catcher, to Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Announced that Jose Rijo, pitcher, will be out for the rest of the season with a stress fracture of his spine. Ended their affiliation with the Greensboro Hornets of the South Atlantic League. HOUSTON (NL) - Optioned Jose Cano, pitcher, to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. Recalled Eric Anthony, outfielder, from Tucson. MONTREAL(NL) - Optioned Larry Walker, outfielder, to Jacksonville of the Southern League. WHITE SOX (AL) - Signed Greg Walker, first baseman, through the 1990 season. YANKEES (AL) - Traded John Candelaria, pitcher, to the Montreal Expos for a player to be named later. Announced the resignation of Syd Thrift, senior vice president of baseball operations. Activated Randy Velarde, infielder, from the 15-day disabled list.

title: Carson's New Role
description: Harry Carson, the former All-Pro linebacker for the Giants, will be a reporter this season for Madison Square Garden Network's ''Giants Journal.'' The show, a weekly half-hour program, features a discussion with Coach Bill Parcells, interviews with players and game highlights. Carson, who made the Pro Bowl eight times in his 13-year-career, will also contribute to the network's ''MSG Sports Desk'' on Sunday evenings during the football season. (AP)

title: Book Notes
description: The Clancy Magic

title: Comparing Their Answers: Crime and Punishment
description: In separate interviews last month, The New York Times asked the six New York City mayoral candidates to discuss some of the major problems facing the city in 1989 and how they would deal with them. This is the third of six articles comparing their responses. Excerpts from the interviews appear [ below ] .

title: 2 Japanese Banks Merging In Preparation for New Era
description: In planning to merge and form the world's second-biggest bank, Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank have an eye on both the new world of deregulation at home and competition abroad.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the killing of a black youth by a gang of whites in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn misstated the address of one suspect, Charles Stressler. It is 2042 66th Street, not No. 2142.

title: Thrift Quits As Top Trader For Yankees
description: Syd Thrift's five-month tenure as the Yankees' senior vice president of baseball operations ended yesterday when he resigned his position for what he said were unspecified personal reasons.

title: Gristede's to Open Basement Market
description: Red Apple Companies, which operates New York's Red Apple and Gristede's food stores, is to open its first basement supermarket tomorrow at 86th Street and Broadway in Manhattan. The company believes the new Gristede's market will be the first basement food store in the country.

title: About New York; Step Right Up! See a Boardwalk! It's Coney Island!
description: The sultry air shimmers as syncopated bodies glide past. A woman in pink carrying a dripping ice cream cone, two scoops. An emaciated, mustachioed man with a million-dollar smile and a ponderous plastic bag of empty cans, a bargain-basement Burt Reynolds if there ever was one. Old women speaking Russian, teen-agers ambling through an endless summer, cotton-candy dreaming, hot dogs with the works.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: E.I.L. Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Seymour Krim, 67, Author and Essayist
description: Seymour Krim, an author and critic, was found dead, apparently of a drug overdose, in his Manhattan apartment last night, the police said.

title: Diplomacy
description: Two months ago the story would have provoked shouted inquiries to the President as he boarded his helicopter and hasty news conferences by members of Congress eager to take a stand. But on Aug. 28, 1989, the report provoked only silence.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: MY friend the bibliophile was setting up her usual moan. She spent too much money on books, had no space in which to store them and, incidentally, the city was going down the tubes.

title: Planners Aim to Keep The Sizzle in Times Sq.
description: Criticized as too classical and not garish and lively enough, the designs for four office towers in the Times Square redevelopment project have been overhauled.

title: Capsule Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $370,000 and $999,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said it has agreed in principle to sell a controlling interest in a subsidiary in Puerto Rico for undisclosed terms. It said the subsidiary had an operating loss in the latest 6-month of $1,769,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Executive Board Adds A Member From U.S.
description: Robert Helmick's election today to the International Olympic Committee's executive board ended a calculated campaign to return the United States into the highest sphere of influence within the Olympic movement.

title: Flirting With Health Claim, Kellogg Announces a Cereal
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that it will soon market a cereal that includes the grain psyllium, aimed at consumers anxious to reduce their blood cholesterol levels. The product, known as Heartwise, follows the lead of General Mills' psyllium-based cereal Benefit, which was introduced last spring, and it is expected to touch off new conflicts about the health claims made for such cereals.

title: Mutual Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of the money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with those of tax-exempt funds rising and those of taxable funds declining.

title: New Currency In Yugoslavia
description: Yugoslavia will introduce a new currency to help fight inflation, which is currently at an annual rate of 800 percent, a Government official said today.

title: Comparing Their Answers: Housing and the Homeless
description: In separate interviews last month, The New York Times asked the six New York City mayoral candidates to discuss some of the major problems facing the city in 1989 and how they would deal with them. This is the fourth of six articles comparing their responses. Excerpts from the interviews appear [ below ] .

title: Varlen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said it benefited from a strong performance by the railroad products segment of its business, as well as a full quarter's contribution by Consolidated Metro Inc., acquired March 7.

title: The Good War
description: Fifty years ago this week, Adolf Hitler fabricated a grotesque incident to justify a German attack on Poland. He told his generals: ''It doesn't matter whether it is plausible or not. The victor will not be asked by the vanquished whether he told the truth. In starting or making war, it is not right which matters but victory.'' He then launched what he crudely called ''Operation Canned Goods,'' which soon exploded into World War II.

title: How Irish Got Date With Cavaliers
description: Can Virginia compete with Notre Dame in the Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium tonight?

title: AN EX-BAKKER AIDE COLLAPSES IN TRIAL
description: A former executive of the PTL television ministry was hospitalized and another collapsed today after testifying in the trial of the former evangelist Jim Bakker on fraud and conspiracy charges.

title: Colorful Clothing From Saudi Arabia
description: Through Oct. 29, ''Palms and Pomegranates: Traditional Dress of Saudi Arabia'' will be on view at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, its final destination on a tour of seven cities.

title: Boycotters at Belmont Send Message and Save
description: The horseplayers who boycotted the Pick-Six on opening day at Belmont Park yesterday not only made a loud statement about new state taxes but also saved themselves some money. The last leg of the bet was the $112,400 Gazelle Handicap for 3-year-old fillies, and the winner was the implausible long shot Tactile.

title: Ex-Official Says Reagan's Aides Often Used Influence at H.U.D.
description: A former Government housing official who is at the center of Congressional inquiries has told a Federal grand jury that Reagan White House aides repeatedly sought to intervene in an urban renewal program once lauded as free of political influence.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Sterling Optical
description: LEAD: Sterling Optical, a chain of eye-care shops, yesterday awarded its $6 million account to Saatchi & Saatchi. The account, which had been at the Bloom Companies, was placed under review in May. Sterling also does a small part of its advertising - about $1 million - through an in-house agency.

title: The Antiquities That Freud Lived With
description: IT was a photograph of Sigmund Freud's desk in his London house that gave Lynn Gamwell the initial jolt. ''The idea just came to me,'' she recalled of the sight of antiquities crowding the top of his desk.

title: The City Council, Old and New
description: It's no wonder New Yorkers have never paid much attention to City Council elections. The Council, lacking much power, has rarely attracted engaging politicians. That may soon change. The proposed City Charter would, as early as 1991, enlarge the Council's membership and authority - which makes this year's elections unusually important.

title: Joe Collins, Former Yankee, 66
description: Joe Collins, a first baseman for 10 years with the New York Yankees, died today at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: Some Deer Hunters May Be Disappointed
description: rrThousands of those planning to hunt deer in New York State this season are going to be disappointed, according to the Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN the time comes to vacate a summer home, having a well-planned strategy eases the inevitable last-day confusion. More important, it helps safeguard the house in your absence. Many tasks for closing up must be taken care of at the last minute, but others can be done in advance. The Exterior and the Yard

title: Bonn Braces for New Wave of East Germans
description: The West German Government said today that four tent camps were being set up for an expected wave of East German refugees from Hungary starting over the weekend. But Bonn and Budapest publicly denied that any formal arrangement on a mass departure had been reached.

title: Banker's Note reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
An Unsightly Finish May Just Be Dirty
description: LEAD: Quite a bit of furniture is unnecessarily purged at the stripping works or in the home workshop, even good pieces that deserve more lenient treatment. But often it is plain economics that banishes them there, as the value of the piece simply does not justify the time and effort involved in a lengthy course of restoration.

title: CUC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months results reflect the company's new accounting policy in which CUC, beginning in the fiscal 1989 fourth quarter, began amortizing membership acquisition costs during the initial membership service period in which they incurred, generally 12 months. The company also said previously, membership acquisition costs were amortized over a three year period.

title: Prisoner With AIDS Virus Wins Reversal of Conviction for Biting
description: An Alabama court has reversed the conviction of an inmate infected with the AIDS virus who had been charged with attempted murder after biting a guard.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. Mayor, Mr. Governor, let freedom ring in Howard Beach.

title: New Designs for Times Square Try to Reflect Neon Atmosphere
description: Bowing to intense public criticism, the planners of the Times Square redevelopment project yesterday presented entirely new designs for four office towers, including one with a 27-story built-in sign.

title: Corrections
description: Articles between Aug. 25 and Aug. 30 about the racial killing of a black teen-ager in Brooklyn included an erroneous rendering of his name provided by the police. His family says the correct name is Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Oneida Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
