description: To The Home Section:

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.H.A. Automotive Technoloies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Collusion Price Tag Due Today
description: Three years and seven months after the grievance was filed, baseball players and club owners will learn today how much the clubs will have to pay free agents for salary lost because of the owners' conspiracy in 1985.

title: Hospital Corp. Cuts Price of Deal
description: The Hospital Corporation of America reduced by $100 million, to $1.125 billion, the sale price of its psychiatric division, which it is selling to the division's executives and an employee stock ownership plan. The company said it would also retain ownership of $150 million in the new company's common stock and preferred stock along with warrants to buy additional shares of common stock.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 President Bush's drug strategy calls for an intensified effort to break up narcotics distribution networks by arresting middle-level figures like pilots and couriers, White House officials said. Page A1

title: Central Sprinkler reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cleopatra Kohlique reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; Mutual Funds Come Back to Life
description: Americans are putting more cash into mutual funds than at any time since the 1987 stock market crash, new figures released yesterday showed. As a result of that and the market's 1989 rally, the total assets of stock and bond mutual funds now almost equal the record set just before the crash.

title: Mayoral Rivals Offer Few New Ideas About Housing
description: The six New York City mayoral candidates offer few new ideas for addressing the lack of affordable housing and the plight of the thousands of homeless New Yorkers.

title: Nutmeg Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment of $113,000.

title: A Punishment Fit For a Hotel Queen
description: LEAD: Leona Helmsley, the self-styled Hotel Queen, was convicted yesterday. Today, the question is:

title: Bizmart Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Included $717,000 pre-opening expenses associated with the five new stores opened in the quarter and two stores opened early this month.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: STEVEN MIRSKY feels he is finally catching up with his family. Mr. Mirsky, a 31-year-old science writer in New York, is the youngest of three children.

title: What Is a Family? Traditional Limits Are Being Redrawn
description: AS the definition of family is expanded by courts and governments, members of nontraditional families are gaining a voice. What they speak of are traditional family values like commitment, nurturing and support, in words like these:

title: Cracks Force Early Shutdown Of Nuclear Plant in Colorado
description: The Fort St. Vrain nuclear power plant, the nation's only helium-cooled reactor, has been shut nearly a year earlier than planned because of cracks found in its tubing.

title: Becker Gets a Scare But Defeats Rostagno
description: Boris Becker did not need to hear a bell tolling to know that the growing buzz of alarm emanating from the stands midway through what should have been a routine victory was meant for him.

title: Fabrics Adorned With Extras
description: HE calls it ''organic embellishment.'' ''The idea,'' said Peter Carlson, ''is to transform the fabric so that it becomes an integral part of the design of a room.''

title: Dynatem Inc reports earnings for Year to May 31
An Ending Revealed
description: To The Home Section:

title: 'Largely New York' to Close
description: ''Largely New York,'' a comedy written and directed by Bill Irwin, is to close after Saturday evening's performance at the St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street. The play will have run for 11 previews and 152 regular performances.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, Chicago, a graphics-products manufacturer, named Joseph A. Verderber president of its specialty products division.

title: Campaign Matters; The Actions Of 2 Candidates Speak of Strife
description: It may be less their words than where Mayor Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins went the day after Yusuf K. Hawkins's murder that speaks volumes about the racial polarization of their city and of their constituencies in the mayoral campaign.

title: Scientist Joins Board Of Exxon
description: Acting in response to pressure to put an environmentalist on its board, the Exxon Corporation yesterday named John H. Steele, a senior scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts.

title: Harman International Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
200 Women Are Arrested in Protest in Cape Town
description: The police arrested at least 200 women in downtown Cape Town today when they marched toward Parliament to protest political detentions and other conditions in South Africa.

title: Celtics Are Sued
description: Dino Radja's former Yugoslav basketball team has filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against the Boston Celtics, charging that the National Basketball Association team lured the 6-foot-10-inch forward to the United States and encouraged him to break a four-year contract.

title: Statement on Cambodia
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the international conference on Cambodia:

title: General Cinema reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $10,796,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $855,139,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $19,309,000 for the quarter and $42,535,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $4,855,000.

title: Panel to Examine Police Policies In New Jersey Town After Unrest
description: In hopes of improving relations between this tense city's police force and its black and Puerto Rican residents, Mayor Harry Curley appointed a task force today to study four police policies, including minority recruitment.

title: Herbert Loper, 92, Retired Army General
description: Herbert B. Loper, a retired Army major general and former chairman of the Military Liaison Committee of the Atomic Energy Commission, died of cardiac arrest on Friday at the Palm Bay Care Center in Florida. He was 92 years old and had lived in Bozman, Md., before entering the nursing home last year.

title: Dissenter Resumes Fight for Amdura
description: A dissident shareholder in the Amdura Corporation, Frank Cilluffo, said that he would proceed with his plan to unseat Amdura's board and that materials had been mailed to the company's shareholders. Mr. Cilluffo and his investor group need the consent of 50 percent of Amdura's shareholders to unseat its board and to replace it with its own slate. The group already controls about 17 percent of the Denver-based hardware distributor's shares.

title: Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Lorenzo Natali, Italian Politician, 66
description: Lorenzo Natali, who served as vice president of the European Commission for 11 years and helped negotiate the entry of Spain, Portugal and Greece into the European Community, died Monday at his Rome residence after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Georgio Sant'Angelo, a Designer; In the Avant-Garde of Fashion, 56
description: Giorgio Sant'Angelo, a fashion designer and member of the avant-garde for more than 20 years, died of lung cancer Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Elliott Horne Is Dead; Music Writer Was 67
description: Elliott Horne, a jazz writer and press agent, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City. He was 67 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Wyle Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Griffin Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and the year included a $1,052,100 charge for write-down of deferred income taxes. The company said the previous quarter and year included pretax charge of $639,800 in write-downs.

title: Uganda Stock Exchange
description: Uganda plans to open a stock exchange early next year to help rehabilitate the country's economy, the market's organizers said today. Leo Kibirango, former governor of the Bank of Uganda, said the stock exchange should help the economy by encouraging private industry and directing new investment to capital-starved businesses. Uganda now depends on coffee exports for 95 percent of its foreign exchange earnings.

title: U.S. Jury Finds Helmsley Guilty Of Tax Evasion but Not Extortion
description: Leona Helmsley, who runs a hotel empire with an iron will, a tart tongue and a self-bestowed title of Queen, was convicted yesterday of evading $1.2 million in Federal income taxes.

title: Atlantic Records Picks Chief's Heir Apparent
description: Atlantic Records, one of the most successful labels owned by Time Warner Inc., yesterday gave its president, Doug Morris, the additional title of chief operating officer.

title: Court Upholds Drug Testing For Civilian Workers in Army
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the Army may subject more than 6,500 of its civilian workers, including law enforcement and aviation personnel, to random drug tests.

title: Rose Tied to Tax-Evasion Plan
description: The chief witness in baseball's investigation of Pete Rose testified in Federal court here today that Rose attempted to avoid paying taxes on race-track winnings.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about rapes involving acquaintances omitted parts of two sentences in some editions. The passage should have read: ''Some women are unable to consent because, for instance, they have passed out while drunk. A sexual encounter may also be considered rape if force or the threat of force is used, Dr. Parrot said. Some of the newest research on forced sex points to the influence of the sexual double standard.''

description: b-Net loss

title: Japanese Bank's Stock Deal Is Investigated by Exchange
description: One of the two Japanese banks planning a large merger acknowledged today that it had urged clients to buy its stock before the merger negotiations were completed.

description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: To The Home Section:

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $10,000 and $80,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $76,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $24,000 for the 9 months.

Metro Cable reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it does not provide quarterly revenue figures.

title: Medex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per-share net figures have been adjusted for 10-percent stock dividend paid in April 1989.

title: Rise in Farm Income Is Seen
description: Cash receipts from larger crops this year are strengthening net farm income more sharply than had been expected, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Greenman Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Israel Criticized by U.N. for Deporting Arabs
description: The Security Council today criticized Israel's deportation of Palestinians from the occupied territories and called for an end to the expulsions.

title: Personal Incomes Up 0.7% in July
description: Americans' personal incomes rose a brisk seven-tenths of 1 percent in July while consumer spending climbed at the fastest rate since April, the Government said today.

title: Dow Edges Up 1.52 Points In Seesaw Trading Session
description: Stock prices ended narrowly higher yesterday, buoyed by the strength in airline and pharmaceutical issues at one juncture, only to be weighted down by program selling and falling bond prices at the next.

title: Sir Peter Scott, Wildlife Advocate And Painter of Birds, Dies at 79
description: Sir Peter Scott, a painter, ornithologist, yachtsman and television personality who abandoned hunting to become one of the world's leading campaigners for wildlife protection, died of a heart attack Tuesday, his environmental group said today. He was 79 years old.

title: F. W. Dietmar Schaefer Lawyer, 60
description: F. W. Dietmar Schaefer, a senior lawyer with the Mobil Corporation for 27 years, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Philadelphia Exchange's 'Basket' Plan
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was moving to get back into trading ''stock baskets,'' after suffering a setback earlier this month because of a legal action brought by the large Chicago commodity exchanges. The American Stock Exchange said it was considering a similar move.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES Kingdom Takes Hurdles: Roger Kingdom won the gold medal in the 110-meter hurdles yesterday in Duisburg, West Germany, but cold weather and stiffness prevented the two-time Olympic champion from challenging his own world record.

title: Telcoa International Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
LTV Steel Closer To Sale of Unit
description: The LTV Steel Company, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, reached a tentative agreement with the United Steelworkers of America that clears the sale of its bar division to an employee stock ownership plan. LTV did not disclose terms of the sale, pending a vote of the union's membership in September, but industry experts have estimated the price would be between $200 million and $300 million. An LTV spokesman said the price ''would probably be toward the lower end of that range.''

title: Eastern Recovery In Jeopardy
description: Eastern Airlines' plan to emerge from bankruptcy as a smaller, trimmer airline is in serious financial trouble, because of its inability to sell certain assets and repay its debt.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Richton International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter sales included $2,878,000 generated by the U.K. subsidiary that was sold last December.

title: Counterfeiter Freed By Forgery Is Seized
description: A twice-convicted counterfeiter who the authorities say forged a hospital pass and walked away from a court-ordered residence program last week was seized Tuesday at an Indiana campsite.

title: Fryar Not in Plans
description: Irving Fryar, the Patriots' wide receiver who has not reported because of a contract dispute and who has been the subject of startling accusations concerning his collegiate career, no longer figures in the plans of the New England team, Coach Raymond Berry said yesterday.

title: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: United States dollar amounts have been translated for convenience at the rate of U.S. $1.00 equals 144 yen. Each American Depositary Share (ADS) represented 10 shares of common stock. The company said that in the breakdown table, certain 1988 figures have been restated as a result of partial reclassification of product group; the number of consolidated companies was 164, and the number of companies reflected on the equity method was 156.

title: Tourists Get Caught In Kenya's Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
CBS Plans Package Deal For Olympics
description: LEAD: HAVING purchased the broadcast rights for the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics, CBS plans to approach prospective advertisers this fall with ideas for long-range marketing promotions and with offers of package deals to buy commercial time for both events at once.

title: Atlantic Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest year included an extraordinary charge of $161,389 from the termination of an agreement.

title: Choosing the Home-Gym Advantage
description: JOHN GREELEY started John Greeley's Fitness Plus in 1985, and since then his business, in Syosset, L.I., has increased twentyfold. Mr. Greeley or one of his staff will go to your home, take measurements and develop a floor plan for the room you wish to convert to a home gym.

title: Thompson Sentenced
description: Charles Thompson, the former Oklahoma quarterback who said he knew he had done wrong and would take his punishment, was sentenced yesterday in Oklahoma City to two years in prison on a cocaine-related charge. United States District Judge Ralph Thompson also ordered the defendant to submit to supervised drug testing or drug counseling for three years after his release. Thompson is to report Sept. 20 to a Federal prison. Thompson, 21 years old, who would have been a junior this season, pleaded guilty April 26 to one count of conspiracy to distribute cocaine. He was arrested Feb. 13 and accused of selling 17 grams of cocaine to an undercover F.B.I. agent on Jan. 26. (AP)

title: For Stein and Messinger
description: Two of New York City's better-known elected officials, Andrew Stein, the City Council President, and Ruth Messinger, a Council member, face only token opposition in their Democratic primary campaigns. Rafael Mendez, Mr. Stein's opponent in his race for re-election, hasn't run a credible campaign. Neither has Barbara Taylor, who is running against Ms. Messinger for the borough presidency of Manhattan.

title: BUSH'S DRUG PLAN AIMS AT CAPTURING MID-LEVEL FIGURES
description: President Bush's national drug strategy calls for an intensified effort to break up narcotics distribution networks by arresting middle-level figures like pilots, couriers and money handlers, White House officials said today.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest 6-month period included a pretax restructuring charge of $800,000; the year-ago 6-month period included a non-recurring pretax gain of $2,904,000 from a supply contract and the sale of midwest warehouse assets.

title: Olympic Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Total assets for the latest and year- ago 6-month periods were $229,905,596 and $187,231,889, respectively.

title: Integrated Computer Graphcs reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $280,367.

title: VIRGINIA EXECUTES KILLER OF WOMAN
description: A man convicted of raping and murdering a 61-year-old woman in 1977 was executed tonight in Virginia's electric chair.

title: A Designer Whose Clients Are the Towhead-and-Freckle Set
description: Some parents would say Terry Nagel got what she deserved for letting her boys choose the colors for their bedroom. ''I was horrified,'' Mrs. Nagel said. Matthew, age 6, chose green. Greg, 3, chose purple.

title: Gil-Med Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: In Colombia, the Military Is Part of the Problem
description: LEAD: If the United States and Colombia are to be effective in their fight against the drug cartels, both must face a cardinal fact: The cartels and their paramilitary squads could not impose their reign of terror on Colombia without cooperation from regional military and police authorities.

title: Lutherans Take Neutral Stance on Abortion
description: Evangelical Lutherans at their first legislative assembly have decided to maintain a neutral position on abortion after first adopting a resolution that some delegates viewed as advocating abortion rights.

title: Republic Capital Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said total assets for the latest year were $601,571,000 versus $602,158,000 for the prior year.

title: 4 Killed in Plane Collision
description: Two small planes collided and crashed Tuesday night, and all four people on board were killed, the authorities said. The crash occurred in clear weather about a mile west of Harvey Field near here. The planes were not under the direction of air traffic controllers, and the pilots were responsible for watching for other craft, said Errol van Eaton, a Federal Aviation Administration investigator.

title: Walter Friend, 69, Paine Webber Executive
description: Walter William Friend Jr., senior vice president of Paine Webber, the Wall Street investment company, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: Israel to Sell Big Stake In El Al
description: El Al, Israel's national airline, announced yesterday that the Israeli Government plans to sell a large stake in the company to domestic and foreign investors.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION - 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Language Now Roils Soviet Moldavia
description: A protest strike by tens of thousands of minority residents of Soviet Moldavia was reported growing today as the republic's legislature prepared to displace Russian with Moldavian as the official language.

title: Q&A
description: Painting Stained Pillars Q.We live in an 83-year-old house that has a front porch with pillars made of hollow concrete sewer tiles stacked on top of each other and joined with cement. They were apparently stained, but now are a splotchy red. We want to paint them when we paint the rest of the house (gray with white trim). How should we proceed, and with what kind of paint? A.I would recommend painting them white to match the rest of the trim. Apply a first coat of masonry sealer or primer, then paint with one or two coats of latex masonry paint. Make sure the sealer (sometimes called a surface conditioner) will be compatible with the finish coat. Restoring Lacquer Surface Q.We used a cream polish on our lacquer dining room table to remove fingerprints and the surface became badly clouded. A mixture of Windex and water removed some of the cloudiness.

title: Aceto Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In Melting Pot, Harmony and Problems Mix
description: Elmhurst, Queens, is a window on the world. Women in saris push baby strollers past Irish pubs and Korean fruit stands. Two children lean out a window and call to their mother in Spanish. In the city's most ethnically diverse neighborhood, the heat that fuels the melting pot also incubates a host of problems.

title: Mulroneys Arrive for a Visit At Bush's Estate in Maine
description: President Bush welcomed Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada to his seaside vacation home today for a low-key visit that is to include informal talks on drugs and other issues.

title: French Economy Slows
description: The French economy grew by seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter of 1989, about half the pace of the first three months of the year, the national statistics institute said today. The report came a day after France reported its worst month external trade performance in a year - a July deficit of almost 7.5 billion francs ($1.14 billion).

title: INSIDE
description: Cambodians Assess Failure The warring Cambodian factions angrily blamed each other for the failure of a monthlong international conference on Cambodia. Page A12. El Al on the Block The Israeli Government said it planned to sell 50 percent of the national airline. Page D1. Scientist for Exxon Board The oil company chose John H. Steele as a director. Critics say he is not an environmentalist, which the company had promised to name. Page D1. Public Office, Private Lives In the Barney Frank case and three others, the House ethics panel will examine a question gripping American politics. News analysis, page B10. What Is a Family? The definition increasingly involves commitment rather than simply legal ties. The Home Section, page C1.

title: Alabama Bans Many Toxic Waste Shipments
description: Alabama is banning hazardous waste shipments from 22 states and the District of Columbia to keep the state ''from becoming the waste dump of the nation,'' Gov. Guy Hunt announced Tuesday.

title: I.B.M. and Toshiba In Joint Venture
description: I.B.M. Japan Ltd., a division of the International Business Machines Corporation, and the Toshiba Corporation announced plans for a venture to manufacture color liquid crystal displays - key components in computer terminal screens. Plant construction for the new company, called Display Technologies Inc., will begin in March 1990 in Himeji, about 375 miles west of Tokyo, with completion scheduled in April 1991.

title: Mack Pleads Guilty To Using Cocaine
description: Kevin Mack, the running back for the Browns, pleaded guilty yesterday in Cleveland to using cocaine. His plea was part of a plea bargain, which included the dismissal of three charges arising from his arrest on June 28 at a drug-infested street corner.

title: Turning Dirt Into Gold: Somebody Has to Do It
description: AT the age of 21, Don Aslett was scrubbing toilets to pay his way through college. At 54, this self-proclaimed ''Porcelain Preacher'' and ''Don Juan of the John'' is so busy writing books like ''Pet Clean-Up Made Easy'' and ''Clutter's Last Stand'' and zigzagging around the world giving seminars on housecleaning, he is forced to tidy up his hotel rooms until he can get home to give his toilet-bowl brush a good swish.

title: American Toxxic Control reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $489,000 on the sale of BCL Associates and the share earnings was less than one cent a share. c-Net loss

title: Books of The Times; A Personal View of the War's Start in 1939
description: How War Came The Immediate Origins of the Second World War, 1938-1939 By Donald Cameron Watt Illustrated. 736 pages. Pantheon Books. $29.95.

title: Politics Sneaks Aboard on Military-Base Mission
description: When politicians have trouble dealing with tough issues, they frequently turn to commissions to bail them out. Such was the case with the closing of military bases, an unpalatable task that Congress consigned to a special panel to insulate the process from political influences.

title: Jet Lands in Emergency
description: An American Airlines MD-80 jet made an emergency landing at an airport today after one of its three hydraulic systems failed, an airline spokesman said. Flight 891, carrying 66 passengers and a crew of six from Oklahoma City to Dallas, returned to Will Rogers World Airport 11 minutes after taking off, said the spokesman.

title: Creatures That Glow In the Dark
description: WHEN she was growing up in Arizona, Sue Scott's nickname was ''lizard.'' ''And I used to go trout fishing,'' said the Oakland, Calif., entrepreneur. So the seminal products of her two-year-old company, Primal Lite, were strings of lights called ''Bunch-A-Lizards'' and ''Mess-O-Trout.''

title: Lincoln to Sell Reinsurer Unit
description: The Lincoln National Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest insurance holding company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its National Reinsurance Corporation subsidiary to the Robert M. Bass Group, Acadia Partners and some of National Reinsurance's management.

title: Latshaw Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $34,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $6,000 for the 9 months.

title: O.A.S. to Meet Today on U.S.-Panama Rift
description: The Organization of American States announced today that it would hold a special meeting Thursday to hear evidence supporting charges by the United States that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had turned Panama into ''a haven for drug traffickers.''

title: Farm Banks Given Triple-A Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday that for the first time it had assigned a triple-A rating to about $29 billion in long-term debt of the Federal Farm Credit Banks, the Federal Land Banks and the Farm Credit System Financial Assistance Corporation.

title: Micros Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Masters of the Craft Prepare for Broadway
description: ''Arrhhmm,'' says Sir Rex Harrison. ''Arhhhmmmmm. Rhhmmmm.''

title: The Lady Was Deadly
description: rrShe came onto Stadium Court, under a sky as dark as smoke, to play her first-round match of the United States Open in Flushing Tuesday afternoon. A long red bag, the size of a violin case, was slung over her right shoulder.

title: New Rules for Credit Cards
description: Federal disclosure rules for credit cards take effect on Thursday, and they may foster competition that could lower interest rates for the nation's 107 million cardholders.

title: Former Mine Director In Mexico Is Arrested
description: The Mexican Government today arrested the former director of the country's largest mine, which was declared bankrupt and occupied by army troops last week, on charges of engineering a multimillion-dollar fraud.

title: Toll Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company it had an increase in sales value of new contracts signed in the latest 9 months and a higher contract backlog as of July 31.

title: Drexel Senior Officer To Become President
description: Howard M. Brenner, a senior executive vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was named yesterday to become president of the Wall Street investment banking firm.

title: Mets Rejoin the Race With Sweep of Dodgers
description: The Mets, who came unraveled in three games in San Diego over the weekend, pieced together their pennant race again tonight when they completed a three-game sweep over the Los Angeles Dodgers and moved to within two and a half games of first place.

title: Plastibec Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A Simple Side Chair Of Many Varied Moods
description: THE idea is as simple as it is ingenious. Why can't a side chair be available with a number of different arm designs? The answer is it can.

title: A Prominent Trader Admits He Schemed To Rig a Stock Price
description: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a leading Wall Street trader who was once a special adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission, pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges that he helped manipulate a stock price in the spring of 1986, in an action that benefited the American Express Company.

title: Talking Deals; Holiday's Plan To Cut Incentives
description: WHEN managers are given stock in a company, the goal is often to provide an incentive to make the company prosper. But what happens when the managers get a lot of stock, and a lot of cash besides? With the initial incentives gone, will the performance continue?

title: A Mansion Touches Off A 2d Battle Of Princeton
description: Morven, the stately Georgian home that has been host to the famous since the Revolutionary War and once served as New Jersey's executive mansion, is the center of a new battle.

title: Merrill Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a charge of $1.8 million from writeoff of an investment. c-Net income

title: Insituform Gulf South Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Commercial Intertech reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Payoffs Not the Rule In Hotel Business
description: To the Editor:

title: FCMI Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Savings-Unit Agency Plans 5 More Sales
description: The agency created to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan institutions announced today that it was putting up for sale five institutions with $10.8 billion in total assets. But officials said it may be as long as two months before any final deals will be struck.

title: Dimitri Yassukovich, 91, Investment Banker
description: Dimitri M. Yassukovich, a retired partner in the investment banking concern of White, Weld & Company, died of complications from pneumonia Tuesday at his summer home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 91 years old and lived in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Cities Cite Need for Child-Care Funds
description: A lack of money is hampering local governments in dealing with child care and other problems involving children and teen-agers, the National League of Cities said Monday in appealing for long-term Federal assistance.

title: Giant Food Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 12
Edison Brothers Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said the 6-month figures represent 26-week periods in both years.

title: Calendar: Children's Harvest Fair
description: Little Green Thumbs, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; 718-622-4433.

title: KEY RATES
Bell & Howell Sale Seen
description: The Bell & Howell Company said today that might sell the Merrill Publishing Company, one of its core businesses. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Bell & Howell said it had told Merrill employees ''that it has initiated discussions with potential purchasers.'' Merrill, based in Columbus, Ohio, publishes textbooks for elementary schools, high schools and colleges. It has estimated annual sales of about $100 million. Last year, Bell & Howell was taken private for $647 million by a group led by the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass.

title: China Is Said to Execute Some in Secret
description: Amnesty International accused the Chinese Government today of ordering the secret execution of dissidents, and a United Nations human-rights panel debated a move to censure China for its suppression of the democracy movement.

title: Angry Artists Cancel Shows at Corcoran
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art here has beome the target of an artists' boycott because of its cancellation in June of a retrospective of the work of the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: V Band Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included pretax charges of about $1,700,000 relating to the writedown of obsolete and slow-moving inventory and increase of warranty reserves, as well as a $600,000 provision of liabilities in connection with management changes occurring in the third quarter. c-Net income

title: SHELLING IN BEIRUT INTENSIFIES AGAIN
description: Christian and Muslim areas came under artillery bombardment again today after a French effort to negotiate a cease-fire between the warring parties apparently failed.

title: Accord Ends Phone Strike in Five Midwest States
description: Michigan Bell agreed on a tentative contract for 12,800 telephone workers today, paving the way for 37,000 Ameritech workers in five Middle Western States to go back to work, company and union officials said.

title: AMR Stock Up $1.50
description: Shares of the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, continued to move up amid speculation that there may be a bid for the company. AMR climbed $1.50 a share yesterday, to $93, on the New York Stock Exchange. On Tuesday, the stock jumped $10.25. But analysts said that there was no evidence that a bid was forthcoming.

title: Talks on Cambodia Break Off in Anger
description: As a monthlong international conference aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia ended in failure, the warring Cambodian factions angrily blamed each other today for the breakdown of the talks.

title: Dorothy Schiff, 86, Ex-Post Owner, Dies
description: Dorothy Schiff, owner of The New York Post for 37 years, died early yesterday in her apartment on the East Side of Manhattan. She was 86 years old.

title: 'Disgusted' McEnroe And Wilander Beaten
description: Like a magician who suddenly found himself onstage with an empty bag of tricks, John McEnroe searched first for his serve, then rummaged for some genius at net, and finally fumbled for sufficient ground strokes to try to keep himself afloat in his second-round United States Open match.

title: Ulster Group Reports Use of Secret Data in Killing
description: An outlawed Protestant group in Northern Ireland has asserted that it penetrated British security and used top-secret intelligence information to locate and kill a Roman Catholic man last week.

title: Salt Lake City Journal; 1974 Case Still Strains Race Relations in Utah
description: The passage of 15 years has done little to calm emotions over the gruesome Ogden Hi-Fi Shop murders in which two black men poured Drano plumbing solvent down the throats of four white people and taped their mouths shut during a robbery, after which one of the robbers shot three of the victims to death.

title: Wide Variety Is Found In Pharmacy Drug Cost
description: Prescription drug prices vary widely around the country and even between drug stores in the same town, according to a private survey that found one pharmacy charging nearly $32 more for a heart medication than did a nearby competitor.

title: Dial 'P' for Privacy in New Phone Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Franchisees Offer To Purchase Arby's
description: A partnership formed by eight franchise holders of Arby's Inc. restaurants said yesterday that it had offered more than $200 million in cash to buy the restaurant company, which is controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami financier. Arby's, which is based in Atlanta, is the marketing, franchising and service company for a chain of 2,100 restaurants.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The City of Houston yesterday tentatively priced a $114.9 million issue of previous and junior lien water and sewer system revenue bonds through a group of underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: The Love of Reading
description: To The Home Section:

title: A White-Gloved Duel For the Shuttles' Skies
description: So far, the battle between the Trump and Pan Am shuttles is something less than a bare-knuckles fight. If anyone expected Donald J. Trump's flamboyant entry into the shuttle business to bring cutthroat competition and rock-bottom fares, that has not happened.

title: AIRLINES ORDERED TO INSTALL DEVICE TO DETECT BOMBS
description: In its strongest effort to counter attacks on airlines, the Government yesterday ordered American carriers to install a new type of bomb detector to check luggage at major airports in this country and overseas.

title: Separation for Princess Anne Is Reported
description: Princess Anne, the daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, and husband, Mark Phillips, are separating, his father said Wednesday.

title: Agency Delays Vote on a Plan To Add Taxis
description: Amid charges of political interference by City Hall, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission put off a vote yesterday on an experimental plan to issue 400 new taxi medallions.

title: Cubs Trade Schiraldi
description: The Chicago Cubs traded the pitcher Calvin Schiraldi, the outfielder Darrin Jackson and a minor league player to be determined to the San Diego Padres last night for the outfielder Marvell Wynne and the infielder Luis Salazar.

title: U.N. Names Nicaragua Envoy
description: Elliot L. Richardson, a former United States Attorney General, will monitor the Nicaraguan elections for the United Nations, it was announced today. Mr. Richardson will be the personal representative of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: Bridge
description: Victories in regional team championships are not easy to come by, and many enthusiasts are proud of having one or two such victories in a bridge lifetime. Some experts amass a large collection, but it is unlikely that anyone at any time has matched the victory string of two New York players during the month of August.

title: U.S. Officials' Families to Quit Bogota
description: With tension running high in the second week of an intensified drug war in Colombia, the United States today ordered the evacuation of all dependents of American diplomats, and an overnight curfew was imposed in the bomb-shaken city of Medellin.

title: Review/Rock; Reunited Jefferson Airplane: Still Loose, Still Utopian
description: Loose ends were a big part of psychedelic rock; they went with its improvisational spirit. The reunited Jefferson Airplane, which opened a two-night stand Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, kept some of those loose ends in a generous, two-part concert that veered between the 1960's and the 1980's. Although it had such modern trimmings as lighting effects, smoke machines and synthesizers, it was also refreshingly informal.

title: Ponderosa To Buy Rival
description: The owner of the Ponderosa steakhouses, the Metromedia Company, has agreed to buy the rival Bonanza steakhouse chain from USA Cafes L.P. for $10.25 in cash for each outstanding partnership unit, or about $70 million.

title: Election by Publishers
description: Russell T. Lewis, senior vice president for production for The New York Times, has been elected president of the New York Newspaper Publishers Association. He succeeds Richard A. Myers, operating vice president of Ottaway Newspapers. The election, for the 1989-90 term, took place this week at the association's 68th annual convention.

title: Government Is Issuing New Pilot's License Requiring Fewer Hours
description: In an effort to lure more people into aviation and replenish the dwindling supply of airline pilots, the Government put rules into effect today to make it easier and less expensive to learn to fly.

title: Personal Health
description: By now, you may think that all physically active people know just what to eat and drink to foster peak performance. Certainly there has been no lack of advice about the kind of diet needed to keep an active body healthy.

title: 2 Indicted for Murder in Racial Attack
description: Two suspects in the racial attack on 16-year-old Yusuf K. Hawkins were indicted yesterday on second-degree murder charges.

title: American Stores Co reports earnings for 13wks to July 29
description: The company said the increase in sales in the latest 6-month was principally due to the acquisition of Lucky Stores Inc. on June 2, 1988. The Lucky pre-LIFO earnings, net of acquisition interest expense and amortization of asset write-ups reduced the 1989 second quarter and year-to-date earnings by 40 cents and 66 cents per common share, respectively, and compares to 56 cents per common share for the last eigth weeks of 1988's second quarter. In addition to the LIFO charge to earnings in the second quarter of 1989 decreased earnings per common share by 33 cents, compared with 23 cents in the prior year's second quarter. The LIFO charge to earnings for the 26 weeks year-to-date decreased earnings per common share by 66 cents, compared with 41 cents in the year- earlier period.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * A.B. Electrolux, Stockholm, a consumer products company, said it would sell its sterilization and disinfection units to Getinge Intressenter A.B. Terms were not disclosed.

title: At Last, Dent Is Able To Smile
description: When Roberto Kelly retreated toward the warning track last night, then finally caught the fly ball that ended the game, Bucky Dent allowed himself a smile. It had been six torturous days since his last one.

title: Gencor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Shifting Rules on Ethics
description: The House ethics committee is preparing to consider in an official setting a question that has bedeviled American politics in recent years: What sort of private behavior is unacceptable in a public officeholder?

title: Tambo Had a Brain Spasm, African Rebel Group Says
description: Oliver Tambo, the African National Congress president, has had a brain spasm, a spokesman for the black nationalist group said today.

title: Belgian Is Named Director Of the Salzburg Festival
description: Gerard Mortier, the director of La Monnaie, Belgium's national opera, has been named artistic director of the Salzburg Festival with a mandate to revamp a cultural showcase some critics say is elitist and conservative.

title: Cordis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,000,000 for the quarter and $11,635,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,851,000 and $3,386,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $1,021,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $777,000, or 6 cents a share for the year.

title: Hauserman reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Shouldn't Candidates' Kids Go to Public School?
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
DDB Needham Wins in France
description: LEAD: DDB Needham France yesterday won the $50 million advertising account for Conforama, a giant French retail chain that is that country's biggest non-food advertiser. The victory is the largest of the year for DDB Needham, and the second largest since Doyle Dane Bernbach merged with Needham Harper to create DDB

title: On Our Conscience?
description: America has many problems, but one is entrenched in our culture, our history. It has defied what we thought were solutions. It is growing worse, eating away at the social fabric. It cries out for leadership. But there is no leadership.

title: Youth's Funeral Focuses on Racial Divisions
description: Yusuf K. Hawkins was buried yesterday in Brooklyn, and just as the 16-year-old black youth's death has been taken as a painful symbol of racial division, so, too, was his funeral used as an occasion to reflect not only on the dead young man but also on the state of race relations in New York City.

title: Comptroller Candidates to Spend $1 Million on Commercials
description: Already acknowledged as the front-runner by her opponents in the race for the Democratic nomination for New York City comptroller, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn last night began a $500,000 radio and television advertising campaign.

title: For Yankee G.M.'s, Once Is More Than Enough
description: George Steinbrenner has made a career out of inviting dismissed and departed employees to assume their previous positions, and many of them have accepted, with trepidation and, of course, good contracts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Helmsley's Personality Not an Issue, Jurors Say
description: Months of testimony portraying Leona Helmsley as an arrogant and vindictive woman had little effect on the deliberations that led to a tax-evasion verdict against her, jurors said yesterday.

title: Inflation's Foe, Argentine Hits Double Digits in Hoops
description: Erasing any doubt about his willingness to take daring initiatives as President of Argentina, Carlos Saul Menem put on a jersey Tuesday night and played in a nationally televised basketball game alongside professionals.

title: Scott Notches No. 18 As Astros Beat Cubs
description: Mike Scott pitched a four-hitter for his 18th victory and added a run-scoring single tonight as the Houston Astros rebounded for an 8-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Avery Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $4,423,000 for the quarter and $9,984,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also included a gain of $2,757,000 from early extinguishment of debt. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,863,000 and $52,118,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain of $2,052,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said its results from continuing operations primarily consist of interest expense and general and administrative expenses.

title: Prices on Notes and Bonds Climb
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in generally dull trading yesterday, aided by a firmer dollar and a hint that the Federal Reserve Board may be on the verge of easing the cost of credit further.

title: Plasti-Fab reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $14,000. c-Net income and included and extraordinary item of $500,000. Some per-share earnings figures were not immediately available. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Critic's Notebook; Horror and Struck! The Things They Never Said!
description: Perhaps the most amusing passage in A. Scott Berg's biography of Samuel Goldwyn is the story of how Goldwyn warned James Thurber not to read the screenplay of ''The Secret Life of Walter Mitty'' because the last hundred pages were too ''blood and thirsty,'' and how Thurber ignored the warning and pronounced himself ''horror and struck.''

title: Sales Up Slightly for New York Retailers
description: Most of New York's large retailers did not have a rewarding first half even though the women's apparel business revived, industry executives said yesterday in an informal survey.

title: A Vote for Bicycles
description: To The Home Section:

title: Wave of Vietnamese Refugees Straining Japan
description: Braving distances of up to 1,500 miles at sea, thousands of boat people from Southeast Asia and China have begun arriving at Japanese shores in recent months, straining Japan's refugee centers and posing difficult new challenges for the Government.

title: Litton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Judge Orders U.S. to Require Tampon Absorbency Labels
description: Concerned about toxic shock syndrome and fed up with Government delays, a Federal district judge has given regulators two months to draft rules that inform consumers about the relative absorbency of different brands of tampons.

title: Cathedral Gold reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cuban Emigre Wins Election To U.S. House
description: Capping three decades of mounting political power here by Hispanic citizens, a Cuban-born Republican, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, has won the Congressional seat of the late Claude Pepper.

title: Pope's Remarks on Jews Leave Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Government General Strike Leaves at Least 11 Dead in India
description: Daily life was disrupted all over India today as a general strike called by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's political opponents closed shops, stopped trains and emptied streets and schools.

title: Savings Unit's Ties to Boesky
description: The Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, whose failure may cost the Government $2.5 billion, invested $100 million with Ivan F. Boesky, newspaper reports said today. The Los Angeles Times and

title: Dial 'P' for Privacy in New Phone Technology; For Road Emergencies
description: To the Editor:

title: Selvac Corp reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $577,500, or 4 cents a share for the latest year and $363,500, or 3 cents a share for the year-earlier period.

title: Pope's Remarks on Jews Leave Questions; A New Covenant
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Ranch Site Ruled Out For Underground Explosions
description: The Defense Nuclear Agency has announced it was no longer considering a ranch near this border city as a site for underground explosive tests but was looking at another site in the area.

title: Jan Stacy, 41, Writer; Started Drug Program
description: Jan Stacy, a writer and artist, died of AIDS on Aug. 20 at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 41 years old.

title: Review/Theater; A Tosca Who Doesn't Sing And Ends in Scarpio's Arms
description: Should there ever be a revival of interest in the plays of Terence Rattigan, ''Before Dawn'' will certainly not be in the vanguard of rediscoveries. In fact, by offering the New York premiere of this flaccid sendup of ''Tosca,'' the Quaigh Theater is doing the late English playwright a disservice.

title: Life Term in Drug-Rape Case
description: A woman was sentenced Tuesday to life in prison for giving her 13-year-old daughter to a rapist in exchange for drugs. The 29-year-old woman, Susan Barbier, who was convicted of first-degree criminal sexual conduct in the May 1988 incident, was told by Judge James J. Rashid of Wayne County Circuit Court that he was exceeding the sentencing guidelines because she had ''very little, if any at all, potential for reformation.'' The guidelines called for 10 to 25 years in prison.

title: PBS Investigating Financing of 'Days of Rage'
description: The Public Broadcasting Service said yesterday that it was investigating the financing of a pro-Palestinian film about the uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories, after it learned that an Arab-American foundation last fall agreed to buy the film's distribution rights.

title: Green Screen: The Hedge's Polite Rebuff
description: GOOD hedges make good neighbors - maybe even better than fences.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday outlining the views of New York City mayoral candidates on health issues included an erroneous statistic from Mayor Edward I. Koch in some copies for medical surgical beds in hospitals in New York City. Municipal hospitals have 16 percent of the medical surgical beds in the city, not 34 percent.

title: Boston Heart Group Approved as Debate Goes On
description: Four prestigious university-affiliated hospitals that have run a heart transplant consortium here on a trial basis since 1985 have won state approval to make it permanent, despite concern that individual hospitals may not perform enough operations to maintain peak proficiency.

title: Maadi Journal; Red Tape of Two Lands in a Child-Custody Tangle
description: Since she left her home and job in Brooklyn, to live in Egypt and search for her children, Barbara Mezo has found obstacles and tangles of faith and bureaucracy that yield despair, but no sight of the children.

title: No Criminal Charges Seen for Mayor Bradley
description: City investigators appear ready to conclude that Mayor Tom Bradley could face civil fines but committed no crimes when he was paid by banks doing business with the city, newspapers here reported today.

title: Burnup & Sims Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
President of Deere Adds Title of Chief Executive
description: Deere & Company, the big farm equipment maker, announced yesterday that it had named its president, Hans W. Becherer, to be chief executive as well.

title: Not Much Excitement As Chang Wins Easily
description: The stands of backless aluminum seats at Court 16 yesterday afternoon were crammed as steamily full as a subway car at rush hour. People sat in the aisles, hung over the top railings, and those unable to gain entrance did manage to gain a view by dropping to their knees and peering under the paneled fence at one end of the court that stands at the limits of the National Tennis Center.
